column2: With the Stock Exchange and the New York Curb closed, the commodity and foreign exchange markets commanded such interest as could be aroused in financial circles yesterday. Most of the Wall Street population took a holiday.

THIS handy little reference book, which measures only four by six inches and is thin enough, notwithstanding its 548 pages, to slip easily into the pocket, fulfills a double purpose. As a supplement to the Funk Wagnalls New Standard Encyclopedia it brings down to date such entries in those volumes as require additional material.
"The college woman who succeeds in business today owes her alma, mater very little thanks. She is the victim of one of the most perfect systems of unpreparedness and misguidance ever devised."

PEEKSKILL, N.Y., Aug. 26 -- August Heckscher, philanthropist, celebrated his eighty-fifth birthday today with a visit to Heckscher camp at Adams Corners, six miles north of here. He was the guest of honor at a birthday party given by the 570 children now at the camp which he founded and has maintained for the last five years.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 24. -- Your Philadelphia Democrat is an astonishingly hopeful individual, considering the beatings he has taken at the hands of National Committee-man William S. Vare's Republican machine and its predecessors. Long the butt of the city's political jokes, he is laying plans to challenge the proverbial power of the Vare organization in the Fall municipal elections.

Further plans now being made for the gala carnival and entertainment on Sept. 9 in aid of the Nassau Speedwell Unit and the Village Welfare of Port Washington indicate that the event will be unique in the history of benefit fetes on Long Island.

GREENWOOD LAKE, N.Y., Aug. 27. -- Two amateurs, Sammy Crooks of Rumson, N.J., and Paul Hyatt of Brooklyn, and one professional, Bill Feldhusen of Stapleton, S.I., scored two-heat victories today to share honors in the Greenwood Lake Boat and Country Club's sixth annual outboard regatta.

BERLIN, Aug. 26. -- While official reports on industry and unemployment returns continue favorable, serious concern was felt this week over the extreme weakness on the Boerse, coming after four months of uninterrupted though slow decline.

The social and industrial ideals for which the churches have stood are now being worked out under the National Industrial Recovery Act, declared the Rev. Samuel McCrea Cavert, general secretary of the Federal Council of the Churches of Christ in America, yesterday, in releasing the council's annual Labor Sunday message.

President Roosevelt mobilized the ships and planes of the Coast Guard yesterday afternoon into a thorough search of the Atlantic coast for the sons of Manhattan neighbors of his who were aboard the sloop Postcript, missing for seven days.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 27. -- Legisation to control the sale and use of firearms, carrying a clause absolutely outlawing the subcalibre macine gun, will be passed in the next session of Congress in the opinion of Senator Copeland of New York, chairman of the Senate Committee on Racketeering.

DALLAS, Texas, Aug. 27. -- Defeated in his effort to make Texas the first State to vote for retention of the Eighteenth Amendment, Senator Morris Sheppard said tonight that prohibitionists should receive

PARIS, Aug. 27. -- While the staff correspondent of one French newspaper, the Paris Soir, complains of the refusal of the German authorities to allow him to attend today's demonstration at the Niederwald mountain, all the other papers carry full reports of Chancellor Hitler's speeches there and at Tannenberg, but refrain from editorial comment.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 27. -- Raymond Moley's resignation came as a surprise to Washington.
CHICAGO, Aug. 27 (AP). -- One-third of the names on last March's unemployment relief rolls have been erased, a nation-wide survey indicated today.

In Washington Square, where paintings grow on trees and lampposts, the fourth outdoor art exhibition was functioning smoothly yesterday. All the preliminary bustle of opening day had died down, and people had begun to stop long enough to pose for portrait sketches and silhouettes, which scarcely ever run into big money.

In his graceful speech at Poughkeepsie on Saturday, renewing old associations with his friends of Dutchess County, President ROOSEVELT took occasion to dwell once more upon his favorite doctrine of "the good neighbor." To it he traced the origin and motive of many laws and policies.
EAST HAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 27. -- Mr. and Mrs. Juan Terry Trippe, grave a dinner for fifty persons last night at their residence.

David Lloyd George is reported to be making drastic revisions in the original manuscripts of his war memoirs, following the publication of parts of them in a London newspaper. Little, Brown will publish the first two volumes this Fall.

CHICAGO, Aug. 27. -- The grain conference in London, which included all leading wheat-producing and consuming countries of the world, obtained more satisfactory terms than a majority of traders expected. There is a belief in the trade that better conditions will gradually dev lop, and that the world situation will improve so that smaller crops and fairly remunerative prices will help producers.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The appointment of a committee on the use of leisure time to act for the NRA will, I hope, focus renewed attention on the growing need for an examination of the whole problem of the wholesome and constructive use of the leisure of the employed as well as the unemployed.

SEATTLE, Wash., Aug. 27 (AP). -- Washington votes upon prohibition repeal on Tuesday under an election system considered by many prohibitionists to be the fairest arrangement yet devised for sounding the sentiment of every section of a State.

MOSCOW, Aug. 27. -- The international wheat agreement is regarded here as a step in the right direction and as making for international cooperation, but actually not of much more than nominal importance at present because no accord has been reached about the export quotas of various grain producing countries.

The theory of evolution has suffered a more complete collapse than most of us can realize, the Rev. Dr. David De Forest Burrell declared in a sermon as guest preacher yesterday at the Marble Collegiate Church, Fifth Avenue and Twenty-ninth Street.

WESTPORT, N.Y., Aug. 27. -- Men all over the world, some of whom fought in the World War, "are mumbling with childlike ignorance that we need another war to settle world problems." Dr. Mary E. Woolley, president of Mount Holyoke College and delegate to the disarmament conference at Geneva, said today in an address at the Westport Union service.

LEIPZIG, Germany, Aug. 27 (AP) -- The new Nazi regime has set its stamp upon this year's Autumn fair, which opened today under new conditions that had not matured when the Spring fair was held here early last March. This time it appeared more a national than an international affair.

Christianity has ceased to exercise any serious claim on the allegiance of many Christians who seek to eliminate the supernatural from religion, the Rev. Dr. Arthur P.S. Hyde said in a sermon yesterday morning at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine.

CHICAGO Aug. 27. -- Light-weight hogs were In good demand here last week top prices ranging from $4.50 to $4.60, or about 5 cents lower than for the previous two weeks. Daily averages ranged from $3.85 to $4.10. The average for the week was $3.90, or the same as in the previous week and 25 cents less than in the week last year.
With a west wind blowing, fishermen off Montauk yesterday were in hopes of having some good sport. It turned out, however, that the wind was very deceiving.

MADRID, Aug. 27 (AP). -- Deputies from wine-producing regions have petitioned the government for funds to enable the National Institute of Wine Exporters to finance a publicity campaign in the United States.

LONDON, Aug. 26. -- While there have been encouraging developments in internal trade, the prospects of an Autumn revival in international trade cannot at present be said to be good. The situation is regarded in financial circles here to be as perplexing as ever.

Four of five participants in an East Flatbush drinking party -- one a woman of 60 -- died Saturday night and yesterday morning from the effects of the drink. It was commercial alcohol, the kind used to protect automobile motors in freezing weather.

NEW HAVEN, Aug. 27. -- Professor Irving Fisher's index number of commodity prices, based on 100 as the average for 1926, fs 70.4, which compares with 70.3,a week ago, 70.3 two weeks ago, 70.6 three weeks ago and 69.6 four weeks ago. The average of three weeks ago was the highest of the year to date; that of March 5, at 55, was the lowest.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 27.-- There was a large gathering at Bailey's Beach today and the event of interest was the annual swimmingrace for the cup offered by Mrs. Arthur Curtiss James some years ago. The water was clear and smooth and there were six entries in the 55-yard event, which was handled by James Brett Stokes with E. Pennington Pearson and Andrew Van Pelt acting as the judges.

STAMFORD, Conn., Aug. 27. -- Captain Ernest E. Harmon, army air service pilot and pioneer in aviation, was killed tonight when his plane crashed in woodland 300 feet off the Long Ridge Highway at Turn-of-the-River, a suburb of this city.
No longer do the cohorts of the Assyrians gleam in purple and gold or the sheen of their spears appear Like stars on the sea When the blue wave rolls nightly on deep Galilee.

PORT WASHINGTON, L. I., Aug. 27. -- An extra-period goal by Cocie Rathborne, scored in following up a long drive of his own, enabled the Sands Point polo team to beat Greentree, 8 to 7, at the Sands Point Club today. The Sands Point team was a pick-up side.

CHICAGO, Aug. 27. -- September liquidation in wheat has been on in all markets in the United States and is rapidly nearing completion, resulting in sharp changes in differentials between the near and distant months. When this liquidation is completed, within a short time, better markets are expected by trade leaders.

BERLIN, Aug. 27 (London Times Dispatch). -- Druzag, the last important foreign concession in Soviet Russia and the control of which is held mainly by the German government, is being forced to liquidate, according to Moscow messages appearing in the German press.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 27. -- Canvassers for the promotion of the NRA were instructed tonight by Hugh S. Johnson, National Recovery Administrator, to go forth on their nation-wide instructional drive tomorrow morning as "missionaries," and not as policemen and snoopers.

One death and injuries to eight other persons resulted from a collision of two automobiles at Sixtieth Street and Eighth Avenue, Brooklyn, early yesterday afternoon. A police radio car, speeding to the scene a short time later, collided with a taxicab at Sixtieth Street and Sixteenth Avenue, causing slight injuries to two patrolmen and the cab driver.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 27. -- Federal relief for unemployed teachers was welcomed and commended today by William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor.
CLEVELAND, Aug. 27 (AP). -- The Indians broke even in a double bill with the Senators today.

An old-fashioned Irish music, dance and athletic festival was held yesterday at Wingate Field, Avenue J and East Seventeenth Street, Brooklyn. More than 3,000 persons paid admission, while hundreds of others watched the events from the fence surrounding the field.

TORONTO, Ont., Aug. 27. -- Gold has been discovered in the south-west section of Carscalion Township, approximately eighteen miles from Timmins and a like distance from the Ontario Government's Abitibi Canyon power transmission line.

ENNIS, County Clare, Irish Free State, Aug. 27. -- While President Eamon de Valera held a large mass meeting here during ninety-minute downpour today. General O'Duffy played hide and seek with civic guards and addressed a secret gathering of his Blue Shirt organization at Bandon.
The Union Club-one of New York's cornerstones of conservatism -- has gone modern.
NEW YORK. James W. Gerard, who has been in Antibes, France, for several weeks, is expected Thursday on the Conta dl Savoia.
MITCHEL FIELD, L.I., Aug. 27. -- The widow of Captain Ernest E. Harmon was notified of his death at the officer's residence here late tonight. Three children also survive.

RIVERTON, N.J., Aug. 27. -- After a grueling struggle, Edward Lee of the New York A.C. won the national ten-mile swimming championship today. The race was held in the Delaware River from Philadelphia to this yachting resort.

John Kelly, who has a hot-dog stand near the Arsenal in Central Park, spiked a frankfurter thoughtfully yesterday and turned it over. He wielded his long fork with a new dignity, a lordly gesture. It might have been a scepter or an assagai.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 27. -- Northrn and Southern non-union bituninous coal operators, said to represent considerably more than 50 per cent of the nation's tonnage, today presented to the National Recovery Administration a revised and rewritten code.

Clattering hoofs waking loud echoes in the early Sunday stillness made Patrolman Joe Monohan. turn yesterday morning as he walked his beat on upper Madison Aveuue. He saw a matronly horse trying to maintain her dignity as two men in white linen suits urged her on.

NEW ORLEANS, La., Aug. 27. -- The main feature in the cotton market her last week was the absence of speculative activity. Trading was largely professional, with an increasing volume of hedging sales as the new crop commence to move more freely.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 (AP). -- The possibility that the Eighteenth Amendment will be voted out of the Constitution within the next eleven weeks became stronger today when Texas recorded itself heavily as the twenty-third repeal State, while sixteen others prepared to ballot.

Turtles from Westchester and the Galapagos, fish from Japan and Siam frogs and snakes and toads, lizards, and pollywogs, amphibia and terraria, in short nearly all kinds of things that swim, creep or crawl, are being groomed by their owners for the annual show.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 27. Mr. and Mrs. Guernsey Curran gave a reception this afternoon at the Moorings for Mr. and Mrs. Walter G. Mortland, who are passing several days with them. At the tea table was Mrs. Graham Williams, who motored from her home in Islip, L.I., to pass Sunday with Mr. and Mrs. Curran.

Insect Class Enemies. The ways of a Russian class enemy may be subtler than we think. Two workmen in a new zipc plant in the North Caucasus were arrested for sabotage when small holes were discovered in the lead and wood reinforced lining of the flotation tanks.

BERLIN, Aug. 27. -- Chancellor Adolf Hitler told an audience of 150,000 gathered at the monument on the Niederwald Mountain above Ruedesheim on the Rhine this evening that Germany would never abandon the Saar Basin territory.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Aug. 27. -- Mrs. Mary Gantz, 34 years old, of 730 East 225th Street, New York City, died early today in St. Agnes's Hospital here of injuries she received when the automobile in which she, her husband and young son were passengers toppled down an embankment north of Old Mamaroneck Road on the Hutchinson River Parkway.
FORT WASHINGTON, L. I., Aug. 27. -- Thomas Hitchcock Jr., top ranking player of American polo, is out of the game for the remainder of the season.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 27. -- In a further effort to speed up the government's public works program, Secretary Ickes, Public Works Administrator, has sent instructions to Federal and local officials to cut red tape, eliminate delays and put a maximum number of men to work as quickly as possible.

Commodity prices regained on Friday substantially more than they had lost from Monday through Thursday, and closed the week with marked gains over the preceding period. The principal gains were registered in the metal, rubber and silk futures, but sugar, coffee, cocoa and other staples were also improved for the period.

ST. PIERRE, Miq., Aug. 27 (AP). -- Armed sailors from two French warships patrolled the streets of St. Pierre tonight after a week marked by two riotous disturbances during which a government building was stormed and prisoners delivered from jail.

In a discussion of problems arising from the activities of the National Recovery Administration, the Guaranty Trust Company, in the current issue of The Guaranty Survey, reaches the conclusion that "in spite of the complexities and irregularities of the situation, the general impression is given that we are moving ahead and that real progress toward recovery is being made."

PRAGUE, Aug. 27. -- Dr. Edouard Benes, Foreign Minister of Czechoslovakia, in a conversation with a NEW YORK TIMES correspondent today, expressed his opposition to attempts of the Hitler dictatorship in Germany to overcome the Dollfuss government in Austria in these words:

To the Editor of The New York Times: Your editorial "Work and Leisure" is very interesting. You say: "To many people work is mainly a means of keeping body and soul together." From general observation It would seem not "many," but the great majority of people.

READING, Pa., Aug. 27. -- Reports read at final sessions of the national convention of the Young People's Socialist League of America, in a meeting at a park here today, outlined plans for greater solidarity with labor groups in all large population centres.

If Adolph Hitler should show himself wise and tolerant in the crises facing Germany, he might become one of the greatest constructive thinkers in history, declared the Rev. Dr. James Gordon Gilkey, pastor of the South Congregational Church ol Springfield, Mass., in his sermon yesterday morning.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 (AP). -- Henry Ford, the only large manufacturer who has not joined in the automobile code, has ten days in which to determine whether he will sign, voluntarily submit to its terms, oppose its effectiveness or offer a proposal of his own.

To the Editor of The New York Times: To all of you who are weary and heavy laden; to the discouraged and faint of heart, a word of comfort and a promise of fairer days. To you who say, "Well, the government had to do something." To those who anxiously ask, "Will the NRA accomplish its ends?"

Youth is a liability rather than an asset in keeping a job in times of depression, according to a survey made by the Association for Improving the Condition of the Poor. The comprehensive study of the relationship between unemployment and sickness was conducted among 4,493 families in the territory bounded by Bleecker and Canal Streets, Broadway and the Bowery.
BERLIN, Aug. 27. -- The Nazis' campaign aiming at the elimination of their "enemies" is being conducted with growing intensity and is being directed more and more against women and children.

The 14,000 fully licensed banks of the country are urged by General Hugh S. Johnson, National Recovery Administrator, to become "double-eagle or government-partnered banks" under the RFC plan for purchases of preferred stock of banks, in a copyrighted article in the current issue of The Bank Director.

HYDE PARK, N.Y., Aug. 27. -- An automobile tour comprising a review of National Guard regiments at Camp Smith and a visit to a Civilian Conservation Corps camp provided President Roosevelt today with much-needed relaxation prior to three conferences of potentially great importance scheduled tomorrow.

The fall of the dollar on last week's foreign markets brought its depreciation to 31 1/2 per cent, which compared with 24 1/2 per cent at the beginning of the month, with 26 1/2 a week ago, and with the year's largest discount of 31 1/2 on the 19th of July.

DUBLIN, Aug. 27. -- Outwitting a strong force of police, General Owen O'Duffy addressed 5,000 Blue Shirts at Bandon, County Cork, but the de Valera government prevented a meeting at Beal-Na-Blath, where Michael Collins was fatally Injured during the civil war in 1922.
DETROIT, Aug. 27. -- The biggest crowd of the season, at Navin Field saw the Yankees divide a double bill with the Tigers today.

YOUNGSTOWN, Ohio, Aug. 27. -- The downfall of the Hitler regime in Germany within six to twelve months was predicted by Samuel Untermyer in an address here today at the annual reunion of triState lodges of the Order of B'nai B'rith.

Former Governor Alfred E. Smith has accepted the chairmanship of the board of directors of the Federal Broadcasting Corporation, which recently acquired the commercial and program presentation rights of station WMCA, it was announced yesterday by the new organization.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 (AP). -- Abandonment of the naval building program and repeal of the Japanese exclusion act were asked of President Roosevelt today in a letter from Hannah Clothier Hull, president of the Women's International League for Peace and Freedom.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 27. -- The Veterans' Administration announced the personnel of three new special boards to review presumptive war disability claims in the District of Columbia and Vermont. One board will review claims in the Washington regional office, another is a special board to review regional cases in the central office, also in Washington, while the third will function in Vermont.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Edward Parkinson writes to THE TIMES that he believes the actual cost of producing a quart of milk should be placed before the proper authorities and that this cost can be correctly ascertained only by taking figures of a dozen farms, these in turn to be interpreted by a dairy expert from the New York College of Agriculture.

BROOKLINE, Mass., Aug. 27. -- George Peabody Gardner Jr. and Richard Bishop of Boston won the national veterans' doubles championship for the first time when they defeated Dr. William Rosenbaum and Fred C. Baggs, 6-4, 6-4, in the final match at the Longwood Cricket Club today.

SOUTHAMPTON, England, Aug. 18. -- The ancient port of Southampton, first called "Tumtum" by the Iberian tribes in 2000 B.C., has made great strides since the American liner City of Paris as the pioneer of the North Atlantic passenger trade called here in February, 1893.
PARIS, Aug. 27. -- ''We are resolved to guarantee the political and economic independence of Austria," Premier Daladier said this morning in a statement to the press.
CHICAGO, Aug. 27. -- They waited around for Macdonald Smith, the old hard luck man of golf, to ''crack up" again today.

A final report from the State Legislative Commission to Investigate the Administration of Justice is requested by October by the City Club of New York. The request, made public yesterday by Richard S. Childs, president of the club, In the form of a letter to Senator John L. Buckley, chairman of the commission, points out that the commission has been in existence more than two years.

BOSTON, Aug. 27 (AP). -- The Braves winning streak was halted at eight games as Cincinnati took the second game of a double-header, 5 to 3, today before a crowd of 40,000. Boston took the opener, 7 to 0.

YONKERS, N.Y., Aug. 27. -- Maintaining their winning streak, the cricketers of the Crescent Athletic-Hamilton Club today defeated an eleven of the Westchester County Cricket Club 74 to 26 in a Metropolitan and New Jersey Cricket Association match.
ST. LOUIS, Aug. 27 (AP). -- The Browns and Red Sox divided two games today, Boston taking the first, 7 to 5, and St. Louis the nightcap, 5 to 3.

CHICAGO, Aug. 27 (AP). -- Religion needs "decoding" that the modern man may understand it and "debunking" that he may respect it, the Maharaja Gaekwar of Baroda today told leaders in religious thought from five continents, attending the second world parliament of religions.
BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 27. -- Argentina will not sign the London wheat agreement tomorrow. There is some doubt whether she will sign at all.

CHICAGO, Aug. 27. -- Oats are being bought by speculators and industries in the belief that an unusually short crop should bring good prices. One industry has bought 650,000 bushels within a few days at Northwestern points which are to be moved to Eastern manufacturing centres.

PARIS, Aug. 27. -- Uneasiness over the possibility of devaluation of the franc was expressed here tonight after Budget Minister Lucien Lamoureux had announced in a speech at Boussac this afternoon that preliminary studies showed the 1934 budget would have a deficit of 6,000,000,000 francs (currently about $340,950,000).
JOLIET, III., Aug. 27. -- Lieutenant Tito Falconi landed his airplane here shortly after 3 P.M. today and claimed a new world's time record of 3 hours 6 minutes and 39 seconds for inverted flight.

SHANGHAI, Monday, Aug. 28. -- With an abrupt rise of the Yellow River to thirty feet, reported at Shenchow in Northwestern Honan Province, the city of Kaifeng, 230 miles eastward, is working feverishly to prevent its dikes from crumbling when the crest arrives.

The drudgery of everyday labor achieves a new dignity when it is considered to be done for the greater glory of God, the Very Rev Dr. Edmund J.M. Nutter, dean of Nashotah House Theological Seminary, Nashotah, Wia., declared in a communion sermon yesterday.

The City Fusion party will not run an independent ticket for county offices in Queens, but will put forward Herbert A. O'Brien, supporter of former Mayor John F. Hylan, for the fusion nomination for City Court Justice.

MR. TIMOTHY J. MARA, the genial promoter, has suggested that Postmaster General Farley use his influence at Washington to obtain a full-feathered Blue Eagle for one fellow in the boxing game. The facts in the case are as follows:

A decrease of more than 30,000 in the number of families receiving public relief from local, State and Federal funds in New York State in July, as compared with April, is shown in the monthly report of the State Temporary Relief Administration, made public yesterday by Alfred H. Schoellkopf, chairman.

PARIS, Aug. 26. -- The attention, of the financial world this week has been centred on the decline of sterling and the dollar. The further drop in the dollar was ascribed here to the recent statement by General Johnson concerning the financing of President Roosevelt's recovery plan.

Today the special committee of fifteen members appointed by the Massachusetts General Court to prepare a code of liquor laws will hold its first public meeting in Boston State House. There will be other hearings in other parts of the State, but the work to which the committee looks forward with the most expectation of fruitful and fruity results is its expedition to Canada.

PARIS, Aug. 27. -- The trench-and-casemate system, which Premier Daladier win inspect tomorrow, extends along a 125-mile front between the Rhine and Luxemburg. It is so constructed that troops would be hidden from enemy view and well protected by the fortifications against bombardment.

Firmly convinced that the NRA codes were "stolen direct from Russia," but also firmly convinced that it "was an excellent move." Theodore Dreiser pledged himself yesterday to "defend President Roosevelt forty hours a week at a minimum of 40 cents an hour."

The Chicago invasion of Ebbets Field yesterday for the Dodgers' fourth double-header in as many days was marked by another even break. The 15,000 fans went home happy when Max Carey's men won the second game. The split put Brooklyn in a tie with the Pilla for sixth place.

PITTSBURGH, Aug. 27. -- Buying of steel last week was light. The markets for semi-finished steel and all finished products were virtually stagnant. There are three separate rates in the steel trade far apart -- the rate of production, the rate of consumption and the rate of buying.

Confusion over prices and delivries and a stringent shortage of goods were the main features of the wholesale apparel markets during the week. At the same time, an excellent consumer response to August promotions was reported, causing a large reorder volume.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 27. -- Calling upon every employer who is able to do so to sign the President's employment code, Senator Harry F. Byrd of Virginia, in a radio address over the National Broadcasting System today, strongly opposed the use of the boycott against employers who are unable to subscribe to the agreement.

The National Association of Subtitute Post Office Employes, with headquarters at 264 West Fortieth Street, announced yesterday that because of the refusal of the Post-office Department to accede to its demands for higher wages and better working conditions it would voice its protest at nation-wide demonstrations before the local offices of the National Recovery Administration.

Suggesting that the United States Treasury should refrain from calling the Fourth Liberty Loan 4 1/4s as a whole or in part on any given date, C.F. Childs Co., specialists in United States Government securities, state in their monthly bulletin that all risk would be eliminated if holders of the bonds had the privilege of exchanging them at any time for the bonds of new Treasury issues.

The Anglo-Saxon is "in the driver's seat" in world politics and he, instead of France or Germany, must be named as the chief obstacle to world peace, a meeting of the Women's International League for Peace and Freedom, held in Central Park, was told yesterday by Dr. Sydney Strong, who has just returned from the Disarmament Conference at Geneva.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 27. -- The signing of the automobile code by the President came as the most encouraging development of a week to Recovery Administration officials as they stood ready to open the nation-wide drive for support of the NRA and to press still harder for a successful "constitution" for the coal industry.

The life of Christianity is not dependent upon the census, and the relative decline of church membership in proportion to the rise in population in this country is no evidence that the Christian faith is experiencing an eclipse, declared the Rev. Dr. S.H. Prince of Halifax, N.S., in a sermon in St. Stephen's Episcopal Church, 122-128 West Sixty-ninth Street, yesterday.

Former Senator William M. Calder of Brooklyn urged yesterday the consolidation of separate postoffices in New York into one organizatlon with one postmaster. He pointed out that only under some such arrangement could New Yorkers benefit from the two-cent postage rate for intradistrict letters.
CHICAGO, Aug. 27 (AP). -- The White Sox swept both ends of a doubleheader with the Athletics before 20,000 fans today, 5 to 3 and 9 to 8.

About 300 Italian naval cadets, enlisted men of the Italian Navy and their officers attended the low mass at 10 o'clock yesterday morning at St. Patrick's Cathedral. They were headed by Admiral Romeo Bernotti, superintendent of the Italian Royal Naval Academy, and Antonio Grossardl, the Italian Consul General.

HYDE PARK, N.Y., Aug. 27. -- Raymond Moley, chief member of the President's "brain trust," resigned today as Assistant Secretary of State and his resignation was accepted by President Roosevelt. It becomes effective Sept. 7.

BRETTON WOODS, N.H., Aug. 27. -- Mr. and Mrs. Van H. Dodge and Mrs. and Mrs. Frank Schuyler Dodge gave a red and white ball, with cabaret, last night for 300 guests at the Mountain View, Whltefield. The dining room was paneled in scarlet, with white decorations in relief, and scarlet flowers and tapers were used on the tables.

America has nothing to fear from any tendency toward collectivism, because the American economic structure is founded on the ideals of the American Indian, whose philosophy and economic life was a collective one, the Rev. Dr. G.F. Beck said yesterday in an address before the congregation of the Community Church at Town Hall.

LONG BEACH, Calif., Aug. 27. -- Movie Star II finished in first place in the third race of the series today and took a commanding lead in the international Star Class yacht championship series off the Pacific Coast.

President Roosevelt has received official and unofficial expressions of approval from practically all Latin-American countries as a result of the administration's Cuban policy, according to a statement made last night by Louis McHenry Howe, the President's secretary, in his Sunday night radio broadcast over an NBC net work.

CHICAGO, Aug. 27. -- A summary of leading lines of manufacture and distribution reveals greatly increased activity in many industries, but some slowing down in others. Adoption of codes for the NRA has produced uncertainties, but there is a gradual clearing up in the situation.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Monticello is still grinning and shaking its head over the clever manner in which our good F.D.R. turned the tables on us today as he journeyed through. And are we pleased? Quite so, for it helps to more sharply emphasize the lovable humanness of President Roosevelt.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 27. -- The text of the automobile industry code as signed by President Roosevelt follows:

There have been grumblings of late from pilots of commercial airplanes over rates of pay. In the code filed with the National Recovery Administration by the air transport section of the Aeronautical Chamber of Com- merce, representing more than 95 per cent of all American-owned air lines, a minimum wage for first pilots of $250 a month was fixed.

The economy committee of five, of which Peter Grimm, chairman of the Citizens Budget Commission, is a member, has not the slightest intention of formulating a plan for raising additional revenue for the city, Mr. Grimm asserted emphatically yesterday.

With the West Side Tennis Club still abuzz over her default to Miss Helen Jacobs in the championship final on Saturday and a storm of discussion raging all over Long Island, friends of Mrs. Helen Wills Moody came to her defense yesterday in the face of generally critical opinion.

The tryout of new plays still occupies the Summer theatre, although this is the last week in which the number of "world premieres" rises to the dozen. The most important of the new ones and the places in which they can be seen are as follows:

The Giants, striving desperately to retain their hold on first place, and the Cardinals, inspired by the indomitable Frankie Frisch, battled for more than five and a half hours at the Polo Grounds yesterday, but produced only one decision.

HIGHLAND PARK, Ill., Aug. 27. -- Approximately 70 to the 115 women golfers who aspire to the crown played the Exmoor Country Club course today in preparation for the thirty-seventh annual national championship, which starts tomorrow.
HYDE PARK, N.Y., Aug. 27. -- President Roosevelt signed a code for the automobile industry in the early hours of this morning. It affects directly 450,000 workers.

On the basis of additional voluntary reports made in increasing number to local NRA headquarters in the Hotel Pennsylvania, Grover A. Whalen, city chairman of the President's Emergency Re-employment Committee, announced last night that there was ample evidence of a widespread improvement in business since the beginning of the NRA campaign.
HAVANA, Aug. 27 (AP). -- A ray of sunshine struck through Cuba's labor storm clouds today as a temporary solution was effected of railway strikes tying up traffic in Camaguey and Oriente Provinces.

TOPEKA, Kan., Aug. 27 (AP). -- The Federal Government summoned Its legal forces today for a prosecution of Tom Boyd, Kansas State Treasurer, and two other defendants in the million-dollar bond forgery scandal.

EATONTOWN, N.J., Aug. 27. -- Scoring in every period, the Fleischmann Primrose Polo team defeated the Monmouth County Country Club Rovers today, 8 to 1. The teams were tied at the end of the first session, but the Primrose defense braced in the following periods, holding the Rovers scoreless.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 27. -- The impressive repeal victory in Texas yesterday is interpreted by wet leaders in Washington as making practically certain the elimination of the Eighteenth Amendment by Dec. 5 or 6.
BRIELLE, N.J., Aug. 27. -- A giant ray, or devilfish, brought ashore here yesterday, drew hundreds of Jersey fishermen and Summer residents to this port today.

PRAGUE, Aug. 27 (Jewish Telegraphic Agency) . -- Testimony given in the magistrate's court at Jaffa. Palestine, Friday, alleging that Revisionist extremists had contemplated recourse to murder over shadowed all other issues here as the eighteenth World Zionist Congress entered its second week of deliberations today.

Several hundred thousand young people will soon be making their final plans for entering colleges, universities, professional and technical schools and other higher educational institutions. In anticipation, the United States Office of Education has issued bulletins and leaflets which are to be had for a nominal sum of 5 cents each.

Leo Friede and Walter Busch were selected as the American defenders of the International Canoe Sailing Challenge Cup yesterday. They will meet Uffa Fox and Roger De Quincey of the Royal Canoe Club of London, England, in a series of match races to be held in Little Neck Bay, starting Friday afternoon.

WESTBURY, L. I., Aug. 27. -- Aurora and Stephen Sanfords hurricane quartet, two of the combinations preparing for the open championship next month, clashed on Whitney field of the Meadow Brook Club today. Aurora emerged victorious after six periods of hard riding, 10 to 8.

Obligations of the United States Government that will mature within the next twelve months amount to $2,950,942,200. They consist of Treasury certificates of indebtedness, notes and non-interest-bearing discount bills.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Aug. 27. -- Consumption of food, clothing, household furnishings and miscellaneous merchandise by the mass of our people has suffered no sharp falling off since 1929, according to a report, "The Behavior of Consumption in Business Depression," published today by the Harvard Business School.

PARIS, Aug. 26. -- Prices in France did not share the recovery movement which occurred in the United States during recent months for two reasons. First, this rise was largely due to depreciation of the dollar against sterling, while the franc remaining stable, there was no reason at all why prices should have advanced in France.

COPENHAGEN, Aug. 27. -- Colonel and Mrs. Charles A. Lindbergh rested today after their tumultuous reception here. Heaps of flowers and thousands of cablegrams and letters for them arrived at their hotel.
NEWARK, N.J., Aug. 27 (AP). -- The Newark Bears made a clean sweep of their series with Jersey City when they took both ends of today's double-header, 3-2 and 7-1.

NEW YORK. Mr. and Mrs. E. Norman Scott of 4 East Seventy-second Street, now at Rock Ridge, Greenwich, Conn., will give a tea dance on Nov. 29 at the Cosmopolitan Club to introduce to society their daughter, Miss Delia Gurnee Scott.

BERLIN, Aug. 28 -- Under an organized counteroffensive against influences which had depressed the average of stock prices below that of last December, the Boerse opened today with a strong effort at recovery. Many stocks, among them heavy industrials, gained between 2 and 3 per cent and come specialties up to 6 per cent.

LONG BEACH, Cal., Aug. 28 -- The International Star Class Yacht Association racing committee today meted out disqualifications in the races of Saturday and yesterday to Eddie Fink, defender and series leader, together with two others.

PLATTSBURG, Aug. 28 -- Bronzed and "fit as fiddles," 850 candidates of the Citizens Military Training Camp completed their thirty-day training today and made ready for home. They will entrain for home tomorrow.

The first "real money job" that Cornelius W. Willemse, a retired Captain of the New York Police Department, had as a policeman here was to stand for eight hours a night "in front of a prominent and exclusive gambling house," he relates in his "A Cop Remember," published today by Dutton.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 (AP) -- Dr. William T. Hornaday, zoologist, was the centre of a clash at the Agriculture Department's hearing today on a proposed regulation prohibiting the baiting of wild water fowl.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 -- The basis of an agreement covering the principal points at issue in the soft coal dispute was reached tonight, according to an announcement by Hugh S. Johnson, National Recovery Administrator.
CHICAGO, Aug. 28 (AP) -- Under a rousing ride down the stretch by the veteran Earl Pool, Princess Camelia, owned by John Marsch of Chicago, accounted for the top event at Hawthorne today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 -- Accepting the general accord reached at the World Wheat Conference as a "substantial achievement," Secretary of Agriculture Wallace decided today that the American farmers would be required to pledge a reduction in their next plantings of 15 per cent of their average seeded acreage to qualify for benefit payments under the Agricultural Adjustment Act.

ALBANY, Aug. 28 -- Governor Lehman said today he would not call the Legislature back for another special session to consider the utility program which he recommended and which was sponsored by the New York State Conference of Mayors, as well as the bill providing $27,500,000 for improvement of the Barge Canal.
Housing properties comprised the bulk of the New Jersey realty turnover reported yesterday.

GENEVA, Aug. 28 -- The first meeting of the Opium Supervisory Board, established by the convention limiting the manufacture and distribution of narcotics, which went into force in July, was held today.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Codes in relation to the public health to be effective must be enforced. If the Sanitary Code of the City of New York does not make unlawful the handling of food by the selfsame person who handles the money in payment thereof, it is wickedly remiss.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 -- One and a half million volunteer canvassers went into action all over the country today as the Blue Eagle drive got under way, their goal being to obtain before the week ends 20,000,000 consumers pledged to buy only where the Blue Eagle is displayed.

After calling upon Assistant District Attorney Harold W. Hastings for "legal advice," the New York County grand jury investigating racketeering adjourned yesterday until tomorrow morning with its future plans still "under consideration."

CLEVELAND, Aug. 28 -- Brilliant riding by Jockey Leon Haas enabled him to win astride all six of his mounts at Thistle Down today. He scored in the first five races on the card, passed up the sixth and capped his record by taking the nightcap.
PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 28 (AP) -- The Pirates brought their losing streak to an end today with a double victory over the Phillies by the scores of 9 to 5 and 9 to 1.

Raymond Moley, leading member of President Roosevelt's so-called "brain trust," denied yesterday that he had resigned as Assistant Secretary of State because of a disagreement with Secretary Hull at the London Economic Conference. Such reports, Professor Moley said, were "interesting but just not true."

WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 -- The Federal Reserve Board's condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety leading cities on Aug. 23 shows decreases for the week of $103,000,000 in loans and investments, $18,000,000 in time deposits, $22,000,000 in government deposits and $9,000,000 in borrowings from Federal Reserve Banks, and increases of $15,000,000 in net demand deposits and $68,000,000 in reserve balances with Federal Reserve Banks.
HAVANA, Aug. 28 -- Three bombs exploded early this morning in butcher shops in this city, causing considerable property damage but no casualties. The authorities blame labor troubles.

While the controversial features of Mrs. Helen Wills Moody's dramatic default to Miss Helen Hull Jacobs in the national tennis championship final continued to agitate sporting circles yesterday on both sides of the Atlantic, it developed that both participants completely disregarded medical advice by competing at all.

Legal beer has materially bettered drinking conditions in up-State and Long Island counties, driven gin and moonshine sellers to the wall and substantially reduced arrests, according to first reports of County Liquor Control Boards to the State Alcoholic Beverage Control Board.

There has been no diminution in the extent of relief required by unemployed in New York City, according to a report made public yesterday by Commissioner Frank J. Taylor of the Department of Public Welfare. On the contrary, figures published by the Commissioner yesterday revealed an increase of 66 per cent in the number of families on the city's home relief rolls on July 31, compared with Dec. 31, 1932.

Market movements were erratic and uncertain yesterday, with the price trend pointing slowly and inconclusively downward. Business was dull on all exchanges. The dollar had a broad recovery in the foreign exchange market, which may have accounted partly for the nervousness of the domestic speculative markets.

Public Administration Service, a non-profit-making organization which was incorporated this month under the auspices of nine national organizations in the field of government, has launched a drive as a consulting and research agency for cities, counties and other governmental units in an endeavor to bring about constructive economy in government.

William M. Chadbourne, one-time Bull Moose backer of Theodore Roosevelt, was chosen yesterday as the manager of the fusion campaign for control of the city government, headed by Fiorello H. LaGuardia as candidate for Mayor.

ALBANY, Aug. 28 -- A temporary four-day stay of gas and electric rate reductions, ordered by the Public Service Commission, was obtained today by the New York City and Westchester companies which are resisting the decrease in their rates.

BERLIN, Aug. 28 -- The Neuer Vorwaerts, the organ of the German Socialist party, which, since the suppression of the party's militant German daily, has been published weekly at Carlsbad, has compiled what it believe to be an almost complete list of Nazi concentration camps in Germany, with the approximate number of persons interned in each.

The first step in a fight to recover nearly $6,000,000 deposited in checks in the Bank of United States on Dec. 9, 1930, the day before that institution closed its doors, was taken yesterday in Federal Court.

MEXICO, D.F., Aug. 28 (AP) -- President Abelardo Rodriguez today addressed an open letter to all manufacturers and farmers urging them to fall in line with his project of establishing minimum wages throughout the country.

AABENRAA, Denmark, Aug. 28 -- The people here are convinced that Nazi Storm Troopers contemplate an unofficial occupation of South Jutland territory at Easter-time in order to present to the powers a fait accompli and compel Copenhagen to negotiate with Berlin.

As the culmination of what the police described as a ten-year-old family quarrel, Samuel Gilanti, 23 years old, shot and critically wounded his father, Anthony Galotio, 46, in the son's home, 1,717 Eighty-fourth Street, Brooklyn, early last night.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 28 -- Mr. and Mrs. T. Markoe Robertson gave a dinner tonight at Wyndecote, their place in Main Street, for Anthony J. Drexel of Philadelphia and Paris, who is leaving the Irving this week for a short visit in Philadelphia.

Montagu Norman, governor of the Bank of England, began yesterday a series of conferences which he is to hold here this week with Federal Reserve officials and other bankers. He was the guest of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, where an office has been provided for him for his visit.

The intervention of General Hugh S. Johnson, National Recovery Administrator, in the cloak and suit situation in this city so that 15,000 cloakmakers not yet back at work may return to their shops was demanded yesterday by the Merchant Ladies Garment Association, representing the jobbers, after a meeting of its officials with representatives of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union.

The reorganization plan for the United Cigar Stores Company and some of its subsidiary and controlled companies has been declared Operative for all classes of securities and all claims entitled to participate in the plan, it was announced yesterday by the reorganization committee, headed by Eugene W. Stetson.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 -- The NRA Consumers Advisory Board, headed by Mrs. C.C. Rumsey, today evidenced opposition, to some provisions of the fair trade practices section of the proposed retail trade and the retail druggists' codes.

Baron George Wrangel is to arrive today from Europe on the White Star liner Majestic. Others who are on the ship include Justice Irving Lehman, Mr. and Mrs. Witherbee Black, Judge William F. Hagarty, Mr. and Mrs. Lansing P. Reed, Judge Isaac Wolfe, Lilyan Astaire and Mary Newcombe, actresses; Miss Constance Armstrong.
DETROIT, Aug. 28 -- Manager Bucky Harris sent Vic Sorrell back at the Yankees on Navin Field today and he blanked the McCarthymen until the ninth inning.

BALBOA HEIGHTS, C.Z., Aug. 28 -- An attempt to prove Corporal Ralph Osman of Brooklyn guilty of violation of the Espionage Act by what the judge advocate called "open circumstantial evidence" began before a general court-martial of the United States Army at Fort Sherman today.
BOSTON, Aug. 28 -- The Braves' pennant aspirations received a decided setback today when Fred (Red) Lucas, star Cincinnati twirler, shut them out, 2 to 0. Hafey made both runs for the Reds.

Helen Succeeds Helen. No one but HELEN MOODY herself is in a position to say that she ought to have made the necessary effort and taken the possibly necessary physical risk to give Miss JACOBS an "earned" championship at Forest Hills by staggering through three more games.
Ida Lupino, the young British actress whom Paramount has under consideration for the title role in "Alice in Wonderland," will leave for Hollywood by plane this afternoon from Newark Airport.

PEIPING, Aug. 28 -- Lieut. Col. Shibayama, military attache of the Japanese Legation in Peiping, gave this correspondent today important details of the Japanese military policies in North China and Chahar, indicating a determination to extend tne Japanese sphere of influence.
A variety of improved properties in Manhattan and the Bronx will be offered by James R. Murphy at foreclosure auctions this week.

PATERSON, N.J., Aug. 28 -- Charged with an attack upon two women, one the wife of a Montclair physician, in their mountain Summer home at Stonetown, Albert Allen, 23 years old, also of Stonetown, is under guard at St. Joseph's Hospital here where he is being treated for gunshot wounds, believed to have been self-inflicted.

In the September number of Current History there is an interesting article entitled "The Challenge to Organized Labor." Written by Mr. LEWIS L. LORWIN of the Brookings Institution, it is a compact study of the development of labor unions. His contention is that they are not properly organized to meet present-day needs.

The misfortunes that have marked the Lewisohn Stadium concerts for their own this season were still in evidence last night. With a very creditable first act of "Carmen" completed, a heavy downpour sent the audience and musicians hurrying for shelter and brought a halt to the performance.

Transactions on the Stock Exchange yesterday made up a total of 2,121,000 shares, compared with 3,328,000 on Friday, the last trading day of the previous week. If there was one positive indication in the day's lazy movement, it was that traders were unable to make up their minds.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 28 (AP) -- Lights in St. Louis medical centres are burning far into the night as science, tired-eyed but undiscouraged, seeks an explanation for an ever-widening spread of a mysterious ''sleeping sickness" which has taken forty lives.

VIENNA, Aug. 28 -- Austrian Nazis, flocking across the border to join the Hitler legions in Germany, will find a vastly increased Austrian army ready to deal with them if they should return, General Vaugoin told an audience at Kilb today.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 28 -- The thirty-first Kentucky Claiming Stakes, won by C.V. Whitney's Jabot, featured the Saratoga card today, but main interest centred in the Belair purse, which went to High Quest. Jabot won by a neck from Miss Merriment, which led until within a few strides of the finish line.

Although quotably unchanged, the money market was easier. In the counter trading, 3/4 money was freely offered and taken, but the board rate remained at 1 per cent. Sixty-day funds also traded at 3/4, the other maturities ruling quiet. Acceptances were steady, commercial paper more active, with the bulk of the paper being discounted at the minimum, 1 1/3 per cent.

GRAND RAPIDS, Mich., Aug. 28 (AP) -- A war of extermination against racketeers and kidnappers was declared today by 600 attorneys, vanguard of those expected at the annual American Bar Association convention which opens a three-day session here Wednesday.
Horace Elliott Wadsworth, who died suddenly in Reno, Nev., on Aug. 10, feared that he might be murdered and nine months before his death he set a trap for the person or persons he suspected.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Aug. 28 -- In the P.G.A. one-day tournament at the Broadmoor Golf Club today. Jack Sabol and John Driscoll of the Westchester Hills Country Club took first honors in the professional-amateur four-ball four-some play.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 -- The Bureau of Navigation issued the following orders today, dated Aug. 25:

Official Washington will not seem the same without Professor MOLEY. His extraordinary position near the Administration and deep in daily intimacy with the President constituted an unprecedented governmental experiment. For some weeks it has shown signs of failing.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 -- The necessity for taking some still further step to put at rest the "open shop" issue arose today despite attempts of NRA officials to dismiss or rule out further questions as to policies in administering the collective bargaining guarantees of the Recovery Act.

EAST HAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 28 -- The memorial exhibition of the work of Marjorie Woodhouse Leroy (Mrs. Carter Randolph Leidy), which has been arranged by a group of artist friends, opens in the Green Room of Guild Hall tomorrow. Sixteen water-colors of flowers will be shown, as well as two oils of fish and under-water vegetation.
LONDON, Aug. 28 -- The dollar bounded upward 9 cents in terms of sterling here today in an outburst of speculation in the London exchange market.

PARIS, Aug. 28 -- With the exception of two small groups holding an isolated ridge fifty miles south of Mount Badou, the French have captured the last strongholds of the Greater Atlas Mountains. Ous Skounti, leader of the resistance on Mount Badou itself, has surrendered with his followers, and for the first time in history these wild Berber tribes have bowed to conquerors.

SALISBURY PLAINS, L.I., Aug. 28 -- Richard and Al Ciuci of Fresh Meadow today won an amateur-pro best-bail tournament staged by the Long Island Golf Association over the championship course of the Salisbury Country Club. They oarded a 69, three strokes under par.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 (AP) -- A maximum workweek of forty hours for productive workers and office help, with minimum wages of $13 to $27.50 for skilled workers in the North and $12 to $24.75 in the South, is provided in the hosiery industry code to which President Roosevelt yesterday affixed his signature.

The Pierce-Arrow Motor Car Company, control of which was purchased for $1,000,000 last week from the Studebaker Corporation by a group of business men and bankers in Buffalo and New York, has notified the New York Stock Exchange of a plan for recapitalization.

DECATUR, Ala., Aug. 28 (AP) -- With the court house surrounded by National Guardsmen. Tom Brown, Negro on whose life mobs have made two attempts, late today entered a plea of not guilty to attacking a white woman. His trial was set for Sept. 4.
The city is negotiating with the bankers for a loan of slightly more than $34,000,000 to carry on city activities during September, it was disclosed yesterday.

BAY SHORE, L.I., Aug. 28 -- Two men escaped death today by jumping into Great South Bay after an explosion had set fire to the speedboat Playmate Thriller, a 45foot craft capable of a speed of thirty-five miles an hour.

TOKYO, Aug. 28 (AP) -- The alleged influence of the United States on Japanese civilian officials was cited in defense of eleven naval cadets charged with complicity in the assassination last year of Premier Ki Inukai as their court-martial neared an end today.

SEA GIRT, N.J., Aug. 28 -- Work on about $4,000,000 of construction for many of the State institutions of New Jersey, banned more than a year ago by Governor Moore, is to be started in the near future. Governor Moore, following a series of conferences with Commissioner John Ellis of the State Department of Institutions and Agencies and Senate President Emerson L. Richards, announced today the lifting of his ban.

Far from refusing to make sound commercial loans, several of New York's leading banks have been actively seeking borrowers lately, it was asserted yesterday. One of the largest banks has instructed its vice presidents to communicate with customers in other sections of the country who have not been borrowers lately, asking them if they do not require credit at this time.

Pressure against leading foreign loans which sent prices down from fractions to more than 4 points featured dealings in bonds on the Stock Exchange yesterday. Domestic corporation issues were irregularly lower on the day and United States Government securities were irregularly higher.

NUREMBERG, Aug. 28 -- Intoxicated with patriotic fervor, Nuremberg is putting on the last touches for the opening three days hence of the National Socialist party rally. Never since this "quaint old town of arts and song," in Longfellow's wording, has been in existence has it had so many visitors.

CHICAGO, Aug. 28 -- Farmers are rushing their pigs to market for sale to the government, and the latter has paid out $2,700,000 in the last five days for 555,000 pigs. Today it bought 167,000 pigs at fourteen leading markets. It is paying around $15 a head for sows and $5 for pigs.

BAGDAD, Iraq, Aug. 28 -- Assyrian refugees are now being taken to Mosul, where they are being fed and clothed at a concentration camp. In explanation of the long Assyrian death roll in the recent Iraqi rebellion, it is significantly reported that nearly every Assyrian rebel carried his life's savings, amounting on the average to L50.

In Good Government, the quarterly publication of the National Civil Service Reform League, Mr. HARRY W. MARSH is rather severe to Postmaster General and Double Chairman FARLEY on the score of his August declaration in regard to the allotment of offices and the relief of Democratic seekers of them.

Averting a threatened shut-down of 25,000 retail cleaners and dyers shops and a sympathetic strike of 10,000 workers, leaders of various groups in the industry initialed a tentative agreement last night after twelve hours of continuous session at the NRA headquarters in the Hotel Pennsylvania.

The ambition of JACOB S. COXEY at 80 to represent Ohio in the United States Senate is not singular. Massillon, a manufacturing city of more than 38,000 people, elected him Mayor. He must have talked them into it, and when the time came for renomination he talked himself out of it.
BROOKLINE, Mass., Aug. 28 -- The adversity that has dogged the heels of Ellsworth Vines all season abroad and at home overtook the national tennis champion again today.

ATHENS, Aug. 28 -- Greek authorities went to Samuel Insull's apartment today and took Borne papers. They said it was a routine matter of no consequence, although it was previously reported that the United States requested the action.

Moderate declines occurred in most commodities in local markets yesterday in sympathy with the advance of the dollar. Tin, copper and hides advanced for the day, and several other staples closed above the lowest levels reached.

LEIPZIG, Aug. 28 -- The Leipzig Autumn fair, with which for the first time is combined the "Brown fair," from which Jews are excluded, has opened here under the aegis of the National Socialist labor creation program. For that reason the chief emphasis Is placed on exhibits of Email or medium-sized manufacturing establishments.

The members of the Mount Everest expedition of 1933, which was a brilliant failure, are now on their way home to England. In The London Observer C.F. MEADE, a veteran Himalayan climber who almost reached the summit of Kamet (25,447 feet) twenty-one years ago, discusses the lessons of the expedition of 1933.
UPPERVILLE, Va., Aug. 28 -- Two men and a woman lost their lives today when one of them picked up a broken high tension electric wire with a croquet mallet and the others went to his assistance.

GENEVA, Aug. 28 -- Nazi demonstrations near the Swiss frontier and frontier incidents recently have caused some unrest in Switzerland, where the people wish to live peacefully and freely under the democratic regime.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 (AP) -- After mounting steadily month by month since March, farm purchasing power received a sharp setback between July 15 and Aug. 15, the opening of harvest seasons for many crops.

William B. Okie Jr. and Robert Adams, both 26 years old, who went riding Sunday morning in a baker's wagon, they did not own, were found guilty of disorderly conduct yesterday by Magistrate Ford in Torkville Court, but received suspended sentences, after a warning not to do it again.

Stores Press for Deliveries. Increasing pressure for deliveries featured the women's apparel markets here yesterday. With current wholesale stocks at a very low point, retailers have become worried regarding shipment of orders which they expect will be needed soon.

HAVERFORD, Pa., Aug. 28 -- Miss Helen Grawn of Detroit, girls' national indoor tennis champion, was one of the first round winners in the open tournament for girls that got under way today on the Merlon Cricket Club grass courts.
VIENNA, Aug. 28 -- The first legal breach in the military clauses of the peace treaties that ended the World War apparently will be made by Austria this week.

LONDON, Aug. 28 -- Talking darkly of "political enemies" and underground criticism, Raymond Moley explained today the circumstances of his resignation as Assistant Secretary of State in a telephone interview with The London Evening Standard.

High school courses based exclusively on college entrance requirements cannot be justified on "social, intellectual, vocational or cultural grounds," according to a study in secondary education prepared by the High School Teachers Association under the direction of Charles M. Stebbins of Erasmus Hall High School, Brooklyn.

GLOUCESTER, Mass., Aug. 28 -- The Vineyard Haven Yacht Club trio of Frank B. Jewett Jr., Richard Chase and Theodore Robie won the first race today as competition opened for the Herbert M. Sears bowl and the North American yacht racing union medals in the national junior championship.

LONDON, Aug. 28 (AP) -- Mrs. Helen Wills Moody's default to Miss Helen Jacobs in the American tennis championship final provided a major sensation for the British press, which continued to give front-page prominence to the story today.

COPENHAGEN, Aug. 28 -- Colonel Charles A. Lindbergh's crowded day included a talk with Premier Theodor Stauning, a dinner at the residence of Mrs. Ruth Bryan Owen, the United States Minister, and a number of business appointments.
A violent downpour of rain, accompanied by a fifty-one-mile southerly gale, brought relief to the city yesterday afternoon from heat and high humidity that had caused one death and one prostration.

BERLIN, Aug. 28 -- A remarkable announcement by the German Land Trade League, published in newspapers here today, would indicate, if correct, that the much-heralded Jewish boycott of German goods has certain qualifications. The league announces the conclusion of a barter arrangement between Germany on one side and Palestine and Syria on the other.

A rearrangement of the teams in the open championship polo tournament, which starts next month at the Meadow Brook Club in Westbury, was made yesterday in order to permit the substitution of Earle W. Hopping for Thomas Hitchcock Jr. on the Sands Point quartet.
Prices on the Cotton Exchange ranged within limits of less than $1 a bale yesterday and ended with losses of 5 to 10 points.

CHICAGO, Aug. 28 -- Fluctuations in sterling exchange are having considerable influence on the grain markets on the Board of Trade here, as the rise or fall of the American dollar is regarded as reflecting the progress or delay of inflation of the currency.

FAIRBANKS, Alaska, Aug. 28 -- Science's picture of the upper atmosphere as a placid ocean of gas undisturbed by winds or currents of any sort and possessing a uniform low temperature appears to have been disproved, Dr. H.B. Maris, naval scientist, declared today in an article published by The Farthest North Collegian, student publication of the Alaska College of Agriculture and Mines.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 -- Asserting that crime costs the American people thirteen billions annually and that the "tribute paid to racketeers amounts to eighteen billions, Secretary Dern called to the attention of the nation "the frightful crime conditions with which it is confronted," in a radio address over the National Broadcasting network tonight.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 -- Joseph B. Eastman, Federal Coordinator of Transportation, called upon executives of Class I railroads today to make a survey of freight car equipment and give their views as to the necessity for repair or retirement of worn-out and obsolete cars.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 (AP) -- Meetings were called today for Sept. 5 in Atlanta, Memphis and Dallas to discuss a program for "the control of next year's cotton crop."

Not even a cloudburst that deluged the Polo Grounds sufficed to keep the Giants and Cardinals a part yesterday. They simply sat around for about thirty-five minutes waiting for some of the water to drain off and then fell upon each other with great vigor.

The dollar rallied strongly in foreign exchange yesterday, partly as a natural rebound from its heavy depreciation of last week, partly in reflection of Europe's interest in the conference between President Roosevelt and Montagu Norman, governor of the Bank of England, and partly from arbitrage operations connected with the United Kingdom 5 1/2 s, which are convertible into sterling obligations.

DETROIT, Aug. 28 -- Judge Harry B. Keidan called today for the appearance of the conservators of the Detroit Trust Company and the Union Guardian Trust Company before the one-man Detroit bank jury for an examination of books and records to determine whether there had been any criminal action in management before the banking holiday.

MOSCOW, Aug. 28 -- Great prominence is given in the Soviet press to the arrival and journey of Edouard Herriot, former Premier of France, who will be the guest of the government in Moscow and will stay at the Foreign Office residence, 17 Spirodonovka, the former mansion of one of the Morossof textile barons and later the headquarters of the American Relief Association from 1921 to 1923.

Huey Long, United States Senator, "Kingfish" of Louisiana politics and stormy petrel of whatever place he happens to be in, is nursing a gash over his left eye and talking mysteriously about having been "ganged."

DUBLIN, Aug. 28 (AP) -- It was reported in political circles tonight that fusion plans involving the political party of former President William T. Cosgrave, the Centre party and the National Guard under the leadership of General Owen O'Duffy nearly have been completed.
ALDERSHOT, England, Aug. 28 (Canadian Press) -- Making a gallant up-hill fight in its cricket match with the Army, the touring British West Indies eleven today tallied 331 runs for only six wickets.

While detectives thronged the conference room and corridor of local NRA headquarters in the Hotel Pennsylvania, Grover A. Whalen met a delegation of sixteen representatives of the Shoe and Leather Workers Industrial Union late yesterday afternoon.

PRAGUE, Aug. 28 -- Dr. Chaim Weizmann is expected to arrive at the Zionist Congress here tomorrow to prepare for his return to the presidency. Some leaders say he will be elected by a majority of 55 votes.

The flood of indignation and protests that followed the announcement a week ago that water carriers would no longer be permitted to participate in the rate categories of the Official Classification Committee of the Eastern Railroads received an encouraging response yesterday, according to Stanley Carpenter, general freight agent of the Seaboard-Great Lakes Corporalion, 17 Battery Place.

HYDE PARK, N.Y., Aug. 28 -- President Roosevelt speeded up his national recovery campaign today. He directed Jesse Jones, chairman of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, to work out immediately a program for extending temporary credit through the banks to the members of the NRA to tide them over the sudden expansion of work and wages.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 28 -- A complaint that bootleggers, paying a premium price for refined gold, had established what amounted to a free gold market in this country and were threatening ruin to the American refining industry, was sent to the committee for the nation today by Rosa M. Barrett of this city, head of the Crucible Service.

Fishing boats for the first time since the hurricane of last week moved out to the fishing grounds yesterday, and from all reports of the boat captains every one had some success. Prospects now along the south Jersey coast, and in fact all along the coast from Sandy Hook to Cape May, indicate good sport.

THE Giants spent all Sunday afternoon at the Polo Grounds working hard and apparently gaining nothing thereby. There were two games and the Giants didn't win either contest. Up in Boston the boisterous Braves broke even in a double-header and moved a trifle closer to the Giants.

ALBANY, Aug. 28 -- Governor Lehman today approved twenty-two bills passed at the extraordinary session of the Legislature. Among them were the Mortgage Moratorium and Deficiency Judgment Bills and also a series of measures which place New York State's laws in conformity with the NRA program.

PARIS, Aug. 28 -- Two American citizens of Russian birth, husband and wife, have given to the newspaper Le Matin an account of a visit which they have just made to their native villages in the Ukraine, Russia. The name of the couple has been suppressed because of fear of reprisals on their relatives, but their identity and the authenticity of their story have been confirmed as fully as possible.

The announcement that relief rolls, the country over, have gone down by one-third since March, carried the encouraging intimation that employment has gone up markedly, if not commensurately. The specific statement made as the result of a survey of thirty-four States is that in these few months 1,223,000 families have " placed themselves " on a self-supporting basis -- or one-third of the names on the list in March, the month of greatest general unemployment.
CHICAGO, Aug. 28 (AP) -- The Athletics reached Sam Jones in the seventh inning today and renewed their assault against Ted Lyons in the ninth to defeat the White Sox, 9 to 5, and even the series.
HIGHLAND PARK, Ill., Aug. 28 -- Miss Bea Gottlieb, the girl who beat the Prince or Wales, didn't qualify for the women's national golf championship today, but she wasn't downhearted at all.

FREEPORT, L.I., Aug. 28 -- Louis P. Stone, father of Fred Stone, the famous actor, died early today, after a long illness, at his home, 56 South Long Beach Avenue. He was 85 years old. Three years ago his wife, Clara, died in the same house.
To the Editor of The New York Times: There is just one point in the recent letter of Edmund Platt upon which perhaps many more readers than I would like a little further information.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 28 (AP) -- Emmett O'Malley, State Superintendent of Insurance, was directed today by Circuit Judge Charles B. Williams to take charge of the Missouri State Life Insurance Company, for which he had asked a receiver, alleging that the company's liabilities exceeded its assets by $27,000,000.

The art of traveling is lost on the American public, according to Dr. W. Beran Wolfe, psychiatrist, who returned yesterday from a fifty-four day cruise on the Holland-America liner Volendam. The Volendam returned with 489 passengers, after steaming for 13,000 miles to twelve countries, visiting twenty-five ports.

CAMP PERRY, Ohio, Aug. 28 -- Scott Romig of Uhrichsville, Ohio, and G.F. Petersimes of Detroit carried off most of the honors today in the three events in the preliminary program of the current national rifle shooting matches.

HIGHLAND PARK, Ill., Aug. 28 -- Twice thwarted in her plans to capture the United States title, Miss Enid Wilson, sturdy British champion, today scored a 76 to establish a new record in the qualifying round of the thirty-seventh annual women's national golf tournament.
International dinghy racing be held at Oyster Bay by the Seawanhaka. Corinthian Yacht Club starting Sept. 15, with crews from England, Toronto, Rochester and Long Island Sound.

MANILA, Aug. 28 -- Despite repeated rumors emanating chiefly from the minority in the Legislature that the plan for a plebiscite on independence is to be abandoned, Senator Manuel Quezon, the majority leader, said today it was going through, sooner or later.
HYDE PARK, N.Y., Aug. 28 -- President Roosevelt had a conference today with Secretary Ickes, wherein he reviewed the public works program.

To the Editor of The New York Times: It was a real stroke of statesmanship on President Roosevelt's part to organize a Consumer Advisory Board. The American consumer has always been a mythical entity, concerning whom other people theorized but did not know. In particular the woman consumer has been without a voice or a representative, in a broad sense.

Net operating income in July of the first forty-eight railroads to report for the month was $48,177,000, against $9,634,000 in July, 1932, an increase of 400.1 per cent; $43,191,000 in July, 1931, a rise of 11.5 per cent, and $62,796,000 in July, 1930, a decrease of 23.3 per cent.

SHANGHAI, Aug. 28 -- A demand for trial and punishment of Governor Liu Shin of Honan Province on charges of cutting Yellow River dikes in Honan, thus deliberately flooding Western Shantung and making 3,000,000 persons homeless to save Honan areas from inundation, was sent to Nanking today.

Plans have been completed for the marriage of Miss Virginia May Dillon, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John J. Dillon of this city and Port Chester, to John F. Curry Jr., son of the Tammany leader and Mrs. Curry of 101 Central Park West. The ceremony will be performed here on Sept. 16 in the Church of St. Ignatius Loyola by the Rev. William Finneran, a cousin of the prospective bride.

The funeral of General Sessions Judge Max S. Levine at Temple Shaare Zedek, 212 West Ninety-third Street yesterday afternoon was attended by about 2,500 persons. The temple was built to accommodate 1,700. Police estimated the number outside as 5,000.

It was learned yesterday that the James Boring Company, travel agents, had been forced to cancel two late Summer cruises to Bermuda and the West Indies as the result of demands made by the United States Shipping Board in defense of established American lines to these ports.

ALGONAC, Mich., Aug. 29 -- One source of concern for Hubert ScottPaine, British challenger for the Hannsworth Trophy, was removed today when 600 gallons of special gasoline and twenty-five gallons of castor oil, which he will use In the Miss Britain III, arrived from Southampton, England.

Asserting that there is no longer "any acceptable excuse for any individual employer or group of employers to refrain from signing up under the NRA." James F. Hodgson, district director of the Department of Commerce, issued an appeal yesterday for 100 per cent augnment under the Blue Eagle of employers in the three States -- New York. New Jersey and Connection which make up the local district.

Controller Berry'a answer to the petition asking his removal from office was filed yesterday with Governor Lehman in Albany. The charges, signed by James E. Finegan and five other taxpayers, were termed "frivolous" by the Controller.

Working hours and rates of pay prescribed by the President's Agreement must be observed by members of the New York Cotton Exchange under that Exchange's code of fair competition submitted to the Recovery Administration for approval.
TOENDER, Denmark, Aug. 29 -- The appointment has been announced of a German trade adviser for Aabenraa, one of four to be appointed for South Jutland.

The fusion of former President William T. Cosgrave's Irish Centre party and the forces of General Owen O'Duffy, head of the Blue Shirts, suggests no startling development in the Free State because their objectives are identical, according to Sean T. O'Kelly, Vice President of the Executive Council of the Irish Free State and Minister for Local Government and Public Health.

E.T. Tomlinson Jr., president of Doremus Co., an international advertising agency specializing in the financial field, has resigned, according to a formal announcement made yesterday. He joined the company as vice president on May 1, 1919, and became president in 1928 on the death of C.W. Barron, founder and president of the agency.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 -- Since Miss Nellie Dougherty was named by the Roosevelt administration on March 9 as acting postmaster of Minot, N.D., 369 women have been put in charge of the mails in their home towns.

BERLIN, Aug. 29 -- The upward movement on the Boerse which the banks organized toward the end of last week began to show signs of exhaustion today. Trading was very quiet, but the opening was generally firm. Heavy industrials gained up to 2 per cent and some specialties, including German Cables, rose 5 1/2 per cent.
SEATTLE, Wash., Aug. 29 -- Washington's voters showed a decisive trend toward repeal of prohibition tonight as early returns from today's special election were tabulated.

The movement for codification and unionization of all needle trades in the ladies' garment field, affecting more than 150,000 workers in New York and vicinity, moved forward another step yesterday with the signing of a collective agreement between the National Skirt Manufacturers Association and the International Ladies Garment Workers Union.

MOSCOW, Aug. 29 -- Moscow is to have a subway system and to insure completioa or the first section by the appointed date, Nov. 7, 1934, the Communist Youth Party has decided to mobilize 10,000 volunteers for the work.

The recapitalization of the FierceArrow Motor Car Company as proposed will eliminate debts totaling $2,108,187 owed to the Studebaker Corporation, according to letters sent to Pierce-Arrow stockholders. Control of Fierce-Arrow was purchased last week for $1,000,000 by business men and bankers in New York, Buffalo and Boston.

The success of women members of the local NRA committee in mediating labor controversies was disclosed yesterday by memoranda supplied by the NRA Bureau of Complaints, of which Henry F. Wolff is chairman.

Professor Gerhard Cohn, his wife and four children, and Professor Arthur M. Feiler and his wife arrived yesterday on the White Star liner Majestic.
