They are Jewish refugees from Germany and came here as the advance guard of fourteen scholars ousted by the Nazis to become members of the faculty of what is termed the Exile University, sponsored by the New School of Social Research.

ALBANY, Aug. 29 -- Two bills designed to undermine the power of gangsters were signed today by Governor Lehman. One conferred sweeping authority on the Attorney Geneal to combat racketeering, and the other outlaws the sub-machine gun.

Daniel Donovan, an attorney, of 433 Forty-third Street, Brooklyn, was arrested yesterday on a disorderly conduct charge after, it was alleged, he had used "abusive and threatening language" to Magistrate Mark Rudich in the Bay Ridge court.

HAVANA, Aug. 29 -- Eleven justices of the Cuban Supreme Court resigned late this afternoon, leaving Chief Justice Juan Federico Edelman, appointed several days ago, as the only member of the supreme tribunal, according to Dr. Carlos Saladrigas, Secretary of Justice and Secretary of State pro tem.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 -- Public works projects which call for an expenditure of $60,000,000 and are expected to provide work for more than 50,000 persons were approved today by the Federal Emergency Administration of Public Works.

PEEKSKILL, N.Y., Aug. 29 -- Operating under simulated warfare conditions, staff officers of the Seventy-first Infantry of Manhattan, commanded by Colonel Walter A. De Lamater, demonstrated here today a command post exercise, the most important military manoeuvre taken up during training.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 (AP) -- The participation of A.A. Berle Jr. as legal adviser to the Farm Administration on the proposed sugar marketing agreement today was formally protested at an open hearing by Wilbur Cummings of New York, representing domestic refiners.

Application by the city to the bankers for a short-term loan of $34,000,000 is described by Mr. UNTERMYER as merely the "customary" borrowing in anticipation of taxes. He denies that there is anything "sensational" about it, and declares that the effort to make it appear so is "unfortunate and injurious to the city's credit."

TORONTO, Aug. 29 -- An international field of 149 swimmers, eightyfive of them from, the United States, will seek $8,000 prize money in the Canadian National Exhibition's annual 15-mile marathon for men in Lake Ontario tomorrow.

VIENNA, Aug. 29 -- The Austrian Foreign Office sought today to explain away, or at least to modify, the statement made by War Minister Vaugoin in a speech Sunday that Austria would supplement her standing army by an organized militia whose recruits would receive six months training.

Chester Wroblenski, 17 years old, of 82 Cleveland Street, New Brighton, S.I., was seriously injured and his brother, Eugene, 15, was hurt yesterday when the second floor of an abandoned brick building at Bank and Jersey Streets, New Brighton, collapsed.

Pairings and starting times were announced yesterday by the United States Golf Association for the thirty-six-hole qualifying trials of the national amateur championship. The tournament will be staged at the Kenwood Country Club, Cincinnati, from Sept. 11 to 16, with the two eighteen-hole qualifying rounds scheduled for the first two days.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 29 -- President Roosevelt's National Recovery Act is the subject of a lyric written by George H. Hull, who with Mrs. Hull is occupying Roselawn. It is called "The National Recovery Anthem," for marching. The music was composed by Carroll W.J. Ball and it will be sung for the first time between the acts at the presentation of the Gilbert and Sullivan operetta.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 -- The NRA announced dates on hearings for two new codes and listed thirty new codes submitted today.
FLEMINGTON, N.J., Aug. 29 -- Calumet Alone, the Elkins Park gelding, won the 2:14 class pace, opening event at the Flemington Fair track today. The victor won the first two heats.

Recoveries occurred yesterday in contracts for future deliveries of most of the principal commodities traded here and closing prices generally were well above the day's low points. The rally followed the publication of the news that the embargo on gold exports had been modified.
ATHENS, Aug. 29 -- Samuel Insull was apparently calm and in good spirits throughout the hearing today, but when the court returned with the verdict his face muscles contracted slightly.

In the boom days of 1929 Miss Edna V. O'Brien, investment consultant, guaranteed the original capital of some small investors who opened accounts with her, she testified yesterday at a hearing before Federal Referee Peter B. Olney Jr. at 19 Rector Street.
HAMILTON, Bermuda, Aug. 29 (AP) -- Former President Gerardo Machado of Cuba sailed late today for Canada after British police refused him permission to go ashore during a stopover of several hours.

CLOVIS, N.M., Aug. 29 (AP) -- A tri-motored mail and passenger plane, flying virtually blind in fog and storm, crashed early today into a mountain sixty miles from here and its five occupants died in flames.

A supplementary report issued yesterday by the Emergency Unemployment Relief Committee showed that by Sept. 30 there will have been issued during the year ending on that date to distressed New York families 45,000,000 pounds of food, 5,333,369 cotton garments, 25,500 men's woolen suits and 113,891 comforters and blankets.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 -- The first court test of President Roosevelt's National Recovery program was won by the government today with the dismissal by Justice Daniel W. O'Donoghue in the District of Columbia Supreme Court, of two suits challenging the constitutionality of the Agricultural Adjustment Act.

Fiorello LaGuardia, candidate for Mayor, and his associates on the fusion ticket decided yesterday to rent offices in the Paramount Building in Times Square for their city headquarters and took steps to unite the various elements supporting the fusion movement.

HAVANA, Aug. 29 -- President Carlos Manuel de Cespedes, in an interview with foreign correspondents this morning, said martial law in Cuba would be lifted about Sept. 8, the end of the thirty-day period for which it was declared. He summed up the ideals of his government in the historic words of Simon Bolivar, the great emancipator of Latin America: "Authority without tyranny, liberty without disorder."

Twenty-two parcels of real estate in Manhattan and the Bronx were put up at foreclosure auctions yesterday and were struck down to the plaintiffs who brought about the default actions, and by this bidding in the properties at auctioneers' stands protected their liens.
The New York State Alcoholic Beverage Control Board joined the ranks of magazine publishers yesterday with the first issue of its monthly bulletin, The ABC News.

HANKOW, Aug. 29 -- The mystery surrounding the fate of seven American missionaries, trapped for two months in the siege of Yuanchow 1250 miles southwest of Hankow] was heightened today when the United States Consulate received a message saying government troops had recaptured the city from rebels.
CHICAGO, Aug. 29 (AP) -- Darting to the front at the start, the Shandon Farm's North Mill led all the way to account for the top event of the card at Hawthorne today.

To the Editor of The New York Times: For the greater benefit of the milkbuying public, as well as for the benefit of all milk distributers, I wish to submit a suggestion to show that a considerable cash saving could be effected by a simple change in the method of distributing bottled milk.

HIGHLAND PARK, Ill., Aug. 29 -- Tired of being a champion, tired of acting like one and eager to play the game for "enjoyment only," Miss Enid Wilson, winner of the British title three years in succession, tonight said she would retire from competitive golf after the current American championship at Exmoor.

The first report of a strike to compel an employer to go under the Blue Eagle was received from Middletown, N.Y., yesterday, by W. Averell Harriman, chairman of the Presidtent's Emergency Re-employment Committee for the State of New York.

Verdi',s "Il Trovatore" was presented last night at the Lewisohn Stadium. A clear, cool night finally permitted the redeeming of the management's promise to put on opera with settings, costumes and action in the Philharmonic-Symphony series of concerts.

The listed bond market yesterday was firmer in tone than on Monday, with rallying tendencies in many sections. On the basis of the averages, however, foreign loans and all classifications of domestic corporation issues closed slightly lower on the day. Most long-term United States Government issues ended higher, the maximum gain amounting to 4-32 point.

LONG BEACH, Calif., Aug. 29 -- Eddie Fink of the defending Long Beach fleet turned in his third sensational triumph in the fourth race of the International Star Class championship yacht series today to pull himself up from sixth to third place in the point standing.

BREMEN, Aug. 29 -- Dr. G. Carl Lahusen and his brother, Hans Lahusen, formerly social and business leaders of Northern Germany, exponents of German nationalism and principal owners of the bankrupt Nordwolle concern, went on trial here today on charges of fraud involving a loss of about 250,000,000 marks.

Daily average gross crude oil production in the United States last week was 2,756,400 barrels, comparing with 2,766,500 barrels in the preceding week, a decline of 10,100 bar- rels, according to the American Pe- troleum Institute. Decreases of 15,100 barrels in Oklahoma and 3,800 in California and gains of 4,550 barrels in East Texas and 4,250 in the Conroe field were the principal changes.

PRAGUE, Aug. 29 -- The conflict within the World Zionist Congress, caused by the presentation during the week-end of charges that the Palestine labor leader, Dr. Chaim Arlosoroff, had been murdered by Zionist Revisionists, brooded over the discussions of the congress today if it did not publicly enter into them.

TUCUMCARI, N.M., Aug. 29 -- Eight persons were killed and more than forty were injured when the Golden State Limited, crack trans-continental passenger train, plunged through a weakened bridge into a flooded arroyo five miles west of here at dawn today. An unestimated number were missing.

ALDERSHOT, England, Aug. 29 (Canadian Press) -- The three-day cricket match between the Army and the British West Indies finished in a draw tonight. The scores were: Army 472 for eight declared and 149 for five declared; West Indies, 346 and 181 for four.

Funds which have been made available for housing under the Federal recovery program should be advanced "in conformity with a definite housing and rehabilitation policy to end the chaotic growth of cities and to prevent waste of Federal money," in the opinion of the committee on economics of site planning and housing of the American Institute of Architects.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 29 -- The climax to the long sequence of losing favorites which has prevailed here was capped today when Mrs. Dodge Sloane's Snap Back, held at 1 to 3 in the featured Amsterdam Claiming Stakes, was soundly beaten by the Brandywine Stable's Pencader.

After much hesitation the share market turned sharply upward shortly before the close of business on the Stock Exchange yesterday following publication of the news that President Roosevelt had modifield the gold embargo.

State of California. The State of California is expected to enter the market on Oct. 10 with a new issue of $6,000,000 relief bonds, according to advices received here yesterday. The issue will carry a 4 1/4 per cent coupon and will mature $2,000,000 annually on July 1, 1938 to 1940.

Refusal of relatives of abduction victims to pay ransom to kidnappers will play a large part in curbing the kidnapping menace, Police Commissioner Bolan said last night in a radio interview broadcast by WOR.

Five representatives of the cottonspinning industry of Japan arrived in this city yesterday, en route for London, where they will attend a conference with British cottonspinning interests on the subject of Anglo-Japanese competition in the world cotton goods trade.

The July statements thus far published by the railways report gross revenue averaging 22 per cent above 1932. Net operating income is five times what it was for the same roads in July last year. When all the railways shall have reported, the percentage increase in gross receipts should be greater, because operating revenue follows closely changes in actual volume of freight carried, and the "loadings" of July exceeded 1932 by 32 per cent.

HIGHLAND PARK, Ill., Aug. 29 -- For a time today the fate of two metropolitan district aspirants for the women's national golf championship, Miss Helen Hicks and Hiss Maureen Orcutt, hung in the balance.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 -- A new record for industrial harmony was established today in the records of the NRA when Malcolm Muir, Deputy Recovery Administrator, concluded a hearing on a code of fair competition for me transit industry after forty-three minutes of complete agreement in the industry.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 (AP) -- The Interstate Commerce Commission has asked the Supreme Court to require the Pennsylvania Railroad and the Pennsylvania Company to comply with its order directing them to dispoes of stock which they had bought in the Wabash and the Lehigh Valley Railroads.

MINNEAPOLIS, Minn., Aug. 29 (AP) -- Sixteen separate suits seeking a total of $2,400,000 from E.W. Backus, president of the Minnesota Ontario Paper Company, were filed in Federal District Court today by plaintiffs living in New York and New Jersey.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 -- Austria's reported moves toward the organization of a conscript army were regarded here as a favorable aspect of the disarmament situa- tion in Central Europe. State Department officials had received no official reports of the plan today, and unofficial reports were conflicting, so that comment was guarded.

It is highly significant of civilized life that whenever a menace to health shows itself anywhere in the world science at once rushes to resist the advance. The outbreak of "sleeping sickness" in St. Louis, as an instance, has speedily brought to the afflicted area not only research specialists and doctors intimately acquainted with this dreaded disease but the United States Surgeon General in person with his senior surgeon.

With a second draft of the Triborough Bridge loan contract completed in Washington yesterday, George Gordon Battle, chairman of the Bridge Authority, said he expected the final draft to be made and signed by the end of this week.

Up to the time when the Presi- dent's plans for a controlled gold market were announced the share market had a slow and uneventful movement yesterday. Most of the time it was reactionary, although only moderately so. The afternoon rally was quite vigorous and it at- traded a considerable number of traders.

Bent on making themselves extremely annoying even if their own pennant chances are considered to be very near a vanishing point, Frankie Frisch's Cardinals are still making themselves heard at the Polo Grounds.
HYDE PARK, N.Y., Aug. 29 -- The text of President Roosevelt's executive order on new-mined gold follows:
NEW ORLEANS, Aug. 29 -- For the last six weeks Senator Huey P. Long, centre of a fight in a Long Island club, has been taking boxing lessons at the New Orleans Athletic Club.

Officials of the State Banking Department are attempting to reach some basis on which to approach the Federal Home Owners' Loan Corporation with a request to help refinance about $10,000,000 worth of small home and apartment mortgages, according to James T. Heenehan, Deputy State Banking Superintendent.

Nicholas Roberts, for some years president of S.W. Straus Co., Inc., whose real estate financing operations have been in the courts for several years, was arrested yesterday afternoon on a grand larceny charge sworn to by Miss Anna Kuhlmann of 655 Greenwich Street.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 -- President Roosevelt's Executive order permitting the exportation of newly mined gold represents no official action cutting the gold value of the dollar, according to high Treasury officials.

MARBLEHEAD, Mass., Aug. 29 -- Miss Helen Jacobs, women's national tennis champion, said today she had approved of the default by Mrs. Helen Wills Moody in their championship match last Saturday at Forest Hills when the former champion was unable to continue because of a back injury.

To the Editor of The New York Times: THE TIMES editorial notice of The American Mercury's criticism of "English English" was, In THE TIMES'S manner, comprehensive, urbane and tolerant. I wish you had turned it toward a plea for local autonomy in the matter of pronunciation.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 -- The operations of Chinese Communists in the vicinity of Yenping, in Fukien Province, have created a situation of sufficient danger to cause the State Department today to request the navy to dispatch a vessel immediately for the evacuation of all Americans in that region.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 -- A new era of peace appears to be assured miners and operators in the bituminous coal fields as the result of an agreement which was being writtern today under the supervision of the National Recovery Administration.

COPENHAGEN, Aug. 29 -- Colonel Charles A. Lindbergh spent most of the day today with mechanics overhauling his airplane, while his wife added to her popularity by visiting and thanking the operators at the airport radio station here for their work during the couple's flight from the Shetland Islands to Copenhagen.

CHICAGO, Aug. 29 -- New low levels for grains on the present movement were recorded today on the Board of Trade here as a flood of liquidation by holders of September contracts came into the pit and found support lacking until near the close of the market.
PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 29 (AP) -- The Pirates made it three in a row over the Phillies today, winning 4 to 1 behind the five-hit pitching of Heinie Meine.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 -- Asserting that no corporation or group can block the recovery campaign, Hugh S. Johnson estimated tonight that 2,000,000 idle had been returned to jobs already through the NRA's effort to start the nation on the pathway to prosperity.

LONDON, Aug. 29 -- The British Government end the Jewish Agency for Palestine today disclaimed any knowledge Of the reported barter, arrangement by which Palestine fruit growers were said to have sold 10,000,000 marks worth of oranges to Germany for double that amount of German goods.

DETROIT, Aug. 29 -- Tony Lazzeri's bat fashioned a victory for the Yankees over the Tigers today at Navln Field, where the world's champions of last year played the final game of their Western invasion.

To the Editor of The New York Times: It is with sincere regret that I have read in the newspapers many articles of criticism concerning the Jamaica Hospital. The forty years of service that this institution has rendered to our community seems to be entirely forgotten.

TRENTON, N.J., Aug. 29 -- The Assembly defeated tonight a bill to extend the temporary beer law until February. It adopted also a resolution calling upon Senate President Emerson L. Richards to make known all the facts surrounding his charge of a "slush fund" to defeat a permanent beer bill.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 (AP). -- A severe drought has been sweeping the nation again this Summer, bringing parched crops and dried up pastures to a large part of the country.
ATHENS, Aug. 29 -- The detention of Samuel Insull pending a hearing on extradition to the United States was upheld today by the Athens Appeals Court.

CLEVELAND. Aug. 29 (AP) -- An enthusiastic ladies' day crowd of 50,000 watched the pace-setting Senators and the Indians divide two games today, the first going to the Senators, 2 to 1, and the second to the Indians, 7 to 2.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 29 -- Mr. and Mrs. Rufus L. Patterson gave a dinner tonight at Lenoir for Mr. and Mrs. Beverley Bogert of Anglesea, Newport, R.I., who arrived yesterday afternoon on their yacht Trudone. Mr. and Mrs. Patterson, who have been visiting in Newport, returned with Mr. and Mrs. Bogert.

BROOKLINE, Mass., Aug. 29 -- The scratch combination of George M. Lott Jr. of Chicago and Lester Stoefen of Los Angeles, organized two weeks ago at Newport, removed the last foreign threat in the national doubles championship today at the Longwood Cricket Club.

The committee in charge of the testimonial dinner to be given for Samuel Untermyer at the Hotel Astor on Sept. 10 will include many leaders in business, religion and the professions, an announcement made yesterday by George Gordon Battle, the committee's chairman, Indicated.

David Lamar, whose mysterious stock market transactions caused him to become known as "The Wolf of Wall Street," was arrested last night at his apartment in the Hotel Laurelton at 147 West Fifty-fifth Street and locked up at Police Headquarters charged with grand larceny.

HYDE PARK, Aug. 29 (AP) -- President Roosevelt brought his recovery program up to date today with the designation of Harold L. Ickes, Secretary of Interior, as administrator of the new deal for the warring oil industry.
NUREMBERG, Germany, Aug. 29 -- Chancellor Hitler is scheduled to make several speeches in the course of the four-day Nazi congress which will open here today.
NEW YORK. Orme Wilson, newly appointed First Secretary of the American Embassy at Berlin, and Mrs. Wilson will leave late in October for his new post.

PARIS, Aug. 29 -- The French Government today issued a decree requiring marks of origin on a long list of office supplies. Many articles of American export come under the ruling, which adds another impediment to already extremely hampered trade relations with France.

The issuance of currency against frozen bank deposits, under the emergency powers available to President Roosevelt, was urged yesterday by the Committee of the Nation. Frozen deposits were estimated by the committee at $7,500,000,000, or nearly 20 per cent of the total of deposits in all commercial banks.

Another even break was the best the reinforced Dodgers could do against the Cubs at Ebbets Field yesterday. Linus Frey, making his first appearance in a Brooklyn uniform, played shortstop in both games, performed well afield and got two hits in the opener.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 -- With the NRA's "big push" to pledge 20,000,000 consumers to buy only under the Blue Eagle advancing its lines throughout the nation today. Mrs. Woodrow Wilson made public a letter calling upon the women of America to back the campaign.

Easy conditions continued in the money market, funds for every class of accommodation being liberally offered. While the Stock Exchange rate for call loans remained at 1 per cent, Street trades were done at 3/4, and the supply at that figure was particularly heavy.
CHICAGO, Aug. 29 (AP) -- Treating four pitchers roughly, the White Sox pounded out a sixteen-hit, 11-to-5 decision over the Athletics in the fifth and deciding game of the series today.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., Aug. 29 -- With talcum powder brushed over a two-inch cut above his left eye, Senator Huey P. Long of Louisiana today lambasted Milwaukee newspapers, Wall Street and certain policies of the Roosevelt administration.

PARIS, Aug. 29 -- The death occurred in a Paris hospital this morning of John Henry Bailey, who for the last ten years had been the doorman at the Paris office of THE NEW YORK TIMES. Mr. Bailey, a Negro, who had a varied and interesting career, was widely known.
Results of operations were announced yesterday by industrial and other corporations. Comparison of earnings with those in previous periods were made.

With a mysterious stab wound in the heart, William Brackebusch, an unemployed actor whose wife said he was a former member of the Freiburg Passion Players, was found dead yesterday in an unoccupied mansion at 115 East Seventy-second Street, of which he was the caretaker.

Plans for the launching of a campaign next Spring to increase the use of silk in this country are now being developed by the Japanese silk industry, it was announced yesterday by Senator Gosuke Imai, president of the Japanese Filatures Association, at a luncheon at the Waldorf-Astoria in honor of the delegation of ten Japanese silk producers now visiting the United States.

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 29 (AP) -- Claire Windsor, movie actress, goes to court tomorrow to fight a $100,000 alienation-of-affections suit confident that the man "who got me into this mess" is "going to get me out."

To the Editor of The New York Times: The resignation of Justice Franklin C. Hoyt from the bench of the Children's Court of New York marks a milestone in the treatment of youthful offenders and compels a retrospective glance over the past twenty-five years.
TOKYO, Wednesday, Aug. 30 -- G.B. Sansom, Commercial Counsel of the British Embassy, who is to act as British adviser for the Indo-Japanese trade conference, sailed today for India.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 -- The pick-up in business resulted in a substantial increase in the number of railroad employes and their compensation in June, according to statistics made public today by the Interstate Commerce Commission.

Albert S. Wiggin, chairman of the American Bankers Committee in Germany and former chairman of the Chase National Bank, is returning today from Europe on the North German Lloyd liner Bremen accompanied by Mrs. Wiggin. Others on the ship include:

WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 -- General Johnson revealed an apprehension today that he was headed for the first major test in the administration of the National Industrial Recovery codes in the application of the automobile agreement to Henry Ford.

HAVANA, Aug. 29 -- United States Ambassador Sumner Welles and Treasury Secretary Martinez Saenz conferred today regarding modification of the Cuban-American reciprocity treaty. It was announced that the Treasury Department had named Dr. Roberto A. Netto as Cuban delegate to the commission that will study the treaty, presumably in Washington.

Anglers again are finding fishing conditions good in Great South Bay and at Fire Island, according to reports from Captain Bauer of the Sea Gull II and Captain Joe Conrad of the Miraany, both of Lindenhurst.

HYDE PARK, N.Y., Aug. 29 -- President Roosevelt visited Albany today for the first time since he entered the White House, motoring northward to inspect two new bridges and to have tea with Governor Lehman in the Executive Mansion.

The first fifty-eight railroads to report for July showed net operating income for the month of $49,454,000, against $9.423,000 in July, 1932, an increase of 424.8 per cent; $43,973,000 in July, 1931, an increase of 12.5 per cent, and $64,283,000 in July, 1930, a decrease of 23.1 per cent.

From a cloud not of war only but detraction rude emerges the head of Louisiana LONG, a bit bloody but still unbowed. He has been assaulted and battered. To make the attack more shameful, he was set upon when, full of music and harmony and at the invitation of other friends of St. Cecilia, he went to a charity revue, himself dripping with charity as usual.

Professors and Politicians. Let us not be too sure that the Gotter-dammerung of the Brain Trust is at hand. It is too early to speak of the failure of a comic experiment in government by amusing college professors.

The first meeting of the board of directors of the American Iron and Steel Institute since the adoption of the steel Industry's code was held yesterday in its offices in the Empire State Building, with three representatives of the National Recovery Administration in attendance.

HYDE PARK, N.Y., Aug. 29 -- President Roosevelt, in simultaneous Executive order, modified today the embargo on newly mined gold to permit its restricted sale and export at world prices and gave gold hoarders the alternative of reporting their holdings within fifteen days or facing prosecution.

YONKERS, N.Y., Aug. 29 -- Under the direction of the Union Methodist Episcopal Church of 229 West Forty-eighth Street, New York, and the Board of Foreign Missions of the Methodist Episcopal Church, about forty-five unemployed young persons of New York have set up a cooperative community house.

CAMP PERRY, Ohio, Aug. 29 -- With eighty-nine competitors on the firing line, T.P. Samsoe of Perth Amboy, N.J., scored 299 out of a possible 300 in a puffy wind today to win the Camp Perry individual small-bore rifle match.
NEWARK. N.J., Aug. 29 (AP) -- The Newark Bears stretched their present winning streak to six straight by defeating Albany in both ends of a double-header tonight, 8 to 5 and 11 to 3.
Small housing parcels again composed the bulk of the New Jesrey realty turnover reported yesterday:

BEAR MOUNTAIN, N.Y., Aug. 29 -- Cleveland May Thorne of 134 West Ninety-second Street, New York, an attorney, was found dead on the freight tracks just south of Iona Island at 11 o'clock last night, two hours after his roadster had plunged through the rails guarding the side of the new High Point Road on Dunderberg Mountain.

The Tawawa Democratic Association, a Negro political club in the Nineteenth Assembly district at 110 West 126th Street, asserted in a petition filed in the Supreme Court yesterday that Martin J. Healy, Tammany leader, had ignored the Negro voters of the district by naming only whites on the primary ticket for members of the county committee.

Representatives of the city-wide banking syndicate that has been financing the city for the last two years met yesterday at the Clearing House, 77 Cedar Street, and discussed for three hours the city's latest application for financing.

To those of us who have done our time before "Going Gay" and "Love and Babies," "Come Easy," which appeared at the Belasco last evening, has the virtue of being unobjectionable. It is a simple comedy of homey folks by Felicia Metcalfe, and it is acted in a familiar vein by an unpretentious band of players.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 (AP) -- While awaiting announcement by Mr. Roosevelt from Hyde Park of the membership of the oil governing body, Secretary Ickes declined tonight to disclose the names that would be found there, but it was authoritatively understood that advocates of price fixing would be in the majority.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 -- The funded debt of New York State on June 30, 1932, was $444,845,576, including $285,986,507 for highways, according to financial statistics for the State made public today by the Census Bureau. The funded debt included $151,304,000 for the barge canal.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 -- The government's movement for a revision of the existing trade treaty structure with Latin America progressed one step further today when preliminary discussions were started with Brazil. R. de Lima e Silva, the Brazilian Ambassador, held his first trade treaty meeting this afternoon with Secretary Hull, Jefferson Caffery, Assistant Secretary of State, and Edwin C. Wilson, chief of the division of Latin American affairs.

The reduction of contract bridge bidding to a series of mathematical formulae is undertaken in "Win With Winslow," published by the Nascon Service, Inc. T.N. Winslow, an expert mathematician, and his co-author, Charles E. Anstett, an experienced bridge player, have undertaken to eliminate the necessity for guessing what one's partner holds.

WATKINS GLEN, N.Y., Aug. 29 (AP) -- If modern engineering methods fail, the wilderness lore of a Mohawk Indian chief may be called upon to extricate the seven-point buck deer which has been trapped on a precarious ledge in Watkins Glen State Park since Saturday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 (AP) -- Fears arose today at the Department of Agriculture that jubilation over the signing of the world wheat agreement by twenty-one nations last Friday might prove premature as further delay was reported in signing a supplement dividing the quota of exports among the four chief exporting nations, the United States, Canada, Australia and Argentina.
ST. LOUIS, Aug. 29 (AP) -- The six-hit pitching of Bob Weiland gave the Red Sox a 9-to-4 victory over the Browns in the second game of a double-header today, after they dropped the first, 10 to 8.
PARIS, Aug. 29 -- The Marquise Cecile de Wentworth, American painter, died yesterday in the Municipal Hospital at Nice.

BALTIMORE, Aug. 29 (AP) -- The Baltimore International Leaguers tonight made their hits count to defeat Jersey City by 17 to 8 and 8 to 5 in a double-header. The Orioles made only twenty-one hits for their twenty-five runs and the Jersey City pitchers gave a total of twenty-one bases on balls.

GLOUCESTER, Mass., Aug. 29 -- The end of the second day of yacht racing by junior crews for the Herbert M. Sears Bowl and North American Yacht Racing Union medals found the colors of the Vineyard Haven Yacht Club still at the main peak today.

The memory of her "small, blue-eyed Jewish grandmother," whose name she venerates, has caused Mine. Ernestine Schumann-Heink to proclaim herself an exile from Germany. The exile is self-imposed, she said yesterday in her apartment in the Buckingham Hotel, and it works no hardship upon her, because "that country" is no longer the Germany where she first won fame, and which she knew and loved in the days of Wagner and the early Baireuth festivals.
PARIS, Aug. 29 -- Henri Cochet, noted French tennis ace, tonight announced he intended to turn professional.

Ellsworth Vines Jr. of Pasadena, Calif., winner of the men's national tennis singles title for the last two years, heads the list of ten American seeded players for the fifty-second annual championship tournament. The draw was made yesterday at the Hotel Vanderbilt.

BERLIH, Aug. 29 -- President von Hindenburg will come to Berlin tomorrow from Neudeck, his estate in East Prussia, for a short stay to receive the credentials of several envoys who have come into residence here in the last few months, notably Professor William E. Dodd, the United States Ambassador.

New York City has experienced a continuing decline, during the past ten years, in the number of annual cases of encephalitis, the Health Department reported yesterday. This malady is the one that, under the less scientific name of sleeping sickness, has been reported as troubling the area around St. Louis.

Buyer Registrations Up in Week Although the number of buyers registered in the market during the week ended yesterday showed an increase over the figures for the preceding week, the total still remained well below the number listed in the corresponding week a year ago, according to the lists published in THE TIMES.

BARCELONA, Aug. 29 -- The Spanish Government took an important step toward re-establishing its influence in Andorra, with the obvious implication that it intends to act to counterbalance the influence of France. It has, in effect, given the ecclesiastical Spanish co-prince of Andorra, Dr. Justin Guitart, Bishop of Urgel, official standing as the Spanish diplomatic representative in Andorra.
NUREMBERG, Aug. 29 -- All roads converged today upon this ancient free city where Adolf Hitler's National Socialist party tomorrow night opens its biennial national convention.

BERLIN, Aug. 29 -- From the City of Worms, in South Germany, where some centuries ago Martin Luther defied the assembled Kings and Kaiser in the name of freedom, came the official news today that the State police had arrested a large number of Jews and sent them to the concentration camp at Osthofen as "a measure of defense."

LONDON, Aug. 29 (AP) -- Confusion over England's left-handed rule of the road was declared in coroner's court today to have been responsible for the death of an American visitor, Edward Epstein, a New York merchant. He was run down by a taxicab in the Strand last Thursday and died Sunday in a hospital.

NUREMBERG, Aug. 30 -- In this ancient city, the scene of its slim annual gatherings in the early '20s, Hitlerism, for the first time since its followers attained full power in Germany, is showing the strength of its party at its new annual congress.

EAST HAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 30. Roller skating is fast becoming popular at East Hampton. Instead of the usual junior dance, a roller skating party was held last night at the Maidstone Club, after an early dinner. Mrs. Shepard Krech and Mrs. Stephen Kelsey chaperoned about fifty members of the younger set, including the Misses Betty.

Fluctuations in bond prices on the Stock Exchange yesterday were generally within narrow limits, with the trend toward slightly lower levels. The principal setbacks in domestic and foreign issues did not amount to more than a point or two, with a scattering of issues moving up a point or more.
ATHENS, Aug. 30 -- Samuel Insull charged tonight that some one had been tampering with mail he had sent to Chicago.
Eleven properties in Manhattan and the Bronx were bid in by plaintiffs at auction sales yesterday. The results follow:

More than 1,000 damage suits against the owners of the steamship Vestris, which sank off the Virginia Capes in November, 1928, with a loss of 112 lives, are approaching settlement it was revealed yesterday.

HANKOW, Aug. 30 (AP). -- Seven American Passionist missionaries who two months ago were caught in warfare at Yuanchow, 250 miles southwest of Hankow, between rebels and provincial troops, were reported safe today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 30. -- Ways and means of expanding credit to meet the demands of the President's recovery program were explored today at conferences among Jesse H. Jones, chairman of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation: Governor Eugene R. Black of the Federal Reserve Board and representatives of the office of the Controller of the Currency.

PRAGUE, Aug. 30 -- In a bid for the support of the Laborite faction in the forthcoming election of the administration of the World Zionist Organization, Nahum Sokolow, 72-year-old president of the organization, addressing the World Zionist Congress tonight, defined his views on the position of labor in the upbuilding of a Jewish national home in Palestine.
CHICAGO, Aug. 30 (AP). -- Hobnail, with A. Tipton in the saddle, raced to a neck victory over Good and Hot today in the feature of another card of claiming events at Hawthorne.

The first family In New York State to benefit from the Home Owners Loan Corporation, a Federal agency to aid small householders, was determined yesterday morning in Brooklyn when the name of Mrs. Eva Rachlin of 2,126 Eightieth Street, Bensonhurst, was drawn from a hat.

PRAGUE, Aug. 30 -- Professor Theodor Lessing, widely known philosopher of Hanover, who had left Germany as a result of Nazi anti-Semitism to find a refuge in Czechoslovakia, died at his villa at Marienbad early this morning after having been shot.

SOUTH ORANGE, N.J., Aug. 30 -- Winning two of the three singles matches and the lone doubles encounter, the East's team gained a 3-to-1 lead today as the annual East-West team tennis competition opened at the Orange Lawn Tennis Club.

GLOUCESTER, Mass., Aug. 30 -- A pair of hair-raising finishes, in one of which Captain Bob Bavier Jr. gave Larchmont a victory, featured today's racing off Eastern Point for the Sears Bowl and North American Yacht Racing Union Medals.

SEATTLE, Aug. 30 (AP). -- Washington's leap to the repeal bandwagon gave it a push that will assure elimination of prohibition before Christmas, national and State repealists said today as mounting returns from yesterday's election indicated the State returned only four dry delegates to ninety-five wets.
PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 30 (AP). -- The Pirates made it four straight over the Phillies today, Ralph Birkhofer allowing only four hits for a 5-to-1 triumph.
BERLIN, Aug. 30. -- President von Hindenburg received today William E. Dodd, newly appointed United States Ambassador to Germany, who submitted his credentials and formally began his envoyship.

New York's traffic and mounted police will soon be sporting white cork helmets, Police Commissioner Bolan announced yesterday. No date for donning the new headgear has been set as yet, the commissioner explained, although officials of the department have already selected the type of helmet to be worn.

To the Editor of The New York Times : Are we adducing the right sort of economic philosophy by limiting the number of hours each of us may work? We seem to be forgetting that underconsumption and not overproduction is the basic cause behind the economic atrophy in which we now find ourselves.

HYDE PARK, N.Y., Aug. 30. -- President Roosevelt today named a committee of fifteen, three members representing the NRA and twelve being outstanding men in the oil industry, to conduct a, broad experiment of self-government for that business under its recently-adopted code.

At 10 o'clock this morning a train Known as the "Inventors Special" will pull out of Jersey City bound for the annual convention of the Associated Inventors of America in Chicago on Sept. 4 and 5. Aboard will be persons who invent not large, spectacular things that change the course of history but obscure things, "gadgets," that keep the royalties flowing in at a decent trickle year after year.
BOSTON, Mass., Aug. 30 -- The text of General Johnson's address here today was as follows:

Commodities were quiet and irregular in the local markets yesterday, with speculative interest virtually at a standstill, and trade buying was dormant in advance of the holiday on Monday. The cash markets also were irregular.

The meeting of representatives of a city-wide banking group at the Clearing House yesterday noon to act on the city's request for a loan of $34,500,000 to meet September requirements lasted just five minutes. Descending the steps of the Clearing House, Charles S. McCain, chairman of the board of Chase National Bank, who presided at the gathering, explained that no decision had been reached and that the meeting had been adjourned until 10 A.M. today.

PARIS, Aug. 30 -- French and American representatives of the phospate industry, after a week of negotiations, have reached a tentative accord which has been submitted to American headquarters. The terms of the agreement are being kept strictly secret, pending ratification, but it is believed a minimum price has been fixed and a division of the European market agreed upon.

From the viewpoint of speculative interests that are committed to the advance, the action of the share market was disappointing yesterday. The announcement on the afternoon before of a modification of the gold embargo made no visible impression upon any of the markets, which suggested that the significance of this step had possibly been misjudged.

NEW ORLEANS, Aug. 30. -- Senator Long came home from the wars tonight and, surrounded by six bodyguards with fists swinging, charged a group of reporters who had gathered at a suburban station to question him about his tour of the East and North.

LONDON, Aug. 30 -- Owing to the serious condition of Scottish agriculture the government has increased the customs duty on foreign oats, oat products and pearled barley, exclusive of certain by-products, from 10 to 20 per cent ad valorem.

Lorenz Strack, Yorkville real estate broker, accused of frauds in investments made for Yorkville residents, and John C. Hoenninger, his attorney, were indicted on grand larceny charges yesterday. Hoenninger was arrested later at his office at 5 Beekman Street.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 -- The Shipping Board regarded as a closed incident today its refusal to permit the Dollar Line to charter the President Johnson to the James Boring Company for two proposed cruises to Havana, Bermuda and Nassau.

TORONTO, Aug. 30 -- Marvin Nelson, powerful long-distance swimmer from Fort Dodge, Iowa, today won the Canadian National Exhibition's annual fifteen-mile men's marathon and became the first man ever to win the event twice.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In the new war against crime, racketeering in particular, attention is being focused on the politician, with whose connivance it is believed the nefarious, but unfortunately the profitable, traffic has flourished.

After many adventures and 1,710 miles of paddling in a nineteen-foot kayak, or eskimo canoe, two Boston youths ended their journey here yesterday. They declared they believed the kayak was one of the most seaworthy craft afloat.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 30. -- "Murder at the Vanities," an experimental combination of revue and drama, was presented at the Garrick Theatre here tonight by Earl Carroll. The curtain rose at 8:50 and it was nearly 12:15 when the twentieth scene ended the performance.

BOSTON, Aug. 30. -- Joe Cook tonight made his first bow to a Boston audience in three years in the musical show "Hold Your Horses." In two acts and twenty scenes, with book by Russell Crouse and Corey Ford.

In the Philippine Islands the orchidhunter finds a paradise. Some of the rarest and most beautiful specimens are to be found there. While the flora of the archipelago is mainly Malaysian, Himalayan and Australian types also occur. There are said to be 10,000 species of flowering plants and ferns in the islands.

Something constructive should be done, and that at once, in the case of Queenie Smith, who has not been suitably visible in our theatre for some time. "The Blue Widow," in which she appeared at the Morosco last evening, presents her in the most unbecoming part that one could hope to find for her.

One of the largest real estate transactions of the year in the Sutton Place section was closed yesterday, when Edward Ellinger purchased from the Bowery Savings Bank the property on the northeast corner of First Avenue and Fifty-third Street.

PITTSFIELD, Mass., Aug. 30. -- Twenty-five riding and driving horses in the Tyringham Valley were entered today for the annual show at the Richard Watson Glider Farm. Miss Rosamond de K. Gilder donated two trophies in pony classes.

THE Giants have gone off to Boston for their big series with the Braves, and there will be a lot of youngsters romping around the Polo Grounds today. The two teams that have survived the elimination rounds of the baseball championship of the Junior Police Athletic League will play for the title today.
ALBANY, Aug. 30 -- In anticipation of repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment, Governor Lehman signed two bills today to control the sale of hard liquor in this State and also to levy a tax.
CHICAGO, Aug. 30. -- Directors of Armour Co. decided today to shelve the proposed financial reorganization plan, which was to have been voted on by stockholders tomorrow morning.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 -- Allotments of $37,500,000 for construction of the proposed midtown vehicular tunnel under the Hudson River between Thirty-eighth Street, New York City, and Weehawken, N.J., and of $15,415,000 for work on fourteen irrigation projects in eight Western States were approved today by the Emergency Administration of Public Works.

MONTREAL, Que., Aug. 30 (Canadian Press). -- Subscription books for this city's bond issue of $13,500,000 were closed a few hours after the issue was offered to the public it was announced tonight. The issue, at 4 1/2 per cent, was made necessary by the addition of four months to the present fiscal year and a consequent addition to the original budget.

The first of the new season's benefit entertainments was given last evening at the Manhattan Theatre in behalf of the Actors Dinner Club and when a final checkup of receipts from tickets and the program sale was made it was discovered that upward of $3,000 had been grossed thereby.

The adjusted index of electric power production fell back for the week ended Aug. 26, as actual output declined contrary to the seasonal trend. The figure dropped to 94.6 from 96.3 in the previous week but is higher than the number of 83.3 for the corresponding week of last year.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 30 -- Mrs. Helen Wills Moody does not expect to be out of the world tennis picture for very long. Neither does she regret her action in defaulting to Miss Helen Jacobs in the national championship final last week.
The name of Mayor O'Brien will head the Democratic primary ballot as the result of drawings for position made at a thronged meeting of the board of elections yesterday.

The consuming public of this city was summoned yesterday by the NRA organization under the chairmanship of Grover A. Whalen to prepare to do its part in the President's recovery drive when a buying campaign is started here on Sept. 14, the day after the big NRA parade, in which more than 250,000 persons are expected to march in support of the NRA.

Eight games back of the league-leading Senators in the pennant hunt, and their chances of recovery rapidly waning, the Yankees came home yesterday, after an unsatisfactory final swing through the West. Not a ripple of excitement did their arrival arouse, a contrast to recent years.

James Boring, head of the travel agency which bears his name, said yesterday that hereafter he would not attempt to charter American flag liners for his cruises but would use foreign ships exclusively.

Applications for the listing of the Capital stocks of five companies which were subsidiaries of Drug, Inc., but became independent through the dissolution of the parent concern, were approved yesterday by the New York Stock Exchange. The applications show the earnings of the new companies for the first few months of this year and the balance sheets as of May 31.

CHICAGO, Aug. 30 -- Prices for hogs here today were 5 to 10 cents a hundredweight lower than yesterday, with a slow market and large supplies. The extreme top was $4.40 or 20 cents lower than a week ago, while the average was $3.70, down 15 cents.

Governor MOORE has removed the ban on going ahead with public building in New Jersey, but the roads are another matter. The New Jersey State Highway Commission of four members, as a reorganization of the commission condemned by the Princeton Survey, will probably have a short life.

Old Familiar Splashes A woman has swum the Old English Channel and the last lingering doubt that prosperity is fast returning has now been removed. If there is any one single trait by which the pre-1929 Bull Mhrket era will stand out in history, it is the endless procession of women crawling in the Australian manner from Grin Nez to the cliffs of Dover in the administration of CALVIN COOLIDGS.

"The Autobiography of Alice B. Toklas," the Literary Guild book for September, published by Harcourt, Brace, was written by Gertrude Stein and is the story of Gertrude Stein and her friends. It is less strangely titled and less strangely written than many of her other works.

Differences of opinion were expressed yesterday regarding the effect of a recent order by Joseph B. Eastman, Federal coordinator, on equipment buying by the railroads. Mr. Eastman directed the railroads to report on the condition of freight cars with a view to eliminating obsolete rolling stock and obtaining operating economies by using modern types wherever possible.

The Board of Estimate reached an agreement yesterday on the substitution of buses on ninety-eight miles of trolley routes in Manhattan, and the awarding of seven additional crosstown bus routes. These embrace about thirty route miles.

Store Ad Experts in NRA Drive. A committee of leading retail advertising executives has been appointed to prepare plans covering the role which retailers can play in the NRA consumer campaign, it was announced here yesterday by F.W. Spaeth, manager of the sales promotion division of the National Retail Dry Goods Association.

Magistrate George B. DeLuca had a delicate problem before him yesterday In Bronx Municipal Term Court. A resident asked him, in effect, to help him get rid of half a million bees which were bothering him. It was a knotty problem until Henry Kroger of 641 Yznaga Place asked the complainant to prove whether his home was besieged by Kroger's honey bees or by nomad wasps from Westchester Creek.

Operations in the steel industry have fallen this week to 47 per cent of ingot capacity, compared with 50 per cent a week ago, according to the mid-week review of The Iron Age. This publication notes that "both steel releases and mill operations have undergone a further decline and that there is nothing to suggest an early change in trend outside of a contra-seasonal upturn in automobile production."

The President's carefully circumscribed order, permitting sale, in foreign markets where a premium exists, of gold produced from American mines, is not in any respect a necessary foreshadowing of arbitrary "dollar devaluation." It is simply an effort to escape from some anomalies and absurdities which were the consequence of the Government's existing policies.

BERLIN, Aug. 30 -- The upward movement on the Boerse organized by banks on Monday was succeeded today by a reaction which, depressed quotations approximately 2 per cent. Some specialties which had risen most lost between 5 and 6 per cent.

B.L. Toad, general secretary of the United Licensed Officers, 15 Whitehall Street, announced yesterday that a mass meeting of licensed deck and engine room officers had been called today to discuss labor conditions on the ships and their relation to the code submitted by the group to the NRA Administrator.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 -- The Bureau of Navigation issued the following orders today, dated Aug. 28:

WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 -- In a prompt endeavor to remedy the problems of the petroleum industry. Secretary Ickes, as oil administrator, late today summoned the committee designated to deal with its troubles to meet with him tomorrow and Immediately set Interior Department agencies to work on proposed revisions of the plan.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Aug. 30 -- Three of Bridgeport's smaller banks, with deposits of $6,650,000, were closed today by the State Banking Commissioner, Walter Perry. They are the first banks in this city to close their doors on order of the State since the depression began.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 30. -- Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt, wife of President Roosevelt, will arrive here from Hyde Park, N.Y., on Saturday afternoon to spend a day as the guest of her cousin and godmother, Mrs. Henry Parish, and Mr. Parish at their Summer home, Ludlow Cottage, on Harrison Avenue.

Many factors may have influenced the market movements yesterday, but professional Wall Street was concerned chiefly with the unsatisfactory response to the President's alteration of the gold embargo. Almost everybody in the financial district had placed a bullish construction upon the new regulations.

FLEMINGTON, N.J., Aug. 30. -- Fire Bush, Lancaster (Pa.) gelding, won the 2:20 pace at the Flemington Fair today. After Fire Bush had captured the first two heats, Mike Cummings paced a mile in 2:08 1/4 to take the final heat.
VIENNA, Aug. 30. -- Three National Socialists entered the Innsbruck jail early this morning by a daring ruse, chloroformed three keepers and set free Franz Hofer, imprisoned Tyrolese Nazi leader.
CHICAGO, Aug. 30. -- Senator Long received today an invitation to meet in a ring the person who battered his eye Saturday at a charity affair at Sands Point, L.I.
Norman H. Davis, United State disarmament delegate, sailed a noon yesterday on the United State liner Washington with verbal measages from the President to heads of foreign countries.
Monarch Theatres. Inc., half of eighteenth floor in 501 Madison Av., through the Alfred N. Williams Company.

While the financial community in general awaited the announcement by the Treasury Department of regulations carrying into effect the President's order modifying the gold embargo, the markets yesterday revised their first response to the news.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 -- With Henry Ford still holding apart from the automobile industry code of fair competition, the Recovery Administration tonight awaited action from President Roosevelt to bring a solution.

CAMP PERRY, Ohio, Aug. 30. -- For the second consecutive year, a Texas-Ohio sharpshooting combination today won the match for two-man teams, one of the featured events in the national small bore rifle championship tournament.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 -- Six directors of the Central Bank for Co-operatives, under the chairmanship of F.W. Peck, cooperative bank commissioner, were named today by the Farm Credit Administration. Three were appointed to represent the general public and three to represent the cooperatives.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 30 (AP) -- Scientists studying the "sleeping sickness" epidemic here were of the general belief today that outbreaks in other parts of the country were of a different type than the St. Louis malady.

After losing the first game at Ebbets Field yesterday, 2 to 1, the Dodgers bounced back vigorously to take the second one, 7 to 3, and push Charley Grimm's Cubs back into fourth place. A concurrent Pirate victory over the Phils gave Pittsburgh third position in the National League standing.
LONDON, Aug. 30. -- Commenting on President Roosevelt's new order regarding gold, the financial editor of The Times of London wrote tonight:

Grover A. Whalen, chairman of the local NRA organization, began yesterday an investigation of complaints from persons claiming to be needle trades workers that the International Ladies Garment Workers Union had made it impossible for them to return to their posts because of their inability to pay back dues or meet alleged exorbitant union initiation fees.
To the Editor of The New York Times: The following is an excerpt from my book "The Broken Tablets":

Interwellen, an oceanfront estate in Sea Bright, N.J., has been sold by Harry I. Caesar of Rumson to Arthur H. Lamborn of Montclair. The frame residence, which includes eight master bedrooms, seven maids' rooms and seven baths, was built in 1898 by Washington E. Connor.

BROOKLINE, Mass., Aug. 30 -- Sixteen days after they threw in their lot together for the first time, George M. Lott Jr. of Chicago and Lester R. Stoefen of Los Angeles won the national doubles tennis championship today at the Longwood Cricket Club.

TRENTON, N.J., Aug. 30 -- Senate President Emerson L. Richards identified today the "certain politician" who, he had charged, had been paid a large sum of money by brewery interests to defeat a permanent beer control bill, as Jesse R. Salmon.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 (AP) -- Another protest today over the continuance of A.A. Berle Jr. as legal adviser to the Farm Administration on the proposed sugar stabilization agreement failed to budge him from his post.

There are weightier issues confronting the world than the question, now agitating some of our correspondents, whether soup should be eaten or drunk. Yet it seems to offer a controversy that will never die, no matter how many dictionaries are flung at inquiring heads.

LONG BEACH, Calif., Aug. 30 -- Glenn Waterhouse of San Francisco saved the international Star Class yacht championship for the West today. He piled up 67 points for the series by winning the fifth and final race with Three Star Two on a choppy sea.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Aug. 30. -- Plans for a $5,000,000 model college for women are set forth in the will of Miss Cassity Mason, for half a century a leading educator of women and for thirty-eight years head of the Castle School, which she founded at Tarrytown. She died Aug. 24 in her seventy-first year.
Stupid and Bronislaw Moson stood before Magistrate Greenspan yesterday in West Side Court. Stupid is a dog with tangled ancestry. Moson, his master, is a clerk. He lives at 3,161 Broadway.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 (AP). -- William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, said tonight that "we will certainly oppose the decision" granting an injunction restraining striking union workers from picketing bakery shops in New York.

SAN JOSE, Calif., Aug. 30 (AP). -- A Sacramento florist testified today that David A. Lamson bought flowers for Mrs. Sara Kelley of Sacramento last Winter and again, last Spring a few weeks before Lamson's wife was found dead with a fractured skull.

HYDE PARK, N.Y., Aug. 30 -- President Roosevelt spent this evening quietly at Hyde Park House, trying to catch up on a mass of work which must be completed before he boards the yacht Nourmahal tomorrow for a cruise lasting until Tuesday and ending at Washington.

In his address at the meeting of the American Bar Association yesterday, its president, the distinguished West Virginia lawyer, Mr. CLARENCE E. MARTIN, considered in two aspects "The Growing Impotency of the States." The first was the inefficient administration of criminal justice.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 -- Technical considerations caused an unexpected delay today in the writing of the code for the bituminous coal industry.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 (AP). -- Labor intends to insist on shorter working-hour provisions in NRA codes to make a greater and faster spread of employment. Its intention was expressed to newspaper men today by William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor and a member of the NRA labor advisory board.

LONDON, Aug. 30. -- Tomas A. Le Breton, the Argentine Ambassador to Paris, signed today the international wheat agreement on behalf of his government, thus enabling the four largest wheat exporting nations -- the United States, Canada, Australia and Argentina -- to bring their 15 per cent restriction scheme into effect immediately.

SOUTH ST. PAUL, Minn., Aug. 30 (AP) -- One policeman was slain and another seriously wounded today as bandits, hiding their movements behind a smoke screen, robbed two bank messengers of a $30.010 payroll.

NEW ORLEANS. La., Aug. 30 -- The women's committee of Louisiana condemns Senator Huey P. Long's vicious attack on President Roosevelt's valiant effort to restore prosperity to America through the NRA.

WATKINS GLEN, N. Y., Aug. 30 -- Suspicious of all measures taken by human beings to help it, a seven-point buck deer remained trapped for the fifth day on a perilous precipice in the Watkins Glen State Park.

NEWARK, N.J., Aug. 30 (AP). -- The Newark Bears ran their winning streak to eight straight today, taking both ends of a doubleheader from Albany, which dropped its seventh in a row. The scores were 5 -- 3 and 6 -- 5.

Today is the official retirement date for 411 employes of the postal service in New York, as announced recently by Postmaster John J. Kiely. Those retiring went on vacation two weeks ago-their last official vacation -- so that the number of workers reporting this morning will not be affected.
RHINEBECK, N.Y., Aug. 30 -- President Roosevelt paid his annual visit to the Dutchess County Fair today. Members of the Roosevelt family have attended this event for many years.

PATERSON, N.J., Aug. 30 -- Completing plans for a walk-out tomorrow, Paterson silk workers predicted tonight that the strike would assume national proportions. As many as 40,000 persons are expected to quit work in New Jersey, Pennsylvania, New York State, New England and part of the South.
Fluctuations covering a range of $1 a bale characterized trading on the Cotton Exchange yesterday and the final prices were 13 to 19 points lower than on Tuesday.
HIGHLAND PARK, Ill., Aug. 30 -- Today was the lull before the impending storm in the women's national golf championship at Exmoor.

DUBLIN, Aug. 30. -- In the early hours of this morning and again this afternoon the police raided the headquarters of the National Guard on Parnell Square. During the second raid a number of papers and documents were removed. General Owen O'Duffy. commander of the Guard, was absent during the raid, but his desk was forced and searched.

One of the largest schools or blue fish located in waters adjacent to this city this season was discovered yesterday in The Rac off New London. Parties of anglers who sailed out of New London reported that this school, which showed upon the surface of the water, extended for three miles west of The Race.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Aug. 30 -- Plucked off the narrow ledge where they had spent more than thirty-one hours, three Plattsburg Boy Scouts were lifted to the top of Wallface Mountain in the Adirondack wilderness tonight, little the worse for their experience.
William H. Woodin, Secretary of the Treasury, denied yesterday that he and Montagu Norman, Governor of the Bank of England, had been conducting any "negotiations."

WASHINGTON, Aug. 30. -- Reports in Tokyo newspapers that Russia is reinforcing her army in Eastern Siberia are not credited in the best-informed circles here. There is no official information to confirm the report.

Changes in the present methods of meeting service on Kingdom of Bulgaria 7 per cent settlement loan of 1926 bonds and 7 1/2 per cent stabilization loan of 1928 bonds, are recommended by the League loans committee of the League of Nations in a communique received here yesterday from London by Speyer Co. and the J. Henry Schroder Banking Corporation, fiscal agents for the loans.

A rehearing was granted yesterday by the Public Service Commission to the electric companies of the Consolidated Gas Company system on the commission's recent order directing a cut of 6 per cent in j electric rates in New York City and 3 per cent in Westchester.

A sweeping injunction order restraining two union locals with a membership of 2,000 bakery workers from picketing bakery plants which are accused of attempting to reduce wages was issued by Supreme Court Justice Selah B. Strong in Brooklyn yesterday.

BOSTON, Aug. 30 (AP). -- Rabbit Maranville gave the Braves a ninth-inning victory today as he singled with Pinkey Whitney on second base for a 3-to-2 decision over the Reds in the final game of the series.

BALTIMORE, Aug. 30 (AP). -- Harry Smythe of the Orioles turned in his twentieth pitching victory of the season, but a former teammate, Joe Cascarella, evened the evening's program as Baltimore and Jersey City divided a double-header tonight.

Josephine de Castelvecchio Frabasilis, niece of Napoleon Bonaparte, granddaughter of Louis Napoleon, King of Holland, and former American actress, who died in the Metropolitan Hospital on Welfare Island, Dec. 19, left an estate of less than $1,000, according to the petition for probate filed with her will in Surrogate's Court yesterday.

UTICA, N.Y., Aug. 30 (AP). -- A taxpayers' action asking return to the city treasury of about $85,000 was filed today against Lieutenant Governor M. William Bray. Mayor Charles S. Donnelly and fifteen other individuals.

GENEVA, Aug. 30. -- A provisional agenda for the seventy-sixth session of the League of Nations Council, beginning Sept. 22, was distributed today. It lists no question touching the persecution of Jews in Germany or other important political matters.

American cotton constituted 43.7 per cent of the total foreign consumption of all grs in the 1932-33 season, according to data compiled by the New York Cotton Exchange Service, compared with 42.8 per cent in the preceding season and only 35.3 per cent two years ago.

The governing committee of the New York Stock Exchange yesterday approved amendments to the Exchange's rules which provide for deliveries of stocks and bonds sold on the Exchange a day later than at present. A week ago the Exchange announced that it was considering this step, which is designed to ease the tasks of employes of Stock Exchange firms in periods of active trading.

ALGONAC, Mich., Aug. 30 (AP). -- The possibility developed today that the Harmsworth Trophy race starting Saturday will see three boats, instead of two in competition, the third boat joining Gar Wood in a defense of the prize.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 (AP). -- George Z. Medalie, United States Attorney for the Southern District of New York, who conferred yesterday with Attorney General Cummings, has "neither resigned nor been asked to resign," it was said today at the Department of Justice.
Staging a couple of dramatic rallies, the Giants brought their hazardous home stand against the West to a successful conclusion at the Polo Grounds yesterday by downing the Cardinals, 5 to 4.

The Western Pacific Railroad Company will pay the $1,232,252 interest due tomorrow on its first-mortgage 6 per cent bonds, Thomas M. Schumacher, chairman of the executive committee, announced yesterday. The Reconstruction Finance Corporation declined recently to lend the railroad $1,000,000 for the purpose.

Harry L. Hopkins, Federal Relief Administrator, issued a warning yesterday that New York City would not be able to depend wholly on the Federal Government for the relief of its needy if local funds should give out.

TRENTON, N.J., Aug. 30 -- Late this evening the Senate approved the House bill extending the temporary code, but first amended it to set up the Governor, Senate President and Speaker of the Assembly as an appellate board to pass on all licenses.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 -- General Johnson today flew to Boston to address 1,000 New England NRA chairmen on the aims of the NRA consumer campaign. Returning to his desk early tonight, he was devoting himself first to answering the request of President Roosevelt, telephoned here from Hyde Park, for a full report on the failure so far to obtain the enrolment of Henry Ford under the automobile industry's code.

BALBOA, C.Z., Aug. 30 -- Corporal Ralph Osman of the United States Army was found guilty today of violating the Espionage Act and sentenced to two years' hard labor and fined $10,000, which, if unpaid, amounts to an additional eighteen years' imprisonment.

HAVANA, Aug. 30. -- President de Cespedes tonight indicated that he was willing to call a Constituent Assembly immediately, if the public so desired. Following a Cabinet meeting which lasted five hours, the Chief Executive said the question had been discussed at length and would be studied further with a view to complying with the will of the people.
NEW YORK. Mr. and Mrs. Louis A. Biddle have returned from Paris and are at the Ambassador.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 30. -- Mr. and Mrs. Beverley Bogert, who had been paying a visit here, gave a luncheon today on board their yacht, Trudone, before leaving for their Summer home in Newport. Among their guests were Princess Miguel de Braganza of Newport, who was a member of their cruising party: Mr. and Mrs. T. Markoe Robertson, Mrs. Fulton Cutting, Mrs. Rufus L. Patterson and Anthony J. Drexel of Philadelphia and Paris.

Major Edwin H. Armstrong, inventor of radio's superheterodyne set, was the recipient of congratulations from Dr. Michael I. Pupin and others yesterday for what is heralded in radio circles as a legal victory in an eighteen-year court controversy to determine who invented the regenerative circuit.

Mr. RICHBERG is the recognized guide, philosopher and friend in all that relates to the National Recovery Act. He defends it on legal grounds. Industrially and socially he contends that it is bound to be a great success. This lends special Interest to his address on the whole subject last Tuesday evening.

Wednesday, Aug. 30, 1933. Under the weight of heavy offerings of money by banks and brokerage firms, a record low quotation of 3/4 of 1 per cent was established for renewals on Stock Exchange call loans. Previously, during the course of trading, 1/2 prevailed for new money as far back as 1910, 1908, 1904.
BOSTON, Aug. 30 (AP). -- General Hugh S. Johnson denied today that the National Recovery Administration was attempting to make business "goosestep."

GRAND RAPIDS, Mich., Aug. 30. -- Organization of all the law-en-forcement agencies of the nation, including the States' militia, into one Federal army to war upon crime was urged today before the American Bar Association here by Pat Malloy, Assistant Attorney General of the United States.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 30. -- E.R. Bradley's chance for victory in the $25,000 Hopeful Stakes looked better today as a result of the thrilling victory of his filly Bazaar in the Albany Handicap.
HELLERTOWN, Pa., Aug. 30 (AP) -- Two men held up the Saucon Valley Trust Company today and fled with about $4,000 in cash.

PRAGUE, Aug. 30 -- General debate ended at today's sitting of the Zionist Congress. Among other speakers was Dr. Marguljess, a Czechoslovak, who presented the Bernheim petition to the League of Nations four months ago.

A ripple of excitement passed through the sultry air of the greenhouses yesterday, on the stroke of noon, in the Bronx park Botanical Garden. Dreamers gazing pensively at the Javanese orchids felt it stirring the humid air, lifted their heads and listened.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The statement of Grover Whalen that the right to picket in an orderly manner has been swept away under the National industrial Recovery Act because the Clayton Act gave workers the right to picket and that act is now in abeyance a contrary to facts which every student of labor law knows.
The New York County grand jury put its investigation of the political connections of racketeering up to the State Attorney General yesterday.

"Heat Lightning," a play by Leon Abrams and George Abbott, will open at the Booth Theatre Sept. 13. It is currently playing at the Country Playhouse at Westport, Conn. Jean Dixon, Robert Gleckler, Emily Lowry, Robert Sloan, Coburn Goodwin and Rosamond Pinchot are in the cast.

As the poet says, "Time goes faster on his way than 2:40 racers." It doesn't seem more than a month or two ago since GROVER WHALEN as Police Commissioner capped the Finest with a new- fangled cap. At first it was received with growls or murmurs. Soon the wearers and the public grew accustomed to it.

Jeers greeted Nicholas Roberts, former president of S.W. Straus Co., as he left the Tombs court yesterday following the adjournment of a hearing on his case. He was arraigned before Magistrate McKiniry, who adjourned the hearing to Sept. 12 at the request of Eugene McAuliffe, Assistant District Attorney, and continued the bail of $5,000 previously set.
DETROIT, Aug. 31 -- Detroit crowds jammed the downtown area tonight for a "victory parade" marking nearly 100 per cent enrolment under the Blue Eagle banner of the National Recovery Administration.

Of the more than 300,000 cases of disappearance reported to the New York City police since the Missing Persons Bureau was established in 1917 about 98 per cent have been accounted for. This estimate was made yesterday by John J. O'Brien, chief inspector, in a radio address over Station WNYC, the municipal broadcasting station.

GRAND RAPIDS, Mich., Aug. 31 -- A personal statement signed by Henry L. Doherty, president of the Cities Service Company, will appear tomorrow as a double-page advertisement in The Grand Rapids Herald asserting that lawyers for the leading oil companies have rejected or abandoned the position that they previously had taken in opposition to him, regarding the power of the Federal government to regulate oil production.
PARIS, Aug. 31 (AP) -- The weekly statement of the Bank of France shows the following changes, in francs:

Steaming up the bay with the tide, the State merchant marine training ship, Empire State, with 143 wind-tanned cadets aboard, warped into her berth at the Navy Yard in Brooklyn at 7 o'clock yesterday morning.
NEW ORLEANS, Aug. 31 (AP) -- While he rested in his home tonight after appearances in New York and Milwaukee, Senator Long learned of a new challenge to his political leadership in Louisiana.

The inquiry into relations between racketeering and politics, begun by the New York County grand jury and turned over by it to the State Attorney General, developed yesterday into a controversy as to who should take the responsibility for continuing the inquiry.

CHICAGO, Aug. 31 -- The market for hogs here today was steady with trade slow. There were 50,000 hogs received. The top price on the best lightweight animals was $4.40 a hundredweight, the same as yesterday, but 10 cents lower than a week ago.
Criticism of some of the policies of the Roosevelt administration is expressed by former Governor Alfred E. Smith in his editorial comment in the September issue of The New Outlook.

When HENRY VAN DYKE, the more widely known of the two brothers, went to Princeton as Professor of English, PAUL was already there as Professor of History, and the welcome given HENRY toy the students in the faculty song was Here's to Henry the brother of Paul.

To the Editor of The New York Times: It gave me a great deal of personal satisfaction to read that President Roosevelt had instructed the Reconstruction Finance Corporation to make provisions for extending credit to NRA members, to enable the latter to finance themselves until the returns from the expected spurt in business are realized.

DALLAS, Texas, Aug. 31 (AP) -- The mistreated body of Miss Katherine Prince, 19, a high school graduate, was found in a cotton patch southeast of Dallas today by officers led to the scene by two Negroes who confessed kidnapping and killing the girl and shooting her escort, Mace Carver, 27 years of age.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 -- The State Department was notified today of the death this morning at The Hague of Dr. J.H. van Royen, Minister of the Netherlands to the United States. He had been accredited to this government since March 15, 1927, and had been on leave of absence in Europe this Summer.

During July thirsty Americans consumed 1,332,790,688 eight-ounce glasses of beer, breaking all records for consumption of the beverage since it was legalized April 7, according to a statement yesterday by C.D. Williams, secretary of the United States Brewers' Association.
The city administration failed yesterday to obtain from the banking syndicate any money to meet the interest payment of $8,746,000 that the city must meet today.
Residential Parcels in Various Towns Conveyed. Small residential properties and plots comprised the New Jersey realty turnover reported yesterday.

Eighteen feet up in the cultured air of the Bronx Park Botanical Garden the much-discussed century plant, now in its heyday, was still going about its interminably slow business of blooming yesterday. On Monday six buds developed rather disappointing yellow blossoms.

HIGHLAND PARK, Ill., Aug. 31 -- Avenging her defeat of a year ago at the Salem Country Club, Miss Enid Wilson, the British champion, today advanced into the semi-final round of the women's national golf championship at Exmoor.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 -- The Treasury Department tonight issued the first of a series of regulations covering the Executive orders issued by President Roosevelt dated Aug. 28 and 29, dealing with gold hoardings and conditions under which newly mined gold may be exported through the Treasury, so that producers may obtain the higher world market prices.

Two new plays by Eugene O'Neill are on the Random House list. The play, "Ah, Wilderness!" which the Theatre Guild is to present Oct. 2 with George M. Cohan in the leading part, will be published Oct. 5. The other is called "Days Without End." Its publication date depends on the date set for production by the Theatre Guild, probably in November.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 -- The Recovery Administration still waited impatiently today for word from Henry Ford on what he proposed to do about compliance with the code for the automobile industry.

Graduating classes heard good general advice last June when they left college. It was largely in an idealistic tone. At the end of their last vacation from school they inevitably are directed in more practical paths. The speeches and sermons are over, but the magazines and papers are filled with talk of jobs for beginners.

Bancroft Mitchell, son of William D. Mitchell, former United States Attorney General, was questioned for more than two hours last night by Charles P. Sullivan, Chief Assistant District Attorney of Queens, in Long Island City concerning his association with Henry F.
