Sanborn, railroad executive, whose body was found in a shallow grave in Bayside on Aug. 5.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 -- A reduction in its interest rate on loans to banks as a means of stimulating credit expansion by assuring the banks that a liberal supply of government cash will be available at low cost to those institutions which cooperate in helping to finance the recovery program is being considered by the Reconstruction Finance Corporation.

The New York Stock Exchange announced yesterday that the new second-day-delivery plan, under which deliveries of stocks and bonds old on the Exchange will be made a day later than at present, will become effective with contracts made on next Friday.

W. Averell Harriman, State Chairman of the President's Emergency Re-employment Committee for the State of New York, reported yesterday that the number of employer agreements signed up-State to date totaled 86,138, of which 3,531 were signed yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 -- The daily average volume of Federal Reserve Bank credit outstanding during the week ended Aug. 30, as reported by the Federal Reserve banks, was $2,267,000,000, an increase of $24,000,000 compared with the preceding week and a decrease of $64,000,000 compared with the corresponding week in 1932.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 (AP) -- Price-fixing arose as a possibility in the lives-stock industry today under a proposed marketing agreement submitted by meat packers to the Agricultural Adjustment Administration.

The parents of Corporal Ralph Osman, who was convicted in the Canal Zone of violating the Espionage Act and sentenced to serve two years in prison and pay a $10,000 fine, said they would seek to appeal the case. In lieu of the fine Osman would have to serve eighteen additional years in prison.
New York will witness the biggest week-end exodus in years, beginning this afternoon. Railroads and bus lines reported yesterday the first pick-up in Labor Day travel since the depression.

Mgr. Michael J. Lavelle, rector of St. Patrick's Cathedral, in a statement issued yesterday, paid tribute to the late Bishop John J. Dunn, whose sudden death he declared to be "a great shock and loss to us all." "He had been ailing for two or three weeks," Mgr. Lavelle added, "but he made light of his illness, and as a rule we followed his sentiments as to his physical condition.

Current Rayon Prices to Hold. Rayon prices will be unchanged when books are opened today for November business by the leading yarn companies. With October all sold up, another large volume of orders during this month is expected, as demand has shown no signs of let-down despite expectations of the trade to the contrary.

RYE, N.Y., Aug. 31 -- Scoring a 45, 38 -- 83, Mrs. Russell Holman of Innis Arden gained low gross honors today at the Rye Country Club in the one-day tournament of the Women's Westchester and Fairfield Golf Association. Her score was six over women's par.

The slackening in the primary markets and in the industries that appeared in August has been accepted as inevitable and has not diminished the prevailing optimism, says the National City Bank in its monthly bulletin.

Stockholders of the Club Aluminum Utensil Company at their annual meeting on next Thursday will vote on reducing the stated value of the common stock from $7 a share to $1. The balance will be transferred to profit and loss and will reduce the deficit to $487,273 from the $2,119,033 recorded on June 30.

NUREMBERG, Aug. 31 -- The more one studies this unique gathering now assembling here for a three-day demonstration of the Nazi power in Germany, the better one realizes that emphasis is being placed not so much on its military as on its popular side.

RHINEBECK, N.Y., Aug. 31 -- Killearn Magician won the highest honors of his notable career today. The noble hackney stallion captured the rosette as the best of all the winners at the fourteenth annual Dutchess County Horse Show.

It was always understood that Spots, the fox terrier, belonged particularly to Mary Rafferty, 10 years old. Of course, her brother and her sister had some claims upon him, but usually they got an opportunity to play with the lively little dog only when Mary was not there.
POMPTON LAKES, N.J., Aug. 31 -- Tony Canzoneri, preparing for his lightweight championship bout with Barney Ross, the titleholder, went through a brisk workout at Dr. Biers's training camp today.

Slackers and conscientious objectors cannot be tolerated in the war upon depression any more than they could in the war against a foreign foe, Louis Johnson, national commander of the American Legion, declared last night.

Before an enthusiastic crowd of 30,000 spectators, composed chiefly of representatives of the city's youth, the Junior Police Athletic League's season was brought to a successful climax yesterday at the Polo Grounds.

The Canadian Hydro-Electric Corporation, Ltd., and subsidiaries report for the quarter ended on June 30 a net profit of $584,965 after $127,026 loss on exchange, charges, depreciation and underlying dividends, comparing with a profit of $762,180 in the same period last year, when there wag a profit on exchange amounting to $125,669.
Prospects of further increases in freight traffic out of New York to Mediterranean and Gulf ports have taken out of "cold storage" six freighters that have been lying idle for more than a year.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 -- Treasury officials are again considering the advisability of calling for redemption and refunding some of the high-interest-bearing Liberty bonds which are outstanding, but it was indicated today that no decision had been reached.
Three men charged with possessing firearms and narcotics were discharged in Yorkville court yesterday for lack of evidence and rearrested immediately on charges of felonious assault.

ANDORRA, Aug. 31 -- For the first time in the history of feudal Andorra, universal suffrage prevailed today. About 600 voters went to the polls to elect a new Council General or Parliament to replace the council closed by order of the co-Princes, the President of France and the Bishop of Urgel in Spain.
The hunting season on rails and gallinules opens in many parts of the country today.

While representatives of the metropolitan bakery industry prepared yesterday to arbitrate with the NRA the wage dispute affecting 2,000 bakery workers, organized labor began plans for public demonstrations against Supreme Court Justice Strong's drastic order enjoining the striking bakers from picketing.
Leaders of the oil industry spoke hopefully yesterday of the prospects for recovery as a result of the adoption of the oil code and other recent developments within the industry.

BY the pale shade of Uncas, the last of the Mohicans, modern civilization has sadly complicated the simple canoe of earlier days. It wasn't like that when Hawkeye drew a deadly bead on the wicked Huron and the woods echoed to the crack of his rifle.

GLOUCESTER, Mass., Aug. 31 -- Captain Bob Bavier Jr., Larchmont's junior skipper, captured individual honors in the competition for the Herbert M. Sears Bowl and the North American Yacht Racing Union's medals in the final races off Eastern Point today.
Public flogging for youthful criminals was urged by the Kings County August grand jury yesterday in a presentment handed up to County Judge Alonzo G. McLaughlin.

In Tight Places. Some people think that if HENRY FORD doesn't look out he will find himself out on a narrow ledge in the face of a precipitous cliff, whence he will have to be extricated either by long ropes let down from the top or by administering an opiate.

PARIS, Aug. 31 -- European economy will be seriously disturbed and European currencies will totter precariously when the dollar reappreciates at some future date, it is predicted by Henry Berenger, former French Ambassador at Washington, who negotiated the debt settlement, writing in Agence Economique et Financiere.
CHICAGO, Aug. 31 (AP) -- Bunching seven of their twelve hits in the sixth and seventh innings, the Indians took the opening game of the series from the White Box, 4 to 1, today.

BERLIN, Aug. 31 -- The reaction which started on the Boerse yesterday continued today. With the exception of a few specialties, stocks lost up to 2 per cent and some of the more volatile issues, including Salzdetfurth, lost as much as 4 1/2 per cent.
HYDE PARK, N.Y., Aug. 31 -- Mr. Roosevelt assumed his favorite role of sailor-President as he boarded the Nourmahal at a wharf in Poughkeepsie at 11:45 A.M.
PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 31 (AP) -- The Pirates laced five of the Phillies' hurlers for nineteen hits and a 13-to-11 triumph today, sweeping the series of five games.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 31 -- The Pompey colt, Caesars Ghost, winner of the Saratoga Handicap and the Whitney Stakes here, thrust himself further into the limelight today when he captured the Huron Handicap.

The Cord Corporation has bought all the capital stock of the Smith Engineering Company of Cleveland, manufacturer of airplane propellers, it was announced yesterday by L. M. Manning, vice president of the Cord Corporation. Through this purchase the corporation has diversified its activities in the aviation industry.

In an effort to dispose of the growing number of strikes impending or under way, the local NRA Mediation Board will meet this morning to take up the calendar prepared by the NRA Bureau of Complaints and Interpretations. The announcement was made yesterday afternoon by Grover A. Whalen, city chairman of the President's Emergency Employment Campaign, at NRA headquarters at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

The cleaners and dyers controversy, which has been under discussion for two weeks came to a conclusion last midnight in NRA headquarters, in the Hotel Pennsylvania, when all parties to the dispute reached an agreement.

PARIS, Aug. 31 -- Although trading was quiet on the Bourse today, prices showed firmness. At the opening South African gold mines and oils were favored, presumably because of weakness in the pound sterling. In the latter half of the session other stocks which had been hesitant joined the advance.
Absence of large demand for funds caused further ease in money rates here in August, both call and time loan rates dropping below those of July and to low records.
LONDON, Aug. 31 (AP) -- The weekly statement of the Bank of England shows the following changes in pounds sterling:
An 18 per cent reduction in the electric rates charged by the Queens Borough Gas and Electric Company for one year starting Sept. 18 was ordered yesterday by the Public Service Commission.
GRAND RAPIDS, Aug. 31 (AP) -- Attorney General Cummings denied late today that he advocated any plan which contemplated the federalization of State, county and police forces.

Price changes in commodities in markets here yesterday were few and the trend was mixed, much of the inaction being attributed to pre-holiday dullness. No cues came from the grain and security markets. Prices were mixed on the spot markets also.

Thursday, Aug. 31, 1933. The undertone of the money market continued soft. Quotations for all classes of accommodation remained unchanged from those effected Wednesday, which in the case of the day loan rate on the board and bill yields were record minimums.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 (AP) -- With their immediate objective said to be a fixed price which would assure at least $1 a barrel for crude petroleum, the new board of directors for the oil industry began its endeavors today to find a solution for the problems of price and production control.

CAMP PERRY, Ohio, Aug. 31 (AP) -- A sharpshooter from Texas who already had won two events, Thurman Randle of Dallas, turned in a perfect 400 score today to capture the individual short range match in the national small bore rifle championship tournament.

TRENTON, N.J., Aug. 31 -- Reaching a compromise shortly before 8 o'clock this morning, the Legislature passed a bill extending the temporary control law to Nov. 28. A recess then was taken until Nov. 14. The measure was rushed to Sea Girt and immediately signed by Governor Moore.
Honorary officials of the Fire Department will not be shorn of their blue motor insignia despite the new State law prohibiting their display, Commissioner Dorman revealed yesterday.

LOS Angeles Flood Control. The Los Angeles County (Cal.) Flood Control District, which failed to sell on Monday its scheduled issue of $3,000,000 5 per cent bonds, due on July 2, 1934 to 1964, has received an offer from the Bank of America of California and the Security-First National Bank of Los Angeles.

The trading pace in the listed bond market yesterday was the slowest since March 20, the turnover amounting to only $7,745,000. Only during abbreviated trading periods have dealings been slower. Prices drifted lower in all sections of the market with the exception of United States Government bonds.
The Dodgers were soundly trounced in both ends of their double bill with Frankie Frisch's Cardinals at Ebbets Field yesterday.

The secret marriage of Ethel Winmin Winter, realty operator, to Alfred Emerson Jr., a 30-year-old salesman, at the Municipal Building on April 5, was disclosed in the Supreme Court yesterday when Justice John F. Carew vacated a decree of Justice Albert Cohn, which had annulled the marriage.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, Aug. 31 -- The Marienbad police today issued a warrant for the arrest of Max Epker, 31-year-old Czechoslovak citizen of German extraction, who is suspected of having murdered Professor Theodor Lessing, German Jewish pacifist and philosopher, near Marienbad last night.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 -- Ninety rivers and harbors projects totaling $70,000,000 were approved today by the Public Works Administration. Out of this total $3,365,000 will be expended on the improvement of New York Harbor.
James J. Walker, former Mayor, is innocent of income tax evasion in the eyes of a Federal grand jury, which for the List three months has been looking into his financial affairs.

KANSAS CITY, Aug. 31 (AP) -- Youthful Democrats asserted their backing of President Roosevelt's recovery program today, but applauded a protest against "set speeches" by administration spokesmen at the first convention of the Young Democratic Clubs of America.
GRAND RAPIDS, Mich., Aug. 31 -- The address of Attorney General Cummings before the American Bar Association tonight was as follows:

The redemption of bonds in August before their due dates made the largest monthly total for the last four months, there being a marked increase in industrial loans redeemed. In all, $22,593,000 in bonds were retired in August, against $12,509,000 in July, and $56,238,000 in August, a year ago.
FLEMINGTON, N.J., Aug. 31 -- After finishing fourth and third in the first two heats of the Allen Handicap Trot at the Flemington Fair today, Joe Watts took the last two to win the race.

RICHMOND, Va., Aug. 31 (AP) -- The Virginia General Assembly to- day adopted unanimously a joint resolution memorializing Secretary of Agriculture Wallace to apply the domestic farm allotment plan for the benefit of Virginia bright tobacco farmers.
BOSTON, Aug. 31 -- Baseball in this staid metropolis, which is functioning under something of a new deal all around, touched a new high in civic enthusiasm today.

Soup is eaten, not quaffed or "taken." The Society for the Advancement of Better Living (SABL) through Pierre Loving of the Committee of Gourmets, took this stand yesterday and considers it final -- the very last word on the soup question.

With business at low ebb on all exchanges, Wall Street seemed to have no positive conviction yesterday with respect to the immediate course of the markets. The disposition everywhere was to postpone operations until after Labor Day, by which time, it was assumed, the speculative picture will have been more clearly outlined.

LONDON, Aug. 31 -- The leaders of Britain's 3,500,000 trade unionists issued tonight a ringing declaration calling on British labor to fight dictatorship in any form, whether coming from the Right or the Left.

Plans for a two-story salesroom and office building to be erected at 178-80 Fulton Street, 41-45 Church Street and 22-24 Dey Street, were filed yesterday with the Manhattan Department of Buildings. The structure is estimated to cost $60,000, and will occupy a plot 50 by 71.3 by 155 feet.

With an extended holiday approaching, traders in the share market were cautious yesterday almost to the point of complete inaction. There was a turnover on the Stock Exchange of 1,141,710 shares as compared with 2,172,610 shares on Wednesday.

Agreement on the principles that will underlie the Japanese campaign to promote the use of silk in this country, to begin next Spring, has been reached with representatives of the silk industry here, it was announced yesterday by Senator Gosuke Imai, head of the visiting delegation of ten Japanese silk producers, at a luncheon yesterday at the Hotel Biltmore under the auspices of the Central Raw Silk Association of Japan.
The formation of two new Stock Exchange partnerships, Drysdale Co. of 71 Broadway and Denny, Saportas Co. of 1 Wall Street, was announced yesterday.

MARQUETTE, Mich., Aug. 31 -- Speculation as to whether there was any reference to the NRA in a long telephone conversation today between Henry Ford, vacationing near here, and his son Edsel, at Seal Harbor, Me., ran high tonight.

Bank clearings at twenty-one leading cities of the country during the week ended Wednesday were $3,999,370,000, comparing with $4,134,378,000 in the preceding week and with $3,788,080,000 in the corresponding week of last year, according to Dun Bradstreet, Inc.

The Marine Midland Trust Company of New York, successor trustee under the debenture agreement dated March 1, 1929, of the Kreuger Toll Company, which is today making a partial distribution of $25 on each $1,000 principal amount of Kreuger Toll 5 per cent secured sinking fund gold debentures, has issued to the debenture holders an interim report of its activities since its appointment as trustee on Sept. 15, 1932.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 (AP) -- The Supreme Court was asked today to decide whether George Crawford, Negro, must return to Loudon County, Va., to stand trial under an indictment charging him with the murder of Agnes B. Ilsley and Mina Buckner at Middleburg, Va.
Most of yesterday's real estate activity in this city was confined to leasehold deals, some of which involved the renting of buildings for the restaurant business.
HAVANA, Aug. 31 -- A consultative commission that will propose emergency legislation to President de Cespedes until a new Congress is elected was ordered this afternoon by a Presidential decree.

Both trading and fluctuations on the Cotton Exchange yesterday were the smallest in several months and operations ended with quotations 6 to 11 points lower than on Wednesday. Prices for the March delivery changed only 6 points in extremely light business.

NEWARK, N.J., Aug. 31 (AP) -- The Bears' winning streak of eight straight ended tonight when Albany took the first game of the night double-header, 6 -- 2, with a four-run rally in the seventh and last inning. Newark came back behind Johnnie Broaca's five-hit pitching to win the second, 4 to 3.

Dividends declared in August were marked by further improvement, the total disbursed being larger than in July because of the resumption of payments by several large corporations and a decrease in the number of payments reduced or omitted.

SOUTH ORANGE, N.J., Aug. 31 -- The West again defeated the East at tennis today. But of much greater import than the victory, achieved at 5 to 4 in the face of a 1-4 deficit, was the fact that Ellsworth Vines finally found himself for the first time since the English championships.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 31 -- The contests for the prizes offered by Dr. Roderick Terry for the best gross golf scores and the season ringer tournament at the Newport Country Club for prizes offered by Mr. and Mrs. Richard Van Ness Gambrill came to a close with today's play.

George J. Schorr, acting for a bondholders' committee, yesterday bought the twenty-two-story Victoria Hotel at the northeast corner of Seventh Avenue and Fifty-first Street at foreclosure for $220,732.97. The foreclosure action involved a lien of $2,231,254 and was brought by the Chase National Bank, as trustee, against the Max Kurzrock Realty Company and others.

The largest increase to the gold stock of the United States since abandonment of the gold standard here was made in August after the foreign owner of $6,249,300 of gold held under earmark had failed to obtain from the Treasury Department a license to export the metal.

A large volume 61 business renting was reported yesterday by brokers, who were kept busy signing up new tenants for buildings in Manhattan and near-by sections. Confidence in an upturn for the better in business was indicated by several contracts for additional space.

Expressing confidence that the bankers would advance to the city at least enough money to meet interest due today, Deputy Controller PARIL was quoted as saying: "Even a pawnbroker "would lend money if he knew that it "was immediately to come back to "him."

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 -- The general provisions of the pending agreement for the bituminous coal industry were discussed during the day and this evening by subcommittees of operators and officers of the United Mine Workers of America and progress was reported.

CHICAGO, Aug. 31 -- No change occurred today in the character of the trading in grains on the Board of Trade here, shifts in prices being erratic again. An early break was followed by a bulge which lifted wheat about 3 cents a bushel and corn 1 1/2 cents from the inside figures, but the up-turns were short.

WATKINS GLEN, N.Y., Aug. 31 (AP) -- Efforts to entice a seven-point buck deer across a rustic bridge from its prison ledge in a State park gorge were renewed tonight after a Mohawk Indian chief, versed in animal lore, failed in a rescue attempt.
To the Editor of The New York Times: On Monday THE NEW YORK TIMES published an article headed "Secretary Ickes Asks End of Red Tape to Put Billion Allocated Into Pay Envelopes."

New securities publicly offered here in August showed a marked decline from the previous month for both bonds and stocks, the total being the smallest since March. Offerings aggregated $36,758,000, of which $32,882,000 was in bonds and $3,876,000 in stocks, compared with a total of $84,044,000 in July, of which $62,028,000 was in bonds and $22,016,000 in stocks.

With a further decline of 0.6 point, The Annalist Weekly Index of Wholesale Commodity Prices dropped to 102.1 on Tuesday from 102.7 a week before. Losses in live stock, due to heavy marketings and to a less extent in wheat and corn accounted for the decline, which was offset in part by net gains for cotton, wool, butter and eggs, bananas, crude petroleum and pig iron.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 31 -- Mr. and Mrs. Adrian H. Larkin gave a dinner tonight at Les Alouettes for Mr. and Mrs. John M. Perry of Bay Head, N.J., who are passing several days with them. Earlier in the day Mrs. William Appleton Burnham, who is passing the season at the Meadow Club, gave a luncheon for Mr. and Mrs. Perry at the National Golf Links of America.

Philip Westley, 27 years old, of 17 West Sixty-seventh Street, was held in $1,000 bail for trial in Special Sessions when arraigned in night court last night before Magistrate Samuel Katz. Westley was charged with inserting misleading advertisements in a morning newspaper last Sunday.
WESTBURY, L.I., Aug. 31 -- Completion of the draw for the national open championship was announced today by the tournament committee of the United States Polo Association.

DETROIT, Aug. 31 -- The Detroit River will be the scene tomorrow of the annual Gold Cup speed-boat race. This event will open a four-day program, featured by the Harmsworth Trophy series, the first contest of which will be held Saturday on the St. Clair River at Algonac.
The Merchant Truckmen's Bureau of New York announced yesterday that it had agreed upon a code for the control of trucking in the metropolitan area.

Employment in manufacturing plants in all but one of the twentyfive leading industries throughout the country increased 10.2 per cent in July over June, according to the monthly survey conducted by the National Industrial Conference Board and made public yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 -- The predicted study of the financial structure of Cuba will be made immediately, Secretary Hull indicated today. The survey will be made by Adolf A. Berle Jr., legal adviser to the Agricultural Adjustment Administration, and John Laylin, special assistant to the Under-Secretary of the Treasury, Mr. Hull said.

To the Editor of The New York Times: While the incident of the five Ameri- cans who became embroiled with the Civil Guard at Palma is happily on its way to an acceptable solution, it emphasizes the danger to international relations which can be engendered by heedless disregard of the laws of a country by the nationals of another.

PATERSON, N.J., Aug. 31 -- The broadsilk industry in Paterson and vicinity was practically at a standstill today following an almost 100 per cent response to the strike call issued by the Associated Silk Workers, Paterson unit of the American Federation of Silk Workers.
PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 31 -- Two union pickets were shot to death today in a riot which climaxed an eight-week strike at the Cambria silk hosiery mill in Northeast Philadelphia.
ROME, Aug. 31 -- With Premier Mussolini's return to Rome following the army manoeuvres, the political activity of the State will be in full swing again in a few days.

PRAGUE, Aug. 31 -- The World Zionist Congress's vote to send a commission to Palestine to investigate alleged terroristic methods by a certain Revisionist group was taken in the face of vehement Revisionist protests.

The Treasury Department's complete monthly report of the stock of all kinds of money in the United States as of Aug. 1 shows the following principal changes in July. Gold earmarked for foreign banks is deducted; gold released from earmark is added:
Yesterday's statement of the twelve Reserve Banks showed that none of the important items in the system reached a new high or low figure for the year.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 -- The resignation from the National Recovery Administration of Dudley Cates of Chicago as Assistant Administrator for Industry was announced late today.

An abstract of the statement filed by R.H. Macy Co., Inc., at the hearing on the retail code before Deputy Administrator Whiteside in Washington on Wednesday was issued here yesterday by executives of the store.

PRAGUE, Aug. 31 -- The eighteenth World Zionist Congress today adopted a resolution providing for the sending of a commission to Palestine to investigate charges of terrorism in connection with the murder of Dr. Chaim Arlosoroff, labor leader there.

GREENWICH, Conn., Aug. 31 -- Larry Lloyd of the Greenwich Country Club and Hamilton W. Wright of the Garden City Golf Club scored 74s today to tie for the medal in the qualifying round of the annual invitation golf tournament of the Greenwich Country Club.

BINGHAMTON, N.Y., Aug. 31 -- Louis A. Johnson, national commander of the American Legion, addressing the New York State Department in session here today, called upon the "Legion to submit to the country "a program for veterans' protection which is so fair in its treatment of both the disabled veteran and the taxpayer that public opinion will be solid in its support."
BALTIMORE, Aug. 31 (AP) -- Jersey City today earned an even division in the six-game series with Baltimore by taking both ends of a double-header, 8 to 7 and 1 to 0.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 -- Fiorello H. LaGuardia, fusion candidate for New York Mayor, led air transport pilots of the country in a protest today against the code submitted for the air transport industry.
William M. Chadbourne, chairman of the fusion Campaign committee, announced yesterday the appointment of David M. Heyman as the committee's treasurer.
Three years ago this month James W. Gerard, former Ambassador to Germany, named sixty-four men who ruled America.

The $35,000,000 rates of government security purchases begun by the Federal Reserve System last week was maintained in the week ended on Wednesday but not augmented, the system's report published yesterday showed. The exact amount bought was $34,758,000, compared with $35,161,000 bought the week before.

RALEIGH, N.C., Aug. 31 -- Governor J.C.B. Ehringhaus tonight met the demands of Eastern North Carolina tobacco growers that he close every warehouse in the State until better prices are paid by proclaiming a voluntary marketing holiday for an indefinite period.

Those German State, municipal and corporation borrowers that have not already defaulted on their American dollar bonds will do so today, pursuant to the German Government's decree of June 9 limiting foreign exchange transfers. American holders who send their coupons to the paying agents here will get them back.

Things are moving in New York City in the field of traffic relief. Only the other day it was announced that the Federal Government had given its approval and support to the Triborough Bridge. Now it follows that up with a substantial loan which will permit the Port Authority to go ahead with the vehicular tunnel under the Hudson River to Weehawken.

The commissioners of the Port of New York Authority, at a special meeting last night, approved the contract offered by the Federal Public Works Administration whereby $37,500,000 is to be lent for the construction of the mid-town Hudson vehicular tunnel.
NEW YORK. Mrs. William B. Trainer and John M. Trainer of Hyannis, Mass., are at the St. Regis.

BERLIN, Aug. 31 (London Times dispatch) -- Edgar Ansel Mowrer, for many years Berlin correspondent of The Chicago Daily News, left Berlin tonight by way of England and the United States for his new post in Tokyo. He had put forward his departure by six days under pressure that ultimately took a most remarkable form.
President Roosevelt sailed around most of Manhattan Island last evening aboard Vincent Astor's yacht, the Nourmahal, on his way to Washington to take charge of the national recovery campaign.
LONDON, Aug. 31 -- Charges implicating the highest Nazi leaders n the burning of the Reichstag building are contained in "The Brown Book of the Hitler Terror," to be published here tomorrow.

The volume of business on the New York Stock Exchange last month was on an extremely slower scale than in July, Saturday holidays throughout the month contributing to the dullness. Sales of stocks in August, as compiled by THE NEW YORK TIMES, totaled 42,466,352 shares, compared with 120,300,463 in July, and 82,649,154 in the same month a year ago.
The Yankees received their worst setback of the year yesterday at the Yankee Stadium. In their first game since returning from the West, the McCarthymen lost to the Red Sox, 15 to 2.

To the Editor of The New York Times: One of the impressions brought back by a New Yorker from a visit to the Century of Progress Exposition in Chicago is a profound feeling of respect and admiration for the public-spirited generosity displayed by men of wealth of that city.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 1. -- Ghosts of past difficulties between this country and the leading European nations over war debts and disarmament arose again today when Secretary Hull made public a denial from Norman H. Davis, Ambassador at Large, that he would discuss war debts on his present trip to Europe.

Montagu Norman, governor of the Bank of England, sailed unexpectedly yesterday on the Cunard liner Laconia. Mr. Norman, who in recent trips to this country has hidden his identity under the name of "Mr. Skinner," arrived a few weeks ago through Canada, and recently visited President Roosevelt and Secretary of the Treasury Woodin.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 1. -- President Roosevelt has been told by Joseph B. Eastman, Federal Coordinator of Transportation, that he is without authority to bring the railroad industry under a code of fair competition in the National Recovery Administration and that such authority should not be exercised even if it existed.
BINGHAMTON, N.Y., Sept. 1 (AP). -- Senator Copeland, chairman of the Senate Committee on Racketeering, asked the American Legion to day to join the war against rackets and gangsterism.

District Attorney Geoghan's attempted clean-up of the Brooklyn laundry racket ended yesterday with the imposition of suspended sentences on Jacob Mellon, known as the Brooklyn laundry "czar," and two of Mellon's associates in the Affiliated Laundry Owners Club.

Dr. Shirley W. Wynne, New York City's defender of public health, went deep into the Bronx last evening, in fact within two blocks of Pelham, and unflinchingly faced strange beasts from the far places of the world.

BERLIN, Sept. 1. -- The Boerse was hesitant and weak today. Influenced by persistent declines in I.G. Farben, Siemens Halske, Harpener and some other leaders, the entire list continued to sag. Losses as a rule ranged up to 3 per cent, but in some cases drops of 5 to 6 per cent were recorded.

HOLLYWOOD, Sept. 1 (AP). -- Actors meeting today at the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences opposed the "anti-star-raiding" clause proposed by the studios as part of the industry's NRA code, and decided to send representatives to the code hearing in Washington Sept. 12 to seek inclusion of their own proposals.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 1. -- An estimate that the purchasing power of the country is $5,000,000,000 greater now than it was last year, largely because of the recovery program was made today by the American Federation of Labor in its monthly survey of business.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 1. -- Settlement of an eight-week strike at the Cambria Silk Hosiery Mill was announced today as preparations were started for bringing George Clementson, a 19-year-old strikebreaker, to trial for killing two union pickets in a battle at the plant yesterday.

The week prior to Labor Day is normally quiet in so far as new bond financing is concerned, and this week was no exception to the rule. New offerings this week comprised five municipal issues aggregating $3,180,000. Last week the figure was $9,944,000.

CHICAGO, Sept. 1. -- No structural faults but the navy policy of rapidly shifting commanding officers from airship to sea duty caused the crash at sea of the dirigible Akron on April 3, with a loss of 73 lives, said J.C. Hunsaker, vice president of the Goodyear Zeppelin Corporation today, in an address at the opening of the aircraft session of the International Automotive Engineering Congress.

In the newspaper accounts of the late SIMEON FORD'S career as a humorous speaker at public dinners the fact was thought strange that he himself summarily cut it short. Still In the prime of life and at the height of his reputation, he announced that never again would he try to set the tables in a roar.

DETROIT, Sept. 1. -- Indications tonight were that Henry Ford was planning a sudden, vigorous offensive in his controversy with the National Recovery Administration, but just what the motor manufacturer intended to do his associates professed not to know.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 1. -- A plea for genuine democracy in industry, with capital and labor organized into a "real partnership in both profits and management," is the feature of a Labor Day message issued today for the Presbyterian Church in the United States of America by the Rev. Dr. John McDowell of New York, moderator of the General Assembly.
NEW YORK. Mr. and Mrs. C. Shelby Carter are returning today from a trip through the West and a visit to Saratoga. They will be at the Seawanhaka-Corinthian Yacht Club over Labor Day.

In a twelve-inning struggle yesterday the Red Sox took their second straight game from the Yankees, winning by a count of 4 to 2 at the Stadium. Fortunately, the Senators dropped a game to the Athletics, leaving the New Yorkers still eight and one-half games back of the league leaders.
AUGUSTA, Me., Sept. 1 (AP). -- Governor Louis J. Brann, a Democrat, said today the State of Maine "does not propose to buy anything from companies that have not signed NRA codes."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 1. -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on Aug. 26 made a total of 631,988 cars, the American Railway Association announced today. This was 2,847 cars, or 0.4 per cent, under the total for the preceding week; 94,231 cars, or 17.5 per cent, more than for the corresponding week last year, and 131,553 cars, or 17.2 per cent, fewer than for the corresponding week two years ago.

The New York Security Dealers Association, consisting of brokers who deal in securities in the over-the-counter market, announced yesterday that it would adopt the new two-day delivery plan which has been approved by the New York Stock Exchange.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 1. -- The staff of the National Recovery Administration began today to group its hundreds of industrial codes in preparation for a wind-up of the codification process within the next sixty days.
MOSCOW, Sept. 1. -- The Red Army has stolen a march on the Soviet Air League by quietly constructing a stratosphere balloon in Moscow Military Factories 3 and 39.
Grand Central and Pennsylvania Stations were thronged yesterday afternoon and evening as New York's Labor Day exodus got under way. Bus terminals were busier than they had been in months.
KANSAS CITY, Sept. 1 (AP). -- A growing movement within the Young Democratic Clubs of America to take over their national convention and substitute action for oratory brought results today.

The New York Curb Exchange has been notified that the interest due yesterday on Rochester Central Power Corporation 5 per cent gold debentures, Series A, due on Sept. 1, 1953, was not being paid. The committee on securities ruled that until further notice the debentures should be dealt in "flat" and must carry the Sept. 1, 1933, and subsequent coupons.

CHICAGO, Sept. 1. -- Five small packers bought 2,400 hogs here today; city butchers, 2,500; three big packers, 500, and shippers, 2,000, and 15,000 were left over, of which 13,000 were pigs. The market had a better tone for the first time in two weeks.

Most of the active stocks improved their price position modestly yesterday on the eve of the three-day suspension for the Labor Day week-end. But so many of the professional traders were absent from their brokerage house haunts, or were so disinterested, that business on all the exchanges fell to an extremely low level.

RALEIGH, N.C., Sept. 1 (AP). -- Tobacco markets of the Carolinas closed indefinitely today as South Carolina swung into line behind North Carolina's plan for a market holiday until growers are assured of better prices for their crop.

All activities, so far as the markets are concerned, will be suspended from last night's close until Tuesday morning. This will mean, for all financial interests except the banks and scattered corporations, a three-day pause. There will be dealings in foreign exchange, but they promise to be most perfunctory.

About 150 internes at Bellevue Hospital walked silently out of their dining hall last night as a gesture of protest on behalf of three of their number, whose suspension and public reprimand had been ordered by the hospital medical board. The entire interne staff has been ordered to report today to the hospital amphitheatre to explain their attitude.

Poised on the edge of the living room's straight-back chair, looking from the comparative luxury of the four-room apartment out into the street of shabby tenements, Mrs. Lena Ornstein of 178 Second Street anxiously scrutinized passers-by beneath her second-floor window early last night.
To the Editor of The New York Times: Has it ever occurred to members of the legal profession, how haphazard and unscientific is the training they receive after emerging from the law school?

GRAND RAPIDS, Mich., Sept. 1. -- The American Bar Association closed the business session of its annual convention today with a warning that the nation's legal talent should prepare itself to change the judicial machinery to take care of the situation if the present emergency program of the government becomes a permanent policy.

The Austrian Government, which fell behind last November in its monthly payments to the trustees of its 7 per cent bonds of 1923 due in 1943, has made provision for the back payments, according to a statement issued yesterday by the trustees, Albert E. Janssen, N. Dean Jay and Marcus Wallenberg, through J.P. Morgan Co.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Sept. 1. -- Many members of the Summer colony and their guests attended the second and last presentation in a series of operatic performances by artists of the Metropolitan Opera Association and other groups under the direction of Wilfrid Pelletier, a conductor of the Metropolitan, which took place tonight at Four Fountains, the Ethel Hunt Tyng Memorial.

CHICAGO, Sept. 1. -- Under perfect conditions of sky and temperature and before an enthusiastic crowd of 10,000, the International Air Races, for trophies and prize money totaling $35,000, opened this afternoon, at Curtiss-Reynolds Airport.

PATERSON, N.J., Sept. 1. -- Representatives of over 7,000 striking broad-silk workers and the Silk Manufacturers Association accepted today the invitation of United States Senator Robert F. Wagner of New York to attend a conference Tuesday with the National Labor Board at Washington.

These orders were issued yesterday: Special Notice. In forwarding applications for special leaves of absence, chief and company officers shall be guided by the conditions existing in their respective division battalion or company , and shall not recommend approval of the application if a shortage exists which cannot be filled by a surplus officer or member as the case may be.

STAMFORD, Conn., Sept. 1. -- Twenty-three boats, representing most of the yacht clubs along the shores of Long Island Sound, started off the Stamford Yacht Club tonight in the annual 232-mile race to Vineyard Haven Lightship and return.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 1. -- Dudley Gates tonight made a further statement, in reply to that of General Johnson on the issue of the NRA labor policy. Mr. Cates said:

WASHINGTON, Sept. 1. -- Many economic uncertainties are clouding the general business situation in the Philippines, leaving gold mining the only really prosperous undertaking at present, the Department of Commerce said today in its weekly summary of business conditions abroad.

MEXICO, D.F., Sept. 1. -- President Rodriguez opened the second 1933 session of the Mexican Congress tonight after driving to the Chamber of Deputies from the National Palace escorted by a squadron of Presidential Guards.

ATLANTIC CITY, N. J., Sept. 1. -- Faith and belief in human effort is the motivating power behind the New Deal, and the program of the NRA, Harold M. Stephens, Assistant United States Attorney General, said here today. He addressed the annual convention of the Maryland Bar Association.

WATKINS GLEN, N.Y., Sept. 1 (AP). -- All efforts to rescue from his rocky ledge the seven-point buck deer imprisoned there for a week were called off by Watkins Glen State Park officials tonight to await arrival from Albany of a State Conservation Department animal specialist.

From Washington, Washington County, in the southwestern corner of the State of Pennsylvania, where GEORGE WASHINGTON himself had large holdings of land, there conies a copy of The Reporter in celebration of a century and a quarter of continuous existence. It has known both privation and prosperity.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 (AP). -- The Farm Adjustment Administration replied today to the demands of growers of flue-cured tobacco for relief by announcing a program which includes benefit payments in return for promises to reduce the crop next year.

In the presence of members of his family and a few friends, Dr. Eugene A. Colligan took the oath of office yesterday as president of Hunter College. The oath was administered in the Brooklyn Supreme Court Building by Supreme Court Justice Charles C. Lockwood, an old friend.
Small advances in quiet trading were the rule yesterday in futures traded on the local commodity exchanges, with cash prices slightly lower on balance and speculative interest absent in all staples.
STRASBOURG, France, Sept. 1 (By Wireless). -- Germany has this great advantage over the other military powers -- it has no out-of-date war material. This is especially the case with air armaments.
Except for the leasing of large space in lower Manhattan to one concern, the real estate market in this borough was exceptionally quiet yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 (AP). -- A recommendation that President Roosevelt employ his discretionary powers to fix the price of oil and its products from the well-mouth to the gasoline tank was said to have been decided upon tonight by the industry's planning and coordination committee.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 1. -- Steady progress is being made in reopening closed banks. Of deposits of $33,743,769,000 in banks, exclusive of mutual savings banks, $31,824,601,000 were in banks licensed to operate on an unrestricted basis by the latter part of August.

BERLIN, Sept. 1. -- Semi-official Views expressed both in the United States and Great Britain showing an inclination to accept the French plan for disarmament control, providing for biennial investigations by an international commission, were received here today with watchful attention both, in official circles and the press.
CINCINNATI, Sept. 1 (AP). -- Their own pitchers wild enough, but those of the Cubs wilder, the Reds celebrated their home-coming today with a 7-to-3 victory over the fourth-place Chicagoans.

MOSCOW, Sept. 1. -- Revolutionary International Youth Day was celebrated here with a monster parade in Red Square this evening by the Moscow Communist Youth party and the older members of the Young Pioneers [Communist children]. There also were delegations of Communist Youths from other Soviet cities and from Germany, China and other countries.

Only $6,908,253 of new State and municipal financing is scheduled to be done next week, a comparatively small total even after allowing for the holiday on Monday and the usual inertia which follows a holiday in Wall Street. This amount compares with this week's revised total of $12,836,811 and the weekly average for the year thus far of $13,343,105.

ALBANY, Sept. 1. -- Governor Lehman cleaned up today all but one of the bills left him by the extraordinary session. The one measure left over, and on which action will probably be taken early next week, provides for the ceding to the United States of land under water for the improvements contemplated for Governors' Island.
BALTIMORE, Sept. 1(AP). -- Don Brennan held Balitmore to six hits in the opening game of the series tonight as the Newark Bears garnered eleven hits for an 8-to-3 victory.

Theodore C. Packard, an actor whose sixty-five years have left him white-haired and jobless, was indicted yesterday by a Federal grand jury for an impromptu part he played last April for only half an hour.

PARIS, Sept. 1. -- Starting on Oct. 1, France will apportion her import quotas according to the treatment she receives from other countries, it was officially announced today after the Cabinet council.

A mortgage for $5,264 due Aug. 28, 1936 at 5 per cent, and given by Frank J. McCabe to the Green-Wood Cemetery on the north side of 31st St., 375 feet west of 9th Av., has been consolidated with another to make one lien of $13,300.

DETROIT, Sept. 1. -- Twelve years of racing weighed lightly today on George Reis's speed boat El Lagarto. The Lake George entry won the Gold Cup contest on the Detroit River and completely demonstrated her superiority over her rivals.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 1. -- Another series of regulations covering the President's recent Executive order on gold hoarding and export was issued tonight by the Treasury Department.

One of the largest armies of saltwater fishermen of the year is expected over today, tomorrow and Monday at points all the way from Montauk to Atlantic City, as well as along the north shore of Long Island and up the Sound as far as New London.

Every unit of the International Telephone and Telegraph Company, with 18,507 employes, and 1,800 Woolworth stores, including 137 in New York City, Westchester and Nassau Counties, with more than 6,000 employes in the local area, went under the NRA Blue Eagle yesterday.

TORONTO, Sept. 1. -- Still toying with the great names of sculling, giant Bobby Pearce of Australia tonight won the world's professional title by defeating Ted Phelps, stocky Thames boatman from England, by nearly a quarter-mile in a three-mile duel.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 1. -- Negotiations between the United Mine Workers of America and the nonunion soft coal operators of the Appalachian field collapsed tonight and some of the operators began leaving for their homes.

JUST to prevent any debates later in the tournament, it might be a good idea for the committee at Forest Hills to require the filing of health certificates by the players before they go on the courts.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 1. -- Voicing a hope that the Roosevelt naval construction program would mean an American navy "second to none" and one which would measure up to the limits fixed for us in the London treaty, Secretary Swanson signed contracts today for seventeen new war vessels.

TOENDER, Denmark Sept. 1. -- The chief constables of South Jutland nave been instructed to go to Copenhagen on Sept. 5 to discuss frontier conditions with the Minister of Justice. Evidence of German Nazi activities will be made available, and it may be assumed the Minister will be asked to consider special measures to insure greater vigilance.

The Engineers Public Service Company and subsidiaries report for the year ended on July 31 a net income of $2,846,220 after taxes, charges, depreciation, underlying dividends and minority interests. This was equal to 27 cents a share on the common stock after preferred dividends.

The New York Stock Exchange announced yesterday that the capital stock of the five new companies formed through the dissolution of Drug, Inc., would be admitted to the list on official notice of issuance of the shares, on Sept. 8, in accordance with the terms of the listing applications approved by the governing committee of the Exchange on Wednesday.

Deputy Controller Frank J. Prial told an audience of more than 1,500 in Brooklyn last night that the issue of his campaign for the Democratic nomination for Controller was whether a "few men" could disregard the will of party members by selecting for the "most important office in New York" a man without adequate knowledge of the job and adequate service to the party.
PRAGUE, Sept. 1. -- The Jewish Agency for Palestine closed its sittings today after presenting and discussing a report on its emigration activities this year.

PARIS, Sept. 1. -- The departure of Norman H. Davis, United States Ambassador at Large, for Europe to take part once more in the disarmament conference has been made the occasion for an outburst of Frencn press comment for the virulence of which, one can find no other reason than the Nuremberg demonstration of the Nazis' power.

HOVE, England, Sept. 1 (Canadian Press). -- The three-day cricket match between the touring British West Indies eleven and Sussex, first-class county side, ended in a draw tonight when the teams were unable to complete the second innings.
LONDON, Sept. 1. -- Liberal and Labor newspapers show great interest today in "The Brown Book of the Hitler Terror" and devote much space to it.

There has been no hesitation in the decisive forward movement of trade according to the weekly review of Dun Eradstreet, Inc. Some idea of the broadness of the sweep with which retail distribution has been advancing under the stimulus of NRA activities is found in the early estimates of August sale increases, which range from a low of 5 per cent to a high of around 35 per cent, the agency says.

HAVANA, Sept. 1. -- A tropical hurricane which had been forming in the Atlantic north of the Dominican Republic for the past few days struck Cuba early this morning at Isabela de Sagua, on the north coast, and cut a wide swath of destruction along the north coast of Santa Clara, Matanzas and Havana Provinces.

The Association of Casualty and Surety Executives has adopted a code of fair competition establishing a forty-hour week for all employes in the insurance business except outside representatives such as adjusters, appraisers, auditors, collectors, investigators, inspectors, service engineers, special agents, solicitors, raters and employes handling mortgage and real estate whose time and duties for the most part are outside the office.

Robert Edmond Jones has been engaged by Jed Harris to prepare the settings for "The Green Bay Tree," the Mordaunt Shairp play which Mr. Harris expects to place in rehearsal by the middle of the month. Mr. Jones also is designing the settings for the new Eugene O'Neill play, "Ah, Wilderness."

HERSHEY, Pa., Sept. 1 (AP) -- Ed Dudley of Concordsville set the pace today at the half-way mark of the $1,500, 72-hole Hershey invitation professional golf tournament. Dudley had a par 73 this morning and a 72 this afternoon for 145.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W.Va., Sept. 1. -- Several hundred visitors attended the Lee monument ball at the Greenbrier tonight, which marked the height of Robert E. Lee week festivities, and the fifty-sixth anniversary of the first Lee monument ball at White Sulphur, to raise funds for the statue of General Lee, now standing in Richmond.

Officials of the United States Polo Association yesterday announced practice plans for the teams entered in the national open championship, which will start next Saturday at the Meadow Brook Club, Westbury, L.I. Under these arrangements the teams preparing for the championship will be in action almost every day from now until the first match.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 1. -- In an application today to the District Federal Court, the Reconstruction Finance Corporation asked appointment of trustees for the St. Louis, San Francisco Railway Company, which is in bankruptcy. The application declared that appointment of trustees was urgent, to enable presentation in behalf of creditors of a new plan for reorganization.

Nearly 300 American educators, including twenty-seven college presidents, endorsed yesterday the University in Exile of the New School of Social Research, to be opened Oct. 1, with a faculty of German scholars dismissed or "furloughed" from German universities by the Hitler government.
LARCHMONT, N.Y., Sept. 1. -- After a comparatively mild trip across the ocean, the Dorade, owned by Olin J. Stephens 2d and Roderick Stephens Jr., anchored safely at Larchmont this morning.

General Francesco de Pinedo, former military attache at the Italian Embassy in Buenos Aires, was poised early this morning for a take-off from Floyd Bennett Field on a flight across the Atlantic. He will seek a new distance record in his Bellanca monoplane.
MARQUETTE, Mich., Sept. 1 (AP). -- Henry Ford apparently is preparing to end his two weeks' vacation at the Huron Mountain Club, near here, probably tomorrow, and return by boat to Detroit.
ANDORRA, Sept. 1. -- The question, "Who won yesterday's election?" is a theme of passionate discussion today in the capital of the little feudal State of Andorra.

NUREMBERG, Sept. 1. -- The only real session of this remarkable biennial convention of the National Socialist party to be held during its three-day pageantry took place this morning and it was as different from a political convention in the American sense as the imagination could well conceive.
The fusion campaign will have its formal start at a meeting in Cooper Union to be held soon after the primary election on Sept. 19. The date has not yet been determined.

BERLIN, Sept. 1. -- A new Central Europe under the joint leadership of Germany and Italy -- that is the vision the German press is beginning to suggest to the world and the German people as the proper and inevitable solution of the political and economic deadlock in that region.

The seven-point buck deer, confined to a narrow ledge high up on a Watkins Glen cliff, must have been puzzled by the antics of human beings who ,were engaged in an effort to give him his freedom. In November they would be on his trail, if they worked his release now.

BRETTON WOODS, N.H., Sept. 1. -- Miss Elizabeth Cushman, wearing foreign peasant costumes, gave a recital at the Mount Washington Hotel tonight, before a large holiday audience. She dined here with Professor and Mrs. H.C. Cushman and Miss Charlotte Cushman.

Testimony that the companies that have opposed a 6 per cent cut in electric rates, on the ground of added expenses under their NRA programs, have not increased their payrolls to the level of April, 1932, was offered yesterday before the Public Service Commission.

Sailing in light-weather conditions advantageous to them, the American defenders of the International Challenge Cup defeated the British contenders as the double-decked canoe sailing competition opened yesterday on Little Neck Bay, off the Bayside Yacht Club at Bayside.

Teaneck Builders, Inc., are extending their New Jersey development operations by the purchase of twenty-three acres of land on Sheridan Avenue, Hohokus. The builders have just bought the tract from May E. Hadley, trustee of the Henry P. Simmons Estate, for about $36,000.

Individual employers who sign the President's Agreement will be deprived of their Blue Eagle if they fail to respect the collective bargaining provisions of the National Industrial Recovery Act, according to a decision of the NRA in Washington, made known yesterday.

The Koenig and anti-Koenig factions of the Republican party carried to the Supreme Court yesterday their protests against the legality of designations of candidates for the New York County Republican Committee. Supporters of Samuel S. Koenig, county chairman, said they expected to have the names of about 800 anti-Koenig candidates stricken from the primary election ballot.

Retail Trade Gains Continue. Retail trade here again registered substantial gains during the week, local store executives reported yesterday. Increases of 15 per cent or more over the corresponding period a year ago were noted by some stores.

The Republican Legislature refused to let the State pull Tammany Hall's chestnuts out of the fire, but the State Controller, ranged alongside the Governor, is unwilling to allow the city to default on its obligations if any legitimate way can be found to avoid it. The advance of $5,000,000 from the State Treasury out of the funds set aside for school teachers' salaries came just in the nick of time.

BOSTON, Sept. 1. -- Bent upon heartening their stricken comrade, Johnny Vergez, who lay in a nearby hospital recovering from an emergency appendicitis operation, the Giants virtually throttled the Braves' pennant threat within the short space of four and a half hours today.
Army engineers said yesterday that no time would be lost in getting under way the harbor improvements authorized by the Public Works administration Thursday.
PITTSBURGH, Sept. 1 (AP). -- The Pirates won their seventh straight game today in their belated pennant drive, defeating the Cardinals, 2 to 1, in eleven innings, and going into second place.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 1. -- Officers at the Navy Department were surprised today at reports from Tokyo indicating a Japanese attack on American naval policy, based on what they considered a misinterpretation of a statement by Admiral Standley.
SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Sept. 1. -- C.V. Whitney's Sassafras, a gelded son of Chicle, was an easy winner today of the second division of the Consolation Claiming Stakes at six furlongs.

SMITHTOWN, L.I., Sept. 1. -- Festivities in connection with the twenty-third annual horse show tomorrow on Fifty Acre Field commenced this evening with many dinners and dinner dances for exhibitors and the executive committee of the show.

The greatest field to assemble for a men's national championship since Forest Hills has stood as the Mecca of the tennis elect in the days of our Davis Cup supremacy will start out today in the fiftysecond annual tournament at the West Side Tennis Club.

ON BOARD THE SCHOONER MORRISSEY, North of Hudson Bay, Sept. 1. -- On the port tack, close hauled under the four lowers, with our sturdy little standard Diesel helping us, the Morrissey's nose is pointed for the Straits of Fury and Hecla, where in a few hours we hope to be.
ARLINGTON, Va., Sept. 1 (AP). -- Test tubes of the Bureau of Public Roads are at work here to keep undue capillarity out of the $400000,000 worth of roads proposed under the public works program.

CHICAGO, Sept. 1. -- More than 9,000,000 bushels of cash grain were delivered today on September contracts and on liquidation by scattered holders who did not want the cash grain. Evening up for the three-day holiday absorbed most of the sales of the September future, while the December was sold, as a good carrying charge exists between the near-by and distant months.

Colonel Franklin S. Hutchinson, chief of the investigation of the Senate Subcommittee on Racketeering, charged yesterday that George Z. Medalie, United States Attorney, was actuated by a political motive in making his recent statement that politicians were allied with racketeers in New York City.

An expansion move is being made by the Gotham Silk Hosiery Company, which is changing its general and executive offices from 389 Fifth Avenue to 200 Madison Avenue, where the company has just leased the entire twenty-second floor. The floor contains about 15,000 square feet of space.
DENVER, Sept. 1 (AP). -- Charging desertion, Mrs. Mary H. Swift filed suit here today for a divorce from Louis N. Swift Jr., member of the Chicago packing company family.

Paul Muni, stage and screen star, has decided not to appear on Broadway for A.H. Woods next December in "The Red Cat." In a telegram from Los Angeles Mr. Muni declared: "I am not doing 'Red Cat.' I am now reading scripts and hoping to find a suitable play to open in New York around Christmas."

ON BOARD THE SCHOONER MORRISSEY, North of Hudson Bay, Sept. 1. -- On the port tack, close hauled under the four lowers, with our sturdy little standard Diesel helping us, the Morrissey's nose is pointed for the Straits of Fury and Hecla, where in a few hours we hope to be.

The listed bond market yesterday lived up to the tradition of "preholiday" trading. Dealings amounted to only a little more than $7,000,000, the smallest for a full five-hour trading period since Nov. 20. Prices moved irregularly lower in all departments, but few net changes were of consequence.

Execution yesterday of a buying order in New Orleans for 25,000 bales of cotton, attributed to the government, caused an equal amount of contracts to be taken from the New York Cotton Exchange, but the transactions had little influence on prices.

Failure of bank credit to expand in recent weeks, in the face of mounting excess reserves and increasing business activity, may be attributed in part to the effect of the discontinuance of interest payments on demand deposits under the Banking Act of 1933, says the Federal Reserve Bank of New York in its current monthly review.

The city met an $8,746,000 interest payment due yesterday with $5,000,000 advanced to it by the State and $3,746,000 which it borrowed from its own sinking fund. It thus escaped default on its obligations, despite the refusal of the banking syndicate which has been financing it for two years to extend any credit for that purpose.

The Rev. Dr. Frederick H. Knubel, president of the United Lutheran Church in America, sent letters yesterday to the presidents of the thirty-three synods which compose the communion summoning them to conferences at which a "Forward Movement" will be started in celebration of the 450th anniversary of Martin Luther on Nov. 12.
A jade carving, valued by its owner at $1,000,000 on which hundreds of Chinese craftsmen labored more than ten years, is to be placed on exhibition in a Rockefeller Center showroom on Nov. 1.
From a wealth of reminiscences, personal and professional, Dr. Franklin H. Martin, one of America's greatest surgeons, has compounded an autobiography, which he calls, "The Joy of Living."

CAMP PERRY, Ohio, Sept. 1 (AP) -- Hitting the targets in A stiff wind for eight bullseyes and a score of 197 out of a possible 200, W.R. Walsh of Union City, N.J., won the Wimbledon match in the national small bore rifle championships today against a field of ninety-seven contestants.

GREENWICH, Conn., Sept., 1. -- Larry Lloyd of Greenwich and Hamilton Wright of Garden City, who tied for the medal yesterday in the annual invitation golf tournament of the Greenwich Country Club, were defeated in the first round today.

BOSTON, Sept. 1. -- With his wife sitting at the bedside, Johnny Vergez, plucky third baseman of the Giants, was reported to be resting comfortably today in St. Elizabeth's Hospital. He underwent an operation there for acute appendicitis yesterday shortly after completing the opening game of the serieg with the Braves.

LONDON, Sept. 1. -- By the narrow margin of one-half penny, the sterling price of gold today reached the highest point on record. Buyers paid 130s 8 1/2d a fine ounce. The previous highest was 130s 8d on Nov. 30 last. Just before England abandoned the gold standard the metal was quoted at 84s 11 1/2d.

HIGHLAND PARK, Ill., Sept. 1. -- After playing brilliantly in the initial stages of the championship, Miss Enid Wilson, the British titleholder, faltered badly in today's semi-final round of the women's national golf event at Exmoor.

Contracts making available $79,500,000 of Federal funds for completion of the Triborough Bridge and construction of the midtown Hudson Tunnel were signed yesterday by the authorities for the two projects.

LONDON, Sept. 1. -- President Roosevelt's recovery policy for the United States received endorsements from two widely separated sources today -- the general council of the Trade Union Congress and the great Midland Bank, headed by Reginald McKenna, former Chancellor of the Exchequer.

DUBLIN, Sept. 1. -- The Centre party and William T. Cosgrave's Cumann na nGaedheal, in separate meetings, tonight voted to accept proposals to merge with General O'Duffy's banned National Guard -- the Blue Shirts -- thus taking definite steps toward establishment of a new United Ireland party.

Century Plant Critics. Unkind things have been said about the century plant up in the Bronx. It has been severely taken to task for not producing its blossoms on schedule. Now that the buds have opened the effect is described as nothing to write home about.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 1. -- President Roosevelt enjoyed a really restful day at sea today.

NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 1. -- Though she was not expected until tomorrow, Mrs. Roosevelt, wife of the President, arrived here this afternoon and is the guest of her cousin and godmother, Mrs. Henry Parish of New York, at their Summer home, Ludlow Cottage on Harrison Avenue.

CUZCO BIG transport planes of the United States Air Mail Service, which have dwarfed to a third the travel and communication time on the great South American continent, now have performed another seeming miracle of the man-made variety to conquer the great Cordilleras of the Peruvian Andes.
WESTBURY, L.I., Sept. 2 -- Playing nicely together and improving as the game progressed, Seymour Knox's Aurora team beat Templeton on Cochran Field at the Meadow Brook Club today, 10 to 8.

MARINE CITY, Mich., Sept. 2 -- Roaring around thirty-five miles of the St. Clair River at dusk tonight, Gar Wood, in his speed boat Miss America X, defeated Hubert Scott-Paine, in Miss Britain III, by 1 minute and 31 seconds in the first heat of the international Harmsworth Trophy race.

EINSTEIN and other savants are convinced that in a mathematical symbol, or series of symbols, lies the solution of the mystery of matter. They seek the clue to a single unified field theory that would embrace all aspects of the physical universe.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 (AP) -- Two tropical storms of "hurricane intensity" tonight were swirling west northwestward from the Caribbean area. The Weather Bureau predicted there was no danger to the United States coast from either during the next twenty-four hours.

SALEM, N.H., Sept. 2 -- John J. Curtis's 6-year-old sprinter, Flying Heels, scored a neck victory over the Superior Stable's Supreme Sweet in the five and a half furlongs of the Speed Handicap as the Fall meeting opened at Rockingham Park today.

MR. BORSODI, his wife and their two small sons made their escape from New York City in the Spring of 1920 and therefore the experiment and its results which he here describes have had ample time for thorough testing.

PARIS, Sept. 2 -- In France everything is very calm. Parliament in on a vacation, and there has been only one Cabinet meeting in the past three weeks. The newspapers are filled with the life story of a girl who poisoned her father and mother.

LONDON "IT'S a good deal like 1914," said a British official recently, speaking of the tension in Europe caused by the German efforts to overthrow the Dollfuss government in Austria and replace it with a Nazi regime.

BERLIN, Sept. 2 -- An energetic protest against continued Nazi assaults on American citizens in Germany was lodged with the German authorities today by George S. Messersmith, United States Consul General, following an attack in the streets of Berlin on Samuel Brertnard Bossard, 21 years old, of Chester, Pa.
'TWAS brillig, and the slithy toves" * * *

S.S. WASHINGTON, AT SEA, Sept. 2 (AP) -- The American disarmament delegation, headed by Norman H. Davis, is hopeful that the negotiations now on between France and Germany may prove the opening wedge in bringing about actual arms reductions.

ON the bright morning of the 8th of September, 1883, two trains drawn by bell-stacked locomotives and wreathed in bunting and evergreen drew together among the bare Montana hills, at Gold Creek, west of Helena.

All domestic markets with the exception of that in foreign exchange were closed yesterday. The banks were open as usual, but most of the other business organizations in Wall Street took a holiday. The banks as well as the various markets will be closed tomorrow in observance of Labor Day.

SHANGHAI, Sunday, Sept. 3 -- The seventeenth typhoon of this season to threaten Shanghai finally struck yesterday after sixteen had missed, and midnight saw the major portion of the business district of this great city disastrously flooded.

IN a brief preface to this book Leo Gershoy, its author, who is an Associate Professor of History at Long Island University, tells us that he is fully aware of the fact that "fresh studies of the period of the French Revolution and Napoleon follow one another so rapidly that on the first consideration a new book on the subject appears totally unwarranted."

Fair to liberal quantities of most kinds of fruit were offered in the wholesale markets here during the week, it was said yesterday by George G. Royce, director of the New York office of the State Department of Agriculture and Markets.

Expanded use of advertising linage by retailers in consequence of the nation-wide consumer campaign planned by the NRA was seen as a probable development during the Fall and Winter by F.W. Spaeth, manager of the sales promotion division of the National Retail Dry Goods Association.

THE recent Presidential order permitting mined gold to be sold under agency of the Treasury, at the world market prices, focuses attention on the gold output of this country and its relation to world output.

WHEN a man has just finished a hearty meal and proceeds to top it off with another for good measure, he is likely to have a severe attack of indigestion. Two meals at a time, indeed, are worth distinctly less than one meal.

ALBANY, Sept. 2 -- The New York State Milk Control Board estimated today that farmers would receive on an average nearly 4 cents a quart for their milk which was delivered in August. Kenneth F. Fee, director of the board, stated that the estimated price was $1.80 a hundred pounds for milk testing 3.5 per cent fat in the 201-210-mile zone.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Sept. 2 -- There was a round of entertainment today for holiday guests at estates throughout the colony. Mr. and Mrs. Reginald Fincke gave a large dinner tonight at their place on the ocean for Mr. and Mrs. Henry G. Gray of Longford, Locust Valley, who are passing "the holiday with them.

THE Cruise of the Zaca" tells the story of a voyage of 27,000 miles in the tropics, except for comparatively short stretches in the Mediterranean and fairly long hauls in the South Atlantic and Eastern Pacific.

GEORGE M. COHAN, who has spent most of his life in the theatre, paused for a breathing spell during a rehearsal of Eugene O'Neill's latest play at the Guild Theatre to pay a glowing tribute to the wizardry of radio. America's song and dance man has always been enchanted by the stirring appeal of something new and he admits that he has found a new fascination in the microphone.

DOLLARS AND SENSE" is a dependable guide for the perplexed in the bewildering mixup of theories and concepts which laymen are asked to accept as forming the economic background of the policies of the new administration.

LONDON, Aug. 15, 1933 THE season of holidays and frivolities coincided this year with two festivals of music which were anything but frivolous. The first of these, organized by Arnold Dolmetsch at Haslemere, introduced us to a number of compositions by masters, known and unknown, who flourished before the age of Handel.

THE great storm that lately lashed the eastern seaboard of the United States, was a northeaster -- but not everywhere, and not all the time. North-east winds drove before, them the huge waves that hattered the coast from Virginia to New England.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 -- The statement sent by Joseph B. Eastman, Coordinator of Transportation, to the heads of all Class 1 railroads and the executives of the standard railroad organizations, read as follows:

CINCINNATI, Sept. 2 (AP) -- Held in check by young Bud Tinning, the crratic Reds lost to the Cubs, 5 to 0, today after yesterday's victory had given the fans hopes that the home team was ready to desert the cellar.

ERNEST K. LINDLEY. Washington correspondent of The New York Herald Tribune is writing a history of the first six months of the present administration, to be published late in October or early in November by the Viking Press.

New York City and adjoining States included in the local NRA district are within sight of 100 per cent enrolment of employers under the Blue Eagle without an important hold-out. Announcement of this was made at NRA headquarters at the Hotel Pennsylvania yesterday by James F. Hodgson, district director of the United States Department of Commerce.

RENEWED attempts by the United States to extradite Samuel Insull from Greece have again focused attention on the legal process through which one government surrenders a man wanted on criminal charges to another. While it is a relatively simple matter to extradite a person from one State in the Union to another in which he committed a crime, extradition between nations is hedged about by many technicalities.

Nine other nations of the world are at present outbuilding the United States in the merchant marine field, according to a statement issued by the American Steamship Owners Association, which declared further that in speed, age and size the American merchant marine was below parity.

Seven States are to vote on repeal in September. Vermont's turn at the polls comes Tuesday. Maine, that faithful Monday State, will go to the polls Monday week. Tuesday, Sept. 12, is the day for Colorado, Maryland and Minnesota; Tuesday, Sept. 19, for Idaho and New Mexico.
BERLIN, Sept. 2 (AP) -- The Reichsbank's statement of Aug. 31 shows the following changes in reichsmark:

HAMBURG. -- The people one meets here and in Bremen, as well as in the country on this side of Berlin, appear cheerful and go about their work as if they are convinced all will come out all right in the end if they can only carry on for the present.

HERE, at last, is a thoroughgoing study of Hitler's Germany by a scholar who knows. Intimately acquainted with Germany, and fortified by the experience gained from a previous study of Soviet Russia which stands in the front rank of books on that subject.

Retail buying throughout the country increased last week in expectation of advances in prices after the holiday. Merchants in many instances were pressing for early deliveries of Fall goods, relying upon improved purchasing power as a result of increases in employment and wages.

OTTAWA, Aug. 31 -- A persistent story of the dog-days in Canada comes year after year from the interior of British Columbia and reports the reappearance of a strange aquatic creature named by the newspapers, for what reason does not appear, Ogopogo.

These orders were Issued yesterday: Transfers and Assignments. PATROLMEN -- Clarence J. Melville, from 42d Precinct to Precinct E; James Grace, from 44th Precinct to 40th Precinct; Thomas F. Kearns, from 73d Precinct to 88th Precinct; Joseph Doctor, from 88th Precinct to 73d Precinct; William F. Searby, from 112th Precinct to 105th Precinct; Charles F. Nienstedt, from Precinct 0 to 109th Precinct.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 -- The Bureau of Navigation issued the following orders today, dated Aug. 30:

ANNA STEN in "Nana" as a picture suggested by the novel of Emile Zola will have a much wider scene than its original. The ancestry of Nana in the gutters and the hovels of Paris in 1870, which the novel takes for granted, will have detail and definition in the film play prepared by Edwin Justus Mayer, Leo Birinski and Harry Wagstaff Gribble.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Matta Akrawi, who wrote to THE NEW YORK TIMES about the present situation in Mesopotamia, seems himself to be not thoroughly acquainted with the fundamental causes of the Assyrian problem.

Retailers, reporting excellent consumer-reaction to August sales, are clamoring for Fall merchandise, according to the market report prepared especially for THE TIMES by McGreevey, Werring Howell, Inc. Although the ready-to-wear manufacturers were busily engaged during the week in whipping their lines into shape and starting factories on the new working schedule, deliveries and in many cases prices remain undetermined, the report said.

CHICAGO, Sept. 2 -- The first of six free balloons to take off in the twenty-first running of the international Gordon Bennett balloon race, the Goodyear IX, piloted by Ward T. Van Orman, famous lighter-than-air expert and winner of three previous Bennett races, was walked out to the starting line in front of the grand stand of the international air races at 6 o'clock this evening.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Sept. 2 -- Gifts to charities amounting to $48,500 and specific bequests of more than $195,000 to friends and cousins, are listed in the will of Mrs. Florence Macy Sutton, daughter of the late Captain Rowland H. Macy, founder of the New York department store bearing his name.
THE following address was delivered by Edwin T. Rice at the unveiling of a bronze portrait of Mrs. Elizabeth Sprague Coolidge at the Temple of Chamber Music, South Mountain, Pittsfield, Mass.:
