Prominent Cubans who were supporters of former President Machado and fled to this country after the fall of his government, are beginning a campaign for reconciliation with the anti-Machado elements now in power in Cuba so that eventually the refugees may return to their homes with guarantees of safety.
BELLE FOURCHE, S.D., Aug. 31 -- Mrs. American Farmer is bringing the nation back to the home.

ST. PAUL, Aug. 30 -- Although eager to support the NRA, business men in the small towns of the Northwest are frankly worried. Few of them in this agricultural territory have the capital or uhe credit necessary to carry through until the greater expense entailed by the code can be offset by an increased volume of buying.
Out of work for months, Irving Kesseler, 27 years old, of 147 East Eighty-sixth Street, collapsed from hunger early yesterday afternoon in front of 102 Maiden Lane.

MINEOLA, L.I., Sept. 2 -- That skeet shooting is growing in popularity was demonstrated at the traps of the Nassau Trapshooting Club today. Twenty gunners took part in the skeet contest, while only eight reported for the regular event.

VIENNA, Sept. 2 -- This week furnished evidence that the Dollfuss government, supported by Premier Mussolini of Italy and even by moderate Nationalist opinion in Austria, still hopes to make peace with Germany.

A 40-hour week and a minimum wage at the rate of 35 cents an hour are established in the code of fair competition adopted by the Theatrical Costumers Association of America, Inc., made public yesterday.

CHICAGO, Sept. 2 -- The shadow of death and accident hung today over the international air races, held before 15,000 persons at the Curtiss-Reynolds Airport as part of the Century of Progress Exposition.

THE nation has traveled two-thirds of the way toward repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment. It will almost certainly reach that goal some time in December. Last Tuesday Washington became the twenty-fourth State to let its people express their will on the question, and the result was what it had been in the twenty-three previous States: for repeal.

CHICAGO, Aug. 31 -- Not for many years have the people of the Middle West done so much serious thinking oh the problem of education as they have since the Chicago Board of Education adopted its economy program six weeks ago.

SERGET EISENSTEIN'S picture, "Thunder Over Mexico," will have its premiere at the Rialto Theatre on Sept. 15. The announcement calls for a few words of explanation. Way back in 1931 Mr. Eisenstein, the director of "Potemkin," "Ten Days That Shook the World" and other Russian pictures, was lured to these shores by lucrative offers from Hollywood.

SMITHTOWN, L.I., Sept. 2 -- Making his round of the outside course with only one insignificant fault, the chestnut gelding Ballot, owned by Mrs. Edward J. McDonald of Smithtown Branch, today captured the Meadow Brook-Smithtown Hunt Cup, most highly-prized trophy of the twenty-fourth annual Smithtown Horse Show.

AN inkling of speed that will seem commonplace when transocean air lines are in operation may be had from a special shipment for which the combined facilities of air, rail and steamship operators were enlisted. This shipment, a memorial book called "British Columbia, the Making of a Province," will complete a journey from Victoria, B.C., to Nairobi, British East Africa, in eleven days, reaching Kenya Colony next Tuesday.

CHICAGO A WORLD symposium on problems of automotive engineering and transport has been in progress here this week in connection with the Century of Progress Exposition. It was arranged by the Society of Automotive Engineers and brought together about 1,200 advanced thinkers and research workers whose minds are centred on progress.

ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 2 -- The "New Deal" legislation passed by Congress has accelerated the "slow demolition" of the Constitution which had been going on for fifty years, and another half-century may see the "cureless ruin" of the whole structure, according to Representative James M. Beck of Philadelphia, former United States Solicitor General.

RADIO stepped away from the electrical industry in 1923 to stage its own World's Fair in the old Madison Square Garden. Veteran industrial showmen marveled at the audacity of radio, not yet rated as an industry, for the bold stroke in even expecting to attract a crowd.

ROME, Sept. 2 -- Aviation circles and the press mourned the tragic death of General Francesco de Pinedo at New York today, while his brother Alberto hastened to Rome to break the news of the General's death to his aged parents.

BANFF, Alta., Aug. 31 -- International differences in the Far East have been exaggerated, according to Dr. Inazo Nitobe, leader of Japan's delegation to the recently ended session here of the Institute of Pacific Relations. Honest and intelligent journalism can remove or smooth over many of the causes of irritation, he said in an interview with THE NEW YORK TIMES correspondent.

BOSTON, Sept. 1 -- Two divergent trends are apparent in the New England business situation. Industrial production has of late been displaying a moderate but unmistakable tendency toward recession, but the movement of goods at retail has been in process of steady expansion.

OMAHA, Neb., Aug. 30 -- The Misssouri River Valley above Kansas City has had Its faith in Santa Claus renewed. Last week it found in its stocking more than $14,000,000 of public construction funds to be devoted to curbing the wandering fancies of its erratic stream.

SOUTHAMPTON -- With an unusually full program of social activities under way, there is no indication that, as in previous seasons, Labor Day will mark the end of the Summer's formal entertainments. So many events of interest are being arranged for September that it is more than likely that a large contingent of the Summer colony will remain through the month.

The statement of policy of the Tennessee Valley Authority with respect to power development, issued by David E. Lilienthal in Washington ten days ago has aroused much perturbation in public-utility circles, where it is feared the authority may take over by condemnation a substantial part of the territory now served by private utility systems in order to supply the government operation with a "yardstick" of utility costs.

HAMILTON, Bermuda -- Visitors to Bermuda are now experiencing a new thrill, that of walking about under the sea with the aid of a diving helmet, an experience that is said to compare favorably in its novelty with flying, or with skimming over the surface of the sea in a fast motor boat.

A new college started recently in Nassau County as a relief project of the Emergency Work Bureau, with widespread cooperation on the part of the community, is proving so successful in reaching students who, in the opinion of the sponsors, ordinarily would not have gone beyond high school, that the plan is now to make it permanent.

HONOLULU, Sept. 2 -- Allen W. T. Bottomley, president of American Factors, a sugar agency, and also of the Bishop First National Bank, lost his life this afternoon ten miles off Honolulu harbor when he was pitched out of his yacht in a heavy sea.

With business suspended on all the security and commodity exchanges, the only financial incident of consequence yesterday was a further decline in dollar exchange. From a gold value of 69.78 cents at the close of business on Friday, the currency fell yesterday to 68.85, a net decline of almost a cent.

GIVING heed to the letters congratulating him upon the theme song, "Who's Afraid of the Big Bad Wolf?" in the Silly Symphony, "Three Little Pigs," Walt Disney has announced he will have theme songs for all new Mickey Mouse and Silly Symphony subjects.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 (AP) -- George Thomas Marye, former Ambassador to imperial Russia, died today in his eighty-fourth year at his home here after two weeks' illness.
PITTSBURGH, Sept. 2 (AP) -- The Pirates stretched their winning streak to eight in a row today by sweeping the two-game series with the Cardinals, 4 to 1.

FORMATION of a "Citizens Volunteer Motor Patrol," composed of motorists pledged to report acts of recklessness or boorishness on the part of drivers they meet on the road, is advocated by Colonel Michael A. Connor, Commissioner of Motor Vehicles for Connecticut.

NO warrior of the New World has more legends garlanded about his name than Emiliano Zapata. He is the great hero of the Mexican revolution, and his cause -- land and freedom for the Indians of Mexico -- is the one enduring cause when all the smoke of gunpowder and words has blown away into the oblivious mountains.
The total number of up-State employers who have signed the President's Agreement was increased to 97,227 out of a possible total of 112,000 by the addition of 3,043 signatures yesterday.

BERLIN. PROFESSOR ERNST BERGMANN of Leipzig has writen a book which he calls "Erkenntnisgeist und Muttergeist." It is published by Ferdinand Hirt-Bresiau. To review this work expertly and thoroughly would require the writing of a second book.
High goal polo enters the final phase of its season this week with the start on Saturday of the national open championship at the Meadow Brook Club in Westbury, L.I.

Complaints have been made by vigilant citizens that the scythe on the new three-cent NRA postage stamp is no longer representative of the American farmer. Today he should be represented astride a tractor or washing down his cow barn with medicated soap. For all practical purposes the mowing machine has superseded the snath and blade.

SALZBURG, Austria, Sept. 2 -- Despite the conspicuous absence of German visitors the Salzburg Festival, which came to an end Thursday night, was in many ways the most successful yet held. The number of visitors was 35,000, as against 45,000 last year.

General Francesco de Pinedo, former chief of staff of the Royal Italian air force, was probably as well qualified as any other flier in the world for his projected solo attempt to set a new world's distance record.

Featured by the $100,000 Futurity, richest race in the world, the Fall meeting at Belmont Park will begin tomorrow, to run for twelve racing days. The traditional stakes, which stretch back to the early days of racing in this State, all have their usual place in the schedule announced by Racing Secretary Victor Schaumburg.

LONDON, Aug. 17 IT was once accepted as a truism that the heart of English theatrical life was in London. There only were new plays produced and new reputations made. The old stock companies were dead and provincial theatres were filled week after week by touring companies sent out from London in plays that had already succeeded there.
Amy Mollison, British flier, has obtained a temporary position as an air line co-pilot in the United States.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Sept. 2 -- A legacy of $5,000 is left to the New York Bible Society, 5 East Forty-eighth Street, Manhattan, and a bequest of $1,000 is made to the Baptist Church of Cross River, N.Y., under the will of George W. Reynolds of Lewisboro, N.Y.

With most of the elect enjoying the respite of a bye, Frederick J. Perry of England and Frank Shields of New York led the field into the second round of the national tennis championship yesterday as the fifty-second annual tournament got under way at the West Side Tennis Club, Forest Hills.
CHICAGO, Sept. 2 -- Gay World, a 17 to 1 shot in the betting, won the $10,000 added Chicago Derby today, beating Esseff by half a length. Mr. Khayyam, the heavily played favorite, was third.

RECENT events in Andorra have brought to this pocket State a news importance inconsistent with the size of the country. For the first time in six and a half centuries Andorra has been invaded, peacefully, by foreign troops, consisting of fifty French gendarmes.

George Z. Madalle, United States Attorney, denied yesterday that politics had inspired his charges that a link between racketeers and politicians existed in New York. His statement was a reply to the attack upon him Friday by Colonel Franklin S. Hutchinson, chief of investigation for the Senate subcommittee on racketeering.

IN thirteen years of Dry America New York got confirmed in the basement and backyard habit of eating and drinking. There were the big wholesale food factories, of course, presenting a plate-glass front to the street. But good cheer retired behind locked doors.

Instead of the dinner party he had planned, Stanley A. Day was host in his penthouse apartment at 120 West Seventieth Street last night to a police emergency squad of nine men, a doctor, the superintendent of the building and several of the dinner guests, all of whom worked furiously for four hours to liberate Mr. Day's wire-haired terrier Peter.

More Vision Needed. I approve of the exception you make relative to Mr. Baker's views regarding education. I have been of the opinion that a purely academic or classical education is the best preparation that can be given to all students.

DUBLIN, Sept. 2 -- The major political development this week was the decision on the part of the Opposition parties to fuse into one organization, to present a united front against the Republicans in the event of a surprise election in the next few months.

THE century plant, a specimen of which recently attracted large numbers of visitors to the Bronx Park Botanical Gardens before and after it blossomed, belongs to an extremely useful family, the Amaryllidaceae, the best known species of which is the Agave Americana, sometimes called the American aloe.

COLD SPRING HARBOR, L.I., Sept. 2 -- The first of the Autumn debutants parties on the North Shore took place tonight when Mr. and Mrs. George Small Franklin gave a supper dance at their country home for their daughter, Miss Lila H. Franklin.

DETROIT, Sept. 2 -- Twenty thousand persons today saw Gallant Sir win the Inaugural Handicap, opening-day feature of Detroit's thirty-one-day racing meeting. The running horses returned to Detroit after a lapse of almost forty years.

IN his introduction to this book Secretary Cordell Hull lays down the proposition that "the history of any country is very largely the history of the men who have led it," and adds that "one who becomes familiar with the lives of the men who have been Presidents of the United States is in the best possible position to understand and appreciate its life story as a nation."

FROM the standpoint of sales increases over 1932, local retail trade during the week made an excellent showing. Gains of 15 per cent or more over the corresponding daily volume figures of a year ago were noted by a number of leading stores here.

THE last week has been of more than passing interest and importance for the air transport industry. The pilots of the major air lines of the country and their operators have met, with each party to the conference holding widely divergent views of its respective rights.

LOS ANGELES, Calif., Aug. 30 -- The nation's open-shop stronghold has girded on its fighting armor and is again ready to battle for what industrial Los Angeles considers its greatest asset, now believed through code interpretation to be in grave danger.

BERLIN, Aug. 24 -- The stork, which in the Third Reich has almost as much honor as the eagle, has been requisitioned to. give direct evidence on the case of ''race" -- or inheritance -- vs. environment, of such fundamental importance in the Nazi catechism.
MONTAUK, L.I., Sept. 2 -- "High hook" and "first catch," President Roosevelt returned to the yacht Nourmahal at anchor in Fort Pond Bay tonight after a day of fishing aboard the sloop Orca.

Lindbergh as Nordic. The headlines say that Colonel LINDBERGH has been visiting the land of his forebears, which is Sweden. Of course, the relationship is really much closer than "forebears" makes it sound.

WALLACE FORD, the comedy lawyer in "Goodbye Again," at the Strand, has something in common with Abraham Lincoln. Both were born on Feb. 12. In Mr. Ford's case, however, the year was 1899 and the place was London.

PARIS. FASHIONS have rarely combined so much complication of detail (in the way of trimmings and accessories) with such stark basic simplicity as they do this Winter, which is the main reason why the new styles do not look fussy, although they are apt to be ornate.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 -- George Wadsworth of Buffalo, First Secretary of the Legation at Teheran, has been transferred to the legation at Bucharest in a similar post, the State Department announced today.
Phil Collins shut out the Dodgers with four hits yesterday as the Phillies opened a two-day campaign at Ebbets Field. The score was 2-0.

Regardless of what one thinks of the policy involved, one is bound to admire the patient persistence with which Norman H. Davis has taken ship to return to Geneva for the discussion of disarmament. The persistence is not alone that of Mr. Davis, for he is sent on his mission expressly and directly by President Roosevelt.

BALTIMORE, Sept. 2 -- Baltimore's lead over Albany for the second berth in the International League play-offs was cut to seven games as the Orioles went down to a 2 to 1 defeat at the hands of Newark today. It was the fifth consecutive defeat for Baltimore.

STURBRIDGE, Mass., Sept. 2 -- Princess, chestnut filly, owned and driven by W.J. Cleary of West Springfield, today won the 2-year-old trot and bettered the Mohawk Circuit record for her class in both heats. The event featured the opening day of the Sturbridge Fair racing meeting.

HSINKING, Manchuria, Aug. 2 -- When late Summer rolls around and the kaoliang grows high in the fields of Manchuria, Japanese and Manchukuo military authorities will be prepared with special measures to combat the resurgence of banditry which is an annual phenomenon of that season.

EAST HAMPTON, L.I., Sept. 2 -- The Maldstone Club held its annual ball tonight. More than five hundred persons danced in costumes representing every nation and period. Original and amusing outfits predominated.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 -- The volume of business changed little in the week ended on Aug. 26 except in the heavy manufacturing industries, where a further drop was recorded from the preceding week, according to the regular survey of business conditions made public today by the Department of Commerce.

One of the greatest stages ever designed, in which almost the entire playing field at the Polo Grounds will be utilized, is being made ready for the Jewish pageant, "Romance of a People," which is to be presented on the night of Sept. 14.

The next few weeks will bring the regular yachting season on Long Island Sound to a close, but before the racing fleet goes out of commission for the Winter plenty of opportunities remain for local skippers to test their skill in competition.
LITTORIA, Italy, Aug. 15 (AP) -- Premier Benito Mussolini, statesman, writer and violinist, has proved to this war veterans' farm community that he can be a good farm hand when occasion arises.

The Women's Swimming Association will be attempting something new in its varied aquatic history this week. There will be a 1,000-yard ocean swim off Atlantic City on Friday and the W.S.A., which had never entered a competition of this sort before, will be represented by three or four girls.

ONCE more the nation's attention turns to steel. The tall stacks are smoking again. The noisy Bessemers are blowing their fiery blasts. Hundreds of mills that were idle are rolling again and others that were operating meagerly a few days a month are back in the running, with increased schedules, increased payrolls and increased output.

A new era in football at Fordham University, which is expected to thrust the Maroon further into the forefront of intercollegiate circles, was launched yesterday. Twenty-eight veterans reported for the assignment of uniforms at Fordham Field. Practice will be inaugurated tomorrow.

The solution of the city's financial problems rested completely yesterday in the hands of Samuel Untermyer, called to take the helm when the administration was able to find no tax program acceptable to the public.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Aug. 31 -- Ohio real estate taxpayers have devised a sort of NRA code for themselves and it is to be submitted to the voters in November in the form of an amendment to the Constitution. The chances are that it will be adopted by a large majority although it is opposed openly or secretly by many leaders of finance and industry represented in the business organizations of the State.

THE automobile of tomorrow will surpass the car of today in performance, economy, comfort and safety. It will be easier to control and give less trouble on the road. Lighter in weight, probably supercharged equipped with an automatic transmission that eliminates gear shifting, and with wheels independently suspended instead of attached to the conventional axle, the car of the future will be faster, more reliable, roomier and cheaper than any machine of today.

TOKYO IF Japanese statesmen had the autobiographical habit, one of them could write a story which, for the color and spice of life and for range of human experience, would be unique. Prince Kimmochi Saionji has telescoped the feudal age and the twentieth century into a single life.

New York University is stronger in every department except enrolment in the non-conferring divisions as a result of the depression, it was revealed yesterday with the publication of the final annual report to the council by Dr. Elmer Ellsworth Brown, who retired as chancellor of the university on July 1.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 -- An appeal to the nation's railroads to back the national recovery program in principle, even though they are not included in it directly under a code, was voiced today by Joseph B. Eastman, Federal co-ordinator of transportation.

EDWARD BURNE-JONES, the hundredth anniversary of whose birth was celebrated last week, is probably more widely known in America than either Morris or Rossetti, the principal members of the little group to which, through interests held in common, he belonged.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 (AP) -- Henry I. Harriman, president of the Chamber of Commerce of the United States, communicated to its membership today the assertion that most thoughtful business men were hopeful of "fair prosperity on a sound basis" soon.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 (AP) -- An estimate that this year's cotton production program had added about $246,000,000 to the prospective income of the growers was made today by the Agricultural Adjustment Administration.

Radical rather than evolutionary methods of changing package designs were recommended to manufacturers of consumer goods yesterday in a statement issued by Ben Nash, president of the Products Development Company, which has completed a survey of package design change employed by leading manufacturers in the last two years.

VARIOUS items out of the office, and hope chest, of Mr. Max Gordon are these: (1) The purposed road tour of "Design for Living" is all off. The actors he wished for the three roles are working in the movies, and, further, the screen version of Mr. Coward's play will be released around Oct. 1.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Sept. 2 (AP) -- Two women were killed and twenty persons were injured, several believed seriously, when an Albany-Saratoga Springs bus with twenty-nine passengers aboard crashed head-on with an automobile near Round Lake, south of here, tonight.

Babe Ruth appeared at the Stadium yesterday in an old, familiar role. His slashing two-base drive to deep right field, the one punch the tottering diamond monarch delivered during the afternoon, gave the Yankees their first victory in three games over the Red Sox.

Californians very evidently take as much pride in their prophetic ability as they do in their athletic supremacy and climate. The seers from the Coast already have picked Fred Perry of England as the next American, lawn tennis champion.

NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 2 -- Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt, wife of the President, ended her Brief visit here this afternoon and left for two weeks' stay with friends in the Adirondacks before returning to Washington.

RYE, N.T., Sept. 2 -- The second annual Westchester flower show will be held here from Thursday to next Sunday, inclusive, in the Playland Casino, under the auspices of the Central Westchester Horticultural Society and the Tarrytown Horticultural Society, with the cooperation of the Westchester garden clubs.
ATHENS, Sept. 2 -- Samuel Insull was notified today by the Athens police that all his documents and letters had been examined, classified and sealed, then handed over to the public prosecutor.

BRETTON WOODS, N.H., Sept. 2 -- The largest arrival for any week-end this season at White Mountain clubs and hotels was noted for the holiday and the entertainment program for the next few days is a full one. Dances at the Maplewood Club, the Balsams in Dixville Notch, the Waumbek at Jefferson, the Forest Hills at Franconia, the Sinclair at Bethlehem and Sunset Hill House in Sugar Hill were given tonight.
More than 1,000,000 New York children will return to their classes a week from tomorrow. Registration, beginning "Wednesday, will continue this week through Thursday and Friday.

Chief Game Warden A. Joseph Williamson of Connecticut yesterday announced five important changes in the hunting laws of the Nutmeg State. At the same time he reported that scores of hunters had taken to the fields for the first day's shooting of rails when the open season began on Friday.

BELLPORT, L.I., Sept. 2 -- Ideal racing conditions prevailed today as the Heliport Yacht Club played host to the Great South Bay and Moriches Bay sailors at a week-end regatta. The committee selected a windward and leeward course which gave the skippers plenty of windward work.

Because tomorrow is Labor Day, today will be observed in the churches as Labor Sunday. The sermons will deal with the NRA, especially as it applies to the churches. Pastors will refer to the fact that there are many unemployed ministers.

The conversion of purchasing power into spending power by a mild increase in the price level, by synchronizing the industrial recovery and public works programs and by a process of public education on the part of the government, was advocated here yesterday by Paul P. Gourrich, consulting economist.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 -- General Johnson today revived the soft-coal parleys between the United Mine Workers of America and the nonunion operators in the Appalachian fields, which collapsed last night.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 2 (AP) -- Irving Hadley held the Tigers to seven hits while his team-mates pounded Carl Fischer to give the Browns a 7-to-1 victory today to open their last home series of the season.

COLONEL JOHN REED KILPATRICK, president of the Madison Square Garden Corporation, which seems to be joining the concert-giving field, announces that the prices for the three concerts already planned will be 40 and 85 cents and $1.10.

NUREMBERG, Sept. 2 -- That master exponent of great stagecraft and mass psychology, the National Socialist organization of Germany, staged two outdoor spectacles today that left upon all beholders an impression rarely equaled even in this new world of huge popular demonstrations.

LONDON, Sept. 1 -- British labor is again in the throes of one of its periodic struggles between the trade unionists, who form the backbone of its voting strength, and its intellectuals, who lead its shattered remnants in Parliament.

HOLLYWOOD SAMUEL GOLDWYN'S Eddie Cantor Company began photographing the slave market and beauty parlor sequences in "Roman Scandals" last week. Some fifty young women, picked from several thousand tests and known as the "Goldwyn girls," posed in a dignified fashion before the cameras to add to Hollywood's latest effort to "beautify and glorify" the screen.

The Labor Day exodus that began in full force late Friday reached. its peak yesterday afternoon as store and office workers left early, to take advantage of every possible minute of the long week-end.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 1 -- Business reports of the week are favorable, with the immediate outlook generally declared satisfactory in most lines except the live stock industry, which is hampered by poor pasturage and high price of feeds as well as a low market for beef.

WASHINGTON TOMORROW is labor's most critical Labor Day. For organized labor the New Deal means a complete reorientation of philosophy, policy and method. This reorientation is being forced at breakneck speed, in the midst of turmoil and excitement.

EUREKA, Nev. NEVADA and her neighbor States have never quite lost their hope that silver will some day come back to its old position as a precious metal. The news of the silver discussions at the recent London Economic Conference had no readers more eager in all the world than in Nevada.

A gold strike on the Potaro River in the swampy jungles of British Guiana has been reported by the LaVarre Brazilian Guiana Expedition, it was announced yesterday by the expedition's representatives in New York.

PRAGUE, Sept. 2 (Jewish Telegraphic Agency.) -- The Eighteenth World Zionist Congress entered its final sessions tonight with a complete lack of agreement among its factions on leadership of the World Zionist Organization for the next two years and with several vital questions to be settled before adjournment.

General Francesco de Pinedo sought to win new aviation honors for Italy and himself yesterday and died in the attempt. He was burned to death at Floyd Bennett Field beneath the wreckage of the Santa Lucia, the monoplane which he had planned to fly to Bagdad.

IT was probably vain to hope that the New Deal, representing as it does an articulate stage in the profound, elemental economic process characteristic of all highly developed forms of modern society, would escape the fate of being made the subject of a primer, though it is as yet too new and too uncertain in its operation and effects in this country to furnish material for elementary instruction.

MR. BURNETT'S hearty series of novels about rambunctious modern men of action moves deeply into the sporting pages again with "Dark Hazard." It is an entertaining story of a minor sinner's periodic and futile stabs at redemption.

ISTANBUL EMANCIPATION of women from harems, veils and other old Eastern restrictions has gone so far in Turkey that a number are now judges, administering civil and criminal justice throughout the land, even at times giving the death penalty.

THE wide and absorbing interest in biography that manifested itself in the years soon after the great war appears to diminish in no way. Not a season goes by but what a large number of excellent lives appear, and they range all the way from the huge painstakingly documented dreadnought of a book to the swift but serviceable little monograph.

A letter criticising policies of the management of the Hupp Motor Car Corporation and asking proxies for the annual meeting of the company, to be held on Sept. 13, in Detroit, has been sent to stockholders by Frederick W. Burnside Jr.

OYSTER BAT, L.I., Sept. 2 -- Starting in practically a dead calm but catching a fresh southerly breeze before the race was a half hour old, a fleet of seventy-nine boats competed today on Long Island Sound in the sixty-first annual Fall regatta of the Seawanhaka Corinthian Yacht Club.

NARROWSBURG, N.Y., Sept. 2 -- Boy Scouts from Queens and Manhattan have broken camp on the reservation maintained for them by the Boy Scout Foundation of Greater New York and called it a season. Boys from Queens boarded a long line of buses on Wednesday.

MANCHESTER, VT. PLUS ca change, plus c'est la meme chose does not, it would seem, apply to the Southern Vermont Artists. The more they change the more at variance they are with the group whose exhibition at the Equinox Pavilion this column covered some five seasons ago.

HERSHEY, Pa., Sept. 2 -- Ed Dudley, Ryder Cup player from Concordville, Pa., today won the Hershey invitation golf tournament and the $500 first prize. He posted a seventy-two-hole total of 288 for the two days of play.

The largest national women's rusade ever undertaken in the United States for the support of community welfare Services is being planned for this Fall by Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt, it was announced yesterday.

A plan by which $12,000,000 to $15,000,000 tied up by Argentine exchange restrictions will be made available to American owners was perfected here yesterday by the American Manufacturers Export Association through the cooperation of the United States Department of Commerce and the Argentine Exchange Control Commission.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 -- The Federal Government ended the second month of the fiscal year with a deficit of $229,685,457, as compared with $663,949,644 on the corresponding date last year.

KNOWLEDGE of the natural resources of Canada's Northwest Territories has been greatly enhanced by the airplane, which has simplified the transportation problems of prospectors. In the present decade, for example, veins of pitchblende, from which radium is extracted, and of silver ore have been located -- so promising that 2,200 claims were staked within a year or two near Great Bear Lake.

Joseph Golway, 38 years old, of 107 East Eighty-ninth Street, who said he had been a chauffeur for President Roosevelt when the latter was Governor, and for former Governor Miller and J.P. Morgan, was held without bail for investigation and hearing next Thursday by Magistrate Greenspan in night court last night.

TORONTO, Sept. 2 -- Jesse Owens of Cleveland, the schoolboy the United States is looking to as a coming sprint champion, hooked up at the Canadian National Exhibition track and field meet today with husky Harry Colman of Winnipeg, who last month won the Canadian sprint title.

OBSERVATION of the manner in which the newly introduced Telefunken records are being accepted here should be sufficient to dispel any pessimism one may be tempted to indulge id about the present status of the gramophone.

THE "Blue Shirts" of Ireland, consisting of the Fascist party, the old Army Comrades who recently changed their name to the National Guard, is the latest of a number of groups that identify themselves by the color of their shirts.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 2 -- Alleging there has been "flagrant violation" of the NRA code, 2,500 employes of the Chevrolet Motor Company here who are members of a union, joined in a request that the right to display the Blue Eagle be denied the General Motors Corporation.

THE place that is referred to as Scandal House is a Summer camp on the shore of a lake in the Adirondacks. It is the property of Mrs. Lydia Whyte-Burrell, widow of Edgrar Burrell, the man responsible for most of the scandals that adhere to the family name.

Many are raising doubts about the recovery of American industry. No one disputes the revival of the American spirit. That has to be set down as altogether the greatest achievement thus far of the Roosevelt Administration. It does not lend itself to precise definition.

While the two Siamese fighting fish glared at each other, through the walls of their tanks, in frustrated rage, peaceable Xyphophorus Helleri next door gave birth to fifty tiny replicas of herself and paused in the middle of the green water, reflectively.
JOHANNESBURG, Aug. 3 -- Farm relief legislation enacted under President Roosevelt is already acting as an inspiration to other countries. South Africa has just adopted a similar program.

HAVANA, Sept. 2 -- Eighty persons are known dead and 450 injured as a result of the tropical hurricane which swept the north coast of Santa Clara, Matanzas and Havana Provinces yesterday. A rapid survey of the stricken area was made today by the writer, who brought the first concrete news from the interior late this afternoon.

The question of whether a corporation derives taxable income from the purchase of its own bonds or notes for a sum less than the issue or face amount of such securities has given rise, under varying conditions, to many reversals of income-tax decisions.
To the Editor of The New York Times: Allow me to comment a few words on a movie that I saw the other night in a neighborhood playhouse. I am referring to "The Girl in 419."

RICHMOND, Va., Aug. 30 -- Action of the Virginia Legislature in refusing by an almost unanimous vote to accept a pay cut for its services at the current special session, although it directed the Governor at its regular session eighteen months ago to cut all State departments and institutions drastically, has caused tongues to wag in the Old Dominion.

NEWPORT -- A late season is looked for here this year. Many members of the Summer colony are making plans to remain at their villas and cottages throughout September, and some of them well into the Fall. The number staying has been growing each year, many having discovered that this city has a period of ideal weather later on.

DINNER AT EIGHT," the film version of the play by George S. Kaufman and Edna Ferber, will soon be telling its joys and woes to audiences virtually all over the world. It is now doing capacity business at the Astor, the spectators being interested not only in the Kaufman-Ferber work but also in seeing the unusual list of distinguished players.

The irregular advance of the stock market, which started in the closing weeks of July after the sharp break in prices, was continued through August and, although trading was greatly reduced, the market managed to recover all the previous month's loss.

AFTER a century and a quarter the Directoire style is apparently achieving the popularity it enjoyed when Jefferson was furnishing Monticello and the era that we know as the Federal period in decoration was taking form.

PARIS. IN New York and London there is no place to sit down. That is what is wrong with New York and London. Of course there are benches in the parks -- but that is another story. In Paris one may sit down on comfortable chairs on the sidewalks at almost every corner and order a coffee or a beer or whatever one may desire and spend an hour watching the caval-cade pass by.

President Roosevelt and his NRA policy are getting popular support in every part of the country, Postmaster General James A. Farley, Democratic National Chairman, declared here yesterday on his return from the convention of the Young Democratic Clubs of America at Kansas City.

To the Editor of The New York Times: THE TIMES editorial on the ''AwTHE TIMES editorial on the "Aw-good laugh. After hearing Americans for twenty years raving about the English accent, this volte face struck me as amusing. Perhaps a right-about was due; for in my ears the trill of the American "r," particularly in, the mouth of an attractive woman, is about the most agreeable sound imaginable.
To the Editor of The New York Times: In reply to your editorial, "A Synthetic Hope," referring to Esperanto, I present a few mildly dissentient thoughts.

ROME, Sept. 2 -- Premier Mussolini and the Soviet Ambassador to Rome, V.P. Potemkin, signed the Italo-Russian treaty of friendship, non-aggression and neutrality at noon today. After the signing, the two men made brief addresses, pointing out the significance of the first political agreement between Fascist Italy and Soviet Russia.
THE great inquiry on "What Is the Matter With Baseball?" was carried to Boston and the answer was discovered. The parks are too small.

THE clarity of the Gallic mind, in which there is also that poetic touch that is perhaps the fine attribute of clear thinking, is well shown in this chastely popularized book by Professor Route of the National Museum of Natural History in Paris.

ALTHOUGH it is later than usual for the opening of a season, the dramatic couriers have only small beer to report. After the prolonged Summer interlude they are, as usual, in a mood of benign expectancy, waiting for something worth competitive serenading.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 -- A plan of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation for financing increased operations of NRA industries through loans to new mortgage companies set up for the purpose in manufacturing communities was disclosed today by Jesse H. Jones, RFC Board Chairman.

HOW amazing and inspiring it is that the man who was the leading organist and an outstanding musician of the England of his period -- a man who worked sixteen hours a day composing and playing and teaching music, but complained that this "mental inactivity" was "killing me" -- should also have been one of the greatest revolutionists in the history of science!
The increase in passenger revenues for July reported by the Baltimore Ohio Railroad directed attention to the efforts the railroads are making to regain traffic lost to the highways.

MOSCOW, Sept. 1 -- The arrival this week of the former Premier Herriot of France and the return of Foreign Commissar Maxim Litvinof from leave are likely to mark the renewal of Soviet diplomatic activity.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 -- The National Recovery Administration settled down today to await an apparently inevitable show-down with Henry Ford.

DETROIT, Sept. 2 (AP) -- With Henry Ford's vacation near its close and his long-awaited declaration of policy on his failure as yet to sign the NRA automobile code apparently near, the first repercussions in the automobile industry were heard today from the code's collective bargaining provision, one of the clauses to which Mr. Ford's associates say he objects.
SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Sept. 2 -- Bazaar, the only filly among fourteen starters in the $38,550 Hopeful, was an easy winner by four lengths today over the best colts in training.

Leading throughout, Roger De Quincey of the Royal Canoe Club of London yesterday evened the series for the International Challenge Cup, emblematic of deckedcanoe sailing supremacy, by winning the second race on Little Neck Bay off Bayside.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 -- Plans for tariff revision are occupying considerable attention in administration circles it was Jearned today. It was regarded possible in some quarters that President Roosevelt would ask Congress, when it convenes in January, for a grant of power along the lines of the plan discarded last Spring.

SEVENTEEN American composers from almost as many different localities will have their compositions presented, many of them for the first time, at the second Yaddo Festival of contemporary American music. There will be three chamber music concerts: on Saturday morning and evening, Sept. 30, and Sunday afternoon, Oct. 1, in the Memorial Room at Yaddo, Saratoga Springs, N.Y.
ROME, Sept. 2 -- The Fascist and Soviet regimes, ofter regarded as diametrically opposed, have maintained remarkably cordial relations ever since Premier Mussolini recognized Russia in 1924.

LONDON, Sept. 2 (AP) -- Portsmouth and the Tottenham Hotspurs won English League first-division games today to move into a three-cornered tie with Leicester City for the early-season leadership. The latter played a scoreless game with Manchester City.

From The Cincinnati Enquirer. It is just possible that the administration is unwittingly developing a new technic of Inflation. Or possibly the brain trusters are more adroit, more subtle than we assume, and are consciously perfecting a psychological control over price levels.

AT the request of the Institute of Pacific Relations R.H. Tawney, the well-known English economist, made economic studies and observations in China and presented the memorandum at its conference held in 1931 at Shanghai. With revisions and additions and the inclusion of another chapter he has made this book.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va -- An extensive program of entertainment Is provided for the large colony here for the first annual Mason and Dixon women's golf championship, which will open on Tuesday and continue through the week.

To the Editor of The New York Times: On my return from London I gave an interview with regard to the Monroe Doctrine. The report of my verbal statement was, in the main, correct as far as it was published, but it did not contain my full statement, which has led to a misunderstanding of my position.

LONDON, Sept. 2 -- The British Government, having consulted France and Italy, today gave Austria formal permission to increase her army to 30,000 men by raising a short-term body of 8,000 for twelve months.

FEW important radio patents have brought glory to an inventor without a long fight to defend them in the courts. That applies to Marconi and the majority of inventive minds which have conceived a new step in the progress of wireless.

An apology by representatives of the 134 Bellevue Hospital internes who refused on Friday evening to listen to a public reprimand of three of their number brought to an end yesterday a situation in which the entire group had been threatened with suspension.

PITTSBURGH, Aug. 31 -- This great soft-coal producing area does not have to wait for completed details of the master code and adjustment of regional arrangements to proclaim the historic importance of the country-wide agreement brought about in the industry by the NRA.

Formal launching of a market for bonds of the Home Owners Loan Corporation created under the Home Owners Loan Act of 1933 is expected soon, following the issuance by the corporation of a prospectus outlining officially the status of the new securities.

LAKE PLACID -- Governor Lehman and Congressman Bertrand H.Snell are among those invited to the annual meeting of the Adirondack Resorts Association, the organization of hotel owners and operators throughout Northern New York, to be held here on Thursday.

The annual convention of the American Bankers Association, which will open tomorrow in Chicago, is expected to be one of the most largely attended and important gatherings in the history of the association. Formulation of a permanent code under the NRA and of proposals for revision of the Banking Act of 1933 with its deposit-guarantee provisions will be the chief business of the meeting.

STOCKBRIDGE, Mass., Sept. 2 -- The twenty-fifth annual Stockbridge exhibition opened at the Berkshire Playhouse this afternoon with the varnishing day reception, an event of importance for artists, sculptors and society of the Berkshire Hills.

The farmer commonly gets less than 5 cents a quart for milk which "the retailer sells to the ultimate consumer at 10 cents or more. The "distributer's spread" has been a long-standing grievance, which naturally tends to become acute in times when adverse general economic conditions, or such old-fashioned disturbances in the dairy cycle itself as a glut of heifers, force prices down.

DALLAS, Texas, Aug. 30 -- It is something of a tribute to Morris Sheppard that both wets and drys alike admit that he emerges from the present ruins of the prohibition cause in Texas with cubits added to his stature. The defeat pf his cause, by an even greater majority than had been hoped for by the most optimistic wets, turned out to be almost a personal victory for him.

Mud and Pedestrians. THE brush-like attachments pictured above are not designed to sweep the streets nor keep an automobile from sinking up to the hub-caps on a muddy road. They are Japan's answer to a problem raised in an article quoted in the current issue of The Safe Driver, a National Safety Council publication.

IT is obvious by a hundred signs that in America at least we face a new period and new conditions of musical performance and music education. The changes that economic conditions are enforcing are more profound and far-reaching than many musicians and educators realize, and they are going to exert a very salutary influence upon music study and the development of the culture of the country.

College graduates and even college students, as well as industrial workers, on the Pacific Coast, at least, already have cause to bless the NRA. Largely because of the renewed business activity of the past month, jobs have now been found for the majority of last June's graduates of the University of Southern California, its employment bureau reports.

PRAGUE, Aug. 15 -- A char-woman's ambition to become a princess has led Marie Bina, the daughter of a stonebreaker in Moravia, into trouble with the Prague police. Her story has an artistocratic and romantic touch.
STONE HARBOR, N.J., Sept. 2 -- Guy Ellsworth of Lewisburg, Pa., and Lou Carlisle of Islip, L.I., battled for honors in the outboard races of the Yacht Club of Stone Harbor today.

PRAGUE, Sept. 2 -- A meeting of the Nazi party in Czechoslovakia, which is taking place at Aussig coincidentally with that of the German Nazis in Nuremberg, Germany, repudiated today all connection with the murder of Professor Theodor Lessing, German philosopher who had been living in exile near Marienbad, Czechoslovakia.
HIGHLAND PARK, Ill., Sept. 2 -- The hole-by-hole description of the match today between Miss Virginia Van Wie and Miss Helen Hicks for the women's national golf championship follows:
Alford J. Williams, flier and former navy speed pilot, was identified tentatively yesterday as the hero of the Battle of Long Island.
The shades Charles A. Dana, Boss Lord, Edgar Allan Poe, Richard Adams Locke, Frank Ward O'Malley and other leaders of journalism wandered once more through the columns of The Sun yesterday.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Aug. 30 -- An issue that has vexed the State of Kentucky for more than two years was settled this week in the House of Representatives when at the special session called to provide State funds, to match Federal relief contributions, Governor Ruby Laffoon's proposed retail sales tax was defeated, 51 to 46.

HAVANA. Sept. 2 -- Cuba tonight watched with apprehension the progress of another storm off the northeastern coast. It was described by the National Observatory as "probably of cyclonic intensity" and was said apparently to be moving toward the East Bahamas.

THE time is evidently past when Labor Day can be said to put an end to the Summer doldrums and to usher in the new season, for not only will that nebulous thing known as "the season" not get under way for a full six weeks, but also the Summer these days has no doldrums.

"WHEN," said the Caterpillar, taking his hookah out of his mouth, "is a ship not a ship?" As Alice fumbled for an answer he spoke more quickly, "When she goes on Summer cruises." And then he went off into a fit of silent laughter that shook the mushroom down all its stem.

THE Prussian Junker has apparently experienced a change of heart. Recently the assembled aristocracy of East Prussia voted to place lands at the disposal of the government, while the landed nobility of Pomerania has offered to give up 20 per cent of its holdings.

SOME heartless and incurable skeptics have ventured to express doubt or denial of the existence of Alice B. Toklas. From these followers of the school of Betsy Prig the good will shrink in horror. In this book full justice is done with pen and pencil to the subject of its title, which in a sense is pleasant fiction.

CHICAGO, Sept. 2 (AP) -- Odell Hale, Cleveland second baseman, hit a home run, a double and two singles and figured in seven runs today as the Indians pounded three White Sox pitchers for a 12 to 4 vitory.

PITTSFIELD, Mass -- Three tournaments are in progress in the Berkshires. The Pittsfield Country Club's tennis tournament for the Berkshire County championships; the mixed doubles tennis tournament at the Wyantenuck Country Club, Great Barrington, and the Berkshire Hunt and Country Club golf tournament at Lenox, will all reach their finals tomorrow.

In a study of the French Canadian by Colonel WILFRID BOVEY it is said that to the average citizen in Canada, if he is English, Scots or Irish, by race, "a Canadian" means a Canadian who speaks English. The French-speaking citizens are always "French Canadians."

KANSAS CITY, Sept. 2 (AP) -- The Young Democratic Clubs of America, taking over complete control of their national convention from the Democratic National Committee, late today chose a slate of officers which included James Roosevelt, son of the President, as secretary.

BERLIN, Sept. 1 -- The race consciousness of Nazi Germany, which has alarmed, affronted and puzzled the outside world, receives a much more common-sense explanation from Professor Eugen Fischer, one of Germany's foremost anthropologists, than it has received from Nazi propaganda based on mythology.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 -- Maximum totals of oil production were fixed for the oil producing States late this afternoon by allocation, which represents a reduction of 300,000 to 350,000 barrels a day.

LONDON, Aug. 22 -- Two eminent politicians the other day met quite by chance at a country club. Sitting on the veranda, after a pleasant round of golf, they fell to talking shop, as is the habit among professional men. One of them, the head of a department in the government, spoke about the great schemes to be discussed this Fall for the settlement of international affairs in Europe.

WHO would believe that there could be romance in such a prosaic thing as a woolen fabric? Usually one would say that wool is a material out of which dresses, suits and coats are made, and that one bought the necessary yardage, paying so much in money and the time it took to choose quality and color, and that there the interest stopped.

DURING the last decade, as Dr. Richmond points out in her introduction, the literature on adolescence has increased steadily. Contributions from psychiatry, psychology and education have added greatly to our knowledge of this phase of human development.

MONTPELIER, Vt., Sept. 2 (AP) -- Vermont, where prohibition ruled for nearly fifty years before the turn of the last century, will decide Tuesday whether it shall be the twenty-fifth State to favor repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment or the first to vote to retain the law.

BOLTON LANDING, Lake George, N.Y., Sept. 2 -- The nominating committee of the Lake George Garden Club, consisting of Mrs. Paul T. Jones of New York, Mrs. C. Everett Bacon of Montclair and Mrs. I.A. Steyens of St. Louis, has nominated Mrs. Willard Church of Montclair for president, Miss Jessie Robertson of New York for second vice president and Mrs. U.G. Stockwell of Albany for corresponding secretary.

With the approach of Autumn, motor boating in Northern waters enters its final and most important period. September brings a series of major events, with the current Harmsworth races, of course, overshadowing the rest in general interest.

The pamphlet report of the Brooklyn-Manhattan Transit Corporation for the fiscal year ended on June 30 shows total operating revenue of the company and subsidiaries amounted to $53,636,427, compared with $57,763,274 in the preceding year.

Month-end business reviews of August agree that, as compared with the immediately preceding period, it was a month of slackening industrial activity. They do not agree on the cause for this so-called "recession" and, in fact, most of the summaries go no further than to point out the very diverse reasons for it.

On a bright autumnal day fiftyseven years ago this month, William T. Larkin ran excitedly down the hill from Bay Street to the government quarantine station. He was going to his first job, as messenger for the Western Union Company at the station on Staten Island.

New York City has just received power to reorganize its purchasing system. The methods that may be pursued under the new law are set forth in the following article, which was prepared under the auspices of the Citizens Budget Commission.

THE National Association of Broadcasters has submitted a code for fair competition in broadcasting to the NRA. The plan provides a forty-hour week for all employes except radio operators and control men, who are given a forty-eight-hour week.
NEW YORK. Lord and Lady Waleran are at the Waldorf-Astoria from London.

To the Editor of The New York Times: There must be many consumers like myself who find it impossible at this time to sign up as consumers under the NRA. The first step to the formulation of industrial codes has been taken, but what of the second, third and fourth steps?

LIKE his "The Kaiser's Coolies," Plivier's new book, though fictional in form, is a record of actual events. Indeed, Plivier's prime concern was to purge it of fiction -- to disengage historical truth from a welter of propaganda and supposition and present the real facts for exactly what they were.

MOSCOW, Aug. 19 (AP), by mail). -- First-hand contact with an acute case of bureaucracy was experienced recently within a stone's throw of the Kremlin by Daniel G. Sulimoff, President of the Council of People's Commissars of the Russian Socialist Federal Soviet Republic.

GREENWICH, Conn., Sept. 2 -- Tommy Goodwin of Monroe won the annual invitation golf tournament of the Greenwich Country Club today, defeating Eugene V. Homans of Englewood, 1 up in nineteen holes, in the final.

Notwithstanding the meticulous care exercised a year ago by the special committee charged with the work of recodifying the rules of the American Kennel Club, situations have developed which may require further alterations. In general, it is the policy of the governing body to let the rules stand throughout the year, submitting amendmments for action only at the annual meeting in February.

A crowd of 5,000 lined the Staten Island shore between New Dorp and Midland Beach yesterday afternoon to cheer the oarsmen from the Raritan Bay life-saving crew when they pulled over the finish line, winners of the annual dory race in which ten units of the United States Volunteer Life-Saving Corps competed.

SMITHTOWN, L.I., Sept. 2 -- The annual Smithtown Horse Show was held today at Fifty Acre Field, St. James. More than 1,000 persons witnessed the show, which was acclaimed as the most successful ever held.

CAMP PERRY, Ohio, Sept. 2 -- With a score only seventeen points less than the 1,100 maximum possible, T.P. Samsoe of Perth Amboy, N.J., tonight was announced the winner of the national smallbore rifle-shooting championship. His total was 1,083.

TORONTO, Ont., Sept. 2 -- Mineral production in Ontario in the first six months of this year had a total value of $43,326,782, a decline of $2,174,159 from the total in the same period of 1932. The figures include structural materials and clay products, amounting to $2,000,000 against $4,000,000 a year ago.

Why all the furor over adult education these days? Tens of thousands of formal and informal discussion groups and associations have come to life all over the United States in the past two years. The bulk of the men and women who form these groups are not unemployed.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 -- Estimates received from Civilian Conservation Corps camps today indicate that 100,000 men will retire from the corps between Oct. 1 and 15. Their places will be taken by new recruits.

DETROIT, Aug. 31 -- Interest among Detroit automobile factory employers and employes in the NRA motor industry code, which will take effect Sept. 5, centres chiefly on Section 7, which contains the modified open-shop provision over which hot controversy waged.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 -- July exports of $144,197,334 were larger than in the previous month to thirty-one of the forty principal foreign countries listed by the Department of Commerce and were also larger to all of the so-called geographical grand divisions.

BERLIN, Sept. 2 -- German "Aryan" film stars and lesser light who are now working abroad are warned more or less officially to return to Germany immediately or face the national ostracism already pronounced against the German Jews.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Sept. 2 -- Mrs. Gordon Wright's capable jumper, Sonny, carried off the blue ribbon in the touch-and-out competition, one of the feature classes at the fifth annual Saxon Woods Hunt Club's Horse Show today. Competing in a strong field, Mrs. Wright's entry survived a five-cornered jump-off to gain the honors.

The Sheffield Farms Company, a subsidiary of the National Dairy Products Corporation, announced yesterday that an increase of 10 to 12 per cent in the wages of 8,500 employes had been put into effect as of last Friday.

NEWPORT NEWS, Va., Sept. 2 (AP) -- A drama of a rescue from a burning ship at sea was unfolded here tonight by thirty-five survivors of the freighter Cold-water, which was in collision last night with the steamship Presiednt Wilson of the Dollar Line off Cape Lookout on the Carolina coast, eighty miles south of Hatteras.

NEW ORLEANS, Sept. 2 (AP) -- Chicago, Western sectional champion, defeated Trenton, N.J., Eastern titleholder, 7 to 6, in the deciding game of the 1933 junior world's series of American Legion baseball today.

WASHINGTON NEW interest is focused upon the Department of Justice for two reasons. One la the fact that, in the evolution of the New Deal, certain laws enacted by Congress may eventually be reviewed by the United States Supreme Court to determine their constitutionality.

THIS collection of Washington Irving's letters became known to Irving students only when it was presented, in 1928, to Harvard University. None of them has heretofore been published. With two exceptions, says Mr. Williams in his preface, it is the largest extant collection of letters written by Irving to any individual or family.

LONDON. SOME years ago a flippant newspaper reporter dubbed Dr. W.R. Inge "the Gloomy Dean." and the nickname has stuck, though there is really little justification for it. There would be much more reason for calling John Masefield "the Gloomy Laureate."
The Roosevelt administration has no intention of aiding Tammany in the city election, it was learned yesterday from a well-informed source.
BOSTON, Aug. 30 -- Who is the official almoner of Federal Democratic patronage in Massachusetts, the son of the President or the senior Senator of the State?

MOSCOW, Sept. 2 (AP) -- Edouard Herriot, former Premier of France, began a strenuous round of entertainment officially arranged in his honor today, but found time to interview Vyacheslaff Molotoff, President of the Council of Commissars.

BOSTON, Sept. 2 -- Toppling the Braves for the third straight time, the Giants today put just a trifle more pressure on a grip that threatens soon to decide the National League pennant race. The outcome silenced a crowd of 20,000.

IF Byron's Manfred did not symbolize the romantic unrest of the early nineteenth century it is doubtful whether the hero of "The Gold Falcon" would bear the name that he does. However personal his problem, and however obscurely it is delineated, the latter-day Manfred of this very curious novel is obviously afflicted by the general malaise which has beset the twentieth century.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Sept. 2 -- Special relief for New York holiday motorists has been provided, according to an announcement today by Leslie Holleran, deputy chief engineer of the Westchester park system. The Briarcliff-Crotonville cutoff was opened tonight as a new route for through traffic between New York and up-State points around Ossining, and eliminating one of the most congested points on the old Albany Post Road route.

GLENS FALLS, N.Y., Sept. 2 -- When play starts in the Glens Falls open golf tourney next Thursday on the Glens Falls Country Club course at Round Pond, three miles north of this city, more than 150 entries will be listed, representing the cream of professional golfdom.

THE mass energy of book collectors was too potent a thing to be denied by the disaster of 1929. Temporarily thwarted to the chief outlet for their enthusiasm, amateurs found new avenues of expression in discussions of the fine points and obscure ramifications of their game.

Roosevelt, Hitler and Mussolini are the three men in the world today attempting revolutionary changes in government and none knows which will be right, in the opinion of Henricus Nijgh, general director and principal owner of the Nieuw Amsterdam Courant, a leading newspaper of Holland.

SEASIDE PARK, N.J., Sept. 2 -- Chesapaake Bay, Delaware River, Barnegat Bay, Ocean City Gravesend Bay sloops of the International Star Class were forced to lower their colors today to a Long Island Sound champion when the Atkin brothers' Jubilee scored a smashing victory in the first race of the fifth annual Bamfaerger Cup series.

IF Casanova were alive today he would easily take his place among the unabashed amateurs swarming to cure the economic ills of the world. National governments would once more bear of his plan to raise revenues by a very special sort of State lottery be suavely planned for the France of Pompadour's day.

HIGHLAND PARK, Ill., Sept. 2 -- Miss Virginia Van Wie, 24-year-old Chicago star, retained her title as women's national golf champion at Exmoor today when she turned back Miss Helen Hicks of Hewlett, L.I., 4 and 3, in the thirty-six hole final.

The sharp decline in failures in the last three months, averaging about 40 per cent under 1932, was attributed yesterday to the increase in inventory values and to a spirit of patience, engendered by the National Recovery Act, by Henry H. Heimann, executive manager of the National Association of Credit Men.

LONDON, Sept. 2 -- Arthur Henderson was swept back into Parliament by a 3-to-1 plurality in yesterday's by-election in the Clay Cross division of Yorkshire, it was announced today. He had been without a seat in the House of Commons since the Labor Party's great debacle in 1931.

David A. Mahoney, Tammany leader of the eastern half of the First Assembly District, announced last night that he was supporting County Clerk Daniel E. Finn, his colleague in the western half of the district, in the primary fight being j made by John A. Hogan against Mr. Finn.

Branding as absurd the charge that the defeat of the United States Davis Cup team by England was to be attributed to too much tennis, Bernon S. Prentice, chairman of the American Davis Cup Committee, answered his critics yesterday in his official report to the membership of that body.
Complaints against employers evading the regulations of the NRA while displaying the Blue Eagle are increasing daily at local NRA headquarters at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

Obligations of the United States Government that will mature within the next twelve months amount to $2,950,886,200. They consist of Treasury certificates of indebtedness, notes and non-interest-bearing discount bills.

To the Editor at The New York Times: Relaxation of credit through advances of government loans to such, of the nation's 1,750,000 retailers as may need help offers an immediate and positive way out of the depression.

NAIROBI, Kenya, Africa, Sept. 3 -- One of Germany's grievances against the Versailles Treaty may be removed with news of the longlost skull of Sultan Mkwawa of Tanganyika, the chieftain who rebelled against the Germans during the war and committed suicide when on the point of being captured.
Seven crews, representing four nations, are awaiting the starter's gun for the annual international lifeboat race which is scheduled to take place this morning at 10:30 o'clock in New York Harbor.

Discussing the importance of work in a man's life, the Rev. Dr. Raymond L. Forman, preaching at St. Paul's Methodist Episcopal Church yesterday morning, said he hoped the shortened hours of lahor would be only a temporary measure. He spoke at the union services of St. Paul's and the Fourth Presbyterian Church.

CHICAGO, Sept. 3 -- Crop, returns are the most disappointing that the grain trade has known in years. Harvesting of small grains is virtually out of the way in the United States and in the Northwest threshing is well advanced, although somewhat delayed by heavy rains.

To the Editor of The New York Times : In N-Town are three carpenters. When the depression came, X could get little work and gradually let his men go. He hired them occasionally to help him at 50 cents an hour. Y felt a certain responsibility for his men, so he kept two of them on part time, paying them $15 a week for thirty-two hours' work.

The old way of earnest sincerity and simplicity "is the only way to substitute for the irregular cycles of giddy prosperity and sickening depression the steady upward plane of the road to Christ," the Rev. Dr. Ralph H. Long, executive secretary of the National Lutheran Council, sajd yesterday morning in a sermon at the Lutheran Church of St. James, Madison Avenue and Seventy-third Street.

NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 3 -- Among today's entertainments in the Summer colony was a musicals and tea given by Mrs. Drexel Dahlgren at her Bellevue Avenue home for eighty of her friends. Mrs. Dahlgren, who is an accomplished harpist, participated in the program.
To the Editor of The New York Times: Dr. W.B. Wolfe, on his return from Europe, says traveling is a lost art with Americans.

SAN JOSE, Cal., Sept. 3 (AP) -- David A. Lamson, fighting the State's accusation that the buldgeoned his wife to death, will bring a scientist to his defense this week in an effort to show that a fall caused her injuries.

BALTIMORE, Sept. 3 (AP) -- Blasting the pitching of Jim Weaver and Pete Jablonowski for a total of twenty-five hits, the Baltimore Orioles trounced Newark in both ends of today's double-header, 8 to 6 and 9 to 3.

BOSTON, Sept. 3 -- Clinging tenaciously to the imposing margin which they had compiled through weeks of tense battling, the Giants today completed the job of successfully repelling what had come to be known as the Boston uprising.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 (AP) -- The Federal Power Commission will undertake to lay down a rule to determine what one power company owes another for regulating the flow of a stream, at hearings beginning tomorrow on the Pacific Coast.

CAMP PERRY, Ohio, Sept. 3 -- A score exceeding the record of 1,963 was amassed by the American team of ten members in finishing the international small-bore Fidac rifle team match late today, a part of the small-bore rifle championship tournament.

EAST HAMPTON, L.I., Sept. 3 -- Mr. and Mrs. Robert Appleton gave an old-fashioned bathing party and luncheon for thirty persona on their private beach at Nid de Papillon today. Guests wore bathing suits of the gay Nineties, with high necks and long, roomy trousers.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Sept. 3 (AP) -- With hurricane warnings displayed between Miami and Melbourne, and storm signals south of Miami, residents of Florida's lower east coast prepared tonight for the reported approach of a severe tropical storm.
OTTAWA, Kan., Sept. 3 (AP) -- A family feud led to the wounding of two outlaw brothers and the capture of one today.

A period of restricted buying and price digestion for iron and steel, rather than the customary Fall upturn in demand, is forecast by the magazine Steel, which believes that fully two weeks will elapse before producers and consumers reach agreements on prices.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 3 (AP) -- The Browns closed their home season today with a 2-to-1 victory over the Tigers in the first game of a double-header and a 5-to-5 tie in the second, which was called after the ninth inning because of darkness.

Cheered by information that Tammany will receive no aid from the Roosevelt administration, independent Democrats prepared yesterday to organize to support Fiorello H. LaGuardia, Fusion candidate for Mayor, and the rest of the anti-Tammany ticket.

To the Editor of The New York Times : Inefficient and extravagant municipal government has placed our city in a bad financial position, but that is no reason why the destitute and unemployed should suffer. It apparently is necessary to raise forty-odd million dollars for relief.

MOSCOW, Sept. 3 -- A flood of light has been thrown upon the Soviet foreign policy and the Soviet attitude toward the swiftly changing European kaleidoscope by two facts this week and by the comment thereupon of the Soviet official press.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 -- Now comes another mathematician with what he hopes to be proof of Fermat's last theorem, an age-old enigma.

Moderate declines marked trading in the principal commodities on local markets last week, but operations were almost at a standstill in some instances and price changes were not important in any instance. Coffee and wool tops moved slightly higher on the futures markets, where sugars were virtually unchanged, while other staples declined moderately.

The marriage of Miss Margaret M. Stafford, caughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Karsner Stafford of 108 Bast Eighty-second Street, to Georges Metaxa, actor, of 40 East Sixty-sixth Street, will take place on Wednesday at Greenwich, Conn. Justice of the Peace William S. Fiske of Greenwich will perform the ceremony in the presence of Miss Stafford's parents and a few close friends.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 (AP) -- Cliff Bolton, rookie catcher, stepping up to the plate as a pinch-hitter with two out in the ninth inning today, slashed a clean single to left to give the Washington Senators a 3-to-2 victory over the Boston Red Sox.

In a communication to Newton D. Baker, chairman of the 1933 Mobilization for Human Needs, William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, warned yesterday that, despite an improvement in conditions, human need and suffering this Fall and Winter would continue to be great.
MOSCOW, Sept. 3 -- The Red Army's stratosphere balloon will make its first ascent next Wednesday from the Moscow Airfield, but the civilian balloon has postponed its ascent to late this month.

BRETTON WOODS, N.H., Sept. 3 -- Many parties were given at the Cave Grill of the Mount Washington here today on the eve of the holiday. Mr. and Mrs. Schuyler N. Rice and Mr. and Mrs. J.K. Rice Jr. gave suppers. Mr. and Mrs. William A. Gould of Brooklyn entertained Mr. and Mrs. James A. Gould.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 -- American labor was ready to salute tomorrow's Labor Day as the dawn of a new era for the worker, finding government, capital and employe joined in unprecedented war against economic foes.
With seven entered for the featured Fall Highweight Handicap, the Belmont Park Fall meeting will begin today.

CHICAGO, Sept. 3 (AP) -- Amy Johnson Mollison, young English veteran of many hard flights, believes she and her husband can better the world's long-distance record when they take off this Fall from America. Their ship, a duplicate of the one in which they crossed the Atlantic, will be ready in two weeks.

CHICAGO, Sept. 3 (AP) -- The lives of an undetermined number of race horses were imperiled tonight by fire which swept, five barns at the Hawthorne race track. The blaze was well under way when it was discovered in barn No. 5, and, fanned by a brisk breeze, spread rapidly.

A split between two factions of the Armenian Apostolic Church of the United States and Canada seemed imminent last night when one of the groups withdrew from the second session of the annual general assembly in St. Gregory the Illuminator's Church, 221 East Twenty-seventh Street.

HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Sept. 3 -- Former Lieut. Gov. Jeremiah Wood and eleven other officers and directors of the closed First National Bank of Hempstead have been named defendants in a depositor's suit. Each is held individually responsible for approximately $870,000, it was announced here today by Charles A.C. Kelly, the plaintiff.

TREBEURDEN, France, Sept. 3 (AP) -- Foreign Minister Joseph Paul-Boncour, reiterating his country's determination to safeguard the independence of Austria, declared today: "France is strong enough to resist any attempts at violence."

CHICAGO, Sept. 3 -- Packers and live-stock interests are uncertain about the future supply of hogs. Upward of 1,400,000 pigs have been sold to the government by farmers in the last two -weeks and 2,000,000 more are to be bought by Oct. 1. Indications are that the government will get Its quota of pigs easily, but buying a million sows is different.

Interpretations of the National Recovery Act in terms of its spiritual substance and needs were undertaken in a number of New York churches yesterday.
NEW YORK. Mr. and Mrs. James Edwards Wyckoff, who are passing the week-end at Montrose, Pa., will return tomorrow to the Plaza.
ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Sept. 3 -- When traditionally dry Vermont votes next Tuesday "it will go for repeal two to one," James A. Farley said here today.

PITTSFIELD, Mass., Sept. 3 -- Announcement of the winners of the Crowninshield Memorial prizes given by Mrs. Carl A. deGersdorff was made at the Stockbridge exhibition varnishing day yesterday afternoon. Jane MacLane (Mrs. John C. Johansen), received an award for her oil portrait of William Gillette.
CHICAGO, Sept. 3 (AP) -- Flashing back to the form of other years, the veteran Dazzy Vance fanned nine Cubs today, the Cardinals winning by 3 to 1 in the opening game of the series.

Three young prisoners made a spectacular escape from the Tombs Prison early yesterday afternoon. Despite almost immediate police pursuit, they managed to reach a rabbit warren of areaways and corridors in the old-law tenements of Mulberry Street and eluded capture.
NUREMBERG, Sept. 3 -- The main parts of Chancellor Hitler's closing address to the National Socialist congress here today follow:

PARIS, Sept. 3 -- While Hitlerite Germany was holding her huge demonstration in Nuremberg, France also held a great ceremony which not even the national mourning for Minister of Marine Georges Leygues could postpone. It was the dedication of a monument to the late Aristide Briand, France's "apostle of peace."

CHICAGO, Sept. 3 -- The French entry in the James Gordon Bennett International balloon races, which started with six contestants here bust evening, came down this afternoon in a cornfield near Homer, Mich., southeast of Battle Creek and about 175 miles in a straight line from Chicago.
CHICAGO, Sept. 3 (AP) -- Wesley Ferrell had little trouble getting his eleventh victory of the season today as the Indians pounded three White Sox pitchers for a 14-to-3 triumph.

PARIS, Sept. 2 -- The tendency on the Bourse this week again showed great irregularity, characterized by alternations of firm and weak days. On the whole, business was quiet, although on Friday the market showed signs of becoming more lively.

WARSAW, Sept. 3 -- Marshal Joseph Pilsudski has been invited to Moscow as the guest of the Soviet Government to participate in the Red Army Celebrations on the anniversary of the Bolshevist revolution, Nov. 7.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 (AP) -- Representative Hoidale, Democrat, of Minnesota, who has just returned from a visit to the Scandinavian countries of Europe, in a statement issued yesterday declared he found those people intensely interested in the recovery program of President Roosevelt.

Observers on the financial watchtowers, whose glass swept the horizon for signs of the "Autumn movement," have often had an incorrigible habit of reckoning Labor Day as the deadline between mid-Summer inactivity and Autumn trade revival. This usually brought profound disappointment during the rest of September, because as a matter of fact the speeding up of Autumn business activity, even in prosperous business years, rarely began until a month or more after the holiday.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Sept. 3 -- Mr. and Mrs. Charles H. Sabin gave a dinner tonight at Bayberry Land, their estate in the Shinnecock Hills, for Mrs. William B. Scaife, who has been visiting Mr. and Mrs. Sidney W. Fish at their home in East Hampton and who joined Mr. and Mrs. Sabin today for the holiday.

WESTBURY, L.I., Sept. 3 -- Playing in a heavy rain which started just before game time, Stephen Sanford's Hurricane quartet and John Hay Whitney's Greentree team battled to an 8-to-8 deadlock on Whitney Field of the Meadow Brook Club today.
