LONDON, Sept. 3 -- The tension on the Austro-German frontier continues to give the British Government so much anxiety that it will be one of the chief issues discussed at the Cabinet meeting Tuesday.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 -- Private enterprise has failed to supply the low-cost type of housing which is contemplated by the Public Works Administration, Secretary Ickes said today in denying that lending for this purpose placed the administration in competition with private builders.

CHICAGO, Sept. 3 (AP) -- The American Farin Bureau Federation appealed to day to domestic sugar producers and refiners to oppose any code under the Agricultural Adjustment Act that would put American sugar on a quota basis in comparison with the foreign product.
The significance of Labor Day in the religious life of the nation was discussed in many sermons in the city's churches yesterday.

For the first time since the New York Canoe Club International Challenge Cup was placed in competition by that organization, in 1885, the trophy was lifted yesterday by two foreign decked-canoe sailors. The successful men were Uffa Fox and Roger De Quincey, representing the Royal Canoe Club of London.

ARMONK, N.Y., Sept. 3 -- Ploughing through the mud of a course made sodden and slippery by a continuous downpour, the veteran bay gelding Precaution, owned by Mrs. Julius Bliss of Bronxville, N.Y., and ridden by Hubert Mosely, triumphed handsomely in the first Westchester Embassy Club horse show today.
The body of General Francesco da Pinedo will be taken home to his native Italy for burial, it was announced last night.

STOCKBRIDGE, Mass., Sept. 3. -- Richard Rogers Bowker, author, editor and publisher of New York, president of R.R. Bowker Company, will observe tomorrow his eighty-fifth birthday at his country place, Glendale Outlook, where, with Mrs. Bowker, he is passing the Summer.

NEW HAVEN, Sept. 3 -- Professor Irving Fisher's index number of commodity prices, based on 100 as the average for 1926, is 70.8, which compares with 70.4 a week ago, 70.3 two weeks ago, 70.3 three weeks ago and 70.6 four weeks ago, before the July reaction.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 -- Two tropical hurricanes, one of which already has claimed scores of lives, were reported by the Weather Bureau tonight to be roaring out of the Caribbean Sea and Gulf of Mexico toward Florida and Texas.

LONDON, Sept. 2 -- The excitement which, arose suddenly in the foreign exchange market toward the end of last week and continued through the first half of this week has subsided to a large extent, current movements and business being similar to the inactivity and steadiness which had prevailed for the greater part of the last month.

ARMONK VILLAGE, N.Y., Sept. 3 -- Hugh Samuel Jarvis Jr., 23 years old, of 10 ElK Avenue, New Rochelle, son of a New York business man, was drowned at dawn today in Kensico Lake. The lake, a reservoir, is part of the New York City water-supply system. Swimming in it is prohibited.

HOUSTON, Texas, Sept. 3 (AP) -- A hurricane, reported to be the most devastating of a season that has been marked by unexampled fury of the elements, roared toward the Texas coast tonight, apparently but a few hours away.

Grarton County in New Hampshire is "well and favorably known " for its woods and lakes and mountains. To it belong WHITTIER'S "winding ways of Pemigewasset," not to apeak of the Lower Ammonoosuc and of the Connecticut on the western marge. Some of the dizziest White Mountain heights are proud to rise from Graftoa County.

NEW ORLEANS, Sept. 3 -- The cotton market here was quieter last week than it has been in many weeks. Even hedge selling was less than common, notwithstanding the increasing movement of the new crop to market. Foreign dispatches indicated that the desire to hold off for developments prevailed abroad as well as in the markets on this side of the Atlantic.

MONTREAL, Sept. 3 (AP) -- Gerard Machado, deposed President of Cuba, declared upon his arrival here today that he is "willing and even eager to go back to Cuba to stand either military or civil trial if Cuba gives me a guarantee of nay personal safety."

LONDON, Sept. 2 -- The stock markets continue to display activity and firmness wholly exceptional for this period of the year. Signs of better trade and underlying firmness in commodity prices are favoring factors. Cheap money, while helping industry, is also continuing to buoy up investment securities, while government funds are receiving additional stimulus from the satisfactory manner in which the national revenue is coining in.

CAMP DIX, N.J., Sept. 3 -- Support of the NRA was pledged today to General Hugh S. Johnson by veterans of the Seventy-eighth or "Lightning" Division at their annual reunion here. The gathering marked the sixteenth anniversary of the arrival here of the first 5 per cent quota called to the colors in the national army by President Wilson.

HERSHEY, Pa., Sept. 3 -- Deploring "a return to selfishness" which, he said had taken place among the American people in the last month, Secretary Wallace said today that the new social machinery being built at Washington would fail "unless there is a change in the human heart."

The beginning of the end of the Summer theatrical season is here -- along with Labor Day -- and the number of new plays, as well as the list of stock presentations, in the rural show-shops this week mark the wane. Eight -- according to the unofficial count -- is the total of new plays to be seen.

Rain dampened the ardor of thousands of New Yorkers spending the Labor Day holidays at nearby coast and mountain resorts yesterday. With more rain promised for today, transportation officials prepared for an early rush homeward.

BERLIN, Sept. 2 -- The week's stock markets opened with the reappearance of the public as buyers and witnessed a sharp recovery, but pronounced weakness In J.G. Barbenindustrie and Siemens Halske led to new selling and many stocks touched the lowest levels of the year.

HAVANA, Sept. 3 -- The government moved today to send relief to the hurricane sufferers in the district along the north coast of Santa Clara and Matanzas Provinces, where the casualty list neared 100 killed and 650 injured. No estimate can yet be made of the property damage, which is believed to run into the millions of dollars.

CINCINNATI, Sept. 3 (AP) -- The Pirates' headlong drive, in which they had won eight straight games, was stopped today by the tail-end Reds, who beat them, 9 to 3, although both teams got twelve hits.

CHICAGO, Sept. 3 -- A holiday crowd of 25,000 persons at Curtiss Wright-Reynolds Airport today saw military and civilian flying of a high order. As an earnest of what may come tomorrow when an attempt will be made to break the land plane speed record, they saw James R. Weddell of Patterson, La., make an average over the three-kilometer course of 296.94 miles an hour.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 -- True to tradition, the biggest fish got away from President Roosevelt's fishing party today.

Taxes on the gross earnings of public utilities, brokerage houses and taxicab companies and an increased water rate have been approved by the Tammany board of strategy as the sources for the new revenue the city must raise, it was disclosed last night.

GRAFTON, Vt., Sept. 3 -- "What we need is not more laws but more men," Representative Samuel B. Pettengill of Indiana declared in an address at the celebration here today of the 100th anniversary of the building of the "Brick Meeting House."

Thousands of families in New York City will be getting children ready for school for the first time next week. There will be many things to think of in equipping them for their new jobs, for they, too, have a five-day week of employment ahead of them -- employment in fitting themselves above all to be citizens.

Handling of the city's finances by John F. Curry, leader of Tammany, and Mayor O'Brien has brought its $1.500,000,000 subway system to the pawnshop and has doomed the 5-cent fare. Representative Loring M. Black Jr., candidate for the Democratic nomination for Mayor, declared yesterday.

Hitler Discovers Apion, HITLER'S chief contribution to the Nazi festival at Nuremberg was a philoaophical discourse on race and art. Its conclusions may be easily guessed. Every race, said HITLER, has its own form of artistic expression, unless, "like the Jews, it has no artistic creative power of its own at all."

ALBANY, Sept. 3 -- The decline in business activities and the consistent reduction of liabilities and losses paid by joint stock and mutual fire and marine insurance companies authorized in New York State during 1932 was summed up in a statement today by George S. Van Schaick, State Superintendent of Insurance, on the report of this department.

The Game Conservation Institute, located at Clinton, N.J., the only place of its kind in the world, may be forced to close on Oct. 1, it was announced yesterday by Arthur M. Bartley, director of field activities.
More than half the women interviewed on the subject have informed investigators of the local NRA committee that they intend to buy only goods manufactured under the Blue Eagle.
LARCHMONT, N.Y., Sept. 3 -- Miss Lorna Whittelsey added another triumph to her long collection today.

Stephen J. Madigan, an attorney, who is a candidate for the nomination for Controller in the Democratic primaries, issued a statement yesterday enumerating ten points of a city recovery plan on which he will base his campaign.

Art's exuberant carnival in Washington Square folds its tents at sundown tonight. This is the fourth show in the open-air bargain-counter series. Each recurrence seems more spirited than the last; and if discoveries of consequence be scarcer than lark puddings, at any rate there can be none to gainsay that the occasion is, as usual, lushly upholstered.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 3 -- Any attempt by either labor or industry to make selfish capital out of adjustments incident to the National Recovery Act should meet with "universal condemnation," W.W. Atterbury, president of the Pennsylvania Railroad, asserted in an address prepared for delivery over the National Broadcasting System tonight.

NUREMBERG, Sept. 3 Germany's greatest National Socialist demonstration thus far reached its climax today with a parade of more than 100,000 storm troopers with 15,000 Nazi flags, each with a color guard. About 150,000 men altogether were in line, and at least 250,000 spectators in a frenzy of enthusiasm over the brave show they made watched them pass.

DETROIT, Sept. 3 -- After a lapse of six years, the Dodge Memorial Trophy for speed craft was raced for today on the Detroit River. It was won by Horace E. Dodge with his new boat, Delphine VII, which his sister, Mrs. Delphine Dodge Baker, drove in the Gold Cup contest.

A national conference of Kosher butchers, made up of delegates from most of the larger cities in the nation, convened yesterday in the Hotel Pennsylvania to pass resolutions modifying the original kosher butchers' code submitted by the Federation of Kosher Butchers of New York to General Hugh S. Johnson on July 6.

BIG BAY, Mich., Sept. 3 -- By remaining in seclusion in his Huron Mountain Club "cabin" over the week-end, Henry Ford gave some indication that he might let Tuesday's deadline for signing the automobile code pass without definite action on his part in his controversy with the NRA.

STAMFORD, Conn., Sept. 3 -- After being an hour behind last night as the boats rounded the Vineyard Haven lightship, Philip Le Boutillier's sloop Alsumar, from Cold Spring Harbor, was first to finish tonight in the annual Stamford Yacht Club race to Vineyard Haven lightship and return.

Mayor O'Brien, who touched even the hardest heart during his campaign with wistful reminiscence of the land of his forebears, is "in dutch." with the Irish. At least, that is, with the Irish-Americans of Staten Island.

VINCENNES, Ind., Sept. 3 (AP) -- The winning of the old Northwest Territory for the United States and the achievements of George Rogers Clark and his associates in the war of the American Revolution were commemorated here today on the sesquicentennial anniversary of the Peace of Paris, which, ended the Revolutionary War.

WEST PALM BEACH, Fla., Sept. 3 (AP) -- Buffeting winds and pounding seas along a 150-mile strip of the Florida East Coast late tonight presaged the approach of a tropical hurricane which swirled through the Bahamas today with wind velocities as high as 110 miles per hour.

IT now becomes absolutely necessary to survey the personnel of the Giants and Senators and weigh their respective chances in the big baseball series up ahead. It is nothing less than a solemn duty and will be done with as much scientific accuracy as possible under the circumstances.

To raise funds for the Social Service Auxiliary of the Metropolitan Hospital and for the Emergency Tuberculosis Relief Committee, a fashion show will be held at the Waldorf-Astoria on Oct. 5. There will be a showing of early Autumn and Winter fashions, furs and jewels for all occasions during the luncheon hour and also during dinner.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 -- Support for the domestic recovery program in order to attain higher living standards for all classes was asked by Secretary Perkins in her Labor Day message made public tonight. Better health and more education will produce better citizens and members of society, she predicted, as a result of the fulfillment of the NRA program.

PARIS, Sept. 2 -- The prevailing opinion among French financiers is that the economic recovery experiment undertaken by President Roosevelt will soon encounter serious difficulties when it becomes necessary to maintain prices at a level sufficiently high to allow manufacturers to meet the burden imposed upon them by raising wages and decreasing working hours.

BERLIN, Sept. 2 -- Discussions of the continued weakness of dollar bonds on the Berlin Boerse in banking circles here this week indicated a widely held opinion that no purely economic threat to maintenance of the recently reduced interest service on the bonds exists.

PRAGUE, Sept. 3 (Jewish Telegraphic Agency) -- An appeal to the United States Government and to the American people, together with the League of Nations, to help the Jews was contained in a resolution submitted by the political commission to the World Zionist Congress at its final session here tonight.

ESSEX, Conn., Sept. 3. -- Henry M. Parmly, 50 years old, New York broker, disappeared while swimming in the Connecticut River near his auxiliary schooner yacht the Seguin late this afternoon and is believed to have been drowned. State police and Coast Guard patrols have been searching for his body without success.

Our team came through a most successful American Zone campaign, defeating Mexico and Canada in the North American Zone and Argentina in the Inter-American Zone final in Washington, Lott and Van Ryn played especially fine doubles and did not lose a set in any of these matches nor in the inter zone final in Paris.

Mr. CURRY of Tammany Hall has today many enemies rising up against him, but what a grand and majestic figure he is amid all the storms that beat upon him Others are troubled and anxious about the city's finances. The Mayor and the Controller show signs of nervousness. Even Mr. UNTERMYER has an occasional doubt concerning the wisest thing to be done.
After a day of lull, the firing will be resumed in the men's national tennis championship at Forest Hills today, with all of the big guns going into action.

The last previous jail-breaking attempt at the Tombs was on Nov. 3, 1926, when five persons were shot and killed in an unsuccessful effort of a trio of desperados to shoot their way to liberty. Those killed were Warden Peter J. Mallon, Keeper Jeremiah Murphy and prisoners named McKenna, Berg and Amberg, all three of whom had been arrested for crimes of violence.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 3 -- The change from an open steel market to a closely regulated one, by reason of the code, has been advanced as a reason for the dullness in the trade last week, although sellers do not suggest that otherwise the market would have been active.

No passage in literature may more pertinently be recalled on this Labor Day than the chapter in the Book of Ecclesiasticus (the Wisdom of the Son of Sirach) which speaks of the joy in creative labor and also of the wisdom that comes by opportunity of leisure." The very instruments of man's inventing which, have taken away so much of the former have given the latter to millions.

OYSTER BAY, L.I., Sept. 3 -- John Foster Dulles's Sculpin, a Fish Class boat, was the winner today of the fourteenth annual Stratford Shoals race, sponsored by the Seawanhaka Corinthian Yacht Club. The Sculpin was victorious in this forty-mile test on corrected time, barely beating out another Fish boat, Elliott Cross's Manatee, by seven seconds.

CHICAGO, Sept. 3 -- Supplies of oats are light, with prospects that there will be a, scarcity. This situation has invited heavy purchases of cash and futures by consuming interests. Speculators, who believe oats should sell higher and nearer to corn, are buying on all weak spots.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Sept. 3 -- Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of Columbia University, proposed today four changes whereby, he said, the American Federal form of government could and should be "readily and quickly improved and strengthened for its mighty task" of meeting the revolutionary forces he saw at large throughout the world and of preserving democracy.

OYSTER BAY, L.I., Sept. 3 Plans are complete for the benefit fashion show and outdoor entertainment to be given at Mallow, the estate of Mr. and Mrs. Walter Farwell at Syosset, for the Oyster Bay Visiting Nurse and Relief Fund, by society women of the Long Island Summer colonies next Sunday afternoon.

GREENWICH, Conn., Sept. 3 -- An outstanding society event of the early Fall season will be an American preview of Tchaikovsky's oneact lyric drama, "lolanthe," which will take place on the estate of Mrs. Valeria Langeloth Bonham, in Greenwich, on Saturday evening, Sept. 9.

PORT JEFFERSON, L.I., Sept. 3 -- More than $10,000 worth of gambling devices, including two roulette wheels, dice, chips and three slot machines, were seized in a raid at the Belle Terre Lodge here early this morning. State troopers from Port Jefferson and Bay Shore entered the place as a dance was in progress.

For several years President BUTLER has surveyed the state of the nation in an address at about this date at the Art Museum in Southampton. Speaking' yesterday, at a time when, as he said, the world is " more politically anxious than it has ever been," 'Dr. BUTLER sought to quiet feara and restore confidence by dwelling upon the fundamentals of all government.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 -- The open-shop issue, which for three weeks has revolved around administration of the labor sections of the National Industrial Recovery Act, cropped out anew today when Henry I. Harriman, president of the Chamber of Commerce of the United States, took the field for industry in resistance to labor's demands.

It is not In the Constitution but in the character of the people that the foundations for peace and prosperity are to be found, the Rev. Dr. James McCullough Farr, associate pastor of the Brick Presbyterian Church, Fifth Avenue and Thirtyseventh Street, declared in his sermon yesterday morning.

MONTPELIER, Vt., Sept. 3 (AP) -- The final drive for votes for repeal or retention of the Eighteenth Amendment closed today. On Tuesday the State votes on the question of repeal and the partisans who have waged campaigns for months in their search for support prepared to rest during Labor Day.

MONTPELIER, Vt., Sept. 3 (AP) -- The final drive for votes for repeal or retention of the Eighteenth Amendment closed today. On Tuesday the State votes on the question of repeal and the partisans who have waged campaigns for months in their search for support prepared to rest during Labor Day.

Armando Cruz, 18 years old and unemployed, sat on one of the front benches in Yorkville Court yesterday morning. Beside him sat Crusita Feliciano, also 18, and near by were Crusita's parents. It was to be the young couple's wedding day and they were very happy.

SEASIDE PARK, N.J., Sept. 3 -- Long Island Sound's heavy weather champion, Jubilee, found the rough going in the second and third races for the Bamberger Trophy to her liking today. She scored a double victory to win the Star Class series with a perfect score of 42 points.

Fresco Painting, a short book by Gardner Hale, the young American artist who did much to revive the old art of fresco, has just been published by William Edwin Rudge. Mr. Hale was killed in an automobile accident late in 1931, when his book was almost complete.

Charles R. Dunn, fiscal agent for the Federal Intermediate Credit Banks, announced yesterday that the September financing for the system would take the form of a new issue of $30,000,000 of 2 1/2 per cent collateral trust debentures. Public offering of these debentures, which will be made soon, will provide for the refunding of the system's maturities occurring this month and additional capital for new business.

CHICAGO, Sept. 4. -- Florence E. Klingensmith, 25-year-old Minneapolis flier, plunged to her death at 220 miles an hour in the Phillips Trophy 100-mile speed race at the close of the international air meet here today.

HAVANA, Tuesday, Sept. 5. -- Noncommissioned officers and privates at Camp Columbia and San Ambrosio military post late yesterday afternoon seized command and demanded the immediate removal of commissioned officers who had supported the Machado government, it was learned at midnight.

TOKYO, Sept. 4. -- Under pressure of demands from American, British and French nationalists for equal treatment with Japanese residents in Mexico, who enjoy exceptionally favorable arrangements, the Mexican Government has approached Japan relative to revision of the 1925 trade convention.

EAST HAMPTON, L.I., Sept. 4. -- Tonight's Labor Day ball at the Devon Yacht Club brought a large gathering. Mr. and Mrs. Graham Youngs gave a dinner for their house guests, Mr. and Mrs. Clinton S. Lutkins of Rye and Curt E. Hanson.

The Armenian Apostolic Church of the United States and Canada had two central councils functioning yesterday, one comprising the opponents of Archbishop Leon Tourian, American primate, and the other consisting of his supporters.

That most intelligent Americans are still strangers to GEORGE ROGERS CLARK'S story of the conquest of the Northwest is due mainly to the fact that "historical scholarship in America "has been dominated, until almost the "present day, by men of the Atlantic "seaboard, and chiefly of New Eng"land."

BERLIN, Sept. 4. -- The downward trend on the Berlin Stock Exchange, interrupted for a few days by the intervention of banks, was resumed today at an accelerated pace. The tone at today's session, the first after the Nazi gathering at Nuremberg, was very weak.

Details of the elephant hunt in which F. Trubee Davison, president of the American Museum of Natural History, and Mrs. Davison were charged by a great bull, are related in a letter to his sons by Mr. Davison. Excerpts from the letter were made public yesterday at the museum.
Before a disappointingly small crowd the Fall meeting at Belmont Park began yesterday with the Sage Stable's Microphone the winner of the featured Highweight Handicap.

BERLIN, Sept. 4. -- The government of Adolf Hitler is now concentrating all its efforts on meeting the dangers of the coming Winter. These dangers consist principally of the usual rise of unemployment following the harvest and of an increased risk of suffering owing to the numerous Nazi measures that have deprived many Germans of their livelihood and many more of the State support which they formerly drew.

LEWISTON, Me., Sept. 4 (AP). -- A threat to kidnap Princess di Sirignano, the former Janet Snowden, with the object of taking her to Italy, native land of her husband Don Francisco Caravita, Prince di Sirignano, a prominent sportsman, whom she left five days after their marriage, was revealed here tonight.

VIENNA, Sept. 4. -- The Austrian Government, despite Nazi outrages and pressure from its own Heimwehr members, will not establish concentration camps for its enemies, according to a speech made by Chancellor Dollfuss in Weltersdorf, Lower Austria, yesterday.

FREEPORT, L.I., Sept. 4. -- After a night in a disabled craft nine miles off Babylon, a fishing party of eight persons, including three women, were towed into Freeport this morning, ending a twelve-hour search by Coast Guards and others.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 4. -- Important developments in connection with the administration's financial and banking programs are expected to unfold soon after the return of President Roosevelt to the capital.

The centuries looked down yesterday as the man who blackened the eye of Senator Huey P. Long in the washroom of the Sands Point (L.I.) Bath Club on the night of Aug. 26 took his place beside the Noble Six Hundred and the thirty-four "starving" McQuades in the realm of anonymous immortals.

MARINE CITY, Mich., Sept. 4. -- Gar Wood, white haired veteran who has campaigned in speed boats for more than a quarter of a century, today successfully defended for the eighth time the Harmsworth Trophy, world premier motor boat prize he brought here from England thirteen years ago.

Noting the list of books written by Mr. R.R. BOWKER and his activities in various fields, one is ready to call him a modern DEMOCRITUS. The cheerful ancient philosopher of that name had a range of interest and knowledge extending from physics to epic poems, from art to prognostics, from agriculture to laws.

LAKEWOOD, N.J., Sept. 4. -- Morton C. Steinberg, local attorney representing a group of utility consumers seeking reductions in gas, water and electric rates, announced today that he had received a letter from Ferdinand Pecora, counsel for the Senate committee investigating banking, stating that Mr. Pecora will call upon him to present his evidence of alleged discrimination to the Senate committee.

As thousands stood with bowed heads, the coffin of the Most Rev. John J. Dunn, Bishop Auxiliary of the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York, was taken late yesterday afternoon from the Church of the Annunciation, Convent Avenue and West 131st Street, to St. Patrick's Cathedral, where a congregation which packed the edifice was waiting to pay a last tribute.

Although Hervey Allen's long novel, "Anthony Adverse," continues as the national best seller, it is in fourth place on the rental library list compiled by Baker Taylor, book wholesalers. This firm says the probable reason is that a reader must be fairly industrious to finish the book in two weeks.
DALLAS, Sept. 4 (AP). -- Federal investigators expressed the opinion that assistance from "inside" made possible the escape of Harvey Bailey.

One of the outstanding leases reported by brokers yesterday was a contract signed by the Emerson Radio and Phonograph Corporation for 40,000 square feet of space in the Port Authority Commerce Build- ing at 111 Eighth Avenue.

If the pleasures of multitudes were spoiled and the expected profits of many lost in the rains of Sunday and Monday, out of that seeming evil let us deduce what good we can, though it be purely symbolic. On Sunday at Willowbrook Park in Staten Island the Ancient Order of Hibernians of Richmond County was trying to keep its annual high festival.

HOUSTON, Texas, Sept. 4 (AP). -- High winds and angry seas lashed the Texas coast this afternoon as the forerunner or a severe tropical hurricane expected to blow inland shortly from the Gulf of Mexico with damaging force.

Fish Don't Prefer Presidents. The first real break in the Roosevelt luck has just occurred in the waters off the eastern end of Long Island. By no stretch of the imagination can the results of the President's fishing trip be called impressive: half a doaen bass and a few porgies.

The coat and suit code signed by President Roosevelt on Aug. 5 has done more within a month to stabilize that industry and to eliminate sub-standard production than more than a decade of effort without government support. This report was made yesterday by Samuel Klein, director of the Industrial Council of Cloak, Suit and Skirt Manufacturers, Inc.

One of the three young prisoners who escaped from the Tombs Prison was in the hands of the police yesterday and detectives expressed confidence that the other fugitives would be caught within a few days.
Blue Monday, the nemesis of tennis for the past three weeks in the women's singles and the men's doubles, overtook the men's national championship singles at Forest Hills yesterday.

INDIANAPOLIS, Sept. 4 (AP). -- Although three of the four events of the opening Grand Circuit races at the State Fair Grounds today were decided in straight heats, close finishes marked most of the heats.
LAKE HOPATCONG, N.J., Sept. 4. -- Fourteen-year-old Peter Cristopolus has been returned to Father Flanagan's Boys' Home in Omaha and will not be adopted by the Strengs family.

UNIONTOWN, Pa., Sept. 4. -- Governor Pinchot, who is expected to oppose Senator Reed in next year's Senatorial contest, attacked Mr. Reed in an address before miners and labor leaders at a mass meeting here today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 4. -- The American Red Cross responded to- day with $10,000 cash, trained relief workers and supplies to requests received from the Cuban Government through the State Department for assistance in dealing with the emergencies created by the hurricane.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 4. -- The Pirates moved to within seven and a half games of the idle Giants today as they prepared for a five-game series opening here with the league leaders tomorrow. Pittsburgh took the single game from the Reds, 1 to 0, to cut the Terrymen's margin by a half game.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Sept. 4. -- Firenze Fairfax, Mrs. M. Robert Guggenheim's well known chestnut jumper, carried off the honors in the touch-and-out competition, one of the outstanding events on the opening day's program of the ninety-third annual New York State horse show today.

The Socialist party refused yesterday to employ the organization's machinery to further the local NRA consumer canvass beginning today. The other political parties have thrown their organizations into the movement in response to an appeal by Grover A. Whalen, city chairman of the President's Emergency Re-employment Committee.

The level of prices on the New York Stock Exchange, viewed from the standpoint of a European investor, has thus far failed to attain the highest point reached in September last year. It has actually hovered 3 to 8 points below that level since the end of May, excepting a period of several weeks following the July break.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 4. -- The Columbia University Rowing Club's intermediate quadruple sculls made up of past and present Blue and White oarsmen, finished second in the forty-second annual Middle States regatta on the Schuylkill River today.

BOSTON, Sept. 4 (AP). -- Secretary of Labor Frances Perkins, in a radio address which was part of a Labor Day program here tonight, said that the Department of Labor, dedicated to the working people of America, was being administered for their protection and suggested a program for the prevention of unemployment in the future.

BUTLER, N.J., Sept. 4. -- James Overton, 26 years old, of 2,635 Columbia Avenue, Philadelphia, was bitten by two copperhead snakes today in the cellar of a cottage at Fayson Lake, near here, where he was spending the week-end.
New York sat at home yesterday and watched through windows clouded with driving sheets of rain, the passing into history of another Labor Day week-end.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., Sept. 4. -- The twelve meter sloop Iris, John K. Roosevelt's eight-meter Roulette III and Robert McC. Shields's Interclub Canvasback were among the winners in the Larchmont Yacht Club's annual Fall regatta today.

PRAGUE, Sept. 4. -- The World Zionist Congress in its final session today re-elected Nahum Sokolow president of the Zionist Organization and elected a new executive containing representatives of only two parties -- the left wing of the main Zionist party and the Labor party.
MONTPELIER, Vt., Sept. 4 (AP). -- With the issue in doubt and the weather and the size of the vote unknown factors, Vermont tomorrow will ballot to repeal or retain the Eighteenth Amendment.

The relief fund being raised by the American Jewish Joint Distribution Committee to aid destitute Jews in Germany has reached a total of $1,092,768, Rabbi Jonah B. Wise, national chairman of the money raising effort, said yesterday.
To the Editor of The New York Times: I would like to submit for your consideration a few facts affecting the restaurant business in its effort to conform to the requirements of the NRA.
DETROIT, Sept. 4 (AP). -- Elden Auker, rookie hurler, after several false starts, today scored a victory for Detroit, winning, 5 to 4, over Chicago.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 4. -- Presi- dent Roosevelt will return to the White House tomorrow to face two of the most serious problems arising out of the National Recovery program -- the coal code and Henry Ford.

Football practice in this city will be the order of the next few weeks. The Manhattan College candidates and aspirants for berths on the C.C.N.Y. eleven will report to their respective coaches today, and will bring the list of local colleges participating in pre-season drills to three.
Jules Henry, counselor of the French Embassy at Washington, is to sail today for Paris on the French liner Ile de France. Others leaving on the liner for Havre via Plymouth include:

HUNTINGTON, L.I., Sept. 4. -- The Rev. J.M. Burke of Mineola was believed to have suffered a fractured skull in addition to other injuries when he was struck by an automobile near Jericho Turnpike and New York Avenue here this evening.

CHICAGO, Sept. 4 (AP). -- Trey, born down in Old Virginia, captured the $2,500 added Joliet handicap for 2-year-olds, the opening day feature of the eighteen-day meeting at Lincoln Fields today, beating Dan Sabath, a 50-to-0 shot, by a length and a half.

NUREMBERG, Sept. 4. -- The great rally of the National Socialist party, concluded last night, was followed by a new boycott of several Jewish stores in Nuremberg today. Brown shirted troopers and other Nazi men and women stood before the doors and warned customers that the shops were Jewish in so impressive a manner that no one dared go inside.

All markets will reopen today after having been closed since Friday afternoon. The banks and other business organizations which shut for the two-day Labor Day week-end will also resume operations as usual today. Most of the Wall Street community took the full three-day leave.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Sept. 4. -- Prince and Princess Irbain-Kahn Kaplanoff gave a luncheon today at the Beach Club for the princess's son-in-law and daughter, Mr. and Mrs. Crosby Tuttle Smith, who returned recently from Bermuda and are passing the holiday with them at Woodhull House.

ARDMORE, Okla., Sept. 4. -- Harvey Bailey, one of the nation's most desperate criminals, was captured at the end of a wild automobile chase here today four hours after he made a sensational escape from the county jail at Dallas by using a smuggled pistol.

Whether the airship Akron, which was blown down off the New Jersey coast and destroyed, was structurally perfect or not, Vice President HUNSAKER of the Goodyear Zeppelin Corporation, speaking: at the Automotive Engineering Congress, was sound in his contention that "the United States " has been proceeding too rapidly in " the training of the lighter-than-air "personnel."

AKRON, Ohio, Sept. 4. -- Court action against violators of NRA collective bargaining provisions was threatened today by William Green as he reminded employers that "labor has the right to organize 100 per cent without interference or restraint."

RYE, N.Y., Sept. 4. -- Juan Carlos Zabala, Argentina's Olympic marathon champion, made the first start of his new American campaign today in the fifteenth annual five-mile road race of the Rye Community A. C. The slender little South American, starting from scratch, was unable to overcome the handicap allotments of nine other runners as he finished tenth.

AKRON, Ohio, Sept. 4. -- Following is the address of William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, broadcast over the National Broadcasting Company's system, under the auspices of the Akron Central Labor Union:

PORT HOPE, Ont., Sept. 4 (Canadian Press). -- The National Recovery Act of the United States was being challenged on its constitutionality, W. Averell Harriman, chairman of the steel committee administering the statute, told the Liberal Summer Conference here tonight.

Twelve thousand passengers will land in New York today from twenty-one steamships. More than 7,000 are returning on ten big cruising ships from Bermuda, Nassau and Halifax. The Columbus, the only liner arriving from Europe, brings 801 passengers from the Channel ports.

LONDON, Sept. 4. -- Prime Minister MacDonald, who is in London for tomorrow's Cabinet meeting, is suffering from insomnia, and Sir William Elder, his physician, is urging him to get a complete holiday from work during the next fortnight.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Sept. 4. -- With the return of harness racing to the State Fair after an absence of two years, Tom Berry and his Hanover Shoe Farms' entries monopolized the spotlight on today's inaugural Grand Circuit program. A crowd of more than 5,000 attended.

MEMPHIS, Tenn., Sept. 4 (AP). -- Speeding here by airplane from Ottumwa, Iowa, where he spoke this afternoon, Donald R. Richberg told a Labor Day audience tonight that the country's economic and political salvation "depends on the successful expansion of our machineries of voluntary cooperation."

FOLKESTONE, England, Sept. 4 (Canadian Press). -- Brilliant centuries by George Headley and Captain G.C. Grant sent the British West Indies into the lead today against an eleven which included a number of England's best cricketers.
MOSCOW, Sept. 4. -- Edouard Herriot, former Premier of France, showed himself an adroit statesman today at an interview given to foreign and Soviet press representatives.

WASHINGTON, Sept., 4. -- The State Department has not been officially informed of the renunciation by Holland of the tariff truce entered into at London during the economic conference, and until some details of the move have been learned officials are reserving opinion as to its possible significance.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 4. -- The third series of regulations covering the Presidential proclamations of Aug. 28 and 29, dealing with hoarded gold and gold exports, were issued today by the Treasury Department. They supplanted regulations in force in connection with earlier Executive Orders.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 4. -- Presi- dent Roosevelt, who is expected to arrive in Washington tomorrow on Vincent Astor's yacht, the Nour- mahal, went fishing outside the Virginia Capes this morning and hooked a turtle weighing more than 100 pounds.

LONDON, Sept. 4. -- The Trades Union Congress, representing more than 3,512,000 British workingmen, met at Brighton today and listened to dark forebodings of fascism, communism and dictatorships of all kinds which delegates declared were threatening the British labor movement.
SEA GIRT, N.J., Sept. 4. -- The Dryden Trophy rifle shooting classic was annexed today by the eight-man team of the Marine Corps.

Clothes are the most Important things in the world, according to Miss Marjorie Howard, American fashion writer, who arrived from Paris yesterday on the French liner Ile de France. She will assist in the opening tomorrow and Thursday of the fashion group in its new quarters in Rockefeller Center.
CHICAGO, Sept. 4. -- Following is the address of General Hugh S. Johnson, National Recovery Ad- ministrator, before the Illinois Fed- eration of Labor at the Century of Progress Exposition today:

Henri Cochet of France, mainstay of the French Davis Cup team for seven years, will make his American debut as a professional in Madison Square Garden on Feb. 21, it was learned at Forest Hills yesterday.

Leaders of organized labor in this city hailed Labor Day yesterday as the most promising in American history. They pointed to a pro- found transformation in American life effected by the National Recovery Act and emphasized the opportunities offered to labor economically and culturally under "the New Deal."

Uncertainty over the delivery of merchandise needed for immediate sale took the edge off the enthusiasm with which retailers greeted the active consumer buying of Fall merchandise last week. Production delays occasioned by recent labor troubles and by the shorter work week under which the needle trades are now working, were responsible for the unsatisfactory situation regarding shipments.

SALEM, N.H., Sept. 4. -- Breaking fast in the heavy mud, W.W. Vaughan's 4-year-old filly Canron, with H. Dabson up, today won a four-length victory over William Ziegler Jr.'s Cattail in the Rockingham Park's $5,000 added Labor Day mile handicap.

PARIS, Sept. 4. -- The Bourse failed today to continue the favorable trend of the end of last week, although it opened firm, owing chiefly to renewed weakness in the dollar and the pound sterling. The latter at one time was at the lowest point since the depreciation started, but it recovered and closed at 80.70.

LIVERPOOL, Sept. 4 (AP). -- Operations on the Corn Exchange were somewhat restricted today by the holiday in America, but a rise of 1d to 1 1/8d in graded wheat futures resulted from reports of continued dry weather in the Argentine grain belts.

With the wage and labor agreement between the theatre managers and the local stagehands' union expiring last Sunday at midnight, negotiations will go forward -- beginning probably next week -- between David B. Finestone and Leonard E. Bergman, representing the League of New York Theatres and the National Association of the Legitimate Theatre, and officials of the union, seeking a new accord.

Refreshed by a three-day rest, the Wall Street business community will enter upon the new week with little more information than it had when operations were suspended on Friday for the protracted week-end.

CAMP PERRY, Ohio, Sept. 4. -- A total score of 7,918 out of a possible 8,000, a new record, was piled up by the United States twenty-man team in the international small bore Dewar trophy team match today. The match closed the national small bore rifle championship tournament.

CHICAGO, Sept. 4. -- The Chicago Cubs rewarded a holiday crowd of 38,000 today by winning both ends of a double-header from the Cardinals, 6 to 4 and 5 to 2, slipping into third place two points ahead of the idle Boston Braves.

At times the author of "Crucible," which was played at the Forrest last evening, has touched on a subject worth dramatic treatment. In the midst of some of the wordiest buncombe staged since "Ten Nights In a Barroom" D. Hubert Connelly shows an occasional flair for the sensational drama.

BASLE, Switzerland, Sept. 4. -- Following is the balance statement of the Bank for International Settlements, giving its condition as of Aug. 31. as made public here tonight. Figures are in Swiss gold francs at par, 19.3 cents.

To the Editor of The New York Times: To debate N'Yawkese with Edward W. Townsend is an undertaking indeed. His tenancy of the chair of N'Yawkese on the old New York Sun is a glory undeparted. But -- shade of Chimmie Fadden assist me! -- I shall be temerarious.

WITH the downpour in this area yesterday, there was nothing to do except play a double-header with the stacked-up mail. The letter on top proved to be a communication from Johnny Sohultz, the veteran oarsman who runs the boathouse at Princeton and teaches the youthful Princetonians how to scull.

BIG BAY, Mich., Sept. 4 (AP). -- With the deadline for acceptance of the NRA automotive code set at midnight tonight, Henry Ford today gave no indication of interrupting his North. Woods vacation for a return to Detroit or a statement of his position.

FORT PIERCE, Fla., Sept. 4. -- A tropical hurricane blowing at a hundred miles an hour struck the coast and south central interior of Florida last night and today and left a trail of more than $1,000,000 property damage and one known dead.

A doubt that the books of D.H. Lawrence will long be read, the opinion that Aldous Huxley is a better essayist than novelist and the lament that although Lytton Strachey effected a revolution in biography there still are "fewer good lives written than spent" are contained in "English Literature in the Twentieth Century," published today by Macmillan.

GREAT NECK, L.I., Sept. 4. -- John A. Hastings, former State Senator, who figured prominently in the Seabury investigation last year, was arrested early Saturday morning on a charge of disorderly conduct at his Summer home, 46 Arleigh Road, Kensington, it became known here today.

The Public Service Commission announced yesterday its approval of revisions of the gas schedules of the Long Island Lighting Company, the Nassau and Suffolk Lighting Company and the Queens Borough Gas and Electric Company.

ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 4. -- Postmaster General James A. Farley in- formed the mail carriers of the country today that the payless fur- lough, put into effect in their service as an economy measure, would be discontinued at the end of this month.

Rehearsals for "The Pursuit of Happiness," by "Alan Child and Isabelle Louden," -- who are, it has finally been admitted, Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence Langner -- will begin today under the direction of Miriam Doyle.

ELIZABETH, N.J., Sept. 4. -- Stricken after a birthday party at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Carmelia Taormina at 14 Nile Street here last night, fifteen persons were taken to the Elizabeth General Hospital today Buffering from food poisoning.
CHICAGO, Sept. 4. -- Discussions of technical problems of banking occupied the first business day of the fifty-ninth annual convention of the American Bankers Association at the Hotel Stevens here.

Thousands of fishermen met with keen disappointment over Sunday and yesterday, according to all reports received last night from points as far east as Montauk and down the Jersey coast as far as Beach Haven.

HOLLYWOOD, Sept. 4 (AP). -- Announcement was made today on behalf of thirteen independent movie producers of Hollywood that they had given two weeks' notice to their 1,620 employes and told them to look for other jobs.
NEW YORK. Mr. and Mrs. Thomas F. Vietor will return to the Barclay tomorrow from Hill Top Farm. Franconia, N.H., where they have been passing the Summer.

OCEAN CITY, N.J., Sept. 4. -- Making an average speed in three ten-mile heats of 40.6 miles per hour, Eugene Apel of Ventnor, at the wheel of Emancipator II, captured the national championship for 125-cubic inch hydroplanes today.
Nathan Taback, a retired silk manufacturer, committed suicide by hanging last night in his apartment at 370 Fort "Washington Avenue. He was 55 years old.

If Tammany has actually decided to increase the water rates, it will be only doing what should have been done long ago. The present schedule virtually dates from 1857. It is no longer adequate to cover the cost of supplying and delivering the enormous amount of water consumed.

ST. PAUL, Sept. 4. -- Joe Hauser, home run champion of organized baseball, elevated his standing today as three drives from his slugging bat whistled over the distant barriers of St. Paul and Minneapolis baseball parks for his sixty-third, sixty-fourth and sixty-fifth circuit clouts of the season.
PATERSON, N.J., Sept. 4. -- A three-day holiday brought a temporary lull in silk strike activities over the week-end, but developments are expected tomorrow.
In a Labor Day message yesterday, Louis Waldman, State Chairman of the Socialist party, warned that "the fate of the present efforts toward recovery rests in the hand of labor."
Metropolitan baseball yesterday suffered the fate that befell many other outdoor pastimes of the citizens of Greater New York and its environs.

CAPE MAY, N.J., Sept. 4. -- The annual juvenile jubilee and baby parade, postponed last week due to rain, was held late today, after thousands of persons had waited for the start of the procession, delayed by a heavy rainstorm.
Under extremely difficult weather conditions a lifeboat crew from the tanker W.C. Teagle of the Standard Shipping Company won the two-mile competition in the international lifeboat race yesterday.

STAMFORD, Conn., Sept. 4. -- The Stamford Yacht Club's Vineyard Trophy, competed for over the week-end by twenty-two yachts from different clubs along the shores of Long Island Sound today was presented to L. Lee Stanton of New York.

CHICAGO, Sept. 4. -- A national campaign to "buy now" and "buy under the Blue Eagle," to be launched Sept. 20, was announced today by General Hugh S. Johnson, National Recovery Administrator, as the next step in the recovery program.

WARSAW, Sept. 4. -- Negotiations for a final settlement of the Polish-Danzig problem are reaching a conclusion here. Poland has agreed to direct 45 per cent of her entire annual imports and exports through the port of Danzig and 55 per cent through her own port, Gdynia.

SLOATSBURG, N.Y., Sept. 4. -- Ernie Riedel of the Pendleton Canoe Club of New York City, international double-blade champion, successfully defended the Bonk Memorial Trophy in the one-man double-blade race which featured the annual Labor Day regatta of the Atlantic Division of the AmeriCanoe Association on Lake Sebago today.

Fordham University launched its football training campaign at Fordham Field yesterday. Head Coach James H. Crowley began a new regime in the sport and sent the forty-seven men on the squad through two vigorous drills which lasted about five hours.

Opposition to Tammany's plan to increase water rates and levy taxes upon utility earnings, taxicab rides and brokerage transactions began to crystallize yesterday. It will take the form of definite and strenuous protests to Mayor O'Brien and other members of the Board of Estimate, even before the new tax program is made public.

In an address before the Jewish Community Centre in Yonkers last night Samuel Untermyer declared that the National Recovery Act, if successful, "will mark the beginning of the greatest social and economic revolution of peace times in the history of the modern world."

STOCKHOLM, Sept. 4. -- Colonel and Mrs. Charles A. Lindbergh arrived here by seaplane from Copenhagen at 3:15 this afternoon at the special invitation of Crown Prince Gustaf Adolf, who promised that their visit would be made as private as possible.

CHICAGO, Sept. 5. -- Leading from start to finish, the Austin Stable's Foxiana scored by five lengths over Arthur Bartelstein's Cold Check in the featured event at Lincoln Fields today. W.H. Harris's Foxland Hall was third.

SEATTLE, Sept. 5. -- Mark E. Reed, industrial, financial and political leader of Washington and Republican National Committeeman of the State, died this morning at Providence Hospital, after an illness of more than a month. He would have been 67 years old in December.

Maranhao, the State in Northern Brazil where a gold "rush" is on, has always been regarded as chiefly agricultural. The main product is cotton. Coffee, cocoa, sugar, tobacco and cereals are also grown. The State is well watered, and the forest wealth is considerable.

Roy V. Crowder, who has been passenger traffic manager of the Grace Lines for two years and a half in the New York office, will leave in a few weeks to take charge of all the Pacific Coast operations of the service, it became known yesterday.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 5. -- Powerless against the pitching of Le Roy Mahaffey in the first game of today's double-header with the Athletics, the Yankees went on a veritable batting rampage in the nightcap and divided the twin bill. As the Senators won twice, the Yankees are now nine and a half games behind the pace-setters.

The significance of the "second revolution" in Cuba, in its relation to the interests of the United States, aside from the possibility of disorders leading to intervention, is that the abrogation of the Platt amendment may soon become a live issue.

ALBANY, Sept. 5. -- In order that thousands may participate in the industrial parade in New York City, Governor Lehman today proclaimed a half holiday for Sept. 13. He urged the "fullest compliance with the spirit of this proclamation."
Resale by a trust company of a Jersey City flat recently in foreclosure featured the New Jersey realty transactions reported yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 5. -- The Federal Reserve Board's condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety leading cities on Aug. 30 shows increases for the week of $49,000,000 in net demand deposits and $28,000,000 in loans and a decrease of $24,000,000 in holdings, of United States Government securities.

MONTPELIER, Vt., Sept. 5. -- Vermont, long a rockbound prohibition stronghold, today joined the parade of States favoring repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment. It was the twenty-fifth consecutive State to record itself in opposition to retention of prohibition in the Constitution.

Three hold-up men entered the superintendent's home in Fieldston Towers, an apartment house in the Riverdale section of the Bronx, yesterday and ecaped with $130 after binding and gagging two women and a man. The home of Edward J. Flynn, Secretary of State, is in the same community, from which several burglaries have recently been reported.

BINGHAMTON, N.Y., Sept. 5. -- Fourteen passengers were killed and thirty others were seriously Injured when the two rear cars of the Erie Railroad's crack Atlantic Express were struck from behind by a milk train and demolished at 7:30 o'clock tonight, Eastern Standard Time.

MATTEAWAN, N.Y., Wednesday, Sept. 6. -- Trapped by four cunning inmates of the State Hospital for the Criminal Insane here, three of the institution's guards were still being held prisoners at 3 o'clock this morning, an hour after the outbreak.
EAST HAMPTON, L.I., Sept. 5. -- The final yacht race of the season was held in Gardiner's Bay yesterday, off the Devon Yacht Club, despite a storm.

Irving Frederick Wilson, 41 years old, of 613 Rugby Road, Brooklyn, was in the line-up in Police Headquarters yesterday morning. He might have been touring leisurely along the Maine Coast, the police said, if he had not been such a good handshaker and greeter.

Postponement of the national open polo championship has been announced by the United States Polo Association. The recent heavy rains have left the fields of Long Island so wet as to interfere with practice by the teams entered for the championship.
Jersey City and Newark divided a double-header at Jersey City yesterday, the Jerseys winning the second battle, 2 to 1, after Newark had carried off the opener by a score of 9 to 6.
Governor Lehman dismissed removal proceedings yesterday against Controller Charles. W. Berry.

Confidence that when his controversy with the NRA is ended Henry Ford will be found to be "as good an American as any one" was expressed here yesterday by the Rev. Charles E. Coughlin, of Royal Oak, Mich., known for his radio sermons.

Buyers' Registrations Down. Due to the holiday, the number of visiting buyers registered in the market during the week ended yesterday showed a drop in comparison with the figures for the preceding week. The total also showed a drop against the number listed at the same time last year.

Dr. Orestes Ferrara, Secretary of State in the late Machado Cabinet in Cuba, now the most prominent of the Cuban refugees in New York, made the following comment yesterday on the new situation in Cuba:

To the Editor of The New York Times: The demand for universal fingerprinting, reiterated yesterday by Senator Copeland, chairman of the special Senate committee to investigate racketeering, might seem to be too preposterous to be taken very seriously, but we are living in a time when almost anything that anybody is willing to declare solemnly to be "necessary" is received with a favor which in normal times it could never possibly obtain.

The existence of at least $16,000 in forged bonds of New York City in $1,000 denominations was disclosed yesterday when the Finance Department was notified of the arrest of two men in Memphis, Tenn., charged with handling the bogus issues.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 5. -- Copies of a petition filed in Federal court by the Spokane International Railway Company for authority to reorganize its capital structure under the Bankruptcy Act were made available today by the Interstate Commerce Commission.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Certain members of the "Brain Trust" have recently asserted that the laws of political economy are subject to constant and progressive change. The following incident is cited to show that there is some basis for that contention.

LONDON, Sept. 5. -- While Norman H. Davis, United States delegate to the disarmament conference, was finishing the last stage of his journey -- he arrived at Plymouth from New York tonight -- the British Cabinet was instructing Foreign Secretary Simon on the line he is to take with Mr. Davis when the disarmament conversations open tomorrow.

BUENOS AIRES, Sept. 5. -- The Argentine Government announces that private banks will reduce their interest rates on loans 2 per cent on Sept. 11. From that date they will charge 5 per cent on agricultural loans, 5 1/2 per cent on commercial and industrial loans and 6 1/2 per cent on unsecured loans.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 5. -- The text of the speech delivered today by Jesse H. Jones, chairman of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, before the American Bankers Association in Chicago, was made public at the corporation offices here as follows:

Probably the "exodus" from the city over Labor Day is instinctive recognition of the last of the Summer holidays. It is also the only one of them which insures a two-day outing. The American habit of fixing holidays on patriotic birthdays or historic dates is apt to bring even Independence Day into the middle of a week.
HAVANA, Sept. 5. -- A manifesto issued early this morning to the Cuban public by the revolutionary group declared:

Daily average gross crude oil production in the United States last week was 2,721,400 barrels, compared with 2,756,400 barrels in the preceding week, a decrease of 35,000 barrels, according to the American Petroleum Institute. A decrease of 57,350 barrels in the daily output of Oklahoma was the most important change in the period.
SCHENECTADY, N.Y., Sept. 5. -- Henry W. Darling, former treasurer and vice president of the General Electric Company, died at his home here last night. He was 86 years old.

CORPUS CHRISTI, Texas, Sept. 5 (AP). -- The devastating hurricane which whipped through the lower, Rio Grande Valley bored its way toward Northern Mexico today, leaving in its wake millions of dollars in property damage and the possibility of considerable loss of life.

NEWARK, N.J., Sept. 5. -- The proposal of the Citizens' Advisory finance Committee to postpone the opening of the Newark public schools for three weeks until Oct. 2 for reasons of economy, was rejected today. Thomas J.D. Smith, president of the Newark Board of Education, acted on behalf of the board which had the final say in the matter.

Crisis at the Glen. Up at Watkins Glen the imprisoned stag was asked yesterday by a specialist in animal interviewing how he expected things to come out. "You may quote me as saying," he remarked, scratching his antlers against the cliffside thoughtfully, "that I regard the situation as serious, not to say critical.

S.L. Rothafel has abandoned his fight to retain his nickname Roxy on the marquee of the RKO Roxy Theatre, it was learned yesterday. The theatre will be known in the near future as the RKO Center Theatre, and the original Roxy, at Fiftieth Street and Seventh Avenue, will continue to use its present name.

It is said that revolutions do not go backward. Sometimes they do -- backward into autocracy or despotism. But there is always a Left Wing mad to go forward furiously, as was the case in the French Revolution, in Russia sixteen years ago, and as is reported in Germany today.

The first Federal loan to a Bronx home owner was determined by a drawing from a hat yesterday in the branch office of the Home Owners Loan Corporation at 391 East 149th Street. Before the day was over the property had been appraised, and a loan approved.

From the eighteenth century to the first third of the twentieth, amelioration of prison conditions and the treatment of prisoners advanced miraculously. In the United States, the most favored nation in this regard, the point has almost been reached where it is easier to break out of jail than to get in.

The validity of designating petitions for Koenig and anti-Koenig candidates for the New York County Republican Committee, involving nearly a thousand on each side, will be fought out in court today. Forgery, "importation" and other irregularities are charged.
William H. Walker Jr., 29 years old, who said be was a nephew of former Mayor James J. Walker and a son of Dr. William H. Walker, was arrested last night in District Attorney Crain's office.
U.S. Department of Agriculture. Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices at New York:

Two midtown buildings are scheduled to be sold at foreclosure auctions next Sept. 27. The structures are the forty-four-story building at 10 East Fortieth Street, extending through the block to 5 East Thirty-ninth Street, and the old home of the. Army and Navy Club at 30-32 West Forty-fourth Street, a twelve-story structure.

To the Editor of The New York Times: A London dispatch to THE NEW YORK TIMES reports that new capital issues in England during August were the largest for any month this year and for any August since the war. The importance behind that dispatch cannot be overemphasized.

While Wall Street had a vague hope that the share market would work itself yesterday into an active position as a gesture of welcome to the approaching Autumn season, no one seemed surprised that the performance was so tame. The market was lashed a few times by speculative leaders, but the response was so unsatisfactory that the attempt was abandoned.

CHICAGO, Sept. 5. -- America, President Roosevelt told the American Bankers Association in a message read to their convention here today, is counting heavily on the bankers' assistance "as we forge ahead" in the national recovery program.
SEA GIRT, N.J., Sept. 5. -- Shooting through a haze that made target visibility difficult, Sergeant Sam Barteletti of the Marine Corps today won the Wimbledon long-range match.

Expressing disappointment at the suspended sentences given to Jacob Mellon and two of his associates who pleaded guilty in Brooklyn's most important laundry racket trial, District Attorney Geoghan of Brooklyn said yesterday that he will consider bringing the men to trial again on the remaining indictments standing against them.

CAMDEN, N.J., Sept. 5. -- Joseph F. Wallworth, former president of the State Senate, who ended his life on Aug. 20, left an estate estimated at "$200,000 and upward" to his widow and father in trust, according to his will probated today His daughter, Mrs. Josephine W. Bentley of Merchantville, is the ultimate beneficiary.

CHICAGO, Sept. 5. -- General Hugh S. Johnson, National Recovery Administrator, today summed up the latest news in the controversy brewing between the NRA and Henry Ford over the latter's delay in signing the code for the automobile industry with the phrase:

The contents of the private sanitarium conducted by Mrs. Alice Fuller LeRoy at 40 East Sixty-first Street were attached yesterday by Sheriff Joseph T. Higgins in a suit by the 40 East Sixty-first Street Corporation for rent in default since Feb. 1, 1931.

BERLIN, Sept. 5. -- The Protestant Church in Germany, which the Nazis claim to have united into one German Evangelical Church, was split wide open today when the non-political wing which in the last church elections had supported the Rev. Dr. Friedrich Von Bodeischwingh for Reich Bishop against the Nazi German Christians bolted the general synod of the old Prussian Union and walked out in a body.

The listed bond market was weaker yesterday man indicated by the averages of the various classifications, as considerable ground was lost by many second-grade issues not included in these compilations. A sizable list of domestic corporation and foreign loans dropped 1 to 4 points.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Sept. 5. -- Brown Berry, from the Lyle Brothers stables of Cleveland, squared matters with Mary Reynolds, winner of the 1933 Hambletonian Stake, by winning the featured $6,865 3-year-old trot today at the State Fair Grounds.

Resuming business after the extended holiday week-end, Wall Street tested the speculative markets cautiously yesterday. Stocks and commodities drifted idly for a time, and it was not until late in the afternoon that a definite trend was established on the Stock Exchange.
PITTSBURGH, Sept. 5. -- The expected triumphal pennant march of the Giants, designed to blast championship aspirations at each succeeding stop, got away rather badly today.

The Interborough Rapid Transit Company reports a loss of $505,074 for July, comparing with a loss of $666,097 for the same month last year, before providing for full dividend rental at 5 per cent on Manhattan Railway Company modified guarantee stock, payable if earned.
NEW YORK. Mr. and Mrs. George Upham Harris gave a dinner last night in the Starlight Roof Garden of the Waldorf-Astoria for Mr. and Mrs. Harold H. Will and the Misses Will.
The Governors of New York, New Jersey and Connecticut have been invited to review the President's NRA Day parade of from 200,000 to 250,000 employers and employes in this city Sept. 13.

Dr. Charles L. Andrews, one of the oldest practicing dentists of the city and long active in liberal movements, particularly in the field of religious belief, died on Sunday at his home, 95 Reid Avenue, Port Washington, L.I., of heart disease.

NO one need say that J.B. Priestley lacks virtuosity. In his latest novel, "Wonder Hero" (Harper's, $2.50), he combines two techniques to make a bid for two mutually exclusive audiences, the original Priestley audience which took to its ample heart the sentiment and sheer story-telling quality of "The Good Companions," and the more "modern" group of readers which bolsters its fading courage with satire.

Grover A. Whalen, chairman of the local NRA organization, intervened yesterday in an effort to stop a threatened strike of 4,000 motion-picture-machine operators in 400 theatres of the city and a strike of 10,000 workers called by the Children's Dressmakers' Union for the latter part of this week.

Football practice started at Manhattan yesterday, while at City College the reporting candidates were examined by the medical staff. Fordham, the other metropolitan college in action, went through another hard day of practice.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 5. -- The Public Health Service said today latest evidence indicates a possibility that the sleeping sickness now epidemic in St. Louis may be spread, like infantile paralysis, through secretions of the nose and throat.

CHICAGO, Sept. 5. -- The Banking Act of 1933 is basically unsound and will therefore "ultimately force its own repeal in amendment" according to Francis H. Sisson, president of the American Bankers Association and vice president of the Guaranty Trust Company of New York.

Rumors of sales were more prevalent in yesterday's real estate market than actual transactions. Brokers and operators, however, are frank to admit that there are several large deals pending, one of which is said to he in the heart of the Grand Central zone, involving properties valued at close to $2,000,000.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 5. -- The request by President Roosevelt and Jesse H. Jones, chairman of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, that members of the American Bankers Association, loosened up in their credit policies to assist industry and business to meet demands of the National Recovery Act, came as the result of a series of conferences held by the President with the financial experts of the government.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W.Va., Sept. 5. -- Miss Maureen Orcutt of the White Beeches Country Club, Haworth, N.J., was medalist with a 36, 39 -- 75 today in the qualifying round of the annual women's Mason and Dixon golf championship, being played on the Old White course.

Harold Cornwell, 25 years old, of 77 Dogwood Avenue, Munson, L.I., was killed yesterday and five persons were injured, four of them seriously, when the automobile he was driving on the Long Island Motor Parkway near Garden City was in a head-on collision with another machine.

The Holland-American line has called a meeting of its bondholders for Oct. 5 to vote on a proposed reorganization of the company. The plan provides that bondholders receive shares in the amount of 200 florins for each bond of 500 florins. The balance sheet of the company as of July 1 shows bonds outstanding in the amount of 22,784,500 florins, all of the 6 per cent issue of 1922.

Samuel Stern, attorney, of 277 Broadway, who said he represented 16,000 unemployed men and women, made public a letter to Governor Lehman yesterday in which he urged State intervention to end alleged abuses in the city's administration of relief funds.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 5. -- Joseph B. Eastman, Federal Coordinator of Transportation, has asked W.W. Atterbury, president of the Pennsylanvia Railroad, for his views on a possible consolidation or unification of the Pennsylvania and Long Island Railroad under a single management.
PHILADELPHTA, Sept. 5. -- Miss Milllcent Hirsh of New York was among the winners as play opened in the girls' national tennis championship at the Philadelphia Cricket Club, St. Martin's, today.

WATKINS GLEN, N.Y., Sept. 5 (AP). -- Balked in a "big push" to drive the Watkins Glen deer from its prison a rocky ledge in the glen gorge, authorities pinned their hopes today on a trail of baited corn to free the seven-point buck from the captivity in which it has spent eleven days.

CHICAGO, Sept. 5. -- James Spencer Dickerson, honorary trustee and corresponding secretary of the University of Chicago and, nationally prominent in education circles, fell dead late today at his Summer home, near Oregon, Ill. Death was attributed to a heart attack.
CHICAGO, Sept. 5. -- The text of President Roosevelt's message to the American Bankers Association follows:
WASHINGTON, Sept. 5. -- President Roosevelt dropped his sailor role again today to step ashore and take up immediately three major problems facing his administration.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 5 (AP). -- Secretary Wallace today announced benefit payments to flue-cured tobacco growers who signed agreements to curtail production in 1934 and 1935.

STOCKHOLM, Sept. 5. -- Despite official attempts to keep his visit private Colonel Charles A. Lindbergh had to leave the Royal Automobile Club by the kitchen door this morning to keep an appointment with General Eric Virgin, Swedish aviation chief, in the offices of the Army General Staff.

MOSCOW, Sept. 5. -- Despite the Russian sense of drama, it seems there is to be no contest between the two new Russian stratosphere balloons as might have been expected, with the one built by the army in Moscow and the other built in Leningrad by the Air League waiting to ascend.
INDIANAPOLIS, Sept. 5 (AP). -- Martina Armstrong won the 2:13 pace in straight heats and turned in the fastest time of the present Grand Circuit meeting at the State Fair Grounds today.
VIENNA, Sept. 5. -- Seven airplanes left Vienna today for the Austrian airdrome at Innsbruck to patrol the Bavarian-Tyrolean border.
LARCHMONT, N.Y., Sept. 5. -- Sailing in a light, puffy breeze, youngsters of the Long Island Sound fleet competed today in the first test of the five-race series for the annual midget championship.

ALBANY, Sept. 5. -- Borough President George U. Harvey of Queens, replying today to removal charges filed by Fritz Brieger, asserted in a document forwarded to Governor Lehman that "animus and disappointed ambition'' had prompted the allegations.

The number of New York State employers, outside the City of New York, who have signed the President's Agreement is 99.107, or 88.5 per cent of the 112,000 establishments estimated for the fifty-seven up-State counties.

The little sidewalk cafes that bloomed along lower Fifth Avenue this Summer are doomed to wilt in the Fall, under an order issued by Borough President Samuel Levy. He admitted yesterday that he had directed and approved an order served last Friday upon the Hotel Brevoort, the Fifth Avenue Chemists, the Restaurant Longchamps and No. 1 Fifth Avenue, instructing them to remove "encumbrances" from the sidewalks in front of their properties.

The commodity markets were irregular yesterday throughout the session, showing gains or leases apparently depending on the particular trading situation in each. Most of the cash markets made gains for the day.
ALEXANDRIA, Egrypt, Sept. 5. -- A sudden Ministerial crisis is rising in Egypt.

BERLIN, Sept. 5. -- The German Ministry of Popular Enlightenment and Propaganda has offered a complete apology to H.V. Kaltenborn, American editor, for the assault by a Nazi on Mr. Kaltenborn's 17-year-old son Rolf in Berlin's main, business street last week.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Sept. 5. -- Professor Henry W. Farnam of Yale, noted political economist and retired member of the Yale faculty, died this afternoon at the age of 79 in the New Haven Hospital, where he had been a patient for a month, after being in poor health for more than two years.

Mother Nellie McCarthy knew when she was picked up at her apple stand at midnight on Monday and whisked away to the Waldorf-Astoria on Park Avenue that she was to be a lady for a day -- only to serve the sweet uses of publicity. But that didn't rob her of the thrill.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 5 (AP). -- A conference between Chairman Wagner of the National Labor Board and representatives of silk manufacturers and striking employes was adjourned today until Friday, when additional employers will be summoned.

A revised program of new taxes, designed to improve the city's credit with the banks and to provide for emergency relief needs will be submitted to the Board of Estimate by Samuel Untermyer within the next day or two, it was indicated yesterday.
The Curry-O'Brien administration has virtually thrown New York City into a receivership, Loring M. Black Jr., candidate for the Democratic nomination for Mayor, charged yesterday.
To the Editor of The New York Times: The Chrystie-Forsyth Street controversy assumes the acquisition of this property for the purpose of model housing.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 5 -- The Bureau of Navigation issued the following orders today, dated Sept. 1.

According to report, Mayor O'BRIEN is planning to call the city department heads together and give them another harangue on economy. It would be a waste of time. In recent years these pleas have taken on the aspect of a solemn farce. Ordered to cut to the bone, and even to "scrape it," the department chiefs have unblushingly left not merely meat on it but fat.

The North German Lloyd Line has renewed its lease on the South Brooklyn pier for another year, with a two-year option in the event it wishes to send the express liners Bremen, Europa and Columbus to the foot of Fifty-eighth Street for a three-year period.

LONDON, Sept. 5. -- The Trade Union Congress at Brighton enthusiastically adopted today a resolution demanding that the British Government start immediately on a policy of shorter hours, higher wages and public works on the lines of President Roosevelt's recovery program.
MOSCOW, Sept. 5. -- Eight persons, including four outstanding leaders of Soviet aviation, were killed today in the crash of a plane near Podolsk, twenty miles south of here.
BINGHAMTON, N.Y., Sept. 5. -- An incomplete list of the dead and injured in the train wreck, as given out at the Binghamton City Hospital, follows:...

BAYONNE, N.J., Sept. 5. -- Unable to agree on a new wage rate put into effect by the Tide Water Oil Company under the oil code, representatives of the management and of the workers voted today to take their differences to Washington for settlement by National Recovery Administration officials.

PARIS, Sept. 5. -- Although some 13,000 men at least are engaged in exercises between the "Red" and "Blue" armies in Eastern France, there are no troops visible. That is one of the principle features of this new method of warfare.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 5. -- The planning and coordination committee set up under the provisions of the code of fair competition for the oil industry is expected to take up tomorrow what is probably the knottiest problem awaiting solution, the price-fixing provisions of the code.

OMAHA, Neb., Sept. 5. -- Peter Christopolus, the 14 -- year-old orphan who was returned to Father Edward Flanagan's Home here after a six-weeks trial adoption period in the family of the well-to-do Jean Strengs of Paterson, N.J., was a bit bewildered today over the two great changes in his life.

Workmen are busy putting the finishing touches on the new $10,000,000 Parcel Post Building in the block bounded by Ninth and Tenth Avenues, Twenty-ninth and Thirtieth Streets, so that the first tenants may enter their quarters in less than three weeks.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 5. -- Two 19-year-old New Yorkers, Stella Bailey of 124 West Fifty-fifty Street and William Stelling of 211 West 106 Street, were named today among the winners of an international contest designed to discover screen talent for Paramount studios.

GENEVA, Sept. 5. -- Undeterred by a stench bomb set off two hours before its opening, the second World Jewish Conference began here tonight by strongly applauding a vehement demand by Rabbi Stephen S. Wise for an organized Jewish boycott of German goods.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 5. -- The National Recovery Administration's test with Henry Ford was considered officially on today with continued absence of any word from the Detroit manufacturer and the fair competition code for his industry going into effect.

PATERSON, N.J, Sept. 5. -- Joseph Donahue of 112 Highland Street and Philip Hartley Jr. of 151 Warren Street, who were injured in the wreck, are students at the East Side High School here. They left with another boy named Edward Mues of 144 Putnam Street and the Mues boy's mother and sister to go to the Chicago World's Fair last Thursday.

PARIS, Sept. 5. -- Franco-American negotiations for an agreement on dividing the European phosphate market and if possible fixing a minimum price have reached a successful conclusion on the major points, it was reliably reported today.

ALBANY, Sept. 5. -- Despite the failure of the Legislature in extraordinary session to pass the Swartz Bill, which would have set up a revolving fund of $10,000,000 for widening and deepening the Barge Canal, there is a prospect that the State will get the money from the Federal Government.

Member banks of the Federal Reserve System must not pay more than 3 per cent on time deposits, beginning on Nov. 1, according to a regulation issued by the Federal Reserve Board and made public here yesterday by George L. Harrison, governor of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.
