Kansas City, Mo. Kansas City, Mo., announced yesterday a new issue of $500,000 of bonds for award on Friday at 2 P.M. The new financing will comprise $200,000 of trafficway bonds, $150,000 sewer and $125,000 Blue River improvement bonds, all due serially on Sept. 1, 1935 to 1973, and $25,000 police station bonds, due on Sept. 1, 1935 to 1959.

More than 50,000 men and women canvassers began the local NRA campaign yesterday to get 7,000,000 consumers in the metropolitan area to sign the pledge to buy only from those employers who are under the Blue Eagle.

HAVANA, Sept. 5. -- President Carlos Manuel de Cespedes and his Cabinet were overthrown today by enlisted men of the Cuban Army and Navy, less than a month after they had supplanted the regime of former President Gerardo Machado.

SANTA CLARA, Cuba, Sept. 5 (AP) -- Army sources reported today an estimated death toll of 300 in last week's hurricane in the previously unchecked vicinity of Cristo Cay, six miles from the mouth of the Sagua Le Grande River on the North Coast.

CALLICOON, N.Y., Wednesday, Sept. 6. -- Vivid accounts of the wreck at Binghamton were given early this morning by passengers aboard the Atlantic Express to a NEW YORK TIMES representative who boarded the train at Deposit, N.Y., and rode as far as Callicoon.

Holders of bonds of the Realty Associates Securities Corporation, which is in bankruptcy, have been notified by Eugene F. O'Connor of Brooklyn, referee, that on Sept. 11 the company will submit to its creditors and to the court an offer of composition.

The old-fashioned method of campaigning by street meetings will be revived this year in the fight against Tammany, William M. Chadbourne, fusion campaign manager, announced yesterday, simultaneously with the opening of headquarters in the Paramount Building.

PARIS, Sept. 5. -- Bulgaria had begun negotiations with private French banks for a loan before the arrival of King Boris in Paris last week, and the Quai d'Orsay said today the government was not concerned in these negotiations.

OTTAWA, Sept. 5 (AP). -- Despite efforts to locate Bennett race balloons, no trace of a big bag seen here last night had been found up to noon today. At midnight, an unidentified balloon was sighted high over the capital moving south.

PARIS, Sept. 4. -- Sir John Simon, British Foreign Secretary, and Captain Anthony Eden of the Foreign Office, will confer here with French Cabinet Ministers Sept. 18, when the former pass through Paris on the way to Geneva. It is expected Norman H. Davis, United States delegate to the disarmament conference, also will be in Paris then or will pay a visit just before the British visitors arrive.

Early modification of the United States tariff of 7 cents on long fibre cotton was predicted yesterday by Ahmed Abdel Wahab Pasha, Under Secretary of State for Finance in the Egyptian Government. Wahab Pasha, here to study "the working of the planned national recovery," said in an interview at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel yesterday that he probably would discuss the cotton tariff in Washington.

Secretary of Agriculture Wallace is expected, within a short time, to announce the 1933 regulations governing migratory wild water fowl. The advisory council submitted its recommendations some time ago and, in the natural order of affairs, it was expected that the regulations would have been announced by this time.
MOSCOW, Sept. 5. -- There is a phase of the press interview yesterday of former Premier Edouard Herriot of France that is not mentioned in today's newspapers, but is none the less interesting.

To the Editor of The New York Times: With reference to your recent editorials on better reiatibns with our neighbors and the settlement of foreign debts, President Roosevelt has stated the beautiful sentiment that we wish to play the role of the good neighbor; that we will faithfully honor our engagements, and that we shall expect others to fulfill in the same manner their obligations toward us.

In a letter sent to members of all stock exchanges in this country, the Association of Stock Exchange Firms urges that opinions of the proposed code of fair competition for the exchanges be sent to the secretary of the code committee. Members of the exchanges are asked to send representatives to the hearing on the code, which will probably be held in Washington on Sept. 25 or 26.

The mightiest figures in amateur tennis paraded across the turf of the West Side Tennis Club yesterday in an unbroken sequence of victories, but when the 4,000 spectators left the stadium neither Ellswortn Vines, Jack Crawford, Fred Perry nor Frank Shields was uppermost in their minds.

ELLSWORTH VINES, wearing his linen cap pulled down well over his forehead, was the first player to appear on the Stadium courts at Forest Hills yesterday. He was closely followed by his prospective victim, Ray Palmer Jr. of Malba, L.I., a medium-sized youngster with a shock of blond hair. Palmer is just out of the junior class. Vines towered almost a full head over him.

Gamaliel Bradford, who was an invalid all his life and yet wrote 113 "writing portraits," or "psychographs," 2,000 poems, 8 novels, several plays, a host of editorials and miscellaneous articles, also found time to keep a 1,400,000-word journal.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 5. -- With two destroyers anchored in Cuban waters and a light cruiser and destroyer en route there, the United States tonight faced a possible test of its whole Latin-American "hands-off" policy as a result of the Cuban revolution that sprang up overnight.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Sept. 5. -- Departing from a prepared speech here today, Secretary Wallace asked, "Should we not begin to deal with the milk industry as a public utility?" and suggested that dairymen propose a processing tax as a means of controlling production.

SEIGNORY, Canada, Sept. 5. -- At the end of eighteen holes of competition for the championship of the Canadian Seniors' Golf Association today, Albert A. Adams of Hamilton, Ont., had a two-stroke lead over a field of ninety golfers. He toured the course in 79.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 5. -- The latest of the navy's "treaty" cruisers will be launched at the Philadelphia Navy Yard at 3:45 o'clock tomorrow afternoon and christened the Minneapolis by Miss Grace Newton of Minneapolis, whose great-great-great-grandfather was a seaman on the frigate Confederacy during the Revolution.

The meeting of shipping men in Washington tomorrow to discuss a code for the industry will not convene under the most propitious circumstances, inasmuch as several shipping companies here, and even the Steamship Owners Association, were ignored in the invitations sent out by Admiral Hutch I. Cone of the Shipping Board Bureau of the Department of Commerce.
David S. Rendt, Democratic leader of the Borough of Richmond, will be back on the city payroll tomorrow, it was learned from a reliable source last night.

The Commercial Credit Company has offered to buy from holders the stock of the Textile Banking Company of New York at $50 a share. More than two-thirds of the stock has been acquired on this basis, it was announced. Commercial Credit will accept the stock on and after Sept. 30, but not later than Oct. 24.

BERLIN, Sept. 5. -- The Boerse suffered another serious slump today. Losses of 2 to 3 per cent were common and some of the more volatile stocks dropped 6 to 9 per cent. At today's closing- quotations the average level of stocks on the Boerse was about 12 per cent below that at the beginning of this year.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Sept. 5. -- Dr. James Bryant Conant assumed office as the twenty-third president of Harvard University today. He took over the direction of the university on the eve of its 298th academic year with a plain informality and lack of ostentation.

An 18-year-old girl plunged into the East River and swam against the treacherous Hell Gate tides half-way to the Bronx shore yesterday afternoon in a vain attempt to escape from the Children's Hospital, an institution for mental defectives on Randall's Island.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 5. -- States and municipalities were called upon today to get busy on jobs for which they may receive allotments from the $3,300,000,000 Federal public works fund, end dilatory tactics and speed their machinery to put men to work within thirty days.
Mrs. Roswell Miller, daughter of Mrs. Andrew Carnegie, is sailing tonight for Europe on the Cunarder Aquitania. Others leaving on the ship for the Channel ports include:

ATLANTA, Ga., Sept. 5. -- Cotton leaders of the Southeast, in conference here today, went on record as opposed to the government's acreage control plan, and suggested, instead, that the 1934 crop be reduced by limiting the number of bales through a rigid system of control at gins.

Martin A. Klein of the Bohemian Gymnastic Association has been renominated for president of the Metropolitan Association of the A. A.U. for the 1933-34 term, according to the list of candidates named yesterday by the nominating committee.

CHICAGO, Sept. 5. -- A Chicago artist has received a Rockefeller blue necktie with a request that he change an unsolicited oil portrait of John D. Rockefeller Sr., and he is still hoping for a Rockefeller dime.

EDINBURG, Texas, Sept. 5 (AP). -- Twelve known dead, more than fifty injured and many millions of dollars' damage was the toll of the Gulf hurricane which last night and today laid waste the rich and populous lower Rio Grande valley.

PARIS, Sept. 5. -- Grave words of warning regarding the future of France's North African empire are appearing in the Paris press. North Africa, like the rest of the world is suffering an economic crisis, the immediate effect of which has been to produce discontent among the native population.

PATERSON, N.J., Sept. 5. -- Three thousand employes of fifteen silk throwing mills went on strike here today, joining the 7,000 broad-silk workers who have been out since last week, according to Eli Keller, organizer for the Associated Silk Workers.

BOSTON, Sept. 5 (AP). -- Although outhit in both games, the league-leading Senators today took both ends of a double-header from the Red Sox. An infield error enabled the Senators to capture the eleven-inning opener, 5 -- 4, and they slugged three of four Boston pitchers for a 9 -- 6 decision in the second contest.
Prices on the Cotton Exchange broke $2 a bale yesterday under the heaviest hedging operations of the season and ended around the bottom with losses of 37 to 44 points.

Juvenile fillies owned by C.V. Whitney and Mrs. John Hay Whitney were winners at Belmont Park yesterday, each by the margin of a length. Rhapsody, a daughter of Pennant and Skylight, carried the familiar Eton blue and brown silks to victory, while Saracen Maid was the winner for Mrs. Whitney.

NUREMBERG, Sept. 4 (delayed). -- The heavy tramp of the last brown battalion departing homeward from the congress of the Nazi party has died away and the last band has blasted its farewell. The railway sidings, packed to the last rail yesterday with special trains destined for all parts of Germany, are empty now, and marching songs no longer echo through the quiet streets.

For an hour last night a police emergency squad and three fire companies cut through a steel plate one inch thick with acetylene torches to release James O'Neil, 6 years old, of 83-74 Talbot Street, Kew Gardens, Queens, who had become wedged at the neck in the shaft of the automatic elevator of the apartment house.

NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 5. -- Thelma Cudlipp Grosvenor (Mrs. Charles S. Whitman) today was declared the winner of the popular prize of $25 for a painting in the annual exhibition of the Art Association here. Her picture is called "Victorian Piece."
DETROIT, Mich., Sept. 5. -- Wage increases for Ford employes, ranging from 40 cents to $1 a day above the present minimum of $4 a day have been placed in effect.
Resumption of production of third-line automobile tires is planned by several manufacturers who discontinued making them in March, according to executives of the companies.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Sept. 5. -- Strong retrenchment in Postoffice Department expenses "other than salaries," particularly in air-mail subsidies, was pledged here today to the National Letter Carriers Association.
RIVERHEAD, L.I., Sept. 5. -- The will of Mrs. Julia T. Mollenhauer Dick, socially prominent widow of J. Henry Dick, sugar refiner, was filed in the Suffolk County Surrogate's Court here today.

Several more witnesses were questioned by Deputy Commissioner Goldberg of the Corrections Department in his investigation of how three youthful prisoners escaped from the Tombs last Sunday morning. Among those interrogated was Henry Simon, one of the fugitives, who was rearrested Sunday night in the midtown district by Detective John J. Meehan.

CHICAGO, Sept. 5. -- Prices for hogs advanced 5 to 10 cents a hundred pounds today to the highest level in eleven days. Around 66 per cent of the arrivals today were pigs to be sold to the government, and after those direct to packers were deducted, offerings in the open market were relatively small.
LONDON, Sept. 5. -- Deep suspicion of the policy and philosophy of Nazi Germany will be expressed tomorrow by The London Times in a bitter editorial on the Nuremberg rally.

COLD SPRING HARBOR, L.I., Sept. 6. -- Miss Nancy Stewart, daughter of Mrs. Frances De Forest Stewart and of William A.W. Stewart of New York, was introduced to society tonight at a dinner dance given by her mother at Edge-over, her Summer home on Cold Spring Harbor.

After the familiar reaction in the forenoon, the share market turned sharply upward in the late dealings yesterday. There was a similar recovery in grain prices. Taking the day as a whole, the net result was almost a stand-off. The one important exception in all the irregularity was cotton, which was firm at the outset and then strong, closing more than a dollar a bale higher.
Colonel Theodore Roosevelt, former Governor of the Philippines, will arrive today with Mrs. Roosevelt on the Manhattan of the United States Lines. Others on board include:

The Latin American Bondholders Association, which was incorporated in 1931 as a membership nonprofit-making organization to aid holders of defaulted Latin-American bonds, announced yesterday that it was sponsoring a nationwide petition asking the Federal Trade Commission to use its offices to urge the creation of the Corporation of Foreign Security Owners authorized by the Federal Securities Act of 1933.

To the Editor of The New York Times: J.C. Hunsaker, vice president of the Goodyear Zeppelin Corporation, was quoted in THE NEW YORK TIMES as saying that "no structural faults, but the navy policy of rapidly shifting commanding officers from airship duty to sea duty" caused the Akron disaster.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 6. -- Movements of vessels follow. All dates are Sept. 5 unless otherwise specified:

A "charem," or boycott, on goods manufactured in Germany was pronounced yesterday by the Assembly of Orthodox Rabbis of the United States and Canada at the closing sessions of its sixteenth annual convention in the Hotel Pennsylvania.

ABOARD THE MOTOR SHIP WYATT EARP, Sept., 6 (By Wireless). -- One thousand miles from Cape Town, the Wyatt Earp, carrying the plane of the Lincoln Ellsworth Transantarctic Flight Expedition, is plunging and bucking over short, lumpy seas in the South Atlantic and giving the slim Northrop polar plane in her hold the joggiest ride it will ever have.

Four families, comprising fourteen persons, two of whom were ill, were evicted yesterday from a six-story tenement at 419 East Tenth Street in spite of two offers for the payment of their arrears in rent. Last night, through the offices of I. Lawrence Lessavoy of the Junior Federation of Jewish Charities, the four families and their belongings were moved to a tenement on East Ninth Street near Avenue D.
NEW YORK. Mr. and Mrs. T. Markoe Robertson gave a dinner for Mr. and Mrs. Anthony J. Drexel 3d last night at the Central Park Casino.

VIENNA, Sept. 6. -- Rumors of a forthcoming Nazi invasion of the Tyrol are being taken quite seriously by the Austrian authorities. Today the entire garrison of Innsbruck, consisting of one alpine regiment, a battalion of Vienna infantry, two mountain batteries and their attendant service corps, was hastily mobilized and rushed to the border near Scharnitz, where it manoeuvred as if to resist an attack.

On one aspect or the bank position it is important that discussions at the bankers' convention should throw light. Tuesday's speech at Chicago by Chairman JONES of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation stated the case for those who believe that banks have not granted the credit required for continuous business recovery.
The government has issued the weekly weather report as follows:

Joseph M. Price, chairman of the independent fusion committee, which held out to the last against the selection of Major F.H. LaGuardia as fusion candidate for Mayor, returned to the fusion fold yesterday and prepared to work actively in the campaign.

SYRACUSE, N.T., Sept. 6. -- Valor, a bay filly sired by Peter Volo and owned by D. McConville of Ogdensburg, was outstanding in the opening today, a classified trot, winning three times in a row to clinch Vie Fleming's first of three purses.

MOSCOW, Sept. 6. -- The best answer to exaggerated stories published abroad saying that there is a "famine like that of 1921" in Russia is given by the steady progress of Soviet industrial production in recent months.

There is something ingratiating in Mr. UNTERMYER'S request to the New York press to be more considerate in dealing with the city government. A master of gentle speech himself, he would have the newspapers be a little blind to the faults of Tammany, and to its virtues, if any, very kind.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 6. -- A new code of fair competition for the newsprint industry, substituting for the one filed last month with the Recovery Administration, was presented today by the Association of Newsprint Manufacturers at a public hearing before W.W. Pickard, Deputy Administrator.

HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Sept. 6. -- Twelve hundred depositors of the closed First National Bank of Hempstead voted tonight unanimously to accept the so-called waiver plan as an immediate means of opening the bank, which has not been functioning for 4,500 depositors since the banking holiday in March.

MIAMI, Fla., Sept. 6. -- Adherents here of former President Mario G. Menocal of Cuba profess to see evidences of his handiwork in the sergeants' mutiny that upset the regime of Provisional President Carlos Manuel de Cespedes Monday.

Behind effective pitching by Don Brennan and Jim Weaver, Newark vanquished Jersey City twice, 2 to 1 and 5 to 3, yesterday at West Side Park, Jersey City. The doubleheader marked the final home contests for the Jerseys this season.
Two Manhattan dwellings, one on the east and one on the west side, were reported sold yesterday. Two flats on Madison Avenue near 115th Street also were reported in new ownership.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 6 (AP). -- The Cardinals retained their record of not having been defeated at home since Frankie Frisch became their manager by rallying sharply in the ninth inning of the second game of today's double-header to vanquish the Phillies, 8 to 7.

GENEVA, Sept. 6. -- Denouncing the Nazi movement as a world menace, Rabbi Stephen S. Wise of New York told the World Jewish Conference here tonight that "what the world needs today is not a Germanized humanity but a humanized Germany." He received an ovation when he ended.

AMSTERDAM, Sept. 6. -- George Branting, Swedish lawyer, in a report today to his colleagues of the committee of international lawyers that is carrying on an independent investigation of the Reichstag fire, declared that a subcommittee had investigated the antecedents of Marius Van der Lubbe, the Dutchman who is among the accused, and had obtained evidence of the utmost importance.

The Burroughs Adding Machine Company reported for the six months ended on June 30 last, a net profit after depreciation, Fed- eral taxes, and other deductions, of $455,902, equivalent to 9 cents a share on 5.000,000 no-par shares of capital stock.

YONKERS, N.Y., Sept. 6. -- Fashioning a fine 79, John P. Downey of the home club led the Class A players today in the first round of the sixth annual 36-hole Westchester seniors' championship tournament at Dunwoodie.

A sharp drop in production combined with a rising seasonal trend to bring about the most severe recession in the adjusted index of steel mill activity since the decline began early last month. For the week ended Sept. 2 the number stands at 63.9, which compares with 75.2 in the preceding week and 18.3 for the week ended Sept. 3. 1932.

Strenuous efforts to avert the strike of 15,000 embroidery workers called by the Bonnaz Embroidery Workers Union for this morning, and threatening to tie up the operation of the dress industry with more than 100,000 employes in this city and vicinity, were being made yesterday by the local organization of the NRA.

CINCINNATI, Sept. 6. -- Suffering the most terrific bombardment centred upon their pitchers this season, the Dodgers were buried under an 18-to-8 score in the second game of today's double-header with the Reds, after winning the opener, 7 to 3.

MOSCOW, Sept. 6. -- An interest- ing account of a trip in the spherotrain on which a young Communist inventor named Yarmochuk has been working for the past eight years appears in today's Communist Youth Pravda, which elucidates rather confusing accounts of the spherotrain published yesterday.

NEWARK, N.J., Sept. 6. -- Joseph A. Ward, one of the three legal assistants dismissed by the new Newark City Commission last May, was ordered restored to duty today as the result of a decision by the State Civil Service Commission. His reinstatement is to take place as of May 16 and he will receive all back pay from that date.
BERLIN, Sept. 6. -- Dr. Hugo Eckener will sail tomorrow for New York to resume his negotiations with American interests for a regular airline between North America and Europe.

Filled with research and imaginative detail and written with a less unconscious humor, the basic tales of brawls, duels, plots and labor from Benvenuto Cellini's classic autobiography are told by Victor Thaddeus in his "Benvenuto Cellini and His Florentine Dagger," published today by Farrar Rinehart.

According to a survey just completed by the Massachusetts officials of the Division of Fisheries and Game, the Bay State anglers have done more salt water fishing this year than ever before in the State's history.
TOKYO, Sept. 6. -- Secretary of the Navy Swanson's signature of the United States shipbuilding contracts has started a reaction in Japan which now pervades the whole press.

HUNTINGTON, L.I., Sept. 6. -- Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Gwynne of Mill Cove, South Down Road, gave a supper dance tonight at the Turf and Field Club to introduce to North Shore Society their daughter, Miss Gwendolyn Gwynne. Before the dance Miss Gwynne was a guest of honor at a dinner given by Mrs. Frances De Forest Stewart at Cold Spring Harbor.

Brooklyn's rejoicing over the North German Lloyd Line's renewal of its lease on Pier 4 is easy to understand. It is a source of pride to be not only the "borough of homes" but the borough of great transatlantic liners. Playing host to the Bremen and Europa also involves no small commercial benefits.
LARCHMONT, N.Y., Sept 6. -- Scoring impressive victories in all three races sailed today, the Larchmont Yacht Club successfully defended its midget championship of Long Island Sound.

BERLIN, Sept. 6. -- Germany's political isolation in the world is beginning to worry the Nazi rulers and the German press. This is becoming more apparent as the reopening of international meetings at Geneva nears.
SKEGNESS, England, Sept. 6 (Canadian Press). -- Batting practically all day, an Eastern Counties eleven scored 217 runs against the British West Indies in a two-day match which started today.
PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 6. -- The Minneapolis, newest addition to the navy, was launched at the Philadelphia Navy Yard this afternoon.

EAST HAMPTON, L.I., Sept. 6. -- Mrs. Thomas Jefferson Mumford gave a tea this afternoon for Rafaelo Diaz, Metropolitan Opera tenor, who is her house guest and who will give his annual East Hampton song recital tomorrow evening at Lasata, the further lane residence of Major and Mrs. John Vernou Bouvier Jr. Mrs. Mumford will also give a dinner for a number of Southampton and East Hampton friends before tomorrow's recital.

HAVANA, Sept. 6. -- The new Cuban Government tonight guaranteed order "in all the republic" as reports of scattered disorders reached the capital while United States destroyers lay within gunshot of the island and others speeded in this direction.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Sept. 6. -- "While the whole nation is putting up the Blue Eagle as the emblem for shorter hours, higher wages and more jobs, the Postoffice Department has been sitting aside watch- ing the parade," Representative Clyde Kelly, Republican, of Pittsburgh, said here today.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Your editorial "The Milk Dealer's Spread" seems to me to be written from the viewpoint of the milk dealer and the Milk Control Board, omitting the position of the milk farmer. Your first premise, "The farmer commonly gets less than 5 cents a quart for milk which the retailer sells to the ultimate consumer at 10 cents or more," is a downright euphemism.

MATTEAWAN, N.Y., Sept. 6 (AP). -- One inmate was shot to death and another wounded today in battle with guards and police at the State Hospital for the criminal insane during an unsuccessful attempt of four crazed felons to escape.

In spite of the Mae West vogue in Paris, where many are flocking to see the screen version of "Diamond Lil," her influence in the realm of waistlines and silhouettes is negligible, according to Marjorie Howard, fashion expert.
DETROIT, Sept. 6 (AP). -- The deadlock between the National Recovery Administration and the Ford Motor Company, still a holdout from the automobile code, continued tonight.
BERLIN, Sept. 6. -- The sending by the Austrian Government of seven planes to patrol the Austro-German border is characterized here as "a flagrant violation of the treaty of St. Germain."
Samuel Untermyer, the city's financial adviser, had completed yesterday his preliminary report on new revenues and the city's financial condition, and was prepared to send it to Mayor O'Brien today.

THERE is a contradiction in the character of H.G. Wells somewhere. He hates war, and the waste of war, yet when he writes about far-flung campaigns, as he does in "The Shape of Things to Come" (Macmillan, $2.50), he makes them sound more exciting than any militarist could succeed in doing. One recalls that among his sixty-one odd books there is one for children entitled "Floor Games and Little Wars."

THEY sent Ellsworth Vines out to start the tennis proceedings at Forest Hills again yesterday. Perhaps he likes to get through early so that he can settle down to some serious reading, or something like that.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 6. -- The Pirate threat was taking something of a serious turn today when the Giants decided to take swift and vigorous action. They tossed all the Corsairs overboard so that it may be reported that Memphis Bill Terry's pennant bound craft is again moving on an even keel.

HARRISON, N.Y., Sept. 6. -- After topping the field in the qualifying round, Mrs. I.M. Wheeler of the Westchester Country Club was eliminated in the first round as the women's Westchester-Fairfield Golf Association nine-hole match play tournament opened today at the Green Meadow Country Club.

It is fair to infer that President ROOSEVELT has had more disturbing information about conditions in Cuba than that -- which is surely disquieting enough -- contained in the press dispatches. Otherwise it is hard to understand the display of force in Cuban waters which he has ordered.

PARIS, Sept. 6. -- That fatality that has dogged all past efforts at international agreement on arms limitation seems not yet to have been laid. Just at the moment when Norman H. Davis arrived in London declaring that agreement was more than ever necessary, the old bogy of order of procedure has once more raised its head.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 6. -- The possibility of a rate agreement which would discourage destructive com- petition between the railroads and the water carriers of the country was discussed today by Joseph B. Eastman, Federal Coordinator of Transportation, with committees representing the interests involved.

BINGHAMTON, N.Y., Sept. 6 (AP). -- Blame for the Erie Railroad wreck which killed fourteen persons and injured scores last night was placed upon the engineer of the milk train tonight by H.J. Bordwell, general manager of the eastern division of the railroad.

WELLESLEY, Mass., Sept. 6. -- Vice President Ralph B. Wilson of the Babson Statistical Organization opened the annual business conference of the organization here today with a prophecy of a good business year in 1934, better prices, higher wages and an increase in sales generally.

School children throughout the city, vacation at an end, began registration yesterday for the Fall term starting Monday. The work of enrolling more than 1,000,000 pupils will continue today and tomorrow from 9 A.M. to noon and from 1 P.M. to 3 P.M.

GLENS FALLS, N.Y., Sept. 6. -- Members of one of the largest golfing groups of the year were gathering in this city today, preparatory to the start of the fifth Glens Falls open championship tomorrow.

A woman, walking on Broadway near Tiemann Place, was shot in the right ankle late last night by a fleeing delicatessen store robber. The gunman was captured after a half-mile chase around the Claremont Hill setcion of the upper west side.

The Continental Bank and Trust Company plans to wind up the affairs of its affiliate, the Continental Corporation, which, while never active as a security-distributing organization, has nevertheless performed certain functions for the bank.

Uffa Fox and Roger De Quincy, the young English sportsmen who recently captured the New York Canoe Club International Challenge Cup, will present to that organization a trophy to be named the Roger and Uffa Cup. The announcement was made last night during a dinner in their honor at the New York Athletic Club on the eve of their departure for England.

SEIGNIORY CLUB, Que., Sept. 6 (Canadian Press). -- The climax of a competitive golfing career of thirty years came today for Albert A. Adams, Hamilton, Ont., when he captured the championship of the Canadian Seniors Golf Association over the Seigniory Club course.
SAN JUAN, P.R., Sept. 6. -- The Liberal newspaper La Democratia, in a front-page editorial in its English-language edition today, called Governor Robert H. Gore a "damn liar."

Loans on securities made to mem- bers of the New York Stock Exchange increased $971,340 in August, the fifth consecutive monthly advance, but the gain was considerably smaller than those in earlier months this year. July's increase was $135,857,814.

CHICAGO, Sept. 6. -- Arthur Bartelstein's good 3-year-old colt Teralice just got up in the closing strides to win by a nose from the Shandon Farm's Evergold in the mile of the Rally Round Purse, feature at the Lincoln Fields track today.

A resolution eliminating ticket "buys," termed "one of the worst evils of show business," was adopted unanimously yesterday by the National Committee of the Legitimate Theatre, the administrative agency for the enforcement of the theatre's master code.

QUANTICO, Va., Sept. 6 (AP). -- The marines got ready today for another big job, but there was no excitement about it. "With cool military precision more than 1,000 soldiers of the sea were assembled here to go to Cuba if the command came.
Young and old tennis idols fell at Forest Hills yesterday as the dwindling number of survivors gained the fourth round of the men's national championship.

H.V. Kaltenborn, former associate editor of The Brooklyn Eagle, described the recent Nazi attack on his son Rolf in a wireless despatch to The Eagle yesterday from the steamship Kungsholm, on which Mr. Kaltenborn and his family are now returning from Germany.
COHASSET, Mass., Sept. 6. -- The lead in the series for the Mrs. Charles Francis Adams Cup and the women's national sailing championship is shared tonight by the skippers from Cohasset and Edgartown.

GLEN COVE, L.I., Sept. 6. -- Dr. F.A. Bean and his six-foot son, Richard, representing the Coldstream Club in Hempstead, captured the Long Island father-and-son championship at the Nassau Country Club today. They succeeded the Pomonok combination of E. L. Beard Jr. and E.L. Beard 3d as the titleholders.

ALBANY, Sept. 6. -- Application of Illinois for the extradition of Aaron Sapiro, New York lawyer, indicted on charges of conspiracy to commit malicious mischief in connection with investigation into a laundry "racket" in Chicago, was granted today by Governor Lehman.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 6 (AP). -- One tariff expert had been removed from the NRA tonight and another put in his place as Hugh S. Johnson prepared to give serious thought to the need of higher import duties to the increased costs of production under the recovery program.

With halting step, a man and a woman walked into the Astoria police station just after noon yesterday. The man approached the desk where Sergeant Francis Burns was busy over the blotter. As the Sergeant looked up, the man threw a cheap souvenor penknife with a long blade down before him.

MANILA, Sept. 6 (AP). -- Nineteen men were killed in a battle between the Philippine constabulary and a band of outlaw Moros on the jungle-covered island of Jolo, a dispatch to constabulary headquarters here today said.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 6 (AP). -- Harold Lloyd, film comedian, was cleared today of a charge of plagiarism brought against him by Mrs. Sadie Witwer, widom of H.C. Witwer, short-story writer, who asserted he had violated the Federal Copywright Act in his picture "The Freshman."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 6. -- In the face of reports of increasingly chaotic conditions in Cuba today, the United States clung to its determination not to intervene in the island's affairs, but took every precautionary step looking toward such a course, if forced to the point of taking it.

The governing committee of the New York Stock Exchange at a special meeting yesterday suspended dealings in the no-par capital stock of the Brunswick Terminal Railway and Securities Company. No explanation was given for the step.

No one who has inadvertently turned on the radio this Summer will begrudge Albert G. Miller his envenomed barbs in "The Sellout," which was played at the Cort last evening. Mr. Miller is a young man who has written radio scripts for some of the biggest accounts.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 6. -- The number of families receiving unemployment relief in July was 267,607 less than the June total in thirty-nine States for which figures are of record. The decrease is shown in statistics made public today by the Federal Emergency Relief Administration.

Edict Against Cafes. Just as people were beginning to hope that the tender plant of the sidewalk cafe could be induced to flourish in our hitherto unfavorable New York climate, there comes an order from the office of the Borough President ordering the suppression of a number of outdoor cafes on lower Fifth Avenue.

Wall Street got so much comfort out of the last-hour rally on the Stock Exchange yesterday that the commission houses began to discuss the possibility that "important developments may be hanging over the market." This phrase appeared in several circulars.

The campaign to enroll the millions of consumers in this city in the NRA campaign received national impetus yesterday when Grover A. Whalen, chairman of the local NRA organization, called upon the 750,000 organized workers affiliated with A.F. of L. organizations to join in the recruiting drive for consumer support.

LEICESTER, England, Sept. 6. -- No prophecies of what biologists would ultimately accomplish and no announcement of any new scientific discovery but a sober technical review of the chemical aspects of life constituted the subject of the presidential address delivered by Sir Frederick Gowland Hopkins in opening this year's meeting of the British Association for the Advancement of Science.

The sidewalk cafes along lower Fifth Avenue won a reprieve yesterday when Assemblyman Herbert Brownell Jr. called on Borough President Samuel Levy to inform him of the impending organization of a "Save the Sidewalks Cafes Committee," including such members as Arthur Garfield Hays and George Jean Nathan.

Walter Damrosch will make his first appearance as a piano soloist at the fifth of this season's Musicians' Emergency Aid concerts at Madison Square Garden, it was announced yesterday. Ossip Gabrilowitsch will conduct the orchestra on this occasion, and then Mr. Damrosch will conduct a concerto with Mr. Gabrilowitsch at the piano.

PATERSON, N.J., Sept. 6. -- The trial adoption of Peter Cristopolus, Omaha orphan, not only brought disappointment to Jean Strengs, his would-be foster father, but also was instrumental in bringing three threatening letters to the Strengs household, it was learned today from sources close to the family.

A "jury" of citizens sat in unoffi- cial judgment yesterday morning at the auditorium of the Russell Sage Foundation, 130 East Twenty-second Street, listening to evidence on the manner in which the city is carrying out its relief program.

The aggregate market value of all listed stocks on the New York Stock Exchange increased $3,907,681,339, or 11.9 per cent, in August, the rise more than offsetting the decline of $3,586,540,000 in July, according to the monthly bulletin issued by the Exchange.

Firms and organizations representing more than 100,000 employes have already enrolled for the NRA parade to be held here Sept. 13, it was announced yesterday at NRA headquarters by Major Gen. Dennis E. Nolan, who will be grand marshal of the demonstration.

Wednesday, Sept. 6, 1933. The develoment of special significance in the day's money market was the drop of 1/4, to 1 1/4 per cent, in the discount on commercial paper. This new minimum applied to quality names of short maturity and has not been duplicated since early this year.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 6. -- The War Department released the following orders today:

CHICAGO, Sept. 6. -- The grain markets on the Board of Trade here continued today to fluctuate erratically, with local operations the dominating influence. The general trade leans to the belief that grain and other commodity markets have come to a crossroad and will await developments under the NRA codes and also more information as to the administration's plans regarding inflation of the currency.

BALBOA, C.Z., Sept. 6. -- Dr. Raymond L. Ditmars, curator of the New York Zoological Park, re- turned from the Panama jungles today without a deadly bushmaster serpent, but with a collection with which he was highly pleased, including two vampire bats, eighteen carnivorous bats and many snakes.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 6. -- Leaders of the construction industry throughout the country were told today that they could expect no return of building activity until 1937 unless they stabilized their industry.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 6. -- Loans aggregating $93,892,523.62 were authorized in July by the Reconstruction Finance Corporation to conservators or receivers of closed banks to aid in reorganizations or liquidations, according to the monthly report of the corporation, made public today by the clerk of the House of Representatives.

HAMMONTON, N.J., Sept. 6. -- Ambushed in a lonely spot a mile west of the Williamstown Junction station of the Reading Railroad, Joseph N. Krause, 53 years old, an oil burner salesman, was apparently robbed, shot or beaten, and then burned to death in his own automobile early this morning.

Shipping men here were notified yesterday that the Senate hearing on ship and air mail subsidies, scheduled to begin today, had been postponed until next Wednesday. The Senate committee appointed last March to investigate these expenditures, headed by Senator Hugo Black, Democrat, of Alabama, notified operators that another week would be required to organize the vast amount of material its investigators had gathered.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 6 (AP). -- Alec McColl, Washington's rookie pitcher, had to wait until he was 37 years old to get a chance in the majors, but the opportunity finally came today and he held Chicago to four hits for a 3-to-1 victory.

The Yankees' greeting to Rogers Hornsby as manager of the St. Louis Browns at the Stadium was a 3-to-2 setback yesterday for the Missourians in a game that was won in the ninth, with Lou Gehrig stealing the show.

BERLIN, Sept. 6. -- The commission of fifteen appointed to work on a program for the reform of the German banking system began its task today with a plenary session in the Kaiser-hall of the Reichsbank building under the chairmanship of Dr. Hjalmar Schacht, president of the Reichsbank.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 6. -- Two players from Los Angeles and one each from New York and St. Paul, Minn., reached the semi-finals of the sixteenth annual girls' national tennis tournament at the Philadelphia Cricket Club at St. Martin's today.

BERLIN, Sept. 6. -- Following new intervention by the banks, the Boerse steadied itself today and even showed slight rallying tendencies, but trade was dull. Some stocks which had lost most in the prolonged downward movement recovered around 1 per cent; only a few specialties gained as much as 2 per cent.

The American Export Line sold the cargo-passenger steamship Exporter yesterday to the Shepard Steamship Company for the latter's intercoastal service. The Exporter has been in Robbins Drydock undergoing alterations and renovations, and at the time of sale yesterday had been outfitted to accommodate sixteen passengers.

Promote Food Group Executives. Appointment of Donald W. White, formerly acting head of the American Institute of Food Distribution's voluntary chain research department and editor of "Facts in Food Distribution," to the post of director in charge of operations for the institute was announced yesterday.

Minnesota Investment Board. The Minnesota State Board of Investment awarded $2,942,000 bonds yesterday from the holdings of the State Sinking Fund. The award was made on competitive bidding for $1,167,000 city of Minneapolis $1,105,000 Ramsey County and $670,000 city of St. Paul bonds of varying interest rates and maturities, comprising forty-nine separate blocks.

In spite of the ancient history books, the oracles have never shut up. They were wide open before the repeal election in Vermont. The God-made parts of the State are Dry; the man-made parts are Wet. "If rain keeps down the rural vote," repeal will win. Like Washington, the State was "doubtful."

That the railroad managements would do all in their power to conform with the views of Joseph B. Eastman, Federal Railroad Coordinator, on the distribution of work among as many employes as possible was an opinion expressed informally following a meeting of railroad officials yesterday in the New York Central Railroad offices.

CHICAGO, Sept. 6. -- The American Bankers Association convention telegraphed to President Roosevelt today a resolution urging that deposit insurance under the new Banking Act be postponed lest it result in "the suspension and liquidation of some thousands of banks" which are unable to qualify in the short time left before Jan. 1, when the guarantee provision goes into effect.
After holding around Tuesday's closing levels for several hours yes- terday, prices on the Cotton Exchange recovered a quarter cent and ended with gains of 17 to 23 points.

HAVANA, Sept. 6. -- The governmental junta representing the soldiers and sailors who overthrew Provisional President Carloa Manuel de Cespedes strove today to set new administrative machinery in operation, but steadily increasing opposition from many quarters gave a feeling of uncertainty and raised doubt in the mind of the public as to the future.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 6. -- President Roosevelt and his Recovery Administration moved swiftly tonight to end the three-weeks deadlock on a fair competition code for the soft coal industry.
Charges that a contractor for the city is paying less than the prevailing rate of wages were heard yesterday morning by Acting Controller Frank J. Prial in his office in the Municipal Building.

With the approach of Oct. 1, traditional Fall "moving day" in the Manhattan residential field, brokers are being kept busy showing their offerings to prospective tenants, and report a brisk business in apartment leases.
ALBANY, Sept. 6. -- The State Budget Advisory Board, formed last year, has been asked by Governor Lehman to continue its activities for another year.

Details of the alleged solicitation of a bribe by former Deputy Collector of Internal Revenue Joseph Alperin were recited on the witness stand in Federal Court yesterday by Albert L. Deane, president of the General Motors Holding Corporation.

Reflecting higher costs of operation under the code for the petroleum industry, prices of crude oil and gasoline were advanced yesterday over virtually the entire country. An additional factor in the increase was the belief that under the code production and consumption would be brought rapidly into line.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 6. -- Fulltime lighting of the principal Federal airways was ordered today by Secretary Roper.

NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 6. -- The first of several entertainments arranged in honor of the 360 midshipmen who are here aboard the U.S. S. Wyoming took place this afternoon. Nearly 100 of the group were the guests at a garden party given by Captain Herbert C. Cocke, U. S.N., commandant of the Naval Training Station, and Mrs. Cocke.

BROWNSVILLE, Texas, Sept. 6 (AP). -- Twenty-two known deaths, hundreds of injured and property damage running into millions of dollars formed the dark-hued picture tonight of the Gulf hurricane which lashed South Texas and the Northern Mexican coast Monday and Tuesday.

LONDON, Sept. 6. -- Norman H. Davis, United States Ambassador at Large and delegate to the disarmament conference, visited Sir John Simon, the Foreign Secretary, this morning and tried to convince him that a disarmament conference would be useless without strict and regular suspervision of armaments.
To the Editor of The New York Times: May I refer to THE NEW YORK TIMES editorial "Higher Water Rates"?

SHANGHAI, Sept. 6. - -Emphatic denial was made today of persistent and sensational reports that most of the American cotton bought with the United States Government's loan to China was being sold to Japanese mills at a price 30 per cent under what China must pay the United States.
The John P. Grier colt, Golden Way, did much to redeem himself in the eyes of his admirers when he captured the sixty-fourth running of the Jerome Handicap for Joseph E. Widener at Belmont yesterday.

Net operating income of 149 Class I railroads in the United States in July was 469.7 per cent higher than in July, 1932, sending the total for the seven months of this year 79.3 per cent above that for the corresponding period in 1932, according to the Bureau of Railway Economics.
BOSTON, Sept. 6 (AP). -- Three Red Sox pitchers were liberal with hits and bases on balls today, and as a result Detroit Tigers took the first game of the current series, 11 to 5. The box score:

Detailed figures on the effect of the NRA on the operating expenses of the gas companies of the Consolidated group were ordered yesterday by the Public Service Commission at the hearing on temporary emergency rate reductions. The commission requested the utilities to submit the data tomorrow when the hearing is resumed.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 6. -- Regulations for the sale of newly produced gold by the Federal Reserve Banks, acting as agents for the producers, were issued today by Acting Secretary of the Treasury Acheson.

Price movements in commodities were again mixed yesterday. De- clines were in the majority, however, with the cash markets also undecided in tone and showing varied results. Corn, lard and cotton advanced in the spot dealings, and wool tops rose 1 cent to a new high mark of $1.05 1/2, while wheat, rye, cocoa, tin, silk and hides declined.

CALVIN W. RICE, secretary of the American Society of Mechanical Engineers, in a letter to THE TIMES a few days ago expressed "a profound feeling of respect and admiration" for the generosity of private citizens of Chicago in making possible an array of museums rivaled only by government-supported institutions in the largest European capitals.

Easily outclassing their opponents in the first of their series of New York matches on the grounds of the Staten Island Cricket Club, at Livingston, S.I., yesterday, the English cricketers won by 30 runs and eight wickets.

LLANDUDNO, Wales, Sept. 6. -- David Lloyd George, amid a colorful crowd of holiday-makers, today unveiled a memorial in memory of Dr. Charles L. Dodgson, who, as Lewis Carroll, wrote "Alice in Wonderland" and "Through the Looking Glass."

Virtually all sections of the bond market on the Stock Exchange were weak yesterday, sustaining the heaviest losses in several days. Trading, however, continued light, with bids on many issues scarce.

HAVANA, Sept. 6. -- Octavio Seigle, a veteran revolutionary advocate suggested for the post of "Minister Without Portfolio" in the new Cuban regime, revealed today the details of yesterday's meeting at which the revolutionary junta formally demanded that Sefior de Cespedes step out.

ALBANY, Sept. 6.-Governor Lehman today proclaimed Sept. 17 Constitution Day. He urged that the .schools, churches, civic, patriotic and fraternal organizations observe the period of Sept. 11 to 17 as Constitution Week.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 6 (AP). -- Jimmy Foxx's forty-first homer of the season and Lefty Grove, pitching his twentieth triumph, were largely accountable today for the Athletics' 5-to-4 victory over the Cleveland Indians. It was the opener of a four-game series, the last between the two clubs this year.

PARIS, Sept. 6. -- France paid a last tribute to Georges Leygues, former Minister of Marine, this morning with all the traditional pomp and military display that characterized national funerals for her great dead.

The Art Etudents League will open tomorrow an exhibition of paintings, drawings and etchings by about 500 New Yorkers who earn their living in more than 100 assorted occupations, but who would like to study art.

Thirteen Manhattan properties and seven in the Bronx were bid in by plaintiffs at foreclosure auctions yesterday. Among the twenty properties apartment houses predominated, though the list included also several dwellings, taxpayers, a loft building and a vacant plot.
CHICAGO, Sept. 6 (AP). -- Bud Tinning withstood a ninth-inning challenge by the Braves today and the Cubs took the opener of the threegame series, 4 to 3.

CHICAGO, Sept. 6. -- Asserting that headlines reporting signs of business improvement "are bringing hope to millions of American families," Howard E. Blood, president of the Norge Corporation, today praised the newspapers as "our greatest public servant in the upswing now under way."

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Sept. 6. -- Joseph A. Mericle, 26, of Beacon, attendant at the Matteawan State Hospital for the Criminal Insane, was suspended late today by Dr. Raymond F.C. Kieb, superintendent, as a result of investigation of the four-hour riot.
LONDON, Sept. 6. -- Former Prime Minister David Lloyd George published today the first volume of his war memories, in which, he says, he is "repeating what he has seen in a nightmare."

DETROIT, Sept. 6 (AP). -- Describing as "a pack of lies" charges of banking misconduct made by the Rev. Charles E. Coughlin against him, E.D. Stair, publisher of The Detroit Free Press, told the one-man grand jury investigating bank closings today that he did not want to "bandy words with a man so devoid of truth and honor as Father Coughlin."
WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., Sept. 6. -- First-round matches in the women's Mason and Dixon golf championship were completed today without an upset on the Old White course.

Information concerning the bonds of the new Home Owners Loan Corporation is being obtained by the committee on stock list of the New York Stock Exchange. When all facts with regard to the issue have been gathered, it is believed the Ex- change will decide whether it will admit the bonds to its list.
After the dismissal by Governor Lehman of removal charges filed by James E. Finegan, Controller Charles W. Berry announced yesterday that his resignation as of Sept. 15 would stand.
WATKINS GLEN, N.Y., Sept. 6. -- Watkins Glen lost its greatest attraction today with the departure of its celebrated deer from the rocky ledge it had occupied for twelve days.

Thirty-eight candidates reported to Head Coach Harold J. Parker at Lewisohn Stadium yesterday as City College opened its annual football drive. Only eight of the thirteen veterans invited to appear were on hand. The others will report later this week.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Condemnation of bullfighting: is as old as the sport itself, and complaints are based upon the prevention-of-cruelty-to-animals sentiment that prompts promoters to strain at a gnat and swallow a camel. In the humble opinion of this entrant into the discussion, any sport in which the contestants have equal chances is not only fair but worthy of encouragement.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 6 (AP). -- A reduction by Texas of one-fourth of its oil output and abandonment there of efforts to delay Federal control was hailed in administration sources tonight as an initial victory for governmental moves to hold the flow of petroleum to market in line with demand.

CHICAGO, Sept. 6. -- Threats were heard today of an embargo on ship- ments of pigs to the market here unless farmers show more disposition to cooperate in marketing the stock to be bought by the government. Tuesday's receipts aggregated 103,000, the second largest on record, and about 25,000 were carried over for today, although packers are working at maximum capacity.

Ralph A. Kohn vice president and treasurer of the bankrupt Paramount-Publix Corporation, told yesterday of the payment to five executives of the company of bonuses in 1929 totaling about $2,225,000. He testified before Federal Referee Henry K. Davis at 140 Nassau Street.

Samuel Untermyer's recommendations for new city taxes were submitted yesterday to the Board of Estimate, and it appeared last night that an attempt would be made to jam them through a meeting of the Board of Estimate and Board of Aldermen today.

WILMER ALLISON and Adrian Quist of the Australian forces were the first pair to swing into action on the tennis front yesterday. Quist is a medium-sized, brown-haired chap from Adelaide, 20 years old. He has a well-rounded game and started smoothly against the Texas ranger. He ran out the first set at 6 -- 1, largely because Allison was storming the net in the wrong way.

CHICAGO, Sept. 7 -- Patriotism and nationalism are a mild form of nostalgia, which, in its more extreme cases, is "a pathological condition involving acute physiological disturbance," Dr. Beardsley Ruml of the University of Chicago told the opening sessions today of the forty-first annual meeting of the American Psychological Association, held at the University of Chicago.
ST.LOUIS, Sept. 7 (AP) -- The Cardinals pounded Ragland and Berly today while Dizzy Dean held the Phillles to seven scattered hits and St. Louis won, 10 to 1, and advanced to fourth place.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 7 (AP) -- The world's second largest telescope, so powerful that it will permit astronomers to photograph stars 1,000,000 times fainter than the faintest star visible to the unaided eye, is to be constructed at Mount Locke, near Fort Davis, Texas.
NEW YORK. Mrs. Ellis Hollingsworth of Paris is at the Plaza.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 7 (AP) -- Monte Weaver of the Senators held the White Sox to a single hit in the first eight innings today, but lost his game, 1 to 0, when he allowed two singles and a walk for a run in the ninth.
MARINE BARRACKS, QUANTICO, Va., Sept. 7 (AP) -- More khakiclad marines, this time an aircraft squadron, were told today to get everything ready to take off toward Cuba on a moment's notice.

With Wall Street undecided whether the national administration, is interested immediately in the course of the markets, speculative interest was reduced yesterday to a minimum. Transactions were of less than the usual size. There was a great deal of gossip, in the financial district, with respect to the market outlook.
LONDON, Sept. 7 -- The British Trade Union Congress showed by an overwhelming vote today that it had as little liking for the Communist form of dictatorship as for the Fascist variety.
NEWARK, N.J., Sept. 7 (AP) -- The Orioles found the offerings and wildness of two Newark pitchers much to their liking tonight and gained an easy 8-to-3 victory.

HAVANA, Sept. 7 -- The revolutionary junta governing Cuba struggled today to preserve order, prove its strength and win from the United States the recognition that possibly is the alternative of intervention.

PARIS, Sept. 7 -- The news of the death of Viscount Grey of Fallodon was received in France today with mingled expressions of admiration and gratitude for his part in bringing Britain into the World War and criticism that he waited until the last moment.
VIENNA, Sept. 7 -- Sixty thousand foreigners have arrived here to attend the "German Catholic rally" which will be in progress for the next five days.

Bank clearings of twenty-one leading cities in the United States in the week ended Wednesday were smaller in the aggregate than in the preceding week and also than in the corresponding week of last year, after having remained at a level above those a year ago during July and August, based on daily average figures for those months.

LEICESTER, England, Sept. 7 -- If the great industrial countries want pre-war prosperity they must recreate the pre-war conditions under which the gold standard proved so highly successful, Professor J.H. Jones told economists of the British Association for the Advancement of Science today.

General John F. O'Ryan, candidate for the fusion nomination for Mayor against F.H. LaGuardia, was appointed yesterday chairman of the Fusion Business, Industrial and Professional Committee by William H. Chadbourne, campaign manager.

LONDON, Sept. 7 -- Anxious interest is being shown in diplomatic circles here over unofficial reports that fugitive Austrian Nazis are drilling in Bavaria and planning a coup to declare the independence of Tyrol.

According to veteran boat captains along the Atlantic Coast from Montauk to Cape May, which takes in most of the salt water angling territory in which metropolitan fishermen enjoy their sport, conditions this year have been very odd.

SHANGHAI, Sept. 7 (AP) -- Plans for a gigantic program of highway, railway and irrigation development, designed to bring China nearer its long-sought goal or economic independence and security, were revealed today by the Chinese Government.

W.S. Farish, chairman of the Standard Oil Company of New Jersey, denied reports emanating from Washington last night that he did not stand ready to give information to the planning and coordinating committee set up under the oil industry's code.
PARIS, Sept. 7 (AP) -- The weekly statement of the Bank of France shows the following changes, in francs:
WASHINGTON, Sept. 7 (AP) -- The Labor Department announced today that wholesale prices continued to advance during the week ending Sept. 2, increasing one-tenth of 1 per cent over the previous week.

Fifteen properties in Manhattan and the Bronx were bid in yesterday by plaintiffs in foreclosure actions. Activity in the auction rooms was almost as great as on the preceding day, when twenty parcels were on the block.

SEIGNIORY CLUB, Que., Sept. 7 (Canadian Press) -- For the tenth consecutive year since the international series began, United States senior golfers today routed the Canadians, 21 points to 11, to retain their hold on the Duke of Devonshire, Cup.

In ability to grasp an intricate subject like transit or city finance Mr. UNTERMYER has few equals. It is a relief to have him put his mind to a problem which has hitherto been too often left to ignorant politicians. However, in his latest report to the Board of Estimate he treats them tenderly enough.

GLENS FALLS, N.Y., Sept. 7 -- Rolling in an eight-foot putt at the eighteenth green, Jimmy Hines, the blond-haired professional from the Timber Point Club, Great River, L.I., capped a brilliant round with a birdie 2 for a 68 to assume the lead today in the Glens Falls open golf tourney.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 7 -- A conference of shipping operators was held behind closed doors at the Shipping Board offices today at the instance of Admiral Hutch I. Cone, chairman of the board, to lay the foundation for an NRA code to cover the whole shipping industry.

BERLIN, Sept. 7 -- Dr. Otto Kiep, German Consul General in New York, has been relieved of his duties as part of a larger shake-up in the German diplomatic service that had long been foreshadowed. The order for it was signed by President von Hindenburg today.

MADRID, Sept. 7 -- The struggle between the old Spain and the new, which has developed into a dangerous class battle, neared a climax today when Premier Azana called on President Alcala Zamora and asked him for an expression of confidence, which was not granted.

HAVANA, Sept. 7 -- Turbulent Cuba stood at the crossroads today, with some political factions convinced that civil war would be necessary to solve her governmental problem, while others looked for intervention by the United States.

TOKYO, Sept. 7 -- Representative Tinkham of Massachusetts, here on his way for a tiger shoot in French Indo-China, has sandwiched into his timetable a faster aerial tour of Manchukuo than any yet made by an American.

WESTBURY, L.I., Sept. 7 -- Three practice games were held by national open championship entries on the polo fields of the Meadow Brook Club today. The fields, still heavy from recent rains, were soft and held play to a slow pace for the most part.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 7 -- The daily average volume of Federal Reserve Bank credit outstanding during the week ended Sept. 6, as reported by the Federal Reserve Bank was $2,304,000,000, an increase of $37,000,000, compared with the preceding week, and a decrease of $26,000,000 compared with the corresponding week in 1932.

Even apart from his role in the Great War, Sir EDWAHD GREY, as most people still prefer to call him, was a great figure in British public life. Responsible for the conduct of foreign affairs over so long a stretch of years, he impressed himself upon his country and the world by his wide intelligence, temperate policies and unresting labors for peace.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 7 (AP) -- Heeding a request of the National Recovery Administration, the executive board of the Cleveland Street Car Men's Union tonight postponed indefinitely a strike called for tomorrow morning which had threatened to paralyze Greater Cleveland's entire public transportation system.

CHICAGO, Sept. 7 -- Operators in grain on the Board of Trade here continue to do little pending developments under the NRA, and while most of them express confidence regarding the ultimate future, they are buying little. The result is that small selling orders have more effect than usual on prices.

The clock turned back to 19.28 at Forest Hills yesterday to toll the heaviest reckoning taken in a men's national tennis championship since William Tilden, William Johnston and R. Norris Williams 2d were engulfed in a French uprising in the quarter finals.

Strict Money Changers. The Associated Press story of a Nazi price on Professor EINSTEIN'S head gives the sum as $4,550. Some readers may be torn for a moment between indignation at the act in itself and wonder at the odd amount.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 7 -- Sixteen more destroyers were drawn into the naval plan as it affects preparations for possible Cuban service today, raising to a total of twenty-nine the number of armed vessels thus far ordered to prepare for action.

Forty-eight candidates, the largest squad in Columbia's modern football history, reported yesterday at Baker Field for the initial drill of the season. A few more aspirants are expected to augment the squad today. When daily sessions actually get under way on Monday the Morningside squad will number well over fifty.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., Sept. 7 -- The Larchmont Yacht Club crew came very close to making a perfect score in the annual midget championship of Long Island Sound by winning the fifth and last race of the series today to tally 49 points out of a possible 50.

There was an early improvement of a few points in prices on the Cotton Exchange yesterday but it was canceled and the list ended at the bottom with losses of 13 to 17 points. Another block of 15,000 bales was taken from the market, believed to represent government operations in obtaining title to seed-loan cotton, although hedging pressure was in excess of buying power.

Production of steel in the United States in August amounted to 2,900,611 tons, according to the American Iron and Steel Institute. This compared with 3,203,810 tons in July, which was the largest output for any month since August, 1930, and with 846,730 tons in August, 1932.

The Western colt Hadagal, owned by the Calumet Farm of Warren Wright, created a surprise at Belmont Park yesterday when he was the easiest sort of winner of the sixty-third running of the Champagne Stakes, one of the oldest tests in the country for juveniles.

Two things that have lately impressed Arthur Garfield Hays, he reports in his new book, "Trial by Prejudice," published today by Covici, Friede, are a drawing with caption, and a remark. The drawing showed a woman looking up from a newspaper and saying to her husband: "But if Mr. Mooney was acquitted and didn't attack these white girls, why is he still in prison?"

Miss Louise Burton Laidlaw, daughter of Mrs. James Lees Laidlaw of 60 East Sixty-sixth Street and Sands Point, L.I., and the late Mr. Laidlaw, has completed plans for her marriage to Dana Converse Backus, also of this city, which will take place on the afternoon of Sept. 16 at Hazeldean, the country place of her mother in Sands Point.

Tammany pledged complete cooperation with the NRA drive, particularly in the campaign to obtain pledges from consumers, at a meeting in Tammany Hall yesterday. After Grover A. Whalen, NRA city chairman, had addressed a meeting of the executive committee, the following resolution, offered by John F. Curry, the leader, was adopted unanimously:

To the Editor of The New York Times: It is stated that with our modern traffic four destructive agencies are at work: suction, abrasion, speed and impact. The effect of these must be successfully eliminated or reduced if road surfaces are to prove durable. According to Harry Tucker's letter to THE NEW YORK TIMES, the latter is the one to combat, and yet to combat this evil engineers still are hide-bound by price considerations.

NEWARK, N.J., Sept. 7 -- More than 15,000 persons marched today in a parade which featured Newark's celebration of its National Recovery Administration Day. The police estimated that another 100,000 persons watched the parade.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 7 -- Hugh S. Johnson, National Recovery Administrator, tonight presented bituminous coal operators with a fair competition code for their industry.
MEMPHIS, Tenn., Sept. 7 (AP) -- Lloyd P. Layne, nationally known well-builder and sportsman, died at a hospital here today after a brief illness. Death was attributed to pneumonia. His age was 41.

HARRISON, N.Y., Sept. 7 -- Mrs. Russell Holman of Innis Arden today won the Women's Westchester-Fairfield Golf Association two-day, nine-hole match play tournament at the Green Meadow Country Club. She defeated Miss Marie Jenney of Hudson River, 2 and 1, in the final of the first flight, after both had triumphed in semi-finals in the morning.

Although the visiting team, of English cricketers under the leadership of Sir Julien Cahn, British sportsman, provided another batting treat at the Staten Island Cricket Club in Livingston yesterday, they had to be content with an official draw in the fourteenth match of the North American tour.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 7 (AP) -- Hugh S. Johnson, NRA Administrator and president of the Lea Fabrics, Inc., when informed of the charge of Eric Ross, labor union official, that the Newark, N.J., plant of his concern was operating in violation of the NRA, immediately telephoned the plant management.

GENEVA, Sept. 7 -- The "instinctive and spontaneous resort to boycott," against Germany by the Jewish masses, as a weapon of self-defense was approved in a resolution adopted tonight by a committee of the Jewish World Conference.

Rogers Hornsby tried an experiment against the Yankees yesterday at the Stadium and it led to disaster. The St. Louis pilot started E. Garland Braxton, southpaw just recalled by the Browns, against the McCarthymen. He lasted just long enough to lay the foundation for a 12-8 Yankee, triumph.

The Federal Reserve Bank of New York announced no change yesterday in its rediscount rate from the 2 1/2 per cent level that has ruled since May 26. The further shrinkage, since a week ago, in the returns possible to holders of bankers' bills, commercial paper and similar investments thus leaves the rediscount rate of still less significance than it was.

Mr. and Mrs. Bradford Norman gave a dinner last night in the Starlight roof garden of the Waldorf-Astoria. Their guests were Mr. and Mrs. Richard F. Hoyt Mr. and Mrs. William L. Cushing, Mr. and Mrs. Burrill Hoffman, Mr. and Mrs. William H. Vanderbilt, Mr. and Mrs. Marshall Field, Miss Eleanor Barry and Colonel William Donovan.

BERLIN, Sept. 7 -- The Boerse was dull and generally weaker today. Yesterday's effort at recovery apparently lacked conviction, and traders sought in cash whatever profits were available, but agreements among banks to "nurse"' quotations prevented larger losses.
An aerial parade of the Blue Eagle over Manhattan will be staged by fifteen of the nation's leading women fliers next Monday at noon.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Sept. 7 -- Tommy Berry climaxed a great week at the State Fair track by capturing the Western Horseman Futurity and the Syracuse Hotel Stakes as the Grand Circuit meeting closed today.

GLEN COVE, L.I., Sept. 7 -- After winning the qualifying round with an almost perfect score, 17-year-old Frank Strafaci of Dyker Beach fought an uphill battle to survive his first match in the Long Island junior championship at the Nassau Country Club today.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 7 -- President Roosevelt, setting aside the period beginning Oct. 8 as Fire Prevention "Week, issued this proclamation today:
The text of Samuel Untermyer's report on city finances as submitted to the Board, of Estimate follows:

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 7 -- A man, believed to be mentally deranged, who has made repeated demands on Cardinal Dougherty, archbishop of Philadelphia, for $50,000, was arrested tonight while prowling about the grounds of the prelate's residence in Merion.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I am aglow with pride because of having been hoisted by Professor Thomas McMorrow, in his letter in THE TIMES, from a lowly perch to a pedestal, cotenant with Max Muller, and I would ask for no more space here than enough to express my thanks, had not the professor issued a challenge I wish to answer.

William F. Delaney, dean of Brooklyn Democratic leaders and member of the Board of Water Supply, left an estate of only $9,000 and failed to make a will, it was disclosed yesterday in an administration proceeding brought in the Surrogate's Court in Brooklyn.
"Berkeley Square," Fox's version of the John Balderston play, will have its premiere at the Gaiety Theatre next Wednesday evening.

NEWARK, N.J., Sept. 7 -- The Lea Fabrics Company, Inc., at 768 Frelinghuysen Avenue, Newark, of which General Hugh S. Johnson, National Recovery Administrator, is president, was accused of being an NRA violator in a telegram sent to the General today by the International Carpet Workers Union, a new labor group.
Each of the ten chain-store organizations that have reported sales for August has made a substantial increase from the corresponding month of 1932. All but one chain showed gains over July.

ROCKLAND, Mass., Sept. 7 -- John Wesley Rice, a prominent scholar and educator, died last night at his home here, where he had resided since 1926, when he retired as assistant librarian at Princeton University because of ill health.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 7 -- Carrying in each hand a large suitcase filled with papers, Raymond Moley, once identified as chief of President Roosevelt's "brain trust," today walked down two long flights of stairs in the State Department and out of the building, closing his career as Assistant Secretary of State.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 7 (AP) -- Heralding the beginning of a more active movement for price control, the Consumers' Advisory Board of the Recovery Administration demanded today that "as a part of the hearings on codes, representatives of the industries affected should be called upon to give such cost and price information as may be necessary as a bench-mark in the checking of price increases under the code."

Springfield, Mass. A syndicate composed of the First of Boston Corporation, R.L. Day Co., Estabrook Co. and Whiting, Weeks Knowles, Inc., won yesterday the award of a new issue of $890,000 city of Springfield (Mass.) bonds, due on Sept. 1, 1934 to 1938.
Commercial and apartment house leases were the outstanding features of yesterday's real estate market.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 7 -- The bright hope of higher salaries enthused government officials today as the Budget Bureau, in calling for expense estimates for next year, asked that salary figures be submitted on the base-pay rate -- without any 15 per cent reduction.

NORFOLK, Va., Sept. 7 (AP) -- Appealing to all Virginians, irrespective of political affiliations, to support repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment at the special election on Oct. 3, Postmaster General Farley expressed hope here today that "the result shall be so overwhelming that it will truly reflect the sentiment of all the voters of your State."
COHASSET, Mass., Sept. 7 -- Cohasset's feminine crew today practically clinched the women's national sailing championship and the Mrs. Charles Francis Adams Cup.

LIVINGSTON, Mont., Sept. 7 -- Some of the innermost and carefully guarded secrets of Yellowstone Park bears -- what they do with their months of Winter slumber or wakefulness -- may be pried from bashful Bruin when cold weather comes.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 7 -- Setting a precedent in method and a record in low interest charges, the Treasury offered a block of nine-month one-fourth of 1 per cent cercificates today, sufficient to meet certificate maturities Sept. 15.

Declines were the rule yesterday in the spot and futures markets for commodities here, with sugar, wool tops and silver showing gains in forward trading, and lard and wool tops advancing in cash trading. The latter rose 1/2 cent to a new high of $1.06. Cash grains, cocoa, tin, zinc, printcloth and cotton declined.
CHICAGO, Sept. 7 -- Loren Morrison of Council Bluffs, Iowa, figured that at 80 he must have reached the age of discretion.

HORNELL, N.Y., Sept. 7 (AP) -- Denying he was wholly responsible for the wreck of the Erie's Atlantic express at Binghamton Tuesday night, M.H. King, engineer of the milk train which plowed into the rear of the passenger, said tonight that he was to blame to the extent of "going too fast to stop within the required distance."

Arnold Sehonberg, one of the world's foremost composers and teachers of music, who is an exile now from Germany, will come to this country next month to teach harmony and composition at the Malkin Conservatory of Music in Boston, it was announced yesterday by Joseph Malkin, director of the conservatory.

BERLIN, Sept. 7 -- The diplomatic relations recently established between the German Attorney General, who is prosecuting a Dutchman, a German and three Bulgarians on a charge of burning down the Reichstag building, and the international commission of jurists intent on showing that the Reichstag was burned by the Nazis themselves were broken off today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 7. -- Solvency in contrast to liquidity will be the measuring stick applied to banks by the new Federal Bank Deposit Insurance Corporation when they apply for membership, Walter J. Cummings of Chicago, who will become chairman of the corporation's board, declared today soon after announcement of his appointment.

BIG BAY, Mich., Sept. 7 (AP) -- Henry Ford, still a silent holdout from the NRA automobile code, is represented by vacation companions at his Huron Mountain retreat near here as "hesitating" over whether he will give final and complete approval to the code.

PATERSON, N.J., Sept. 7 -- The executive board of the United Textile Workers branch of the American Federation of Labor voted today to call upon silk workers through the nation to join the strike which started in Paterson one week ago.

Construction of a ship canal to connect the Delaware River at Bordentown with Raritan Bay at Sayreville is not a new project. The visit of a New Jersey committee, appointed by the State Senate, to Washington to confer with Secretary ICKES was made not only to advance the enterprise but to urge that it would give employment to 2,000 men for five years.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 7 -- The text of the code for the bituminous coal industry as presented by General Johnson follows:

CHICAGO, Sept. 7 -- In the first procedure of the kind in Chicago, a Catholic Church tribunal is holding daily sessions in a small room of Columbus Hospital hearing testimony regarding the virtues and miracles associated with Mother Frances Xavier Cabrini, a resident of Chicago for several years before her death in 1917.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 7 (AP) -- Hurling, shut-out ball as he made his big league debut, Johnny Marcum, rookie righthander, pitched the Athletics to a 6-to-0 triumph over the Indians today, giving the victors two straight in the four-game series.
BARCELONA, Sept. 7 -- A new revolt flared up today in Andorra, the fourth of the kind this year.
The closing of "Music in the Air," at the Forty-fourth Street Theatre, which was announced for tomorrow evening, has been postponed for another week.

TURIN, Italy, Sept. 7 -- United States track and field athletes today won one title in the national interuniversity games in Mussolini Stadium, took second place in another event and qualified two men for the finals in two others.

Prices of bonds continued weak on the Stock Exchange yesterday with the exception of United States Government obligations. While the Federal issues were up 1-32 to 9-32 point, many domestic corporation bonds lost 1 to 3 points and in a few cases more.
To the Editor of The New York Times: The experience of an orphan recently returned to an institution after an unsuccessful trial adoption has been needlessly painful to every one concerned.
