Opera was resumed last night at the Hippodrome, where it blossomed forth last June as an overnight popular sensation. "Aida," which was presented last night, does not come exactly under the head of sensation, but its popularity was sufficient to attract a goodsized audience on a warm evening.

After Sept. 15 no more beer licenses will be issued in the State, for a time at least, the State Alcoholic Beverage Control Board ruled yesterday. Announcements of the ruling were sent to all county boards.

Supreme Court Justice Irwin Untermyer heard argument and reserved decision yesterday on applications by political factions of both parties for the removal of the names of candidates for county committees at the coming primary. Charles H. Tuttle, appearing for the anti-Koenig forces of the Republican party, told the court that he had the opportunity of "vindicating the election laws" while arguing to have 129 names stricken from the county committee ballot.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 7 -- President and Mrs. Roosevelt will open at the White House tomorrow the annual conference to consider the welfare needs of American communities and the part of social agencies in the National Recovery Program.

It was reunion day yesterday atop the United States liner Manhattan, when nearly all the Roosevelts in the country -- cousins and distant cousins, sons and mothers, and even grandchildren met by chance to meet returning travelers. Only the President was absent.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 7 -- Rear Admiral Richard E. Byrd will start from Boston on Sept. 25 on another exploration expedition to the Antarctic.

DETROIT, Sept. 7 (AP) -- In sharp language, James O. Murfin, former director of the closed First National Bank-Detroit, attacked the Federal Government today for "filing false reports," and criticized Senator James Couzens and the Rev. Father Charles E. Coughlin for their testimony before the one-man grand jury investigating bank closings here.

Pleading for a cessation of rate adjustments before the Public Service Commission yesterday, Floyd L. Carlisle, chairman of the board of the Consolidated Gas Company, said the effect of the NRA compliance might force the electric companies of the Consolidated group to apply for rate increases.

W.E. Hedger, president of the Canal Carriers Association, Inc., in a letter to General Hugh S. Johnson accompanying a code of fair competition for this group of water carriers, pledged the association's wholehearted cooperation with the NRA, it was reported yesterday.

Preparations for putting into effect the use of the NRA label on all garments produced in the industry as a guarantee of observance by employers of the provisions of the agreement for the coat and suit industry were completed yesterday by the Coat and Suit Code Authority, the agency set up under the code for the governing of the industry.

BERLIN, Sept. 7 -- Despite a denial from the Ministry of Propaganda, persistent rumors were current in diplomatic circles tonight that Chancellor Hitler intended to take charge of the Foreign Ministry.

OKLAHOMA CITY, Sept. 7 (AP) -- The Oklahoma Corporation Commission issued today an order setting the State's allowable oil production at 540,000 barrels daily, a reduction of 61,500 barrels, to meet the Federal code allocation. The order is effective at 7 A.M. tomorrow.

The New York Stock Exchange anounced yesterday that it would be open for business tomorrow. The two-hour session will be the first held since July 24. For six consecutive Saturdays, the Exchange has been closed as a relief measure for the personnel of brokerage firms.
BALTIMORE, Md., Sept. 7 -- The St. Mary's Industrial School baseball team defeated the Bronx Terrors, champions of the New York Junior Police Athletic League, today, 5 to 3.

The firm of George Abbott and Philip Dunning has decided to open its first play of the new season, "Heat Lightning," next Thursday night at the Booth Theatre. Leon Abrams and Mr. Abbott collaborated on the play, which was tried out two weeks ago in Westport, Conn.

More stories of dire want unaided by the Home Relief Bureau were presented by unemployed persons and were corroborated by professional social workers yesterday when an unofficial "jury" of citizens at the Russell Sage Foundation auditorium held, its second session.

CHICAGO, Sept. 7 (AP) -- Grave fears that two balloons in the International James Gordon Bennett balloon races might have drifted out over the Atlantic Ocean and carried four men to their deaths were expressed tonight by officials of the race.

The vacant vice presidency of the Westchester Racing Association has been filled by John Hay Whitney, it became known yesterday. The step is one of unusual significance for race followers inasmuch as it assures the continuance of the present administration of Joseph E. Widener as president of the association which operates Belmont Park.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 7 (AP) -- The death last night of Viscount Grey of Fallodon was termed today by former Secretary of State Frank B. Kellogg a great loss to the world.

Methods of combating the Dutch elm disease that threatens destruction of elm trees of the Northeastern States occupied the special attention yesterday of the ninth national shade tree conference in the New York Botanical Garden Museum in Bronx Park.

PARIS, Sept. 7 -- The question of what constitutes a professional tennis player and just how closely the line should be drawn today was put squarely to the French Tennis Federation by Henri Cochet, who announced he would play with and against professionals in a Franco-American series beginning here Sept. 23, but would not accept pay for his efforts.

Three Brooklyn detectives arrested yesterday five men suspected of being members of a racketeering gang which in the last three months has been holding up the drivers of loaded trucks along the Brooklyn waterfront and stealing the shipments, mostly of tin, valued at a total of $50,000.

The Henry Mandel Holding Corporation has added to its properties the four-story dwellings at 531 and 537 West End Avenue, near Eighty-sixth Street. The plots are 19 by 100 and 20 by 100 feet, respectively. The sale was arranged for the Littlefield family by the Hoaglands Realty Company and Kidder, Fitzpatrick Allison.
PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 7 (AP) -- Scoring her third triumph in the women's middle States tennis championship, Miss Joan Ridley, ranking entrant from Ipswich, England, forged into the semi-finals today.

Fall Assortments Worry Stores. Lack of adequate assortments of Fall merchandise was cited yesterday as something of a handicap in the development of retail trade this week. The situation was traced to depletion of store stocks by excellent consumer buying in August and to the slow deliveries which have prevented the complete rounding out of Fall offerings to consumers that is normal at this time.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 7 -- Joseph B. Eastman, Coordinator of Transportation, told the railroads of the country, today that "managements must keep their hands off, so far as labor organizations are concerned."
LONDON, Sept. 7 (AP) -- The weekly statement of the Bank of England shows the following, changes, in pounds sterling:
CINCINNATI, Sept, 7 -- In marked contrast to their slugging performance in yesterday's second game, the Reds subsided meekly before the Dodgers today and were blanked, 2 to 0.
PITTSBURGH, Sept. 7 -- The Giants ran full tilt into an adverse wind today that fairly uprooted them.

Reactionary influences were at work yesterday in all the important markets. Stocks, commodities and corporation bonds suffered losses in their open-market values. United States Government securities moved upward, against the trend. The dollar had a partial recovery in the foreign exchange market.
BEVERLY FARMS, Mass., Sept. 7 -- Colonel Edward M. House said today, after learning of the death of Viscount Grey of Fallodon:

Several important issues of securities which were to have been offered to the public as soon as conditions in the capital market were favorable were reported yesterday to have been held up in their preliminary stages because of the civil liabilities applicable to independent auditors as well as to officers, directors, underwriters, appraisers and others under the Securities Act of 1933.
CHICAGO, Sept. 7 -- The code for banks adapted by the American Bankers Association is as follows:

The charge that the bankruptcy action begun last March in Federal court against S.W. Straus Co. was the result of collusion was made yesterday before Judge Martin T. Manton, presiding judge of the United States Circuit Court of Appeals here.

WARSAW, Sept. 7 -- Reports are current here about a secret Polish-Russian-Rumanian conference at Zaleszczyki, a holiday resort in Southern Poland near the Rumanian frontier, where Marshal Pilsudski has been staying since last Sunday.

CHICAGO, Sept. 7 -- James F.T. O'Connor, the Controller of the Currency, announced here today the names of the two directors of the Deposit Insurance Corporation who, with himself, will direct the machinery set up under the Banking Act of 1933 to guarantee bank deposits.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 7 -- Initial consignments of newly mined gold were received for assay at the San Francisco Mint and the New York Assay Office today. Treasury officials on the basis of preliminary reports estimated that they aggregated about 10,000 ounces.

Yesterday the bare-headed lad who si alertly silent in inanimate bronze through the other days and nights of the year in Princes Street Gardens, Edinburgh, looking up to the Castle Rock which thrusts itself against the sky, was articulate in the voice of the sculptor, Dr. R. TAIT MCKENZIK, who made the anniversary address.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 7 (AP) -- Circuit Judge H.A. Hamilton approved late today the sale of the Missouri State Life Insurance Company to a group of financiers in New York headed by David Milton, son-in-law of John D. Rockefeller Jr., and Walter W. Head, former president of the American Bankers Association.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Sept. 7 -- Speaking before a crowd of 7,000 at the State Fair, Governor Lehman today urged use of Federal funds for development on a large scale of a system of improved roads to connect farms with main highways.

NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 7 -- About 100 persons were present this afternoon at the mah jongg, bridge and backgammon party given for the benefit of the New York Women's League for Animals at Wyndham, the home of Miss Rosa Ann Grosvenor, a vice president of the league.

A number of leases in the Park Avenue section and in Greenwich Village were included in the long list of apartment rentals announced by brokers yesterday, as Fall leasing continued briskly. Several suites on lower Fifth Avenue also were taken.

Strenuous efforts were made yesterday by Grover A. Whalen, chairman of the local NRA organization, for settlement of the strike of 15,000 embroidery workers that went into effect yesterday morning despite attempts to prevent it. The Bonnaz Embroidery Workers Union, an affiliate of the International Ladies' Garment Workers, reported a 100 per cent response to its strike call.
The dispatch of United States naval forces to the vicinity of Cuba drew protests from various quarters yesterday.

The New York Stock Exchange will close at 1 o'clock Wednesday to enable its members to march in the President's NRA Day Parade up Fifth Avenue, according to Major Gen. Dennis E. Nolan, who was so advised yesterday by Richard P. Whitney, president of the Exchange.

The hope that Central Park eventually would have children's playgrounds at all its entrances was expressed yesterday by August Heckscher, the philanthropist. He spoke at a party given in his honor by about 150 children at the Hecksher Playground near the southwest end of the park.
Reports of earnings for various periods were issued yesterday by industrial and other corporations. Comparable figures were given. The deposits follow.

The new NRA stamp, which gave rise to a controversy two weeks ago when it was charged that the figure representing agriculture was "Russian," has aroused a second furore among stamp collectors and others, it became known yesterday.

A growing demand that the NRA program be made mandatory is being registered by consumers who are voicing their sentiments on the consumer pledge cards returned to local NRA headquarters at the Hotel Pennsylvania:

WASHINGTON, Sept. 8. -- Hundreds of thousands at men in the oil industry are on the watch for "chiselers" and important unreported violations of the industry's code are unlikely, in the opinion of the planning and coordination committee, the principal advisory agency set up.
BERLIN, Sept. 8. -- Nazi headquarters tonight issued a manifesto to "the party comrades" that was also a broadcast calling on them "to aid their German brothers of Austria."

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 8. -- Carl Hubbell today brought an abrupt halt to the Giants' alarming retreat from their seemingly impregnable hold on first place in the National League pennant race by turning back the Pirates with six hits in the concluding game of the series.

The United States paid honor yesterday to General Francesco de Pinedo, famous Italian flier who was killed at Floyd Bennett Field last Saturday morning. The coffin, carried on a caisson with a full military escort from the army and representatives of the crews of the Italian naval vessels now in the harbor, was borne through the streets to St. Patrick's Cathedral as crowds lined the sidewalks with outstretched palms in the Fascist salute.

Nearly 500 striking shoe workers crowded into the Supreme Court in Brooklyn yesterday to hear arguments on the suits by eleven Brooklyn shoe manufacturers to enjoin picketing by members of the Shoe and Leather Workers Industrial Union.
The New York Stock Exchange announced yesterday several changes in partnerships and in securities listed on the Exchange.

BERLIN, Sept. 8. -- The German Foreign Office has apologized to the United States Government through Ambassador William E. Dodd for recent attacks by Nazis on American citizens. The following communique was issued by the United States Embassy:

Subsidiaries of the Standard Oil Companies of New Jersey and Indiana yesterday advanced prices of crude oil in the greater mid-continent area 15 cents a barrel. This is the second advance this week and brings the price of 40 gravity oil in that territory to 97 cents a barrel.

The government's estimate yesterday of a cotton crop 100,000 bales larger than was indicated a month ago came nearer to the expectations of the cotton trade than any report issued in a long time, and after a temporary rally of $1 a bale, prices on the Cotton Exchange broke 30 points and ended with losses of 15 to 20 points.

To the Editor of The New York Times: It will be recalled that when the American delegation to the recent World Economic Conference in London suggested a scheme of public works, Walter Kunciman promptly announced that the British Government would not engage in any such undertaking; that they had already, spent u100,000,000 in that way, and had been disillusioned by the results.

Transactions on the Stock Exchange yesterday amounted to 1,270,740 shares, compared with 1,072,320 shares on the day before. The composite index of averages showed a net decline of 17 cents. The share market was irregular most of the day, but the drift was toward lower levels.

HARTFORD, Conn., Sept. 8. -- With the approval of Governor Cross, the Connecticut Insurance Department today lifted all bans on insurance-policy lending, which have been in effect since March 9, when the national banking holiday forced fast action by the Legislature.

A new competition for international military teams has been added to the program of the National Horse Show, it was announced yesterday. This will be a high-score jumping event, and will replace the class for pairs of international officers' jumpers at the exhibition to be held in Madison Square Garden Nov. 8-14.
Activity in the auction rooms yesterday continued to surpass the private realty trading. Fourteen foreclosed properties in Manhattan and the Bronx were bid in by plaintiffs in the various actions.

EAST HAMPTON, L.I., Sept. 8. -- The work of training shepherd dogs to guide the blind was outlined to a group of one hundred persons here this afternoon by Mrs. Harrison Eustis, president of The Seeing Eye, at Bayberry Camp, the estate of Mrs. Charles H. Sabin.
VIENNA, Sept. 8. -- Politically, socially and in lesser degree industrially Vienna at present is the liveliest capital in Europe.
PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 8. -- Miss Joan Ridley of England and Miss Alice Francis of Orange, N.J., won the women's Middle States doubles tennis championship today.

Fusion leaders decided yesterday to appeal to the courts to establish the right to have their candidates appear on the voting machines as nominees of both the Republican party and the City Fusion party.

TOKYO, Sept. 8. -- Chief Officer Johnson, Second Officer Hargraves and Second Engineer Blue of the British steamer Nanchang, who have been released after being held captive by Chinese bandits twenty-three weeks, today reached Newchwang, Manchuria, where a British Vice Consul, D.H. Clarke, relieved their Japanese liberators of further responsibility for them.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Sept. 8 (AP). -- The death of Professor Henry W. Farnam, Yale economist, released from trust a fund which it was estimated had multiplied to $5,000,000 since its creation a half century ago by his father, Henry Farnam, railroad pioneer, it was disclosed today.

EAST HAMPTON, L.I., Sept. 8. -- John Roosevelt, youngest son of President Franklin D. Roosevelt, and Mr. Roosevelt, arrived today for a visit with John Graham, son of Mr. and Mrs. Kelley Graham and a class-mate at Groton. Young Mr. Graham has just returned from Kennebunkport, Me., where he visited another class-mate, Hugh Auchincloss.

Carlos Montalvo, son-in-law of Alberto Barreras, former President of the Cuban Senate, was set upon by a group of young Cubans in the lobby of the Walton Hotel, 104 West Seventieth Street at Columbus Avenue, last night.

Bank exchanges in August in the principal clearing houses of the country totaled $20,716,733,315, a decline of 18 per cent from the turn- over in July, but 3.5 per cent greater than the aggregate in August, 1932.

With more than 207,000 Blue Eagle employers and employes al- ready enrolled for the President's NRA Day parade up Fifth Avenue next Wednesday, Major Gen. Den- nis A. Nolan, chairman of the parade committee, announced yesterday that divisional quotas might have to be cut.

About 100 policemen searched every corner of Central Park last night for an unidentified Negro who in the last few weeks has been terrorizing couples, robbing them under the threat of laceration by his razor and threatening harm to young women.

ON BOARD THE SCHOONER MORRISSEY, In Hecla Strait, Sept. 8. -- Tonight, perched ninety fee above the deck of my little Morrissey, I was permitted to see a never to-be-forgotten sight. The Strait of the Fury and Hecla runs east and west, and Oid Sol, stowing himself away for the night, went down be hind the many floating pieces of ice in one blaze of glory.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 8. -- The Roosevelt recovery program was denounced today by Senator Hatfield, Republican, of West Virginia, in a letter to General Johnson.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler's address "Our Ship of State," reported in THE TIMES of Sept. 4, he suggests the introduction in the United States of some features of the Cabinet form of government as practiced in Great Britain and France, by having heads of the executive departments sit in the Senate and House and answer questions from the floor.

LEICESTER, England, Sept. 8. -- It was a gloomy picture of the effect of science and invention that Sir Josiah Stamp, British economist, held up for the contemplation of the British Association for the Advancement of Science, today.

The new city tax program was not rushed through yesterday, after all. Any attempt to enact all the items in the Untermyer schedule on less than twenty-four hours' notice would have been intolerable. Some of them, notably the proposed levy on the "investments" of savings banks, had not been so much as mentioned before, much less analyzed or weighed.

TRENTON, N.J., Sept. 8. -- An attempt of four inmates of the criminal insane wing of the New Jersey State Hospital here to make a break for freedom was frustrated today. One of the four, whose name was withheld, informed Oscar Heaps, supervisor of the criminal insane building, of the plans to make a break Sunday morning and steps immediately were taken to round up the four men.

BERLIN, Sept. 8. -- The Boerse continued its downward course today. Losses up to 3 per cent were common, while gains were rare. The additional declines were recorded in the face of an official announcement that unemployment during the second half of August had decreased by 207,000.

The Citizens Committee on Relief, which has held "jury" hearings for the last three days in the Russell Sage Foundation Building, with unaided needy persons testifying as to the city's handling of relief, will continue as a permanent organization and will press the fight for improvements.

MADRID, Sept. 8. -- The government of Premier Manuel Azana collapsed today under the load of reverses in last Sunday's election for members of a Tribunal of Constitutional Guarantees and the gradual disintegration of the parties supporting the government, especially the Radical Socialists and the Federals.

The electric companies here facing a 6 per cent rate cut by order of the Public Service Commission were rebuked yesterday by the commission's chairman, Milo R. Maltbie, for failure to supply details of losses estimated to result from compliance with the NRA.
CHICAGO, Sept. 8 (AP). -- Dan Sabath, racing in the colors of Albert Sabath of Chicago, easily scored in the Des Plaines Purse at five and one-half furlongs at Lincoln Fields today.

Colonel John Reed Kilpatrick, president of the Madison Square Garden Corporation, yesterday revealed that he was making some progress in his plan to bring boxing to a more solid standing by making known to the public the difficulties surrounding the signing of outstanding fighters.

BERLIN, Sept. 8 (London Times dispatch). -- There is reason to believe three of the highest Prussian legal officials have been arrested and faced with the threat of being placed in a concentration camp.
ST. LOUIS, Sept. 8 (AP). -- The Cardinals, back in a batting stride against the hapless Phillies, today downed the visitors, 6 to 5, to sweep the four-game series.

States and their political subdivisions continue conservative in the matter of new public financing. Next week only $5,180,038 of new bonds will come up for award, compared with this week's revised total of $8,048,253 and the weekly average for the year thus far of $13,196,026.

PORT HOPE, Ont., Sept. 8 (Canadian Press). -- The World Economic Conference in London failed because it adhered to economic ideas that were outworn and because it was too closely concerned with saving things that were not worth saving, Professor Raymond Moley told the Liberal Summer Conference here tonight.

One of the most interesting racing programs of the year is scheduled for this afternoon at Belmont Park. The three stakes on the card have such stars entered that each contest seems certain to be a thriller.

With business at a low ebb on the Stock Exchange yesterday, the price movements were of less interest than ordinarily. Operations for the advance were resumed in the forenoon and abandoned later. Prices were moderately lower at the end of the day.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 8. -- Damage to public buildings, docks and other government structures as a result of the recent three-day storm which lashed the Atlantic Coast will be repaired at once out of the funds of the Public Works Administration.

OTTAWA, Sept. 8 (Canadian Press). -- That the policy of government intervention to insure the orderly marketing of Canada's wheat crop will be carried out again this year has been accepted by observers at Ottawa. Information obtainable in official circles has been such as to indicate that no other course of action would be consistent in view of the wheat agreement signed at London.

HAVANA, Sept. 8. -- The Cuban revolutionary council sought today to carry out an agreement of all political factions to form a coalition Cabinet with a new President. All anti-Machado factions agreed early this morning to support the coalition move, but many questions remain to be settled.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 8. -- With all preparations completed to cope with any eventuality, officials here awaited patiently today the outcome of the meeting in Havana of the representatives of the many factions seeking to create a new government.

In idle or sleepless hours one meditates on Farleian multiplicity. JIM is how many gentlemen at once? He is two chairmen plus one Postmaster General in two aspects -- one sedentary at Washington, one itinerant -- plus the most Yoluminous of form-letter writers pigs the personal conductor of repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment plus the orator, statesman, sage.

CHICAGO, Sept. 8. -- Psychologists from Harvard, Yale, the University of Chicago and other universities who are attending the annual meeting of the American Psychological Association here engaged today in an impromptu discussion which at times threatened to become acrimonious.

PARIS, Sept. 8. -- Yesterday's listlessness continued today on the Bourse. The principal characteristic of the session was paucity of transactions. Although the general tendency of prices was downward, the business was so small that closing quotations were only slightly lower than those of yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 (AP). -- A cotton production control program for 1934 and 1935 has been approved by President Roosevelt and its outlines are expected to be announced tomorrow or early next week by Secretary Wallace.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The hours of my life spent with THE TIMES editorials, which are unparalleled in any other newspaper in the world, so far as my observation goes, are as acres of precious gems to me. Those columns are fabulously rich mother-lodes of current and ancient facts and learning, marvels of literary acumen and interpretative ability.
DUBLIN, Sept. 8. -- The fusion of Opposition parties against the de Valera government was ratified at two important national conferences at Mansion House today.

Frederick E. Murphy, chief American delegate to the wheat conference, returned yesterday on the North German Lloyd liner Europa well pleased with the accomplishments of the conference and convinced that "we will see $1 wheat within a year."

Miss Magnhild Almskaar of 147 Columbia Street, fiancee of Henry F. Sanborn, murdered railway executive, "is or may be or may claim to be his widow," it was disclosed yesterday in papers filed in Surrogate's Court.

MADRID, Sept. 8. -- Spanish observers are of the firm opinion that direct intervention by the United States in Cuba would ruin its prestige in South America and would seriously harm that trade market of the States.

PARIS, Sept. 8. -- If Austria becomes a part of Germany another European war will certainly follow, Henry Berenger, who is president of the Foreign Affairs Commission of the Senate, writes in today's Agence Economique et Financiere.
NEW YORK. Lady Louise Montagu of Brampton Park, Huntingdonshire, England, daughter of the Duke of Manchester, is at the Waldorf-Astoria.

WELLESLEY HILLS, Mass., Sept. 8. -- Standards of business based on social welfare and the right of labor to organize to protect consumer buying power to maintain the economic structure are the essentials of national recovery as exemplified in the NRA, Donald R. Richberg declared in an address here tonight before the Babson Institute.

Many Roosevelt Kin. There was a time in the last Presidential campaign when the Roosevelt cousinships reminded one of the student in music history. He was asked how many symphonies BEETHOVEN wrote, and he said three, the Fifth, Seventh and Ninth.
ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Sept. 8. -- Rebellion in the National Letter Carriers Association was voted down today when delegates at the annual convention here re-elected the old guard of officers.

King Feisal el Husein of Iraq, whose name means "the sword flashing down at the stroke" and who was a lineal descendant of the Prophet Mohammed in the thirtyseventh generation, was one of the most important and most glamourous figures of the war and postwar period.

PARIS, Sept. 8. -- At yesterday's meeting of the French Cabinet the situation regarding the debt to the United States was raised by Finance Minister Georges Bonnet, and it is understood that what may be called a decision in principle was reached.

TURIN, Italy, Sept. 8. -- Johnny Morriss and Ivan Fuqua added two more titles today to the United States total as they won their events in the international interuniversity games before a capacity crowd in Mussolini Stadium.
BOSTON, Sept. 8 (AP). -- The Tigers took a double-header from the Red Sox today, winning both games, 4 to 3, before a Shriners' and Ladies' day crowd of 10,000.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 8 (AP). -- Answering the separate maintenance suit of Mary McCormic, grand opera singer, today, Prince Serge M'Divani denied her charges of cruelty and contended he is not obligated in any way to support her because she deserted him without cause.

As a Massachusetts farm boy Dr. PARKHUKST "heard of New York with awe and trembling," as he himself said. When he was called to the pastorate of a church here he must have hesitated as did the prophet JONAH when summoned to go and preach against Nineveh.

MAZO DE LA ROCHE won $10,000 for the first book of her Jalna series because Little, Brown and the Atlantic Monthly Press thought it the most interesting of 1,100 manuscripts submitted. Judged for interest her newest book, "The Master of Jalna" (Little, Brown, $2.50), deserves as good a prize and probably, in the sum of royalties, will just about get it.

ELIZABETH, N.J., Sept. 8. -- The Union County Board of Freeholders Has given authorization for changing an issue of $200,000 registered county bonds as of April 7, 1931, to coupon bonds, the interest to remain at 4 per cent. The request was made by investment bankers who hold the bonds.
Tammany's plan to jam the Untermyer tax program through the Board of Estimate and the Board of Aldermen in one day was shelved suddenly yesterday noon, and hearings were set for Monday and Tuesday.

Continuing the foar months' record of expanding sales, retail trade not only has broadened under the stimulus of the opening of the Fall season, but has been accelerated by the "Buy Now" policy advocated by the NRA, according to the weekly review of Dun Bradstreet, Inc.

Sales of General Motors cars to consumers in the United States in August totaled 86,372 cars, compared with 87,298 in July and 37,230 in August, 1932. In August, 1931, 69,876 cars were sold, and in August, 1930, 86,426.

By the time the city fathers get around to settling the rights of the sidewalk cafes the outdoor dining season will be virtually over. After the middle of September the climate at this point in the world's surface grows unsteady. Some time next week expect that hit of mystic folklore, "the linestorm."
U.S. Department of Agriculture. Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices at New York:

According to officials of steamship lines which call at Cherbourg, dredging of the new port there is expected to be completed early next year. Although the new wharfs and sheds have been completed for some weeks, few lines have changed their plans to dock their ships instead of using the tender service.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I seem to recognize the N-Town and its NRA problems suggested by "X.Y. Z." in THE TIMES of Sept. 4. The answer, a partial one perhaps, is already in the making. In my N-Town the local administrators of NRA have already decided to temper its application, and the hardship, such as it is, falls on the better workman.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 8. -- A campaign to dispose of a large number of the cases pending before the Board of Tax Appeals by the end of the year has been launched by the Internal Revenue Bureau.

MADRID, Sept. 8. -- Premier Manuel Azana and his Cabinet resigned today. Now the Spanish Republic is trying to decide whether to form a national government, including representatives of all parties from Left to Right, and presided over by Senor Azana, the strong man of the republic.

LONDON, Sept. 8. -- "Ball at the Savoy," adapted by Oscar Hammerstein 2d from the German of Alfred Grunwald and Fritz LohnerBeda, with music by Paul Abraham, dazzled the first night audience at the Theatre Royal, Drury Lane, tonight by its size and swift gaiety.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Sept. 8. -- After engaging in a stiff morning session, the Navy football candidates today were driven to track equipment for the afternoon drill because of the extreme heat. The latter workout was carried on at a moderate pace, whereas the morning drill had been featured by a scrimmage between the first and second teams.

GREENWICH, Conn., Sept. 8. -- The 42-foot cruiser Lita, owned by Arthur Bull Sullivan of Belle Haven, Greenwich, formerly with Sullivan, Vail Co. of New York, was burned to the water's edge this afternoon.

Soviet Russia is spending 200,000,000 rubles a year -- about half that number of dollars -- to determine the extent of her mineral resources. Academician I.M. Goubkin, who in this country would be known as "Professor," said yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 (AP). -- Cotton of this year's crop ginned prior to Sept. 1 was reported today by the Census Bureau to have totaled 1,394,220 running bales, counting round bales as half-bales and excluding lintera.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 (AP). -- America's sailors, from barge hands to able seamen of the deep, will soon share with workers ashore the benefits of NRA.

Formal request has been made by the Actors Betterment Association for a charter from the American Association of Actors and Artists, the American Federation of Labor branch for actors in all fields, granting it permission to represent all vaudeville and "presentation house" artists, other than chorus members, in this country.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 8. -- A compete collapse of all negotiations for a fair competition code for the bituminous coal industry was barely averted today in a dramatic display of iron fists and kid gloves on the part of General Hugh S. Johnson.
BOSTON, Sept. 8 (AP). -- Billy Petrolle, the Fargo Express, and Sammy Fuller, Boston welterweight, boxed to a draw in the Boston Garden's ten-round feature bout tonight.
GENEVA, Sept. 8. -- The second Jewish World Conference closed today after unanimously adopting three resolutions.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In a letter which you published this morning a correspondent says that a statement which appeared in one of your recent editorials is a "downright euphemism." This is harsh language, and would be saddened if it were true, because THE TIMES is one of the few candles I trust to enlighten a naughty world.

The exhibition of drawings, paintings and etchings representing a four-month search by the Art Students League for undeveloped creative ability in Greater New York, broke all records for Summer art exhibit attendance on its opening yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 8. -- A cotton crop of 12,414,000 bales for 1933 is indicated by the Department of Agriculture's report based on conditions as of Sept. 1.

CHICAGO, Sept. 8 (AP). -- A belief that four missing balloonists might have landed in some inaccessible, sparsely settled territory in the Bennett race was held tonight as airplanes, boats and land crews searched without result.
BEDFORD SPRINGS, Pa., Sept. 8. -- The New Deal came in for sweeping criticism here today at the closing sessions of the convention of the Pennsylvania Electric Association.
CHICAGO, Sept. 8. -- A code of fair practices for grain exchanges was unanimously adopted by the directors of the Chicago Board of Trade at a special meeting this afternoon.

The origin of the Dutch elm disease threatening elm trees throughout the Northeastern States has been traced to a shipment of elm logs from Le Havre, France, to Norfolk, Va. The graphium fungus that destroys the elms and two closely related beetles that carry the fungus were discovered recently in the logs.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 8. -- An appeal to the men and women of the country to join whole-heartedly in the high endeavor of relieving the needs of those less fortunate than themselves was made today by President and Mrs. Roosevelt.
The oldest newspaper in New York, The Evening Post, will change its form Thursday to become the first major experiment in publishing a conservative daily tabloid.

The Child Placing and Adoption Committee of the State Charities Aid Association at 105 East Twenty-second Street, which is observing its thirty-fifth anniversary this week, found itself confronting a problem yesterday. Margaret and Alida, sisters, 7 and 4 years old, respectively, have been abandoned by their parents and given into the committee's custody for adoption.

The two-day delivery plan, adopted by the New York Stock Exchange to ease the tasks of clerical forces of brokerage firms, became effective yesterday. Henceforth, securities will be delivered on the second full business day after they are sold.

Tammany leaders make up a very poor audience to which to preach taxation, economy or efficient government. Like the members of the House of Commons when BURKE went on refining, Tammany thinks "only of dining." And in order to dine as well as usual, it must have a banquet table spread thick with the spoils of office.
BOSTON, Sept. 8 (AP). -- The Commercial Bulletin will say tomorrow:
GLEN COVE, L.I., Sept. 8. -- When 16-year-old Keenan Morrow of Pomonok re-enters Choate School this Fall he will return as the Long Island junior golf champion.

Charles H. Tuttle, chairman of the Committee of Christian Friends sponsoring the presentation of the Jewish pageant, "The Romance of a People," at the Polo Grounds next Thursday evening, sent a letter yesterday to the pastors of New York City appealing to them to pay tribute from their pulpits tomorrow to the Jewish race and its contribution to the culture and progress of the world.

CHICAGO, Sept. 8 (AP). -- The Chicago Cubs, continuing their desperate though belated bid to retain their National League laurels, ran their winning streak to five straight today by sweeping the three-game set from the Boston Braves, 8 to 3. It was the seventh straight defeat for the Braves.
PARIS, Sept. 8. -- Henri Cochet, famous French tennis star, formally announced tonight he had turned professional and signed a contract with Bill Tilden.

SEIGNIORY CLUB, Quebec, Sept. 8 (AP). -- R.W. Lee of Youngstown, Ohio, today captured the United States Senior Golf Association trophy, which is regarded as emblematic of the senior golf championship of North America, by scoring an 80 over the club course.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 8. -- Hear- ings have been scheduled as fol- lows by the NRA on codes for the following industries:

SOUTH RIVER, N.J., Sept. 8. -- A police alarm was broadcast tonight for William T. Armstrong, cashier of the First National Bank here, who disappeared today while a Federal examiner was making an examination of his accounts.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 8. -- The longest non-stop flight in formation in the history of aviation was completed at 6:25 P.M. today when five of the six twin-motored seaplanes comprising Squadron 5-F, United States Navy, landed at Coco Solo, Canal Zone.

Lost in a dense fog over New York City with gasoline enough for hardly more than another hour in the air, a squadron of seven army planes bound back to Mitchel Field from Chicago groped for emergency landing fields late last night.

To the Editor of The New York Times: THE TIMES published a letter objecting to Senator Copeland's proposal for universal fingerprinting, because this form of identification is peculiarly degrading, and the author opposes any form of police control of the movements of innocent people.

FREDENSBORG, Denmark, Sept. 8. -- Prince Knud and Princess Caroline Mathilde were married today as a strong guard was posted to ward off any demonstrations. The precautions were taken after decorations on the streets had been torn down during the night, allegedly by Communists.

Declines continued in futures in all principal commodities on local exchanges yesterday, except in the case of wool tops and coppei because of an absence of favorable developments and a further advance in the dollar.

HORNELL, N.Y., Sept. 8 (AP). -- Federal and railroad officials, seeking to fix responsibility for Tuesday's Erie train wreck, are expected to make an inspection tomorrow of the wooden passenger car in which fourteen persons were killed. The coach has been hauled to Susquehanna.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 8. -- The text of President Roosevelt's ad- dress at the White House today before the Conference on Mobiliza- tion for Human Needs follows:

HAVANA, Sept. 8. -- Sumner Welles, United States Ambassador, this evening denied persistent reports in Cuban circles that American marines had been landed in various sections of Cuba, including Cienfuegos and the Isle of Pines, where American citizens have become alarmed over conditions.

Various circumstances combined to make FEISAL Emir and later King; one of the most picturesque figures emerging out of the World War. Chief of these is the fact that the war as fought on land had for the most part neither movement nor color. It was a prolonged and hideous adventure in methodical slaughter -- the technical word was "attrition" -- between deadlocked armies in a setting of mire and mud.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 (AP). -- With Manager Joe Cronin's four hits setting the pace, the Senators scored an 11-to-2 victory over the White Sox today to hold their lead over the Yankees.
ST. LOUIS, Sept. 8 (AP). -- Seven more deaths sent the sleeping sickness fatalities to near the hundred mark tonight.

with the success of the United States Treasury's financing on Sept. 15 assured by the ready response yesterday to the offer to exchange certificates drawing one-quarter of 1 per cent and due on June 15, 1934, for the maturing a 1 1/4s, and the absence, as was expected, of any reference to refunding the war loans, United States Government bonds continued strong.

BERNE, Switzerland, Sept. 8. -- King Feisal of Iraq, known to the Arabs as "Feisal the Fearless" and one of the most romantic figures emerging from the World War, died suddenly at the Bellevue Hotel here at 12:30 o'clock this morning of heart disease.

THE tennis championship has now reached the singing stage. They cut the field to a quartet yesterday. The firing started early in the morning at Forest Hills. Vivian Bede McGrath (pronounced "McGra-a-ah") and Cliff Sutter were brushing with hasty steps the dew away to greet the sun upon the tennis lawn. They had to finish out an argument started the previous day.
PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 8 (AP). -- Taking their third straight from the Indians, the Athletics today climbed to within two games of third place with a 9-to-2 triumph.

Money market was quiet in tone and steady in quotations for all classifications. Business was chiefly of a routine character. Stock Exchange call loans continued at 3/4, and street trades at 1/2 of one per cent. Maturity money and business paper were unchanged.

NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 8. -- Mr. and Mrs. Robert Goelet gave a dinner followed by dancing at Ochre Court this evening. About forty guests were present for the dinner and others came in later for the dancing. The party was given in honor of Ogden Goelet and his fiancee, Miss Enid Connfelt, whose engagement was recently announced.
INDIANAPOLIS, Sept. 8. -- Straight-heat victories were scored in every event on the day's program as the Grand Circuit meeting was brought to a close at the State Fair Grounds track today.

GLENS FALLS, N.Y., Sept. 8. -- Matching his first-round score with another 69, Walter Kozak of the Pomonok Country Club, Flushing, L.I., gained the lead today with a thirty-six-hole total of 138 in the Glens Falls open golf tourney.

With an introduction in which there is some talk of Little Nell Theatre and the railroad tracks, Burns Mantle has finished work on his new "Best Plays of 1932-33," which Dodd, Mead will publish on Sept. 22. Nine of the ten plays in the year book are of American authorship.

CHICAGO, Sept. 8. -- Celebrants of New York State Day at a Century of Progress Exposition today were told by Governor Herbert H. Lehman, the guest of honor from the Empire State, that the "skies have brightened and that we are on the road to industrial, economic and agricultural recovery."
Several flats, in addition to a variety of dwellings, were included in the New Jersey realty turnover reported yesterday.

TORONTO, Ont., Sept. 8. -- The American Association of Port Authorities decided this afternoon to meet in New York City in 1934 on a date to be set later. Billings Wilson, assistant general manager of the Port of New York Authority, was elected president.

LOCUST VALLEY, L.I., Sept. 8. -- Miss Priscilla A. Poor, daughter of Mrs. Henry V. Poor of Roslyn and the late Mr. Poor, was introduced to society tonight at a dinner dance given by Mr. and Mrs. James King Norris of Syosset at the Piping Rock Club in Locust Valley.

The Brooklyn Union Gas Company submitted data to the Public Service Commission yesterday to show its rate of return would be less than 6 per cent this year. The company thus completed its testimony in opposition to temporary emergency rate reductions.

Regulations covering the shooting of migratory wild water fowl are expected to be issued by Secretary of Agriculture Wallace on Monday. There will be no shortening of the season -- it was sixty days during 1932 -- but there will be a rearrangement of the bag limits, it is understood.

The old feud among Broadway theatre ticket men was revived yesterday when the Theatre Ticket Brokers Association, organized in 1926 and representing twenty-five agencies, charged that a group of four leading ticket brokers, members of the National Theatre Ticket Distributers, Inc., were attempting to gain control of the ticket brokerage business here.

The first of a series of three concerts was presented at Madison Square Garden last night. The management of the Garden is attempting to discover whether there is an audience in New York for indoor concerts at popular prices on the scale of those given by the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra at the Lewisohn Stadium.

BELFAST, Me., Sept. 8 (AP). -- A madman, armed with an assortment of firearms, went berserk on the main street of this small city today, killing two men outright and mortally wounding two others, before he barricaded himself in a blacksmith shop and committed suicide by blowing off the top of his head.
CINCINNATI, Sept. 8. -- Silas Johnson scattered six hits among the Dodgers today and sent the Careymen away to Pittsburgh on the short end of a 12-to-0 shout-out.

The strike of 15,000 embroidery workers that had threatened to cripple the operation of the entire dress industry, with a personnel of more than 100,000, was settled yesterday by Grover A. Whalen, chairman of the local NRA organization, with the prospect that all strikers would be back at work by Monday.

CHICAGO, Sept. 8. -- The grain markets on the Board of Trade here were weak early today, and scattered liquidation appeared, especially in wheat, which dropped about 2 cents a bushel below yesterday's closing price. The December equaled the lowest level of last week, but its failure to break through that figure, combined with short covering and removal of hedges against sales of flour by mills, started the market upward.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 8. -- Loans to railroads to finance the purchase of steel rails, as a means of extending employment, are in prospect, if the makers of rails will reduce the price of this commodity, it was learned in authoritative quarters today.

Allan W. Dulles, legal adviser to the United States disarmament delegation, will sail tonight for Europe on the North German Lloyd liner Europa. Others sailing for the Channel ports on the ship include:
Russell Van Atta, southpaw pitching ace of the Yankees, has shaken off the effects of the flu germ which has kept him out of action for the past three weeks.
State Attorney General John J. Bennett Jr. started his inquiry yesterday into charges that an alliance exists between political leaders and racketeers.

DETROIT, Sept. 8 (AP). -- There will be no "fight to the finish" between the Ford Motor Company and the National Recovery Administration, according to an authoritative source today, because the Ford company feels it is complying with the code and there is nothing to fight about.

Crop Figure Halts Cotton Goods The main effect that the government cotton crop estimate had on the primary market yesterday was to hold up a large volume of business which buyers had prepared to place, if the report was anyway bullish.

COHASSET, Mass., Sept. 8. -- Miss Ruth Sears of the Cohasset Yacht Club today successfully completed the formality or sailing the sixth race in the series for the women's national sailing championship and won the title by 2 1/4 points over Miss Lorna Whittelsey of the Indian Harbor Yacht Club.

"War the Super Racket," a one-ton book espousing the cause of peace, has been banned from the World's Fair, according to an announcement made yesterday by Mrs. Estelle M. Sternberger, executive director of World Peaceways.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 8. -- Schools, colleges, universities, churches, hospitals and charitable institutions are exempt from provisions of the Recovery Act, under a ruling au- thorized today by General Johnson. Recommendations to that effect were made by the Industrial and Labor Advisory Boards, headed by Walter C. Teagle and Dr. Leo Wolman, respectively.

Three carnivals in aid of philanthropic endeavor will take place tonight near New York in settings of beach and countryside. All have been in preparation for several weeks and have received large advance subscriptions from members of society passing the Summer at their country homes or at beach resorts.

LONDON, Sept. 8. -- The sudden death of King Feisal of Iraq, came as a severe blow to the British Government. Throughout his twelveyear reign he had been the ally and friend of Great Britain. But equally important in the British mind was that he stood for moderation in conducting the affairs of his Arab kingdom.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 8. -- Price increases under NRA codes will be checked by a special board established under the NRA Consumers Advisory Board to prevent profiteering, under a policy adopted today.
TORONTO, Sept. 9 (AP). -- Frank Pritchard of Buffalo and Mrs. Evelyn Armstrong of Detroit cap- tured the Canadian national exhibi- tion's three-mile swims for men and women today.

PANAMA, R.P., Sept. 6. -- Intervention, one of the problems of the Roosevelt administration's "good neighbor" policy, will not be solved by a policy of non-intervention regardless of the theory that a good neighbor is one who minds his own business.

CHICAGO, Sept. 8. THESE are harvest days for the shows that contrived to get themselves adjusted to the World's Fair Summer -- the well-known quartet that contains the familiar titles of "Dinner at Eight," "Take a Chance," "Her Majesty the Widow" and "Skidding."

President Roosevelt wired his congratulations yesterday to Grover A. Whalen, city chairman of the Emergency Re-employment Cam- paign, on the success of the organ- ization of the President's NRA Day Parade of 250,000 employers and employes up Fifth Avenue next Wednesday.

LOCUST VALLEY. L.I., -- Sept. 9. -- Supreme Court Justice George E. Brower and Mrs. Brower of Locust Hill, Roslyn, and Brooklyn, gave a dinner dance tonight at the Piping Rock Club to introduce to society their daughter, Miss Marion W. Brower.
PORTLAND, Me., Sept. 9. -- Maine will set up probably the most intricate piece of election machinery used by any State thus far voting on ratification of the Twenty-first Amendment.

Practically all the Gold cup boats in the country are being groomed to race for the President's Cup, which will be competed for on the Potomac River at Washington on Sept. 29 and 30. Among them will be the year's champion, El Lagarto, which her owner, George Reis, drove to victory in the Gold Gup content at Detroit and the National Sweepstakes at Red Bank, N.J.

HALLE, Germany, Sept. 9. -- Captain Paul Koenig, who during the World War outwitted the Allied blockade and piloted the trading submarine Deutschland to the United States, died today in Gragau. He was 66.

PARIS. THE big change that has come over Paris fashions is nowhere more noticeable than in the new manner of treating furs. Whether they be sewed on or detachable, useful or merely decorative, the furs that are scattered with a prodigal hand all over the Winter stylescape have a cachet, peculiar to 1934 Winter fashions.

THE complete ratification of the repeal amendment within the next few months may now be taken for granted. The American people are demonstrating for the second time within a year how expeditiously they may amend the Constitution when the mood seizes them.

WASHINGTON. SINCE President Roosevelt entered the White House it has been necessary to provide storage space for rather voluminous envelopes and books containing the tokens of his most constant hobby -- stamps.

LONDON. PRESIDENT ROOSEVELT has been authorized to borrow, by bond issues, up to $3,300,000,000 for a program of pub lie works. The purposes are to provide employment, to distribute new purchasing power and thus to help raise prices.

IRVING FINEMAN, whose first novel, "This Pure Young Man," received the Atlantic Monthly prize, has written a book which in depth and beauty and poetic expression dwarfs the earlier volume. The first book was doubtless autobiographical, in spirit, if not in fact; this one, too, is autobiographical, provided one allows the word the boundaries of race and tradition as well as of personal experience.

Promotions of rugs, millinery and school accessories led in retail trade here during the week, accord- ing to analyses by shoppers of the Meyer-Both Retail Reporting Bu- reau. The rugs were close-outs of popular price lines and featured American Orientals at $49.50 and $69.50, broadloom types at from $2.97 to $175 and linoleums at varied prices.

MEMPHIS, Tenn., Sept. 7. -- Whether the government's acreage reduction plan is successful or not, whether the plowing up of 10,000,000 acres in the Cotton Belt is to bring higher yields to the farmers or not, the experiment has been so successful, and has so captured the imaginations of the cotton farmers of the South that they are perfectly willing to leave next year's method of production control to the authorities in Washington.
America's eclipse on the tennis courts for 1933 reached the point of complete totality yesterday.

THE Brookline Musical Society, Inc., has just concluded its third season as sponsor of the People's Symphony Orchestra, Will Dodge conductor. In the enlarging field of musical activities that comprise symphony orchestras of modified personnel, not much has been heard beyond its local habitat of this one of Boston's many musical societies.

SALEM, N.H., Sept. 9 (AP). -- Carrying 126 pounds, top-weight, J.J. Curtis's 6-year-old flying heels gained his second Rockingham Park stake victory in a week today by leading nine speedy rivals by a length in the New Hampshire handicap, a six-furlong sprint for 3-year-olds and up.
Clarence M. Charest, one-armed player from Washington, won the veterans' national tennis championship yesterday for the third time, to gain permanent possession of the challenge trophy.

The Ward liner Morro Castle, which arrived yesterday morning from Havana and left again for the same port at 4 P.M., brought reports of the activities of adherents of the revolutionary group in Havana who were said to have delayed the ship's sailing last Wednesday by rushing about looking for Machado sympathizers.

No. 1, 404 Yards -- Par 4. Tee slightly above fairway. Old orchard and rough on left from 125 to 300 yards. Nest of traps on the right at 200 to 235 yards. Shot to green must be pitched to avoid two traps in the left approach on the high-banked trap on the right front of green itself.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 9. -- Rules governing the expenditure of Federal funds for medical, nursing and dental care of sick and destitute unemployed persons who are "on relief" were announced today by Harry L. Hopkins, Federal emergency relief administrator.

QUEBEC, Sept. 9. -- Two Polish balloonists, who set out from Chi- cago as contestants in the James Gordon Bennett race last Saturday, arrived tired and hungry but tri- umphant tonight at the little village of Riviere a Pierre, twenty-five miles north-west of Quebec.

COPENHAGEN. WITH frank simplicity Martin Andersen Nexo tells the story of his boyhood, between the ages of 5 and 8, in a new volume of memoirs, "Et Lille Krae." The title is, in effect, a humorous Danish version of what is known in solemn pedagogical circles as the "problem child," a concept that usually hypothecates also the existence of problem parents.

RALEIGH, N.C., Sept. 9. -- All tobacco markets in North Carolina and South Carolina have been closed this week under proclama- tions of the Governors of the two States and it now seems assured that when the markets reopen tobacco will command materially higher prices.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Sept. 7 (AP). -- Writing Portuguese as it is spoken will be obligatory from now on in Brazilian public offices, schools and in petitions or documents submitted to the government.
PRINCETON, N.J., Sept. 9. -- The Princeton varsity football squad, numbering eighty-six members, will begin Fall practice on Friday.
An understanding among candi- dates for Democratic nominations against the designees of the regular organization was announced yesterday by Representative Loring M. Black Jr., candidate for Mayor.

IT must be all of five years ago that a prospectus was issued outlining a vast "Corpus of Florentine Painting" by Richard Offner, to be published under the auspices of the College of Fine Arts, New York University. Many a well-intentioned and ambitious proposal comes from the printer's press, only to evaporate, as regards actual realization, in the steam of its own high-stepping enthusiasm.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 9. -- The War De- partment issued the following orders to- day:

SEVEN painters and six sculptors participate in the opening event of the College Art Association's season, current until the end of the month at the New School for Social Research. Each of the painters has a complete one-man show and the sculpture forms a composite group.

NEWARK, N.J., Sept. 9. -- Newark took both ends of a double-header from Baltimore today, winning the first game, 9 to 6, and the second, 7 to 2. Pete Jablonowski and Johnny Broaca divided the hurling of the Bears in the opener, while Jimmy DeShong pitched his sixteenth victory in the nightcap.

Less than 4 per cent of the employers of New York State outside this city remain to be signed up under the Blue Eagle, it was announced yesterday by W. Averell Harriman, chairman of the President's Emergency Re-employment Committee of this State.
The Literary Digest, which has accurately forecast the outcomes of the last four Presidential cam- paigns through its polls, has start- ed a poll on Mayor of New York City.

Washington reports that the administration will recognize Russia shortly and depend upon the large volume of business believed available from that nation to help cushion any unexpected drop in the present rate of industrial activity stirred widespread interest among producers in every branch of export trade last week.
NEW YORK. Sheldon Whitehouse, newly appointed Minister to Colombia, and Mrs. Whitehouse will sail early next month for Bogota where he will take up his new duties.

The United States Volunteer Life Saving Corps of Greater New York held its first aquatic meet yesterday afternoon at the Allen Point station. Fifty-fifth Street and the East River. The meet was sponsored by the New York Community Councils, and gold medals were awarded to winners of first prizes in eight events.

Following what is reported to be a successful fight against the NRA attitude that plant improvements, looking toward elimination of wasteful procedure and speeding up of production, are not in line with the recovery program, management engineers are now preparing to handle a large volume of business under the new industrial conditions, according to leading executives in the field here yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 9. -- President Roosevelt and Secretary of State Hull expressed the regret of the United States Government at the death of King Feisal of Iraq in messages made public here today.

To the Dramatic Editor: The interesting article in the Sunday Magazine brought to mind some incidents connected with Denman Thompson and his play. Thompson for many years had been playing in what were termed variety houses, in a none too refined sketch called "Joshua Whitcomb."

PRINCETON, Sept. 9. -- Final plans for the $300,000 group of buildings of the Westminster Choir School of Princeton were announced here today, following the ceremonies on Wednesday when ground was broken for the new musical centre.

THE "battle of the century" has come and gone. Primo Camera, world's heavyweight champion, and Max Baer, leading contender, fought for ten rounds. Jack Dempsey was the referee. There were only 1,100 spectators and not one paid admission.

LONDON. AN autograph letter of an eminent person is always of interest as indicating something of the idiosyncrasies of the writer. An autograph manuscript by a distinguished author offers the additional value of revealing how his first thoughts were modified in the process of literary composition.

It is time for the American public to stop visualizing domestic shipping efforts as disassociated from their immediate welfare, according to Henry Herbermann, president of the American Export Lines. He said the ordinary American had only a "hazy conception of the American merchant marine and should wake up to the trade value and employment stimulus it provides."

HORNELL, N.Y., Sept. 9 (AP). -- The daughter of Martin King, engineer of the Erie milk train which crashed into a passenger express at Binghamton Tuesday night, killing fourteen, came to the defense of her father today when he appeared confused and nervous on the witness stand.

YONKERS, N.Y., Sept. 9. -- The body of J. Glenn Blaisdell, 51 years old, who had been missing from his home at 6 Arden Place here since yesterday, was found today in a wood off Tompkins Avenue, a short distance from St. Joseph's Seminary.

The convention of the American Bankers Association in Chicago last week was the most dramatic that the association has had in many years. It was imbued with a sense of conflict -- conflict between the old-fashioned, independent American hanker and the forces of changing economic conditions summed up by President Roosevelt in the expression, "the new deal."

Despite the presence of a hot sun that produced anything but traditional football weather, the sport came back to New York yesterday with the convention of the Eastern Intercollegiate Association at the Hotel McAlpin and the second annual demonstration game at Baker Field.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 (AP) -- A crusade by New Jersey women to gather information on human needs and to advise the public of the use to which its relief dollar is put will start in a few days.

More than 1,100,000 children and 36,000 teachers, returning to school tomorrow, will be enlisted in the movement for national recovery. In the spirit of "good citizenship," teachers and children alike will be called upon to "stand by the national government in this crisis, without regard to personal or political opinions."

CINCINNATI, Sept. 9 -- The Giants, fully expecting to experience a much-sough let-up in their trying labors through the West, spent seven very annoying rounds as they opened a five-game series with the Reds today.
Notably coincident with the economic situation has been the tenacious adherence of followers of sport to their favorite forms of diversion and exercise.

BUFFALO, Sept. 7. -- Perhaps a wider acquaintance of communities with one another's local problems would break up among Americans generally the too pronounced tendency to determine all questions of government according to their opinions on national politics.

Assuming that there will be no further Federal income tax legislation affecting returns for the year 1933, the deducibility of losses incurred from the sale of securities and those resulting from the operation of a trade or business, for this year, will be governed by the Revenue Act of 1932 as amended by provisions of the National Industrial Recovery Act.
From The Milwaukee Journal. The best way is to let Cuba work out its political salvation.

BOSTON, Sept. 6. -- Maine, the original prohibition State, will vote on repeal of the prohibition amendment on Monday. This referendum will be the most interesting of all the forty-eight as taking place in a State that has been legally dry for eighty-two years, lacking one short interval when license came back.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 9 (AP). -- Thanks to the involuntary cooperation of inoculated monkeys, science apparently has produced the mysterious "sleeping sickness" in animals and has entered a new phase in the study of the disease.

NOT very frequently is an anthology a real contribution to literature. But this collection of the best of our younger poets, incomplete though it is, affords an introduction to a number of new names in poetry, names which are likely to become important.

YONKERS, N.Y., Sept. 9. -- Hirsch Smulowitz, who although 109 years old only had twenty-seven birthdays because he was born on Feb. 29, died in his sleep at the New York Guild for Jewish Blind on St. John's Avenue today. He was one of the oldest men in the State.

If American bondholders are to recover any substantial amounts on the Latin-American Bonds now in default, a "blanket code" should be drawn up to serve as a starting point and foundation for the nego- tiation of individual debt settle- ments, according to Dr. William E. Dunn, formerly Director Gen- eral of Internal Revenue of the Re- public of Haiti and an authority on Latin-American fiscal affairs.

LONDON, Sept. 9. -- Professor Einstein, who was reported to be in fear of his life because a Nazi faction had put a price on his head, arrived in London tonight as the guest of Commander Oliver Locker-Lampson. Dr. Einstein was greatly perturbed, not on account of the alleged threat to his life, but because he had lost two valuable mathematical books on his journey from Belgium.
MOSCOW, Sept. 8. -- There is no organized crime in Moscow nor commercialized vice -- no racketeering nor kidnapping, no speakeasies, gambling hells nor brothels.

EAST HAMPTON, L.I., Sept. 9. -- Tonight's roller skating party, dance and bridge for the village improvement society benefit at the Sea Spray Inn was a gala affair attended by several hundred people and was preceded by numerous dinners.

WAYS and means of making automobile driving and riding more enjoyable and less fatiguing engaged the attention of motor experts in the concluding sessions of the International Automotive Engineering Congress of the Society of Automotive Engineers, which came to a close last Monday in Chicago.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 9. -- Repeal of national prohibition is a thing now taken for granted at the capital. This is an axiomatic statement for the organized wets who have found success thrust upon them. It is none the less true of leading drys who face the facts.

THE theatrical producer whose audiences throughout the country have slowly disappeared and who desires to express his ideas to a larger public than the theatre can command must inevitably turn to motion pictures or the radio, two fields up to now largely neglected by him.

RADIO CITY, when the architects' plans were announced, was heralded as an electrical acropolis in which the wedding of the arts and sciences would he celebrated. The Music Hall and the citadel of the motion picture opened several months ago.
TOKYO, Sunday, Sept. 10. -- In a three-hour interview today with Finance Minister Takahashi, Lieut. Gen. Sadao Araki, the War Minister, laid down the army's view on international and domestic policy.

The dollar and the pound sterling advanced together yesterday against the "gold basis" currencies of Europe, marking another stage in a movement launched in Continental Europe at the middle of last week.
VIENNA, Sept. 8. -- Central European reconstruction seems to have become practical politics, so much so that, having set statesmen to traveling, it is now dictating the itineraries of Kings.

THIS addition to the Modern World series is an informative description of present - day Persia. By design Sir Arnold Wilson leaves to the writer of travelogues the amusing and bizarre in Persian life and seeks to discover what is of contemporary significance.

NEW ORLEANS. IT was fifteen years ago, back in 1918, when Huey Pierce Long Jr., then 25 years old, came tearing out of the political bushes of Winn Parish, in North Louisiana, with a bag of political tricks at which Louisiana's veteran politicians laughed.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Many readers of the article concerning Burne-Jones in THE NEW YORK TIMES Magazine will be interested to know that a stained glass window designed by him and made by William Morris is to be found among the notable windows in St. Peter's Episcopal Church here.

The first sabotage against the Blue Eagle in Brooklyn was reported yesterday to the police of the Empire Boulevard precinct by Miss E. Viola Reif, owner of a beauty parlor at 721 Flatbush Avenue and chairman of the Hairdressers Committee of Greater New York under the NRA, reported that a plate glass window in the front of her shop had been broken.
LONDON, Sept. 9. -- Bernard M. Baruch, American financier, sailed for home aboard the liner Empress of Britain today. He was an overnight guest of Winston Churchill last night.

FIRST came "narratage," which involved something known as the static pan lap dissolve. Now it is "swiping," the successor to "wiping," which, in turn, followed the fadeout and the dissolve. No one knew much about the static pan lap dissolve, but First National has been waxing positively lyric over the beauties of "swiping."

WASHINGTON. TO the list of those who have been called "dictators" has been added, in dual fashion, the name of Harold L. Ickes, Secretary of the Interior. If by "dictator" is meant a man in whom the President has vested unusual responsibility for the carrying out of the recovery program, then Mr. Ickes became a dictator, in the first instance, when he assumed the duties of administrator of the $3,300,000,000 public orks program.

In prosperous times a man with a good job is likely to hold on to it, even though he might prefer another one. But with the throwing of millions out of employment, many are free to try to equip themselves to do what they would most like. This is one group for which this present ill wind may blow some good.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 9. -- Allotments from the $3,300,000,000 fund of the Public "Works Administration are nearing the half-way mark, Secretary Ickes said today in announcing two allotments totaling $3,793,671 for public works construction in various States.

THE announcement that the Saturday before Labor Day had set a record for marriage licenses issued in New York City and for the number of couples having the ceremony performed in the Municipal Chapel raises the question as to whether this is an indication of the return of better times.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 6. -- After a month's operation the State's 2 1/2 per cent sales tax, which began in confusion, is rather more than less confounded than it was four weeks ago. Moreover, it threatens to bring confusion into the field of politics and already it has set various Republican groups to clashing.

FREEPORT, L.I., Sept. 9. -- With Harry Newman, former Michigan star, leading the attack, the New York Football Giants launched their 1933 campaign by defeating the All-Long Island Stars, 24 -- 0, in an exhibition game under the floodlights at the Freeport Municipal Stadium tonight.

The entire estate of Colonel Arthur Frederic Schermerhorn, member of one of the oldest Dutch families in the United States and for half a century connected with the New York National Guard, was bequeathed to his widow, Mrs. Harriet Pullman Schermerhorn of 111 East Forty-eighth Street.

CHICAGO, Sept. 9. -- Yesterday's advance in the prices of grains on the Board of Trade here apparently weakened the technical position of the market and a return of selling pressure today disclosed a lack of support. Sharp rallies were numerous, but all grains weakened again toward the last, and the finish was at the bottom.

BOSTON, Sept. 9 (AP). -- Roy Johnson packed the punch that gave the Red Sox a 6-to-4 victory over, the Tigers today in the final game of their series. The left fielder slapped three singles, drove in three runs, scored two and stole a base.

Are there any serious or festive oyster-eaters of the old type left? To whom does the head of the United States Bureau of Fisheries give valuable advice and directions in The "United States News? All his information is kind and much of it sound:

NEWARK, N.J., Sept. 9. -- Lea Fabrics, Inc., the manufacturing company of which General Hugh S. Johnson is president, was cleared of the charge of violation of its NRA agreement today by the Bureau of Complaints and Compliance of the New Jersey State Recovery Board.

WHITE PLAINS, Sept. 9. -- The Rev. Dr. H. Pereira Mendes, minister of the Spanish and Portugese Congregation of New York and one of the oldest New York rabbis, who served on the Committee of Seventy with the late Dr. Charles H. Parkhurst, issued a statement today denouncing the "charem" or boycott voted Thursday, by the Assembly of Orthodox Rabbis of the United States and Canada as "decidedly unorthodox."

ASBURY PARK, N.J., Sept. 9. -- Missing a nine-inch putt on the eighteenth hole today cost Joe Ghezzi of the Swimming River Country Club his second chance to win the North Jersey Coast amateur golf championship.

LONDON, Sept. 8. -- Faced with growing evidence that Germany is rearming in secret, the British Government intends to make every effort this month to get a world-wide disarmament convention signed without delay.

MORE than ten years ago fascism came into being in Italy, but the first book in English to discuss its economic foundations has appeared only now. Mr. Einzig makes a special point of this laggardness of public interest and ascribes it mainly to the ignorance of our popular writers.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 (AP). -- The veteran Red Faber weakened in the eleventh inning today, issued two passes in succession and forced in the winning run to give the Senators a 3-to-2 victory over the White Sox.

Many clergymen will today pay tribute from their pulpits to the Jewish people and its contribution to the culture and progress of the world. This is on the request of Charles H. Tuttle, chairman of the committee of Christian friends sponsoring the presentation of the Jewish pageant, "The Romance of a People," at the Polo Grounds Thursday evening, to raise funds to enable German Jews to settle in Palestine.

HAVANA, Sept. 9. -- The five com- missioners now heading Cuba's rev- olutionary government will be re- placed by a President and a Cab- inet who will continue the revolutionary program, according to an official statement from the palace this afternoon.

CHICAGO, Sept. 9. -- About 3,000 chemists from, the world's research and industrial laboratories, as well as leading universities, will convene here Monday for the Century of Progress meeting of the American Chemical Society.

SAN JUAN, P.R., Sept. 5. -- Less than two months after his inauguration Governor Robert H. Gore started for Washington, leaving behind a group of thoroughly perturbed island politicians. They are more perturbed, apparently, by his technique than his objective.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 (AP). -- In preparation for legislation to supersede the tangle of antiquated liquor statutes, decisions and rulings which would come to life with the death of prohibition, three veteran Treasury officials are making a searching study of all the questions involved.

HAVANA, Sept. 9. -- The presence of United States Ambassa- dor Sumner Welles quietly smoking a cigar in the lobby of the National Hotel early this morning undoubtedly saved hundreds of deposed army officers meeting there from an open attack by sol- diers who were surrounding the hotel.

Further gains in retail dollar volume featured the first week of the normal Fall buying season, with practically all lines of merchandise sharing in the increase, retail ex- ecutives here reported yesterday. Estimates placed the probable in- crease in sales for the first half of this month at about 10 per cent over a year ago for department stores.

The Cunard Line announced yes- terday that the Mauretania had been so well received as an allwhite cruising liner that they have decided to paint the liner Fran- conia white before the beginning of her world cruise next January.

Unfilled orders of the United States Steel Corporation decreased 129,681 tons in August to a total of 1,890,444 tons at the end of the month, it was announced yesterday. It was the second consecutive decline, and it brought the corporation's backlog to the lowest level since last March 31, when a three-month upturn in bookings began.
ST. LOUIS, Sept. 9 (AP). -- The Cardinals broke a fourteen-game-at-home winning streak and the Braves a seven-game losing streak today as Boston defeated St. Louis, 6 to 3, in the series opener.

THESE lyrics by Frances Frost are among the best poems this versatile poet has written. They are for children or about children. They have therefore no clever effectiveness; they show none of Frances Frost's rather dangerous ability to change her style at will.

MANILA, Sept, 9. -- Serious difficulties in the islands were predicted by Rafael Alunan, president of the Philippine Sugar Association, as a result of the sugar stabilization agreement reached at Washington this Summer drastically limiting insular imports.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 9. -- After dropping the first game of a doubleheader with the Pirates today, 6 to 2, the Dodgers contrived to capture the afterpiece, 8 to 7, after various interruptions, which included bitter arguments with the umpires, the banishment of Max Carey and a rainstorm.

THE coming season bids fair to break all records in the number of foreign dancers who are scheduled to appear in this country. Indeed, from the advance announcements, we are in for a veritable foreign invasion, with no fewer than nine attractions promised, of which six seem reasonably certain.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The recent report from Billings, Mont., published in THE TIMES, of the discovery by Professor Thom of Princeton of an extinct volcano in the Beartooth Mountains comes as a refreshing antidote to the many disturbing national and international questions in which we are involved.
