In the War the word "mobilization" became familiar to millions in whose vocabulary it had never been before. It meant, of course, something more than mere mobility. It meant a purposeful, organized, destinated mobility -- the liberation of every effective latent force -- natural, economic, social, spiritual.

MOST harried of earth's strategic spots is the neighborhood of Khyber Pass on India's Northwest Frontier. There, in the seventy-sixth year of British rule in India, 4,000 British troops, armored cars and four squadrons of bombing planes are resisting the seventy-sixth onslaught on the border.

CHICAGO, Sept. 9. -- The Dixiana Stable's 3-year-old, Esseff, owned by Charles T. Fisher of Detroit, ran to a surprising victory in the seventh renewal of the $5,000 Lincoln Handicap today. The filly defeated the heavily played favorite, Indian Runner, by five lengths before 15,000 spectators.

More conspicuously than ever this Fall, the public high school stands as one of our most flourishing enterprises. A business which, through good times and bad, could show the same rapid customer increase, that has more than doubled the high school's patronage since the war, would be the wonder of America.

IT was not so many years ago that the broadcasters could not reach over the Rockies to "pipe" entertainment from California into the network, but that is no problem in 1933. Performers broadcast in New York one week and a few days later from the Pacific Coast with the unseen audience unaware of their location if it were not for the announcer's comment.

CHICAGO, Sept. 9. -- The "teletactor," an instrument for distinguishing minute variations in sound vibrations through the skin, particularly the fingertips, was described here today at the annual meeting of the American Psychological Association.

The sale of 3.2 beer has increased freight traffic on the New York Central lines and the Lackawanna Railroad, according to a statement yesterday of Edward P. Mulrooney, chairman of the State Alcoholic Beverage Control Board. Mr. Mulrooney also said the board was engaged in a study of regulations to govern the sale of hard liquor.

BERLIN. THE victory of the National Socialist movement in Germany was greatly facilitated by the invention of one magic word which covered many sins. That word was "Gleichschaitung," which literally means "switching in the same direction" and is generally translated as "coordination."

With the twofeld aim of forcing action on an NRA code for the industry and obtaining a uniform wage scale, union dyers and cloth printers in New York City and New Jersey will go on strike tomorrow morning.
BERLIN, Sept. 9 (AP). -- The Reichsbank's statement as of Sept. 7 shows the following changes in reichsmarks:

WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 (AP). -- To insure prompt action on specific problems of the various petroleum divisions, ths oil industry's governing board today set up nine subcommittees of the National Planning and Coordinating Committee, which is in general command of procedure under the oil trade code.

Everybody pays lip-service to the will of the people. But how to find out what it is -- that is the puzzle. Americans are always ready to accept the dictum of Lord BRYCE that public opinion rules in the United States, being more powerful than any man or party or government.

THE new Packard models for 1934 were publicly introduced last week. There are three lines, two of straight-eights and one of twelve cylinders. The entire group is one of the most comprehensive ever offered, comprising eight chassis, thirteen different types and forty-one body models.

CORNWALL, N.Y., Sept. 9. -- One of the most notable records in recent canine history is being compiled by Heather Reveller of Sporran. This black brindle Scottish terrier was named best in show today at the ninth annual all-breed show of the Storm King Kennel Club by Theo Offerman of New York City.

IT is reported from abroad that the British Royal Automobile Club is planning an overland route from London to India. The proposed route will run from London to Dover and then via Calais, Ostend, Brussels, Aix-la-Chapelle, Cologne, Vienna, Budapest and Stamboul.

A drive in this city and vicinity against violators of the statutes governing the sale and distribution of milk will start tomorrow, Burt W. Miller, assistant director of the State Milk Control Board announced yesterday at his offices in the State Building, 80 Centre Street.
ROSTOV-ON-DON, U.S.S.R., Sept. 9. -- The grain harvests are virtually all cut in the North Cau- casus, but only 43.4 per cent had been threshed by last Tuesday.

ONE who likes to make a collection of children's books of olden times derives more pleasures from his hobby than the single satisfaction of possessing rarities. He is conscious that his cherished relics have been dear to children innumerable, to children of generations now almost forgotten.

Public opinion in favor of the recovery program has grown so strong in recent weeks that manufacturers who originally disclaimed any intention of using the NRA label on packages are now frantically rushing to place the Blue Eagle on their goods.

Stocks marked time yesterday in the most unexciting market witnessed in more than a year. Transactions on the Stock Exchange made up a total of 279,110 shares, compared with 1,270,740 shares on Friday. Yesterday's volume was the smallest since July 9 of last year; in the bond market the business was the slowest in two years.
Bluefishing this year has been poorer than in several seasons, according to the old-timers, and even they cannot fathom the mystery.

A violent rainsquall, accompanied in some sections by thunder and lightning, passed over New York late yesterday afternoon, bringing relief after a day of unseasonal heat and stifling humidity. The storm lasted less than an hour, but in that hour the temperature dropped 14 degrees.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 9. -- Federal Reserve Banks were notified by the Treasury that today's selling price for gold was $29.12, as compared with $29.62 quoted yesterday.

EVER since man rose above the savage cave-man who attained the peak of his mental powers when he thought, "Here's a lion -- what shall I do?" he has meditated about the relalation of human life to the vast star-spangled universe about him.

SCARBOROUGH - ON - HUDSON, N.Y., Sept 9. -- The first American performance of Tehaikovsky's opera, "Iolanthe" will be presented in the Garden Theatre of the Sleepy Hollow Country Club here tomorrow night, under the auspices of the Musicians Emergency Fund.

HAVANA, Sept. 9. -- Dr. Horacio Ferrer formally demanded today, on behalf of the army officers ousted in last Monday's revolutionary coup, that the junta step down to make way for the reinstatement of Carlos Manuel de Cespedes as Provisional President.
PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 9. -- The women's Middle States tennis crown went to England for the third straight year today, the flashing racquet of Miss Joan Ridley of Ipswich carrying it there.

The determined effort on the part of industry, particularly the con- sumer goods producers, to improve advertising ethics through the codes of fair competition is not meeting with as much success as executives had hoped, according to comment in advertising circles yesterday.
The question, "After repeal -- what?" is more frequently heard as State after State moves to eliminate the Eighteenth Amendment from the Constitution.

PHILADELPHIA. SEVERAL institutions, including Dropsie College and the Jewish Theological Seminary, will celebrate next Wednesday the seventieth birthday of Dr. Cyrus Adler, who has won distinction not only as a college administrator but as a scholar of rare attainments.

LONDON, Sept. 9. -- Captain Koenig's wife is a British woman living in "Worcester Park near London, under her maiden name of Pennington. She enjoyed none of the glamour of being married to the public hero which Captain Koenig became.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 9. -- A possibility of currency inflation through a reduction of the gold content of the dollar within three months was admitted today by Secretary Wallace. This possibility the Secretary of Agriculture based on the lag so far of farm prices behind industrial prices.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 9. -- The United States clung "tenaciously to the hope of maintaining a non-intervention policy in Cuba today, as officials awaited the South American reaction to Mexico's proposal of yesterday for a joint communique urging Cuba to organize on a stable basis.

PARIS, Sept. 7. -- Maria Guy's large dressy afternoon hats, of which the front part of the brim is symmetrically flared so that all of the forehead is exposed and which are trimmed under the drooping back brim, modernize and magnify the Quaker-girl bonnet.

AMATEUR fishermen, returned after exploits in sylvan waters, were chagrined recently to read of the capture, off the coast of Long Island, of a 1,200-pound sunfish -- larger, by more than 1,199 pounds, than the sunfish they had inadvertently taken while awaiting bass beside a submerged ledge in a Maine lake.

THE Jewish pageant, "The Romance of a People," which will be presented at the Polo Grounds next Thursday, Saturday and Sunday evenings, chronicles a series of significant moments in the history of a race through the use of dramatic action, dancing and music.

MEXICO CITY. THE subsoil bearing archaeological remains now being excavated on the cathedral lot in downtown Mexico City is believed to be part of the old pagan plaza that stretched out at the west foot of the great Teocalli, or god-house.

Food relief activities among 40,000 families of New York City's unemployed will be discontinued on Sept. 22 by the Emergency Unemployment Relief Committee because of the exhaustion of supplies, it was announced yesterday by Frank Kidde, chairman of the committee's food and clothing division.

BERLIN, Sept. 8. -- The new Germany, with a population too large for her territory under present economic conditions and unable to increase her elbow room terrestrially, turns increased attention to the air, which is still fairly free for all, as a sphere for conquest and defense.

PARIS, Sept. 9. -- On Sept. 20 there will be offered for sale throughout France 2,000,000 national lottery tickets, costing 100 francs [about $5.60 at current exchange] each, one of which will win for the lucky drawer a 5,000,000-franc prize.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 9. -- New units were added to the ring of United States warships circling Cuba tonight as official concern increased at the continued failure of the contending forces in Havana to settle their disagreements and establish a government regarded by other nations as satisfactory.
A strike of 25,000 members of the White Goods Workers Union has been called for Tuesday as a result of an impasse reached by workers and employers in the women's underwear industry yesterday.

Settling a Vexed Question. Let it be settled now and for all time at least as long as soup and ice cream form part of our menus: We drink bouillon and broths from cups; we take thick vegetable soups and puree from plates; we drink ice cream soda out of a glass; we eat ice cream out of a plate.

Joseph Alperin former Deputy Collector of Internal Revenue in the Third New York District, was acquitted of charges of bribery in a sealed verdict opened yesterday morning in Federal Court by Judge T. Blake Kennedy. The trial began Tuesday, andn the jury had deliberated for more than five hours late Friday.

Wall Street interests, banking and insurance houses, and realty organ- izations throughout the city presented a united front yesterday in opposition to the new taxes sug- gested by Samuel Untermyer, and approved by Tammany Hall.

PACK up your cottons and your linens. Summer is gone. There are other things to think about, especially for the sports-minded. Look about -- it is assumed that you have already left the great open spaces and are once again haunting the city's steel-walled canyons -- and become aware of the new tweeds and knits.

GREAT NECK, L.I., Sept. 9. -- Little Rabbit, fleet brown gelding, captured two first places in the afternoon of racing events which featured the horse show and race meeting staged by the Lake Success Racing and Horse Show Association on the grounds of the Oaks Hunt Club today.
RENO, Nov., Sept. 9 (AP) -- Senator Pittman of Nevada said today that President Roosevelt was considering a plan whereby the price of silver would be increased automatically to $1.19 an ounce.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 9 -- Francis Joseph Morgan Grace, 60 years old, a nephew of the late W. R. Grace, steamship operator, was shot and killed at his Summer home at Santa Cruz tonight by a woman, said to have been his former nurse.

BERLIN, Sept. 9. -- The Reich Institute for Labor Placement and Unemployment Insurance announced today that during the second half of August the number of unemployed in Germany had been reduced by 207,000, bringing the total on the list down to 4,128,000.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 (AP). -- Frederick E. Murphy, Minneapolis publisher and the United States representative at the recent London wheat conference, said today in a statement that the agreement reached for limiting wheat exports "speaks most encouragingly for the future of international cooperation in control of production and marketing."
Japanese ambition for empire has now borne another fruit.

IN "The Master of Jalna" Mazo de la Roche continues the absorbing, and by now rather extensive, saga of the Whiteoaks of Jalna -- that patriarchal Canadian family which clings so picturesquely to its English traditions, and which insists upon maintaining its dignity and its estate intact, in spite of the lean years and the reduced income which make this a matter of increasing difficulty.

OKLAHOMA CITY, Sept. 9 (AP). -- Federal Judge Edgar S. Vaught refused today to interfere with Federal and county authorities in the manner in which they are holding Harvey Bailey, Southwestern outlaw, as he awaits trial for the Charles F. Urschel kidnapping.

IN recent years our institutions of learning have been giving official encouragement to the growing interest in rare books through lectures and exhibitions, and in the periodical reports of news in this field undergraduates are seen to play an increasingly prominent part.

TURIN, Italy, Sept. 9. -- Luigi Beccali, the slender Italian who surprised the athletic world last Summer when he won the 1,500-meter final at the Olympic Games, today showed that victory was no flash in the pan. He outraced Jack Lovelock, sensational New Zealander, to win the 1,500-meter event in the inter-university games before a huge crowd in Mussolini Stadium.

HERBERT HALLIWELL HOBBES, the butler in "The Masquerader" at the Rivoli, is a well-known Engglish actor whose stage career has included appearances with Ellen Terry, Mrs. Pat Campbell and Ethel Irving, among others.

IN the past few weeks Henry Ford has again revealed himself as the player of a lone hand. He has always been an individualist in industry, sometimes leading, sometimes fighting alone. And in his dealings with the NRA his individualism has again been displayed.

PROTESTS by parents and teachers that numerous "broadcasts directed to children terrorized the ears of youth have encouraged the showmen to consider a more pleasing form of entertainment. The latest effort along this line will feature celebrated children's stories such as Robert Louis Stevenson's "Treasure Island," "King Arthur and His Knights," "Robin Hood," "The Three Musketeers" and "Oliver Twist" in dramatized form.

The annual report of the Inter-borough Rapid Transit Company for he fiscal year ended on June 30, 1933, issued by the receivers, Victor J. Bowling and Thomas E. Murray Jr., shows a loss of $969,397 after taxes, rentals and charges, but before deducting the 5 per cent dividend rental on Manhattan Railway Company modified guarantee stock, comparing with a loss of $831,749 in the preceding fiscal year.

Samuel D. Riddle s War Glory, a chestnut son of Man o' War, again thrust himself forward in the 3-year-old division when he led from start to finish of the mile and five-eighths of the featured Lawrence Realization Stakes at Belmont Park yesterday before 10,000 persons.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 9. -- "As Thousands Cheer," the new Irving Berlin-Moss Hart revue, opened here tonight at the Forrest Theatre for a two-week stay, after which it will open at the Music Box in New York.
CHICAGO, Sept. 7. -- Illinois's antiquated prison system is in process of scientific reconstruction.

With the exception of a few lines, such as chocolate and confectionery, electrical products and bakery sup- plies, which moved ahead, most trades in the metropolitan area pro- ceeded at an unchanged pace dur- ing the week, according to the report prepared especially for THE TIMES by the New Tork Credit Men's Association.

DUBLIN, Sept. 8. -- The united political opposition of the Cosgraveites. General Owen O'Duffy's young men of the National Guard and the Centre party farmers against the de Valera government is now complete. At conferences held in Dublin yesterday the rank and file approved the Opposition leaders' action.

RETURN" introduces us to a new novelist in what must be called, for want of a better term, the long English tradition -- a novelist who records, with ample detail and with a strong feeling for English country and the sense of home, the doings of a large family.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 9. -- Modification of the strict censorship that had been placed on field forces of the prohibition unit of the Justice Department was ordered today by Attorney General Cummings.

SCHENECTADY, N.Y., Sept. 9. -- W. Kingsland Macy, State Repub- lican chairman, received a rising vote of confidence today from the Young Men's Republican Clubs of New York State, gathered here in State convention.

Rising high above the serried ranks of brownstone fronts between Fort Greene Place and South Elliott Place on De Kalb Avenue, Brooklyn, is a great edifice of steel, granite and limestone, a monument to the educational ideals of one man.
PARIS, Sept. 9. -- The Franco-Soviet commercial negotiations are taking a longer time than was originally expected but it was announced this morning that appreciable" progress was being made.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 -- A total of $73,000,000 equal to the 1929 Community Chest budget, was agreed on as the required sum for 1934 at the final session today of the Conference on Human Needs.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 (AP). -- A marketing agreement for the national evaporated milk industry went into effect tonight after receiving the signature of Secretary Wallace. Previously it had been signed by manufacturers who operate 161 evaporating plants in twenty-five States and who utilize 3 1/2 per cent of the total fluid milk production in the nation.

THE dramatic developments ow taking place in Cuba have brought a crisis in President Roosevelt's Latin-American policy. Although in certain respects the situation in Cuba is unique, the policy applied by Washington to the Cuban problem may determine our future course toward Latin America as a whole.

The New York University football squad of more than fifty will leave the University Heights campus this morning bound for its new training camp on Lake Sebago, near Sloatsburg, N.Y. The preseason campaign will be begun tomorrow.

New York's Seventy-seventh Division will hold its annual reunion here for three days, beginning Sept. 22. It is expected that 10,000 of its former officers and men will attend. The reunion will commemorrate the date of the battle in the Argonne in 1918 in which the division took a leading part.

FOUR HUNDRED years ago there were astrologers at Greenwich on the River Thames, and like the astronomers who have taken their place they studied the stars. Nervously the astrologers were talking to a huge mountain of a monarch, overbearing and overdressed, who was in a royal fever of irate anxiety.

The hunt in Central Park for a man who, in the last few months has attacked about twenty-five women and robbed scores of men, continued last night. The regular park police were reinforced by about seventy-five detectives, plainclothesmen and policewomen, who lurked in the shadows of the park hoping the culprit might take them for loiterers and thus attempt to victimize one of them.

Many brokers concluded, after the day's results had been tallied, that it would have been just as well yesterday if they had not resumed the usual Saturday schedule. Yesterday was the first Saturday since July 23 that the Stock Exchange did business.

Students of the weekly figures of electric output in the United States frequently have observed changes in the percentage of total production apparently out of line with the changes in the different geographi- cal sections. This is because cer- tain areas bear more weight in comparison with the country as a whole than others do.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Sept. 9. -- Wnen Reginald Root, Yale's new head coach, greets the 109 football candidates he has summoned for the season's initial practice next Friday he will immediately organize several elevens for signal drill and rudimentary practice.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 9 (AP). -- The Athletics' mightiest batter, Jimmy Foxx, kept up his homer-a-day average of the last week by blasting two circuit clouts today as the Athletics scored their fourth straight victory over the Indians, 5 to 3.

The Man With Eyes. THE Winged Victory of Singapore, pictured above, is known, among the natives as orang mata-mata. This doesn't mean that he is a wild animal of any kind. The whiskers are part of his religion -- he's a Sikh (they never shave) and, in the Malay language, orang means "man."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 (AP). -- Do- mestic crude petroleum production in July was reported today by the Department of Commerce as 84,- 387,000 barrels, a daily average of 2,722,000, which is 40,000 barrels less than the June average but 583,000 greater than the average for July, 932.

Seeking Naked Truth. "Sometimes," said Alice, "I find myself wondering what one nudist says to another when they meet. Don't you?" The Duchess stopped choking the baby and looked up at Alice with a terrific sneer.

MR. MALLON'S interesting and important work is the first considerable attempt to present for public consideration in this country a policy of economic relief known as "social credit," advocated by the Douglas School in England.

ARTISTS are showing great in- genuity in adapting the tra- ditions of painted wall deco- ration to the modern home. Small rooms and new methods of lighting present complications un- known in the past, but several recently devised techniques meet these new needs and at the same time offer original and individual effects without departing from the essentials of tradition.

TRENTON, N.J., Sept. 9. -- Louis Haist, 35 years old, a guard in the criminal insane building at the New Jersey State Hospital, was held in $7,000 bail today after Prosecutor Erwin E. Marshall obtained from him a confession that he was to receive $1,000 for smuggling arms and ammunition to four desperate convicts who were planning to escape.

AMSTERDAM, Sept. 9. -- A court here will pass on Monday on a case arising from the boycott of German firms. The management of the Dutch Industries Fair, now being held in Utrecht, seeks an injunction and damages against the leading members of the Dutch "general committee against terror and persecution in Germany."

AGLAD message is that which Dr. Rose announces at the very beginning of his book. "All disease," he says with emphasis, "is preventable. Even the common cold must go!" And then he continues to set forth hope and cheer, especially for the oldsters.

Ellsworth J. Healy, who had been a justice of the Court of Special Sessions since the Spring of 1922, died yesterday of heart disease in the Webb Sanitarium, 188th Street and Webb Avenue, the Bronx, where he had been a patient since Aug. 1, 1932.

RALEIGH, N.C., Sept. 9 (AP). -- Producers of the bulk of the nation's cigarette tobacco moved quickly today to share in the agrarian New Deal and to expedite the resumption of auction sales on the Carolina markets.

The Financial Advertisers Association will hold its eighteenth annual convention this week in the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria. The theme chosen, "Public Relations," is complementary to the discussions of the American Bankers Association convention last week in Chicago.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 9. -- The naval airship Macon tonight stood ready at Lakehurst for a methodical search of the New England coast for the missing American balloon Goodyear IX, unreported since it started from Chicago in the Gordon Bennett Cup race a week ago today.

THE Poet Laureate's sea fever still burns with great warmth. His manifest love of the nautical illuminates this rather specialized record of an English school for mariners. But even readers who may be mildly appalled by the profusion of technicalities that strew its pages will find a good deal of interest and entertainment in the yarns of men who learned their seamanship on the Conway.

PARIS, Sept. 9. -- Despite previous unofficial forecasts, there will be an excess of only 11,000,000 metric quintals [about 40,370,000 bushels] of wheat at the end of next season, most of which can be utilized, Henri Queuille, Minister of Agriculture, said in a statement prepared today.

As is usual at this season of the year, week-end hedging operations on the Cotton Exchange reached substantial proportions yesterday and prices declined again. The market came under pressure at the opening and ended at the bottom with losses of 13 to 19 points.

AFTER an author has written sixty-one books, not counting short stories, as Mr. H.G. Wells has now done, it is reasonable to suppose that he has said about all he has to say about his fundamental reactions to life. There is, in fact, no mystery about Mr. Wells's fundamental reactions.

IT was late in 1883, or perhaps early in 1884, that a little play known as "The Hoop of Gold" crept into the Park Theatre in the city of Brooklyn. Contemporary reviewers treated the "melo-drama" with a kindly pen. A few had some words of praise for one actress, whose name it seemed had been left off the program, but who had the role of Tillie, a slavey.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 9. -- A further recession in industrial productive activity occurred in the week ended on Sept. 2, according to the weekly survey of business conditions made public today by the Department of Commerce.
LONDON, Sept. 9 (AP). -- The Tottenham Hotspurs swept into the lead in the first division of the English Soccer League today with a 3-1 victory over Leicester City.

OMAHA, Neb., Sept. 6. -- The price of overalls has gone up. At the same time the price of hogs has been slipping back. Here is the occasion for no little anxiety on the farm and in those activities close to it. Out of it come the first notes of a discontent akin to that which was so suddenly silenced by the phenomenal and rapid rise of farm prices last May.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 9. -- Opposed at practically every turn by objecting operators, the National Recovery Administration today was pushing forward on an upstream course toward a code for the bituminous coal industry.

TORONTO, Ont., Sept. 9. -- The mining industry is now the second largest primary producer in Canada, superseding forestry, which had held this place for many years, ac- cording to the monthly commercial letter of the Canadian Bank of Commerce.

CHICAGO, Sept. 9 (AP). -- Taking advantage of misplays to score all of their runs, the Phillies defeated the Cubs, 3 to 2, today in a thirteen-inning battle. The defeat snapped the Cubs's winning streak of five games.

A "huge potential general market" for supplies of all kinds will develop throughout the country as soon as conditions become sufficiently clarified to permit purchasing agents to build up inventories to the point considered necessary, the business survey committee of the National Association of Purchasing Agents predicted yesterday in its regular monthly report on industrial conditions in the United States and Canada.

ISTANBUL. THE literature of republican Turkey has taken a new direction, as radical as the political, social and religious changes which have transformed Turkey in the last decade. The objectives today are fundamentally different from those that defined the literary product of the preceding epoch.

CINCINNATI, Sept. 9 (AP). -- The Blue Eagle found itself invoked in a court action today in an engineer's effort to get the pay he said the NRA had held to be his due, but which he said he didn't get.

Adults are to have their own school in San Francisco, under a plan being developed there by Dr. Alexander Meiklejohn, formerly president of Amherst College and more recently head of the University of Wisconsin experimental college.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Sept. 9. -- About 3,000 work relief checks totaling about $25,000, due on Thursday, remain unpaid because of the inability of T. Darrington Semple, Westchester's new county treasurer, to obtain a bond of $200,000.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 (AP). -- Fresh conflict between industry and the Recovery Administration over the merit clause, already in the automobile code, was forecast tonight as shoe manufacturers pre- pared to strive for its retention in a charter for their industry.

IN this new book Evelyn Cheesenan, author of "Everyday Doings of Insects," "Hunting Insects in the South Seas" and "A First Book of Nature Study," discusses the behavior of insects in carrying out their varied and often immensely complex activities.

CARMEL, N.Y., Sept. 9. -- Worthy Lassie, a 3-year-old bay filly, owned by Mrs. W.F. Vail of Greenwich, Conn., won the Class A trot and pace at the Driving Park today. All three heats were closely contested, with the victor taking the first two.

Difficulties in obtaining deliveries of merchandise, although of a tem- porary nature, are being multiplied, especially in goods required for im- mediate selling, according to the market report prepared especially for THE TIMES by Kirby, Block Fischer.
LONDON. ABRONZE lion, twelve feet high, wiich will roar at noon, and a rooster, six feet high, which will crow at sunrise and sunset, are features of a huge new clock erected in Messina, Sicily.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 9. -- From the consumers' advisory board came a request today that the master code for the retail trade, involving several millions of employes, be delayed to permit investigation into the subject of minimum price control.

TIENTSIN. IN Tientsin and in Peiping there are stationed two small bodies of troops, collectively something less than 2,000 men, who during the recent Japanese advance into North China continuously faced tremendous odds of potentially hostile armies without flinching.

GREENWICH, Conn., Sept. 9. -- A distinguished list of patronesses has been announced for the annual Flower Show of the Westchester and Fairfield Horticultural Society, with the Greenwich Garden Club, Old Greenwich Garden Club, Riverside Garden Club, Garden Club and Little Garden Club of Rye and the Hortulus Club of Greenwich cooperating. The show will be held Sept. 20, 21 and 22.

HOLLYWOOD. THE cycle, that element of the cinema which Hollywood is continually abandoning only to re-embrace immediately in some new form, is being observed even more prominently than before in the numerous biographical yarns which have a place in the schedules of every studio in town.

Announcement was made yesterday at the offices of both the German steamship lines confirming the cabled report that the North Ger- man Lloyd and Hamburg-American lines had formed an internal organ- ization in Europe to bring about close cooperation in passenger and freight services to and from the United States and Canada.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Sept. 9. -- After being marooned all night on lonely Robins Island in Great Peconic Bay two young girls were found in a New Suffolk (L.I.) general store this morning peacefully eating their breakfast. They were unmindful of the fact that their parents, members of the State Police, coast guard cutters and aeroplanes had been conducting a frantic search for them through the night.

PARIS. IN his voluntary exile in France, Thomas Mann, author and the winner of the Nobel Prize for literature several years ago, is pessimistic about Germany. With the rise of Hitler in German politics, Mann deserted his Fatherland, though he was under no compulsion to leave his home in Munich.

CAIRO, Sept. 8. -- With the departure this week of William M. Jardine, for the last three years United States Minister to Egypt, the American community here loses its most popular member and the diplomatic corps will be minus one of its ablest representatives.

BERLIN, Sept. 8. -- The flotation of an international currency independent of national monetary values, to be used in international commerce, is advocated by Carl Greulich, retired official of the Disconto Gesellschaft, a large German bank.

GREENWICH, Conn., Sept. 9. -- The four Long Island Sound Interclub sloops that will form the team to meet the Bermuda one-design craft in the international series next week will be Cornelius Shields's Aileen, M.O. Griffiths's Kenboy, R. McC. Shields's Canvas-back and Emil Mosbacher's Susan.

John F. Galvin, chairman of the Port of New York Authority, said yesterday that the improvement program in New York Harbor made possible by the Public Works grant of nearly $3,500,000 would not only aid the unemployment situation, but would facilitate commerce and make the harbor one of the safest in the world.

PORTLAND, Me., Sept. 9. -- Maine, pioneer prohibition State, will re- cord at the polls Monday a convic- tion that prohibition has failed, Governor Brann declared tonight at a rally winding up the repeal drive.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 9. -- The Bureau of Navigation issued the following orders today, dated Sept. 7:

MARCONI in looking through what he calls "a new vista" to the future of wireless is watching the phenomenon of tiny waves, of which he caught a glimpse in the Nineties. He started his early experiments on the ultrashort wave track, but when evtdence appeared that longer waves traveled much further when empowered with the apparatus then available, Marconi and others turned their attention to the long waves.

YOU are sure to like Peter Kerrigan, although he is not the sort of person you should like. He lives by his wits, is an accomplished picker of locks and of pockets, swears fluently in eighteen languages and is woefully ignorant of literature, art and the higher things of life in general.
MINEOLA, L.I., Sept. 9. -- Breaking 98 out of 100 targets, L.G. Moffatt won the registered shoot at the Nassau Trapshooting Club today.

ENDING of the holiday season brought the customary up- turn in retail trade activity during the week, with the added encouragement that volume ran about 10 per cent above the figures of a year ago in the local area.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In his recent speech before the Maryland Bar Association, James Beck, former Solicitor General, sees the New Deal as a climax of a half century of gradual demolition of the Constitution. Heading between the lines one senses a note of sorrow and disapproval.

The expulsion of Edward A. Crawford from membership in the New York Cotton Exchange was announced from the rostrum of the Exchange yesterday morning by the secretary. Mr. Crawford was suspended by the Chicago Board of Trade on July 24 after a sharp break in grain prices there had been attributed largely to his overextended long position.

GENEVA, Sept. 8. -- The resumption of the disarmament talks, signalized by the return of Norman H. Davis to Europe, finds the tone here less pessimistic or more hopeful than in July, depending on the viewpoint. This is particularly true of positively minded circles.

NEWARK, N.J., Sept. 9. -- Pacing the last half in 1:03 3/4, Betsy Prigg, brown mare owned and driven by Arthur Sawyer of New York, stepped a mile in 2:09 1/4, the outstanding performance of the matinee at Weequahic Park today.

ILLUSTRATION even now and here has learned to stand by itself. A number of sensitive persons are seeing in pictures made for books as great possibilities of personal expression as in pictures made for walls. In other -- and more accurate -- words, they see that neither page nor plaster can control the independent spirit of art.

PARIS, Aug. 31. -- A number of New Yorkers, some of whom visit the Continent regularly about this time of the year, have been returning these days from Salzburg, where the big August musical and dramatic festival has just come to a close.
MADRID, Sept. 9. -- Alejandro Lerroux, leader of the Republican conservatative element, was charged tonight by President Niceto Alcala Zamora with the task of forming a Cabinet.

The Cambridge Vandals came perilously close to suffering the first defeat of their North American rugby tour yesterday. The visiting Englishmen faced a team of American stars at Innisfail Park and after trailing for the greater part of the battle, staged a closing rally that enabled them to subdue the native fifteen, 14 to 11.

BRETTON WOODS, N.H., Sept. 9. -- Bright leaves decorated the ballroom at the Balsams in Dixville Notch tonight when an Autumn dance was given. Mr. and Mrs. C. Eastwood of Garden City, Mr. and Mrs. R.C. Witherspoon of East Orange, N.J., Mr. and Mrs. Earl B. Osborne and Master Laurence Osborne, Mr. and Mrs. Robert C. Taylor, New York, are there.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Sept. 9. -- Simple funeral services were held here today in the First Presbyterian Church for the Rev. Dr. Charles H. Parkhurst, noted New York pastor, who died early yesterday at the age of 91, in the Atlantic City Hospital, a few hours after falling in his sleep off a porch roof at the home of his nephew, Winthrop Parkhurst, in Ventnor.
LONDON, Sept. 9. -- Gold fell sharply by 1s 8 1/2d to 129s 2 1/2d a fine ounce today. The quotation was fixed on the basis of the Paris exchange rate of 81 9-16 francs to

The lightweight championship of the world will hang in the balance at the Polo Grounds on Tuesday night, when Barney Ross of Chicago encounters Tony Canzoneri, rugged Brooklyn warrior, in a fifteen-round battle. The bout is being staged by the Aram A.C., and the Free Milk Fund for Babies will share in the proceeds.

FREDERICK LONSDALE, who takes the jumps in his stride and has never been known to rush one, will voyage hither from his English hearthstone the latter part of this month with the completed script of his new play, "Foreigners," once called "The League of Nations," in his kit bag.

PROBABLY no period in the history of New York was more glamourous than that era around 1900 known roughly as "The Turn o' (of) the Century." Who does not recall with a sentimental sigh those colorful days of Diamond Jim Brady, Lillian Russell, Anna Held, Joe Cook or Dave Chasen?

ONE of the world's greatest battles -- that which liberated Vienna and halted the westward march of the Turks 250 years ago, will be celebrated on Sept. 12 both in Austria and Poland. The anniversary is of especial interest to the Poles, for with the Battle of Vienna is inseparably associated the name of Jan Sobieski, son of a country squire, who became King of Poland and one of the great heroes of his age.
GLENS FALLS, N.Y., Sept. 9. -- Jimmy Hines, the 29-year-old professional from the Timber Point Club, Great River, L.I., today captured the Glens Falls open golf tourney in spectacular fashion.

Rather than be taxed out of existence, members of the New York Stock Exchange are seriously considering removal to a more hospitable place. This is no idle threat. After the Untermyer tax program was announced last week, many of the influential men in Stock Exchange firms discussed plans looking to a transfer of operations. It will not be easy to pick up and move, but it may become necessary.

ANOTHER air-racing season has passed into history. And there has been some history in its making. The Bendix Race of the National meet produced a new East-West transcontinental record, when Roscoe Turner made the Floyd Bennett-Los Angeles flight in 11 hours 30 minutes.

PROBABLY no period in the history of New York was more glamourous than that era around 1900 known roughly as "The Turn o' (of) the Century." Who does not recall with a sentimental sigh those colorful days of Diamond Jim Brady, Lillian Russell, Anna Held, Joe Cook or Dave Chasen?

ONE of the world's greatest battles -- that which liberated Vienna and halted the westward march of the Turks 250 years ago, will be celebrated on Sept. 12 both in Austria and Poland. The anniversary is of especial interest to the Poles, for with the Battle of Vienna is inseparably associated the name of Jan Sobieski, son of a country squire, who became King of Poland and one of the great heroes of his age.
GLENS FALLS, N.Y., Sept. 9. -- Jimmy Hines, the 29-year-old professional from the Timber Point Club, Great River, L.I., today captured the Glens Falls open golf tourney in spectacular fashion.

Rather than be taxed out of existence, members of the New York Stock Exchange are seriously considering removal to a more hospitable place. This is no idle threat. After the Untermyer tax program was announced last week, many of the influential men in Stock Exchange firms discussed plans looking to a transfer of operations. It will not be easy to pick up and move, but it may become necessary.

ANOTHER air-racing season has passed into history. And there has been some history in its making. The Bendix Race of the National meet produced a new East-West transcontinental record, when Roscoe Turner made the Floyd Bennett-Los Angeles flight in 11 hours 30 minutes.

A well-known golf observer of many years' connection with the sport was discussing the national amateur championship which is to be played over the course of the Kenwood Country Club, near Cincinnati, starting tomorrow.

The white cork sun helmets recently proposed as part of the standard uniform for mounted and traffic policemen have failed to arouse as keen enthusiasm as was expected from the men who are to wear them, it was disclosed yesterday.

The week closed with the price trend lower in the commodity futures markets here. A further advance in the dollar and a decline in wheat prices discouraged speculative activity in the principal staples.

SINCE in his introduction Professor Schutze himself suggests that the lay reader may omit certain parts of the earlier chapters, we may put the cart before the horse in dealing with the book and take up the last part first. By way of entry into the work there is a key passage very near the close, a passage containing certain terms possibly not understandable at first glance, although they should become clear later:

IN many respects a motion picture company planning to make scenes "on location" prepares and travels like an army on the move. It has its advance scouts, its sanitary and medical squads, kitchens and commissaries, and signal and transportation corps.

Retail trade continued last week to show satisfactory contrasts with that of a year ago, but remained approximately at the levels which obtained in the weeks immediately preceding Labor Day, indicating that fairly general advances in prices so far have not resulted in a suspension of buying.

MR. COHAN opened the door himself. He was feeling affable. He had just come home from a rehearsal of O'Neill's impending "Ah, Wilderness," in which he is to play the leading part under the Theatre Guild's impeccable management.

MIDDLETOWN, Conn., Sept. 9. -- Four New England outboard cham- pions were crowned today in the first day's program of the Connecti- cut River Outboard Regatta Asso- ciation's regatta. Final events were run off in Classes A and C for both amateur and professional drivers.

George Salvo led a starting field of 101 as the initial eighteen holes of the two-day qualifying round in the Greater New York match play championship got under way yesterday at the Dyker Beach Golf Club. Salvo posted a card of 35, 29 -- 64, three over par for the course.

ALBANY, N.Y., Sept. 9. -- Albany and Jersey City broke even in a double-header today, Albany winning the first game, 6 to 3, behind good pitching by Al Shealy, and Jersey City scoring a 3-to-2 victory in the second.

MELBOURNE, Sept. 8. -- The aborigines of the Caledon Bay tribe in North Australia have the most sinister reputation of any of the natives in Australia. For many years their name has been associated with murders and outrages.

HISTORY will become drama next Thursday evening when the pageant of "The Romance of a People" is presented at the Polo Grounds. Being designed as spectacle and oratorio, the pageant will turn six thousand people into the cast of a play.

BAIREUTH, Aug. 28, 1933. AROUND a room of moderate size and of no particular decorative pretense on the second floor of a government building opposite the Neue Schloss at Baireuth are disposed some two dozen glass cases.

OKLAHOMA CITY, Okla., Sept. 6. -- You may remember marveling at the mob on horseback, mule- back, in covered wagons and creak- ing surreys that made the most ex- citing part of Edna Ferber's novel picturing the settlement of Okla- homa, and for that matter of the "movie" that followed it.

New York taxpayers will not stand, for additional taxation without receiving from Tammany guarantees of economies, Bernard S. Deutsch, fusion candidate for President of the Board of Aldermen, declared last evening just before he left on the Cunarder Mauretania on a short West Indies cruise.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I believe it will be of interest to the public generally to review what a group of women composing the board of trustees of the New York Infirmary for Women and Children has accomplished in these hard times.

As schools closed last June, New York was the bright spot in the educational firmament. During the 190-day school year no schools had been closed; no child had been deprived of the right of school attendance; no teacher had gone unpaid, and only in minor instances had school districts failed to meet their financial obligations.

TOKYO, Aug. 25. -- Economic recovery began early in Japan and is now well under way. Acting under the compulsion of events rather than by plan, Japan went off the gold basis, thus anticipating the Rooseveltian policy in the United States, and entered a campaign of stimulating exports and spending money on farm relief and public works at home.

VIENNA, Sept. 9. -- The Heim- wehr supporters of the present Aus- trian Government have served a virtual ultimatum on Chancellor Dollfuss to counter Hitlerism by es- tablishing a Fascist State, and there are indications that he will meet their wishes.

BRUSSELS, Sept. 9. -- Professor Albert Einstein in a letter to a Belgian pacifist, Alfred Nahon, published in today's Patrie Humaine, abandons his previously uncompromising attitude toward war and urges Belgians to prepare against the Hitlerite menace.

SHENANDOAH, Pa., Sept. 9. -- Picketing miners today stoned William F. Carey, former president of the Madison Square Garden Corporation, New York, and now an executive of a contracting firm working on coal stripping operations at Jackson, near here.

GREENWICH, Conn., Sept. 9. -- About fifty women golfers from the metropolitan area, Greenwich and Stamford, Conn., are entered in the annual women's golf tournament at the Greenwich Country Club, starting Monday and continuing through Wednesday.

Harold O. Voorhis, secretary of New York University, yesterday announced the addition of eighteen teachers in the university's instructional staff and the promotion of forty-three members of the faculty and administrative staff.

To the Editor of The New York Times: THE TIMES recently told of a wild-flower garden in Wayne, Neb., which Mr. Teed has been cultivating. I have a garden of this kind with 120 different species of wild flowers. Drainage of swamps, cultivation and pasturing have made it difficult for the shy and dainty woodland occupants to survive.

TWENTY-ONE informal papers on books and authors make up A. Edward Newton's forthcoming book. "End Papers," which Little, Brown Co. will publish late in November. Mr. Newton announces that he will autograph no copies of the trade edition of this book.
To the Editor of The New York Times: In many ways the recent conditions in the industrial world resemble the conditions in Europe at the time of the breaking up of the feudal system.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Sept. 9. -- Next Friday Head Coach Eddie Casey, with his reconstructed, staff of assistants, will look over Harvard's football squad for the first time this Fall. More than 100 candidates are expected to report, but the qualifications of at least forty of these players are well known.

ROME, Sept. 8. -- It is doubtful whether any city in the world has undergone such a radical transformation in all its services as well as in actual architectural appearance as has Rome in ten years of Fascist rule, especially the last few. It probably would be necessary to go back to Paris under Napoleon III to find a parallel case.

THE programs at the New York Hippodrome this week will be confined to familiar operas. The Chicago Opera Company, under the management of Alfredo Salmaggi, began its Fall season with a group of preliminary performances last week.
Although the current tournament season has several weeks to go, the officials of the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association are already looking ahead to 1934.

George Rensa, recruit backstop relieving Bill Dickey, yesterday launched a seventh-inning rally that saved the Yankees from a rout in their last game of the season with the St. Louis Browns at the Stadium.

BOSTON, Sept. 9. -- Boston's new $6,000,000 Federal building housing the main postoffice, Federal courts and other government agencies, was dedicated today by Postmaster General Farley in the presence of Governor Ely, Mayor Curley and State and Federal notables.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 9. -- The most ambitious non-stop mass formation flight ever attempted was under contemplation today at the Navy Department, involving the same seaplanes that only yesterday bung up the present record.

HAVANA, Sept. 9. -- Sumner Welles, United States Ambassador, declined to comment this afternoon regarding the agreement between the de facto government and op- position groups for the return of the Presidential and constitutional form of government, but it became known that the embassy regarded the -- compromise as a step in the right direction.

Sharply higher prices for United States Government bonds featured yesterday an otherwise dull and ir- regular market for bonds on the Stock Exchange. The government's issues climbed 1-32 to 6-32 point, with the exception of the Treasury 3 3/8s, due in 1943, callable in 1941, which held unchanged, and the Liberty 3 1/2s, which sold off 2-32 point.

In last week's address on the money standard to the British Association for the Advancement of Science, by Professor JOHN H. JONES of the University of Leeds, general return to the gold standard was predicted almost as a matter of course. That a single economic expert should make this prediction would be itself of no great significance, but the consensus of judgment to the same effect has been impressive.
NOW that the grouse shooting season on the Bronx moors is over, there may be time to peruse this eye-witness account of a stirring spectacle in Sunny Spain:

For the seventh consecutive week THE NEW YORK TIMES weekly index of business activity has declined, the figure for the week ended Sept. 2 dropping to 82.6 from 84.9 in the preceding week. For the week ended Sept. 3, 1932, the number was 66.5.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Sept. 9. -- Bill Cummings of Indianapolis won the 100-mile championship auto race at the New York State Fair today as 35,000 fans looked on. Cummings, who had the fastest mile in the qualifying round, took the lead at the start and kept it through each of the 100 whirling turns about the mile dirt track.

The historic peace conference at the Christopher Billopp House in Tottenville, S.I., where representatives of the Continental Congress met Admiral Lord Richard Howe in September, 1777, in a final and unsuccessful effort to reconcile Great Britain and her American Colonies was re-enacted yesterday on the steps of the old mansion.

BOSTON, Sept. 10 (AP). -- Fine pitching by Irving Hadley and George Blaeholder enabled the Browns to capture a double-header from the Red Sox today, 3 to 2 and 4 to 0, the second game going eleven innings.
NEW YORK. Major Gen. Guy V. Henry. U.S. A., and Mrs. Henry of Washington are at the Waldorf-Astoria.

PORT CHESTER, N.Y., Sept. 10. -- Johnny Jorroicks, bay gelding owned by Miss Margareta Noble of Greenwich. Conn., won the jumping championship in the second annual Junior Horse Show at the Blind Brook Turf and Polo Club today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 (AP) -- Confidently expecting repeal within a few months, distilleries have virtually doubled their prices for medicinal whisky, and even at such a level are, in many cases, refusing to part with their stocks of aged liquor.

An intelligent interpretation of the signs of the times points overwhelmingly to the enduring supremacy of Christ's spirit, the spirit of self-sacrifice, said the Rev. Dr. J. Ross Stevenson, president of the Princeton Seminary, in his sermon yesterday morning at the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church, at Fifth Avenue and Fifty-fifth Street.

Hitlerite Germany's foreign policies have alienated much of the sympathy formerly felt for the Reich in foreign quarters, declared James Grover McDonald, chairman of the American Foreign Policy Association, in an address broadcast from London yesterday.

A slight improvement in dress and coat deliveries featured the week, but shipments for the most part continue to be seriously delayed. Some gain in output is expected to accrue from the addition of two days to a notably short production period this month, but it is doubtful if complete deliveries on orders already placed can be made by the end of the month.
Carl Altio, Consul General for Finland in New York, accompanied by Mrs. Altio, is due here today from Helsingfords via Gothenburg on the Swedish-American liner Kungsholm.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Your editorial "Higher Water Rates" is interesting to those who have studied the subject for many years. It is true that the present schedule needs readjustment, but why continue an obsolete method of selling water?

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., Sept. 10. -- Sands Point and the Hurricanes rode through seven periods of a practice match for the open championship on the polo field of the Sands Point Club today, with the Hurricanes winning, 14 to 8.

DENVER, Sept. 10 (AP). -- Two persons were drowned, at least three were missing and damage estimated in the hundred thousands of dollars was caused by a series of floods that deluged Denver and suburbs today.
CHICAGO, Sept. 10. -- Chicago lawenforcement officials are giving Fair visitors reason for believing that the backbone of this city's much publicized gangland may have been broken.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 10. -- Sena- tor Wagner appealed today to em- ployers and employes to use the National Labor Board for arbitration of their disputes in accordance with the President's recovery pro- gram. He is chairman of the board.

The fifth instalment of the Fact-Finder's Report on Japan, made public today by the Laymen's Foreign Missions Inquiry, says: "In confidential interviews most of the leaders of the Japanese Christian churches declared that no more missionaries should be sent for evangelistic work."
CINCINNATI, Sept. 10. -- The top and the bottom of the National League moved a little further apart today as the front-running Giants bagged both ends of a doubleheader from the tail-end Reds.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., Sept. 10. -- A strong northwesterly breeze interfered seriously with the racing program of the Manhasset Bay Yacht Club today. The skippers evinced considerable reluctance to take to the waters of Manhasset Bay.

LONDON, Sept. 9. -- The Economist's fortnightly index of commodity prices, based on the average of 1927 as 100, stood on Sept. 6 at 65.6, comparing with 65.2 two weeks before and 60.4 at the September date in 1931, when England abandoned the gold standard.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 10. -- The steel trade does not expect an early increase in steel buying of such, extent as to cause an upward turn in the rate of production, but it does not look for a much further decrease in output.

CHICAGO, Sept. 10. -- New conditions are developing steadily in the business and manufacturing situation, and giving rise to greater caution in regard to readjustment of prices. The impression prevails that ultimately there will be greater stability of production and prices.
CHICAGO, Sept. 10 (AP). -- The Chicago business man, of the recent gloomy visage, is wearing an expansive smile these days.

The President's NRA Day Parade up Fifth Avenue from Washington Square to Seventy-second Street Wednesday afternoon from 1:30 to 8 o'clock will be featured by one of the largest aerial demonstrations ever staged over New York. More than 2,000 policemen have been assigned to parade duty by Commissioner James S. Bolan.

Some essays written by the late Lytton Strachey over a period of thirty years have been collected and are to be published in a book called "Characters and Commentaries" this Fall by Harcourt, Brace. There are six essays on English letter writers; nine early essays discussing, among others, Horace Walpole and Lady Mary Wortley Montagu, and fourteen essays on subjects ranging from Russian humor through French poets to militarism.

BRETTON WOODS, N.H., Sept. 10. -- The last polo match of the season brought a throng to the Lyle Phillips private polo ranch at Whitefield this afternoon. The ranch team played against the Hillwood polo team of Bloomfield Hills, Grosse Pointe, Mich.
WESTBURY, L.I., Sept. 10. -- Four of the teams preparing for the open championship, which gets under way on Saturday, took part in practice matches at the Meadow Brook Club today.

CHICAGO, Sept. 10 (AP). -- The Cubs kept their meager hopes of repeating as National League champions alive today by sweeping a double-header from the Phillies, winning the second game, 4 to 2, on a home run by Adolph Camilli, rookie first baseman, after Bud Tinning's shut-out hurling had given them the opener, 4 to 0.

PEEKSKILL, N.Y., Sept. 10. -- The celebration of "Governor's Day" at Camp Smith here this afternoon by the 369th Infantry of Harlem attracted a record crowd for the season. More than 13,000 visitors, mostly from Harlem, saw the 1,100 guardsmen of the Negro regiment, led by Colonel William A. Taylor, pass in review before Governor Herbert H. Lehman.

TORONTO, Sept. 10. -- The first British Common-wealth Relations conference will open a ten-day session here tomorrow, which will take up such subjects as improvement of communication, consultation and action among members of the Commonwealth.

Among many apartment rentals announced by brokers over the week-end were a number in buildings on the west side of Manhattan, including several on West End Avenue and Riverside Drive. The list follows:
The Shrewsbury River in the vicinity of Red Bank now is providing some of the best fishing in Jersey waters, according to advices received yesterday.

PARIS, Sept. 10. -- Since all efforts at collaboration seem doomed "to interminable discussions," France intends to remain strong, Edmond Miellet, Minister of Pensions, declared today in an address at Meaux climaxing the celebrations of the nineteenth anniversary of the victory of the Marne.

Censure of the Specialty Bakery Owners Association for its unwillingness to cooperate with the NRA was expressed in a statement issued yesterday by the mediation board of the local NRA organization. The statement was issued following rejection by the association of the board's decision in the strike of about 2,500 members of the Bakery and Confectionery Workers Union, which has been in progress for more than four months.
Park Av., 1,355, 27x100.11; Benjamin Nelman et al. to Samuel Liebovitz et al., 201 W. 94th St.; same premises. Samuel Liebovitz et al. to Bryant Square Realty Corp. 10 Amsterdam Av.

BUENOS AIRES, Sept. 10. -- Argetitina's long drought was broken by general rains throughout the cereal belt yesterday and today. The wheat crop is believed saved. The ground is now in condition to replant flaxseed and to prepare for planting corn. More rain is needed, but there is no longer danger of crop loss.

DIXON RYAN FOX, president of the New York State Historical Association, as he welcomes guests to the annual meeting of the society this week has but to speak the name "Ticonderoga" to summon back the glorious memories that are the most "opulent asset" of the village which is their proud steward.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 (AP). -- President Roosevelt's course in the Cuban situation was decided long before his inauguration, friends revealed today. He began his study of Cuban affairs a year ago. Before his inauguration he told a friend and close adviser:

The schedule for receipt of bids for the first construction contracts on the Midtown Hudson Tunnel was announced yesterday by the tunnel construction committee of the Port of New York Authority under the plan whereby the project becomes part of the national recovery program.

"This is the first day of school." To something more than a million youngsters in the five boroughs of New York the realization came at bedtime last night that they had definite and unavoidable engagements for today and for tomorrow and the next day and what may seem like an endless succession of days.

CHICAGO, Sept. 10. -- Armour Co., packers, paid about $1,300,000 in salaries from 1923 through last year to the three bankers serving as members of the finance committee of the company, T.G. Lee, president, disclosed today.

CINCINNATI, Sept. 10. -- Headed by C. Ross Somerville of Canada and Johnny Goodman of Omaha, the leading golfers of the United States and the Dominion are assembled here for the national amateur golf championship, which begins at the Kenwood Country Club tomorrow.

Mrs. Anne Whelan Kahn, who obtained a divorce in Reno last Jan. 10 from Gilbert W. Kahn, was seriously injured at 11:40 o'clock yesterday morning when she fell from a window of her ten-room apartment on the third floor of 784 Park Avenue to the sidewalk of East Seventy-fourth Street.

With two out and two strikes on him in the ninth, Johnny Frederick delivered a vital blow for the Dodgers that brought them victory and an even break in the double-header with the Pirates at Ebbets Field yesterday.

Based on the local market quotations for the French franc last week, the dollar was strong. The highest was 71.69 cents, reached on Saturday, following a sharp break in all gold currencies of the Continent, as a result of which the franc sold down to 5.46 1/2 cents. The week's lowest was 68.85, on Wednesday, and the close 71.04, a gain of .77 over the preceding Saturday.

HAVANA, Sept. 10. -- Dr. Ramon Grau San Martin became Cuba's new President when he took the oath of office, administered by Chief Justice Edelman of the Supreme Court at noon today in the Presidential Palace. He had been elected President by the revolutionary council shortly after midnight.

ALBANY, Sept. 10. -- Revision of the Trade Marks Law of New York State is the objective of a legislative committee which will meet on Sept. 19 in the Woolworth Building, New York City. The sessions are scheduled to last two days.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Sept. 10. There promises to be a showdown Monday as to whether Miss Josephine Sutton of White Plains, deputy Westchester County treasurer under the late Charles M. Miller, can hold her office. Miss Sutton was discharged by T.D. Semple, appointed treasurer by Governor Lehman.

Brains in Havana. Cuba has her own Brain Trust in the "Directorio Estudiantil," the Student Directorate. The role it has played in recent events would make the Cuban organization as important, in proportion to the scene and the task, as the complex of academic talent mobilized by the Roosevelt administration.

ANTWERP, Sept. 10. -- King Albert of the Belgians, accompanied by the royal family, came to this city this afternoon to preside at elaborate ceremonies for the inauguration of the new tunnels under the Scheldt River.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 10. -- A "definite reflection of renewed confidence on the part of the nation's business" is shown by newspaper display advertising linage figures for August as compared with 1932, NRA officials said today.

A new morality, with love as its basis, was urged yesterday by the Very Rev. Hughell E.W. Fosbroke, dean of the General Theological Seminary, who preached at St. Bartholomew's Protestant Episcopal Church. Park Avenue and Fiftieth Street.

Tammany is confident of its ability to re-elect Mayor John P. O'Brien, though by a smaller plurality than the half million received four years ago by James J. Walker. The fusionists are hopeful of electing Major F.H. LaGuardia and regard the general political situation as even more favorable for the defeat of Tammany than at the time of the last fusion victory in 1913, when the late John Purroy Mitchel was elected Mayor.

The 1934 budget must include $24,944,987 more for certain items than was provided for 1933, according to advance estimates made public last night by Mayor O'Brien. This increase, which he hopes will be sufficiently offset by various savings to bring the 1934 total close to that of the 1933 budget, is attributed to six causes.

Consideration for one's neighbors, "the people across the street," has achieved a place in religion that it never occupied for our forefathers, the Rev. Dr. John L. Davis told his congregation at the Washington Square Methodist Episcopal Church, 135 West Fourth Street, yesterday morning.
GOSHEN, Ind., Sept. 10 (AP). -- A mother and her two daughters were killed today when a New York Central passenger train struck an automobile that had stalled on a crossing here.

FORT THOMPSON, S.D., Sept. 10 (AP). -- Eight persons were drowned, thousands of dollars worth of property was damaged and scores of head of livestock were destroyed early today when a cloudburst drove small creeks out of their banks on the Crow Creek Indian Reservation, flooding lowlands and sweeping homes and farm buildings away.

WESTBURY, L.I., Sept, 10. -- Independence Boy, clever hunter, owned by Mrs. V.S. Makaroff of Oyster Bay, was awarded the hunter championship at the sixth annual horse show of the Soldiers and Sailors Club today. Ridden by Albart Kernan in his several victories, the chestnut gelding was the outstanding performer in his division.

PARIS, Sept. 9. -- The belief is widely held here that the United States soon will be forced to have recourse to inflation to maintain prices and to insure the working of the NRA program. In this connection, the opinion is held that the government itself will be obliged to finance the recovery plan, owing to reports from the United States indicating that American banks are unwilling to grant extensive credit facilities.

CHICAGO, Sept. 10. -- Corn and oats, like wheat, failed to respond to bullish statistics last week and prices were on the down grade, with some scattered liquidation appearing. The same factors operative in depressing wheat were also effective in feeding grains in general.

Distinguished Christian leaders of city, State and nation joined with eminent Jews at the Hotel Astor last night in denouncing the persecution of Jews in Germany as a descent into barbarism which was bringing disaster to Germany as well as to the Jews.

NEWARK, N.J., Sept. 10 (AP). -- Myril Hoag's twenty-second home run of the season with the bases loaded in the fifth climaxed a sixrun rally today and gave the Bears a 6-5 decision over the Orioles in the final game of the season. The triumph gave Newark an even break on the season's series with Baltimore.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 (AP). -- Federal aid for education, not only in the present emergency but as a continuing policy, was advocated today in a report made by the National Conference on Financing of Education.

MEMPHIS, Tenn., Sept. 10 (AP). -- New Orleans finished first in the second half of the Southern Association split season today, dividing a double-header with Memphis. The Pelicans will meet the Chicks in a play-off series for the title.

Further discussion of the problem respecting ticket brokers and the allotment of tickets to them by theatrical managers will take place this morning when the subcommittee of the National Legitimate Theatre Committee, appointed to deal with the question, meets in the office of Brock Pemberton, its chairman.

HAVANA, Sept. 10. -- The official American viewpoint here is that the United States will recognize the new Grau San Martin government if it shows capacity to govern, maintain order, receives distinct popular lar support and complies with all its obligations.

How to play is something that has to be taught to Americans, according to many foreigners and a number of the more knowing natives. Some of our novelists have turned out good stories based on the inability of the American business man to enjoy anything whole-heartedly except work.

CHICAGO, Sept. 10 (AP). -- Following the lead of President Roosevelt In creating the NRA, Mayor Edward J. Kelly has evolved a Chicago recovery administration, "brain trust" and all, to cope with the city's muddled finances and other municipal problems.
LONDON, Sept. 10. -- Professor Albert Einstein, who fled from Belgium fearing murder by Nazis, has secluded himself in a log hut high on a barren Norfolk heath where he is closely guarded.

BERLIN, Sept. 10. -- In a few weeks President Paul von Hindenburg will be 86. His very years recurrently raise the question of who is to succeed him, and before the Nazi conquest this was a grave anxiety of the liberal parties, which looked on him as the main dike against the brown tide.

RIVIERE A PIERRE, Que., Sept. 10 -- The two Polish entrants in the James Gorden Bennett balloon race today told of their sufferings from hunger, cold and weariness on their ninety-mile trek through the forests after running a gamut of thunderstorms on their air journey.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 -- One strong prohibition organization making a determined drive for a new, but different, prohibition amendment to the Constitution was advocated today in a letter from Deets Pickett, research secretary for the Board of Temperance, Prohibition and Public Morals of the Methodist Episcopal Church, to weekly church papers.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Sept. 10 (AP). -- Charles B. Barnes, mediator for the National Labor Board, tonight announced that a dispute between the Cleveland Railway Company and 3,000 car men, which had threatened to tie up the city's transportation system with a strike, was practically settled.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 10. -- Touching on several questions before the public, Louis McHenry Howe, secretary to President Roosevelt, in his weekly radio speech tonight defended the Securities Act and expressed a view that, while Congress might alter the law, it would not repeal it.
LONDON, Sept. 10. -- Professor Albert Einstein, fleeing reported Nazi threats against his life, went from London today to a quiet spot on the East Coast of England, known only to a few persons.

TROY, N.Y., Sept. 10. -- Following long discussion at the closing business session of the convention of the New York State Federation of Young Men's Hebrew Associations. Young Women's Hebrew Associations and kindred associations here today a resolution was unanimously adopted declaring that the State Federation "deplores the present Nazi situation in Germany and regrets deeply such an unfortunate attempt to turn backward the course of world civilization."

MANILA, Sept. 10 -- The Benguet Consolidated Mining Company, the largest mining concern in the Philippines, signed a contract Saturday for the exploitation of extensive chromium deposits in the Province of Ambos Camarines and is planning an expenditure of $125,000 on the project.

CROSS SOMERVILLE of Ontario, Canada, is United States amateur golf ehampion at the moment, but the debate that gets under way at the Kenwood course, Cincinnati, today probably will produce a different champion by the end of the week.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Sept. 10. -- The Harvard Athletic Association tonight announced a re-scaling of ticket prices for the stadium football games this year, with two prices prevailing for all except the games with Army and Yale.

BOSTON, Sept. 10. -- Formation of a huge development company to remove the Newfoundland railroad and steamship lines from government operation and in the course of five years to expend $21,000,000 in exploiting the timber and coal resources of the country, is said to be under consideration by the Newfoundland Government, the British Colonial Office and a royal investigating commission.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Are not apples of indignation the Apples of Sodom, but by another name? Of these Thevenot said, "There are apple trees on the sides of the Dead Sea which bear lovely fruit, but within are full of ashes." John Webster, in "The White Devil, or Vittoria Corombona," wrote, in 1612:
With certain exceptions, the principal staples traded on local commodity exchanges declined last week with wheat and cotton prices, while the dollar advanced on brisk European buying.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 10. -- Revision of the immigration laws to admit religious and political refugees, particularly from Germany, in harmony with the American "tradition of asylum for refuees escaping from foreign tyrannies," was urged in a memorial addressed to President Roosevelt today by the American Civil Liberties Union.

The Statue of Liberty was conducted on an imaginary tour of lower Manhattan yesterday by the Rev. Dr. Charles Trexler, pastor of the Lutheran Church of St. James, Madison Avenue and Seventy-third Street. The tour purported to be an inspection of Wall Street, City Hall Square and Times Square, and resulted in the decision on the part of the statue to return to her post wih the torch turned face downward.
AUGUSTA, Me., Sept. 10 -- The wets of this pioneer prohibition State predicted tonight that Maine would swing into the repeal column by a 2-to-1 vote in the election tomorrow.
LONDON, Sept. 9. -- On the whole commodity prices are holding their ground fairly well with considerable irregularity in individual movements.
LONDON, Sept. 9. -- Although recent excitement in foreign exchanges has died down and sterling is outwardly steadier, its undertone remains weak and the market restive.
Former Governor Smith's address at the dinner to Samuel Untermyer follows:
WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 (AP). -- The Senators defeated the Indians today, 7 to 3, giving the visitors their fifth straight setback since coming East.
Albert Leonard George, men's wear, three store units in British Empire Building, Rockefeller Center. The lessee is to continue a shop in 608 Madison Av. which he has operated for six years.

NEW ORLEANS, La., Sept. 9. -- The cotton market here last week was dominated mainly by the Census Bureau's estimate of this year's crop of cotton, which was issued on Friday. In anticipation of the report trading had consisted mainly of evening-up of commitments.

Senator Robert F. Wagner, in a letter to Nathan Straus Jr., accepted yesterday an honorary vice chairmanship of the committee of sponsors of the Jewish pageant, "The Romance of a People," which is to be presented at the Polo Grounds Thursday, Friday and Saturday.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 10 -- The well-preserved remains of a people belonging to an early Eskimo culture have been discovered in Alaska by an archaeological and ethnological expedition sent by the University of Pennsylvania Museum.

MIDDLETOWN, Conn. Sept. 10. -- Cab Walier, New York State outboard champion, added two more titles to his collection today in the finals of the New England-Middle Atlantic outboard championships on the Connecticut River.

The city's independent subway system carried 76,607,424 passengers and earned $439,000 in excess of operating and maintenance charges in its first year of operation, according to a summary issued yesterday by the Board of Transportation.
Several store structures were included in the New Jersey realty conveyances reported over the week-end.

The four first division teams, Newark, Rochester, Baltimore and Buffalo, won the right to take part in the International League playoffs as the regular season for the big minor circuit closed yesterday.

NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 10. -- About fifty of the visiting midshipmen from the U.S.S. Wyoming were entertained with a beach picnic at Bailey's Beach late this afternoon. Mrs. Aymar Johnson acted as hostess, assisted by a number of friends.

Obligations of the United States Government that will mature within the next twelve months amount to $2,950,396,200. They consist of Treasury certificates of indebtedness, notes and non-interest-bearing discount bills.

A political organization extending into each of the 3,700 election districts in New York City has been set up for Deputy Controller Frank J. Prial, candidate for the Democratic nomination for Controller, it was announced yesterday at his headquarters, 295 Madison Avenue.
ALBANY, N.Y., Sept. 10 (AP). -- Albany won both games of the double-header with Jersey City today in bringing the International League season to a close. The score in each game was 2 to 1.

MADRID, Sept. 10. -- One after another of the left-wing or so-called revolutionary parties that make up the working majority of the Cortes turned thumbs down on proposals of Alejandro Lerroux, conservative Republican, who is charged with the task of forming a government.

HUNTINGTON, L.I., Sept. 10. -- The Crescent Athletic-Hamilton Club cricketers today scored another victory in the annual championship competition of the Metropolitan and New Jersey Cricket Association. They defeated the veteran Sons of St. George by 138, for the loss of four wickets, to 104.

Plans are going forward rapidly for the Fashion Show in aid of the Social Service Auxiliary of the Metropolitan Hospital and the Emergency Tuberculosis Relief Committee, which will take place throughout the day on Oct. 5 at the Waldorf-Astoria.

VIENNA, Sept. 10. -- Tomorrow promises to be a notable day for Austria. If Chancellor Dollfuss makes the statements generally expected from him although never officially promised, the little central European republic, that is all the peace treaties left of the great Hapsburg Empire, will probably set out upon a new path.

Preliminary plans are now being made for the annual Victory Ball which will take place on Armistice Eve, Nov. 10, in the ballroom suite of the Waldorf-Astoria. As usual, the event will be given under the auspices of the American Legion Welfare Committee of New York County in aid of that organization's welfare and employment relief work among needy veterans and their families.

MONZA, Italy, Sept. 10. -- Three noted racing pilots, Giuseppe Campari and Mario Borzachini, Italians, and Czaichowski, a Pole, were killed today during the annual running of the Grand Prix de Monza, automobile classic, in which the American, Whitney Straight, finished fourth.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 10. -- An appeal for recognition and protection of the position of small independent retail gasoline dealers with low operating costs who pass savings along to the consumer was made in a brief submitted to President Roosevelt today by Richard F.
