Cleveland of Baltimore, son of President Cleveland.

Recommendations for payroll and administrative economies of at least $19,000,000, to be reflected in the 1934 budget, will be contained in a report to be completed within three days by the special committee on municipal economy headed by Peter Grimm, chairman of the Citizens Budget Commission.

To the Editor of The New York Times: After reading the letter in THE TIMES captioned "Navy Airship Policy" and signed "Junior Officer's Wife," I would like to make a statement regarding Mr. Hunsaker's speech at Chicago.
For the first time in thirty years, the United States tennis championship has been won by a player from the British Isles.
WARRENSBURG, N.Y., Sept. 10. -- Three boys drowned in the Schrooh River near their homes here last night after jumping from a burning rowboat.
CHICAGO, Sept. 10 (AP). -- George Johnson and Larry Goetz tonight were named as umpires for the American Association pennant playoff between Columbus and Minneapolis by President Thomas J. Hickey.

ISTANBUL, Sept. 10. -- The Turkish press extended a cordial welcome today to Premier Tsaldaris, Foreign Minister Maximos and Minister of Economy Pesmazoglu of Greece, who arrived aboard the cruiser Helle and proceeded to Angora.

Dr. Ramon Grau San Martin, Cuba's new President, is a bachelor within a few days of 49 years old, has for many years been dean of the Medical School of Havana University and professor of anatomy. A determined oppositionist, he was arrested several times and finally left Cuba for the United States early in 1932.

The children's fad of flying kites from tenement roofs claimed three victims yesterday, two of them in East Harlem, where, within two blocks of each other, a boy was killed in a five-story plunge and a girl was injured seriously in a fall. Another boy was hurt badly in Brooklyn.

The J. Weinstein Rubin Building Corp. has received a contract to build a new State hospital group for tubercular patients in Mount Morris, N.Y., Brown's Letters. Inc., reports. The general contract totals $657,740. William E. Haugaard is the architect.

"I knew one," said BACON, "that "when he wrote a Letter, he would put "that which was most Materiall in the "Post-script, as if it had been a By"matter." Mr. UNTERMYER and Mr. GRIMM, pledging themselves to economy second, if not first, feel called upon to explain in separate declarations attached to their joint statement this morning the nature and scope of their respective commitments.

BERLIN, Sept. 10 (London Times Dispatch). -- It is only now possible to tell the story of the remarkable events of Aug. 11 in the Grenadierstrasse, a mean street in the small Jewish quarter of Berlin, whose inhabitants were compelled by uniformed Nazis, with the cooperation of the police, to participate in filmed crowd scenes depicting Jews in a manner calculated to incense credulous minds against them.
RYE, N.Y., Sept. 10. -- With bones in their teeth, twenty-five yachts of the Long Island Sound racing fleet competed today in the American Yacht Club's last special regatta of the season.

CHICAGO, Sept. 10. -- Prices of hogs in the regular market here at the close of last week were steady to 5 cents a hundred pounds higher than the week before. The top was $4.70, and the average $3.90, or 15 cents more than in the previous week.

CHICAGO, Sept. 10. -- Failure of the grain markets to advance on what is now almost unanimously regarded as an extremely bullish situation has resulted in a pessimistic view of the immediate future by many operators. This is in sharp contrast with the belief that ultimately the shortage in wheat and coarse grains will bring about higher prices.

More than 250 Jewish and non-Jewish business leaders, civic workers and professional men met yesterday in the Hotel Astor and voted to raise $500,000 with which to organize and promote on a nationwide scale a boycott against German products.
TURIN, Italy, Sept. 10. -- Germany captured the team title in the track and field division of the International University Games today.

The tennis championship of the United States was captured by a player from the British Isles for the first time in thirty years yesterday. Frederick J. Perry, Davis Cup hero of England, won the title by defeating Jack Crawford of Australia before a crowd of 11,000 at Forest Hills.

With the largest field competing in the history of the event, the annual individual masters' contract bridge championship of the American Bridge League will be held at the Ritz Carlton Hotel here on Friday, Saturday and Sunday, it was announced yesterday by Sir Derrick Wernher, president of the league.

NEW ORLEANS, La., Sept. 10. -- Three men were killed and several others were wounded in a daring break in which twelve convicts shot their way to freedom at 3:45 P.M. today from a sugar camp at the Angola State prison farm.

Statistics show Manhattan realty activity still in a downward trend, according to The Real Estate Record and Builders' Guide, published by the F.W. Dodge Corporation. Measured by mortgage loans and extensions, conveyances and foreclosures, the decline during more than three years continues, the publication finds.

BERLIN, Sept. 10. -- Business sentiment this week was emphatically gloomy and was reflected in the stock market, which underwent early in the week and again on Friday further sharp declines, bringing the level of prices below that of September, 1932, during the so-called von Papen boom.

Marked Increases, not only in employment and payrolls in New York City, but in the volume of business generally since the National Recovery program began functioning, were indicated in reports made public here yesterday.

PITTSFIELD, Mass., Sept. 10. -- Mr. and Mrs. Denison D. Dana of Englewood, N.J., and Norfolk, Conn., entertained forty guests with a clambake at the Wyantenuck Country Club, Great Barrington, last night.

To the Editor of The New York Times: We appeal directly to newspapers to publish our views on what we believe is an unfair, unethical and an unstatesmanlike use of the depressed economic condition to put over the repeal of prohibition. Postmaster General Farley, acting simultaneously as chairman of the Democratic National Committee and also representing the administration, has stated that repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment is an important part of the National Recovery Act.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 10. -- Rapidly setting the stage for its drive to crush the "army of the underworld," the Department of Justice has gathered an amazing collection of records of racketeers, kidnappers, extortionists and other criminals.

Eight persons were injured, three seriously, in a head-on collision between two automobiles on the Cross Bay Boulevard near Broad Channel shortly after 2 o'clock yesterday morning. Those hurt were passengers in a car driven by William J. Daly, 28 years old, ot 11 West 103d Street, which was in collision with a machine driven by Wilbur H. Stark, 21, of 425 Riverside Drive.
ST. LOUIS, Sept. 10 (AP). -- The Cardinals knocked Fred Frankhouse out of the box in both games of a double-header and hammered other Brave pitchers hard for two victories, 7 to 0 and 10 to 5, today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 10. -- In the face of the most vehement protest yet filed by a controlling group of a major industry against the administration's Industrial Recovery program, General Johnson tonight re-emphasized his confidence that he would get an "agreed" code for bituminous coal producers.

Fifty-seven members of the Metropolitan Opera Orchestra have joined with Cesare Sodero, conductor, to give opera at popular prices at Mecca Auditorium under the name of the Fides Opera Company, it was announced yesterday. The new organization has no connection with the Metropolitan, but since the Thirty-ninth Street house's season does not begin until Dec. 26, the players have been able to take part in the venture which aims to give them employment until Christmas.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 10. -- The Federal Government collected $1,619,839,224 in internal revenue during the 1933 fiscal year, at a cost of $1.85 for each $100, as compared with $1,557,729,042 at $2.17 in the preceding year, Commissioner of Internal Revenue Guy T. Helvering announced today.

Thus far, September markets have run true to form; that is to say, continued inactivity has resulted in a slow downward drift of prices for stocks and wheat and cotton. On the whole, this conforms to the period's general rule; for staple prices, even before 1930, always moved hesitantly at this time of year, and stocks went somewhat lower in September in the majority of the ten years preceding the 1929 panic.

President ROOSEVELT'S first approach to South American diplomats when the Cuban trouble became acute led to more than he perhaps foresaw. His friendly offer to them was to keep them fully advised of all official information that reached him. He also took occasion to assure them of his ardent hope that intervention at Havana would not be necessary.

Destruction's car is out today And Death sits at its wheel, And on its front in bold display The shameless motto of "Repeal." So a Maine Dry singer, living up to his name, which is CANARY. Some letters in the Portland papers repeat the old rhetorical felicities.

In a long and elaborate service, similar to those held in Russia during the days of the Czars, Russian Orthodox clergy consecrated a new Bishop yesterday morning at the Russian Orthodox Church, East Houston Street near Chrystie Street. The new prelate, formerly an Archimandrite, or Abbot, is the Right Rev. Bishop Benjamin, who will take office soon at Pittsburgh.

ROSTOV-ON-DON, U.S.S.R., Sept. 10. -- If the North Caucasus is the touchstone -- and by all accounts it has been not only that but the Verdun-Gettysburg of the Bolshevist struggle with the peasants -- then the Bolsheviki have won. That much can be said from quite cursory observation.

Dr. Marion Brown, research graduate at Teachers College, Columbia University, found in a survey of leadership among high school classes that pupil leaders represent a "highly selected group." High school students who lead in extra-curricular activities, Dr. Brown asserted, have a higher degree of intelligence and are superior in other respects to students who do not participate in school affairs.

CHICAGO, Sept. 10. -- Plato's ideal of an intellectual aristocracy, in which the wisest will rule, is now approaching realization through recent advances in the science of nutrition, Professor H.C. Sherman of Columbia University stated here tonight on the eve of the opening of the Century of Progress meeting of the American Chemical Society.
The appointment of Samuel Seabury, arch foe of Tammany, as chairman of the fusion campaign committee was announced yesterday by William M. Chadbourne, campaign manager.
LONDON, Sept. 11 (Canadian Press) -- Football games played in the British Isles today resulted as follows:

Five men, two with revolvers, stepped out of a dark sedan at Ninth Avenue and Twenty-fourth Street at 5 o'clock yesterday afternoon and hijacked a load of raw furs valued at $45,000 from Vincent Szcerbeckie, truck driver, according to his report to detectives of the West Forty-seventh Street precinct.
WASHINGTON. Sept. 11 -- The Bureau of Navigation issued the following orders today, dated Sept. 8:

OTTAWA, Sept. 11 (Canadian Press) -- A crop report issued today by the Dominion Bureau of Statistics told how devastating had been the effect of the drought and armies of grasshoppers on Canada's wheat crop.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 -- To help American Government employes take care of themselves in old age, the United States Treasury Department Beneficial Association has worked out with the Sun Life Assurance Company of Canada a group annuity division.

Henry Galbraith Ward, former presiding judge of the United States Circuit Court of Appeals for the Southern District of New York, left $10,000 to St. James Protestant Episcopal Church of 865 Madison Avenue and a like amount to the Association of the Bar of the City of New York.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Sept. 11 -- Westchester's financial dilemma was temporarily straightened out today by the withdrawal of T. Darrington Semple from the office of county treasurer and the return to her duties of Miss Josephine Sutton, first deputy, who acted as treasurer after the death of Charles M. Miller, former treasurer, until the appointment of Mr. Semple by Governor Lehman early last week.
A 20 per cent dividend to creditors of the United Cigar Stores Company, which was adjudged bankrupt on Aug. 29, 1932, was ordered yesterday by Referee Irwin Kurtz at a hearing at 15 Park Row.
Adoption of the Untermyer emergency tax program by the Municipal Assembly today seemed assured last night.

BERLIN, Sept. 11 (Jewish Telegraphic Agency) -- Theodor E. Fritsch, one of the founders of modern anti-Semitism, is dead at the age of 80. Mr. Fritsch owned the Hammer publishing concern of Leipzig, which published Henry Ford's anti-Semitic books and the Protocols of the Elders of Zion.
The Accent Varies. On Aug. 13 The Associated Press said:

WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 -- A race against time to forestall a possibly nation-wide soft coal strike will begin tomorrow, when the National Recovery Administration opens a public hearing on its proposed code for the bituminous coal industry.

Expressing regret at his inability to attend in person, President Franklin D. Roosevelt yesterday designated Postmaster General James A. Farley to represent him at the opening performance of the Jewish pageant, "The Romance of a People," at the Polo Grounds on Thursday evening.

TORONTO, Sept. 11 -- Great Britain is confronted with a serious problem by an influx of American capital for safekeeping, Viscount Cecil of Chelwood and Sir John Power, treasurer of the Royal Institute of International Affairs, agreed today at the opening of the British Commonwealth Relations Conference at the University of Toronto.
CINCINNATI, Sept. 11 -- Hughie Critz hooked a drive on the Redland course today, but it produced admirable results.

NEWARK, N.J., Sept. 11 -- Rochester and Newark, which led the northern and southern sections, respectively, during the International League season which closed yesterday, will begin their first-place play-off series at Ruppert Stadium tomorrow.
A group of school children in the North Bronx went on strike yesterday against crowded classrooms and traveling long distances to schools.

Five young men, armed with sawed-off shotguns and revolvers, held up the clerk and two other employes of the Half Moon Hotel, Coney Island, at about 5 o'clock yesterday morning. After binding and gagging the three employes they escaped with about $1,000 in cash from the hotel safe.

Enrolment of 957,000 consumers, pledged to buy from employers under the Blue Eagle, has heen achieved in the first week of the NRA consumer canvass in New York City, it was announced last night by Grover A. Whalen, NRA chairman.

Dividing interest this week with the final practice games among the teams entered in the open polo championship, which starts Saturday at Meadow Brook, is the Thorn Memorial Cup tournament at Meadow Brook, which will get under way today with two games.

More than a million children under college age took their seats in the classrooms of more than 700 school buildings yesterday for the beginning of another school year. The enrolment, by official estimate, would be well over 1,100,000. The attendance, while falling short of this maximum, would not be much below it on opening day.

NRA and bear floats, twenty bands of music, the usual quota of clowns and gaily clad buffoons, 1,000 members of the Loyal Order of Moose and scores of bathing beauties were cheered last night on Surf Avenue, Coney Island, at the start of the resort's thirty-first annual Mardi Gras.
EDWARDSVILLE, Ill., Sept. 11 (AP) -- The trial of six persons charged with kidnapping August Luer, Alton banker, began today.

Merlin have begun to run off Montauk, according to reports received yesterday. Tuna also have shown up in such abundance that the veterans are assured now that fishing for these big fellows for the next four or five weeks will be worth while.

Stop intervals of thirty seconds to permit traffic turns and pedestrians to cross the streets during the restricted traffic period in the theatre zone at night were suggested yesterday at the first Fall meeting of the board of directors of the Broadway Association in the Hotel Astor.

BALTIMORE, Sept. 11 (AP) -- The pitcher whose record is the poorest of any Baltimore hurler was nominated today by Frank McGowan, manager, to start tomorrow night in the opening game of the play-off series with Buffalo. The pitcher is Guy Cantrell, credited with two victories against eight defeats.

COLON, C.Z., Sept. 11 -- Secretary of the Navy Claude A. Swanson arrived here today from Havana on the cruiser Indianapolis and inspected the naval establishment at the Atlantic end of the Panama Canal, including the fleet air and submarine bases.

Starting his Manhattan campaign for the Democratic nomination for Mayor last night, Assemblyman Jerome G. Ambro declared that former Governor Smith's statement that a nation could stand criticism but not ridicule, when speaking of the Hitler regime in Germany, was one for New York voters to remember at the primary election on Sept. 19.

The twenty-story apartment building at 320 Central Park West, south corner of Ninety-second Street, known as the Ardsley, was sold in foreclosure yesterday on a single bid of $2,575,000 to the Manufacturers Trust Company, plaintiff in an action against the Aidsley Realty Corporation and others inv Iving a lien of $2,866,050.

A committee of Western railroad presidents has prepared a report proposing a reduction in passenger fares, which will be studied on Thursday by the presidents traffic conference for central territory. This territory runs from the Buffalo-Pittsburgh line to Chicago and St. Louis and embraces the Eastern trunk lines.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Sept. 11 -- Labor leaders in State convention here today were told that while the NRA is "the greatest opportunity in history for organized workers," at the same it holds a threat of danger to trade unionism.

BROCKTON, Mass., Sept. 11 -- Following a mediocre performance for fourth place among thirteen novice hunters, Stanley A. Briggs's Virginia more than atoned for her earlier defeat by capturing the blue ribbon for lightweight hunters in the feature class of the opening session of the Brockton horse show today.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 (AP) -- Secretary Cordell Hull issued the following formal statement late tonight:

Since the middle of August the nation's movie theatres have been doing more business than at any period since the halcyon days of 1928-29. Statistics cited yesterday by Martin Quigley, publisher of the Motion Picture Herald and other trade papers, indicate that the film industry definitely is on the upswing.

BAGHDAD, Sept. 11 -- The continuance of Iraq's alliance with Great Britain was pledged today by Premier Rashid Ali Beg at the first meeting of the newly constituted Cabinet since the death of King Feisal.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 -- Amendments under the Migratory Bird Treaty Act, again limiting to two months the open season for hunting waterfowl, coot and jacksnipe through the United States this Fall and Winter were approved today by President Roosevelt.

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., Sept. 11 -- Arthur C. Newby, transportation financier and philanthropist, died at his home here tonight after a long illness. He was born on a farm near Monrovia, Ind., in 1866, and came to Indianapolis as a youth. Employed in various capacities by the Nordyke Marmon Company, he in 1890 organized the Zigzag Cycling Club and by 1899 was manufacturing 60 per cent of the bicycle chains used in this country.

Hans V. Kaltenborn, journalist and lecturer, returned yesterday on the Swedish American liner Kungsholm from a four months' tour of Europe, accompanied by his wife, daughter and his son Rolf, who was slapped by a civilian Nazi for failing to salute at a parade in Berlin on Sept. 1.
Leasing of several shops and other quarters for commercial uses, particularly in buildings in the west side garment district, was reported by brokers yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 (AP) -- Monte Weaver defeated the Indians, 5 -- 1, today, and led the Senators a step nearer the world's series.

Rich in the fruits of the inquiring spirit as is the census of 1930, it throws no light on the number of Young Republican clubs or of their members. So many persons of all ages voted the Democratic ticket last year that young Republicans are to be more treasured, on account of their comparative rarity, than young Democrats.

MONTREAL, Sept. 11 ( Canadian Press) -- Paintings valued at $30,000 stolen this Spring from the Montreal Art Gallery have been recovered, Louis Jargaille, head of the Quebec Provincial Police Detective Bureau, announced today. Paul Thouin, 28, who had confessed stealing the pictures and was facing a murder charge following the shootings of a railroad detective, was found dying in a police cell a few hours before announcement of the recovery.

Prices in the cotton market yesterday rallied from last week's declines. Except for hedging at the start and toward the close, offerings were comparatively light, probably reflecting an improved technical position. Buying was promoted by renewed talk of inflationary possibilities, a more favorable long-range view of the statistical situation and rumors of continued control of cotton production for next season.
CHICAGO, Sept. 11 (AP) -- State bank supervisers were admonished today against needlessly sacrificing the interests of depositors in marking down the values of bank assets.

BERLIN, Sept. 11 -- Sharp declines on the German Stock Exchanges continued unchecked today. Losses of 2 to 4 per cent were usual among leaders on the Berlin Boerse and some specialties registered losses up to 8 per cent.
The public and parochial school systems in the city, offering free education to more than 1,200,000 children, opened yesterday for the Fall term.

MADRID, Sept. 11 -- Although Al ejandro Lerroux, 69-year-old Republican, who is struggling to form a government, announced for the third time during this crisis of the republic that he had formed one, it is learned authentically tonight that be is still hesitating about accepting the stringent conditions laid upon him for collaboration by the moderate and revolutionary parties.

CHICAGO, Sept. 11 -- New "scales" for weighing the electron, proton and deuton, fundamental units of matter, were described here today before the opening sessions of the Century of Progress meeting of the American Chemical Society.
ALBANY, Sept. 11 -- Factory employment showed a rise of 6.2 per cent and payrolls of 6.7 per cent in the period from July 15 to Aug. 15, Elmer F. Andrews, Industrial Commissioner, reported today.

SUDBURY, Ont., Sept. 11 -- Ward T. Van Orman and Frank A. Trotter, James Gordon Bennett Cup balloonists missing for more than a week, were found about forty miles north of here today, ill and their clothing torn, after they had cut down a telephone pole in the Canadian wilds to make sure that searchers would reach them.

Effective today, the Standard Oil Company of New York, Inc., a subsidiary of the Socony-Vacuum Corporation, will advance service station, tank-wagon and tank-car prices of gasoline half a cent a gallon throughout its territory. This advance, which brings the cash price of gasoline at service stations in the metropolitan area to 18 cents a gallon, follows an increase of 1 cent a gallon on Sept. 2.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Sept. 11 (AP) -- Repealists and prohibitionists have been waging oratorical contests in Minnesota the last few days on the merits and demerits of prohibition. Tomorrow the electors will determine who won. The special election; in accordance with machinery set up by the last Legislature when it legalized 3.2 per cent beer, will submit only one question to the electors: Shall Minnesota ratify repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment?

PARIS, Sept. 11 -- Rioting reminiscent of the Sacco-Vanzetti disturbances here in 1927 occurred tonight in the streets around the Salle Wagram, where a mass meeting was held to protest against the forthcoming trial of four German Communists accused of burning the Reichstag Building.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 -- Slightly higher yields of Spring wheat, corn, oats, barley, buckwheat, commercial fruit and some truck crops than were predicted a month ago were forecast by the Department of Agriculture today in its Sept. 1 crop report.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 -- In a drive to speed up the program of the Public Works Administration, four of its staff will start tomorrow afternoon from the Anacostia naval air station on a 6,000-mile airplane flight to discuss various problems With regional and local authorities throughout the country.

Julia Peterkin and Doris Ulmann have just completed a "collaboration in two mediums" on Negro life in the South, Mrs. Peterkin furnishing the text and Doris Ulmans about seventy full-page photographs. The book will be called "This Side of Jordan" and will be published Nov. 29 by Robert O. Ballou.

Oswald Thomas, 33 years old, Negro owner of a hand laundry at 135 Wyckoff Street, Brooklyn, captured after a achase by radio cars last night, was booked at the Grand Avenue station on a statutory charge.

About the time that 1,200,000 pairs of lagging shoes were scuffing their way into city schoolrooms yesterday. Mrs. Julia Blackman heard shrill cries coming from the elderberry patch back of her home in Graniteville, S.I.
A duel of husky right-handers ended in victory for Fred Marberry of the Detroit Tigers over Charley Ruffing of the Yankees at the Stadium yesterday. The score was 5 to 1.
NEW YORK. Sir Arthur Worley. Bart, and Lady Worley of London, and their daughter. Miss Stella Worley, are at the Waldorf-Astoria.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 -- Confronted with "real warfare which an armed underworld is waging upon organized society," the government is ready to emerge with a definite and constructive program to meet the situation, Attorney General Cummings declared tonight in a radio talk on "Predatory Crime" arranged by the United States Flag Association over the National Broadcasting System.
ST. LOUIS, Sept. 11 (AP) -- Ed Brandt of the Braves blanked the Cardinals with six scattered hits today and Boston, took the last encounter of the season with St. Louis, 3 to 0.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 -- Extension of credit to the small business man under the NRA program and economic problems facing the administration were discussed in a three-hour conference today at the White House.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 11 (AP) -- Filmland's immense vaults hold huge stores of motion pictures which cost scores of millions to make but which now are of scarcely any money value. Many of these films were "box office smashes" which launched on the screen faces now familiar to all theatregoers.

To the Editor of The New York Times : In the complex era which our present troubled society presents, it is interesting to note what our scientists and economists have to say. THE TIMES reprints the following statement of Sir Josiah Stamp, noted British economist :

Samuel S. Koenig, chairman of the New York County Republican Committee, made specific denial yesterday that he had participated in any deal that resulted in the nomination of Supreme Court Justices Aron Steuer, Democrat, and Samuel H. Hofstadter, Republican, by both Tammany and the Republican party.

Hervey Allen explained yesterday that the reason he made "Anthony Adverse" so long was that he is a "copious fellow, with the ambition to write one story in a book spacious enough really to fit it." He is not likely, he said, to do another novel quite so lengthy.

Monday, Sept. 11, 1933. Business in money in the new week was featured by another shading in rates for maturity money on top of the fractional decline last week. Short dates were offered at 1/2, and over-the-year at 3/4@1 per cent. These rates are the lowest since February.

Miss Enid Wilson, three times winner of the British women's golf championship, whose defeat by Miss Virginia Van Wie at Exmoor on Sept. 1 marked her third unsuccessful attempt to capture the United States titles, will sail today for England aboard the liner Georgic of the White Star Line.

HAVANA, Sept. 11 -- While President Grau San Martin's government strove to complete its cabinet today the interest of the nation centred on the National Hotel where 300 officers, augmented by 200 supporters, have armed themselves and continue to defy the revolutionary government.

CHICAGO, Sept. 11 -- A new compass for exploring the mysterious processes of thought and for penetrating further than has hitherto been possible into the forbidden realm of dreams was described here today by Professor Louis William Max of New York University before the annual meeting of the American Psychological Association.

To the Editor of The New York Times. Five-years before the entire world was astounded with the announcement of a conflict between European nations, one of the leading New York dailies carried an article written by me in which I asked why it was not within the scope of diplomacy to settle all national disputes by compulsory arbitration.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 -- Objections voiced in Toronto today against a "flood of unwanted money pouring into the banks of the United Kingdom" were regarded by officials here as referring to a departure of capital from the United States since gold payments were suspended and to be expressive of fears lest a sudden withdrawal of these American funds might precipitate a crash.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 11 (AP) -- Johnny Marcum, rookie righthander from Louisville, who broke into the big leagues with a shutout triumph last week, duplicated the feat today in the Athletics' doubleheader victory over the White Sox.
GREENWICH, Conn., Sept. 11 -- Miss Helen Hicks of the Lido Club, Long Beach, L.I., won the qualifying medal in the annual women's invitation golf tournament today at the Greenwich Country Club.

BALTIMORE, Sept. 11 (AP) -- The campaign for repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment was brought to a close in Maryland today with a speech by Postmaster General Farley, who asked for an "overwhelming" vote.

To the Editor of The New York Times: A great many people doubt the wisdom of governmental action that tends to raise prices by controlling the supply of a commodity, but nearly all will agree that action, once decided on, should be thorough.

GENEVA, Sept. 11 -- It is unofficially intimated here that Poland is contemplating proposing in the coming League of Nations Assembly a general convention with a view of establishing everywhere the rights guaranteed to racial minorities now only by special treaties in the post-war States.

LAKE SEBAGO, N.Y., Sept. 11. -- New York University's pre-season football campaign was launched at its new training camp today. Forty-five candidates for the Violet eleven engaged in two spirited sessions under the direction of Howard G. Cann, who commenced his second season as head football coach.

To the Editor of The New York Times. George W. Graham in a letter to THE TIMES complains that banks throughout the country are refusing to exchange mortgages they hold for the bonds of the Home Owners Loan Association and are foreclosing in preference. The reasoning prompting this course is very simple and understandable.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 -- Profiteering on textiles was charged against sections of that industry today by George N. Peek, Agricultural Adjustment Administrator, in a new move to prevent the farm recovery program from being jeopardized by "unreasonable" prices to consumers.

Tony Canzoneri will try to bring the world's lightweight championship back to New York tonight, when he clashes with Barney Ross, young Chicago titleholder, in a fifteen-round bout at the Polo Grounds.

LONDON, Sept. 11 -- At least u400,000,000 of foreign balances, according to rough estimates, are in London at present, unwanted by British authorities and constituting a perpetual threat to stability of exchanges.

Although the Bronx Gas and Electric Company saved 2.8 cents on each 1,000 cubic feet in the cost of gas in 1932, consumers' bills were not reduced, according to testimony given yesterday at the hearing on permanent rates before the Public Service Commission.

COACH MERCER BEASLEY wrote a book entitled "How to Play Tennis." It is now suspected that his star pupils never read it. Anyway, Fred Perry of jolly old England did better than to write a book. He gave a demonstration. It's easier to follow that way.

CHICAGO, Sept. 11 -- Farmers in the Corn Belt are so eager to sell their small pigs to the government that they are forwarding them regardless of orders that they must be shipped only through instructions of government agents to obtain the price of $6 to $9.50 the government is paying.

CINCINNATI, Sept. 11 -- Led by solemn Sandy Somerville, the depending champion, and an 18-year-old Texas boy. Jack Munger of Dallas, the golfers participating in the first eighteen-hole qualifying round of the national amateur championship at the Kenwood Country Club today went on one of the greatest Scoring sprees in the event's thirtyseven-year history.

Last efforts to avert the strike of 25,000 underwear workers, most of them women and girls, members of the White Goods Workers Union, failed last night when a conference of representatives of the union and employers at the headquarters of the local NRA organization ended hi a deadlock.

ALAMEDA, Calif., Sept. 11 -- The "probability" that Sir Francis Bacon, statesman, scientist and essayist, was in reality King Edward VI is asserted by J. Edward Morgan, Elizabethan student. Mr. Morgan has made public conclusions based upon more than seven years of research and on thousands of photostatic copies of Shakespearean folios, documents, letters and writings gathered from all over the world.

Six oompah men wandered through Forty-seventh Street with the westering sun last night and stopped at Ninth Avenue, on the southwest corner. The three other corners have beer gardens -- O'Hara's, Sheehan's and Kiernan's.

Final instructions for the President's NRA Day Parade up Fifth Avenue from Washington Square to Seventy-second Street at 1:30 o'clock tomorrow were made public yesterday by Major Gen. Dennis E. Nolan, commander of the Second Corps Area, and Grand Marshal of the parade.

Resenting what he described as an attack on his integrity, County Judge Alonzo G. McLaughlin in Brooklyn told the Kings County August grand jury yesterday that he soon would make a full explanation of his reasons for suspending sentence on Jacob Mellon and two other alleged laundry racketeers on Sept. 1.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 -- William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, declared today that there must be a "reviving of purpose" toward the two main objectives of the National Recovery program if unemployment was to be materially relieved by the coming of Winter.

Even a zoo has to keep up with the times. The elephants and the zebras and the tigers linger on, much as in Queen VICTORIA'S time. But what child of that era could have dreamed that there would come a day when lie could feed bread to a polar bear or peanuts to an elephant, almost as he might to a dog, with no iron bars between?
VIENNA, Sept 11 -- Chancellor Dollfuss made his eagerly awaited announcement regarding Austria's future today, but it was neither so definite nor so comprehensive as had been expected.

From the very beginning of the overturn in Cuba there were rumors to the effect that certain elements, or factions, of the population really desired American intervention and were trying to bring it about. Yesterday that sort of gossip centred about the army officers who are holding aloof from the new Provisional Government, and, in fact, have been demanding that it abdicate.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 11 -- The Cambridge University Vandals of England defeated the All-Philadelphia Cricketers today, 222 for eight wickets to 103 runs. This was their fifteenth victory against one defeat since the Vandals landed in Montreal on Aug. 5 for their tour of Canada and the United States.
Following are the remarks, in part or in full, of those who debated the Untermyer tax program, at the hearings before the Board of Estimate and the Board of Aldermen yesterday at City Hall:

Closing prices in local commodities markets yesterday were irregular as trading continued within moderate limitations. Slight rallies marked most sections in the afternoon. Cash prices were nearly all higher.
CHICAGO, Sept. 11 (AP) -- Gift of Roses, cleverly rated by W.D. Wright, won the Blue Eagle Purse in a spectacular stretch finish with Princess Camelia at Lincoln Fields today.

The four Bermuda interclub yachts which will be sailed in the international competition for the Royal Bermuda Trophy arrived in New York yesterday on the Queen of Bermuda of the Furness Bermuda line. Three of the skippers and seven of the crews also debarked.

TOKYO, Sept. 11 -- The procurator's demand at the court-martial today for the death penalty for three young naval officers involved in the assassination on May 15, 1932, of Premier Inukai, life terms for three more and long imprisonment for the remainder has surprised the public by its severity.

ROSTOV-ON-DON, U.S.S.R., Sept. 11 -- Whatever the situation was here last Winter or Spring, there is no doubt Rostov-on-Don is a busy, flourishing city today, with an immense amount of building under way and an actual shortage of labor, both skilled and unskilled.

More than 500 official representatives of investment, savings and commercial banks and trust companies throughout the country, will open a three-day convention here today at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel to discuss their relations with the public.

The first export of newly mined American gold since the United States Government's new regulations for the metal were put into effect last week is expected to be shipped to London on the Berengaria, sailing tomorrow. The shipment will represent the excess of new gold not taken for domestic consumption by the arts and crafts.
Results of operations were announced yesterday by various industrial and other corporations, with figures showing comparisons with a year before.
PATERSON, N.J., Sept. 11 -- The strike that has paralyzed the silk-weaving industry spread to the dyeing mills today, with the accompaniment of violence.
The granite walls of the $6,000,000 State Office Building, 80 Centre Street, erected three years ago, are beginning to crack.

Increased activity in the share market yesterday accompanied the sharp advance in prices. On the Stock Exchange the business was about 50 per cent more active than on Friday, the last five-hour day of the previous week. There was a corresponding expansion of trading interest in the other domestic markets.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 -- The long-awaited announcement by the Home Owners Loan Corporation concerning its bond program and presenting arguments as to the soundness of its funds as investment securities was distributed today to banks, insurance companies and other financial institutions expected to deal in them.

EPSOM, England, Sept. 11 (AP) Sir Leo Chiozza Money, fellow of the Royal Statistical Society, fellow of the Royal Geographical Society, eminent economist and former Member of Parliament, was fined u2 10s today for annoying a young woman by kissing her. At current exchange u2 10s is about $11.25.

WASHINGTON, Sept 11 -- Only $268,100 of $832,800 of first farm mortgages in twenty-one closed banks in New York State are eligible for refinancing through the Farm Credit Administration, Henry Morgenthau Jr., governor of the Farm Credit Administration, said today in an announcement of the application of its farm mortgage refinancing program to closed banks throughout New York.

Two important changes were announced yesterday in the executive heads of subsidiaries of the Shell Union Oil Corporation. A.F. Carter has resigned as president and a director of the Shell Eastern Petroleum Products, Inc., effective as of Sept. 1.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 -- The Federal Reserve Board's condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety leading cities on Sept. 6 show decreases for the week of $47,000,000 in net demand deposits, $13,000,000 in time deposits and $49,000,000 in holdings of United States Government securities.

NEWARK, N.J., Sept. 11 -- Mayor Meyer C. Ellenstein wrote today to Richard Whitney, president of the New York Stock Exchange, inviting the Exchange to move to Newark. In making the letter public the Mayor said he might offer "certain advantages" to the Exchange. The location he suggests is the Lefcourt Plaza, behind the Newark Lefcourt Building. The Mayor's letter follows:

PORTLAND, Me., Sept. 11 -- Maine, the first "bone dry" State, joined the parade for repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment today, with a majority of over 2-to-1 wet on a count of four-fifths of the precincts. It is the twenty-sixth State in line to end prohibition, and tomorrow Maryland, Minnesota and Colorado vote on the question.

Transactions on the Stock Exchange yesterday amounted to 1,917,490 shares, compared with 1,270,740 on Friday. The turnover in the bond market was $8,559,000, against $8,623,000. These comparisons do not, however, suggest the revival in interest that occurred yesterday.

One reads with, great relief that the reported illness of the archaeologist JAMES H. BREASTED is not serious and that he is going forward with his studies of remains of ancient peoples nearer home than those with whom he has made the world acquainted in Western Asia and Northern Africa.
COMMERCIAL PAPAR. Per Cent. Yerterday. Friday. For the best names . . . . . . . . 1 1/2 1 1/2 The quotations are for three-four months' paper.

Arthur M. Tode, national president of the Propeller Club of the United States, on his return yesterday from a visit to the Panama Canal and the West Indies, said that vast opportunities for trade still existed in the islands of the Spanish Main.
WASHINGTON, D.C., Sept. 11 -- Movements of vessels follow; all dates are Sept. 9 unless otherwise specified:
LEICESTER, England, Sept. 11 -- It was "atom-smashing day" at the meeting of the British Association for the Advancement of Science today.

The Hopeful favorite High Quest was made the choice in the Futurity Trial, best race at Belmont Park yesterday, and won it in a manner to gain him new admirers. At the end of the six furlongs the son of Sir Gallahad III was the winner at 11 to 10.

CHICAGO, Sept. 11 -- Only a breath of inflation talk from Washington was needed to start grain markets on the upgrade today, and the rise was not checked until near the close, when profit-taking for the government report due later caused a fair recession from the extreme top.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 -- Grants of $9,000,000 to Illinois and $1,400,000 to Maryland were made today by Harry L. Hopkins, Emergency Relief Administrator, from the administration's discretionary fund.

ALBANY, Sept. 11 -- Governor Lehman met with his Cabinet today for the purpose of discussing the 1934-1935 budget, work on which is to be started earlier this year than usual. The heads of departments were asked to present their estimates of needed appropriations by the end of this week.

Playing the first nine holes of the Pomonok Country Club course at Flushing, L.I., in 31 strokes, Alex Ednie, Shelter Rock professional, gave his team a great start in the Long Island Golf Association's amateur-pro tourney yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 -- The price-fixing clause in the oil code will be retained, but actual price-fixing will be resorted to only when and if it appears necessary, according to Secretary Ickes.

LONDON, Sept. 11 -- Statesmen and diplomats joined today in a national tribute to Viscount Grey at an impressive memorial service in Westminster Abbey. In the congregation, which filled the choir and transepts, were representatives of all phases of the national life and of the dominions and foreign countries, including the Ambassadors from the United States, Italy, Japan, Argentina and Chile.

The finishing touches to the list of regulations governing the "new deal" in the sale and distribution of theatre tickets were made yesterday by Brock Pemberton, chairman of the subcommittee for the National Legitimate Theatre Committee, and William McBride and Harry Kaufman, representing the National Theatre Ticket Distributers.

DETROIT, Sept. 11 -- Henry Ford is back in his Dearborn home. Saturday night he quietly and successfully slipped away from his Huron Mountain camp evading a small army of newspaper correspondents by riding unrecognized through the lines.

After moving steadily lower virtually all last week, the listed bond market rallied yesterday, although trading continued dull. Domestic railroad, utility and industrial bond groups averaged higher. Foreign loans were irregularly lower. United States Government bonds were exceptionally strong, nine of the dozen active issues climbing 3-32 to 12-32 point, three in the list holding unchanged, and two selling off 1-32 point.

Full returns of the internal revenue collected by the Federal Government during the fiscal year ending with last June confirm the inferences already drawn from the successive monthly reports. In spite of the higher rates, the yield of income taxes showed a reduction of $300,000,000, even from 1932.

NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 11 -- H. M.S. Norfolk, flagship of the British North America and West Indies Squadron, with Vice Admiral Reginald A.R. Plunkett-Ernle-Erle-Drax aboard, arrived here this morning for a nine days' stay. An extensive program of entertainment has been arranged for the Admiral, his officers and men, by the city, the colonists and the officers of the army and navy here.

ENGLISH agriculture is always going to the devil. In the sixteenth century, when the Tudor barons enclosed the common lands to make fine sheep-runs for themselves, the better thereby to profit from the Flemish wool trade, it supposedly meant an end to yeoman England -- the "England of the fields," as Hilaire Belloc, with a catch in his voice, refers to it.

SALEM, N.H., Sept. 11 -- Johnny Westrope, leading jockey on American race tracks this year, with more than 200 victories to his credit, continued his sensational riding at Rockingham Park today by scoring a triple. His winning mounts were Oriley in the first race, Mixed Party in the second and Vested Power in the sixth.

VATICAN CITY, Sept. 11 (AP) -- The concordat between Germany and the Holy See, agreed upon in July, was ratified yesterday. The final text arrived from Berlin by airplane and formal ratifications were exchanged by Cardinal Pacelli, the Papal Secretary of State, and Dr. Eugene von Klee, counselor in the German Embassy here.
SCARBOROUGH, England, Sept. 11 (Canadian Press) -- Rapid progress was made today in the cricket match between the British West Indies and H.D.G. Leveson-Gower's eleven.

Purchase of a building for the use of the American Kennel Club was authorized by the delegates to the governing body of the canine world at their quarterly meeting yesterday. Although the directors received power under a resolution to purchase a suitable property it does not necessarily follow that the deal will be completed immediately.

Control of the Kentucky Home Life Insurance Company was acquired at auction yesterday by the Contal Corporation of 30 Broad Street. The corporation bought 51 per cent of the capital stock, which had been held by the Continental Bank and Trust Company as collateral for a loan of $500,000.

VIENNA, Sept. 12. -- A new spirit was born in Austria yesterday, a spirit of confidence in the country and in its future. It came from the great demonstration at the Vienna race track and the five miles of procession through, cheering thousands that followed it. In neither was there discernible a single note of hostility or indifference.
CHICAGO, Sept. 12 (AP). -- As a final tune-up for their series with the Giants, which opens here tomorrow, the Cubs downed the Phillies, 2 to 0, today and took the series, three games to one.

After a promising advance in the forenoon, stocks turned downward yesterday and closed at the lowest levels of the day with net losses that averaged a little more than one-half point. This was a disappointing conclusion to what had seemed, at one time, to be an impressive market movement.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 12. -- The filing of twenty-three additional statements, covering issues of about $23,000,000, have been made under the Securities Act, bringing the total of proposed issues so far recorded under the new law to about $210,000,000.

Superlatives about the NRA parade today have been exhausted in advance. It is to be the biggest, the most varied and the most colorful in the history of this city. The chief significance lies on its voluntary character. The thousands who take part in the march, and the many more thousands who behold it, are bearing witness to their willingness to do everything within their power to carry the President's recovery program through to success.

Several large apartments on the east side were included in the long list of residential rentals reported by brokers yesterday, as Fall leasing activity continued at a high level. Several penthouses were taken. Renting appeared to be particularly brisk in the Park and Madison Avenue sections.

COMSTOCK, N.Y., Sept. 12. -- After taking correspondence courses and passing Regents examinations, Earle F. Peacox, convicted several years ago in Westchester County of killing his wife and burning her body, is studying at Great Meadow Prison to take college entrance examinations before Jan. 1, it was disclosed today.

WARWICK, R.I., Sept. 12. -- Lively Lady, sailed by Robert C. and E.S. Stevens of the Eastern Long Island Sound Fleet, won the first race of the Atlantic Coast Star Class championship series today. Moonshine, the Narrangansett Bay boat that won in 1931 and 1932 was second over a ten-mile course, trailing the victor by 57 seconds.

TOKYO, Sept. 13 (Wednesday). -- The political activities of General Sadao Araki, the War Minister, rather than preparing the way for a military dictatorship or the abolition of parliamentary government, are concerned primarily with obtaining appropriations for Japan's defense which financial conditions make Korekirgo Takahashi, the Finance Minister, reluctant to grant.

GENEVA, Sept. 12 (AP). -- The world awaits anxiously the results of the great economic experiment now being carried on in the United States, seeking lessons that may be profitable, Joseph Avenol, new Secretary General of the League of Nations, said tonight.

Daily average gross crude oil production of the United States last week was 2,691,950 barrels, compared with 2,721,400 in the previous week, a decline of 29,450 barrels, according to the American Petroleum Institute. A drop of 34,300 barrels daily in Oklahoma and an increase of 11,900 in California were among the principal changes.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 (AP). -- President Roosevelt will speak before the Conference of Catholic Charities in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel in New York on the night of Oct. 4.

John G. McCrory resigned yesterday as chairman of the board of the McCrory Stores Corporation, which he founded forty-eight years ago. His move was made with the object of regaining complete liberty of action to enter a bid for the properties at an early date.

President Roosevelt's recovery program has lifted the country "one-quarter" of the way out of the depression since last March, General Hugh S. Johnson declared last night at a mass meeting in Madison Square Garden.

CHICAGO, Sept. 12 (AP). -- Bank supervisors of the forty-eight States today voted themselves in accord with Federal deposits insurance, aligning with the national administration and against the stand of the American Bankers Association.

CINCINNATI, Sept. 12. -- A new record was established in the national amateur golf championship today when Johnny Fischer. University of Michigan star, posted the lowest qualifying score in the 37-year history of the event.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The replies of E.H.B. and V.L. Havens to my letter of Sept. 6, regarding fingerprinting, seem to be based upon a misconception. I am not objecting to voluntary fingerprinting for purposes of identification. That is available to every one at the present time.
PITTSBURGH, Sept. 12. -- Shutting out the Dodgers in both ends of a double-header today, the Pirates bounced into a tie for second place with the Cubs.

The President's NRA Day Parade up Fifth Avenue today has enrolled a marching strength of 254,475. The line of march will be from Washington Square to Seventy-second Street. The parade is scheduled to start at 1:30 o'clock and end at 8 P.M.
Frank Wagenbrenner was getting good breaks in a stiff solitaire game in the detectives' room in Jamaica at 1 o'clock yesterday morning when the phone interrupted. He picked up the receiver.

Trading in United States Government bonds on the Stock Exchange yesterday reached $1,853,000, the heaviest for a single day in more than a month, and in the over-thecounter market, where most of the trading in the government's issues is done, considerable activity was reported.
MADRID, Sept. 12. -- After five days during which many cabinets took shape only to collapse Alejandro Lerroux "was able to announce his government today.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, Sept. 12. -- It was the esteemed barrister, Bob Jones of Atlanta, Ga., who took a glimpse at the scoreboard at the Kenwood Country Club today and remarked: "There's a jot of strangers in town."

NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 12. -- A dinner was given tonight by Mayor Mortimer A. Sullivan, in honor of Vice Admiral the Hon. Reginald A. R. Plunkett-Ernle-Erle-Drax, R.N., and the officers of the H.M.S. Norfolk and the U.S.S. Wyoming.

HAVANA, Sept. 12. -- The new Cuban Government is a youth dictatorship, based on force, professing as its aim the creating of "a new Cuba" as a sovereign State purged of long-standing social, economic and political evils and promising to restore a democratic form of government to the people when the "purification" is completed.

Traditional Latin and Greek requirements for graduation at St. Stephen's College, Annandale-on-Hudson, N.Y., have been modified by action of the board of trustees of the college, it was announced yesterday by Acting Dean Donald G. Tewksbury.

MAMARONECK N.Y., Sept. 12. -- John H. Forsman, the defending champion, won the low gross prize in the qualifying round of the twenty-first annual New York Athletic Club championship golf tournament at the Winged Foot Golf Club today.

Representatives of the American Committee for the World Congress of Youth Against War and Fascism protested yesterday at the Board of Education against the denial of an application for use of the Washington Irving High School auditorium.
NEW YORK. Mrs. James W. Gerard has returned to 1,014 Fifth Avenue from a visit with her mother, Mrs. Marcus Daly, in Hamilton, Mont.
"A Party," at the Playhouse, and "The Blue Widow," at the Morosco, will delay the opening curtain at their matinee performances today in deference to the NRA parade.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 12. -- On the eve of a "holiday" strike of soft coal miners in Western and South-western Pennsylvania, the National Recovery Administration this afternoon convened a conference of 500 operators and devised machinery which it was hoped would expedite an agreement upon the long delayed bituminous coal code.
The New Jersey realty turnover reported yesterday was confined almost exclusively to one-family dwellings.

A Brooklyn beer garden was wrecked by gangsters yesterday and the wife of the proprietor was badly beaten in what the police described as the first attempt here to compel by racketeering methods the sale of one brand of legal beer to the exclusion of all others.

GREENWICH, Conn., Sept. 12. -- Miss Helen Hicks of the Lido Club, Long Beach, L.I., today won her match in the first round of the annual women's Invitation golf tournament at the Greenwich Country Club.

BERLIN, Sept. 12. -- A determined effort made by the banks here to stem the downward course of prices on the Boerse produced today several fluctuations which in the end left 'the average stock level practically unchanged. Large purchases were concentrated on leading security issues and produced advances up to 3 per cent, but toward its close the market turned weak again and gains and losses were about equally balanced.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 12 (AP). -- Robert C. Reid, 50, brother-in-law of Governor James Rolph Jr. and vice president of Balfour-Guthrie Company, Ltd., leaped fourteen stories to his death late today from the Balfour Building.

DENVER, Sept. 12 (AP). -- Colorado voted to strike prohibition from the Federal Constitution by about 2 1/2 to 1, it was indicated tonight in tabulations of ballots from more than half the precincts in today's special election.

Price movements in local commodity markets were irregular yesterday. For the most par prices were somewhat higher in the morning, but profit-taking and a downward trend in stocks halted this movement and prices slipped somewhat.

FREEHOLD, N.J., Sept. 12. -- Mrs. Minnie M. Richardson, widow, receives all personal jewelry and an outright bequest of $200,000 in cash in the will of Benjamin F. Richardson of Spring Lake, former president of the Union Paving Company of Philadelphia, filed for probate here.

NEWARK, N.J., Sept. 12. -- Mayor Meyer C. Ellenstein is considering a protest to Washington against the awarding of a group annuity contract by the United States Treasury Department Beneficial Association to the Sun Life Assurance Company of Canada. In identical letters tonight to Edward D. Duffield. president of the Prudential, and John R. Hardin, president of the Mutual Benefit Life Insurance Company, the Mayor asked them whether they thought a protest advisable.
Three years ago last Spring Lou Little arrived at Columbia University to whip up ebbing undergraduate football interest with an inaugural proclamation that was the original new deal.

The Western Union Telegraph Company reports for July a sharp increase in operating revenues over the same month last year for the third successive month, in its monthly statement to the Interstate Commerce Commission.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Extraordinarily wide discussions concerning the effect of NRA on business, finance and industry are taking place. With many phases of this very important matter subject to searching investigation and analysis, practically nothing is heard about the result that NRA is having on widows and retired people living on a fixed income.
MEXICO, D.F., Sept. 12. -- The government today awarded the Mexican Eagle collar to President Alcala Zamora of Spain and President Alessandri of Chile.

An investigation of the attitude and conduct of the courts in issuing injunctions against labor unions has been ordered by Governor Lehman, it became known yesterday. The investigation will be made by the State Commission on the Administration of Justice.

Cooperation must replace competition if college fraternities and sororities are to survive. This conclusion has been reached by Dr. Barbara Reid Robson, Chi Omega Fellow of Teachers College, Columbia University, who yesterday made public the results of a nation-wide survey she has been making of the college society problem.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 12. -- In a quick move to rid this metropolitan area of organized crime and a possible reign of gangsterism, law enforcement agencies began a registration today of all persons convicted of felonies within the last ten years.

Senator William Gibbs McAdoo, former Secretary of the Treasury; Mrs. McAdoo and Miss McAdoo are among the passengers sailing today on the Manhattan of the United States Lines for the Channel ports. Also on the ship were: George H. Earle 3d, United States Minister to Austria; Mrs. Earle, their four sons and the following others:

Opposition to the Federal attempt to level the prices of cash-and-carry and delivered milk was voiced yesterday by a new association of consumers at the Hotel McAlpin. The organization, which elected officers and named itself the Protest League Against Unfair Milk Codes, contended the codes thus far presented for the milk industry foisted the burden of milk costs on those least able to pay increases.

Members of the Theatre Ticket Brokers Association, composed of the smaller ticket agencies, held a closed meeting yesterday afternoon at the Hotel Astor and drafted a request to William A. Brady, chairman of the National Legitimate Theatre Committee, that he call a meeting of his committee at which the association's representatives might present their side of the latest ticket controversy.

RYE, N.Y., Sept. 12. -- One of the lowest rounds in the history of the United States senior golf championship enabled Dr. George T. Gregg of Pittsburgh to set the pace with a 74 today in the first day's play for the first section of the field.

BERLIN, Sept. 12. -- Advertising in Germany has been put under government control by a decree that was passed at today's Cabinet and made public late tonight. Thus the first branch of economic enterprise to be "socialized" by National Socialism is that in which it has most confidence.

Candidates for county committeemen can serve as election inspectors, but not in their own districts, Supreme Court Justice Irwin Untermyer ruled yesterday. The ruling was part of a decision covering disputes among factions of both major parties.

CHICAGO, Sept. 12. -- Discovery of a new growth-promoting substance, universally present and very powerful, was reported here today before the Century of Progress meeting of the American Chemical Society by Dr. Roger J. Williams and Dr. Carl M. Lyman of Oregon Agricultural College.
HAVANA, Sept. 12. -- The Cabinet of the new revolutionary government headed by President Ramon Grau San Martin was sworn in this morning.

WATERBURY, Conn., Sept. 12. -- Mrs. Rose Nemeth of Torrington is believed to be the first person in the United States to buy a Home Owners' Loan Corporation bond purely as an investment, the local office of the corporation disclosed today.

LEICESTER, England, Sept. 12. -- Strange things happened to the universe when the physicists of the British Association, for the Advancement of Science gathered today to hear such celebrities as Abbe Georges Lemaitre, Professor Willem de Sitter and Sir Arthur Eddington discuss the new cosmogony.

Newark for Refuge. Mayor Newark ELLENSTEIN of Newark hastens to extend the hospitality of his city oun own -- perhaps -- refugee Stock Exchange in terms that suggest Dr. JOHNSON. The finest view in Scotland, said that outspoken sage, is the road south into England.

Where so many other ex-champions of the ring have failed before him Tony Canzoneri fell down last night. The Brooklyn Italian, fighting the battle of his life in a bid to regain his lost world's lightweight title, bowed to Barney Ross, Chicago's capable holder of the crown, in fifteen sizzling rounds at the Polo Grounds.

Direct-current "breakdown" service must be supplied by the New York Edison Company to any present user of direct current who applies for it and is willing to observe reasonable rules and regulations of the company, according to an order issued yesterday by the Public Service Commission.
Following is the full text of the address delivered by General Hugh S. Johnson at the Madison Square Garden rally last night:

CINCINNATI, Sept. 12. -- The Giants' gay dash through the West and to their first National League pennant in nine years slowed down a bit today when threatening weather induced the Reds to call off the final game of the series.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 12. -- Pledging support of the Motion Picture Industry to the Administration in the effort to work out a code that would be acceptable to all its varied elements, Will H. Hays, president of the Motion Picture Producers and Distributors of America, today opened the public hearings on the tentative code before Sol Rosenblatt, Deputy Administrator.

CHICAGO, Sept. 12. -- A tiny ultraviolet lamp, so constructed that it can be inserted in the bronchial tubes for treatment of tuberculosis, was demonstrated before the American Congress of Physical Therapy today By Dr. M. Joseph Mandelbaum of New York City.

BERLIN, Sept. 12 (London Times Dispatch). -- Heinrich Hirtsiefer, for eleven years Prussian Minister of Welfare until he and his colleagues of the Socialist-Centrist government under Otto Braun were forcibly expelled from office by Chancellor von Papen last year, was paraded through the streets of Essen yesterday by two battalion commanders of Nazi storm troop detachments and guards.

The Fall tournament for the Curb Exchange's golf championship cup will be held tomorrow at the Fenimore Country Club, White Plains. Five members each have won a leg on the cup. To gain permanent possession of the trophy, a member must win three times.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 12. -- With Maine, the pioneer prohibition State, voting so decisively yesterday for repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment, anti - prohibitionist leaders were encouraged today to believe that not a single State to vote this year would go dry.

Buyers' Arrivals at Peak. The number of buyers registered in the market during the week ended yesterday established a new weekly peak for the year. This high total, however, failed to reach the peak of last year, which was registered at this time.

A cast-off's revenge was experienced yesterday for the second time by George Uhle when the Yankee pitcher turned back the Detroit Tigers, 5 to 3. It was the last clash of the season, between the McCarthymen and Bucky Harris's clan at the Stadium.

Under the guiding hand of Samuel Untermyer, the Board of Estimate branch of the Municipal Assembly passed four new emergency tax measures yesterday calculated to yield $24,700,000 in new revenue for unemployment relief in the next six months.

Cambridge, Mass. A new issue of $700,000 City of Cambridge (Mass.) relief bonds, unexpectedly announced yesterday morning for award at noon, drew a full complement of competitors. The bonds, dated Sept. 15, 1933, and due $140,000 annually from 1934 to 1938, were awarded to the City Company of New York, Inc., at 100.26, with the rate of interest named as 3 1/4 per cent.

Francis M. Law, newly elected president of the American Bankers Association, announced yesterday the committees and commissions of the organization to serve in the year that will end with the convention in the Fall of 1934.

BOSTON, Sept. 12. -- The great day of business advertising has just begun. Edward A. Filene declared today before the Advertising Club of Boston. But to fulfill its place under the New Deal, he asserted, it must be "realistic advertising, with the bunk left out."

The existence of a large and prosperous rum ring which for seven years has had virtual immunity against the seizure of its rum boats as a result of information as to the movements of Coast Guard vessels obtained through bribery, was revealed yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 12. -- A national conference on child health recovery in the interest of the steadily increasing millions of children known to be suffering from malnutrition as a result of the depression has been called by Secertary Perkins to meet in Washington Oct. 6 under the auspices of the Children's Bureau.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 12 (AP). -- Suit for $33,950,000 was filed by the local of the International Alliance of Theatrical Stage Employes against most of the major motion picture producers and two unions in Superior Court here today. The I.A.T.S.E. charged that the defendants oppressed and boycotted them during the recent Hollywood strike in which some 4,000 screen technicians were involved.

Monday's advances on the Cotton Exchange here were followed yesterday by further moderate gains. Buyers', though, were not aggressive, and after rising 35 to 37 points above recent low levels, prices reacted under Southern selling and realizing.

A dispatch, from Washington will make glad the hearts of scores of Government employes abroad. It announces that the Administration will ask Congress in January to raise the salaries of all such employes who have been adversely affected by the decline of the dollar since this country went off the gold standard.

Dirigo, Maine's motto, means "I set straight." At last Maine has set herself straight. On account of the sainted memory of NEAL DOW, the Maine law, the place of precedence it occupies among Dry statutes, myth has long clustered about her. Yet she has been no community of ascetics.

LE BOURGET, Sept. 12. -- Air Minister Pierre Cot and his eleven associates, who hopped off for Russia today, will try to "sell'' French commercial aviatlon to the Soviet. The planes are manned by crews totaling fourteen men.

The NRA consumer campaign passed the million mark yesterday when latest reports from the 50,000 canvassers showed 1,198,000 consumers pledged to buy from employers under the Blue Eagle, it was announced last night by Grover A. Whalen, local NRA chairman.

BALTIMORE, Sept. 12 (AP). -- Mulleavy capped a good night at bat with a triple in the eleventh inning of the' International League playoff game tonight to send home two men and aid the Buffalo Bisons to defat the Baltimore Orioles, 5 to 3.
New Jersey pressed its bid yesterday for the business of the New York Stock Exchange, giving the market heads official assurance of tax-free operations at any point within the State's borders.

LONDON, Sept. 12. -- Concerted action by the United States, France and Great Britain against Hitlerism was urged today by Wickham Steed, the distinguished British publicist, who addressed the American Chamber of Commerce at its luncheon.
Barney Ross scaled 135 pounds and Tony Canzoneri 133 1/4 for their bout last night. Arthur Donovan was the referee and George Kelly and Harold Barnes were the judges.

The Association of Marine Workers submitted a new scale of wages yesterday to James G Conway, president of the New York Tugboat Exchange, to replace the agreement between workers and employers which terminates at the end of this month.
The largest tuna fish to be hooked and landed hereabouts in recent years was brought to shore Monday, it was learned yesterday, by Francis H. Low, 22 years old, a senior at Yale.

The actual result of the new legal responsibility placed on long-term borrowers by the Securities Act of 1933 has been a suspension of the flow of capital into industry at a time when it is sorely needed, Allan M. Pope, former president of the Investment Bankers Association of America, said yesterday, at the opening session of the eighteenth annual convention of the Financial Advertisers Association in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 12. -- Weary officials at the State Department were relieved at the absence of news from Havana today. A confidential cablegram from Ambassador Welles was received late this afternoon and hastily decoded, but it was decided not to make any comment on it after a conference between Secretary Hull and Jefferson Caffery, Assistant Secretary of State.

DOBBS FERRY, N.Y., Sept. 12. -- A bomb was hurled early this morning from a passing car into the foyer of the Embassy motion-picture theatre here. The explosion caused $3,000 damage to the theatre, rocked the neighborhood and shattered window-panes in near-by stores.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 12. -- The National Labor Board, by unanimous decision ruled unequivocally today that employes have a right to be represented by any one they may choose, irrespective of whether or not he is an employe of the plant involved in a dispute.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 12. -- Reports of increasing gasoline prices will be promptly investigated by the Oil Administration, Secretary Ickes announced today.

Silk dyeing and printing plants in Paterson, Passaic, Clifton, Delawanna and other New Jersey towns closed down yesterday as strikers continued to resort to mass picketing to induce employes in the industry to leave their jobs.

Morris E. Packer, former Chief Assistant United States Attorney in the Eastern District and a member of the Kings County Republican Committee, bolted his party yesterday and announced that he would support Mayor John P. O'Brien and the rest of the Tammany ticket.

That England should regard with nervousness the recent movement of foreign capital to London for safekeeping illustrates the extent to which the normal machinery of International finance has been upset. Before the war, London was regarded by the entire financial world as the natural depository of international capital; the banking centre of the world which, like private banks and bankers, received deposits from the outside and employed them in financing outside trade and industry.

GLEN COVE, L.I., Sept. 12. -- Mrs. J. Norris Miller gave a supper dance tonight at the Woman's National Golf and Tennis Club at Glen Head to present to North Shore society her daughter, Miss Jane M. Miller. Before the dance the debutante was guest of honor at a small dinner given by her mother at Merrifield, their country home.

PARIS, Sept. 12. -- Some 2,500 motor-driven vehicles, including trucks, tractors, gun-carriages, machine-gun cars, armored cars and tanks, were used during the French Army "exercises" which have just been completed in Champagne.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Sept. 12. -- John D. Rockefeller Jr. today bought the Van Tassel Apartments in Beekman Avenue, North Tarrytown, from William Scott 2d, referee, at a sale in the court-house rotunda. Mr. Rockefeller, represented by his attorney, John J. Sinnott, was the only bidder, taking the property at $950,000.

ST. PAUL, Sept. 12 (AP). -- Piling up a heavy wet vote in the urban centres, repealists tonight maintained a 2-to-1 margin over prohibitionists in today's State-wide referendum on proposed repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 12. -- On Aug. 5 President Roosevelt created the National Labor Board, with Senator Robert F. Wagner as chairman, to mediate industrial disputes and minimize strikes and lockouts that would interfere with the national recovery program.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 (AP). -- Controversy over the merit clause in the code of competition proposed for the boot and shoe industry was moved back-stage today while labor started a many-sided attack against the wage and hour provisions proposed by manufacturers.
BRETTON WOODS, N.H., Sept. 12. -- The first snow on Mount Washington attracted throngs of visitors today. They took the forest drive to the base of the mountain. Many made the ascent by rail.

A new and cheaper edition of the huge Oxford English Dictionary, which originally cost about $1,500,000 to make and represents fifty years' work by a permanent staff of 1,300 workers and thousands of volunteer readers, is to be issued in November by the Oxford University Press.

If the quarterly auction of unclaimed articles in the General Post-office at Eighth Avenue and Thirty-third Street is a fair barometer of the state of the Union, the New Deal already has turned up face cards.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 (AP). -- Henry T. Rainey, Speaker of the House, today protested against what he called the "failure" of the Farm Credit Administration to give the farmers "adequate relief," and said the "old Republican set-up" still was in charge of dispensing the loans.
HAVERILL, Mass., Sept. 12. -- An uproar has been created here by the appointment of a young druggist as receiver of the closed Essex National Bank.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Referring to the pursuit of a Negro thief in Central Park by policemen, it appears that the guardians of the peace have been overlooking the possibility of crime in that quarter. Any one passing through the gate at Columbus Circle, west of the Maine monument, will at once observe the chances of disorder and crime.

SALEM, N.H., Sept. 12. -- By riding the Le Mar Stock Farm's Silver Cord to victory in the second race at Rockingham Park today Jack Westrope equaled the modern record for winners ridden by a jockey in a single year. Silver Cord was Westrope's 212th winner and he thereby tied the mark set last year by Johnny Gilbert.

Business on the various security and commodity exchanges will be suspended at noon today to permit participation in the National Industrial Recovery demonstration. Business will go on otherwise as usual. The banks will be open the full day and other financial houses will keep skeleton staffs at work.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 12. -- The Public Works Administration today allotted $8,149,000 for two low-cost housing projects in New York City. Of this amount, $5,184,000 was granted to the Hillside Housing Corporation for a development in the Bronx and $2,965,000 to the Hallets Cove Garden Homes, Inc., for one in the Borough of Queens.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 12. -- Despite the urgent recommendation of Senator Harrison of Mississippi, chairman of the Finance Committee, for "rational inflation" of the currency to stimulate industrial activity, President Roosevelt is still opposed to any new radical financial policy until the recovery program has been thoroughly tested.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 12. -- The Agricultural Adjustment Administration tonight announced its intention to subsidize the exportation of 30,000,000 to 35,000,000 bushels of stored wheat from the Pacific Northwest and, if need be, to sustain a maximum loss of $7,000,000 in the process.

William M. Chadbourne, fusion campaign manager, and W. Kingsland Macy, Republican State chairman, each moved yesterday to settle the quarrel between the city fusion party and the Queens Republican organization, headed by Warren B. Ashmead, over the announced intention of the Clty Fusion party to nominate independent candidates for Aldermen and Assemblymen in four of the six Queens districts.

STOCKHOLM, Sept. 12. -- Disregarding warnings of the Swedish Military Air Force, Colonel Charles A. Lindbergh today flew an airplane of a type which aviation students had been forbidden to use as unsafe.

George D. Widener's Kawagoe, a son of the imported sire Sickle, qualified handsomely for the $100,000 Futurity when he led from start to finish down the Widener chute yesterday in the sixty-fourth running of the Nursery Handicap.

In response to a request from Felix M. Warburg, Mischa Elman has returned to New York from California to take part in preparations for the concert to be given on Sept. 28 at the Westchester County Centre, White Plains, for the benefit of German Jewish Relief.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Sept. 12. -- Yale's freshman football coaching staff was appointed tonight by Dr. Marvin A. Stevens, former head coach.

PARIS, Sept. 12. -- Responding to Wall Street's strength yesterday, the Bourse today reversed its recent downward trend and forged ahead on all fronts. Closing prices were generally best of the day. As business continues to be confined almost wholly to professional speculators, the volume transaction remained relatively low, although larger than it had been for ten days.

If "Murder at the Vanities," which was put on at the New Amsterdam last evening, accomplishes nothing else, it suggests that the time is ripe for a bountiful musical show in this desolate town. Some of Mr. Carroll's newest side-show serves to remind us of the musical color-boxes he used to produce in the past.
