UNIONTOWN, Pa., Sept. 12 (AP). -- The vast soft coal fields of South-western Pennsylvania seethed with unrest tonight as plans went forward for a general mine "holiday."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 (AP). -- Smoldering resentment over patronage directed especially toward Secretaries Ickes, Perkins and Wallace, has brought a group of Democratic Senators to the point of planning open rebellion against the Roosevelt administration in the coming Congress.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 12. -- A plea and a hope for the end of the "dog-eat-dog" rule in retail business resulting from destructive price cutting were voiced tonight by B.H. Namm of Brooklyn before the conference of the Affiliated Better Business Bureaus.

LIMA, Peru, Sept. 12. -- Dr. Julio C. Tello, famous in Peru as an archaeologist, announced today the discovery of what he called a perfectly preserved portion of an Indian building belonging to the ancient Chavin civilization.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 (AP). -- Monte Pearson, ace of the Indians' staff, today topped the veterans Alvin Crowder in a neat pitching duel and Cleveland defeated the Senators, 3 to 1.

To the Editor of The New York Times: According to THE TIMES, the Polish aeronauts traveled for five days through the woods of Quebec with nothing to eat excepting a dozen oranges. A gill net of three-inch mesh and weighing not more than a pound, worn as part of the clothing, would have given them riches in the way of whitefish, pike or trout for three fine meals daily.

Resumption of work on the $55,000,000 Triborough Bridge project, which is expected to provide employment for 18,000 men, was delayed yesterday as a result of local opposition to the proposed method of widening a six-block section of the Bronx approach.

CHICAGO, Sept. 12. -- A sharp falling off in the last two days in the movement of pigs for sale to the government has resulted in increasing the demand for heavier hogs. Prices moved up 10 to 15 cents a hundredweight today to the highest levels since Aug. 14.

To the Editor of the New York Times: Although but just landed on these shores, and having submerged for three months the Great National Thought and decided to resist all anti-prohibition Appeal for this season, I nevertheless suoe cumb to it since, at the breakfast table this morning', fate revealed to me Allan Nevins's article "Repeal -- The Amazing Turnabout," appearing in THE NEW YORK TIMES Magazine.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 12. -- Three German scientists will join, the faculty of the Carnegie Institute of Technology this Fall, Dr. Thomas S. Baker, president, announced today. They are Professor Otto Stern, experimental physicist and former head of the Institute of Physical Chemistry at the University of Hamburg; his assistant, Professor I. Estermann, and Professor Ernst Berl, chemist and professor at the Technical University at Darmstadt.

BERLIN, Sept. 12. -- The Reichstag fire case will come up in the Supreme Court at Leipzig Sept. 21. In anticipation of its opening, the Associated Anti-Communists of Germany, a society heretofore unheard of, comes forward with a compilation of evidence marshaled to show that toward the end of last February German Communists were ready for action to overthrow the Hitler government by violence and to seize control of Germany.

One of the busiest days of the year in the Manhattan and Bronx auction rooms was experienced yesterday. Thirteen Manhattan parcels and twelve Bronx properties were offered in foreclosure proceedings. Twenty-four of the total were bid in by the plaintiffs; sale of the one other parcel was adjourned.

THOR LAKE, Ont., Sept. 12. -- While all that remains of the balloon Goodyear IX reposes amid the jack-pines of the Thor Lake area, ruined beyond repair, Ward T. Van Orman and Frank Trotter, co-pilots in the Bennett air race, were able to get out of the Northern Ontario backwoods today under their own power.

NEWARK, N.J., Sept. 12. -- Coming from behind with, a brilliant batting rally in the closing innings, the Newark Bears overpowered Rochester's Red Wings, 6 to 8, today in the opening game of the International League first-place playoff.

Two of the theatre's leading monologists, Cornelia Otis Skinner and Dorothy Sands, have announced their plans for the present season. Miss Skinner has completed the script of her new dramatic sequence, "The Love of Charles II," which will be similar more to her solo drama, "The Wives of Henry VIII."
ALBANY, Sept. 12 (AP). -- Surrounded by bodyguards since his release by kidnappers six weeks ago, Lieutenant John J. O'Connell Jr. has again been threatened with harm.

Magistrate Ford in Tombs Court yesterday, over the objection of a defense lawyer, granted the request of Eugene B. McAuliffe. Assistant District Attorney, for postponement until Sept. 27 of the hearing on the grand larceny charge against Nicholas Roberts, for many years president of S.W. Straus Co.

The business of New York City has been disrupted and the savings of the poor menaced by the tax program of the Curry-O'Brien administration because it is not competent to finance a "chicken-feed" transaction, Representative Loring M. Black Jr. declared last evening.

The code of fair competition for the transit industry was signed yesterday by the first transportation group when the Green Bus Lines, Inc., operating crosstown bus lines in Manhattan and other boroughs for the past four years affixed its signature.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 (AP). -- The NRA brought a halt to public hearings on a code of fair competition for the silk textile industry today pending settlement of strikes involving between 50,000 and 60,000 workers.
LONDON, Sept. 12. -- The Times says, in comment:
WASHINGTON, Sept. 12. -- Compliance boards to facilitate observance of the residential re-employment agreement under the NRA will be created immediately in every city and town of the nation.
WESTBURY, L.I., Sept. 12. -- The Juniors and Great Neck rode through to the final round of the Thorn Memorial Cup polo tourney at the Meadow Brook Club today.

ELMSFORD, N.Y., Sept. 12. -- Doing most of the low scoring himself with a round one stroke under par, Johnny Farrell of Quaker Ridge paired with Emil Mossbacher to win the pro-amateur beat ball tournament today at the Fairview Country Club.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 12. -- The stringent regulations that for months have governed the sale of gold were modified today by the Treasury to create, in effect, a free gold market for the industries, arts and professions licensed to acquire and use the precious metal.

SOUTHPORT, Conn., sept. 12 -- Kenneth H. McNeil, sailing the Kumon, today won the initial race in the championship series of the Atlantic Class of racing sloops. His boat is the representative of the Black Rock Yacht Club of Bridgeport.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 12. -- The cricket match between the Vandals of Cambridge University and All-Philadelphia, which marked the last contest for the Britons on their American tour, was declared a draw today. Each side played seven wickets.

An appeal to enrolled Republicans of New York County to vote for anti-Koenig candidates for the county committee was made last night by Chase Mellen Jr., who is seeking election as county chairman in place of Samuel S. Koenig. Only by thus rebuilding the party could loyal support of the fusion candidates be insured, Mr. Mellen declared in an address from radio station WOR.
BALTIMORE, Sept. 12. -- With a 10-to-1 vote in Baltimore city and a majority in every county outside except one, the wets swept Maryland in today's election on repeal of the prohibition amendment.

CHICAGO, Sept. 12. -- The wheat market on the Board of Trade here was relatively firm in undertone early today and, while buying was fair on declines, the outside trade was not sufficient to carry prices more than about a cent a bushel above yesterday's finish.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 12. -- Substantial increases in department-store sales in August as compared with July, 1933, and August, 1932, were shown in an analysis made public today by the Federal Reserve Board.
Duck hunters who do most of their shooting in Great South Bay are very likely to have some resentment against the new regulations covering the taking of migratory wild waterfowl.

The recovery in domestic corporation bonds was extended yesterday on the Stock Exchange to some of the leading foreign loans. The trading pace was more active on the recovery, the turnover approximating $10,000,000. The maximum gains for the active domestic issues, however, did not amount to more than a point or two.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 12. -- The Reconstruction Finance Corporation has purchased $125,000 in preferred stock of the National Bank of the Virgin Islands, which will replace the only existing bank there, a Danish institution. An equal amount of common stock is to be subscribed locally.

Exactly what form of government in Austria Chancellor DOLLFUSS proposes his statement on Monday does not make clear. Some of his phrases seem to look toward a Fascist State. This might be a reflection of his recent talks with MUSSOLINI. On the other hand, he speaks of an "authoritarian" rule, "based on corporations formed on occupational lines."
WASHINGTON, Sept. 12. -- The War Department issued the following orders today:

Samuel S. Koenig, Republican county chairman, at a rally last night at the Manhattan Republican Club, 3,410 Broadway, defended his leadership against attacks made by Chase Mellen Jr., anti-Koenig candidate for the county chairmanship.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 13. -- An investigation of the competition between railroads and motor trucks has been undertaken by Joseph B. Eastman, Federal Coordinator of Transportation, who sent questionnaires today to about 16,000 operators of motor fleets throughout the country.

HAVANA, Sept. 13. -- American official opinion, carefully studying Cuba's student and soldier government, is unable to discern any progress toward establishing a government sufficiently stable to warrant recognition by the United States, at least in the near future.
BELGRADE Yugoslavia, Sept. 13. -- A Universal Christian Council, representing all Christian churches except the Roman Catholic Church, has been meeting at Novi Sad.

Steel operations have fallen this week to 41 per cent of capacity from the 45 per cent average reported last week, according to the review of The Iron Age. This publication again associates the contraction with the fact that the steel trade is still "wrestling with the details of filing prices and standardizing market practices under its new code."

One of the most puzzling problems thus far presented to Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt, who is conducting a questions and answers page in The Woman's Home Companion, came from a reader who used only the signature "Apprehensive," it was said yesterday at the offices of the publication, 250 Park Avenue.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 13. -- Although Frankie Frisch was banished from the field by Umpire Magerkurth in the fourth inning, the Cardinals had little difficulty in defeating the Dodgers in the opening game of the series today, 4 to 1.

An attack against that "mealymouthed British neologism, 'aren't I,' " is made by Arthur Guiterman in the September issue of Word Study, a leaflet published by G. C. Merriam Co., dictionary makers of Springfield, Mass. Although a comfortable contraction of "am I not" is a "long-felt want," writes Mr. Guiterman, "we strain at 'ain't' because it has been drilled into us that this colloquialism is low and iniquitous."

Robert P. Lamont has resigned as president of the American Iron and Steel Institute, it was announced yesterday at the institute's offices in the Empire State 'Building. Mr. Lament, it was learned, will be succeeded by Charles M. Schwab, who stepped out of the post a year ago to make room for Mr. Lamont.

BAYONNE, N.J., Sept. 13. -- Three silk mills in this city were closed today, with the result that 375 workers, mostly young women, were involved in strike situations affecting about 2,500 silk workers in Hudson County. Meetings of the workers immediately were called by labor representatives with a view to enrolling them in the United Textile Workers Union.
NEW YORK. Baron and Baroness d'Estournelles de Constant of Paris arrived on the Champlain and are at the Madison.

Declaring that the NRA and recent State legislation have placed broader responsibilities on accountants, the School of Business of Columbia University yesterday announced that new courses, "designed to aid the profession in meeting its new obligations," would tie introduced this year.
PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 13 (AP). -- The Athletics and White Sox wound up their season's series by dividing a double-header today. Chicago won the opener, 3 to 2, and dropped the nightcap, 4 to 2.

BOSTON, Sept. 13 (AP). -- For the first time in more than ten years, the Boston Symphony Orchestra, under the direction of Serge Koussevitsky, will give a series of concerts in Washington and Baltimore during the coming season.

Bankers throughout the country have come to the conclusion within the last few months that they have taken the blame and criticism for the economic ills of the country long enough, John H. Puelicher, president of the Marshall Ilsley Bank of Milwaukee, said yesterday in an address to more than 500 delegates representing banks, trust companies and investment houses at the eighteenth annual convention of the Financial Advertisers Association in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

MARKSVILLE, La., Sept. 13 (AP). -- Possemen closing in on eleven desperadoes, who fled Angola penal farm after a murderous riot there Sunday, today killed two of tie fugitives. They wounded another probably fatally in capturing him and took three of the fugitives unharmed.

Prompt action by the Federal Government to release the springs of credit, so that the march of the national recovery program might continue unchecked, was forecast last night by General Hugh S. Johnson, NRA Administrator. He addressed the NRA Day dinner of the Merchants Association of New York at the Hotel Pennsylvania.
German Press Freedom. Government control of advertising has just been decreed in Germany. Supreme authority has been vested in Herr GOEBBELS, who is Minister of Propaganda and Enlightenment.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 13. -- So great has been the increase in the consumption of medicinal liquor since the ban was lifted from prescriptions that the Industrial Alcohol Bureau will be forced to authorize additional production of whisky about Oct. 15, Dr. James N. Doran, head of the bureau, said today.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In Samuel Untermyer's report to the Board of Estimate on an emergency tax program was included a paragraph on the estimated savings from the central purchasing system to be established on Jan. 1, 1934, by the law enacted at the recent extraordinary session of the Legislature.

The duck baiting question will not finally be settled until after the duck hunting season, according to an announcement from W.C. Henderson, acting chief of the Bureau of Biological Survey. It is very likely that by that time some new points will be brought up regarding this very controversial question.

If the city and State are to obtain any more of the $3,300,000,000 to be distributed by the Federal Public Works Administration, application for the money must be made within a month or six weeks, it was announced yesterday at a conference of officials in the office of Secretary of State Edward J. Flynn.

Reports of a more active demand for cotton goods and renewed talk of inflation were accompanied yesterday by increasing activity and strength on the Cotton Exchange here, December contracts selling up to 9.38 cents a pound in the late trading, a grain of 27 points on the day.

ROSTOV-ON-DON, U.S.S.R., Sept. 13. -- The use of the word "famine" in connection with the North Caucasus is a sheer absurdity. There a bumper crop is being harvested as fast as tractors, horses, oxen, men, women and children can work.

Never in the history of the United States have the people given such united support as they have to President Roosevelt and the NRA, Mayor James M. Curley of Boston declared last night at a dinner in the Hotel Victoria which brought to a close the annual reunion of the Army and Navy Legion of Valor. About 200 were present.

Irving J. Denmark, said by Federal authorities to be an "important member" of a liquor ring that obtained reports of movements of Coast Guard boats, was arrested yesterday at the Belvedere Hotel and arraigned before United States Commissioner Francis A. O'Neill.

The government's policy with respect to Henry Ford will continue to be one of watchful waiting, General Hugh S. Johnson, National Recovery Administrator, said yesterday at the Hotel Pennsylvania, where he inspected the headquarters of the local NRA organization before the big NRA parade held in the afternoon.

While the police were looking for the two gangsters who wrecked a Brooklyn beer garden Tuesday night and injured two women, in an attempt to force the sale of one brand of legal beer to the exclusion of others, the State Attorney General and the State Alcoholic Beverage Control Board announced yesterday that they had begun independent investigations in the case.
TOKYO, Thursday, Sept. 14. -- Count Yasuya Uchida resigned as Foreign Minister today for reasons of health and Koki Hirota, former Ambassador to Moscow, accepted the post. The change was unexpected.

LOS ANGELES, Calif., Sept. 13. -- After nearly developing an open rupture an accord has been reached and the long delayed plan of the Standard Oil Company of California to buy the assets of Richfield Oil will be submitted formally to creditors within a few days, it was learned today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 13. -- Friday is the deadline for the call of the Fourth Liberty Loan, of which $6,263,000,000 is outstanding, if all or any part of that issue of 4 1/4 per cent bonds is to be retired on March 15, 1934.

BINGHAMTON, N.Y., Sept. 13 (AP). -- The engineer of the Erie Railroad's Atlantic Express, which was rammed from the rear by a milk train on the night of Sept. 5 with the loss of fourteen lives, testified at the inquest today that after his train was flagged because of switching operations ahead some time elapsed before he blew the whistle signal for a flagman to go back and protect the rear of the express.

CHICAGO, Sept. 13. -- The local and Eastern trade paid considerable attention today to fresh inflation talk from Washington, especially the East, which bought on a fairly large scale. With no material pressure, prices advanced sharply on the Board of Trade, as few care to sell short in existing conditions.

BUENOS AIRES, Sept. 13. -- President Justo will sign seven new treaties with Brazil when he visits Rio de Janeiro, Foreign Minister Saavedra Lamas told the Chamber of Deputies today. He said the pacts had been drawn up by the Argentine Foreign Office to embody the new international policy of reciprocal benefits that Argentina hopes eventually to make effective with all the other American nations.

Patrolman Edward White of the East 104th Street station was arrested yesterday on a formal homicide charge for the shooting of John Maher, delegate of the Bartenders Union, outside a beer garden last Aug. 10. White pleaded not guilty in the Homicide Court and was released in $1,000 bail by Magistrate Renaud for a hearing tomorrow.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 13. -- The importance of London as a world gold market is discussed in a study completed today in the Finance and Investment Division of the Department of Commerce.

Renewed activity in the purchase and leasing of properties in Manhattan and the Bronx was indicated by deals announced yesterday. Manhattan trading included two east side houses, a theatre on Seventh Avenue and two houses on the west side.
WESTBURY, L.I., Sept. 13. -- All six of the teams entered for the national open polo championship, which starts on Saturday, played their final practice games at the Meadow Brook Club today.

KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Sept. 13 (AP). -- Government production and distribution of electric power will not mean disaster to private companies, says David E. Lilienthal, member of the Tennessee Valley Authority.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 13. -- Extension of Federal emergency relief activities was authorized today by President Roosevelt to meet the "bitter needs" occasioned in the Cotton Belt by recent storms and in larger areas devastated by drought and grasshoppers, as well as by unemployment due to the industrial depression.

SOUTHPORT, Conn., Sept. 13. -- Repeating her victory in the initial race for the Atlantic Class championship, Kenneth H. McNeil's sloop Kumon won again today, defeating by 1 minute and 23 seconds John E. Rousmaniere's Lynx III, which was second yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 13. -- Modi- fication of existing plans for New York Harbor, to improve anchor- ages and thus reduce congestion and promote safety of navigation, was recommended to Congress to- day by Major Gen. Lytle Brown, Chief of Army Engineers, in a report embodying a preliminary examination and survey of steps which may be taken to improve the harbor.

Tallulah Bankhead will not appear in Owen Davis's play, "Jezebel," it was announced last evening by Guthrie McClintic, who is producing it. Miss Bankhead has been ill and her physicians have insisted that she give up all thought of acting for several weeks.

WASHINGTON, Sept 13 (AP). -- A day of NRA conferences failed to bring settlement of the strike of about 60,000 silk workers or to give any indication when that industry might be brought under a code of fair competition.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 13. -- John Van Antwerp MacMurray, newly appointed American Minister to Estonia, Latvia and Lithuania, was directed by the State Department today to proceed to London immediately as an alternate American member at a meeting of the wheat committee of the World Economic Conference.

SALEM, N.H., Sept. 13. -- Jockey Jack Westrope today established the best record made by any American jockey since 1908 when he rode the Greentree Stable's Nights End to victory in the second race at Rockingham Park.

Under the golden glow of Fifth Avenue's festive arc lights the legions of the Blue Eagle marched until midnight last night before hundreds of thousands of spectators whom weariness could not drive away from a demonstration of confidence and enthusiasm such as had not been seen for half a generation.

Except for General Johnson, who had to attend an NRA dinner last night, the notables in the reviewing stand took no time out for dinner last night. Governor Lehman, Mayor O'Brien, Grover A. Whalen and the others got hungry shortly after the arc lights were turned on and somebody sent out for coffee and sandwiches.

HAVANA, Sept. 13. -- While the Cuban public maintained its attitude of watchful waiting, the government of President Grau San Martin, ignoring the rebellious army officers who have taken refuge in the National Hotel, set about reorganizing the armed forces and accumulating funds to meet the immediate obligations of the administration.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 13. -- Faced with several serious arguments between opposing factions before the Motion Picture Code is acceptable to air parties concerned, Sol A. Rosenblatt, Deputy Administrator, adjourned today's hearings on the code to confer privately with differing groups.
Twenty-two rugged young giants were mixing it at Fordham Field yesterday in as rough, tough and furious a scrimmage session as the budding football season has probably witnessed on any gridiron.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 13. -- President Roosevelt revealed today that the administration has under consideration direct Federal loans to industries for payrolls should banks fail to furnish sufficient credit for business operating under the NRA codes.

PATERSON, N.J., Sept. 13. -- Delegates from the Institute of Dyers and Printers and a committes from the Paterson and New York unions of the United Textile Workers conferred here today with Federal Conciliator John A. Moffitt. It was decided that the best way to hasten the end of the dyers' strike was to speed governmental action on the dyers' code.

The American Hawaiian Steamship Company announced yesterday that, to keep its stockholders more fully informed on results of its operations in the intervals between its semiannual and annual reports, it would in future furnish to the New York Stock Exchange and the press reports of its monthly operations.

TOKYO, Thursday, Sept. 14 (AP). -- General Sadao Araki, Minister of War, today cited American sympathy and aid to China combined with the continued presence of the American Atlantic fleet in Pacific waters among factors making necessary immediate strengthening of Japan's national defense.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 (AP). -- Allotment of $25,537,625 for nineteen non-Federal projects in California, North Dakota, Wisconsin, Minnesota, Maryland, Illinois, Indiana, Ohio, Massachusetts, Colorado, Oregon and Florida was announced today by Secretary Ickes.

Indignant representatives of the International Seamen's Union met yesterday in the offices of Silas B. Axtell, marine lawyer and legal representative of the union. They were concerned over unconfirmed reports that the American Steamship Owners Association planned to include in its code of fair competi- tion a flat wage scale of $40 a month for able-bodied seamen.

CHICAGO, Sept. 13. -- The mystery of cancer and the mystery of life itself have their key in the recently discovered enzymes, Professor Richard Willstaetter of Munich declared in an interview here tonight. He is a Nobel Prize winner in chemistry and is regarded by his fellows as the "world's greatest organic chemist."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 13. -- Retail food prices continued to rise between Aug. 15 and 28 in twentyeight of the fifty-one cities reporting to the Bureau of Labor Statistics, but fluctuations were within narrower limits. The average increase for the period was fixed at three-tenths of 1 per cent.

In a letter to stockholders of the General Motors Corporation, accompanying the quarterly dividend checks, Alfred P. Sloan Jr., president of the corporation, said yesterday that the company would press its work in the field of technological development even more aggressively than it had done in the past.
TOKYO, Sept. 13. -- A War Office spokesman today gave the following statement to THE NEW YORK TIMES:

GREENWICH, Conn., Sept. 13. -- Miss Helen Hicks of the Lido Country Club will meet Mrs. Catherine Singer Eastman of the Westchester Country Club in the final of the women's annual invitation golf tournament of the Greenwich Country Club tomorrow.

Weather Now Is Sales Factor. From this point on, the weather will play a major role second only to the NRA consumer campaign, in either aiding or retarding consumer buying, retail executives here said yesterday. They cited the sales dips on the warm days of last week as bringing lowered sales totals, whereas the cool period so far this week has increased dollar volume.

NEWARK, N.J., Sept. 13. -- Rochester evened the first play-off series with Newark today when Tony Kaufmann, veteran righthander, outpitched Don Brennan, leading pitcher of the International League last year, for a 4-to-3 triumph.

PITTSFIELD, Mass., Sept. 13. -- Miss Mable Choate has offered the use of her Summer home, Naumkeag, Prospect Hill, Stockbridge, Tuesday and Wednesday, Sept. 26 and 27, from 10 A.M. to 6 P.M., for an exhibition and Christmas sale of articles made by infantile paralysis patients of Vermont.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., Sept. 13. -- The vagaries of the weather upset the program for the Manhasset Bay Yacht Club's Fall series of races, scheduled to start today. With more than fifty boats lying off the club for almost four hours, hardly a puff of wind stirred and the race committee deliberated as to whether to postpone the regatta.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 13. -- President Roosevelt will make public soon the text of an agreement reached last night by the Labor Advisory Board and the Industrial Advisory Board of the NRA concerning the controversial "merit clause" inserted into the automobile code.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 13. -- Events moved swiftly today toward early intervention by President Roosevelt in the tangled bituminous coal code situation.

With business interrupted at midday by the NRA parade, the security markets did not have an opportunity yesterday to extend themselves. Stocks and bonds had a modest advance in quiet dealings, but there was a broad upward movement in the grain markets.

Unselfish cooperation by capital, labor and consumer was urged as essential to the success of the national recovery program in an address last night by Owen D. Young, chairman of the board of the General Electric Company.

DURHAM, N.C., Sept. 13 (AP). -- The sales committee of the United States Tobacco Association voted today to postpone the opening of auction tobacco sales in the middle, old bright and other belts where sales have not started, by as many sales days as the South Carolina and new bright belt markets stayed closed.

The tenth "White List" of books approved by the Cardinal Hayes Literature Committee was issued yesterday, with compliments to the publishers that "so many works of exceptional merit should have appeared in what has often been called the silly season."

CHICAGO, Sept. 13. -- Struggling valiantly through four and a half hours of high gale and rain, the Cubs today launched their last-ditch stand to retain their National League laurels, but despite their great perseverance, they met with only partial success.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Theodore Reed Kendall, writing to THE TIMES advocating the use of water meters on city water outlets, gives one the impression that meters are now unknown in New York City. But as a matter of fact all water that can be sold to consumers by the gallon to the advantage of the city as a whole now passes through meters.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 13. -- Two hundred and forty delegates from sixty-eight United Mine Workers locals, representing 32,522 miners, met at Pricedale this afternoon and voted to continue the holiday which began yesterday until the coal operators accepted the NRA code promulgated by the administration.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 13. -- Deaths from automobile accidents increased during the four weeks ended Sept. 2, 1933, as compared with the four preceding weeks in the same period last year on the basis of reports from eighty-six large cities, according to a compilation announced by the Census Bureau today.

Yesterday's news was rich in the re- ports of scientific discussions both in America and in Britain. They leave one somewhat bewildered in a cosmos about which the expansionists and the contractionists cannot agree, but with a more hopeful view of our own little earth in a universe "which is only a hypothesis, like the atom," as DE SITTER declares it to be.

"This is without a doubt the most marvelous demonstration I have ever seen," declared General Hugh S. Johnson, National Recovery Administrator, while reviewing the parade yesterday. "It shows that the country is responding to the President's plan.

LONDON, Sept. 13. -- The stock markets here were again cheerful and generally firm today, with some increase in business. A sharp recovery in the price of gold to 129s 2d an ounce stimulated Kaffir shares, and there was strong buying on home, South African and Paris account.

The Hackensack River Sewerage Authority, recently appointed by Governor A. Harry Moore, was organized formally yesterday at a meeting in the court house in Jersey City. The new board authorized its newly elected chairman, Thomas J. Wasser, to negotiate with the Reconstruction Finance Corporation for a loan not to exceed $25,000,000.

To the Editor of The New York Times: This month a new president assumes office at Hunter College, the largest woman's college in the world. It was founded through the vision and untiring efforts of Dr. Thomas Hunter, one of the first educators to champion the higher education of women and to foresee that as women were intellectually trained many would become teachers.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 13. -- Members at the planning committee on oil took up a new question today, the refusal of the Texas Oil Company, one of the companies opposed to price-fixing, to submit operating and cost data which had been requested informally by the group to aid in its work.
VIENNA, Sept. 13. -- Application of the Nazi method of reprisals by taking hostages obtained the release of two Salzburg Heimwehr auxiliary policemen from a German prison today:
The Richard C. du Pont soaring expedition to the Blue Ridge Mountains of Virginia will start tomorrow and continue two weeks, with leading soaring pilots in the East seeking glider records.

CHICAGO, Sept. 13. -- Use of State bank examiners' findings as a basis for judging eligibility of State non-reserve member banks for admission under the Federal deposit guarantee was urged today by the National Association of State Bank Supervisors.

A menace to Equipoise's supremacy in the handicap division arose yesterday at Belmont Park, where the Wheatley Stable's Dark Secret was an easy winner of the mile and a half of the Manhattan Handicap. The winner gave ten pounds and a decisive whipping to Morton L. Schwartz's Gusto, heretofore considered Equipoise's only rival.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 13. -- A master code for retail stores, including drug stores and pharmacies, which is expected to bring a sharp clash between certain prominent New York department stores, has been drawn by Deputy Administrator Whiteside of the NRA, and was reviewed, by a number of well-known retailers this afternoon.

The return tout between Barney Ross and Tony Canzoneri at the Polo Grounds Tuesday night attracted the largest turnout for a lightweight championship match since 1929, when Canzoneri fought Sammy Mandell.
BALTIMORE, Sept. 13 (AP). -- Buffalo laid down a home run barrage today to beat Baltimore, 6 to 5, in the International League's play-off series. The victory was the second straight for the Bisons.
Registration in evening classes for adults in the city's elementary schools will begin on Monday. Instruction will be offered for 100 nights beginning on Sept. 25, the Board of Education announces.

Wall Street was on a half-holiday schedule yesterday as a result of the NRA demonstration. The security exchanges closed at noon, and otherwise business was sharply curtailed after that time. The total turnover on the Stock Exchange in the two hours to which business was confined was 735,090 shares, compared with 2,243,400 on the previous five-hour day.
PARIS, Sept. 13. -- Former Premier Edouard Herriot returned to Paris today from his trip to Russia, and almost immediately went on the Lyon without saying anything.

One marcher died of a heart attack and forty-six others were injured yesterday along the line of the NRA parade on Fifth Avenue. The ardor with which young and old edged into the milling throng that turned out to see the celebration was evidenced by the ages of the injured persons, which ranged from 6 to 77.

CAMDEN, N.J., Sept. 13. -- Dr. Carlton D. Haegis, a Camden engineer, has developed a two-way radio telephone communication permitting conversations between aircraft and land stations aft a distance of seventy-five miles without static interference.

BERLIN, Sept. 13. -- Extensive supporting purchases made by the banks under "persuasion" of the government produced today an aspect of firmness on the Boerse. The market was supported also by traders speculating on quick turns while the banks' intervention lasts, but the public still remains skeptical.

CAPE TOWN, South Africa, Sept. 13. -- Phineas Mackintosh, white British subject, who was flogged by order of an African native tribal court, was banished today from all native territories in South Africa.

PARIS, Sept. 13. -- David Levinson, American lawyer, who has been seeking permission to aid in the defense of the three Bulgarians accused with two others of the burning of the Reichstag building, announced today that his request had been refused.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 13. -- Secretary Ickes submitted to President Roosevelt today far-reaching amendments to the oil code, one of them giving the President wide authority on price-fixing and authority to impose such conditions, including reports and accounts, as might be necessary for protection of consumers, competitors, employes within the industry and others.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 13. -- Robert P. Lament, who resigned tonight as president of the American Iron and Steel Institute, took an active part in the formulation of the code under which the industry now is operating.

VIENNA, Sept. 13. -- Bronislaw Hubermann, internationally famous violinist, whose permanent home is in Vienna, has declined to appear again in the subscription concerts of the Berlin Philharmonic Orchestra conducted by Dr. Wilhelm Furtwaengler.

Once a ROOSEVELT signed a round-robin. Now, according to report from Washington, a round-robin signed by certain Democratic Senators has been or will be sent to a ROOSEVELT. The august letter-writers complain and wail. Little or nothing is being served at the pie-counter.

LONDON, Sept. 13. -- A commission of leading jurists of seven nations will hold its first hearing in London tomorrow to determine in an "unemotional and sane way" who really burned the Reichstag building in Berlin on the night of Feb. 27 last.

BURLINGTON, Vt., Sept. 13. -- George Henry Perkins, vice president emeritus of the University of Vermont and dean emeritus of its department of the arts and sciences, died suddenly last night. He would have been 89 years old on Sept. 25. When he gave up teaching this Summer, he had been a member of the faculty for sixtyfour years.

The New York Stock Exchange firm of Stetson Blackman, whose floor partner, John B. Stetson Jr., was formerly United States Minister to Poland, was prohibited yesterday from trading on the Exchange. The firm's financial condition would not permit it to "continue in business with safety to its creditors," the Exchange announced.

The question whether S.W. Straus Co. are bankrupt should be tried before a jury as soon as possible, Federal Judge Alfred C. Coxe said yesterday in denying "at this time" a motion to appoint a receiver in bankruptcy. The bankruptcy action has been pending since March.

RYE, N.Y., Sept. 13. -- Raleigh W. Lee of Columbus, Ohio, who recently won the international senior golf crown in Canada, made a serious bid to carry off the United States senior title today with a two-round score of 156 to top the first section of the field.

DONCASTER, England, Sept. 13. -- Hyperion won additional honors for Lord Derby today. The young colt by Gainsborough out of Selene, hailed earlier in the Summer as winner of the famous Derby, today outdistanced twelve other crack 3-year-olds in the 154th running of the St. Leger Stakes over the course of one mile, six furlongs and 132 yards on the historic Town Moor.
Supporters of F.H. LaGuardia, fusion choice for Mayor, expect Alfred E. Smith to take the stump for Mayor O'Brien, the Tammany candidate, it was learned yesterday.
NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 13. -- Entertaining in honor of Vice Admiral Drax and the officers of H.M.S. Norfolk continued today.
Continuance of activity in apartment renting was apparent yesterday. In Manhattan the east and west sides were about equally favored by tenants. The leases reported included the following:

Gold to the amount of $8,333,300 was withdrawn here yesterday for export to France. All of it came from the stock under earmark for foreign account at the Federal Reserve Bank. Thus, the monetary gold stock of the United States was not affected.

With a few minor changes, Mr. UNTERMYER'S tax program has now been adopted by the Board of Estimate. The Board of Aldermen is expected to sign on the dotted line today. As soon as a few other formalities are complied with the new taxes will be officially in force.

Domestic corporation bonds and leading foreign loans moved irregularly higher yesterday in the two-hour trading period on the Stock Exchange, while United States Government bonds drifted generally lower. Transactions in bonds on the Exchange amounted to $4,682,000, compared with $9,977,000 in the five-hour market on the previous day.
Prices for commodity futures on local exchanges were steady with slightly higher tendencies in yesterday's short session. Trading was in fair volume. Cash prices were irregularly higher.

NATHAN STRAUS Jr. has at last got the necessary backing for his fine housing venture in the Bronx. It almost came to the point where he could qualify as a prophet not without honor save in his own borough. Ex-Mayor McKEE opposed the project on the ground that it was not "slum clearance."

BRETTON WOODS, N.H., Sept. 13. -- Major Gen. and Mrs. William Crozier of Washington arrived last evening at the Mount Washington here for a short stay. Arriving from Scarsdale on their Autumn visit were Mr. and Mrs. Joseph F. Duffy.

A report on a survey of some of the major art projects undertaken by the Emergency Unemployment Relief Committee was made yesterday by the College Art Association of 137 East Fifty-seventh Street, which supervised the work. The survey was made by Audrey MeMahon, executive secretary of the association, and Harry Knight, acting for the Emergency Work Bureau.
WARWICK, R.I., Sept. 13. -- Today was just the right weather for Moonshine of the Narragansett Bay fleet in the International Star Class regatta.

The speech which General JOHNSON delivered in Madison Square Garden on Tuesday evening was one of the best yet written for him. This is not said disparagingly. No one can work eighteen or twenty hours a day as General JOHNSON has been doing, wrestling with vexing problems, and find time to prepare the addresses which he has made.

Efforts to settle the strikes of 25,000 underwear workers, members of the White Goods Workers Union, and of 3,000 cleaners striking under the direction of the Cleaners, Dyers and Pressers Union will be resumed today by the local NRA organization.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 (AP). -- Around a nucleus of fifty permanent army camps, to be improved and expanded through an allotment of $50,000,000, President Roosevelt today planted a redistribution and consolidation of the United States' land forces.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 13. -- The modifications of the petroleum industry's code of fair competition, made public today by Secretary Ickes, the oil administrator, follow in full:

BERLIN, Sept. 13. -- Shortened rations once a month for every man, woman and child in the Reich, as well as for the strangers within its gates, are to constitute the nucleus of the government's program for social relief this Winter.

LONDON, Sept. 13. -- An expert thief, who apparently knew what he was after, today smashed a show-window of the store of Samuels, Harris Son, Ltd., in the heart of the diamond trade district. and stole a rare Brazilian stone of 32.7 carats, valued at $100,000.

RIVERHEAD, L.I., Sept. 13. -- Society will dominate the Suffolk County Horse Show to be staged on Friday afternoon as one of the innovations in the annual Suffolk County Fair, which is being held at the Fair Grounds, Riverhead, this week.

Much to the amusement of spectators who jammed Fifth Avenue's sidewalks in the vicinity of the Public Library yesterday, Mayor John P. O'Brien was roundly booed by groups from both the stock exchanges as they marched past the reviewing stand where the Mayor stood with other high officials.

Child-welfare workers representing courts and protective institutions throughout the State yesterday voiced agreement that agencies for the care of neglected children were confronted with an undiminishing number of cases. They discussed the policies and functions of protective societies at the fourty-fourth annual State convention of Societies for the Prevention of Cruelty to Children in the shelter of the New York society at 2 East 105th Street.

A contest over the estate of Mrs. Mary Eliza Blodgett, philanthropist, daughter of the late John Hinman Sherwood, founder of the Fifth Avenue Bank, was started yesterday in Surrogate's Court. Two objections to the will were filed, one by five distant relatives and the other by the board of managers of the Diocesan Missionary and Church Extension Society of the Protestant Episcopal Church in the Diocese of New York.

Definite evidence of a strong revival in consumer buying during recent weeks is the chief factor in the marked increase in advertising by retailers, manufacturers and other business interests, a survey made yesterday by THE NEW YORK TIMES indicated.

The perennially popular twin bill of opera, "Cavalleria Rusticana" and "Pagliacci," acted as a tonic on the attendance at the New York Hippodrome last night. The Chicago Opera Company has been playing to distinctly smaller houses than those of the June and July season, but last night's performances attracted the largest audience of the week.

Jubilant over victories in Maryland, Minnesota and Colorado Tuesday, repeal forces are now concentrating on the ten States slated to vote on the prohibition question between now and Nov. 7, The Associated Press reports. The elections in Maryland, Minnesota and Colorado brought to twenty-nine the number voting in unbroken succession to abolish the Eighteenth Amendment.

With approval of the city's new tax program by the Board of Aldermen scheduled for this afternoon, plans for establishing a branch of the New York Stock Exchange in New Jersey to avoid the impending stock transfer tax of four cents a share were receiving serious consideration last night.

Swollen by streams of passengers, from every transit line in the city, a vast lake of humanity overflowed the grass plots and concrete plazas of Washington Square yesterday and broke in a white surf of banners against the encircling hotels and housefronts.

CINCINNATI, Sept. 13. -- Johnny Goodman's ambition to add the national amateur golf crown to his open title was crushed today when H. Chandler Egan of Oregon eliminated him in the opening round of the tournament at the Kenwood Country Club.
PITTSBURGH, Sept. 13 (AP). -- Turning in their third straight shutout, the Pirates today defeated the Braves, 1 to 0, as Larry French shaded Ben Cantwell in a pitching duel.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 (AP) -- Sumner Welles, United States Ambassador to Cuba, received orders from the State Department today to remain at his Havana post indefinitely or until complete calm and stability had been restored on the island.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 13. -- Extension to Sept. 26 of the time when national banks and State member banks must have filed reports as to condition of affiliates was announced today by the Controller of the Currency.

PARIS, Sept. 13. -- During the next few days discussions of the disarmament problem will be begun again here and in England in the hope that some outline agreement will be reached so as to prevent complete failure next month at Geneva.

The downpour yesterday caused postponement of the initial performance of "The Romance of a People," scheduled for opening last night at the Polo Grounds. More than 15,000 first-night ticketholders were disappointed.

TOKYO, Sept. 14. -- The newspaper Nichi Nichi says today the new Foreign Minister, Koki Hirota, will not only continue to cultivate good relations with all friendly powers, but will endeaver to improve Japanese-American relations by promoting an arbitration treaty and working for reasonable revision of the Washington and London naval treaties.

Another organization devoted to the production of opera at popular prices, known as the Fides Opera Company, made its bow last night at Mecca Auditorium. The operas were "Cavalleria Rusticana" and "Pagliacci," and the performances were, on the whole, on a level notably high, for companies whose aim is presentations on a modest scale.

TOKYO, Sept. 14. -- Koki Hirota. Japan's new Foreign Minister, said in his first public pronouncement today that the outlook was hopeful for amity between Japan and her three great neighbors -- the United States, Russia and China.
The schedule for the series of International dinghy races to begin tomorrow off the Seawanhaka Corinthian Yacht Club, Oyster Bay, L.I., was announced yesterday.

A further advance in the cotton market here yesterday carried the December option to 9.74 cents, or 38 points above Wednesday's closing quotation and 88 points higher than the low price touched last week. Then followed a reaction under realizing and Southern selling.

GENEVA, Sept. 14. -- The lowest point of the depression in the world's productive activity appears to have been passed about the middle of 1932, according to a substantial report entitled "World Production and Prices, 1925 to 1932," issued by the League of Nations' economic intelligence service.
U.S. Department of Agriculture. Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices at New York.

VIENNA, Sept. 14. -- Fascism is the wrong term to apply to the new regime that Chancellor Dollfuss is about to institute in Austria. The authoritarian government on a corporative basis that he proposes Will not necessarily be a copy of the Italian original, as it will most certainly not be modeled after Hitler theory or Hitlerite method.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., Sept. 14. -- The Fall regatta of the Manhasset Bay Yacht Club got under way today despite a steady rainfall and heavy wind that made for unpleasant sailing conditions. A fleet of thirty-nine boats answered the call of the committee, which postponed the start of the regatta yesterday because of lack of wind.

PRINCETON, N.J., Sept. 14. -- Fearing "danger of our becoming quacks," the Rev. John McDowell, Moderator of the General Assembly of the Presbyterian Church, told assembled ministers here this afternoon that successful interpretation of the Word of God called for a knowledge of the relation between religion and society.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 14 (AP). -- A verdict of $75,000 damages in favor of Mrs. Marian Read was returned today in her $100,000 alienation of affections suit against Claire Windsor, the actress, whom she charged with stealing the love of her husband, Alfred C. Read Jr.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 14. -- Allegations that the principles of price control and price fixing had been inserted in the master code for retail stores, drawn by Deputy Administrator Whiteside of the NRA, led to protests today from consumers fearing a rise in their purchasing costs if the plan is ratified.

With silver futures the feature or the day, all commodities traded on local exchanges continued to push into higher ground yesterday. For the most part, the advances were made early in the day, after which prices held firm.

BERLIN, Sept. 14. -- Recovery on the Boerse, initiated at governmental suggestion by concerted intervention on the part of banks, continued today. It was supported by both professional and some public following. Gains of 2 per cent were the rule, but some specialties rose as much as 6 per cent.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Sept. 14 (AP). -- Behind the seven-hit pitching of Charley Perkins the Buffalo Bisons swept to their third successive victory over Baltimore, 3-0, tonight and advanced to the championship play-off finals, where they will face either Newark or Rochester.

Apartment rentals continued in volume yesterday. The Manhattan leasing centred in midtown, followed by uptown sections also providing quarters for tenants in the annual shift. Included were the following:

Randall Heads Sales Group. I.S. Randall, sales manager of Frosted Foods Corporation, yesterday was elected president of the Sales Executives Club of New York, Inc., at its annual meeting in the Hotel Roosevelt. Mr. Randall succeeds Alien Zoll, sales counselor, who headed the club since its organization last September.

Fishermen along the Atlantic Coast from the tip of Long Island to the Atlantic City sector were not over-optimistic yesterday regarding weather conditions which might prevail over the coming week-end.
PARIS, Sept. 14 (AP). -- The weekly statement of the Bank of France shows the following changes, in francs:
LONDON, Sept. 14 (AP). -- The weekly statement of the Bank of England shows the following changes in pounds sterling:

WASHINGTON, Sept. 14. -- The movement for repeal, which has, swept unchecked across twenty-nine States, was shown today by an unofficial tabulation to have piled up a total popular vote of nearly 3 to 1 for the end of constitutional prohibition, a result now officially possible on Dec. 5.

Excess reserves of the member banks of the Federal Reserve System reached a new record peak of approximately $700,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday, compared with the last high record of close to $635,000,000 in January. Deposits in the member banks are smaller than they were and consequently the reserve requirements are less, so that the reserves actually on hand tend to swell the excess figure.

CINCINNATI, Sept. 14 (AP). -- Scheduled to play two games, the Phillies and Reds splashed around in the rain long enough today for the visitors to win, 2 to 1, in seven innings. The game then was called after an hour's wait.

LONDON, Sept. 14. -- The unofficial inquiry into the burning of the Reichstag building opened here today with a statement by Paul Herz, former prominent Socialist member of the Reichstag, that Communists could not have set the building ablaze.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 (AP). -- The general level of wholesale prices was said by the Labor Department today to have shown no change for the week ended Sept. 9.

GREENWICH, Conn., Sept. 14. -- Miss Helen Hicks of the Lido Country Club, Long Beach, L.I., won the women's annual invitation golf tourney at the Greenwich Country Club today. She defeated Mrs. Charles Eastman of Wykagyl, former Westchester champion, by 5 and 4.
Small residential parcels in various communities comprised the larger part of the New Jersey realty turnover reported yesterday.

Prices of domestic corporation bonds were bid up briskly on the Stock Exchange yesterday in heavy dealings, and some sections of the foreign group pointed higher United States Government bonds, however, continued lower, the active issues losing 2-32 to 7-32 point, except the First Liberty 4 1/4s, which advanced on the presumption that the Treasury will not exercise its option to call the issue for payment on Dec. 15, 1933.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 14. -- In reply to pleas of independent motion-picture exhibitors for the right to buy quality productions on the same terms as producer-affiliated houses, leaders in the industry argued today that producers who owned theatres properly had priority.

SOUTHPORT, Conn., Sept. 14. -- Driving through a dripping wet and cold northeaster out on Long Island Sound, the sloop Kumon, owned and sailed by Kenneth H. McNeil, today captured the Atlantic Class championship for the Black Rock Yacht Club of Bridgeport.
Following its unprecedented rise from 58.5 for March to 89.4 in July, The Annalist index of business activity dropped to 84.0 (preliminary) for August, thus canceling 17 per cent of the rise.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 14. -- President Roosevelt has approved the creation of 335 new staff jobs for the Navy Department under the shipbuilding and naval store establishment program made possible by public works funds. Pending before the President for approval are an additional 175 similar positions for the department.

HARRISBURG, Pa., Sept. 14. -- Governor Pinchot canceled orders tonight which would have sent about 350 Pennsylvania National Guardsmen into the Fayette County soft coal strike fields, and instead ordered fifty State police into the area tomorrow.

The Casaranos -- nine of them -- got a $10 food ticket from the Emergency Home Relief Bureau last night after The World-Telegram had printed a statement from the mother that the family ticket had been withheld because she had testified before the citizens' "jury" investigating relief breakdown in the city.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 (AP). -- A sparkling three-run rally in the ninth inning today grave the league-leading Senators a 4-to-3 victory over the Tigers and Earl Whitehill, southpaw, his twenty-first pitching triumph.

A kind of semi-pamphlet, inside-coat-pocket size, which is the result of a hobby of Governor Joseph Garland Pollard of Virginia, is issued today by Thomas Y. Crowell Company. It is called, "A Connotary, Definitions Not Found in Dictionaries, Collected from the Sayings of the Wise and the Otherwise."

To the Editor of The New York Times: The stimulating speech made by former Governor Smith Monday morning stirred me so that I suddenly voted myself a committee of one to ask a dozen persons their views of the NRA plan. Accordingly, I asked: What do you think of the NRA? and received the following replies:

WASHINGTON, Sept. 14. (AP). -- Labor leaders were joined by one manufacturer in a demand for limited hours of operations of papermaking machines today in a hearing on a code of competition for the paper and pulp industry.
Big oaks from little acorns grow, and if the arboriculturist is a Chick Meehan they reach up to a place in the sun almost overnight.

OLD WESTBURY, L.I., Sept. 14. -- Members of the Brussels Griffons Club of America and the Pekingese Sleeve Dog Association of America held a combined specialty show today at Catawba Farm, the estate of Mrs. James M. Austin, who is president of both organizations.
NEW YORK. Mr. and Mrs. Walter Kobbe and Miss Evelyn Kobbe will be at the Blackstone for the season.

Domination of Japan by the military will wane in the next two or three years and liberalism will re-assert itself, Count M. Soyeshima, outstanding Japanese liberal, declared yesterday in an interview at the Biltmore.

ROSTOV-ON-DON, Sept. 14. -- If any one says the Soviet agrarian system in the North Caucasus has been unsuccessful, he has a tough little citizen of Turkish blood but Soviet citizenship, named Oglee-Abib, to reckon with.

Success of the industrial recovery program would result in a need for increased school expenditures, Dr. Eugene A. Colligan, new president of Hunter College, said yesterday at a luncheon meeting of the Brooklyn Rotary Club in the Hotel Bossert, Brooklyn.
Six Manhattan properties and seven Bronx parcels were bid in by plaintiffs in foreclosure actions yesterday.

To the Editor of The New York Times: As a Republican candidate for Alderman I have just received an inquiry from the Citizens Union as to my attitude regarding a reorganization of the Board of Aldermen into a smaller body with some form of proportional representation.

Beginning last Friday, in accordance with the President's executive order of Aug. 28, the Treasury has announced daily the price per ounce at which it would accept new gold from American mines. That price has varied between $29.62 and $29.10, as against the $20.67 per ounce which the Mint by law pays for coinage purposes.

CHICAGO, Sept. 14. -- The 1933 world's, series will open Tuesday, Oct. 3, at the park of the National League champions, presumably the New York Giants, with sell-outs expected for every game at the old price scale.
One of the most popular events of the polo season returns today with the fourteenth annual polo pony show of the National Polo Pony Society at the Meadow Brook Club in Westbury.

"MANDOA, MANDOA!" (Macmillan, $2.50) is such gorgeous, energetic satire that, in the course of reading it, one forgets to ask why it was written. It is so thoroughly amusing, and Miss Winifred Holtby, the author, writes with such verve, vigor and sustained comic invention that one only half perceives its final lack of aim. Miss Holtby herself appears to have had some hesitations, for she subtitles the book "a comedy of irrelevance."
Fifth Avenue has memories of parades such as no other street in the world has known:
F.H. LaGuardia, fusion candidate for Mayor, pledged an aggressive campaign yesterday at a "harmony luncheon" of fusion and Republican leaders at the Hotel Astor.

CAPE TOWN, South Africa, Sept. 14. -- The African native chieftain Tshekedi, who recently ordered a Briton, Phineas McIntosh, to be flogged, was suspended from his chieftainship today and banished from the territories of his tribe.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 14. -- Winning further victories in disputes between employes and employers, the National Labor Board announced today that it had settled three important strikes, those of the silk workers in New Jersey, Pennsylvania, New York and elsewhere; of the shoe workers in Brockton, Mass., and of the grain elevator operators and scoopers in Buffalo

BERLIN, Sept. 14. -- Age is the result of a constant bombardment of the human body by cosmic rays, according to a theory advanced by Professor Paul Kunze of Rostock and published in the scientific periodical, Research and Progress.

ISTANBUL, Sept. 14. -- Greece and Turkey, ten years ago the bitterest enemies, signed today at Angora a ten-year pact of non-aggression. The treaty was signed by the Greek and Turkish Premiers and Foreign Ministers.

The setting up of a permanent organization of the NRA for New York City under a deputy recovery administrator will be recommended to the Federal Government by Grover A. Whalen, chairman of the city's NRA.

NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 14. -- A tea was given today by Mrs. Nicholas Brown at Harbour Court in honor of Vice Admiral the Hon. Reginald A.R. Plunkett-Ernle-Erle-Drax, R.N., who is visiting Newport on H.M.S. Norfolk. Mrs. Drax shared the honors with her husband.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Without in any way attacking the desirability of such a "mental gymnasium" as Mr. Kettner proposes in his letter to THE TIMES, it is necessary to attack the scheme for such a "gymnasium" to develop character traits on the ground that such training cannot be accomplished by the means proposed.

CHICAGO, Sept. 14. -- A new "chemical tree of life" and the outlines of a new Eden in which man is to enter in the not too distant future, with chemistry acting as the gardener, was presented today before the Century of Progress meeting of the American Chemical Society by four of the world's outstanding chemists.
CHICAGO, Sept. 14. -- Playing for the second successive afternoon under climatic conditions scarcely conducive to perfection in baseball, the Giants today were again bowled over by the Cubs.

Grover A. Whalen, chairman of the NRA organization here, called a conference yesterday of employers and union representatives for this morning to discuss settlement of the underwear workers' strike, involving 25,000 employes, mostly girls, and affecting some 500 shops.

Raymond P. McNulty, counsel for the Long Island State Park Commission, has brought charges against Harry Levey, real estate man, of 1,457 Broadway, and his organization which is known as the Harry Levey Realties, Inc. This was made known yesterday by Robert Moses, president of the commission.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 14. -- Cotton consumed in the United States in August totaled 588,570 bales as compared with 404,497 in the same month last year, according to a survey made public today by the Department of Commerce. For the twelve months ending July 31 consumption totaled 6,135,525 bales as against 4,866,016 in the preceding twelve months.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 14. -- Bituminous coal operators and mine workers will agree upon a satisfactory NRA code and wage agreement within the next twenty-four hours, they told President Roosevelt tonight, and the President acquiesced.

Among the passengers due today on the North German Lloyd liner Bremen are Walter Buckner, vice president of the New York Life Insurance Company, with Mrs. Buckner; Geraldine Farrar, singer; Senator George F. Harding of Ohio, Judge Daniel F. Cohalan of New York, with Mrs. Cohalan, and Fernando Gonzales Roa, Mexican Ambassador to the United States.

BERLIN, Sept. 14. -- The opening in London of the international inquiry into the Reichstag fire, received with ridicule by the German newspapers, has also been formally protested by the German Government.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 14. -- Calling attention again to the executive order requiring persons possessing gold to file a return by Sept. 18, Attorney General Cummings disclosed today that Department of Justice lists contained names of 342 persons who refused to turn in gold.
Influential members of Tammany at last have awakened to the posibility of the defeat of Mayor John P. O'Brien for re-election.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 14. -- A three-fold credit program, which the administration hopes will rapidly expand credit facilities and finance activities under the National Recovery Act over the next six months, was made public today by Jesse H. Jones, chairman of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation.

Another decline in the total of bank clearings throughout the country is shown in the compilation by Dun Bradstreet, Inc., for the week ended on Wednesday. For twenty-one leading cities, clearings totaled $4,134,848,000, against $4,351,070,000 in the corresponding week last year, a drop of 5 per cent.

CHICAGO, Sept. 14. -- Recommendations for a permanent national transportation policy are expected to be forwarded tomorrow to Washington by a group of railroad men, shippers, steamship operators, bankers and waterway representatives who convened today at the Chicago Club.

CHICAGO, Sept. 14 (AP). -- Acceding to the petition of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, Federal Judge John P. Barnes today appointed a trustee to supervise reorganization of the Chicago Eastern Illinois Railway. He selected Charles M. Thomson, formerly judge of the Superior and Appellate Courts of Cook County, Illinois.

Another attack on the validity of the will of Mary E. Blodgett, philanthropist and daughter of the founder of the Fifth Avenue Bank, was foreshadowed yesterday when a third will made by her was filed in Surrogates' Court.

The Metropolitan Museum of Art will direct its educational program during the ensuing year toward high school students by giving illustrated lectures and exhibitions from the museum's collections in the city schools, it was announced yesterday by William Sloane Coffin, president of the institution.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 14. -- Secretary Ickes, as Administrator of the Oil Code, ordered today an investigation of reports that the Texas Corporation, one of the largest companies in the so-called independent group, has refused to give to the Planning and Coordination Committee information to which the committee was entitled under the provisions of the code.

Plans for fighting the city's tax on stock transfers and brokers' profits were discussed yesterday by the board of governors of the Association of Stock Exchange Firms, Frank R. Hope of Paine, Webber Co., president of the association, said that the entire tax problem had been turned over to the association's lawyers, Hornblower, Hornblower, Miller Boston.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 14. -- The daily average volume of Federal Reserve Bank credit outstanding during the week ended Sept. 13, as reported by the Federal Reserve banks, was $2,337,000,000, an increase of $33,000,000 compared with the preceding week and of $45,000,000, compared with the corresponding week in 1932.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 14. -- Morris Tremaine, New York State Controller, has been discussing with officials the possibility of Federal Reserve Banks' agreeing to rediscount short-term securities to protect municipal credit. He said that this probably would require legislation, although the Reserve Banks may now purchase such securities on a fifteen-day basis, but do not accord them a longer rediscount privilege.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 14. -- Chairman Harrison of the Senate Finance Committee, who yesterday urged a program of inflation, on President Roosevelt after a tour of the South, declared today that "if something is not done through rational currency inflation to raise commodity prices, the next Congress will repeal the President's discretionary powers, and make monetary inflation compulsory."

CAMDEN, N.J., Sept. 14 -- Arrested today for threatening a girl who had rejected his attentions, William Hartel, 38 years old, of Glendale, L.I., broke away from a police sergeant in Woodlynne, south of here, shot three men and fired a bullet into his own head before he finally was captured.

DITCHLING, England, Sept. 14 (AP). -- Frank Brangwyn, world-famous artist, who is doing a set of four huge murals for Rockefeller Center in New York, has encountered what he characterizes as the geatest puzzle of his artistic career.
CINCINNATI, Sept. 14. -- With the national amateur golf championship just two stages removed from the finish, only two golfers with established reputations are left.

CHICAGO, Sept. 14. -- The success of artificial fever as the antidote for formerly "incurable" paresis was described today to a section of the American Congress of Physical Therapy by Dr. Ralph H. Kuhns of the State Psychopathic Institute at Elgin, Ill.

CINCINNATI, Sept. 14. -- A player has to make a certain number of moves per hour in a chess championship, but in golf there is a more liberal spirit. Each contestant may set his own pace. Thus the quarter-final round in the national amateur championship at the Kenwood Country Club furnished some astonishing contrasts.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 (AP). -- An about-face on its policy toward milk marketing agreements was taken today by the Farm Administration with the announcement of a thirty-day trial period for future pacts.

BERLIN, Sept. 14. -- The government has appointed Dr. Paul Joseph Goebbels, the Minister of Popular Enlightenment and Propaganda, to the German disarmament conference delegation, which will be headed by Baron Constantin von Neurath, the Foreign Minister.

HAVANA, Sept. 14. -- This writer has visited a meeting of the Students Directorate, which, at least temporarily, is ruling Cuba, and he has sought to plumb the minds and get a clearer view of the ideas and aspirations of the members.

New York University became the owner yesterday of a faded old parchment. It is the first diploma issued by the university, and was returned for preservation in university archives on the one hundredth anniversary of its presentation to "Jas. Josephum Acheson, by particular virtue of his having passed in examination."

PARIS, Sept. 14. -- Pierre Cot, French Air Minister, arrived in Russia today just after former Premier Herriot's return from there. Today also Maurice Rossi and Paul Codos, holders of the world nonstop flight record, in their plane, the Joseph Lebrix, and Rene Couzinet in his big plane, which recently established a South Atlantic record, started for Moscow.

Mary Kalbron, 16 years old, of 401 1/2 East Seventieth Street, has never seen a motion picture. Brought up in the east side, she has been taught to use her time for work. Yesterday she received the silver cup of the New York Plant and Flower Guild for her garden in the community plots at Sixty-fifth Street and the East River.

HAIFA, Palestine, Sept. 14. -- More than 100,000 Arabs from Palestine, Trans-Jordan, Syria and even from as far distant as Iraq, gathered here before daybreak this morning to pay homage to the body of King Feisal of Iraq which arrived from Brindish Italy, aboard the British cruiser Dispatch.

Following the passage yesterday by the Board of Aldermen of the city's new $40,000,000 tax program, the Board of Estimate last night, at Samuel Untermyer's suggestion, voted to reduce the salaries of its own members to the 1929 level, putting the revised figures in the 1934 budget.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 (AP). -- Processing taxes on virtually every type of tobacco were levied today, effective Oct. 1, to finance the campaign for higher prices to growers.

CHICAGO, Sept. 14. -- The price peg was removed suddenly today from the Winnipeg grain markets, checking what had appeared for a few minutes at the opening of the Board of Trade here to be the development of another drastic upturn in prices.

Dr. John E. Daugherty, hospital consultant and former executive director of the Jewish Hospital in Brooklyn, was appointed superintendent of the Jamaica Hospital at a special meeting of the board of trustees in the hospital yesterday.

Thursday, Sept. 14, 1933. Business in money was small and chiefly of a routine character, with quotations for all classifications unchanged from Wednesday. Stock Exchange call loans remained at 3/4 of one per cent, while Street trades went at 1/2.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The scrapping of the Day Line steamer Washington Irving is reviewed in the day's news with regret by thousands who enjoyed the Hudson River trip by daylight on this commodious boat. The vessel was not in service long enough, however, to become as well known and popular as the Hendrick Hudson is now or as the Mary Powell was years ago.

To the roll of winners of the Ladies' Handicap, which goes back to 1868, Mrs. P.A.B. Widener's White Lies yesterday added her name at Belmont Park. Through a drizzle and over a sloppy track the 3-year-old daughter of John P. Grier and Gossamer led from start to finish to score by three lengths.

The National League pennant race tightened yesterday as the Giants lost to the Cubs, the Chicago team taking undisputed possession of second place while the Pirates were idle. The Giants' advantage was reduced to five and a half games over the Cubs and sis over the third-place Pittsburgh club.

Artists and Emergency. When the depression clouds have lifted around New York they will leave a number of churches, synagogues, university buildings and other public institutions better off than before in respect to beauty.

W. Kingsland Macy, chairman of the Republican State Committee, showed that he was in complete control of that body yesterday, when it met at the National Republican Club and nominated Judge Leonard C. Crouch, a Democrat, for Associate Judge of the Court of Appeals.

UNIONTOWN, Pa., Sept. 14. -- Fifteen striking soft coal miners and a deputy sheriff were wounded by shots today as riots broke out at the Gates, Edenborn and Foote-dale mines of the, H.C. Frick Coke Company. More than a score of others were injured by beatings, stoning or knife wounds.

We don't know that Mr. OWEN D. YOUNG had any part in Wednesday's parade, but his radio address in defense of the recovery program was worth a whole division of marchers. In general, his plea was for self-restraint. It is better not to pitch expectations too high.

At a ceremony yesterday on the steamer American Banker of the American Merchant Line Captain Giles Stedman, youthful master of the liner, received the Navy Cross in recognition of the heroic rescue of twenty-two men on the British freighter Exeter City in January.

Stocks displayed quiet strength yesterday as business was resumed after the interruption occasioned on the day before by the NRA demonstration. Transactions on the Stock Exchange involved a total of 2,896,000 shares, compared with 735,090 shares in the two-hour market of Wednesday.
"Heat Lightning," by Leon Abrams and George Abbott, will have its Broadway premiere this evening at the Booth Theatre. Jean Dixon and Robert Gleckler will have the leading roles.

RYE, N.Y., Sept. 14. -- With a steady rain beating down on the course, sixty-eight senior golfers competing for the United States title found the elements a decided obstacle at the Apawamis links today.

WARWICK, R.I., Sept. 14. -- D. H. Atwater's Moonshine added another first place in the Atlantic Coast championship series of the International Star Class today and increased her lead in total points over Fleet Star II. The latter boat finished fifth but still holds second place in the series.

From the quarterly instalment of income taxes, due today, the Federal Treasury expects to receive about $135,000,000. This is less than the September payment last year. Despite the higher rates imposed by Congress, revenue from income taxes continues to make a sorry showing.

PARIS, Sept. 14. -- In preparation for next week's disarmament conversations, the French Cabinet this evening gave long consideration to its position, with special attention to the question of control of armaments and definition of the French plan, for it is felt that the first essential step is to obtain agreement among the European nations as to the measures that are to be taken to insure that no country can increase its armaments secretly.

CHICAGO, Sept. 14. -- The scramble for Chicago Stock Exchange seats by out-of-town brokers sent the price of memberships to $9,900 today, more than double the highest price offered three days ago. Later in the day $14,000 was the lowest price at which seats were offered.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Sept. 14. -- T. Darrington Semple of Armonk, who had been unable to qualify for the office of Westchester County Treasurer when he had been sworn in last week because of his inability to produce the required bond of $200,000, obtained the bond today.

On the heels of the enactment of the Tammany-Untermyer tax program by the Board of Aldermen, a revolt of property-owners against the 50 per cent increase in water rates was urged last night at a meeting of the Council of Real Estate Associations of New York.
CHICAGO, Sept. 14. -- Jack Sharkey, former heavyweight champion of the world, hits the come-back trail tomorrow night by braving the flying fists of Chicago's King Levinsky.
HAVANA, Sept. 14. -- A proclamation containing statutes under which the revolutionary government will provisionally govern Cuba was issued this afternoon by President Grau San Martin and his Cabinet.

For the first time in nineteen months, or since January, 1932, sales of new life insurance were greater than in the corresponding months of the preceding year, according to the August report of the Association of Life Insurance Presidents to the United States Department of Commerce.
STAMFORD, Conn., Sept. 14. -- Because she cut up the will she executed on July 2, 1923, Mrs. Caroline Robertson of Coscob was adjudged today to have died intestate.

With all Mayor O'BRIEN'S talk about the needs of unemployment relief, it is strange that he has hardly lifted more than his little finger to tap one source of funds. Before Congress adjourned it set aside $3,300,000,000 for public works. Slowly this vast sum is being distributed through Federal bureaus and the States.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 14. -- Oral discussions, described by State Department officials as "guarded," were carried on here a few weeks ago between Japanese representatives and United States Government officials over the question of policy in extending financial aid to China.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 14. -- Filing of twelve additional registration statements under the 1933 Securities Act, bringing the amount of securities filed to about $218,000,000, was announced today by the Federal Trade Commission. The new list follows:

Every once in a while somebody becomes elegiac over the decay of letter-writing and looks back to the happier age when telegraph, telephone and typewriter were not. Yet Grays and Walpoles, Cowpers, Byrons are still practicing their delicate art among us. Posterity will read their correspondence.

The Appellate Division of the Supreme Court, called in special session yesterday to hear appeals from decisions in primary ballot disputes between Republican and Tammany factions, upheld the decision of Supreme Court Justice Irwin Untermyer striking out the names of forty-three pro-Koenig candidates for county committee in the Third Assembly District.
