C.B. Ames, chairman of the Texas Corporation, denied yesterday a statement attributed to E.B. Reeser, a member of the planning and coordination committee of the oil administration, that his company had refused to submit operating and cost data that the oil board had requested informally.
To the Editor of The New York Times: In your issue of today you publish in the Letters to the Editor an epistle by "Dun My Part."

UTICA, N.Y., Sept. 14. -- A little girl in a pretty frock, who sobbed out a plea with her arms about the neck of a Supreme Court justice while all the court looked on, had temporarily won her case tonight.

DUBLIN, Sept. 14. -- Dr. P.J. McGintley, coroner at Gordatsork, County Donegal, today found that Professor Arthur Kingsley Porter, archaeologist and Professor of Fine Arts at Harvard University, probably had died from a "misadventure."

Details of the offer of the Standard Oil Company of California for the acquisition of the Richfield Oil Company of California, which has been in receivership almost three years, have been completed and are expected to be announced early next week.

Joseph Smith, president of the National Association of American Seamen, Inc., said last night that the demands of the International Seamen's Union for higher wages on ships was "ridiculous." and that the proposed scale was so high the steamship companies could not pay it.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 (AP) -- Reiterating a determination to avoid intervention in Cuba at any cost except serious threats to American lives, the administration kept anxious watch today over sporadic disturbances in widespread parts of the island.

There are "threats of the removal by government of the control of finance and financial provision from private hands," Henry Bruere, president of the Bowery Savings Bank declared yesterday, addressing representatives of more than 500 banks, trust companies and investment houses at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel at the closing session of the Financial Advertisers Association.
The New Yorker Theatre on West Fifty-third Street, opened in 1927 as a new departure in grand opera houses, is to give way to a restaurant and amusement centre, it was announced yesterday.

LONG BRANCH, N.J., Sept. 14. -- Jail sentences were imposed upon five members of the Amalgamated Clothing Workers of America and the organization was fined $1,000 by Vice Chancellor Maja Leon Berry here today for violation of a Chancery Court order which restricted picketing at the Sigmund Eisner Clothing Company plant at Red Bank.

An application by the New York Shoe Repairers Association for an injunction restraining the Shoe and Leather Workers Industrial Union from recruiting members and seeking recognition, came before Supreme Court Justice McGeehan yesterday. After a brief argument the case was adjourned until next Wednesday to enable the union to prepare its defense.

TICONDEROGA, N.Y., Sept. 14. -- A proposal that the State provide funds with which to finance local or county historical museums and that an authority be set up to protect buildings and other properties of historical value was made here today as the New York State Historical Association's thirty-fourth annual meeting got under way.

LONDON, Sept. 14. -- Business again was brisk on the Stock Exchange today. The general tone was cheerful, although most prices reacted in the afternoon owing to lack of fresh support. An exception was the international group, which was stronger on New York advices.

State Attorney General Bennett's recent request for a transcript of the statements made last month before the New York County Grand Jury by George Z. Medalie, United States Attorney, and Chief Justice Frederic Kernochan of Special Sessions in an investigation of racketeering was granted yesterday by General Sessions Judge Cornelius F. Collins.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 14. -- Muscle Shoals rates to domestic users of electricity were announced today by the Tennessee Valley Authority, and except for a few municipally-owned plants, are understood to be the lowest ever offered to any community in the United States.

There was a sharp Increase yesterday in market activity everywhere. It was most pronounced on the Stock Exchange, where impatient speculative operators resumed business after the restraint of the day before, when trading was cut short by the NRA half holiday.

The Federal Reserve Bank announced yesterday the withdrawal of $16,900 gold for export to France, reducing the monetary gold stock of the United States by that amount, as metal earmarked here for foreign account was not correspondingly changed.
The text of Samuel Untermyer's letter urging general salary reductions for city officials follows:

CHICAGO, Sept. 14 (AP). -- French Knight revelled in the muddy going at Lincoln Fields today and captured the fifth race by a neck over Journey's End. Hoops finished, third in the six-furlong feature. Seven ran and the time was 1:13 4-5.

Millions of dollars of school funds re lost annually due to ineffiiency, waste and maladministration by those charged with the custory of these funds, Dr. Fred F. Beach, research worker at Teachers College, Columbia Univerity, declared in his survey on "The Custody of School Funds," made public yesterday.

BOMBAY, Sept. 14. -- Mahatma Gandhi today declared a year's truce with the British Government, promising not to engage in civil disobedience or otherwise defy the authorities until Aug. 3, 1934. This is the end of the one-year sentence imposed on him last month and from which he was later released after having fasted six days.

Weather Cuts Retail Volume. Inclement weather served to reduce substantially the expected volume of retail sales during the week, store executives here reported yesterday. Gains were noted on Monday and Tuesday, but declines under a year ago were quite general on the other days of the week.
CHICAGO, Sept. 15 (AP). -- Compared to the number of new automobiles financed, the business of selling used cars on the instalment plan has experienced a decided decline in 1933.

The terms of the settlement, hitherto not made public, of the suit last year of A.C. Blumenthal against the Paramount Publix Corporation, now bankrupt, were revealed yesterday in testimony before Henry K. Davis, Federal referee in bankruptcy, at 140 Nassau Street.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Sept. 15. -- The Rochester Red Wings went one up on the Newark Bears in their International League play-off series tonight by capturing the third game played under the floodlights at Red Wing Stadium, 5 to 3.

Announcement of the completion of the fusion organization is expected either today or tomorrow, as the result of a conference held yesterday afternoon at the fusion campaign headquarters in the Paramount Building.

SUMMIT, N.J., Sept. 15. -- Miss Edythe Gwynne Pearson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Reginald F. Pearson of 316 Summit Av., was introduced to society tonight at a dance at the Short Hills Club. She is the season's first debutante. Several hundred persons were present.

Northeast winds, whipping up a long ground swell along the Atlantic Coast, apparently have driven most species of fish to cover. Until the wind hauls around and the swell flattens out, anglers may as well sit at their comfortable firesides and contemplate future operations, according to most of the boat captains who reported yesterday.

ATLANTA, Sept. 15 (AP). -- Pryor Bowen, 17 years old, was found guilty by a jury today of participating with W.R. Delinski in the kidnapping of John K. Otttey Sr., president of the First National Bank of Atlanta. Bowen was sentenced to one year on the chain gang.
GENEVA, Sept. 15. -- The idea of electing Austria this year to a seat in the League of Nations Council, launched a few days ago in the European press, seems to be making progress behind the scenes.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Sept. 15. -- Yale put a football squad of ninetysix on the field today at the opening practice of the season. The session was held on Anthony Thompson Field in a light drizzle, following a heavy morning rain which drove seventy candidates indoors for the opening organization meeting.

DETROIT, Sept. 15.-Employment of 5,000 war veterans by the Ford Motor Company was authorized today by Harry H. Bennett, personnel director. Beginning Monday Rex Humphrey, commander of the Wayne County Council of the American Legion, will hire 300 veterans a day until the quota has been completed.
NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 15. -- Mr. and Mrs. Robert D. Huntington gave a dinner tonight.
WARWICK, R.I., Sept. 15. -- Fleet Star II today won the fourth Atlantic Coast star class championship race. The Great South Bay entry scored by 2 minutes and 35 seconds.

LONDON, Sept. 15. -- The German Government's version of the burning of the Reichstag building was described as a "fairy tale" today during the second day's session of the unofficial international commission, which is inquiring into the fire.

Three more of the American track and field stars who have been touring Europe returned to the United States yesterday. Joe McCluskey of Fordham and the New York A.C., Johnny Morriss of Louisiana and Ivan Fuqua of Indiana arrived aboard the North German Lloyd liner Bremen.

Some of the bonds issued by S.W. Straus Co. at $100 each have been purchased and sold in the last months for $10 and $15 by the Straus Securities Company, according to testimony given yesterday by William R. Gillespie, treasurer of both concerns.

CHICAGO, Sept. 15. -- A new scientific and painless test for drunkenness, and also the first scientific proof that 3.2 per cent beer is nonintoxicating, were presented here today before the closing sessions of the Century of Progress meeting of the American Chemical Society.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 15. -- The National Labor Board today summoned officials of the Sigmund Eisner Company of Red Bank, N.J., to appear here next Monday to explain the delay in effecting settlement of a strike at that plant.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 15 (AP). -- Admission that he permitted his personally selected real estate agent to reap "huge" profits "for services rendered" in the assembling of school sites during the last ten years came today from Edward Merchant, business manager of the Board of Education.

The American Steamship Owners Association, whose members have been in conference almost daily for several weeks working on a code for the industry, have the agreement virtually completed and probably will submit it to General Hugh S. Johnson within a few days.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 15. -- The Treasury today issued $174,905,500 in 1/4 per cent nine-month certificates of indebtedness, exchanging them for a similar amount of 1 1/4 per cent certificates which matured.

The tradition that MOHAMMED'S coffin rests suspended in midair must invite fresh credence among his followers who behold the coffin of King FEISAL, son of the sometime ruler of the sacred city of the Prophet, borne between earth and sky from Haifa back to Baghdad.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 15 (AP). -- Firing the opening gun of the collegiate gridiron season. Duquesne, displaying a reliable air game, tonight defeated Waynesburg by 18 to 6, beneath the flood lights of Forbes Field.

To the Editor of The New York Times: If the administration of the low-cost housing loan provisions in the National Industrial Recovery Act is to be nationally uniform, a definite maximum of rentals constituting low-cost housing cannot be applied to suit all communities.

CINCINNATI, Sept. 15 (AP). -- Doubles by Bottomley and Adams in the eighth grave the Reds two runs and a 3-to-1 triumph over the Phillies in the second game of a double-header today after being blanked, 4 to 0, in the opening contest.

The movement to convince Mayor John P. O'Brien and John F. Curry, leader of Tammany, that the Mayor should be withdrawn as a candidate for re-election will await the result of the primary election next Tuesday, it was learned yesterday.

The bondholders' committee for State of Arkansas highway and toll bridge bonds, headed by William L. De Bost, president of the Union Dime Savings Bank of New York City, announced yesterday that it had filed an application in the United States District Court in Little Rock, Ark., for an injunction to restrain the State Treasurer from making any further disbursements of the revenue heretofore pledged for the service on these bonds.

The history of Cuban revolutions shows that control of Havana does not always mean control of the whole island. This is unlike France, where the rest of the nation has usually followed meekly the revolutionary lead of Paris. In Cuba the interior provinces and Oriente have frequently been the starting point of seditious activities.

BERLIN, Sept. 15. -- The upward movement on the Boerse inspired by the government continued today, but began to show signs of slowing up. Cautious professionals cashed in their profits. Nevertheless the list registered numerous gains up to 2 per cent and a few specialties rose as much as 6 per cent.

PARIS, Sept. 15. -- Foreign Minister Paul-Boncour submitted today to the full Cabinet, presided over by President Lebrun, his report on the position France will take at the forthcoming disarmament conversations.

CHICAGO, Sept. 15., -- The world-wide boycott being organized against German goods in protest against Nazi persecution of Jews will be developed in Chicago at once. This announcement was made last night by Max M. Korshak, master in chancery and a member of the council of fifteen which will direct the nation-wide organization of the boycott.

All the markets were under selling pressure yesterday and prices were generally lower at the close. The one important exception, among the commodities, was cotton, which retained about half of an early $1 a bale advance.
DETROIT, Sept. 15 (AP). -- If there is anything in the outlook for the automobile industry that is in any respect adverse, the producers and distributers are keeping it very much under cover.
PITTSBURGH, Sept. 15 (AP). -- Staging five-run parades in both the third and fourth innings, the Braves trounced Pittsburgh, 10 to 1, today in the second game of their series.

State Attorney General John J. Bennett Jr. announced yesterday that he would appear before the New York County grand jury on Monday morning in connection with the investigation he began last week into charges of alliances between politicians and racketeers.

The Health Department will utilize a new weapon, the recently announced precipitated and redissolved diphtheria immunization toxoid, in an intensive immunization campaign in the Bronx and Queens for five weeks, beginning Monday. Health Commissioner Shirley W. Wynne announced yesterday that the Bronx and Queensboro County Medical Societies would join in the campaign, the object of which was the immunization of all children in the two boroughs.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 15. -- Declaring that there had been no real expansion of credit and currency through steps thus far taken by the administration, Chairman Fletcher of the Senate's Banking and Currency Committee today urged the president to make use of an issue of Treasury notes provided in the Thomas inflation amendment.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I was interested in a Knoxville dispatch to THE TIMES headed "Tennessee Project Held Hate Yardstick," in which David E. Lilienthal, member of the Tennessee Valley Authority, was quoted as saying: "We must develop methods of cost accounting to learn what is a fair return for power."

An easier undertone in time money, without, however, any extensive demand for accommodation, was the only incident of an otherwise quiet session. A little over-the-year money at 3/4 was done. On the Stock Exchange, the call loan rate held at three-fourths of 1 per cent, while Street trades went at 1/2.

PEIPING, Saturday, Sept. 16. -- The inhabitants of the town of Kalgan were thrown into a panic Thursday when Japanese airplanes flew over dropping leaflet warnings from the Japanese military accusing Sung Che-yuan, the Governor of Charhar, of violating the Tangku truce and warning that unless Chinese troops withdrew from Kuyuan the Japanese intended aerial bombardments of Kalgan.

To the Editor of The New York Times: As THE TIMES pointed out in a recent editorial, the primary system of nominating, candidates has not proved to be successful in eliminating those who would serve the utility interests and others who seek to influence legislative bodies.

PARIS, Sept. 15. -- Wall Street's rumor today that France was about to go off the gold standard caused the Ministry of Finance officials either to smile tolerantly or to frown and shrug their shoulders. Not only could no confirmation be had here but nobody could understand what possible excuse there might be for the rumor's invention, with the reconvening of the French Parliament still a month away.

SALEM, N.H., Sept. 15. -- Jockey Jack Westrope scored a triple at Rockingham Park today, including among his winners Mrs. Clyde Phillips's Marcasite, which captured the featured Lawrence Telegram Purse. This brought his total of victorious mounts to 217 for 1933.

BERLIN, Sept. 15. -- The German Statistical Office today announced an improvement in Germany's foreign trade that had raised her surplus of exports over imports from 25,100,000 marks [currently about $8,910,000] in July to 65,700,000 marks [about $24,323,000] in August.

CINCINNATI, Sept. 15. -- Radio waves so short they once were looked upon as useless for communication were used by The Associated Press today to report the national amateur golf championship at the Kenwood Country Club.

Toward midnight Wednesday, when Lieutenant Tom Walsh had finished scratching the last entry of his tour in the blotter at the West Thirtieth Street station, a peculiar noise at the back window made him cock his ears.

Mainly because of the city's financial troubles, which have brought to a virtual halt the new sub-way construction program, the Board of Transportation has asked for only $2,599,057 to cover salaries and expenses in 1934, contrasted with its revised request for $4,398,852 in 1933.

With the announcement of its rate schedule for municipal and domestic consumers of Muscle Shoals power the Tennessee Valley Authority has taken the first step to develop that "yardstick" which, like the convenient ruler on dad's desk, is to serve as both a measure and a switch.
U. S. Department of Agriculture. Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices at New York:

VIENNA, Sept. 15. -- An emphatic pronouncement against fascism as a governmental system for Austria was made today in a newspaper article by Vice Chancellor Winkler, head of the Farmers' party, which supports the Dollfuss government.

TICONDEROGA, N. Y., Sept. 15 -- A resolution petitioning Congress to authorize and make appropriations for a sesquicentennial celebration in 1937 of the adoption of the Federal Constitution along lines similar to the observance of the George "Washington bicentennial was adopted at the business session of the New York State Historical Association here today.

Heavy selling of public utility stocks and bonds occurred on the security markets yesterday following the announcement by the Tennessee Valley Authority of future electric rates in the Muscle Shoals area. Leading shares declined from fractions to 3 1/2 points under active selling pressure, while bonds were 1/2 to 4 5/8 points lower.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 15. -- Returning to the Treasury after a long absence because of illness, Secretary Woodin said today that the finances of the government had greatly improved and that there was a real chance that the budget would be balanced for the current fiscal year.

YONKERS, N.Y., Sept. 15. -- Two young gunmen escaped here today with a $1,900 payroll from 75 South Broadway. The robbery took place in the heart of the city's business section, across the street from the Yonkers Public Library, but, although South Broadway is a main artery and part of the Albany Post Road, the "getaway," believed to have been made by motor, attracted no attention.

Boards of Estimate are but parvenus. An alderman or ealdorman bears an ancient Anglo-Saxon title. Properly, he is a lord lieutenant, an earl of high degree. However much time has abated his historical dignity, he has not forgotten it. Members of the Board of Estimate may shave their pay.

Papers reserving the designation "National Stock Exchange" were filed in Trenton, N. J., yesterday by counsel for a group of New York brokers who contemplate opening a new exchange in Newark to escape the New York City tax on stock transactions.

MAMARONECK, N.Y., Sept. 15. -- Neither rain nor a chilling northeaster kept thirty-three golfers from their appointed rounds today in the twenty-first annual New York A.C. championship golf tournament at the Winged Foot Club.

An appraisal yesterday of the estate of William Colgate, retired business man, who died March 7, 1932, at the age of 92 years, showed that twenty-two public institutions and organizations received $1,936,886, of which $331,766, or 30 per cent of the residue, went to Colgate University at Hamilton, N.Y.
Labor disputes continued to occupy the attention of the local NRA organization yesterday as efforts were continued to settle pending strikes and iron out difficulties between employers and employes.
Many Prosperity Ailments. One sign of returning prosperity is when heads of families begin to abandon their wives and children in larger numbers.

HAVANA, Sept. 15. -- An antiAmerican mass meeting was held tonight in the National Theatre to protest against "Yankee imperialism and intervention." Most of the 4,000 present were Negro laborers and lower class unemployed.

TORONTO, Sept. 15 (AP). -- Justice W. H. Wright ruled today that Martin J. Insull, former Chicago public utilities operator, could not appeal from a judgment refusing appointment of a commission to hear witnesses in Chicago in connection with attempts to extradite him.

PRAGUE, Sept. 15. -- A sensation was caused here today by publication in a Nationalist newspaper of a letter allegedly addressed by Papal Nuncio Ciriaci to Father Hlinka, leader of the Slovakian Autonomy party, complaining of the way he had been treated by the Czech Government.

An early advance of approximately 20 points In prices on the Cotton Exchange was followed yesterday by moderate reactions under realizing and Southern selling. The offerings were absorbed on declines of about 17 to 18 points, however, and prices were steady in the late trading.

Encouraged by the high prices bid by municipal bankers for new issues of State and municipal bonds in the last fortnight, communities which had delayed their financing programs are now hastily scheduling new issues for award. Nest week thirty communities in various parts of the country will offer new bonds in the amount of $17,239,413, compared with this week's revised total of $5,480,038 and with the weekly average for the year to date of 512,971,269.

PETER PIPER picked a peck of pickled peppers -- according to ancient history -- but Sidney W. Noyes Jr. simply picked a prostrate pear and an awful fate overtook him. The pear-picking incident cost him a hole in his quarter-final championship golf match with Max Marston and ultimately he lost by that narrow margin.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 15. -- The Bureau of Navigation issued the following orders today, dated Sept. 13:

Aside from the rather violent advance of foreign currencies against the dollar, there was little of interest for Wall Street yesterday in the action of the various markets. It was regarded as something of a phenomenon that the stock market should decline on the day when the dollar was sinking to its lowest level since the gold embargo was first applied.

From $50,000,000 to $75,000,000 further credit is being sought by the Soviet Government from the Reconstruction Finance Corporation for additional purchases of American commodities through the Amtorg Trading Corporation in the plan under negotiation between the two agencies, it became known yesterday.
NEW YORK. Mr. and Mrs. James Rockwell Sheffield will leave the Plaza today for their home at 45 East Sixtyseventh Street.

YOKOHAMA, Sept. 15 (AP). -- Toshio Shiratori, the man who made Japan's "Foreign Office spokesman" famous, sailed today for his new diplomatic post in the Scandinavian countries by way of the United States.

Purchase of a site in Garden City, L.I., for a new branch to be operated there by the Best Co. department store, was reported yesterday. The property, a vacant plot of about 35,000 square feet at the northwest corner of Stewart and Franklin Avenues, was acquired from the Royal Indemnity Company through the Cross Brown Company.

CHICAGO, Sept. 15. -- The grain markets on the Board of Trade fluctuated erratically today, but the trade had sufficient confidence in predictions of inflation of the currency to take the buying side on all the dips. The close found wheat at the same level as the previous day, while corn was 3/8 to 1/2 cent a bushel higher.

Relentless rain, accompanied by an unseasonable chill, wrought havoc with sports events over a wide area yesterday. Postponements were wholesale as the downpour made mudholes of playing fields. Even that hardy adventurer -- the golfer -- was chased to cover.

RYE, N.Y., Sept. 15. -- Raleigh W. Lee of Columbus, Ohio, captured the senior golf championship of the United States today when none of the competitors in the second section of the field threatened his lead.

BAGHDAD, Sept. 15. -- King Feisal of Iraq was buried today in the new royal tomb in the grounds of the Parliament House amid scenes such as have not been known at the funeral of any previous Moslem monarch.
To the Editor of The New York Times: Samuel Untermyer is quoted in THE NEW YORK TIMES as follows:

WASHINGTON, Sept. 15. -- The master code for the retail stores is delayed in NRA machinery partly because of a "terrific difference of opinion," but chiefly because General Johnson has had no chance to review it, the Administrator said today, indicating that completion of the code would require a week.

The electric companies of the Consolidated group were directed yesterday by the Public Service Commission, to show the actual cost and details of the employment of 250 of the 2,100 additional employes contemplated by the code under which the seven companies are operating.

A drastic reduction in executive expenses was decreed for the Denver Rio Grande Western Railroad by the Reconstruction Finance Corporation in return for a loan of $950,000, it was disclosed yesterday. In addition, the government exacted a pledge that the management would observe "all lawful orders of the Federal Coordinator of Railroads."

The dollar declined yesterday to the lowest mark made since the gold standard was abandoned, as all foreign currencies rose briskly in the exchange market and the price of gold was raised at the Federal Reserve Banks. Based on quotations for French francs, the dollar declined to 67.43 cents gold and closed at 67.49 cents, down 1.03 cents for the day.
Two parcels taken over by mortgagees were included in the New Jersey realty conveyances reported yesterday.

The State Alcoholic Beverage Control Board announced yesterday afternoon that no more applications for the sale of beer would be received. It also revealed that more than 400 restaurant operators who paid about $80,000 in fees had surrendered their licenses because of insufficient business. Virtually all asked for a refund of their fees.

PRINCETON, N.J., Sept. 15. -- A heavy rain drove the Princeton football squad indoors for its first day of practice today and forced the postponement of the scrimmage which Head Coach Fritz Crisler had expected to hold in the afternoon.

WASHINGTON, Saturday, Sept. 16. -- An NRA code for the soft coal industry was approved late last night by the committee of bituminous operators and miners conferring with Hugh S. Johnson, the Recovery Administrator.

CHICAGO, Sept. 15. -- The gallant last stand of the Cubs to retain their laurels as champions of the National League just about had the props knocked out from under it today as the Giants stormed their way to a dazzling pair of triumphs.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 (AP). -- Employment in the cotton textile industry from March to September increased by 145,515 workers, George A. Sloan president of the Cotton Textile Institute, reported today to General Johnson, Recovery Administrator.

PATERSON, N.J., Sept. 15. -- Signs that pointed to early settlement of the broadsilk and dyers' strikes were swept away here today. Representatives of the 8,000 broadsilk strikers in the Paterson district voted to continue the strike and to picket any shops which try to open Monday under a five-weeks truce, the terms of which were arranged by conference committees of Strikers and manufacturers at Washington.

KHARKOV, U.S.S.R, Sept. 15. Here, too, in the Ukraine the Kremlin has won the battle with the peasants. The harvest is so good that grain elevators, depots and delivery points are overcrowded to bursting.

By order of Mary L. Gibbons, director of the Home Relief Bureau, Mateo Casarano, head of a family of nine, living at 348 East 104th Street, was dropped from the relief rolls yesterday after investigators for the bureau had ascertained that Casarano was employed at a fruit and vegetable store at 1,996 Broadway at a salary of $10 a week.

CARSON CITY, Nov., Sept. 15 (AP).-- A former cowboy who rose to a position of such wealth and political influence that he came to dominate an entire State will tell the Federal court here tomorrow that he is now about broke.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 15. -- The elimination of child labor by the National Recovery Administration has taken out of employment about 100,000 children, most of whom would now enter the public schools, Dr. George F. Zook, Commissioner of Education, today told the National Council of State Superintendents and Commissioners of Education.
CHICAGO, Sept. 15. -- New methods for the treatment of hay fever, which may also aid goitre and asthma sufferers, and of erysipelas were revealed today at the American Congress of Physical Therapy.

The executive committee of the Chamber of Commerce of the State of New York made public a report yesterday expressing its opposition to "the predominance of members of war veterans' organizations" on the boards of review which pass upon the elimination of presumptive cases from the pension rolls.

PARIS, Sept. 15. -- Quotations on the Bourse were irregular today. For most part quotations remained steady, but isolated groups, particularly rentes, which improved, and electrical stocks, which dropped, showed sharp variations. Electrical utilities lost ground because of a report that the government was planning to ask them to reduce rates in order to facilitate deflationary measures it has in view.

CAPE TOWN, South Africa, Sept. 15. -- All through South Africa the outcry continued today over the suspension of Acting Chief Tshekedi of the Bamangawato tribe and his banishment by order of a British court for having ordered the flogging of a white British subject.

LONDON, Saturday, Sept. 16. -- A semi-official hint was expressed by The London Times tonight that Great Britain would take no action on Germany's secret rearmament in coming weeks, no matter what might be revealed in the coming Anglo-French, conversations in Paris.

The belief of many economists that a turn in the business cycle came last year rather than during recent months finds further support in a dispatch to THE TIMES from Geneva yesterday. It summarized a new report prepared by the economic intelligence section of the League of Nations.

Maurice A. Stephenson, budget director, cut $30,930 yesterday from the budget of the Board of Aldermen, dispensing with eight sergeants-at-arms and several other positions in response to the recommendations of Samuel Untermyer. At the same time members of the Board of Aldermen filled the City Hall corridors with their protests against the Untermyer proposal to cut their salaries from $5,000 to $2,000 a year.

Recent accessions at the Metropolitan Museum of Art include a number of objects of Far Eastern art, the bequest of Edward G. Kennedy, whose collection of cloisonne, presented to the museum several years ago, is considered one of the finest in the world.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 (AP). -- Preparatory to an appeal to President Roosevelt to call for the free coinage of silver, Senator Pittman, Democrat, of Nevada, is making a study of the Inflation powers given to the Executive under the Farm Relief law.

Local NRA headquarters are being flooded with complaints from manufacturers unable to get bank credit though they are swamped, in some cases, with the largest number of orders in their history, it was revealed yesterday by Grover A. Whalen, local NRA chairman.

Title to additional parcels of land in Manhattan, the Bronx and Queens needed for the Triborough Bridge was vested In the city yesterday. It was expected that the Board of Estimate would adopt a resolution to vest title in the remainder of the needed parcels on Monday.

BOMBAY, Sept. 15. -- The confusion regarding the All-India Nationalist Congress party's policy was aggravated by the publication today of letters that passed between Pandit Jawaharlal Nehru and Mahatma Gandhi.

In the Drapers' Summer School at Oxford an authority on fashion came very close to telling students of the retail business why the mode is so unstable. The young men must have been all agog when he said: "It would be a "mistake to imagine that fashions "caught on just by chance."

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Sept. 15. -- With weather unprecedented for the opening of football practice on Soldiers Field, Harvard's coaches today were able to stage the stiffest initial program a Harvard squad ever has known.

Miss Marie Patricia Cahill, a niece of Cardinal Hayes, has entered the novitiate at the Convent of Mount St. Vincent, at Mount-St.-Vincent-on the Hudson, N.Y., to prepare to become a Sister of Charity. Miss Cahill is the daughter of Mrs. Anastasia Cahill of Ozone Park, Queens, a sister of the Cardinal.
HOLLYWOOD, Sept. 15 (AP). -- Adolph Zukor, president of Paramount-Publix, was in the Cedars of Lebanon Hospital here today suffering with gastro-enteritis.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 UP). -- Theodore A. Walters of Idaho, First Assistant Secretary of the Interior, was understood authoritatively today to be seriously considering resigning as a protest against the way the department is being run.

If the local drama keeps improving by arithmetical progression we may have a good play in this town before the snow sets in. "Heat Lightning," which flickered for three acts at the Booth last evening, falls a good bit short of cash customer's perfection.

CHICAGO, Sept. 15 (AP). -- Two New York fur dealers and a Chicagroan, detained today after the seizure of five trunks containing $45,000 worth of alleged stolen furs, disclaimed ownership of the shipment.

COLUMBUS, O., Sept. 15 (AP). -- Scoring a lone run in the last half of the ninth inning, the Columbus Red Birds defeated the Minneapolis Millers, 3 to 2, tonight in the third game of the play-off for the American Association pennant.

HAVANA, Sept. 15.-- Having successfully put down the first counterrevolutionary movement with the capture of Captain Ramon Aran and his followers in Pinar del Rio Province the administration late this afternoon sought to gain the support of all Opposition factions.

Local NRA boards of compliance are being organized in the fifty-seven counties of the State outside New York City, it was announced yesterday by W. Averell Harriman, State NRA chairman, at his headquarters in the Hotel Pennsylvania.
Square area obtained a new lease of life yesterday when Borough President Samuel Levy postponed for three weeks his decision whether they were legal encumbrances on the streets.
Seventeen have been named for the running this afternoon at Belmont Park of the $105,000 Futurity, richest race in the world.

PITTSFIELD, Mass., Sept. 15. -- Mrs. Bruce Crane of Dalton was the bride and Mrs. Alexander Simpson 3d of Pittsfield her matron of honor at a fashion show parade held tonight at the Maplewood Hotel, Pittsfield, for the benefit of House of Mercy Hospital Auxiliary.

Because of the public interest in the Jewish pageant, "The Romance of a People," ten or twelve performances, instead of the three originally scheduled, will be given, it was announced last night by aides of Nathan Straus Jr., chairman of the committee in charge.

AUCKLAND, N. Z., Sept. 15. -- The radio equipment for the Ellsworth Transantarctic Flight Expedition is by all odds the finest of its kind so far devised. We will have four transmitters and a like number of receivers.

RIVERHEAD, L.I., Sept. 15. -- Clonmeen, a graceful chestnut mare owned by Miss Rosemary Ward of East Hampton, carried off the hunter championship at the Suffolk County horse show today. The exhibition was conducted by the Suffolk County Agricultural Society at the Fair Grounds in conjunction with the eighty-first annual fair.

UNIONTOWN, Pa., Sept. 15 (AP). -- With State police on guard, quiet generally prevailed today in the Southwestern Pennsylvania soft coal fields where more than 30,000 men are on strike against delay in signing the coal code.
For a game that was declared to be moribund, as its calumniators would have it, football is showing a surprisingly strong pulse this year and nowhere more than in Father Knickerbocker's environs.

BERLIN, Sept, 15. -- General Hermann Wilhelm Goering, Prussian Premier and next to Chancellor Hitler Nazidom's most powerful potentate, ushered his personally conducted Prussian State Council into office today.

With unexpected speed eight jurors were selected in the Criminal Branch of the Supreme Court yesterday at the start of the trial of Isidor J. Kresel, lawyer. He is being tried on an indictment charging him and other directors of the defunct Bank of United States with aiding in the misapplication of nearly $3,000,000 of the funds of an affiliate, the Municipal Safe Deposit Company.
The American Society of Composers, Authors and Publishers opened an attack yesterday on the sale of song sheets on street corners through its general manager, E.C. Mills.

There will be afternoon and evening performances at the Hippodrome by the Chicago Opera Company today. "Hansel and Gretel" will be sung in English at the matinee, and "Cavalleria Rusticana" and "Pagliacci" will make up tonight's double bill.

GREENWICH, Conn., Sept. 15. -- Mrs. Henry W. Pinner, who was one of the principal winners in the ninth annual flower exhibition, held in the June Binney Memorial Parish House in Old Greenwich this afternoon, received a tall silver vase, presented by Mrs. Allan F. Kitchel, the president, for having the greatest number of points in the show.

Theatrical box-office treasurers and assistants yesterday afternoon formed a national organization called the National Theatrical Treasurers Association. Although fifty were present at the meeting held in the Waldorf Theatre, it was estimated by Harry B. Nelmes, who was elected president, that 700 applications for membership had been received from all over the country.

With unexpected speed eight jurors were selected in the Criminal Branch of the Supreme Court yesterday at the start of the trial of Isidor J. Kresel, lawyer. He is being tried on an indictment charging him and other directors of the defunct Bank of United States with aiding in the misapplication of nearly $3,000,000 of the funds of an affiliate, the Municipal Safe Deposit Company.
The American Society of Composers, Authors and Publishers opened an attack yesterday on the sale of song sheets on street corners through its general manager, E.C. Mills.

There will be afternoon and evening performances at the Hippodrome by the Chicago Opera Company today. "Hansel and Gretel" will be sung in English at the matinee, and "Cavalleria Rusticana" and "Pagliacci" will make up tonight's double bill.

GREENWICH, Conn., Sept. 15. -- Mrs. Henry W. Pinner, who was one of the principal winners in the ninth annual flower exhibition, held in the June Binney Memorial Parish House in Old Greenwich this afternoon, received a tall silver vase, presented by Mrs. Allan F. Kitchel, the president, for having the greatest number of points in the show.

A hurricane struck Cape Lookout, N. C., on the middle Atlantic Coast at 9:30 o'clock last night, sending a heavy gale up toward the North Atlantic seaboard. During the day heavy rain driven by an easterly wind lashed the coast in this vicinity.

Because of the disappearance from the State Labor Department of a voluminous report on wages paid under State and city contracts. Deputy Controller Frank J. Prial adjourned a hearing yesterday called to set the prevailing wages for iron workers on city contracts.

Theatrical box-office treasurers and assistants yesterday afternoon formed a national organization called the National Theatrical Treasurers Association. Although fifty were present at the meeting held in the Waldorf Theatre, it was estimated by Harry B. Nelmes, who was elected president, that 700 applications for membership had been received from all over the country.

Sweden, along with the Irish Free State, will be represented at the National Horse Show in Madison Square Garden Nov. 8-14, it was announced yesterday by the National Horse Show Association. The Swedish and Irish officers will compete in the International military competitions, one of which will be a feature of the card at every evening session.

Strength in foreign bonds, in keeping with the gains in the leading foreign exchange rates against the dollar, featured trading in bonds yesterday on the Stock Exchange. Domestic corporation bonds, notably the utilities and rails, were irregularly lower on the day.

CHICAGO, Sept. 15. -- Science's newest weapon against disease, the hormones of the endocrine glands, is helping to win its fight to reduce incurable insanity, it was indicated today in a report in the Illinois Medical Journal by Dr. James H. Hutton of Chicago.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 15. -- With a revamped infield behind him, Van Lingle Mungo today evened the series with the Cards and a the same time jumped into the 500 class of pitchers. He has won fourteen and lost the same number.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 (AP). -- A highly increased possibility that United States troops might be forced to land in Cuba was felt tonight by administration officials as diplomatic reports related threats of mob violence against an American factory and other dangers.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 15. -- A code to govern the operation of industrial enterprises in all the prisons of the country was submitted informally to the NRA by a committee headed by Colonel John J. Hanna, president of the State Board of Control of Wisconsin, as the result of deliberations of prison representatives of thirty-two States here last week.

BERLIN, Sept. 15. -- How the new Germany views her position in the world and what course she intend to pursue in her foreign policies were outlined by Foreign Minister von Neurath to representatives of the foreign press tonight.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 15. -- A 7 per cent gain in employment during August jobs sent the number of wage earners in Pennsylvania past the 750,000 mark, the Federal Reserve Bank of Philadelphia estimated today.

MANCHESTER, Vt., Sept. 15. -- Noting a substantial increase in industrial activity in New England since March, President Henry D. Sharpe of the New England Council in a report to its quarterly meeting here today, stated that its research studies indicated improved employment, reduced calls on welfare rolls, especially in industrial areas, and significant increases in retail sales.

Equity Builders, Inc., has been formed by Eugene Blitz to build and finance dwellings for lot owners. Mr. Blitz, a construction engineer, was formerly with the Burt Building Company. Associated with him are Thomas W. Mullins, sanitary engineer and plumbing and heating contractor, and Jack Lang, who has been with mortgage and financial organizations.

David Burnstine, veteran contract bridge expert, led the field early this morning at the conclusion of the second session of the annual individual master's championship of the American Bridge League, Which began yesterday at the RitzCarlton Hotel.

The trend on local commodity exchanges was strong yesterday, but some futures reacted in the afternoon and closed with losses on the day. Trading volumes held fairly close to those of the preceding day.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 15 (AP). -- The Post-Dispatch says an investigation is under way to determine if a $418,623 fund set aside by the St. Louis-San Francisco Railway to further a reorganization plan included money borrowed from the Reconstruction Finance Corporation.

PARIS, Sept. 15. -- With the arrival in Paris this morning of Foreign Minister De Kanya of Hungary, the whole question of a Danubian economic union has been reopened and has taken its place among the great problems occupying European Chancelleries at present.
Several changes in memberships in Stock Exchange firms and in securities listed on the Exchange were announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 (AP). -- Harry L. Hopkins, Relief Administrator, today appealed for public support for Red Cross efforts to raise more than $200,000 for relief of hurricane victims in Florida and Texas.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 (AP). -- The Interstate Commerce Commission was asked today by Guy T. Helvering, Commissioner of Internal Revenue, to withhold approval of any reorganization of the Missouri Pacific Railroad under the Bankruptcy Act that does not "adequately provide" for payment of $5,423,485 in back income taxes owed to the government by the road, its subsidiaries and affiliates.

The Federal grand jury cited for contempt yesterday one of the men called before it in its investigation of the alleged non-payment of income tax by Irving Wexler, known in the beer trade as Waxey Gordon. The witness was Dr. Abraham L. Hoffspiegel of Paterson, N.J., physiotherapist and renting agent.

PARIS, Sept. 15. -- The Foreign Ministry tonight professed "complete satisfaction." with the German Government's reply to Ambassador Andre Francois-Poncet's protest against the recent presentation to a Nazi storm troop unit stationed at Kehl, across the Rhine from Strasbourg, of a flag bearing the inscription "Strassburg" and the slogan "Germany, Awaken! "Strasbourg became French after the World War.

The National Industrial Recovery Act, with its industrial control features, is "a charter of possibilities" which should play an important role in the movement to substitute cooperation toward social ends for the "old, outmoded, rugged, self-seeking individualism" in the present economic system.
Dr. Raymond D. Morris, a well-known surgeon of Western New York, died last evening of myocarditis at his home in Olean, according to word received here. He was about 48 years old.

The dollar declined yesterday for the sixth consecutive day, losing 58 points in gold value based on local quotations for the French franc. For the week the loss amounted to 4.13 cents in gold value. A new low record of 66.86 cents in gold was established yesterday and the final quotation was 66.91 cents, comparing with 71.04 cents a week ago.

WARWICK, R.I., Sept. 16. -- The Atlantic Coast championship of the Star Class remains with Narragansett Bay for another year. Moonshine, placing sixth in the final race today, stands first in the table of total points for the five races, 19 points ahead of Chuckle from Great South Bay.

DUBLIN. ANEW personality now looms in Ireland. President de Valera, who for a year has been regarded as the only national leader that Ireland has, faces a rival in the person of his former Police Commissioner, General Eoin O'Duffy, one of the most popular of Irishmen.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 (AP). -- The Senators won today's double-header with Detroit, taking the first game, 11 to 4, and shading the Tigers, 4 to 3, in ten innings in the nightcap.

BEFORE the month is out Universal expects to begin "Sutter's Gold," a picturization of Blaise Cendrar's story of the California gold rush in '49. The studio oracle explains the picture will be primarily biographical, devoted to the life of Mr. Sutter himself.

For the forty years ending with his death in 1866 THOMAS THORNTON'S business was of the dreariest. He summarized for The London Times the debates in the House of Commons. Yet he lived to be 80. His memory is faintly preserved in the still standard three-volume edition of THOMAS OTWAY.

HOLLYWOOD. CHARLES LAUGHTON is returning to England following completion of "White Woman," in which he appears with Carole Lombard, Charles Bickford and Kent Taylor. He came to Hollywood expecting to do two films, but the strike delayed production to such an extent that he is returning in a week or so.

During the first seven months of this year manufacturing production in the United States averaged 16 per cent above 1932, the National Industrial Conference Board announced yesterday in making public an analysis of Federal Reserve Board indexes.
DUBLIN, Sept. 15. -- From now on to the end of the year the Free State will be the centre of hectic political activity.

LONDON. BRUTUS, who had perhaps the longest and most distinguished descent of any of London's "official" cats, and was also unique in possessing a ticket to the National Gallery of Art, died the other day, mourned by many friends.

A FURTHER spread of fascism was seemingly foreshadowed by Chancellor Dollfuss's announcement at Vienna last Monday, when he said, speaking for the Austrian Government: "We will build up a Catholic, German State which will be thoroughly Austrian, upon a corporative [Fascist] basis.

MARIO PRAZ defines this book as a "monograph and not a synthesis"; as a study of the education of sensibility through works of art and of the means by which the transmission of themes from one artist to another is effected.

THE unofficial record for magic -- the account was never fully substantiated -- was the performance of a certain sleight-of-hand artist on the high seas. Among others, Mr. John Mulholland, the tall and esteemed vice president of the American Society of Magicians, has been telling the story for some years with great gusto and no little professional pride.

Manufacturing production advanced 16 per cent in the first seven months of this year compared with the corresponding period of 1932, according to an analysis of Federal Reserve Board indexes by the National Industrial Conference Board.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Sept. 16. -- The outstanding contest in the Westchester primaries is the fight among fifteen candidates in New Rochelle for the two Council vacancies in that city. The regime of City Manager John F. Donovan hangs in the balance.

DURING the course of his breezy soliloquy in these columns last Sunday George M. Cohan remarked: "One of the troubles with the drama today is that it has become a cult. * * * You have to be on the inside to figure it out."

IT is the business of the public schools to furnish the means of mental nutrition, but the waste their time and monetary substance if the physical nutrition of their subjects is impaired. The ill-fed child cannot fully digest and utilize the mental diet which is presented to him.

CHATTANOOGA, Term., Sept. 15. -- The Tennessee Valley, or at least that part of it in and about Chattanooga and Knoxville, is approaching a none too promising Winter in a spirit of bitter resentment against the Tennessee Valley Authority.

GROUND has been broken and construction has started on a group of three new buildings for the Westminster Ohoir School In Princeton, N.J. The buildings, the gift of an anonymous donor, will house the school and the Westminster Choir, and there will be living quarters for the student body.
The Protestant church in America is bankrupt, the Rev. Charles J. Dutton declares in October Current History.

Lacking definite assurance from the bankers that they would advance a $72,000,000 loan applied for by the city, the city administration last night faced the fact that unless the loan is forthcoming there must be a default on three payrolls due to 143,000 city employes before election day, Nov. 7.

VIENNA, Sept. 16. -- In the long line of automobiles containing representatives of those aristocratic and industrial elements of the Austrian social structure which participated in Monday's demonstration at the Vienna race track in favor of Austrian unity under the Dollfuss government was one lone car bearing the arms of the old empire -- the black double eagle on a yellow ground.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Sept. 16. -- "The Newspapers and the New Deal" will furnish the general theme for the twelfth annual Newspaper Institute to be held Oct. 9 at Rutgers University in cooperation with the New Jersey Press Association, Dr. Carl R. Woodward, chairman of the committee in charge, announced today.

CHICAGO, Sept. 16. -- In a spectacular drive down the home stretch, Evergold, the big chestnut gelding owned by Dick and Pat Nash of Chicago, captured the $2,500 added Crete Handicap at Lincoln Fields today. He defeated the favorite, No More, by one length.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 16. -- Productive activity slackened further in the week ended on Sept. 9, according to the weekly survey of domestic business conditions made public today by the Department of Commerce.

PRAGUE, Sept. 16. -- At a special session of the Czechoslovak Cabinet, summoned tonight to consider the situation resulting from the letter of the Papal Nuncio, Mgr. Peter Ciriaci, to the Slovak autonomist leader, Father Hlinka, which the latter published, it was decided to make objection to the letter and demand the recall of the Nuncio to the Vatican so that he could furnish an explanation.
An important factor in the development of a new generation of dog fanciers was the establishment of children's classes.

Betting odds of two to one that Mayor John P. O'Brien would defeat F.H. LaGuardia, fusion candidate, was reported yesterday. One such bet of $2,500 to $1,250 was said to have been made at the Belmont Park track, where many Tammany leaders were gathered.

MANX valuable contributions to aeronautics may be traced to research work conducted by universities giving courses in aeronautical engineering, Eugene L. Vidal, director of air regulation in the Department of Commerce, said last week.
CINCINNATI, Sept. 16 (AP). -- A boyhood dream was realized today by George T. Dunlap Jr. of New York in winning the national amateur golf championship.

MAMARONECK, N.Y., Sept. 16. -- Twenty-one-year-old Joseph Gagliardi, a senior at Williams, became the youngest golfer ever to win the New York Athletic Club championship when he carried off the honors in the final at the Winged Foot Golf Club today.

HAVANA, Sept. 15. -- There has been considerable anti-American propaganda in circles close to the dominant group in Cuba's new government, the Students' Directorate, but it is believed to be likely diminished. A better understanding is developing on the part of the student leaders of the policy of the United States and the actions of Ambassador Sumner Welles in executing that policy.

EQUINOCTIAL storms, a half holiday and the apparent completion by the public of its "price protection" purchases brought about a marked slump in retail trade here during the week. Reports from other sections of the country, with the possible exception of the South, told of similar declines.

GREENWICH, Conn., Sept. 16. -- Buster, an 8-year-old bay gelding owned by Miss Becky Lanier of Greenwich, carried off the major honors In the twentieth annual Greenwich Horse Show today. Competing in mud and rain that made the going extremely difficult, Buster took five blue ribbons and won three trophies.

DR. LENARD is a Nobel Prize winner in physics, a Rumford and Franklin medalist, and formerly Professor of Physics and director of the Radiological Institute in the University of Heidelberg, in the days when to occupy such a position in a leading German university meant something more than adherence to Heir Hitler.

COOPERATION-in-Government, Inc., a movement made up of a group of New York's high school students who have been outstandingly active in their classes, is now ten years old. Started in 1923, with less than 200 members, it has developed into a society, incorporated under the laws of the State of New York, with 4,000 members.

AT THE moment of writing neither earthquakes nor tornadoes have striven to dislodge "One Sunday Afternoon" from the Forty-eighth Street Theatre. But almost every other form of cataclysm known to the show world has at one time or another overtaken the quiet little comedy that James Hagan fashioned out of the oddments of small town life at the turn of the century.

CHICAGO, Sept. 16. -- Thomas E. Bragg, a leading operator in Wall Street, has bought a membership on the Chicago Stock Exchange, according to reports from New York tonight. The seat was one of the eight which changed hands this week during the bidding that followed the proposed imposition of heavy taxes on stock transactions executed in New York.

The $870,000,000 Associated Gas ind Electric Company is increasing its efforts to carry out the plan of rearrangement or its capitalization innounced on May 15. The management has been spurred to greater activity in this direction by the latest estimates of the added expenses and taxes that confront it.

The American Bible Society soon will place on exhibition at the Century of Progress Exposition at Chicago a large globe of the world. Made of aluminum, it is fifty inches in diameter. Inside the globe there is a heavy shaft with an electric motor, which turns the sphere on its axis.

GUAYAQUIL, Ecuador, Sept. 12. -- Four centuries ago Atahualpa, last of the Inca rulers, died at Pizarro's hands, but today his heir and descendant, Luis Felipe Huaraca Duchicela XXVI, proclaims that he will soon restore in its original glory the Tahuantisuyo, or old Inca Empire, which covered all of South America from the Isthmus of Panama to the Strait of Magellan.

THE eighty-sixth meeting of the American Chemical Society ended a week of sessions yesterday at Chicago. Among those attending were fortytwo pioneers in American chemical science who had attended the Columbian Exposition in 1893.

New York University expects the greatest number of applications for admission in recent years tomorrow when it opens its 102d year because of the advance already made toward economic recovery, Henry G. Arnsdorf, university registrar, said yesterday.

The World Trade League, non-partisan organization formed two years ago to promote the interests of foreign trade, will merge its efforts with those of the American Manufacturers Export Association, George F. Bauer, founder and chairman, announced yesterday.

District Attorney Thomas J. Walsh of Richmond County announced yesterday that he would seek indictments from the Richmond County grand jury early this week on charges of fraud resulting from an investigation of the Staten Island Home Relief Bureau.

THE library of Yale University was once the fortunate recipient of a thousand volumes judiciously selected for the use of students in various departments of learning. Nearly 500 titles appeared in the collection, many of them being in duplicate.
PARIS. Sept. 15. -- This coming week will see the beginning of new activity in international affairs on the outcome of which will depend the whole future of Europe.

LONDON. The question of the novelist's use of actual persons as models is discussed by Allan Monkhouse in The Manchester Guardian. Of course, he remarks the extent to which they are employed in fiction must vary according to the temperament and the circumstances of the writers.
NEW YORK. Mr. and Mrs. H.G. Pell, General and Mrs. William Gibsone of Montreal and Mrs. Robert Weeks Kelley are visiting Mr. and Mrs. Stephen H.P. Pell at The Pavilion, Fort Ticonderoga, N.Y.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Sept. 16. -- Army's football squad has been In action a fortnight engaging in daily workouts on the Plains Gridiron. The cadets have been handicapped, however, by drills and other military duties, which have cut into the time for practice.
EAST HAMPTON, L.I., Sept. 16. -- Mr. and Mrs. John V. Bouvier 3d were among those entertaining tonight at the dinner dance given at the Devon Yacht Club.

POP HART, beloved vagabond and great artist, is gone. He died Sept. 9 -- not quite in harness, although years of physical agony had failed to break that fine, courageous spirit. Pop Hart must have left with a pang of very real regret the world he had found, all in all, such a "swell" place.

WITH the end of prohibition forecast for early December, if not before, distributers and drinkers of hard liquor are now surveying the whisky situation. Will there be enough of the legitimate stock to satisfy America's demand?
PINE VALLEY, N.J., Sept. 16 (AP). -- Four golfers from as many States battled into the semi-final round for the George Arthur Crump Memorial Cup at Pine Valley Golf, Club today.
BEDFORD HILLS, N.Y., Sept. 16. -- A costume circus party was held tonight at the Community House here for the benefit of the Bedford Hills Memorial Association.

RICHMOND, Sept. 14. -- The outburst of Dr. William R. Dancy, retiring commander-in-chief of the Sons of Confederate Veterans, at that organization's annual convention last week in Atlanta, in which he denounced the proposal to erect a $100,000 "peace monument" at Appomattox as "insulting" to the South, has brought considerable criticism upon the doctor.

David Burnstine maintained his lead over the field of thirty-six star contract bridge players in the third session of the individual masters' championship of the American Bridge League at the Ritz Carlton Hotel yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 16. -- The Bureau or Navigation issued the following orders today, dated Sept. 14:

AMSTERDAM, Sept. 16. -- Belief that Marinus van der Lubbe had been forced to decline aid offered in defending him from accusations of complicity in the Reichstag fire was expressed today by Francois Pauwels, a well-known Dutch lawyer.

Chemistry to the Rescue? There seems to be no question, on the basis of the news of the week, that the future of chemistry will influence enormously the future of the human race. The only doubt that remains is whether chemistry will raise men to the level of the gods or will wipe them out of existence.

PARIS, Sept. 16. -- Renewed talk of inflation in the United States, yesterday's rumors in Wall Street that France would be forced to abandon the gold standard and the huge French budgetary deficit have all served to create a nervous feeling in Paris.

Concern over the skill and audacity of the burglars who are trying to steal more valuable paintings from the Brooklyn Museum led museum officials yesterday to include funds for a new burglar-alarm system in their 1934 budget request.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 16. -- The public works administration is being placed in a false position before the country by "political sharpshooters and snipers," Secretary Ickes declared today.

HAROLD A. LA FOUNT, Federal Radio Commissioner, has proposed that the number of fifty-kilowatt stations in the United States be increased from twenty to forty, if there is an inclination among American broadcasters to step up power to that mark.

PARIS, Sept. 16. -- The French reaction to Baron von Neurath's outspoken declarations yesterday as to Germany's position on disarmament leaves no doubt that the Reich Foreign Minister has prejudiced opinion here more than ever against disarmament almost on the eve of the important discussions that will begin Monday.

Louis F. Magnolia, boxing referee, died last night in the Rockaway Beach Hospital, Queens, where he had teen a patient since Sunday night. Death was due to an ailment of the throat. He was 54 years old. At his hedside were his entire immediate family, his wife, Mae, his two sons, Walter and Louis, and his daughter, Louise.
Edward Nichols sailed around the harbor again yesterday and recalled the day nearly eighty years ago when he had his first taste of the salt air as a pilot's apprentice.

OYSTER BAY, L.I., Sept. 16. -- Colonel Theodore Roosevelt, former Governor General of the Philippines, was welcomed home tonight by about 1,000 of his townspeople at a reception and meeting in the high school auditorium here. A parade from the American Legion clubhouse, led by the Quentin Roosevelt Band, preceded the reception.

Who killed Chadwick Morne, and how, and why? Was his murderer the press agent who arranged for the airplane flight and parachute jump and who refuses to account for his actions on the night of the murder? Or was it Giulio Vanuzzi, Morne's silent partner in a night club and his rival for the favors of one of the entertainers?

ONE job holder who has apparently vindicated her usefulness through good times and bad is the school nurse. And in the new national drive on malnutrition, just called for by the Secretary of Labor, her tribe and her task are expected to increase.

PATERSON, N.J., Sept. 16 -- With broadsilk manufacturers determined to open their shops on Monday despite the refusal of organized strikers to accept a five-week truce, it was expected here today that the broadsilk strike would reach its most critical period next week.

THE author of this volume is an authority on utility problems. He has had a distinguished career as Comptroller of the City of New York, as chairman of the Public Service Commission of the State of New York, and as a director of an electric light and gas company.

Study of the reasons for the failure of the world economic conference in London last July discloses the fact that the world is working fumblingly and half-consciously toward a new economy to replace the Nineteenth Century type fostered by England, Dr. Lionel D. Edie, Vice president of Mayflower Associates and formerly professor of finance at Chicago University, said yesterday.

MADRID, Sept. 15. -- Seventeen political parties, many without fixed orientation, are one of the salient features of the Spanish political situation. Only two parties are large and well organized. They are the Socialists and Premier Lerroux's Radicals, so called because long ago in the days of Bourbon absolutism they were radical by comparison.

MISS HOLTBY'S many-bladed satire cuts a wide swath. Her view of the vainglory of the world is that all people have their full and disarmingly vulnerable share of it, and so when she has laughed at her people for a time she has the skill and imaginativeness to turn and explore their serious sensibilities.
Football swung into line with its new season during the past week, when the last of the conservatives, the colleges with the Sept. 15 deadline for practice starts, opened their workouts.

WAGNER, Verdi, Puccini and Ponchielli are the composers who will be represented in this week's performances of opera at the New York Hippodrome. "Tannhauser" is scheduled for Monday night with Milo Miloradoviteh, Edwina Eustis, Georg Fassnacht, Alex Tcherkaasky, Sigurd Nilssen and Harry Ladek conducting.

VANCOUVER, Sept. 14. -- The twenty-second annual Arctic cruise of the Hudson's Bay Company got under way with the departure from this port recently of the S.S. Anyox, Captain B.D.L. Johnson, R. N.R., commanding.

WHITEMARSH, Pa., Sept. 16. -- John Strawbridge's Sea Rig won the Wissahickon Cup, feature of the Wissahickon Farms' Fall hunt races, today over a wet and heavy three-mile timber course. The veteran jumper, capably ridden by Morris H. Dixon, never was threatened after the first half mile.
The city's voters, going to the polls on Tuesday for the primary election, are expected to register an unusually large protest vote aimed at both the Democratic and Republican machines.

MR. HAYS might, more dramatically, have titled his book "The Thirteenth Juror." For in his text he constantly refers to that unseen power, that community emotionalism antagonistic to the accused for any reason which he brings out in the accounts of the trials he has collected here as "the ominous presence of the thirteenth juror -- prejudice."

SAN JUAN, P.R., Sept. 14. -- After a second interview with President Roosevelt in Washington last week, Governor Robert H. Gore was quoted in a news cable published here as saying: "I have the full moral support of the President."

NEW ORLEANS, La., Sept. 14. -- Governor Mike Conner of Mississippi proved he was something of a bulldog by imposing the sales tax, but now in undertaking to rewrite the Constitution of his State upon the most advanced lines, he has set his teeth into a bone that may well wear out the most tenacious bulldog.

Two men were pitched into Long Island Sound yesterday afternoon when a strong northeast breeze caught the sail of a small craft and capsized it midway between Fort Schuyler and Belden Point, City Island.

BERLIN, Sept. 16. -- Richard Walther Darre, the Reich Minister of Agriculture, in announcing an undertaking by the government to obtain "a just price" for the produce of German farmers, especially grain, warned them today that it was conditioned on their offering no more than the amount for which there is a genuine domestic demand.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I was interested to read a recent article in THE TIMES dealing with vampire bats; also your comment on the same subject. Might I, however, take exception to the statement that vampire bats do not attack human beings?

The Queens County Jockey Club's Fall meeting at Aqueduct will begin tomorrow with the most promising outlook in the last two years, according to a statement from John E. Cowdin, president of the association. Mr. Cowdin and Racing Secretary Joseph McLennan, have done everything possible to insure the success of the two-week session.

YELLOW SPRINGS, Ohio, Sept. 16 (AP). -- The family board feeds fifty at the home of Lucy G. Morgan, wife of Arthur E. Morgan, president of Antioch College and chairman of the Tennessee Valley Authority.

WASHINGTON. THE dispute over the design chosen tar the National Recovery atamp recently issued by the Postoffice Department has served to arouse interest as to who designs, who approves and engraves postage stamps and turns out Federal coins and bills.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Sept. 16. -- It took both baseball cages to fill Harvard's football needs today. A downpour of rain drove the coaches and the two varsity squads indoors and kept them there.

When wholesale prices for all products were moving up emphatically between March and the middle of July the recovery brought general relief; and that was so, notwithstanding the very divergent explanations of the cause for it. Although there had been no increase in the currency during the interval but a substantial decrease, a considerable body of opinion insisted on ascribing the rise to "inflation."

EVIDENTLY we are not alone in our partiality for the Brahma centennial recording of the quintet for strings in G (Op. 100). Made quite recently by the Budapest Quartet, plus Hans Wahlke (second viola), in lass than two months after its English release we receive it here in Victor) Masterpiece Album 184.

NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 16. -- Brig. Gen. Cornelius Vanderbilt, who returned from New York early today, was a host this evening with Mrs. Vanderbilt to Vice Admiral the Hon. Reginald A.R. Plunkett-Ernle-Erle-Drax, R.N., and Mrs. Drax at a dinner at their Summer home, Beaulieu.

ATLANTA. FOR Clark Howell, editor of The Atlanta Constitution and Nestor of Southern journalism, there are two notable anniversaries this year -- his seventieth birthday, next Thursday, and the completion of his fiftieth year as a member of the staff of The Constitution.

Registration for New College, Columbia University, opens tomorrow and will continue through Tuesday, it was announced yesterday. According to Dr. Paul M. Limbert, in charge of enrolment, 150 new students are to be added to the college this Fall, bringing the total number to nearly 300.

NORTH WATER GAP, Pa., Sept. 16. -- At the close of three days of training in Camp Wyomissing, the University of Pennsylvania varsity football squad is fairly well advanced. As the season does not open until Oct. 14, when F. and M. will be met, Head Coach Harvey Harman is not trying to rush the squad but feels the players need all the hard work they can assimilate as Spring practice was not allowed.

IN "Deep Country" Amory Hare presents an authentic and vivid picture of the life of the fox-hunting set of Pennsylvania. As the wife of the master of the foxhounds in that section she knows whereof she speaks, and she dwells with loving care on all the minutiae of hunting, racing, hunt balls and hunt breakfasts.

GLASGOW, Mont., Sept. 16 (AP). -- United States Senator Burton K. Wheeler suffered a slight concussion and other injuries when his car careened wildly and overturned on a highway twenty-four miles west of Glasgow today. Tonight he was seemingly out of danger.

PARIS, Sept. 16. -- Conversations characterized in a communique as "opening new perspectives on the economic situation in the Danubian States," were held today here between Foreign Minister de Kanya of Hungary and Foreign Minister Paul-Boncour, and later between M. de Kanya and Premier Daladier.

As a result of a survey made of farming conditions in Massachusetts, Professor Richard P. Doherty of the Bureau of Business Research at Boston University's College of Business Administration, declares that part-time or "backyard" farming offers a partial solution of unemployment.
Now that the Fall season is at hand again, field hockey will assume an important place on the sports calendar of women's schools and colleges.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Sept. 16. -- A committee of fifty taxpayers and property owners, including many prominent New York Summer residents here, are attempting to relieve unemployment here by conducting a labor clearing house and also by canvassing property owners to interest them in having repairs done to their homes and places of business.

In the last two years the Old John Street Methodist Episcopal Church, 44 John Street, has helped more than 3,000 unfortunate men and women. Many of them were in dire want and did not know where they could obtain food and lodging.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Sept. 16. -- Students of New Jersey College for Women held their opening exercises today, when Dr. Robert C. Clothier, president of Rutgers University, addressed the undergraduates in the Elizabeth Rodman Voorhees Chapel.

NOW that the Fall has rolled around, it is possible to group a great many things under the heading of Near Future. There are, for example, the plays scheduled for a week after this. There are, moreover, tryouts of a legitimate nature, past and present.

LONDON, Sept. 1. THE new season has already yielded two plays which, in spite of a heat-wave and a drought, give promise of success. Lennox Robinson has brought to the Ambassador Theatre what he describes as "an exaggeration of Irish life" called "Is Life Worth Living?" and at the Lyric Theatre Raymond Massey is appearing in "The Ace," an English adaptation by Miles Malleson of a German piece by Herman Rossman.

The tropical hurricane that devastated several North Carolina towns, lashed the Virginia coast and unsettled the weather of most of the Atlantic seaboard was expected last night to strike New York about noon today.

HARRIETT MONROE, founder and editor of Poetry, a Magazine of Verse, has announced that the Carnegie Corporation of New York has generously come to the aid of the magazine with a subsidy which will enable it to continue, thus putting an end to the fears of its friends that it might be compelled to suspend publication.

BOSTON, Sept. 14. -- The campaign against the Massachusetts compulsory automobile liability insurance system apparently will be fought upon a new front this season. The public no longer charges that the officials who fix the rates are in cahoots with the insurance companies, or that the insurance commissioner is incompetent, or that the actuaries manipulate the statistics on which the rates are supposed to be based.

NO broadcast showman, whether he be associated with a coast-to-coast network or with an independent station, ever confesses that he is not alert, with eyes and ears open, for new talent and original ideas.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 16. -- The resignation this week of Robert P. Lament as president of the American Iron and Steel Institute and his protest of the increasing governmental regulation of business served to focus attention here or the serious consideration already being given to his lamentation that "no one knows how far it may go."

CUPAR, Fire, Scotland, Sept. 16 (AP). -- Sir John Simon, British Foreign Secretary, said today disarmament was "one of the most immediate urgencies at present occupying the best thoughts of the statesmen of the world, and one upon the solution of which it may be the future happiness of mankind depends."

More than sixty postgraduate students from distinguished foreign families, who have arrived in the United States to enroll in various universities on exchange fellowships granted by the Institute of International Education, were addressed yesterday by a group of student advisers at a week-end house party in the Riverdale Country School.

UNTONTOWN, Pa., Sept. 16 (AP). -- Informed that bituminous coal operators had signed an NRA code for the industry, striking South-western Pennsylvania miners awaited word tonight from their local leaders that would send them back to work.

THIS eighth volume in what is to be a ten-volume series, called "The Corridors of Time," dealing with prehistoric ages carries the story from the fourteenth century B.C. through about five centuries. The chronological series will be completed by the next volume, which will continue the survey to the time of the appearance of prophets, lawgivers and philosophers and the resulting possibility of treating history by other methods than those employed here.

Speed boat records are going by the board in fast sequence in Europe and the real reason la that the drivers of fast craft there are doing their utmost in preparation for the international racing to be held in Florida the coming Winter.

OUTSTANDING symphony orchestras are booked for broadcasting this season. An attempt will be made to inject some of the classics into the afternoon programs to "boost their quality," in the words of a radio showman.

GERMANY'S loss is this country's gain. Arnold Schonberg has agreed to come to Boston next month to teach harmony and composition at the newly organized Malkin Conservatory of Music. One of the outstanding figures in the world of music, Schonberg is known here only from a portion of his works.

The first twenty-seven chain-store and mail-order organizations to issue their sales reports for August showed an average gain of 5.7 per cent over the total of the same month last year, according to a compilation prepared by Lehman Brothers.

The assertion that the so-called Hoovsrite group was backing Chase Mellen Jr., in his fight to oust him as chairman of the New York County Republican Committee, was made yesterday by Samuel S. Koenig. Mr. Koenig spoke at a meeting of district leaders and workers at the headquarters of the "Loyal Committee" supporting him, at 105 West Fortieth Street.
ISTANBUL, Sept. 15. -- The Balkans, after a period of comparative quiet, seem again about to attract attention in international politics.
