The coming resumption of the Arms Conference in Geneva may be a far different affair from the desultory and helpless negotiations which have been predicted in so many quarters. There may be little disarming next month, but there may be a gay time on the banks of Lake Leman, with the possibility of an interesting European political crisis.

HARTFORD, Sept. 14. -- For the first time since 1921 the State of Connecticut has found its treasury empty, and, although the current fiscal year is only two and a half months old, the State has teen compelled to borrow $2,100,000 to pay the operating expenses of the government.

CHICAGO, Sept. 16. -- Aaron Sapiro, New York lawyer, who was indicted with Al Capone, Alderman Oscar F. Nelson and twenty-one others on charges of conspiracy to terrorize Chicago business men, was Drought from New York tonight and lodged for nearly two hours in the Cook County Jail.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 (AP). -- Assurance of higher prices to producers of flue-cured tobacco for the remainder of the season seemed virtually certain tonight with the announcement by the Farm Administration that a hearing on a proposed marketing agreement for flue-cured buyers would be held next Thursday.

HAVANA, Sept. 12. -- After having seen, a former army Captain of aviation acting as drink-mixer at the bar of the Hotel National, the regular bartender being on strike, I had pointed out to me former Sergeant of Aviation Chavez who is now wearing a Captain's bars.

ROME, Sept. 16. -- At the end of an unusually long and laborious Cabinet session today a decree was approved for the defense of Italian goods against the competition of imports from countries with depreciated currencies. It is presumed the decree will be instrumental in curtailing the entry into Italy of American goods, along with those of other countries that have gone off the gold standard.
ST. LOUIS, Sept. 16. -- Seven hours of weird baseball today resulted in only one decision, the Cardinals defeating the Dodgers in the opener of a scheduled double-header, 14 to 13, in ten innings.

WASHINGTON. THE present trouble in Cuba raises the question of the extent and nature of American investments in that country. It is generally agreed that they are in excess of $1,000,000,000 and that more American capital is invested there than in any other foreign country, except Canada.

WESTBURY, L.I., Sept. 16. -- The tournament committee of the United States Polo Association today inspected the damage done to Meadow Brook fields by the unprecedented rains of the past few days and decided to put off until next week the adjustment of the disrupted open polo championship schedule.

ANEW college designed as the first coeducational college to be "articulated directly with the progressive schools" is to open this Fall near Black Mountain, N. C., a town near Asheville. As an earnest of this aim it will have a number of well-known educators connected with progressive secondary schools as well as a few interested laymen on an active advisory council.

MRS. ALLINSON, who as Anne Crosby Emery was dean of women at the University of Wisconsin and later dean of Pembroke College, Brown University, has left an illuminating record of her life and thought in this book of essays, posthumously printed.

Instructions covering procedure under the Schackno Bill, incorporating many of the provisions of the National Industrial Recovery Act, were sent yesterday to the chairmen of all NRA committees up-State by W. Averell Harriman, chairman of the President's Emergency Re-employment Campaign Committee for New York State.

Charged with attempting to extort $10,000 from Dr. Albert Fritz of 8,622 Bay Parkway, Brooklyn, a physician well known in the Bath Beach-Bensonhurst section of that borough, Mrs. Jean Costello, 29 years old, of 1,599 West Sixth Street, and John Isola, 34, of 2,246 Eighty-fourth Street, both, of Brooklyn, were arrested last night.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 (AP). -- Because so many farmers want to sell their small pigs at premium prices the farm adjustment administration announced today that 5,992,000 would be purchased in its reduction campaign instead of only 4,000,000.

HAVANA, Sept. 16. -- Hope for the establishment of a coalition administration to replace the student and army government was aroused today following a meeting between President Grau San Martin and the chiefs of the most important opposing groups which terminated at 3 o'clock this morning.
CINCINNATI, Sept. 16. -- George T. Dunlap Jr. of New York today succeeded C. Ross Somerville of London, Ont., as amateur golf champion of the United States.

An official and a legal representative of the Sigmund Eisner Clothing Company which has been asked to explain to the National Labor Board its delay in settling a strike at the company's Red Bank (N.J.) plant are active representatives of the NRA organizations of New York City and of New Jersey, it was learned yesterday.

IN "Kingdom Coming" Roark Bradford, whose "On Man Adam an' His Chillun" provided the material for "The Green Pastures," has written a novel of Negro life before and during the Civil War. As Mr. Bradford knows his blacks of the deep South better than perhaps anybody else writing today, the reader is assured in advance of a document authentic throughout, however fictional the projected story may actually be.

TRENTON, N.J., Sept. 16. -- Under the patronage of the Most Rev. Thomas J. Walsh, Bishop of the Roman Catholic Diocese of Newark, N.J., and formerly Bishop of Trenton, the American Branch of the Religious Teachers Filippini, will open its first boarding and day school for girls on Monday.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 14. -- For twenty-two years the city of Los Angeles fought the three trans-continental railroad lines with terminals here -- the Southern Pacific, Santa Fe and Union Pacific. The city wanted a union station in a designated central, downtown location, with grade-crossing elimination.

TICONDEROGA, N.Y., Sept. 16. -- An international celebration held here today rescued from obscurity the name and fame of the Marquis Michel de Chartier de Lotbiniere, the French engineer who designed Fort Ticonderoga. He also aided Benjamin Franklin in obtaining French help for the Revolutionary Colonists and, next after the Iroquois Indians, first owned this village.

IF the theatre bites a code, that's not news; but if a code bites the theatres, that is news. After twenty years or more of trifling with codes the theatre has finally flirted with one that has taken it seriously and snapped back.

NEWTON, Mass., Sept. 13 (AP). -- Joseph T. Gilman, president and general manager of the Boston Garden and a member of the board of athletics at Dartmouth College, died last night in the Newton Hospital, where he underwent an operation a week ago.

PRINCETON, N.J., Sept. 16. -- An informal scrimmage today featured the second day of practice off the Princeton football squad on rain-soaked University Field, with pass plays receiving special attention.

Such encouragement as Wall Street received yesterday in the markets in which it is most interested was ascribed, perhaps with exaggerated vociferousness, to the growing demand for currency inflation. The propaganda in that direction is more active, if less persuasive, than at any time since the movement was started.

PLACID uneventfulness, after a promising start, prevails in this four-cornered love story, whose scene throughout Is a secluded Summer colony on the southern shore of the Gulf of St. Lawrence. Two young Canadians, Chris a lawyer and Lewis an architect, former schoolmates, are thither bound in a new roadster when the car somersaults from the road, pinning Chris helplessly beneath but throwing Lewis, with painful injuries, a few feet clear of the wreck.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 16 (AP). -- A fog that rolled in from Lake Erie swallowed up a mail plane bound from Chicago to Cleveland early today and no trace of plane or pilot has been found, although an airplane was reported sighted late today in a dense woods about ten miles south of Sandusky.

BERLIN, Sept. 15. -- Under the velvety persuasion of Dr. Joseph Paul Goebbels, the Nazi Minister of Propaganda and Public Enlightenment, 15,000,000 German households and another 5,000,000 or 6,000,000 bachelors and spinsters who conduct their own menages are expected to accept humbly a mess of pottage in lieu of their conventional Sunday main meal this coming Winter.

THE fanfare which attends the publication of a prize novel inevitably works some injustice upon the book so fortunately singled out. Perhaps it is because one's expectations are raised too high. Few novels -- and they never seem to be awarded prizes -- have a plan sufficiently original or a merit sufficiently distinguished to answer our subjective notions of what a prize novel ought to be.
International team racing between the Bermuda one-design yachts and the Long Island Sound Interclub Class sloops is scheduled to start this afternoon at the Larchmont Yacht Club.
Retail trade slackened throughout the country last week, with wholesale business about the same and manufacturing in general showing further recessions in the face of modest recording of goods.

A modern version of the biblical handwriting on the wall will feature the opening of the 1933 National Electrical and Radio Show in Madison Square Garden next Wednesday, sponsors of the exposition announced yesterday.

BODGE CITY, Kan., Sept. 14. -- The Southwest is doing more than thinking about crime since "Pretty Boy" Floyd, the Underbill and the Majors gang have robbed, murdered and kidnapped with impunity. While the improvement of high-ways and higher-powered automobiles are partly responsible for the assaults, the indifference of citizens has been a handicap to law enforcement as well as a deterrent in the apprehension of criminals.

TOKYO. A PICTURESQUE film - drama figure, half tomboy, half heroine, flits through the Japanese press these days with the nickname "the Manchukuo Joan of Arc." Yoshiko Kawashima is her name, and there are about her many strange circumstances to make her appealing to a nation which takes deep pride in the army and its exploits.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Diplomatically speaking, the last j ten years of campaigning have not been fruitful in victories for the professional killers of game, nor for their allies, the exploiters. They lost out on their big-bag limits, possession limits and long open seasons and on getting public shooting clubs for dues of $1 a year.

At least two independent groups of members of the New York Stock Exchange are taking steps to incorporate new exchanges in New Jersey, to escape the New York City tax on stock transfers and on brokers' profits.

Garment manufacturers are being overwhelmed with orders, and although work has been resumed, labor troubles still persist, according to the market report prepared especially for THE TIMES by McGreevey, Werring Howell, Inc. "It is the consensus of opinion," the buying office remarks, "that it will be utterly impossible to fill orders 100 per cent this season."

Most of the 35,000,000 bushels of Northwest Pacific wheat that the Agriculture Adjustment Administration plans to subsidize for export to foreign countries will be sold to China, Japan and the Philippines, Smith W. Nelson, president of the Port Authority of Seattle, said yesterday in an interview at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

OLD WESTBURY, L.I., Sept. 16. -- Miss Elise Ladew Grace, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Russell Grace, and Miss Martha Emily Allen, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frederic Winthrop Alien of White Oak Farm, Manhasset, were presented to North Shore society tonight at a supper dance given by Mr. and Mrs. Grace at Crossroad, their country home here.

HAVING so far published nearly thirty novels, the prolific Charles Alden Seltzer must be hard put to it now to find good new titles, for this one is not particularly apposite. But the story is much better than the title and, indeed, deserves a better.

DALLAS, Sept. 14. -- It looks now as though the hungry in Texas will be fed by the thirsty. Beer will probably be made to pay for the relief bonds to be issued by the special session of the Legislature. The economic argument was so much used in the campaign for beer that the brewers and distributers will find it difficult now to counteract it when a practical show-down is demanded.
CINCINNATI, Sept. 16. -- George T. Dunlap Jr., member of the Pomonok Country Club near Flushing, L.I., is one of the youngest players ever to win the National Amateur Golf championship.
Turning back the Cubs twice while the Pirates broke even with the Braves, the Giants yesterday practically clinched the National League pennant.

LAKE SEBAGO, N.Y., Sept. 16. -- The first week of New York University's pre-season football practice ended at the new training camp today. The squad of forty-six will remain here for another seven days. after which it will return to the campus gridiron at Ohio Field to complete preparations for its opening game against West Virginia Wesleyan on Oct. 7.

HANKOW, China, Aug. 11. -- The discovery of several chests of treasure, which have been buried for more than ninety years, has aroused a great commotion at Wuchang, the capital of Hupeh Province, which is just across the river from Hankow. Incidentally the first treasure find has brought the local Kuomintang party into fresh disrepute, and it is being vigorously attacked in the newspapers here.

DOWN at the Seamen's Church Institute, at 25 South Street, where men are mariners even though their ship has come in and left them stranded on Manhattan's beach, there is a tendency to scoff at the softer things of life.
Prices continued to move higher yesterday in trading on local commodities exchanges, with silver futures again in the lead. Trading was in fair volume for the halfday. cash prices also showed gains.

LONDON. AS the economic depression has dragged on, the British public, as distinct from the scholars and specialists, has become increasingly aware of that remarkable person, J.M. Keynes. He is to be heard occasionally in lecture halls or over the wireless.

Stocks and commodities rose sharply yesterday while the dollar was extending its decline in the foreign-exchange market. The advance on the Stock Exchange amounted to more than 2 points on the average, which canceled the losses of Friday.

Last Spring Mr. Gardner presented "The Case of the Velvet Claws," with Perry Mason as the leading character. Mason is not a detective but a lawyer who specializes in getting his clients out of the messes in which they happen to be involved.

Columbia will enter the most strenuous stage of its pre-season practice sessions tomorrow at Baker Field, for Coach Lou Little has scheduled an intensive scrimmage for the Lions. In fact, actual combat will be a daily diet for the Blue and White during the next two weeks, as Little believes in giving his pupils much heavy scrimmaging before the campaign actually opens.

AFTER a brief vacation in England, Patricia Bowman is back at work at the Radio City Music Hall, where she is to be seen at the moment in a choreographic setting of Rachmaninoff's C minor prelude. Miss Bowman's career is worthy of consideration not alone by reason of her personal endowments but also because it is representative of so many other American ballet dancers' careers.

CHICAGO. THE man in the boat drew a long breath as the fan of rainbow lights opened across the western sky. "It's sure pretty at night," he said. "In the daytime -- I dunno -- you can sort of see the thumb tacks.
POTSDAM, Sept. 16. -- The new Prussian State Council, Premier Goering's creation, met in the New Palace here today for its first "working session." The public and newspaper men were excluded.

TUXEDO PARK, N.Y., Sept. 16. -- For the tenth, time in his spectacular career in the show ring Champion Heather Reveller of Sporran went best-in-show today. The far-famed Scottish terrier, owned by S.S. Van Dine of New York City and shown in the ring by William Prentice, was declared best of the 478 dogs in the annual exhibition of the Tuxedo Kennel Club.

Federal and State legislation has tended to revive the minimum wage. Section 7 of the NRA provides that in every code of fair competition "employers shall comply with the * * * "minimum rates of pay * * * approved "or prescribed by the President." In addition, six States, New York among them, have recently enacted wage laws for women and children in industry, and similar legislation is under consideration in other States.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Sept. 16. -- As the gates of Harvard University open this week, students will learn that officials have taken several steps to reduce their living costs.

SHANGHAI, Aug. 26. -- Next month the Japanese naval landing party permanently stationed in Shanghai will occupy the largest, most costly and most completely equipped headquarters maintained inChina by any of the foreign powers.

CHICAGO, Sept. 16. -- The Giants' advance to the National League's 1933 pennant, halted on the first two days here, developed into a regular stampede today with even the Cubs jumping aboard the bandwagon.

VIENNA, Sept. 16 (AP). -- The centre of gravity in Austrian politics shifted today to Graz, where Vice Chancellor Winkler tomorrow will open the first big gathering of his National Corporative Front under the slogan of peace with Germany and the maintenance of Austrian independence from the control of anti-German power.

A continuation of the recent buying on. the Cotton Exchange absorbed week-end realizing and a moderate volume of hedging yesterday and sent prices back to or above the previous high prices of the week in the late trading. December contracts, after selling off early from 9.71 cents to 9.61, advanced to 9.79 cents and closed at 9.76.

GENEVA, Sept. 16. -- On Prime Minister Ramsay MacDonald's invitation, the directors of the financial and econoraic sections of the League of Nations, Alexandre Love-day and P. Stoppani, left today for London to discuss the situation regarding the World Economic Conference with him.

CHICAGO, Sept. 16. -- A belief that inflation of the currency was a fact instead of a theory suddenly became an influence today in the grain markets on the Board of Trade and prices rushed upward on a wave of buying that swept all before it.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Sept. 16. -- Rochester defeated the Newark Bears for the third straight time today, 9 to 7, to win the first-place International League play-off series by a margin of three games to one. Newark led the league at the end of the regular season.

LONDON, Sept. 10. -- Captain Anthony Eden, the Under-Secretary at the Foreign Office, who has done so well for himself at Geneva, is to be in Paris on Monday to discuss with the French Ministers the measure of common agreement possible with regard to the rearmament of Germany.

Another decline has been recorded by the weekly business index of THE NEW YORK TIMES, although two of its component series turned upward. For the week ended Sept. 9 the combined index dropped to 79.8 from 81.6 (corrected) in the preceding week.

ENCOURAGED by Marconi's success in ultra-short waves experimenters are turning attention to development of apparatus to function in that spectrum of the "ether" where waves are measured in centimeters instead of yards or meters.

The code committee of the ship-building and ship-repairing industry announced yesterday through the National Council of American Shipbuilders that hearings would be held on administrative rules and regulations of the industry in Washington on Sept. 26.
To the Editor of The New York Times: May I reply to the letter of Old Timer in regard to the brain power of the younger generation compared to that of Julia Newberry's time?

NEW YORK can look forward to a Mayoralty campaign which will be marked by verbal fireworks. The fact that Fiorello H. LaGuardia is one of the candidates is sufficient to insure this. Mayor O'Brien may be content to conduct a leisurely contest, but it is a foregone conclusion that his opponent will not permit things to drag along in a quiet fashion.

NO one in this country has been more constantly or more effectively on the job at guarding and guiding our mother tongue than Dr. Vizetelly, whose score or more of books and frequent admonishments from press and platform have for several decades exercised a wholesome influence upon our daily speech.
ROME, Sept. 16. -- Early next Spring the present Chamber of Deputies will end its full span of five years and Italy will face the problem of a general election.

THE four months since May 12, when President Roosevelt signed the Agricultural Adjustment Act, seems to me to constitute the most amazing period in the history of American agriculture. That swift, brief period has seen the launching of undertakings which are without precise parallel not only in the farming industry, but, also, I think, in any other industry in any country at any time.
GREENWICH CONN., Sept. 16. -- Many debutante parties are listed on the social calendar for the season here.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 16. -- To prevent further deterioration of War Department properties damaged in recent storms the Public Works Administration allotted $1,125,285 today for repairs.

MARY AGNES HAMILTON, former Member of Parliament and biographer of Ramsay MacDonald, has written a life of Sidney and Beatrice Webb which will do a great deal toward explaining the amazing career of this unique couple.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 15. -- Traditionally, this should be an off-year in Philadelphia politics. Actually, the political pot is boiling, on the eve of the primary election to be held Tuesday, as it has not boiled in years.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 16. -- European debtor nations tonight let their last opportunity for a legal postponement of war debt principal payments totaling $50,005,875 slip by without action.
CINCINNATI, Sept. 16. -- The hole-by-hole description of the match between George T. Dunlap Jr. and Max R. Marston for the national amateur golf championship follows:

WASHINGTON, Sept. 16. -- A basis for peace in the harassed bituminous industry and a wage contract covering about 500,000 miners seemed assured tonight when the United Mine Workers of America and the operators of the Appalachian field agreed upon the major points in dispute between them.

THE German word "anschluss," which bobs up in the news with almost every reference to Austro-German relations, has been more to the fore than ever with the accession of the Hitler party to power in the Reich. It is one of those words of many meanings and uses, although it has come of late to have special significance as identified with the union of Germany and Austria.
DENVER, Sept. 16 (AP). -- An abortive plot to kidnap Adolph Coors, wealthy Denver and Golden (Col.) brewer and clubman, for $50,000 ransom was disclosed today by Albert T. Clark, Chief of Police.

A FEW years ago transoceanic flying and attempts at the world's distance record called for almost identical preparations. They demanded the limit in loading. They required the utmost in cruising range. Then, with the introduction of higher speeds and more efficient engines and propellers, a transoceanic hop of itself did not require, that the perilous margin be attained in loading.

To the Editor of The New York Times: From time to time vociferous complaint is made from Panama that profitable trade is lost to its merchants because of the services rendered by the canal organization itself.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The letters you have published about universal fingerprinting were very interesting to members of the Federal Grand Jury Association. From their service they constantly realize the need of and the immense benefits that would arise from universal registration with thumb impression.

STRATFORD, Conn., Sept. 16. -- Dr. and Mrs. R.G. Vance of Waltham, Mass., gained the principal honors at the Remington Gun Club as the two-day Great Eastern skeet shooting championship meet got under way today, with more than 100 competing.

Ten forums will constitute the featured part of the program of the twenty-second annual convention of the Investment Bankers Association which will be held from Oct. 28 to Nov. 1 at Hot Springs, Va. According to the convention committee the forums are designed to encourage discussion to augment the usual regular program of addresses and committee reports.
TOKYO, Sept. 16. -- The references of Foreign Minister Hirota to Japan's China policy at his first meeting with foreign correspondents today were not accidental but have a deep significance. He said:

To the Editor of The New York Times: The daring cases of kidnapping, the prevalence of racketeering and and gang murders have focused attention on the growing need for more effectual repression of crime. Those who have given careful thought to this subject agree that prompt and certain punishment prevents crime more effectually than severity and cruelty.

THE fair name of Martha, Park Avenue beauty and orphaned heiress, had been sullied by the innuendos of the broker who bad managed her investments since her parents' deaths. Two masterful men, both in love with her, Cranston, a famous explorer, the other Pete, a young physician in charge of a charity clinic, spring loyally to the slandered girl's defense.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 16. -- A list of twenty-five camps for use in reforestation employment work during next Winter in New York State parks has been approved by the Civilian Conservation Corps. The list includes twelve present camps and thirteen new ones, but is only partial, as others may be added later.

BECAUSE "the women lied" the blond young giant Karl Sands becomes an outcast from his adoptive father's Lazy S ranch out on the crooked John Day River in Oregon. A bullet bad crashed through a window of the ranch-house and seared the eyeballs of j Prank Sands, the father, blinding him for the rest of his days.

Because today Is the 146th anniersary of the adoption of the Constitution of the United States many pastors will preach patriotic sermons. They will draw lessons from the parade of last Wednesday in support of President Roosevelt's reovery program, pointing out how the churches can help.

Grover A. Whalen, city chairman of the NRA, joined yesterday with employers and union representatives in the ladies' underwear industry in appealing to NRA authorities in Washington to defer action on the code for that industry pending settlement of the local strike of 25,000 workers.

MORE than a century after his death. De Witt Clinton's name is still illustrious and familiar, though most of his eminent -- even great-- New York contemporaries have become mere names to all but historical students. Many of them are no longer even names.
MXNEOLA, L.I., Sept. 16. -- Skeet shooting again held the centre of the stage at the Nassau Trapshooting Club today.

THE history of the Paris Peace Conference is yet to be written, but Mr. Nicolson has given us a book without which the writing of that history would be extremely difficult. Here is a picture of Europe of 1918-19 and of the peace conference itself, absolutely essential as background for any serious study of what happened and why.

Small lots of municipal bonds and warrants for September payment, four entire issues of bonds, three of them domestic and one foreign, together with parts of several domestic and foreign issues for redemption in future months, made up most of last week's announcements of securities to be retired before the dates when due.

As a result of the heavy rains, wholesale prices of string beans and lima beans advanced sharply in New York during the latter part of the week, particularly on fancy stock. This was announced yesterday by George G. Royce, director of the local office of the State Department of Agriculture and Markets, in his weekly consumers' review of local markets.

HAVANA. IN the heart of Havana, easily within reach of the most casual American tourist, stands a certain wall as a symbol which explains much that has been happening in Cuba. It is hallowed ground, a national shrine comparable, in the respect it receives from the Cuban people, to patriotic monuments in the United States in honor of our Revolutionary heroes.

TOKYO, Sept. 16 (AP). -- The Japanese Naval Minister, Admiral Mines Osumi, visited the navy's oracle, the national hero, Count Heihachiro Togo, today and asked the Russo-Japanese War leader for some word to allay a rising indignation among officers over the trial of ten young naval officers accused of killing Premier Inukai on May 15, 1932.
WILKES-BARRE, Pa., Sept. 16. -- Two men are known to be dead as a result of torrential rains which drenched this area today, flooding mines, imperiling dams and causing streams to overflow.

THE Radio and Electrical Exposition opens at Madison Square Garden at 11 A.M. on Wednesday. Until the exhibit closes on Sept. 30 the public will be admitted from 11 A.M. to 11 P.M. daily to view the new receivers, accessories and electrical equipment for the home, displayed by ninety-three manufacturers.

SOMEBODY has been holding out on us; otherwise we should have had an opportunity before this of meeting Benvenuto Brown, the painter detective, for there have been two other honks about him. Those two books may have slipped by in the days when publishers were putting out detective stories faster than they could possibly be reviewed.

A NEW season is bound to back and fill more or less before really getting round to a more resolute tack. A couple of sizable exhibitions have, however, served to indicate that the city's festival torpor is wearing off. Last week this page reported the first of the College Art Association's offerings (seven one-man traveling shows and some sculpture, at the New School far Social Research).

Street improvements under way or about to be started on the east side of Manhattan will bring further improvement in the crosstown traffic movement, according to the First Avenue Association, which announced yesterday that it had received notice from Borough President Samuel Levy of the awarding of a contract for widening East Fiftieth Street between First and Lexington Avenues.
PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 16 (AP). -- The Athletics divided a double-header with the Browns today. The Mackmen won the first game, 6 to 0, and the Browns took the second, 5 to 2.

GENEVA, Sept. 16. -- A plan for thorough "reorganization of a section of the League Secretariat is now in process of completion for submission to the forthcoming assembly in connection with the League's budget. Its adoption seems certain, although, judging from the opposition it is arousing, it is liable to cause a fight in the Assembly.

WHEN Edie Jones, a slum girl who worked in a jam factory, discovered that she was going to have a child as a result of a chance encounter on the docks with a romantic young foreigner name and nationality unknown-she realized it was high time to get married.

THIS first novel must inevitably remind the reader a little of the work of Elizabeth Madox Roberts and not suffer too badly by the comparison. It has a wonderful freshness about it; not simply the freshness of a new writer, but the freshness of a new world.
WILLIAMSBURG. Va., Sept. 16. -- William and Mary had a hard time tonight defeating Roanoke College, finally winning, 7 to 6.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Sept. 16. -- Yale's football squad, 100 strong, divided its second day of practice today between a two-hour morning session of grappling with the fundamentals and a demonstration drill of equal length and severity in the afternoon.

The engineer's task in the new industrial scheme of things now taking shape throughout the country will be in the development of new industries, Maurice Holland, director of the division of engineering and industrial research of the National Research Council, told THE TIMES yesterday.

CHICAGO, Sept. 16 (AP). -- Scoring their touchdowns in the third and final periods and showing far better team-work, the championship Chicago Bears of the National Professional League defeated the Notre Dame All-Stars in an exhibition game at Soldier Field today, 14 to 0.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Sept. 16. -- Extensive faculty and curricula changes will go into effect at Yale University upon the opening of the Fall term Sept. 25.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 18 (AP). -- Scientists who have struggled with animal experiments for weeks in an effort to solve the mystery of sleeping sickness finally have dedicated their own lives to the study.
PARIS, Sept. 14. -- A wave of sophistication in sweeping over the animal kingdom, in fact, goose feathers and monkey fur are having a permanent wave for hat and dress trimmings.

NEW YORK is no exception among American municipalities in having a powerful political machine controlling the policies and administration of the city. The organization selects and designates the candidates for office in the primaries, and elects them with ridiculous ease and regularity.

Declaring that the Board of Estimate was merely making a pre-election gesture in reducing salaries, Major F.H. LaGuardia, fusion candidate for Mayor, said yesterday these economies should have been put into effect long ago. He cited suggestions he made last June for salary reductions and added that political sinecures must be abolished to save the salares of teachers, policemen, firemen and other hard working city employes.

DALLAS, Texas, Sept. 16 (AP). -- A Federal official expressed the opinion, today that "about $50,000" was the price agreed upon between Harvey Bailey, notorious outlaw, and those who aided him in his Labor Day break from the Dallas County jail.

CINCINNATI, Sept. 16 (AP). -- Benny Frey singled in the tenth to score Morrissey and win his own game, 3 to 2, from the Phillies today. The last-place Reds also crashed through to win the second contest, 6 to 1.

BALBOA, C.Z., Sept. 16. -- Two United States soldiers, missing since last Sunday, when they sailed out of the Caribbean entrance of the Panama Canal in a tiny canvas-covered boat, were rescued 150 miles at sea today by the oil tanker Franz Klasen.

The fairly sharp setback in retail trade during the week from the volume increases noted in August focused attention once more on the vital role which the NRA drive must play in the stimulation of consumer demand, store executives here said yesterday.

WHEN May Robson left New York for Hollywood last week she imparted the information she was going to make a picture called "Hill Billies." Hollywood was too fast for her. The title already has been changed to "Comin' Round the Mountain."

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Sept. 16. -- National fraternities and local clubs have pledged eighty members of the Rutgers freshman class, thirteen sophomores and three juniors, Edward H. Heyd, assistant to the dean of men, announced today. This number represents an increase of seventeen over the number of men pledged by the twenty-one groups at the conclusion of the pre-season rushing period last Fall.

LONDON, Sept. 15. -- British, enthusiasm for the NRA campaign in the United States has cooled perceptibly in the last two or three weeks, compared with the early Summer, when it set whole sections of the House of Commons aflame.

BERLIN, Sept. 16. -- The organized recovery on the Boerse which had raised quotations sharply was succeeded today by reaction. Many stocks lost up to 3 per cent and some specialties declined as much as 5 per cent. Brewery shares which were strong yesterday, were among the biggest losers.

Miss Sara Cleveland Clapp, executive secretary and one of the founders of the Kips Bay Neighborhood Association at 794 Second Avenue, who had gained a national reputation in social work, died yesterday morning of a heart attack at the Murray Hill Sanitarium.

OYSTER BAY, L.I., Sept. 16. -- A strong northeasterly breeze that whipped the surface of Oyster Bay into whitecaps interfered with the opening schedule for the international dinghy series today. It forced the postponement of the second set of tests after the English team bad taken a commanding lead in points in the morning program.

GEORGE TICHENOR served his apprenticeship for novel writing as newspaper man in the South, trade-paper editor in New York and publicity man in the field of boom and depression finance. He has had a thorough grounding in the intricacies, philosophical problems and catch-as-catch-can tactics of the whole stock-and-bond hierarch led by those intrepid "younger" bankers who so unhappily steered the ship of Big Money onto the reef of Norman's Woe.

THE provincial lady is in the saddle again. With this novel Ethel Boileau joins the amiable procession of English women who manage to cast a roseate literary glow over the life of the county gentry in intimate, humorous, sometimes wry-mouthed, records.

TRENTON, N.J., Sept. 16. -- Governor A. Harry Moore made public today a letter which he said he had just received from Richard Whitney, president of the New York Stock Exchange. Mr. Whitney said that the offer of Governor Moore of a taxless haven for the Stock Exchange in New Jersey would "receive serious discussion and attention."

GENEVA, Sept. 16. -- Missionary work for the American NRA experiment will be done by the League of Nations International tabor Office, which, plans to publish in a fortnight a volume giving in English, French and German the texts of the chief laws and most Important codes in the Roosevelt recovery program.
Steel producers are expected to attempt to raise prices in the fourth quarter of the year unless the volume of business increases this month, according to authorities in the industry.

To mark the first anniversary of the establishment of Manchukuo as an independent State, an elaborate program of its plans for the future has been published. It is issued in a fifteen-page pamphlet by the South Manchurian Rail-way Company. To start with, an explanation is given of the "basic principle which underlay the founding of "the State."

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Sept. 14. -- Did the proceeds from highway bonds aggregating $163,000,000, sold at par or better, find their way into Arkansas's haphazard highway system? Governor J. M. Futrell says not.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 (AP). -- Here is the text of the NRA code agreed to by Hugh S. Johnson and the committee of eighteen representing the bituminous coal industry:
LONDON, Sept. 16. -- John McCormack's voice filled the Brompton Oratory today when he sang at the wedding of his only daughter, Gwendolyn, to Edward Pyke.

TORONTO, Ont., Sept. 16. -- Ontario's gold mines in August produced bullion to the value of $3,716,395, the second largest total for a month so far this year. The amount was exceeded in March, when the output ran $4,059,248. In July it was $3,636,754.

The explosion of an overheated steam boiler in the basement of a tenement at 601 East 139th Street yesterday rocked the four-story structure and threw the neighborhood into a momentary panic. Four persons were injured, windows were shattered and plastering and other debris fell in a shower.

BAIREOTH, Aug. 28, 1933. THOSE who possess the facsimile reproductions of the "Tristan" orchestral score (of which Wagner did not make his customary "fair copy" because of the necessity of sending batches of pages to the publisher as soon as they were instrumented) are aware of the evidences of turmoil In the composer's spirit which this extraordinary manuscript betrays.

SUPERIOR, Wis., Sept. 16 (AP). -- Ratification by the Senate, followed by immediate construction of the St. Lawrence deep waterway project, opening the Great Lakes ports to the commerce of the world and affording the Middle West a larger share of the benefits of the nation's industrial development, were urged here tonight in an address prepared for delivery by Secretary of War George H. Dern.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 16. -- An increase of slightly less than 1 per cent in wholesale commodity prices in August, compared with July, was reported today by the Bureau of Labor Statistics of the Department of Labor on the basis of a tabulation of 784 commodities.

LOS AHGELES, Sept. 16. -- Without encountering serious opposition, the national mixed doubles champions, Miss Elizabeth Ryan of England and Ellsworth Vines Jr., won their way to the third round of play in the Pacific Southwest tennis tournament today.

ATRIAL that may be one of the most celebrated in history is to open in Germany next Thursday after several postponements. At that time the Nazi government will begin to present voluminous evidence against five men accused of complicity in setting the Reichstag building afire on the night of Feb. 27.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 16. -- Price-fixing and price-maintenance, as defined in the proposed code for the retail trade, may be considerably changed or even eliminated from the program, it was learned today, as the NRA strove to complete the coal code and focus full attention upon the retail plan.

SIX years have passed since the rumor ran about that somebody, apparently with adequate command of funds, was rescuing from slow death as a decaying village -- or transformation into a modern college small town -- old Williamsburg, capital of Colonial Virginia from the beginning of the eighteenth century almost to the close of the Revolutionary War.

NOT all increases in incomes of colleges are due to added endowments. If a wealthy alumnus stepped into the office of a college president and presented to him a package of high-grade bonds which would yield his Alma Mater $100,000, $500,000, or even $25,000 a year, this gift would justly receive great publicity.

IRENE BROWNE, currently appearing in the film of "Berkeley Square," at the Galety, has only two other American pictures to her credit. The first was "The Letter," with Jeanne Eagels, which was produced here in 1929. The other was "Cavalcade," in which she had the role of Margaret Harris.
Fighting on bitterly in the last furlong at Belmont Park yesterday. Singing Wood beat off the challenge of Sir Thomas by a head and was first in the 5103,300 Futurity, richest race in the world.

PRECEDING H.S. Jennings, eminent biologist and Professor of Zoology at Johns Hopkins, as Terry lecturer at Yale have been J. Arthur Thomson, Robert A. Millikan and half a dozen other famous specialists in one or another branch of science.

Steamship companies of the North Atlantic continue to be foolish and stubborn and even "stupid," and have yet to take the most obvious step toward recovery, in the opinion of Andreas Frederik Bronsing, prominent Netherlands shipping man, who arrived Friday on the Hamburg-American liner Hamburg.

HARRISBURG, Pa., Sept. 16 (AP). -- The State Insurance Commission today said that the State ruling that life, fire, marine and casualty insurance companies may not purchase Home Loan Corporation bonds for investment will not materially affect out-of-State companies.

OMAHA, Neb., Sept. 13. -- Special sessions of both the Iowa and Kansas Legislatures are among the assured facts for the coining Fall, although the formal call has not yet been issued in either case. The present expectation is that both these law-making bodies will be assembled not later than Nov. 1.
JOHANNESBURG. KING MIDAS and his magic wand were not greater than the gold mining industrialists of the Witwatersrand in the Province of the Transvaal. Everything they touch promptly turns to gold.

In Mr. OWEN YOUNG'S NRA radio address on Wednesday he glanced backward for a moment to the conditions of industry and finance which preceded the collapse of 1929. In a summary phrase he declared that it was the system which broke down, not men. He was speaking of the failure of the large corporations to control their own business as they should have done, and also to make trade agreements with others.

LONDON, Sept. 16. -- Germany will not be able to raise money again in Britain, France or the United States "during our lifetime," declared Sir Arthur Samuel, member of Parliament and former Financial Secretary of the Treasury, speaking at Cambridge today.

CAMDEN, N.J., Sept. 16. -- A 72-year-old Camden political leader was shot dead tonight by his son when he attempted to prevent the younger man from shooting his estranged wife, according to the police.

PARIS, Sept. 16. -- A firm stand against disarmament until there is a slackening in the European tension was expected tonight to be taken by France during the tripartite conversations between the United States, French and British representatives beginning here Monday.

JERUSALEM, Sept. 15. -- Thousands of German Jews have been flocking into Palestine in the last few months, and, thanks to the existing prosperity of the country, they are all able to establish themselves comfortably.

THIS book is the result of field observations made by Professor Wheeler while in Western Australia in charge of the Harvard Australian Expedition for the Museum of Comparative Zoology. Australia, "faunistically still in the Mesozoic Age," is still the home of many forms of life which have disappeared elsewhere.

Now that the weather has turned its face toward Autumn, fugitives from the city are boarding up their Summer homes. After a season of toil and crisis they can look forward to a Winter of peace and rest in town. The city will coddle them; it will protect them against the savagery of the mechanical world.
The Manhattan football team will make an early start in its second season under John F. (Chick) Meehan, facing a strong opening opponent in St. Bonaventure College at Ebbets Field next Saturday.

GOBINEAU'S belief in the racial superiority of the German Aryans restated a predilection for things Teutonic which marked much of the early political thought in France. In his recent book, Dr. Barzun demonstrates very interestingly in what manner the conflict between exponents of the Nordic and of the Latin origin of the French race has influenced the current of history.

Deputy Controller Frank J. Prial received the good wishes of thousands of city employes and friends yesterday, when he closed his twenty-eight years of city service as a preliminary to his independent fight for the Controllership.

AMITYVILLE. L.I., Sept. 16. -- Garvin Denby, former head of the Denby Motor Truck Company of Detroit and a brother of the late Edwin Denby. who was Secretary of the Navy in the Hording administration, died this morning in the Brunswick Hospital here after an operation for acute appendicitis.

MACHINES are not mind readers. It Is still necessary for the master to tell his slave what he wants done. But when he has given the order, using the mechanical language which the machine understands, he can pretty well sit back and let the automaton do the work -- as Wiley Post found perfectly practicable on his recent aeronautical tour around the world.

Gama birds In the United States have shown a decided increase in almost very State, according to surveys now being made public. For many years the problem of halting the decrease has been a vexing one. With the aid of science, however, the trend is now upward.

SYRACUSE, Sept. 16. -- With a well-defined, training policy in mind, Vie Hanson, head coach at Syracuse University, had his first group of thirty-five football mea in active scrimmage three days after the opening of practice during the past week.

HERE and there in our standardized civilization (possibly one should now say our highly coded civilization) it seems that remnants of individuality linger and that not all American biographies are alike. Here, are twenty-seven narratives, though not all of them are life-rstories.
ELKINS, W. Va., Sept. 16 (AP). -- Clicking in mid-season fashion, Davis and Elkins today swamped Morris Harvey in its opening gridiron clash of the season, 45 to 0.

Rare books, autographs, original manuscripts and prints from the estates of Benjamin Alexander and Charles Wharton Stork, and other private sources will be sold at auction next Wednesday afternoon and evening at the art galleries of Samuel T. Freeman Co., 1,808-10 Chestnut Street, Philadelphia.

EVERY now and then a wave of color printing breaks across the shore line of graphic art. Usually it serves to convince most of us that we are not yet ready to improve upon black and white through the use of color.

WITH England, Scotland, Ireland and Wales pretty much excited about the play, "Is Life Worth Living?" is now destined for this country, too. Harry Moses has acquired the usual rights, and he expects to put forward Lennox Robinson's latest whimsical gesture almost immediately.

CHICAGO, Sept. 16. -- A suit charging seventeen present and former directors or officers of the Standard Oil Company of Indiana with making $6,000,000 to $8,000,000 in "secret profits" through breaches of trust was filed in the Federal District Court today.

The number of consumers who have signed the NRA pledge to buy from employers under the Blue Eagle has been increased to 2,225,000 by the 50,000 canvassers in New York City, it was announced yesterday by Grover A. Whalen, city NRA chairman.
TODAY. SYMPHONY -- Nicolai Berezowsky conducting an hour program of symphonic music: WABC, 3 P.M.

CHICAGO, Sept. 14. -- There are so many variables in the new deal for agriculture that future trends in the basic industry cannot be chartered with any degree of accuracy, farm and market experts through the Middle West agree. Whether the total bonus of the wheat farmer will be larger than the earning power of the acres which, he will not use for commercial crops if he reduces his wheat acreage is arousing much controversy.

DINNERWARE, attractively new in form and decoration, now tempts the householder, who wants to have her dining board as up to date as her clothes. Augmenting the traditional period designs. American makers are offering tableware in accord with present-day decorative vogues and new ideas of efficiency.

BRENTWOOD, L.I., Sept. 16. -- A. Leo Flynn, theatrical business manager who had been associated with James K. Hackett, Otts Skinner and many other actors and producers in the last twenty years, was found dead today in a wooded spot near here.

Faced with the task of adopting an entirely new brand of football at the outset of its pre-season practice, the Fordham University squad has revealed in a fortnight an adeptness and versatility which has exceeded the expectations of its new coach, Sleepy Jim Crowley.
JEFFERSON CITY, Mo., Sept. 16 (AP). -- Sam A. Baker, former Governor of Missouri, died at his home here early today. He was 59 years old.

The Eastern railroad presidents traffic conference will meet this week with a view to bringing about the first reduction in the basic passenger rate in a decade. The object of the meeting will be to reconcile their views with those of the West and South and it is their hope to reach an agreement at least by Nov. 1.

Fairly wide irregularity of prices marked the two-hour trading yesterday in the listed bond market. Domestic corporation issues averaged lower, foreign loans went higher and United States Government long-term obligations closed 7-32 higher to 2-32 point lower.

ONE of Mr. Kauffman's best the novels in serious vein, this is the graphic story of a deeprooted American family in slow material disintegration during the prewar years and after. Its scene is a town in Southeastern Pennsylvania where, since early Colonial days, the Kearsleys and their kin have provided the community with an unbroken line of leading citizens.

SAN JOSE, Calif., Sept. 16 (AP). -- David A. Lamson was convicted tonight on a charge of murdering his attractive wife, Allene Thorpe Lamson, in their Stanford University campus home last Memorial Day by a jury which recommended the death penalty.

HAVANA, Sept. 16. -- Sumner Welles, United States Ambassador, said this afternoon that he was much encouraged by the results of the informal conference late last night, and early this morning with members of the Students' Directorate.

A heavy demand for sewing machines from the women's garment industry in order to increase output under the shorter hours of the NRA codes was reported here yesterday. While executives of the leading sewing machine companies declined to give details of the increase in orders, the gain was described as "substantial."

Additional conferences of officials of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation and representatives of the Amtorg Trading Corporation are scheduled in a week or two, it was said yesterday. Negotiations for a loan of $50,000,000 to $75,000,000 to the Soviet Government will be continued then.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 16 (AP). -- After losing the first game of a double-header to Boston, 6 to 4, chiefly because of lax fielding, the Pirates came back today behind Birkofer's four-hit pitching and shut out the Braves, 10 to 0, in the nightcap.

TACOMA, Wash., Sept. 16. -- A condenser which provides protection against electric waves brought relief this week from years of suffering to Martin Bodker, an Enumclaw rancher, known in this section as the "human radio."

THE bell that summoned more than 1,000,000 of the city's children back to their classes last Monday was also the signal for a new drive to save them from the Moloch of traffic. Education in a motorized metropolis includes learning to avoid the spinning wheels of automobiles.

GREEN BAY, Wis., Sept. 17 (AP) -- The Boston Redskins came from behind in the closing minutes of a National Professional Football League game today to score a touchdown and gain a 7-7 tie with the Green Bay Packers.

VIENNA, Sept 17 -- A spirited reply is made in an editorial in the Reichspost, official organ of the Austrian Government party, to assertions of Foreign Minister von Neurath of Germany that his country had not "interfered in the affairs of a foreign power" in its activities to support Naziism in Austria.

John F. Curry, leader of Tammany, denied last night rumors that Mayor John P. O'Brien would be withdrawn after the primary election tomorrow and Grover A. Whalen or former Aldermanic President Joseph V. McKee substituted.

The Ward liner Morro Castle, which was due to arrive from Havana at 8 A. M. on Saturday and to sail again at 4 P. M. the same day, has been delayed by the 100-mile-an-hour hurricane which has been blowing up from the South since Friday.

Many prominent women of society in New York and several other large cities of the East are aiding in the arrangements for the National Charity Air Pageant, to be held on Oct. 7 and 8 at Roosevelt Field for the benefit of the Judson Health Centre, the Emergency Exchange Association and the Junior League relief divisions outside New York State.

Obligations of the United states Government that will mature within the next twelve months amount to $2,904,912,200. They consist of Treasury certificates of indebtedness, notes and non-interest-bearing discount bills.

WARSAW, Sept. 17 -- A sensation has been caused here, especially among Polish Jews, by the unexpected arrival of Dr. Hildesheimer, chief rabbi of Berlin, who attempted to dissuade the Polish Jews from continuing their boycott of German goods.

SEA GIRT, Sept. 17 -- Passage of enabling legislation in New Jersey to make bonds of the Federal Home Owners Loan Corporation legal investments for State banks and insurance companies will be sought within a few days, Governor A. Harry Moore said here today.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 (AP) -- President Roosevelt has asked for the resignation of William E. Humphrey, Republican member of the Federal Trade Commission, and Mr. Humphrey has refused to resign.

The Provident Institution for Savings of Jersey City resold to Mrs. Eleanor Max the residence at 44 Gifford Av., Jersey City, for a reported price of about $23,500. The buyer gave back to the seller. In part payment, a mortgage for $15,000, due July 1, 1936, at 6 per cent, with $125 of the principal to be paid off quarterly beginning next Jan. 1.

CHICAGO, Sept. 17 -- After a three-day postponement, Jack Sharkey, former world's heavyweight champion, will meet Chicago's wild-swinging King Levinsky in their ten-round outdoor battle in Cominsky Park tomorrow night, weather permitting.

An iron worker, a hairdresser, a carpenter, a letter carrier, a Park Avenue governess and a patent attorney are among the twenty-nine men and women who have received scholarships or merit awards in the amateur artists' contest of the Art Students' League of New York, it was announced yesterday.

PARIS, Sept. 17 -- On the eve of what every one is calling the most fateful disarmament discussions since the end of the World War, the temper of the French people and officials seems adamant against disarmament, but fear of the consequences of failure in the talks this week is so great that there is a chance the French may lean over backward to yield something to Germany.

The southern hurricane, hurtling northeastward, passed New York well out at sea yesterday, lashed at the eastern tip of Long Island and struck with slowly diminishing fury along the Massachusetts coast.
BERLIN, Sept. 15. -- By means of a belated but successful attempt to check the sharp decline in securities, Germany last week narrowly escaped a bad financial situation.
CHICAGO, Sept. 17 -- Moving backward with unusual celerity, the Dodgers dropped both ends of a double-header to the Cubs today before 20,000 fans.
A crowd of about 18,000 saw enough baseball thrills at the Stadium yesterday to make up for the shortage provoked by the long absence of the sun.

Creditors of Palmer Co., a former New York Stock Exchange firm that was petitioned into bankruptcy on Dec. 9, 1931, will receive an additional dividend of 15 percent, it was announced yesterday by Percival E. Jackson of counsel for the Plan Liquidating Corporation, which was formed to liquidate the assets of Palmer Co.

THE judges in the Frederick A. Stokes Company-Hodder and Stoughton prize novel contest have awarded $20,000 to an appealing anachronism. The winning novelist is Janet Beith, the niece of Ian Hay; her book, "No Second Spring" ($2.50) makes use of the ancient theme of the minister's wife to whom the flesh was not fundamentally an evil thing, nor profane love necessarily a one-way ticket to Purgatory.

Construction contracts for the month of August throughout the country attained the highest volume for any month this year, reports the F.W. Dodge Corporation. The aggregate volume of $106,131,000 also represented a gain of about 38 per cent over July.
NEW YORK. Mrs. Stephen H. Tyng has returned from Dixville Notch, N.H., and is at the Ambassador for the Winter.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., Sept. 17 -- Bermuda skippers took the first race in the series with the Long Island Sound Interclub sloops today. The invading one-design boats scored 19 points to 17 1/4 for the home craft.

OYSTER BAY, L.I., Sept. 17 -- Once again a stiff northerly breeze interfered with the international dinghy series in Oyster Bay today and once more it was Great Britain which dominated the one set of races held.

An exhibition and sale of handicraft made by refugees from the Near East will be held on Friday at the home of Mrs. Herbert S. Houston in Plandome, L.I., under the auspices of the Near East Foundation.
NEW BERN, N.C., Sept. 17 (AP) -- Reports arriving tonight added almost hourly to the toll of dead in the tropical hurricane which whipped the sparsely settled North Carolina sound country yesterday.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Senator Hatfield of West Virginia attacked the NRA recently. The attitude revealed in this attack was much more enlightening than the stupid arguments presented to substantiate it. At last a bitter partisanship, which has been smoldering in opposition to the New Deal, burst out with a blaze of condemnation in a feeble attempt to light the way for a few last-ditchers.

BALTIMORE, Sept. 17 (AP) -- George M. Shriver, senior vice president of the Baltimore Ohio Railroad, announced today that, "as a result of improved business conditions," the railroad was in a position to pay the $5,000,000 of Cleveland, Lorain Wheeling consolidated bonds which mature Oct. 1.

NORFOLK, Va., Sept. 17 -- Badly battered and with her skipper suffering from cuts about his throat from falling glass, the Diamond Shoals lightship has been ordered in and will probably reach this port Tuesday. Lightship No. 80 was dispatched from the Norfolk lighthouse depot today to relieve the Diamond Shoals craft and is expected to reach her position off Cape Hatteras tomorrow.

Mrs. Charles Suydam Cutting heads a group of prominent women who are aiding in the sale of seats for the first showing of the motionpicture version of Eugene O'Neill's "The Emperor Jones," which will be given tomorro night at the Rivoli Theatre for the benefit of the babies' wards of the Post-Graduate Hospital.

ELIZABETH, N.J., Sept. 17 -- By defeating Union County at Warlnanco Park today, the Brooklyn Cricket Club tied the Crescent Athletic-Hamilton Club for the Metropolitan and New Jersey Cricket Association title.
BERLIN, Sept. 17 -- The Institute for the Study of Trade Fluctuations warns that the present wave of German price rises is not in accord with the nation's reduced buying power.

The most ambitious radio broadcast ever attempted will be part of the second Byrd Antarctic expedition next Winter, it was announced yesterday by representatives of Admiral Byrd and the Columbia Broadcasting Company. The broadcasting company will pick up the voices of the expedition in Antarctica and will relay them over its nation-wide network.

An intensive study of slums and blighted areas is to be undertaken immediately by the Phelps Stokes Fund, it was announced yesterday. The investigation will deal with slum causes, prevention, elimination and conversion for proper housing or other uses.

CHALK up another victory for the NRA program. The Havemeyer Trophy was recovered from Canada amid the firing on the Kenwood course near Cincinnati last week. The championship title in amateur golf was won by George T. Dunlap Jr. and custody of the big silver cup goes with it. George is on the small side, rather thin, with a blond thatch and a quick smile.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 (AP) -- The Senators maintained their pennant march today with a stirring ninth-inning rally to beat the Tigers, 4 to 3.

STOCKHOLM, Sept. 17 -- Colonel and Mrs. Charles A. Lindbergh visited today the farm that the Colonel's grandfather owned, and, while they did not reveal their plans, it is believed their next destination will be Leningrad, Russia. Colonel Lindbergh is anxious to meet Soviet airmen with a knowledge of Siberian air routes.

Despite the fact that obligations of domestic corporations maturing in the first half of 1933 amounted to approximately $575,000,000, less than $160,000,000 of refunding securities was offered to the public, according to R.H. Van Deusen, president of Stone Webster and Blodget, Inc., in an article in the current issue of the Stone Webster Bulletin.

Six Americans are among twelve men chosen by Jewish newspaper editors as the greatest Christian champions of the Jewish people during the last year. The result of the nation-wide poll, embracing forty-three Jewish newspapers, was made public yesterday by Joseph Brainin, editor of the Seven Arts Feature Syndicate.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 -- Instructions have been sent by General Johnson to local compliance boards directing them to maintain a lenient and courteous attitude toward employers who have signed President Roosevelt's Blue Eagle agreement.
ALLENTOWN, Pa., Sept. 17 -- Silk workers of the Lehigh Valley district, where upward of 10,000 are employed, decided today to join with other centres of the industry in continuing to strike.
CHICAGO, Sept. 17 (AP) -- Pickets were missing today from most of the Northern Illinois counties where for four days milk shipments were halted. Milk moved into the Chicago market in normal amounts.

Jewish civilization, in order to succeed, must be founded on an economic system that will insure justice for all, Dr. Samuel Dinin, research graduate at Teachers College, Columbia University, asserts in his survey on "Judaism in a Changing Civilization," made public yesterday.

Stolen goods valued at $10,000 and consisting of such heterogeneous articles as surgical instruments, a Pekingese dog, women's apparel and a viola said to belong to Alma Gluck, opera singer, were recovered yesterday by detectives of the West 100th Street station.

CHICAGO, Sept. 17 -- Farmers in the Corn Belt need money, particularly those in Illinois and Iowa who were credited with selling more than 4,000,000 bushels of old corn to Chicago cash handlers last week. This corn, which will be shipped in the next ten days, was largely hedged by sales of futures in the pit.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Your editorial "Federal Funds for New York" gives the impression that Mayor O'Brien and New York City have been neglectful of the opportunity of securing some of the $3,300,000,000 appropriated for public works in the National Recovery Act.

HAVANA, Sept. 17 -- Civil war in Cuba is inevitable it a coalition Cabinet is not formed, business leaders of the island warned today in a statement prepared yesterday at a joint meeting of the largest corporations.

Two men were injured and two others arrested in Jersey City yesterday following a fight on First Street, near Coles Street, said by the police to have resulted from a disagreement between two factions of shoe workers on strike. Police reserves dispersed a crowd of about one hundred workers in the street.

Outdistancing thirty five star competitors by his remarkable consistency through the three-day grind, David Burnstine won the annual individual masters' contract bridge championship of the American Bridge League at the Ritz-Carlton Hotel yesterday.

The two-story building at 441 West Twenty-fifth Street, adjoining the Flanagan-Nay Brewery plant, has been purchased by the brewing company, of which Thomas G. Lanphier is president, for expansion purposes.

PLAINFIELD, N. J., Sept. 17 -- Five Plainfield girls will be introduced at supper dances to be given at the Plainfield Country Club next Friday and Saturday nights. All are former students of Miss Porter's School, at Farmington, Conn.

Alpha Distributors, Inc., has been formed by the former executives of the securities department of Henry L. Doherty Co. to deal in securities of every kind. R.C. Russum is president of the organization and S.B. Irelan is first vice president and general manager.

The Literary Guild choice for October is "Peter Abelard," a novel over which Helen Waddell worked, she says, for seven years. Miss Waddell is an Irish, woman who was born in Tokyo. Henry Holt will publish her book on Sept. 28.

BERLIN, Sept. 17 -- Addressing a large rally of Hitler youth in Weimar today, Dr. Wilhelm Frick, Reich Minister of the Interior, who equally with General Hermann Wilhelm Goering and Dr. Paul Joseph Goebbels can be accepted as the mouthpiece of militant Nazidom, made this statement:

Support of the National Recovery Act as a necessary social, economic and spiritual instrument was urged by ministers in various pulpits here yesterday. President Roosevelt's policy of national reconstruction was hailed as a step in the right direction.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 17 -- Thus far there has been no seasonal increase in steel buying, but majority opinion in the trade had been that any rise would begin late in September rather than in the early part of the month, while some observers had expected no improvement before the early part of October.

OAKLAND, N.J., Sept. 17 -- The Rev. Isley Boone, former supply pastor of the Ponds Reformed Church here, involved in a controversy over nudism, has tendered his resignation as a member of the consistory of that church. The Rev. Allen B. Reed and the officials will not accept it because of some of the sentences in the letter, which said:

The largest volume of sales in their history has been made since July 1 by time-recording instrument companies, particularly the four largest concerns making timeclocks, it was announced yesterday by Grover A. Whalen, City NRA Chairman, at NRA headquarters in the Hotel Pennsylvania.

PARIS, Sept. 16. -- After displaying some weakness, prices on the Bourse showed a tendency to harden slightly. The improvement this week was not due to any increase in the volume of business, which remained small, but chiefly to the better tendency in Wall Street, which has been followed attentively by the Paris market.

SAN JOSE, Calif., Sept. 17 (AP) -- Convicted of wife murder and facing death on the gallows, David Lamson, 31-year-old Stanford University publishing house executive today clung to the hope of being saved by an appeal.

CHICAGO, Sept. 17 -- With 85 percent or more of business and manufacturing concerns here included in the NRA agreement and with consumers in general pledging support and buying in a fairly liberal way, a survey of business has raised the question of profits since the trade revival started.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 (AP) -- With the time limit for filing returns by gold hoarders expiring at midnight tomorrow, the Treasury announced to day it would entertain requests for extensions from individuals unable to comply because of circumstances beyond their control.

Because officials of the Irving Trust Company refuse to submit to a private preliminary examination by the subcommittee of the Congressional Judiciary Committee investigating Federal and equity receiverships in this district, public hearings scheduled here for Oct. 2 must be postponed for two or three weeks, Leo T. Kissam, counsel for the committee, announced yesterday.

Protest against the contemplated award of Manhattan bus franchises to the New York City Omnibus Corporation and the Comprehensive Bus Company was made in an open letter sent to Mayor O'Brien yesterday by John R. Thompson, president of the Green Bus Lines, Inc., operator of six crosstown routes under a one-year franchise.

One of the first memories of THE NEW YORK TIMES is of the creation of Central Park. In a message to the Common Council in the year 1851 (the same year in which THE TIMES first appeared) Mayor KINGSLAND called attention to the need of recreation spaces uptown.

PITTSFIELD, Mass., Sept. 17 -- Representative Alien T. Treadway observed his sixty-sixth birthday yesterday at Stockbridge, and was the guest of honor at a luncheon given by his daughter-in-law, Mrs. Heaton I. Treadway, at the Crossways.

The Christian ministry of today is desperately in need of men of faith and strength to stand fast against the tidal wave that is sweeping the country in the colleges and in literature, destroying the religion of our young men and women, declared the Rev. Dr. Cortland Myers of Los Angeles, Calif., in his sermon yesterday morning at the First Baptist Church at Broadway and Seventy-ninth Street.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I have a sidelight on what the man in the Corn Belt thinks. I send you a few excerpts from a letter received from a retired farmer and banker who still makes his home on his farm, operating a part of it:

WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 (AP) -- A general program calling for inflation to improve farm prices will be outlined here tomorrow by members of Congress from Southern States who are expected to present their views to President Roosevelt.

With a race for horses of all ages occupying the place of honor on the card, the Fall meeting of the Queens County Jockey Club will begin today at Aqueduct. The featured event is at six and one-half furlongs and finds seven entered, three juveniles, two 3-year-olds and two 5-year-olds.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 17 -- Fred Perry, national champion and English Davis Cup star, made his first appearance in the defense of his Pacific Southwest singles title today and defeated Richard Belote of South Pasadena, California intercollegiate doubles champion, 6 -- 1, 6-3.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 -- Senator Thomas D. Schall, independent Republican of Minnesota, in another statement today attacking the administration's recovery program, said General Johnson would be able to exercise a complete censorship of the press after Jan. 1.

GENEVA, Ind., Sept. 17 -- The Limberlost, made famous by the writings of Gene Stratton Porter, may be turned into a lake as a result of the efforts of Mrs. Virginia Jenckes, Indiana's woman Member of Congress, to keep the Wabash River within its banks.

The Fifth Avenue Coach Company will place in operation today on its Washington Square-Riverside Drive route a new and more comfortable type of bus, equipped with front entrance and exit facilities and pneumatic tires. Only one of these vehicles will be available for the present, but additional buses of the same type will be substituted for existing equipment if the trial operation proves satisfactory.

NEW HAVEN, Sept. 17 -- Professor Irving Fisher's index number of commodity prices, based on 100 as the average for 1926, is 71.1, which compares with 70.9 a week ago, 70.8 two weeks ago, 70.4 three weeks ago and 70.3 four weeks ago. The present average is the highest of the year to date; the highest July figure was 70.4.
CHICAGO, Sept. 17 (AP) -- An Illinois commission today was engaged in evolving a bill for liquor contral after the projected repeal of prohibition.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 -- President Roosevelt is preparing to fight for ratification of the St. Lawrence treaty with Canada and will move this week to include the project in the Federal public works program, according to some of his advisers.

The Manhattan Railway Company, owner of the elevated lines operated under lease by the Interborough, has asked the United States Supreme Court to bar Senior Judge Martin T. Manton of the United States Circuit Court of Appeals from further participation in the Interborough equity receivership proceedings.

Modern intellectuals who scorn religion are only provincial pagans, declared the Rev. Dr. Ralph W. Sockman yesterday at the Madison Avenue Methodist Episcopal Church, Sixtieth Street and Madison Avenue.

CHICAGO, Sept. 17 -- Prices of hogs advanced to $5 a hundred pounds on Friday, the highest since June 3, but they slipped again as the big packers refused to follow the upturn. The top price was 40 cents higher than a week ago and 50 cents above that of two weeks earlier.
MADRID, Sept. 17 -- In order to strengthen its hand the Lerroux government has cleared out in half a week not only the leading officeholders in all the government departments but many minor ones.

MILLINGTON, N.J., Sept. 17 -- The annual military field mass of the Veterans of Foreign Wars was held at the Veterans Hospital here this morning. About 4,000 were present. Veterans of the Twenty-ninth Division, who held their annual reunion in Newark yesterday, were present in large numbers.

The adoption of the NRA newspaper code has placed the present national administration on record as recognizing the unrestricted freedom of the press. This assertion was made by Dean Carl W. Ackerman of the Columbia School of Journalism in his annual report to Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of the university, made public yesterday.

ON BOARD THE STEAMSHIP MORRO CASTLE, Sept. 17 -- Lost to the Ward Line owners, without radio two days, Morro Castle sent word this noon, that her 140 passengers and crew of 200 were safe, having weathered a hurricane for forty-eight hours off Hatteras.

Administrative savings totaling at least $25,225,063 are recommended in a final report made public yesterday by the special committee on municipal economy, headed by Peter Grimm, chairman of the Citizens Budget Commission. Additional savings of $10,000,000 are possible, if the city authorities co-operate sincerely, the report concludes.

Samuel Untermyer, in a letter sent last night to Peter Grimm, head of the economy committee that submitted a report on possible savings in the administration of the City Government, disagreed with some of the recommendations contained in the report.

PARIS, Sept. 16 -- The deficit in the French budget is officially estimated at 6,000,000,000 francs, but in reality it is probably seven or even eight billions. It will be impossible to get Parliament to vote so huge a cut in expenditures, so that the deficit will probably be met partly by economies and partly by fresh taxation.

Fearful that steadily mounting prices will disrupt their established pricing policies, retailers in the women's apparel trade last week appealed to suppliers to plan new merchandise so that it can be fitted into price ranges with which consumers have become familiar.

Formation of the firm of Hedden, Farwell Co. to engage in underwriting new capital issues for industry, was announced yesterday by Stuart Hedden, who will retire today from the Stock Exchange firm of Fuller, Rodney Co. The new firm will include Grosvenor Farwell, formerly a partner in Hitt, Farwell Co. Its offices will be in the Bunkers Trust Building, 14 Wall Street.

Guthrie McClintic, producer and director of "Jezebel," the new Owen Davis play in which Tallulah Bankhead was scheduled to appear, will decide today whether to defer the opening of the play, originally scheduled for the Martin Beck Theatre next Monday night, until Miss Bankhead recovers from her present illness or to abandon its production altogether.

There will be plenty of upland game birds for the hunters in New Jersey this Autumn, according to an announcement made yesterday by the Fish and Game Commission of that State. A survey, completed only last week, disclosed that there is an abundance of quail, grouse and pheasant in the woods and fields.

NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 17 -- A number of members of the Clambake Club braved the wind and rain today to drive to the clubhouse at the tip of Easton's Point to attend an oyster roast, the last regular gathering of the season. The trap shoot for the Walter S. Andrews trophy, originally set for Labor Day, was again postponed.

MANILA, Sept. 17 -- The Filipino Veterans Association, composed of insurrectionists who fought for independence thirty years ago, meeting in convention under the leadership of General Emilio Aguinaldo today, rejected the Hawes-Cutting Independence Law and adopted a resolution to be forwarded to the United States Congress and to President Roosevelt.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 -- Seeking to bring about "more equitable competitive conditions" among rail, water and highway transportation agencies, the Chamber of Commerce of the United States today began a poll of member organizations on eighteen questions designed to eliminate present unfair competitive advantages.

SPILLVILLE, Iowa, Sept. 17 (AP) -- To the strains of the "New World" symphony and other compositions of Antonin Dvorak, this village celebrated today the fortieth anniversary of the three-months' visit of the noted composer here.

SAARBRUECKEN, Saar Basin Territory, Sept. 17 -- Although it is at least sixteen months until the plebiscite to decide the future sovereignty of this border district, a vigorous campaign is already under way to insure its return to Germany.

CINCINNATI, Sept. 17 -- George T. Dunlap Jr., the New York boy who concentrated on developing his golf game because it was good for his health to be outdoors, has now achieved the third and the greatest of his three goals in becoming the new amateur champion of the United States.

Only a changed heart can bring a changed world, and a spirit convinced of its own freedom can impose a like joyousness upon outside appearances, the Rev. Dr. James Black, minister of St. George's Church, Edinburgh, Scotland, said in his sermon yesterday morning at the Collegiate Reformed Church of St. Nicholas, Fifth Avenue and Forty-eighth Street.
