Governor Lehman, at the joint request of the city and its bankers, will confer with them this week in an effort to work out a comprehensive financial program which will so restore municipal credit as to make possible a loan of at least $72,000,000 to meet current expenses for the remainder of 1933.

With silver taking the lead, all commodities traded on local exchanges made substantial gains in prices in last week's operations. The volume of trading increased from its abnormally low level. All cash prices were higher on the week also.

Reflecting the approach of the traditional "moving day," Oct. 1, numerous apartment rentals were reported over the week-end, In Manhattan the larger volume of leases came from the west side, though numerous tenants for east side houses and structures in the Washington Square and Greenwich Village areas also were listed.

Modern people are masterless men and women and are crying for leadership, the Rev. Dr. Bernard Iddings Bell declared yesterday in his sermon at St. Thomas Episcopal Church, Fifth Avenue and Fifty-third Street. He deplored what he termed the "caricature of true democracy" that has long prevailed in America and welcomed the reassertion of leadership in the United States and elsewhere.

Revision of the State trade-mark law to conform in general with the Federal statutes will be urged by the Merchants Association tomorrow at a hearing by the joint legislative commission appointed to consider proposed modifications. The session will open at 2 P.M. in the association's assembly room at the Woolworth Building and continue Wednesday.

BALTIMORE, Sept. 17 (AP) -- The 12-year-old daughter of F. Scott Fitzgerald, whose novel, "This Side of Paradise," dealt with the American flapper some years ago, thinks that most of the girls and boys about whom her father wrote are rather incompetent parents today.

HINGHAM, Mass., Sept. 17 -- While Thomas Magner, 76, took off his coat and stood ready to flag the train, his grandson, Daniel Magner Jr., 16, of Eldridge Court, ran to give the warning of a serious washout on the Greenbush division of the New Haven Railroad seven minutes before a local was due this afternoon.

DUBLIN, Sept. 17 -- Blue Shirts were worn in large numbers in a procession at Thurles tonight as the United Ireland party opened its campaign with a public rally. Blue shirts were also around the platform, from which General Owen O'Duffy, William T. Cosgrave and other leaders spoke.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 -- The amended bituminous coal code which was signed yesterday will not go to the White House before tomorrow, and may be further delayed for the President's signature in order that the labor, industry and consumers advisory boards may have an opportunity to examine the document.

CHICAGO, Sept. 17 -- Assistant State's Attorney Edwin J. Raber said today that he was prepared to go to trial next month on the indictment naming Aaron Sapiro, Alphonse Capone, Murray Humphries, Alderman Oscar F. Nelson, Dr. Benjamin M. Squires and nineteen others in an alleged racket conspiracy.

Mr. McCOOEY is and has to be cheerful in his predictions about the results at the primary elections tomorrow. Mr. O'BRIEN will have an easy victory over his two Democratic opponents. Mr. HARMAN, " solidly" supported by the organization, working with perfect smoothness, will have no trouble in disposing of Mr. PRIAL.

HAVANA, Sept. 17 -- President Grau San Martin and the Students Directorate that rules Cuba have been warned by Professor A.A. Berle, adviser to Ambassador Welles, that the economic paralysis crippling the island's industries threatens a complete business collapse and widespread disorders.

A new beginning is necessary for the continued existence of the present set-up of the modern economic and social life, the Rev. Paul B. Ward said yesterday in his sermon at the 11 o'clock high mass of the Roman Catholic Church of St. Paul the Apostle, Sixtieth Street and Columbus Avenue.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 -- William F. Stevenson, chairman of the Frderal Home Loan Bank Board and of the board of directors of the Home Owners' Loan Corporation, today announced the appoinment of James Bruce of Baltimore as financial adviser to the board of directors of the corporation, and of George M. Lindsay of New York as fiscal agent of the corporation.

KHARKOV, Russia, Sept. 17 -- The writer has just completed a 200-mile auto trip through the heart of the Ukraine and can say positively that the harvest is splandid and all talk of famine now is ridiculous.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., Sept. 17. -- Edward K. Campbell, special master of the United States Supreme Court, will hear testimony here tomorrow in New Jersey's action to have New York City declared in contempt of court for failing to carry out the United States Supreme Court's order to cease beach pollution on June 1 of this year.

STRATFORD, Conn., Sept. 17 -- In a most dramatic finish Glen B. Watts of Lynbrook, L.I., won the Great Eastern individual skeet championship today as the two-day tournament came to a conclusion on the grounds of the Remington Gun Club at Lordship.

The Marquis of Lothian, Parliamentary Under-Secretary for India and Secretary of the Cecil Rhodes Trust, will arrive today from England on the Cunarder Carinthia. Also on board is Gerald Campbell, British Consul General here. Others arriving are:

WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 -- The Reconstruction Finance Corporation has agreed to lend the Farm Credit Administration $150,000,000 "as a means of assisting and co-operating with the administration's program for the refinancing of farm mortgages."
MAGDEBURG, Germany, Sept. 17 -- The Green and Red Sports Club handed the American women's field hockey team the first defeat of its European tour today. The score of the match was 5 -- 4.

LONDON, Sept. 16 -- The Transvaal gold output continues to decline in consequence of the treatment of lower-grade ore which the high price now obtainable for gold makes possible at a substantial profit.

PARIS, Sept. 17 -- Premier Daladier was said today by parliamentary friends to be considering an appeal to various public service groups to initiate a plan of monetary deflation to salvage the budget and protect the franc.

YONKERS, N.Y., Sept. 17 -- Francis H. Sisson, vice president of the Guaranty Trust Company of New York and former president of the American Bankers Association, died early today at his residence, 70 Undercliff Street, Park Hill, here.

Completion of the fusion campaign organization by the selection of managers for Manhattan, the Bronx and Queens was announced yesterday by William M. Chadbourne, campaign manager. The selection of George Boochever as campaign manager for Brooklyn and of former State Senator C. Ernest Smith as campaign manager for Richmond was announced some time ago.

A conflict between the International Ladies Garment Workers Union and the United Textile Workers of America for jurisdiction over 18,000 knit wear workers was revealed yesterday. The dispute may require the intervention of the American Federation of Labor, with which both organizations are affiliated.

PEIPING, Sept. 17 (AP) -- Despite Japanese allegations that the Chinese have occupied Kuyuan, near the Jehol border, indications tonight pointed to no impending clash between Japanese and Chinese in Southeastern Chahar Province. The Japanese asserted the Kuyuan occupation was a violation of the Tangku armistice.

WILKES-BARRE, Pa., Sept. 17 -- Given up for dead, four miners emerged from the Truesdale Colliery of the Glen Alden Coal Company in Hanover Township early today after being trapped for twenty-four hours by a flood in the mine.

NEW ORLEANS, Sept. 17 -- Although the volume of business in the cotton contract market here was rather moderate early last week and traders were disposed to be hesitant under the influence of the government's rather full crop estimate issued at the close of the previous week, there was a considerable increase in trading in the second half of the week and prices on the Cotton Exchange developed a decided upward trend.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The opening of the school and colleges term finds our country in the midst of an attempt to cut its way through the morass of depression. At a time where there should be a premium upon logic and reason our emotions are being played upon to bring us to the support of the administration's recovery program.

The political prestige of John H. McCooey, Brooklyn Democratic leader, and to a lesser extent that of John F. Curry, leader of Tammany, are at stake in tomorrow's primary election. The polls will be open from 3 P.M. to 9 P.M.

VIENNA, Sept. 17 -- Demonstrations of disunion within the ranks of the Austrian Government parties over the question of whether or not Austria should go fascist, and Nazi demonstrations against the Dollfuss regime resulted today in the wounding of about thirty policemen and civilians and 150 arrests.

PATERSON, N.J., Sept. 17 -- Ken Strong and Harry Newman, former all-America football luminaries, starred as the New York Football Giants scored an impressive 20 -- 0 victory over the Paterson Night Hawks today. Seven thousand persons saw the game at the Hinchliffe City Stadium.
CINCINNATI, Sept. 17 (AP) -- Fighting to get out of the National League cellar, the Cincinnati Reds trounced the Boston Braves, 5 to 2 and 6 to 0, in a double-header today.

There has been much loose talk in this city lately about the impracticability of making further substantial economies in the administration of municipal affairs. Men who should know better have shaken their heads, declaring that even with the best intentions the Board of Estimate could not reduce the budget, swollen as it is with debt service and necessary welfare appropriations, much below the level of present expenditures.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 -- The political developments in Cuba are not proceeding to the satisfaction of the American Government, it was said tonight in official circles. Hope still exists, however, that a stable government may be formed in Havana, and to this end American officials are lending all assistance that properly can be given.
ALBANY, Sept. 17 -- New York State's suicides and homicides in July set the lowest rates for that month of several years, according to a vital statistics report of the Department of Health.

PARIS, Sept. 16. -- Rumors circulated abroad that the gold standard would shortly be abandoned by France are not taken seriously here. Stability of the franc might indeed be imperiled either through withdrawal of foreign capital deposited in French banks, or through the effects of recourse to inflation to balance the French budget, but movements of foreign capital remain favorable to France.

Last week provided a highly illuminating picture of the state of things always created by tampering with the money standard, accompanied by inability or unwillingness of the official mind to say what it proposes to do next. On July 19 the dollar's exchange-market value fell to what was then the low level of 31 5/8 per cent depreciation.

Republican State Chairman W. Kingsland Macy offered to Attorney General Jonn J. Bennett yesterday the services of many young lawyers willing to act as special deputies of the Attorney General to prevent fraud at the polls this Fall. They would serve without compensation.

MEXICO, D. F., Sept. 17-- Incomplete War Department reports from the storm-battered area of coastal and Central Mexico tonight accounted for thirty-nine dead and 136 injured in the wake of the hurricane which struck Tampico Friday and drove 300 miles inland.

Samuel S. Koenig, chairman of the New York County Republican Committee, and Chase Mellen Jr., his opponent, each issued a statement yesterday predicting victory in the primary election tomorrow. Each claimed the election of more than 2,000 out of the 2,900 members of the county committee.
ALBANY, Sept. 17 -- New York State's suicides and homicides in July set the lowest rates for that month of several years, according to a vital statistics report of the Department of Health.

PARIS, Sept. 16. -- Rumors circulated abroad that the gold standard would shortly be abandoned by France are not taken seriously here. Stability of the franc might indeed be imperiled either through withdrawal of foreign capital deposited in French banks, or through the effects of recourse to inflation to balance the French budget, but movements of foreign capital remain favorable to France.

Last week provided a highly illuminating picture of the state of things always created by tampering with the money standard, accompanied by inability or unwillingness of the official mind to say what it proposes to do next. On July 19 the dollar's exchange-market value fell to what was then the low level of 31 5/8 per cent depreciation.

Republican State Chairman W. Kingsland Macy offered to Attorney General Jonn J. Bennett yesterday the services of many young lawyers willing to act as special deputies of the Attorney General to prevent fraud at the polls this Fall. They would serve without compensation.

A bronz plaque, dedicated to the memory of Colonel John R. Slattery, deputy chief engineer of the Board of Transportation and general manager of the city's new subway system, will be unveiled on Saturday by civic organizations. The plaque will be located in the exit concourse of the Pennsylvania Station, Eighth Avenue and Thirtythird Street, where the unveiling ceremonies will be held at 11 A.M.

More than one-third of the entire national debt of the United States consists of two issues of Liberty bonds, the First and Fourth, outstanding since war days. The First amounts to $1,933,000,000, of which part bears interest at 4 1/4 per cent and the bulk of the remainder at 3 1/2.

The Independent Bondholders Committee for the Republic of Colombia, headed by former Senator Robert L. Owen of Oklahoma, announced yesterday that it has presented to President Roosevelt a memorandum expressing its views as to the importance of issuing the proclamation creating the Corporation of Foreign Security Holders authorized by Congress in May as part of the Federal Securities Act.

OKLAHOMA CITY, Sept. 17 (AP) -- In a carefully guarded Federal court room Harvey Bailey, South-western bad man, will go to trial here tomorrow with eleven other alleged conspirators for the kidnapping which cost Charles F. Urschel $200,000.

LONDON, Sept. 16. -- All interest in the monetary situation continues to centre around the dollar and the franc. The dollar is steadily weakening under persistent Continental selling. This arises presumably from the withdrawal of European capital from America.
CHICAGO, Sept. 17 (AP) -- Retaliatory disputes over automobile licenses are retarding highway commerce between a dozen States.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 -- Addition of at least 500,000 new members to the American Federation of Labor since last October will be announced at the opening of the federation's convention on Oct. 2, President William Green said today.

The new group of North European birds now nearing completion at the American Museum of Natural History will be open to the public next month. It includes more than sixty specimens, ranging from the tiny gold-crest to the tawny owl, and will be a memorial to Viscount Grey, former Ambassador to the United States and one of England's leading ornithologists.

LAKE SEEBAGO, N.Y., Sept. 17 -- Four miles from civilization in the fastnesses of the Ramapo Hills your intrepid correspondent came upon a race of giants energetically cavorting upon a clearing at the end of a trail of boulders.

Captain H. Hashagen, master of the North German Lloyd liner Bremen, said before sailing early yesterday morning with 650 passengers that he would have liked to make a voyage in command of the Europa to see how she operated, but that he could not spare the time.
LONDON, Sept. 17 -- One of the most bitter denunciations of Nazi Germany ever to appear in England is published in today's Observer from the pen of its veteran editor, J.L. Garvin.
CHICAGO, Sept. 17 (AP) -- Retaliatory disputes over automobile licenses are retarding highway commerce between a dozen States.

UNIONTOWN, Pa., Sept. 17 (AP) -- The first indication that the H.C. Frick Coke Company may relent from its strong anti-union policy and accept the coal code came tonight in a statement by Thomas Moses, president.

BEDFORD HILLS, N.Y., Sept. 17 -- The Tapscot Kennels of Mr. and Mrs. Lindsley Tappin of Wilton, Conn., scored heavily today at the exhibition of the Cairn Terrier Club of America, held on the estate of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick C. Brown, winning four of the six events on the program.
PARIS, Sept. 18. -- Complete financial reorganization of the Compagnie Generale Transatlantique (the French Line) was voted at a shareholders' meeting this afternoon.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 18 -- Intent on making her own way in the theatre, Eugene O'Neill's ex-step-daughter, Barbara Burton of Mount Pleasant, N.J., registered at the Carnegie Tech School of Drama today. Miss Burton says she is not going to "trade" on the name of the famous playwright to win a foothold behind the footlights.

Willie Klein of Wheatley Hills, the Long Island champion, and Ray Kilthau of Oakland, collaborated well yesterday at the St. Albans Golf Club, St. Albans, L.I., and scored a 68 to carry off the leading honors in a pro-amateur event staged by the Long Island Golf Association.

William B. Wheeler, a veteran transportation expert in both railroad and steamship fields, will become general passenger traffic manager of the Grace Line on Oct. 1, succeeding Roy Crowder, it was learned yesterday. Mr. Wheeler went to the Grace Line in 1930 as assistant passenger traffic manager.

In sympathy with other markets and influenced by a decline in the gold value of the dollar, prices on the Cotton Exchange advanced yesterday about $2 a bale, making $500 pounds of cotton worth from $49.75 to $54, according to the month in which delivery is to be made.

BARNEGAT CITY, N.J., Sept. 18. -- The recent storms which swept the Jersey coast have washed away all surrounding earth and sand, leaving the bare foundations of Barnegat Light exposed to the buffeting of the waves. At the end of the storm a few weeks ago, fifteen feet of sand bluff, twenty-five feet high, separated the light from the ocean.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Bumbledom has reached an impasse. It did not know how to obtain any more revenue for the City of New York, yet it did not want to go along without payrolls. It hit upon the brilliant idea of increasing its revenue by making justice more expensive and burdensome.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Sept. 18. -- King Boris of Bulgaria and King Alexander of Yugoslavia met at Belgrade station today for the second time in their lives, but for the first time since they became sovereigns.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Members of the New York Child Labor Committee have been much interested in recent references in the public press to the effect of the NRA movement upon school attendance of employed children under 16 years of age.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 -- Complete authority over prices paid by manufacturers for flue-cured tobacco and the right to require full reports on operation of manufacturers and their subsidiaries is conferred upon Secretary Wallace in a proposed marketing agreement for the industry which he will submit at a hearing at the Department of Agriculture Thursday.

KHARKOV, U.S.S.R., Sept. 18 -- "Ukraine grain deliveries to the State had been accomplished 66 per cent by Sept. 10 -- which was the same as the figure reached three months later last year -- and we expect the full quota of 5,000,000 tons to be completed by mid-October," said the chief of the Ukrainian Communist section of the tractor stations, Alexander Asatkin.

Big game hunters are trooping into Canada in considerable numbers, according to reports from the Canadian National Railways. Most of these are seeking deer, but a good proportion are out to bag moose, if possible.

Ten Pulitzer free scholarships, awarded annually to successful competitors from a field of nearly 200 of the most promising graduates of public high schools of New York City, were announced yesterday at Columbia University.

Fourteen jurors were accepted in the criminal branch of the Supreme Court yesterday to try Isidor J. Kresel on an indictment charging he abbetted the misapplication of funds of an affiliate of the defunct Bank of United States. It was the first time in the 300 years of jurisprudence in New York County that more than twelve jurors were chosen for a criminal trial.

The volume of outstanding bankers' acceptances declined unexpectedly in August following the sharp rise in July, according to the monthly survey of the American Acceptance Council. The drop was put at $44,247,352, making the amount $694,011,611 at the end of the month.

The fight for the Democratic leadership of the Fourteenth Assembly District between Thomas M. Farley, incumbent, and Michael T. MeCarren, aspirant, came to a close last night on the eve of the primary election.

A conference of New York City bankers to consider plans for easing the credit of small employers, who are heavily booked with orders under the NRA but unable to finance operations, will be called early next week by Gro er A. Whalen, City Chairman of the President's Emergency Re-employment Campaign Committee.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 18 (AP). -- Seeded stars in the Pacific Southwest singles tennis championship ran into trouble today but were able to survive the second round of play. Unranked players put up a determined fight, only to fall short of turning in upsets.

MINNEAPOLIS, Segt. 18. -- The National Boxing Association was asked late today by its retiring president, James Brown of Detroit, to refuse recognition of national championship fights of less than fifteen rounds' duration.

ALBANY, Sept. 18. -- "Fullest cooperation" was promised the Budget Advisory Committee by Governor Lehman as the committee began today its consideration of the 1934-35 budget. The Governor, in his brief address of welcome, pledged the assistance of every department and requested the committee members not only to visit the departments but to visit institutions as well, so they could see their practical working.

A nine-story apartment house to cost $100,000 is to be built at 3 East Sixty-sixth Street, according to plans filed yesterday with the Manhattan Department of Buildings by Boak Paris, architects. The owner of record is the Trans-Boro Realty Corporation, of 521 Fifth Avenue, headed by Sam Minskoff, builder.

OKLAHOMA CITY, Sept. 18 (AP) -- Twelve small-town business men and farmers were chosen tonight to hear the trial of eleven men and one woman accused of conspiring and kidnapping Charles F. Urschel, one of the oil country's richest men.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Sept. 18 -- A football renaissance has long been overdue at Rutgers and those who are close to the scarlet-clad squad say that it is as near at hand as the Raritan hard by the practice field.

NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 18 -- Miss Eva Dahlgren was hostess at a large luncheon party at her home today. Mrs. Leonard M. Thomas, who was hostess of a large luncheon on Sunday at Brick House, gave another luncheon there today.

Aimee Semple McPherson arrived in New York yesterday for her evangelistic tour of the theatres, which will begin on Friday at the Capitol Theatre, at a guarantee of $5,000 a week. When she stepped off the Twentieth Century Limited from Chicago at the Grand Central Station four policemen escorted her through the crowd that had assembled to greet her.

BERLIN, Sept. 18 -- A new anti-Dollfuss campaign to be waged throughout the Reich was begun here tonight with a mass meeting at the Sports Palast. The principal speaker was Theodor Habicht, the "Inspector General of the Nazi organization in Austria," expelled from that country by the Dollfuss government because of his activities when attached to the German Legation in Vienna.
An exchange of two Jersey City properties was included in the New Jersey realty transactions reported yesterday.

LONDON, Sept. 18. -- The unofficial international Legal Commission of Inquiry into the Reichstag fire concluded the taking of evidence tonight after four days of public hearings and began preparing its report.

Four Atlantic liners, the Britannic, Dresden, Carinthia and Westernland, arrived in port yesterday after passing through a storm on Sunday which the captains described as about the worst they ever had encountered. The wind's velocity was more than 100 miles an hour and the seas were from sixty to seventy feet high.

BUENOS AIRES, Sept. 18. -- Alexander A. Weddell, new United States Ambassador to Argentina, presented his credentials to President Justo at noon today. The Argentine Government surrounded the impressive ceremony with all the pomp and dignity possible under a democracy, emphasizing its full significance as the formal reception of the diplomatic representative of the world's leading republic by one of South America's most important States.

Governor POLLARD'S little glossary of social and political satire defines a Radical as "a Liberal exceeding the speed limit." The definition has peculiar force and pertinence today. There was a time, and not so many months ago, when the edge of the epigram would have cut the other way.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 -- Charles J. Brand, co-administrator of the Agricultural Adjustment Administration since its establishment four months ago, has resigned that office effective Oct. 1.

Mayor O'Brien did his best yesterday to mollify the angry Irish of Staten Island by making public copies of an official explanation of why the use of the Willowbrook Park clubhouse was refused to them when rain marred their picnic two weeks ago.

PATERSON, N.J., Sept. 18 -- The last-minute decision of manufacturers not to open their plants this morning is believed to have averted a flare-up the broadsilk strike here today. The manufacturers, it is reported, changed their plans at an executive meeting last night.
NEW YORK. Brig. Gen. and Mrs. J. William Kilbreth have left the Barclay for Hot Springs, Va.

EDWARDSVILLE, Ill., Sept. 18 (AP) -- Mrs. August Luer, 77, calmly told a jury today how kidnappers seized her husband, an Alton banker, the night of July 10 and hustled him away after knocking her down.
OYSTER BAY, L.I., Sept. 18. -- Canada's dinghy sailors today entered into a tie for first place with England in the international round-robin team series at the Seawanhaka Corinthian Yacht Club.

A bundle of old-fashioned ten, twenty and fifty dollar bills that had been hidden in an automobile, abandoned for more than a year, was found by four boys in a junk yard in Jersey City and burned, in the belief that it was "stage money," the police were informed yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 -- Abolition of the cotton processing tax, and immediate inflation, along with Federal action to raise the price of cotton on the farm to twenty cents were demanded today by cotton planters and members of Congress from cotton States meeting here.

LONDON, Sept. 18 (AP). -- The national executive council of the Labor party, in a report to be submitted at its annual conference in Hastings next month, will eulogize President Roosevelt's program for industrial recovery in the United States.

Two diplomats are among the notables expected today from Europe on the French liner Ile de France. They are Count de Sartiges, French Minister Plenipotentiary to Chile, and William Hamilton, Minister to Luxemburg to the United States.

RYE, N.Y., Sept. 18 -- Miss Alyce Pressprich, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Reginald William Pressprich, and Miss Angelene Pell, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Williamson Pell, both of Rye, made their debut tonight at a joint supper dance given by their parents at the Apawamis Club here.
WESTBURY, L.I., Sept. 18 -- Officials of the United States Polo Association announced today that the postponed national open championship would start Saturday at the Meadow Brook Club.

LINDEN, N.J., Sept. 18. -- Sixteen persons were arrested here tonight in a raid by policemen in plain clothes at the dog-racing track operated by the Union Kennel Club, just off the main highway between New York and Philadelphia.

While Grover A. Whalen, chairman of the local NRA organization, was bending his efforts yesterday to bring about a settlement of the strike of 25,000 underwear workers, strike movements developed in two other branches of the needle trades and a strike of 5,000 drivers was in prospect, threatening to tie up flour, bakery, grocery and furniture deliveries in the metropolitan area.

To the Editor of The New York Times: About 1915 the States were given seven years in which to ratify the Eighteenth Amendment. It seemed absurd to think that it could pass in seven years. But the war caused a food scare. We were told early in 1917 that within six months the United States would be as badly off for food "as any country in Europe," and Belgium was starving.

SPRINGFIELD, N.J., Sept. 18 -- A round of 81 over the testing lower course of the Baltusrol Golf Club by Miss Maureen Orcutt of White Beeches was the feature of the qualifying round of the women's New Jersey golf championship today.

WUERZBURG, Germany, Sept 18 -- The German Physicists' and Mathematicians' Congress convened here today, obviously under the influence, for the first time, of the "primacy of politics" ordained in the Third Reich.

The Federation of Foreign Trade Associations, which comprises foreign trade and export groups throughout the country, added its voice yesterday to the growing chorus urging that American holders of foreign bonds be protected by the formation of the Corporation of Foreign Security Holders, for which provision was made in the Federal Securities Act of 1933.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 18. -- New York today obtained an additional unemployment relief grant of $3,000,000 from Harry L. Hopkins, Federal Emergency Relief Administrator.

YONKERS, N.Y. Sept. 18. -- Messages of sympathy from men and women in all walks of life were received here today by the family of the late Francis " H. Sisson, vice president of the Guaranty Trust Company and former president of the American Bankers Association.

BOSTON, Sept. 18. -- "The New Deal will surely pitch us into an economic morass even more serious than the one from which it is designed to save us unless a strong political opposition to some of the policies now becoming manifest develops soon," Christian A. Herter declared today in an address before the Norwell Women's Republican Club.

Although there was an irregular movement of stocks and agricultural staples yesterday, the dollar held steadfastly to a downward course. None of the other markets conformed to the conventional pattern.

HAVANA, Sept. 18 -- Despite President Ramon Grau San Martin's assertions that a settlement of political differences will come about immediately, opposing factions today viewed the situation with frank pessimism and growing apprehension.
BERLIN, Sept. 18 (AP). -- The Reichsbank's statement as of Sept. 15 shows the following changes, in reichsmarks:

Robert Menz, 6 years old, was crushed to death last night while saving his younger brother George, 4, from a similar fate when a frightened horse attached to a laundry wagon mounted the sidewalk near their home at 2,412 Crotona Avenue, the Bronx, where they were playing.

The ninety-sixth anniversary of the founding of William Knabe Co. will be observed in the Knabe Concert Hall with two concerts and teas this week, at which Marek Windheim, Metropolitan Opera tenor, will be guest artist. The first of these will take place tomorrow at 4 and the second on Saturday afternoon at the same hour.
CINCINNATI, Sept. 18 (AP). -- With a chance to crawl from the league celiar in sight the Reds fell before Boston, 8 to 2, today as Si Johnson failed to exercise his usual mastery over the Braves.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Sept. 18 (AP). -- Muscletone, owned by the Coldstream Farm and driven by Parshall, today won the forty-first renewal of the $7,000 Kentucky Futurity for 2-year-old trotters. The Victor scored in two straight heats. Vitamine trotted a good second, and Emily Stokes also a sharp contender, was third.

BERLIN, Sept. 18 -- Germany's Grand Economic Council, recently appointed By Chancellor Hitler and designated by him as the consulting general staff to deal with economic problems, was ordered today to meet Wednesday. It will be the council's first formal gathering.

While Representative Anning S. Prall was breaking ground yesterday for the new $2,000,000 Public Health Service Hospital at Stapleton, S.I., a telegram was received from Assistant Secretary of the Treasury Lawrence W. Robert. It read:

WEST SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Sept. 18.n -- A little black filly, Frolic, owned by George A. Graves of Boston and driven by Aubrey Rodney of this city, captured the Mohawk 2-year-old trot, feature event on the opening program of the Eastern States Exposition meeting today.

Influenced almost entirely by the weakness in the dollar, prices on local commoditiy exchanges again moved forward yesterday. Silver was the feature of the day, although rubber and silk were also much higher. Trading was in good volume. Cash prices also rose.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 (AP) -- The used car industry complained to the Recovery Administration today that the code for retail dealers was unfair because it empowered the National Automobile Dealers Association to fix prices and stipulate what trade-in, allowances would be.

Retail Volume Up Yesterday. Retail trade picked up rather sharply here yesterday, proving to retailers' satisfaction that adverse weather has been the major hampering factor in the expansion of trade. Reports on Saturday's volume differed somewhat, but several stores here equaled last year's figures for the corresponding day.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 -- Senator Shipstead of Minnesota, Farmer-Laborite, who has long advocated better river transportation as a means of increasing the incomes of farmers, today endorsed President Roosevelt's program for ratification of the St. Lawrence seaway treaty in the next session of Congress, and predicted that this would be accomplished.
Two spectacular catches by Mule Haas nipped a ninth-inning Yankee uprising yesterday at the Stadium and the McCarthyjnen split a double-header with Lew Fonseca's Chicago White Sox.

BINGHAMTON, N.Y., Sept. 18 (AP). -- Martin H. King of Elmira, engineer of the Erie milk train which on Sept. 5 crashed into the rear of an Erie passenger train here, killing fourteen persons and injuring twenty-four others, took the witness stand today at the coroner's inquest.

LONDON, Sept. 18. -- Concerned over the violent break of the dollar and the indications of inflation in the United States, Prime Minister MacDonald today held a long discussion at his official residence with three of Great Britain's foremost economists.

The Fall meeting at Aqueduct opened yesterday with victories for the first three favorites, but a defeat for the public choice in the featured Sunrise Purse, when Garden Message finished second to Sgt. Byrne.

The Chesapeake Ohio Railway sharply increased its gross revenues in August. The rise, it was stated, was about evenly divided between merchandise and coal and coke revenues, with passenger returns running within a fraction of last year's levels.

CHICAGO, Sept. 18 -- Eastern and local operators who bought grain futures late on the Board of Trade last week took profits today on their holdings, and while the outside trade was broader than it had been recently, it was insufficient to absorb all the selling, and the markets reacted sharply after an early bulge.

NEWARK, N.J., Sept. 18. -- Vince Dundee, Baltimore's veteran middleweight, passed from the championship picture tonight at Dreamland Park. His place was usurped by Teddy Yarosz, Pittsburgh newcomer, campaigning for recognition as successor to the late Harry Greb among the 160-pounders.

Circumstances have brought Europe's war debts back into the news. Under their contracts with us, it is the privilege of debtor nations to suspend payments of principal on their obligations, provided they give ninety days' notice of such intention. Since the next payment falls due on Dec. 15, Saturday of last week marked the deadline for a notice of postponement.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 -- The Federal Advisory Council, composed of representatives of each of the Federal Reserve districts, met in its Autumn session today to discuss the various economic problems before the government at this time.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 18. -- A substitute code for the basic plan to govern the commercial printing industry and newspapers outside metropolitan limits drew fire of employer and employe as the public hearings on a permanent code were opened today before Lindsay Rogers, Deputy Recovery Administrator.
PARIS, Sept. 18 -- Another effort to secure limitation of armaments by international agreement was begun in Paris today when representatives of Great Britain and France met at the Quai d'Orsay.

The 1933 Radio-Electrical Exposition will open at 11 o'clock tomorrow morning in a fairyland of color created in the arena of Madison Square Garden by thousands of concealed colored flood lights playing over a maze of purple and gold hangings covering both ceiling and sides of the vast interior.

TOKYO, Tuesday, Sept. 19 (AP). -- The judges in the army court-martial of eleven army cadets charged with participation in the assassination of Premier Inukai in May, 1932, and in the accompanying terrorism sentenced the defendants today to four years' imprisonment each.

DETROIT, Sept. 18 (AP). -- Judge Harry B. Keidan, who took testimony for three months in oneman grand jury investigation of reasons for the collapse of Detroit's two national banks, tonight found that the banks were solvent at the time of the Michigan banking holiday and that there was no evidence of criminality on the part of the bank officers.

The announced intention of the International Ladies' Garment Workers Union to call a strike in the knit goods industry in opposition to the United Textile Workers, with whom the employers have concluded an agreement on the basis of the textile code, provoked a protest yesterday from Morris Rubinger, chairman of the executive committee of the Metropolitan Knitted Textile Association, Inc., the employers' organization.

The spirit of political unrest and dissatisfaction with existing party leadership was counted upon yesterday by insurgent Democratic and Republican candidates to bring them victory at the primary election today. The polls will be open, from 3 P.M. to 9 P.M. and there was every indication of a larger vote than usually turns out for the primaries.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 18 (AP) -- Jean Harlow, the film actress, was married for the third time today in a romantic early-morning airplane elopement to Yuma, Ariz., the Southwest's Gretna Green, with Harold G. Rosson, film cameraman.

SAN FRANCISCO Sept. 18. -- The United States Circuit Court of Appeals upheld the District Court today in a decision that the Standard Oil Company must pay the government about $1,500,000 in taxes on pipe lines throughout this State.
Another link with the past -- the past of Sargent and of John Lafarge, the past of the mauve decade and the World's Fair of forty years ago -- has been severed.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 18. -- Movements of vessels follow; all dates are Sept. 17, unless otherwise specified:

WASHINGTON, Sept. 18. -- Initial steps to bring banks, not members of the Federal Reserve System, into the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation have been completed by Walter J. Cummings, chairman of the corporation. A letter and application blanks have been sent to each non-member bank outlining the requirements for membership.

Determined to drive out racketeering from the beer business, Chairman Edward P. Mulrooney of the State Alcoholic Beverage Control Board issued an order yesterday requiring all brewers and wholesalers to file with the board a complete record of all male employes, their photographs and fingerprints.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 18. -- The oil industry faces no immediate prospect of a price-fixing schedule for gasoline, crude oil or petroleum byproducts, Secretary Ickes, the oil administrator, said today as the planning and coordination committee of the industry met.

THE Chicago Cubs won a double-header from the forlorn Flatbush Flock on Sunday and their last chance to catch the Giants disappeared on the same day. This emphasizes a curious delusion that has been harbored in the bleachers for the past month or so.

Postmaster General James A. Farley declared yesterday that under its new system of budgetary control the Federal Government had out its deficit about $500,000,000 from July 1 to Sept. 12, compared to the same period last year. Mr. Farley made this statement at a luncheon at the Hotel Roosevelt opening the second annual meeting of the Controllers Institute of America.

HAVRE DE GRACE, Md., Sept. 18 (AP). -- Dark Hope, racing for J. W.Y. Martin, scored a smashing victory today in the Fort Henry Purse, the mile and seventy-yard feature of the Havre De Grace inaugural program.

Two groups of harbor workers met with employers yesterday to discuss proposed increases in pay submitted last week. Joseph P. Ryan, president of the International Longshoremen's Association, conferred with Oakley Wood, chairman of the New York Shipping-Committee, on the proposed increase of longshoremen's wages from 75 cents to 85 cents an hour, and $1.10 to $1.30 an hour for overtime.

RYE, N.Y., Sept. 18. -- With a flaming sunset behind them over black water, the international racing yachts in the Sound Interclub-Bermuda series tonight completed two races. The Interclubs won both of them, making the score 2 to 1, with four contests necessary to a decision.
Charges that the Irving Trust Company is hindering the Congressional investigation of receiverships here were denied yesterday by Alfred A. Cook of Cook, Nathan Lehman, counsel for the bank.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 18. -- The Federal Reserve Board's condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety leading cities on Sept. 13 shows increases for the week of $178,000,000 in net demand deposits, $86,000,000 in reserve balances in Federal Reserve Banks and $58,000,000 in loans, and decreases of $39,000,000 in holdings of United States Government security and $11,000,000 in time deposits.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 18 (AP). -- Ed Holley shut out the Pirates, 6-0, with four hits in the second game of a double-header today, pulling the Phillies out of the league cellar, where they had dropped due to a 2-1 defeat in the opener.

CHICAGO, Sept. 18 -- Former President Hoover and Mrs. Hoover will arrive here tomorrow morning from Palo Alto, Calif., to visit A Century of Progress Exposition. The visit is in fulfillment of a promise Mr. Hoover made last March 18. when he stopped in Chicago while homeward bound from Washington following the inauguration of President Roosevelt.
George Nelson Page, scion of one of America's oldest distinguished families, announced yesterday his intention of renouncing his American citizenship and becoming a citizen of Fascist Italy.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 (AP). -- The third and latest version of the proposed sugar stabilization agreement tonight was almost ready to be laid before President Roosevelt and Farm Administration officials.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 -- President Roosevelt signed the bituminous coal code late this afternoon, promulgating it in an Executive Order which puts the code into effect in two weeks.

At the suggestion of Sol A. Rosenblatt, deputy administrator, who assisted in drafting the theatre's unified code, the two rival factions of ticket brokers -- the National Theatre Ticket Distributors and the Theatre Ticket Brokers Association -- may each have one representative on the National Legitimate Theatre Committee, the enforcement branch of the master code, when questions arise concerning the sale and distribution of theatre tickets.
CHICAGO, Sept. 18. -- King Levinsky, Chicago's ex-fish peddler, tonight scuttled Jack Sharkey, perhaps forever, as a heavyweight threat.

A score of representatives of the Federation of German Jewish Societies abruptly departed from a meeting of the United German Societies last night, when it became obvious that, despite their objections, the meeting would vote to invite Dr. Hans Luther, the German Ambassador, to the German Day celebration here, and, consequently, to display the German national and Nazi swastika flags on that occasion.

TRENTON. N.J., Sept. 18. -- With only about twenty inches of sand remaining between Barnegat Light and the sea, as a result of last week's storm, the State Board of Commerce and Navigation voted today to ask the State House Commission for an emergency appropriation of $12,000 for the erection of steel sheathing to prevent further encroachment.

Bond prices declined sharply yesterday on the Stock Exchange, many domestic corporation issues of all shades of credit rating losing 1 to 6 points, with corresponding losses in some sections of the foreign bond group. Trading was heavy, amounting to $13,377,000.

LONDON, Sept. 18. -- Outstanding in the markets today was a rise in gold to 131s 9d an ounce, the new gain being recorded following further improvement in the franc. On the other hand, a further sharp fall in the dollar followed renewed selling on fears of American inflation.

The plan of the New York City electric companies under the recovery code to hire 2,100 new employes at an average wage of $32 a week has resulted so far in the employment of 368 persons at an average wage of $19.81, Milo R. Maltbie, chairman of the Public Service Commission, noted yesterday.
PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 18 (AP). -- Putting on a four-run rally in the seventh inning, the Athletics captured a see-saw contest from the Tigers today, 9 to 8.

SAARBRUECKEN, Saar Basin Territory, Sept. 18 -- Like Germany -- or as they insist upon saying here, "the rest of Germany" -- the Saar offers impressive evidence against the theory of the hated Marxists that economic motives are the predominant ones.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 (AP). -- Sam Gray, the St. Louis Browns' veteran hurler who probably lost a chance to get a share of world series money a few weeks ago by confessing a sore arm, pitched a 4-to-2 victory over the Senators today.

George W. Wickersham, United States Attorney General in President Taft's Cabinet and still a leader in public affairs and in the practice of constitutional and corporation law, will be 75 years old today.

LA PAZ, Bolivia, Sept. 18. -- Paraguay is driving hard for a victory in the Chaco region during the present dry season, in which Bolivia is declared here to be at a disadvantage because of the better water supplies behind the enemy's lines.

Not only against the two JOHNS, the princes orgulous of Brooklyn and Manhattan, rages rebellion, the roll of whose forces is to be called today. For the who-knows-how-manyeth time sacrilegious hands are striving to thrust King SAMUEL from his throne. That venerated sovereign has a prescriptive right to his place.

Martin A. Klein of the Bohemian Gymnastic Association was elected president of the Metropolitan Association of the A.A.U. for the fourth successive time at the annual meeting at the Hotel Paramount last night. Mr. Klein was unopposed for the office.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 18 -- Clement E. Chase, member of the engineering firm of Modjeski, Masters Chase and one of the builders of the Delaware River Bridge, was killed instantly today when he was hurtled from a girder of the bridge to a waterfront street 120 feet below.

The member banks of the New York Clearing House Association have agreed upon a change in the fee charged by them to out-of-town banks for the service of placing the funds of these out-of-town banks in the call money market.

Nothing occurred in the opening session of the week in money to distinguish it from last week's markets. Business ran to small lines, and quotations for all classes were carried forward without change.

VIENNA, Sept. 18. -- Chancellor Dollfuss will leave Vienna at the end of this week for Geneva. The League Council will meet on Sept. 25 and, although it is understood Austria's position will not be discussed, the Chancellor will make use of the opportunity to talk our economic problems with the European statesmen whom he can meet so conveniently at Geneva.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 -- Discussion of intergovernmental debts owed to this country by Great Britain will start here early in October, it was said today. It Is expected that the first meeting will be held between President Roosevelt and the British delegation about Oct. 5.
STOCKHOLM, Sept. 18. -- The proudest person in all Sweden today was the elderly widow, Bertha Perssen of Borreby, a cousin of Colonel Charles A. Lindbergh, whom the famous airman has just visited.

The value of the dollar in the foreign exchange market continued yesterday to decline, reaching a new low price in terms of gold and the gold standard currencies and coming within a narrow margin of the lowest price thus far reached in terms of sterling since the suspension of the gold standard here.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In reply to my letter on water meters John Yearwood wrote: "Domestic water, however, used in apartment houses and one-family dwellings is not now required by law to be metered, because It is the well-settled policy of the city to encourage, for the purposes of health and sanitation, the free use of water in the home."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 18. -- Former workers in the Sigmund Eisner Company plant at Redbank, N.J., who have been on strike will be reemployed "as soon as work is available, without prejudice or discrimination," representatives of the company assured the National Labor Board today.
HAVANA, Tuesday, Sept. 19 -- President Grau San Martin refused early today to submit to pressure which had been placed upon him to resign.

Mrs. Rosalie D. Winslow of 80 Summit Avenue, Bronxville, mother of two children and wife of E. de Forest Winslow, an engineering editor of 110 East Forty-second Street, plunged to her death yesterday afternoon from the fifteenth floor of the Hotel Roosevelt to the Madison Avenue sidewalk.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 (AP). -- The strike at Brockton added today to the difficulties of National Recovery Administrators in removing obstacles threatening to delay promulgation of a code of competition for the boot and shoe industry.

Results of operations were announced yesterday by various corporations. The Caterpillar Tractor Company reported net profit of $77,987 for August, against net loss of $44,394 in the corresponding month last year. The Glidden Company earned $1,096,912 net for ten months ended on Aug. 31.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 18. -- The Giants had it within their grasp to clinch the 1933 National League pennant today when another one of those annoying series of circumstances which occasionally crop up to test the fortitude of this remarkable ball club deferred matters for at least another twenty-four hours.

BOLTON LANDING, N.Y., Sept. 18 (AP) -- Enthusiastic declarations that the skies were clearing and that real estate values throughout the State were on a firm basis of steady up-trend marked the opening session of the twenty-ninth annual convention of the New York State Association of Real Estate Boards here today.

WESTBURY, L.I., Sept. 18 -- With a steadily increasing flow of power, the Great Neck polo team captured the Thorn Memorial Cup today, turning back the Juniors, 7 to 6, at the Meadow Brook Club. In a closely fought, exciting final-round match, the Great Neck youngsters took the Boys' Trophy from the Juniors who were the defending titleholders.

Ralph C. Holmes, whose resignation as chairman of the Texas Corporation, the largest independent oil organization in the country, was occasioned some months ago by opposing interests, is attempting to rally behind him enough support to recover the executive management.
Closing appeals for support at the primary election today were made last night by Samuel S. Koenig, Republican chairman in New York County, and Chase Mellen Jr., his rival for the post.

CHICAGO, Sept. 18. -- The Dodgers today made another dent in the tradition that they can't beat the Cubs on their home field by winning the third game of their series in convincing fashion, 6 to 4. It was the second time Brooklyn has taken a game here in more than a year.

Reading on Buses. One answer awaited from the new type of Fifth Avenue bus now being tried out is whether it is possible to read on a gas-driven vehicle with, moderate comfort. It cannot be done on the present buses.

A jury was chosen and sworn in late yesterday afternoon in United States District Court for the second trial of United States Senator James J. Davis of Pennsylvania on charges of violation of the Federal lottery laws. He is on trial this time together with Theodore G. Miller, head of the propagation department of the Loyal Order of Moose, of which the Senator is director general.
GENEVA, Sept. 18 -- The auditor's report to the cowing Assembly on the financial administration of the League of Nations shows League officials have made a rare record for sound investing.

Twenty leading stores here announced yesterday through H. Nelson Street, secretary of the Retail Dry Goods Association of New York, that the consumer boycott on German-made merchandise has become "so extensive and effective" that their purchases of such goods "are now confined to a very few essential items which are not obtainable in any other country."

Twelve of the largest and most influential firms in the New York Stock Exchange announced yesterday that they were cooperating in a movement to form a new exchange in New Jersey to escape the city's proposed emergency taxes on stock transfers and gross profits of brokers.

MINEOLA, L.I., Sept. 18. -- District Attorney Elvin N. Edwards today asked the Nassau County Board of Supervisors to invite the directors of the New York Stock Exchange to move the Exchange building to Nassau County. The District Attorney declared Mineola would be an ideal location, particularly the fair grounds, if the Exchange were moved from New York City.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 18. -- Hoarders of gold had until this midnight to make a return to Collectors of Internal Revenue showing the amount of their holdings. Under the gold-hoarding executive order they have fifteen days within which to return the gold to the Treasury or Federal Reserve Banks.

ALBANY, Sept. 18 (AP). -- Tomorrow's primaries will be warm in a number of up-State counties and cities where old party followers have revolted from the ranks. Political leaderships are at stake in several cases.

George Murphy and Julie Johnson (Mr. and Mrs. Murphy), who appeared together in "Shoot the Works," have been engaged by Max Gordon for "Gowns by Roberta," the Jerome Kern-Otto Harbach-Alice Duer Miller musical show.

Governor Lehman will confer today with city officials and representatives of the city's bankers in an effort to dissolve the impasse caused by the unwillingness of the banks to extend a credit of $72,000,000 to the city.

DETROIT, Sept. 18 -- Swarming into the streets and paralyzing traffic for three blocks in Detroit's downtown section, a good-humored throng of veterans, estimated by police to number 5,000 at one time, answered the call today of the Ford Motor Company for 5,000 war veterans to be hired through the local American Legion Council.
Further rental activity in the apartment field was reported yesterday. All sections of Manhattan were represented in the lists of tenants. Among the lessees were the following:

No greater compliment has been paid to Governor LEHMAN than the invitation extended to him by the city and the bankers to come to their aid in the present emergency. Both Mr. PEOSSER and Mr. UNTERMYER refer to the need of action by the State, and it may well be that some further legislation will be required outside the scope of existing home rule.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 -- The text of President Roosevelt's order approving the bituminous coal code follows:

Seventy-six fellowships have been awarded by the Institute of International Education to American students for study in foreign countries during the academic year 1933-34, it was announced yesterday by Professor Stephen P. Duggan, director of the Institute of International Education.
FONTAINEBLEAU, France, Sept. 18 (AP). -- A reconciliation between former King Alfonso of Spain and his eldest son, who for love renounced his claim to the throne, is believed imminent.
Gethard M. Dahl, chairman of the board of the B.M.T., voluntarily reduced his own salary from $135,000 to $90,000 annually, it was revealed yesterday at a meeting of the stockholders.
A purchase money mortgage for $55,000, payable Sept. 15, 1938, at 4 per cent, was given by Gladys G. Straus to the United States Trust Company of New York on 4 and 6 East 93d St., 40 feet wide.

More than 1,000 workers in the financial district joined with leaders of patriotic organizations yesterday in commemorating the 146th anniversary of the adoption of the Constitution of the United States at the exercises held at noon on the steps of the Subtreasury Building at Wall and Nassau Streets.

Cardinal Hayes celebrated the fourteenth annual mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral yesterday morning for the repose of the soul of Cardinal Farley, fourth Archbishop of New York, who died on Sept. 17, 1918.

The twenty-two-year reign of Samuel S. Koenig as Republican leader of New York County apparently was nearing the end this morning, as incomplete returns indicated that Chase Mellen Jr., anti-Koeniz candidate for county chairman, was leading in the number of county committeemen elected at yesterday's primary election.
The quotations are for three-four months' paper.

SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Sept 19 -- Fillies predominated in all three events on the Eastern States Exposition program today. First Frances Knight won the 2:18 class trot and then Betty Signal came up in the final two heats to take the 2:25 class pace.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Sept. 19 -- Funeral services will be held here tomorrow for Robert E. Dundon, 46 years old, veteran sports and political writer and correspondent for metropolitan newspapers, who was accidentally drowned in the Louisville and Portland Canal here last night.

aWASHINGTON, Sept. 19 (AP) -- Organized labor insisted today that any NRA code which reduced unemployment among the 30,000 units of the commercial printing industry must provide a maximum thirty-two-hour work week and a minimum wage of 50 cents an hour.

CHICAGO, Sept. 19 -- Although nearly 16 per cent of the banks in the United States were closed in the twelve months ended on June 30, causing tremendous withdrawals from the remaining 84 per cent, the total banking resources of the nation declined less than 10 per cent in that period, according to a compilation in the current issue of Rand, McNally Co.'s Bankers Directory.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 19 -- "In all my eighteen, years in baseball I never experienced such a thrill out of the game as I got today when the boys In the press box signaled down, to us that the Pirates had lost and the race was over," said Manager Bill Terry as he boarded the Giant special which is conveying the new National League champions back to New York tonight.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 -- Price-fixing and price-control still loomed today as twin stumbling blocks ift the way of completing the retail trade code in the national recovery program.

HAVRE DE GRACE, Md., Sept. 19 (AP) -- Jockey Don Meade flashed a sensational closing effort to urge R.J. Tubbs's Cutie Face to a head victory over A.L. Aste's Character in the feature of the second welfare day of racing at Havre de Grace today.
BAY SHORE, L.I., Sept. 19 -- Returns from four districts in which contests were listed in this section gave the following results for Suffolk County Committeemen:

Joseph Mayper, secretary of the Transatlantic Steamship Conference, has notified American lines with services to West Indies ports that the Atlantic lines will meet this week to agree on a cruise schedule for the Winter. Later in the week the 'West Indies group of regular services will be asked to attend a conference on this question.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 19 (AP) -- Charges against Irving Austin of Brooklyn, N.Y., a commercial photographer, of kidnapping his 9-year-old son, Alexander, from the home of his estranged wife were dismissed today by a Federal Commissioner.
The clinching of the National League pennant by the Giants yesterday brought to New York its thirteenth championship in the senior circuit and tied Chicago for the major league record.
Rosh ha-Shanah, or the Jewish New Year, will begin at sunset today. This will be the year 5694.

PARIS, Sept. 19 -- With the dollar closing at 16.67, virtually the same level as yesterday; and the pound also remaining at 79.73, where It closed yesterday, the Parisian press and financial circles are bending every effort to analyze the probable effect of this on the franc and world markets.

TRENTON, N.J., Sept. 12 -- Hearing was begun today by the State Board of Tax Appeals on the petitions of railroad companies operating in New Jersey for a reduction in the taxes assessed against them for the current year. The board will sit tomorrow and Friday and then recess until next Wednesday.

The growing army of strikers in New York City was augmented yesterday by the addition of 15,000 painters who responded to the strike call of the Brotherhood of Painters, Decorators and Paper Hangers of America, District 9, and walked out in support of the union's demands for shorter hours and more pay.
NEW YORK. Mr. and Mrs. Albert William Putnam of Rye will give a dance on Nov. 4 to introduce to society their daughter, Miss Nancy Tucker Putnam.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 -- William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, today presented to Hugh S. Johnson, Recovery Administrator, a mass of documents to support his assertion that many large corporations were coercing employes to join company unions in contravention of Section 7 (a) of the Recovery Act.
Organization candidates for the Assembly nominations of both major parties were swept to victory in yesterday's primary election in almost every instance, although a few upsets were recorded.

As chairman of the committee on unfair practices for the six national retail associations that signed the retail code, Benjamin Namm, head of the Namm Store in Brooklyn, wrote last Monday to A.D. White-side, Deputy Administrator of the NRA in Washington, telling him that merchants all over the country hope for a speedy approval of the code signed in the national capital a month ago.

After many delays, much discord and the threat of a strike, which General JOHNSON describes as having "almost scared the wadding out of him," a code for the bituminous coal industry has finally been presented to the President and signed by him. Its chief provisions have been discussed at length.

CAPE TOWN, South Africa, Sept. 19 (by Wireless) -- Bernt Balchen, with the Ellsworth Transantarctic Flight Expedition as pilot of the monoplane Lincoln Ellsworth will use on his long flight across the Antarctic Continent, will be operated upon for appendicitis here tomorrow.

CAMDEN, N.J., Sept. 19 -- State Senator Emerson L. Richards of Atlantic City becomes Acting Governor of New Jersey tomorrow, when Governor Moore starts a vacation trip. Harry L. Maloney, Uaited States Internal Revenue Collector for South Jersey, filed yesterday a lien against any salary that might accrue from this temporary office.

MR. JAMES J. DYKES of the Chicago White Sox was smoking a cigar. Incidentally, there is a reward out for any one who catches James J. Dykes without a cigar in his mouth except when James is actively engaged in eating or playing third base. However, this being the fag end of the season, the cigars are getting smaller day by day. Sighting a visitor approaching, Mr. Dykes said in a loud, resonant tone:

Except for a flurry In the shares of metal companies, there was little in yesterday's proceedings on the Stock Exchange to arouse interest. The market did not shake off its lethargy until late in the day and then it demonstrated a partiality for only one group of stocks.

YOUNGSTOWN, Ohio, Sept. 19, -- Steel output in this district continued to expand today, reaching 48 per cent of the capacity of the mills. The Republic Steel Corporation is changing its plant at Lansingville to use producer gas instead of oil and tar as fuel.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 19 (AP) -- Support and care of the two young sons of Charlie Chaplin, film comedian, cost $33,994.62 in the past twenty-two months, his divorced wife, Lita Grey Chaplin, reported today in her fifth annual accounting of her custody of the children.
The majority of the organization designees for Aldermen triumphed in yesterday's primary election, returns indicated early this morning.

OKLAHOMA CITY, Sept. 19 (AP) -- Charles F. Urschel, oil millionaire, related in unemotional voice from the witness stand in Federal court here this afternoon the story of his nine days in the hands of kidnappers who collected $200,000 ransom, and named Albert Bates, one of the twelve defendants on trial, as one of his abductors.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 -- Cotton men from the South who are demanding repeal of the processing tax, a fixed 20-cent price and currency inflation met with rebuffs today on two official fronts.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 -- Upon adjournment of the Federal Advisory Council today, Walter W. Smith, president of the First National Bank of St. Louis and president of the council, issued a statement in which he said that "banks are beingr unfairly and widely criticized on the presumption that they are refusing to make loans."

Countering the move of a group of stockholders supporting the efforts of Ralph C. Holmes, former chairman, to regain executive control, the Texas Corporation yesterday added three new directors to represent some large stockholding interests in the corporation.

BOISE, Idaho, Sept. 19 -- A slowly widening margin against prohibition appeared in Idaho tonight as about one-fourth of the State's precincts reported returns from the election on repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment.

ATHENS, Sept. 19 -- One of the original English and original Greek versions of the Insull dossier as well as four photostatic Greek copies were deposited with the Foreign Ministry today by the First Secretary of the United States Legation, Gerhard Gade, in a sizable transfer operation.

Gerhard M. Dahl, chairman of the board of the B.M.T., has voluntarily accepted a 70 per cent salary cut, a reduction in his yearly stipend to $40,000 from $135,000, it was announced yesterday on his behalf by the transit company.

WESTBURY, L. I., Sept. 19 -- Aurora and Sands Point played a pony game on Meadow Brook's No. 4 field today by way of swinging back into action after the rain in preparation for the coming open polo championship. The Aurora four slid through to an easy victory at 15 to 4.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 -- The Bureau of Navigation issued the following orders today dated Sept. 16:

LEIPZIG, Sept. 19 -- All preparations have now been completed for the trial, scheduled to begin Thursday before the Fourth Criminal Senate of the German Supreme Court in this city, to fix responsibility and exact punishment for the fire that burned out the Reichstag building on the night of Feb. 27.
HAVANA, Sept. 19 -- Regardless of whether the student government falls, regardless of who or what succeeds it. Cuba appears destined for some sort of a struggle between fascism and communism.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 -- A delegation from nine Southern States failed to put personally before President Roosevelt and Secretary Wallace their demands for inflation and removal of the cotton processing tax today, but, instead, received an invitation to show the Farm Administration how prices could be raised under the Farm Act.

KHARKOV, Russia, Sept. 19 -- Summing up the impressions of a ten days' trip through North Caucasus and "Ukraine, where this correspondent traveled with greater freedom and absence of supervision than had been expected, I repeat the opinion that the decisive engagement in the struggle for rural socialization has been won by the Kremlin.

Embattled Tammany's primary contests yesterday were enlivened by tactics reminiscent of the plus-hand-velvet era of politics. There were reports of slugging, ballot-stuffing and intimidation from various parts of the city, particularly where the leadership fights were hottest.

S.W. Straus Co., who were placed in receivership on March 3, began to suffer financial reverses in 1930 and their losses continued during 1931 and 1932, according to testimony given, yesterday at a hearing in the office of John E. Joyce, Federal referee, at 70 Pine Street.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Sept. 19 (AP) -- W.N. Reynolds's Meda, driven by Ben White, won the forty-first renewal of the $14,000 Kentucky Futurity handily today, scoring in two straight heats. The times were 2:03 1/4, and 2:03 1/2. The first heat equaled the season's record for 3-year-old trotters.
The hapless white Sox felt the power of an old-time Yankee hitting offensive at the Stadium yesterday.

Testimony to show that Senator James J. Davis of Pennsylvania, as "czar" of the Loyal Order of Moose, received $175,000 in 1930 and 1931 through promoting lotteries of that order, was introduced yesterday in Federal court.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 -- Progress was made today toward formulating separate district wage agreements between soft coal operators and the United Mine Workers of America, but there was no Indication as to when the complete agreements in all the fields recognizing the union would be reached.

The president of the British Association for the Advancement of Science, Sir FREDERICK GOWLAND HOPKINS, in his presidential address quoted one of his scientific peers who had died during the year as saying in a national British broadcast shortly before his going that" we can find safety and prog "ress only as we bring into our meth"ods of statecraft the guidance of "biological truth."

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 19 (AP) -- In the first real upset of the Pacific Southwest tennis tournament, Jack Tidball, University of California at Los Angeles star, defeated Adrian Quist, leading Australian entrant, in decisive fashion, 6 -- 4, 6 -- 2, in the third round of the men's singles today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 -- Warehouse receipts for non-beverage wine of more than 3.2 per cent alcoholic content may be accepted as collateral for loans by banks to wine manufacturers for purchasing grapes for processing, Attorney General Cummings has ruled.

BERLIN, Sept. 19 -- The Boerse opened today with a continuation of the downward trend, registering losses up to 2 per cent. Later, however, it reversed itself under the leadership of the heavy industrials, especially coal shares, and scored gains of 3 per cent and more.

BERLIN, Sept. 19 -- The Jews of Germany, having rallied from the first attacks of the National Socialists, are beginning to mobilize all their spiritual and material powers for a new struggle for survival.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 19 (AP) -- The Pirates ended their 1933 National League pennant chase today when they fell before the tantalizing slants of Phil Collins in the second game of a double-header with the seventh-place Phillies, 3 to 2.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Sept. 19 -- A year ago this time Rip Miller, the upstanding young Navy coach, looked over an inexperienced squad and delivered himself of one of the most bullish prophecies of the football season.

HAVANA, Sept. 19 -- Bluntly refusing to form a national government in collaboration with opposing factions, the student and army government today faced a second counter-revolutionary movement which may grow to serious proportions.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 (AP) -- Steamship companies operating through the Panama Canal today won an initial contest with transcontinental carriers when the Interstate Commerce Commission refused to suspend the first joint water-rail rate ever proposed between Pacific ports and Mississippi Valley points.

After holding within a narrow range for several hours yesterday, prices on the Cotton Exchange surged upward violently under one of the most aggressive buying waves in the last six months. October sold within 10 points of 10 1/2 cents a pound, July rose above 11 cents.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Frequent columns of your paper seem to question the time when France will go off the gold standard. An informed friend of mine who resides abroad tells me France has been off the old standard of gold for some months. He says various administrative regulations have been set up which make it virtually impossible for private individuals to buy government gold.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 19 -- The concluding chapter to one of the most startling upsets in major league baseball in recent years was written today when the Giants clinched the National League pennant for 1933.

WASHINGTON Sept 19 -- Henry Morgenthau Jr , governor of the Farm Credit Administration, today ordered all executives and employes responsible for success of the farm mortgage refinancing program to ''get results or give way to somebody who will."

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., Sept. 19 -- Jumping about Long Island Sound more like kangaroos on a rampage than like yachts in a race, the interclub sloops and the Bermuda ones engaged'today in the fourth contest of their international series.

A draft of proposed legislation to regulate the use of trade-marks on manufactured articles was submitted yesterday by the Merchants Association of New York at a hearing before the join legislative, commission appointed to consider this matter.

RYE, N.Y., Sept. 19 -- Mrs. Martin C. Missir, the defending champion, today won the play-off for, the medal in the annual Westchester Country Club women's championship golf tourney after she had triumphed in the first round of match play in the morning.

BERLIN, Sept. 19 -- "The fixing of just prices for German wheat and rye is only part of a scheme of the new German Government for taking the whole of German agriculture out of the capitalistic traffic," Richard Walther Darre, Reich Minister of Agriculture, declared in a broadcast speech today.

CHICAGO, Sept. 19 -- Plans of the farm administration to bring returns to the dairy industry back to pre-war parity were outlined here today by Dr. Clyde L. King, dairy administrator of the Agricultural Adjustment Administration.

John F. Curry, chieftain of Tammany Hall, suffered a crushing defeat in yesterday's primary election as returns indicated that three of the important district leaders he had counted on to retain their posts had been swept into the discard.

Sharp declines in the bond market had a depressing effect upon financial sentiment yesterday. Transactions in this market were the heaviest in two months and prices were reduced anywhere from 1 to 9 points.

Observers in Cuba find at play some of the forces that have helped to make the revolution in Spain. Cuban revolutionary leaders are aware of what hag been going on in the mother country and have been following events there with sympathy. If that is indeed the case, it is to be hoped that Cuba may further copy the Spanish model in exhibiting self-control and a healthy sense of self-preservation.

The policemen, firemen, school teachers and other civil service employes of the city won a victory over Tammany and its allied Democratic organizations at the primary election yesterday by bringing about the nomination of Frank J. Prial for Controller.

BOSTON, Sept. 19 (AP) -- Dr. Mordecai Ezekiel, economic adviser to Secretary Wallace, suggested today that too high a proportion of the nation's population might be engaged in selling and transportation as compared with production.
PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 19 (AP) -- The Athletics hit Detroit pitching for three home runs today and a 5-to-2 victory.

Dallas, Texas. The city of Dallas, Texas, is expected to offer next month a new issue of $2,168,000 of bonds to retire its overdrafts on banks, according to private advices received here yesterday. In 1931 the State Legislature passed laws authorizing communities to issue bonds to fund their respective deficits.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 -- An apparently rising tide of internal turmoil to the east of Havana, was pictured by Secretary Hull today as he unfolded to newspaper men a series of excerpts from consular reports, telling of strikes, acts of violence, discord, tension and overthrown local governments in the central and eastern sections of the island.

Flee From What? Why do Hollywood residents elope to get married when there is nothing to prevent their getting married at home? Or prevent their going anywhere else to get married without elaping there? Film luminaries who are quite free to wed are always eloping to Yuma or Tia Juana or Nogales, leaving by airplane early in the morning and returning to Hollywood in time for lunch.

SAN JUAN, P.R., Sept. 19 -- The Chase National Bank plans to open a branch in Puerto Rico, according to an announcement by Governor Gore today. He said officials of the bank in New York had advised him that they had applied to the Federal Reserve Bank for authorization to establish the branch.
Six properties in Manhattan went to the plaintiffs at foreclosure sales conducted toy auctioneers yesterday.

HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Sept. 19 -- John Mears of the Garden City Country Club, with a 78, captured the low gross honors today in a one-day amateur tournament conducted at the Hempstead Golf Club by the Long Island Golf Association.

The Most Rev. Thomas E. Molloy, Bishop of the Roman Catholic Diocese of Brooklyn, celebrated a solemn pontifical mass of thanksgiving in the St. James Pro-Cathedral, Jay and Chapel Streets, Brooklyn, yesterday morning, commemorating the twenty-fifth anniversary of his ordination to the priesthood.

Leases of entire buildings formed the bulk of real estate trading in Manhattan yesterday when brokers announced deals involving a variety of structures, including downtown commercial buildings, dwellings, a warehouse and two uptown theatre buildings.
CHICAGO, Sept. 19 -- Former President and Mrs. Hoover received a warm welcome in Chicago tonight when they arrived from California to visit the Century of Progress Exposition for a few days.

To the Editor of The New York Times : A great deal is heard these days about the need of producing capital goods, such as new plants, machinery, locomotives and other equipment. It is said that this is required to bring about a permanent business recovery; that if this is done a much-needed step in the right direction will be taken.
MINNEAPOLIS, Minn., Sept. 19 (AP) -- A relief pitcher who could hit as well as hurl gave Columbus the championship in the American Association play-off today and the club's first pennant since 1907.

The two candidates for the four nominations to the New Rochelle City Council who favored the continuance in office of City Manager John F. Donavan against the combined opposition of the thirteen other candidates were named yesterday in the outstanding contest of Westchester's primaries, according to complete returns late last night.

Sherwood Anderson's next novel will come out under the Scribner Imprint.
