His books formerly were published by Liveright, Inc., and the story is that Horace Liveright lost Ernest Hemingway from his list because he refused to publish "Torrents of Spring," an early collection by Hemingway consisting of take-offs on the Anderson style.

A warning lest recovery efforts result in stalling American progress was sounded yesterday by A.W. Robertson, chairman of the board of the Westinghouse Electric and Manufacturing Company. Mr. Robertson spoke at a luncheon of the Controllers Institute of America at the Hotel Roosevelt.

Severe pressure was exerted against the bond market on the Stock Exchange during the early hours of the session yesterday, substantial losses appearing in all parts of the list. Rallies in late trading reduced the losses in some degree, although all groups averaged lower on the day.

VIENNA, Sept. 19 -- A sensational turn was given tonight to the Austrian political situation by a formal offer of Socialist cooperation with the Dollfuss government coupled with the assertion that the present regime, having lost most of its supporters, could not even defend Austria's frontiers without the assistance of the Socialist Schutzbund.

BERLIN, Sept. 19 -- Reports from Paris that yesterday's conversations between Foreign Minister Joseph Paul-Boncour of France and Captain Anthony Eden of the British Foreign Office had terminated negatively were received in Berlin as corroborating the prevailing German thesis that France is determined to sabotage any attempt to arrive at an ultimate settlement of the disarmament issue at this time.

Since it is inevitable, Summer will end and Fall will begin at 8:01 A.M., Daylight Saving Time, on Saturday. And then, early on the next day -- Sunday -- Daylight Saving Time will depart for another year when clocks are turned back one hour at 2 A.M.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I write to send a humble plea that you give us the important facts of the news about Cuba. In this morning's issue your correspondent refers to the efforts by Cuban laborers to "force a betterment of wages and living conditions," but says nothing about what the demands are or what practices are being condemned.
LONDON, Sept. 19 -- An emergency meeting of the Cabinet will be held tomorrow afternoon to decide Britain's policy on disarmament, especially on the crucial question of supervision.

BOLTON LANDING, N.Y., Sept. 19 (AP) -- William W. Farley, former State Excise Commissioner, speaking here today before the New York State Association of Real Estate Boards, said that if President Roosevelt had not taken the United States "off the gold standard, the country would have had financial chaos and possible revolution."
Success of the plan to organize a New Jersey Stock Exchange was regarded by its sponsors as assured last night.
A man leaped from the lower observatory on the Eighty-sixth floor of the Empire State Building yesterday and lived. He landed one story below, on the building's only extension balcony.

Plans for a Broadway production of "White Horse Inn," the colorful musical show which was presented in London two years ago, have been definitely abandoned, at least until next season, it was stated last night by Erik Charell, who had intended to direct the production.

A million families who have been "doubling up" with relatives and friends because of financial stress will return to their own homes within the next twelve months, in the opinion of Philip Lieber, newly elected president of the United States League of Building and Loan Associations.

SOME day in the far future a man who can achieve the "exterior view" will have a lot of fun with American reviewing of literary criticism. For example, our hypothetical literary anthropologist will look back and discover American critics praising Vernon Parrington's "Main Currents in American Thought" and condemning Granyille Hicks's "The Great Tradition," just published by Macmillan ($2.50).

MOUNT KISCO, N.Y., Sept. 19 -- Miss Rosalie de Forest Crosby, daughter of Mrs. Henry Ashton Crosby of Mount Kisco, was introduced to society tonight at a supper dance given by her mother at the Lawrence Farms Golf Club here.

The Class 1 railroads had a further increase in ton-mileage of freight moved In Julys according to the Bureau of Railway Economics. June was the first month in which an upturn had been reported since 1929.

An air of quiet confidence prevailed at Tammany Hall last night as a mere handful of party leaders and workers gathered there to receive returns from the primary election. In striking contrast to the cheering crowds with red flares, usual on election night, only about thirty men had congregated at the building by 10 o'clock last night.

Louis H.F. Mouquin, grandson of Henri Mouquin, who started in business as a wine merchant in New York sixty years ago, returned yesterday on the French liner Ile de France after a tour of the wine districts in Europe. He placed orders, he said, for 6,000,000 gallons of wine at a cost of about $9,000,000.

Madison Square Garden opens its doors at 11 A.M. today to admit visitors to the 1933 Radio-Electrical Exposition, which will continue for ten days. On view will be the latest designs in radio sets and home electric appliances.

ALLENTOWN, Pa., Sept. 19 -- Dillon Direct, by Braden Direct, won the 2:13 class pace, and Guy Lewis, by Adioo Guy, outstepped a large field to capture the 2:25 class pace in Central Circuit light-harness races today at the Allentown Fair track.

CHICAGO, Sept. 19 -- Imbued with new life, the Dodgers swung with accuracy in their farewell appearance at Wrigley Field today, crushing the Cubs under a 12-to-8 count. They hopped for Pittsburgh tonight with their spirits and batting averages generally improved as a result of sixteen hits.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 -- Former Representative R. Walton Moore of Fairfax, Va., was appointed by President Roosevelt today to be Assistant Secretary of State, succeeding Raymond Moley.

Cats were denounced in a statement yesterday by the National Association of Audubon Societies, in which it recommended that towns accept the responsibility of exterminating stray felines. The association's aversion to cats is based upon their fondness for birds and their habit of caterwauling in the dark of the night.

While fourteen jurors histened attentively yesterday in the Criminal Branch of the Supreme Court, the prosecutor and the chief defense counsel outlined their cases at the trial of Isidor J. Kresel. Mr. Kresel is accused of being a party to the wrongful conversion of about $2,000,000 of the Bank of United States funds to an affiliate, the Municipal Safe Deposit Company.

BOSTON, Sept. 19 -- Louis Fairchild of the Fairchild Publications told the retail distribution conference that "between the NRA, agricultural adjustment and inflation, there will be more jobs, more money in circulation for all, and more leisure time."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 -- Eugene L. Vidal, director of air regulation of the aeronautics branch of the Department of Commerce, was appointed director of aeronautics today and wiil henceforth direct the combined activities of that branch, Secretary Roper announced.

CHARLESTON, S.C., Sept. 19 (AP) -- Three and a half days behind schedule, the Mallory passenger liner Henry R. Mallory arrived in Charleston this afternoon, having encountered one of the worst hurricanes to sweep the Atlantic seaboard.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 -- Eleven new registration statements of issues have been filed under the Securities Act with the Federal Trade Commission.

PEORIA, Ill., Sept. 19 -- Five young gunmen last night tried to kidnap Wilton G. Newman, 68, a banker and merchant, from his home here. Quick action by Mr. Newman's wife and her sister, Mrs. Rosa Kahn, upset the thugs' plans. The gunmen fled as Mrs. Kahn telephoned police and Mrs. Newman ran for a revolver.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Sept. 19 -- Asserting that the Recovery Administration is full of "lawyers, economists, statisticians and other doctrinaires," each with a pet theory, Professor Philip Cabot of Harvard University writes in the Autumn number of The Yale Review that if they are kept under lock and key they will do no harm, but if they are let loose to administer the act, the thing will end in a "dog fight."

PARIS, Sept. 19 -- In the role of listener rather than that of adviser, Norman H. Davis, United States Ambassador at Large, carried the disarmament discussion a step forward today when he had long interviews with the Foreign Minister, Joseph Paul-Boncour, and Premier Daladier.

The dollar underwent further depreciation in foreign exchange yesterday to register new low quotations in terms of the gold standard exchanges. It dropped to 64.65 cents in gold valuation, measured against the French franc, compared with the previous low of 64.81 cents made on Monday.

The Merchants Association of New York City and the Chambers of Commerce of the Bronx, Brooklyn. Queens and Richmond have been made a part of the local NRA Compliance Bureau to carry on the activities of the permanent NRA organization by Grover A. Whalen, city NRA chairman.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 -- The first challenge of government authority to compel a reduction in salaries of railroad officers has been offered in the apparent refusal of the Pennsylvania Railroad to comply with the request of Joseph B. Eastman, coordinator of transportation, that such action be taken.

Governor Lehman conferred yesterday with city officials and representatives of the city's banks in an effort to untangle the city's finances, after Samuel Untermyer had earlier in the day submitted a program to the Board of Estimate to add another $7,000,000 a year to the city's revenues.

It cost the city, for interest charges alone, about 12 1/2 cents a passenger to operate its new subway lines in the year ended Sept. 10, according to Nathan L. Amster, president of the Manhattan Railway Company, who made another plea yesterday for early unification of all rapid transit lines.

George McAneny took a temporary leave of absence yesterday as Sanitation Commissioner to accept Mayor O'Brien's appointment to the vacant Controllership until Jan. 1, when the newly elected Controller will take office.

By cooperating with the Washington administration's re-employment program and with the policies of Joseph B. Eastman, Federal Coordinator of Transportation, the Missouri-Kansas-Texas Lines have added $500,000 monthly to their payroll, M. H. Cahill, president, said yesterday.

MINNEAPOLIS, Sept. 19 -- King Levinsky, Chicago heavyweight, who defeated Jack Sharkey, was rated higher than his opponent in the list of champions approved today by the National Boxing Association, at its annual convention. Levinsky was rated fourth, in the heavyweight division and Sharkey fifth.

Commodity values were improved again yesterday by a decline in the world value of the dollar and gains were noted on most of the futures and cash markets. Trading was active as a rule and speculative interest appeared to outrun trade buying for most staples.

Few are the Presidents who have avoided a controversy over their power to appoint and remove Federal officials. President WILSON won a posthumous victory when the Supreme Court of the United States, in the Myers case, recognized his right to remove executive officers without the consent of the Senate which confirmed them.

A hundred children of the lower east side turned harvest hands yesterday afternoon to gather in the crops of vegetables, and even tobacco, cotton and peanuts, that they had planted and cultivated in tiny plots in Seward Park. The miniature city farm is conducted by the Educational Alliance under the supervision of the Park Department.

LONG BEACH, L.I., Sept. 19 -- By coming back in 35, Charles A. McGuire Jr. and Thomas F. Scholl of Huntington brought in a 74 today to tie J.B. Mackie Jr. and his partner, Stanley Harte, for the lead in the M.G.A. team best-ball tournament at the Lido Country Club.

SPRINGFIELD, N.J., Sept. 19 -- In the opening round of the wokmen's New Jersey State golf championship today, Miss Charlotte Glutting made an auspicious start for the title which she has won the past two years.

LONDON, Sept. 19 -- France and Germany of their own free will today announced to the wheat advisory committee that they were ready to renounce the worst forms of the economic nationalism that each of them has followed ever since the world depression began.
GENEVA, Sept. 19 -- The League of Nations budget for 1934, which will be submitted at the coming Assembly for approval, totals $6,000,000 gold, including funds for the World Court.

An interesting lease in the midtown shopping district was reported yesterday for the building at 590 Fifth Avenue, where Budd, Ltd., headed by Hudson Budd, rented through Wm. A. White Sons a store for the sale of men's furnishings.

Various concessions were asked by representatives of the Theatre Ticket Brokers Association yesterday in a communication to Brock Pemberton, chairman of the subcommittee handling the ticket controversy for the National Legitimate Theatre Committee.

At a meeting held yesterday at 99 Park Avenue the Emergency Committee on Unemployment of the United Neighborhood Houses of New York made a definite demand for adequate cash relief in the following statement:

It need occasion no great surprise that the President and Secretary WALLACE deftly evaded consideration of the "cotton committee's" resolutions. That document submitted a demand for currency inflation sufficient in scope "immediately to establish a minimum "price for cotton, of 20 cents per "pound on the farms."

Expanding activity in the clothing trades, due in part to the national recovery program, has led many garment firms in the West Thirty-fifth Street zone to enlarge their quarters and add many workers, according to reports received from renting agents yesterday.
PITTSBURGH, Sept. 19 (AP) -- United Mine Workers' officials in District No. 5, comprising part of the rich Connellsville coke region, tonight ordered their members to return to work immediately.

ARMONK, N. Y., Sept. 19 -- Competing in a field of 125 golfers, Mrs. Lew A. Satz of the Fenlmore Country Club, Mamaronecfc, won both low gross and low net honors in the annual one-day women's invitation golf tournament at the Westchester Embassy Club, today.

MINEOLA, L.I., Wednesday, Sept. 20 -- Returns in the Democratic primary fight in Nassau County early this morning indicated that Philip N. Krug would have control of the County Committee lay a 3-to-2 majority.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Sept. 19 (AP) -- Two home runs by Estel Crabtree and Ray Pepper and Jim Lindsey's excellent relief hurling overcame Buffalo today, 6 to 3, and gave Rochester an advantage of two games to one in the final playoff series for the International League championship.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., Sept. 19 -- Antonio Marino, proprietor of a barber shop at 96 Main Street, carried today to the Port Washington postoffice the. Blue Eagle placard which has been in his window for two weeks and explained that he did not want the Blue Eagle in his window any longer.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 19 -- Early returns tonight indicated that the Vare organization ticket bad won in the Republican primary and that the Independent Democrats had bowled over the old Democratic organization leadership that has been accused of bi-partisan deals with the Vare machine.

Equipoise, handicap champion of America for the last two seasons, will end his racing career after one more start. The announcement was made yesterday by C.V. Whitney, owner of the famous son of Pennant and Swinging.

LISCOMB, N.S., Sept. 19 (Canadian Press) -- Safe after a thrilling voyage from the northern tip of Newfoundland, three American university undergraduates today prepared to sail the Grenfell Mission schooner Jessie Galtwaith to Portland, Me.

Resolutions urging that the National Recovery Administration and the National Labor Board act immediately to end the strike in the silk dyeing industry and that the o e as presented for the industry at the hearing on Sept. 12 be approved, were adopted yesterday at a mass meeting of weavers of broad silks held in the offices of the Silk Association.

Asserting that facts showed that the percentage of losses by security investors was lower than the percentage of losses through holdings of other forms of property, such as real estate, farm products and merchandise, Frank M. Gordon, president of the Investment Bankers Association of America, told the annual convention of the National Association of Security Commissioners in Milwaukee, Wis., there was a widespread disposition to attribute all losses in securities to fraud.

GLEN COVE, L.I., Sept. 19 -- Miss Rosalie Knapp of the Women's National Golf and Tennis Club led a field of fifty-two in the Women's Metropolitan Golf Associaltion one-day handicap tournament today. She posted an 82 over the Nassau Country Club course for low gross honors.

Daily average gross production of crude oil in the United States last week was 2,603,450 barrels, compared with 2,691,950 in the preceding week, a decline of 88,500 barrels, according to the American Petroleum Institute. A drop of 62,900 barrels in East Texas and a gain of 50,800 in Oklahoma were among the important changes.

Residential development of 94 3/4 acres In Closter, Bergen County, is forecast by sale of the tract to the Alpfarm Company, Inc., of 147 Summit Avenue, Union City. The sellers were August Bentkamp of Alpine and Alfred Endler of the Bronx.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 -- A critical situation in the relations of the National Labor Board, of which Senator Wagner is chairman, and General Johnson, the Recovery Administrator, apparently was relieved today upon the promise of the Administrator not to permit interference by his subordinates with the activities of the Labor Board, which was appointed by President Roosevelt.

John Milton, a lawyer of Jersey City, former Prosecutor of Hudson County and Corporation Counsel for Jersey City, was reported yesterday as under consideration by Governor A. Harry Moore for nomination to the Port of New York Authority as a successor to General William C. Heppenheimer, who died last week.
The much-discussed duck-stamp tax legislation, which has been in Congress for the past four years, again is to come before the Senate Committee on Wild Life Resources this Winter.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 -- After nearly a, year of investigation and hearings, the Treasury Department today issued anti-dumping orders against incandescent light bulbs and rubber-soled fabric-topped footwear from Japan, celluloid-covered thumb tacks from Germany and saponified stearic acid from the Netherlands.

J.A. Robert Quinn, former president of the Boston Red Sox and business manager of the St. Louis Browns, was named as business manager or the Dodgers yesterday, according to an announcement made by Stephen W. McKeever, president of the Brooklyn club.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 -- The War Department issued the following orders today:

R.A. Orray Taft Jr., United States Vice Consul at Warsaw, and Mrs. Taft are to sail for Europe today on the President Roosevelt of the United States Lines. Others sailing on the liner include Miss Eveline Elliott, Mrs. Jean Gilmore, Miss Helen Morris, Mr. and Mrs. George Clarke, J.P. O'Brien and Lieut. Col. and Mrs. Clifford Corbin.

The Boston Symphony Orchestra will play "what is important and interesting of the music composed last year" during the coming season, Serge Koussevitzky said yesterday on his arrival from abroad on the Ile de France. Mr. Koussevitzky, who will begin his tenth season as conductor of the Boston Orchestra on Friday afternoon, Oct. 6, plans his customary longlist of new works by contemporary composers of many nations.
BOSTON, Sept. 19 (AP) -- Bill Werber led the Red Sox to a 4-to-3 victory over the Indians today, the last meeting between the two teams this season.

The estate of Sidney M. Colgate, chairman of the Colgate-PalmolivePeet Company, manufacturer of soap and perfumery, was appraised yesterday at $10,689,952 gross and $8,269,607 net, of which $8,521,854 was in securities.

SOUTH BEND, Ind., Sept. 20 (AP). -- Virtually penniless and without plans for the future, Colonel George Milburn Studebaker, scion of a pioneer Indiana manufacturing family, sat in his sixty-four-room house here today, a victim of the Insull utilities collapse.

PATERSON, N. J., Sept. 20 -- The strike of 15,OOO dyers in the Paterson district is no nearer settlement after a series of conferences between members of the Institute of Dyers and Printers and delegates representing workers affiliated with the American Federation of Labor.

The preliminary disarmament conversations at Paris have gone so far as to report progress; that is to say, there is as yet no visible progress. Mr. NORMAN DAVIS has spoken with the French and conveyed to them President ROOSEVELT'S sincere desire to see the work of real disarmament set in motion at Geneva next week.

DETROIT, Sept. 20 (AP). -- Asserting that he had been "prevented" from making further sensational disclosures before the now closed Detroit bank investigating jury, Senator Couzens let it be known today that he intended to continue a fight for banking reform.

The fleet High Time filly, Spoilt Beauty, which carried the colors of A.C. Schwartz in the Futurity, was first in the featured Babylon Purse for fillies at Aqueduct yesterday. A 4-to-5 shot, the Schwartz color-bearer led practically from start to finish to score by three-quarters of a length.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 (AP) -- Prominent wets and drys of both political parties united today in organizing retail beverage dealers to seek uniformity of State laws on liquor dispensing and low taxes to drive out the bootlegger.
SPRINGFIELD, N.J., Sept. 20 -- Producing another brilliant round of golf, Miss Charlotte Glutting gained the semi-finals of the women's New Jersey State championship today.

EDWARDSVILLE, Ill., Sept. 20 (AP) -- The text of a note demanding $16,000 received by August Luer, Alton (Ill.) banker, following his release by kidnappers, was introduced here late today at the trial of six alleged abductors.

A new squabble between Samuel Untermyer and the Municipal Economy Committee, headed by Peter Grimm, was the chief development yesterday in the city's financial affairs, while further solution of the city's difficulties awaited a second conference tomorrow with Governor Lehman.

MINEOLA, L.I., Sept. 20 -- J.P. Morgan of Glen Cove again succeeded in capturing one of the blue ribbons at the second day of the annual fair here of the Queens-Nassau Agricultural Society. He won one of the special awards for Guernsey exhibitors with his prize stock and carried off the Cornell Remsen Cup for the best junior bull.

HAVRE DE GRACE, Md., Sept. 20 (AP). -- Selby Burch's Thursday, surging out of claiming company, drove to a brilliant head victory over S. W. Labrot's Tred Avon, redoubtable Maryland mare, in the mile and a sixteenth Susquehanna Handicap, feature of the inauguration of the Harford Association's regular Fall meeting today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 -- Threat of a strike of 6,000 house wreckers in New York today and the tie-up of millions of dollars' worth of demolition contracts hung last night upon the action of the Policy Board of the NRA here, which was asked by employers and employes to approve an agreement to pay a minimum wage scale above the minimum provided in the President's Re-employment Agreement.
NEW YORK. Sir Arthur and Lady Worley and their daughter, Miss Stella Worley, accompanied by Mr. and Mrs. Cecil F. Shallcross, are at the Waldorf-Astoria.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 20. -- The long-continued battle for adequate housing of the regular army was partly won today when the Public Works Administration approved an allotment of $54,709,358 for construction and reconditioning work at thirty-two posts in nineteen States.

Following their custom of beginning the theatrical season on Rosh ha-Shanah, the Jewish New Year, ten Yiddish playhouses in the city will open today. Three of the theatres are in Manhattan, three in the Bronx and four in Brooklyn.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 20. -- Progress toward ratification of the Great Lakes-St. Lawrence treaty with Canada was made today by President Roosevelt at a conference in his study at the White House.

SCARBOROUGH-ON-HUDSON, N.Y., Sept. 20 -- Miss Phoebe Davis made her debut tonight at a supper dance given by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Pierpont Van Derveer Davis, of Beaver Hill, Ossining, at the Sleepy Hollow Country Club here.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 20. -- Disturbed over continuing reports that imports of cheaply made commodities are threatening to disrupt some parts of the national recovery program, administration officials have completed the draft of a plan by Which President Roosevelt could arbitrarily impose extra fees in addition to the import duty.

The threat of a strike on subway, elevated, surface and bus lines in New York City loomed yesterday as the American Federation of Labor, through its affiliate in the street transportation industry, moved to invoke the aid of the National Recovery Administration to force unionization of more than 30,000 workers employed on transportation lines in the city.

Among passengers scheduled to sail on the Cunarder Aquitania tonight for Cherbourg and Southampton are Count M. Soyeshima, member of the Japanese House of Peers; Lady Walter Gordon-Lenox, Sir Arthur and Lady Worley, Miss Stella Worley, Sir Alexander Murray, Count Y. Futara, Captain Arthur Evans, Bert Wilson and Captain and Mrs. Charles H. Wombwell.
PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., Sept. 20 -- With Long Island Sound quieted down to just a slight bounce and the breeze still energetic, the Bermuda sloops had sailing conditions of their liking today.

Attacking inflation as productive of "monkey money," James W. Gerard, former Ambassador to Germany and former treasurer of the Democratic National Committee, expressed the hope yesterday that President Roosevelt would "lash himself to the mast of sound finances."

TRENTON, N. J., Sept. 20. -- A few hours after Governor and Mrs. A. Harry Moore had sailed for a three-weeks vacation abroad. Senate President Emerson L. Richards of Atlantic City, a Republican, was sworn at the State House here as Acting Governor.

Thomas G. Chamberlain and William R. McComb gave a dinner last night in the roof garden of the Pierre for Miss Barbara Scudder, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Marvyn Scudder, and David E. Hudson, to whom Miss Scudder will be married here tomorrow in the Central Presbyterian Church.
LONDON, Sept. 20. -- The British Cabinet discussed disarmament for two hours today without letting France have a definite decision on her demand for the supervision of armaments of nations.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 20. -- President Roosevelt has received no protests from foreign governments against building up the United States Navy within treaty limits, it was made known at the White House today.

BERLIN, Sept. 20. -- Lifting industry and trade out of the depression by stimulating consumption and productive investments is the primary goal of the German government's economic program, it was announced at the initial session of the Grand Economic Council today.

BUFFALO, Sept. 20 (AP). -- The Buffalo Bisons pounded three Rochester pitchers for nineteen hits to hammer out a 16-4 victory tonight and even their International League final play-off series at two games each.
PRINCETON, N.J., Sept. 20. -- The word has gone abroad that Princeton is one of the teams of the East to watch this season.

As in July, when the pound sterling reached normal parity with the dollar and all speculative markets broke sharply, prices on the Cotton Exchange declined more than two-fifth cent a pound yesterday and ended with losses of 40 to 46 points.
Several flats were included in the New Jersey realty conveyances reported yesterday.

Tuesday's primary disorders which flared up again yesterday and resulted in the shooting of Martin Smith, a former amateur boxer, brought a demand last night from Fiorello H. LaGuardia, Fusion candidate for Mayor, that stringent methods be taken to protect the polls and the count of votes at November's election.

The National Municipal League announced yesterday that it would hold its annual convention on Nov. 9, 10 and 11 in Atlantic City in cooperation with the National Association of Civic Secretaries, the Governmental Research Association, the Proportional Representation League and the National Conference of Citizens Councils.

BERLIN, Sept. 20. -- A firmer tendency and a reawakening of public and professional buying interest were the features of today's market on the Boerse. Weakening of the dollar and the pound apparently had an effect on the prevalent tone of the market, and trading was limited, although there was a steady demand for both stocks and bonds, inspired undoubtedly by expectations of definite action by the government in connection with its economic policies.

BOSTON, Sept. 20. -- Charged with looting their own banking chain of 5450,000 in cash and $183,000 worth of stocks, the presidents of four Massachusetts banks and the treasurer of a fifth were indicted by the Federal grand jury here today, The indictments marked the second phase of the government's investigation of the collapse of the $60,000,000 Federal National Bank and its eight State affiliates.

MOSCOW, Sept. 20 -- A Nazi raid on the Soviet Club in Berlin last Saturday night, only a short while after Ambassador Khinchuk of the Soviet Union had left a reception given to him there, is featured indignantly on the front pages of Soviet newspapers today.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 20 -- Mrs. Clarence H. Vanderbeck, women's national golf champion in 1915, lost in the first round of the Berthellyn cup event at Huntingdon Valley today to Mrs. Norman P. Rood of Wilmington, 3 and 1. Mrs. Vander-beck had won the Berthellyn cup twice.

BOGOTA, Colombia, Sept. 20. -- The Board of Control of Exchange and Exports decided today to permit foreign mining companies to remit abroad payments for dividends, machinery and supplies, apparently as part of a plan to stimulate the production of gold.

PARIS, Sept. 20 -- Within a half hour after they had been put on sale in banks and postoffices this morning all of the 2,000,000 tickets of 100 francs each in the first French national lottery had been sold. [200,000,000 francs equals $12,100,000 at the current exchange.]

ALLENTOWN, Pa., Sept. 20 -- Split-heats furnished exciting finishes today in the central circuit light harness classes over the Allentown Fair track. Peter F.J., bay gelding by Frisco June, won the 2 : 09 class trot, while Pluto Barient, by Pluto Watts, outstepped a large field to win the 2 : 26 class trot.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 20. -- The New York Giants spoiled the National Professional Football League debut of the Pittsburgh Pirates at Forbes Field tonight when they scored a 23-to-2 victory before 25,000 fans. The game was also the first league contest of the season for the New Yorkers.

CHICAGO, Sept. 20. -- Farm price-fixing schemes eventually must fail and inflation would be powerless to help the agricultural situation unless the law of supply and demand were complied with, Secretary 'Wallace declared in an address here today.
The Yankees downed the Chicago White Sox yesterday at the Stadium, and delayed for at least another day Washington's ownership of this year's American League pennant. The score was 5 to 3.
"Double Door," a play by Elizabeth McFadden, will open tonight at the Ritz Theatre. Mary Morris, Granville Bates and Aleta Freel are in the cast.

LONDON, Sept. 20. -- A further flight from the dollar on inflation fears had sharp repercussions today on the gold currencies, which appreciated substantially, resulting in a fresh high record price for gold at 133s 9d. Heavy selling of dollars sent the dollar down overnight from $4.79 to the pound to $4.85 3/4, the lowest level since July, when it was below parity of $4.86 2-3, touching $4.87 1/4.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 (AP). -- Behind the steady pitching of Alvin Crowder, Washington drew closer to the American League pennant today by pounding out a 13-to-5 victory over St. Louis.

Plans for the New Jersey approach to the new Midtown Hudson. Tunnel, made public yesterday by the Port of New York Authority, call for a new roadway connecting the Weehawken plaza in the initial stage with Bergenline Avenue in Union City and ultimately with the Hudson County Boulevard and North Bergen.

New York roared a boisterous welcome to Memphis Bill Terry and his Giants late yesterday as the newly crowned National League champions arrived at Grand Central Terminal from their triumphant invasion of the West.

Witnesses Introduced yesterday by the government at the second trial of Senator James J. Davis of Pennsylvania for violation of the lottery law refused to support the contention of the prosecution that Mr. Davis had known of the sale of tickets to members of the Loyal Order of Moose.

The Radio-Electrical Show opened ysterday afternoon at Madison Square Garden, where the main arena and basement are covered with booths in which radio receivers and household appliances will be on display until Sept. 30. There are 16 exhibitors, thirty-seven of whom are radio manufacturers.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 20. -- Marie Dressler visited NRA headquarters today to offer her help to General Hugh S. Johnson. After waiting three-quarters of an hour for him to return from the White House, she left, promising to return tomorrow.

"My Weakness," with Lilian Harvey and Lew Ayres, is the new feature at Radio City Music Hall. Although it is the second picture made by Miss Harvey since she was brought here from England, it is the first to be shown. The other, "My Lips Betray," has not yet been released.

ALBANY, Sept. 21. -- As a result of the efforts of the sixty cities in New York State to reduce expenses, the total amount appropriated for all municipal purposes this year is $123,068,329 or 15 per cent less than it was in 1932.

That President ROOSEVELT is about to be subjected, in his attitude toward the present "inflation drive," to the supreme test of statesmanship, there are numerous indications. Some such test invariably has to be confronted during the early part of a Presidential tenure, and the manner in which it is met is apt to determine the position which the incumbent of the White House will occupy in history.
Banks bought in six of the ten properties taken over by plaintiffs at foreclosure sales in Manhattan and the Bronx yesterday. The results follow.

The medal for which a fund of several hundred dollars was subscribed spontaneously throughout the country to honor the unknown man who blacked Senator Huey Long's eye a month ago in the washroom of the Sands Point Bath Club, was formally accepted yesterday as part of the collection of the American Numismatic Society.

ALBANY, Sept. 20 (AP) -- Four Republican Assemblymen, all of whom were outspoken drys and one of whom belonged to the inner circle which controls the State's lower house, were defeated in yesterday's election, virtually complete returns showed tonight.

Washington dispatches broke the spirit temporarily yesterday of the more clamorous advocates of inflation. What the government spokesmen had to say was most discouraging to the inflationists. There was an accompanying decline in all the speculative markets.

Copyright. 1933. by The Associated Press. WASHINGTON, Sept. 20. -- Henry Morganthau Jr., Governor of the Farm Credit Administration, has been designated by President Roosevelt to direct Russian trade negotiations, the vast scope of which is expected to have an important bearing on recognition of the Soviet Republic.
PARIS, Sept. 20 -- France must show President Roosevelt she can balance her budget and avoid inflation, Germain Martin, former Minister of Finance, writes today in EI Capital.

HAVANA, Sept. 20. -- A homemade "tank" manned by Cuban soldiers rumbled up to the Presidential Palace tonight, accompanied by extra cavalrymen, following persistent rumors that the foes at President Ramon Grau San Martin were about to strike.

TRENTON, N. J., Sept. 20. -- Prior to departing today for a vacation abroad, Governor Moore said that he would recommend to the Legislature at its adjourned session on Nov. 14 that a water authority, similar to the Port of New York Authority, be created to direct development of a water supply in North Jersey.

GENEVA, Sept. 20. -- Press Information that bubonic plague has broken out in Northern Manchuria is causing considerable concern in the health organization of the League of Nations. It cabled today to the League's epidemiological intelligence centre at Singapore for confirmation and details.

To the Editor of The New York Times. The recent death of Miss Kate Kaufman, former librarian of the Riverside branch of the New York Public. Library, has brought to all who knew her and recognized the value to the community of her character and work an acute sense of their loss.

HOT SPRINGS, Ark., Sept. 20. -- Although the formal opening will not take place until high officials of the government can arrange to be present, the doors of the big new $1,500,000 Army-Navy General Hospital were thrown open for the reception of patients today.

MINNEAPOLIS, Sept. 20 (AP) -- Edward C. Foster of Providence, chairman of the Rhode Island State Athletic Commission, was elected president of the National Boxing Association today, succeeding James Brown of Detroit.

WASHINGTON, Sept, 20. -- Tension in the State Department over Cuba today clearly arose from the reports of Spreading disturbances at the eastern end of the island rather than from negotiations still being watched in Havana between leaders of the political groups.

The committee organizing the New Jersey Stock Exchange announced yesterday that it had received applications for membership from 1,103 of the 1,375 members of the New York Stock Exchange, and would proceed at once with the organization of the new exchange to escape the proposed municipal taxes.
Newton D. Baker defends the internationalist viewpoint in foreign relations in an article published yesterday by Foreign Affairs.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Sept. 20. -- William L. Ward's Republican organization, built up over a thirty-year period, easily overcame numerous primary onslaughts yesterday, despite the loss of Mr. Ward's personal leadership. He died July 16.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 20. -- The Bureau of Navigation issued the following orders today, dated Sept. 18:

Chairman KOENIG has been so long invulnerable to opposition that he may well have believed, as the public had almost come to believe, that he was a tenant for life and irremovable. If he now refuses to acknowledge defeat, he need not be accused of acting on the old political motto, Concede nothing.

Picked up yesterday afternoon by Jersey City detectives for failing to have an automobile owner's license, Lewis K. Neu, 26 years old, an aspiring radio crooner, calmly and casually volunteered the information that he had committed two murders within the last two weeks, one in Paterson. N. J., and the other in New Orleans.

PARIS, Sept. 20. -- American securities will not be permitted entrance to the Paris Stock Exchange when the new law admitting foreign securities is put into effect, it was reliably reported today. It is understood that the action is being taken on the ground that the American dollar is of such uncertain value at present that it is felt that only confusion would result from the introduction of securities based on dollars.

MINEOLA, L. I., Sept. 20. -- Complete returns from yesterday's primary, regarded as the most intense in the history of the county, still Jeave the question of Democratic leadership of the county decidedly in doubt. The issue will be settled at the first county committee meeting to be held following the primary, on next Wednesday.

OKLAHOMA CITY, Sept. 20. -- Government officials beard new gangland threats today and answered by driving straight ahead with their prosecution of the dozen persons accused in the Charles F. Urschel kidnapping.

Machinery to help small business men obtain necessary credits and thus stimulate the process of recovery was set up yesterday by the local NRA organization in cooperation with a group of the city's leading bankers.

Teddy, a 200 pound cub bear, who, since he was snatched last Winter from the privacy of his den near Flagstaff, Me., and brought to New York for exhibition, has been inhabiting a cage in a used car lot at Metropolitan and Jamaica Avenues, Queens, escaped early yesterday morning.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 (AP) -- A further challenge of the Roosevelt administration's stand against interpretation in NRA codes of the Recovery Act's labor provisions is planned by traditionally non-union employers.

WHITE PLAINS, Sept. 20 -- Miss Elizabeth Curtis Langdon of Larchmont, a daughter of the late Andrew Langdon of Buffalo, said to have been "the last of the great independent coal operators," left the bulk of her large estate to friends, according to her will, filed for probate here tod She died on Sept. 1.

Steel business continues to decline, according to the weekly report of The Iron Age. This publication notes in its midweek review that "the combination of declining business volume and rising costs has caused the iron and steel industry to become uneasy about prices recently filed for the fourth quarter."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 -- Completion tomorrow of the wage agreement between the United Mine Workers of America and the bituminous coal operators of the Greater Appalachian Range appeared tonight to be likely.

APPARENTLY a game called football, is under way again. There are rumors to that effect. Word comes from a pleasant little place in Indiana that Notre Dame is getting ready to unleash a human projectile on the Autumn gridiron, the same being a fullback answering to the name of Don Elser. Southern California will visit Notre Dame in late November. Doubtless Fullback Elser will be an important member of the Reception Committee for Distinguished Guests.
The royal family of Tammany leaders faced incipient revolt last night that menaced their reigns in four of the five counties of New York City as a result of the primary election.
LEXINGTON, Ky., Sept. 20 (AP). -- Allan J. Wilson's Logan Scott today won the $3,000 Kentucky Futurity for 3-year-old pacers in two straight heats.

CHICAGO, Sept. 20. -- When talk of inflation of the currency is rampant prices of grains advance, and when it dies down, they decline. Yesterday the trade was confident that important developments regarding inflation were almost a certainty overnight, but as these failed to develop and President Roosevelt was said to be cool toward an immediate inflationary plan, those who bought yesterday on the Board of Trade turned sellers today.

MINEOLA, L.I., Sept. 20. -- Godfrey Preece of Westbury, L.I., cleaned up in the polo division today at the opening sessions of the thirty-first annual Mineola Horse Show. He not only won the blue ribbons in both the lightweight and heavy and middleweight classes, but also captured the championship and the reserve honors.
PITTSBURGH, Sept. 20. -- George Gibson's idea of bringing the Dodgers back to play one postponed game proved to be a bright one, for Pittsburgh won, 3 -- 0, and strengthened its grip on second place.

CHICAGO, Sept. 20. -- In a first-page editorial headed "We must all fight flat money." The Chicago Dally News today urges "every newspaper and indeed every citizen to support the President in the fight he is making against radical demands for the issuance of fiat money."

CHICAGO, Sept. 20. -- The Standard Oil Company of Indiana, through its general counsel, Louis L. Stephens, issued today a statement in reply to charges made against seventeen present and former officials of the company in a suit for the recovery of approximately $8,000,000 filed on last Saturday by Frederick W. Wilhelmi of Minnesota, owner of twenty-two shares of common stock in the company.

CHICAGO, Sept. 20. -- Herbert Hoover visited A Century of Progress Exposition today under especial circumstances surrounding the only living ex-President of the United States. His every move was trailed by a large throng and his day was one impromptu reception after another.

HAVANA, Thursday, Sept. 21. -- President Grau San Martin announced at 1:30 A.M. that the government had ordered striking newspaper employes of Havana to return to work and had given the publishers and employes until Saturday to settle their differences.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 20. -- St. Croix, one of the Virgin Islands, may regain its place as a producer, of rum after repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment as a result of studies being made by the Interior Department.
LONDON, Sept. 20 -- Ernest Milton's fine acting distinguished tonight's new production, "Night's Candles," adapted by Grant Yates from Alfred De Musset's tale of lust and vengeance, "Lorenzaccio."

WESTBURY, L.I., Sept. 20 -- Another impressive display of power was in evidence on Meadow Brook's No. 4 field today when Greentree defeated Westbury, 9 to 2, in another warm-up encounter for the open polo championship which starts Saturday.

The National Hospital for Speech Disorders, Inc., now at 138 East Thirty-ninth Street, has purchased the two three-story houses at 126-128 East Thirtieth Street, between Fourth and Lexington Avenues. The houses occupy a plot 35.8 by 98.9 feet and were sold by James H. Cruikshank, operator.

The Jewish New Year, called in Hebrew Rosh ha-Shanah and chronicled as the Year 5694, began at nightfall yesterday, and on its arrival devout members of the House of Israel went to their respective synagogues. The observance of the New Year will continue for Orthodox Jews through tomorrow, while for Reform Jews it will end this evening.

The dollar depreciated further yesterday in a foreign-exchange market characterized by exceptionally wide fluctuations, judged even by recent erratic standards. Opening weak, the United States unit sank rapidly to a new low against the gold-standard exchanges.

Weakness in the security markets yesterday arose principally from the action of bonds, against which there was aggressive pressure throughout the day. The share market was doll and colorless. Grains were week.
LONDON, Sept. 20 -- Beading the findings of the internatienal legal commission on the Reichstag fire, D.N. Pritt, K.C., chairman of the commission said:

The indications yesterday were that the forces backing Chase Mellen Jr. for the Republican leadership of New York County had elected about 1,700 of the 2,964 county committee members chosen at Tuesday's primary election.
LEIPZIG, Sept. 20 -- The Reichstag fire trial will begin before the German Supreme Court tomorrow with the lives of five men and the moral prestige of the Nazi regime at stake.
Uncompleted surveys in a majority of the Eastern States, including New York State, indicate a plenitude of game birds for the sportsmen this Fall.

SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Sept. 20 -- Toll Gate, the famous Canadian-owned horse, returned to the Eastern States Exposition oval today and flashed surprising speed to conquer the favorite, Guy the Tramp, and capture the 2:08 class pace.

Bequests totaling nearly $100,000 left by Isadora Saks, one of the founders and former president of Saks Co., to relatives, friends, employes and charitable institutions were canceled in a codicil to his will, it was disclosed when his testament was offered for probate in Surrogate's Court yesterday.

Although a successor to Robert P. Lament as president of the American Iron and Steel Institute was not appointed yesterday at a meeting of the institute's, board of directors, Walter Sheldon Tower of the Bethlehem Steel Company was elected executive secretary and he will organize the institute's staff under the NRA.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 20. -- President Roosevelt declined today to define his position on inflation, as requested by the cotton farmers, who last night addressed a letter to him asking for a public reply to their demands for inflation, twenty-cent cotton and repeal of the cotton-processing tax.

GREENWICH, Conn., Sept. 20. -- The - garden flower feature, the twenty-second annual flower show of the Westchester and Fairfield Horticultural Society with the Garden Clubs of Greenwich, Riverside, Old Greenwich and Rye cooperating, opened here at the Y.M.C.A. Building this afternoon.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 -- Containing the highly disputed principles of price-control and price-fixing, codes for the general retail trade and for drug stores were released to the public today by Deputy Recovery Administrator Whiteside, who commented that they had been submitted to General Johnson.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Mr. Untermyer's opposition notwithstanding, the Grimm committee is to be congratulated upon its findings, and especially as these bear upon the Department of Education.
CHICAGO, Sept. 20 (AP). -- Fifteen hundred high school students went on strike today, but encountered police resistance that turned many back to classrooms from an attempted march on the City Hall.

Coming Back Home. In one sense the wolf has been howling at fewer doors during the depression. That was because there were fewer separate family doors for him to howl at. People took refuge against the storm by doubling up with relatives and friends.

In the last two months the Atlas Corporation has made substantial changes in its portfolio. Cash has been reduced from $12,700,000, reported as of June 30, to below $10,000,000 on Aug. 31. The latter figure represents the lowest proportion of cash in relation to total assets reported by the trust in nearly four years.

To lose an election now and then is no reflection on a political leader. The organization may be compelled by circumstances to run an unpopular candidate. Hard times may cause a revulsion against the party in power. Corruption may labor and bring forth reform. These accidents will happen even in the best of regulated political families.
OYSTER BAY. L.I., Sept. 20 -- Canada's team of dinghy sailors today assumed first place in the international round robin series at the Seawanahaka Corinthian Yacht Club.

Two vigorous clashes between opposing counsel signalized yesterday the first day or testimony in the trial of Isidor J. Kresel in the Criminal Branch of the Supreme Court in connection with a $2,000,000 loan by the defunct Bank of United States to an affiliate.

Bernard Coles Weideeker, a partner in the banking firm of Neidecker Co. of Paris and 40 Wall Street, arrived yesterday on the Cunarder Aquitania as an unofficial representative of the French Government, he said, to negotiate a purchase of 3,000,000 bales of cotton at a cost of about $150,000,000 to extend over a period of three years.

Pach Brothers, photographers, had a house-warming and "tintype tea" yesterday afternoon at their new gallery at 642 Fifth Avenue in observance of the sixty-sixth anniversary of their business. The new gallery, which will be opened on Sept. 25, includes the top floor, penthouse and terrace of the building, which is near Fifty-second Street.

Spokesmen, for the Green Bus Lines, Inc., operator of six important crosstown lines in Manhattan, declared yesterday their intention to ask the Board of Estimate on Monday to make closer inquiry into the financial responsibility of the New York City Omnibus Corporation and the Comprehensive Bus Corporation.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Within the past few days THE NEW YORK TIMES has devoted considerable space to the work of the New York Child Labor Committee. The Sunday broadcast by Mr. Ehrich, Senator Wald and Miss J. Minor was followed by a letter from G. A. Hall.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 20. -- At W. W. Atterbury's request, the board of directors of the Pennsylvania Railroad reduced his salary as president to $60,000 a year. The announcement was made in a. telegram received today by Joseph B. Eastman, the Federal Coordinator of Transportation.

The kidnapping: of John J. O'Connell Jr., four bank robberies and at least five murders were declared solved or near solution by the police yesterday following the arrest of five men here and the seizure of two women and a small arsenal in Mount Kisco.

Acute weaknesses developed yesterday in all sections of the listed bond market. United States Government bonds were down 4-32 to 18-32 point on the day, although rallies in the final hour on the Stock Exchange minimized the earlier heavier losses.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Sept. 20. -- Inroads of rackets and corruption into the workmen's compensation field were described before the Connecticut Medical Society tonight by Howard S. Cullman, head of the committee to review problems in connection with compensation which was appointed by President Roosevelt when Governor of New York.

TO come upon Violet Clifton's "The Book of Talbot" (Harcourt, Brace, $3.50) is a puzzling and a strange experience for an American reader. This country doesn't breed men like Talbot Clifton, arrogant, self-willed, deeply certain that the world is made for them and them alone, yet dowered with a sense of noblesse oblige to temper the more military virtues.

The constantly swelling totals for insurgent candidates at Tuesday's primary election left the party leaders stunned yesterday. It was the general opinion that the astonishing results indicated a political revolution and a disposition among many thousands of voters to vote against any one in office or in a party position.

WILMINGTON, Del., Sept. 20 (AP) -- Public sale of the property of the Pick Earth Holding Corporation of New York was ordered by a Federal bankruptcy referee today after two judges had refused to interfere.

Leo T. Kissam, counsel to the Congressional subcommittee investigating Federal receiverships here, accused Alfred A. Cook, attorney for the Irving Trust Company, yesterday of impeding the investigation by "limitations" and "restrictions."

Dr. Raymond L. Ditmars, curator of reptiles and mammals at the Bronx Zoo, arrived yesterday on the United Fruit liner Metapan with a vampire bat and numerous other specimens for the zoo which he collected in Panama with the aid of Dr. Arthur M. Greenhall of the University of Michigan.
The American Steamship Owners Association has been caled for a conference today on the proposed owners' and operators' code under the National Recovery Administration.

LONDON, Sept. 20 -- On the eve of the trial of the five men accused of having set fire to the Reichstag building in Berlin, an accusing finger was pointed straight at the Nazi leaders tonight by the unofficial international legal commission that has been investigating the affair here.
WASHIMITON, Sept. 20. -- Movements of vessels follow: all dates are Sept. 19, unless otherwise specified.

First copies of "Die Sammiung," the new monthly o magazine for exiled German writers, have just reached this country, imported by Van Riemsdyck Book Service, 15 West Forty-fifth sreet. The magazine is edited by Kiaus Mann, son of Thomas Mann, and Aldous Huxley, Andre Gide and Heinrich Mann sign as patrons of the new publication.

A settlement of the status of theatre ticket brokers under the legitimate theatre code was reached Yesterday. At a meeting of the sub-committee of the National Legitimate Theatre Committee, the there-tofore discontented members of the Theatre Ticket Brokers Association expressed their willingness to accept the plan to have one delegate from their group and one from the National Theatre Ticket Distributers present on the national committee whenever ticket problems are discussed.

An action against former and present officers of the bankrupt Paramount Publix Corporation to recover "excessive salaries" was threatened yesterday by Samuel Zirn, representing a group of creditors, at a hearing before Henry K. Davis, Federal referee in bankruptcy, at 140 Nassau Street.

Charging that the purpose of the recent statements of Ralph C. Holmes was to destroy the present harmonious operations of the company and to effect his own reinstatement as its head, the management of the Texas Corporation sent yesterday a letter to stockholders stating that the signers of a petition for a special meeting, drawn up at Mr. Holmes's behest, represented less than 1 per cent of the outstanding shares of the corporation.

The round up yesterday of a gang of five men and two women who are accused of kidnapping John J. O'Connell Jr. added another solved abduction to the growing list of cases in which the guilty persons have been caught. Some of the outstanding cases and the penalities meted out follow:
Declines took place yesterday in most of the local commodity markets, althoug in several cases opening prices showed an advance. Cash prices were steady. Trading was maintained in fair volume.
VIENNA, Thursday, Sept. 21 -- Fascism triumphed in Austria today with the formation of a "Cabinet of Personalities" head by Chancellor Engelbert Dollfuss and Major Emil Fey, Heimwehr leader.

HAVANA, Sept. 20. -- Major Lico Balan, noted revolutionary leader against the Machado regime, and a large group of followers have captured the town of Gibara, on the north coast of Oriente Province, it was learned today.

LONDON, Sept. 20. -- Two years after the memorable day on which Great Britain abandoned the gold standard, the pound sterling and the dollar slid today to their lowest gold values in the memory of living men. The pound was allowed to fall below 79 in terms of French francs before the official control stepped in.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 20. -- Increasing anxiety over the safety of American citizens in outlying parts of Cuba was apparent at the State Department today. Secretary Hull said that United States Consuls in troubled areas were advising American citizens to take refuge on the nearest American war vessel.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 20 -- The disastrous tennis season for Ellsworth Vines Jr. came to an abrupt end in his home State today when Jack Tidball, national intercollegiate champion, eliminated the former national titleholder in the quarter-finals of the Pacific Southwest tournament, 1-6, 6-4, 7-5.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 -- The "price control" provisions of the Retail Code 'presented today by Deputy Administrator Whiteside of the NRA to General Johnson for his consideration reads as follows:

BERLIN, Sept. 20 -- On the eve of the Jewish New Year the Jews of Germany, put beyond the pale by her new rulers, are bravely falling back on their immemorial reserve of moral strength and endurance. Driven in upon themselves by official ostracism, they have been drawing more closely together, and it is expected that tomorrow's services in the synagogues throughout Germany will see larger congregations than they have held in recent years.

Direct Selling Revived. A strong revival of house-to-house sales campaigns by producers in a number of lines is now actively under way, and preliminary reports indicate favorable consumer sales Response, it was said here yesterday. Among the major items being pushed are oil burners, vacuum cleaners, hosiery and refrigerators.

CAPE TOWN, South Africa, Sept. 20 (By Wireless). -- Bernt Balchen, pilot of the Lincoln Ellsworth Trans-Antarctic Flight Expedition, was operated upon for appendicitis in a hospital here tonight as arranged yesterday. The operation was entirely successful and Balchen is resting easily.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 20. -- The Agricultural Adjustment Administration has spent $20,000,000 in buying pigs and sows under its emergency marketing program to reduce next year's supply of pork and expects to spend an additional $30,000,000 in the same way in the next nine days.
Albert Capone guided his taxicab through, the city streets last night, cutting off more timid drivers and out-staring traffic policemen. He was no longer bis own boss.

CHICAGO, Sept. 20. -- American Industry is in no danger of having the closed shop forced upon it through the workings of the National Recovery Act, Henry I. Harriman, president of the Chamber of Commerce of the United States, told 400 members of the Chicago Association of Commerce at a luncheon today.

Mayor O'Brien presided yesterday at a hurriedly called special meeting of the Sinking Fund Commission flushed with what he described as unexpected pleasure at the plaudits of a crowd of city employes in the meeting room.

TOKYO, Sept. 20. -- A denial that aircraft landing facilities, even temporary ones for use in the recent naval manoeuvres, or any other new defences had been constructed in the Bonin Islands since 1922 was given to this correspondent today by Captain Gumpei Sekine, a Navy Office spokesman.

NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 20. -- A large audience was present tonight at the Art Association to hear the concert by Miksa Merson, pianist, assisted by Mr. and Mrs. Gustave J.S. White, the former as pianist and the latter as vocalist. A feature of the program was a group of selections for two pianos played by Mr. Merson and Mr. White. Mr. Merson also played a group of solos.
The football teams of Columbia and Manhattan engaged in a lengthy scrimmage yesterday at Baker Field in the first of what is expected to be a series of practice sessions between the elevens.
GENEVA, Sept. 20. -- Japan has decided to transfer her League of Nations bureau from Paris to Geneva soon.
Disturbed by the rising strike wave in the city and its threat to the recovery program, the local NRA organization moved yesterday to check industrial strife.

Two years ago people in every part of the world were discussing with intense interest the dramatic news of England's suspension of the gold standard. From, the Autumn of 1931 to midsummer of 1932 that country experienced the same deepening depression which afflicted all other important countries.

NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 21 -- Dr. and Mrs. Alexander Hamilton Rice entertained with a family dinner tonight at their Summer home, Miramar, in celebration of Mrs. Rice's birthday. Mr. and Mrs. George D. Widener, the former a son of Mrs. Rice, arrived early this evening, joining the family party which included Mrs. F. Eugene Dixon, Mrs. Rice's daughter, who has been a guest at Miramar for some time.

The New Jersey Stock Exchange, Wall Street's reply to Mayor O'Brien's tax program, came officially under the wing of the New York Stock Exchange yesterday. Officials of the institution here formally accepted corresponding positions with the proposed new trading organization.

F. Trubee Davison, president of the American Museum of Natural History, and Mrs. Davison, who left New York last June to join the Martin Johnsons at Nairobi, Africa, to get elephants and other specimens for the museum, will return here on the Europa on Oct. 11, Dr. George H. Sherwood, director of the museum, announced yesterday.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Sept. 21 (AP) -- The Buffalo Bisons swamped the Rochester Red Wings under a flock of basehits to win tonight by 18 -- 7 and go one ahead in their International League play-off finals. The victory gives the Bisons three to Rochester's two in the four-out-of-seven series.

One of the smallest armies of hunters in years enjoyed shooting in field and forest last season, reports show, but preliminary estimates which have been made by a great number of States this year indicate that there will be a decided increase in the number of licenses issued.

Peter Grimm, head of the Municipal Economy Committee, defended the committee's proposed savings of more than $25,000,000 in city expenditures as being "definite and reasonable" in a speech yesterday before the Thirty-fourth Street Midtown Association at the McAlpin Hotel.
The plight of the Jews in Germany and the New Deal in the United States were the chief topics of sermons yesterday at Rosh haShanah services marking the dawn of the year 5694 of the Jewish calendar.

WESTBURY, L.I., Sept. 21 -- Miss Enid Connfelt, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Maitland Connfelt of Brookville, was married this afternoon to Ogden Goelet, oldest son of Robert Goelet of 2 East Sixty-first Street, New York, and Chester, N.Y., and Mrs. Henry Clews of Chateau de la Napoule, Alpes Maritimes, France, in a simple ceremony at the Church of the Advent at Westbury.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 -- Clashes over the retention of the principles of price control and price fixing in the retail and drug trade codes occupied NRA officials today.

Lyons to Leave Chain Group. Robert W. Lyons has tendered his resignation as executive vice president of the National Chain Store Association, effective Oct. 1, it was announced here yesterday. In accepting his resignation, based on Mr. Lyons's desire to resume his law practice, the executive committee of the association formally expressed appreciation of his "splendid service."

BERLIN, Sept. 21 -- The announcement that the government would not interfere with private initiative in executing its economic program was received with considerable gratification on the Boerse today. One of its immediate effects was to precipitate a bull movement in the bond market where State and municipal loans scored gains of 1 to 3 per cent.

BOSTON, Mass., Sept. 21 -- The usually conservative Boston Transcript printed in a news story leading its first page this afternoon a statement that the Roosevelt administration had decided upon a shift in the Democratic leadership of Massachusetts.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Sept. 21 (AP) -- The Castleton Stake, won by Mi Peter after four hard heats, proved the feature race of today's card at the Lexington trots. The historic Transylvania, raced this year as a handicap in two divisions, was disappointing to the crowd.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 21 -- Mrs. Lawrence A. Harper of Oakland defending champion, was eliminated in the women's semi-finals of the Pacific Southwest tennis tournament by Miss Dorothy Round of England today. The score was 6-1, 6-2.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 -- Suppressing their demand for immediate inflation of the currency, a committee of cotton growers, headed by Senator Bankhead of Alabama, urged the President today to pledge the government to buy 5,000,000 bales of this year's cotton crop at 15 cents a pound.

A brisk rally in United States Government bonds featured an otherwise weak bond market on the Stock Exchange yesterday. The government issues closed 11-32 point higher to 4-32 lower in dealings of $4,360,000. The total for the entire bond market on the Exchange was $16,676,000.

The attitude of the American public toward the currency-inflation question has not been convincingly discussed. As is usual in Congressional campaigns for such purposes, this consideration has been surrounded by pure assumption. Relying on the influence of hard times in unsettling public judgment or creating willingness to try any kind of experiment, the agitators for Inflation occasionally hint that an irresistible body of public opinion is behind them.

HAVANA, Sept. 21 -- President Grau is taking stronger measures in Havana and in the interior to prevent attempts to upset his government. Many were arrested last night and today as the government strove to round up those involved in counter-revolutionary plots.

Exactly one hundred years ago the Legislature of the State of New York passed a law requiring that by the close of the year 1833 all lotteries in the State should be ended. They had flourished from the earliest days of the settlement of this island, the first being a "book lottery" authorized by the Burgomasters in 1655.

OYSTER BAY, L.I., Sept. 21 -- The Long Island Sound team scored two notable victories over the Canadian Yacht Club sailors in the international round-robin dinghy series at the Seawanhaka Corinthian Yacht Club today.

Acting in harmony for the first time since the extent of the debacle or the Kreuger Toll company was revealed, several weeks after Ivar Kreuger killed himself in Paris on March 12, 1932, the security holders and creditors of the Kreuger Toll, Swedish Match and International Match companies have appointed delegates in Stockholm to assist in a general reorganization of the world match business.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 -- Views on the open shop and organized labor, expressed yesterday by Henry I. Harriman, president of the Chamber of Commerce of the United States, and Robert L. Lund, president of the National Association of Manufacturers, were roundly criticized today by President Green of the American Federation of Labor.

Flying at her fore the red and white flag of Vice Admiral the Hon. Reginald Aylmer Ranfurly Plunkett-Ernle-Erle-Drax, the British 10,000-ton cruiser Norfolk steamed up the Hudson yesterday morning and berthed at Pier 35 for a week's visit.

Because of the Jewish holiday yesterday, Mayor O'Brien postponed the final statutory hearing on the new city tax program until 2:30 o'clock Monday afternoon. The Mayor complied with the law by opening the hearing, reading the titles of four tax bills and then adjourning the session.

TARRYTOWN, N.Y., Sept. 21 -- The first Fall revue of the Hudson River Junior Service League was presented here tonight in the Music Hall Theatre for the joint benefit of the Robins Nest Home for Crippled Children in Tarrytown and the Westchester County Children's Association.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 -- An allocation of $14,800,000 to the Coast Guard for equipment to combat an anticipated increase in smuggling activities following prohibition repeal was made today by the Public Works Administration.

SPRINGFIELD, N.J., Sept. 21 -- Rallying on the second nine, Miss Maureen Orcutt of White Beeches waged a successful uphill battle against Miss Jane Brooks of the Knickerbocker Club to gain the final of the women's New Jersey golf championship today.

The possibility of Joseph V. McKee, former President of the Board of Aldermen, running as an independent Democratic nominee for Mayor grew yesterday as important business groups, opposed to the re-election of Mayor John P. O'Brien and dissatisfied with the nomination of Fiorello H. LaGuardia by the fusionists, continued to urge him to run.

The groups supporting Chase Mellen Jr. and Samuel S. Koenig within, the Republican party maintained their silence yesterday pending the completion by the Board of Elections of its canvass of Tuesday's primary election.
Thursday, Sept. 21, 1933. Money market was quiet. No changes occurred in any section either in the volume of business or quotations. Stock Exchange call loans continued at 3/4 and street trades 1/2.

The National Theatre, occupying a plot 111 by 98.9 feet at 208-216 West Forty-first Street, was bid in at $285,000 yesterday by the Dry Dock Savings Institution, plaintiff in a foreclosure action against the Forty-first Street Theatre Company and others.

LONDON, Sept. 21 -- Leading figures in two decades of British history are again held up to the scrutiny of the Countess of Oxford and Asquith (Margot Asquith) in "More Memories," published today. This volume complements her "Autobiography," the candor of which caused a sensation in 1922.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Sept. 21 -- Prospectors in the upper waters of the Saobento River in the State of Minas Geraes today reported finding a diamond weighing 540 grams or more than 2,000 carats, which was appraised at $800,000. This is the second largest diamond ever recorded.

ALBANY, Sept. 21 (AP) -- New York municipalities have asked the State Advisory Board to approve 155 public works projects involving an estimated $130,000,000 to be obtained from the Federal Public Works Administration.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 -- August factory sales of automobiles built in the United States totaled 236,480 vehicles, of which 195,076 were passenger cars, 41,336 trucks and 68 taxicabs.

HAVRE DE GRACE, Md., Sept. 21 (AP) -- Adolphe Pons's Discovery, vigorously ridden by Johnny Gilbert, drove to a clean-cut victory over five other 2-year-olds in the Tulip Hill Purse, six furlong feature of the Harford Association's racing program today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 -- Bituminous mine operators' and United Mine Workers' representatives joined tonight in a statement pledging cooperative effort in the execution of the unprecedented wage agreement just completed to accompany the coal code.

Harry Scherman of this city has bought ninety-five acres adjoining his country residence in Bernardsville from Dr. William Lawrence of Summit. The tract, in Old Army Road, includes virgin forest, two streams and a seven-acre lake. The property is part of the former William Childs holdings including Shannon Lodge, operated as a health resort by Dr. Lawrence, Eugene V. Welsh was the broker.

The Second Avenue Theatre made a moderately successful start in its new policy of offering the better type of play when it presented yesterday as its opening production of the season, Peretz Hirshbein's "Once Upon a Time," with incidental music by Lazar Weiner.

Eva B. and Little Lad, both owned by John J. Robinson, were victors at Aqueduct yesterday, while a third one of the string, Annarita, was cut down at the post and withdrawn from the fifth race. Eva B. scored in the featured event in rather easy fashion, but her triumph was none the less a surprise to many.

CHICAGO, Sept. 21 -- A top price of $5.40 a hundredweight for hogs in carload lots was paid here today excelling the best previous figure of the season. A small lot was sold at $5.45 on May 18, but with that exception today's price was the highest since July, 1932, when $5.55 was paid.

WESTBURY, L.I., Sept. 21 -- Templeton and Aurora today rode through the fastest practice game the teams preparing for the open championship have played yet, with Templeton coming through in the seventh and last period to win, 10 to 8.
The situation in Cuba was described yesterday as "a kind of passive anarchy'' by Professor A.A. Berle Jr., one of President Roosevelt's closest advisers, who flew back from Cuba to report.

LONDON, Sept. 21 -- While Germany began the trial of the accused in the sensational Reichstag fire H.G. Wells today bitterly condemned the Nazi regime as a "clumsy lout's revolution against civilization."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 -- President Roosevelt today authorized the Agricultural Adjustment Administration to buy $75,000,000 worth of surplus food and clothing materials for distribution among the destitute unemployed. He considered such action as "one of the most direct blows at the economic paradox which has choked farms with an abundance of farm products while many of the unemployed have grown hungry."

The trend of futures prices on local commodity exchanges was again downward yesterday. For the most part, however, opening prices were the lowest of the day, with small recoveries from those levels occurring in most markets. Trading was smaller in volume.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 (AP) -- Richard Newstadt was designated by the National Labor Board today to represent the board in Paterson, N.J., in dealing with the silk dyeing and finishing strike.

PRINCETON, N.J., Sept. 21 -- Major Gen. Hugh Lenox Scott, former commandant of West Point, former Chief of Staff and famous Indian fighter, will celebrate his eightieth birthday tomorrow by doing a hard day's work.
New York, pluming itself in the prospect of playing host to a world's series with two rather unexpected entrants in the cast, became baseball-minded yesterday in a serious and official way.

After their sanguinary defeat in the primaries, two courses were open to the Tammany leaders. They could shelve their palpably unpopular candidate for Mayor and cast about for some better vote-getter to put in his place, or, in the spirit of the old guard which dies but never surrenders, they could rally around Judge O'BRIEN and bid Fusion do its worst.

After an absence of two seasons from the Yiddish Stag in this country. Ludwig Satz appeared last night at the Public Theatre in "Longing for Home," by Gershon Bader, with music by Joseph Rumshinsky. A complete review of this "chassidic musical extravaganza" is not possible here, since, with all its lavish material, it was only getting under way when the reviewer's time was up.

After the starvation fare of the past two months "Double Door," which was put on at the Ritz last evening, is the sort of husk a hungry man should seize. It is grim melodrama of the inhumanities a rich woman practices upon her brother's bride to preserve intact the family fortune and the pearls.

Elimination of the contract system of ash removal in Brooklyn and transference of the work to the Sanitation Department was recommended yesterday by George McAneny to save the city $1,612,846.86 a year.

Regulation of the motor trucking business in New York State was urged by representatives of rail-roads and opposed by trucking interests at the first hearing yesterday of the joint legislative Committee on Motor Carriers and Transportation.

HAYS, Kan., Sept. 21 (AP) -- Four machine gunners held up the Farmera State Bank here, abducted twelve persons for a wild flight southward in stolen, motor cars and escaped across the Oklahoma line after freeing the last of their hostages near Holyrood, Kan., tonight.

Among the passengers due today on the Hamburg-American liner Deutschland are Victor F. Ridder, publisher and secretary of the Staats-Herold Corporation; Thomas St. John Gaffney, former United States Consul General at Munich, Germany; Professor Joseph von Bradish, Professor of German at College of the City of New York; Professor William R. Shepherd of Columbia University and Mme.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 -- Strikes of employes of public utilities all over the country are threatened because of grievances arising from application of the substituted Presidential re-employment agreement, according to officers of the International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers, in a letter today to Hugh S. Johnson, Recovery Administrator.

Featuring a new bloom, named in honor of Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt, the nineteenth annual flower show conducted by the American Dahlia Society opened yesterday in the ballroom suite of the Hotel Pennsylvania. The exhibit, in which 200 classes for private and commercial growers will be judged, will close this evening.

IT is both an interesting and uncomfortable experience to read Fairfax Downey's "Richard Harding Davis: His Day" (Scribner's, $3). Interesting, because it renews a time when life could be lived uncritically -- which is to say, pleasantly, as an animal lives. Uncomfortable, because it raises questions about the relative percentage of tin in the gold alloy of the old gods.

The Saratoga Springs Authority has retained Professor Franz M. Groedel, a European heart specialist, as consultant for the final development of the State-owned spa, it was announced yesterday. Dr. Groedel will arrive in New York on Oct. 10 and will remain at Saratoga Springs during completion of the work to be done with $3,200,000 lent by the Reconstruction Finance Corporation.

The dollar rallied sharply but briefly yesterday, then resumed its fall in foreign exchange value to close with another net loss on the day. Opening quotations of leading European currencies were all lower and the Treasury's daily price from newly mined gold was marked down to $31.33, compared with $32.28 an ounce on Wednesday, the first reduction from a previous day in the gold price since Sept. 11.
LEIPZIG, Sept. 21 -- Marinus Van der Lubbe, the young Dutchman who is the main defendant in the Reichstag fire trial, laughted often while the court was questioning him at the opening session today.
PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 21 (AP) -- The Tigers won the last of a four-game series with the Athletics today, 10 to 3, behind the six-hit pitching of young Eldon Auker.
