MINISINK HELLS, Pa., Sept. 21 -- For a team that lost twenty letter men, including every regular in the line, except the centre, and eight of the eleven players that started against Cornell, Pennsylvania is as far from being a skeleton of its former self as could be imagined.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In a letter to THE TIMES Catherine B. Ely, giving her interpretation of the "workings of the wet minds," states: "Because some sheep have jumped the repeal wall, all the rest should hop over to the wet side."

MINEOLA, L.I., Sept. 21 -- Harry Pownall, driving Hanover Maid, a bay filly and owned by William B. McKee of New York City, won the featured 3-year-old Governor's Trophy in a field of eight today at Mineola.
Columbia's football team will give up its living quarters at Baker Field when classes start next Wednesday, it was announced yesterday by Dr. Edward S. Elliott, director of athletics.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 -- There are 284 known hoarders of gold holding $1,487,182, the Justice Department announced today, this being a substantial reduction from a week ago.

PARIS, Sept. 21 -- Although the outcome of yesterday's Cabinet meeting in London is not fully known here, there was expressed in official circles tonight a fair amount of confidence that the outlook for agreement on disarmament control was hopeful.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 (AP) -- Preparing for a spirited set-to tomorrow between employers and organized labor men, who have been unable to agree on a code for daily newspapers, the NRA pushed to a conclusion today its hearings on twenty-one recovery charters submitted for other branches of the industry.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Among other things of less interest which are discussed with fervor and occasional indignation today, the question of inflation seems to be the most popular. While this popularity is frequently of a complimentary nature, inflation is similarly the target for many unjust and illogical criticisms, the most recent of which is an attack against credit inflation as compared with printing-press inflation.

Events alone can show just how Fascist is the new Fascist Cabinet which Chancellor DOLLFUSS has set up in Austria. The fact that Herr DOLLFUSS has reserved five Cabinet places for himself does suggest the original Mussolini model, but that is not a characteristic feature of the Fascist scheme.

Arrangements have teen completed for the transfer of another New Tork Stock Exchange membership at $150,000, unchanged from the previous transaction announced on Sept. 19. The latter transaction represented the proposed transferof the membership of James B. Barry, a member of the Exchange since April 7, 1927, to George A. Dixon Jr.
NEW YORK. Mrs. William J. Ryan will give a reception tomorrow afternoon at Yarrow, her country place in St. James, L.I., to introduce her daughter, Miss Jane Yarrow Ryan.

OKLAHOMA CITY, Sept. 21 (AP) -- Another purported death threat by George (Machine Gun) Kelly, fugitive alleged kidnapper, directed this time against defendants who "talked" and government witnesses, caused a sensation today at the trial of twelve persons charged with the abduction of Charles F. Urschel, oil millionaire.

TODAY there will be in the region of that old country gentleman's farmhouse which became, back in the early Eighties, the Meadow Brook Club, motor vans and strings of blanketed horses turning into a white-graveled drive lined on both sides with tall privet. The vans and the ponies will not head to one of the seven or eight fields of the club.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 -- The text of the bituminous coal wage agreement signed tonight by operators and miners' representatives follows:

A killing was added to the violence growing out of Tuesday's primary election when Martin Smith, former boxer, died yesterday afternoon of bullet wounds received in a brawl with adherents of ex-Sheriff Thomas M. Farley, defeated Tammany candidate for re-election to the leadership of the Fourteenth Assembly District.

HIGHLANDS, N.C., Sept. 21 -- Clark Howell Sr., editor and general manager of The Atlanta Constitution, today quietly observed his seventieth birthday with members of his family at his mountain home here.

The Eastern presidents' conference acted yesterday to bring about a general reduction of railroad passenger fares by authorizing the appointment of a committee to confer on the subject with the Western and Southern managements. A committee beaded by Paul Shoup, vice chairman of the Southern Pacific Company, has recommended a cut from the basic rate of 3.6 cents a mile.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., Sept. 21 -- Throwing water high from their bows, the Sound Interclub sloops came through today to win the international series from the Bermuda one-design yachts. The score on points in the final race was 20 1/4 to 16 for the invaders.
LONDON, Sept. 21 (AP) -- The weekly statement of the Bank of England shows the following changes in pounds sterling:

The credit committee of the New York City NRA, formed to ease credit for small employers, moved yesterday into its offices at the local NRA headquarters in the Hotel Pennsylvania. The committee was appointed by the New York Clearing House Association through Percy H. Johnston, president of the Chemical Bank and Trust Company, at the request of Grover A. Whalen, NRA chairman here.

CHICAGO, Sept. 21 -- Conflicting reports from Washington as to the probability of inflation of the currency, with numerous other influences regarded as inconsequential in themselves but important in the aggregate, gave traders in grain a hectic session on the Board of Trade today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 -- Seven weeks of negotiations between the United Mine Workers of America and the bituminous coal operators of the Appalachian field were brought to a close tonight at the Shoreham Hotel when the operators signed a contract covering wages and working conditions for 340,000 coal diggers in hitherto non-union fields, from Pennsylvania to the Alabama line.

NEWARK, N.J., Sept. 21 -- An airliner bound for Washington with two pilots and fifteen passengers on board crashed here this afternoon just after the take-off. Except for minor bruises, the passengers all escaped injury. The pilots, Glen J. MacDonald of Elizabeth and Benson Hoy of 777 High Street, Newark, were seriously hurt.

The revised retail code was approved almost in its entirety at a meeting here yesterday of representatives of fourteen leading department and specialty stores. The meeting, under the auspices of the Retail Dry Goods Association of New York, was held in the conference room of Lord Taylor.

His Heart's Desire. RAYMOND DITMARS is back from the Panama jungle with a live vampire bat, a spider which kills small birds, and other trophies of the chase. Yet how many would suspect that it is not really a triumphant return but only a cleverly camouflaged retreat?

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 -- Success for the New Deal in industry was hailed by Secretary Perkins today on the basis of wage rate increases and work-week reductions, with a payroll increase of $12,000,000 recorded between July 15 and Aug. 15.

The Federal Reserve System reported further purchases of United States Government securities, at the rate of $35,000,000 a week, established five weeks ago, in its statement of condition as of Wednesday, published yesterday.
DES MOINES, Iowa, Sept. 21 (AP) Secretary Wallace is "the goat for things for which, he is in no wise responsible," Senator Murphy declared today in an address to the Iowa Farmers Union.

LONDON, Sept. 21 -- Montagu Norman, governor of the Bank of England, confessed to the stockholders today that not even he could tell them what was happening in the United States. "It is two weeks at least since I have been there," he said with a gesture of helplessness, "and in those two weeks a new situation, almost a new country, has grown up.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Sept. 21 -- The Rev. Dr. Augustus F. Beard of Norwalk, Yale's oldest graduate and the oldest Congregational minister in the United States, took his first airplane ride at Mollison Airport here this afternoon at the age of 100 and said: "It was wonderful."

The first decision in the local courts upholding the validity of the mortgage moratorium law passed at the recent special session of the Legislature was handed down yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Irwin Untermyer. The ruling was made in a suit by Bertha Mayer against the Prudence Bonds Corporation for the face value of two overdue $500 mortgage bonds in which the plaintiff asked summary judgment on the ground that there was no defense.

DETROIT, Sept. 21 (AP) -- Senator Couzens, who has sworn to use "every available means" in his command to inform the Detroit public of bank practices which he condemns, charged today that some officers of the closed Guardian National Bank of Commerce knew two years ago that the bank's condition was "doubtful."

The old bees die, the young possess the hive: that text is commended to Mr. KOENIG for contemplation in the days of philosophic leisure that await him. He might also compare the swiftly passing procession of Republican State chairmen with his own long occupancy of the throne.
WHITEMARSH, Pa., Sept. 21 -- Mrs. John Hay Whitney of New York enjoyed a successful start in the opening program of the threeday Wissahickon Horse Show at Wissahickon Farms today.

ARCOLA, N.J., Sept. 21 -- Johnny Dawson of Glen Oaks, Chicago, today proved again his mastery of the Arcola course. Clipping one stroke from the record-breaking 73 with which he won the medal in the fourteenth Arcola invitation gold tourney last year, he led the largest field ever to play in the event with a 72, one under par.
Somewhere in the Bronx late last night Alexander Colonnelli was still looking for a brown-and-white bulldog.

Joseph P. Ryan, president of the International Longshoremen's Association, announced yesterday that the union had been requested by the New York Shipping Com- mittee to extend the existing agreement between shippers and longshoremen until after settlement of a code for the industry.

While Wall Street could not agree as to the cause of yesterday's rather violent decline in the markets, most of the explanatory discussions were centred around the fact that the inflation campaign seemed to have stalled. Brokers reported heavy selling orders from abroad.
PARIS, Sept. 21 (AP) -- The weekly statement of the Bank of France shows the following changes, in francs:
After twenty-five years as a best-selling author Mary Roberts Rinehart plans to change her ways. She is going to write her next book, she said in an interview yesterday, to please herself.

ALLENTOWN, Pa., Sept. 21 -- Estrellita, by Adioo Guy, a Western entry, outstepped a large field to win the 2:15 class pace, opening event today at the Fair Grounds. The victor took the opening two heats, the third going to Sally D. Scott.
ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Sept. 21 -- Fully 2,500,000 Americans have so far been put back to work under the NRA, the National Petroleum Association convention was told here today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 -- After official calibration of barographs and checking of landing certificates, Poland was declared by the National Aeronautical Association today to be winner of the 1933 International Balloon Race for the James Gordon Bennett Trophy.

HANOVER, N.H., Sept. 21 -- Social-mindedness must characterize the American college today as it does the government, President Ernest Martin Hopkins of Dartmouth College told a gathering of faculty and undergraduates this morning in his annual address at the convocation exercises marking the start of Dartmouth's 164th academic year.
Several housing properties in Manhattan, the Bronx and Brooklyn were acquired yesterday in investment deals. The trading indicated a demand for income-producing properties.

To the Editor of The New York Times: One who dares to defend the position of Henry Ford in regard to the NRA code, or one who declines to sign a pledge to boycott every one who refuses to fall in with a policy which he may be convinced is ruinous, is called "unpatriotic," or at least told that those who differ should, in the common interest, fall in line, suppressing their prejudices.

MONTREAL, Sept 21 (Canadian Press) -- United States Customs patrols along the Quebec border have been increased owing to smuggling of Canadian wool into American milling centres, according to information reaching authorities here.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 -- Led by a "boy manager," as in their last pennant-winning years of 1924 and 1925, the Washington Senators stepped again today into the charmed circle reserved for winners of the American League bunting.

MINEOLA, L.I., Sept. 21 -- Mrs. J.V. Bouvier 3d's chestnut mare Danseuse captured the hunter championship of the thirty-first annual Mineola Horse Show today, the East Hampton exhibitor showing her title winner in the ring to take the award.

Two organizations of German-Americans joined four German-Jewish societies yesterday in resigning from the United German Societies as a result of the dissension which disrupted a meeting of the parent group Monday night.

LEIPZIG, Sept. 21 -- The trial of Marinus Van der Lubbe, alleged Dutch Communist; Ernst Torgler, German Communist leader, and their three alleged Bulgarian accomplices on charges of having burned the Reichstag building began today before the Criminal Senate of the German Supreme Court.

George White has entered into an agreement with the Fox Film Corporation, whereby he will produce and direct original film versions of five annual editions of the "Scandals." The first will be started at the Fox studios in Hollywood on Nov. 1, it was announced yesterday by Sidney R. Kent, president of Fox, and will be ready for release early next year.

Rear Admiral Richard E. Byrd announced yesterday that he had changed the name of the flagship of his forthcoming second Antarctic Expedition from Pacific Fir to Jacob Ruppert, in honor of the brewer, who is one of the principal sponsors of the expedition.

In Leonard Scarnici, 27 years old, suspected of complicity in the O'Connell kidnapping and accused of several robberies and at least two murders, the police yesterday believed they had caught the first real hired killer to come into their hands in a long time.

Yesterday's statement of the twelve Reserve Banks showed total gold holdings for the system as a whole to be at the highest point of the year to date, while total bills discounted reached a new low figure. No other important item in the system went to a new high or low point.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 -- Charges that airline operators were attempting to force unionized pilots into a national strike were filed today with the National Labor Board. David L. Behncke, president of the Air Line Pilots Association, composed of about 650 commercial aviators, handed the charges to Dr. W. M. Leiserson, secretary of the board.

The radio-electrical show in Madison Square Garden got well under way yesterday as crowds filled the aisles of the exposition to view the new receivers and other equipment displayed by 162 manufacturers.

Aggressive selling pressure was directed yesterday against all the financial and commodity markets. Stocks passed through the severest reaction in two months. Wheat, leading the downturn in agricultural staples, closed 5 cents a bushel lower, while cotton dropped more than $2 a bale.

The fusion forces prepared yesterday for the Mayoralty election and mapped their plans for the campaign with the openly expressed hope that Tammany would not shift to a candidate, other than John P. O'Brien.

Another decline from a year ago in the total of bank clearings of the twenty-one leading cities of the country took place during the week ended on Wednesday, according to Dun Bradstreet, Inc. The aggregate was $4,615,502,000, compared with $5,258,619,000 in the corresponding week last year, a drop of 13.9 per cent.

Two dollars a bale more, or twofifths cent a pound, were clipped yesterday from prices on the Cotton Exchange under heavy liquidation. The weakness that developed on Wednesday became more pronounced, and final prices were down about a cent a pound from Tuesday's best figures.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 -- The administration is ready to proceed against violators of the oil code, Secretary Ickes, administrator of the code, announced tonight. Many cases have been reported to the administration, Mr. Ickes asserted, and he authorized Louis R. Glavis, Chief of the Bureau of Investigation of the Department of the Interior, to "go ahead" with the prosecution of the worst of the violations.
VIENNA, Sept. 21 -- Chancellor Engelbert Dollfuss denied today that his new non-party and non-parliamentary government, in which he himself will hold five portfolios, was a dictatorship.

A sharp increase in the rate of consumer buying and a decline in productive activity developed in August and has carried through into the first half of September, according to the current report of the Conference of Statisticians in Industry of the National Industrial Conference Board.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 -- Looking forward to the time when he hopes to have all industry operating under codes of fair competition, General Johnson is endeavoring to work out a plan for the self-regulation of industry with the least governmental interference consonant with the protection of the public interests.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 -- The daily average volume of Federal Reserve Bank credit outstanding during the week ended Sept. 20, as reported by the Federal Reserve Banks, was $2,364,000,000 an increase of $27,000,000, compared with the preceding week and of $95,000,000 compared with the corresponding week in 1932.

ST. PAUL, Sept. 21 (AP) -- Colonel Russel G. Martin, 86-year-old Civil War veteran from Los Angeles, today was re-elected commander-inchief of the Grand Army of the Republic at its sixty-seventh annual encampment.
EASTON, Pa., Sept. 22. -- Herbert McCracken will round out ten years of coaching at Lafayette this Fall with a team which he figures will rate neither as the best nor the worst of his regime to date.

Dr. Edouard Oppert, chief of the radium division of the Hospital Lariboisiere in Paris, is sailing today on the French liner Ile de France. Others departing on the ship for Havre via Plymouth are William T. Dewart, publisher of The New York Sun; Maurice Chevalier, actor; Carl Laemmle, movie producer; Charles Lawton, English actor, and:
WASHINGTON, Sept. 22. -- Movements of vessels follow; all dates are Sept. 21, unless otherwise specified:

MONTGOMERY, Ala., Sept. 22. -- Auburn tonight defeated Birmingham-Southern, 20 -- 7, in the opening game of the season here. Tied 7-7 at the end of the half Auburn pushed the ball over Southern's goal in the last period and made the third touchdown with only three minutes to play by intercepting a pass.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Sept. 22. -- Yale's annual honor scholarship list announced today, contains the names of 704 students, of whom 189 are from New York State, 198 are from Connecticut and 43 are from Massachusetts.

LONDON, Sept. 22. -- The prophets of gloom here and elsewhere are answered by The London Times in an editorial today saying it is "altogether premature" to assume that President Roosevelt's recovery program is headed for disaster.

The pennant clinched and the excitement attending this unusual feat having somewhat subsided, Memphis Bill Terry and his Giants settled down yesterday to preparing themselves for the next and concluding act in the drama. A world's series with the Senators starts at the Polo Grounds on Oct. 3.

BERLIN, Sept. 21. -- A symbol of a new unity among German Jewry in the face of Nazi ostracism is the formation of a "central committee of German Jews for aid and reconstruction." In it are represented all the Jewish organizations in Germany, both Zionist and antiZionist.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., Sept. 22. -- In a fine breeze from off the Westchester and Connecticut shores the three twelve-meter sloops today sailed the first of their final three races of the season for the Isolde Trophy.

A code for the unemployed, establishing a minimum grant of $14 a week in cash for each unemployed person, with $3.50 added for each dependent, was mailed to President Roosevelt and the National Recovery Administration yesterday by the New York State Federation of Unemployed Organizations.

SANDS POINT, L.I., Sept. 22. -- Alfred Gwynne Vanderbilt celebrated his coming of age tonight at a dinner dance given for him by his mother, Mrs. Charles Minot Amory, at their Sands Point place, Cedar Knoll. There were seventy-five guests, many of whom had attended the Greenvale School at Roslyn with him and his brother, George Vanderbilt.
Spiritual growth and "militant religion" were stressed in sermons yesterday in connection with Rosh ha-Shanah. Economic stress and international discord were deplored.

VIENNA, Sept. 22. -- A sketch of the forthcoming new Austrian Constitution published today by the well-informed Christian Social organ, Neuigkeits Weltblatt, indicates that government will be by a lower chamber elected by plural voting and an upper chamber composed of representatives of the various professions and provincial chambers.

PARIS, Sept. 22. -- An appeal couched in terms of deep distress was sent to Premier Daladier yesterday by a group of exporting organizations representing virtually all the exporters of France. Their letter, which was called "our supreme appeal," said the exporting industries had reached the limit of their resistance and would soon have to shut down if relief were not granted.

Summer ends this morning at 8:01 A.M., Eastern Daylight Saving Time. The conservatives at the Weather Bureau conceded that much last night, but, as usual, were a bit wary about making general comments on the season as a whole. It's so easy to libel one of the seasons, they said.
BERLIN, Sept. 22. -- A measure providing for reprisals against countries that restrict imports from Germany was enacted at today's Cabinet meeting.

PLAINFIELD, N.J., Sept. 22. -- This week-end, two supper dances at the Plainfield Country Club, marking the resumption of the social season, introducing five Plainfield debutantes, all former students of Miss Porter's School at Farmington, Conn.

LONDON, Sept. 22. -- Lord Weir, prominent shipping engineer, is leaving for the United States tomorrow on a secret mission, believed to be connected with the impending merger of the Cunard and White Star Lines.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 22. -- Loadings of revenue freight in the week ended on Sept. 16 amounted to 652,016 cars, the American Railway Association announced today. This was 80,629 cars, or 14.1 per cent, more than in the preceding week and 64,770 cars, or 11 per cent, more than in the corresponding week last year, but 90,598 cars, or 12.2 per cent, fewer than in the corresponding week two years ago.
NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 22 -- Mrs. Philip Rhinelander 2d was a luncheon hostess for members of the younger set at the Pine Lodge today.
Two major theatrical offerings will be placed in rehearsal Monday. They are "Three and One" and "The Green Bay Tree."

Returning from visits to the former Kaiser and Chancellor Hitler, St. John Gaffney, former United States Consul in Munich and Dresden, arrived yesterday on the Hamburg-American liner Deutschland. Ha had a long talk with Hitler at his Summer home in Bavaria and spent two days at Doom as the former Kaiser's guest.

VIENNA, Sept. 22. -- Rumors of negotiations between Austria and Germany for a settlement of their differences increased tonight on the eve of the departure of Chancellor Dollfuss for Geneva, where he will attend the World Disarmament Conference.
LONDON, Sept. 22. -- David Lloyd George begged the British Government in a speech at Barmouth today not to "bully" Germany, no matter how bad the excesses of the Nazi regime might be.

TIME, and not necessarily a great deal of it, brings about some astonishing changes in the theatre of sport. Not more than five months ago, New York was complacently viewing the start of another baseball season. It did not promise to bring about any startling alteration in the general scheme of things, but with New York's seat in the next world's series assured, every one was content.
Final awards, including sweepstakes prizes for private and commercial growers, were made last night at the closing of the annual flower show of the American Dahlia Society at the Hotel Pennsylvania.
U.S. Department of Agriculture. Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices at New York:

GENEVA, Sept. 22. -- Baron von Neurath, German Foreign Minister, on failing to receive a visit today from Baron Aloisi, the Italian delegate to the League of Nations Council, called upon him tonight. Baron Aloisi, who is only a director in the Foreign Office at Rome, considerably underranks the German Foreign Minister.

MONTICELLO, N.Y., Sept. 22 (AP). -- The court test of the Public Service Commission's order to reduce gas and electric rates in New York City and Westchester County was adjourned today until Oct. 16 at Kingston. Justice Stephen Foster in Supreme Court granted the adjournment with the consent of counsel for both the commission and the six utility companies involved.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Sept. 22 (AP). -- Alfred H. Schoellkopf resigned today as president of the Buffalo, Niagara and Eastern Power Corporation. William Kelly, who had been vice president and general manager, was made president.
LEXINGTON, Ky., Sept. 22 (AP). -- Lord Jim won the fifty-seventh renewal of the Lexington Stake for 2-year-old trotters today as the Grand Circuit program was brought to a close.

Prisons also are to have their code. Convict labor has long played a highly controversial role in the industrial system. Critics of the existing regime, both in Federal and State institutions, have naturally become increasingly vocal during the depression. The outcry against "unfair competition" has sometimes overlooked the fact that prisoners are costly to maintain and are an unjust burden to the taxpayers if allowed to remain in idleness.

As a feature of Religious Education WeeK, which will begin tomorrow, the Fall conference for leaders of weekday church schools will be held on Friday in the auditorium of Wanamaker's store, beginning at 2 P.M. It will close with a dinner in the Wanamaker banquet hall, at which there will be two addresses.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Sept. 22 (AP). -- Before the largest crowd in Buffalo's baseball history, the Bisons tonight won the International League baseball pennant by defeating the Rochester Red Wings, 8 -- 1. It was their fourth victory of the seven-game series.
Although there will be activity on only one field in the immediate neighborhood, the opening, rangefinding barrage of a new football season begins throughout the college front today.

August A. Busch Jr., vice president and general manager of Anheuser-Busch, Inc., brewers, and Mrs. Elizabeth Overton Dozier of St. Louis were married yesterday afternoon in Mrs. Dozier's suite at the Savoy-Plaza.

George T. Dunlap Jr., national amateur golf champion, carried off all the Individual honors in the eleventh annual tournament of players connected with Wall Street banking firms in competing yesterday for the Charles Hayden trophy at the Oakland Golf Club, Bayside.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 22. -- Joseph B. Eastman, Federal Coordinater of Transportation, announced today that he was making a special study of plans for the consolidation of railroad properties along regional lines.

SOFIA, Bulgaria, Sept. 22. -- The Turko-Bulgarian conversations here were concluded today with a result disappointing to Turkish ambitions, namely, the renewal for five years of the Turko-Bulgarian treaty of friendship which expires next March.

WHITEMARSH, Pa., Sept. 22. -- Mrs. John Hay Whitney of New York and Upperville, Va., riding her 6-year-old gray gelding Two Leggins, today won the coveted Clairemont Champion Trophy during the second session of the Wissahickon Horse Show.

The bond market on the Stock Exchange halted yesterday its downward trend, which had been in progress since Monday. Losses of the previous day or two were erased in some instances by recoveries ranging from 1 to more than 5 points.

INDIANAPOLIS, Sept. 22. -- The American Legion Monthly today released for publication an article written for its October issue by Wright Patman, in which the Texas Representative, himself a legionnaire, makes a "confession of honest error" as to his attitude toward National Commander Louis Johnson's policy on the National Economy Act.

A warning that further restrictions of wild-fowl shooting may be adopted and that the Federal Government will lend strong support to the effective enforcement of such a measure was issued yesterday by W.C. Henderson, associate chief of the Biological Survey, through which department the statement was released.

In an effort to avert a strike by the employes of the Fifth Avenue Coach Company, Grover A. Whalen, chairman of the local NRA organization, held a hearing yesterday at NRA headquarters in the Hotel Pennsylvania. A group of the company's employes dismissed from the service presented charges that they were discriminated against for union activity and demanded the intervention of the NRA to bring about their reinstatement.

Citing the disorder and violations of law at the primary election last Tuesday, W. Kingsland Macy, Republican State chairman, appealed yesterday to Governor Lehman to take action to protect the polls at the general election on Nov. 7. This followed a similar letter to Attorney General Bennett for protection at the primary election, which Mr. Macy said had not been answered.

NEW YORK. Mr. and Mrs. Rene Du Champ Bellinger will give a dinner tonight in the Starlight Roof Garden of the Waldorf-Astoria for Miss Constance Pierrepont Zabriskie and R. Draper Richards, whose marriage will take place on Sept. 29.

Despite the severe pressure exerted against the general bond market this week and in particular the losses sustained by United States Governmant securities, the municipal bond market showed comparatively little unsettlement. While most dealers were inclined to quote prices on old blocks on their lists unchanged from last week, in a few instances prices were reduced to show increased yields of 5/100 to 10/100 in basis.

Although the financial and commodity markets were nervous and irresolute yesterday, they showed no such acute weakness as developed on Thursday. Stocks and bonds had a partial recovery, commodities were mixed and the dollar extended its decline only slightly in the foreign exchange market.

BALBOA, C.Z., Sept. 22. -- With the refusal of the navy to surrender Lieutenant John Henry Cross, charged with involuntary manslaughter, to the civil courts for trial, both the army and the navy have defied the civil authorities of the Canal Zone.

WESTBURY, L.I., Sept. 22. -- Stephen Sanford's veteran English mare, Fairy Story, won the championship of the National Polo Pony Society today to add to her triumphs of 1924 and 1925. Fairy Story became the first pony in the history of the organization to capture three titles.

Whether the pneumatic underground mail tubes used to shoot 6,000,000 letters daily between postal stations in the city will be bought by the government or remain under private ownership and government lease was discussed yesterday at a hearing at the General Postoffice presided over by Fourth Assistant Postmaster General Silliman Evans.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 22. -- Demands by certain groups of editorial employes for changes in the wages and hours suggested and by others for alterations in the provisions regarding newsboys were voiced at the hearing which began today on the code for the newspaper industry submitted by the American Newspaper Publishers Association.

GLEN COVE, L.I., Sept. 22. -- Tracy Barnes, recently of Yale, where he concentrated on baseball rather than golf, won the medal in the Nassau Country Club invitation golf tournament today. He scored a 75 to lead a number of other notable linksmen participating in the annual event.

CHICAGO, Sept. 22. -- Speculative owners of grain who found themselves unable yesterday to dispose of long lines of wheat, rye and oats because the markets closed at the maximum declines permitted under the regulations of the Board of Trade, resumed liquidating today.
A late rally in most markets produced irregular closing prices on local commodities exchanges yesterday. Trading was quieter than on recent days. Cash prices were irregularly lower.

Grover A. Whalen, city NRA chairman, said yesterday that he would name fifteen more members to the Committee on Leisure Time he appointed recently, as soon as he received a formal report of the meeting on Thursday at which the request for additional members was made.

Discussing in THE TIMES last Sunday the Government's " farm recovery" program of the past six months, Mr. GEORGE N. PEEK described these experimental measures as " without pre" cise parallel, not only In the farming " industry but also, I think, in any " other industry in any country at any " time."

GENEVA, Sept. 22. -- The seventysixth session of the Council of the League of Nations opened this morning in the crystal chamber and dealt rapidly with the Assyrian, opium and intellectual cooperation questions.

OKLAHOMA CITY, Sept. 22. Four days of pounding away at the twelve persons accused of conspiring in the kidnapping of Charles F. Urschel, wealthy oil man, ended late today as the government rested and let the defense begin its counter-offensive.

EDWARDSVILLE, Ill., Sept. 22. -- The assertion that he was forced into the kidnapping of August Luer, the Alton banker, was made today by Randol Eugene Norvell, one of six defendants at their trial here. His testimony came as a surprise to attorneys of the other defendants and indicated that the defense would have no united front.

The United States Army had its day yesterday at Madison Square Garden's radio-electrical show. Scientific research conducted by the engineers of the Signal Corps in the electrical fields was emphasized in exhibits of defense apparatus created for war manoeuvres and by other equipment designed for peacetime activities.

SPRINGFIELD, N.J., Sept. 22. -- Overcoming the tremendous handicap of being 5 down at the fifteenth hole in the morning, Miss Maureen Orcutt of White Beeches carried off the women's New Jersey golf title by defeating Miss Charlotte Glutting, 3 and 1, at Baltusrol today.
DUBLIN, Sept. 22. -- The first serious attempt on members of the Blue Shirt National Guard was reported today from Dingle, County Kerry. Captain Martin Fitzgerald was critically wounded.

NEWARK, N.J., Sept, 22. -- The two pilots of the air liner which crashed at its take-off here yesterday are improving rapidly at St. James's Hospital. Both men, Glenn J. MacDonald of Elizabeth and T. Benson Hoye of Newark, now are off the serious list at the hospital.

Following a decline of about a cent a pound in two days, prices on the Cotton Exchange steadied and recovered more than 1/4 cent at one time yesterday. With the technical position improved by liquidation of many speculative long accounts, support appeared from several directions, and the demand from consumers was larger than for some time.

The joint facilities contract between the Bronx Gas and Electric Company and the Consolidated Gas Company was questioned by city counsel yesterday at the hearing on rates of the Bronx company before Public Service Commissioner George R. Van Namee.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The kindly notice taken by THE TIMES of the death of Dr. Annie Besant seems likely to engender some misconceptions in the minds of your readers who are unfamiliar with the history of modern theosophy.

LEIPZIG, Sept. 22. -- The trial before the German Supreme Court of the five men accused of having burned the Reichstag building to precipitate a Communist revolution in Germany turned today into a battle between the German judicial forces and the international jurists' commission that has just published a report charging the fire was really set by the National Socialists themselves to further their own revolution.
The Bay Shore Handicap and the Harbor Hill Steeplechase, two of the four Queens County Jockey Club's stakes, will be run this afternoon at Aqueduct.

On Nov. 13, the seventy-seventh birthday of Supreme Court Justice Louis D. Brandeis, the Princeton University Press is to publish "Brandeis: Lawyer and Judge in the Modern State," by A.T. Mason, Professor of Politics at Princeton University.

A plea to President Roosevelt not to inject himself into the New York City situation by backing a third candidate for the Mayoralty was sent to the President yesterday by George Henry Payne, a Republican, and representative of W. Kingsland Macy, State chairman, on the harmony committee that picked the fusion ticket.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 22. -- President Roosevelt today widened his plans to raise commodity prices and silence the demand for currency inflation by pledging the government to lend to cotton farmers 10 cents a pound on their holdings of this year's crop, on condition that they accept the program of the Agricultural Adjustment Administration for reducing the crops of 1934 and 1935.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 22. -- President Roosevelt today approved the bituminous coal wage agreement between the United Mine Workers of America and the operators of the Appalachian field and gave the soft coal industry his blessing.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 22. -- Various ways of revamping the structure of the old National Credit Corporation so that it may be used in making available loans to small industries and business men throughout the country are being considered as another step in the administration's program of credit expansion.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 22. -- Steadily increasing with business improvement and greater buying power of the public internal revenue receipts for the first two months of the 1934 fiscal year amounted to $294,273,298, as compared with $141,626,778 in the same period of 1933, the Internal Revenue Bureau announced today.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 22 (AP). -- An alleged plan to kidnap E. L. Doheny, California oil man, and Jesse L. Livermore, New York stock broker, entered today into the investigation of the slaying of Buell Dawson, a young gangster, aboard the gambling ship Johanna Smith, anchored off Long Beach.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Sept. 22. -- Search for Mrs. Mabel Douglass, 56, retired dean of the New Jersey College for Women at Rutgers, was continued today in the surrounding mountain trails, and a diver went down in the lake.

HAVANA, Sept. 22. -- An unofficial, nation-wide military movement, ostensibly intended to wipe out communism is believed to have been revealed today by the capture of the town of Manguito, Matanzas Province, by a guerrilla band under the leadership of Rodriguez Duarte and Gabriel Barreto.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 22. -- Important interpretations of points in the so-called civil liabilities section of the Federal Securities Act which have been giving much concern to underwriters, were made public today by the Federal Trade Commismission in a letter written to an unnamed correspondent in New York by Baldwin B. Bane, chief of the commission's securities division.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 22. -- Three new champions were crowned and one driver retained his title in the annual Eastern and American Power Boat Association championships on the Schuylkill River in Fairmount Park today, No world records were broken.

PARIS, Sept. 22. -- Henri Cochet made his debut as a professional tennis player today, but William T. Tilden 2d stole most of the spotlight as the United States and France divided the first two singles matches of a professional series played along Davis Cup lines.

ATLANTIC CITY, N. J., Sept. 22. -- A tremendous reaction against the whole NRA may be expected If the industries themselves fail to bring about a complete cooperative understanding among their members. This was pointed out by Gilbert H. Montague, New York attorney, in an address here today at the closing session of the annual convention of the National Petroleum Association.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 22. -- The Bureau of Navigation issued the following orders today, dated Sept. 20:

CHICAGO, Sept. 22 -- Using a smoke screen, six machine-gun ban- dits swept into the Loop early this morning, held up two Federal Re- serve Bank messengers and two guards, and a few minutes later murdered a policeman.
NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 22. -- Now it can be told!

Estimates of added expenses to the electric companies of the Consolidated system, under the excise tax on gross incomes and increased water costs proposed by the city, were rejected by Milo R. Maltbie, chairman of the Public Service Commission, when counsel for the utilities sought to introduce the figures yesterday at the rehearing on temporary emergency rate reductions.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 22. -- Early creation of regional agencies of the National Labor Board to adjust labor disputes became a certainty today as a joint statement to that effect was issued by Senator Wagner, chairman of the board, and Hugh S. Johnson, Recovery Administrator.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 22. -- The wholesale commodity price index resumed its rising trend during the week of Sept. 16, according to a report issued today (Wednesday) by the Bureau of Labor Statistics of the United States Department of Labor.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Sept. 22. -- Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr., son of the President, became a freshman at Harvard College today, registering at Memorial Hall along with nearly 1,000 other young men of about his age.
Friends of Joseph V. McKee, former Aldermanic President, are ready to support him as an independent Democratic candidate for Mayor if he will consent to make the race.

Decreases amounting to $1,177,801 are contained in the 1934 budget request of the Sanitation Department, transmitted yesterday by Budget Director Maurice A. Stephenson, to George McAneny as Sanitation Commissioner.
CHICAGO, Sept. 22 (AP). -- A new wage scale will be submitted to pilots of five air lines next week, affording increases to about 250 of the 375 pilots employed, the companies announced today.

The prospects of an early agreement between the city and its bankers on an economy program which would insure new loans to avert payroll and interest defaults in the near future remained doubtful yesterday at the end of a fourand-a-half-hour conference in the home of Governor Lehman at 820 Park Avenue.

Clergymen of the Catholic, Protes tant and Jewish faiths met yesterday afternoon with Grover A. Whalen, city NRA chairman, at headquarters in the Hotel Pennsylvania to form an organization among the city's clergy to support the NRA movement.

More than 4,000 men who served abroad during the World War with the Seventy-seventh Division -- many of them from distant parts of the United States -- flocked to the division organization's headquarters yesterday to register for a three day annual reunion.

There are 70,000 workers on strike in New York City. Other strikes are in prospect which, if called, would add at least 50,000 more. These conditions are not local to New York. There is evidence in many other cities of a resumption of industrial conflict precisely at a time when the nation is being organized to place industry on a paying basis and restore purchasing power to its personnel.

More than $2,000,000 worth of gold, silver, jade and carved articles taken from a tomb among the 600 or more repositories in the Monte Alben archaeological projects in Mexico will be placed on exhibition tomorrow in the Pennsylvania Station.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 22. -- Confusion in the interpretation of the code of fair competition for the oil industry led Secretary Ickes, who is the oil administrator, to issue a statement today in which he sought to make the provisions and the obligations incurred under the code Clear to all concerned.

Frank J. Prial, Democratic nominee for Controller by virtue of having beaten the organization in the primaries, paid a visit yesterday morning to Tammany Hall, where he conferred for about an hour with John F. Curry, Tammany leader.

BERLIN, Sept. 22. -- Hermann Wilhelm Goering, German Aviation Minister, received me in his private study. A large swastika ornaments the chimney piece. Below the room, between two windows looking on a peaceful garden, there is a stone Virgin in the Nuremberg style, with flowers recently renewed at her feet.

The Golden Age of Tammany Hall, when street meetings were pelted from roofs with brickbats and election campaigns were gorgeous affairs of torchlights, clambakes, beer and free ice cream for children, was revived last night for two hours.

TRENTON, N.J., Sept. 22. -- Former United States Senator David Baird Jr. took the stand today as the first witness at the Legislative investigation of Senate President Emerson L. Richards's charge that brewing interests had paid $25,000 to Jesse R. Salmon, Essex County Republican chairman, to block enactment of a law for control of beer.
MINEOLA, L.I., Sept. 22. -- Harry Brusie of Hartford, Conn., drove two entries to victory today in the closing light-harness program at the Mineola Fair track.
ARCOLA, N.J., Sept. 22. -- Two former winners of the Arcola Country Club invitation golf tourney entered the semi-finals today.
LONDON, Sept. 22. -- Ramsay MacDonald returned to the political arena tonight with a slashing attack on his old time Labor friends.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 22. -- Gen eral Johnson is considering demand ing either an end of controversial statements or resignations from prominent members of his advisory boards.
Beyond routine requirements, there were no signs of fresh activity in the money market. Turnover was small and quotations for all classes of accommodation were carried forward without change.

LONDON, Sept. 22. -- A shabby army of 420 unemployed Catholics, recruited from street corners in all parts of the British Isles, is leaving London for Rome tomorrow on a pilgrimage to the Pope to win special Holy Year indulgences and pray for work.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 22. -- A formal request to the National Recovery Administration for substitution of a thirty-six-hour week in codes now allowing a maximum of forty hours was made today by a large manufacturing establishment operating under the cotton textile agreement.
The Atlantic steamship lines met yesterday at 80 Broad Street to write the 1933-34 West Indies cruise agreement which will bind them within a maximum of seventy-one cruises for thirteen companies.

LEWISBURG, Pa., Sept. 22. -- Bucknell defeated Waynesburg tonight, 46 to 7, in the season's football opener for the Bisons. The visitors displayed a powerful running attack and a complete superiority over the Yellow Jackets.

Was It by Way of Parable? Was the Mayor addressing himself exclusively to the champion Giants when he said what he said on Thursday? He called attention to the "commentators on baseball" whose early season predictions put the New York team in the second division.

At first blush there might be a little perplexity about the apportionment by the Public Works Administration of $14,800,000 to the Coast Guard for the construction of cutters, patrol boats, revenue cutters and seaplanes to deal with the expected approach of rumsmugglers in great force after the repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment.

Retail Trade Shows Some Gain. Retail trade picked up during the week, but volume did not increase sufficiently to bring sales figures above the corresponding period a year ago for the metropolitan district, retail executives here reported yesterday.

Restoration of mileage books is planned by the Eastern railroads as part of a general reduction in passenger fares to be considered at a general meeting expected to be held next week in Washington or Chicago, Books good for 2,000 miles of travel would be sold for $54, or 2.7 cents a mile, compared with the present basic rate of 3.6 cents.

PARIS, Sept. 22. -- Although many troublesome obstacles remain, what may be called the world's eightyear disarmament plan began to take outline today at the Quai d'Orsay when representatives of France, Britain and the United States found themselves nearer agreement than at any time in the past eighteen months of discussion.

DETROIT, Sept. 22. -- Henry Ford moved today to place his 50,000 employes, now working forty hours a week, on a work-week to comply with the thirty-five-hour maximum provided in the NRA automobile code which he has not signed.

To the Editor of The New York Times: As one who for twenty-five years has been deeply interested in every effort to improve protective laws for helpless children in this country, I was considerably concerned to read a letter in THE TIMES from the Rev. Joseph V.S. McClancy, Superintendent of Catholic Schools of Brooklyn.

Somebody ought to write a fable about ash removal in Brooklyn. In the manner of the Flies and the Honey, perhaps, or the Lion, the Bear and the Fox. Only when the lion and the bear fought over the fawn's carcass until they lay down panting, and the fox went off with the prize, their complaint was that they had exhausted themselves " merely to give a dinner to a rogue."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 22. -- Enough worthy projects are now before the Public Works Administration, or in course of preparation, to exhaust the $3,300,000,000 public works fund by Jan. 1, Secretary Ickes announced today.

GREENWICH, Conn., Sept. 22. -- A supper dance was given by Mr. and Mrs. John A. Topping of Belle Haven, Greenwich, at the Greenwich Country Club tonight to introduce to society their granddaughter, Miss Mary Topping.

BERLIN, Sept. 22. -- The bond market dominated today's session of the Boerse, a heavy demand for municipal, communal and State bonds being an outstanding feature. Announcement that the government would undertake overhauling of the financial administration of communes and States and increased activity of the Reichsbank in the open market diverted attention of the investing public to fixedinterest securities to an extent not experienced in a long time.

The President's authorization of the purchase of $75,000,000 worth of surplus food and clothing materials will not only help to relieve the destitute unemployed. It should also show itself in some benefit to those whose want is born of plenty -- the farmer and those who transmute his products into the necessaries of life.

Its funds exhausted, the Emergency Unemployment Relief Committee yesterday stopped distributing food packages to needy unemployed. More than 30,000 families who have been dependent upon the committee for their food supply will now be compelled to seek assistance from the city and private agencies.

WESTBURY, L.I., Sept. 22. -- Play will start tomorrow in the delayed national open polo championship with the match between Templeton, defending title holder, and Greentree, on the famous stretch of International Field at the Meadow Brook Club. These teams were the finalists in 1932.

VALLEYFIELD, Que., Sept. 22 (Canadian Press). -- In a fire that raged through the night the Roman Catholic cathedral of Valleyfield and an adjoining convent school were destroyed with a loss of about $1,600,000.

BOSTON, Sept. 22 (AP). -- Aroused because Democrats have failed to settle upon one candidate for Boston Mayor, Mrs. Mary E. Gallagher, 46 years old, a mother and president of the Women's Political League of Massachusetts, entered the free-for-all today.

UNIONTOWN, Pa., Sept. 22. -- Striking miners in Pennsylvania were planning today to march tomorrow on West Virginia mines in Monongahela County, and there Sheriff Charles T. Hickman, with a force of deputies and State police, kept an armed vigil against the proposed invasion.

Because the heaviest business was done on the Stock Exchange in the first hour yesterday, when prices were declining, it was assumed that the reversal in the market's course at a time when rallying tendencies appeared reflected the subsidence of liquidating pressure.

The meeting held recently at Elmira by members of the Democratic Union and affiliated organizations will be followed by a series of meetings in each of the judicial districts outside the city, it was announced yesterday by the Democratic State Committee.
DETROIT, Sept. 22 (AP). -- Senator Couzens is going to carry to the floor of the Senate "several aspects" of this city's banking situation which he finds objectionable.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I read in THE TIMES that Attorney General Cummings has a new plan to Impose special fees in addition to the already inflated import duties on all articles which will compete with socalled NRA products. I sincerely hope this is merely a ballon d'essai and that this fool notion will go no further.

St. Bonaventure of Olean, N.Y., will furnish the opposition for the Manhattan eleven in the inaugural of the metropolitan college gridiron season at Ebbets Field, Brooklyn, this afternoon at 2:30 o'clock. An attendance of 20,000 is expected.

All the officers and directors of the United German Societies resigned last night, giving as their reason that the societies refused to follow them in a declaration that Nazi politics and anti-Semitism would have no part in the annual celebration of German Day on Oct. 29.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Thomas Woodward in his letter to THE TIMES, in which he called the salary increments ridiculous, seems to show a lack of understanding of young teachers' salaries.

The Board of Elections made public last night the results of the contest for members of the Republican County Committee between the forces backing Samuel S. Koenig, veteran county leader, and Chase Mellen Jr.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I receive a salary from the State of New York. No reason occurs to me why I should not pay Federal income tax upon it. My neighbor receives a salary from the Federal Government. No reason is apparent to me why he should not pay this State an income tax upon it.

Speakers appearing before the joint legislative committee on motor carriers and transportation at its session yesterday in the State Building 80 Centre Street, charged that the move to have trucks regulated was fostered largely by the railroads, which wished to curb this form of transportation business.

SOUTH HADLEY, Iass., Sept. 22. -- Speaking at a convocation opening the ninety-seventh academic year at Mount Holyoke College, President Woolley today called for development of the full powers of the individual in the face of growing complexities of modern life.

CHICAGO, Sept. 22. -- President Roosevelt, in a message today to the Conference of Mayors here, called upon the nation's cities to send immediately to "Washington requests for their share of the $3,300,000,000 public works funds. Allocations were pledged with all possible speed.

BURTON STEVENSON, compiler of the famous "Home Book of Verse," writes his publishers, Dodd, Mead Co., that he is well started on the final revision of the manuscript of his mammoth "Home Book of Quotations, Classical and Modern" and that he hopes to have it completed in November.

BOSTON, Sept. 21. -- Concord, capital of New Hampshire, has a barber whose resolution is as hard and enduring as the rock for which the Granite State is named. Retiring at the age of 79 after a half century of work, he proudly boasts that never has he cut a woman's hair.

The New York Botanical Garden has listed the State flowers of the United States and has disclosed the fact that a fourth of them are immigrants. This is not surprising, for most of the early comers brought the seeds or plants of their cherished flowers with them. Their perfume, color and form were as medicines for the nostalgia of many who were strangers in a strange land.

THE efficacy of the remedy for poisonous snakebites was dramatically demonstrated recently. In the auditorium of the Ramapo Arts and Crafts Centre, in Suffern, sat 200 physicians and a sprinkling of camp directors awaiting a lecture on snakebites and their treatment by Colonel Martin L. Crimmins, U.S. A., retired.

SCARSDALE, N.Y., Sept. 23. -- The veteran Charles Kear from Stratford, Conn., led the field in quest of the metropolitan archery championship when the first day's shooting was concluded on the Scarsdale High School athletic field today.

PARIS, Sept. 23. -- Following yesterday's disarmament conversations and in preparation for their sequel at Geneva, the French Cabinet met today at the President's Summer home at Rambouillet to discuss the situation.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 23. -- Hollywood paid its final respects today to Sime Silverman, 61 years old, founder and owner of Variety, trade paper of the show world. Afterward his body was taken back to New York for burial by Arthur Unger, editor of the coast edition of the paper and Mr. Silverman's close friend for twenty-four years.

BARCELONA, Sept. 10. -- The various United States consular officers in Spain, eighteen in number, under the supervision of the Consulate General at Barcelona, are in a difficult plight as a consequence of various reductions in pay and allowances, in conjunction with the fall of the dollar as compared to the Spanish peseta.
PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 22. -- Notwithstanding political turmoil and strikes, business in the Third district has been active this week.
ITHACA, N. Y., Sept. 23. -- A fairly seasoned line and a back field in which the younger players will have a chance are indicated at Cornell. On the whole, the squad is light and lacks experience.

PARIS. BERNARD FAY is one of the three or four French authors most widely known in the United States. And this is only fair. For he is thoroughly acquainted with your history; he has taught at a number of your universities; and almost every year he spends several months in your country.

WHAT strikes the reader of these poems is that to a remarkable degree they live up to the author's characterization of them -- that is to say, the poems come very close to being actually ballads of the English and Scottish type, the traditional ballad as distinguished from the purely artificial type.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 (AP) -- A code of competition for the boot and shoe industry, accompanied by adverse reports from at least two advisory agencies, is expected to be sent to Administrator Hugh S. Johnson early next week.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23. -- Major Thomas E. Watson of the Marine Corps has been ordered by Secretary Swanson to proceed to Santo Domingo City to report to General Raphael Trujillo, President of the Dominican Republic, for duty in connection with training of the Dominican Army.

A PRE-VIEW of the thirty five studios in Radio City, where a corps of artisans are now adding finishing touches, makes it safe to predict that an endless procession of radio listeners will beat a pathway to the electrical acropolis "to see the wheels go round."

The nearest approach in the United States to the internationally famed hound show at Peterborough in England is the annual Bryn Mawr hound show to be held this week at Bryn Mawr, Pa., in connection with the Bryn Mawr Horse Show.

PIERRE, S. D., Sept. 21. -- Setting a precedent of far-reaching significance, South Dakota for the first time has definitely announced elimination of the general tax levy for 1934. Through its Board of Tax Equalization the State has told its citizens that it has reduced total property valuations $144,227,732 compared with a year ago.

The need for economic, political, social and religious cooperation throughout the world was the keynote of addresses at a luncheon in Town Hall Club yesterday in honor of Raja Jai Prithvi Singh and Dr. Shyama Shankar, delegates from India to the World Fellowahip of Faiths in Chicago.

Do young newspaper men of the big cities have day dreams, as their predecessors had, of buying a weekly in some "thriving" but still reasonably idyllic town, accumulating merit there and money in the bank and combining, by some magical process, a close attention to business with something of the leisure and pleasure of a country gentleman?

Applying so much pressure in the closing laps that their closest rivals wilted away, Juan Carlos Zabala of the Argentine and Joe McCluskey of the New York A.C. registered runaway victories in the 131st track and field games of the New York Athletic Club yesterday.

THE longest stick in the world has two ends to it; so has the shortest stick. There to one force called centrifugal motion; there is another force, an answering force, called centripetal motion. A raindrop falls to the ground in answer to the call of gravitation; the same raindrop rises from the earth in answer to the call of evaporation.

The Rev. Bernard R. Hubbard, known as the "Glacier Priest" as the result of his explorations in Alaska, returned to New York yesterday and told of his visit to the windiest spot on earth, in the Aleutian Islands.

KINGSTON, R.I., Sept. 23. -- Displaying a fast, varied attack, Rhode Island State College turned back Brooklyn College, 12-0, in the opening football contest of the season for both teams today. A crowd of 2,000 witnessed the game.

Back-Seat Thrills. THE inscrutable Chinese certainly are. They placidly contemplate life's commotions and measure time by the century. Yet they drive automobiles as if every second counted in the rush of the world.

VIENNA, Sept. 23. -- Major Emil Fey, Acting Chancellor of Austria in the absence of Chancellor Dollfuss at Geneva, will establish concentration camps for Austrian Nazis, according to a statement tonight in Major Pay's personal Heimwehr newspaper, the Oesterreichische Abend Zeitung.

BERLIN, Sept. 23. -- A continuing bull movement in the bond market enabled the Boerse today to round out the week with a firm tendency, in which stocks shared to the extent of more than recovering yesterday's slight losses. The Reichsbank's demand for fixed interestbearing securities caused municipal bonds to make gains of 4 per cent.

Limitation of the number of retailers in any given trading area, a suggestion brought once more to the fore during the week by H. Gordon Selfridge, London merchant, in a radio address at the Boston conference on retail distribution, was seen here yesterday as an eventual development, "which may materialize sooner than many realize."

HAVANA, Sept. 23. -- The United States destroyer Hamilton was rushed to Cayo Mambi, on the north coast of Cuba, today to protect United States citizens and British subjects held prisoners by workers who have seized the Tanamo sugar mill.

MR. ABBOT'S very readable autobiography is in part a survey of political events during his more than forty years of kaleidoscopic journalism. He has personally known most of the Presidents of the United States of his time, and a great number of candidates for office, and politicians of high and low degree.
PARIS, Sept. 23. -- Having abandoned practically all her former positions on disarmament, France has planted her flag on the last ditch -- international control.

Following Communist threats to clear out local NRA headquarters at the Hotel Pennsylvania yesterday morning with stench bombs, ten policemen from the West Thirtieth Street police station were rushed to the headquarters to prevent any disturbance.

THETFORD, Vt., Sept. 22. -- Troubled in spirit and weary of present civilization, Dwight Goddard, 72year-old mystic, Buddhist and "mystery man" generally of this town for the last twelve years, has left to enter a Buddhist monastery in Tibet.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23. -- Unions at newspaper mechanical workers attacked the provisions of the American Newspaper Publishers Association code and Assailed the publishers as hypocritical toward the national recovery movement as hearings ended on the code today.

AN insignificant little pebble upset the entire result of a world's series in 1924. The Giants seemed to have it won, the ball struck the pebble, bounced high over Freddy Lindstrom's head when it should have stuck in the young third baseman's glove for the third out and some of the finest calculations John McGraw ever made went right out the window. Triffing details sometimes do bring about momentous changes.

Announcements made last week of securities called for payment before their dates of maturity were principally for October, only two small amounts of warrants being called for September. Little change was made in the month's total, which is now $25,794,900, compared with $22,593,000 in August, and $25,406,300 in September a year ago for corresponding weeks.

A vigorous rally took place in local commodity trading yesterday in sympathy with the movements in cotton, wheat and stocks. Silver, rubber, copper and hides closed with gains. Trading was in fair volume. Cash prices were higher.

The increasing movement of crude oil from California and the Gulf Coast ports to the Atlantic seaboard has brought about a sharp recovery in the charter rates for oil tankers, it is stated in oil circles. Coastwise and intercoastal shipments are confined by law to American vessels, and the present activity also has diverted many American tankers into these runs.
VILLANOVA, Pa., Sept. 23. -- By scoring in every period, Villanova opened the season with an easy 45 to 0 victory over the West Chester State Teachers today.

THREE scientists in the medical forces seeking to solve the mystery of sleeping sickness have submitted to bites from mosquitos which previously had bitten victims of this exotic malady. Their purpose is to determine whether insects carry the infection.

The Seventy-seventh Division marched up Park Avenue yesterday; not with the quick springy cadence their feet once beat across French soil, not in khaki and steel helmets, not men-at-arms, but veterans of a war that is past.

CAMP DIX, N.J., Sept. 23. -- Loaded with trophies of the "Wild and Woolly West," some sporting the latest styles in whiskers, others half obscured under sombreros and huge Montana hats, but all the picture of exuberant health, New York's first returning details of the Civilian Conservation Corps reached Camp Dix shortly before noon today for demobilization.

Around the church of the Christian, the synagogue of the Jew, the mosque of the Mohommedan and the temple of the Hindu there sweeps an atmosphere electric with emotion, breaking into storms of violence, conflecation, incendiarism and a somewhat pitiless persecution.
COLUMBUS, Sept. 23 (AP). -- The Columbus Red Birds will meet the Buffalo Bisons in the first game of the little world's series here tomorrow.

THE opening of the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra season is a few days more than a week away. On Thursday evening, Oct. 5, Bruno Walter will return to direct the beginning of the ninety-second season, which will be thirty weeks long.

FLINT, Mich., Sept. 23 (AP). -- Stating that they would "take no part" in the strike of an undetermined number of skilled workers in the plants of the General Motors Corporation here, officials of the United Auto Workers Union, affiliated with the American Federation of Labor, today held a mass meeting in which they urged auto workers to join their organization.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Sept. 23. -- In the biggest shake-up which has hit the Harvard squad since Eddie Casey has been head coach, five members of Team A today lost their positions while three sophomores and two juniors were promoted to the varsity.

HEMPSTEAD, L. I., Sept. 23. -- With Harold Lube playing a conspicuous role in the victory, the Flushing High School football team of Queens registered a 13-to-6 triumph over Hempstead High on the latter's field today. A crowd of 3,000 saw the rival elevens open their campaigns.

WITH planning uppermost in the minds of many, industrial purchasing is likely to gain a place in the economic management of the industrial plant commensurate with its influence for ill or good. A "DIVERTIMENTO" for eleven instruments by Rodolfo Halffter (brother of the celebrated Ernesto) was received with marks of disapproval when premiered recently by the Orquesta Clasica of Madrid, under the baton of Jose M. Franco, successor to the late Saco del Valle.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21. -- The Department of Labor and the Veterans Administration have begun selection of 75,000 new recruits for enrolment in the second contingent of the Civilian Conservation Corps. The new men will be called in October, Robert Fechner, director of the CCC work, announced, and all except war veterans will be selected by State agencies under the supervision of the Department of Labor.

Wounded in a hold-up in which two men of about 30 acted as supervisors for two boy gunmen, Charles Solomon, 45 years old, bric-a-brac and electric goods dealer at 325 East Tenth Street, was taken to Bellevue Hospital yesterday in a serious condition.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 23. -- Paul Hyatt, 24-year-old Brooklyn driver, not only captured the $5,000 Sir Thomas Lipton Trophy on the concluding day of the sixth annual outboard motor boat regatta on the Schuykill today, but also broke a world's record.

OF the four pretentious productions Jesse L. Lasky has made since he threw in his lot with the Fox Film Corporation, his pictorial version of "Berkeley Square" is the outstanding achievement. This is no lefthanded compliment, for two of these cinematic works, "Zoo in Budapest" and "The Power and the Glory," revealed definite progress in motion picture technique.

CAMERA studies by John N. Sennott constitute the current "special feature" at the gallery of Mrs. Carroll French in New City, Rockland County. In addition may be seen work by Morris Kantor, George Constant, Charles Eills, Carroll French, A.S. Baylinson and others.
CANTON, Ill., Sept. 23 (AP). -- A will-o'-the wisp desperado, seriously wounded, fled before deputies and policemen today after a daring break from custody and the abduction of four persons.
BERLIN, Sept. 23. -- Critical reflection on the German Government's economic program, announced last night, finds one surprise in it -- its conservatism.

LONDON, Sept. 22. -- It is so long since Prime Minister Ramsay MacDonald played an energetic part in the affairs of this country that his political speech tonight and his busy consultations earlier in the week have cheered his admirers everywhere.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Sept. 23. -- A concert will be given Thursday evening at the County Centre here for the benefit of German Jews who have come under the ban of the Nazis. AKRON, Ohio, Sept. 23. -- Hoping to start a transatlantic service between Germany and the United States in the Spring of 1935, Dr. Hugo Eckener, Graf Zeppelin skipper, will seek permission of the United States Navy to use the naval air station at Lakehurst as a temporary terminal in this country, he announced here today.

The five men and two women held in connection with the kidnapping of John J. O'Connell Jr. and other crimes, including several bank robberies and murders, were arraigned in Washington Heights Court yesterday. They were held another forty-eight hours without bail when the police said they needed more time for investigation.

PLAINFIELD, N.J., Sept. 23. -- Mr. and Mrs. Lewis Alfred Williams of Oak Hill, Plainfield and Washington, Conn.; Mrs. Mary dePeyster Charles or Evergreen Avenue and Lawrence, L.I., and Mrs. Harvey Fisk of Prospect Avenue and Woodstock, Vt., presented their daughters, the Misses Mary CliffJones Williams, Adrienne Bruton, Charles and Margaretta Fisk, at a supper dance at the Plainfield Country Club this evening.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23. -- A prediction that the American Federation of Labor might soon join the boycott of German goods being organized by European trade unions was made today by William Green, its president.

GENEVA, Sept. 23. -- Reassurance that nothing had been done behind the back of Germany in the recent arms conversations in Paris between the United States, France and Great Britain was given Foreign Minister Konstantin von Neurath of Germany today by Sir John Simon, British Foreign Secretary, and Captain Anthony Eden, Undersecretary for Foreign Affairs.

WITH the announcement by Secretary of War Dern that the administration proposes to press for Senate ratification of the St. Lawrence treaty with Canada, the great joint waterway and power project again comes into the spotlight.

GREENWICH, Conn., Sept. 23. -- Carleton H. Palmer's Rond du Roi won the Connecticut Cup, feature of the third annual races of the adjacent Hunts Racing Association today. The meeting was held under the auspices of the Fairfield and Westchester Hunts, on the estate of the late John W. Sterling.

TORONTO. ABOUT one thousand buffaloes are finding new grazing ground this year as the surplus of Canada's increasing buffalo herds at Wainwright, Alberta, are moved north-ward to the larger preserve in the Northwest Territories.

GENEVA, Sept. 23. -- Concentration of attention on the army, and especially the German, aspects of disarmament control which the Paris talks have encouraged, appears here to have led to overlooking the naval significance of the British joining the United States in agreement with France on this principle.

OKLAHOMA CITY, Sept. 23 (AP). -- Unprecedented rulings by Federal Judge Edgar S. Vaught today swept aside demurrers of nine defendants in the Charles F. Urschel kidnapping conspiracy trial, won freedom for one man and a deferred judgment for two others.

WILLIAMSBURG, Va., Sept. 23. -- William and Mary easily defeated the Randolph-Macon eleven today, 12 to 0, making it two straight in the present season. The Indians scored in the second and third quarters, after a shaky start.
BALTIMORE, Md., Sept. 23. -- Baltimore University inaugurated the 1933 football season today, overwhelming a visiting Montclair Teachers' eleven, 25 to 0.

PARIS, Sept. 23. -- Pierre Cot, the French Air Minister, returned to Paris last night from his propaganda tour in Soviet Russia. While French and Soviet officials are negotiating a new trade treaty here, M. Cot made a flying visit to Moscow in one of the latest types of three-engined planes used by the government-controlled commercial air lines.

PEIPING, China, Aug. 22. -- The millions of dollars invested in China by the Rockefeller Foundation in an effort to spread the benefits of modern medicine and to raise, thereby, the level of public health, are beginning to bring substantial results.
COMMACK, L.I., Sept. 23. -- Miss Judy Johnson, noted Long Island rider, was the star of the racing meeting staged today by the Northport Post of the American Legion.

OYSTER BAY, L.I., Sept. 23. -- Yachtsmen from the Royal Norfolk and Suffolk Yacht Club in England defeated Long Island Sound skippers today in the final race of the international dinghy series at the Seawanhaka Corinthian Club. It was the English team's fourth victory in six contests.

Seven Gold Cup speed boats have been entered for the President's Cup race on the Potomac River at Washington this week and eight may start. The regatta in connecnection with the big Fall event will include contests for all types of craft, and include those for women drivers.

Confident of the support of the Roosevelt administration and Postmaster General James A. Farley, sponsors of the movement to launch Joseph V. McKee, former Aldermanic President, as an independent Democratic candidate for Mayor made considerable progress yesterday in organizing support for him.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 (AP). -- The States and the expert commodity distributers were called upon today by the Federal Relief Administration to assist in getting help to the destitute both at home and afield.
COLORADO SPRINGS, Col., Sept. 23. -- Football hag been discarded for rodeo sports at the Cheyenne School here. Bucking horses and some wild steers will provide the fun.

LONDON, Sept. 23 (AP). -- Portsmouth and the Blackburn Rovers led in the English League, First Division, today as many of the favorites dropped decisions to rival teams. Portsmouth's 1-0 victory over Sheffield United and the Rovers' 3-1 defeat of Sheffield Wednesday left the two winners tied for first place, each with nine points.

PETERBORO, N.H., Sept. 23 (AP). -- John Lawrence Mauran of St. Louis, internationally known architect, died in a hospital here early today at the age of 67. Dr. Ronald M. Clark said Mr. Mauran's death was caused by peritonitis, which developed after an emergency operation, performed last Sunday.

ALBANY, Sept. 23. -- Designation of Justice Edward J. Glennon of the Bronx as an associate justice of the Appellate Division, First Department, to succeed the late Henry L. Sherman, was announced today by Governor Lehman.

FAR HILLS, N.J., Sept. 23. -- For the sixteenth time in his brief span of four years in the show ring. Champion Benson of Crombie was named best-in-show today. The white-and-liver pointed dog, an importation of the Giralda Farms of Mrs. M. Hartley Dodge of Madison, N.J., gained the highest honors at the annual exhibition of the Somerset Hills Kennel Club, held on the fair grounds in this town.

HAVANA, Sept. 23. -- With sporad- ic uprisings in various parts of the island and labor difficulties be- coming more alarming, the student government today faced the pros- pects of holding control by the force of arms alone. While the students believe the army is in com- plete accord with the administra- tion, some friction has developed and many believe this may lead to a complete change of government.

A collection of thirty-six stones and other minerals mentioned in the Bible and of the varieties used by the ancient Hebrews to adorn liturgical vestments has been added to the geology department exhibit at Hunter College, it was announced yesterday.

A code fixing a 32-hour week, a minimum wage of $18 a week and a maximum of $40, was adopted by the Fountain Pen and Mechanical Pen Workers and Gold Pen Makers' Union, Local 1790, affiliated with the A.F. of L., at a meeting yesterday at the Queens County Labor Lyceum, Forest and Putnam Avenues, Ridgewood, Queens.

Charges have been made that the Federal Government's vast program of public works has been held up by red tape and timidity. In a statement published yesterday and in an article published in the Feature Section of THE TIMES today, Mr. ICKES replies to such criticism.

President ROOSEVELT'S curt refusal to discuss its fiat-money proposals with the inflationist "cotton committee" was a fairly broad hint of the Administration's attitude. The broadcasting of their purposes in advance last week by this and similar bodies has accomplished nothing except to arouse financial misgiving, accelerate the flight of capital and provide a few days of rich opportunity for professional speculators in the currency and on the markets.

There is no difficulty at all in being sardonic about the circumstances under which the annual meeting of the Assembly of the League of Nations opens tomorrow. The League has a year's record of defeat and disappointment to look back upon. Japan capped a policy of open defiance by withdrawing from the organization.

THERE are some men in whom continual contact with old books kindles a rare kind of warmth and gentleness, a quality that smells neither of the lamp nor of commerce. Of course they are affected in this way only because of a native capacity to expand and ripen in the pursuit of the amenities that go with good literary company.
PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 23. -- The Philadelphia truck drivers' strike, which kept 12,000 drivers, helpers and loaders idle for a week, was ended tonight with the aid of Federal mediators.
