BOSTON, Sept. 23. -- The alleged discovery that a high official of the Federal National Bank chain profited to the extent of $500,000 by exchange of worthless stock for funds of the bank, was made known here today, following the recent indictment of four hank presidents and a treasurer for misapplication and abstraction of bank funds totalling close to $2,000,000.

LEIPZIG, Sept. 23. -- The National Socialist regime in Germany, which before its own Supreme Court yesterday found it necessary to defend itself against charges raised by representatives of Western democracy in connection with the Reichstag arson trial, was exposed to fire from another quarter today, that of the revolutionary communism of the East.

IN recent months motorists have begun to notice crank-case oil displayed and sold in sealed, quart-size tin cans. Those who have asked the reason for this innovation have been told that the answer lies in bootlegging rather than in ballyhoo.

In anticipation of a general strike tomorrow of drivers and helpers employed by the coal companies of New York City, Chief Inspector John O'Brien ordered the police throughout the city yesterday to be prepared to give protection to coal trucks.

BERKELEY, Calif., Sept. 23. -- Striking fast when a break of the game put them in possession of the ball twenty yards from the goal, Santa Clara's Broncos scored a 7-0 victory over California's Bears today to start the season on its way here with an upset.

CONVENT, N.J., Sept. 23. -- Sayre MacLeod Jr. of Morris County retained his honors in the Morris County Club's annual weekend golf tournament today by defeating Eugene V. Homans of Englewood in the final, 4 and 3.

OMAHA, Sept. 21. -- There are impatient voices in the Corn Belt which still clamor for a miracle, the miracle of immediate and complete restoration of farm prices to a profitpaying level. They are so convinced of the simplicity and ease of such a miracle that they furnish specifications for its performance, chief of which are greenback currency inflation and arbitrary price fixing.

MOSCOW, Sept. 23 (AP). -- After more than two weeks of postponement because of bad weather, orders were issued at the Moscow military airdrome tonight to prepare the Red Army's stratosphere balloon, the U.S.S.R., for a takeoff at dawn tomorrow.

Instead of the colossal bluff which New York City's political leaders thought it was, the threat to remove the stock market is actually being carried out, with the prospect that the whole elaborate system of security trading will have been transplanted within two or three months. As matters stand today, nothing short of the abandonment of the municipality's tax plan can prevent the removal.

A plot to kidnap a niece of Russell C. Leffingwell, a partner of J.P. Morgan and former Assistant Secretary of the Treasury, was frustrated yesterday by Department of Justice agents and the police of Yonkers, N.Y.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23. -- National Recovery Administration officials redoubled their efforts today to settle the controversy revolving around the price-control features of the fair competition code for the retail trade, in order to get this important document to President Roosevelt as soon as possible.

LARAMIE, Wyo., Sept. 21. -- Drought is causing cattlemen considerable concern as the grazing season on the open ranges comes to an end. General feed conditions in many Western areas are described by government agricultural officials as "the worst in thirty years."

CHICAGO, Sept. 23. -- Startling overnight developments in Washington which the trade and the public construed as bullish on grains brought in a rush of small buying orders today on the Board of Trade and it was not until wheat had advanced more than 3 cents from yesterday's finish and corn 2 3/4 cents that the upturn was checked.

BERLIN, Aug. 27, 1933. MORE important by far than the recent festivals at Baireuth and Munich -- more important, indeed, than almost any musical happening in Germany these past two years, is the appearance from the press of Max Hesse of the fourth and last volume of Adolf Lorenz's monumental and altogether epoch-making work, "Das Geheimnis der Form bei Richard Wagner" ("The Secret of Form in Richard Wagner").

LA PAZ, Bolivia, Sept. 23. -- The Bolivian Government has definitely accepted the proposal of Argentina, Brazil, Chile and Peru for a settlement of the Chaco dispute, with certain modifications it had asked of the document originally presented to it and suggestions by the Brazilian Foreign Office.

DURING the past few years we have been hearing a good deal about Bali, the "Enchanted Isle," as Helen Eva Yates calls it in her very pleasant account of her visit to this last earthly Paradise, which an all but perfect climate and great natural beauty, richness of soil and scarcity of machinery have developed into a sort of Elysian fields.

WHENEVER a book on criticism is published every critic who is in his right mind rushes to the bookstalls to buy it. Books on criticism are written for critics. It is difficult to imagine why any one else, except the academicians, should bother with these discussions of esthetics and trade mechanics.

The World War Memorial Grove will be dedicated in Pelham Bay Park, the Bronx, this afternoon. It is expected that 500,000 persons will attend the ceremonies. Prior to the dedication a parade of members of military, veteran, civic, fraternal and patriotic organizations will converge upon the grove from three directions.
Manhattan College opened the football season in the metropolitan district yeserday by turning back a game St. Bonaventure eleven at Ebbets Field, 6 to 0.

EVER popular is the so-called "theme" exhibition. In last few seasons we have had quite a variety of gallery and museum offerings of this nature. Oddly enough, when related to art exhibitions tie word "theme" bears connotations vaguely dissimilar to those that attend the use of the word in the realm of the novel.
Jim McEvoy's secret came out yesterday.

WESTBURY, L.I., Sept. 23. -- With a stirring rally in the last period, Greentree took the first game of the National Open polo championship by defeating Templeton before a crowd of 4,500 on International Field at the Meadow Brook Club today.

BALTIMORE, Sept. 23. -- Strong opposition to the Prince plan of consolidation of railroads, which would divert the Baltimore Ohio Railroad's through traffic, freight and passenger, to the Pennsylvania Railroad, was expressed today by Daniel Willard, president of the B. O.

PHILADELPHIA, Pa., Sept. 23. -- Impelled by a slump in church finances, the Presbyterian General Council is launching throughout the country a "spiritual recovery crusade," aimed at enrolling church members who will pledge "personal service and enlarged giving."

PORTLAND, Ore., Sept. 21. -- Taxation for relief work and liquor control are the two major items on the agenda for the special session of the Oregon Legislature, to be called by Governor Julius L. Meier late in October. Both items are troublesome, but it is forecast by observers they will not be the only source of annoyance.
HONGKONG, China, Sept. 23 (AP). -- General Chen Chiung-min, one of the most famous Southern Chinese military leaders of the republican period, died today at the age of 58.

IN New York City's financial crisis we naturally turn for suggestions to the older cities of Europe which have already given us so much inspiration in the fields of constitutional law, art and architecture. It is not necessary for us to turn to European cities in great humility, because there are many features of our city government which Europe might well copy with benefit.

PARIS, Sept. 21. -- On festive evenings in Biarritz fashionable women wear two large fresh roses near the throat of their high-necked gowns or they place bouquets of tiny natural flowers at their waistline.

Impetus to the movement for an eight-hour day for nurses, without added cost to the patient, is expected to result from the annual convention of the New York State Nurses' Association at Rochester from Oct. 17 to 19, it was said yesterday at the headquarters of the organization, 450 Seventh Avenue.
Following is the statistical comparison of the Labor Bureau's monthly average of wholesale prices in the United States for August, as submitted last week. The average of 1926 is taken as 100:

Visitors at the radio-electrical show in Madison Square Garden caused more than one manufacturer's representative yesterday to forget his doubts about the return of prosperity and marvel at the apparent eagerness of people to learn all about the new set models and place orders for merchandise.
MINEOLA, L.I., Sept. 23. -- Breaking 99 out of 100 targets, J.H. Wantling captured the seventh annual Long Island trapshooting championship at the Nassau Trapshooting Club today.

While the so-called price-fixing provisions at the revised retail code continued to draw heavy fire, sentiment favorable to the adoption of the pact as released on Wednesday by A.D. Whiteside, deputy NRA administrator, had reached a high point in retail quarters at the end of the week.

LOUISVILLE, Sept. 21. -- Continued shipment of fine old whiskies from Kentucky and the establishment of a southern branch of a New York distillery company in Frankfort, were the week's outstanding development as the end of prohibition nears.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Sept. 23. -- The Harvard Corporation has elected A. Lawrence Lowell, retiring president of the university, a senior fellow in the newly created Society of Fellows and also an honorary associate of the Seven Houses in the Harvard House Plan.

So far as the stock market was concerned yesterday, speculators were unable to go the full way with traders in cotton, wheat and other commodities. While impressed with the possibilities involved in the government's more aggressive price-inflation undertakings, cautious traders had in mind, no doubt, the extent to which they had plunged on the prospect of a change in monetary policy.
STORRS, Conn., Sept. 23. -- Connecticut State outplayed Cooper Union to defeat the New York team 19 to 6, in the opening contest for both elevens today.

TO any one who knows Cornwall this book will be welcome as a source of information on its history and its past and present customs. The tourist who has not penetrated into this corner of England will realize that he has missed much.
William Woodward's Dominus, a 3-year-old son of Stimulus, was first yesterday at the end of the mile of the Bay Shore Handicap, which featured the racing program at Aqueduct.

The recovery in bond prices on the Stock Exchange, which began on Friday, gained momentum yesterday when all classifications of loans averaged higher. Trading was active for a Saturday, amounting to $6,211,000, compared with $5,460,000 on the previous Saturday.
NASHVILLE, Tenn., Sept. 23. -- Four Vanderbilt sophomore backs scored a total of eight touchdowns to defeat Cumberland University, 50 to 0, in the season's opening game today.

Seemingly stirred by recent political developments, including the prospect of the independent candidacy of Joseph V. McKee, Fiorello H. LaGuardia, fusion candidate for Mayor, has changed his plans and will begin speaking a week ahead of his original schedule.

The larger banks in this city are strongly opposed to the suggestion of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation that they should lead the way in selling preferred shares of their institutions to the government.

WASHINGTON. AT the present time there are 3,530,000 families receiving relief from public funds in the United States. While the number is large, it represents a decline of 1,000,000 from the 4,530,000 families who were receiving relief last March.

JOHANNESBURG, Aug. 21. -- Serious complications may develop from conversations initiated recently by Germany with the South African Department of External Affairs. Some say that the conversations have already given place to representations of protests.

John J. Bennett Jr., State Attorney General, received and took under advisement yesterday a request by Paul Blanshard, executive director of the City Affairs Committee, that a tripartisan group of attorneys investigate and prosecute election-law violations.

CHICAGO, Sept. 23. -- George (Machine Gun) Kelly, desperado of the Southwest, was identified today as the purchaser of the automobile used and abandoned by five machine-gunners who seized a mail consignment of the Chicago Federal Reserve Bank early yesterday morning, and killed a policeman making their escape.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23. -- Action on many applications for permits to import whisky and other liquors from abroad because of the rapidly increasing prices for medicinal liquors may be taken by the Treasury next week. Dr. James M. Doran, chief of the Industrial Alcohol Bureau, also disclosed today that a decision as to increasing the year's quota of domestic whisky manufacture will be made soon.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Sept. 23. -- Yale's development in closing its first full week of preliminary football practice was today pronounced further advanced than that of any recent Blue squad. The line-up is practically settled, in spite of the need to pick eight new members of the eleven.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23. -- President Roosevelt during the past week met the first rumblings of discontent toward his program for industrial and agricultural recovery with a bold display of his intentions to see it through, whatever the effort required of the Federal Government.

ALEXANDRIA, Egypt, Sept. 23. -- Despite the feeling of tension that has been apparent for some weeks past, Egypt has received the news of Premier Sidky Pasha's resignation calmly. The Opposition press ostentatiously "thanks God for deliverance," but forewarns that another Sidky Pasha will be found to "tyrannize" over the nation.

THE missing skull of a long dead African chieftain, which became a veritable bone of contention under the Versailles treaty and has -- in absentia -- been recurrently in the limelight for fifteen years, has come into the news again.

BOSTON, Sept. 22. CONSERVATION being one of the most conspicuous of Yankee traits, the new season in Boston has opened cautiously, to broaden out on a well-established base as belated vacationists return to their homes and the schools and colleges, which supply a substantial part of the theatre public here, reopen.
LONDON, Sept. 23. -- Many articles on European war fears will appear in the newspapers here tomorrow.

FINANCING its program for the future is one of the most important problems that public education faces today. The extent of this program has been determined not entirely by educators but by public demand for a broader concept of the meaning of public education and by the new social and economic order.

The program of activities of the Child Study Association of America for 1933-34 is ready for distribution, the association announces. It will be mailed on request to the association, 221 West Fifty-seventh St.

WHITEMARSH, Pa., Sept. 23. -- Mrs. John Hay Whitney of New York and Upperville, Va., made a clean sweep in the hunter classes at the Wissahickon Farm horse show today. Riding The Grey Knight, she carried off the champion hunter challenge trophy.

MANILA, Aug. 23. -- The "Buy Philippine" movement has taken a new lease on life. Divorced, largely, from politics and working through definite distributive factors rather than through an oratorical campaign, it seems to have a better chance of success than when it was initiated two years ago.
Promotions, effective Jan. 1, for seventeen members of the faculty of City College were announced on Friday.

LONDON, Sept. 22. -- Through channels of previous reliability details of a supposed German scheme to crush France have now reached London and Paris. Publicity is given to the reports as a means of balking any such plan.

THE author of these four short stories was not a prolific writer, yet at his untimely death, in 1930, he had already won for himself a distinguished place in Italian letters both as a novelist and as a short-story writer.
LOS ANGELES, Sept. 23. -- Frederick J. Perry, the national champion, retained his Pacific Southwest tennis championship today by defeating Jiro Satoh, Japanese star, at his own game.

OMAHA, Sept. 21. -- New Yorkers who have had their sleep disturbed by a crescendo of decibels have something to learn about night noises If they have never lived on the route to the Omaha stock yards.

THE death this month of Charles Adams Platt deprives us of not only a notable architect but an artist of the highest distinction in all the forms of art essayed by him. He was an etcher and a painter before he was an architect.

As "Religious Education Week" begins today many clergymen will preach on the duty of training children. In several pulpits a prominent layman will speak for five minutes on "What Christianity Means to Me." This is at the request of the Sunday School Superintendents Union.

CHICAGO, Sept. 23. -- Replying to critics and picturing the government as the most liberal money lender in world history, Secretary Ickes tonight urged that American cities help end the depression by participating more fully in the $3,300,000,000 public works program, of which he is administrator.

TO counteract possible imputations that "S.O.S. Iceberg," which now is on exhibition at the Criterion, was made in Hollywood, Universal has prepared a modest history of the production. Admitting at the outset that some of the incidents were dramatized.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Sept. 23 (AP). -- No one need worry lest he have too few prejudices, James Bryant Conant, new president of Harvard University, told freshmen entering Harvard College today.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., Sept. 23. -- With the last of the season's championship regattas of the Yacht Racing Association of Long Island Sound held today by the Manhasset Bay Yacht Club, Horace Havemeyer's 12-meter sloop Mouette loomed as the probable winner for another year of her class title.

A NETWORK of twelve stations along the Atlantic seaboard, and possibly seven others in New England, are scheduled to broadcast the first program of the Amalgamated Broadcasting System, known as Ed Wynn's network.

The threatened loss of revenue to the city and State of New York, on the one hand, and the possible temporary disruption of a world's securities market incident to its partial removal from the City of New York, on the other, if the special municipal tax measures should be enacted into law, amply justify the most deliberate and calculating exercise of judgment and foresight on the part of both parties to the controversy.

The National Recovery Administration in Washington is studying the operations of the NBA credit committee established at the Hotel Pennsylvania here by the Clearing House Association, it was announced yesterday by Grover A. Whalen, city chairman.

VIENNA, Sept. 22. -- Three Foreign Ministers of the Little Entente will meet at Sinaia Monday, while near-by in the castle at Pelesch, King Carol of Rumania and King Alexander of Yugoslavia will confer, probably about the same subjects as seen from the dynastic, rather than the statesman's, angle.

DOES a low automobile license number mean anything? Does it serve any purpose other than to satisfy the owner's craving for ostentation and display? Does it possess some subtle power which soothes the ruffled spirit of patrolmen and closes their eyes to minor traffic infractions?

BUFFALO, Sept. 23. -- Hiker Joy, former Fordham coach, made his debut today as Canisius College mentor. Canisius piled up a 39-to-0 victory over Albion College, after having a 6-to-0 advantage at the half.

Dr. Thomas Darlington, former Commissioner of Health and Grand Sachem of Tammany Hall, is 75 years old today. He is passing the anniversary in quiet and seclusion at the wilderness camp he gave to his children for a playground years ago, near Forestburg, in Sullivan County, N.Y.

PEIPING, Aug. 24. -- The high-rolling, rollicking days of the 500 American Marines who constitute the legation guard here have been cut short by the deflation of the dollar and a 15 per cent pay cut. Measured in terms of local currency, the income of the marines is today 40 per cent less than it was a few months ago.

THE American nation, which has deified work and looked with suspicion upon leisure for the masses, has in its search for economic recovery suddenly faced about and granted the boon of greater leisure to its toiling millions. Almost overnight the dreams of working men and women for shorter hours of labor have been turned into reality.
NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 23. -- One of the larger dinners tonight was that given by Princess Miguel de Braganza, who had forty guests at her home, the Moorings.

Enactment of the National Industrial Recovery Act doomed the trade association of the type which has been in existence in this country for the last decade to early extinction, A.F. Allison, secretary of the International Association of Garment Manufacturers, said here yesterday.

PARIS, Sept. 23. -- As in all recent currency trading, particularly in dollars, the market is completely dominated by professional speculators. No longer does the man in the street here figure in dollar trading.

BERLIN, Sept. 23. -- Discriminatory measures against Jews are being enacted remorselessly In an ever-widening radius. Thus it is now announced that the nationwide organization created by General Hermann Wilhelm Goering as Aviation Minister to train the German civilian populace for defense against air attacks will not admit Jews to membership.

MINEOLA, L.I., Sept. 23. -- Bob Sall Paterson, N.J., auto race star, today duplicated his victory of last year when he captured the fifteenmile feature of the Mineola Fair auto races. He finished half a lap ahead of Chester Gardner. Long Beach, Calif. Maynard Clark, midWestern champion, was third.

IN the South Pacific is a little group of islands called the Gam biers. On one of these, Manga Reva, Mr. Eskridge, the artist who wrote this book, spent six months painting pictures, and there he made friends with two native children, a boy and a girl, named Yo and Ti.

LONDON, Sept. 23. -- Bernard Shaw today explained why he sent a "peppery" postcard to the World Committee for Relief of the Victims of German Fascism, stating that they had no right to interfere in the Leipzig trial of several Communists accused of setting fire to the Reichstag Building, as the prisoners were not British.

Germany, despite an expected substantial decline in national income from world trade for 1933 and consequent greatly reduced supply of foreign exchange, should be able to meet in full her actual foreign debt service requirements this year, according to an analysis of official German Government trade figures by the National Industrial Conference Board.

Little change appeared last week in the general economic situation in the country. Reports from leading centres indicated that in several places some of the declines of the preceding week had been counteracted by improvement, although in other parts activity continued to drop slightly.

THE white moth takes to the closing bine, the bee to the opened clover, and within the next few weeks the Civic Repertory company, with Eva Le Gallienne in the van, will take to the open road. It may be that the gypsy blood is calling or the faintest suggestion of a whisper has come rustling down the field.

To the Editor of The New York Times: At one time, we are told, the gangster was the agent who provided harvest laborers when the farmers of a locality were in need of helpers to house crops ready to be garnered.

IN keeping with his proved enthusiasm for air travel, the Prince of Wales has added a new twin-engined Vickers Viastra monoplane to his stable of aircraft. The new plane, which makes the fourth owned by the Prince, is a modified form of the liners now operating in Australia.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Sept. 22. -- Statistics as a possible means of relief for cotton farmers are suggested by State Senator Shelby Fletcher, who is an important North Alabama cotton grower and mill operator.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., Sept. 21. -- 01' man river may keep rolling along for centuries but an era of transformation has come for the historical stream, borne on the wings of the Blue Eagle. The glamorous days are gone. In the near future the Mississippi will be harnessed and made to serve a dual role of medium for transportation and medium for water power.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Sept. 23. -- The Diario de Noticias editorially says the Cuban situation is hourly growing worse, "placing the United States between the devil and the deep sea."

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Sept. 23. -- White Plains, scene of the naming of the State of New York and of the Battle of White Plains, a relatively small engagement which marked the turning point in the fortunes of American revolutionary forces, will celebrate the 250th anniversary of its purchase from the Indians on Wednesday.

MEXICO, D.F., Sept. 23. -- Four of Mexico's leading agitators against the government were killed last night when the Guadalajara city police broke up a meeting at which more than fifty persons were said to have been plotting a subversive movement.

ARCOLA, N.J., Sept. 23. -- Charles G. Clare of Race Brook, Conn., today captured the fifteenth Arcola Country Club invitation in the longest match ever played for that honor, defeating Tommy Goodwin of Monroe, N.Y., 1 up. twenty-four holes.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 (AP). -- Postmaster General Farley announced that an investigation had disclosed some fourth-class post masters were increasing their compensation by personally swelling the mail at their offices.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 (AP). -- Cotton of this year's crop ginned prior to Sept. 16 was reported today by the Census Bureau to have totaled 3,100,701 running bales, including 84,347 round bales, counted as half bales, and sixty-three bales of American-Egyptian.

PRINCETON, N.J., Sept. 23. -- When Princeton University officially opens its 187th year Tuesday it will be starting on the administration of its fifteenth president, aided by other new administrative officers who also will begin active work.

THIS is Mr. Gowen's second novel. It emerges from the same background as his first. "Mountain Born," a regional novel of the Tennessee hill country. Gowen's groundwork is realistic; he does not shy away from the truth in representation, from facts however ugly, raw or tragic.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 21. -- Wet California'a enthusiasm for repeal has been greatly dampened by the discovery that the fading out of the Eighteenth Amendment will be far from assurance of the immediate reappearance of the happy days whose return was so lustily sung when the State voted overwhelmingly to end national prohibition.
HAVANA, Sept. 23. -- The tense situation that developed here following the arrival of United States warships seems to have abated.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23. -- Industrial activity was at a slightly higher rate in the week ended on Sept. 16 following the holiday week, but there was no change in the trend of the seasonal adjusted indexes which were moderately lower in some instances, the Department of Commerce reported today in its weekly business survey.

BARBARY has been subdued again. Correspondents with the French forces report that this time it is final. Berbers in the Atlas Mountains, their last retreat, have slain beeves before the armies and "brought in roast meats" -- in token of utter submission.

THOUGH Kathleen Norris has never lacked versatility, as her twoscore novels amply attest, she has seldom written a story which departs so notably from her familiar manner as does "The Angel in the House." In the main, the departure is a happy one.

MADRID. THE flag of the second Spanish Republic is yellow, red and purple. And, because it turns out that purple bunting and purple paper and even purple ink fade rapidly to all shades of dirty violet, bold wits remark that nobody knows what color the Republic really is.

Cooler weather has undoubtedly helped to bring about a definite pick-up in retail trade, according to the market report prepared especially for THE TIMES by Kirby, Block Fischer. The confusion due to impaired deliveries of women's apparel and accessories has dwindled since the settling of the recent strikes, the buying office notes.

A bronze memorial plaque to Colonel John R. Slattery was unveiled yesterday in Pennsylvania Station within sound of the Eighth Avenue subway line, whose engineering work he directed. Colonel Slattery died a year ago yesterday.

BOSTON, Sept. 21. -- New England considers education a major industry. The statistics collected and analyzed by Boston University a few years ago showed conclusively that when the community economic value of the colleges and universities, the academies and seminaries, which are scattered over these six States, is reckoned up in all its ramifications, it represents an investment from which millions in dividends are realized every year.

Sir Hugo Cunliffe-Owen, chairman of the British-American Tobacco Company, is due to arrive today from England on the North German Lloyd liner Europa. Among others coming from Channel ports On the liner are Mrs. Vincent Astor, Mr. and Mrs. John McCormack, Ina Claire, Diana Wynward, O.E. Hunt, Mr. and Mrs. Frederick H. Bedford, Professor and Mrs. Robert M. Hutchins, Martin Conboy, Dr. Frederick Stock, and also:

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23. -- The Federal Trade Commission today announced a new rule defining the powers conferred upon the person designated in securities registration statements as authorized to receive communications from the commission regarding such securities.

The supporters of Chase Mellen Jr., asserting they elected 1,599 of the 2,964 members of the Republican County Committee at the primary election, made known yesterday the names of the persons they have chosen to be leaders of the districts in which they defeated Samuel S. Koenig's supporters.
GENEVA. SERENELY unaware that the "era of conferences has ended," there opens here on Sept. 25 another world conference, the Assembly of the fiftyseven member States of the League of Nations.

BERLIN, Sept. 23. -- On the eve of his departure for Geneva as a member of the German delegation to the disarmament conference, Dr. Joseph Paul Goebbels, Minister of Propaganda and Public Enlightenment, sounded a conciliatory and optimistic note.

IN reporting an estimated decline in the gross revenue from State gasoline taxes for the first six months of 1933, as compared with the same period of last year, the American Petroleum Industries Committee also notes a reduction in the registration of motor vehicles.

MILAN, Sept. 7, 1933. IT is reported in the Italian press that, of the three Italian novelties billed for La Scala this season, one will be Respighi's "La Fiamma" (which, it is understood, the Metropolitan contracted for and then canceled).
BOSTON, Sept. 23 (AP). -- Coaled and provisioned, the staunch Bear of Oakland was awaiting tonight the command to head for Little America and the enduring ice of the Antarctic.

BERLIN, Sept. 23. -- Chancellor Adolf Hitler flew to Frankfurt-amMain this morning to turn a shovelful of earth at the ceremonial opening of construction work on the new motor high-way from Frankfurt-am-Main to Heidelburg. His flying record thereby passes 31,500 miles.

ROME, Sept. 23. -- The Italian Government is reported to have interposed its good offices to bring about an accord between the Vatican and Soviet Russia and contacts between the Holy See and Moscow are said to have taken place recently.
REPEAL is just around the corner, and Mr. and Mrs. Probono Publico are wondering what the State is going to do about the flow of honest hard liquor that will set in when prohibition goes out.

Manufacturers of all types of machinery are enjoying a sharp increase in the demand for their products from a score of industries at present. Leading the list are the builders of machine tools, who handled more than 400 per cent more business last month than they did in March.

WASHINGTON. IF sheer intelligence is to be of any aid in solving the problems facing the National Recovery Administration, that organization apparently has plenty of the right kind of help. The Division of Economic Research and Planning, which has the task of supplying General Johnson and his aides with cold, clear facts about the industries rushing in to present codes, was recently submitted to an intelligence test and emerged with flying colors.

Ninety-three new organizations of voluntary chain grocery stores were established throughout the country in the last fifteen months, according to a survey made by the American Institute of Food Distribution and issued yesterday. The number of independently owned retail grocery stores now linked up in voluntary chains, the survey shows, is 90,787.
Five Archbishops and more than thirty-five Bishops will attend the nineteenth meeting of the National Conference of Catholic Charities from Oct. 1 to 4.

ATLANTA, Sept. 21. -- In a concise statement, emphasized by the thud of his fist, Colonel H.N. Waite, Deputy Administrator of Public Works, notified representatives of the advisory boards of five Southern States yesterday that the minimum wage was obligatory and applied to both whites and Negroes.

FASHION is looking backward. Yes, she is making your exit from a room as thrilling as your entrance. It is her most modern gesture. The front of your dress may be sauve and smooth, the back exciting and full of movement.
MADRID, Sept. 22. -- The only news in Spain this week was a military revolt that did not take place.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., Sept. 23. -- William T. Timmons, president of the Electrotypers and Stereotypers Association of New York, and regarded by his associates as the best electrotype finisher in the country, died here this morning at his home, 130 Gates Avenue, after an illness of six months.

To the Editor of The New York Times: It is accepted by every financier and economist that the foundation upon which our business recovery must be laid is a safe and sound banking system. Almost every banker will agree that we must not return to the arrangement that existed prior to and during the depression.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 (AP). -- An appeal to workers throughout the nation to submit their troubles to the National Labor Board before resorting to strike was made today by its chairman, Senator Wagner of New York.

DETROIT, Sept. 23 (AP). -- Explaining that he felt somebody else should have a chance to see what he could do with the Detroit Tigers, Stanley R. (Bucky) Harris today submitted his resignation to Frank J. Navin, the club's president.

AN alumnus graduated before this recent sea of troubles broke over the colleges gave me his first impressions of the campus. He was in no sense a pampered youth; he had in large part earned his way. He had expected that for him college would mean hard work.

With all its components showing declines, the weekly business index of THE NEW YORK TIMES for the week ended Sept. 16 has dropped to 78.4 from 79.8. The number was 66.7 in the week ended Sept. 17, 1932.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23. -- Discussions of reciprocal trade agreements with Colombia, Brazil and Portugal will be started within a few days, it was announced at the State Department today. For the present, Jefferson Caffery, Assistant Secretary of State, will conduct the conversations with the foreign negotiators.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 23. -- The value of the contracts awarded by the Navy Department on account of new naval vessels to be built out of the $328,000,000 public works allocation is $21,429,438.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 (AP). -- Still watchful for the protection of Americans in troubled Cuban spots to the east of Havana, officials here appeared encouraged tonight over the reported possibility of an early political compromise.

NYACK, N.Y., Sept. 23. -- Justice Arthur S. Tompkins of the Appellate Division presided at a clambake at his home here tonight at which former Justice Albert H.F. Seeger of the Appellate Division received the sympathy of prominent members of the bar and judiciary who had attended the Judges' Trotting Classic at the Orangeburg track this afternoon.

THE public works program is successfully launched. Men throughout the country are finding employment in worth-while work financed by the Federal Emergency Administration of Public Works. This direct-action phase of President Roosevelt's national recovery program has already loosed its power at the top.

BOSTON, Sept. 23. -- The Yankees and Red Sox went through a comedy baseball skit at Fenway Park today before some 4,000 fans. It ended with victory perching on the Yankee banner, 16 to 12, as dusk was falling.

MOSCOW, Sept. 23. -- When Colonel Charles A. Lindbergh made his historic flight to Paris, the only account of the exploit in the Soviet press was a four-line item without a caption three days later in an afternoon newspaper. Subsequently, there appeared ironic verses by "the Red poet laureate," Demyan Byedny, about "bourgeois stunts and sensationalism."

PEIPING, Sept. 4. -- Although the withdrawal of the Japanese main force from Hopel Province and the evacuation of Chahar Province by the malcontent General, Feng Yuhsiang, have clarified two of the most difficult situations facing the Chinese authorities in North China, there remain numerous other problems to be solved.
The program of the United States women's senior golf championship has been completed. The tenth annual tourney will be held at the Westchester Country Club, Rye, N.Y., on Oct. 5 and 6.

GREENWICH, Conn., Sept. 23. -- A distinguished list of subscribers has been announced for the concert series sponsored in Greenwich by the Wednesday Singing Club. The first concert will present Lucrezia Bori, noted soprano, on Oct. 2. Other artists will be Ossio Gabrilowitsch, pianist, on Nov. 7, and Yehudi Menuhin, youthful violinist, on Jan. 8.

Three thugs fatally beat a Negro watchman, then slashed the cushions of 300 seats, smashed three motion picture projecting machines and damaged a stage curtain in the Windsor Theatre at 4,001 Fifteenth Avenue, Brooklyn, early yesterday.

PARIS, Sept. 16. -- The building into which the American Embassy and Consulate and affiliated government services are moving is the most palatial and luxurious American foreign service building in the world. Contracted for in the prosperous days of 1928 by the late Ambassador Myron T. Herrick, it was planned with the idea of an everexpanding service, and at a cost possible only in that time of easily balanced budgets.

Announcement that the government would lend 10 cents a pound on the 1933 cotton crop to all growers pledging a reduction in 1934 planting in the aim to cut the area to 25,000,000 acres caused yesterday an excited market on the Cotton Exchange here.

NEWARK, N.J., Sept. 23. -- Lulu J., trotting mare owned by the Newbrook Stables and driven by Dan Knight of Morristown, won the classified trot, feature of the weekly matinee at Weequahic Park today, in straight heats.

Arthur M. Tode, national president of the Propeller Club of the United States, issued a statement yesterday strongly urging popular support of the American Merchant Marine as a vital necessity to peace-time commerce and war-time emergency.

VERY still life and statuary of the stage" was not said of Sarah Siddons. It was her brother, John Philip Kemble, who was so epitomized by Hazlitt. But all the family have been granted a marmoreal quality except Fanny, who had a mother from the Continent of Europe and was so much more (or less) than an actress.

ATLANTA, Sept. 23. -- Indignation mingled with approval and sympathy when leading professional men and others expressed opinions on the ethics of thirteen Telfair County physicians, who have banded together "not to visit any one whose name appears on the delinquent or bad-pay list except for cash in advance."

ENZYMES, hormones and vitamins figured largely in discussions at the meeting of the British Association for the Advancement of Science at Leicester, England, and also at the Century of Progress meeting of the American Chemical Society, which closed a week ago at Chicago.

GENEVA. THERE has been submitted to some of Europe's leaders for study a plan devised to harness the war debts to a world recovery program which the debts have so long helped to block. It would make the debts supply the motive force for the international extension of the NRA which the United States sought at London as an essential to its success.

DUBLIN, Sept. 22. -- Even his political opponents must have some small sympathy for President de Valera in the unenviable and difficult position his government finds itself in today. On every side difficulties are being created which are making the task of the Cabinet thankless and almost impossible.

Announcement by Joseph B. Eastman, Federal Railroad Coordinator, that he would study a plan under which the railroads would be consolidated into seven or eight systems may result in hastening plans for consolidations already pending, it was intimated yesterday in railroad circles.
CHICAGO, Sept. 23 (AP). -- Paul Derringer suffered his twenty-seventh defeat of the season today as the Chicago Cubs defeated the Cincinnati Reds, 7 to 1, in the opening game of their series.

DETROIT, Sept. 23. -- William L. Mills, publicity chairman for the NRA committee in suburban Dearborn, said tonight that steps would be taken Monday for official consideration of complaints against the Ford Motor Company, Dearborn's largest employer.

OSSINING, N.Y., Sept. 23. -- H. Russell Ryder, gaudiest of the playboys of the gaudy 1920's, walked out of Sing Sing prison today with his self-confidence and his sartorial elegance undiminished. He is not worried about a job. He announced breezily that he had offers of two positions, but he would not say what they were.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 (AP). -- The Senators, American League champions, were defeated today by the Athletics, 3 to 1. Monte Weaver held the victors to five hits, but four of these came in the sixth and seventh to net enough tallies to win.

Teachers College, Columbia University, opened its forty-eighth academic year yesterday with the beginning of the registration period. Thousands of teachers, educational workers and undergraduates representing every section of the country and many foreign nations are expected to enroll.

ON a private beach near the Belgian city of Ostend a mother and her eight children have been spending morning hours of the Summer days. The mother has Just turned 41, but her youthful features belle her age.

To the Editor of The New York Times: May I, in this way, endeavor to arrest the progress of a strange disease which seems to be spreading with alarming rapidity among our scientific intelligentsia? Unlike the average microbe which usually attacks organs already in a weakened condition, the distinguishing feature of the new virus which has sprung into life is that it develops best in the soundest minds.

PARIS, Sept. 23. -- A decree abrogating the law of 1916 prohibiting the introduction of foreign securities on French stock exchanges was promulgated today. Next week a committee of officials of the Bourse, bankers and shareholders will meet to consider applications, and from then on it is expected the Paris market will assume the international importance which its size and prestige merit.

Finding the pennant - winning Giants in a state of complete relaxation at the Polo Grounds yesterday, May Carey's sixth-place Dodgers took advantage of the situation to capture both ends of a double-header, 7 -- 4 and 3 -- 0.

An official field inspection report by the United States Army National Guard Bureau, rating the 107th (Old Seventh) Regiment, New York National Guard, "a first-class regiment in all respects," was made public yesterday by the regiment. The report was based upon inspection of the famous regiment's encampment last month at Camp Smith, Peekskill, N.Y., by regular army officers.

LONDON, Sept. 12. -- Attention is called to conditions in the German newspaper world, according to a Berlin dispatch to The London Times, by the action of one of the best-known provincial newspapers in reducing its space rate payment to contributors to the abnormally low limit of 15 pfennings a line and in reducing editorial salaries by 40 per cent.

A NEW series of Franklin Airman cars, following the "design fundamentals" of the company's twelve-cylinder line, was introduced last week. The series includes a Standard five-passenger sedan, a five-passenger Club sedan and a sedan for seven passengers.

GLEN COVE, L.I., Sept. 23. -- An extra-hole match from which Larry Lloyd of Greenwich emerged victorious was one of the high lights of the first two match-play rounds of the annual Nassau Country Club invitation golf tournament today.

Senior Judge Martin T. Manton of the United States Circuit Court of Appeals has been restrained from entering any further orders or decisions or taking any action in the Interborough receivership case until the full bench of the United States Supreme Court has disposed of the pending application by the Manhattan Railway Company to divest him of all jurisdiction in the proceedings.

Columbia University will begin its 180th academic year on Wednesday. Registration figures now indicate that the student enrolment will be about the same as that of last year, when the total in all parts of the university for the Winter session was 18,576.

LONDON. THOSE who listened to Bernard Shaw's New York lecture or who read the reports of it in the American press will find some piquant additions in the little volume in which he has now put it before the British public, as might be inferred from the last three words of its title.

CHICAGO, Sept. 24. -- Declaring hundreds of American cities were hopelessly insolvent, the Mayors' conference tonight called upon Congress for laws making it possible for them to go through bankruptcy.

RADIO styles for 1933-34 revealed at the New York Radio-Electrical Show now being staged at Madison Square Garden indicate the popular trend is toward email receiving sets, many of which get away from the conventional cabinets by featuring modernistic designs.
DALLAS, Sept. 21. -- The NRA is forcing I. Rude out of business, but he is quite cheerful about it.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23. -- Continuing a drive against wildcat land speculators in the vicinity of Muscle Shoals, the Tennessee Valley Authority revealed today that it had asked for, and wag receiving, the cooperation of the Department of Justice.

HAZLETON, Pa., Sept. 23. -- Three miners, entombed by tons of earth dropped in a shaft of a Glen Alden coal company mine at nearby Tesckow, were rescued unharmed tonight though standing in water up to their shoulders.

WELLINGTON, N.Z. ON the high western cape of the island, where Mount Egmont looks over sea and farmland, a perfect duplicate of Fujiyama, New Zealand has built a memorial to Turi, the Maori discoverer of these shores. In the Aotea, the first of the seven long canoes which tradition says arrived here 500 years ago, Turi sighted the gleaming flank of the mountain.

OUT of Los Angeles comes the report of the highest cruising speeds yet attained in a commercial air transport. Lockheed Aircraft Corporation announces its latest Orion, a singlemotored, low-wing monoplane similar in these respects to its predecessor, but with a cruising speed, according to Lloyd Stearman, president of the company of 200 miles an hour.

GENEVA, Sept. 23. -- This much background can be given to the recurrent question of American relations with the League of Nations, whose discussion in the American press this week seems to have caused some misunderstanding.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23. -- Stimulated by a continuation of the downward movement of the dollar in terms of foreign exchange, United States imports in August increased by $13,000,000 over the value of those of the preceding month, to a total of $155,000,000, according to figures made public today by the Commerce Department.
PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 23 (AP). -- The Phillies and Braves divided a double-header today, the locals winning the first game, 5 -- 4, and the visitors taking the second, also 5 to 4.

MORE favorable weather brought an upturn in retail trade last week and dispelled some of the fears which had commenced to grow concerning a buyers' strike against higher prices. The gain in volume was enough to bring local stores about even with a year ago on the average, some of them exceeding last year's figures by small percentages.

The government's proposal for a revival of the machinery of the National Credit Corporation in the form of a new corporation to make small business loans to individuals is regarded with favor by most bankers, it was indicated in Wall Street yesterday.

THE Democratic National Committee has decided to exert control over the speeches which administration leaders make over the radio, and in the future will use Herbert L. Pettey, Secretary of the Federal Radio Commission, to arrange broadcasting time for committee speakers.

ARTHUR HOYT, the cinema's prototype of Caspar Milquetoast, H.T. Webster's celebrated cartoon character, is one of Hollywood's busiest actors, but has yet to appear in a leading or featured role. Mr. Hoyt's latest picture is "Shanghai Madness," the new feature at the Seventh Avenue Roxy.
NEW YORK. John Dyneley Prince, former American Minister to Yugoslavia, and Mrs. Prince are visiting James Speyer at his country place in Scarborough-on-Hudson.

BOGOTA, Colombia, Sept. 23. -- Retail sales of imported merchandise were at a standstill here today while merchants awaited the outcome of conferences of the Exchange Control Board, the Bank of the Republic and the Minister of Finance Jaramillo in an attempt to solve the exchange problem.

NEWARK, N.J., Sept. 23 (AP). -- Thomas W. Reilly, Major in the Mexican army of Pancho Villa, soldier of fortune and former newspaper man, died last night in the Medical Centre, Jersey City, where he was taken after suffering a heart attack four days ago.

All markets pointed upward yesterday under the vigorous leadership of the principal agricultural staples. Business in the share market was of about normal Saturday proportions, but transactions in bonds were the heaviest for any Saturday since the middle of July.

An injunction suit filed yesterday to block the city's 5-cent tax on all taxicab rides disclosed that Mayor O'Brien had quietly signed that tax bill last Wednesday, and led to the dscovery that he had also signed the ordinance increasing water rates by 50 per cent.

The first performance of "The Romance of a People," the musical and dramatic pageant in which 6,200 actors will portray forty centuries of Jewish history, will be given, tonight at the Kingsbridge Armory, Jerome Avenue and Kings bridge Road, the Bronx.
GLENS FALLS, N.Y., Sept. 23 (AP). -- With Governor Herbert H. Lehman as guest of honor, Warren County today observed Governor's Day for the thirty-ninth time with a program in City Park here.

The Giants may have the National league pennant clinched, but they like to win games just the same. Against the Boston Braves yesterday the Terrymen, with nothing to gain in the flag race, staged a late uprising that enabled them to tie the count in the ninth, and then carried on in the tenth to score four runs for a 6-5 victory.
BOSTON, Sept. 24. -- Charley Devens Day at Fenway Park was far from a complete success this afternoon. Dedicating the game in honor of the ex-Harvard star, the Yankees lost to the Red Sox by 10 to 8.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., Sept. 24. -- Westbury, which made a belated entry in the national open polo championship, sprang a decided upset today at the Sands Point Club by conquering the Sands Point riders, 11 to 7, in a first-round match.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., Sept. 24. -- The Greenbrier polo team defeated the Lake Shore polo team of Derby, Buffalo, N.Y., 12 to 9, this afternoon on the Greenbrier Polo Field before 1,500 spectators. Mrs. Kenneth O'Brien of New York and Southampton, L.I., daughter of Clarence Mackay, presented the cups to the members of the winning team.

That no single factor has been responsible for the tragic decrease of waterfowl in this country and Canada is shown by a recent report of observers in Alberta, members of the Calgary Fish and Game Association.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 24. -- President Roosevelt and government financial leaders mapped out their program for credit expansion tonight at a White House conference, which centred on release of funds in closed banks.

The presidency of The American Spectator, Inc., has been accepted by Catherine McNelis of the Tower Magazine group, magazines originally established to sell only in five and ten cent stores but now reaching out for a general market. The editorial policy of The Spectator will not change.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., Sept. 24. -- Live Yankee of the Stamford Yacht Club, owned by Schuyler Gillespie and sailed by William F. Gillespie, drifted around an eleven-mile course to win the historic Childs trophy today.

The revised city plan for development of Jacob Riis Park on the Rockaway Peninsula has failed to win the approval of the landscape architects committee of the Park Association of New York City, according to a letter from A.F. Brinkerhoff, committee chairman, made public yesterday.

PARIS, Monday, Sept. 25. -- Oscar Dufrenne, Municipal Councillor for the Tenth Arrondissement of Paris and a director of several big theatres, including the Folies Bergere, was found dead early this morning in his office at the Palace Music Hall, just off the Grand Boulevards.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 24 (AP). -- The Pirates and Cardinals divided a double-header today with the same scores, 5 to 4, as Dizzy Dean increased his strike-out total by four to 198, although losing the second game.

For many years the 2-cent rate on first-class letter mail prevailed throughout the country. With the coming of hard times and the demand for new revenues the Government was persuaded to increase the rate to 3 cents. But times got harder, and some corporate critics of the higher rates took to delivering local letters themselves, with the result that revenue from first-class mail did not rise as rapidly as had been hoped.

GLEN COVE, L.I., Sept. 24. -- Eddie Driggs won the Nassau Country Club invitation golf tournament for the second year in succession by defeating Larry Lloyd of Greenwich, 2 up, in the final round today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 24. -- Seeking to encourage construction of fireproof buildings and to permit lower rentals, the Public Works Administration determined today to extend to thirty-five years the amortization period of housing loans in cases where fireproof buildings are erected after clearance of slum areas.

LONDON, Sept. 23. -- Great Britain has now completed two years off the gold standard and the period has strikingly demonstrated the extent to which gold currencies have reacted to the situation thus created. But the dollar vagaries bring the pound no nearer to reinstatement on the gold basis.

A remark about political organizations made by an experienced and sagacious public man in England has a certain appositeness for New York. He said that a party machine, while capable of doing rough things for a time, was also very delicate and easy to throw out of gear.

HAMBURG, Germany, Sept. 24. -- The "purity campaign" in the Third Reich, which would, for example, stop women from smoking or powdering their faces, has drawn a stinging rebuke from Colonel Ernst Roehm, Chief of Staff of the Hitlerite army.

Miss Helen Germaine of Manhattan, former national public parks champion, advanced to the quarter-final round as play started in the women's metropolitan public parks tennis tournament at Central Park yesterday.

HAVANA, Sept. 24. -- A strong plea for a coalition government as a means of terminating the disturbed political situation was made today by Colonel Fulgencio Batista, Army Chief of Staff, at a conference of various factions this afternoon.

NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 24. -- Mrs. Richard T. Wilson entertained a company of forty at luncheon at her home, Shady Lawn, on Narragansett Avenue, today. Miss Julia A. Berwind entertained at The Elms; Mr. and Mrs. George Henry Warren Jr. at Paulholm and Mrs. Henry Walters at Sherwood.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 (AP). -- Organized labor and publishers are not expected to meet in conference until next week to work out a recovery code for daily newspapers.

With legal difficulties threatening to upset their choice of the Centre Market Building in Newark as the site of their new trading floor, organizers of the New Jersey Stock Exchange were uncertain last night where they would locate it.

New York State should adopt a new plan of automobile compensation, similar to that now used in workmen's compensation cases, "Which would remove from the courts all personal injury litigation and create a system of compensation tribunals and insurance.

PORTSMOUTH, Ohio, Sept. 24 (AP). -- Playing beneath a sweltering sun that sent the thermometer above 90, the Portsmouth Spartans scored a 17-7 victory over the New York Giants today. A crowd at approximately 7,000 saw the National Professional Football League game.

Catching such vaunted rivals as Carl Coan and Frank Crowley out of condition, Dave Kantrowitz of the St. Anselm's A.C. won the Martin J. Sheridan Memorial Mile which featured the Round Tower A.C. track and field meet at the Brooklyn Sports Stadium yesterday.

WAYNESVILLE, N.C., Sept. 24. -- Thomas Price of South Orange, N.J., who retired this year as secretary of the Union Pacific Railway system, was shot and killed from ambush this afternoon while he was riding with two mountaineers on his 1,200-acre estate near here.

Plans are being made for the third annual Peacock Ball in aid of the tuberculosis division of the Association for Improving the Condition of the Poor. Although the date for the ball has not yet been set, it will be held in January, in the grand ballroom suite of the Waldorf-Astoria.

BUENOS AIRES, Sept. 24. -- The continued rapid decline of the dollar here has effectively put the brakes onto Argentina's exports to the United States and stopped the brisk trading which had begun under the impetus of rising prices in the United States.
Small residential properties comprised the bulk of the New Jersey realty turnover reported over the week-end.

A community service marking the close of the pastorate of eighteen years of the Rev. Dr. William Carter, author, poet, traveler and former chaplain of the National Officers Reserve Association, at the Throop Avenue Presbyterian Church, Brooklyn, was held yesterday afternoon in that edifice, Throop Avenue and Macon Street.

YORKTOWN HEIGHTS, N.Y., Sept. 24. -- The dedication of Saint Patrick's Church here today by his Eminence Patrick Cardinal Hayes, Archbishop of the Diocese of New York, was attended by 400 parishioners and about thirty members of the clergy.

A shipping code for the steamship industry will be submitted to General Hugh S. Johnson and Deputy Administrator William H. Davis in Washington this morning by J. Caldwell Jenkins, chairman of the code committee of the American Steamship Owners Association.

Miss Nicolina de Palma and James Medley, who are accused of trying to extort $10,000 from Franklin A. Batcheller of 250 Palisade Avenue, Yonkers, by threatening to kidnap his daughter, Helen, are to be turned over to the Federal authorities today.

A fundamental fault of Americans is that they have found no "scheme for making life count," the Rev. Dr. Bernard Iddings Bell, who was appointed Sept. 20 to be canon of the cathedral in Providence and preacher to university congregations, said yesterday afternoon in a sermon at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine.

There has been an encouraging subscription for the fashion show to be held in conjunction with a luncheon and dinner on Oct. 5 in the Grand Ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria for the benefit of the Social Service Auxiliary of the Metropolitan Hospital and the Emergency Tuberculosis Relief Committee.

Executives of railway companies in all sections of the country plan to meet this week to discuss a reduction of passenger fares. The present basic rate of 3.6 cents a mile has stood unchanged for thirteen years. But various experiments with lower charges have been made by different roads.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 (AP). -- New methods to keep the NRA linked closely with President Roosevelt's credit expansion plans were being studied tonight by Hugh S. Johnson, the Recovery Administrator.

LONDON, Sept. 24. -- Just after smashing the British sea-mile record with a run of 95.08 miles an hour, Hubert Scott-Paine's speedboat Miss Britain III burst into flames in Poole Harbor, Dorset, tonight and was partly destroyed.
Having tasted the joys of winning a double-header from the Giants on Saturday, the Dodgers pounced merrily upon the Phillies yesterday to take another twin bill.

Sponsors of the movement to run Joseph V. McKee, former President of the Board of Aldermen, as an independent Democratic candidate for Mayor with the backing of the Roosevelt administration, prepared yesterday to name running mates on the proposed independent ticket.

MOSCOW, Sept. 24. -- If the Soviet note to Japan on Friday was what might be described as a "calling to order," it is nothing, as far as vigor of language is concerned, to today's comment in the official press, which, as always, defines and elucidates the Kremlin's viewpoint.

Weakness in the dollar sent several commodities higher last week, although others continued to be heavy. Silver, rubber, hides, copper, tin, coffee and wool tops closed higher, while sugar and cocoa were lower. Trading was in moderate volume.

One of the greatest human necessities is that of finding, accepting, and being oneself, the Rev. Dr. Charles R. Brown, dean emeritus of the Yale Divinity School, said in a sermon yesterday morning at the Riverside Baptist Church.

A campaign to unionize 50,000 bakery and grocery drivers throughout the city will be opened tonight at a mass meeting at the Chateau de Luxe, 671 Prospect Avenue, the Bronx, under the direction of Teamsters Local 138 of the American Federation of Labor.

Barring the one or two inevitable unexpected results which are still called upsets, despite the fact they occur with regularity on each playing day, the chief thing in evidence as football made its start Saturday was a lack of attacking strength.
CHICAGO, Sept. 24 (AP). -- The Chicago Cubs ran into Benny Frey at his best today and were forced to split a double-header with the last-place Cincinnati Reds.

The Treasury Department has issued anti-dumping orders against an odd quartet of foreign products: incandescent-light bulbs and rubber-soled, fabric-topped footwear from Japan; celluloid-covered thumb-tacks from Germany and saponified stearic acid (used in making candles) from the Netherlands.

ELIZABETH, N.J., Sept. 24. -- The Brooklyn Cricket Club and Crescent Athletic-Hamilton Club battled to a draw at Warinanco Park today in the play-off for the Metropolitan and New Jersey Cricket Association title.

"Hold Your Horses," the musical show by Russel Crouse and Corey Ford, which will return Joe Cook to the local stage and reclaim the Winter Garden from the movies, opens tonight. Among Mr. Cook's associates in the cast are Harriet Hoctor, Tom Patricola, Rex Weber, Inez Courtney and Ona Munson.

The image of the country as the haunt of American virtue and the city as the Babylon of sin was long ago shattered by that lover of cities, H.L. Mencken. Time, and hence presumably temptation, hangs heavy on the hands of lout and yokel, said Mr. Mencken, but the world of the city dweller is so full of a number of things that he hasn't time to play fast and loose with the Ten Commandments.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 24. -- The Reconstruction Finance Corporation is preparing to offer to investors about $200,000,000 in municipal securities which it has agreed to buy in connection with loans to municipalities for the construction of various types of public works, such as water and sewer systems, toll bridges, docks and tunnels.
BOSTON, Sept. 24 (AP). -- Rear Admiral Richard E. Byrd's Bear of Oakland awaits the dawn for the start to the glacial regions about the South Pole.

Copyright, 1933, by The Associated Press. PASADENA, Calif., Sept. 24. -- Experiments showing pure motion apparently changing into solid matter, indicating that for the first time man actually has seen the miracle of creation of matter, are described in recent reports of several radiation laboratories.

PARIS, Sept. 23. -- The exchange market was agitated this week as consequence of dollar and pound fluctuations. In part, the fall of the dollar, early in the week, was due to transfers of capital from New York to Paris, Amsterdam and Basle, but undoubtedly a greater proportion of the selling represented speculation.

While reorders in the wholesale markets here during the week were not particularly heavy, due both to the religious holidays and the desire of retailers to await further consumer response, considerable headway was made by ready-to-wear manufacturers in catching up on deliveries on old orders.

GENEVA, Sept. 24. -- There is a feeling of hope in Geneva today on the eve of the opening of the League of Nations Assembly as Premiers, Foreign Ministers, high-powered propagandists and the United States Ambassador-at-Large arrive.

Specifications against expiring contracts were so extensive last week that the national steel rate sank only one point to 40 per cent of capacity, according to the magazine Steel. Because of the advance of $2 a ton in plates and shapes and $3 a ton in bars, effective on next Saturday, contracting for these heavy finished steel products for the fourth quarter of the year is expected by the publication to be brisk this week.
Realty transactions announced in Manhattan and the Bronx over the week-end indicate a good demand for housing properties.

Dr. Heinrich Albert, director general of the North German Lloyd, whose resignation becomes effective Sept. 30, arrived yesterday from Bremen on the liner Europa. He was met at Quarantine by John Schroeder, who will head the joint passenger service of the North German Lloyd and Hamburg American lines after their consolidation.

PARIS, Sept. 24. -- As a result of the flight of Pierre Cot, French Air Minister, to Russia and the renewed bonds of friendship between France and the Soviet Union, the French are going to send a mission of military, naval and public works experts to Moscow, it is reliably reported today.
He Doesn't Worry -- Much. President ROOSEVELT spent the week-end on the water in the hope, says The Associated Press, of getting away "from all but the most urgent problems for a day or two."

Aimee Semple McPherson, appearing in person on the Capitol Theatre's stage, is the headliner also at the Embassy News Reel Theatre this week. The evangelist tells her screen audience that Broadway is a "citadel of sin" where the proverbial one stray is followed by the other ninety-nine.
CHICAGO, Sept. 24. -- A committee selected to promote Chicago as a securities and financial centre completed arrangements today for a vigorous campaign opening tomorrow.
NEW YORK. Mr. and Mrs. Richard Van Nest Gambrill will give a dinner for their niece, Miss Anne Blair Clark, in the Crystal Room of the Ritz-Carlton Jan. 5.

CHICAGO, Sept. 24. -- The readjustment of business to fit into the new conditions is reported to be moving irregularly, but indications are that different interests in merchandising and manufacturing eventually will come to a more complete understanding.

If Federal building projects and housing developments backed by RFC loans are carried through this year building construction in the five boroughs of this city will outstrip last year's total by about $25,000,000, according to an estimate prepared for the current Dow Service by Myron L. Matthews.

Formation of a non-partisan committee to get the Democratic and fusion nominations for Judge of the Court of General Sessions for Magistrate Jonah Goldstein was announced yesterday. The committee is headed by Harold R. Medina, law partner of Joseph V. McKee, as chairman, with Professor Raymond Moley and Arthur Lehman among the members.

Obligations of the United States Government that will mature within the next twelve months amount to $2,904,566,200. They consist of Treasury certificates of indebtedness, notes and non-interest-bearing discount bills.

LEIPZIG, Sept. 24. -- Arthur Garfield Hays, American attorney and representative of the international jurists' commission that investigated the Reichstag fire, is expected to take the witness stand in the treason trial now being fought out before the German Supreme Court.

MOSCOW, Sept. 24. -- Five minutes before noon today Air Commander Garankidze made a sudden discouraged gesture with his right hand and shouted an order. High up on the side of the Soviet's huge silvery stratosphere balloon a great gash cut downward as the rip-cord was pulled and thousands of cubio feet of hydrogen poured out like white smoke.
LARCHMONT, N.Y., Sept. 24. -- In their scheduled last race of the season, the 12-meter sloops were unable to cover a 14 1/2-mile course today. The breeze failed them.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 (AP). -- The Senators dropped the second game in a row to the Athletics today, 11 to 4. A vicious attack, led by Mickey Cochrane, sent the Senators' star hurler, Alvin Crowder, to the showers in the third inning. Started only as a conditioner for the world's series, Crowder allowed seven hits and as many runs.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 (AP). -- The American Bakers Association has some further explaining to do before Dr. Fred C. Howe, consumers' counsel for the Agricultural Adjustment Administration, is satisfied as to the seeming disparity in bread prices in several cities.

In a statement issued yesterday, following a meeting of the administrative committee of the American League for the Defense of Jewish Rights, held at his home, Greystone, in Yonkers, Samuel Untermyer, president of the league, announced that "complaints are being lodged and the immigration authorities being petitioned" to deport Nazi propagandists from this country.

The struggle of a people through forty centuries of despair and hope, enslavement and emancipation, degradation and grandeur was told last night to an audience of 20,000 persons who filled the Kingsbridge Armory in the Bronx almost to capacity for the opening performance of the Jewish pageant, "The Romance of a People."
BETHLEHEM, Pa., Sept. 24. -- There is an air of confidence around Bethlehem and one need not be extraordinarily wise to learn the reason.
To the Editor of The New York Times: I read with great interest the article on New York housing which appeared in THE NEW YORK TIMES recently.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 24. -- Urging reliance upon the bonds of the Home Owners Loan Corporation by mortgage holders who face the alternative of foreclosure or the sacrifice of past due and future interest, the Home Loan Bank Board today stressed its belief that acceptance of the bonds was the wise course to pursue.

VIENNA, Sept. 25. -- A monarchist sensation of the first order was created tonight by news that editions of the reliable Herzog News Agrency of Vienna had been confiscated for publishing the contents of letters from Archduke Otto of Hapsburg to the municipalities of Austrian villages that today formally conferred honorary citizenship upon him.
The last communication received by THE NEW YORK TIMES from Judge ALPHONSO T. CLEARWATER of Kingston, N.Y. (in February of this year), began with this general statement:

CHICAGO, Sept. 24. -- A streamlined, self-propelled railway coach designed for ninety-miles-an-hour passenger service was announced today by the Pullman Car and Manufacturing Corporation. It is an adaptation of aircraft architecture to track operation and has been named the "rail plane."

Love is an impulse toward good and all true love is distinguished by the four elements of sympathy, attraction, sacrifice and joy, the Rev. William A. Lynahan declared yesterday in his sermon at the 11 o'clock mass at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Paul the Apostle, Sixtieth Street and Columbus Avenue.

Forging to the front in the second period and remaining ahead the rest of the game, the First Division polo team of Fort Hamilton registered an 11 to 3 triumph over the West Point Polo Club on the victor's field in Brooklyn yesterday. A crowd of 5,000 witnessed the encounter.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 24. -- Currency inflation will not solve the farmer's present economic troubles and increase farm prices, Secretary Wallace declared in a radio speech tonight.

One hundred thousand New Yorkers, headed by civic leaders and commanders of patriotic and veterans' organizations, dedicated a living memorial yesterday in Pelham Bay Park to the 947 men and women of the Bronx who gave their lives for their country during the World War.

The tempestuous history of Ireland, of which the latest chapters now being written are none too full of promise, recalls an old legend. It is to the effect that when the Devil took the Saviour up into the high mountain and offered Him all the kingdoms of the world, he reserved Ireland for himself.

PARIS, Sept. 23. -- The Bourse showed a heavy tendency this week, following the weakness in Wall Street, and particularly on the reports from Washington that the government disapproves inflation. Bourse circles continued to think the United States Government will not be able to stand indefinitely against the strong pressure and will be forced to satisfy inflation partisans one way or another.

WONALANCET, N.H., Sept. 24 (AP). -- So many of the 150 dogs which Admiral Byrd had planned to take with him to the Antarctic have developed troubles that a hurried emergency trip to Labrador for twenty-five more huskies will be made this week by Captain Alan I. Taylor of White Horse, Yukon Territory.

Louis Waxenberg, 51 years old, a veteran confidence man, according to detectives, whose periodical transactions with American and European police go back for more than three decades, was arrested yesterday aboard the North German Lloyd liner Europa when the vessel docked at the foot of Fifty-eighth Street, Brooklyn.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 24. -- Although the general level of industrial production declined in August and the early part of September, reflecting reduction in activity of industries in which there had been a rapid rise in recent months, employment and wage payments were larger in August than in July, according to the monthly survey by the Federal Reserve Board.

NEW ORLEANS, La., Sept. 24. -- The cotton market here was dominated last week by conjectures and rumors as to the administration's plans relative to inflation of the currency, and prices for the staple advanced or receded as the advices from Washington seemed to favor or repress the attempts that were being made to bring about a broader application of inflation.

Miss Diana Chase, radio singer of station WINS, was picked last night from a field of eight finalists and crowned "Miss Radio of 1933" at the National Electrical and Radio Exposition now going on at Madison Square Garden. The judging, which took place as the climax of "Broadcast Day" at the Garden, was made by a committee of artists headed by Howard Chandler Christy.

BERLIN, Sept. 23. -- Financial sentiment this week recovered from the extreme pessimism of last week, and there was witnessed a substantial recovery in the securities market, which, however, was the cause, not the consequence, of the improvement in sentiment.
PITTSBURGH, Sept. 24. -- No increase in steel requirements of any consuming line is observed, but the trade is confident of a substantial increase in buying soon.

TURIN, Italy, Sept. 24 (AP). -- A solemn Te Deum in the Turin Cathedral, with tens of thousands of worshipers gathered inside and outside the edifice, inaugurated today a three weeks' period, during which the Holy Shroud will be displayed to the public.

SCARSDALE, N.Y., Sept. 24. -- A veteran bowman and his protege captured metropolitan archery championships in their respective divisions today after two days of keen competition on the Scarsdale High School athletic field.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 24 (AP). -- A six-run outburst in the fifth inning today gave the Cleveland Indians a 12 -- 6 victory over the Chicago White Sox in the second game of a double-header that ended the Tribe's home stand this season. The Sox took the first game, 8 to 7.

OKLAHOMA CITY, Sept. 24 (AP). -- While other attorneys conferred over defense plans for eleven persons on trial for the Charles F. Urschel kidnapping, John V. Roberts today urged his fugitive client, Kathryn Kelly, to "come on in and surrender."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 24. -- Government purchases for 300,000 young men in Civilian Conservation Corps camps will include "millions of dollars' worth of Winter clothing," in addition to a large outlay otherwise.

The possibility of an additional cut of 10 per cent in the salaries of all city employes receiving more than $3,000 a year was suggested yesterday by Samuel Untermyer, special financial adviser to Mayor O'Brien, in a radio address from station WOR.

PARIS, Sept. 24. -- The question of inflation of the franc in now in the forefront of the discussions about the French budgetary deficit, although it is the opponents of inflation who occupy the stage. In speeches and editorials the subject takes only one aspect -- a warning that if the budget is not balanced inflation must follow.

Belief that the regents' examinations are "in many respects a decided handicap to our schools," and have no excuse for existing is expressed in a report on secondary education prepared by the High School Teachers' Association under the direction of Charles M. Stebbins of Erasmus Hall High School, Brooklyn.
DETROIT, Sept. 24 (AP). -- The biggest name in modern baseball stood out today in speculation as to Stanley R. (Bucky) Harris's successor as manager of the Detroit Tigers.

YUMA, Ariz., Sept. 24 (AP). -- Sally Eilers, screen actress, and Harry Joe Brown, motion picture director, flew here from Los Angeles today and were married by Justice of the Peace Earl Freem. The couple was accompanied by Bebe Daniels and her husband, Ben Lyon of the films.

PARIS, Sept. 24. -- The doubts with which the opening of the Geneva conversations are regarded here received new impetus today from widespread publication of an article by "Augur," London writer on foreign affairs, stating that the German General Staff had a plan for the invasion of France through Switzerland.

In spite of a continued decline in business activity in the last month, the events of the last few weeks seem to support the belief that definite progress toward recovery has been made and that the normal stimulating influences of the Autumn season may reasonably be expected to bring further improvement, says the Guaranty Trust Company in the current issue of its review of business, The Guaranty Survey.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 24. -- Building operations as indicated by estimated costs declined 2.2 per cent during August, as compared with July, although the number of undertakings increased 6 per cent, the Labor Department announced yesterday.
