NEW HAVEN, Sept. 24. -- Professor Irving Fisher's index number of commodity prices, based on 100 as the average for 1926, is 71.6, which compares with 71.1 a week ago, 70.9 two weeks ago, 70.8 three weeks ago and 70.4 four weeks ago. The present average is the highest of the year to date; the highest July figure was 70.4.

The Socialists opened their city election campaign yesterday with a crowded meeting at Town Hall. Norman Thomas, Charles Solomon, candidate for Mayor, and others on the slate assailed Tammany, Fiorello H. LaGuardia and Joseph V. McKee as agents of large interests and opposed to necessary reform in the fundamental policy of city operation.

CHICAGO, Sept. 24. -- In the face of the smallest crop of oats in thirty-nine years, farmers are selling fairly well. Primary receipts since Aug. 1, when the new crop movement started, have been 27,788,000 bushels, compared with 30,192,000 bushels for the same time last year, the big loss being at Chicago, while substantial gains were made at Minneapolis and Duluth.

BERLIN, Sept. 23. -- Except among those who owe money abroad and who welcome every reduction in their burden, the new falls of the dollar and sterling are taken unfavorably here. Exporters apprehend exchange dumping.

The memorial service last week for THOMAS J. MCMANUS, for twenty-five years leader of the Fifth Assembly District, and also for his brother CHARLES, who succeeded him, recalls battles long" ago. As head of the clan the former became "The" MCMANUS and ruled benevolently and absolutely mid-Manhattan from Broadway to the River.

Rabbi Stephen S. Wise, honorary president of the American Jewish Congress, who returned recently from a ten weeks' trip abroad, speaking at a special meeting of the national executive committee of the organization yesterday afternoon at the Hotel Pennsylvania, outlined a four-point program to help Jews in Germany.

READING, Pa., Sept. 24. -- Two persons were killed and fifteen injured, ten of them seriously, before daybreak this morning when a bus of the Sunset Stage Corporation, bound from New York to Pittsburgh, swerved to avoid a pedestrian and turned over an a rain-swept concrete highway at Jalappa, six miles west of Hamburg.

OSSINING, N.Y., Sept. 24. -- Using a modified Notre Dame attack, the Sing Sing football team won its first game of the current season in businesslike fashion this afternoon. It played the Holy Name Society eleven of Williams-bridge, the Bronx, and when the final whistle sounded the score was 36 to 0.

PITTSFIELD, Mass., Sept. 24. -- Mr. and Mrs. John Matthews gave a hunt breakfast this morning at Foothill Farm, Lenox, for thirty members of the Lebanon Valley Hunt Club, of which Captain Sydney R. Smith is M.F.H., after a rabbit chase on the Robert E. Bonner farm, east of Mahkeenac Lake.

BERLIN, Sept. 24. -- Dr. Paul Joseph Goebbels, the more skillful yet equally virulent and implacable of the two leading exponents of militant Nazism under the chieftainship of the mystical, fanatical Adolf Hitler, is now in Geneva, where the preliminary moves in the struggle to obtain European disarmament and to insure European peace are under way.

"There has never been a more serious problem confronting the city than exists today" in the matter of unemployment relief, despite signs of improvement and universal support of the NRA, the Welfare Council of New York City, representing the city's major relief agencies, declared yesterday.

AS one critic recently remarked, with humorous intent, but not without a touch of irony, the remarkable part about the Giants is not so much that they won a pennant, but that Bill Terry ever thought they could possibly win. That seems to be a remarkable tribute to Memphis Bill.

The American educational system was criticized yesterday morning by the Rev. Dr. Charles Trexler in his sermon at the Lutheran Church of St. James, Madison Avenue at Seventy-third Street. He charged our schools, by ignoring character-building, were making "weaklings" of our boys and girls.

CHICAGO, Sept. 24. -- Balancing of wheat production and consumption the world over and especially in the United States, and the balancing of corn and live stock, are regarded here as one of the greatest projects that the world has seen. It is being watched everywhere and other countries in several instances are following the lead taken by the United States and Canada.
WALLACE ALEXANDER, San Francisco: Has extensive shipping interests on Pacific Coast, important as sugar factor, a director of various, diversified business enterprises. Republican.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Sept. 24. -- Official organization of the class of 1937 in Woolsey Hall tomorrow will open Yale's freshman week and the university's 232d academic year.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 24. -- Confronted with many complexities in connection with his economic program, chiefly the lack of credit to finance operations under the NRA and the lag in farm prices, President Roosevelt conferred at the White House tonight with Secretary of the Treasury Woodin and other officials responsible for government finances and recovery activities.

LONDON, Sept. 25. -- A balloon dropped out of the skies onto the beach at Berwick-on-Tweed today after drifting helplessly across the North Sea in a gale. From its gondola tumbled three Germans, all astonished to be told they had landed in the heart of the "manoeuvre area" where the British fleet is having battle practice.

Snooky, a female chimpanzee, shifted uneasily yesterday in her cage at Coney Island. Outside the house where she was quartered, at 2,550 Stillwell Avenue, rose sounds of celebration. Several hundred Italians, residents of the neighborhood, were observing the Feast of Our Lady of Solace.

Vigorous opposition to the awarding of twenty-five-year franchises in Manhattan to the New York City Omnibus Corporation and the Comprehensive Bus Company will be voiced before the Board of Estimate today at a final public hearing on proposed contracts with those concerns.

Philip Le Boutillier's Alsumar and G.W. McNaughton's Nachtan, both sloops, were victors in the auxilliary and sailing divisions, respectively, of the City Island Yacht Club's seventy-mile race to Stratford Shoal Light and return, which ended yesterday.

Committees of presidents from railroads in all parts of the country are to attend a conference on passenger fare reduction to be held here tomorrow in the office of F.E. Williamson, president of the New York Central Railroad. Mr. Williamson is chairman of the committee which will represent the Eastern lines in the discussion.

Communication with the hurricane-torn city of Tampico, Mexico, was maintained today only by two pilots of Pan. American Airways. C.M. Drayton, landbound on the muddy airport, used the cockpit of his bogged plane as a radio station. F.J. Nolan, flying over the city enroute from Brownsville, Texas, to Mexico City, and unable to land because of the condition of the airport, reported the city three-fourths destroyed and greatly in need of food and water.
NEW YORK. Brig. Gen. and Mrs. Cornelius Vanderbilt returned yesterday from Newport to 640 Fifth Avenue.

A unanimous vote to Join in a move against Tammany taken yesterday afternoon by the Brooklyn-Nassau Presbytery was reversed later at the close of its first Fall session in the Lafayette Avenue Presbyterian Church, at South Oxford Street, Brooklyn.
The United States is looked upon around the world as "easy," according to former Secretary of Agriculture William M. Jardine, who returned on the Dollar liner President Monroe last night.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 -- The Public Works Administration today issued a correction as to the rate of interest to be charged on fireproof housing where slums are first destroyed. In an announcement yesterday the rate on such projects was given as 1.51 per cent beginning two years after the loan.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Sept. 25 -- Harvard's football coaches today cut their big squad down to a working basis, retaining forty-three of the fifty-seven players originally picked on Sept. 15.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Sept. 25 (AP). -- Universities and colleges in New York State, already opened or soon to open, are showing an increase in enrolment or a holding of the same level in almost every instance.

The opening of "Hot and Bothered," the Harlan Thompson-Lewis Gensler musical show, which had been announced for the Boulevard Theatre, Jackson Heights, on Oct. 9, has been set back until Oct. 23, Morris Green, coproducer with Frank McCoy, said yesterday.

The New York Giants, deciding on the disposition of their share of the receipts of the world's series in which they are to clash with the Senators, yesterday voted twenty-six full shares to twenty-one players, the club secretary, the three coaches and the club trainer.

The labor situation continued to occupy a prominent place in the activities of the local NRA organization yesterday, with Grover A. Whalen, chairman of the NRA, and its labor mediation committee devoting their energies to settlements of pending strikes and efforts to avert threatened walkouts.

BUCHAREST, Sept. 25 -- Festivities in celebration of the anniversary of the founding of Castle Pellas at Sinaia reached a climax today with a great military parade commanded by King Carol. The royal residential city in the mountains was a mass of flags and the royal guests and members of the government and diplomatic corps passed through the streets to divine service at the royal castle early this morning.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 25 -- Prince Serge Mdivani filed a divorce suit today in which he charged that the association of his wife, Mary McCormic, grand opera star, with Samuel Insull caused him "great mental suffering, humiliation and anguish."

GENEVA, Sept. 25 -- Danger of war which hangs over the world was placed before the League of Nations today by Premier Johan Mowinckel of Norway, who, as president of the Council, opened the fourteenth session of the Assembly.

CHICAGO, Sept. 25 -- News favorable to inflation of the currency failed to develop over the week-end and many traders who had gone long of wheat on Saturday on the Board of Trade here went out of their holdings early today. Their selling carried wheat off about 2 1/2 cents a bushel and corn 2 cent from the previous close.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Sept. 25 -- A barrage of hits in the fourth inning, including two home runs and a double, and three singles allowed the Columbus to even the little world's series with Buffalo today at one game each. The score was 8 to 4.

Mr. and Mrs. O.O. Mclntyre gave a dinner last night in the roof garden, of the Waldorf-Astoria for Meredith Nicholson, recently appointed United States Minister to Paraguay, and Mrs. Nicholson. The other guests were:

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 -- While fiscal experts met with Secretary Woodin at the Treasury this afternoon to perfect the administration's monetary and credit expansion policies, representatives of the farm and live stock industries, headed by Edward A. O'Neal of the American Farm Bureau Federation, called at the White House to appeal for immediate steps to raise the price level of their commodities.
Physicists here described as "interesting" yesterday the reports of experiments in Pasadena, Calif., and Cambridge, England, tending to show the conversion of motion into matter.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 -- Establishment of a private corporation, with Federal capital was decided upon by the Agricultural Adjustment Administration today for distributing up to $400,000,000 in loans to cotton farmers under the program to lend them 10 cents a pound on this year's crop.

ALBANY, Sept. 25 -- Former State Senator Henry M. Sage, who during ten of the years he served in the Legislature was chairman of the Finance Committee, died of a heart attack early today at his home, Fernwood, in Menands. He had been an invalid from paralysis for several years.

PARIS, Sept. 25 -- The sensitiveness of the foreign exchange market here was strongly marked today when, following news from Washington that was interpreted as indicating that President Roosevelt was still opposed to inflation, the dollar, and with it the pound sterling, rose appreciably.

Samuel Seabury will arrive today on the White Star liner Olympic. Also on board will be the Rev. S. Parkes Cadman, Judge Richard P. Lydon, Gates McGarrah, former president of the Bank for International Settlements, and Mrs. McGarrah; Eugene Goossens, conductor, and:
Melville O. Griffiths's Kenboy compiled a percentage of .813 to head the Sound Interclub Class yacht standing for the past season according to an announcement made yesterday by the class committee.

The Paterson Cricket Club carried off all the honors for the season just closed in the New Jersey State Cricket League. In addition to winning the pennant, the individual batting and bowling standings were also headed by two of its members.

Prices of commodities traded on local exchanges were substantially lower at the close yesterday, although in several cases there had been a fair recovery from the day's low levels. The markets were guided almost exclusively by outside trends.

Samuel S. Koenig, president of the New York County Republican Committee, will offer no opposition to the election of Chase Mellen Jr. as his successor as the head of the party organization in Manhattan. This announcement was made by Mr. Koenig last night after a conference with the Republican district leaders who had remained loyal to him throughout the primary fight in which his opponent claims the victory by a substantial margin.

OKLAHOMA CITY, Sept. 25 (AP). -- R.G. (Boss) Shannon, elderly Texas farmer, turned on two of his co-defendants in the Charles F. Urschel kidnapping trial here today and testified he and his family were forced to" hold the oil man captive on their farm under threat of death.

MOSCOW, Sept. 25 -- Some skeptics in Moscow are beginning to understand today why there was so much talk about Colonel Charles Lindburgh's good-will flights to Paris and Central America. Some of tham thought it was a sentimental phrase, meaning little save ballyhoo.

After a lengthy hearing, the State Alcoholic Beverage Control Board revoked yesterday the license to sell beer at wholesale issued to Michael F. Zappolo, operating in Brooklyn and Queens under the name of the Queens Distributing Agency.

Judge John J. Fitzgerald, in Kings County Court, yesterday granted the motion of Assistant District Attorney Henry J. Walsh for a special panel of jurors to be called for the trial of Jacob Mellon, Morris Rothenberg and Samuel Solomon on charges of activities in the "laundry racket" in Brooklyn.

Samuel L. Rosenman, intimate of both President Roosevelt and Governor Lehman, returned to the Supreme Court bench yesterday to fill the vacancy caused by the death of Justice Henry L. Sherman. The induction ceremonies were at the home of the Governor at 820 Park Avenue.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Sept. 25 -- Award of honors to twenty-six juniors and twenty-five sophomores for last year's work was announced today by Dean Thompson at Vassar College at the opening of the new academic year. The lists follow:
WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 -- A code for the marine shipping industry, employing about 500,000 workers, was submitted to the National Recovery Administration today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 -- Continuing its efforts to speed reorganization or liquidation of closed banks, to release tied-up deposits, the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, according to a monthly report, authorized in August loans of $17,381,800 to banks and trust companies for such purposes.

A national meeting in celebration of the 450th anniverary of the birth of Martin Luther will be held in the Hippodrome on Sunday afternoon, Nov. 5, under auspices of the twenty-four leading bodies of Lutherans in the United States. Luther's birthday falls on Nov. 10.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 -- While in the writing of the Recovery Act all other authorization for loans to private industry was stricken out, no limitation was set on the possible allocation to railroads from the $3,300,000,000.

MOSCOW, Sept. 25 -- Applauded by thousands of watchers lining the waterfront and bridges of the narrow Moscow River, Colonel Charles A. Lindbergh brought his transatlantic seaplane to a perfect landing on the dangerously limited surface today after an overland flight from Leningrad.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 (AP) -- Thousands of manufacturers over the nation were told by the National Association of Manufacturers tonight that a closed union shop under which labor contracts were made with a single union would violate the intent of the Recovery Act.

DETROIT, Sept. 25 (AP). -- The third and fourth rounds in the annual championship tournament of the Western Chess Association were contested today, leaving Reuben Fine and Robert Willman of New York tied at the top of the standing.

August was a bad month for the theory that a depreciated currency is of advantage to American export trade. Contrary to the presumption that a dollar cheaper in terms of other currencies would enable us to undersell foreign competitors and increase our sales abroad, exports declined by $13,000,000 (or 9 per cent) compared with July.

MOSCOW, Sept. 25 -- There are unmistakable indications of a change in the Soviet foreign economic policy. Perhaps there has not been an actual change of policy as yet, but there is a change of attitude on the subject. That change in turn has been produced by a change in circumstances.

An appropriation of $2,500,000 to cover unemployment relief expenditures for the rest of September was voted yesterday by the Board of Estimate. The board authorized the controller to issue serial bondsto this amount.

The Deposit Insurance Corporation, created under the Banking Act of 1933, has issued a request to the banks of the country for a "loan" of 2,500 credit men to supplement its staff of bank examiners in scrutinizing applicants for membership in the corporation.
Sale of an apartment house in Bayonne and a business building in Orange featured the New Jersey realty trading reported yesterday.

PEIPING, Tuesday, Sept. 26 -- As the time limit set in the Japanese ultimatum for General Fang Chen-wu and his allies to quit the demilitiarized zone draws near, Chinese sources confusedly report first that General Fang is preparing for withdrawal and next that he is massing his forces at Niulanshan, less than twenty-five miles north of Peiping.

CHICAGO, Sept. 25 -- With a run of 90,000 swine here today, including 50,000 pigs for the government, 14,400 hogs sent direct to packers and 2,000 carried over from Saturday, supplies were unusually heavy, but prices for light hogs and light sows dropped only 5 to 10 cents a hundredweight from Saturday's level, although the general market was 15 to 25 cents lower than on Friday.

LONDON, Sept. 25 -- Police are investigating the death of the novelist, Mrs. A.M. Williamson, author of "The Lightning Conductor," who was found unconscious during a week-end in a hotel at Bath. Doctors waged a desperate all-night fight to save her, but she died early yesterday.

CHICAGO, Sept. 25 -- A group of pre-prohibition brewmeisters, meeting today with the Master Brewers' Association of America, gave an informal lecture entitled "How to Drink Beer." To get full enjoyment from a foaming stein of brew is a real art and the present general conception that beer should be drunk ice cold is "absolutely wrong," they said.

CHICAGO, Sept. 25 -- Radiology, the youngest of the medical sciences, may yet deal with the formula of life itself, it was predicted today at the opening session of the first American Congress of Radiology. Life, it was pointed out, is light, and light is made up of rays which are rapidly yielding their secrets to the physicist, the chemist and to those who apply them to the cellular activities of the human body.
CHICAGO, Sept. 25 (AP). -- In a spectacular nose finish, Mrs. John Marsch's Princess Camelia won the top race from Gift of Roses today at Washington Park.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Sept. 25 -- Aside from an immediate stringency at the ends, which has been more or less chronic at this early stage in recent years, Yale's football setup Is such as to portend the dawn of another golden age for the Bulldog.
To the Editor of The New York Times: A correspondent complained recently of low window sills as a cause of accidents. Another hazard is narrow window sills, especially for the window cleaner.
LAKE GEORGE. N.Y., Sept. 25. -- At a meeting of the directors of the Lake George Club it was decided to sponsor the Gold Cup race to be held on Lake George in 1934, it was announced today.

CHICAGO, Sept. 25 -- A new uniform wage scale, effective next Sunday, for pilots flying for the five leading air lines of the country was announced today. It will raise the pay of pilots on four of the lines and will keep the pay of the pilots employed on the fifth line at last year's high level.

The aggregate net operating income of the first sixteen railroads to report for August showed not only a substantial increase from August, 1932, but also from August, 1931. Gross revenues continued to run below the level of 1931.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Sept. 25 -- A record-breaking enrolment for Harvard College was announced tonight at University Hall at the end of registration, in all departments of the university. The total registration in the college is 3,429, as compared with 3,361 last year and 3,233 two years ago.
Little activity was apparent in the local realty field yesterday. The dullness was attributed in part to uncertainty regarding property values under increased city taxation.

Yesterday brought pretty plain indication that both, the city authorities and Mr. UNTERMYER were preparing to recede from their ill-considered proposals of taxation affecting the Stock Exchange. They had already retreated from their original and indefensible 5 per cent tax on the gross income of every individual engaged in the buying and selling of securities.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 25 (AP) -- Patrick T. Fagan, district president of the United Mine Workers of America, was informed today by officials of several independent steel corporations that they are "not ready" to sign union contracts for their soft coal mines.

Large-scale credit expansion by government direction, as an alternative to currency inflation, continued to intrigue the markets yesterday. The speculative elements in Wall Street did not appear to be specially enthusiastic over the altered conditions, but they seemed to recognize possibilities in the program which the Federal administration seems determined to press as the more desirable course in the face of the, demand for outright degradation of the dollar.

EDWARDSVILLE, Ill., Sept. 25 (AP). -- After blaming others for his part in the kidnapping of August Luer, the Alton banker, Randol Norvell, a defendant, was himself accused today by Christ Nicola Gitcho, another defendant, of forcing him unwittingly into the abduction scheme.

PITTSFIELD, Mass., Sept. 25 -- The New England Senior Golfers Association will hold its annual tournament at the Wyantenuck Country Club, Great Barrington, tomorrow. Fifty-five is the minimum age. Those over 75 are not expected to play more than eleven holes.

Activity in the listed bond market slowed down perceptibly yesterday, following the heavy dealings last week. Yesterday's transactions in bonds on the Stock Exchange amounted to less than $9,401,000. Domestic corporation bonds moved irregularly lower, while foreign loans and United States Government issues were generally higher.

LONDON, Tuesday, Sept. 26 -- Cecil Henderson, 21-year-old amateur novelist, admitted tonight having plagiarized "The Maltese Falcon," a detective novel by an American, Dashiell Hammett. Henderson said he did it "just for fun."
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Sept. 25 -- Two thousand truckmen today left their seats, practically paralyzing highway freight traffic through Central Connecticut.

BERLIN, Sept. 25 -- Buoyancy in bonds following the announcement that the Reichsbank would become a buyer of fixed-interest-bearing German securities overshadowed stocks in today's trading on the Boerse. Public interest was supported by speculative buying.
ON BOARD THE SCHOONER, MORRISSEY, OFF BRIGUS, Nfld., Sept. 24 -- Frost and snow and the Fury-and-Hecla Strait filled with pack ice drove us back to the South.

GENEVA, Sept. 25 -- The disarmament talks which are dominating the fourteenth League of Nations Assembly marked across its opening day a series of dialogues ending with Norman H. Davis, United States Ambassador at Large, dining with Baron Konstantin von Neurath, German Foreign Minister.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 -- The greater latitude allowed to United States naval officers in Cuba in dealing with dangers to United States citizens and foreign nationals was explained by Secretary of State Hull today. They are to be permitted to exercise their judgment in regard to sending bluejackets ashore.

At a brief but acrimonious session of the Board of Estimate yesterday afternoon the board put over until Friday action on the formal granting of seven crosstown bus franchises to the New York Omnibus Corporation and the Comprehensive Bus Corporation.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 25 (AP) -- Infuriated at being brought into court for questioning concerning expenditures she made as guardian of her two sons, Mrs. Lita Grey Chaplin, former wife of the film comedian, Charles Chaplin, was led from the witness stand in a state of semi-collapse today, forcing a continuance of the hearing.

In a letter to the President made public yesterday, the Merchants Association of New York, over the signature of its president, Louis K. Comstock, called attention to the difficulties of exporters under the recovery program. At the same time Mr. Comstock made it clear that he was in no wise criticizing the program, which he recognized as a fundamental necessity.

The Chamber of Commerce of the State of New York adopted resolutions yesterday condemning the city's current tax program. Describing some of the proposed new imposts as "a capital levy,' the chamber urged the city to abandon the entire tax program and to meet its financial needs by budgetary economies.

An overwhelming preponderance of opinion that prices of securities should be higher a year from now than at present is indicated in the returns of the annual questionnaire sent to investment bankers, security dealers and economists by Allied Distributors, Inc.

WAYNESVILLE, N.C., Sept. 25 -- The body of Thomas Price, former secretary of the Union Pacific Railway, shot to death from ambush yesterday, lay in state today in Waynesville. Hundreds of persons in this county who admired Mr. Price for his many philanthropies, thronged a funeral establishment here to express their grief over his death.

VATICAN CITY, Sept. 25 (AP) -- The hope that the lessons of the depression will not soon be forgotten by the peoples of the world was expressed by Pope Pius today in an audience with Cardinal O'Connell of Boston.

SHANGHAI, Sept. 25 -- With Japanese troops from the Great Wall about 125 miles north of Peiping, nearing Miyun, only forty-five miles from the old capital, and General Shang Chen's government divisions entrenched along the boundaries of the demilitarized zone nearest Peiping, the situation of Fang Chen-Wu and other rebels between Miyun and Peiping is precarious in the extreme.

Senator James J. Davis of Pennsylvania, as director general of the Loyal Order of Moose, lent his approval to the methods used by that organization in its fund-raising campaigns, Rodney H. Brandon, Commissioner of Public Welfare of Illinois, testified yesterday.
BERLIN, Sept. 25 -- Representatives of the new Germany are now buoyed by the consciousness that they are in the centre of the world's interest.

The belief that the Stock Exchange would remain in New York was expressed yesterday by representatives of some of its most important member firms, after Samuel Untermyer, fiscal adviser to the city administration, had recommended the abandonment of the threatened emergency taxes affecting the brokerage business.

Celestin Durand and Jimmy Hines of Timber Point carried off the honors in the special amateur-pro tournament staged at the Fresh Meadow Country Club at Flushing yesterday under the auspices of the Long Island Golf Association.

NRA Not in Them. As the college year begins, the welcoming speeches to the hoys and girls definitely convey the impression that the principles of the NRA are not for them. The country at large is to have, under the NRA, less work, more leisure, less competition, less individual initiative.

The reduction in bag limits on wild water fowl in the United States this year, decreed under the recently announced regulations of the Biological Survey, has not met with the hearty response expected.

The city administration capitulated yesterday to stock brokerage interests by offering to abandon the proposed new city taxes on stocks and brokers if the Stock Exchange did not carry through its plans for moving to Newark.

The two coasts of America had a part in the education of HENRY SUZZALLO. His bachelor's degree was won in his native State at Stanford University, his doctorate at Columbia. And his life work, divided between these two coasts and embracing all between, gave him a national field and his service a national prominence among educational statesmen.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 -- Receivers of national banks, with the approval of the Controller of the Currency, may exchange their mortgage holdings for Home Owners Loan Corporation bonds. A letter from Controller J.F.T. O'Connor to Chairman William F. Stevenson of the Home Loan Board announced today.
COPENHAGEN, Sept. 25 -- Dr. Lauge Koch, Danish explorer, returned from Greenland today with the announcement of his discovery of the longest and deepest fjord in the world.

BUENOS AIRES, Sept. 25 -- Colombia is Inclined to admit Ecuador to the forthcoming Peruvian-Colombian conference at Rio de Janeiro and make it a general conference for definite settlement of all upper Amazonian territorial conflicts, according to well-informed sources in the Latin-American section of the diplomatic corps here.

LONDON, Sept. 25 -- Dr. Hendryck Colijn, blunt and pessimistic Premier of the Netherlands, and Ramsay MacDonald, idealistic and ever-hopeful Prime Minister of Britain, today felt the pulse of the World Economic Conference without deciding whether it could be revived.

Appointment of Professor Joseph Hudnut as acting dean of the Columbia University School of Architecture for the academic year 193334 was announced yesterday by Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of the university. Professor Hudnut replaces Professor William A. Boring, head of the school since 1919, who has received a leave of absence for the coming year.

As a reply to the charge that banks are withholding credit from worthy commercial borrowers, leading banks in this city have started intensive campaigns to locate good borrowers who can make use of the surplus funds now cramming the banks.

Boos and catcalls interrupted the speech of Bernard Ridder, publisher, when he warned delegates of the United Grman eSocieties last night in New Yorker Turn Halle, Lexington Avenue and Eighty-fifth Street, against pro-Nazi tendencies. His brother, Victor, also spoke.
COMMERCIAL PAPER. Yesterday. Friday. For the best names........1 1/4% 1 1/4% The quotations are for three-four months' paper.

The twelfth annual Exposition of Women's Arts and Industries, of which Mrs. Oliver Harriman is chairman, opend at the Hotel Astor yesterday afternoon with a large attendance. The innovations this year include the educational sections on vitamins and nutrition, visual education and pure cosmetics.

GOSHEN, N.Y., Sept. 25 -- Bert J. Griswold, 51-year-old painting contractor, is in jail here charged with an attempt to extort $1,000 from Campbell Steward, 82, retired member of the New York Stock Exchange.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Sept. 25 (AP) -- The pennant-winning march of the Washington Senators has pushed Joseph W. Engel into the limelight again, although Engel is the type of fellow who doesn't need much pushing.
PARIS, Sept. 25. -- William T. Tilden 2d today accomplished in brilliant fashion as a professional what he had failed to do as a Davis Cup player from 1927 to 1930.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 -- President Roosevelt has decided to keep his hands off the New York political fight, according to an authorized White House announcement today.
FARGO, N.D., Sept 25 (AP) -- Defeat of a State special election measure which would permit motion-picture shows on Sundays appeared probably tonight.
Summer lingered in New York and other sections of the Eastern United States yesterday, but in the Canadian Northwest biting Arctic winds brought sub-freezing temperatures and snow.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 25 -- Defeating the Phillies today, 7 to 2, for their fifth straight victory, the Dodgers were astonished to discover that they had compiled their longest winning streak of the year.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Sept, 25 -- Yale doors which were thrown open today in beginning the 232d year of the institution included those of seven new colleges which will inaugurate the college housing plan for the three upper classes.

The local NRA policy committee, composed at the executive and publishers' committees, approved yesterday the plan of Grover A. Whalen, city NRA chairman, to continue NRA activities in New York City with virtually the same organization from Oct. 1 to Jan. 1.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 (AP). -- Already approved by President Roosevelt and Secretary Hull, a sugar stabilization agreement today was laid before Secretary Wallace with the expectation that his signature would put the pact into effect soon.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In view of the general desire to increase the purchasing power of the community it may be of interest to consider, in what purchasing power at a given time consists.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 -- The Washington Senators today held a private batting practice with the slightly-less-lively National League ball that will be used in the opening of the world's series. They returned a jubilant verdict to the effect that it "rides plenty" when you hit it.

Bankers here and in other financial centres who specialize in municipal loans have been asked by the Reconstruction Finance Corporation to give their opinions on its plan to market up to a maximum of $200,000,000 of the municipal bonds that are in its portfolio or that it has undertaken to purchase.

No one can escape a feeling of confusion about the city campaign. With so many wars and rumors of wars injected into the affair there is a general impression of uncertainty and muddle and cross-purposes. Many must be impelled to rush in like the man in the play to demand:

Certain passages in The London Times of 1833, reprinted this year, have made some of its' readers write, " How like DICKENS!" A magistrate named LAING, the supposed original of Mayor Nupkins of Ipswich in " The Pickwick Papers," accused a prisoner's friend of being drunk and asked his officers to corroborate the charge, so suggesting his worship's appeal to Grummet to confirm the drunkenness of a special constable.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 25 -- Miss Edith Quier of Reading and Huntingdon. Valley led the way in the qualifying round of the Pennsylvania women's golf championship at Aronimink today by turning in a record-breaking medal card of 75.

NANUET, N.Y., Sept. 25 -- George Haerle Jr., an inspector in the New York City Police Department, died at his Summer borne here early this morning. He was 64 years old. He had been ill about a month with a heart ailment.

An order calling upon William L. Schneider, vice president of the Manufacturers Trust Company, and other officers of that bank to appear in the Federal Court in Brooklyn for examination concerning the affairs of the bankrupt Realty Associates Securities Corporation was signed yesterday by Judge Grover M. Moscowitz.

The Consolidated Gas Company and its gas affiliates expect to incur additional expenses of more than $3,000,000 during the next twelve months as a result of the NRA, the city's increased water rates and the proposed excise tax on gross incomes in the city.

CHICAGO, Sept. 25 -- State control of public utilities as opposed to national regulation was advocated today at the convention of the American Gas Association. Opposition was expressed to a reported tendency on the part of Legislatures to increase the taxes on utilities.
LOS ANGELES, Sept. 25 -- A scientist and a medical man said here today that the world is growing too noisy.

Because of reductions of rates, imposition of additional city excise taxes and refusal of the Public Service Commission to grant applications for authority to issue bonds which would permit the company to reimburse its treasury for capital expenditures, the directors of the New York and Richmond Gas Company have voted to defer action on the preferred dividend payable on Oct. 1.
Prices on the Cotton Exchange fluctuated irregularly yesterday in a range of $1 a bale and ended with losses of 2 to 9 points.

WILMINGTON, Del., Sept. 25 (AP) -- An injunction against the carrying out of the recapitalization plan for the Associated Gas and Electric system was asked in a bill of complaint filed in Chancery Court today by Tessie Berwick, owner of $30,000 in debentures of the Associated Gas and Electric Company, a New York corporation.

BERLIN, Sept. 25 -- A new press law that is in the making and will soon be promulgated will in all probability not only make the German newspapers virtual instruments of the "totalitarian" State but also take charge of the training of newspaper men and lay down the conditions, especially in points of political and theoretical conformity, on which they will alone be able to find employment.

LONDON, Tuesday, Sept. 26 -- Lord Beaverbrook, owner of The Daily Express, admits in a frontpage article that between March 1 and June 30 his paper had spent more than $1,000,000 in gifts and prices to attract new readers.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 -- Inviting sponsors of non-Federal projects to speed their applications for public works funds, Secretary Ickes put on steam within the department today to expedite such allocations by ordering a double-shift of clerks, lawyers, publicity men and others employed by the Public Works Administration.

An increasing number of people in the United States are apprehensive of currency inflation and fearful of its results. Eight distinguished men, representing both major political parties, have approved and sponsored a series of articles presenting their viewpoint on the money problems of the day. The series will appear in this newspaper in sixteen consecutive daily chapters. The second is presented herewith.
RENO, Nev., Sept. 25 -- A socially prominent Boston couple and two socially prominent New York couples figured in divorce actions here today.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Owen R. Lovejoy of the New York Child Labor Committee took attention away from the substance of my former letter. He writes in your columns on the proposed amendment to the Federal Constitution. This is not presently my concern.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 -- President Roosevelt was urged today to use the power conferred on him by the Independent Offices Appropriation Act to prevent further wholesale dismissals of married women from the Federal service.

VIENNA, Sept. 25 -- Regulations authorizing the preventive detention of the National Socialists or other enemies of the State in ''definite places or districts," by which concentration camps is understood, were issued tonight and will go into effect immediately and remain in force until Oct. 1, 1934.

Horace Liveright had completed about 60,000 words of his autobiography, "Turbulent Years," before his death on Sunday. He left fairly thorough notes for the rest of it. Simon Schuster, who were to publish it, have not yet made a decision but probably will publish it, it was said at their offices yesterday.

Mrs. A. Lincoln Filene of Boston, music patron and philanthropist, and George Gershwin, American composer, are among those who have contributed toward scholarships with Arnold Schonberg, internationally famous musician and teacher, who will come here next month to teach at the Malkin Conservatory of Music in Boston.

Chambers of commerce through-out the country must lead a fight to reduce municipal expenses, must guide business to self-government to avoid political control and must organize youth, to prevent an American Hitler from capitalizing on the unrest of youth.

PITTSBURGH, Pa., Sept. 25 -- An overflow audience gave enthusiastic reception to George M. Cohan and his supporting cast in the premiere of Eugene O'Neill's new play, "Ah, Wilderness!" at the Nixon Theatre tonight.

HAMBURG, Sept. 25 -- Max Oboussier. the new head of the Hamburg- American Line, announced today in a statement to shipping companies that German lines would stand up against world competition and cease competing among themselves.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 -- President Roosevelt today laid before leading steel men of the country a virtual ultimatum on a plan by which he hopes at one stroke to step up production in the steel industry and maintenance operations on the railroads, with consequent material gains in employment, before Winter sets in.

Tom Chester of the Salem-Crescent A.C., national A.A.U. champion, was outpointed by Raymond, Miller of Newark in a special intercity bout, one of the features of the New York A.C. amateur boxing program at Travers Island last night.

HAVANA, Sept. 25 -- Colonel Juan Blas Hernandez, rebel leader who was reported in revolt in Camaguey Province, came to the Presidential Palace this morning accompanied by Captain Benitez, who had been sent to combat him, and several students of the militia known as the "Caribe Army."

The Investment Bankers Association of America announced yesterday the leaders of the ten forums on financial and economic subjects which will feature the twenty-second annual convention of the association at Hot Springs, Va., from Oct. 28 to Nov. 1.

LEIPZIG, Germany, Sept. 25 -- Ernst Torgler, wounded war veteran, Parliamentary leader of the Communist party in Germany, and now the principal defendant in the Reich arson and treason trial, faced the German Supreme Court today and in a raging speech proclaimed his innocence and put a broad gulf between himself and Marinus Van der Lubbe, trembling Dutchman, who was caught in the burning Reichstag Building.
Leading almost from start to finish, the 2-year-old Sgt. Byrne, owned by John Simonetti of Jamaica, captured the featured Bushwick Handicap at Aqueduct yesterday, again scoring over older rivals.

Joseph V. McKee, former Aldermanic President, told a group of 200 independent Democrats yesterday that he had not decided whether or not he would run for Mayor as an independent Democratic candidate. He added that his decision, when made, would not be inspired by personal ambition or political considerations but by what he believed would be for the best interest of the residents of New York City.

Speeding up its drills, Fordham's football squad began its final week of pre-season practice yesterday at Fordham Field. The Rams will face their first opponent of the 1933 campaign, on Saturday when they line up against Albright.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 -- General Johnson awaited today a tabulation of opinions of thousands of retailers throughout the country before presenting their fair competition code to President Roosevelt for approval.

OSSINING, N.Y., Sept. 25 -- Using their regular line-up at the start, the New York Giants defeated the Mutual Welfare League nine of Sing Sing today, 9 -- 3, in a seven-inning game. A crowd of 2,000 inmates watched the game.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The labor disputes which, have taken so pronounced a turn since industry has been preparing to function under NRA codes draw attention to the work for business arbitration by Judge Moses H. Grossman. As founder and guiding spirit of the American Arbitration Society he has extended its usefulness throughout the entire country.

CHICAGO, Sept. 25 -- Verne Miller, former Sheriff of Huron, S.D., exconvict and leader of the Oklahoma gang of desperadoes responsible for many crimes, was identified today as one of the bandits who last Friday robbed the Federal Reserve Bank mail and killed Policeman Miles Cunningham.

DETROIT, Sept. 25 -- A local NRA compliance board was named late today for suburban Dearborn, where the Ford Motor Company is situated, but the board will have no authority to pass upon or discuss complaints lodged against the Ford company.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 -- A proclamation by President Roosevelt to set up the Corporation of Foreign Security Holders within a short time was predicted today in official circles.

Captain Francizek Hynek and Lieutenant Zbigniew Burzynski, the Polish balloonists who won the James Gordon Bennett Trophy for 1933 and then were forced to trek ninety miles through, the wilds of Northern Quebec nearly a fortnight ago, arrived in New York yesterday.

HAVRE DE GRACE, Md., Sept. 25 (AP). -- T.H. Somerville's Pova., undefeated in three starts this year, qualified handsomely for her $10,000 Eastern Shore engagement when she coasted to an easy victory over six other juveniles in the six-furlong Federal Hill Purse, feature of the program at the Harford Association's course today.

WILMINGTON, Del., Sept. 25 (AP) -- With an injunction suit already hanging over their heads, stockholders of the Pacific Eastern Corporation of New York debated for hours today whether to accept an offer of cash and stock in settlement of all claims against Goldman, Sachs Co. No vote was reached.

Market statistics conveyed the impression yesterday that speculators were content to let well enough alone, or to remain on the sidelines until such time as some of the more significant government policies are outlined more clearly. For the time being Wall Street -- as Its opinion was reflected by the scattered comment -- is convinced that currency inflation, if it ever actually was seriously considered, has been put far into the future.

Joe Cook, the acrobatic cabman, has finally succeeded in driving "Hold Your Horses" into town. All his horses and all his men reclaimed the old Winter Garden from the cinema last evening. In spite of Joe's beaming smile and his demented inventions, his show is a little labored.

MEXICO, D.F., Sept. 25 -- Tampico, Mexico's greatest oil port, lay in ruins tonight after the passage of a hurricane that destroyed at least three-fourths of the city. Some reports put the toll in dead and injured as high as 5,000.

Colonel Roscoe Turner flew from Los Angeles to New York yesterday in 10 hours 5 minutes 30 seconds, a new world's record for the distance. He not only set a record for the transcontinental flight but eclipsed all previous marks for such a distance, 2,520 miles.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 -- The Federal Reserve Board's condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety leading cities on Sept. 20 shows a decrease for the week of $39,000,000 in net demand deposits, and increases of $18,000,000 in time deposits and $12,000,000 in loans and investments.
Every Fusion candidate on the city slate has pledged himself to reject any endorsement that may be offered by the backers of the movement to run Joseph V. McKee for Mayor or by any other group.
Henry Suydam, former Assistant Secretary of State and secretary to the recent naval conference, and Mrs. Suydam will sail today for Europe on the Cunarder Mauretania. Others on the ship will be:

To the Editor of The New York Times: According to John Yearwood, the unions now have the power to place their heels on the neck of industry and destroy it, under the mandate of the NRA, and that is the principal point of Mr. Ford's objection to signing up with NRA.

CHICAGO, Sept. 26 -- The power which X-ray and cathode ray tubes afford for artificially altered hereditary traits in living things, for making variations which persist for many generations, and originating species, was described today before the biology section of the American Congress of Radiology.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 -- Testimony that the Shipping Board spent $1,825,718 in repairing eighteen ships that were sold to the Export Steamship Corporation for $1,071,431, and that a Hoover Cabinet member approved a loan extension to the company when its liabilities were $3,952,000 and assets $1.172,199, was received today by a Senate investigating committee.

The New York Stock Exchange abandoned yesterday its plan to transfer a large part of its business to its new affiliate, the New Jersey Stock Exchange, to avoid new city taxes. The taxes affecting the Exchange were vetoed early last evening by Mayor O'Brien.
MOSCOW, Sept. 26 (AP) -- Colonel and Mrs. Charles A. Lindbergh topped off a strenuous day of sightseeing in the Soviet capital tonight night with a visit to a Russian ballet, let, "The Red Poppy."
PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 26 -- Tommy Loughran of Philadelphia and Jack Sharkey of Boston will meet at the Phillies' ball park tonight in the first legalized fifteen-round bout in Pennsylvania's history.

Plans still tentative are under way, It was revealed here last night, for establishing an international transatlantic airship service within, the next two years. Airships of the Zeppelin type would he used and sailings would he on a bi-monthly basis, according to the program.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Sept. 26 -- While Harvard will make no curtailment in its extensive athletic program, rigid economy will be practiced in all branches of sport, it was announced today by William J. Bingham, director of athletics.
PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 26 -- The peaceful progress of the Pennsylvania women's golf championship was disturbed by two reversals of form in the first match round today at the Aronimink Golf Club.

HIGHLAND, N.Y., Wednesday, Sept. 27 -- Two hundred passengers asleep on the Hudson River Night Line boat Rensselaer were thrown from their berths when the Rensselaer, southbound, was hit by an unidentified freighter in the dense morning fog 200 feet off shore here at 2:40 A.M. this morning.

The first quarter-million signed consumer pledge cards were delivered at local NRA headquarters at the Hotel Pennsylvania yesterday by 150 women canvassers who arrived from the Bronx in four motor buses accompanied by a brass band.

Reports of apartment rentals in the city yesterday indicated an extended house-hunting season. Brokers and managing agents were kept busy signing up new tenants for buildings scattered over a wide area. Many tenants are renewing their leases.
TRENTON, N.J., Sept. 26 -- Sturdy, previously unconquered this season, met defeat today in the 2-year-old trot, feature of the inaugural program at the Trenton Fair.

The color-bearers of Joseph. E. Widener, which did not do so well at their home course, Belmont Park, are making a good record at Aqueduct, where Peace Chance added to the success of the stable yesterday by taking the Adriana Purse.

The movement to put Joseph V. McKee into the Mayoralty race by nominating him on an independent Democratic ticket continued yesterday. It appeared that nothing short of a direct repudiation of his candidacy by President Roosevelt, of which there is little chance in view of the White House attitude against interference in local politics, would prevent Mr. McKee from running.

CHICAGO, Sept. 26 -- Stockholders of Commonwealth Edison Company and Public Service Company of Northern Illinois will be presented with a plan in the near future for a closer unification of the Chicago district's electric utilities, according to reports in La Salle Street today.
Logical city planning as a measure of economy was advocated last night by Controller George McAneny, who is president and general director of the Regional Plan Association of New York.

PARIS, Sept. 26 -- The Bourse was unable today to hold yesterday's gains, except in the case of government rentes, which continued to prove their strength. Today's discouraging market was ascribed to the irregularity in Wall Street yesterday.
MOSCOW, Sept. 26 -- A "rupture of press relations" is the latest and most novel step in the growing tension between the Soviet Union and the Nazis.

Pressure against the markets yesterday was the result not so much of apprehension as of uncertainty. Indecision was shown in all trading operations, in both the financial and commodity markets. But the final result was a mark-down of prices, all along the line.

DETROIT, Sept. 26 (AP) -- Reuben Fine and Robert Willman of New York, and three Detroiters -- E. Michelsen, E. Opsahl and L. Stolcenberg -- were winners in the fifth round of the championship tournament of the Western Chess Association today.
MEMPHIS, Sept. 26 -- The "home folks" got a big surprise today when they learned that Machine Gun Kelly was really George F. Barnes Jr., a native son.

Daily average gross crude oil production in the United States last week was 2,487,000 barrels, compared with 2,603,450 barrels in the previous week, a decline of 116,450 barrels, according to the American Petroleum Institute. Decreases of 79,600 barrels in the average daily output of East Texas and 14,200 barrels in that of California were the most important changes for the week.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Sept. 26 -- Under the will of Arthur Kingsley Porter, internationally known archaeologist and Harvard lecturer, who was drowned off the Irish coast this Summer, his home in Cambridge will ultimately become the property of the president and fellows of Harvard College, to be held by them as a historical monument.

PITTSFIELD, Mass., Sept. 26 -- The Lenox Garden Club had its final meeting of the season this afternoon at the home of Mrs. Anson Phelps Stokes. Brook Farm. The Rev. Dr. Edward Russell Bourne, chairman of the club's roads committee, spoke on Berkshire highway beautification.

JERUSALEM, Sept. 26 -- The Empress of Abyssinia arrived here this morning for a visit to Palestine in circumstances quite different from those of the Queen of Sheba, the ancestor of her husband, who came to the Holy Land bearing rich gifts of vassalage for King Solomon 3,000 years ago.
New York University student leaders approved yesterday the recent suggestion of Chancellor Harry Woodburn Chase to set aside a part of the university for student discussion.

NORTHAMPTON, Mass., Sept. 26 -- At the opening chapel exercises of Smith College's fifty-ninth academic year President William Allan Neilson announced the awarding of the Dwight W. Morrow, the William Allan Neilson and the Sophia Smith honorary scholarships.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 -- The war Department issued the following order today:
The name of Ben Cantwell yesterday was added to those of Carl Hubbell and Dizzy Dean in the select circle of National League pitchers who have won twenty games this season.

Pierpont V. Davis, vice president of the City Company of New York, Inc., was elected chairman of the New York group of the Investment Bankers Association at the group's annual meeting yesterday at the Bankers Club. Mr. Davis, who has been vice chairman of the group, succeeds Robert E. Christie Jr. of Dillon, Read Co., who has been nominated for the presidency of the association.

Pierpont V. Davis, vice president of the City Company of New York, Inc., was elected chairman of the New York group of the Investment Bankers Association at the group's annual meeting yesterday at the Bankers Club. Mr. Davis, who has been vice chairman of the group, succeeds Robert E. Christie Jr. of Dillon, Read Co., who has been nominated for the presidency of the association.

OKLAHOMA CITY, Sept. 26 -- Kelly and his wife will be started on their way to Oklahoma City for trial in the Urschel kidnapping case immediately after the jury now hearing the trial of ten other defendants files out to seek a verdict.

GENEVA, Sept. 26 -- Even more strenuously than yesterday the disarmament talks continue today, this time centred in the compromise project which the Italian delegates, Signors Suvitch and Aloisi, were busily explaining to the French, British, Germans and Americans.

RING LARDNER illustrated in his own person the efficacy of laughter as a buckler against fate. Long months of invalidism preceded his untimely end, but to the last it is astonishing how the fountain of rich humor in him continued to play unimpaired. His latest "manner" was his earliest manner.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 -- Applications are reaching the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation by the hundreds from State non-member banks for admission into the insurance fund, J.F.T. O'Connor, Controller of the Currency, said today in an address before the Washington Advertising Club.
Joe Gregorovic always called on Louis Zelenka when trouble threatened. Louis was his best friend and his buddy in the naval militia. Joe was 19 and his friend two years younger.

MICHIGAN, CITY, Ind., Sept. 26 Ten convicts, all desperate men imprisoned for murder, bank robbery or automobile banditry, escaped from the Indiana State Penitentiary here today after shooting Finley C. Carson, a 72-year-old clerk.
Emil Ludwig, biographer and historian, said yesterday on his arrival on the French liner Paris that he hated biographies and would write no more of them.

TOKYO, Wednesday, Sept. 27 -- Foreign Minister Koki Hirota's foreign policy will be primarily directed toward breaking the deadlock in Japan's relations with China, according to inspired statements in the principal morning newspapers.

Final plans for the $4,200,000 campaign of the Federation for the Support of Jewish Philanthropic Societies, which opens on Oct. 15, were outlined last night at the Harmonie Club, 4 East Sixtieth Street, at a meeting of more than 150 committee chairmen in charge of the drive.

The new New York County Democratic Committee, which is the legal name for Tammany under the election law, met last evening in Tammany Hall. It organized by the re-election of David H. Knott as chairman, Raymond J. O'Sullivan as secretary and Philip F. Donohue as treasurer.

Fishing reports for recent days should encourage those who like to angle in the ocean and bays until the last chance of catching any species is gone. Once more there are indications that fishermen intend to continue operations as long as they can.

New York shipping men said yesterday that the operators would welcome almost unanimously the provisions of the shipping code submitted on Monday which will tend to regulate rates of the trade more strictly than ever before.
OXFORD, England, Sept. 26 (AP) -- The Oxford repertory company today scrapped plans to produce Oscar Wilde's "Salome" because objections were entered by the university vice chancellor, F.J. Lys.

In response to a request from Governor Lehman, the State Charities Aid Association has organized a citizens' committee to promote favorable action by the voters on the $60,000,000 bond issue authorized for unemployment relief at the last session of the Legislature and to be voted on in November as Proposition I.

PRINCETON, N.J, Sept. 26 -- "We are entering an era when system and organization will be of greater and greater importance; it is the business of learning to explain and direct these systems," asserted President Harold Willis Dodds of Princeton at the opening exercises of the university's 187th year in the university chapel this afternoon.

The bond market on the Stock Exchange closed steady to firm yesterday, with total dealings slightly above $10,000,000. United States Government and leading foreign loans finished higher. Strength marked New York transportation issues.

Columbia and Manhattan resumed actual football combat yesterday at Baker Field in another of their practice scrimmages. The Lions went on the offense during the first hour and, although they were hampered by the absence of Ed Brominski and Sam Maniaci, injured halfbacks, put on a dazzling aerial attack.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 -- The United States Government has notified Great Britain that it cannot delay or modify its naval program to conform with recent British suggestions about reducing the tonnage of vessels in the cruiser B or six-inch gun class under the London Naval Treaty.
NEW YORK. Mr. and Mrs. Charles S. Whitman have returned from Newport to the Delmonico.
PROVIDENCE, R.I., Sept. 26 -- There is no man in football who is more atune with the spirit of experiment and change abroad in the land than De Ormond (Tuss) McLaughry.
NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 26 -- Mr. and Mrs. Verner Z. Reed Jr., who will close their season next week at Sea Cove, gave their final dinner of the Summer there tonight.

Elimination of city-paid life guards and the transfer of their work to the United States Volunteer Life Saving Corps would save the city $200,000 a year, Budget Director Maurice A. Stephenson was told yesterday by speakers for the corps.
An unemployed dress operator leaped under northbound Jerome Avenue subway train at the 149th Street station in the Bronx during the rush hour last night, dragging his fiancee with him.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 -- Two plans to protect American holders of defaulted foreign securities are now under close examination in official circles, Secretary Hull said today.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., Sept. 26 -- Scoring seven birdies in the course of his round, Paul Runyan, Ryder Cup player, enabled his team to capture the Westchester amateur-pro tourney with a 66 at the Bonnie Briar Country Club today.

LEIPZIG, Sept. 26 -- Marinus Van der Lubbe, the twisted instrument of a dark power whose nature is still to be determined, confessed before the German Supreme Court today that on the night of Feb. 25 he attempted to burn down three public buildings in Berlin, including the City Hall and the Palace of the former Kaiser, as a preliminary to setting the Reichstag fire that has so gravely affected the political fate of Germany.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Apropos Ernest E. Rich's dissertation in THE TIMES regarding the distinction in the use of "anxiety" and "eagerness." let me add a word about "surprise" and "astonish."

RYE, N.Y., Sept. 26 -- Thc seventh annual national professional tennis championship tournament started at the Westchester Country Club today, with nineteen matches being completed after more than eight hours of play.

CHICAGO, Sept. 26 -- Efforts of Eastern operators to advance the wheat market today were without avail except for a short time after the opening of the Board of Trade, when the price went about 1 cent a bushel above yesterday's finish.

After fourteen hours of discussion and argument the Committee of Eighteen appointed to prepare a milk marketing agreement for the New York Metropolitan Area Milkshed adjourned at midnight last night with the announcement that "most of the essential features" of the regional code had been worked out.

James Roosevelt, eldest son of the President, sailed for Europe last night on the North German Lloyd liner Europa. Mr. Roosevelt, who is in the insurance business, said his trip was primarily for pleasure, but that he hoped to combine some business with it.

Frederick Barter Campbell, an attorney of 20 Exchange Place, who is a director of numerous American and English insurance companies and a member of several prominent clubs, began suit yesterday in United States District Court to test the constitutionality of President Roosevelt's orders against gold hoarding.

Two years ago the Group Theatre actors upset the early autumnal complacence. Last evening, at the Broadhurst, they performed the same office by mounting the first engrossing play of the season, "Men in White," by Sidney Kingsley. Although Mr. Kingsley is not a medical man, he has written about the ideals and conflicts of loyalty of the medical profession with fervent convictions, disclosing uncommon familiarity with his subject.

The particular event celebrated today (rather than the actual anniversary, which falls on Nov. 22) is the purchase of White Plains from the Indians. There might also be commemorated a nearer 250th anniversary -- that of the creation on Nov. 1, 1683, of Westchester County.

NEW ORLEANS, Sept. 26 (AP) -- The New Orleans Pelicans, champions of the Southern Association, today captured their first Dixie series title by scoring a third straight victory over San Antonio, Texas League title-winners. New Orleans took the series by four games to two.

OUT in the West they are taking Mike Donlin to his final resting place. A glamourous figure was Turkey Mike, the first of a long list of notables who came with the dawn of what might be called the modern era of baseball.

Whatever else may be said of the plans conveniently grouped as NRA, they are at least in line with an old American tradition. This is that legitimate business should be helped in every reasonable way, and never hampered more than necessary. President ROOSEVELT ever since March 4 has been proceeding on these assumptions.

Determined efforts to relieve the "excessive overcrowding" and "appalling conditions" of municipal hospital maternity wards were brought to the attention of Mayor O'Brien yesterday by a delegation of civic leaders, who later reeeived a hearing before Budget Director Maurice A. Stephenson.

It is surprising to find Mr. UNTERMYER still damning the work of the Grimm, committee with faint praise. Regardless of the compliments and vague promises with which even his sharpest thrusts are introduced, the net effect of his public utterances recently has been to discourage genuine economy.
WESTBURY, L.I., Sept. 26 -- Two games today started off the sixteen-goal Autumn Plate polo tournament at the Meadow Brook Club.

Dr. Henry T. Fleck has retired as head of the Music Department of Hunter College after more than thirty years' service, it was announced yesterday. Dr. Fleck, widely known in educational and musical circles, has been especially active in popularizing good music and has worked through a long career to make free concerts an institution in metropolitan life.

Earl Carroll, theatrical producer, who himself served a prison term in a clash with the law a few years ago, played policeman in the District Attorney's office yesterday when he arrested two officials of Local 829 of the United Scenic Artists Union on a conspiracy charge.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 -- So many proposals and details were suggested today at the first meeting of the National Advisory Committee on Subsistence Homesteads, a part of President Roosevelt's recovery program, that it was decided to continue the session through tomorrow.
PEIPING, Wednesday, Sept. 27 -- Chinese and Japanese military authorities conferred today and reached an understanding on the disposition of the rebel forces of Fang Cheng-wu.

WESTFIELD, N.J., Sept. 26 -- R.C. Maxwell of Princeton and the Trenton Country Club led the field at the end of the first round of play for the twelfth annual New Jersey State Seniors Golf Association championship at the Shackamaxon Country Club today.

The rights of holders of $500,000 of debentures of the Cigar Stores Realty Holdings, Inc., a bankrupt subsidiary of the United Cigar Stores of America, were restored yesterday by a decision by Irwin Kurtz, Federal referee, who has presided at hearings in the case held in the last year in his offices at 15 Park Row.

George S. Carr, a director and a vice president of the defunct Bank of United States, was the State's most important witness yesterday in the trial of Isidor J. Kresel on charges of abetting in the misapplication of about $2,000,000 of the bank's funds in 1929.

Hesitation on the Stuck Exchange yesterday seemed to indicate to the Wall Street tape-watchers that the market needed nourishment. There was nothing of consequence in the day's news to arouse speculators outside of the fact that the brokerage community apparently had won its fight against the proposed city tax on stock transactions.

Samuel Seabury returned from Europe yesterday, unwilling to discuss the local political situation until he had had an opportunity to get first-hand information from his colleagues in the Fusion movement.

The United States Smelting, Refining and Mining Company reported for the eight months ended on Aug. 31 a consolidated net profit after interest, depreciation, depletion, amortization and other deductions, of $2,504,039. This is equivalent after 7 per cent preferred dividend requirements, to $2.67 a share on 528,765 average shares of $50 par common stock and compares with $1,163,596, or 9 cents a share on 540,527 average common shares in the corresponding period of 1932.

The city administration, lacking the will to save, has failed to cooperate with, the Municipal Economy Committee in its efforts to reduce governmental costs, Peter Grimm, chairman of the committee, charged yesterday at a meeting of the City Club at 55 West Forty-fourth Street.

Immediate approval of the NRA code of fair practice for the retail stores of the country was urged yesterday by Ward Melville, president of the National Council of Shoe Retailers, Inc., in a letter to A.D. Whiteside, deputy administrator.

CHICAGO, Sept. 23 (AP) -- Testimony that the underworld had marked the late Mayor Ahton J. Cermak for execution because of his anti-criminal activities and had chosen Louis (Little New York) Campagna as his executioner was given today in Criminal Court.

Pay dirt, "or something that glitters like it, was struck by Sam Abrams, the plumber, at 2 o'clock yesterday afternoon in Nathan Garelik's back yard at 1,221 Vyse Avenue, the Bronx. The gold rush kept up until dark when Garelik ordered the front door locked to keep out wide-eyed, twitching-fingered neighbors who came rushing through the hall to collect samples.

The annual school health day in the public schools will be held Thursday. All academic work will be suspended until all pupils have been observed and tested for acuity of vision, for evidences of eyestrain, defective hearing, defective teeth, malnutrition, obstructed nasal breathing and other evident defects.

HAVRE DE GRACE, Md., Sept 26 (AP) -- J.E. Hughea's Silent Shot drove to victory over three other 3-year-olds in the Perryville Purse, one mile and seventy yards, which was the feature of the Harford Association's racing program today.
Joseph V. McKee still commands popular support for the Mayoralty, if a straw vote being conducted at the Exposition of Women's Arts and Industries at the Astor is any indication.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 23 -- John O'Donnell, chairman of the Democratic city committee and leader of the Roosevelt campaign in Philadelphia last year, was ostracized today by State and national party leaders.

SPARKILL, N.Y., Sept. 26 -- Turning in a splendid card of 44, 40 -- 84, three strokes over women's par, Miss Jane Brooks of the Rockland Country Club won low gross honors today over her home course in the one-day tournament of the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association.

ROME, Sept. 26 -- Latest reports tonight showed sixteen persons killed, about 200 injured and hundreds made homeless in the earthquake which occurred in the Abruzzi Mountain region in the early morning hours. That district has furnished tens of thousands of emigrants to America.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 -- Confident that public works funds soon will be made available for the purchase of about 1,000,000 tons of steel rails, officials engaged in negotiations of the transaction said today its outcome was dependent upon the price offered by steel companies equipped to supply orders.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 -- All advocates of inflation were urged today by Senator Thomas, Democrat, of Oklahoma, a leader of the campaign for cheaper money, to quiet their demands to permit a full trial of President Roosevelt's credit expansion program.

After so many triumphs over the Insurrectos Mr. KOENIG may be forgiven for having believed in his invincibility. He could have kept his legend unshattered if he had not tempted fortune once too often. His long record of success is more than sufficient evidence of his consummate skill in the art of political self-preservation.
To the Editor of The New York Times: A life insurance statement recently showed a high percentage of mortality among people of middle age, due to casualties.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 -- President Roosevelt will have the extremely important master retail and drug trade codes before him ready for his signature some time during the coming week-end, if hopes expressed by the Recovery Administration today are realized.

Mayor O'Brien, joining hands with his fellow-candidates, M. Maldwin Fertig, Democratic candidate for President of the Board of Aldermen, and Frank J. Prial, nominee for Controller, officially opened yesterday the Mayoralty campaign of the Brooklyn Democratic organization by giving a "pep talk" to the district leaders.

HARRISON, N.Y., Sept. 26 -- Miss Barbara Stoddard, daughter of Louis E. Stoddard, chairman of the United States Polo Association, pjayed a round of golf today that established her as a potential candidate for major honors in the metropolitan district.

A tightening in the Street offerings against call loans to 5/8 from 1/2, which has ruled for weeks, was the only incident of an otherwise featureless session in money. Preparation for end-of the-quarter statements was ascribed as reason for firmness.
RENO, Nev., Sept. 26 -- Suit for divorce against Frederick Thayer Merrill of Santa Barbara, Calif., has been filed by Isabel Thacher Merrill, formerly of New York.

TAMPICO, Mexico, Sept. 26 -- The known death toll from last Sunday's hurricane which buffeted this oil port for several hours was placed officially tonight as 54, with an estimate of 850 injured and much of the city laid waste.

Holidays Cut Buyers' Total. Due to the religious holidays the number of buyers regsitered in the market during the week ended yesterday continued to show a decrease under the number listed in the preceding week and for the same period a year ago, according to the lists published in THE TIMES.

A dispatch to THE TIMES yesterday reported belief In Washington that a new "Corporation of Foreign Security Holders" will shortly be set up by proclamation of the President. Provision for such an agency was made in Title II of the Securities Act approved last May.

PITTSBURGH, Pa., Sept. 26 -- Five hundred striking miners of Fayette County staged two demonstrations before workers of the Carnegie Steel Company in Clairton today as a small army of heavily armed officers stood guard.

BRIARCLIFF MANOR, N.Y., Sept. 26 -- The administration at Washington was praised here today as sponsor of a "square deal" as well as a "new deal" by Paul W. West, general manager of the Association of National Advertisers. He told members of the Insurance Advertising Conference at Briarcliff Lodge that he had been impressed deeply in Washington last week by the sincerity and high purpose of the nation's leaders.
Mayor O'Brien vetoed the two city bills taxing stock shares and the gross income of security dealers at 8:35 o'clock last night, thus preventing the removal to Newark of the Stock Exchange trading.
BERLIN, Sept. 26 (AP) -- The Reichsbank's statement as of Sept. 23 shows the following changes, in reichsmarks:

MEMPHIS, Tenn., Sept. 26 -- George (Machine-Gun) Kelly, wanted for murder in three large cities, was captured here this morning without a shot being fired. He will be taken to Oklahoma City in few days to stand trial for alleged participation in the kidnapping of Charles F. Urschel, wealthy oil man.
PARIS, Sept. 26 -- The French Government is seriously considering denouncing the Franco-German trade treaty of 1927 and the modus vivendi of 1932, it was authoritatively learned today.

The strike of 16,000 painters in Manhattan, Brooklyn and the Bronx that for more than a week had tied up building and renovating work totaling many millions, was settled last night through the mediation of Grover A. Whalen, chairman of the local NRA, at the headquarters of the organization in the Hotel Pennsylvania.

Sharp increases in payroll additions and the number of signed consumer pledges up-State were shown by reports from the fifty-seven counties outside New York City yesterday. W. Averell Harriman, chairman of the President's Emergency Re-employment campaign Committee, announced.

PHILADELPHIA (Wednesday), Sept. 27 -- A rebellion of nearly 1,700 convicts flared at the Eastern Penitentiary here last night and raged for six hours before two fire companies, 600 Philadelphia policemen and several details of State police controlled the situation early today.

LONDON, Sept. 26 -- The Royal and Ancient Golf Club of St. Andrews tonight adopted the revised rules of golf, a draft of which has been submitted to the United States Golf Association. The rules will become effective Jan. 1.

The National City Bank issued yesterday reports of all its affiliates in compliance with the terms of the Banking Act of 1933, which required publication of statements of national bank affiliates by yesterday at the latest.

PRETORIA, South Africa, Sept. 26 -- Major C.K. Cochran-Patrick, a distinguished wartime pilot, and Sir Michael Oppenheimer were killed this morning when their airplane crashed at Baragwanath Airdrome and burst into flames. Stanley People, ground engineer, made a heroic effort to save the fliers.
PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 26 -- That record winning streak of five straight compiled by the Dodgers came suddenly to an end in a ninth-inning finish today.
WASHINGTON. Sept. 26 -- Increased "velocity" in bank deposits was an important factor in financing business improvement in July, the Federal Reserve Board said in its monthly bulletin today.
Price movements in commodities traded on local exchanges were irregularly lower yesterday in relatively quiet trading. Cash prices also dropped.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 -- Postmaster General Farley was in conference for two hours today with President Roosevelt and later discussed the New Tork political situation with Louis McHenry Howe, chief secretary to the President.
HAVANA, Sept. 26 -- Communists' efforts to oust President Grau and form their own government are expected to result in a general strike throughout Cuba.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 -- A return to the gold standard within the next calendar year, with the dollar "devalued," appeared to be a strong possibility tonight with the revelation that Federal Reserve Board officials and others high in the confidence of the government on fiscal issues were studying such a move, and that it was being urged upon President Roosevelt.

In the preceding article we traced the development of exchange from its origin in simple barter down to the emergence of "real money," gold coin. We come now to that refinement of "real money" known as "representative money."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 -- In spite of its efforts to stop further attempts to modify the collective bargaining clauses of the National Industrial Recovery Act in industrial codes, the NRA was confronted today with the necessity of restating its ruling on this subject.

The first thirty-seven railroads to report for August showed net operating income of about $26,679,000, against $12,720,000 in August, 1932, an increase of 109.7 per cent, and against $24,052,000 in August, 1931, an increase of 10.9 per cent. Their July net was about $27,983,000, compared with $5,247,000 in August, 1932, an increase of 433.3 per cent.
