Circulation of notices for about 45,000 bales had little effect on prices on the Cotton Exchange yesterday. One block of 25,000 bales stopped by a commission house was believed to represent the acceptance of any payment for spot cotton on contracts purchased below 7 cents a pound last Spring.

The public works part of the recovery program, now lagging behind the NRA, will be brought into line in the next thirty days, Daniel C. Roper, Secretary of Commerce, predicted here yesterday. He appealed for voluntary cooperation of business men to keep purchasing power ahead of price rises and urged upon organized industry its responsibility in the second, or enforcement, phase of the NRA, now beginning.

Eagles in Moscow. Colonel and Mrs. LINDBERGH were acclaimed by the Moscow crowds on their arrival from Leningrad. The cheering spectators, reports Mr. DURANTY, "did not think of politics or the possibilities of American recognition; they felt a thrill of admiration, affection and emulation."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 -- Joseph Edward Cronin, the youngest man ever to manage the Washington Senators, has decided to do a little master-minding as to just which one of his Dig-four pitchers will he started against the Giants next Tuesday at the Polo Grounds.
President Roosevelt arrived in New York last night to the acclaim of thousands of persons who lined the streets from the Pennsylvania Station to his home at 49 East Sixty-fifth Street.

CHESTER, Pa., Sept. 26 -- Employes of the Ford Motor Company's local assembly plant, the Eastern seaboard outlet for Ford shipments, in the European and South American trade, walked out today in protest against a shortening of the work week, which reduced their minimum weekly wage to $16.

WILMINGTON, Del., Sept. 26 (AP) -- Approximately 501,000 shares of stock of the Goldman-Sachs Trading Corporation, now the Pacific Eastern Corporation, with miscellaneous stocks and bonds, were sold today at public sale for $1,493,998.80 to Milton Kramer, New York attorney.

Supreme Court Justice Alfred Frankenthaler decided yesterday that because the Empire Trust Company, as trustee of a mortgage on the sixteen-story building at 257-267 West Thirty-ninth Street, had a receiver appointed for the property in May, 1932, before the summons in a foreclosure suit had been served on any of the defendants, it losses $33,071 in rents collected by the receiver before he was removed.

GENEVA, Sept. 26 -- Wide interest has been attracted here by an article in THE NEW YORK TIMES of Sunday describing a plan for what is called the World Recovery Act (WRA). An extensive summary was published in the Journal des Nations in a prominent place and much attention was given to it in other newspapers of Europe.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 -- All Americans at Tampico, Mexico, are believed to have escaped the destruction of the hurricane, according to a report received by the State Department today from R.S. Carey, United States Vice Consul at that port.

As crowds hurried in and out of the Essex Street station of the B.M.T. subway at 5:30 o'clock last evening, a man was shot and killed on the platform. Another man, seen by a subway porter to run through an exit gate and up the steps to Delancey and Norfolk Streets, was seized by a policeman after the pointer, following, shouted to him to stop the runner.

BOSTON, Sept. 26 (AP) -- Federal Judge James A. Lowell, already under fire in Congress for his decision involving a Negro wanted in Virginia for murder, was disclosed today as under investigation for his conduct of cases involving the shipment of poisonous ginger extract from Massachusetts to Western States.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 -- President Roosevelt, in a letter to Captain J.W. McQueen, commander of the Disabled American Veterans, commending the annual forget-me-not campaign of that organization, congratulated the association on deciding not to press for redemption of the adusted service certificates until the condition of the Treasury warranted.

Supporters of Chase Mellen Jr., prospective successor to Samuel S. Koenig as president of the New Toils County Republican Committee, made a beginning last night at ushering in the new deal in the affairs of the Republican county organization.

MEXICO, D.F., Sept. 26 -- More than fifty bodies had been recovered up to tonight in the Tampico storm area. Three hundred injured persons are, under treatment. [The Associated Press states fifty-four bodies have been recovered and places the number injured at 850.]

DETROIT, Sept. 26 -- Mechanics Educational Society spokesmen claimed tonight that 8,000 tool and die makers had responded to a strike order issued this afternoon and that 2,000 more were expected to walk out within twenty-four hours.

SALEM, N.H., Sept. 26 -- Jack Westrope, who leads all jockeys on American tracks this year with a total of more than 200 winners, placed with all six of his mounts at Rockingham Park today. He was first in two races, second in two events and third twice.

Police chiefs from nearly 100 Connecticut, New Jersey, New York and Pennsylvania towns are scheduled to visit the radio-electrical show in Madison Square Garden today as guests of Commissioner Boland and the New York Police Department.

PARIS, Sept. 26 -- Purchases of Young Plan bonds on the Paris market for account of the Reichsbank have been arousing interest in financial circles here. It is impossible to ascertain the amounts but the quotation on those bonds yesterday rose from 424 to 443, and, according to the Agency Economique et Financiere, it was solely due to intervention of the Reichsbank.

The first of the plays about the new regime in Germany arrived in New York last evening -- at the Mansfield Theatre. It was "Kultur," a work adapted from the German of Theodore Weacnter by Adolf Philipp (a night rumor had it that they are the same), and it was put on under the aegis of J.J. Vincent.

WITTENBERG, Germany, Sept. 27 -- A protest signed by 2,000 Protestant clergymen was lodged with the National Synod today after the Rev. Dr. Ludwig Mueller army chaplain chosen by Chancellor Hitler to head the newly created United German Protestant Church, had been formally confirmed as Reich Bishop by the Synod in session here.

SHANGHAI, Sept. 27. -- While General Chiang Kai-shek, national commander-in-chief, continues active preparations for early launching of the greatest anti-Communist drive, thus far having more than 400,000 of his own troops in Kiangsi, the provincial authorities in Fukien reveal that the Red invasion of that province resulted in the massacre of some 17,000 civilians.
NEW YORK. Mr. and Mrs. William M. Beard win give a dinner tonight in the small ballroom suite of the Ritz-Carlton for Prince and Princess Fabrizio Colonna and their niece, Princess Colonna, of Rome.

Joseph V. McKee's candidacy now can serve only to divide the anti-Tammany vote, Samuel Seabury declared yesterday. Mr. McKee had his chance and ran away, the Fusion leader said, and his entering the Mayoralty campaign at this time would be in violation of a solemn promise.

ALBANY, Sept. 27 (AP) -- A campaign was started today by the State Charities Aid Association to encourage voters to approve the $60,000,000 bond issue for unemployment relief at the November election.
BOSTON, Sept. 27 (AP). -- The Braves defeated the Red Sox, 2 to 1, today in a game played before a crowd of 15,000 for the Boston Unemployment Fund.

WESTBURY, L.I., Sept. 27 -- Starting slowly, but gaining momentum through the latter part of the game. John Hay Whitney's Greentree four rode to the final round of the national open polo championship today, defeating Westbury, 14 to 9, on International Field at the Meadow Brook Club.

While it seemed yesterday to be the opinion in Wall Street that the administration was satisfied to let "business seek its own level," the impression was that some decisive action in Washington might be expected soon. The report that currency stability is being sought excited much comment, but it came too late in the day to be useful as a market influence.
BOSTON, Sept. 27 -- Admiral Byrd honored two marine veterans today with commands of high responsibility in his expedition.
PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 27 -- Jack Sharkey's climb back to another heavyweight title match ran against another snag tonight.

The fate of the local NRA organization will be decided at conferences in Washington today by Grover A. Whalen, local chairman, with General Hugh S. Johnson, National Recovery Administrator, and Senator Robert F. Wagner, chairman of the National Labor Mediation Board.

SPRINGFIELD, N.J., Sept. 27. -- A two-point victory for Mrs. A.D. Faxon in the last match gave the New Jersey team the Myra, D. Paterson Cup in the annual triangular team matches with Long Island and Westchester at the Baltusrol Golf Club today.

Mistaking him for a hold-up man, Patrolman Charles Meehan of the Bathgate Avenue station early today shot and killed Fred Conrad, 30 years old, in the midst of three friends with whom he had been talking in front of 454 East 183d Street, the Bronx.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 27. -- Lefty Gomez's superb pitching in the pinches marked the double-header with which the Yanks closed the season with the Athletics at Shibe Park today. About 6,000 fans witnessed the skirmishes.

GENEVA, Sept. 27 -- Argentina, which ratified its league membership only Monday, is almost certain to be elected to the League Council next Monday. Denmark and Australia also are expected to get seats.

MICHIGAN CITY, Ind., Sept. 27 (AP). -- Two hundred National Guardsmen were mobilized in Indiana's "war zone" tonight to assist hundreds of police and citizens in hunting down tell escaped killers and robbers from the State penitentiary.

Bishop William T. Manning has refused to let the Greater New York Federation of Churches use the Cathedral of St. John the Divine in November for a service of united New York Protestanism in commemoration of the 450th birthday of Martin Luther on Nov. 10.

PROVIDENCE, Sept. 27. -- An entering class of about 390 students from all sections of the country gathered in Sayles Hall today at the beginning of the 170th year of Brown University to hear the urgent plea of President Barbour that all Brown undergraduates "try the focus of appreciation instead of that of criticism" in these confused and difficult days.

ST. JOHN'S, Nfld., Sept. 27 -- The Hudson's Bay Company steamer Nascopie brought back to civilization today Corporal H.W. Stallworthy and Constables R.W. Hamilton and A. Monro of the Royal Canadian Mounted Police, out of the Arctic wastes whose silence had engulfed them for more than two years.

HYDE PARK, N.Y., Sept. 27 -- Methods for bolstering key industries by Federal credit, with the railroads as the probable first beneficiaries, occupied President Roosevelt today as he returned for the final visit of the year to his home here.

TULSA, Okla., Sept. 27 -- Further steps toward reorganization of the Oklahoma Natural Gas Corporation and sale of its assets and liabilities to a new company were taken today in Federal court as Federal Judge Kennamer set Nov. 8 for the sale on a creditor's bill.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Sept. 27 -- Kemper Peabody, who was general supervisor of buildings of the New York Central Lines east of Buffalo at his retirement in 1931, died last night at his home here, 17 Dillon Road. His age was 72. He had served the railroad for thirty years.

NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 27. -- A girls' doubles tennis tournament was started at the Casino this afternoon. In the first round Virginia French and Lesley Ripley defeated Ann Wickes and Sylvia Szechenyi, 6-4; Phyllis Gillespie and Frances Ferry defeated Hope and Lucy Saunders, 6-2; Le Brun Rhinelander and Frederica Ripley defeated Eileen Gillespie and Betty Corbin, 6-4, and Peggy Easton and Nandine Szechenyi defeated Penelope Winslow and Nancy Saunders, 9-7.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 27. -- The Washington Senators today declared an unofficial "Carl Hubbell Day" at Griffith Stadium and took a long and only medium well-pleased look at about the best "screw ball" the American League offers.

TOKYO, Sept. 27 -- Revised regulations for the Japanese Naval General Staff, promulgated today, give the Chief of Staff important additional powers, the effect of which is to increase the staff's independence of the Cabinet.

GENEVA, Sept. 27 -- Sir John Simon, British Foreign Secretary, in a speech before the League of Nations Assembly today indirectly confirmed reports that an effort was being made by Germany and Italy to delay the disarmament negotiations here and to transfer them to Italy.
Following is the address by President Nicholas Murray Butler at the opening yesterday of Columbia University's 80th year:
GENEVA, Sept. 27 -- Negotiations by the Dutch Government with other neighbors of Germany to bring the German refugee question before the League of Nations Assembly moved ahead today.

Apartment rentals announced yesterday indicated a continued demand for suites in all sections of Manhattan. Brokers and renting agents report that many tenants are making renewals of their present leases.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 27. -- An increase from $60,100,000 to $61,000,000 in relief costs for August as compared with July, in spite of a decrease of 120,000 in the number of families "on relief" in forty States was announced today by Harry L. Hopkins, Relief Administrator.

There is no use in deceiving ourselves about the need for unemployment relief next Winter. Every penny that public and private agencies can lay their hands on will have to be devoted to the care of those in real distress. New York City has already been urged to increase its contribution.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 27. - Industrial unionism based on the "vertical" organization of industry rather than craft unionism based on "horizontal" organization is the "new phase" into which the trade-union movement must move to cope with modern industrial development, according to James O'Connell and John P. Frey, respectively president and secretary-treasurer of the Metal Trades Department of the American Federation of Labor.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Sept. 27 -- Sixty-two awards for participation in varsity baseball and varsity, junior varsity, combination and freshman rowing were announced today by the Harvard Athletic Association.

SALEM, N.H., Sept. 27 -- Jabot, a filly bearing the silks of C.V. Whitney, outclassed seven rivals in the $4,000 added Juvenile Handicap at Rockingham Park today. The winner, ridden by Robby Robertson, earned $3,420 for her owner.

James Young, 62 years old, a carpenters' labor leader, was summarily arrested yesterday in District Attorney Crain's office on a charge that he extorted $1,500 last Summer from two partners in a contracting concern under promise of "protecting" them from strikes and other possible interference by labor organizations.

The Hudson River Night Line sidewheeler Rensselaer reached New York under her own power yesterday after a collision with the Swedish freighter Roxen in a dense fog off Poughkeepsie shortly before 2 A.M.

WHITE PLAINS, Sept. 27 -- With the President of the United States and the Governor of New York pausing here today as honored visitors, this city celebrated the 250th anniversary of the purchase of its site from the Indians.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 27. -- Representatives of the radio broadcasting industry at a hearing on the code of fair competition submitted by the National Association of Broadcasters today declared that while annual expenditures by radio advertisers increased from $3,832,150 in 1927 to more than $70,000,000 in. 1931, the statistics indicate, that the industry as a whole has not yet operated on a profit basis.

Domestic corporation bonds and leading foreign loans drifted lower yesterday on the Stock Exchange, while most of the United States Government long-term issues registered gains of 1-32 to 10-32 points. Domestic railroad bonds, in particular, were weak, many falling a point or more.

EDWARDSVILLE, Ill., Sept. 27. -- Five men and a woman heard the State demand their death in the electric chair today as punishment for their alleged participation in the kidnapping of August Luer, wealthy Alton banker.
COMMERCIAL. PAPER. Yesterday, Tuesday. For the best names.... 1 1/4% 1 1/4% The quotations are for three-four months' paper.

An appeal to the theatregoing public was made yesterday afternoon at the weekly meeting of the National Legitimate Theatre Committee for assistance in eradicating theatre ticket abuses. To that end placards will be displayed in all theatre lobbies and theatre ticket agencies.

Addresses at the opening of the academic year are as the cries of watchmen on the walls of civilization. We hear again the voice of President. HOPKINS of Dartmouth. Last year he spoke of change "as opportunity." Now he speaks of it " as necessity." In the 163 years of DANIEL WEBSTER'S little college, conditions have never undergone "such fundamentally radical and vital changes " in a twelvemonth as in the year past.
The Fordham varsity football squad went through a lengthy scrimmage session with the freshmen yesterday at Fordham Field in preparation for the opening game on Saturday against Albright.

Evidence which on preceding days had been rejected at the trial of United States Senator James J. Davis for violation of the Federal Lottery Laws in 1931, was allowed yesterday by Judge Johnson Hayes. Judge Hayes had previously held that the government could not introduce testimony relating to a purported lottery conducted in 1930 through charity balls sponsored by the Loyal Order of Moose, of which the Senator was director general.
There will be plenty of native black ducks in the waters adjacent to New York City when the season opens on Oct. 16, according to the latest reports.

New York experienced yesterday the hottest Sept. 27 in the annals of the local weather bureau. The thermometer touched a maximum of 86 at 2 P.M., exceeding by two degrees the previous high mark that had stood since 1881. The day's average temperature, 78, was fifteen degrees above normal for the date.

Three new Tammany district leaders were formally elected last night after last week's bitter primary battles. Although all had been opposed by John F. Curry, they pledged their support to the Tammany chieftain, and to Mayor O'Brien.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W.Va., Sept. 27 -- Declaring that up to Sept. 15 the government's "emergency expenditures" for the year had amounted to $267,000,000, Arthur A. Ballantine, Under-Secretary of the Treasury under President Hoover, warned today that we were facing the prospect of an aggregate expenditure this fiscal year exceeding receipts by a larger figure than in any year since 1919.

George R. Beach, as special master, sold to Pierpont Davis and Paxton Blair, representing the first mortgage bondholders' committee, the property of the Pennsylvania Dock and Warehouse Company, consisting of two eight-story concrete warehouses erected on a plot 1,020 by 377 feet, located just north of Exchange Place, Jersey City, for $2,100,000, and all personal property, including 500 shares of preferred and 4,000 shares of common stock of the General Cold Storage Company, for $3,500.

Music, heavenly maid, had a hard time of it among "our wise and pious ancestors." Mr. JOHN A. KOUWENHOVEN tells us about it in The New England Quarterly. Psalm-singing in the churches is generally called the beginning of American music. This congregational singing may have enraptured the performers and hearers, but it would seem monotonous to the unregenerate.

BROWNSVILLE, Texas, Sept. 27 -- The belief that the death toll from the hurricane which swept Tampico, Mexico, and the surrounding country will exceed 200 was expressed here this afternoon by G. W. Johnson, auditor of Pan-American Airways, the first man to return here after spending three days in the storm section.

VIENNA, Sept. 27 -- The position of the new Dollfuss Cabinet was strengthened today by the formal entry of Heimwehr supporters into the "Patriotic Front" which the Chancellor founded for the express purpose of absorbing all parties and party members who favor the present government.

COLEMAN, Texas, Sept. 27 (AP). -- From a cotton patch Federal agents today dug up $73,250 of the Charles F. Urschel ransom money, reputedly buried by George (Machine Gun) Kelly, who is under arrest at Memphis.

CHESTER, Pa., Sept. 27. -- The Ford Motor Company's assembly plant here was shut down today while Federal mediators attempted to settle the labor dispute which caused a walkout of more than 3,000 workers yesterday.
NEW ORLEANS, La., Sept. 27. -- The Women's Committee of Louisiana has sent the following telegram to Senator M.M. Logan of Kentucky:

A strong fight will be waged by retailers against the changes in existing terms and discounts now being sought in the provisions of manufacturers' codes, it was announced yesterday by Lew Hahn, president of the National Retail Dry Goods Association, following a meeting at which the investigations and action taken to date on producers' codes were reviewed.
LONDON, Sept. 27. -- Eight winners of Paramount's film competition will sail tomorrow on the liner Manhattan, en route to Hollywood.

LONDON, Sept. 27 -- Sir Frederick Leith-Ross, chief economic adviser to the government, sailed on the liner Majestic for the United States today for discussion of war debts with the Washington government.

PEIPING, Thursday, Sept. 28. -- Harassed by Japanese bombing planes the rebel army of Fang Chen-wu is pushing westward through the demilitarized zone, apparently attempting to leave the forbidden territory which it had entered ostentatiously a week ago.
Business on the Cotton Exchange yesterday was comparatively small, and, although prices rallied $1 a bale at one time, the list closed around the bottom with losses of 5 to 12 points.

William C. Creamer, who will celebrate his eighty-third birthday anniversary in November, was the guest of honor yesterday afternoon at another celebration held in the executive offices of Arnold, Constable Co. at Fifth Avenue and Fortieth Street.

The salary of John D. Hertz in 1932 as chairman of the finance committee of the Paramount-Publix Corporation was $87,055, although his contract called for $2,750 a week, or $143,000 annually, according to testimony yesterday at a hearing before Henry K. Davis, Federal Referee in Bankruptcy, at 140 Nassau Street.

The nation is faced with the necessity of removing at least 40,000,000 acres of "marginal" farm lands from cultivation, chamber of commerce secretaries from all parts of the country were told yesterday.

County Judge Alonzo G. McLaughlin, who recently suspended sentence on three alleged laundry racketeers after they had pleaded guilty to indictments charging unlawful conspiracy, said yesterday in a statement that District Attorney William F. X. Geoghan had entered into a pact with him to free the men on probation.

Aggressive efforts by the government to advance its public works program and to increase capital expenditures have "put new life into a flagging steel market," according to the midweek review of The Iron Age. The national average of production of steel is holding at 41 per cent of capacity, the same as two weeks ago and 2 points below the figure of last week.
OKLAHOMA CITY, Sept. 27. -- The defense in the Urschel kidnapping case ended today.

Bruno Walter, who arrived on Tuesday to prepare for the beginning of his third season with the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra next week, told interviewers at the Savoy-Plaza yesterday of his programs and novelties for his eleven-week stay with New York's major orchestra.

By concessions agreed to by defense counsel yesterday in the criminal branch of the Supreme Court, the trial of Isidor J. Kresel, accused of abetting the misapplication of about $2,000,000 of the funds of the Bank of United States was shortened by at least two weeks.

In the article published in THE TIMES today, in the series on "Money and Inflation," it is pointed out that bank credit is a larger factor in the modern world of industry and finance than currency. The latter is a convenient medium for hand-to-hand transactions. But more than 90 per cent of the business dealings within the United States are settled with checks drawn on funds deposited in banks.

HAVRE DE GRACE, Md., Sept. 27 -- Striding their way into the thick of the battle for the 2-year-old turf championship, High Quest and Cavalcade, racing under the colors of Mrs. Dodge Sloane's Brookmeade Stable of New York, today finished one, two in the twenty-first running of the $10,000 added Eastern Shore Handicap.
MOSCOW, Sept. 27. -- During the past ten years the Soviet capital investment has totaled 86,500,000,000 rubles, according to the Gosplan's official records.

The problem of unemployment relief in New York City was considerably aggravated yesterday when the Emergency. Unemployment Relief Committee, of which Harvey D. Gibson is chairman, brought its work to a close at a meeting of its executive committee in the Chamber of Commerce of the State of New York and appointed its appropriations committee to act for it after Oct. 1.

Joseph V. McKee will "have a definite announcement to make" this morning on whether he will be a candidate for Mayor. He went to work on the announcement after 1 o'clock this morning after a long conference at the Hotel Biltmore.

LEIPZIG, Sept. 27 -- Rage that for seven months had been feeding on itself exploded in the Reichstag arson and treason trial before the German Supreme Court today when Judge Vogt, who made the preliminary investigation of the case, was called to the stand and put on the grill by the accused.

Reports to date indicate that the net operating income of all Class railroads in August was greater than in the same month of 1932 for the second consecutive month. While estimated gross revenue for August was ahead of that for July, increased expenditures for maintenance resulted in a smaller amount being transmitted to net in August than in July.

Six concrete proposals, including an "end to the farce of the five-cent subway fare," to keep New York City from financial disaster, were put forward yesterday by Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of Columbia University, in an address at the opening exercises of Columbia's 180th academic year.

Moving-picture films depicting a happy home circle were exhibited before Supreme Court Justice Samuel H. Hofstadter and a jury yesterday by Max D. Steuer, counsel for Mrs. Helen Vogel Stern, in a suit against Mrs. Ruth Erlanger Nathan for $4,000,000 damages for alienating the affections of Allison L.S. Stern, a broker.
A request for Federal fund amounting to $16,486,808 to build seventeen new public school buildings and to complete nineteen others in the city was approved yesterday by the Board of Education.

BOSTON, Sept. 27 -- Lack of funds to purchase "things vital to the safety of the men" was proving a serious hindrance to his second expedition to the Antarctic, Admiral Byrd said tonight. He added that until he obtained the money he needed the bulk of his party would not sail from Boston.

PRINCETON, Sept. 27. -- The 124th year of Lawrenceville School opened this morning with Dr. Mather Abbott, headmaster, addressing the student body in a brief ceremony of welcome. The regular schedule of classes will begin tomorrow morning.

WESTTIELD, K.J., Sept. 27. -- Robert C. Maxwell, left-handed golfer of the Trenton Country Club, retained his lead in the twelfth annual New Jersey State Senior Golf Association championship at the Shackamaxon Country Club today. Maxwell posted an 88 for a thirty-six-hole total of 170.

TRENTON, N.J., Sept. 27. -- Mike Cummings, bay gelding owned by William B. Eckert of Reading, swept to victory in the 2:19 class pace, feature event of today's Trenton fair program. The Reading entry won all three heats. Mr. Frank Worthy was second in every brush.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 -- Political conferences which may have an important bearing on the formation of a coalition government in Cuba, leading to recognition by the United States, will be carried on here in the next few days between Dr. Carlos Finlay, Minister of Sanitation in the Grau San Martin Cabinet, and Dr. Manuel Marquez Sterling, who has been designated Secretary of State in the same Cabinet.
With an indictment obtained in eighteen minutes, the United-States Government took its first step yesterday against the owners of gold who have failed to register their holdings.

ST. ANDREWS, Scotland, Sept. 27 (AP). -- The Prince of Wales and Archie Compston, his personal golf professional, were defeated today by Lord Castlerosse and Miss Dorothy Pearson, runner-up for the women's British golf title in 1927, 4 and 3.
To the Editor of The New York Times: A letter which I am sending this morning to Mr. McKee contains the following paragraph:

The Rev. Dr. Henry A. Stimson, retired Congregational minister, who fought the Indians on the Western plains and hunted buffalo when a young man, will celebrate his ninety-first birthday today. He plans to spend a quiet day at his home, 25 Claremont Avenue, with his family.

The yellow mineral taken out of the Gareliks's back yard at 1,221 Vyse Avenue, the Bronx, isn't gold, after all; it is weathered biotite, a kind of mica. Dr. Daniel T. O'Connell of the geology department at City College settled the point to his satisfaction last night after an analysis.

GLEN HEAD, L.I., Sept. 27. -- Mrs. Helen Matzinger of Roslyn Harbor and Mrs. Royal Victor of the home club were the two prize winners in the one-day tournament of the Women's Long Island Golf Association today at the Women's National Golf and Tennis Club.

Oscar, whose surname in forty-one years in the hotel business has been changed by common consent to "of the Waldorf," is 67 years old today. Yesterday afternoon he sat at his desk poring over plans for the biggest banquet he ever has supervised.

GENEVA, Sept. 27 -- The League Assembly showed sympathy with Austria today by almost unanimously giving long and warm applause to its diminutive Chancellor, Dr. Engelbert Dollfuss, when he rose to address it for the first time.

A complicated strike situation, involving a jurisdictional dispute between two big unions affiliated with the American Federation of Labor, was laid before Grover A. Whalen, chairman of the local NRA organization, yesterday. The situation threatens to develop into a general walkout of 20,000 workers in the knitted outerwear industry and Mr. Whalen was asked to mediate in the controversy.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Sept. 27 -- A year ago a Harvard team whose personnel included three of the most renowned football players in the East, wound up a drab season with the most crushing defeat suffered at the hands of Yale in thirty years.
LONDON, Sept. 27 -- The Anglo-Argentine tariff agreement signed at Buenos Aires last night was hailed here today as the best trade news British manufacturers have had in many months.

OYSTER BAY, L.I., Sept. 27. -- Thomas H. Roulston of Huntington won today the silver cup presented by Mrs. Clifford Vail Brokaw of Centre Island, for the best display of dahlias covering fifty square feet in the first day's showing of the annual Fall flower and vegetable show of the Oyster Bay Horticultural Society.

BERLIN, Sept. 27 -- Discrimination between "Aryan" and "non-Aryan" business establishments was emphatically discountenanced by the Nazi government in a rescript issued today by Dr. Kurt Schmitt, Minister of Economics.

An increasing number of people in the United States are apprehensive of currency inflation and fearful of its results. Eight dtstinguished men, representing both major political parties, have approved and sponsored a series of articles presenting their viewpoint on the money problems of the day. The series will appear in, this newspaper in sixteen consecutive daily chapters. The fourth is presented, herewith.

HAVANA, Sept. 27 -- The Grau San Martin government, backed by the moral force of the student movement and the physical force of the "army of sergeants," has been in power twenty-three days, the same period as the de Cespedes government which the students and soldiers overthrew.

Shipped to Aqueduct from Havre de Grace especially for yesterday's featured race at the Long Island course, N.E. Stanton's Action won decisively in 1:12, the fastest race thus far of the meeting at six furlongs. At the finish he was two lengths before J.J. Robinson's Eva B., which gained the place by a neck over J.H. Louchheim's Fancy Flight.

To the Editor of The New York Times: THE TIMES leading editorial of today admirably discourses on the confusion which characterizes the political situation in the city. After shedding no little light on the subject, the editorial admonishes its readers to hold fast to original principles.

CHICAGO, Sept. 27 -- Light hogs of best grades were in small supply here today and brought prices unchanged to 5 cents a hundredweight higher than yesterday's. Heavy hogs were in limited demand and 10 cents lower. A top price of $5.25 to $5.30 was made for the best light selections of 150 to 225 pound averages, but the market closed easy.

NEW HAVEN', Conn., Sept. 27. -- President James Rowland Angell of Yale University declared tonight in addressing a freshman class rally in Woolsey Hall that the national economic life of that nation is at stake and that principles, systems and institutions must serve society or disappear.

In line with other sections of the realty field, the auction market yesterday was unusually brisk. Despite postponement of sales of the two largest parcels, listed for the block, the foreclosure list was long. It included ten Manhattan parcels and six properties in the Bronx, all of which were bid in by the plaintiffs.

The Protestant churches of the United States received a total of $378,000,000 in contributions during 1932. according to a report made public yesterday by the Federal Council of Churches of Christ in America.
ALEXANDRIA, Egypt, Sept. 27 -- Instead of the "one-man" Sidky Pasha Cabinet, Egypt now has a "three-man" Ministry.

A comprehensive plan to extricate the city from its financial plight, provide for its unemployment relief needs and to restore its credit standing will be presented to the Board of Estimate and the city's banks today for approval, Governor Lehman announced last night at his home, 820 Park Avenue.

PITTSFIELD, Mass., Sept. 27 -- The Lenox Library Association, of which Grenville Lindall Winthron is president, opened Sedgwick Hall today for the fourteenth annuai exhibition of arts, crafts and handiwork done by Summer visitors and townspeople.

Fiorello H. LaGuardia told a cheering crowd of 2,300 Brooklyn Republicans last night that Fusion had embarked on a winning campaign, and that the ticket he headed would be elected regardless of an independent candidacy by Joseph V. McKee.

The Engineers Public Service Corporation reports for the twelve months ended on Aug. 31 consolidated gross earnings of $42,184,423, as compared with 547,029,231 in the preceding twelve months. Net operating revenue was 119,400,320, against $21,249,457.

Senator Marchese Guglielmo Marconi, inventor of wireless telegraphy, is arriving today from Rome on the Italian liner Conte Di Savoia, with the Marchesa Marconi, on the way to the World's Fair in Chicago.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 (AP). -- A proposal to prevent machine guns from falling into the hands of criminals was offered by the small arms and ammunition industry today at a hearing on a proposed code of fair competition.

MEMPHIS, Tenn., Sept. 27 (AP) -- R.E. Lee Wilson, 68-year-old founder and sole owner of the "model" town of Wilson, Ark., one of the world's largest cotton planters and a powerful figure in Arkansas politics, died here today after an extended illness.

The dollar rallied 33 points yesterday to a gold valuation of 66.12 cents, measured in terms of the French franc. The imnrovement of dollar exchange was ascribed to intimations from Washington that President Roosevelt was considering a stand against the demands of the inflationist party.

Two of Bill Terry's aces went to the mound at the Polo Grounds yesterday for their final world's series warm-up exercises in the Giants' double-header with the Phils, but only one was returned a victor.

A message to Lutherans in Germany, lauding the Hitler regime for its friendliness to the Christian religion and for its morality campaigns, but expressing the hope that no principles limiting the freedom and universality of Christianity might rule the church there, was sent by a body of Lutherans here yesterday.
Futures prices continued to decline yesterday in trading on local commodity exchanges. The volume of transactions was somewhat greater than on the preceding day. Cash prices were irregularly lower.

The highest salary paid by the Long island Railroad to an officer serving it exclusively is $12,100 annually, W.W. Atterbury, president of the Long Island and of the Pennsylvania Railroads, disclosed in correspondence made public yesterday. The major executives of both companies are identical.

BUCKTT HARRIS has just dropped the reins as manager-of the Detroit Tigers. That makes one job open, and as Bucky, though he never quite did for Detroit what he accomplished for Washington, is still rated a very capable leader, he is almost certain to be bossing a major league club somewhere else next Spring. That means another job is open even if its present occupant does not know about it at the moment.

Purchases of a group of garden apartment houses in Jackson Heights, Queens, and of a vacant parcel on Lexington Avenue were among the chief features of real estate transactions reported in the metropolitan district yesterday.

Stock Exchange Plebs. Seven million people in New York 'henceforth know that they are not without a last resource against 'their political bosses. If reason, pleading and threats fail to bring better government, we can all pack up and move over to Newark.
The outside market for call loans relapsed to 3/2, after an interval of 5/3, on Tuesday. Money market was otherwise quiet, and rates Unchanged for all classifications.

Alteration work on the proposed home of the New Jersey Stock Exchange in Newark was definitely discontinued yesterday as officials of the Stock Exchange sought to reach a settlement with Mayor Ellenstein of Newark on the rental to be paid on the Centre Market, which was to have been the home of the new Exchange.

MINEOLA, L.I., Sept. 27. -- The much disputed leadership of the two major political parties of Nassau County will be decided tomorrow night when the Republicans and Democrats hold their reorganization meetings. The Democrats will meet in Chaminade High School here, while the Republicans will convene in Police Headquarters here.

TAMPICO, Mexico, Sept. 27 -- A fresh catastrophe menaced this hurricane-stricken city today as the Panuco and Tamesi Rivers rose to new heights, inundating large areas that had escaped the full brunt of Sunday's storm.

WEIRTON, W. Va., Sept. 27. -- More than 5,000 employes of the Weirton Steel Company were; on "holiday" here today as a result of what leaders of the walkout termed a conflict between company and independent unions.

The New YorK University "Curb Exchange" began operation yesterday in front of the Frederick Brown Building on Washington Place. More than 750 student operators gathered to barter, sell and exchange books, test tubes, scales, football stubs and a host of other paraphernalia.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 -- The total subsidies paid to the Export Steampship Corporation for carrying mail in 1931, 1932 and 1933 amounted to considerably more than the line paid for the eighteen Shipping Board vessels it purchased, Senator Black, chairman of the special Senate committee investigating ocean, mail contracts and ship construction loans, brought out today at the inquiry.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 27. -- Upon the advice of some of his financial advisers, President Roosevelt is represented as considering definite monetary action by Thanksgiving Day. A statement is contemplated, it is said, in which the President will pledge early stabilization and a return to the gold standard as soon as feasible.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., Sept. 27. -- Sal Di Buono of Bonnie Briar held the centre of the spotlight as the first thirty-six holes of the Westchester open golf championship were played over his home course today.

Several years have passed since the last of Clare Kummer's light omelets was served up in the theatre. But two of them are posted on this year's bill-of-fare and the first of them, "Amourette," was taken out of the oven at Henry Miller's last evening.

With the share market carrying a greater burden of liquidation than it was accustomed to, Wall Street took a rather gloomy view yesterday of the financial position. Transactions on the Stock Exchange footed up to 2,321,000 shares, compared with 1,432,000 shares on the day before.

CHICAGO, Sept. 27. -- Attended to her compartment in a railroad train by a police guard, Mrs. Joseph B. Long, a social leader who received a threatening letter demanding the payment of $10,000, left Chicago for New York City this afternoon.

Opposition to the code submitted by the American Steamship Owners' Association to the National Recovery Administration developed yesterday among shippers in the metropolitan district. When the public hearing on the code, promised by Deputy Administrator W.H. Davis of the NRA, is held in "Washington the shippers will urge the elimination of provisions which they consider unfair.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 -- About 2,800,000 persons have returned to work since March, according to estimates of the American Federation of Labor.

PORTLAND, Me., Sept. 27 (AP) -- George L. Record of Jersey City, who had been a candidate for Governor and United States Senator in New Jersey, died here early today in the State Street Hospital at the age of 74.

BOGOTA, Sept. 27 -- Dollar exchange is expected to, rise to 150 pesos for $100 when the banks here resume exchange operations tomorrow under new regulations issued today by the Exchange Control Board. In the local market the dollar was quoted today at 140 bid, 159 asked, with one legitimate sale at 148.

MEMPHIS, Sept. 27 (AP). -- George Kelly, reputed machine gunner for the underworld of the Western bad lands, confessed tonight, officers said, to a part in the kidnapping of Charles F. Urschel, Oklahoma oil man.

A third series of North American Trust Shares, an investment trust of the fixed type, has been created by Distributors Group, Inc. The New York Stock Exchange has ruled that it has no objection to the association of its members with the shares of the new trust.

Railroad officials held a national conference yesterday on a proposal to reduce the baste passenger rate, but adjourned after failing to reach an agreement. With the possible exception of New England, the managements in all regions are prepared to make reductions, but they have been unable to harmonize their views on the method to be followed.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 (AP) -- A forty-eight-hour maximum week for retail grocery employes and a forty-four-hour week for workers in wholesale grocery houses were proposed in codes submitted today to the Recovery Administration.

PATERSON, N.J., Sept. 27. -- At a conference here this afternoon between manufacturers and strikers in the Jacquard branch of the silk industry it was agreed to appoint a joint committee of eight which will arrange a wage and hour agreement.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 27 (AP) -- Dr. James Main Dixon, 77 years old, internationally known educator and professor emeritus at the University of Southern California, died today at his residence after a long illness.

RYE, N.Y., Sept. 27. -- With only, one match outstanding, the quarter-final bracket of the seventh annual national professional tennis championship was completed today on the turf courts of the Westchester Country Club.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Bulwer-Lytton, in "The Parisians" (alas! how few read that brilliant writer nowadays), makes a German Count, whom he describes as "that terrible German," in a conversation with de Breze, philosophized on the "oeuvriers" of Paris under the well-meaning rule of the Third Napoleon.

PARIS, Sept. 27 -- The departure of Sir Frederick Leith-Ross for the British-American debt talks in Washington and reports from New York of the meetings of Ambassador Strauus and President Roosevelt at which debts were discussed, have temporarily resurrected what had been a dead issue in Paris since June.
Although leases of dwellings formed the bulk of real estate activity in Manhattan yesterday, an outstanding deal was the outright sale of a housing property in the Chelsea section.

BAYONNE, N.J., Sept. 28. -- The Bear of Oakland, supply ship for Rear Admiral Byrd's second Antarctic expedition, made her first stop on her journey to the South Pole here today when she docked at Pier 3 in the Kill Van Kull, at the plant of the Tide Water Oil Company.
PARIS, Sept. 28 (AP). -- The weekly statement of the Bank of France shows the following changes in francs:

Yom Kippur, or the Day of Atonement, will begin today with the going down of the sun, due at 5:46 o'clock Eastern Standard Time. It is the most solemn holiday in the Jewish calendar and will be observed by Jews the world over until sundown tomorrow.
The freshman class of Columbia College decisively defeated the sophomores yesterday morning in the 179th annual class rush, held on South Field of the Morningside Heights campus.

The world is on the threshold of a new era in radio, according to Senatore Guglielmo Marconi, who arrived yesterday with Marchesa Marconi on the Italian liner Conte di Savoia. The inventor of wireless, soon after his arrival, found his way to Radio City, as he said, "to have Americans put me wise to what is taking place over here."

The report of the Bancamerica Blair Corporation, published yesterday in San Francisco, showed as of June 30 total assets of $19,072,208. The corporation reported marketable securities of $12,033,169; other investments of $182,864; syndicate participations of $341,932; syndicate notes and advances of $521,112, and other net receivables of $582,520.

CHICAGO, Sept. 28. -- Captain Matt Leach of the Indiana State Police said tonight that he would file formal charges with the Federal Radio Commission as a result of the allegedly faked description of a desperate gun battle between police and escaped convicts which was broadcast last night by Station WIND at Gary.

Lull May Bring Price Test. With deliveries now nearly caught up in several major department store lines, both producers and retailers are giving much attention to the next development in the merchandising situation. While the present lull at both wholesale and retail is regarded as temporary, it was held significant that, for the first time since July, retailers are in position to obtain goods without undue delay.

BERLIN, Sept. 28. -- A high German official made it clear today that the plea of Dr. Kurt Schmitt, Minister of Economics, for a hands-off policy toward Jewish business concerns represented no deviation from Nazi-ism's plan to rear a purely "Aryan" State.
CHICAGO, Sept. 28. -- Directors of the Commonwealth Edison Company today declared a quarterly dividend of $1 a share, the same as three months ago, when the quarter rate was reduced from $1.25.

Among the passengers arriving today on the Berengaria of the Cunard Line are Lord Weir, British shipping expert; Henry L. Stimson, former Secretary of State; the Count and Countess de Chambrun, Mr. and Mrs. Simon Guggenheim and Maud Morgan, who retired several years ago after a long career as one of the country's leading harpists.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 (AP). -- A cut into the national daily oil production was ordered today by Secretary Ickes in efforts of the Federal Government to bolster petroleum prices through controlling the output while studying closely the question of price regulation.
SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 28. -- From 250 to 400 men employed at the Richmond Bay district plant of the Ford Motor Company were out of work tonight.

PATERSON, N.J., Sept. 28 Strikers, manufacturers and business men who are suffering as the result of the tie-up in the silk industry looked today to Washington with renewed hope. Telegrams were received from United States Senator W. Warren Barbour and Representative George N. Seger of this district, who have agreed to appeal to General Hugh S. Johnson, NRA Administrator, for help in settling the strike.

Excepting moderate advances in some sections of the foreign group, the bond market on the Stock Exchange closed irregularly lower yesterday in quiet trading. Losses in domestic corporation bonds ranged from fractions to more than 5 points.

GRAND RAPIDS, Mich., Sept. 28 (AP). -- Testimony that Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt in 1930 accepted $1,000 from an advertising agency to endorse furniture manufactured by the Berkey and Gay Company of Grand Rapids was introduced today in the Federal Court suit of receivers for the company against the Simmons Company of New York.

Mrs. Helen Vogel Stern of 930 Park Avenue, who is suing Mrs. Ruth Erlanger Nathan of Elberon, N.J., for $4,000,000 on the ground that she alienated the affections of Allison L.S. Stern, broker, from whom she has been separated since 1926, testified before Supreme Court Justice Hofstadter and a jury yesterday that she was called a "mid-Victorian prude" because she resented her husband's attentions to Mrs. Nathan.

Joseph A. Broderick, State Superintendent of Banks, appeared as a State witness yesterday in the criminal branch of the Supreme Court at the trial of Isidor J. Kresel for alleged misapplication of about $2,000,000 of the funds of an affiliate of the Bank of United States.

Counsel for the defense yesterday challenged the contention of the government in the trial of Senator James J. Davis for violation of the Lottery Law that Senator Davis had received $40,000 in 1931 from the proceeds of charity balls operated by the Loyal Order of Moose.
Governor Herbert H. Lehman was confined to his bed yesterday at his home, 820 Park Avenue, suffering from an attack of appendicitis. His physicians, by a period of rest, hope to avoid an operation.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Shortly before the French Revolution France was confronted with very acute financial problems. Different panaceas were suggested, which led to the following remark by a man of note: "When waste and unthrift deplete the royal treasury, there arises a cry of despair and of terror.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28. -- The debt discussions with the British mission, scheduled to begin here on Oct. 5, will be conducted for the United States principally by Treasury Department officials and experts, Secretary of State Hull said today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28. -- Unless further revision of maximum hours provided in codes reduces the work week to five days of about six hours each, organized labor will be compelled to go before Congress at the next session and support a thirty-hour bill, according to William Green.

NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 28. -- A Halloween ball will be held at the Naval Training Station for the benefit of the Navy Relief Society on Oct. 31. There will be a meeting of the officials of the society next week to decide upon the details of the ball, which is an annual affair.

A throng including many notables of the theatrical world filled all the pews and 900 extra chairs in Temple Emanu-El yesterday at the funeral services for Sime Silverman. Many of those present had felt, in turn, the sting of his criticism and the enthusiasm of his praise, during the twenty-eight years since he founded Variety and made it a weekly handbook of the entertainment business.

Civil radio facilties of the country were extolled yesterday by Lieut. Commander E.M. Webster of United States Coast Guard headquarters, Washington. He reported that "fine cooperation" existed between all classes of radio service and the Coast Guard, facilitating the rapid handling of urgent messages and SOS calls.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., Sept. 28. -- Hitting the pin with a perfect mashie niblick shot at the last hole today, Mike Turnesa of Fairview tapped in a birdie 3 to tie Sal Di Buono of Bonnie Briar for the Westchester open golf championship.

Transactions on the Stock Exchange yesterday were smaller by about 880,000 shares than on the day before, but the market was much stronger and more impressive. There was a fractional advance at the opening, followed by nervous declines that reduced the initial prices somewhat.

Nearly the full range of yesterday's fluctuations on the Cotton Exchange was covered in the last few minutes of trading, when prices ran off quickly under hedge selling and ended 6 to 10 points lower than oft Wednesday. The business was about the lightest of the season.

The code of practice for the shipping industry, recently submitted by the American Steamship Owners Association to the National Recovery Administration, was attacked as impracticable and a threat to the export trade of the nation, in a statement yesterday by Hans J. Isbrandtsen, president of the Isbrandtsen-Moller Company, operator of ships to the Far East.

RYE, N.Y., Sept. 28. -- The first four seeded players in the seventh annual national professional tennis Championship reached the-semifinal round today on the grass courts of the Westchester Country Club.

Governor, Lehman has called upon the State Alcoholic Beverage Control Board to formulate a set of hard liquor regulations that will be "a model for the entire United States and a victory for real temperance."

Shareholders of the Massachusetts Investors Trust have been informed that the Treasury Department has ruled that, on account of losses realized by the trust from sales of securities, distributions made to the shareholders since Jan. 1, 1931, should be considered for tax purposes as paid from capital and therefore exempt from both normal taxes and surtaxes.

BALBOA, C.Z., Sept. 28. -- President Arias said this evening that he would go to Washington soon to confer with President Roosevelt concerning relations between Panama and the United States. He said the date of his departure had not been set and he was undecided on whether to go by ship or airplane.

LONDON, Sept. 28 (Canadian Press). -- Word was received here today of the death in Johannesburg, South Africa, of E.R. Bird, Conservative Member of the House of Commons for Skipton, Yorkshire. While touring Rhodesia for the last six weeks he had contracted pneumonia.

WASHINGTON. Sept. 28. -- President Harmodic Arias of Panama will pay an official visit to Washington soon after President Roosevelt's return from Hyde Park, the State Department announced today. He will discuss with Mr. Roosevelt a number of difficulties between the two countries which have hung over since the rejection by both Senates of the treaty of 1926.

WESTFIELD, N.J., Sept. 28. -- William Beck of the White Beeches Golf and Country Club today won the New Jersey State Seniors Golf Association championship for the second successive year at the Shackamaxon Country Club.

Local commodity markets opened yesterday with some irregularity, but most of them held steady at about their opening levels for the rest of the day. Trading was quiet. In the cash markets the price trend was lower.

The outstanding three major league baseball players of the year, on the basis of final returns in The Associated Press all-star poll, are Manager Joe Cronin of the Senators, Southpaw Carl Hubbell of the Giants and slugging Chuck Klein of the Phillies.

Mayor O'Brien's designation yesterday of Edward F. Boyle as Presiding Justice of the new combined Children's-Domestic Relations Court stirred the Bar Association to quick resentment. The association's court committee had recommended Magistrate Jonah Goldstein as best qualified for the post.

HYDE PARK, N.Y., Sept. 28. -- Laying aside virtually all of his official tasks, President Roosevelt spent the day In the role of "gentleman farmer," a temporary relaxation preparatory to further intensive work on national recovery policies.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Sept. 28 (AP). -- The Columbus Red Birds batted their way into a 2-to-l lead in the little world's series tonight by taking the third contest, 8 to 5, from Buffalo while some 6,000 fans huddled in the stands.

The recognition of the Jewish people as a national entity through giving them juristic representation in the League of Nations was urged as "imperative" in an address here last night by Emil Ludwig, historian and biographer, who has been living in exile in Switzerland since the rise of Hitlerism in Germany.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Sept. 28. -- Westchester County responded enthusiastically tonight to the call of needy German Jews by filling the County Centre at the concert presented for the benefit of the Joint Distribution Committee.

A man is entitled to change his mind. That right has been established ever since Benedick explained that when he swore to die a bachelor he did not think he should live to be a married man. But when a public man eats his own words he ought to give good reasons for being compelled to adopt that diet.
TRENTON, N.J., sept. 28. -- Calumet Donald, bay colt owned by Will Caton of Syracuse, captured the Governor's Trophy for 3-year-old trotters, closing-day feature at the Trenton Fair track today.

WASHINGTON, Pa., Sept. 28. -- The centre of the bituminous coal strike shifted to Washington County today as miners here arranged for a mass meeting Saturday to deliver their final ultimatum to operators.
NEW YORK. Lord Weir of London is arriving on the Berengaria and will be at the Savoy-Plaza.

Two men were killed and two others injured critically last night when an automobile in which they were crossing the Madison Avenue Bridge over the Harlem River swerved into the side railing, crashed through and plunged twenty-five feet into East 138th Street, the Bronx.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28. -- The National Labor Board will create a district mediation board in New York City which will absorb the mediation board of the organization headed by Grover A. Whalen, Senator Wagner, chairman of the National Board, announced this afternoon after a conference with Mr. Whalen.

New leases announced by brokers and renting agents of buildings in Manhattan yesterday showed a continued demand for apartments at a time generally considered late in the house-hunting season. In addition to reporting numerous renewals of existing leases, brokers also said that several apartment buildings had been fully rented as the result of the late seasonal demand.

PARIS, Sept. 28. -- The disapproval and irritation caused here by an article in a New York newspaper by former Ambassador Walter E. Edge, stating that the debtor nations should be asked to say whether they are ready to grant commercial advantages to the United States in return for war-debt concessions, reached a climax today with attacks on him by three newspapers.
LONDON, Sept. 28 (AP). -- The weekly statement of the Bank of England shows the following changes in pounds sterling:

The National Conference of Catholic Charities, hich will begin its nineteenth annual meeting next Sunday, will be under the patronage of Pope Pius XI, it was announced yesterday at conference headquarters in the Waldorf-Astoria.
New York University's Violet eleven, triumphed over the Red team, 20 to 6, in a hard-fought encounter at Ohio Field yesterday.

The Emergency Work Bureau, operating agency of the Emergency Unemployment Relief Committee, which brought its activities to a close this week, made public yesterday a report for the three years of the bureau's operations from Oct. 1, 1930, to Aug. 31, 1933.

OKLAHOMA CITY, Sept. 28 (AP). -- Governor William H. (Alfalfa Bill) Murray, who frequently has denounced the Oklahoma Supreme Court, has created another sensation by threatening to call a special election by initiative petition, change court district boundaries and thus bring about the unseating of the justices, who then would have to seek re-election.

Contingent plans for increasing the number of employes and their hours of work were announced by the New York Central Railroad yesterday. The plans, which depend on business conditions, call for the employment of 9,500 men in October, an increase of 1,337, or 16 per cent, from the 8,213 at work in September and of 1,725, or 21 per cent more than the 7,825 employed in August.

Reserve balances of member banks of the Federal Reserve System increased $53,000,000 this week, lifting excess reserves to a high record at nearly $800,000,000, it was indicated in the Federal Reserve's report, issued yesterday.

WESTBURY, L.I., Sept. 28. -- Play started today in the last high-goal polo tournament of the year, the Monty Waterbury Memorial Cup event, Stephen Sanford's Hurricanes winning the opening match from Sands Point, 10 to 5.

SOME people there are who, though not the most talented of their generation, yet seem to sit like spiders at the centre of things. They do not write the greatest novels or the best poetry, nor are they the profoundest critics. But somehow, in their eagerness to listen, to experience and to experiment, they are more symbolic of the time-spirit than many more gifted contemporaries.

Jewish Business Spared. It is obviously an event of importance when the German Minister of Economics expresses stern disapproval of the drive against Jewish business men. But the significance of the act must not be carried beyond the sphere of its immediate application.

How private effort helped to hold the fort for three years against unemployment and want in this city is a story that can now be told. One part of it is indeed told in outline and within the span of fifty pages by the director of the Emergency Work Bureau and his assistants.

OKLAHOMA CITY, Sept. 28 (AP). -- A decisive blow at crime through conviction of all ten defendants in the Charles F. Urschel kidnapping conspiracy trial was demanded of the jury today by the government.

Joseph V. McKec, former president of the Board of Aldermen, failed yesterday to announce his candidacy for Mayor on an independent ticket. This second delay in making an announcement after one had been scheduled was regarded as tantamount to a declination.

With officeholders and office-seekers rigidly shut out from the management of its affairs, the Republican Builders, Inc., was launched yesterday at a meeting held by its prospective directors at the Downtown Club. Officers still remain to be elected.

DETROIT, Sept. 28. -- As the way was cleared today for mediation by the Detroit NRA Compliance Board in the strike of tool and die makers in the Detroit, Flint and Pontiac areas, John M. Carmody, representing Chairman Wagner of the National Labor Board, arrived here to work for a settlement.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28. -- With more than 100,000 workers, notably in the coal, steel and automobile industries, out on strike, the National Labor Board is working on a tremendous task of trying to settle disputes.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 28. -- The War Department issued the following orders today:

PHILADELPHIA, Fa., Sept. 28. -- Mr. and Mrs. Henry Huddleston Rogers Jr. took an enforced aftermidnight jaunt along the lonely roads near Wayne early this morning after their chauffeur had left them stranded.
CHICAGO, Sept. 28. -- The beneficial effects of X-rays in the treatment of cancer were discussed today by members of the American Congress of Radiology.
ABOARD THE MOTOR SHIP WYATT EARP, Sept. 28 (By Wireless). -- The Wyatt Earp is once again tossing and rolling toward her Antarctic goal.

THE comeback trail, at best a very bumpy road, seems to have run Jack Sharkey off on another detour. That makes it twice, and even so convincing a talker as the distinguished Squire of Boston soon will have trouble making folk believe he ever could fight if this sort of thing continues.
HANOVER, N.H., Sept. 28. -- Dartmouth has gone back to first principles and after three years of depression Jackson Cannell feels that the football situation is fundamentally sound.

The Chicago, Rock Island Pacific Railroad would be a desirable inclusion in the pending Denver Rio Grande Western merger, Ralph Budd, president of the Chicago, Burlington Quincy Railroad, said yesterday. The Rock Island is now devising a merger with the St. Louis-San Francisco.

COLUMBUS, Ga., Sept. 28 (AP). -- Miss Sarah Hines Ford, Columbus society girl, was married here today to Dr. Hassow Von Wedel of Ardsley-on-Hudson, N.Y., whom she rescued from drowning some weeks ago.

A temporary agreement was reached yesterday by the International Ladies' Garment Workers Union, the United Textile Workers Union, and the Metropolitan Division of the National Knitted Outerwear Association, which terminated the strike in the knitted outerwear industry in New York, Brooklyn and near-by New Jersey towns.
Chase Mellen Jr. was unanimously elected last night as chairman of the New York County Republican Committee to succeed the veteran Samuel S. Koenig.

This has been called the machine age and breeders of game birds, both private agencies and those representing States, have come to realize that this is not a mere catch phrase. They have found that the electrical incubator and brooders have done more to rear wild birds in captivity than any other factor, factor.

President Roosevelt will deliver the closing address at the Women's Conference on Current Problems, which is sponsored by The New York Herald Tribune, and will be held this year on Oct. 12 and 13 at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria. The conference will be the third in a series that was inaugurated in 1930.
Another victory for the Audley Farm of B.B. Jones was recorded yesterday when Carbina came home first in the Yaphank Purse, feature at Aqueduct.

MOSCOW, Sept. 28 (AP). -- Colonel and Mrs. Charles A. Lindbergh have been so much, impressed by the experimental aviation work that is being carried on in Soviet Russia that they hope to return to this country in two years to see for themselves how the experiments have worked out.

SAN PEDRO, Calif., Sept. 28 (AP). -- Under conditions that will be strikingly close to actual warfare, 120 ships and 250 aircraft will put to sea next week for tactical manoeuvres under plans completed today by the fleet's commander-in-chief, Admiral David F. Sellers.

Fusion leaders are making plans for an early campaign of marked intensiveness, even in its opening stages. They count upon aggressive fighting in the next week or ten days to arouse interest among the voters and bring out the large registration which, they are aware, will be essential to an anti-Tammany victory.

When the French Parliament reconvenes it will face a budgetary deficit for 1934 estimated officially at 6,000,000,000 francs and unofficially by some observers at from 7,000,000,000 to 8,000,000,000. The first figure is about $360,000,000 at current rates of exchange.

HAVRE DE GRACE, Md., Sept. 28 (AP). -- Watch Him, racing for Mrs. John Hertz, Chicago sportswoman, easily defeated three others of the handicap division in the Penn Athletic Club Trophy, feature of the racing program today. C. V. Whitney's Halcyon was a fast closing second and the Brookmeade Stable's Snapback third.

The following is the text of the agreement reached yesterday between the city and its bankers which is expected to restore the city's credit over the next four years and at the same time provide for its unemployment and home relief needs and of Samuel Untermyer's report to the Board of Estimate: The City's Part. Memorandum of steps proposed to be taken by the City of New York in connection with its financial requirements.

CHICAGO, Sept 28. -- Despite the experiences of the last few months there is no reason to scrap the loan and cash surrender provisions of life insurance policies, George S. Van Schaick, Superintendent of Insurance of the State of New York told the National Association of Life Underwriters in session here today.

Ten Manhattan and Bronx properties offered at foreclosure auctions yesterday were bid in by the plaintiffs. Sale of the forty-four story skyscraper at 10 East Fortieth Street, adjourned to yesterday, was further postponed to Oct. 5. The results yesterday were as follows:

As a result of more than a year's research work into the failure of many persons to take an active interest in the work of their religious denominations, the National Laymen's Back to Church Movement has been incorporated, it was announced yesterday.
Arrangements were made yesterday for the sale of a membership in the New York Stock Exchange at $150,000. It was the third sale at this price in ten days.

NEWCASTLE, Ind., Sept. 28 (AP). -- An Illinois inventor, who claims the idea was his, filed suit in Henry County Circuit Court today for an accounting of the Chrysler Corporation's profits from the use of "floating power," an engine-mounting device.

EDWARDSVILLE, III., Sept. 28 (AP). -- With repeated demands by the State for the death penalty before them, a jury tonight took the case of five men and a woman charged with kidnapping August Luer, Alton (III.) banker.

Bank clearings turned better in the week ended on Wednesday after several weeks of declines, according to the compilation made public yesterday by Dun Bradstreet, Inc. Clearings in twenty-one leading cities amounted to $4,252,517,000, comparing with $3,894,025,000 in the same week last year, a gain of 9.2 per cent.

Criticisms of the effigy of the Blue Eagle have necessarily been superficial. It has been considered as a work of good, mediocre or bad art. The adjustments, arrangements and modifications made by the artist have been praised or blamed. But its esoteric and mystical significance, its prophetic meaning, has escaped observation.

Pleas for support of private welfare agencies, on the ground that these fill a need that cannot be met by public relief agencies, were voiced yesterday in a letter from Governor Lehman and in addresses at the Town Hall Club.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 28. -- The Bureau of Navigation issued the following orders today, dated Sept. 26:

A cut in prices for arena seats for the afternoon and evening performances at the National Horse Show in Madison Square Garden, Nov. 8 to 14, was announced yesterday. For the afternoon performances the scale will be $1.10 to $1.65.

LOCUST VALLEY, L.I., Sept. 28. -- A remarkable round of golf by Miss Charlotte Glutting and Robert A. Lester of New Jersey was the outstanding feature of the qualifying stage of the first annual mixed foursome tournament at the Piping Rock Club today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28. -- The code of fair competition for the banking business of the United States, which proposes a working week for employes of forty hours and a minimum wage, based on population, from $12 to $15 per week, had its hearing before the National Recovery Administration today.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In international relations there is no such thing as a closed book. Complications which the public considers satisfactorily settled may only be held in abeyance by the Foreign Office. Later they may bob up as irritants or as confounding precedents.

The Public Service Commission completed yesterday the rehearing on its order directing temporary emergency rate reductions by the electric companies of the Consolidated system. Milo R. Maltbie, chairman of the commission, set next Wednesday as the last day for filing briefs.

ROCHESTER., N.Y., Sept. 28. -- Postmaster General James A. Farley, addressing the 500 delegates to the annual convention of the National Association of Postmasters here tonight, defended the administration's policy of drastic cuts in personnel and salaries to save money.

LONDON, Sept. 28. -- Sweden's denunciation of the tariff truce has aroused gravest doubts here as to whether the "economic armistice" so laboriously won by Norman H. Davis of the United States last Spring can endure much longer.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28. -- The signing Tuesday of a tariff agreement between Great Britain and Argentina is regarded here as an added incentive to push the conclusion of a similar agreement between the United States and Argentina Discussions will begin here next week.

About 10 per cent of the persons asked at sixty-one store and theatre booths to sign the consumer pledge to buy from employers under the Blue Eagle have refused, it was disclosed yesterday by Miss Clarissa H. Stem, chairman of the Manhattan division of the consumers' campaign, at NRA headquarters at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 28 (AP). -- The Boston Red Sox bunched hits in two innings today to defeat the Athletics, 4 to 3, in the first game Of a three-contest series. Trailing at the end of the fifth, the Red Sox tallied twice in the sixth to tie the score and then went out in front in the seventh with another pair of runs.

SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Sept. 28 (AP). -- Joseph B. Eastman, Federal Coordinator of Transportation, said tonight railroad service must be improved to meet changing conditions and warned that labor-saving economies could not be postponed indefinitely.
GENEVA, Sept. 28. -- The French and German delegations had their first direct contact this evening in this series of disarmament talks.
Several flats and business properties, in addition to numerous small dwellings, were included in the New Jersey realty turnover reported yesterday.

The National League's champion Giants spent a day of observation at the Stadium yesterday where the American League's champion Senators went through the motions o playing the first of their last three games with the Yankees.
GENEVA, Sept. 28. -- Dr. Paul Joseph Goebbels, Reich Minister of Propaganda and Enlightenment, pleaded here today in defense of National Socialism as "a higher form of democracy."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28. -- Far-reaching plans of the Pennsylvania Railroad to inaugurate a store-door pick-up and delivery service at all points touched by its system were disclosed in correspondence of Joseph B. Eastman with Presidents W.W. Atterbury of the Pennsylvania and F.E. Williamson of the New York Central, which he made public today.

Most of the news about the United States Navy is so grim and technical that it is refreshing to listen to the humane point of view of Kenyon Nicholson and Charles Robinson in "Sailor, Beware!" which was acted at the Lyceum last evening. By associating almost exclusively with the enlisted men, they have discovered that the navy is as efficiently prepared for love as it is for war.

HILLSIDE, N.J., Sept. 28. -- The township committee here has awarded to H.L. Allen Co. of New York City $170,000 serial bonds to be used toward redeeming a $500,000 temporary bond issue maturing on Oct. 1. The serial bonds consisted of $55,000 general improvement bonds maturing from 1935 to 1943 and $115,000 assessment bonds maturing from 1934 to 1939.

The principal clause, affecting dramatists in the master code for the legitimate theatre, which went into effect on Aug. 26, has not yet received the endorsement of the managers and probably will not be approved, it became known, yesterday.
Reports of earnings issued yesterday by the Fox Film Corporation and the Columbia Pictures Corporation showed marked improvement this year, compared with the corresponding period of 1932.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28. -- A new and far-reaching credit expansion policy is being formulated by government officials, Secretary Wood-in admitted today during a lull in the almost continuous conferences in progress in his office at the Treasury.

Henry H. Abel, 36 years old, of 1,910 Wallace Avenue, the Bronx, an attorney, and his secretary, Mrs. Ethel Greenberg, 30, of 408 Maryborough Road, Cedarhurst, L. I., were held in bail of $1,500 each yesterday in West Side Court for examination Monday on a charge of forgery.

The State Publishing Department of Moscow has paid Lloyd George a higher price for the book rights of his war memoirs than has been paid in any other country except England. The memoirs are being translated into several languages. Little-Brown is to bring out the first volume of them here on Oct. 6.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Sept. 28. -- Robert E. Farley, one of Westchester's pioneer real estate developers, hanged himself late this morning in the attic of his home at 29 Greearidge Avenue, according to the police. He was 62 years old and had been in ill health.

CHICAGO, Sept. 28. -- Uncertainty as to the government's monetary policy has curtailed speculative interest in grains and other commodities on the Board of Trade and more leading operators are coming to the conclusion that little is to be expected of the markets until this situation is changed.
A four-year program to finance the city, restore its credit and provide for its relief needs was officially approved last night by the Municipal Assembly.

PITTSFIELD, Mass., Sept. 28. -- Sir Wilfred and Lady Grenfell are guests of Mrs. Alexander Sedgwick at the Sedgwick Mansion, Stockbridge. Sir Wilfred tonight addressed the boys at Indian Mountain School, Lakeville, Conn. A tea will be given tomorrow at Stockbridge Town Hall in compliment to Lady Grenfell and in the evening Sir Wilfred will deliver a lecture there.

MEMPHIS, Sept. 28 (AP). -- George (Machine Gun) Kelly, with shackles on his feet and a heavy guard outside his steel cell, awaited today his removal to Oklahoma City to stand trial for the Charles F. Urschel kidnapping.

Mayor John P. O'Brien and other members of the Guild of Catholic Lawyers, attending their sixth annual "Red Mass" yesterday, heard an indictment of the errors of the legal profession and an appeal to save it. The mass, in preparation for the opening of the Fall term of the courts, was celebrated at St. Andrew's Church, Duane Street and Cardinal Place.

To the Editor of The New York Times: A recent news item quotes a critic of the State Office Building to the effect that the structure has settled and that this is evidence of poor engineering and faulty construction. The State Engineer at Albany is quoted, in rebuttal, that no measurable settlement has occurred.

Market movements yesterday were confused, but there was evidence of some revival of speculative confidence in Wall Street. Part of the previous day's decline on the Stock Exchange was canceled. Bonds and commodities were easier and there was a fair-sized rally of foreign currencies against the dollar.

LEIPZIG, Sept. 28. -- The "bridge" that the prosecution in the Reichstag fire trial erected yesterday between Marinus Van der Lubbe and the Communist party of Germany, over which it is seeking to lead him and the four others accused to the gallows, shook perceptibly today as one of its keystones cracked.

Charles J. Phillips announced yesterday that the first part of the great stamp collection owned by the late Arthur Hind will be sold at auction in the Astor Galleries of the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel on the five days beginning Nov. 20. The auctioneer will be Walter S. Scott.

Minimum prices on steel plates and structural shapes have been filed with the American Iron and Steel Institute by all matters or these products in accordance with the industry's NRA code. The new prices represent a rise of $2 a ton for deliveries in the last quarter of the year.

County Judge Alonzo G. McLaughlin will begin an investigation this afternoon into reports that a $4,500 fund wag raised by three alleged laundry racketeers the day-before they were made parties to a pact in Brooklyn County Court which freed them under suspended sentences, despite their pleas of guilty.
