George V.S. Williams, former Public Service Commissioner, one of the attorneys for the defendants, will be the first witness.
Nineteen employes in the immigration service at Ellis Island were dismissed yesterday on orders received from the Department of Labor in Washington.

Fannie Brice has been signed to appear in the forthcoming Ziegfeld Follies, which Billie Burke, in association with the Shuberts, will produce. Her last legitimate appearance on Broadway was in "Crazy Quilt."

An increasing number of people in the "United States are apprehensive of currency inflation and fearful of its results. Eight distinguished men, representing both major political parties, have approved and sponsored a series of articles presenting their viewpoint on the money problems of the day. The series is appearing in this newspaper in sixteen consecutive daily chapters. The fifth is presented herewith.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28. -- With the exception of the case of Frederick Barber Campbell, New York lawyer indicted on a charge of failing to file a gold return, prosecution of gold boarders will be held up until after next Monday. That is the date on which those having the metal in their possession must have surrendered it to the Treasury.

St. Louis, Mo. A new issue of $1,700,000 city of St. Louis public building and improvement bonds was awarded yesterday to a syndicate composed of the Bankers Trust Company, the Guaranty Company of New York, the Mercantile-Commerce Company, Inc.; Stone Webster and Blodget.

It takes punch and power to drive runs across. If nothing more were needed to win ball games, the playing of the coining world's series would amount to little more than a perfunctory piece of 'business. In fact, one could almost dispense with the playing of it entirely, paying off the Senators with the winner's end and letting the Giants have what is left.

HOLLYWOOD, Sept. 28 (AP). -- A young woman killed late last night by an automobile driven by John Huston, 26-year-old son of Walter Huston, actor, was Identified today as Mrs. Raul Roulien, wife of the Brazilian actor who has been appearing in films.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 28. -- Contracts covering detailed wage scales and other long-controverted issues involved in the holiday of Western Pennsylvania coal miners were signed here today by officials of the Coal Control Association of Western Pennsylvania and the United Mine Workers of America.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28. -- The daily average volume of Federal Reserve Bank credit outstanding during the week ended Sept. 27, as reported by the Federal Reserve Banks, was $2,392,000,000, an increase of $28,000,000 compared with the preceding week and of $141,000,000 compared with the corresponding week in 1932.

HAVANA, Sept. 28. -- Owing to the uncertainty in Cuba and growing opposition to the government, the student and army administration has initiated a series of energetic measures to prevent possible further counter-revolutionary movements.

WASHINGTON, Sept, 28. -- Attorney General Cummings served notice today on the legal profession that the Federal Government has started a campaign to ferret out of its ranks "scavenger" lawyers who by illegal practices abet crime.

To the Editor of The New York Times: There ought to be a law -- yes, there really ought to be -- compelling every housewife to read a morning paper immediately after breakfast, if not before. I have found that half an hour with THE TIMES is the most stimulating tonic there is.

DUBLIN, Sept. 28. -- There was a tense atmosphere in the Ball and the public galleries were packed this evening when a motion of censure on the government was made by Frank MacDermot, one of the leaders of the United Ireland party. MacDermot moved that in the opinion of the Dail the government's use of the Public Safety Act was unjust and deserving of censure.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28. -- The aims of the Grau San Martin Government in Cuba were laid today before Jefferson Caffery, Assistant Secretary of State, by Dr. Carlos Finlay, Minister of Sanitation in the Grau government.

GENEVA, Sept. 28. -- The name of Herbert Hoover is being suggested in some quarters for the post of League of Nations high commissioner for German refugees, which the Dutch hope to get created. It is not known here whether he has been sounded out on the matter.

LONDON, Sept. 28 (AP). -- Russia again flatly refused today to be drawn into the world wheat agreement despite an offer by the United States and Canada to allow the Soviet Union to share any possible extension during the next year of the limit now set for world exports.

BERLIN, Sept. 28. -- Chancellor Hitler today reaffirmed his determination to scotch any Nazi zeal unauthorized by himself. He unexpectedly summoned the Governors of the federated States, who are his personal representatives, to Berlin and kept them in secret conclave for several hours.

OYSTER BAT, L.I., Sept. 28. -- John M. Schiff won "today the sweepstakes award in the final count of points for his entries in the twenty-second annual Fall flower and vegetable show of the Oyster Bay Horticultural Society which closed tonight in St. Dominick's Auditorium. Mr. Schiff exhibited flowers and vegetables grown at Northwood, his country estate in Oyster Bay, in almost every section of the show.

The federal government moved speedily yesterday to bring to trial the only man in the nation who has been formally accused of violating President Roosevelt's proclamation requiring owners of gold to report their holdings not later than Sept. 18.

The Texas Corporation has advanced crude oil prices in the greater Mid-Continent area, approximately 10 cents a barrel, effective today. The rise, unlocked for in the trade, was laid to expectation of the reduction in the allowable output of crude oil for October ordered yesterday by Secretary Ickes, Oil Administrator.

LONDON, Sept. 28. -- The British Government decided tonight to reinstate Tshekedi, Bechuanaland chieftain, who was suspended recently and banished from the territory of his tribe because he had ordered a white man to be flogged.

TRENTON, N.J., Sept. 28. -- Meeting in special session for that particular purpose, the Legislature passed today a bill authorizing State banks, insurance companies, building and loan associations and trust estates to invest in bonds of the Federal Home Owners' Loan Corporation.

Yesterday's doubleheader at Ebbets Field brought only one decision, the Braves defeating the Dodgers by 5 to 4 in the opener and darkness being the only winner in the nightcap, which was called at the end of the tenth with the count deadlocked at 2 -- 2.

The New York Civic Orchestra, Rudolph Thomas, conductor, will present a program consisting of the "Meistersinger" Prelude, Corelli's Concerto Grosso in G and Brahma's First Symphony at the Museum of Natural History this afternoon.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The augmented interest shown in governmental affairs and policies during the past few years has been to no small degree enhanced by the personal addresses of the President and leaders of the country over the radio. From the reaction obtained from the millions of interested radio listeners, it is not presumptuous to assume an increasing use of this means of disseminating the activities and policies of Washington.

WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., Sept. 29 -- A classic example of the vagaries of the football coach's fortunes was furnished at Williams last year when, after putting out four successive "Little Three" championship elevens, Charles Caldwell saw his team lose seven successive games.

Governor Herbert H. Lehman announced last evening that he would convene the Legislature in special session in a few days to enact new legislation permitting the city to carry out its part of the comprehensive financing plan accepted by the municipal assembly last Thursday.

An idle boast to three youths implicated in petty crimes that he was present when "a Nassau cop was bumped off in 1928" brought the arrest of the boaster yesterday and the end of a five-year search for the gunman who crippled Patrolman Jack Kennedy.

AMHERST vs. Hobart -- Lord Jeffrey Amherst was a soldier of the king. John Henry Hobart (1775-1830) was a New York clergyman and educator. This information is not included in the Football Guide. Sticking to the Confusion Ticket, one vote for Amherst.

Closing of the contracts between the Reconstruction Finance Corporation and Knickerbocker Village, Inc., the corporation which is to carry forward the Knickerbocker Village slum clearance on the socalled "lung block" of the lower east side, was signalized yesterday in the office of Fred F. French at 551 Fifth Avenue.

HAVRE DE GRACE, Md., Sept. 29 -- C.V. Whitney's Equipoise, holder of the world's record for one mile and winner of $320,970, will bid farewell to the races tomorrow in the renewal of the $10,000 added Havre de Grace Handicap, matching strides with ten of the country's leading thoroughbreds over one and one-eighth miles.

The Allegheny Corporation announced yesterday that it would meet the $613,300 interest payment due on Monday on its $24,532,000 of 5 per cent bonds due in 1950. Funds for the purpose were understood to have been derived from a loan extended by the J.P. Morgan Co. banking group.

Senator Guglielmo Marconi finds Radio City fascinating. He spent most of his time there yesterday inspecting the thirty-five new studios which the National Broadcasting Company plans to begin using Nov. 15.

GENEVA, Sept. 29 -- The two chief German delegates left this afternoon to consult Chancellor Hitler on the deadlocked disarmament situiation. Dr. Paul Joseph Goebbels, Minister of Propaganda, went by air, and without planning to return, while Foreign Minister von Neurath, who went by train, plans to return in a few days.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 -- Regulation of advertising ethics will soon be a fact if code authorities prove competent to enforce regulations now being written into a substantial number of the codes, according to Alfred T. Falk, director of research and education for the Advertising Federation of America and representative in Washington for advertising interests.
BERLIN, Sept. 29 -- The Boerse was quiet and uneven today, with interest converging on mining stocks. Other favorites maintained their price levels of yesterday but commanded no buyers.
PHILADELPHIA, Pa., Saturday, Sept. 30 -- Rioting broke out afresh last night at the 103-year-old Eastern Penitentiary, where almost all of the long-termers had rebelled on Tuesday night.

CHICAGO, Sept. 29 (AP) -- Sherab, the English imported horse, for which the Chappell Brothers of Rockford, Ill., paid $35,000, won his first race on United States soil today when he conquered Baby Stare by a nose in the main race at Washington Park.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 (AP) -- Price-fixing in the form of minimum mark-ups for the $9,000,000,000 food and grocery industry is slated for definite rejection by the Farm Adjustment Administration.

The municipal bond market faces a comparative dearth of new high-grade issues, according to the list scheduled for award next week and subsequently. There is, however, a fairly sizable floating supply of blocks of old issues in the market. Next week only $7,850,996 of new issues will come up for award, compared with this week's revised total of $24,566,829 and with the weekly average for the year to date of $13,395,980.

Prices on the Cotton Exchange improved nearly a dollar a bale yesterday morning in sympathy with a rally in other markets, but the heaviest hedge selling of the week developed later and left the final quotations 1 to 9 points lower on the day.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 -- Age was no handicap today in the first heat of the President's Cup race on the Potomac River. El Lagarto, owned and driven by George C. Reis of Lake George, N.Y., ran away from five other Gold Cup boats.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 -- The War Department issued the following orders today: Halla, Maj. C., Finance Department, 14 days leave.
LEWISBURG, Pa., Sept. 29 -- Bucknell's football team won its second game of the season tonight when it defeated Lebanon Valley, 34 to 0.

Henri Barbusse, French, author and communist, and his secretary, Annette Vidal, were detained for an hour aboard ship by immigration officials when they arrived her yesterday on the Cunarder Berengaria. M. Barbusse, the author of "Under Fire," was ordered held for further examination after an inspector had questioned him while the ship was coming up the bay.
BRYN MAWR, Pa., Sept. 29 -- Rockabye, a brown mare owned by Miss Emily S. Bromley of Germantown, won the Melbrook Bowl for the second straight year today at the Bryn Mawr horse show.

For several weeks Mr. MCKEE has been setting the people of this city a puzzle in character study. Where they had thought of him as a strong man, firm in his convictions, prompt and resolute in his decisions, they have had presented to them an extraordinary spectacle of vacillation and timidity.

BERLIN, Sept. 29 (AP) -- An oral communication, from the Foreign Office to the Soviet Embassy today described the expulsion of German correspondents from Moscow as a "reprisal which heavily burdens the amicable relations of both countries, for which the Soviets are solely responsible."
PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 29 -- The Temple football team, playing its first game, under the coaching of Pop Warner, registered a decisive triumph over South Carolina at Temple Stadium tonight.

Coincidentally with the announcement by the National Retail Dry Goods Association that a nation-wide committee of store heads would attend all future hearings in Washington on codes affecting the interests of retailers, R.H. Macy Co.

MEMPHIS, Sept. 29 (AP) -- A government prepared to spend more money for Machine Gun Kelly's conviction than the $200,000 ransom he and purported associates allegedly obtained for the release of Charles F. Urschel spared no expense tonight in mobolizing its forces for the desperado's removal to Oklahoma City.

Joseph V. McKee's entrance into the Mayoralty race was welcomed last night by Charles Solomon, Socialist candidate for Mayor, as offering opportunity to "debunk this white-haired boy of New York City politics"

It is plain from yesterday's interview that MARCONI has lost none of the optimism and courage that imbued him a generation ago and that ultimately enabled him to realize the long-cherished dream of remote peoples bridging the ocean with waves carrying their thoughts.

Swinging around to the defensive play as it is expected to unfold itself in the coming world's series, we now come to the real domain of the Giants, the stronghold which enabled them to rush off with the National League pennant. It is their one line of action with, which they can possibly hope to overthrow the Senators, who, it has already been shown, will enter the conflict with a far heavier attack.

With additional defaults due on Monday on German dollar bonds and certain other foreign loans under moratoria decreed by the governments of those countries because of conditions in the foreign exchange markets, the New York Stock Exchange's committee on securities ruled yesterday that the following issues would henceforth be dealt in "flat" with the Oct. 1, 1933, and subsequent coupons attached:

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Sept. 29 -- Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr., who declared yesterday that camera men drove him off the Harvard freshman football squad, is still a member of one of the Harvard freshman crews, but doesn't know how long he'll remain.

TAMPICO, Mexico, Sept. 29 (AP) -- Flood-swollen waters of the Panuco River swept again over the city today, vastly complicating relief work and threatening new peril to thousands made destitute by Sunday's hurricane.
With the opening kick-off today, Fordham University will open a new chapter in its football history when it starts the 1933 gridiron campaign against Albright at Fordham Field at 2:30 o'clock.

Moving vans lumbering through traffic and backed to curbs yesterday gave visible evidence of peak activity in the apartment renting field. Long lists of tenants furnished by brokers were additional indications that the annual migration within the city was at its height.

Joseph A. Broderick, State Superintendent of Banks, occupied the witness stand all of yesterday in the trial of Isidor J. Kresel, in the Criminal Branch of the Supreme Court, on the charge he abetted in the misapplication of about $2,000,000 of Bank of United States funds.

CHICAGO, Sept. 29 -- Holding, that tinkering with the currency would work to the disadvantage of life insurance policy holders, members of the National Association of Life Underwriters in their annual convention today passed resolutions opposing any money debasement and commending President Roosevelt for resisting inflationary measures.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 -- While 1,000,000 to 1,500,000 retail merchants and 120,000,000 consumers awaited completion of the highly important master retail code, it was, in the words of Deputy Adminstrator Whiteside of the NRA, "up in that little bedroom" where General Johnson today was recuperating from what is described as a minor operation.
NEW YORK. Mrs. William R. Simonds who passed the Summer at Willet House, Southampton, will be at the Park Lane for the season.

MOSCOW, Sept. 29 -- Constantin Yureneff, Soviet Ambassador to Tokyo, delivered to Foreign Minister Hirota of Japan yesterday an oral note regarding the arrest on Sept. 24 of six Soviet officials of the Chinese Eastern Railway by Japanese and Manchukuoan police.

WASHINGTON, Sept, 29 -- Retail food prices fell .1 per cent from Aug. 29 to Sept. 12, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics. Following the sharp advance between June 15 and Aug. 15, prices had shown very little change from Aug. 15 to 29.

After an early show of strength the dollar again declined yesterday in terms of all foreign exchanges. Measured against the franc, it showed a net loss of 69 points on the day to 65.21 cents gold valuation. In conformity with the lower gold value of the dollar, the Treasury advanced its daily price for newly mined gold by 28 cents an ounce to $31.33.
PARIS, Sept. 29 -- Premier Daladier laid before the French Cabinet this evening the latest reports he had received from Geneva regarding the disarmament negotiations.

EDWARDSVILLE, Ill., Sept. 29 -- More than twenty-nine hours after it had received the case of five men and a woman charged with kidnapping August Luer, 77-year-old Alton banker, the jury ended its deliberations for the night at 10 P.M. without giving any indication of its progress.

To the Editor of The New York Times: As chairman of the committee on public health of the Women's City Club I feel called upon to clarify some points regarding the club's insistence on relief of the overcrowding in the maternity wards of the public hospitals by amending the ruling of the Board of Estimate which provides for the care of only emergency maternity cases in the wards of private hospitals.

Joseph V. McKee -- the "V" is for Vincent -- whose entrance into the Mayoralty campaign gives New York for the first time in years the prospect of a contest between three major candidates, was born in the Bronx forty-four years ago.

A statement by Joseph B. Eastman, Federal Railroad Coordinator, served to disclose yesterday that the New York Central Railroad controlled the Universal Carloading and Distributing Company through loans and advances of $15,314,000 made to the L.C.L. Corporation.
The interest of the New York public in politics in general and the candidacy of Joseph V. McKee in particular was shown twice yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 -- Three questions bearing on the American Legion's attitude toward pensions for veterans were asked today by Henry H. Curran, director of the National Economy League, in an open letter to Louis A. Johnson, national commander of the legion.
CHICAGO, Sept. 29 -- Fluctuations in the wheat market continue extremely erratic, prices responding to small orders either way and the news counting for little.
The Fall meeting at Aqueduct comes to an end today featured by the running of the Junior Champion Stakes and the Aqueduct Handicap, each of which carries $2,000 i added money.

A study of the part ministers had in the spreading of war propaganda in 1917 will be published by Round Table Press next week under the title, "Preachers Present Arms." It is the work of Dr. Ray H. Abrams of the University of Pennsylvania, who drew upon sermons and pronouncements by several hundred American clergymen during the World War to discover how the church reacted to war hysteria.
HAVANA, Sept. 29 -- Today's clash between soldiers and Communists does not mean intervention or the landing of marines under present conditions.

In the Fusion camp the announcement of Joseph. V. McKee that he would run as an independent candidate for Mayor was the signal for the loosening of verbal broadsides by leaders and candidates alike. In the statements emanating from the Fusion group, Mr. McKee was denounced as an assistant Tammanyite and a decoy to divert votes from the anti-Tammany candidates fighting under the Fusion banner.

CHICAGO, Sept. 29 -- Criticism of Chancellor Hitler's anti-Semitic campaign in Germany as ''not reconcilable" with "the reign of Christ in this world" was voiced here tonight by Bishop Manning of New York.

NEW ORLEANS, La., Sept. 29 -- George M. Cox, wealthy Chicago and New Orleans shipowner, was so alarmed today over his failure to find his wife, his 2-year-old son and Mrs. Cox's parents, that he announced an offer of $25,000 for information that would lead to their safe return.

Grover A. Whalen, city NRA chairman, returned from Washington yesterday to reorganize the local NRA organization into three groups and to set up a single central compliance board for the city. He will continue to head the city NRA.

Bonds listed on the Stock Exchange moved higher yesterday in fairly active dealings, except United States Government bonds, which sold off 2-32 to 10-32 point. Of the latter, only one issue closed higher, the Treasury 4 1/4 s, which were up 2-32, and one, the fourth Liberty 4 1/4 s, held unchanged.

The derangement of foreign exchange has become beneficial to the American and Foreign Power Corporation in recent months, although the company was handicapped previously By the limitations set up by the governments of many foreign countries in which it operates.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 -- A special advisory committee is being planned by the Roosevelt administration to work out legislation by which it hopes to put a curb upon violent price fluctuations on the New York Stock Exchange.
For nearly two weeks, by letter and by telegram, by resolution and personal appeal, I have been asked to be a candidate for Mayor of New York city on an independent ticket.

Considerably more in the way of solid food graces the board for the follower of football with this second Saturday of a new season. True, a great many of the more substantial citizens of the game remain a week longer at practice before starting play, but today finds sufficient or the more important in action to call It a football day.

LONDON, Sept. 29 -- P.V.G Mitchell, vice president of the International Mercantile Marine, interviewed before sailing on the liner Manhattan for New York today, said big ships were "unsound and uneconomic," his views conflicting with those recently expressed here urging resumption of work on the giant Cunarder.

The NRA in its present stage was compared to the first experimental phonograph of Thomas A. Edison yesterday by Charles Edison, son of the late inventor. He spoke at the Nearly a Century of Progress exhibit at Gimbels, celebrating the ninety-first anniversary of the founding of that store.
The first issue of Building Modernization, to appear monthly, has been published by Business Journals, Inc., of 192 Lexington Av. C.G. Peker is editor of the magazine.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Sept. 29 -- Although William L. Ward was absent as chairman for the first time in thirty-seven years, the annual organization convention of the Westchester County Republican Committee was conducted here today in the smooth manner which characterized the Ward regime.

The first seventy railroads to report earnings for August showed a net operating income of $55,902,000, against $27,956,000 in August, 1932, an increase of 99.9 per cent, and against $51,622,000 in August, 1931, an increase of 8.2 per cent. In July their net income was $59,720,000, against $11,856,000 in July, 1932, an increase of 403.7 per cent.
News for the fishermen is encouraging. All along the coast a mild westerly wind is predicted for the week-end, which means good conditions for angling.
The eve of Atonement, the most solemn holy day of the Jewish year, commenced at sundown yesterday.

BAYONNE, N.J., Sept. 29 -- The Bear of Oakland, Admiral Byrd's Antarctica expedition supply ship, sailed from Bayonne this morning, bound for Norfolk, Va., where she was to take on 300 tons of coal before proceeding to Panama. The crew and officers having said their farewells to relatives and friends yesterday, there were only a few Tide-Water Oil Company employes present when the ship was towed out into the Kill Van Kull.
GENEVA, Sept. 29 -- "All signs in the Far East point to a major conflict within a few years," Dr. V.K. Wellington Koo of China told the Assembly of the League of Nations today.
CHESTERTON, Ind., Sept. 29 (AP) -- The official protest sent by Captain Matt Leach, commander of the Indiana State Highway Police, to the Federal Radio Commission was as follows:

LONDON, Sept. 29 -- The stock markets were cheerful and active today, with a considerable increase in business over yesterday's volume. British funds were quieter, with interest centred on the more speculative sections, but some were slightly better.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 -- Interest on government bonds is not subject to excess profits tax, Guy, T. Helvering, Commissioner of Internal Revenue, ruled today.

FAR HILLS, N.J., Sept. 29 -- Members of the hunting colonies of New Jersey gathered at the fair grounds today for the opening sessions of the annual Far Hills Horse Show, which will be concluded tomorrow with competitions during the morning and afternoon.

Forms of contracts for twentyfive-year bus franchises on Manhattan routes were approved yesterday by the Board of Estimate and set down for final hearing on Oct. 27. The contracts, as now drawn, contain the names of the New York City Omnibus Corporation, the Madison Avenue Coach Company and the Comprehensive Bus Company as prospective grantees.

MONTREAL, Sept. 29 (Canadian Press) -- For the first time since Canada entered Lesley Cup competition in 1927, its representatives tonight found themselves leading teams from the New York, Pennsylvania and Massachusetts Golf Associations at the end of the first day's play over the Royal Montreal Golf Club's south course.

CHICAGO, Sept. 29 -- An X-ray machine which permits one to read or see pictures with eyes closed was exhibited today at the American Congress of Radiology. Completed only two wrecks ago, it was brought to Chicago by its inventor, Dr. A.H. Pirie of the Royal Victoria Hospital at Montreal.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Sept. 29 -- Henry Lou Gehrig Jr., first baseman of the New York Tankees, was married this morning at his home, 5 Meadow Lane, this city, to Miss Eleanor Grace Twitchell of Chicago, daughter of Frank Bradford Twitchell, retired Chicago restaurant operator.
PITTSBURGH, Sept. 29 -- Duquesne defeated the West Virginia football team, 19 to 7, at Forbes Field tonight.
SOUTH ORANGE, N.J., Sept. 29 -- About 250 guests attended the horse show ball tonight at the Montclair Golf Club after the opening day of the annual horse show at the Montclair Riding Club.
LONDON, Sept. 29 -- Material said to make an airplane immune to fire was demonstrated in action at Heston airport today by a Belgian officer, Major R. van Rolleghem.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Sept. 29 -- Great importance is attached by the Yugoslav press to the forthcoming meeting of King Alexander and President Mustapha Kemal in Istanbul, which is taken to presage closer cooperation among all Balkan countries.

MOSCOW, Sept. 29 -- The newspapers feature today a speech in Kharkov by Peter Postisheff, one of the most interesting figures in the new Russia. A man in his early thirties, M. Postisheff played no role in the old revolutionary struggle, but it is believed here that he will be a member of the Political Bureau of the Communist Party after the next Communist Congress late this Winter.

HYPE PARK, N.Y., Sept. 29 (AP) -- The nation was told tonight by President Roosevelt that spiritual values must be held just as high as economic values "if the task we all face" of gaining better times is to succeed.
CHICAGO, Sept. 29 (AP) -- A $2,000,000 track relaying program for the rest of 1933 and 1934 was announced today by President Ralph Budd of the Chicago, Burlington Quincy Railroad.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Sept. 29 (AP) -- Columbus made it three in a row from Buffalo tonight by winning the fourth game of the little world's series, 11 to 5. The series will be resumed in Buffalo tomorrow night with Columbus having a 3-to-1 edge.

HEWLETT, L.I., Sept. 29 -- Jarvis Hicks Jr., brother of Miss Helen Hicks, former women's national champion, captured a bit of golfing glory for himself by winning the medal in the Seawane Club's invitation tourney today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 (AP) -- The Farm Adjustment Administration completed its role as hog buyer today with a final flood of pigs at live stock marketing centres which brought its purchases of the animals weighing less than 100 pounds to more than 6,000,000.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 -- Loadings of revenue freight in the week ended on Sept. 23 amounted to 652,669 cars, the American Railway Association announced today. This was 653 cars, or 0.1 per cent, more than in the preceding week, 57,065 cars, or 9.6 per cent, more than in the corresponding week last year, but 85,367 cars, or 11.6 per cent, fewer than in the corresponding week two years ago.
Savings banks were among the plaintiffs who bought in Manhattan and Bronx real estate at foreclosure auctions yesterday. Seventeen properties were taken over in this manner as follows:
U.S. Department of Agriculture. Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices at New York.

With Bill Terry and his champion Giants the most keenly interested of the 4,000 spectators in the Yankee Stadium yesterday, Joe Cronin's Senators put a winning spirit on display that set the Yankees back, 8 to 5, and evened the current series.

DETROIT, Sept. 29 -- A crowd of more than 10,000 saw the 1933 football season opened tonight between the University of Detroit and Ypsilantl Normal College. Detroit scored a 31 to 0 victory. The outstanding star was McCracken, who scored two touchdowns.

The climax comes today in the most important polo tournament of the year, the national open championship. At 3:30 P.M. on International Field at the Meadow Brook Club, Greentree and Aurora will ride out to decide the successor to Templeton as the year's national champion.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 (AP) -- Meat packers and other large food companies joined today in the effort to transfer farm surpluses to the tables of the needy by promising to sell their products to the Farm Relief Administration without profit.

Indications of a decline in the number of families "doubling up" with relatives constituted the chief feature of the Fall moving season in the apartment house field as van owners reported yesterday that the peak of the annual movement was passing quietly.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 -- The administration at an early date will define its monetary policy, which will include devaluation and stabilization of the dollar, together with a promise to return to the gold standard. This was disclosed by a high-ranking government official today, who said a statement from President Roosevelt, designed to stimulate business, was imminent.

The estate of Alfred E. Ommen, lawyer and former city magistrate, who died Dec. 21, 1932, was appraised yesterday at $347,958 gross and $329,630 net, the bulk of which goes for life to his widow, Elsie E. Ommen of 14 East Ninetieth Street. On her death the estate will be distributed among organizations and institutions in which he was interested.

Governor Herbert H. Lehman, ill of appendicitis, spent a comfortable day yesterday at his home, 820 Park Avenue. An informal bulletin, issued in the afternoon, described the attending physicians as satisfied with the progress he is making.

TROY, N.Y., Sept. 29 (AP) -- Leonard Scarnici, New York gangster chief; Anthony Reino and Charles Herzog were arraigned today in County Court on charges of murdering Detective James Stevens of Rensselaer during a bank hold-up on May 29.

Frank A. Vanderlip Jr. gave a dinner last night on the terrace of the Central Park Casino for Miss Rosemary Street and C. Hunt Lewis 2d., who will be married Tuesday in All Angels Church. The guests were seated at a crescent-shaped table decorated with white roses and fern.

TRENTON, N.J., Sept. 29 -- G. Frank Shanley, State manager for the Federal Home Owners Loan, Corporation, said today that it probably would be six weeks before any loans were closed in New Jersey. About fifty cases are well on the way, he said, and these will be settled first.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., Sept. 29 -- Brilliant jumping victories by the entries of the G. and B. Stables of West Orange, owned by Julius Glaser and A. St. John Boycott, today featured the opening competition in the eighth annual two-day exhibition of the Montclair Horse Show.

MONTEVIDEO, Sept. 29 -- All the members of the Pan American Union have accepted without reservation Uruguay's invitation to the Pan-American conference in Montevideo, according to a statement by Foreign Minister Alberto Mane today.
LONDON, Sept. 29 -- Lord Merrivale, 88-year-old president of the Divorce Court, has decided to retire. Sir Boyd Merriman, Solicitor General, is mentioned as his successor.
PITTSBURGH, Sept. 29 -- Four thousand striking miners swept over Clairton today in the greatest mass picketing effort since the soft coal "holiday" began two weeks ago.

Hoarded currency is continuing to return gradually to the banks, according to the monthly review of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, published yesterday. The bank bases this opinion on the unseasonable reduction of money In circulation during the last month.

In the Federal Government's prosecution of lawyers who aid the criminal activities of their clients Attorney General Homer S. Cummings will have the "vigorous cooperation" of the Association of the Bar of the City of New York.
Many leading Eastern prep school football teams, including those of Lawrenceville, Exeter, Andover, Kent, Mercersburg and Blair, are scheduled to open their seasons this afternoon.

The duty of the United States in common with the British Common-wealth to stand for personal and political liberty in opposition to "repressive policies adopted and violent actions taken in some of the countries of Europe, notably in Germany and Russia," was urged in a lecture delivered here yesterday by Sir Herbert Samuel.

As a result of complaints of coercion to force the retail sale of certain brands of beer, detectives attached to the new racket bureau of the State Attorney General's office visited the headquarters of three beer distributing firms in Brooklyn yesterday afternoon.

An increasing number of people in the United, States are apprehensive of currency inflation and fearful of its results. Eight distinguished men, representing both major political parties, have approved and sponsored a series of articles presenting their viewpoint on the money problems of the day. The series is appearing in this newspaper in sixteen consecutive daily chapters. The sixth is presented herewith.

LEIPZIG, Sept. 29 -- Marinus Van der Lubbe, the pyromaniacal enigma of the Leipzig treason trial, put his neck in the hangman's noose by confessing before the German supreme Court today that on the night of Feb. 27 he flung twenty-seven firebrands into the Reichsstag building, thereby helping to precipitate the greatest political up-heaval in recent German history.

Grocers' NRA Certificate Ready. A certificate attesting to the fact that 300 grocery manufacturers, whose names are listed, have subscribed to the recovery code, was completed by the Associated Grocery Manufacturers of America yesterday and will be distributed to about 500,000 distributers of grocery and food products.

HAVANA, Sept. 29 -- Six persons were killed and twenty-seven wounded in riots this afternoon when police broke up a Communist demonstration. One of the wounded is an American and another a British subject.

Henry L. Roosevelt, Assistant Secretary of the Navy, paid a flying visit to the navy yard in Brooklyn yesterday. He described his visit as a "usual inspection," although Representative John D. Delaney indicated Thursday he had asked Mr. Roosevelt to come to New York in an effort to obtain more work for the local yard, where a part-time schedule is now in effect.
Residential properties made up the New Jersey realty turnover reported yesterday.

Formation of two Stock Exchange firms, G.A. Dixon Co. of 42 Broadway and J.A. Hogle Co. of 132 Main Street, Salt Lake City, Utah, has been proposed, it was announced yesterday by the Exchange. Partners in Dixon Co. will be George A. Dixon Jr., J.M. Covo, A.J. Bodenheimer and Robert Rein. Hogle Co. will consist of James A. Hogle and Mary C. Hogle.
Boston's chances of getting a fourth-place share of the world's series receipts brightened yesterday when the Braves downed the Dodgers in the play-off of Thursday's tie game, 4 to 1.

What kind of Postmaster General is this man FARLEY? Multitudes of faithful Democrats, eager to serve their country, will be asking that question when they have read his speech at Rochester at the convention of the National Association of Postmasters -- most of them Republicans, probably, confound it!

BOSTON, Sept. 29 (AP) -- The Commercial Bulletin will say tomorrow: "The week has found a fair interest continuing in wool, although it has been less pronounced than in either of the preceding two weeks. Altogether some 75,000,000 pounds of wool have been sold in the months of August and September, an unusually large movement and especially for these two months, which usually are dull periods.

RYE, N.Y., Sept. 29 -- Vincent Richards, former Davis Cup star, teamed with Charles Wood of the Somerset Hills Country Club of Bernardsville, N.J., to gain the final round of the national professional doubles tennis championship at the Westchester Country Club today

VIENNA, Sept. 28 -- Fresh from a triumphant reception in Geneva when the assembly of the League of Nations applauded his reiteration of Austria's desire to remain independent, Chancellor Dollfuss returned by fast train today in time to preside over a journalistic reception at which Dr. Karl Buresch, the Minister of Finance, announced the terms of the new domestic loan that is to be issued by the Austrian Government.

Deploring the lack of speed in the execution of the Federal Government's $3,300,000,000 public works program, former Governor Alfred E. Smith, writing as editor of The Outlook in the current issue of the magazine, makes several suggestions designed to facilitate the program.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 -- Organized labor, speaking through the metal and building trades departments of the American Federation of Labor, charged today that "certain public office holders in charge of law-enforcement" in some of the larger cities of the country are seeking to control and dominate organized labor in their respective communities through the "intimidation and coercion" of the officers and members of units of the National Federation.

LOCUST VALLEY, L.I., Sept. 29 -- Mark Stuart and his partner, Mrs. Marion Turpie Lake, one of the favored teams in the mixed foursomes tourney at the Piping Rock Club, triumphed twice in hard-fought matches today to become one of the eight pairs left in the running for the Marshall Field Trophy.
Tammany Hall yesterday received the announcement of the candidacy of Joseph V. McKee for Mayor to silence, in so far as comment for publication was concerned.

After two days of indecision, Joseph V. McKee, former president of the Board of Aldermen, announced yesterday that he would run for Mayor as an independent candidate. He promised a war against political "bossism," and, in the event of his election, pledged to the people of the city "what they now have in the nation -- a new deal."

President BUTLER, in welcoming the members of Columbia University to its new year "of effort, of intellectual and "spiritual growth and of many-sided "service," emphasized this year its continuing duty to the City of New York. What he said is largely in iteration of what has been said again and again, but it must be repeated till the patent evils are overcome.
The Columbia Broadcasting System denied yesterday that WIND, a member of its network at Gary, Ind., faked a broadcast of a convict hunt in Indiana on Wednesday.

HYDE PARK, N.Y., Saturday, Sept. 30 -- President Roosevelt approved early today an agreement giving to employes in mines operated by steel companies for their own consumption, the so-called "captive mines," the same wages and working hours as are accorded to miners under the coal code.

Mayor O'Brien responded yesterday to the Bar Association's criticism of his appointment of Justice Edward F. Boyle as presiding Justice of the Children' s-Domestic Relations Court, with the statement that he would stand on the appointment.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 -- Government subsidies to the Export Steamship Corporation amounting to $26,663,151 since 1928 on vessels either sold to the line for less than their market value or constructed with Shipping Board loans were recounted today in the Senate's investigation into the administration of ocean mail contracts.

There was a great deal of confusion in the markets yesterday. While it seemed for a time that stocks were about to engage in a broad advance, weakness cropped out and the brokers appeared not to know whether it was because of suddenly impaired confidence or the unsatisfactory performance of the commodity markets.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The letter of Thomas Woodward, published in THE TIMES, in which the recommendations of the Grimm committee for the Department of Education are acclaimed, contains a mixture of information and misinformation about the administration of the city schools that makes it seem wise to answer it.
GENEVA, Sept. 29 -- The German refugee situation was twice brought before the League of Nations Assembly today.

Friday, Sept. 29, 1933. Money market was quiet. Business was small and quotations for all classifications unchanged from Thursday. Street loans were arranged at 1/2 @ 3/8, while the board rate remained at 3/4.
The Columbia Broadcasting System denied yesterday that WIND, a member of its network at Gary, Ind., faked a broadcast of a convict hunt in Indiana on Wednesday.

Announcement from Washington, on the authority of the Secretary of the Treasury, that new credit expansion plans are under consideration gave encouragement to the speculative markets for a time yesterday. There was a short-lived rally on the Stock Exchange and a more durable advance in the bond department.

The Rev. Walter P. Doty, who has been rector of St. Paul's Protestant Episcopal Church, Ossining, N.Y., has accepted a call to the rectorship of St. John's Church, Eleventh Street and Waverly Place, and will preach his first sermon as rector there tomorrow morning.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 (AP) -- A $20,000,000 allotment for a third giant power development on the Pacific Coast topped the list of projects which today received the go-ahead signal from the Public Works Administration.

Many Lumber Feet. There is nothing odd in the government's buying 250,000,000 feet of lumber to build Winter camps for its 250,000 enrolled forest workers. The first temptation is to ask what is the point of cutting down forests for the purpose of enabling a quarter of a million people to conserve the forests.

LONDON, Sept. 29 -- A manuscript of a sermon believed to have been written by the great lexicographer, Dr. Samuel Johnson, has been acquired by the American collector Gabriel Wells for presentation to the Yale University Library.

"As Thousands Cheer," a "topical revue," by Irving Berlin and Moss Hart, will open this evening at the Music Box Theatre. Among those who are taking part are Marilyn Miller, Clifton Webb, Helen Broderick and Ethel Waters.

The first quarter of the fiscal year 1933-34 ends today, with the Federal Treasury showing a surplus, new-style, in the neighborhood of $75,000,000. Except for income taxes, which continue to make a disappointing showing, revenues are much improved by comparison with those of the preceding year.

Postmaster Francis J. Sinnott of Brooklyn announced yesterday the voluntary retirement of 102 postal employes from the Brooklyn Postoffice Department. This action was taken under the terms of the Federal Economy Act providing for the retirement of postoffice employes who had completed thirty years of service regardless of their age.
The following editorial comment on Joseph V. McKee's announcement of his candidacy for Mayor appears in the New York newspapers of yesterday and today:

The Crown Cork International Corporation and its more than 50 per cent owned subsidiaries reported for the six months ended on June 30, last, a net profit of $179,743. This is after depreciation, interest, Federal taxes, minority interest, adjustments for fluctuation in foreign exchange and other charges and is equal to 50 cents a share on 359,000 no par shares of class A stock.

OKLAHOMA CITY, Sept. 29 -- A verdict in the trial of the nine men and one woman charged with the kidnapping for ransom of Charles F. Urschel, wealthy oil man, was reported reached by a Federal court jury tonight after two and a half hours' deliberation.
Futures prices for most of the commodities traded on local exchanges worked their way into higher ground in yesterday's dealings. Trading was in fair volume. Cash markets were quiet and irregular.

BUENOS AIRES, Sept. 29 -- Arrangements have been completed to make the visit of President Augustin P. Justo of Argentina to President Getulio Vargas of Brazil one of the most imposing and spectacular events in South American history.

A call to leaders in Catholic charity work to cooperate more closely in the enactment of social legislation was delivered here yesterday by Father Francis J. Haas, director of the department of social action of the National Catholic Welfare Conference and member of the Labor Advisory Board of the National Recovery Administration.

Remain Rolland, French dramatist, historian and novelist, in a letter received last week by THE NEW YORK TIMES, requested the assistance of correspondents in Germany of "great foreign independent papers" in ascertaining the fate of Carl von Ossietsky, former editor of Die Weltbuhne, German antimilitarist weekly.

ACCORDING to one of the gentlest rumors imaginable, "The Dark Tower" (nee "Snake in the Grass") deals with the stage and its people. There is, they say, a Svengali twist to the affair, the difference being that the object is forced to act, not sing.
Yesterday was Dahlia Day at the New York Botanical Garden. More than 1,000 plants, comprising 400 varieties, were exhibited. There was also a voting contest for the most popular bloom.

BUFFALO, Sept. 30 (AP). -- Lefty Milstead tonight scored his second little world's series triumph as he halted Columbus with ten scattered hits as Buffalo pounded four pitchers for a 7-3 victory before 10,000 fans. Milstead pitched the only game won by the Bisons in the four contests played in Columbus.

To the Editor of The New York Times: May I redirect the attention of THE TIMES readers to a portrait which you printed in the rotogravure section a few weeks ago. It was a close-up portrait of a sloth, suitable for framing, as I have already done with my copy -- framed it under the plate glass of my writing desk.

THE BOWERY," a Twentieth Century production, will have its local premiere on Wednesday at the Rivoli Theatre. Michael L. Simmons, who, with B.R. Solomon, wrote the book on which the film was based, assisted the producers in recapturing some of the spirit of a street known in the traditionally gay Nineties as "the livest mile on the face of the globe."

BERLIN, Sept. 30. -- In a decree supplementing the Nazi government's civil servants' act the Nazis today gave a privileged position to those "who have made themselves helpful to the cause of national revolution" and provided for protection against those who because of prior political nonconformity are unworthy of exerting Nazi power.

LOCUST VALLEY, L.I., Sept. 30. -- A fifteen-foot putt, holed bY Mrs. Robert C. Lake on the seventeenth green, put the former Southern champion and her partner, Mark J. Stuart, the metropolitan champion, into the final round of the mixed foursome tournament, at the Piping Rock Club today.

HYDE PARK, N.Y., Sept. 30. -- A Federal relief program, shorn of red tape, in the interest of feeding, clothing and providing coal for the needy during tha coming Winter will be started within a week under plans approved today by President Roosevelt in a three-hour conference with Harry L. Hopkins, Administrator of Federal Relief.

CHICAGO, Sept. 30. -- Senator Copeland of New York, whose Congressional subcommittee on racketeering and kidnapping will meet in Chicago the latter part of October, today outlined some of the suggested legislative reforms which are being considered for use in a nation-wide war on organized crime.

Value of Dollar on Exchange Market The value of the dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on quotations for the French franc on the days indicated, compares as follows. Quotations are in cents:

SUPPOSE that the heat and light so prodigally radiated into space by the sun were reconverted into matter -- perhaps into another sun. The process is no more startling than that which, we were told last week, has been observed in the laboratories of Pasadena, Calif., and of Cambridge, England.

Gold shipped abroad in September was smaller in amount than in either of the two preceding months and was consigned, as in those months, principally to France. It was the third consecutive month without imports. Of the gold exported all was released from earmark, except $4,666,400, which amount was lost to the monetary gold stock, of the United States.

HEWLETT, L.I., Sept. 30. -- Jarvis Hicks of the Hempstead Country Club, brother of Miss Helen Hicks, former woman's national titleholder, advanced into the semi-final round of the Seawane Club's golf tournament today, downing two opponents by 2 and 1 scores today.

PRINCETON, N.J., Sept. 30. -- Changes in the economic and social systems of this country will not reduce the importance of the individual declares President Harold Willis Dodds of Princeton University in his first, message to Princeton alumni, published in the current issue of the Princeton Alumni Weekly.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30. -- A proposal considered by NRA officials to reduce minimum wages for common labor in the construction industry has been rejected because of the danger of serious labor troubles.

New financing in September was little changed from the almost dormant condition of August. Except the offering of one large block of government short-term debentures, only one sizable bond issue was marketed. In all, twenty-one separate bond issues, aggregating $52,995,000, were floated here last month, compared with twenty totaling $32,882,000 in August and twenty-seven, offered at $98,328,000 in September, 1932.

LONDON. IN London and at the English resorts in recent weeks one has heard Continental languages spoken with striking frequency, in contrast to their almost complete absence in other years. Numerous visitors have come from France, Belgium, Germany, even Czechoslovakia.

INDIANAPOLIS, Sept. 30. -- Captain Matt Leach of the State police, directing the hunt for the convicts who escaped from the State prison at Michigan City, went to Nashville, Ind., tonight on word that Joseph Jenkins, second of the ten fugitives to be caught, had been killed near there.

Manual Training ushered in its campaign by crushing the Richmond Hill High, 39 to 0, before 1,000 spectators at Dexter Park, Woodhaven, yesterday. Roddy Costello, fullback, and Jack Wallace, quarterback, led the attack for the winners.

The shofar, the sacred ram's horn, which is blown only on the highest holidays of the Jewish year, called young and old to atone for their slns yesterday as Yom Kippur, the most solemn holy day in the Jewish calendar, was celebrated.

From the viewpoint of dividends declared, September came closer to equaling the figures of the same month in the preceding year than any other month had done in more than two years. Declarations for shareholders of 1,027 corporations aggregated $197,636,097, compared with $205,984,924 by 1,191 companies the year before.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 30 (AP). -- The Athletics closed their home season today by losing a double-header to the Red Sox by the scores of 2 to 1 and 12 to 1. The double triumph gave Boston the season's series with the Mackmen, 14 games to 8.

PHOENIX, Ariz., Sept. 28. -- The Republican party in Arizona will reach its nadir next Tuesday when Mrs. Isabelle Greenway is elected to Congress practically by default. The Republicans failed to nominate a candidate at the primary, but the State central committee in an admittedly hopeless gesture named H. B. Wilkinson, a Phoenix lawyer, in order that the organization may be kept functioning against what the G.O.P. leaders hope may be better days.

BERLIN, Sept. 30. -- The process of adjusting the German penal code to National Socialist conceptions of criminal jurisprudence is nearing completion. A memorial by Hans Karl, Prussian Minister of Justice, forecasts how the criminal law will be administered in the Nazi State, and says the judicial experts have in preparation a penal code that will squarely conform to the prevailing revolutionary procedure.

SINCE illustration has been said to be the best definition. Miss Sitwell, in forming this gallery of characters, has bound herself to no rigid examinations for entrance. She says that eccentricity "exists particularly in the English, because of that peculiar and satisfactory knowledge of infallibility that is the hallmark and birthright of the British nation."

AMSTERDAM, Sept. 25 (by mail). -- The Peking Man had a brain distinctly human in type, showing a notable advance in development over the brain of Pithecanthropus, the Java Man, discovered more than forty years ago by Professor Eugene Dubois of the University of Amsterdam.

One of the pioneer movements in adult education was the Chautauqua Literary and Scientific Circle launched fifty-five years ago. The claim made for it -- that it is the oldest reading club in the world -- may not be indisputable, but it has added to the educational institutions of our country a system of home reading that has been a source of inspiration and cultural aspiration to thousands.

EDWARDSVILLE, Ill., Sept. 30 (AP). -- Six members of the gang which kidnapped August Luer July 10 were convicted and sentenced today to prison terms ranging from life to five years. The State had demanded the death penalty.

EASTON, Pa., Sept. 30. -- Introducing a deceptive shift, an innovation in Lafayette football, the Maroom eleven scored a 20-0 victory over Muhlenberg today. A crowd of 7,000 saw the winners launch their campaign.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30. -- Permission to construct the Midtown Hudson Tunnel, from Thirty-ninth Street to Weehawken, was granted today by Harry C. Woodring, Assistant Secretary of War, to the Port of New York Authority. Mr. Woodring acted on the opinion of the Chief of Army Engineers that the work would not unreasonably interfere with navigation.

ITHACA, N.Y., Sept. 30. -- Cornell encountered stiffer opposition than customary in its football opener with St. Lawrence today, winning, 48 to 7, with St. Lawrence scoring on a 70-yard forward pass play, Glinsky to Warren, in the fourth period.

Hunter College students have elected officers for the Fall term in sixteen organizations of extracurricular activities. These include two dramatic societies, three religious clubs, two political discussion groups and three publications. The organizations and their officers follow:
MINEOLA, L.I., Sept. 30. -- High scores prevailed in close competition at the Nassau Trapshooting Club today.

CONVERTING the basement into a game room has become a leisure-time activity for many householders. Moving coalbins that occupy the best-lighted part of a cellar and introducing oil or gas furnaces facilitate the making of these new interiors.
DETROIT. RAW materials that go into automobiles are costing manufacturers from 5 to 8 per cent more than at this time one year ago. The trend of prices is upward and is likely to continue so.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 28. --Southern California has just had its first experience with the newly legalized pari-mutuel betting on horse races. The Southern Counties Fair at Pomona drew a gate of 350,000 customers more than the State Fair at Sacramento attracted.
MIDDLETOWN, Conn., Sept. 30. -- Wesleyan and Union fought to a 7-to-7 tie today. Neither eleven scored in the first half during which the offensive honors were about even.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30. -- Though still a hospital patient, General Johnson spent hours today reasoning with representatives of steel companies and of organized labor in an effort to bring about entire peace in the "captive mines" owned by the steel companies.

The story of the hare and the tortoise is just a fable. But the story of the tortoise and the hawk is not, and William Carr, director of the Trailside Museum at Bear Mountain, N.Y., wants everybody to know it.

BY resolution the General Assembly of the Presbyterian Church in America has endorsed the movement to celebrate "the 250th anniversary of the organization, in 1683, of the original Presbyterian churches in this country by Francis Makemie, on the Eastern Shore of Maryland and Virginia."

MINEOLA, L.I., Sept. 30. -- Three of New York State's leading authorities on constitutional law have been asked to decide the constitutionality of the proposed city charter for Nassau County. They are Nathan Miller, former Governor of the State of New York, a Republican; John W. Davis, former Democratic Presidential nominee, and William D. Guthrie, former president of the New York State Bar Association and former Professor of Constitutional Law at Columbia University, a Republican.

DALLAS, Texas, Sept. 28. -- When genial Jim Parley makes his grand tour of Texas nest month he will be expected to play his old role of political miracle man. He may not be able to pull political rabbits out of a tall silk bat, but he is expected to lay on the healing hand and to renew the well-springs of faith in the Roosevelt Administration.
WEST POINT, N.Y., Sept. 30. -- Army, in its opening game of the football season, defeated Mercer University of Macon, Ga., today after a hard-fought battle by 19 to 6. A crowd of 10,000 saw the game.

OCTOBER has rolled around once again, with its assorted hopes, fears, promises, rumors and reports. This column, acting as a mad sort of sieve, has scanned the lists of the month now entering its tenancy. Below is the result of considerable separation; the plays are those most likely to come in during the three weeks that follow this one.

BERLIN. THE youthful stories or Frank Thless were permeated by a delightful, profoundly mystical view of nature that often sounded a tragic note. His great novel, "Die Verdammten," also showed men in a curiously deep-seated state of oneness with their native soil, and at the same time gave a comprehensive portrayal of German social conditions in the Baltic provinces.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30. -- Convictions obtained in the Urschel kidnapping case at Oklahoma City and the Luer trial at Edwardsville, Ill., are regarded by Justice Department officials as the most important victories for law enforcement in a decade.

An increasing number of people in the United States are apprehensive of currency inflation and fearful of its results. Eight distinguished men, representing both major political parties, have approved and sponsored a series of articles presenting their viewpoint on the money problems of the day. The series is appearing in this newspaper in sixteen consecutive daily chapters. The seventh is presented herewith.

ALLENTOWN, Pa., Sept. 30. -- Senator David A. Reed, speaking at a Republican rally at Fogelsville today, marking the opening of the Fall campaign, declared that the National Recovery Act reposed "too much power in the President." He added, however, that "as a good citizen I shall support the administration in the fond hope that ultimately it will work out to the benefit of the country."

We publish in another column today a collection of editorial comments on the currency-inflation proposal, clipped more or less at random from newspapers in all sections of the United States. Limitations of space prevent making such a symposium complete, but the reader may be assured that the views presented in these extracts typify fairly the trend of judgment in a much longer list of newspapers which have been examined.

Funds for the Federation for the Support of Jewish Philanthropic Societies will be solicited during the coming campaign by 2,500 volunteer workers, according to an announcement yesterday by Samuel D. Leidesdorf, chairman of the Business Men's Council, the organization's fund raising unit.

NEW ORLEANS, La., Sept. 30. -- Tulane's green wave washed against a stalwart breakwater in the form of a Texas A. and M. forward wall today. As a result Tulane met the first opening football defeat in over a decade, as the Aggies romped to a 13-6 victory.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 (AP). -- Formation of seven regional offices with a manager in charge of each to assist Washington headquarters in enforcing the Agriculture Adjustment Act were announced today. District offices will be established "where and when necessary."

IF, as the late Moses Malevinsky in his volume on playwriting believed, dramas may be summed up in one word, Elizabeth McFadden, authoress of "Double Door" at the Ritz Theatre, may also be so described. There is no need to mull over page after page of thesaurus or dictionary.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 30. -- The Reconstruction Finance Corporation today ordered full speed ahead in the administration's plan to assist in the financing of the NRA industries.

THE great Mormon crusade, inspired by the astonishing Mormon gospel, forms one of the most extraordinary and dramatic chapters in American history. But little seems to have come of it as a theme for poets, metaphysicians, historians and novelists.

Christopher Dreiss, a 73-year-old retired farmer, of 65-13 Forty-fifth Avenue, Woodside, Queens, was struck and killed by a hit-and-run driver while crossing Queens Boulevard at Sixty-fifth Place about 11 o'clock last night.
According to transatlantic correspondence, most of the details for the international match between the women squash racquets players of this country and England have been arranged.
NEW YORK. Mr. and Mrs. Frank B. Kellogg are expected today at the Ritz-Carlton.
MINNEAPOLIS, Sept. 30 (AP). -- A promising Minnesota football team opened the 1933 season today with a 19-to-6 triumph over South Dakota State.

SALEM, N.H., Sept. 30. -- The little considered Mad Frump, 4-year-old brown colt owned by C.V. Whitney, today gained a surprising triumph in the $7,500 Rockingham Park Handicap under the masterly riding of Earl Porter, the track's leading jockey.

OMAHA, Neb., Sept. 28. -- There is habitually noticeable a stirring of the instinct for politics about the time of the first frost in Nebraska. It derives from an earlier day, when elections were held annually, and October was a month of brisk campaigning.

Members of the present and of previous administrations, and of both branches of Congress, will discuss national problems before the League for Political Education at the Town Hall, 123 West Fortythird Street, during the coming season, it was announced yesterday by Robert Erskine Ely, its director.
ANDOVER, Mass., Sept. 30. -- Andover defeated New Hampton Prep, 14-0, today in a game marred by fumbles and loose play. The battle was the first of the season for both schools.

FLOWERS are so cheap in New York City today that a penny now will buy a Briarcliff rose. Peddlers and hawkers, some of whom are licensed by the city, roam the streets and offer carnations for 10 cents a dozen. Orchids have become so inexpensive that other than millionaires can buy them.

MORGANTOWN, W.Va., Sept. 28. -- After a week in which six West Virginia municipalities have suspended normal governmental functions because they have no money to pay current running expenses, State and city officials are no nearer a solution of their problems than they were on Sept. 19, when the State Supreme Court ruled that the limitations of the new constitutional tax amendment precluded the laying of special levies to pay debts.

THE English Poet Laureate's short drama, "End and Beginning," is, concerned with the last hours and execution of that most beautiful of Scotch heroines, Mary Stuart. It is certainly not a work to rank among Mr. Masefield's major efforts, but there is a quiet intensity and poignant strength about it that places it somewhat apart in the range of his work.

MONTREAL, Sept. 30. -- The Massachusetts Golf Association today won the 1933 Lesley Cup competition from, the golf associations of New York, the Province of Quebec, representing Canada, and Pennsylvania.

MADRID, Sept. 29. -- Concentration camps for beggars, established this week, are the newest spectacle in this country. Spanish beggars have indeed been kings. The law could not touch them, generosity protected them from hunger and an easy life and a comfortable stipend for old age have been their "reward."

MIDDLETOWN, Conn., Sept. 30 (AP). -- Seeking a remedy for poison ivy, Wesleyan University scientists have found that its virulent essence does not vaporize, hence that simply being near the plant without contact is not dangerous.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30. -- Close to the eve of the American Federation of Labor's annual convention on Monday, organized labor is plagued by the recurring problem of jurisdictional strikes which threaten to weaken and undermine its prestige, influence and future course of action.

MENOMINEE, Mich., Sept. 28. -- Fred Johnson's hobby is saving lives. For thirty-five years he has spent his evenings and Sundays watching from his back-yard dock for marine accidents. Single-handed he has built a lifeboat and equipped an efficient life-saving station.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Sept. 30. -- The Tennessee Valley Authority has told persons interested in the Chickamauga dam project that the authority has absolutely no interest in any project in the valley that will not enable it to make money and therefore is concentrating its entire attention on the question of power.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Sept. 30. -- Rutgers opened its season by defeating a stubborn Franklin and Marshall eleven before 6,000 persons today, 10-0. Neither team was able to score in the first two periods, but in the third quarter the scarlet attack gained momentum and accounted for a touchdown and field goal.

Attorney General Bennett, on behalf of the State, has acquired title to the few remaining privately owned parcels of land on the Spuyten Duyvil peninsula, jutting out into the Harlem River Ship Canal, it was announced yesterday. The land will be ceded to the Federal Government.

HAVANA, Sept. 30 (AP). -- Dr. Juan Maspons, chairman of the Cuban Economic Commission, tonight revealed he had recommended to President Grau a two-year suspension of payments on the capital of Cuba's foreign debt.

THE Reconstruction Finance Corporation began operations on Feb. 2, 1932, and did everything within its power to stem the tide of falling values and business stagnation. The diagnosis of our troubles, however, was not thorough enough, and the dose administered was entirely too mild.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30. -- Only slight changes occurred in the volume of business in the week ended on Sept. 23, according to the weekly survey of domestic conditions made public today by the Department of Commerce. Industrial production was maintained close to the level of the preceding week, and there was some improvement in retail trade.

Price changes in the bond market on the Stock Exchange were chiefly of a minor character in the two-hour trading yesterday. In general, domestic corporation bonds and United States Government longterm issues worked irregularly lower and foreign loans irregularly higher.
RICHMOND, Va., Sept. 30 (AP). -- Virginia on Tuesday will become the thirty-second State to vote on repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment.

HACKENSACK, N.J., Sept. 30. -- Without the services of seventy-two drivers of two automobile transport companies that deliver Ford cars to dealers in the metropolitan area, and with 1,200 of its 2,000 employes on strike, the assembly plant of the Ford Motor Company at Edgewater is badly crippled and there was some question today whether it would resume operations Monday.

CHICAGO, Sept. 30 (AP). -- A new wave of major crime will encompass the country within the next few months, Colonel Calvin Goddard, Director of Research of Northwestern University's Crime Detection Laboratory, predicts.

CAROLE LOMBARD, who tops the cast of "Brief Moment," a Columbia picture now on view at the Seventh Avenue Roxy, will celebrate Her twenty-fourth birthday next Friday. She wag born in Fort Wayne, Ind., and her real name is Carol Jane Peters. Her parents moved to Los Angeles when she was 7.

Inspection of taxicab meters to see that they complied with the new ordinance imposing a five-cent tax on each fare was almost completed by the Police Department last night. The meters, in accordance with an order issued last week by Commissioner Bolan, must be calibrated so that the first drop registers 20 cents instead of the prevailing 15-cent rate for the first quarter mile.

EVERY tumult to Cuba stirs in American landowners of the Isle of Pines an Impulse to signal for the Stars and Stripes. Not that they are averse to the settler's duty to identify himself with the country that yields him his living.

PELHAM MANOR, N.Y., Sept 30. -- Miss Deborah Black, daughter of Mrs. R. Clifford Black of Pelham Manor, will be introduced to society at a reception and tea to be given at her mother's home here on Thanksgiving Day. Mrs. Black will entertain with a dinner dance at the Pierre, New York, in honor of her debutante daughter.

An unusual entertainment has been arranged by a group of prominent women interested in the Maternity Centre Association. The event will be held the night of Nov. 1 in the Grand Ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria to raise funds to carry on the many philantropic enterprises of the association.

MR. STRACHEY begins his book with an exhibit of horrors and terrors made up of extracts from accounts in The London Times and Manchester Guardian of the treatment which Jews, Communists, Socialists and other groups have undergone at the hands of the German Nazis.
OLD WESTBURY, L.I., Sept. 30. -- A veteran of the Aintree Grand National triumphed in the thirty-fifth running of the Meadow Brook Cup Steeplechase at the Meadow Brook Hunts meeting today.

NEW LONDON, Sept. 30. -- The Coast Guard Academy Cadets surprised Worcester Tech's eleven today at Jones Field when they defeated the Engineers by a score of 25 to 0. Blouin, Lathrop and Land starred for the Cadets with long runs.

JACKSON, Miss., Sept. 30 (AP). -- Offering their bodies for experiment into the mystery of encephalitis, or sleeping sickness, ten white Mississippi convicts, between the ages of 21 and 40, are being used by State and Federal authorities to determine whether the disease which has caused many deaths in St. Louis is communicated by mosquito bites.

Encountering unexpectedly strong opposition, the Manhattan eleven battled its way to a 13-6 triumph over a resourceful Clarkson Tech eleven before a homecoming-day crowd of 6,000 at Manhattan Field yesterday.

PARIS, Sept. 19. -- Miss Anne Morgan and Mrs. W.K. Vanderbilt, who have just completed their annual cure at Marienbad, are spending a few weeks in Paris before sailing for New York. Miss Morgan has a house here in the Rue de Courcelles and Mrs. Vanderbilt in the Rue Leroux.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Sept. 28. -- The business of escaping taxes by failing to declare personal property is being handicapped seriously in Alabama now by the activities of special personal property assessors appointed by the State Tax Commission.

JESSE L. LASKY is preparing to produce a film based on the life of Anna Pavlova. The producers have purchased "Flight of the Swan," by Andre Oliveroff, one-time member of Pavlova's company, and are having it readied for the screen by Philip Dunne and Bessie Lasky.

THE National Air Pageant, concerning which much has been written during the last four months, is to be held next Saturday and Sunday at Roosevelt Field. Advance reports indicate that it will be the greatest air meet New York has seen in eight years -- since the Pulitzer and National Air Races in 1925.

MOSCOW, Sept. 28. -- The great "cleansing" of the Communist party that has been in progress for three months is now drawing to a close, and it is possible to give a general picture of the methods and results.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30. -- Walter Chrysler is to make an investigation of the strike situation in the automobile industry for General Johnson, who conferred with him today on conditions in the industry. Mr. Chrysler plans to go to Detroit soon.

MONTREAL, Sept. 30 (Canadian Press). -- The protective committee for holders of bonds of Price Brothers Co., Ltd., announced today that it had concluded an agreement with Bowater's Paper Mills, Ltd., newsprint manufacturers, of London, England, for a reorganization of Price Brothers.

FIRST principles make admirable neighbors. In the hurly-burly we are inclined to forget that our neghbor's true value as a citizen, is not to be measured, necessarily, by the modishness of his motor car. Evaluations tend to become superficial unless held strictly to account.

Increased retirements of public utility, municipal and foreign bonds in September before their dates of maturity raised the total of redemptions to the highest for any month since April and slightly above the total for September a year ago.
RUMSON, N.J., Sept. 30. -- The annual invitation golf tournament dinner dance was held at the Rumson Country Club tonight with more than 225 persons present.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30. -- Bronzed and hardened through outdoor life, hard work and wholesome food during the past six months, 125,000 members of the first Civilian Conservation Corps will return to their homes and private employment within the next fifteen days.

The Four-Power Pact, recently signed by Great Britain, France, Italy and Germany, was interpreted last night as "an actual instrument which makes it possible to resist by force the actual threat of communistic Russia to overwhelm Europe."

NASHVILLE, Ind., Sept. 30 (AP). -- A man identified as Joseph Jenkins, one of the ten convicts who escaped from Indiana State prison last Tuesday, was shot to death tonight in a gun battle at Beanblossom, near here.

PARIS, Sept. 15. WITH the month of October theatrical Paris will once more come to life; but many of the first openings will, as usual at this tentative period, consist of revivals with the promise of original works to follow.

The southeastern zone organization of the New York State Teachers Association will meet here Oct. 27 as part of the eighty-eighth anniversary of the parent association which will be marked by zone meetings in eight sections of the State in October and November.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, Sept. 30. -- The reopening of Admiralty House with Vice Admiral, the Hon. R.A. R. Plunkett-Ernle-Erle-Drax R.N., and Mrs. Drax in residence will immediately follow the return to her Bermuda base on Friday of H.M.S. Norfolk, flagship of the Eighth Cruiser Squadron.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Sept. 30. -- The second annual festival of contemporary music, which began here today at Yaddo and continues through tomorrow, is providing public hearings for the work of eighteen living composers. Most of the compositions have not been played publicly before, and some of the composers have been known only to their friends.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In recent months persons have been heard to speak of the "elimination" of the labor of children as the result of the NRA code as though thousands had been released from bondage. The exact number is comparatively small.

THE Giants spent two afternoons watching the Senators at the Yankee Stadium. On the second afternoon, which was Friday, Al Schacht looked over a group of Bill Terry's merry men, pointed to Charley Dressen and said ''Ha!" in a very loud tone, his normal vocal pitch.

HAVANA, Sept. 29. -- The action of the Roosevelt administration in withholding recognition of the student regime in Cuba represents a departure from the State Department's policy of recent years, but it has numerous precedents in American history.
WORCESTER, Mass., Sept. 30. -- Holy Cross in the first test of its new Notre Dame offensive overwhelmed St. Michaels College today, 50 -- 0.

RYE, N.Y., Sept. 30. -- Vincent Richards and Francis T. Hunter, top-seeded favorites, won their way to the final round of the singles in the seventh annual national professional tennis championship on the turf courts of the Westchester Country Club today.

Contrary to the policy adopted recently by many other public utility companies, the Southern California Edison Company has decided to maintain the dividend rate on its common stock although the dividend was not fully earned. It is a contribution toward the recovery program in its district, Harry J. Bauer, president of the company, says in a letter to its more than 123,000 stockholders.

VILLANOVA, Pa., Sept. 30. -- Ursinus, with a spectacular forward passing attack in the last period, tied Villanova today, 7 to 7. A 20-yard pass, Calvert to Seiple, who made a one-hand catch, gave the Collegeville Bears their touchdown, while Quarterback Shuman place-kicked for extra point.

HAVANA, Sept. 30. -- Apparently completely recovered from the shock of yesterday's clash between soldiers and Communists, Havana was back to normal tonight and only slight repercussions from the conflict were reported in the interior.

FABULOUS stories still come out of Ireland. Those that are not indigenous may be planted there and developed with suitable incantations. This is the course that A.E. Coppard and Robert Gibbings took and their first Idea -- of all things -- to write "a straightforward book of instructions about a game of cards, a noble game."

New York is not surrendering to other cities its position as the stock trading centre of the country, according to a survey of the volume of business transacted in the last two years on the local Stock Exchange and on the markets in six other cities.
