CHICAGO, Sept. 30. -- The American Legion gathered here today for its fifteenth annual convention to "resell itself to the American people."
BLAIRSTOWN, N.J., Sept. 30. -- In its initial game today, the Blair Academy eleven conquered the Pean State Teachers College freshmen by 12 to 6.

Looking forward to the effective date of the revised retail code with its stop-loss and fair practice provisions, store executives during the week gave increasing attention to the shaping of store promotional policies under the new NRA conditions.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Sept. 30 (AP). -- The International Association of Chiefs of Police will lay before the United States Senate Committee on racketeering at Detroit on Tuesday a program it believes will crush the racketeer.

BERLIN, Sept. 29. -- One of the most distressing features of the arrest of political enemies by Nazi agencies is the mystery, thereafter, as to what happens to the prisoner. A Brown, Shirt detachment calls upon, him and invites him to step around to the nearest barracks.

Whether the monetary policy expected to be announced by the President in a few days involves a turn to the "right" or "left," it will end a guessing contest that has heen trying to Wall Street nerves. Belief that the announcement will carry assurance against currency inflation is based largely upon the fact that the President has been taking counsel lately with experienced financial men of conservative leanings.

DODGE CITY, Kan., Sept. 28. -- Impatient at the delays in the wheat allotment, Kansas farmers are losing their enthusiasm for the administration's wheat reduction plan. The skepticism which was strong at first has returned as the allotment payment has been postponed and visitors in the Wheat Belt hear predictions that Christmas and the bounty money may arrive at the same time.

The report of an examiner for the Interstate Commerce Commission, recommending the elimination of free lighterage of freight between the railroad terminals in New Jersey and other parts of the port district, has prompted the railroads, transportation experts and civic leaders to study methods of using transportation other than lighterage to hold down the cost to importers and exporters and retaining a single freight rate for the district.

GENEVA, Sept. 30. -- A decisive role in recent disarmament developments was attributed to Norman H. Davis. United States Ambassador at Large, today in the local Journal des Nations, which usually is extremely well informed on this subject. It says:

AT last we have an authentic explanation of the anomaly or the eminent bachelor. Dr. A.S.W. Rosenbach, who collects children's books. It occurs in the prefatory matter of the charming catalogue of his early American juveniles just published by the Southworth Press of Portland, Me. A. Edward Newton contributes a foreword about the doctor and the doctor supplies an introduction about the books.

The attention of the financial community and of the thousands of American holders of foreign dollar bonds is focused on the controversy that has sprung into being in the last few days over whether the interests of the holders of some $3,000,000,000 of foreign dollar bonds now actually in default will be protected by the Corporation of Foreign Security Holders authorized by Congress at its last session or by a single private group.

TRENTON, N.J., Sept. 30. -- When a gasoline tank on a machine operating an amusement device exploded today at the Trenton State Fair, at least twenty-eight persons, including eighteen volunteer firemen, were injured.

THE Whitney Museum of American Art reopens for the season today with a selection of paintings, water-colors, prints and sculpture from the permanent collection. A new schedule of hours has been arranged: from 2 to 6 P.M. on all days except Saturdays, when the museum will be open to visitors from 10 A.M. to 6 P.M., and Mondays, when the museum will be closed.
Contending Teams -- New York Giants, champions of the National League, and Washington Senators, champions of the American League.

ELABORATELY undertaking to prove that the depression caused widespread unemployment and hunger seems a superfluous task. But Mr. Hallgren is fully justified in giving initial chapters to these and other consequences. He rightly views formal public records as undependable.

WESTBURY, L.I., Sept. 30. -- Riding at a hard, driving pace from the first period right on through the final session, with all four play era contributing their full share. Seymour Knox's Aurora team took the twenty-first open championship of the United States Polo Association today.

Record low rates for call money, established in the closing week of August, continued throughout September on both of the stock exchanges here. Time loan rates moved lower to quotations approximating those of January. Funds for both classes of loans were greatly in excess of demand, with the result that call money rates as low as one-half of 1 per cent were quoted in the outside money market in an effort to place funds.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Sept. 30. -- The ABCP nations late today cent a cable message to the League of Nations rejecting a proffered mandate to serve as mediators in the Chaco war. The message said the four countries had expended the utmost effort to harmonize the viewpoints of Paraguay and Bolivia, and it expressed the view it was useless to proceed further.

Six boards or bureaus, each headed by a chairman assisted by a paid executive, are contemplated by the reorganized local NRA organization which will continue to function under the leadership of Grover A. Whalen, NRA Administrator for the City of New York, it was learned yesterday.

Daylight Saving. If the daylight saving period were to be extended, it should commence a month earlier in the Spring, but not continue any later in the Autumn than at present. The sun rises at the same time in the last week of March as it does in the last week of September -- a few minutes before 6, local time, in either case.

The exceedingly high rate of production at which shoe plants have been operating for the last six months makes it appear likely that the final quarter of the year will witness a sharp recession in output, according to opinions expressed here yesterday.

HIGH schools throughout the country have accepted the suggestion of the Committee on Education by Radio, Washington, D.C., to debate the merits of the American versus the British broadcasting system. The University Extension Association Committee framed the question: "Resolved: The United States should adopt the essential features of the British broadcasting system."

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 30 (AP). -- The American Olympic Association, with headquarters in New York City, has injected itself into a suit brought by the Tenth Olympiad Committee, demanding that it receive the surplus money of the 1932 international games, amounting to more than $1,000,000.

LONDON. INASMUCH as the French Government has conferred the Cross of the Legion of Honor on Camille Robert, who wrote "La Madelon," the marching song which the French Army made world-famous during the war, a proposal has arisen here to launch a national testimonial to Jack Judge, who wrote "Tipperary," the die-hard of all the war songs.

AMONG other things, the Victor release for October contains two comparatively early re-pressings from foreign recordings which have been available as importations for some time. On four disks, in Album No. 186, is Debussy's unique quartet for strings (G minor, Op. 10) by the Pro Artes, and on three sides of Nos. 11559/60, Piero Coppola leads the orchestra of the Paris Conservatory in d'lndy's "Istar Variations."

The Rev. Dr. Adam W. Burnet, pastor of the Westborne Presbyterian Church, Glasgow, Scotland, has declined an invitation to the pastorate of the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church, at Fifty-fifth Street, it was learned last evening. The pastorate became vacant with the death of the Rev. Dr. Henry Howard last July.
All the domestic markets continued yesterday to weigh uncertainly and with some nervousness the possibility of an early definition by the administration of its monetary policy.

IN Princeton tomorrow a cherished dream, shared by savants from Plato to Sir Francis Bacon, comes true. The promised land of scholars where, freed from want and worry, they may live in the comradely pursuit of pure research, is to come into actual existence, endowed by millions made in a department store.
LONDON, Sept. 30. -- The soundest financial position in many years is revealed by Great Britain's half-yearly revenue returns, a statement on "which was issued by the Treasury tonight.

The five weeks' strike of 5,000 toy and doll workers, involving a loss to the industry estimated at $1,500,000, was settled yesterday after a sixteen-hour conference of representatives of workers and employes with Henry F. Wolff, chairman of the local NRA Mediation Committee.

BOSTON, Sept. 28. -- The most grotesque farce ever put on in this city in connection with an election of Mayor came to an end Tuesday. The most curious and perplexing campaign for the Mayoralty began yesterday. On Tuesday Boston had twenty aspirants for the premier post in City Hall.

To the Editor of The New York Times: There is much significance in our choice of what we do in our leisure hours. The selection of our recreation shows the trend of our thoughts; it indicates our attitude toward life; reveals our character and is an expression of our personality.

FROM the Century of Progress at Chicago to the Pennsylvania Station, pausing in a vast exhibition room belonging to that caravansary, the treasure recently excavated from a medieval tomb at Monte Alban, in the southwest section of Mexico, is attracting many visitors, some of whom surely must question the inclusiveness of our progress.

MINEOLA, L.I., Sept. 30. -- Assistant District Attorney Albert M. Demeo and Lieutenant Jesse May-forth flew to Albany today and obtained from Lieut. Gov. Bray papers for the extradition of Alphonse Brengard, former State trooper, from Trenton, N.J., prison to Mineola for questioning in the murder of Patrolman John Kennedy.

THAT the world is moving so fast it is now a question whether any of us can much longer remain on board, or whether we may not at any time all be blown off into interstellar space, is too obvious for discussion. Discussion there is, however, and if the presses work rapidly enough it is possible for a writer to get a book on the stands before the contents shall be outmoded.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., Sept. 30. -- Three stake classes, the Good Hands Cup competition and the William Heyser Buchsbaum Memorial Challenge Cup event for New Jersey hunters, were the outstanding features on the second and final day's program of the eighth annual Montclair Horse Show, held today in the ring of the Montclair Riding Club.
Trading on the New York Stock Exchange last month continued on a moderately active scale. The heaviest day's business was 3,652,544 shares on Sept. 21, and the smallest, 1,072,320 on Sept. 7.

WESTBURY, L.I., Sept. 30. -- In accord with a custom of many years, Mr. and Mrs. F. Ambrose Clark were hosts today at a large luncheon on the lawn of their place at Westbury after the running of the famous Meadow Brook Hunt Cup over a course on the fields of their estate and the running also of the Wheatley Hills Cup, a steeple-chase over a three-mile course.

More than one year will be required to complete the sale of the $1,000,000 stamp collection left by the late Arthur Hind, it was said yesterday by Charles J. Phillips of this city, who, with William C. Kennett, Mr. Hind's stamp adviser for many years, has charge of its dispersal under instructions from the First Citizens Bank and Trust Company of Utica, executor of the Hind estate.

PATERSON, N.J., Sept. 30. -- In the presence of a large crowd, the award of best in show at the combined exhibition of the Englewood Kennel Club and the Paterson Kennel Club was given today to the noted Airedale terrier Ch. Walnut Challenger, owned by Fred H. Hoe of New Brunswick, N.J. Walnut Challenger was shown in the ring by Leonard Brumby.

AMHERST, Mass., Sept. 30. -- The Amherst football team opened its season today on Pratt Field with an impressive 38-7 victory over Hobart. The Jeffs scored in every period, while Hobart's lone tally came just before the game ended.

ISTANBUL, Sept. 29. -- The visit of Premier Tsaldaris and other members of the Greek Cabinet to Turkey, which resulted in the signature of the Greco-Turkish peace pact, was the occasion of extraordinary scenes of enthusiasm both here and in Angora.

YUMA, Ariz., Sept. 30 (AP). -- Willard Doughty, former New York taxi driver and electrician, was convicted today by a Superior Court jury of second degree murder for the slaying of Ralph Hart, prospector. The jury deliberated twenty-three hours.
LONDON. WHILE the international economic system as a whole experiences the uncertainty brought about by America's financial policy, about 500 men in London are perhaps most intimately affected by it.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Sept. 30. -- The Naval Academy opened its football season today by defeating William and Mary, 12 to 0. This was especially pleasing to Navy followers, as the same opponent opened last season by winning, 6 to 0.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 30. -- a joint expedition of the University of Pennsylvania Museum and the Boston Museum of Fine Arts will start in January to excavate the ancient city of Ray, six miles southeast of Teheran, Persia.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 30 (AP). -- Dizzy Dean was knocked out of the box today as the Chicago Cubs defeated the St. Louis Cardinals, 12 to 2, to cinch third place in the National League race. He fanned five, however, to run his strike-out total for the season to 202.

HONOLULU, Sept. 30. -- Secretary of the Navy Swanson said today that he still stood by his policy of a navy built up to the treaty limit for the United States, and he indicated his conviction that America's building program was no concern of any other world power.

DUBLIN, ALMOST any road that takes you out of Dublin takes you into the thick of the economic war. Its pressure begins just outside the semicircle of mountains which encloses Dublin and the bay, and in a patchy fashion it extends to the North.

Freddy Fitzsimmons knuckled down to his final bit of homework at Ebbets Field yesterday in preparation for the arduous examination the Senators will give him this week and passed his preliminary test with honors.

FOR thirty years, the world has been astonished by a miracle. A girl, totally blind, totally deaf and totally dumb has learned to read and write several languages, to converse fluently by touch of the hand, and even to speak from the platform.

MEMPHIS, Tenn., Sept. 28. -- Visions of a floodless valley from Cairo to the head of the passes, a vision only partly fulfilled by the Flood Control Act of 1928, are taking shape for Mississippians and Arkansans in the backwater areas. Two tremendous projects are in the making which, if carried to a conpletion, will virtually eliminate the century-old complaint of control of the tributaries of the big river.

IF it shall seem to many stanch admirers of Edwin Arlington Robinson that in "Talifer" this distinguished poet has laid aside temporarily his regal dress to walk with more democratic freedom among the people, only the judgment of time can say if he has done well or ill.

OKLAHOMA CITY, Sept. 30. -- Seven defendants in the Charles F. Urschel kidnapping conspiracy case were convicted by a Federal Court jury here today and held for senatence next Saturday to terms which may range up to life imprisonment.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 30. -- Acting to prevent profiteering by some industries, operating under codes, General Johnson has ordered Deputy Administrator Whiteside to hold hearings to ascertain the facts.

When SAMUEL BUTLER wrote in "Erewhon" of a country in which Invention was a criminal offense and the destruction of labor-saving devices a function of the police he was looked upon as a sour philosopher with a warped view of a scientific age. Now he is quoted almost with approval.

LABORING against the severest competition which the have yet had to face, the American dancers are planning a vigorous and active season. The invasion of spectacular European ballet companies with the backing of substantial business organizations to look after their interests is a matter that cannot be lightly laughed off.

THE transcontinental speed record established last week by Colonel Roscoe Turner is looked upon in the commercial aviation world as one more indication of the high speed trend in air transport. It is peculiarly an American record. While the fastest speeds in the world have been attained over short courses by British and Italian sea-planes, the lessons derived there-from have been applied solely to military aviation.
Twenty miles an hour under sail, which is by far the greatest speed ever attained with canvas and a hull drawn through the water, has been made by a catamaran designed by the veteran Nat Herreshoff.
COPENHAGEN. -- One of the chief features of the picturesque old capital of Denmark, apart from its beautiful lakes, parks and gardens, is its bicycles.

To the Editor of The New York Times: A few days ago S.L.G. Knox, writing to THE TIMES, attempted to defend Henry Ford's attitude toward the NRA'code. He referred to Section 7A, which recognizes labor's right to select their own union leaders and bargain collectively, as "a stumbling block in practically every case."

THESE are revolutionary days when democracy is on trial, and amid the speculation there has been much discussion of Cabinets -- what purpose they serve and how they may be made more effective. President Butler of Columbia University has revived the proposal that Ministers who sit in the Cabinet shall also have seats in Congress and make speeches and answer questions, as is the custom in the British and most other Parliaments.

CHICAGO, Sept. 30. -- With $25,000 reward offered by her husband for her return and four men held by the Federal authorities on his suspicion that they might know something about her "kidnapping," Mrs. George M. Cox, wife of a Chicago and New Orleans ship owner, telephoned the police today that she was safe and contemplating divorce.

THE somewhat improved level of retail trade was fairly well maintained in the week, and sales averaged up about even with a year ago. The best business was done, according to reports, on home wares and dress accessories. Apparel lines continued to feel the effect of unfavorable weather.

LONDON, Sept. 15. A DRAMATIST is to be judged by his artistic purpose and by his fulfillment of it, not by his failure to achieve some different purpose that a critic's inclination would impose upon him.
Mrs. Payne Whitney's First Minstrel, a home-bred son of the English sire Royal Minstrel, was a decisive winner of the Junior Champion Stakes, feature yesterday of the closing-day program at Aqueduct.

Today will mark the resumption of the Winter program in the churches of the city. During the week the last of the pastors returned from their Summer vacations and will appear in their pulpits this morning. The second service, in most churches held at 8 P.M., but in a few in the heart of the city at 4 P.M., will be resumed.

The declaration of President Roosevelt that he was not interfering or committed to any candidate in the Mayoralty campaign must be taken at its face value. Fiorello H. LaGuardia, Fusion nominee for Mayor, told Republican women at their regional conference at the Hotel New Yorker yesterday afternoon.

CHICAGO, Sept. 30. -- Iowa's Hawkeyes, beaten underdogs of Big Ten football warfare for four long years, snapped the championship hopes of a highly touted Northwestern team with an astounding 7-to-0 Victory today.

Public interest in the annual convention of the American Legion, to be held this week at Chicago, will be centred chiefly on any declaration it may make with respect to veterans' relief. In the year that has passed since the Legion last assembled, the Federal pension system has been thoroughly reorganized on the initiative of President ROOSEVELT.

HYDE PARK, N.Y., Sept. 30. -- President Roosevelt "hopes" to visit Chicago during the American Legion Convention next week, but it was uncertain late tonight whether such a trip would be possible, Stephen T. Early, assistant White House secretary, announced.

PARIS. IT IS predicted that a greater variety than usual will prevail in the afternoon stylescape this Winter. You can wear anything from a simple downy wool frock and duvetyne coat to a luscious fur-draped velvet creation and still fit smartly into the fashion picture.

ON a broad front President Roosevelt has begun a drive for credit expansion -- an enrichment of the "life blood of industry" -- in order to consolidate such gains as have been won in the NRA campaign and to add the impetus needed to bring the nation back to economic health.
DUBLIN, Sept. 29. -- President de Valera has won out in his first encounter with the Irish Republican army since his government assumed office.

MOSCOW. -- The editor of the leading Moscow paper today, with more than 3,000,000 circulation, was raising funds twenty years ago for the Communist party in Russia. One of his fellow-campaigners and a fellow-student was Stalin, now head of the Communist party, the benevolent despot of Russia.

MOSCOW, Sept. 30. -- Three men in an aluminum sphere hooked to a balloon ascended 11.8 miles today, the greatest height ever reached by man. They enjoyed themselves so much that when they landed the first thing they said was they would do it again as soon as they could.

WHILE there have been many references in literature to the unhappy and unwholesome environment for childhood afforded by Puritan New England and some personal accounts of what it meant to children, this exhaustive inquiry into the subject is doubtless the first attempt to deal with the subject comprehensively and by scholarly methods of investigation and treatment.

THE never-ending fight between men who look at land with an eye to the public delight, and their elder brothers who see it merely as a means of private profit has moved to Taurus now. Private dynamite is blowing the face off the mountain to sell it for broken rock, as private dynamite once started to wreck the Palisades.

BERLIN, Sept. 30. -- Tomorrow, which in America will be just another Sunday, is the official Thanksgiving Day in Germany, but it is a Thanksgiving Day of another kind. It is not to be a feast day, but a fast day inaugurating a series of monthly self-denial Sabbaths for the benefit of the government fund for the unemployed and destitute.
CHICAGO, Sept. 30 (AP). -- Three White Sox hurling veterans combined today to hold the Browns to four hits, and Chicago took a 4-to-1 victory.

PALO ALTO, Calif., Sept. 30. -- Stanford's Indians opened their Pacific Coast Conference campaign today with a 3-0 victory over the University of California at Los Angeles, gained by the margin of one field goal.

Although, industry, for the present, is in for a "merger holiday," grim economic forces will dictate a revival of intelligently directed consolidations shortly, Arthur Lazarus, special instructor on mergers and consolidations at the College of the City of New York and a financial and accounting authority, said here yesterday.
Slang and Trade The late SIME SILVERMAN is believed to have made a notable success of Variety because he edited that trade journal of the vaudeville stage and the theatre in the slang of Broadway.

PARIS, Sept. 20. -- The following story of his experiences during eight weeks in a Nazi concentration, camp was written by a German Jewish boy of 18, who was Tests and taken there last June forty-two other boys.

ST. JOHN, N.B., Sept. 30 (Canadian Press). -- The Union Jack and the Stars and Stripes went floating side by side through city streets today as members of the Ancient and Honorable Artillery Company of Massachusetts, 300 strong, arrived here on the steamship St. John to celebrate the 296th annual field day.

BOSTON, Sept. 30. -- Working through the long Winter night at the bottom of the world will be an old story to the fifty men of Admiral Richard E. Byrd's Antarctic expedition crew now working night and day to load his second ship, the Jacob Ruppert, in time to permit her sailing from Boston by Tuesday or Wednesday at the latest.
MANHASSET, L.I., Sept. 30. -- James Marion Thornton Jr., 13-year-old chemical experimenter, was burned to death here yesterday in the garage in the rear of his parents' home at 21 Andrew Street.

PARIS. THE Salon des Echanges was taken seriously in Paris. Serious showrooms were chosen at the Parci des Expositions, and the press, in order to prove its good sense of values, became almost solemn. Too solemn in fact.

At a stalemate for nearly two hours yesterday, the share market showed its only animation in the few minutes just before the closing gong was sounded. The turnabout was accompanied by swift advances in many stocks which are understood to have harbored large short interests.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30. -- Mrs. Harold L. Ickea held today her first press conference since her husband assumed office as Secretary of the Interior, and disposed of rumors in regard to her plans by announcing that she bad no intention of resigning from the Illinois Legislature, in which she is now serving her third consecutive term. Whether she will be a candidate to succeed herself is "on the lap of the gods," she said.

Efforts of manufacturers to cut discounts in half through, clauses in the various producers' codes were scored here yesterday by Samuel W. Reyburn, president of the Associated Dry Goods Corporation, who said that if the manufacturers are successful in their aims they will add $140,000,000 a year to their prices.

BEAR MOUNTAIN, N.Y., Sept. 30. -- Police of the Palisade Interstate Park System and United States soldiers from West Point searched the underbrush along the main highway between Highland Falls and West Point today in a fruitless hunt for a burlap sack filled with bones, which two women mushroom-pickers reported they had seen recently.

A general lull In market activity was noted this week, particularly in coats and suits, a development attributed largely to the prevailing warm weather, according to the market report prepared especially for THE TIMES by McGreevey, Werring Howell, Inc.

TOMORROW is Marconi Day at the Century of Progress Exposition in Chicago. The inventor of wireless will be there. The radio exhibits will enable him to look back across his tracks in the sands of science and to see how hundreds of other experimenters followed in his footsteps since the mauve decade.

Paul Joseph Goebbels, Propaganda Minister of Nazi Germany, carried to Geneva last week a 5,000-word address for delivery before the Assembly of the League of Nations. His party expected him to turn world opinion in its favor when he delivered it. Herr Goebbels, after taking the temperature of the Assembly and finding, it both too hot and too cold, decided not to address that body. The speech was made before the newspaper correspondents.

One man was fatally burned and two others were seriously scalded early yesterday when a steam pipe in the boiler room of the municipal ferryboat Brooklyn exploded shortly after she had landed 1,000 commuters and forty vehicles from Staten Island.

Although the Stock Exchange and other branches of the securities business have decided against moving to New Jersey, the trend of financial institutions across the Hudson River has continued. Many of the leading trusts now have their headquarters in Newark or Jersey City.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 29. THERE are at the moment of writing exactly two legitimate offerings to be seen on the local stages which, according to pony express dispatches lately received, is not so very far behind the Broadway of recent weeks.

CHICAGO, Sept. 30. -- Prices of wheat fluctuated rapidly within a range of 2 1/4 to 2 3/4 cents a bushel today on the Board of Trade. The East liquidated long grain early, but after a break of 1 1/2 to 1 7/8 cents the market turned upward as rapidly as it had declined, the action of stocks being a factor.

ADMITTING that under the supervision of its producer, Sergei M. Eisenstein, "Thunder Over Mexico" might have emerged as a far more impressive production than the edition now on exhibition at the Rialto, there is no denying that those responsible for the film as it stands were confronted with a stupendous task.

The Not So Gay White Way. ROLLING through the night in a symphoniously murmuring motor car. A crescent moon in a jeweled setting of stars above and an opening path of smooth highway parting the darkness ahead.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30. -- Judge Martin H. Manton withdrew today from further participation in the Interborough Rapid Transit receivership case and Chief Justice Hughes designated Circuit Judge Julian W. Mack to act in his stead.

BETHLEHEM, Pa., Sept. 30. -- Lehigh's campaign was auspiciously launched in Taylor Stadium today when a veteran Drexel eleven, which last season stalemated with the Bethlehem Engineers, was moved down under a 19-to-O score.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Pressure of business prevented me from answering Edmund Platt's original letter, which seemed at the time to be a curious mixture of truth and fallacy. Now that Mr. Platt has taken to patting himself on the back, it is high time that some one challenged his views.

To the Editor of The New York Times: "Oldtimer" wishes to acknowledge with sincerity and respect the demurrer of "Nineteen." Because "Nineteen" speaks authoritatively for the youth of today and "Oldtimer" not only has no quarrel with the youth of today but has genuine respect for its candor and for its intelligence.
HANOVER, N.H., Sept. 30. -- Dartmouth opened its football season with a 41-0 defeat of Norwich, but credit went to the second team today for the punch.

BANGOR, Me., Sept. 30. -- Intercepting a forward pass right on his own goal line, Johnny Mantenuto, substitute left halfback, tucked the ball away and raced a full 100 yards for a touchdown to give Rhode Island State a 6-to-0 victory over University of Maine in the opening game for both teams today.

With two of its components showing gains, the decline in the weekly business index of THE NEW YORK TIMES was less sharp for the week ended Sept. 23. The number moved down to 77.7 from 78.4 in the preceding week and compared with 67.9 for the week ended Sept. 24, 1932.

Prospects for early stabilization of the dollar approximately its present foreign exchange value, which is 65 per cent of its former value, discussed last week in dispatches from Washington, have led to conjecture in Wall Street, with a divergence of views, as to what the immediate effect might be upon the speculative markets.
BUFFALO, Sept. 28. -- The Mayoralty campaign in Buffalo presents aspects of both national and personal politics.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30. -- Orders from railroads for more than 1,000,000 tons of steel rails, tie-plantes, splice-bars, c., are available to steel companies if the price is sufficiently attractive, R.V. Fletcher, general counsel for the Association of Railway Executives, reported today to Joseph B. Eastman, Federal Coordinator of Transportation.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 30. -- The Reconstruction Finance Corporation's circular, setting forth its policy regarding loans for financing NRA industries as issued today, reads as follows:

Prices on the Cotton Exchange made new law records for the week at one time yesterday, but improvement in stocks and grains brought a sharp recovery in the final trading and left the list 4 to 7 points higher than on Friday.

THIS latest addition to the excellent Appleton series of popular but authoritatively written biographies of the great men and women of history has an alluring subject and its author is in full sympathy with the call that still sounds across the centuries from the life of King Richard I to romantics of all time.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Your correspondent, William R. Daingerfield, has fully explained Esperanto and its aims. Very worthy and noble motives were the cause of its appearance. We, in Rio de Janeiro, named a street after Professor Zamenhoff -- a simple homage to its founder.

DENVER, Col., Sept. 28. -- A welldefined movement to place a limit on government spending, with the avowed purpose of reducing taxes, is getting under way in Colorado, Wyoming and New Mexico. Evidences crop out in unexpected places.
Joe Cronin's lively band of Senators made their farewell appearance at the Yankee Stadium yesterday an occasion befitting true champions.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 30. -- Scoring in the second heat and finishing as runner-up the final time out, George C. Reis's glistening Gold Cup speed boat, El Lagarto, today won the President's Cup race.

HAVERFORD, Pa. A HUNDRED years ago twenty-one young Quakers assembled in classrooms on a rolling tract of farm land ten miles west of Philadelphia for an introduction to the classics and higher mathematics.

LEIPZIG, Sept. 30. -- When the Nazi Judiciary Commissar for the Reich, Herr Franck, opened the Lawyers' Congress today in the biggest exhibition hall of the Leipzig fair grounds, there was barely standing room in the huge edifice, which can hold more than 20,000 persons.

More than $1,500,000 worth of business was done by manufacturers at the Radio-Electrical Exposition in Madison Square Garden during the ten-day period of the show, according to an estimate made late yesterday by the Garden management following a canvass of the exhibitors.

With, an impressive display of power against a rival which, was far from the easy mark so many had supposed, Fordham signalized its first start under the coaching regime of Sleepy Jim Crowley by slashing its way to a 52-0 victory over Albright at Fordham Field yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30. -- Eighty-four newly commissioned Second Lieutenants who were graduated from West Point in June will start on their quest for air corps commissions at Randolph Field, Texas, on Oct. 12. They have been commissioned in other branches of the service for the present, as existing regulations provide that only graduates of the Air Corps primary and advanced schools can be commissioned in the corps.
Led by the hard-driving Jack Fink, a picked team of Long Island Civilians rode roughshod over the Second Corps Area quartet to win a special high-goal polo match, 12 to 4, yesterday.

Speedily and silently, the Attorney General's Office, in cooperation with District Attorney L. Barron Hill of Suffolk County is moving against New York City racketeers who allegedly have been levying a $2,000,000 annual tribute on the Long Island duck industry.

IN a speech before the General Commission of the Disarmament Conference at Geneva last Spring, the American delegate pointed out that the world had reached a stage at which it must choose between falling back into the old habits of armed conflicts and proceeding energetically to develop machinery for the maintenance of peace.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Sept. 30. -- Harvard's collection of animals, reptiles, fish and insects varies from African bullfrogs and alligators to gila monsters and South American raccoons, it was shown here when the university authorities took stock of the specimens on hand for research purposes.

Although no official announcement of the payment was made, officers of the Associated Gas and Electric Company said yesterday that they planned to pay the interest due tomorrow on the company's 5 per cent gold debenture bonds.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 30. -- A guard armed with a machine gun was stationed at the entrance to each cell block in the Eastern Penitentiary by Warden Smith today, as the result of last night's rioting, the second mutiny of the convicts within a week.

Present protests in Europe against existing church organizations do not constitute a serious "anti-religious" movement, the Rev. Raymond C. Knox, chaplain of Columbia University, declared yesterday. Chaplain Knox has just returned from a fifteen-month study tour on the Continent, where he was commissioned by the university to observe religious movements abroad in order to assist in formulating plans for religious work at Columbia.

WHEN Charles Lutwidge Dodgson, teacher of mathematics at Oxford University, first related "Alice's Adventures in Wonderland" to the three daughters of his associate, Dr. Liddell, he little realized that three-quarters of a century later his simple tales would become the year's major production problem for Paramount studios.

In one of his essays BACON spoke of what he called" the solecism of power." It consisted, he said, of "thinking to "command the end yet not to endure "the mean." He was writing of sovereigns and governments. But his remark is just as true of a modern democratic nation and of rulers elected by the people.

PAULINE FREDERICK, who has been touring in "Her Majesty, the Widow" since May, will arrive sooner or later in New York. That would be some time after the first of the year. Miss Frederick started out from the West Coast, arrived in Chicago June 26 and purposes to remain there until Oct. 14.

CHICAGO, Sept. 30. -- An attack on the political patronage system as the malady threatening the destruction of public ownership and operation of utilities was made tonight by Arthur E. Morgan, chairman of the board of directors of the Tennessee Valley Authority.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 30. -- Fifteen Pennsylvania banks, which had operated on a restricted basis, were finally closed for immediate liquidation today by Dr. William D. Gordon, State Secretary of Banking.

Marshaling a broad array of benefits which have accrued and are expected to accrue to industry from the various codes of fair competition, trade association officials and business executives yesterday voiced their approval of the NRA program.

MOUNT KISCO, N.Y., Sept. 30. -- The third annual horse show of the Lawrence Farms Hunt Club was held today under ideal weather conditions and with the largest entry list in the history of the event. From morning till evening followers of the sport gathered in the picturesque surroundings to witness sixteen events.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30. -- Because of his concern over numerous strikes, William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, issued a statement today counseling "conservation of effort" and urging all workers who had grievances to make use of mediation before striking.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 30. -- Surplus army beef, as well as cured pork from surplus swine purchased by the Agricultural Adjustment Administration, is to be devoted to the relief needs of the unemployed.

NO one will begrudge the Group Theatre the triumph of "Men in White." Ever since its initial venture, two years ago, with Paul Green's "The House of Connelly," the Group Theatre has stuck to its program in the face of disaster and privation.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30. -- The strongest indication that a definite monetary policy is soon to be announced by the government developed here this week out of a realization within President Roosevelt's "brain trust" that such a step must be taken before the program for economic rehabilitation can go much further. Official Washington is apparently unanimous in the opinion that the currency must be stabilized before business confidence will return to stay.

Scoring in the first four minutes of play, the Theodore Roosevelt High School eleven of the Bronx defeated St. Francis Prep of Brooklyn, 7-0, yesterday at the Brooklyn Sports Stadium. A crowd of 2,500 saw the rival teams open their gridiron campaigns.

Joseph V. McKee's campaign for the Mayoralty as an independent candidate will start tomorrow with a conference at his headquarters in the Biltmore Hotel. A campaign manager will be announced and plans for nominating a full ticket for places on the Board of Estimate will be considered.

A new flaring up of labor difficulties last week in many parts of the country unsettled the processes of economic recovery again. Counteracting this, however, was the steadying effect of reports that the administration was officially doing its best to check the spread of propaganda for inflation of the currency.

FOOTLIGHT PARADE," the lineal descendant of "42d Street" and "Gold Diggers of 1933," is scheduled to make its modest bow to Broadway from the screen of the Strand Theatre on Thursday. It is a twelve-reel production and will require exactly two hours for its unfolding.

According to reports from sporting goods stores and manufacturers of equipment which hunters use in the field, it is very likely that this Autumn will see a greater interest in hunting than has been manifested in the last four years. Stores in this city which handle shotguns, rifles, boots, hunting suits and camping outfits declare there never has been such a demand since the depression set in.

IN the standard edition of Emerson's works are twelve volumes and there are ten more of his "Journals." The ordinary reader, for whom time la precious, has long needed some sort of guide which would help him to select from so large a choice the things that would best reveal to him the spirit of Emerson, "the heart" of his works.

Except for the lack of uniformity, the excess profits tax, one of the emergency measures enacted in the National Industrial Recovery Act, could be said to form the third side of a triangle of Federal taxation with especial reference to corporations; the income tax return, supplying the measure of tax, and the capital stock tax declaration, furnishing the measure of credit, complete the triangular system.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., Sept. 30. -- The Westchester open golf championship title went to Mike Turnesa of Fairview today when he defeated Sal Di Buono, the home pro, in the eighteen-hole play-off at the Bonnie Briar Country Club.

NOWHERE does the extravagant elegance that seems to be the keynote of the Winter's manifestation of good dressing show itself as strikingly as in furs. One should either be up to one's ears in furs or dispense with them altogether.
VIENNA, Sept. 29. -- With the formation of the second Dollfuss Cabinet one phase of Austrian politics ended and another began.

WE have come to think, through the blithe dichotomy of some old Greek, of tragedy and comedy as two absolute moods. The reviewers of Erskine Caldwell's "Tobacco Road" called it a novel of terse tragic power; and these same gentry bailed its very similar successor, "God's Little Acre," as the work of a leading American humorist.
THE vast army of the Civilian Conservation Corps is carrying out a tremendous program looking toward the rebuilding and conserving of the nation's 600,000,000 acres of timbered lands.

THE selection of Eugene L. Vidal as the head of the aeronautics branch and the confirmation of his appointment with the title, Director of Aeronautics, has straightened out a situation which had been a source of concern to the aeronautical industry.

When Professor Augusts Piccard, Swiss scientist, and Charles Kipfer landed on the Gurgl glacier in the Austrian Tyrol on the night of May 27, 1931, the first successful flight into the stratosphere had been accomplished. From Professor Piccard's experiences much was learned of the difficulties to be expected and guarded against in subsequent flights.
Tax exempt property carrying a total assessed valuation of $268,827,000 was studied yesterday by the city administration with a view to placing most of it on the 1934 tax rolls.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 30. -- After staving off two desperate assaults on their own goal line by a sturdy Washington and Jefferson team, the Pittsburgh Panthers scored a 9-to-0 victory through a field goal and touchdown in the last period today.

NEW LONDON, Conn., Sept. 30. -- The convocation program for 1933-34 at Connecticut College includes such outstanding names as Countess Alexandra Tolstoy, youngest daughter of the famous Russian writer; Sir Herbert Ames, former financial director of the secretariat of the League of Nations, and Governor John G Winant of New Hampshire.

HELEN WADDELL has written the 800-year-old story of Abelard and Heloise as a modern psychological novel. In doing so she has altered, it would seem, certain of the facts. Neither the Encyclopaedia article nor Moore's very famous novel dwell on the change in the Canon Fulbert, Heloise's uncle, after his discovery of Abelard's sin.

THE ethereal curtain is rising on what promises to be an active entertainment season on the air. And this is Radio Progress Week with the broadcasters getting off to a good start with an address by President Roosevelt, festivities honoring Gugllelmo Marconi on a visit to the United States, the world series, football games and numerous new programs in which noted artists will enliven the quality or the microphone's presentations throughout the Autumn and Winter.

The following excerpts from newspaper editorials on the currency inflation gives a picture of the trend of newspaper opinion on the question: CLEVELAND PLAIN DEALER. The President knows, as every student of finance and currency knows, that the path of money inflation is a primrose path which leads to perils which wise men are taught by experience to avoid.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Sept. 30. -- Seventy-six freshmen and one sophomore accepted bids to national fraternities and local clubs at Rutgers University at the close of the restricted rushing period which ended Monday, it was announced today by Edward H. Heyd, fraternity and rush officer.

To the Editor of The New York Times: To the interesting contribution read by Dr. Carleton Sprague Smith recently at Ticonderoga, which concerned the origin of "Yankee Doodle," traced to a British officer encamped in Albany in 1758, may I submit an addition for what it may be worth?

Differences of opinion in the copper industry over the provisions in the proposed NRA code are understood to be far from settlement and the opinion in some quarters is that the officials of the NRA may have to write the code. Because of divergent views in the oil industry the officials of the NRA drafted a code for it.
HAVRE DE GRACE, Md., Sept. 30. -- Equipoise, C.V. Whitney's gallant campaigner, lost what probably was his last race today, but it took a new course record to turn the trick.

HAVANA, Sept. 30. -- Militarization of the Havana Police was begun by the government today as part of the policy suddenly adopted yesterday toward the maintenance of order by force of arms and toward the establishment of effective control throughout the republic.

THE landau bearing Truth's reporter rolled up to the stage door of the Winter Garden -- not the old Winter Garden, but the old, OLD Winter Garden -- one Winter's evening last week and deposited the aforementioned baggage, hot and dusty, on the paving stones.

WINSTON CHURCHILL, who has written an infinitude of pages justifying his own works to man, has now written a book to make "John Churchill intelligible to the present generation." John Churchill was the first, and still is the most durably famous, Duke of Marlborough.
PARIS, Sept. 21. -- The American tourist who lit his cigarette with a five-franc note and asked jocularly, "Well, how much does that amount to in real money?" is no longer to be found in Paris.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Our experience teaches us that credit extended to each other by going concerns has been of much more assistance during these serious times than accommodations made by banks. As a matter of fact, many institutions are carrying on with this method of procedure without the aid of the natural credit privileges ordinarily extended to them by banks.

INNSBRUCK, Tyrol. MUCH that is happening in Europe in these days is only a repetition of an old, old story. It is so here in Tyrol, once more the key in a struggle between Germany and Austria, with Italy and France in the background, keen observers of the shifting advantage, ready to snatch such crumbs at the spoils of conflict as the chief contestants may let slip.

THE appearance in translation of a new novel by the Norwegian winner of the Nobel Prize for Literature in 1928 is an event to flutter anticipation. Nor will anticipation be disappointed by "Ida Elizabeth," which was brought out in Oslo last year under the same title.

A GIRL reporter, Mary Llewellyn, recovering from an operation for appendicitis, takes what she thinks is going to be a rest cure by embarking on a voyage to Rio Janeiro on the S.S. Moderna. Later on, because of what happens on that voyage, Mary rechristens the boat "S.S. Murder."
Samuel Untermyer's letter to Mayor O'Brien, recommending that most of the $268,827,000 of property now tax exempt be placed on the tax rolls as far as the law permits, follows:

Additions to the faculty and several new courses have been listed by Fordham University's College of Arts and Science, Graduate School and Teachers College. Six new professors will lecture in the College of Arts and Science in the Bronx and will direct courses in the Graduate School and Teachers College at 233 Broadway.

BROWNSVILLE, Pa., Sept. 30. -- With upraised hands and deafening shouts, many in an estimated crowd of 25,000 striking miners and sympathizers from all over the Western Pennsylvania bituminous fields declared today their refusal to return to work Monday, despite the announcement that the H.C. Frick Coke Company had signed a labor agreement for its "captive" mines.

Declaring that Albert Einstein had abandoned his stand against war because he was deceived into visualizing a war against Germany as a means of crushing fascism, Henri Barbusse, Communist author, linked fascism and capitalism yesterday as the enemies of proletarian peace.

MADISON, Wis., Sept. 30. -- Former Governor Philip F. La Follette revealed today what he asserted he believed was an attempt to ambush him because of his economic theories expressed in recent speeches in which he attacked "the vested interests."

WITH the top of the Palisades virtually secure against defacement for all time, and with other beauty spots of the Hudson Highlands included in public park areas and thus fortified against private enterprise, those who are zealous for the scenic preservation of the Hudson view with concern the attack on the face of Mount Taurus, where men with dynamite and machines are destroying its natural beauty.

AMERICA will sound the call this week for government and private agencies to unite on a child health-recovery program designed to bring relief, better health and smiling faces to thousands of the small victims of the last few years of depression.

LONDON. LEOYD GEORGE'S first volume of "War Memoirs" bristles with controversial material, and specific points in it will be keenly debated for many days to come. There is no question, however, as to the value of the book, J.B. Firth, in The Daily Telegraph, thinks the story of the war from the British side would be sadly incomplete without it.

KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Sept. 30. -- A group of brilliant back-field stars racing behind almost perfect interference led Tennessee to an easy 27-0 victory over the Virginia Polytechnic Institute eleven today on a sun-scorched gridiron.

PRESIDENT ROOSEVELT, who last week returned to Hyde Park, his estate in Dutchess County, was in truth visiting the home of his ancestors. For there have been Roosevelts in Dutchess for 181 years, and the President's children are the fifth generation of his family to be residents of the county.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 (AP). -- Justice Department experts are studying the legal aspects of prohibition repeal in an effort to decide what new legislation will be needed if the Eighteenth Amendment is removed from the Constitution.

OBSCURELY set in Simla, India, separated by half the world from such 'engrossing preoccupations as the NRA, prohibition repeal and Cuban revolutions, a little-noticed gathering of three nations is now seeking a solution to a tariff dispute that appears humdrum but holds explosive possibilities.

With Joe Cronin and his Senators, champions of the American League, back in town again tonight, New York is beginning to take on a genuine world's series atmosphere which promises to gain steadily in volume within the next forty-eight hours.

BRUNO WALTER will begin his third season with the Philharmonic-Symphony on Thursday evening, when the orchestra opens its ninety-second season. The program is entirely orthodox; its ingredients are Beethoven and Brahms.

AMONG the observers who visited the New York Radio-Electrical Show was a noted radio engineer, who inspected the exhibits unnoticed by the crowds. He is little known to the public. Much of his time is spent in the laboratory.

CHICAGO, Sept. 28. -- Of the estimated 1,225,000 homeless and transient persons roaming from one end of the country to the other, approximately one-half are somewhere in the Mississippi Valley, studies by various welfare groups have revealed.

PERHAPS there is nothing more blighting to faith in human nature than the stories of rulers to whom men have tamely submitted, have even acclaimed with loyalty, veneration and love. This new book by Henry Channon, heretofore known as a novelist, on certain members of the Wittelsbach dynasty of Bavaria offers a case in point.

Coming from behind twice to tie the score and then surging ahead strongly in the final period to tally the winning touchdown, City College opened its 1933 football season at the Lewisohn Stadium last night by conquering Brooklyn College, 18 to 12, before a crowd of 4,000.

PARIS, Sept. 29. -- With a declared deficit of 6,000,000,000 francs on the forthcoming budget in prospect all interest in France just now is centred on how the Ministry is going to get out of its difficult financial situation.

MILAN, Sept. 16, 1933. NEWS of Igor Stravinsky's latest work, an opera, "Persephone," based on a mythological subject, is given by an Italian critic who interviewed the composer late in August at his Summer retreat at Voreppe, near Grenoble.

There was a meeting of accomplished old brewmasters with master brewers in Chicago last week. It was agreed that the alcoholic percentage of beer would be but slightly "stepped up" after repeal. Never high, it used to run from 3.75 to 4.25 by weight. The brewers expect for the most part to stick to 3.2, making and separately marking beer of stronger but still mild alcoholic content.

Attendance at the twenty-second annual convention, of the Investment Bankers Association of America, to be held from Oct. 28 to Nov. 1 at Hot Springs, Va., is expected to exceed greatly that of 1932, possibly by as much as 40 to 50 per cent.

TLAXIACO. PRIMITIVE conditions exist today in the Mixteca. Here people still have Spanish pleces-of-eight in back drawers; and the Indians count in reales, or threes and sixes, and not in pesos and fives and tens, as the law requires. They make change in salt, goatskins or hats.
EXETER, N.H., Sept. 30. -- Phillips Exeter Academy opened its football season today by defeating the University of New Hampshire freshmen, 6-0. The elevens battled without a score for three periods.

Three completed relief maps of Western Europe of a size and accuracy never before attempted, the work of unemployed architects and sculptors selected by the Emergency "Work Bureau, are on public view in the Alexander Hamilton Institute building, 13 Astor Place.

THE news of the approaching arrival of Arnold Schonberg, who is coming to this country this month for the first time, to teach at the Malkin Conservatory of Music in Boston, has brought an instantaneous response from patrons and friends of music.

PARIS, Sept. 28. -- Jewel-colored hats made in the tones of all precious and many semi-precious stones, and matching the wearer's other accessories are new features. A jade hat and scarf ensemble worn with a taupe outfit is a notable combination.

NEW ideas about the anatomy of weather embodied in the so-called "polar front hypothesis," which has been the theme of much discussion among meteorologists for more than a decade, are now finding their way into textbooks and reference books.

LONDON, Sept. 30. -- British party politics will begin to stir from its Summer slumbers next week when the Conservatives hold their annual conference at Birmingham and the Laborites hold theirs at Hastings.

LONDON, Sept. 15, 1933. THE 213th meeting of the three choirs of Hereford, Gloucester and Worcester was held this year in the demure and, in many ways, most charming of the three cathedral cities-Here-ford. Hereford is not wholly immune from the blasts of modernity; but it is not that new purgatory, the motoring centre.

HOLLYWOOD. THE town has gone mad over new faces -- new personalities, the studios call them -- and every lot is participating in the scramble to discover, among the hundreds being imported, persons with the qualities that will bring cinema customers in droves to the box office.

FAR HILLS, N.J., Sept. 30. -- St. Monan, a 9-year-old bay mare, owned by the Ellistan Farm of Far Hills, today captured the grand champion hunter honors as the Far Hills Horse Show came to a thrilling climax.

The National Conference of Catholic Charities will open its nineteenth annual meeting formally with a solemn pontifical mass at St. Patrick's Cathedral this morning. More than forty Archbishops and Bishops will be in attendance, and among the worshipers will be thousands of clerical and lay leaders in welfare work from all parts of the country.

RICHMOND, Va., Sept. 28. -- The University of Virginia has been without a president for nearly two and a half years, and the faculty and alumni of the institution, together with the press of the State, are becoming aroused over the situation.

ANEW order for America's most benighted industry begins tomorrow when the agreement between the United Mine Workers and the bituminous coal operators goes Into effect under the NRA. A Magna Carta of human rights underground has been written.
BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Sept. 30 (AP). -- Fourteen leaders of public safety forces throughout the nation were named for an emergency committee of police chiefs today to combat crime.

The "utilitarian" view of God by which men "use religion to overcome nervous disorders and keep their minds sane and wholesome" was denounced yesterday by the Rev. Dr. Henry Sloane Coffin, president of Union Theological Seminary, in his sermon at the James Memorial Chapel, Broadway and 120th Street.

A study of what he says were the methods employed by the government to make use of church organizations in the United States during the World War is presented in a volume, "Teachers Present Arms," by the Rev. Dr. Ray H. Abrams, published today by the Round Table Press.

OKLAHOMA CITY, Oct. 1 (AP). -- A warning that Charles F. Urschel "hasn't got long to live" was uttered in the county jail here today by George (Machine Gun) Kelly, officers said, soon after his arrival by plane to face trial for kidnapping the oil operator for $200,000 ransom.

A summons to American Catholics to fight the poverty and distress growing out of today's economic and social crisis, with new devotion and with weapons adequate to unprecedented problems, was sounded last night by some of the foremost clerical and lay leaders of that church.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 1. -- No important changes were observed last week in steel consuming requirements, except a further decrease in activity in the automobile trade. The trade has little expectation of improvement before Oct. 15.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 1. -- In order to maintain a balanced budget despite greatly reduced income the University of Pennsylvania will attempt to limit its operating expenses for 1933-34 to $5,246,000, a sum about $602,000 less than that expended during the preceding year, and $1,331,000 less than in 1931-32.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1. -- Since the enactment of the National Recovery Act the American Federation of Labor has increased its membership by 1,300,000, according to William Green, president of the federation, who reported to the Executive Council today that the total membership was about 4,000,000.

Mouquin, Inc. Offering of a block of 55.000 shares of Mouquin, Inc., common stock of $1 a share par value, will be made today by E. F. Gillespie Co., Inc., at $6.75 a. share. The company was formed in July to acquire the assets and business of the Delaware company of the same name.

CHICAGO, Oct. 1. -- Prices of hogs early last week were $5.15 a hundredweight for the best lightweight animals, while in the previous week $5.45 was the top. The average price here for the week was $4.45, a drop of 15 cents. A year ago it was $3.90.

Human progress depends upon the ability of leaders to make the correct decision when confronted with emergencies such as exist today, the Rev. Dr. Harry Emerson Fosdick, pastor of the Riverside Church, Riverside Drive and 122d Street, said in his sermon there yesterday.

BOSTON, Oct. 1 (AP). -- A convalescing outfielder, Wally Berger, gave the Braves a split of the world's series money today by putting them into fourth place in the league standing with a pinch-hit home run with the bases loaded, which defeated Philadelphia, 4 to 1.

THE situation seems to be a bit muddled, as usual. The man wearing the gray suit and the gray soft hat was William Harold Terry, manager of the Giants. The man wearing the brown suit and the brown soft hat was Joseph Edward Cronin, manager of the Senators.

The Chinese Nationalist party in America opened a five-day convention yesterday afternoon at the New York headquarters of the party at 18 Doyers Street. Between forty and fifty delegates, all supporters of the New China, attended the meeting.

HOLLYWOOD, Oct. 1 (AP). -- Harold Lloyd, film comedian, was on his way to New York today by train, expecting to arrive there Wednesday, in search of a new leading woman and added details for the story of his next picture, "Cat's Paw," written by Clarence Budington Kelland.
WESTBURY, L. I., Oct. 1. -- For the second day in succession the Airedale terrier Ch. Walnut Challenger, owned by Fred H. Hoe of New Brunswick, N. J., today was proclaimed best in show.
NEW ORLEANS, La., Oct. 1. -- Trading in cotton here last week was less active than in the several preceding weeks.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 1. -- Under a slogan "Now Is the Time to Buy!" a campaign to persuade the public to help industry and trade in this direction will be started Oct. 9 by the NRA.

BEAUVAIS, France, Oct. 1. -- International politics with their whole gamut of treaties, pacts, protocols and systems for the improvement of international relations which are the usual subject of discussion when Ministers meet, were laid aside today.

ON BOARD THE ROOSEVELT TRAIN EN ROUTE TO CHICAGO, Oct. 1. -- Instructions from President Roosevelt to Harry L. Hopkins, the Federal Relief Administrator, to set up, immediately, a non-profit corporation to buy supplies to be distributed among the needy were announced this evening after President Roosevelt left Hyde Park.

The designation of Judge Julian W. Mack of the United States Circuit Court of Appeals to replace Senior Judge Martin T. Manton of that court in the Interborough and Manhattan Railway receivership proceedings would be followed, it was indicated, by another effort by the Manhattan Railway Company to oust William Roberts as receiver.

SHANGHAI, Monday, Oct. 2. -- Chinese financial and patriotic circles were stirred by a revelation from Tokyo to the effect that Japan's protest against Dr. V. K. Wellington Koo's conduct at Geneva contains this open threat-that if anti-Japanese propaganda of that sort is not checked Japan probably will not purchase cotton from China.

PARIS, Sept. 30. -- The depreciation in sterling sinca June did not affect trade between France and England very much. Imports from Great Britain into France in June and July totaled in value 357,000,000 francs and French exports to England were 247,000,000 francs, compared with 414,000,000 of imports and 285,000,000 of exports in the same period of 1932.

BERLIN, Oct. 1. -- With, world attention focused on Germany's attitude toward disarmament, the nation's official view was revealed today as placing the country in the position of a creditor, to whom other nations, as debtors, must make offers for disarmament.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 1. -- Grand opera divas, baritones and bassos who hope to become members of the Pittsburgh Metropolitan Grand Opera Company, Inc., recently organized, must first agree that they will not become temperamental. In contracts sent to all artists today by Chevalier Antonio Certo, the general manager, a clause states that every artist must do as he or she is told by the artistic director.
PITTSFIELD, Mass., Oct. 1. -- There was much entertaining in the Berkshires during the weekend and sports claimed their share of attention.

MACON, Ga., Oct. 1. -- "Young" Stribling's ring career came to an end here today when an automobile crushed off his left foot while he was riding a motorcycle. Dr. A. P. Kemp amputated the foot at the Macon Hospital a half hour after the crash.

Before the four-year plan for the restoration of New York City's credit can become effective it must have the formal endorsement of the city, the bankers and the Legislature. The O'Brien administration has already accepted it, and the bankers have evidenced their conditional approval by making available the money for payrolls and other urgent needs.

Price movements on local commodity exchanges last week were irregular. Silver and rubber futures closed the week with gains as a result of a late rally. Most of the others, however, showed losses. Trading was less active than in the preceding week. Cash prices were irregularly lower.

The State Department is planning to begin this week a discussion of reciprocal trade agreements with representatives of Argentina, Brazil and several other South American countries. This will be the first effort to put into practice the theory of bargaining tariffs which Mr. ROOSEVELT championed a year ago in his campaign addresses.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., Oct. 1. -- Mr. and Mrs. Gould Shaw gave a luncheon at the Casino for Mrs. Robert R. Meyer and Miss Kitty Barrett and Wilbur H. Horton. In other luncheon parties were Mr. and Mrs. Anthony J. Drexel, Colonel James A. Blair Jr. and Mrs. Joseph R. Guernsey.
Alfred Dashiell of Scribner's Magazine is making a collection of examples for a book to be called, "How Not to Write Short Stories." Long Smith will publish it.

Chief Red Fox addressed a solemn invocation yesterday to the Great Spirit from an unpainted wooden platform erected by the Department of Parks in a leafy cove fronting the waters of Spuyten Duyvil Creek. The descendant of a Mayan high priest was inaugurated president of all the tribes in the two Americas, and Redskins from the five boroughs disported themselves in tribal songs and dances.

BERLIN, Oct. 1. -- With the issue of scrip offered by Germany at a discount of 50 per cent in part payment of her foreign debt service, Germany is also beginning a new offensive for foreign trade, to be financed by her foreign creditors.

The Bank of Savings has sold through Brooks, Harvey Co., brokers, the nine-story apartment house at the northeast corner of Riverside Drive and West Ninetysecond Street. The house occupies a plot 150 by 61.6 feet and has been acquired by the Ninety-second Drive Corporation, Isidore Wolff, president.

HUNTINGTON, L.I., Oct. 1. -- The first annual triangular team golf match among the New York A.C., Crescent-Athletic Hamilton Club and the Downtown A.C. was held today over the Crescent West course and resulted in a decisive victory for the Winged Foot.

HAVANA, Oct. 1. -- While the government of Ramon Grau set to work today to combat a movement designed to protest "Bloody Friday," the scattered forces of labor were being marshaled to attempt another island-wide general strike Continued from Page One. which, they said might begin at midnight tonight.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 (AP). -- The Senators headed for the world's series tonight, planning a practice session at the Polo Grounds in NewYork tomorrow after closing their regular season today by losing to the Athletics, 3 to 0. They appeared confident and happy as they entrained for Manhattan.

No doubt some one will be able to suggest how "As Thousands Cheer" could be improved. But on the evidence disclosed Saturday evening at the Music Box, where the revue had its New York premiere, this column can only give its meek approval to every item on the program.

PARIS, Sept. 30. -- Financial circles, while following American events attentively, maintain an attitude of reserve. According to reports from the United States, the Washington Government is opposed to currency inflation, and President Roosevelt is expected soon to make a statement to that effect.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The letter of Frederick Drew Bond, entitled "Purchasing Power," published in THE TIMES, is worthy of the thoughtful consideration of those who at present are in command of governmental policies.
AMHERST, Mass., Oct. 1. -- One of the most striking transformations on record in recent years on the American college scene has taken place at Amherst.

Charging the Fifth Avenue Coach Company with violation of NRA principles in its dealings with labor, Harry W. Laidler, Socialist eandidate for Controller, protested yesterday against the proposed grant- ingr of a twenty-five-year bus franchise to the company's subsidiaries, the New York City Omnibus Corporation and the Madison Avenue Coach Company.

TOPEKA, Kan., Oct. 1 (AP). -- Governor Landon announced today that William H. Jardine, retiring Ambassador to Egypt and former Secretary of Agriculture, had accepted appointment as Kansas State Treasurer in succession to Tom B. Boyd, resigned.

LONDON, Sept. 30. -- Although it may be merely a temporary phase, the steadier condition of the foreign exchange market this week has attracted considerable notice. During: this quieter period the dollar has recovered moderately, while sterling has risen in terms of the gold currencies.

The first wage order to be issued under the Minimum Fair Wage Act of the State of New York will become effective today, Elmer F. Andrews, State Industrial Commissioner, announced yesterday. This order sets the minimum rates which may be paid to women and minors employed in laundry occupations throughout the State.

BUFFALO, Oct. 1 (AP). -- Buffalo of the International League won the sixth game of the little world's series from Columbus of the American Association, 7 -- 4, today and tied the series at three games each. The remaining games of the series also will be played here, victory going to the club which takes five contests.

CHICAGO, Oct. 1. -- "The whole machinery of demolition will be set in motion the instant A Century of Progress closes and the fair closes officially at midnight of Oct. 31. It must happen this way whether we like it or not, because of financial stringency and the imperative need to conserve all cash available."

CINCINNATI, Oct. 1 (AP). -- The baseball season at Redland Field ended today with Pittsburgh in second place in the National League and Cincinnati in the cellar for the third consecutive year as the Pirates trounced the Reds 7 to 5 and 6 to 5, in a double-header.
MILWAUKEE, Oct. 1 (AP). -- The once mighty Green Bay Packers slipped deeper into the depths of the National Football League standing today when they were humbled by the New York Giants, 10 to 7.
CHICAGO, Oct. 1. -- Plowing through the chilly waters of Lake Michigan, Marvin Nelson of Fort Dodge, Iowa, won the $10,000 fifteen-mile William Randolph Hearst marathon swim today.

MOSCOW, Oct. 1. -- Under the proud headline, "Two World Records," the newspaper Pravda, in its leading editorial today, waxes lyrical over "the glorious day in Soviet history" which simultaneously witnessed the record breaking stratosphere flight and the return of twenty-two trucks and automobiles from a great endurance test over a route that included the Central Asian desert.

BUENOS AIRES, Oct. 1. -- The Argentine Government is Studying the advisability of canceling all commercial agreements containing the most-favored-nation clause, including the conditional clause contained in the treaty with the United States.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 1. -- An upward trend in American export trade for the first six months of 1933 was shown in a survey made public today by the Chamber of Commerce of the United States.

CHICAGO, Oct. 1. -- Efforts to follow market fluctuations caused by gossip as to currency inflation and its possible effect on grain markets in North America, kept traders in grains highly nervous last week. It has been a long time since the markets have been as thin as at present, and it is difficult for operators on the Board of Trade to get in and out of large lines without materially affecting prices.

ON BOARD THE ROOSEVELT TRAIN EN ROUTE TO CHICAGO, Oct. 1. -- President Roosevelt tonight was speeding toward Chicago as the result of a last-minute decision to address the opening session of the American Legion Convention and visit the Century of Progress.

A uniformed non-commissioned army officer turned pacifist yesterday at the final session of the United States Congress Against War held in the new St. Nicholas Rink, 69 West Sixty-sixth Street, an announcement by the Congress said. The soldier's identity was kept secret.

Memphis Bill Terry of the Giants turned most of the heavy work over to his junior varsity, including Johnny Salveson, in the season's finale at Ebbets Field yesterday, and the Dodgers defeated the pennant winners, 5 to 2.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 1. -- The Rev. Howard P. Weir, former rector of St. Paul's Church in New Haven was inducted as rector of Holy Trinity Church today to succeed the late Rev. Dr. Floyd W. Tomkins, who had occupied the pulpit thirty-three years.

CORK, Irish Free State, Oct. 1 (AP). -- Between thirty and forty persons were treated for slight head wounds today after clashes following rival meetings of the Blue Shirts and the Irish Republican Army, but residents heaved a sigh of relief as the day ended without worse trouble.

Andrew Hyklor, 32 years old, of 610 Henry Street, Brooklyn, was sleepy early yesterday and he rested his weary head against a pile at the foot of East Seventy-ninth Street. The shadow of the pile shielded his eyes from the glare of the street lamps.

An increase of 83 per cent in illness as a result of unemployment between 1930 and 1932 is found in a survey of 4,500 families just completed by the New York Association for Improving the Condition of the Poor. The survey, the findings of which were made public yesterday, covered the area bounded by Bleecker Street, Broadway, Canal Street and the Bowery.
To the Editor of The New York Times: Apropos your various editorials on inflation, I wish to add what happened to Colombia after experimenting with fiat money.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1. -- A public opinion aroused for disarmament was called for today by Secretary Hull and Dr. Mary E. Woolley, American delegate to the Geneva conference, at a mass meeting held to begin a two-week nation-wide campaign in behalf of an international disarmament treaty.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1. -- As another step in the administration's credit expansion program, in advance of rumored action on devaluation and stabilization of the dollar. President Roosevelt has authorized a reduction from 5 to 4 per cent in the rate payable on preferred stock of banks which the Reconstruction Finance Corporation may purchase.
Governor Lehman continued to improve yesterday from the attack of appendicitis, which was made known at the close of conferences on New York City finances.

State socialized medicine is seen as an inevitable development by Dean H.V. Arny of the Columbia University School of Pharmacy in his annual report to Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of the university, made public yesterday. Such socialization also will include pharmacy, Dean Arny predicted.
They Come by Nature. In Tammany, as all men are aware, merit and fitness rule. But Tammany is the judge of just how that merit and fitness may best be manifested.

MONTREAL, Qua., Oct. 1. -- Price Brothers Co., historic Canadian newsprint and lumber enterprise founded in 1817, which has passed through varied vicissitudes in the last few months, is destined to be controlled by British interests but will retain its wholly Canadian character, it was predicted here today.

Guy Helvering, Internal Revenue Commissioner, has been appealed to by the Merchants Association, it was (announced yesterday, to aid in solving a pressing problem of cotton textile exporters. Some of them, it is deiclared, have been forced to refuse orders because of their inability to obtain the drawback of the processing tax to which they are entitled.

A strike of 20,000 truckmen and helpers in the flour, bakery and retail furniture trades was called for this morning by the Teamsters Union, Local 138, at a meeting yesterday in Central Plaza Hall, 111 Second Avenue, attended by what union officials said were 1,500 "key men" in these trades.
Babe Ruth, the greatest individual figure that baseball has ever known, yesterday rounded out twenty seasons of major league experience as he started -- a pitcher.

The Literary Digest announced yesterday that about 600,000 ballots had already been sent out by the magazine to registered voters in New York City, in what was described as the largest municipal straw vote ever to be attempted in this country.

CHICAGO, Oct. 1. -- Reports are numerous that the NRA is disturbing business in this area and making it difficult for many manufacturing and merchandising lines to obtain satisfactory results, but in the main it is said that business is steadily increasing its volume, and expectations are that operating costs will be adjusted by those who thus far have been unable to meet NRA requirements.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1. -- As preparations were made by the government to negotiate a settlement of the British war debt to the United States, Representative Hamilton Fish Jr. of New York predicted in a statement today that Congress would never accept an agreement of 10 per cent of the total.

Warfare between man and insect is progressing rapidly in Westchester County. The residents in the hills to the north of the New York City line are rushing their defenses against a return invasion of the Spring cankerworm.
PORTSMOUTH, Ohio, Oct. 1 (AP). -- Portsmouth scored a 7-to-6 victory over the Chicago Cardinals in a National Football League game today. It was the Spartan's third straight victory.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1. -- F. Scott McBride, general superintendent of the Anti-Saloon League, accused national political leaders today of violating party platform pledges in trying to persuade dry States to repeal their State prohibition laws.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In the current drive for economies in the city budget, with which I am wholly in sympathy, I trust that no attempt will be made to curtail those activities and departments of the city which are essential to the health and well-being of its citizens.

NEW KOCHELLE, N. Y., Oct. 1. -- Pellegrina, owned by J. T. and W. W. Northrop, was one of the winners in the annual regatta of the Handicap Class Yacht Racing Association, held off the New Rochelle Club today.
