The American Smelting and Refining Company reports for the six months ended on June 30 a net income of $2,030,209 after all charges and reserves, including a revaluation of excess stocks of metal then on hand, which resulted in a credit to earnings of $1,916,908.

LONDON, Oct. 1. -- An airplane returning with photographs of the R101 memorial ceremony at Allonne, France, crashed in a mist this afternoon near Hawkhurst, Kent. All three of its occupants were killed.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 1. -- Methods by which the behavior of individuals in groups can be scientifically measured are discussed in a book, "Observational Studies of Social Behavior," to be published tomorrow by the Institute of Human Relations of Yale University.

"With the ending of September, the comment very generally made in that the month's results were disappointing. It would be hard to find any other year in which the same comment was not made at the end of the same month; for most people habitually begin to watch for the "Autumn trade revival" immediately after Labor Day.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Oct. 1 (AP). -- A pronouncement by the Federal Council of the Churches of Christ in America on the permanent spiritual and ethical implications of the national recovery program and aimed to express the point of view of "thoughtful groups in protestantism" was made here tonight by the Rev. Dr. Albert W. Beaven.
BUENOS AIRES, Oct. 1. -- The discovery of a Communist revolt plot, having widespread ramifications, and the arrests of the leaders in the plot were announced here at midnight by the police.

RICHMOND, Va., Oct. 1 (AP). -- Governor Pollard, a lifelong dry, in a statement tonight said that he would vote for repeal when Virginia ballots Tuesday on repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment and on substitution of a liquor control law for her State prohibition act.

It was once said that the Irish question had never passed into history because it had never "passed out of politics." The New York Mayoralty has not yet so passed. The political interest in it was intensified, at the same time that it was made more complex, by Mr. MCKEE'S hesitating plunge last week.

BERLIN, Sept. 30. -- The stock market closed the week firm, with heavy buying of bank shares and potashes, but some irregularity cropped out. Electrics, in particular Siemens Halske and Schuckert, were bought.

NEWBURGH, N.Y., Oct. 1. -- Fifteen hundred uniformed Knights Templar from New York City, the Hudson Valley, New Jersey and Springfield, Mass., paraded here today, and were reviewed on the lawn of Washington Headquarters by George F. Argetsinger, Grand Commander of the State, and his official staff.

PATERSON, N.J., Oct. 1. -- While city officials and civic groups looked forward to Federal action toward strike settlement in the ensuing week, silk unions connected with the American Federation of Labor were planning to start the week with a labor demonstration which, they say, will be the biggest since the 1913 strike.

Moral idealism of a high order is urgently needed in the present efforts for economic recovery, the Rev. Dr. Minot Simons, minister of All Souls Unitarian Church, Eightieth Street and Lexington Avenue, said yesterday in his morning sermon.

P. A. Schoellkopf, president of the Mohawk Hudson Power Corporation, an important unit in the Niagara Hudson Power system, has notified holders of the company's second preferred stock that because of decreased revenues from operating subsidiaries, increased taxes and higher operating expenses as a result of the NRA program, the dividend due today has not been declared.

RYE, N. Y., Oct. 1. -- Vincent Richards won his fourth national professional singles tennis championship today when he conquered Francis T. Hunter in the final on the turf courts of the Westchester Country Club, 6-3, 6-0, 6-2.

PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 1. -- A new aid to experiments in nearly all scientific departments at Princeton University has been made available by the production in recent research here of relatively large quantities of "heavy water."

The special session of the Legislature to be called by Governor Lehman to consider measures to perfect the comprehensive four-year plan for city financing and unemployment relief will begin next week. Every effort will be made, it was indicated yesterday, to limit the session to one day.

Five have been named for the Montague Purse, feature event today on the Metropolitan Jockey Club's opening-day program at Jamaica. The meeting will run two weeks and is the last of the year on Long Island. The session at Empire City will mark the end of the New York season on the Jockey Club tracks.
MOSCOW. -- In modern Russia the machine has taken the place that religion had in old Russia. Today in Russia the will of God is a mechanistic process.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Although it may seem a very satisfactory solution of the present financial difficulties of the city so far as the city officials and the bankers are concerned, yet a protest might rightly be made by the already overburdened real property taxpayer, with his doubled water rates as well.

The National Electrical Manufacturers Association made public yesterday a resolution from its offices at 155 East Forty-fourth Street expressing the determination of its members "collectively to resist" what the association characterized as unjustified and illegal encroachment of labor unions against members of the association.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 (AP). -- The, result of months of undercover digging into the books of New York banks will be outlined to Chairman Fletcher of the Senate Banking Committee tomorrow by Ferdinand Pecora, counsel, in preparation for the resumption Tuesday of the investigation into Wall Street practices.

CHICAGO, Oct. 1. -- With President Roosevelt on his way here to address the opening session of the annual convention of the American Legion, opening tomorrow, leaders of the organization were confident tonight that no insurgent movement would upset their plans for regaining public confidence.

Flans for the restoration or game in the United States are numbered by the thousands. Almost every conservationlst and every State conservation official has a plan, of his own Which he believes would go a long way toward, checking the diminution of game birds and game animals in our fields and forest.

LOCUST VALLEY, L.I., Oct. 1. -- Mark Stuart, metropolitan amateur champion, and Mrs. Robert C. Lake became the first winners of the Marshall Field trophies today. In the final match of the mixed foursome tournament they defeated Miss Charlotte Glutting and Robert Lester, New Jersey medal-winning combination, 4 and 3.

What promises to be the most hotly contested city Mayoralty fight in years will receive its formal start tonight with the opening of the Fusion campaign at a meeting in Cooper Union with Florello H. LaGuardia, candidate for Mayor and Samuel Seabury, city Investigator, as the principal speakers.

Obligations of the United States Government that will mature within the next twelve months amount to $2,903,951,200. They consist of Treasury certificates of indebtedness, notes and non-interest-bearing discount bills.

The program of relief approved by the President is as the "one good word that warms three winter months." He recently authorized the Agricultural Adjustment Administration to buy $75,000,000 worth of surplus food and clothing material for distribution among the destitute unemployed.

Many prominent men and women as well as debutantes of this and recent seasons are aiding in the arrangements for the fashion show to be held in conjunction with a luncheon and dinner on Thursday in the Grand Ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria.

The Shippers Conference of Greater New York appealed yesterday to the 145 steamship and railroad lines operating terminals in the port district to abolish the practices of freight loaders at the terminals and to take direct control of the handling of consignments of inbound commerce.

The final quarter of the year will see an increase of nearly 15 per cant in carloadings, compared with the same period last year, according to estimates of the thirteen Shippers Regional Advisory Boards. The estimate is based on the shipment of twenty-nine commodities.

ST. LOUIS, Oct. 1 (AP). -- The St. Louis Cardinals fell to fifth place, finishing out of the first division by a half game, as Tex Carleton's wildness gave the Chicago Cubs a 7-to-1 victory today in the closing game of the season. The Cubs wound up in third place as the Pirates won a double-header.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1. -- Secretary Ickes, Public Works Administrator, in announcing today that half of the $3,300,000,000 for construction by the Federal Government, States and political subdivisions had been allotted, denounced "propaganda" to the effect that fear of scandal and graft had bred an overcaution which retarded apportionment of the money.

The bureau of complaints of the local NRA has handled 10,468 complaints of alleged violations of NRA provisions since Aug. 7, it was reported yesterday to Grover A. Whalen, city NRA chairman, by H.J. Kenner of the bureau of complaints.

Adult students seeking free education in Greater New York during the Winter are enrolling in larger numbers than ever before, according to a report made public yesterday by the State Department of Education.

BERLIN, Oct. 1 -- All Germany celebrated today a bountiful harvest and Chancellor Hitler's rule, glorified the peasant who had raised and garnered the crop and prepared by a day of self-denial and relief contributions for the Winter that is coming.
MADRID, Oct. 1 (AP). -- Sidney Franklin, American bull fighter, was successfully operated on today at Crespo Hospital. It was the last of five operations resulting from a bullring accident in 1930.

Reiterating opposition to the recognition of Soviet Russia, Lawrence B. Elliman, chairman of the executive committee of the Chamber of Commerce of the State of New York, in a report to be submitted to that organization today will warn that dangers are involved in the proposed loan to Russia for the purchase of American goods.

A direct relationship exists between the amount of money spent on schools and the advancement of its pupils, in the opinion of Dr. Orrin E. Powell, research graduate at Teachers College, Columbia University.

NEW HAVEN, Oct. 1. -- Professor Irving Fisher's index number of commodity prices, based on 100 as the average for 1926, is 71.4, which compares with 71.6 a week ago, 71.1 two weeks ago, 70.9 three weeks ago and 70.8 four weeks ago. Last week's average was the highest of the year to date; the highest July figure was 70.4.

WASHINGTON. Oct. 1. -- The four-day President's Cup regatta program was concluded with rowing and canoe races on the Washington Channel today. A strong incoming tide and stiff head winds slowed the racing considerably, but provided numerous spills.

The economic situation would be benefited immeasurably by some assurance or declaration of policy that would establish confidence in a reasonable stability of the currency and in firm control over it, the National City Bank says in its current monthly bulletin.

CHICAGO, Oct. 1. -- The grain trade, as well as farmers, is interested in seeing how the government comes out in its efforts to cut next year's corn crop to 2,000,000,000 bushels. Last year's crop was 2,872,000,000 bushels.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1. -- Striving to force through an agreement whereby 100,000 strikers in the "captive" coal mines of the great steel corporations would return to work tomorrow, General Johnson spent another strenuous day pleading and arguing with steel executives and union leaders.
Football bade farewell to September on Saturday and headed into October with an afternoon of play in which, with one exception, nothing happened that might be termed an outstanding upset.
A tense record on a police file card "6-18-15 -- Concealed weapon; suspended sentence" -- recorded eighteen years ago Joseph (Spot) Leahy's first milestone on his career of crime.

A growing fear of war is felt by international leaders, the Right Rev. William Hall Moreland, Bishop of Sacramento, Cal., said yesterday morning in a sermon at Holyrood Protestant Episcopal Church, West 179th Street and Fort Washington Avenue.

New business came into the wholesale apparel markets here during the week at a reduced rate, as retail trade declined. The unusually warm weather, coupled with the fact that some of the normal September business was obtained in August, was responsible for the decline in store sales.

An ancient Persian ceremony, given in English, with incense rising beside the altar and ministerial chants accompanied by dramatic music, marked the opening of St. Mark's-in-the-Bouwerie, Tenth Street west of Second Avenue, yesterday morning.

New York's baseball public, although keyed up to a high pitch for the impending world's series, which opens tomorrow at the Polo Grounds, apparently is still not of a mood to bring about a complete sell-out on the basis of buying reserved seats in three-game strips.

It being generally accepted that the Giants will enter the coming world's series excelling in defensive play and the Senators will hold the advantage in attacking power, one who seeks to determine the winner need only compare how these two forces will operate when pitted against each other.

Vigorous attacks upon Tammany Hall, coupled with pleas to the electorate to rid the city of domination by machine politicians, were voiced yesterday in several pulpits as ministers commented upon the municipal campaign.

The tale of a mad high priest, hunchbacked but powerful, honored in his lifetime by his fifteenth century Mixtecan followers as the incarnation of Xolotl, the god of the monsters, and buried with gold and precious stones, was unfolded here yesterday.

The sale of three apartment houses in the North Hudson section of Hudson County involving $350,000 was the outstanding realty transaction in New Jersey for the close of the week. The sale was made by the Paulus Hook Corporation, Daniel E. Evarts, president, to the Sixteenth and Park Avenue Corporation, Morris Broadman, president.

Henry Carnegie Phipps, accompanied by Mrs. Phipps and their daughters, Audrey, Barbara and Sonia, are among the passengers due today from Europe on the North German Lloyd liner Bremen. Others on board from the Channel ports are Mrs. Graham Fair Vanderbilt, Edward Johnson, tenor; William T. Tilden III and Bruce Barnes, tennis players, and:

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Oct. 1. -- The second festival of contemporary music came to a close here at Yaddo today with a morning conference on the relations between composer and interpretative artist and an afternoon concert. Yesterday there had been morning and evening concerts.

A solemn, pontifical mass, with Cardinal Hayes as the celebrant, in St. Patrick's Cathedral at 10:30 A. M. yesterday formally opened the nineteenth meeting of the National Conference of Catholic Charities. The mass was in commemoration of the centenary of the Society of St. Vincent de Paul and it was under papal patronage.

BRUSSELS, Oct. 1. -- A huge demonstration by the middle class against excessive taxation, expenditures on armaments and the taxation of necessities of life, such as bread, milk and butter, took place in Brussels this afternoon. Nine provinces of Belgium sent large delegations.
MINNEAPOLIS, Oct. 1 (AP). -- How lack of a job, when it lasts more than a year, takes the heart out of men and women, is shown in a study of 500 Minneapolis unemployed by Jessie A. Bloodworth.

BERLIN, Sept. 30. -- An abnormally heavy demand for short-term credit, a sharp advance in interest rates and other indications of a money tension were the features of the week here in financial circles.

GREAT RIVER, L.I., Oct. 1. -- In the special professional invitation tourney staged by the Timber Point Golf Club today, Leo Diegel, former national P.G.A. champion, was the winner after a two-hole play-off.

WESTBURY, L. I., Oct. 1. -- Roving all over the field and hitting almost at will, Winston Guest's Templeton team piled up 22 goals on International Field at the Meadow Brook Club today to defeat Westbury, 22 to 13, and ride into the semi-final round of the Monty Waterbury Memorial Cup polo tournament.

Off and on since last Tuesday there have been spirited demonstrations by the guests at that sterling old Pennsylvania hotel, the Eastern Penitentiary. The public is familiar with these evidences of high animal spirits on the part of the boarders. They're a little rough in their play at times, but so are undergraduates.

Douglas W. Clinch Co. of 48 Wall Street, specializing in foreign dollar bonds, have changed their corporate name to Clinch, Morse Co., Inc. Douglas W. Clinch, Arthur W. Morse and Theodore H. Auerback are senior officers of the company.

Conceding the early repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment as a "virtual certainty," the Rev. Dr. Henry Darlington, preaching yesterday at the Protestant Episcopal Church of the Heavenly Rest, Fifth Avenue and Ninetieth Street, urged all temperance workers to unite upon a "campaign of education," in order to keep the liquor interests from controlling politics.
HAVANA, Oct. 1. -- Drastic measures against Communists and other disturbers of public order will be taken by the Grau government, it announced today.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 (AP). -- The Senate committee investigating ocean mail contracts will swing from its study of ship subsidies tomorrow long enough to look into alleged propaganda activities of the steamship lines.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 1. -- An unsuccessful attempt by Eastern Penitentiary convicts to seize six Salvation Army workers as hostages, presumably as the first step in a general prison delivery plot, was revealed today by Warden Herbert Smith.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 (AP). -- Minimum price-fixing for swine, one of the major products of American farms, appeared today to have an even chance for inclusion in the Farm Adjustment Administration's newest commodity program for boosting farm buying power.
NEW YORK. Mrs. Ethelbert I. Low will give a dinner dance on Jan. 5 at the Pierre for her niece, Miss Louisa B. Herrick, debutante daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Newbold L. Herrick.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1. -- Protest against diversion of highway funds from construction and labor to unemployment relief in the States was made by the National Highway Users Conference in a letter from Roy F. Britton to President Roosevelt, which was received at the White House today.

The Museum of Modern Art begins its Autumn season today with a private showing of an exhibition of European modern painting and sculpture, which will remain until Oct. 25. The exhibit will be open to the public beginning tomorrow. The work on view was selected from several private collections, including the Bliss collection and from the examples owned by the museum.
MIDDLETOWN, Conn., Oct. 2 -- James Andrew Oberlander, known to fame as the Swede Oberlander who was the Dartmouth terror of 1925, is winding up his career as a football coach this year at Wesleyan.

DETROIT, Oct. 2 (AP) -- The Beau Brummel Stable's Thistle Play got up in the closing strides to beat the heavily played favorite, Al Neiman, by a nose in the feature race at the Fair Grounds track today.

The University in Exile, established as a graduate faculty of political and social science composed of ten processors of international reputation who were dismissed or furloughed from Germany, began its first semester yesterday at the New School for Social Research, 66 West Twelfth Street.

As a writer of comedy Mr. O'Neill has a capacity for tenderness that most of us never suspected. "Ah, Wilderness!" with which the Guild opened its sixteenth season last evening, may not be his most tremendous play, but it is certainly his most attractive.

CHICAGO, Oct. 2. -- This city took President Roosevelt to its heart today. During a crowded five-hour visit, hundreds of thousands of persons, packed along the curbs of La Salle Street, Jackson Boulevard, Michigan Boulevard and other thoroughfares through which he rode, shouted cheers that mingled with the roar of automobile horns, while ticker tape, torn paper and confetti floated down through the air.

HAVANA, Oct. 2 -- The ABC Revolutionary Society, which was a secret organization during the Machado regime, is believed to be largely responsible for the street fighting against soldiers which began tonight in this city soon after officers in the National Hotel had surrendered.

BUFFALO, Oct. 2 (AP) -- Paul Dean, slim right-hander, who has been the particular jinx of the Buffalo Bisons in the Little World's Series, tonight registered his third triumph as he pitched Columbus to a 7-2 victory. The result gave the Red Birds a 4-to-3 advantage in the five out of nine game series.

To the Editor of The New York Times: A legion of small business men who daily deliver our product to the door-step, extending weekly, semi-monthly or monthly credit to the householders of the nation, are signers of the NRA codes. Our business in aggregate runs into a tremendous figure.

ATLANTA, Oct. 2 (AP) -- The biggest kick 13-year-old Dorothy Kirby got out of winning the Georgia women's golf championship Saturday was the rousing reception the neighborhood children gave her on the triumphant return home.

Donald F. Stewart, editor at the Moose Magazine who testified last Friday in Federal court that he had been part author of an article crediting Senator James J. Davis with the idea of raising funds through charity balls, said yesterday on the witness stand that he had had no direct information to that effect.

Private hospitals in New York City will be forced to close their doors if the Untermyer-O'Brien plan for ending, their tax exemptions is enacted, members of the medical social service section of the Welfare Council were told yesterday at a luncheon in the Gramercy Square Hotel, 52 Gramercy Square West.

NEWARK, N.J., Oct. 2. -- Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt arrived at Newark Airport tonight on a United Air Line plane from Chicago, where she had gone yesterday with the President. An automobile took her to her home in New York. Tomorrow night she will dedicate the new Theodore Roosevelt High School at West Orange.
Baseball's greatest show of the year -- the world's series -- found New York gripped in a wave of civic enthusiasm last night quite without parallel in recent years.

Not as Predicted. The opening of the world series here today represents one baseball surprise piled upon another. When the season began not one of the wise ones of the game prophesied that Washington would meet the Giants for the world's championship.

BOSTON, Oct. 2 -- Since the palmiest days of the late Florenz Ziegfeld this city has known no such opening as that of "Let 'Em Eat Cake" at the Shubert this evening. The theatre was filled, with 200 New Yorkers in the audience. For days $17.50 had been asked and bid for a pair of orchestra chairs.

With the Phillies and the Brooklyn Dodgers, second division clubs of the National League, showing the way, eight major league clubs selected twelve players from the minors by the draft route at the annual major league draft meeting last night.

BROOKLINE, Mass., Oct. 2. -- A plucky girl clerk prevented the wholesale looting of the Washington Square branch of the Brookline Trust Company today when she dropped to the floor and sounded the burglar alarm under the guns of six hold-up men.

The Columbia football team entered the final week of its pre-season training yesterday at Baker Field, directing its preparations toward the Lehigh encounter here on Saturday. At the same time Coach Lou Little's pupils gave an exhibition of plays for the benefit of 200 New York City high, school pupils and their coaches.

With dealings in bonds on the Stock Exchange yesterday amounting to only $7,707,200, domestic corporation issues and United States Government bonds drifted irregularly lower, while foreign loans, reflecting the weakness in the dollar yesterday, pointed higher.

PARIS, Oct. 2 -- A categorical denial was given today by a Foreign Office spokesman on the authority of Premier Daladier to statements by Pertinax in the Echo de Paris that the French Government had agreed, if Germany accepted a disarmament convention, to reduce the French army to 200,000 men with a reduced term of service during the four-year transition period.

Joseph V. McKee consented last April to become the Fusion nominee for Mayor, after a meeting at which the Fusion leaders had agreed upon him as their standard-bearer in the anti-Tammany fight, Joseph M. Price, head of the Independent Fusion Committee, declared yesterday.
Play in the Monty Waterbury Memorial Cup tournament, last of the high-goal events of the polo season, reaches the semi-final stage at the Meadow Brook Club in Westbury this afternoon.

PANAMA, Oct. 2 -- President Arias of Panama sailed from Cristobal on the steamship Quirigua tonight to visit President Roosevelt after an enthusiastic demonstration by thousands of supporters at Panama and Colon.

GENEVA, Oct. 2 -- World-wide improvement in industrial production, trade and employment was reported today by Alexander Loveday, director of the League of Nation's financial section and by the League's labor office.

James Medley, 25-year-old garage attendant who was arrested recently with Nicolino Caroline De Palma, a Yonkers nurse, pleaded guilty yesterday before Federal Judge Johnson Hayes to a charge of using the mails in an attempt to extort $10,000 from Franklin A. Batcheller.

EDGEWATER, N.J., Oct. 2 -- C.A. Esslinger, general manager of the assembly plant of the Ford Motor Company here, indicated today that the plant might be obliged to close within the next few days, because or a lack of sufficient men to continue operations.

HISTORICAL novels are usually firecrackers that fail to explode. With a disrelish born of many boresome hours in the past, we picked up Helen Waddell's "Peter Abelard" (Henry Holt, 2.50) in expectation of finding another dud. But the firecracker exploded this time, cracking the categorical framework which ordinarily brackets the words "historical" and "dull."

Charitable institutions in this city and vicinity receive a total of $425,000 under the will of Madeleine S. Stern, widow of Benjamin Stern, former president of Stern Brothers department store, it was disclosed yesterday when her testment was offered for probate in Surrogate's Court.

BROOKHAVEN, L.I., Oct. 2 -- Grant Taylor Jr., 11 years old, a student of the Brookhaven public school, was clawed to death today by a black bear that broke loose from a chain in the yard of a hunting lodge operated by Gardner Murdock, sportsmen's guide, near here.

Traffic Court was transformed into an educational institution yesterday by Magistrate Benjamin Greenspan and Ernest N. Smith, executive vice president of the American Automobile Association. Lectures were followed by suspended sentences for half of the 164 violators as they repentantly bowed themselves out of the room.
Mayor O'Brien will present medals at City Hall next Monday to the 200 children who wrote winning essays on protecting homes against fire, as a feature of Fire Prevention Week.
CHICAGO, Oct. 2 -- Robert G. Lotspiech, who was killed in Havana today by a stray bullet, is survived by a brother and a sister.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 -- Organized labor voiced vigorous opposition to currency inflation today and demanded that wages be paid in "honest dollars."
LONDON, Oct. 3. -- Commenting on President Roosevelt's Chicago speech, The London Times remarks editorially:
ALBANY, Oct. 2. -- A campaign against the St. Lawrence shipway treaty was urged today at the opening session of the State Waterways Association, which reiterated its stand against the treaty.

BERLIN, Oct. 2. -- The Boerse began the week with an uncertain trend. The turnover was small and gains and losses were about equally distributed. Heavy industrials showed some firmness toward the close and Rheinische Braunkohlen advanced 5 per cent.

The "stop loss" provision of the retail code does not constitute "price fixing" and "no one should be misled that this provision will or can react against the best interests of the consumer," Edward T. Corcoran, counsel for the six retail organizations which sponsored the original draft of the retail code, said in a statement yesterday.

LOS ANGELES, Oct. 2 -- An earthquake of minor intensity shook buildings in Southern California cities early this morning, caused one death and injuries to twelve persons, and drove hundreds into the streets of Santa Barbara, Los Angeles, Long Beach and San Diego in the fear that the tremor of March 10, which cost many lives and heavy property damage, would be repeated.

All things considered, Wall Street regarded the opening of the new month as auspicious. If early advances on the markets were not sustained, there was an optimistic sentiment in the latter part of the day which indicated that the unsatisfactory results on the exchanges had not done any great damage.
GENEVA, Oct. 2 -- Joseph Paul-Boncour, the French Foreign Minister, impressed upon the League of Nations Assembly tonight the decisive character of the coming session, of the Disarmament Conference.

A committee to present a plea to the American Federation of Labor to drive racketeering out of the labor field was formed at the campaign school of the Women's National Republican Club yesterday morning. The move followed a suggestion by William Fellowes Morgan Jr., who also urged that all NRA codes contain anti-racketeering provisions.

BERLIN, Oct. 2 -- The Hitler government published today the text of the so-called hereditary homestead law, effective Oct. 1, which creates in Germany a new "peasant aristocracy" based on inalienable and indivisible protection of the ancestral estate and its inheritance by one principal heir, elected according to definite rules among the owner's next of kin.

BAY SHORE, L.I., Oct. 2 -- J. Ebb Weir, chairman of the Long Island Golf Association's tournament committee, paired with Ted Walker, Timber Point professional, to win his association's amateur-pro event at the Southward Ho Country Club today with a round of 72.

Facing a capacity audience last night in the hall at Cooper Union, which sixty years ago witnessed the beginning of the crusade that led to the downfall of Boss Tweed, Samuel Seabury aroused a thunder of applause when he predicted that Tammany would again be vanquished.

Reorders Reflect Retail Lull. Reorders in the wholesale market here yesterday again reflected the lull manifest in the apparel and several of the accessory trades last week. The call for coats was small by comparison with recent activity, while interest in better-grade dresses showed up stronger than was the case in the cheaper lines.
The text of the address at Cooper Union by F.H. LaGuardia, Fusion candidate for Mayor, follows:

Six jurors were selected yesterday for the trial of four men on a charge of murdering Michael Malloy, a stationary engineer, to collect $1,788 insurance they had placed on his life. The case, which is before Judge James M. Barrett in Bronx County Court, will be resumed today.
HONOLULU, Oct. 2 -- Governor Judd announced today that the Territory of Hawaii had no funds in sight to meet its payroll of 5,000 and other government obligations incurred from Oct. 1.

The members of German-Jewish societies who walked out of a stormy meeting of the United German Societies two week ago returned last night in response to an invitation to compose their differences. They remained only long enough to hear the meeting vote not to allow them until after German Day, on Oct. 29, to discuss the rising influence of pro-Nazi representatives and the anti-Semitic sentiment that caused their first exit.

NEW YORK. Mr. and Mrs. William Bayard Hawthorne will give a reception this afternoon at their home, 65 East Fifty-fifth Street, to celebrate the fourth anniversary of their marriage. Mr. and Mrs. Ernest Atky Ratsey will give a dinner for them tonight in the Starlight Roof Garden of the Waldorf-Astoria.

Special hunting regulations for Connecticut now are being considered by members of the Board of Fish and Game Commissioners. A hearing next Saturday at Hartford probably will end in the issuance of a new code.
PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 2 -- Miss Edith Quier gained an impressive lead today in the annual two-day medal play tournament for the Dorothy Campbell Hurd Cup.

MOSCOW, Oct. 2 -- Under the headline "Forward," the Industrial Gazette launched today a campaign for bringing freight-car loadings, coal, pig iron and steel production and heavy industry generally up to the program in the final quarter of this year.

JOHN BROWN'S body came a-near to being banged in Dublin the other day. There was an auction sale in Prussia Street, the very name of which is an invitation to strong measures. The assistant registrar of the County Waterford Circuit Court was trying to sell six cattle distrained on the land of a Clonmel farmer for non-payment of taxes.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 -- Upon the return of President Roosevelt from Chicago, conferences will be held with Acting Secretary of the Treasury Dean Acheson, in which will be outlined the White House policy on the debt negotiations with the British Government.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 -- The State Department today sent congratulations to Sumner Welles, Ambassador to Cuba, for extricating twenty-four United States citizens who were endangered during the fighting between the Cuban soldiers and the officers quartered in the National Hotel in Havana.

Reorganization of the local NRA machinery will be begun today with the arrival from Washington of Senator Robert F. Wagner, chairman of the National Labor Mediation Board, who will confer with Grover A. Whalen, head of the city NRA, on the remodeling and extension of the local mediation committee handling labor disputes.
HAVANA, Oct. 2 -- Heavy firing broke out early today at the National Hotel, where 500 army and navy officers, opponents of the Grau San Martin regime, have been barricaded and besieged for weeks.

Tentative assessments on all taxable real estate in New York City for 1934 are fixed at $16,702,961,046 by the new assessment rolls made public yesterday by James J. Sexton, president of the Department of Taxes and Assessments. The net reduction in the final assessments for 1933 is $1,056,883,898.

HOLLYWOOD, Oct. 2 (AP) -- Voicing dissatisfaction with the representation of motion picture players at the film industry's NRA code hearings in Washington, twenty-six actors banded together today and protested to a deputy recovery administrator against formation of a "salary control board."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 2. -- The Senate Banking and Currency Committee will resume its investigation of stock market practices tomorrow morning after a recess of nearly three months, with every prospect that the inquiry will continue for three months.

Mr. ROOSEVELT'S address to the American Legion at Chicago yesterday was a triumph of geniality combined with firmness. Gracefully associating himself with the veterans in experience and endeavor, he dwelt first of all upon the spirit of national unity. Exhibited wonderfully throughout the war, the demand for it today is fully as urgent.

Continued uncertainty over the monetary outlook here again depressed the dollar in foreign exchange yesterday, driving it down 1 cent in gold valuation to 64.38 cents. The pound sterling also weakened in terms of the gold standard exchanges, but did not fall as heavily as the dollar.

Early settlement of the truckmen's strike which started yesterday morning was forecast last night with the announcement of an agreement, reached under NRA auspices, which will send 5,000 strikers back to work this morning.

Art increasing number of people in the United States are apprehensive of currency inflation and fearful of its results. Eight distinguished men, representing both major political parties, have approved and sponsored a series of articles presenting their viewpoint on the money problems of the day. The series is appearing in this newspaper in sixteen consecutive daily chapters. The ninth is presented herewith.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Through the candidacy of Joseph V. McKee every man and woman of this city is furnished an opportunity to lift this community from the slough of despond in which it has been weltering so long. Now we have a chance in an effective way to express our opinion of the stupid, incompetent administration that has made our municipality a laughing stock and a by-word throughout the nation.

Transactions on the Stock Exchange fell short yesterday of a million shares for the first time in six weeks, and Wall Street did not bother to explain the decline of 1 1/2 to 2 points in the average price of popular issues. Nor did the slow reaction in agricultural commodities or the irregular downward movement in bond's occasion any special comment.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 2. -- The Federal Reserve Board's condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in 90 leading cities on Sept. 27 shows decreases of $63,000,000 in loans and investments and $14,000,000 in net demand deposits and an increase of $53,000,000 in reserve balances with Federal Reserve banks.

BUENOS AIRES, Oct. 2 -- With flags flying, military bands playing and two regiments drawn up as a guard of honor, President Justo boarded a train this morning for Mar del Plata, where he embarked on the battleship Moreno this afternoon for Rio de Janeiro to visit President Vargas of Brazil.

PITTSBURGH, Pa., Oct. 2 -- The President of the United States has "commanded" 75,000 striking men to go back to work in the Western Pennsylvania soft coal mines, Philip Murray, vice president of the United Mine Workers of America, told eighty-two of their representatives here today.

PARIS, Oct. 2. -- The present uncertainty regarding President Roosevelt's plans caused the dollar to drift downward today. It closed at 16.41 francs after touching 16.33, which was close to the lowest level yet reached. Friday's closing quotation was 16.73 francs.

HASTINGS, England, Oct. 2 -- Joseph Compton, newly elected chairman of the Labor party, opened the party's conference here today with an attack on "all forms of dictatorship." Speaking as a trade union official -- Mr. Compton is a leader of the Vehicle Builders Union -- he said that trade unionists ''still believe in democratic methods and principles and never tolerate dictatorship from outside from whatever source it might come."

Dr. Harry Woodburn Chase, new chancellor of New York University, was welcomed to his post yesterday by administrative officers, faculty and student representatives at an academic convocation in the School of Education Auditorium in West Fourth Street.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 -- Evidence indicating attempts by the American Steamship Owners Association to influence the selection of Congressional committees in which it was interested was spread today on the record of the Senate's investigation into the present system of merchant marine subsidies.

HAVANA, Oct. 2 (AP) -- Full accounts of events that took place today on the battlegrounds of the National Hotel can be gathered only by piecing together the tales of onlookers, official reports and the personal observations of newspaper men who dodged bullets at the climax of the day's battle.
Managers Bill Terry of the Giants and Joe Cronin of the Senators yesterday expressed complete satisfaction with the condition of their teams.

BERLIN, Oct. 2 -- Field Marshal and President Paul von Hindenburg became 86 years old today. All Germany is celebrating his birthday, but he himself is observing it as quietly as may be in his greatly restricted family circle at Neudeck, East Prussia, on the great estate recently bestowed by a grateful nation upon him and his heirs forever.

WORCESTER, Mass., Oct. 2 -- The annual music festival of the Worcester County Musical Association opened tonight with impressive attendance and special ceremonies in the new Worcester Memorial Auditorium, which is henceforth to be the home of one of the oldest and most important music festivals given in America.

The Board of Transportation sent yesterday to Mayor O'Brien's special committee on public works its application for $25,500,000 of Federal funds with which to complete rapid transit construction work on about eighteen additional miles of the city's new subway system.
New York City will spend $578,888,680,62 next year, according to the tentative 1934 budget total submitted yesterday to the Board of Estimate by Mayor O'Brien.
There was weakness yesterday in futures in the local commodity markets and trading in most of them was lighter than usual. Prices in the cash markets were irregular.

Testifying yesterday at the trial of Isidor J. Kresel in the Criminal Branch of the Supreme Court, Joseph H. Zwerres of Rochester, a former examiner for the State Banking Department, told of the examination of the Bank of United States that he and another examiner made in July, 1929.
SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 2 (AP) -- I. Itoh of Japan defeated Carl Holmes, San Francisco, 7 -- 9, 6 -- 4, 6 -- 4, today in a second-round men's singles match of the Pacific Coast tennis championships.
The text of the address of Samuel Seabury, chairman of the Fusion Campaign Committee, at Cooper Union last night follows:

OKLAHOMA CITY, Oct. 2 (AP). -- The government pressed the Charles F. Urschel kidnapping case with new vigor today as County Attorney Lewis R. Morris followed recommendations by the Federal attorney, Herbert K. Hyde, for the filing of capital charges against George Kelly and Albert Bates.
Several business buildings and vacant plots, in addition to various dwellings, were included in the New Jersey turnover reported yesterday.
The heaviest series betting in five years is the way Broadway is reacting to this year's annual baseball classic.

RICHMOND, Va., Oct. 2 (AP) -- Virginia tomorrow will take its place among the States which have by popular vote expressed their decision on ratification of the Twenty-first Amendment, repealing the Eighteenth. It will also determine its disposition toward State prohibition.

The selection by the Fusion leaders of George Trosk, one of Samuel Seabury's assistants in the city investigation, for nomination for the Supreme Court caused a rebellion last night at the Republican Judicial Convention, held at the National Republican Club.

CHICAGO, Oct. 2 -- A temporary restraining order preventing removal by Samuel Insull or any representative of any part of a $1,000,000 "secret fund" which, it is said, he created for himself before his flight to Greece was issued today by Judge John P. Barnes in Federal court.

Twice within the past few weeks steamships bound up and down the Atlantic Coast have been lashed by hurricanes. Although all of them were brutally tossed about and some of them were severely battered, the damage was relatively slight. When the wind is at hurricane force the ferocity of the open sea is one of the most malevolent phases of nature.
To the Editor of The New York Times: Once more the old comedy is being reenacted, and the gods that control the decay and corruption of cities must be laughing up their sleeves.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 2. -- Movements of vessels follow, all dates are Oct. 1 unless otherwise specified:

TRENTON, N.J., Oct. 2 -- After hearing testimony by Acting Governor Emerson L. Richards today, as a "surprise" witness, the Legislative Judiciary Committee went into conference to prepare a report on its investigation of his charge that there was a "slush fund" of $25,000 passed to defeat a beer-control bill.

For years the so-called "budgets" of the City of New York have been such in name only. They lacked several of the essentials of a real budget. They contained no authoritative revenue figures. On the expense side the figures were misleading, since they customarily omitted appropriations from State-aid funds, bridge tolls, fines for the violation of the Sanitary Code and other miscellaneous revenues.
SALEM, N.H., Oct. 2 (AP) -- Howard Hughes and Johnny Westrope featured today's closing race program at Rockingham Park by riding five of the seven winners.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 -- Uncertainty as to the monetary outlook has subjected the security markets to confusion and contributed to a stagnation of the market for new capital security issues by industry, according to the October survey of current business, made public today by the Department of Commerce.

WASAGA BEACH, Ont., Oct. 2 (Canadian Press). -- Bound for Baghdad tomorrow, "if all's well," the flying Mollisons brought their black two-motored plane Seafarer II down on the hard-packed sands of Wasaga Beach at 5:30 this afternoon. Their flight from Toronto occupied Jess than three-quarters of an hour.
CHICAGO, Oct. 2. -- The President's address before the American Legion Convention today follows:

Reporting that his company experienced a "very large increase in output" during the Summer, Walter S. Wyman, president of the Central Maine Power Company, has written to his stockholders to express his confidence in the NRA program.

Thirty-three cadets of the New York State Merchant Marine Academy received diplomas and licenses as junior officers yesterday afternoon at the semi-annual commencement exercises of the New York State Merchant Marine Academy at the Maritime Exchange Building, 80 Broad Street.

George V. McLaughlin, former Police Commissioner, was named yesterday as chairman of the general campaign committee for Joseph V. McKee, independent candidate for Mayor, and Harry M. Durning, Collector of the Port, was named as Mr. McKee's campaign manager.

Mrs. Cecelia McCormick, 19-year-old widow of Andrew McCormick, who shot and killed Head Keeper William McConnell n the Raymond Street jail, Brooklyn, last Winter and then turned the pistol on himself, went on trial yesterday in the Kings County Court on a charge of first degree murder.
MACON, Ga., Oct. 2 (AP) -- Attending physicians said late tonight that W.L. (Young) Stribling "won't last twenty-four hours unless he can sleep soon."

SINGAPORE, Oct. 2. -- Governor Sir Cecil Clementi said today, in defining the Malayan Government's rubber policy, that any arrangement for restriction in output must be comprehensive and include alternatives for rubber raising.

Jim Browning successfully repulsed Joe Savoldi's attempt to gain the world's heavyweight wrestling championship last night at Madison Square Garden. After 36 minutes and 59 seconds of grappling, the Verona (Mo.) wrestler, only semi-conscious as the result of a heavy fall sustained a few seconds before, threw himself on his Notre Dame rival and pressed his shoulders to the mat.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 -- Under the strongest pressure from President Roosevelt, the United States Steel Corporation and other great steel companies owning "captive" soft coal mines were forced today to yield recognition in every way but in actual name to the United Mine Workers of America.

Speed horses held the spotlight as the Fall meeting opened yesterday at Jamaica, and a new five and one-half furlong track record was set which aroused wide discussion. The Greentree Stable's Miss Mouse, handled by Silvio Coucci and running in the Hiawatha Purse, was officially clocked in 1:04, lopping two-fifths of a second off the mark established by Old Dutch in 1927.

ALBANY, Oct 2 -- Postmaster General Farley, the State and national Democratic chairman, and his forces were manoeuvred today by John F. Curry into adoption of a resolution endorsing Mayor O'Brien of New York.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 2 -- Harvard's varsity football team was put through an intensive 75-minute defensive scrimmage against the junior varsity team today at the end of which the jayvees had one touchdown.

HAVANA, Oct. 2 -- Ambassador Welles is investigating the circumstances of the killing of an American citizen, Robert G. Lotspiech, assistant Havana manager of Swift Co., during today's battle between soldiers and officers who were besieged in the National Hotel.

SO the Giants and Senators are about to engage in a world's series. "Backward, turn backward, O Time, in thy flight!" Nine years ago the Giants lost just such a series by a foot. The sharp cry of despair was the voice of John McGraw, but the foot was the foot of Hank Gowdy.

Seating her own record made last November by eight minutes, the North German Lloyd liner -- Bremen arrived yesterday from the Channel ports, steaming the 3,081 miles from Cherbourg Breakwater to the Ambrose Lightship in 4 days, 15 hours and 48 minutes.

HAVANA, Oct. 2 (AP) -- Perched high upon a cliff above the Malecon Drive, the National Hotel provided a strangely modern though strong fortress for the 500 besieged officers of the de Cespedes regime.
Following is the text of Mayor O'Brien's message to the Board of Estimate and Apportionment in submitting the executive budget for 1934:

Dr. Elmer Edgar Stoll, will have his "Art and Artifice in Shakespeare: A Study in Dramatic Contrast and Illusion," published this Fall by Cambridge University Press. The general theme of the book is that in drama the dramatist is concerned with the esthetic effect as a whole, and therefore the criticism which regards plays as social or psychological documents is unsound.

An unidentified woman rescued a young woman from the East River last night after the car which the latter had been learning to drive had hurtled over a string-piece at the foot of East Sixty-fourth Street. A man was believed to have been trapped in the closed car and drowned.

"A Party," in which Mrs. Patrick Campbell had the star role, was unexpectedly withdrawn from the Playhouse on Saturday night after an engagement of five and a half weeks. The next attraction at that theatre is expected to be A.H. Wood's production of "Virtue on Horseback," opening the week of Oct. 16.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 -- Joseph B. Eastman, Federal Coordinator of Transportation, made it known today that he would not at this time take steps to compel a consolidation of the Pennsylvania and Long Island Railroads under a single management.

James J. Hines, Tammany leader of the Eleventh Assembly District, denied last night that he was leading an insurrection against John F. Curry, leader of Tammany, or was against the re-election of Mayor O'Brien.

NEWARK, N.J., Oct. 2. -- Mayor Meyer C. Ellenstein was authorized today by the City Commission to execute a new lease with the New Jersey Stock Exchange on the Centre Market Building, which had been picked as the site for the Exchange until the New York Stock Exchange decided not to move.

CHICAGO, Oct. 2. -- The rehabilitation commitee of the Legion convention tonight approved a four-point program it will recommend to the convention for adoption as general Legion policy. Despite the position of President Roosevelt as given in his address today, it included a statement that care of disabled veterans whose ailment was not connected with service should be provided by the Federal Government.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 -- By direction of President Roosevelt, an intensive canvass will be started almost at once to ascertain from employers over the nation what progress has actually been made in the recovery drive.

CLEVELAND, Oct. 2 (AP). -- An application of the Pennsylvania Railroad and allied interests for a permanent injunction to stop construction of a 13-mile railroad between Smith's Ferry, Pa., and Negley, Ohio, was denied today by Federal Judge Samuel H. West.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Oct. 2 -- The Westchester Board of Supervisors authorized the Park Commission this afternoon to make an engineering survey of the cost of building a municipal airport on property already owned by the county.

The three members of the National Investors group of investment trusts issued yesterday their statements for the three and the nine months ended with September. These showed that although the value of the net assets of the trusts had declined since June 30, it was higher than at the end of 1932.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 2 -- Mrs. Edward M. Biddle and her husband, a Philadelphia attorney, have separated, Mr. Biddle saying today that while he did "not wish to contradict the report" he wanted to make clear that the matter lay "entirely with Mrs. Biddle."

PATERSON, N.J., Oct. 2 -- Silk strikers staged one of the largest labor demonstrations in the history of the city today when 15,000 attended a mass meeting at the Hinchliffe Stadium and more than 10,000 of these took part in a parade over a five-mile course.

Chastened by the depression, American industry is rising to a new conception of its obligations to the public as a whole, Secretary of Labor Frances Perkins declared last night at a general session, of the National Conference of Catholic Charities at the Waldorf-Astoria.
CHICAGO, Oct. 2 -- President Roosevelt gave a straight-from-the-shoulder talk to the American Legion today at the opening session of its annual convention.

Sir Ronald Lindsay, British Ambassador to the United States, will arrive from England today on the White Star liner Majestic, accompanied by Lady Lindsay. Also on board are Sir Frederick W. LeithRoss, chief economic adviser to the British Government, and T.K. Bowley, financial counselor of the British Embassy at Washington.

PORT CHESTER, N.Y., Oct. 2 -- With Miss Maureen Orcutt setting the pace, the New Jersey women's golf team overwhelmed the Westchester-Fairfield players, 11 1/2 to 3 1/2, in the annual match at the Tamarack Country Club today.

After many delays, Major Chester P. Mills, former Prohibition Administrator for the New York area, was placed on trial yesterday in the Federal court in Brooklyn on an indictment charging him with conspiracy to divert industrial alcohol into bootleg channels.

Shoe retailers face their most promising Spring season in several years, according to opinions expressed yesterday at the semiannual style conference of the National Shoe Retailers Association at the Hotel Astor. In addition to the brighter economic outlook under the NRA program, the new colors and styles will make replenishnments of shoe wardrobes essential, it was said.
While publication of the new as- sessment figures yesterday claimed a large part of attention, the market activity reported involved several interesting deals.

CLEVELAND, Oct. 2 (AP). -- Frank Purnell, president of the Youngstown Sheet and Tube Company, announced today that improvements costing $250,000 at the Indiana Harbor plant of the company have been authorized and are to be started immediately.

HALIFAX, N.S., Oct. 2 (Canadian Press) -- Heavy earth tremors which lasted almost an hour were recorded today on the seismograph at Dalhousie University, between 11:38 A.M. and 12:30. The first disturbance was marked at 5:33 A. M., which Professor J.H.L. Johnstone said coincided with the one that shook sections of California.
Ticket sales for the world's series spurted yesterday to a noticeable degree, while the Giants and the Senators went through their final preparatory drill at the Polo Grounds.

Jesse H. Jones, chairman of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, conferred here yesterday with several bankers on the subject of sale of preferred bank stock to the RFC. He also discussed the question at a luncheon given for him by Seward Prosser, chairman of the managing committee of the Bankers Trust Company, and attended by executives of the leading downtown banks.

HAVANA, Oct. 2 -- One hundred and nineteen persons are known to have been killed and more than 200 wounded in fighting here today which brought about the surrender of the 525 army officers who have been besieged in the National Hotel since the middle of August.
U.S. Department of Agriculture. Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices at New York.

Despite the recovery, 15,000,000 persons in this country are still dependent on public relief and face a desperate Winter unless heroic action is taken. Harry L. Hopkins, Federal Relief Administrator, declared yesterday at the National Conference of Catholic Charities at the Waldorf-Astoria.

Two attempts to put stocks above the high level of August failed in September, following which a reaction set in and at the end of the month prices were near the low points of July. All the enhancement in August was canceled in the downward drift in September.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 2. -- Production of crude petroleum in the United States in 1932 amounted to 785,159,000 barrels, a decline of 65,922,000 barrels or 7.7 per cent from 1931, according to final figures made public today by the Bureau of Mines of the Department of Commerce.

PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 2 -- Frank Frederickson, former Olympic hockey player, has been appointed coach of the Princeton hockey team, it was announced tonight by Thurston J. Davies, supervisor of sports.

The sale to the public of approximately $15,000,000 securities in a dining property bought by the promoters for $700 in cash and the assumption of $15,000 in liabilities was temporarily halted yesterday in the New York County Supreme Court by Justice Louis A. Valente.

CHICAGO, Oct. 2. -- Important announcements relating to the government's efforts to advance the prices of agricultural commodities are expected soon by operators on the Board of Trade here, and it is believed they will be more important as market factors than the purchases of large quantities of grains and provisions for relief purposes.

Weakness of the dollar in foreign exchange caused an early improvement yesterday in prices on the Cotton Exchange, but an increase in hedging operations closed the list at the bottom with net losses of 4 to 9 points. For several hours all transactions were at a slight advance in quotations and trade interests absorbed contracts steadily.

One Deputy Police Inspector, six captains and a lieutenant were involved in a series of transfers and promotions in the Police Department made yesterday by Police Commissioner James S. Bolan. The Commissioner said none of the transfers reflected on the ability of the men involved, but merely resulted from the policy of making transfers from time to time.

The first hearing on the application of Westchester communities to require the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad to reduce its commutation fares by 19 per cent to the level of the New York Central rates was held yesterday in the offices of the Public Service Commission before Commissioner George R. Lunn.

HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Oct. 2. -- A. Holly Patterson, counsel to the village of Hempstead and counsel to the Second National Bank here, was nominated Republican candidate for presiding supervisor of the Nassau Board of Supervisors at the meeting of the Town of Hempstead Republican committee this afternoon.

CHICAGO, Oct. 2. -- Tribute to the part played by business men in the development of radio was paid today by Guglielmo Marconi, father of the radio, at a luncheon given in his honor by the Museum of Science and Industry.

No calls for statements of condition of banks in their charge as of the close of the third quarter had been issued by either the Controller of the Currency or the State Superintendent of Banks up to yesterday, and the opinion was expressed in banking circles that the customary calls would again be omitted.
CHICAGO, Oct. 2 (AP) -- Woodlander, racing for Mrs. Emil Denemark of Chicago, triumphed in the main event at Washington Park today, beating Kentucky Helen by five lengths over a slow track.

Virginia votes today on the Eighteenth Amendment, and there is little reason to doubt that by sundown the list of States won for repeal will number thirty-two. Governor POLLARD, long an advocate of prohibition, has announced that he will vote to end it. The voice of Bishop CANNON has been silent in the State. Competent judges of opinion predict a repeal majority perhaps as large as 2 to 1.

BERLIN, Oct. 3. -- The Boerse was dull and listless today, but on the whole, quotations were unchanged. The public maintained the utmost reserve, and in view of this fact, the comparative steadiness was taken as a favorable sign. Heavy industrials and banks generally were weaker, and business remained entirely in the hands of professionals.

Leases on two large army base piers in South Brooklyn, which have been let to the Atlantic Tidewater Terminals Company for the last ten years, will be granted to the highest bidder on Oct. 16, officials of the Shipping Board Bureau of the Department of Commerce announced yesterday.

A permanent organization to enforce industrial codes, the final step in the administration's codification program, took tentative form yesterday as President Roosevelt conferred at his home here with Hugh S. Johnson, NRA Administrator.

Some 80,000 dressmakers in the metropolitan area, members of the Internatiotial Ladies' Garment Workers' Union, will hold a "victory celebration" today to mark the recent agreement in the dress industry achieved through the mediation of Grover A. Whalen, chairman of the local NRA organization.

With hit shows arriving almost nightly on Broadway, the ticket brokers licensed by the National Legitimate Theatre Committee, the enforcement division of the theatrical code, are complaining that they are not receiving a sufficient number of tickets to meet their requirements.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 3. -- A sharp increase in miscellaneous internal revenue receipts was revealed today in the Treasury's statement covering the first quarter of the 1934 fiscal year. For the three months ended Sept. 30 these revenues totaled $362,150,000, including beer, tobacco, manufacturers excise and stamp taxes.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 3. -- Plans for the formation of the new relief corporation to carry out President Roosevelt's announced intention to feed, clothe and keep warm the destitute unemployed throughout the Winter were discussed today by Harry L. Hopkins, Federal Emergency Relief director, and officials of the Agriculture Department and Agricultural Adjustment Ad- ministration.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 3. -- A complete rearrangement of the revenue structure of the government, particularly as it relates to taxation policies, will be among the first tasks laid before the first regular session of the Seventy-third Congress when it convenes Jan. 3, it was predicted today by Chairman Doughton of the House Ways and Means Committee.

Deprived of speculative incentive, the share market continued yesterday to drift idly. Transactions on the Stock Exchange again fell short of 1,000,000 shares. Other markets were equally dull and colorless.

DALLAS, Texas, Oct. 3. -- Judge Randolph Bryant of the eastern district of Texas, sitting at Tyler, today denied an injunction sought by the Panama Refining Company to prevent regulation of the petroleum industry under the National Recovery Act.

So excellent an example in organizing its charities has been set by the Archdiocese of New York under the direction of Cardinal HAYES that he has come to be known as the "Apostle of Charity." Such beneficent "action" as he represents was never more needed than now.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Oct. 3. -- Charlotte Calthrop Weller was the daughter of Mrs. Blanche A. Calthrop of 717 University Avenue, and the late Richard Grant Calthrop, baritone, a member of the faculty of the College of Fine Arts of Syracuse University for many years.

LOS ANGELES, Oct. 3. -- Trapped in gullies and ravines where they were felled by the smoke and gases of a raging brush fire, thirty-three workmen and civilian foresters were burned to death in Griffith Park this afternoon. None of the charred bodies had been identified in the county morgue at a late hour, all victims being unrecognizable.
LA PAZ Bolivia, Oct. 3 -- Bolivia's war with Paraguay is likely to continue indefinitely, as a result of the failure of the latest peace negotiations, in the view of Bolivian officials.

The New York Stock Exchange announced yesterday that the recent stringent margin requirements had been revised to permit brokers to carry on margin stocks selling at less than $5 a share when the securities are accepted by banks as collateral for call loans.

LAUREL, Md., Oct. 3. -- Handlers of Winooka, Australian sprint star, announced late today that C.V. Whitney had consented to run Equipoise, American handicap champion, against their horse in a match race.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 3. -- Sir Frederick W. Leith-Ross and T.K. Bewley, British debt negotiators, accompanied by Sir Ronald Lindsay, the British Ambassador, arrived here late this afternoon to find that no definite plans had been made for starting the conversations with United States experts.

WESTBURY, L.I., Oct. 3. -- Polo's new open champions rode into the final round of another tournament today when Aurora scored a last-period victory over the Hurricanes on Cochran Field of the Meadow Brook Club. The score was 10 -- 9.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 3. -- How two investment trusts with a combined capitalization of $90,000,000 were formed by Dillon, Read Co. and associates, with an original investment of $5,100,000 of their money, was told to the Senate Banking and Currency subcommittee today during the examination of Clarence Dillon, head of the New York firm.

LAUREL, Md., Oct. 3 (AP). -- G.D. Widener's Jamestown, fighting his way back into the racing picture, drove to a smashing victory in the Capital Handicap, feature of the opening of the Laurel meeting today.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Your editorial "The McKee Mystery" reminds me of a hospital orderly attending patients in a psychopathic ward suggesting to the boys and girls that the "so and so" is "such and such" and not as they think, "such and so" is "so and such."
Thirteen Manhattan and Bronx properties were bought in by plaintiffs at foreclosure auctions yesterday. Scheduled sales of two properties were adjourned.

SOFIA, Oct. 3. -- King Alexander of Yugoslavia and Queen Marie reached Bulgarian waters at 4 o'clock this afternoon on the Yugoslav cruiser Dubrovnik. The vessel was met by two Bulgarian gunboats and escorted to the port of Varna, where royal saluates were exchanged with the shore batteries.

CHICAGO, Oct. 3. -- Leopold Godowsky, pianist and composer, left Chicago for Rochester, N.Y., today following an unusual attack by a large police dog in which the musician suffered a bitten lower lip.

At the first regular Fall meeting of the Chamber of Commerce of the State of New York tomorrow noon, resolutions will be submitted if dealing with public questions that have arisen in the last three months.

Charles Solomon, Socialist candidate for Mayor, sent a letter to Governor Lehman yesterday requesting the Governor to broaden the scope of the coming special session of the Legislature to include consideration of legislation to create municipal housing agencies.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 3. -- A Giant named Hubbell held a check valve upon the enthusiasm of series-minded Washington baseball fans today in the clusters that mushroomed before scoreboards.

The trial of Major Chester P. Mills of Fairfield, Conn., former Prohibition Administrator for the New York area, and seven other persons charged with conspiracy to violate the internal revenue laws by diverting industrial alcohol into bootleg channels, was continued yesterday in the United States District Court in Brooklyn before Judge Mortimer W. Byers and a jury.

The estate of William T. Schley sold to an investing client of Horn Burke, brokers, the five-story brownstone house at 17 West Fifty-second Street, between Fifth and Sixth Avenues. The building occupies a lot 20 by 100 feet near Rockefeller Center.

A fractional hardening in the Street rate on call loans to 5/8 from 1/2 on Monday was the only incident of a listless market. Stock Exchange rate remained at 3/4. Time money, commercial paper and acceptance markets were all quiet and unchanged.

Three men who said they were striking truckmen kidnapped a driver and his helper late yesterday afternoon, as they were taking a truck laden with groceries though the Williamsburg section of Brooklyn. The kidnapped men were driven to Manhattan and released a block from the headquarters of Local 138, Teamsters' Union, at 158 Rivington Street.

Samuel Seabury, head of the Fusion campaign committee, and Fiorello H. LaGuardia, Fusion nominee for Mayor, will invade the Bronx, political home of Joseph V. McKee, tonight. Both will speak at a mass meeting under the auspices of former supporters of Mr. McKee, who in this campaign have rallied to Fusion.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The effect of the various NRA codes to provide shorter working hours in almost every industry has been emphasized repeatedly in newspaper and magazine articles with the question. "What will people do with their leisure time?" The radio, the automobile, the movies and the golf course hardly supply a sufficient answer to this question.

ALBANY, Oct. 3. -- Urging a campaign against ratification of the St. Lawrence waterway treaty, the State Waterways Association adopted a resolution at its final session today calling upon Governor Lehman to put New York on record as opposed to the project.

TRENTON, N.J., Oct. 3. -- Announcement was made today by State Treasurer Middletown that New Jersey had received $12,199,000 in bonds of the Delaware River Joint Commission as its share of proceeds from sale of the Camden-Philadelphia bridge.

An increasing number of people in the United States are apprehensive of currency inflation and fearful of its results. Eight distinguished men, representing both major political parties, have approved and sponsored a series of articles presenting their viewpoint on the money problems of the day. The series is appearing in this newspaper in sixteen consecutive daily chapters. The tenth is presented herewith.

WEATHER clear, track fast. Manager Joe Cronin decided to make it a left-handed battle by tossing in Wally Stewart against Carl Hubbell. He was sorry later, but it was too late to do anything about it. By that time the Giants were one up in the series.

Mrs. Helen Wills Moody and John B. (Jack) Crawford, the Australian, are ranked as the outstanding tennis players of the world by A. Wallis Myers, internationally known British tennis expert, in his annual "First Ten of the World," received in the United States yesterday.

CHICAGO, Oct. 3. -- The American Legion, 120,000 strong, paraded before more than 1,000,000 cheering Chicagoans today, while the leaders of the conservative and the so-called radical factions met in hotel rooms to draw the battle lines for the fifteenth annual convention, which holds its first business session tomorrow.
Amateur boxing returned indoors last night when the Metropolitan Association of the Amateur Athletic Union conducted the first show of the Fall season in Madison Square Garden.

Plans for mass distribution of food from Federal stores to the needy and unemployed in the coming Winter, as a supplement to the city's own relief work, were worked out yesterday at a conference in City Hall presided over by Mayor O'Brien.

"Kultur," the play by Adolf Philipp first announced as the work of Theodore Weachter, will close an engagement of almost two weeks at the Mansfield Theatre on Saturday night. Charles Coburn is the featured player.
Count Franz Colloredo-Mansfeld and the Countess are among those sailing tonight for Channel ports on the North German Lloyd liner Bremen.

The crowd that made its way into the Polo Grounds was a cheerful, tractable one despite its size. The early birds were out in great numbers, many hundreds appearing at the bleacher entrances shortly after midnight, long before the police arrived to take up their duties.

The Giants were as happy schoolboys after their victory yesterday. Happier and more n chalant than any was the irrepressible Blondie Ryan, the first-year man on the club, whose spirit much to win the National League pennant.

Despite the fears of business men and the recent recession in trade activity, the country is definitely on the upgrade of a new business cycle, "which will be much larger and much grander than any seen in the past," Dr. Virgil Jordan, president of the National Industrial Conference Board, told several hundred manufacturers and merchants attending the style conference of the National Shoe Retailers Association at the Hotel Astor yesterday.
PRAGUE, Oct. 3. -- Czechoslovakia and Germany are growing steadily more hostile.

The Consul General of Greece is to move from 960 Sixth Avenue to the RCA Building, the Rockefeller Center organization reported yesterday. P. Paraskevopoulos, head of the consulate, is to occupy the new offices about Oct. 15.
CHICAGO, Oct. 3 (AP). -- Foxiana, racing in the colors of the Austin Stable and ridden by Jockey J. Kacala, triumphed in the feature event at Washington Park today.
MADRID, Oct. 3. -- Alesandro Lerroux's moderate government fell this evening in the Cortes by an overwhelming adverse vote, 189 to 91, after existing four weeks without a vote of confidence.
TOKYO, Oct. 3. -- Japan's cotton industry pointed to statistics today and claimed it had ended Great Britain's century-long reign as the world's greatest cotton cloth exporting nation.

Joseph V. McKee, independent candidate for Mayor, struck back last night at Samuel Seabury, leader of the Fusion forces, assailing him as a "boss" and asserting that the issue of the campaign was whether McKee, Mayor O'Brien or Fiorello H. La Guardia was best qualified to restore the government of New York City.

HELSINGFORS, Finland, Oct. 3. -- Publication of the new AngloFinnish trade pact was received here with mixed feelings. To safeguard Finnish exports of timber, paper, celluloid, butter and bacon to the British market Finland was obliged to grant tariff reductions on numerous commodities.
LONDON, Oct. 3. -- The text of Professor Albert Einstein's address in Albert Hall tonight follows:

United States Senator James J. Davis, who has denied having any knowledge of alleged lotteries conducted by the Loyal Order of Moose, of which he was director general, not only set the date for a drawing conducted by that order on Jan. 3, 1931, but was in the "drawing room shortly before winners were selected, according to evidence introduced yesterday in Federal Court.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 3. -- Sixteen registration statements filed under the Securities Act and representing more than $18,000,000 in new securities issues were made public today by the Federal Trade Commission. They bring the total amount of securities registered to $243,000,000.

President Roosevelt gave special study to a plan for reopening hundreds of closed banks, presented to him by Secretary Woodin, when the latter, in company with George L. Harrison, governor of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, called on him yesterday at his home here.
PARIS, Oct. 3. -- The French Government's public works plan came nearer to realization today when several Ministers, headed by Premier Daladier, discussed its details.

Close finishes distinguished the racing at Jamaica yesterday, one of the tightest coming in the featured Dunton Purse when A.C. Schwartz's Gay Monarch was just up to win by a nose at the end of five and one-half furlongs. Lee Humphries was in the saddle of the winner, which closed a 3-to-4 favorite in a field of six.

Sir Herbert Samuel, leader of the Liberal party in England, declared in an address here last night that "principles belonging to the age of barbarism have been adopted by Germany, a nation which was long in the forefront of progress."

The local NRA Credit Committee, organized at NRA headquarters at the Hotel Pennsylvania two weeks ago by the Clearing House Association at the request of Grover A. Whalen, city NRA chairman, has found no evidence of any credit stringency here, Mr. Whalen announced last night.

Tom Mann, veteran labor leader and Socialist, who started his work on Tower Hill, London, in 1889, with John Burns to get the dock laborer his "tanner" -- a minimum of 12 cents an hour, arrived yesterday in the third class of the White Star liner Majestic and received a hearty reception at the pier from a hundred Communists.

GENEVA, Oct. 3. -- A lively FrancoGerman debate over the Jewish question marked the opening of the annual discussion of the minorities question in the League of Nations Assembly's sixth commission this morning.

General Hugh S. Johnson, Recovery Administrator, returned to Washington last night following a conference with President Roosevelt with the pronounced intention of stopping the "quibbling" that he said resulted in renewed labor trouble in the Pennsylvania coal fields yesterday afternoon. He denounced "mob conditions" there.

Monday was Resolution Day at Albany. While the business of the Democratic State Committee was the nomination of LEONARD C. CROUCH as an Associate Judge of the Court of Appeals, a post which he now holds by appointment, pleasure may be said to have dictated the full set of resolutions adopted.

Appointment of three German educators to visiting professorships in Columbia University was announced yesterday by Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of the university. They are Dr. Paul Tillich, Professor of Philosophy; Dr. Felix Bernstein, Professor of Mathematics, and Dr. Rudolf Schoenheimer, Professor of Biological Chemistry.

Bluefish are running near this city, according to the latest reports. Anglers at Montauk over the last week-end found plenty of this species and one catch of sixty-three was reported. Another catch of eighty-three was reported from Middleground Light off Port Jefferson.

Two theatrical producing firms are claiming the services of Helen Menken. On Monday Miss Menken was announced by Abbott Dunning to appear in the star role of "The Drums Begin." Yesterday the Theatre Guild made known that Miss Menken would be seen as Elizabeth in the Maxwell Anderson play, "Mary of Scotland."

Richard F. Hoyt has retired as a partner in Hayden, Stone Co., members of the New York Stock Exchange, and has been elected vice president of the Haystone Securities Corporation. Charles Hayden, senior partner in Hayden, Stone Co., is president of Haystone Securities, a privately owned corporation engaged mainly in underwriting securities.

Exemptions from taxation are an ancient subject of controversy. Somebody is always complaining about some feature of the present system under which charitable, religious, educational and other similar enterprises are placed, under certain conditions, beyond the reach of the tax-gatherer.

The boycott of German goods must go on and those who oppose it as a "dangerous precedent" are those to whom "profit is more important than principle," Samuel Untermyer declared last night. He addressed 23,000 persons at a performance of the historical pageant, "The Romance of a People," at the Kingsbridge Armory.

BUFFALO, Oct. 3 (AP). -- The Columbus Red Birds of the American Association tonight won the Little World's Series as they defeated the Buffalo Bisons of the International League, 10 -- 2. It was the fifth victory for the Red Birds in eight games played in the minor league classic.

Some lines of the Third Avenue Railway Company system have suffered seriously because of the diversion of traffic to the new city subway lines, S.W. Huff, president of the company, declares in his annual pamphlet report to stockholders.

BETHLEHEM, Pa., Oct. 3. -- Lehigh University will hold its annual celebration tomorrow in honor of the late Judge Asa Packer, its founder. The Founder's Day address will be delivered by Dr. Hans Zinsser, Professor of Bacteriology and Immunology at Harvard University Medical School.
