HAVANA, Oct. 3. -- A general round-up of members of the ABC student revolutionary organization is going on.

Mr. LAGUARDIA'S first full-dress speech on Monday night shows that he, unlike some others, knows what it is all about. In direct and explicit form he told what is wrong with our city government and what must be done to set it right. First of all, we must decimate the Tammany army of drones and wastrels now in the municipal service.
NEW YORK. Lady Alexandra Metcalfe of London is at the Savoy-Plaza.

The heads of New York's biggest banks have agreed, subject to the approval of their directors, to cooperate with the government in its efforts to expand bank capital by selling capital notes to the public or to the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, or both.

Additional banks and trust companies issued statements yesterday of their condition as of Sept. 30. On the whole they reported no important changes from their statements of three months ago. Deposits were slightly higher in most cases. Holdings of cash and United States Government securities continued exceptionally large, indicating a maintained highly liquid status.

Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt stressed the value of expenditures for municipal recreation facilities for children, when she addressed the opening of the annual Recreation Conference at the Hotel Roosevelt yesterday afternoon.
St. Mark's Church in the Bouwerie gave to the Republic of Panama a mortgage for $17,000, due five years hence at 5 per cent, on 127 and 129 E. 10th St.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 3. -- Broadway chorus girls and motion picture exhibitors will meet in Washington tomorrow to discuss the higher wages and shorter hours which the girls are demanding before the motion picture code becomes a reality. The actresses will be represented chiefly by Mrs. Dorothy Bryant, executive secretary of the Chorus Equity Association, which includes men as well as women.

NEW ORLEANS, La., Oct. 3. -- Senator Huey P. Long is facing the fight of his life. His followers are deserting him all over the State, and, despite his usual escort of armed men, many are disposed to debate his self-imposed title of Kingfish.

The union inland terminal built and operated by the Port of New York Authority at Fifteenth Street and Eighth Avenue completed its first year of operation yesterday. It had handled more than 84,000,000 tons.

BERLIN, Oct. 3. -- Baron von Neurath, German Foreign Minister, telegraphed tonight to Chancellor Dollfuss of Austria, expressing the German Government's sympathy and gratification that the attempt to assassinate him had failed.

Estimating that in the next sixteen months corporate obligations aggregating about $1,200,000,000 will mature and almost 2,000 borrowers who will be compelled to repay them out of earnings or refund them through new offerings, Frazier Jelke Co., members of the New York Stock Exchange, issued a statement yesterday making a plea for amendment of the Federal Securities Act. They said:

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 3 (AP). -- Lester Stoefen of Los Angeles and Keith Gledhill of Santa Barbara, first and second seeded players, scored third-round victories today in the men's singles of the Pacific Coast tennis championships.

Two quiet, unassuming young men, epitomizing the spirit of the New York Giants, dominated the scene as the world's series of 1933 unfurled itself before a capacity throng of 48,000 at the Polo Grounds yesterday.

HASTINGS, England, Oct. 3. -- Sir Charles Trevelyan, Minister of Education in the last Labor Government, will introduce a resolution at tomorrow's session of the annual Labor party conference, committing the party and all British trade unions to a general strike it the British Government puts this country into any war.
BERLIN, Oct. 3 (AP). -- The Reichsbank's statement as of Sept. 30 shows the following changes in reichsmark:

LONDON, Oct. 3. -- Believing that the Anglo-Saxon peoples are true children of Israel and that King George V is a lineal descendant of David, members of the British Israel World Federation continued their annual conference in Central Hall, Westminster, today.
HAVANA, Oct. 3 -- A special guard of soldiers was placed around the United States Embassy tonight in response to what one of them said were rumors that the structure was to be bombed.

A charter of Catholic action, proclaiming the right of labor to a decent living and protection against the hazards of unemployment, accident, sickness and old age, was adopted yesterday by Catholic leaders at the National Conference of Catholic Charities at the WaldorfAstoria.

Strength in United States Government bonds in some sections of the foreign group featured an otherwise dull and irregularly lower bond market on the Stock Exchange yesterday. The turnover remained below $8,000,000. Our government's issues rallied 1-32 to 7-32 point except for the Treasury 3 3/5s due 1943, callable 1940, which held unchanged.

In an address last night, made at the invitation of General Hugh Johnson, National Recovery Administrator, Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of Columbia University, declared that the first step toward recovery was to re-establish confidence.

Sime Silverman, founder and owner of the theatrical magazine Variety, who died at Los Angeles, Calif., on Sept. 22, Jeft 300 shares of the capital stock of his company to eight of his employes and the rest of his estate to his family. This was disclosed yesterday when his will was filed in Surrogate's Court.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 (AP). -- The board of army engineers submitted a formal report to the War Department today favoring the improvement of the New York Barge Canal between. Waterford and Oswego at a cost of $27,500,000. The work would be done by the State under Federal supervision.

HAVERSTRAW, N.Y., Oct. 3. -- An abandoned freighter was lying at anchor several hundred yards offshore in the Hudson River here tonight, and seventeen members of her crew, who had rowed ashore in lifeboats, were under arrest.

Buyers' Registrations Down. Registration of visiting buyers in the market during the week ended yesterday continued to show a decrease under the figures for the preceding week and for the corresponding week a year ago. For the week 557 buyers were listed as against 855 in the previous week and 678 in the same period last year, according to the lists published in THE TIMES.

A Fusion victory in the election would assure reconstruction of the "best elements" in both Democratic and Republican parties and thus guarantee "decent government" to the city in the future, F. A. Weller, head of the Fusion speakers' bureau, told members of the Town Hall Club yesterday.
MACON, Ga., Oct. 3 (AP). -- William Lawrence (Young) Stribling, Georgia heavyweight, died at 6 A.M., Eastern Standard Time, today, of injuries received Sunday in a motor accident.

CHICAGO, Oct. 3. -- Declaring that the nation has undretaken "the most stupendous effort ever tried in all history to manufacture prosperity," President Williamson of the New York Central Railroad, praised President Roosevelt today in an address to the Safety Section of the American Railway Association.

While the peak of the apartment rental season has passed, reports from brokerage firms yesterday indicated that changes of abode with in Manhattan still are keeping the moving men busy. Yesterday's lists of new tenants showed the balance tipped slightly toward the upper east side.
Long before either the Giants or Senators had finished their prelimnary drills for the classic battles the bleachers and upper reserved tier were jammed with eager fans.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., Oct. 3. -- Colonel A.P. Gray of Arcola took a commanding lead at the halfway mark in the sixth annual Metropolitan Golf Association seniors' championship at the Montclair Golf Club today. He scored a 79 in the opening round to lead his nearest rivals by six strokes.

The remarks of President GREEN and their reception by the national convention of the American Federation of Labor are a significant expression of opinion on the question of currency manipulation. Unless he and his colleagues can be assured that wages paid in cheaper dollars would keep pace with higher prices and rising costs of living, Mr. GREEN asserted his belief that "labor will stand unflinchingly against inflation."

Plans for the development of judicial machinery under the auspices of the Federal Government for settlement of industrial disputes, prevention of strikes and elimination of all such forms of class warfare as interfere with the recovery program, were discussed here yesterday by three high government officials at a conference in the Waldorf-Astoria.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 3. -- A list of all corporations in which any partner or representative of the firm of Dillon, Read Co., or any of its agencies, is a director or officer was placed in the record of the subcommittee of the Senate Committee on Banking and Currency today.
Prices moved irregularly yesterday on local commodity exchanges, most staples showing losses. Trading volumes were further restricted. Most cash prices were lower.

LONDON, Oct. 3. -- The establishment of an international monetary standard was one of four objects named tonight by Neville Chamberlain, Chancellor of the Exchequer, when reviewing the possibilities of a revival of international trade.

Competing with the first world's series baseball game, the stock market was at a great disadvantage yesterday. Trading almost came to a halt at about 1:30 o'clock, and from then on Stock Exchange operations were conducted in a desultory fashion.

LONDON, Oct. 3. -- Sheffield today is producing a much greater tonnage of steel than before the World War, with the present output 27,000 tons more than at the same time last year, according to C.J. Walsh, the new master cutler.
DANBURY, Conn., Oct. 3. -- So many horses declared for the 2:18 pace and the 2:21 trot on the Danbury Fair card today that they were split into two divisions each, with $200 added to the purse.

TOKYO, Wednesday, Oct. 4. -- A regulation has been put into effect at Vladivostok compelling foreign shipping to employ Russian pilots. Russia has refused to exempt Japanese vessels from it, but this refusal is not accepted as final by Japan.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 3. -- The American Federation of Labor was urged today to throw the full force of its strength and prestige into a campaign for the early organization of the 5,000,000 women in industry and business.

LONDON, Oct. 3. -- Defying warnings that he might be assassinated, Professor Albert Einstein stood before 10,000 persons in Albert Hall tonight and pleaded for help for German scientists who, like himself, have been driven into exile.

A Piece of Timely Advice. Buried deep in the more than twenty volumes of the essays and letters and stories of ROBERT LOUIS STEVENSON is a bit of advice which many a man, woman or youth in reduced fortune and increased leisure will find it for that reason easier to follow.
LONDON, Oct. 3. -- The dean of Windsor, the Very Rev. A.V. Bailey, returned to England today after a six weeks' tour of the United States.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 3. -- Increased imports from nearly all the grand geographical divisions were responsible for the $23,524,631 unfavorable trade balance of the United States in August, according to a survey made public today by the Department of Commerce.

Two applications for Federal funds to be expended on projects affecting Brooklyn and Queens were forwarded yesterday to the State Advisory Board of the Federal Emergency Administration of Public Works by Maurice A. Stephenson, director of the budget.

A confession, alleged to have been made by Mrs. Cecelta McCormick at Raymond Street jail the night her husband, Andrew (Red) McCormick, shot and killed the head keeper and then committed suicide, was introduced yesterday at her trial in Kings County Court for first-degree murder.

Fiorello H. LaGuardia, Fusion nominee for Mayor, has no intention, if elected, of abandoning the so-called "four-year plan" for future city financing agreed upon by city authorities and the bankers with the aid of Governor Lehman. Legislation is now being sought by the city preparatory to putting the plan into effect.

RICHMOND, Va., Oct. 3. -- Virginia, the second State to ratify the Eighteenth Amendment, today became the thirty-second State to vote for its repeal. At the same time the voters, in a special election, approved a plan for liquor control to replace State prohibition.

MONTREAL, Oct. 3. -- While details are still lacking, the agreement reached between the protective committee for the bondholders of Price Brothers Co. and Bowater's Paper Mills of London, England, is believed in well-informed quarters to make it probable that the holders of the bonds will receive 100 cents on the dollar.
TRENTON, N.J., Oct. 3. -- "It is true that political influence was sought but there is no proof that it was bought."

MANILA, Oct. 3 (AP) -- The people of the Philippines will have no opportunity to vote in the near future on the independence offer by the Congress of the United States. Senate President Manuel Quezon, veteran campaigner for immediate independence, announced all plans for a plebiscite had been dropped, at least temporarily.

WORCESTER, Mass., Oct. 3. -- The Worcester Music Festival presented tonight Mendelssohn's "Elijah" as the second night's performance of the seventy-fourth annual festival, in the new Municipal Memorial Auditorium. More than 1,500 persons, many of them prominent in the musical world, attended the performance.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 (AP). -- Viscount d'Alte retired from the post of Minister of Portugal at "Washington on May 12, having then reached 70.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 3. -- Secretary Ickes, administrator of the oil code, declared today that the decision of the United States court in Texas was a "sweeping victory" for the National Recovery Act.

Mrs. Charlotte C. Weller, 35 years old, wife of a retired army officer, was killed at about 6:20 A.M. yesterday when she fell or jumped from a window on the nineteenth floor of the Hotel Gotham, Fifth Avenue and Fifty-fifth Street.

President Roosevelt returned to his home here yesterday to prepare a speech that he is scheduled to deliver tonight before the Conference of Catholic Charities. He came directly from Chicago, where he spoke to the convention of the American Legion.
The Board of Elections announced yesterday that paper ballots probably would be used in the Nov. 7 election instead of voting machines. The plan met with immediate opposition by Fusion leaders.

The threatened clash between the Tammany and the Bronx delegates at the First Judicial District Democratic Convention at Tammany Hall last night was averted by an agreement at an earlier meeting of the Tammany and Bronx executive committees to nominate Justices Samuel I. Rosenman, Charles B. McLaughlin and Edward R. Koch, Democrats, now sitting on the bench by appointment.

The eighty-sixth flower and fruit show of the School Nature League opened yesterday at Public School 15, Fourth Street near Avenue C, with displays of garden and wild flowers, berries and fruit on the bough.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 3. -- The shouted refusal tonight of Fayette County's insurgent coal miners to end a three-week strike frustrated the efforts of Recovery Administration officials and union leaders for a unified back-to-the-mines movement.

PARIS, Oct. 3. -- President Roosevelt's silence in his Chicago speech with regard to the future of the dollar was one of the contributory causes for its decline in Paris today to 16.20 francs, or 63.47 cents gold, a new low level.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 3. -- The special Senate committee investigating the administration of ocean mail contracts was told today by J.E. Dockendorff, president of the Black Diamond Steamship Corporation, that he paid $100,000 to William J. Donovan, former assistant to the Attorney General, for helping to block the sale of twelve Shipping Board vessels to Paul W. Chapman of the United States Lines.

PITTSFIELD, Mass., Oct. 3. -- "Continuous Blooms in the Garden" was the topic of discussion this afternoon for members of the Richmond Garden Club, who held their final meeting at the home of Mrs. Charles W. Power in Pittsfield.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 3 (AP). -- Frank Hayes, Democrat, was reelected Mayor of Waterbury today at the city election, defeating Andrew J. Cooney, Republican, by 8,579 votes.

The return of Ed Smith, star sophomore back, to action featured yesterday's three-hour practice of the New York University football squad at Ohio Field. Smith suffered a leg injury in scrimmage last week and was ordered to rest on the sidelines.

HAVANA, Oct. 3. -- Sumner Welles, United States Ambassador, continues his calm, patient attitude toward the Cuban revolution despite insistent private urgings from American residents and Cuban oppositionists for intervention.
Samuel Untermyer and the Citizens Budget Commission joined yesterday in expressing dissatisfaction with the tentative city budget for 1934, which contemplates gross expenditures of $578,888,680.
The play-by-play description of the first game of the world series follows:
WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 (AP). -- An advance in world wheat prices from "recent levels" was predicted today by the Department of Agriculture's bureau of agricultural economics.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 3. -- In the Autumn of a career that goes back well nigh forty years, Glenn Scobey Warner has come back to the East and the State in which a quarter of a century ago he won national renown as the coach of the Carlisle Indians.

"Her Man of Wax," the new comedy in which Lenora Ulric is starring, will have its Broadway premiere next Wednesday evening, Oct. 11, at the Shubert Theatre. The play, which has been adapted by Julian Thompson front the German of Walter Hasenclever, is now showing at the National Theatre in Washington.

For the first time since last February, loafs on securities made to members of the New York Stock Exchange or "Street loans," decreased in September, it was announced yesterday. The decline was $20,619,743. In August they increased by $971,340 and in July by $135,857,814.

To the Editor of The New York Times: What are the churches doing to help in this economic crisis? It will be said, with truth, that they are feeding the hungry, housing the homeless, caring for the sick, clothing the naked and providing for the orphans. In doing this, however, they but perform the duty laid upon them, by both the Jewish and the Christian dispensations.

New long-term financing for New York State of slightly less than $30,000,000 will be announced soon, possibly this week, by Controller Morris S. Tremaine for award late this month. The issue, to be offered through competitive bidding will consist of general improvement bonds, due in from one to twentyfive years; emergency construction bonds, also due in from one to twenty-five years, and grade-crossing elimination bonds, due in from one to fifty years.

Under steady pressure of hedges against the mounting receipts of the new crop, prices on the Cotton Exchange ended with losses of 9 to 12 points. December broke below 9 3/4 cents in the last hour, but liberal scale buying at each point recession created resistance.

Belden Manufacturing Company -- Six months ended June 30: Net income after depreciation, amortization and other charges, $3,456, equal to 19 cents a share on 18,680 shares. Quarter ended June 30: Net income after same charges, $72,785, or $3.90 a share, contrasted with a net loss of $69,329 in quarter ended June 30, 1933.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The letter of Francis Ralston Welsh should not be allowed to stand unanswered. In that letter, Mrs. Frederic Schoff is credited with the leadership of the child-labor movement. I leave it to "the various States" to answer for themselves how far she has affected their laws, while I reply for Pennsylvania that rather has she been with the opposition group.

IENNA, Oct. 3. -- Chancellor Engelbert Dollfuss was wounded in the right upper arm this afternoon by a bullet fired by a 22-year-old former adherent of the Austrian Nazi party. A button on the Chancellor's vest deflected a second bullet, which otherwise would have pierced his heart.
GENEVA, Oct. 4. -- The current edition of the "World Economic Survey," which was easily the test seller among all the League of Nations reports last year, appeared today.

RIDGEWOOD, N.J., Oct. 4. -- Johnny Kinder, twice holder of the New Jersey open title, scored a 70, one below par, to set a competitive course record and win the medal with a thirty-six-hole total of 145 in the Jersey P.G.A. championship at the Ridgewood Country Club today.

An elaborate fashion show with added features of diversion -- one of the first large philanthropic entertainments of the Autumn -- will be held this afternoon and tonight in the grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria to raise funds for the Emergency Tuberculosis Relief Committee and the social service auxiliary of the Metropolitan Hospital.
PITTSBURGH, Oct. 4 (AP) -- The Boston Redskins had little trouble tonight defeating Pittsburgh's Pirates in a National Professional Football League game, 21 to 6.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 (AP). -- Pat Malloy of Oklahoma told newspaper men tonight that a series of sharp differences with Attorney General Cummings had caused him to resign as Assistant Attorney General.

The strong demand for apartments, unusual at this stage of the Fall house hunting season, is resulting in the renting up of many buildings in Manhattan. Brokers and managing agents also report an encouraging volume of renewals in all sections of the city.

SEROWE, British Bechuanaland, Oct. 4. -- With as much ceremony as he had been banished from the tribal territory, Chief Tshekedi of the Bamangwato tribe was reinstated today by British authority, amid the rejoicings of his tribesmen and the approval of the many white persons in South Africa who have been sympathetic toward him.

LOS ANGELES, Oct. 4 (AP). -- A settlement out of court has ended the $250,000 "heart balm" suit filed against Alan Dinehart, Hollywood screen actor, by Betty Kaege, former Follies dancer. A dismissal of the suit was on file in Superior Court today, but terms of the settlement were not disclosed.

LONDON, Oct. 4 (Canadian Press). -- The Court of Appeals held today that restaurants and similar places using radio sets for entertainment are liable to pay copyright fees for turning in on copyright music. The decision will affect thousands of places in Great Britain.

When Catherine D.L. Parsons and two others sold to Agnes David the dwelling at 110 W. 127th St. the buyer gave back a purchase money mortgage for $6,000, to be paid in monthly instalments, at 5 per cent. The last payment is to be on Oct. 1, 1938.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 4 (AP). -- Donald Budge of Oakland, State singles champion, met defeat today in the first major upset of the forty-fourth Pacific Coast tennis championships, losing to Joe Coughlin of San Francisco, national intercollegiate doubles champion, 6-3, 6-3.

THROUGH all her days as a novelist Virginia Woolf has been straining to burst the trammels that are the accepted limitations of most writing people. In her famous Hogarth pamphlet, "Mr. Bennett and Mrs. Brown," read before the Heretics Society at Cambridge, she launched a formidable attack upon the reputation of Arnold Bennett.

Mrs. Payne Whitney's Greentree Stable gained a double at Jamaica yesterday. Soon Over scored in the featured Belgrade Purse, in which five went to the post, while Tomfoolery was the winner in the second. Mrs. Whitney's Hideho also went to the post in the fifth and ran third.

For the first time since the last quarter of 1930, a gain in telephone connections over disconnections for the entire American Telephone and Telegraph system was assured yesterday for September. The New York Telephone Company, largest operating concern in the system and accounting for about 20 per cent of the total stations, reported a rise of almost 10,000 phones for the month.

HAVANA, Oct. 4. -- Five persons, including two soldiers and a sailor, were killed today when sniping and looting broke out while Havana was being swept by a hurricane, accompanied by torrential rains.

Miss Rosalie Knapp, club champion at the Women's National Golf and Tennis Club at Glen Head, captured the low gross prize in the one-day tournament held under the auspices of the Women's Long Island Golf Association at the Old Country Club, Flushing, yesterday.

With only a few exceptions the commutation fares of the New York, New Haven Hartford were shown to be higher than those of any other railroad serving the metropolitan area, at a hearing yesterday before Public Service Commissioner George R. Lunn.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 (AP). -- Three associated New York corporations, one of which, the petition said, was formed to buy foreign estates for sale to American motion-picture stars, filed a joint petition with the Board of Tax Appeals today claiming a huge loss on a French chateau.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 (AP). -- Spurred by Virginia's 2-to-1 majority in favor of repeal and substitution of a liquor-control law for her bone-dry statute, numerous Federal agencies today hurried studies they have been making in anticipation of repeal.
Jimmy McCarron, a member of the United States Olympic team last Summer, scored two victories in the amateur boxing tournament that came to an end in Madison Square Garden last night.

PARIS, Oct. 4. -- The international jurists' commission of inquiry into the Reichstag fire met here today and reaffirmed its recent London decision regarding the innocence of all accused except Marinus van der Lubbe. The commission passed a resolution to that effect after the examination of new witnesses and new facts brought out during the Leipzig trial.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 4. -- The text of a letter from Joseph B. Eastman, railroad coordinator, to the four steel companies which produce steel rails, either directly or through subsidiaries, read as follows:

An alleged conspiracy that resulted in the murder of Michael Malloy, a derelict stationary engineer, was described yesterday by District Attorney Samuel J. Foley to a jury before Judge James M. Barrett in Bronx County Court. Four men are on trial, accused of killing Malloy for less than $2,000 insurance they had taken out on hjs life.

Testimony that Major Chester P. Mills, former prohibition administrator, on trial with seven others in the Federal Court in Brooklyn on a charge of conspiracy to divert industrial alcohol into bootleg channels, sought to purchase large quantities of completely denatured alcohol, was introduced yesterday.
Buildings formerly occupied by two leading clubs passed into new hands yesterday, one as the result of a sale over an auctioneer's block and the other in contracts announced by real estate brokers.

President Roosevelt, speaking in New York City last night for the first time since he became the nation's Chief Executive, declared that while we have proceeded part way on the road to recovery, the harder part still lies ahead.

Passenger traffic executives of the New York Central, Pennsylvania, Baltimore Ohio, Erie and New York, New Haven Hartford Railways will draw a plan for the reduction of passenger fares in the East at a meeting today in the office of L.W. Landman, passenger traffic manager of the New York Central.

With the approach of the hunting season it is natural to expect discussions regarding free shooting, posted lands, public preserves and the areas which, so far as the hunter may know, may be public or private domain.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 4. -- A new code for the motion picture industry, very different from the proposal on which hearings were held in mid-September, was presented to producers, exhibitors and distributers today by Sol A. Rosenblatt, Deputy Recovery Administrator, and was taken under consideration.

CHICAGO, Oct. 4. -- A resolution opposing American recognition of Russia was reported out of the American Legion's Americanization Committee tonight and will be before the convention for adoption tomorrow.

MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., Oct. 4. -- The Universalist State convention here witnessed a presentation today by the Rev. Fred M. Holloway, pastor of the First Congregational Church, setting forth the value of dramatizing church work.

Clashes between opposing counsel enlivened yesterday the trial of Isidor J. Kresel in the Criminal Branch of the Supreme Court on the charge he abetted in the misapplication of about $2,000,000 of the funds of the defunct Bank of United States.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 4. -- A strike of about 650 commercial air pilots, threatened for tomorrow, was averted at a conference today of fliers and transport company officials with Chairman Wagner of the National Labor Board.
Apparently those singular New York Giants, who have been trained to do such extraordinary things at the bidding of Memphis Bill Terry, have not yet run out of their store of surprises.

CLEVELAND, Oct. 4. -- Developer of the silcrome aviation valve, used in the plane which carried Colonel Charles A. Lindbergh on his epochal flight across the Atlantic Ocean from New York to Paris, Charles E. Thompson was an organizer and first president of the Glenn L. Martin Company, airplane manufacturers.
PITTSBURGH, Oct. 4 (AP) -- Two men were critically wounded and Several others were clubbed during a five-minute riot in Ambridge today as industrial chaos spread to the rich Beaver Valley.

Memphis Bill Terry had to shout his feelings of exultation in the clubhouse after the Giants' victory yesterday. For the place was a beehive of industry. Traveling trunks were being packed for the trip to Washington and well-wishers clamored up the stairs into the reception room.

NEWMAKKET, England, Oct. 4 (Canadian Press). -- No fewer than thirty-seven racers were left in when final acceptances were made today for the Cesarewitch Stakes, great Autumn handicap to be run over the two and a quarter-mile distance here next Wednesday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 4. -- The administration sent to executives of four large steel companies today a list of forty-seven railroads ready to buy 844,525 tons of steel rails and 245,221 tons of fastenings. Bids on rails at the earliest possible moment were asked.

CARDIFF, Wales, Oct. 4 (Canadian Press). -- Wales administered Scotland's second defeat in international soccer matches this season when the Welshmen withstood a furious closing attack by the Scottish to emerge on the long end of a 3-2 score.

CANBERRA, Oct. 4. -- The House of Representatives reassembled this afternoon to hear the most striking budget in Australian history. Prime Minister Joseph A. Lyons characterized it as "a reward which the Australian people have earned by sacrifices made and self-discipline imposed to meet the depression."

HOT SPRINGS, Va., Oct. 4. (AP). -- Eliminated in the singles after a hard-fought match, William Jackson Clothier of Philadelphia, national champion twenty-seven years ago, was on the winning side today in three doubles matches in the twenty-first annual Fall tennis tournament at Hot Springs.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The recent proposals to erect a great dock structure combined with an airplane landing field on the Hudson River near Twenty-third Street are about as practical and would be as "self-liquidating a project" as the Bronx Terminal Market proved to be.

HAVANA, Oct. 4. -- Cyclonic winds reaching a velocity of 60 to 70 miles an hour, accompanied by driving rains, lashed Havana, Matanzas and Pinar del Rio Provinces today. The storm, which struck Santa Clara and Matanzas Provinces last night, swerved back on the north coast today.

Scores of persons filed through the chapel of the Mother Cabrini High School at 701 Fort "Washington Avenue yesterday to pay silent reverence to the new resting place of Mother Frances Xavier Cabrini, founder and first Mother Superior of the Missionary Sisters of the Sacred Heart of Jesus.

As Magistrate Aurelio in Tombs Court yesterday was about to adjourn again until Saturday the bearing on a grand larceny charge against Nicholas Roberts, president of S.W. Straus Co., he told Eugene B. McAuliffe, Assistant District Attorney, that the testimony thus far would not warrant grand jury action.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 4. -- President Roosevelt has consented to the establishment of a "Division of Labor Service and Labor Standards" in the Department of Labor so that wage earners may obtain every facility for complete information of an economic, financial and industrial nature.

With further reduction of the 1934 budget centring on salary cuts yesterday, Mayor O'Brien refused to take responsibility for ordering the Board of Aldermen to reduce their pay from $5,000 to $2,000. He also denied that he would seek to prevent salary increases over the next four years through Municipal Assembly legislation.

A strong tide in the East River yesterday caused the three-masted wooden schooner T.K. Bentley, of 509 gross tons, to drag anchor. Drifting downstream, her stern struck E.L. Cord's motor yacht Virginia, anchored off the New York Yacht Club at the foot of Twenty-sixth Street, and the impact crumpled the yacht's port rail and stove in one of her lifeboats.
OKLAHOMA CITY, Oct. 4 (AP). -- Word came today from Denver that Federal authorities had information which they believed would reveal an attorney as the ''master mind" in the Urschel abduction plot.

BETHLEHEM, Pa., Oct. 4. -- Lehigh University honored the memory of its founder, Judge Asa Packer, at the annual Founder's Day ceremony this morning and conferred honorary degrees of Doctor of Engineering on Joseph Becker of Pittsburgh and Edwin Jay Prindle of New York and the honorary degree of Doctor of Science on Dr. Hans Zinsser, Professor of Bacteriology and Immunology at the Harvard University Medical School.

BERLIN, Oct. 4. -- The bond market on the Boerse developed unexpected strength today through renewed public interest in securities and a wave of buying sent prices up 2 per cent. Provincial bonds benefited with municipal securities. The tone of the market remained firm.

MIAMI, Fla., Oct. 4 (AP). -- A sudden change in the direction of a tropical disturbance moving northward from Cuba caused Richard W. Gray, meteorologist, to warn residents here and at other adjacent cities to take precautionary measures against whole gale winds of from 55 to 75 miles an hour late tonight or early tomorrow.

OTTAWA, Ont., Oct. 4. -- A Canadian loan of $225,000,000 will be offered to the public on Oct. 10. It will be payable in Canadian funds. The purpose is to meet $169,000,000 of 5 1/2 per cent non-taxable bonds maturing next month and $40,000,000 of short-term loans made by Canadian banks.

WEST ORANGE, N.J., Oct. 4. -- Mrs. F. Reginald Wilson of West Orange won the sweepstakes prize at the second annual flower show of the West Orange Woman's Club at the Ridgeview Community Church, here. She won 11 points.

Trading on the New York Stock Exchange was interrupted at 2:15 P.M. yesterday, while Richard Whitney, president of the Exchange, read from the rostrum resolutions adopted by the governing committee praising the work of the late Samuel F. Streit, president of the Stock Clearing Corporation, who died on Tuesday night.

A warning that "the United States can only remain autarchic if it is willing to go socialistic" was sounded last night by the Marquess of Lothian, who was political secretary to Premier Lloyd George during the World War, before sailing for England on the Berengaria.

PARIS, Oct. 4. -- There was a general slump on the Bourse today. Although trading on margin is severely restricted here, a selling movement began this morning and prevailed throughout the session. It was attributed principally to the dumping of collateral by professional traders who were forced to meet pressing engagements.

Flying false colors and with the painted name of an innocent vessel still fresh on her sides, a smuggler's freighter slipped through the harbor Monday night with a cargo of 25,000 cases of Canadian liquor valued conservatively at $1,000,000.

To the Editor of The New York Times: First, let's be fair. Let's use a more sensible word -- namely, expansion "inflation" is a "dyslogistic" term, obviously circulated to block true money reform at the start. BanK credit might with some Justice be called "inflation," for it is so impalpable as to consist of mere figures on a bank ledger.

Bluntness at Geneva. Before a committee of the League of Nations at at Geneva yesterday the new German race philosophy came into a head-on collision with British rule of thumb. After listening to the exposition of German views about pure Aryans, c., the British delegate declared that England was unable to understand the theories and purposes of Chancellor HITLER.

When transactions on the Stock Exchange jump from 932,000 shares on one day to 2,127,000 shares on the next, there must be some reason, Wall Street concluded yesterday. The sudden renewal of speculative activity may have been due to several incidents, but more than anything else it indicated, so far as could be learned, that traders had judged that the market was again a "buy."
DANBURY, Conn., Oct. 4. -- Favorites prevailed in all five races on today's card at the Danbury Fair.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 4. -- Evidences of "wire pulling and favoritism" which recalled to the chairman the Teapot Dome investigations were spread on record today before the special Senate committee investigating the ocean mail contract system of the last twelve years.

Progress of City Campaign. Samuel Seabury, with Fiorello H. LaGuardia and other Fusion candidates, carried their campaign last night into the Bronx, home borough of Joseph V. McKee and Edward J. Flynn.

There were gray skies overhead and a chill in the air at the Polo Grounds yesterday when the crowd at the second world's series game, not so large as on opening day, had settled down to see what the Giants could do to the Senators.
CHICAGO, Oct. 4. -- The American Legion was preparing tonight to ask Congress for a gift of $50,000,000 a year to "World War veterans as a substitute for immediate cash payment of the bonus.

RICHMOND, Va., Oct. 4 (AP). -- Virginia repealists maintained a majority of nearly two to one tonight as returns from yesterday's dual referendum on national and State prohibition came in from remote precincts.

Measured in British currency, the price of gold bullion went on Tuesday's London market to the highest price in history. Before suspension of gold payments in 1931 the London quotation was 84 shillings 9 pence per ounce for gold, or nearly the price which the Bank of England had been required to pay under the now suspended statute.
A suspect in the theft of $131,000 worth of securities from the mail of the United States liner Leviathan last February was in the line-up at Police Headquarters yesterday.
U.S. Department of Agriculture. Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices at New York.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., Oct. 4. -- Adding an 85 to his opening 79, Colonel Alex P. Gray of Arcola won the sixth annual metropolitan seniors golf championship with a thirty-six-hole total of 164 at the Montclair Golf Club today.

SHANGHAI, Oct. 4. -- An admission that governmental unsecured loans had piled up because of military costs, despite claims to a balanced budget, is contained in official dispatches from Nanking to the effect that the Executive Yuan has approved an issue of $100,000,000 in Treasury notes.

Ex-Senator WATSON'S favorable prognosis and full set of prescriptions for the recovery of the Republican party have been almost rudely neglected by some of his patients. Professional jealousy among the other volunteer medicos may account in part for that discourtesy.

The Federal Government, which in the past has concentrated its investigations of income tax dodgers on racketeers, turned yesterday to traders in the stock market. Wall Street customers formed the first target.

This city campaign ought not to be permitted to drop into a contest between metaphysicians and masters of dialectics. Just now there is a good deal of that sort of thing going on. Mr. McKEE, for example, makes a fetching retort to Judge SEABURY, much in the spirit of a medieval logician.
A partial recovery from recent low levels occurred yesterday in most of the local commodity markets as the volume of trading improved. Cash quotations were irregularly higher.

DETROIT, Oct. 4. -- Seven Detroit automobile manufacturers in an announcement today set Friday as the deadline for the return to their jobs of tool and die makers who are now on strike and for whom there is work.

All sections of the bond market gained ground yesterday in trading on the New York Stock Exchange that rose to above $10,500,000. Railroad bonds led in the domestic corporation list, while strength in the foreign group was fairly general. United States Government bonds rose 1-32 to 7-32 point.

BOSTON, Oct. 4. -- "The greatest threat to the success of the program to raise cotton prices by control of production in this country is found in cotton production abroad," said Alston H. Garside, economist for the New York Cotton Exchange, in an address today at the opening of the annual meeting of the National Association of Cotton Manufacturers.

With entries coming in steadily and many advance reservations for boxes being made, this year's National Horse Show will merit the name "Golden Jubilee" in every respeet, it was stated yesterday by Manager Edward King.

Directors of banks here began yesterday to vote on the proposal to issue capital notes to the public or the RFC or both. Meeting's were held by the Chase National Bank, the Guaranty Trust Company and the Corn Exchange Bank Trust Company.

VIENNA, Oct. 4. -- Chancellor Dollfuss awoke this morning after an excellent night of rest and recuperation to celebrate his forty-first birthday to the sound of the bells of St. Stephen's Cathedral calling for a thanksgiving service for his escape from assassination.

LOS ANGELES, Oct. 4 (AP) -- The county grand jury will start investigation tomorrow of an alleged plot to disfigure the face of John Warburton, English movie actor, District Attorney Buron Fitts announced today.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 4. -- The first formal attempt of any governmental war debtor of the United States to seek revision of existing agreements will begin tomorrow morning.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 4. -- Eleven members of the firm of Dillon, Read Co. realized in the boom market of 1928 and 1929 a profit of $6,819,270.26 on the sale of common stock of the United States and Foreign Securities Corporation for which they paid $24,110.40, according to testimony obtained today by the Senate Banking and Currency Committee from Robert E. Christie Jr., a member of the firm.
The play-by-play description of the second game of the world's series follows:
Mrs. Cecelia McCormick took the stand in her own defense yesterday at her trial in Kings County Court for first-degree murder.

PRINCESS ANNE, Md., Oct. 4 (AP). -- Honoring the memory of the Rev. Francis Makemie, who arrived in 1683 to found five churches on the eastern shore of Maryland, Presbyterians today commemorated the 250th anniversary of the denomination in America by a pilgrimage to the churches and his grave.

Dr. William J. O'Shea, Superintendent of Schools here since May 1, 1924, will be retired automatically on Jan. 31, when, the present school semester ends, according to an announcement last night by officials of the Board of Education.
PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., Oct. 4. -- Greentree came through a fast, rough game of polo today on the Sands Point Field to reach the final of the Monty Waterbury Memorial Cup tournament.

Representatives of the member lines of the Atlantic Passenger Conference will meet today in Paris to consider proposals for the adjustment of passenger rates and the re-classification of cabin ships. The conference held several meetings in London early in August and adjourned to consider proposals advanced by member lines.

Mindful of the rush staged on Tuesday, when 12,000 persons clamored for the 4,000 bleacher seats that were on sale, the police took elaborate precautions yesterday to forestall a similar occurrence. Inspector Thomas Leahy of the Sixth Division was in charge of the police arrangements and had 10 sergeants, 10 mounted policemen and 150 patrolmen under his command.

LONDON, Oct. 4. -- Colonel and Mrs. Charles A. Lindbergh landed at the Woolston Airport in Southampton at 5:10 this afternoon from Stavanger, Norway, in the seaplane in which they made a recent survey flight of the Greenland air route in behalf of the Pan American Airways.

CHICAGO, Oct. 4. -- "Sad Sam" Jones was the "Happy Warrior" today as he silenced the Cubs' siege guns with a six-hit pitching performance to send the White Sox out in front in the opening game of the city series with a 3-to-2 victory.
LAUREL, Md., Oct. 4 (AP). -- George D. Widener's Kings Minstrel, ridden by Jockey Don Meade, cleverly defeated seven other 2-year-olds in the outstanding event on the Laurel racing card today.

A public expression of the views of Mayor O'Brien, Joseph V. McKee and Fiorello H. LaGuardia regarding rapid transit unification and the city's participation in the Interborough receivership case has been sought by Samuel Untermyer, special counsel for the Board of Estimate on transit and related matters.

Members of the New York City Federation of Women's Clubs, at their forum on public utilities at the Hotel Astor yesterday, heard attacks upon the utilities as "unwilling to deal fairly with the public." They were also asked to aid in obtaining a law to put "teeth" in the Public Service Commission's powers.

Final details of the plan for reorganization of the local NRA under the program recently worked out in Washington between General Hugh S. Johnson, National Recovery Administrator, and Grover A. Whalen, local NRA chairman, were completed yesterday at a conference at NRA headquarters in the Hotel Pennsylvania attended by all the NRA borough chairmen.

LEIPZIG, Oct. 4. -- Attmepts to link Marinus van der Lubbe, confessed Reichstag incendiary, with his alleged accomplices emphasized the weakness of the prosecution's case when the trial was resumed this morning in the Supreme Court here.

Morris S. Tremaine, State Controller, announced yesterday that he had set Oct. 24 as the date for opening sealed bids on the new financing for the State aggregating $29,500,000. The offering will be in three separate issues: $10,000,000 of general improvement, $10,000,000 of emergency construction and $9,500,000 of grade-crossing elimination bonds.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In THE TIMES of Oct. 3 is an article by William Allen White, who in a previous article had spoken of Stalin as a "benevolent" dictator. Mr. White now says that Russia wants recognition "only for purposes of trade." Probably Mr. White's informant was the man who told him that Stalin was benevolent.

Trade Gain Spotty This Week. Cooler weather has brought some improvement in retail trade this week, but the gain over the two preceding weeks has been quite spotty as between departments and individual stores, reports here yesterday indicated.

GENEVA, Oct. 4. -- For the country that first told the world "if an opposition did not exist it would have to be invented," William G.A. Ormsby-Gore took up in the League of Nations Assembly commission dealing with minorities here today "the challenge of Dr. Goebbels," the German Minister of Propaganda, in calling Parliaments obsolete.

A "victory celebration" to mark the conclusion of the recent agreement in the dress industry by which the sweatshop was abolished and comprehensive wage and working improvements were obtained by 80,000 workers in New York and vicinity was held yesterday by the International Ladies Garment Workers Union.

The need for additional aid for unemployed musicians was presented yesterday by Walter Damrosch before sponsors of the Musicians Emergency Fund, Inc., at a luncheon in the Hotel St. Regis. Mr. Damrosch also announced the programs for four of the five festival concerts to be given under his direction at Madison Square Garden for the benefit of the fund.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 4. -- Formation of the Federal Surplus Relief Corporation, suggested by President Roosevelt to help deal with the needs of the destitute unemployed, was announced today by Harry L. Hopkins, the Emergency Relief Administrator.

New York has seen nothing more "impudent or hypocritical than the belated appearance" of Joseph V. McKee as a reformer, Norman Thomas, Socialist leader, declared in a radio debate last night over Station WEVD with Oswald Garrison Villard, publisher.

A charge that the government of the Republic of Colombia is relaxing its restrictions on foreign exchange to further its foreign trade and has not made any provisions for debt service on the $80,000,000 of Colombian departmental and municipal bonds held by American investors was made yesterday by Lawrence E. deS.

Three American diplomats are arriving today from Europe on the steamship Manhattan of the United States Lines. They are Gilchrist Stockton, Minister to Austria, who is accompanied by Mrs. Stockton; Herman Bernstein, Minister to Albania, and Edward E. Brodie, Minister to Finland.

President Roosevelt boarded a special train, on which he is making his return trip to Washington, in Jersey City late last night after a day in which he remained at his home here and was visited only by two persons, Postmaster General Farley and Henry Bruere, president of the Bowery Savings Bank.

Additional local banks and trust companies yesterday issued statements of their condition as of Sept. 30, although no calls for reports had been made yet by the State or national banking authorities. The reports indicated a continued high degree of liquidity on the part of the banks, but some decline in holdings of United States Government securities, due to the purchases made by the Federal Reserve Banks.

A nation-wide program to provide recreation for workers whose hours have been shortened under the NRA was advocated last night by Park Commissioner John E. Sheehy. He spoke at a supper dance at the Roosevelt Hotel under the auspices of the Recreation Conference, sponsored by the Park Department.

A court room on the third floor of the old Federal Building echoed with laughter yesterday at the opening of the defense of Senator James J. Davis and Theodore G. Miller, on trial for alleged violation of the Federal lottery law.

BUENOS AIRES, Oct. 4. -- Finance Minister Frederico Pinedo is being bombarded with petitions from commercial and industrial organizations setting forth arguments why he should or should not raise prices by depreciating the value of the peso.

Sir FREDERICK LEITH-ROSS ana Mr. T.K. BEWLEY have arrived in Washington to discuss with representatives of our Government the British war debt. This procedure is a consequence of the exchange of notes last June. Making then a partial payment of $10,000,000, the British Government requested an opportunity " to enter upon formal negotiations for an ultimate settlement "of the whole debt question."

Along with a quickening of speculative interest, a smart rally occurred yesterday on all the important markets. The most emphatic recovery took place on the Stock Exchange, where both stock and bond prices were advanced sharply. The agricultural commodities displayed moderate strength and the dollar advanced against all the foreign currencies.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 4. -- In order to establish an accurate statistical service on purchasing power of the country, a new system for the collection and publication of information has been worked out at the Department of Commerce.

BOSTON, Oct. 4 (AP). -- Bishop William Lawrence of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of Massachusetts took the opportunity today on the eve of his fortieth anniversary as a Bishop to contemplate prohibition and the NRA.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 (AP). -- The National Recovery Administration today undertook the responsibility for preventing any hardship that may be caused by loss of a child's job through an NRA code, at the same time issuing absolute instructions to all local boards that exceptions to the prohibition on child labor must not be granted.
Improved business conditions continue to result in the leasing of larger space by firms in Manhattan.

DANBURY, Conn., Oct. 4. -- Celebrating its semi-centennial, the Danbury Agricultural Society was rewarded by the largest entry it ever has received for its annual dog show. Just 519 dogs were on the benches today when the fiftieth exhibition threw open its doors, the total entry being 582.
Prices on the Cotton Exchange improved about 1-5 cent a pound at one time yesterday and ended 9 to 12 points higher.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., Oct. 4 -- Establishing a new record for the tournament, Mr. and Mrs. J. Laroque Anderson of the North Hempstead Country Culb won the husband-and-wife tourney of the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association today.

The dollar rallied further yesterday to 64.84 per cent, of its par value, up 38 points from Tuesday's final price. In conformity with the dearer dollar, the Treasury reduced its selling price for newly mined gold 33 cents an ounce to $31.79.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 4. -- The Mississippi Drainage Area Board held its first hearing today when Governor Pinchot of Pennsylvania, Mayor John S. Herron of Pittsburgh and other Pennsylvanians urged the allotment from the public works fund of $51,000,000 for flood control on the Allegheny and Monongahela Rivers.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 4. -- Rejection of the proposed sugar stabilization agreement in its present form will be recommended to President Roosevelt by Secretary Wallace.
Park Avenue will join with the prize ring tonight to form a combat organization to conduct canvasses and guard the polls for the Fusion ticket, it was announced yesterday at Fusion headquarters.

The city-wide ticket headed by Joseph V. McKee, independent Mayoralty candidate, was completed yesterday. James I. Cuff, a Brooklyn lawyer, was selected as candidate for Controller and former State Senator Nathan Straus Jr. of Manhattan for President of the Board of Aldermen.
The Board of Elections received nominations yesterday by the Fusion group and by seven minor parties for various offices in the Nov. 7 election.

CHICAGO, Oct. 4. -- A belief that President Roosevelt would announce his monetary policy in his speech tonight in New York, combined with the sharp advance in stocks, resulted today in an increase in speculative buying of wheat.

Tobey, the sad-eyed French poodle that was Ella Wendel's closest companion and for years slept in a special little bed in her bedroom and ate at a tiny table near the red velvet covered table at which she ate, is dead.
The weekly weather report of the United States Weather Bureau follows:

PATERSON, N.J., Oct. 4. -- A delegation representing workers, manufacturers and civic groups will go to Washington Monday to attend the hearing on the cotton finishers' code, it was decided at a conference here today. The delegates will seek to have wage provisions of the code raised to a point where it will no longer be profitable for cotton finishers to take business from silk dyers.

THE five-and-ten series continues. The Giants made their usual ten hits and the Senators stuck to their ration of five. But the diet doesn't seem to suit the Senators. They are two down and the Giants are telling them that the series is just half over.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 4. -- The diehard band of Washington baseball fans received their twice-defeated Senators home tonight with cheers that had warmth if not tumult.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 (AP). -- The "flat wallet era" is ended, General Johnson declared in a letter made public today urging leading manufacturers and advertisers to participate actively in the buy-now campaign starting next week.

The Rev. Frederick H. Sill and his triumphant Kent School crew, which won the Thames Challenge Cup at the historic Henley Regatta, were feted at a testimonial dinner at the Columbia University Club last night. Close to 400 guests were present, among them notables from many walks of life.

Testimony concerning details of the sale, of a half interest in the stock of the Columbia Broadcasting system by Le Paramount Publix Corporation and the existence of a surplus in the treasury of the motion picture corporation at the ne of the sale in March, 1932, was rred yesterday at a hearing bee Henry K. Davis, Federal eree in bankruptcy, at his ofes in 140 Nassau Street.
WEST POINT, N.Y., Oct. 4. -- There's an entirely new football set-up at West Point this year, but it is not the Army team.
GENEVA, Oct. 4. -- William G. A. Ormsby-Gore, British League of Nations delegate, in challenging the German view of the Jewish question before the Political Commission of the League today said:

NEW YORK. Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence Lewis Gillespie will give a dance on Dec. 8 in the grand ballroom of the Pierre to introduce to society their daughter, Miss Eileen S.S. Gillespie. Before the dance Mrs. Gillespie and Mrs.

LOS ANGELES, Oct. 4. -- Police today arrested Robert D. Barr, 29 years old, an unemployed motion-picture operator, on suspicion of arson in connection with the fire which swept a 1,000-acre tract in Griffith Park yesterday, killing twenty-seven persons.

The orchestra of the Philharmonic-Symphony Society opens its ninety-second season at Carnegie Hall tonight, with Bruno Walter returning for his third season as conductor. The program tonight will include Beethoven's "Coriolanus" overture and "Pastorale" Symphony and Brahms'a First Symphony.
Several Jersey City flats were included in the New Jersey realty turnover reported yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 4. -- The Bureau of Navigation issued the following orders today, dated Oct. 2:

Ed King, substitute guard on the Columbia football squad, probably will start at tackle against Lehigh on Saturday, it was announced yesterday at Baker Field. King was on the first team in place of Joe Palenchar, who was nursing an injured shoulder.

Sharply criticizing the banking fraternity for its lack of constructive leadership, Senator Pat Harrison of Mississippi told members of the Tanners Council of America yesterday that industry cannot improve if banks refuse to take care of its legitimate credit needs.
Five men escaped from the penitentiary on "Welfare Island in two prison breaks, eighteen hours apart, it became known yesterday.

The Board of Transportation is now in the market for a loan from the Federal Government. It asks $25,500,000 to complete eighteen additional miles of city subways. Hitherto Chairman DELANEY has been a trifle diffident in this matter. When others rushed to Washington, he held back.

The orchestra of the Philharmonic-Symphony Society opens its ninety-second season at Carnegie Hall tonight, with Bruno Walter returning for his third season as conductor. The program tonight will include Beethoven's "Coriolanus" overture and "Pastorale" Symphony and Brahms'a First Symphony.
Several Jersey City flats were included in the New Jersey realty turnover reported yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 4. -- The Bureau of Navigation issued the following orders today, dated Oct. 2:

Ed King, substitute guard on the Columbia football squad, probably will start at tackle against Lehigh on Saturday, it was announced yesterday at Baker Field. King was on the first team in place of Joe Palenchar, who was nursing an injured shoulder.

The National Conference of Catholic Charities ended its nineteenth annual meeting at the Waldorf-Astoria last night with the election of the Very Rev. Mgr. R. Marcellus Wagner, director of Catholic Charities in Cincinnati, as president for the coming year.

The preliminary poll conducted by The Literary Digest of the Mayoralty campaign, without the name of Joseph V. McKee included on the ballot, revealed that Fiorello H. LaGuardia, Fusion candidate, was leading Mayor O'Brien almost five to one, it was announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 -- Charges that distressing conditions existed in the Southern Illinois coal field as a result of the non-compliance of bituminous operators with the NRA code were filed with Attorney General Cummings today.

Aided largely by a long list of store deals, renting of space in business buildings formed the bulk of realty trading yesterday. Many of the larger store leases were closed in the midtown section of Manhattan.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 -- Turning to the subject of investment trust portfolios, the Senate Banking and Currency Committee today sought to ascertain the relationship of their directors who have other investment or market interests to their responsibility as directors of the trusts.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 -- Conflict within the National Recovery Administration on whether the "check-off" is an integral part of the recent agreement worked out by General Johnson for operation of steel companies' "captive" mines in Western Pennsylvania has placed the NRA in an embarrassing position.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Your chief criticism of Mr. McKee's entry into the Mayoralty race is identical with the majority of censure emanating from other sources -- namely, that "he is dividing the anti-Tammany forces, thereby making it possible for Mr. O'Brien to be re-elected."

LEIPZIG, Oct. 5 -- Scathing attacks against the International Jurists Commission that investigated the Reichstag fire and placed the responsibility for it on the National Socialists were launched before the German Supreme Court today at the treason trial of Marinus van der Lubbe and four others.

Leigh Hunt, a pioneer realty and mining developer in several countries, college president, newspaper owner and editor, died suddenly yesterday afternoon of a heart attack while seated at his desk in his office at Las Vegas, Nev., according to an announcement by relatives in this city.

CHICAGO, Oct. 5 -- The American Legion put itself on record today as favoring sound money, demanded cancellation of interest on veterans' loans and expressed sharp disagreement with one of the principles of veterans' relief enunciated by President Roosevelt Monday at the opening session of the national convention.

Consolidating its New York offices in one of the largest leasing transactions of recent weeks, the Shell Union Oil Corporation has taken nearly five entire floors in the seventy-story RCA Building in Rockefeller Center. The deal, involving more than 100,000 square feet of office space at an aggregate rental in excess of $5,500,000, was announced yesterday by the renting organization of the $250,000,000 business and amusement development.

The epidemic of strikes in New York City is abating and indications for the present are that the general situation is becoming normal, although possibilities of conflict between capital and labor cannot be regarded as exhausted, Grover A. Whalen, chairman of the local NRA organization, announced last night in making public a survey of the situation.

HAVANA, Oct. 5 -- Despite pressure from some student and professor elements, the Students Directorate declared today that it had resolved to continue its control over the government and carry out its revolutionary program. The decision was made at an all-night session.

Speaking at a dinner of the Young Republican Club at the Town Hall Club last night, F.H. LaGuardia, Fusion nominee for Mayor, said that the entry of Joseph. V. McKee, former President of the Board of Aldermen, independent candidate for Mayor, was prompted by a desire by James A. Farley, Postmaster General, to build up a personal machine to make himself Governor of this State and, in 1940, President of the United States.

E.K. Gordon, vice president of the Knott Management Corporation, yesterday announced the purchase by the Knott Hotel interests of the twelve-story Cornish Arms Hotel, 311 West Twenty-third Street, at Eighth Avenue. This well-known Chelsea district hostelry was bought from the Corn Exchange Bank, which acquired it in foreclosure last August.

An increase of 19.1 per cent in gross revenues reported by 149 Class 1 railroads to the Bureau of Railway Economics for August brought the gross revenues for the first eight months of the year to within 3 per cent of those for the same period last year.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 -- Inspired doubtless by the presence of President Roosevelt, who with 26,000 other residents of the capital braved a lot of bad weather that for a time threatened to wash out everything, the Senators today caused the early trend of the 1933 world's series to go sharply into a reverse.
The fate of Mrs. Cecelia McCormick, who is on trial for first degree murder in Kings County Court, will be in the hands of the jury by tonight.

HAZLETON, Pa., Oct. 5 (AP) -- George T. Brown, a New York lawyer, died here today at the home of his sister, Miss Mary E. Brown. Another sister, Mrs. Martha Everet of New York, also survives. Mr. Brown was 64 years old.

While the share market was slow in its action yesterday, the belief in Wall Street was that something of interest was being developed, but possibly without immediate speculative appeal. The market huzzas were not sung so enthusiastically as they might have been.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 -- The American Federation of Labor moved toward a crisis today when a resolution was proposed at the annual convention providing for a strategy board of seven which would be empowered to meet the challenge presented to the federation's present structure and its method of organization by the extraordinary wave of unionization.

Mr. NEVILLE CHAMBERLAIN'S recent statement of the four main, objectives of Great Britain's economic policy merely repeated what he has said before. They are, the Chancellor declared, a rise in wholesale prices, removal or lowering of oppressive trade barriers, resumption of international lending and establishment of an international money standard.

NEW YORK. Miss Barbara Stokes Baxter has returned from Norway, where she visited friends during the Summer, and is with her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Frederic Baxter in Mayfair Lane, Greenwich. Miss Baxter is a debutante of the season, and will be introduced to society by her parents in New York during the Winter.

To the credit of the American Legion must be set its refusal to be stampeded into another claim for immediate cash payment of the bonus. Representative PATMAN proposed that it make such a demand and offered a plan for payment in flat money. His project was rejected both by a special subcommittee and by the committee on legislation.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 -- The dally average volume of Federal Reserve Bank credit outstanding during the week ended Oct. 4, as reported by Federal Reserve Banks, was $2,426,000,000, an increase of $34,000,000, compared with the preceding week and of $184,000,000, compared with the corresponding week in 1932.

Dr. Louis Blumm, a Queens physician, was killed early today when he was struck by a bullet fired by a policeman at two Negroes, traffic violators, whose automobile was traveling behind Dr. Blumm's on Lenox Avenue, between 119th and 120th Streets.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 -- Ferdinand Pecora, counsel for the Senate Banking and Currency Committee investigating stock market practices, accepted an invitation from Joseph V. McKee today to become a candidate for District Attorney of New York County on the independent ticket.

A court order will be sought today to compel the Board of Elections to accept the certificates of nomination of five Republican candidates for the Supreme Court in the First Judicial District, composed of New York and Bronx counties.

American seamen made plans at two meetings last night to fight the wage schedules which the American Steamship Owners Association has submitted to the National Recovery Administration. The International Seamen's Union sponsored a meeting of sailors, firemen and cooks at 70 South Street and the National Association of American Seamen met at 164 Eleventh Avenue.

CHICAGO, Oct. 5 -- Yesterday's bulge in wheat on the Board of Trade was more than wiped out today by a break in prices. At no time were quotations as high as yesterday's closing figures and the finish was at the bottom, with net losses 1 1/2 to 1 3/4 cents a bushel.

Business in the money market failed to develop a feature. Day loans on the Stock Exchange remained at 3/4, with street money at 1/2 @ 5/3. Offerings were plentiful enough, but demand light. Maturity money, commercial paper and acceptances were steady in quiet trading.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 -- The administration took cognizance today of the march of prohibition repeal when the Treasury Department sent to collectors of internal revenue throughout the country a list of the taxes and import duties to be imposed upon re-legalized liquors.

According to present plans, the stage version of the Kaufman-Ferber play. "Dinner at Eight," will end its road tour at the Grand Opera House, Chicago, on Oct. 21, after a run of nineteen weeks in that city. The company will disband and Constance Collier, one of the principal players, will depart for London to appear in a revival of Noel Coward's play, "Hay Fever," to be staged by the author.
SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 5 (AP) -- Seeded players performed up to expectations for the most part today as the quarter-final matches were completed in the forty-fourth Pacific Coast tennis championship.

RYE, N.Y., Oct. 5 -- Playing for the first time in the tournament, Mrs. Clarence H. Vanderbeck of Philadelphia, a former national champion, today went into a threestroke lead in the tenth annual women's senior national championship.

Despite the vagaries in movements of stock and commodity prices yesterday the bond market on the Stock Exchange displayed good strength in all departments. The gains in the United States Government group ranged from 1-32 to 7-32 point, while in domestic corporation bonds the maximum recoveries amounted to a point or two.

The dollar declined yesterday 14 points in gold valuation to 64.70 cents, measured against the French franc. Weakness in the United States exchange against the goldstandard currencies was more than matched by the pound sterling, however, so that the dollar valuation of that currency fell 7/8 cent net to $4.75 5/8.
A resolution describing the municipal economy program as a first step toward retrenchment, and demanding additional economies, was adopted yesterday by the Citizens Budget Commission.
Code 2945/10, Municipal Court, Personal Service, Assistant Clerk: 48 at 4,000 (3730); $179,040. -- Executive Budget, 1934.
In announcing the completion of his ticket, Joseph V. McKee, independent candidate for Mayor, made the following statement:

Jacob Gould Schurman Jr., Fusion candidate for District Attorney of New York County, declared yesterday that the nomination of Ferdinand Pecora to run against him on the McKee ticket was meaningless so far as the real issues of the campaign were concerned.

GENEVA, Oct. 5 -- Senator Henry Berenger of France moved a resolution in the political committee of the League of Nations today that greatly strengthened France's previous proposal that the League Assembly reaffirm its minorities resolution of 1922.

Mrs. Henry R. Butler, one of the respondents at a State Labor Department hearing yesterday on the complaint of live employes of the Roosevelt Democrats for LaGuardia League, Inc., that they had failed to get pay due them, caused a stir during the hearing.

BIRMINGHAM, Oct. 5 -- Tory anxieties over the future of the British Empire were the keynote of the Conservative party conference which opened at Birmingham today in the presence of 1,800 cheering delegates.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 -- President Roosevelt returned to the White House this morning to plunge into conferences on the credit and monetary situation, of prime importance to his recovery program.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 -- Negotiations looking to a rearrangement of the British war-time debt to the United States were begun at the Treasury Department this morning, but the opening session proved little more than a formality. It was indicated that future monetary policies of the two governments would play an important part in any decisions reached.
PARIS, Oct. 5 (AP) -- The weekly statement of the Bank of France shows the following changes in francs:
WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 EARL WHITEHILL used the whitewash brush in a large, left-handed manner and gave the Giants a light Fall coat. It was no bargain.

DETROIT, Oct. 5 (AP) -- Form players at the Fair Grounds track were blanked today as seven straight long shots galloped down in front at varying odds with the favorites usually running right out of the money.

CHICAGO, Oct. 5 -- Albert A. Baroni's 4-year-old gelding, Yonkel, was an easy two-and-a-half-length victor in the featured Hobby Purse at Washington Park today. Polydorus, a heavy favorite, was second. Aladdins Dream took the show.

WILMINGTON, N.C., Oct. 5 -- The barkentine Bear of Oakland, supply ship of Admiral Richard E. Byrd's second expedition into the Antarctic, sent out a call for assistance early this morning off Frying Pan Shoals, when strong head winds cut her speed down to two miles an hour, and this afternoon the tug Blanche, responding to the call, towed her into Southport.

Wholesale Orders Up Slightly. A slight improvement in wholesale demand for merchandise has developed, but the gain has not been enough to end the lull which has featured major ready-to-wear and accessory trades during the last three weeks.

On a single bid of $750,000, the forty-four-story skyscraper at 10 East Fortieth Street was knocked down yesterday at a foreclosure auction sale to a bondholders' committee. The Chase National Bank, as corporate trustee, brought the foreclosure action against the 10 East Fortieth Street Corporation and others to satisfy a $5,737,811 lien.

"Inspector Charlie Chan," adapted by Valentine Davies from a novel by Earl Derr Biggers, will have its Broadway premiere on Tuesday evening, Oct. 17, at the Fulton Theatre. The play is being produced by Sigourney Thayer and is now running at the Broad Street Theatre in Philadelphia.

The McKee campaign has worked itself out of its first period of uncertainty. Whether a complete city ticket would be made up was long in doubt. There was talk of endorsing one or more of the Fusion candidates, but that proposal was blocked by their absolute refusal.
ITHACA, N.Y., Oct. 5 -- It has been ten years since the chimes of Library Tower last pealed out a merry threnody in celebration of an all-victorious football season for Cornell.

LONDON, Oct. 5 -- Members of the Atlantic Shipping Conference will meet again tomorrow in an effort to find a solution in the dispute over the rates charged for passage in cabin-class ships. For two days a subcommittee has been seeking a settlement, but it is understood the United States representatives are resisting the proposed classification.

The electric companies of the Consolidated system, asking the Public Service Commission yesterday to vacate its order for temporary rate reductions, cited net increases of $12,607,000 in expenses. Opposing vacation of the order the city filed a brief showing a net decrease in the companies' operating expenses of $3,047,794.

LONDON, Oct. 5 -- The British Admiralty announces that a contract for the construction of the convoy sloop Bittern, the first vessel of the 1933 program, has been placed with the John Brown Company of Clydebank. This contract is being let six months earlier than had been expected.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 -- Official entertaining at the White House this Winter will be marked by a maximum of cordial good fellowship at minimum expense, according to plans announced today by Mrs. Roosevelt.

Frederick Barber Campbell, New York attorney, who was the first man in the United States to be indicted for failure to report his holdings of gold to the Treasury Department, as required by act of Congress and by executive orders of President Roosevelt, was accused yesterday in a superseding indictment of actual hoarding as well.

AMBRIDGE, Pa., Oct. 5 -- Behind a barrage of bullets, tear gas and swinging riot sticks, 200 deputy sheriffs charged a disorderly picket line at the Spang-Chalfant Seamless Tube Company's plant late today, killing one man and wounding at least fifteen others.

A reaction followed Wednesday's gain in yesterday's trading on local commodity exchanges. Prices for future contracts in all markets closed substantially lower on the day. The volume of trading was reduced. In the cash markets also quotations declined except tin, which was higher.

To the Editor of The New York Times: There is a letter in your issue of Sept. 30 by Henry W. Taft severely criticizing various expressions made use of in our current speech which itself raises some questions.

BOSTON, Oct. 5 -- Boston paid tribute today to Bishop William Lawrence of the Protestant Episcopal Church when St. Paul's Cathedral was thronged with Bishops, clergy and laity in honor of his fortieth anniversary in the episcopate.

VIENNA, Oct. 5 -- While Chancellor Engelbert Dollfuss received official visitors and carried on government business while in bed today the State police were unearthing definite proof that his assailant, Rudolf Dertil, was a National Socialist.

One of the most important transportation questions in the United States today is uniform regulation of interstate buses and trucks. There are forty-nine different sets of regulations, including that of the District of Columbia. They relate chiefly to dimensions, licensing and taxation.

Bruno Walter opened the 1933-34 season of the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra last night in Carnegie Hall. The distinguished conductor received a greeting pf special warmth and duration when he appeared. That he would have been cordially welcomed under any circumstances goes without saying, but no doubt the demonstration received added impetus from the fact that Mr. Walter is one of the great artists who have been driven from Germany by Hitlerism.

In none or the speculative markets was Wednesday's advance extended enough yesterday to attract attention. Stocks were turned around with great uncertainty and there was an uneven decline in the commodity markets. Measured by closing prices, the results were not altogether satisfactory; certainly they did not live up to the market promises of the day before.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 -- The Giants were not disheartened by today's shut-out defeat when they trooped into the clubhouse after being held to five hits by Earl Whitehill.

BERLIN, Oct. 5 -- The Hitler government made public today the text of its National Press Law, under the terms of which every working newspaper man in Germany becomes a servant of the State. He will be licensed as such through membership in the National Press Federation and will be held morally and legally responsible to the State for his professional activities.

Probably 500,000 to 1,000,000 men will receive employment by the beginning of Winter on projects under the Federal Government's public works program, according to an independent country-wide survey made by The Engineering News, Record to be published today.
LONDON, Oct. 5 -- Official and diplomatic London rang with praise today for the courageous speech delivered by William G.A. Ormsby-Gore before, the League of Nations Minorities Commission at Geneva.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I have read with great interest the articles "Money and Inflation" appearing daily in your columns. I hope before the authors of these articles finish their task they will not overlook defining "Sound Money." Just what is sound money?
