To the Editor of The New York Times: Mr. Hussey's statement that "the law of 1932 expressly limited the deduction of a net loss for the year 1931 to the taxable year 1932" is correct. But his conclusion -- "so that such a loss would have no bearing on the taxable year 1933" -- is incorrect in respect to fiscal years ending in 1933.

CHICAGO, Oct. 5 -- Prices for hogs today here were 10 to 20 cents a hundredweight lower than yesterday, although 50 to 60 cents higher than last week's close. Pour days' receipts for the regular trade at eleven markets were 102,000 head less than a week ago.

A reception for more than 200 old customers, many of them in their seventies and eighties, and twenty-six employes who have been with the store for more than twenty years was given yesterday afternoon by the Hearn Department Stores, Inc., in West Fourteenth Street in connection with the concern's 106th anniversary celebration.

LONDON, Oct. 5 -- Colonel and Mrs. Charles A. Lindbergh spent their first night in England on their present aerial tour at the Botleigh Grange Hotel in a village about six miles from Southampton, where they landed yesterday. They left early today before the other guests in the hotel were awake.

BOSTON, Oct. 5 -- The securities division of the Department of Public Utilities has barred from sale in Massachusetts the 5 1/2 per cent cumulative preferred stock of the Solvay American Investment Corporation.

Flights of geese have been sighted winging southward over various sectors along the New England Coast within the past two days. However, none of the observers along the Connecticut shore -- one of the resting places where this species of wild fowl would be expected to land -- has noted any flights taking refuge.

The Bronx Democratic organization, which previously had endorsed Mayor O'Brien and his associates on the Tammany ticket, voted yesterday at at meeting of the Democratic executive committee to support Joseph V. McKee and the other candidates on the independent Democratic ticket.

An increasing number of people in the United States are apprehensive of currency inflation and fearful of its results. Eight distinguished men, representing both major political parties, have approved and sponsored a series of articles presenting their viewpoint on the money problems of the day. The series is appearing in this newspaper in sixteen consecutive daily chapters. The twelfth is presented herewith.

A series of weekly radio talks on "The Crisis in Municipal Finance" under the sponsorship of the Committee of Civic Education by Radio of the National Advisory Council on Radio Education and the American Political Science Association was announced yesterday.
Two keepers in the Welfare Island penitentiary were suspended by William J. Cahill, Commissioner of Correction, yesterday for failure to prevent the escape of five prisoners on two successive days.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 -- President Roosevelt turned baseball fan today and drove in a drizzling rain to Griffith Stadium, where he tossed out the first ball and saw Washington score its first victory of the world's series.

An all-day entertainment with divertissements to please all sorts of tastes was held yesterday in the Grand Ballroom of the WaldorfAstoria to raise funds for the Social Service Auxiliary of the Metropolitan Hospital and the Emergency Tuberculosis Relief Committee.

There is a New York sequel to the pioneer events of 250 years ago celebrated in Maryland on Wednesday. The Rev. FRANCIS MAKEMIE, who founded five Presbyterian churches on the Eastern Shore of that colony, beginning in 1683, and who is regarded as the organizer of the Presbyterian Church in America, came to New York in 1707.

Traffic executives of the principal Eastern railroads drew up yesterday a proposal for passenger fare reductions and immediately transmitted copies to their respective presidents, who will take up the question at a meeting of the Eastern presidents' conference next week.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 -- The play-by-play description of the third game of the world's series follows:

BERLIN, Oct. 5 -- Stocks again slumped today as buying converged on the bond market. Most favorites showed losses against yesterday. Siemens Halske dropped 5 per cent and prices for minings and industrials generally lost anywhere from three-quarters of 1 per cent to 3 per cent as against yesterday's closing levels.

Mayor O'Brien delayed action on three city bills involved in the city's agreement with its bankers yesterday, while Republican members of the Legislature were reported ready to block further financial relief for the city unless they could obtain relief for Monroe County.

HARRISBURG, Ill., Oct. 5 -- Six companies of the National Guard enforced an armed truce here this evening after lifting the siege of Mine 43 of the Peabody Coal Company, during which sixteen men, including three non-combatants, were wounded.
Mayor O'Brien asked 3,000 men and women who attended a Young Democratic Association rally last night at the Astor to re-elect him on his record.

Voting Joseph V. McKee, independent Democratic candidate for Mayor, a member, the State Chamber of Commerce at a meeting yesterday dissolved a committee it had appointed to work with the Fusion organization and approved a resolution supporting transit unification and a self-sustaining fare.

Additions to the cast of the Ziegfeld "Follies," which will go into rehearsal today under the direction of Bobby Connolly, are Vilma and Buddy Ebsen, Eunice Quidens, Jack Pepper and Tommy Mack and the Rocke Twins. Sketches have been contributed by Fred Allen, Norman Anthony and H.I. Phillips.

THE guns of the Somme and the Marne have long been silent, but the guns are still thundering in the war over the character of David Lloyd George, the first volume of whose "War Memoirs" (Little, Brown, $4) is published today. One does not easily forget the passionate indictment of the "Welsh Witch," "the femme fatale" of the Peace Conference, published last Spring by John Maynard Keynes in his "Essays in Biography" (Harcourt, Brace).

A grand jury investigation to determine what connections there may be between Tammany politicians and racketeers was pledged yesterday by Justice Frederic Kernochan in case he is elected on the "Fusion ticket as a judge of the Court of General Sessions.

More than thirty clubs in the midtown area have been asked by the subcommittee governing the sale and distribution of theatre tickets for the national legitimate theatre committee to support its campaign in eradicating ticket abuses. To that end a discussion will be held between the representatives of the clubs and the subcommittee next Monday in the offices of the League of New York Theatres.

LONDON, Oct. 5 -- The stock markets were more cheerful today, helped by better American news. Outstanding was renewed strength in British funds, on success of the New Zealand loan, which was heavily oversubscribed after being open only a short time, the books closing at 9:35 A.M. Internationals rallied, reflecting the improvement in Wall Street yesterday.
GENEVA, Oct. 5 -- Senator Henry Berenger, discussing Germany's racial and minorities contentions before a League of Nations committee today, said:

HASTINGS, England, Oct. 5 -- The 1,000 delegates to the annual British Labor party conference, representing about 8,000,000 voters, stood in silence at the opening of today's session in memory of fellow-workers in Germany who had lost their lives under Nazi repressions.
Following are reports of the condition of banks as of Sept. 30, which were received yesterday, giving the principal items and comparisons with a year ago:

WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 -- Night hotel conferences held by officials of the Black Diamond Lines, against the instructions of Chairman Black, were a theme at the hearing today before the special Senate committee investigating ocean mail subsidies.

The abolition of lawlessness, the promotion of temperance, and the elimination of profit motives in liquor sale were listed by John D. Rockefeller Jr. yesterday as the aims which should be sought in liquor control legislation after repeal.

Following the revolt from Tammany yesterday of Democratic leaders in the Bronx, Mayor O'Brien emphatically denied reports that he had asked for the immediate resignation of every Bronx leader holding a city position.

Bernard Leahy was a busy man yesterday. Two guards took him from the Tombs to an undertaker's establishment in West Sixty-first Street, where the remnants of the old Gopher gang of the west side paid their last respects to his brother, Joseph (Spot) Leahy, who was stabbed to death last Sunday.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 -- The War Department issued the following orders today:

A seasonal rise of $57,000,000 in money in circulation during the week ended on Wednesday was shown in the weekly report of the Federal Reserve System, published yesterday. This extra currency demand over the beginning of the month more than offset the influence of further purchases of $35,000,000 of United States Government securities by the Reserve banks in the week, so that member bank reserve balances were drawn down $73,000,000.

PARIS, Oct. 5 -- The annual automobile show opened in the Grand Palais today. Fewer American cars are being exhibited than in any previous year since the war. This does not mean that the Paris salon has lost any of its prestige or "its primacy as an international motor car exposition," in the opinion of Charles F. Kettering, vice president of General Motors.
Henry L. Mencken is soon to sever his connection with The American Mercury, it was disclosed last night by his publisher, Alfred A. Knopf.

GENEVA, Oct. 5 (AP) -- There can be no lasting improvement in the world's economic situation, the Economic and Financial Commission of the League of Nations Assembly reported today, unless the countries are prepared to abandon "the system of closed national economies."

BERLIN, Oct. 5 -- The Reich today threw out the window the principle of the freedom of the press as understood in America, set up the death penalty for the circulation of treasonable articles and placed German newspaper workers under the thumb of the authorities.

PARIS, Oct. 5 -- The Radical Socialist party, which provides the majority of the members of the present French Government, opened its annual congress at Vichy this morning. With the Parliament scheduled to convene within two weeks and a budgetary crisis threatening the franc and hence the economic structure of France, the entire country will have its eyes on Vichy during the next four days.
ASBURY PARK, N.J., Oct. 5 -- The annual convention of the New Jersey League of Municipalities opened tonight with a dinner attended by prominent national and State officials.

MIAMI, Fla., Oct. 5 (AP) -- Having struck Havana and given a glancing blow at South Florida, an erratic storm of gale strength is headed eastward across the Atlantic Ocean tonight by way of the Bahama Islands.

Columbia applied the finishing touches to its offensive manoeuvres yesterday at Baker Field in preparation for its opening encounter with Lehigh tomorrow. During two hours of the three-hour session, Coach Lou Little concentrated on speed and blocking on the attack.

Insurance agents told yesterday how attempts were made to collect insurance on the life of Michael Malloy, a derelict engineer, who was murdered last Feb. 22 with illuminating gas, according to the police. The agents took the witness stand before Judge James M. Barrett in Bronx County Court, where four men are on trial, charged with killing Malloy to get less than $1,800 insurance.

A warning on the dangers of currency inflation was voiced yesterday by Senator Joseph T. Robinson of Arkansas, who returned with Mrs. Robinson yesterday on the United States liner Manhattan. The Democratic leader said he had gone abroad primarily for a rest, but had given considerable attention to studying monetary problems, and he was convinced that currency inflation, "as commonly proposed," was likely to do more harm than good to the cause of recovery.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 -- The Fere Marquette Railroad, following complaints of labor unions, has formally adopted a hands-off policy in connection with the formation of unions within the organization, it was announced today by Joseph B. Eastman Coordinator of Transportation.
LONDON, Oct. 5 (AP) -- The weekly statement of the Bank of England shows the following changes in pounds sterling:

TOKYO, Oct. 5 -- The latest sign of the grave unrest that still exists among the younger naval officers was seen in the resignation today of S. Yamada as chief of the judicial bureau of the Navy Office.
Miss Faith Whitney gave a dinner last night at the Central Park Casino for Miss Mabel Smithers and B. Bonner Bowring, who will ba married tomorrow in Locust Valley, L.I. The other guests were:

After a temporary improvement bank clearings turned downward again in the week ended on Wednesday and fell slightly below the total for the corresponding week last year, according to Dun Bradstreet, Inc. For twenty-one leading cities clearings aggregated $4,792,901,000, against $4,847,458,000 last year, a drop of 1.1 per cent.

Support for the NRA buying campaign, starting next Monday, has been pledged by 130 trade and industrial organizations representing 130,000 retailers in New York City, it was announced yesterday at local NRA headquarters at the Hotel Pennsylvania, by William H. Ingersoll, chairman of the NRA Committee on Advertising.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I have read the editorial "Tax Exemptions" in THE NEW YORK TIMES and regard it as a convincing argument for continued tax exemption of our churches, those bona-fide charitable organizations, and our parks and schools, which have so unquestionably proved themselves a rich blessing and whose one claim to existence is service without personal or corporate monetary profit.

Proliferation of Genius. On the editorial page of The Montreal Gazette reference to "the powerful Chairman McFarley" amazes for the moment an American reader. What region of the world isn't full of that name, so disfigured?

The 100th anniversary of the publication of a book which made medical history -- Dr. William Beaumont's famous work on gastric juice and the physiology of digestion -- was celebrated last night at a special meeting at the New York Academy of Medicine.

RIDGEWOOD, N.J., Oct. 5 -- Favorites moved into the third round of the New Jersey P.G.A. championship at the Ridgewood Country Club today. Clarence Clark, State open champion, sank a sixtytwo-foot putt on the final hole to win from Dick Metz, Pennsylvania open champion, by 1 up, in the best match of the day.

To refute the charge that Senator James J. Davis, of Pennsylvania made a profit in 1931 through the sale of lottery tickets by members of the Loyal Order of Moose, of which he was Director General, Charles H. Tuttle, his attorney, began his defense yesterday by putting a fellow Moose on the witness stand.

DANBURY, Conn., Oct. 5 -- Champion Walnut Challenger, noted airedale terrier owned by Fred H. Hoe of New Brunswick, N.J., will go down in canine history as the best of more than 500 dogs which broke all records in point of numbers at the semi-centennial exhibition of the Danbury Agricultural Society.

PARIS, Oct. 5 (AP) -- General Nicholas Yudenitch, commander of Russian forces in the Caucasus during the World War and one of the leaders of the White Russians against the Reds in the revolution, died here today. He was 71.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 -- An antiinflation group is forming among Senators to combat efforts of the inflation bloc headed by Senator Thomas of Oklahoma.
The code of fair competition for the motor vehicle retailing trade, signed by President Roosevelt on Tuesday, was made public here yesterday.

LONDON, Oct. 5 -- Attempting to surpass Fred Archer's record, established in 1885, of riding 246 winners in a flat racing season, Gordon Richards, Britain's champion jockey, in the past three days has ridden twelve winners in succession, a feat unprecedented in British turf history.
CHICAGO, Oct. 5 (AP) -- Old Urban Faber today showed the Cuba why he is still pitching in the American League after twenty years of service.

George H. Bostwick's Garden Message was rather neglected in the five-horse Eldorado Claiming Handicap at Jamaica yesterday, but outclassed his rivals over a sloppy track. At the end of the mile and seventy yards the son of Messenger was coasting five lengths in front of Help Me, the outsider in the betting.

Among the passengers arriving today on the Cunard liner Aqultania are H.C. Blackiston, director of the Furness-Withy Steamship Company, accompanied by Mrs. Blackiston; Mrs. Gerald Campbell, wife of the British Consul General; E.H. Sothern, retired actor, with his wife, the former Julia Marlowe; Ida A.R. Wylie, novelist, and Jackie Held, 9-year-old musician.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 (AP) -- Officials of the Public Works Administration, replying to a resolution proposed to the American Federation of Labor convention, said today that work was under way on projects totaling $400,000,000, and that by the middle of October that figure would be swollen to $500,000,000.

Services marking the Jewish festival of tabernacles, Succoth, were held yesterday in temples and synagogues throughout the city. The holiday began at sundown Wednesday and will continue until Oct. 13.

MOSCOW, Oct. 5 -- That Northeastern Russia and Northwestern Siberia are getting warmer has just been discovered by the Soviet Arctic expert, N.G. Datsky, in a recent visit to the north coast of Russia and Siberia. The phenomenon is attributed to a gradual recedence of the polar ice-cap to the north of Russia.

Transformation of the former home of the New York Club at 20 West Fortieth Street, near Bryant Park, into an office building of unusual interior desgn for the sale and display of well-known brands of whisky will be made at a cost of $75,000 to $100,000, it was learned yesterday.

Moving swiftly toward completing a city-wide organization and with constantly increasing assurances of support, Joseph V. McKee, independent candidate for Mayor, announced yesterday the completion of his ticket by naming candidates for Borough Presidents of Manhattan, the Bronx and Richmond and for District Attorneys for New York and Bronx Counties.

ROME, Oct. 5 -- Donato Battelli, a friend of Premier Mussolini, with whom Battelli attended school, has been held in strict custody in a prison here since Sept. 2 on charges of complicity in a spy plot, it was revealed tonight.

RIDGEWOOD, N.J., Oct. 6 -- Johnny Kinder, golf pro at Jumping Brook, and Victor Ghezzi of Rumson will play the thirty-six-hole final match for the New Jersey P. G.A. title at the Ridgewood Country Club on Sunday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 -- The National Labor Board was enlarged from seven to eleven members today by President Roosevelt at the request of Chairman Wagner, who told him that the press of work made this necessary.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In a letter to THE TIMES John H. White likens guaranteeing by the government of bank deposits in all banks, both the well-conducted and the ill-conducted, to an insurance company accepting both bad and good risks indiscriminately.

The dollar regained some of its recent losses yesterday. In extremely dull dealings it advanced against all important foreign exchanges to close at 65.21 per cent of its former value, up 51 points on the day.

Mrs. James Roosevelt, mother of the President, has issued invitations for a meeting to be held under the auspices of the New York Committee of the National Cathedral Association at her home in Hyde Park, N.Y., Wednesday afternoon at 3 o'clock.

SOUTH ORANGE, N.J., Oct. 6 -- Miss Claire W. Faitoute's wellknown chestnut gelding Old Gold was the outstanding performer in the thirteenth annual Orange Horse Show, which started today on the grounds of the Orange Lawn Tennis Club.

M. Maldwin Fertig, regular Democratic candidate for President of the Board of Aldermen, announced yesterday that he "was no longer a candidate," and urged all of his friends to lend their support to Nathan Straus Jr. and all of the independent ticket headed by Joseph McKee.

Production of steel in the United States in September amounted to 2,310,982 tons, according to the American Iron and Steel Institute. This compared with 2,900,611 tons in August and 3,203,810 tons in July, which was the largest output for any month since August, 1930.

Minor irregularities characterized trading in most of the bond issues at all active on the Stock Exchange yesterday. As usual, the price variations in infrequently traded issues were fairly wide. United States Government bonds were strong until about midday and closed irregularly, 2-32 point lower to 5-32 point higher.

Under the heaviest selling in the last few months prices on the Cotton Exchange broke more than 1/4 cent a pound yesterday and ended at a loss of 21 to 29 points and with all months below the 10-cent level.

MINEOLA, L.I., Oct. 6 -- After deliberating nearly eleven hours a jury in the County Court here returned early this morning a verdict convicting James J. McCabe, City Clerk of Long Beach and Re- publican leader of that city. He was accused of willfully and wrongfully refusing and omitting to turn over the proper official moneys collected in his office in June, 1932, from health licenses.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Oct. 6 -- The team of Syracuse sophomores that saw its chance fumbled away for the greater part of the 1932 season will run out on Archbold Stadium tomorrow against Clarkson, eager to make amends for those manual transgressions and to prove that this time it is as good as it looks.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 -- The Giants whooped it up in their clubhouse after today's game for the first time since the world's series started. They had cause for jubilation and they celebrated accordingly.
COMMERCIAL PAPER. Yesterday. Thursday. For the best names. . . 1 1/4 % 1 1/4 % The quotations are for three-four months' paper.

Despite the improvement of business which has occurred in many countries during recent months, the Economic and Financial Commission of the League of Nations holds that full recovery requires abandonment of the present system of "closed national economies."

These orders were issued yesterday: Deaths Announced. Fireman 1st grade Harry Loewenstein, of Engine 233, died Oct. 5. Funeral will take place from the funeral parlors of George Peth, 15 Palmetto St., Borough of Brooklyn, at 9:45 A.M., Monday, Oct. 9. Interment at Lutheran Cemetery.

The local NRA organization has received 12,044 complaints of alleged violations of the President's Agreement and NRA codes, it was announced yesterday by Grover A. Whalen, city NRA chairman, at his headquarters at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 -- Increasing employment in Canada was reported by the Department of Commerce today in its weekly survey of foreign business conditions, based on advices from its commercial attaches abroad. The report by countries, in part, follows:

Vital statistics are the most important of all census data. An individual will find a birth certificate handy to prove the validity of a contract, or his right to vote, or to marry, or to obtain a pension or a passport. Accurate offi- cial information regarding deaths is equally desirable for the widow seeking to collect insurance.

PARIS, Oct. 6 -- The idea that the United States and her policy toward Japan have been instrumental in encouraging friendly relations between France and Russia was advanced today in the leading editorial in the newspaper Quotidien.

The sixth year of broadcasting music appreciation concerts to the school children of the country was inaugurated yesterday by Dr. Walter Damrosch over the WEAF-WJZ coast-to-coast networks. Dr. Damrosch thanked inventors and engineers for improvements made in broadcasting equipment in the last year.

The acquittal of PETER ZENGER in the trial for seditious libel in 1735 is generally considered the cornerstone of the liberty of the press in America. GOUVERNEUR MORRIS said that it revealed the philosophy of freedom of thought and speech as "an inborn human right "so nobly set forth by MILTON'S "'Treatise on Unlicensed Printing.'"

WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 (AP) -- President Roosevelt announced today that the first concrete move in his newest effort to raise commodity prices and increase farm purchasing power would be the immediate creation of a credit corporation to lend to farmers on crop security.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 -- Officials of the Treasury Department are planning to resume on Monday negotiations for the rearrangement of the wartime debt of Great Britain to the United States.

Exchange of checks at the leading clearing houses of the country in September totaled $19,748,181,276. This was a loss of 4.6 per cent from the preceding month, and of 4.1 per cent compared with September, 1932.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 6 -- Harvard's varsity and freshman cross-country teams started their season today by turning back two teams from Holy Cross. The varsity won 19 to 36, while the freshmen scored a 20-to-35 victory.

Traders who might ordinarily have been interested in the share market were distracted again yesterday by the baseball contest. As a result, prices were allowed to drift slowly downward after the grain markets had turned sour.

LOS ANGELES, Oct. 6 (AP) -- The grand jury today indicted Martin Block and Russell Brown on a robbery charge in connection with what the police say the two confessed was a plot to mar the handsome features of John Warburton, a movie actor.
The market value of shares listed on the New York Stock Exchange declined $3,939,951,135 in September, or almost the same amount as the value had increased in August, it was announced yesterday.

The North German Lloyd and Hamburg-American steamship companies, whose sale of passage in exchange for "blocked" marks aroused the member lines of the Transatlantic Steamship Conference last Spring and threatened disruption of the conference, have been fined $113,000 and $69,000 respective by Emil Lederer, sole arbiter of conference disputes, it was learned yesterday.

A resumption of activity in the municipal bond market is expected next week, when new issues aggregating $12,967,706 come up for award. This week new bonds for $8,938,996 were scheduled for award, but most of them failed to attract bids.
DANVERS, Mass., Oct. 6 -- Two sensational defensive plays gave the Fordham freshman football team a 9-to-7 victory over St. John's Prep School today in the dedication game of the new Prep Stadium.

MIAMI BEACH, Fla., Oct. 6 (AP) -- Information accidentally picked up in a Washington speakeasy has led to the arrest of James Melville Williams in connection with the $80,000 armed robbery of the Anglers Hotel here Feb. 4, Detective Sergeant Eugene Bryant said today.

Hyman Schorenstein's alleged inability to read and write has no bearing whatever on his fitness for holding the office of Commissioner of Records in Brooklyn, Supreme Court Justice George H. Furman in Brooklyn ruled yesterday.
Bed and Bedding Manufacturers Board of Trade. Inc., second floor in 407 4th Av. Lawrence-Williams Co., fourth floor in 166 5th Av.; Cuyler Co., brokers.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 -- Uncertainties cloud the economic outlook, according to a survey of business by the American Federation of Labor issued today. Capital goods industries are lagging, the report says, and consumptive prices are rising, with purchasing power not equal to higher living costs and credit facilities very tight.

Chase Mellen Jr., newly elected Republican leader of New York County, told the Women's National Republican Club last night that there was no room for "statesmen" within the ranks of the party in Manhattan.

CHICAGO, Oct. 6 -- Liquidation developed today in the grain markets on the Board of Trade and until the closing bell corn, oats, rye and barley declined. There was no heavy selling, but a steady stream of small orders came into the pits from scattered holders and finally uncovered stop-loss orders.

WILKES-BARRE, Pa., Oct. 6 -- Over the protest of his parents, surgeons at General Hospital today amputated the leg of 14-year-old Pawl Popwichak of Hudson, who was said to be facing death from gangrene following an injury to his hip.

LOCUST VALLEY, L.I., Oct. 6 -- Society of the North Shore arrived early at the ringside to see the opening classes of the thirty-first annual Piping Rock Horse Show, which is taking place today and tomorrow at the showgrounds of the Piping Rock Club.
CHICAGO, Oct. 6 -- A message from President Roosevelt was read here today at the final session of the annual convention of the National Safety Council.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 -- When in trouble call on Hubbell.

Joseph V. McKee is opposed to an adequate educational system and in office would "demand a ruthless slashing of the city's educational budget and social services generally in order to increase profits by reducing tax bills," Charles Solomon, Socialist candidate for Mayor, charged last night.

The general pace of trade has become perceptibly slower, reports from nearly all parts of the country this week emphasizing a slackening of activity in both centres of production and distribution, according to the weekly review of Dun Bradstreet, Inc.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 -- Suddenly appearing today before the Senate committee investigating stock-market practices, Patrick J. Hurley, former Secretary of War, offered to produce Howard Colwell Hopson of New York, whom agents of Ferdinand Pecora have sought to subpoena in connection with a prospective inquiry into the Associated Gas and Electric Company.

BUENOS AIRES, Oct. 6 -- Argentina's negotiations with the United States for a new trade agreement based on reciprocal customs concessions have been undertaken with less optimism and fewer illusions than have accompanied any of its other negotiations.
Some of the "nicest, sweetest" people Dr. Margaret Mead knows strangle superfluous babies and marry their daughters off at 8 years of age.

OTTAWA, Ont., Oct. 6 -- The new $225,000,000 Canadian refunding loan will be divided into three series: two, six and twelve years. The two-year bonds will yield 3.75 per cent, the six-year bonds, 4.20 and the twelve-year bonds, 4.35 per cent, it was announced officially tonight.

GENEVA, Oct. 6 -- The League of Nations subcommittee dealing with the Dutch proposal on German refugees recommended to the Assembly's second commission today as "matter of urgency" appointment by the League of a high commissioner for refugees who should have "the fullest freedom of action."

A conference of employer and employe representatives in the dress industry has been called by Grover A. Whalen, City NRA Chairman, at NRA headquarters at the Hotel Pennsylvania this morning at 10 o'clock to try to avert a reopening of the controversy that resulted in a strike of 60,000 workers.

Money market wag dull. Street money on day loans was done at 1/2 @ 5/8, as prevoiusly, but the official trading on the board remained at 3/4. Other sections of the market showed no change in quotations.

CRACOW, Poland, Oct. 6 -- Twelve regiments of Polish cavalry, at least 10,000 mounted men, passed in review today on the great public common outside Cracow before the Polish President, Ignaz Moscicki, and the man who really rules Poland, Marshal Pilsudski.

LONDON, Oct. 6 -- Only a few hours after Germany's rejection of three-power disarmament proposals today, Stanley Baldwin, Lord President of the Council, gave the German Government the most pointed official warning it has had from any British Minister in many months.

LONDON, Oct. 6 -- The embattled Tory die-hards, led by Lord Lloyd and Winston Churchill, were routed by more than two to one at Birmingham today when they tried to swing the Conservative party conference against the government's India policy.

Joseph O. Eaton of Cleveland gave a dinner last night in the small ballroom of the Pierre for his stepson, Winsor Brown French 2d, whose marriage to Miss Margaret Hall Frueauff will take place this afternoon in St. Bartholomew's Church.

ASHEVILLE, N.C., Oct. 6 (AP) -- A charge that an attempt was made to bribe Solicitor Zeb V. Nettles in the prosecution of Gus Langley, convicted here recently of the slaying of Lonnie G. Russell, filling station operator, was made today at a hearing called for presentation of evidence looking toward granting Langley a pardon.

While the duck season on Long Island will not open until Nov. 1, there are many indications already that the hunting in that sector will ba good. Flight ducks already have reached the south shore of the island, many species having landed in the Jones Beach sanctuary maintained by the Long Island Park Commission.

Mrs. Cecilia McCormick was found not guilty last night of first degree murder in providing the revolver with which her convict husband, Andrew McCormick, killed a keeper in an attempt to break jail. She was temporarily insane, a blue-ribbon jury in the county court, Brooklyn, decided after ten hours of deliberation solely on her mental condition.

EDWARDSVILLE, Ill., Oct. 6 -- Six kidnappers of August Luer Alton banker and meat packer, were denied new trials by Judge D. H. Mudge in the Madison County Circuit Court this afternoon, after he had heard arguments of lawyers who filed motions for the defendants.
The Citizens Budget Commission said yesterday that at least $250,000 could be saved by cutting payrolls in the five Sheriffs' offices in the city without impairing the service.
PITTSBURGH, Oct. 6 -- Duquesne University continued its unbroken string of victories by defeating Bucknell, 6 to 0, at Forbes Field tonight.
NEW YORK. Mr. and Mrs. John Alexander Rogers have returned from Peterboro, N.H., to 169 East Seventyeighth Street.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 -- Up to the 1st of October plans had been approved for the reorganization of 376 unlicensed national banks in thirty-seven States, J.F.T. O'Connor, Controller of the Currency, announced today. Aggregate frozen deposits of these banks amounted to $398,735,000, and unrestricted deposits totaled $31,151,000.

An effort will be made by Arthur M. Oberfelder, a prominent Western showman, to restore the road to its former glory. Mr. Oberfelder, who makes his headquarters in Denver, is now in New York engaging casts and arranging for the productions.

The notification ceremony to be held for Mayor O'Brien by Tammany at City Hall on Tuesday apparently is to be a substitute for the traditional "ratification" rally at Tammany Hall, at which former Governor Alfred E. Smith for years has been the principal speaker.

GENEVA, Oct. 6 -- The German reply to the disarmament offer of the French, Americans, British and Italians, which they gave today to only the last two, seems to have been as stiff and ambiguous as possible while keeping the door open for further negotiations.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Here is a translation of an excerpt from Heinrich Heine's "Geschichte der, Religion und Philosophie in Deutschland." written in 1834 in Paris; it reads as if it might have been written a century later:

PARIS, Oct. 6 -- The first reaction to Germany's counter-proposals on disarmament were distinctly unfavorable in France, not only because they were considered to demonstrate that the Reich's attitude had not changed, but also because France is snubbed in not being directly notified by Germany of her stand.

With the repeal of prohibition the United States will revert to a hodge-podge system of liquor control, with some States dry and others wet without control and the rest varying between these extremes, it was pointed out yesterday as the second part of the report on liquor control sponsored by John D. Rock- efeller Jr. was made public prior to publication of the full document.

An increasing number of people in the United States are apprehensive of currency inflation and fearful of its results. Eight distinguished men, representing both major political parties, have approved and sponsored a series of articles presenting their viewpoint on the money problems of the day. The series is appearing in this newspaper in sixteen consecutive daily chapters. The thirteenth is presented herewith.
Only one of the big guns of football remains silent today as teams all over the country which have been delaying their openings join the procession.

RYE, N.Y., Oct. 6 -- By coming within two strokes of tying the course record of 75 made by Mrs. Glenna Collett Vare in the Eastern championship when it was held here in 1923, Mrs. Clarence H. Vanderbeck of Philadelphia today ran away with the 1933 women's national senior golf championship.

PITTSFIELD, Mass., Oct. 6 -- The Pittsfield Art League is holding its annual Fall exhibition at the Berkshire Museum in Pittsfield. Seventy artists are represented in three galleries of paintings, water-colors, prints, etchings, pieces of sculpture and handicraft.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 -- President Roosevelt stepped into the troublesome coal strike situation today, summoning for a White House conference tomorrow morning three spokesmen for steel companies operating "captive" mines.

The organization of the publishing house of Reynal Hitchcock, Inc., was announced yesterday by Curtice Hitchcock, recently vice president of The Century Company, and Eugene Reynal, president of Blue Ribbon Books, from the firm's offices, 448 Fourth Avenue.
The New Jersey realty turnover reported yesterday was made up largely of dwellings in various communities.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 6 -- Leopold Stokowski, opening the thirtyfourth season of the Philadelphia Orchestra, told an audience at the Academy of Music this afternoon that the "very existence of the orchestra" was at stake, owing to the economic situation.

BERLIN, Oct. 6 -- The Boerse generally was firm today. Trading in bonds fell off, due apparently to momentary saturation of demand, but this did not produce much change in the average price level. There were some declines, mostly in communal loans, but other issues, especially State bonds, advanced.

Edward J. Flynn, Secretary of State and Democratic leader of the Bronx, promised the Irish "an equal place in the sun and an equal opportunity for the advantages which other races in this city enjoy" if Joseph V. McKee is elected Mayor.

Miniature ship models and a model airport mingled with other handicraft in basketry, weaving and furniture as features of the annual exhibit conducted by the park playgrounds of the Bronx, held yesterday in the McComb's Extension Recreation Building at Jerome Avenue and 154th Street.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 -- Responding to the announcement that the "now is the time to buy" campaign will begin Monday, manufacturers and merchants all over the country have notified General Johnson that they will increase their advertising heavily.

LONDON, Oct. 6 -- The Atlantic shipping conference adjourned tonight without settling vital differences which threaten to result in a fierce rate-cutting war. The delegates will resume discussions tomorrow on the findings of the subcommittee which sat on two previous days here.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 -- The hypothesis of an ancient northern Atlantis, with great rivers depositing the sediment which formed the upper crustal layers of the lands now bordering the North Atlantic, is advanced by Professor Albert Gilligan, English geologist, in a paper issued in the annual report of the Smithsonian Institution.

GAMBIER, Ohio, Oct. 6 (AP) -- Using a college student as an unwilling shield, one of two robbers today engaged in s pistol duel with the cashier of the Gambier People's Bank, wounded and kidnapped that official and escaped with an undetermined amount of money.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 -- Never was the need for complete unionization in the United States more urgent than at this time, according to the Rev. Francis J. Hass, who was appointed by President Roosevelt today to the National Labor Hoard.

HASTINGS, England, Oct. 6 -- Attacks on Prime Minister Bennett and other Canadian politicians characterized the debate on a pro-Russian resolution which was adopted today at the final session of the Labor party's annual conference.

NO writer is more inspiring on the blessings that reward zip than Walter B. Pitkin. His alarm-clock preachments against the locusts that eat the years -- inefficiency, lack of ambition and general worthlessness -- spur and enliven thousands. An ascetic for success, he hardly fitted the times while the Coolidge boom was on. But when markets crashed and jobs fell away there was a very real demand for his teachings.

After hearing arguments in behalf of Tammany Hall against the application by the Republican organization for an order directing the Board of Elections to receive the party nominations for the Supreme Court in New York and Bronx Counties, Supreme Court Justice Salvatore A. Cotillo reserved decision last night.

DUBLIN, Oct. 6 -- A visit by General Owen O'Duffy, leader of the United Ireland party, accompanied by Commander E.J. Cronin and other members, to hold a convention at Tralee, County Kerry, this afternoon led to serious riots, lasting until a late hour.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on Sept. 30 totaled 661,827 cars, the American Railway Association announced today. This was 9,158 cars, or 1.4 per cent, more than for the preceding week; 40,169 cars, or 6.5 per cent, more than for the corresponding week last year, but 115,885 cars, or 14.9 per cent, fewer than during the corresponding week two years ago.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 -- Kenesaw Mountain Landis, Commissioner of Baseball, tonight ruled that Heinie Manush, Washington left fielder who was put out of today's World Series game, would be allowed to play tomorrow and that if any fine were placed on him it would not be done immediately.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 -- The Home Owners Loan Corporation in six weeks of operation has prevented 12,793 impending foreclosures on home properties valued at $36,033,677.

The use of voting machines, rather than paper ballots, in the municipal election virtually was assured yesterday at a special meeting of the Board of Elections, although a final decision will not be reached until next Wednesday.

Hereafter editors and publishers are to regard themselves, and will be regarded by the authorities, as abject servants or slaves of the government.

F.H. LaGuardia, Fusion nominee for Mayor, issued a statement yesterday in which he charged that to aid them in building up an organization for the election of Joseph V. McKee as Mayor, James A. Farley, Democratic National Chairman, and Edward J. Flynn, sponsor for Mr. McKee's candidacy, were holding up the public works program of the Federal Government for unemployment relief in this city.

ESSEX FELLS, N.J., Oct. 6 -- Miss Charlotte Glutting of Rock Spring led the field in a women's New Jersey Golf Association tournament at the Essex Fells Country Club today. The former State champion's card of 40 -- 43 -- 83 was the best gross score by six shots.

NEWARK, N.J., Oct. 6 -- The first flying sleeper to be placed in service on airlines serving New York landed this morning at the Newark Metropolitan Airport. The machine, a converted liner of Eastern Air Transport's fleet, left Atlanta last night, its two berths occupied by Captain Edward Rickenbacker and Alexander Strong, Boston business man.

Columbia's football team will make its season's debut at 2:30 P. M. today when it opposes Lehigh at Baker Field. A crowd of 10,000 persons is expected to see this third battle between the institutions Since 1889.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 -- The index number of wholesale commodity prices of the Bureau of Labor Statistics of the United States Department of Labor showed a reaction during the week ending Sept. 30 and dropped by more than one-half of 1 per cent from the week previous.

LOCUST VALLEY, L.I., Oct 6 -- Pactolus, 3-year-old chestnut gelding, by Snob II out of Queen Mab, and owned by Mrs. James M. Austin of the Catawba Farm, Old Westbury, L.I., today carried away the rosette in the only championship competition on the program of the first day of the thirty-first annual Piping Rock horse show.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 (AP) -- The players' pool, drawn from gate receipts of the first four games and amounting to $284,665.68, is the smallest for any baseball championship battle since 1922. It failed to pass the $300,000 mark for the first time in eleven years.

Mayor O'Brien began last night Tammany's reprisal campaign to wipe 200 McKee supporters off the city payroll when he appointed Charles V. Halley Jr. as Commissioner of Plant and Structures to replace Albert Goldman.

Manhattan foreclosure conveyances last month were fewer than in the preceding August and in September, 1932, The Real Estate Record and Builders Guide reported yesterday. This decline, the publication says, reflects locally a trend being registered in all parts of the country.
Governor Lehman moved yesterday to clear up the charges of laundry racketeering alleged to exist in Brooklyn.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 -- Allocations of $10,095,068 by the public works administration today brought the total to $1,669,098,378 out of the $3,300,000,000 voted by Congress.
Gifts and bequests to Columbia University, aggregating $655,499.61, were announced yesterday by Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of the University.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 -- Authorization for the manufacture of an additional 7,000,000 gallons of medicinal spirits between Oct. 15 and the end of the year was granted to distilleries today by Dr. James M. Doran, chief of the Bureau of Industrial Alcohol.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 -- Testimony that the Black Diamond Steamship Corporation overcharged for stevedoring services to the Shipping Board and also included charges for work never undertaken was given today before the special Senate committee investigating ocean mail subsidies.

HAVANA, Oct. 6 -- Political leaders of Cuba continued today a series of secret conference and two groups of Americans met in executive session to discuss the fate of the army and navy officers who were imprisoned following Monday's battle at the National Hotel.

CHICAGO, Oct. 6 -- An advance of 10 to 15 cents a hundred weight in prices for hogs here today, with scattered sales showing greater appreciation, brought the top quotation to $5.40, or within 10 cents of the year's high level and 15 cents above yesterday's figure.

Asserting that he meant what he said when he promised a "new deal" in politics in New York City, Joseph V. McKee, independent candidate for Mayor, repudiated in general last night support of those whose records and reputations do not conform to the principles of his newly organized party.

Operating expenses of the Interborough Rapid Transit Company have been so decreased as to indicate an annual saving of about $6,000,000, according to the second report of the receivers, Victor J. Dowling and Thomas E. Murray Jr., which was submitted yesterday to Judge Julian W. Mack of the United States Circuit Court of Appeals.

Brilliant jewels of tremendous size -- red, green and startling white -- floated in the clear sky above Times Square and vicinity at 7:40 o'clock last night, raining theoretical destruction on the city. The jewels were magnesium flares, each of 50,000 candlepower, released from a fleet of twelve droning army bombers composing the Seventh Bombardment Group from Langley Field, Va.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 -- The playby-play description of the fourth game of the world's series follows:

LEIPZIG, Oct. 6 -- Georgi Dimitroff, fiery Bulgarian Communist and one of the five men accused of having burned the Reichstag building, was banished today from the courtroom where he is on trial for his life. In a new explosion of temperament, he charged the German police with having "framed" him.

CHICAGO, Oct. 6 -- Edward Lebensberger, wealthy night club owner, shot himself to death this morning in his home at 1,258 Lake Shore Drive. Late in the afternoon an indictment charging him and two others with disposing of negotiable bonds from a $500,000 mail robbery was returned in the Federal court of Judge John P. Barnes.

Officials of Rockefeller Center presented to the Board of Estimate yesterday their plans for a vast underground system of pedestrian and vehicular passageways to relieve traffic congestion in the three blocks occupied by the midtown commercial and amusement project.

CHICAGO, Oct. 6 -- The Western Association of Railway Executives decided here today on a radical reduction of passenger fares and an elimination of the Pullman surcharge for an experimental period of six months beginning Dec. 1.
Sales and leases of housing properties featured real estate trading in the metropolitan area yesterday.
CHICAGO, Oct. 6 -- The White Sox turned the Chicago series into a rout today by crushing the Cubs, 9 to 0, for their third straight victory.

To the Editor of The New York Times: With a very important municipal election near at hand and with our citizenry politically minded because of the three-cornered fight, this is an appropriate time to give serious consideration to a much-needed reform in our political system.

More than 500 McKee workers met in the music room of the Biltmore Hotel yesterday to receive instructions in obtaining signatures on petition for the Recovery party ticket and to organize the McKee committee.
An exhibition of Islamic miniature painting and book illumination will be opened to the public at the Metropolitan Museum of Art next Tuesday.

TUCKAHOE, N.T., Oct. 6 -- A play-off was necessary to decide the first Scotch foursome championship sponsored by the Metropolitan Professional Golfers Association at the Mount Vernon Country Club today.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 -- President Roosevelt today signed an executive order eliminating from future Presidential Agreements the right to employ factory or mechanical workers or artisans a maximum week of forty hours for any six weeks until Dec. 31, when the agreements expire.

The task of persuading a sick brother to go to Arizona for his health took United States Senator James J. Davis to Mooseheart, Ill., on Jan. 3, 1931; the fact that tickets were placed in a barrel in the Mooseheart printery on the same day and winners were selected in a drawing was a mere coincidence, attorneys for Mr. Davis sought to establish yesterday at his trial here.

Since the Summer of 1932, when the low point of the world depression was reached, a marked improvement in business activity in the principal industrial countries has taken place, accompanied by a recovery in world prices of staple commodities, the National Industrial Conference Board declared yesterday, in a survey of international economic conditions.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 -- Despite the opposition of the American Legion and the American Federation of Labor, renewed this week, President Roosevelt has called for a complete memorandum on the question of Russian recognition.
The investigation by State Attorney General John J. Bennett of alleged racketeering in the beer industry, resulted yesterday in the arrest of a beer salesman on the charge of attempted coercion.

Federal regulation of the New York Stock Exchange and other similar markets, which has been hanging over Wall Street for two years, came closer to realisation yesterday. It became known that a committee has been formed to study conditions as a basis for a legislative program to be submitted to the next Congressional session.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 -- Trade of the United States with the Far East during August amounted to $64,194,000, the Department of Commerce announced today. This was a gain of $22,023,000 over August, 1932, but a loss of $7,526,000 from July, 1933, due largely in the latter case to considerable reduction in the quantity of cotton shipped to the Orient and lower imports of sugar from the Philippines.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 -- President and Mrs. Roosevelt joined today with Miss Frances Perkins, Secretary of Labor, and Harry L. Hopkins, Federal Emergency Relief Administrator, in making the health and well-being of little children a first charge on the resources and activities of relief, social, educational and welfare workers throughout the country.

Two directors of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York will be elected next month to succeed David C. Warner, president of the Endicott Trust Company of Endicott, N.Y., and Samuel W. Reyburn, president of the Associated Dry Goods Corporation, whose terms will expire on Dec. 31, according to an announcement yesterday by J. Herbert Case, chairman of the board of the local Reserve Bank.

Prices moved irregularly yesterday in the local commodity markets. Trading activity was about equal to that of the preceding day. Rubber, sugar and silk closed higher, while silver, copper, cocoa and hides were lower. Most cash quotations were lower.

So far as Tammany is concerned, the city election has taken on the appearance of desperate efforts by it to maintain its power as an "organization." Rival organizers are now in the field and are eating into its strength. The managers of the McKee campaign declare that they are going into every Assembly district to establish a party machine of their own to which discouraged and disgruntled members of Tammany Hall may resort.

The best field of 2-year-olds to be brought together at the meeting will vie for honors this afternoon at Jamaica in the Remsen Handicap, six-furlong feature of the weekend card. The Whestley Stable filly Slapdash, a sensation in Florida last Winer and winner of the Schuylerville at Saratoga, is one of the ten entered.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 DON CARLOS HUBBELL had a shut-out in his hand today, but his floot slipped. So the earnest athletes in the world's series had to work overtime. But they may get through the series on schedule, anyway. After the first two games Clark Griffith planned to carry it back to New York for settlement. It may not get as far as Baltimore now.

An abrupt and somewhat violent decline in grain prices unsettled all the other domestic markets yesterday. Stocks, bonds, cotton and most of the minor commodities were marked down. The foreign exchange market was quiet, but with the dollar again firm in terms of all the foreign currencies.

The departure of a strike delegation to the Ford Motor Company plant at Dearborn, Mich., was postponed yesterday following a conference between strikers at the Ford assembly plant in Edgewater, N.J., and Harry L. Tepper of the New Jersey NRA organization.

HAVANA, Oct. 6 -- The government of President Ramon Grau San Martin has gained considerable strength as a result of its soldiers' victory over the 526 officers dislodged from the National Hotel. This was the third important victory won by the government.

Mr. STANLEY BALDWIN is one of the broadcasters in a series of talks on "National Character." He has himself in a marked degree the characteristics commonly ascribed to the English. He ought to be able to speak with authority. It is not necessary to follow him in his journey from Britain under the Romans.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In its efforts to stimulate business recovery the Roosevelt Administration has criticized the bankers for not making credit more readily available. More recently it has touched upon the possibility of forced credit inflation, either through the banks or through loans made directly to borrowers by the government.

LOCUST VALLEY, L.I., Oct. 7 -- Hunters from the stable of Mr. and Mrs. Bernard F. Gimbel of Port Chester, N.Y., made practically a clean sweep of the championship competitions that marked the closing session of the thirty-first annual Piping Rock horse show today.

VIENNA, Oct. 7 -- Despite the protests of his doctors that he should remain in bed, Chancellor Dollfuss refuses even to stay at home. His first visit today was to St. Stephen's Cathedral to give thanks for his escape from the assassin's bullets last Tuesday.

Labor's Share. The outstanding feature of the respective codes emphasizes the effort employers should exercise to do their part toward the unemployed. Is there in any of these codes, or in the introduction leading up to "their provisions, or in the final summing up of the provisions, a suggestion of what is expected of labor in return for what is offered to labor to help it out of unemployment?

TIENTSIN, Sept. 10 -- Increased Japanese influence on political affairs in North China and virtual suspension of the anti-Japanese boycott in this part of the country have opened new opportunities to Japanese commercial interests.

Correction Commissioner William J. Cahill, one of the Bronx officials slated for retirement by Mayor O'Brien, announced yesterday that he had transferred nine heads of city penal institutions. The transfers will become effective on Oct. 16.

IN his "Essay on the Inequality of the Human Races," the late Arthur Count Gobineau, a mediatized Frenchman, had considerable trouble in explaining France before he could place Germany on the Aryan throne. Paul Cohen-Porthelm, a mediatized German, has less trouble in explaining Germany before he reveals what may have been the preoccupation of Aristide Briand.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 7 -- Glenn S. (Pop) Warner, returning to the scene of some of his greatest gridiron triumphs nearly twenty years ago, saw his Temple University team take a 25-to-0 defeat from Carnegie Tech today. The game marked the debut of Howard Harpster as a coach of Carnegie Tech.

To the lack of a definite declaration on inflation by the administration is attributed a very large part of the uncertainty now noted in retail merchandising circles. Until there is a clean-cut stand for or against inflation, a store president said yesterday, the merchandise operations of retailers may be expected show no marked trend.

As one who, for nearly twenty years now, has walked up and down the street called Broadway (the cheapest street in the world, perhaps) and whose own minor success has been won entirely within the precincts of what is called the commercial theatre, I have had all too ample opportunity to study and to appraise both the strengths and the weaknesses of the American drama and the machinery of its public presentation.

THE sixty-ninth convocation of the University of the State of New York, to be held in Chancellors' Hall, in the State Education Building at Albany on Thursday and Friday of this week, will commemorate the one hundred and fiftieth anniversary of the establishment of the university.

TOKYO. ABOUT half of Japan's enormous output of films are dramas of chivalry. In this the cinema is faithful to the dualism of Japanese life. So are the newspapers which publish in the morning a feuilleton of modern life and in the evening a tale of cloak and sword.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Oct. 7 -- With the completion of the town Elates for Supervisors during the last week, Westchester voters had their first opportunity to appraise the candidates who will seek to wrest control of the board from the Republican organization, of the late William L. Ward.

The cold spell during the week appeared to ba all that was necessary to get retail trade off to a good October start, according to the market report prepared especially for THE TIMES by KIrby, Block Fischer. The number of reorders received, however, was not in keeping with the gain at retail, which Is probably due to the heavy stocks which stores are now carrying.
Fordham's football eleven dominated the scene at Fordham Field yesterday, hammering out a 57-to-0 triumph over a valiant Muhlenberg aggregation.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 -- If certain Democratic Senators and Representatives coming into Washington from the Hinterland had the courage to say the things out on the street or stump which they have been uttering in the safe sanctums of the Senate and House office buildings, the country doubtless would conclude that an intra-party revolt of the first magnitude was on against the Roosevelt policies under the "New Deal."

JERUSALEM, Oct. 6 -- The synagogues in Palestine during the Jewish high holidays this year have been crowded to capacity with German-Jewish refugees, most of whom hitherto had taken no interest in the Jewish religion.

LEIPZIG, Oct. 7 -- Georgi Dimitroff, the Bulgarian revolutionary who is one of the five men on trial for their lives before the German Supreme Court on charges of having burned the Reichstag building, was back in court today after a protest against his exclusion from the proceedings yesterday had been lodged with the court by five foreign lawyers acting as the world's unofficial observers in the case.
Dr. John H. Finley, third president of City College, will be greeted by the faculty and students on Oct. 26 In the Great Hall at the college in honor of his 70th birthday, it was announced yesterday.

AT the Winslow, Ariz., airport, the other day a transport airplane carrying the equivalent of full load -- twelve passengers, 1,000 pounds of mail or express, 650 pounds of baggage and 570 gallons of gasoline -- took off on a unique test.
NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Oct. 7 -- An improved Rutgers team defeated Providence today, 21 to 0. The Scarlet offense was greatly strengthened by the return of Al Chizmadia, veteran halfback.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 -- Many of the standardization problems of the railroads, which have been subjects of controversy for many years, are believed to be on the eve of solution as the result of steps taken by Joseph B. Eastman, Federal Coordinator of Railroads.

STROUDSBURG, Pa., Oct. 7 -- Mrs. Clara Batten, wife of the Rev. Dr. Loring W. Batten of New York City, died at her Summer home at Swiftwater here yesterday noon of a complication of ailments. Dr. and Mrs. Batten had maintained their Summer home here for the last forty-two years.
To the Editor of The New York Times: I have been reading the series of articles on money and inflation with great interest and take this occasion to thank and congratulate you upon them.

BRUSSELS. IN the hilly district of Famenne, Belgium, lies the market town of Beauraing, scene of "the miraculous appearances of the Virgin Mary." Having only 2,000 inhabitants, Beauraing recently played host to 180,000 pilgrims who had journeyed there to witness an extraordinary occurrence.

LONDON, Sept. 28 -- In the eyes of the British people, few events have done so much real harm to the Germans as Hitler's persecution of the Jews. As time goes on, resentment here settles into a steady dislike. From a moral point of view the Germans have lost caste in this country.

SOUTH ORANGE, N.J., Oct. 7 -- The Orange Lawn Tennis Club horse show trophy today passed into the permanent possession of Mr. and Mrs, Fred Wettach of Shrewsbury, N.J., at the closing session of the Orange horse show, when their 7-year-old bay gelding, Crumpet, gave his owners a third leg on the prize.
CANTON, Sept. 11 -- Automobile drivers in Canton must hereafter be clad in something more than their underwear, may not smoke while they are at the wheel and may not drive while they are barefooted.

CLEVELAND, Oct. 7 -- Responsibility for the existence of racketeering was thrown back upon a public which tolerates inefficient and dishonest men in public office, in a speech made before the City Club here today by George Z. Medalie, Federal District Attorney for the Southern District of New York.

Fluctuations in bond prices on the Stock Exchange yesterday held within narrow ranges. Trading was light, even for a Saturday, and only a few issues showed any activity. Domestic railroad, industries and utility bonds and United States Government issues averaged a shade higher and leading foreign loans a trifle lower on the day.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Oct. 7 -- President Augustin Justo and Foreign Minister Saavedra Lamas of Argentina arrived here at 11 A.M. today aboard an Argentine warship and were greeted by President Getulio Vargas of Brazil.
PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 7 -- Princeton's 1933 edition of a football team came from under cover today and moved with relentless precision over the grass of Palmer Stadium to bury Amherst, 40 to 0.

William T. Tilden 2d returned to American courts yesterday and in approximately thirty minutes disposed of two rivals. Beginning his campaign to gain a meeting with Henri Cochet to determine the world's indoor professional tennis championship, Tilden mowed down Bruce Barnes, 6-1, 6-1.

Rear Admiral Yates Stirling Jr., Commandant of the Third Naval District; was revealed as a poet yesterday when he read an original free verse "Arraignment of War" at a meeting of the New Netherland-Chapter of the D.A.R. at the Hotel McAlpin.

The Commodity Credit Corporation being organized by the government to lend upon and deal in commodities will afford the banks of the country an opportunity to co-operate with the administration without risk to themselves and at considerable profit, it was said yesterday in Wall Street banking quarters.

The familiar headline is this time true. It is no longer the wish-fulfillment of a reform orator, but stark reality. The entry of Mr. McKEE, with powerful political support, as a rival Democratic candidate, with Mr. LAGUARDIA, the Fusion candidate, already in the field against Tanunany, only confirms what the wild waves have been saying.

More than 1,200 men and women are expected at the opening dinner of the 1933 campaign of the Federation for the Support of Jewish Philanthropic Societies, to be held next Sunday evening at the Hotel Commodore, it was announced yesterday. An army of volunteer workers will seek to obtain pledges to complete a budget of $4,200,000 for the support of the organization's ninety-one affiliated charitable agencies.

A reception and tea in behalf of Irvington House will be held on Wednesday at the headquarters of the organization in Irvington-on-Hudson, The occasion will mark the first anniversary of the opening of the new building, which provides shelter and care for boys and girls of New York and Westchester County who are suffering from heart ailments.

VICHY, France, Oct. 7 -- With many good intentions but without any definite active program, the French Radical Socialist party closed the work of its annual congress this evening. It is the majority party in Parliament and in the country but, robbed of the presence of former Premier Herriot, who is ill, it has seemed to have lost its initiative and its purpose.

PROFITING by the experiences of Professor Auguste Piccard, two huge balloons have been constructed in the Soviet Union to rise into the stratosphere. After several vain attempts to leave the ground one of these, built by the army under the auspices of the War Commissariat, has attained a height of 62,320 feet (11.8 miles), thereby breaking Piccard's record of 53,152 feet (10 miles).
HAVANA, Oct. 7 -- President Grau of Cuba charged tonight in a radio broadcast to the United States that American financiers were plotting to upset his government.

Although, field hockey adherents in this country and especially those who play the game in the metropolitan district have been watching the progress of the all-American team on tour in Europe, they have not limited their interest in the sport to observation.

PIERRE, S.D., Oct. 5 -- Paradoxically, the Indians on the Rosebud, Pine Ridge, reservations in South Dakota, on the Wind River in Wyoming and on others in Montana, are facing hardship owing to drought and grasshoppers, while in Washington the "Great White Father" is formulating a plan for the government to buy land for the Indians "to make them more selfsustaining."

Judge Freschi of General Sessions dismissed yesterday the indictment accusing Horace C. Sylvester Jr., vice president of the former National City Company and now the City Company of New York, an affiliate of the National City Bank, of making a false entry on June 2, 1931, in connection with a loan of $10,020 to John E. Ramsey, general manager or the Port of New York Authority.

WITH "Ah, Wilderness!" off his chest and the notices enthusiastic and the prospects cheerful, Mr. O'Neill felt like talking about anything. He was even willing to listen; and from the point of view of the interviewer that was bad.

TIMBER -- R R R! The familiar cry of the forest rang out. A giant Douglas fir, five feet or more in girth, quivered and shook as it had not done for seven hundred years. Slowly it toppled and then its dead stem, more than 250 feet high, crashed with a mighty roar along the highway.

More than 300 babies between the ages of 1 and 1 1/2 years entered the baby contest conducted by Uncle Robert, with the assistance of the Police Department, in Macombs Park, 165th Street and Jerome Avenue, yesterday afternoon.

While conferences were in progress yesterday at NRA headquarters seeking a settlement of the window-cleaners' strike, and a compromise on the question of limitation of contractors to avert a recurrence of the strike of 60,000 workers in the dress industry, seventy painters were arrested on charges of disorderly conduct growing out of the picketing of the Savoy-Plaza Hotel, Fifth Avenue and Fifty-ninth Street.

Although the Harmsworth Trophy was competed for only a little more than a month ago, driven abroad already are talking of another challenge for it next year. Advices from there last week were to the effect that Hubert Scott-Paine, defeated in his Miss Britain III by Gar Wood in Miss America X, was planning a larger boat with more powerful motors.

The hand being quicker than the eye, Columbia completely bewildered a hard-fighting Lehigh team with back-field trickery at Baker Field yesterday to romp off with its opening contest of the season, 39 to 0. A crowd of 16,000 attended.
The two-masted schooner, Effie M. Morrisey, chugged home again yesterday, with her master, Captain Robert A. Bartlett, conning.

SIDELIGHTS on the business of privateering during the American Revolution are presented in letters which nave come into possession of the Business Historical Society of Boston. The owners who furnished the ships ordinarily received one-half the value of the prizes taken. The crew received a certain stipulated portion of the prizes as pay.

THE discriminating antiquarian, in choosing his pieces, now places a premium on individuality. This quality may be expressed in some small detail, such as the arrangement of the cubby-holes of a secretary; or in the unusual design of a certain piece.

WITH a situation prevailing between the air-line operators of the United States and their pilots which would be mildly described as tense over questions of total pay and the hourly rather than the mileage, basis for flying pay, airline patronage continues to expand.

A recurrence of the destructive merchandising practices that have plagued the cotton-textile industry for the last four years threatens the successful operation of the NRA code, according to comment in the primary market yesterday.

ACORDING to present indications, the death knell of the speak-easy, as we know it today, will sound at about the same time 1933 departs. The speakeasy, a place for intimate dining, has helped to teach American women the art of dressing semi-formally.

Many pastors will preach today on "The Cause and Cure of War" and kindred topics, owing to the approach of the reopening of the Disarmament Conference in Geneva. Others will devote their sermons to a movement for "A Spiritual Recovery Act."

LAKELAND, Fla., Oct. 4 -- It is at this time each year that Floridians begin to perk up and look toward returns from investments in their two most important economic stimulants -- the citrus crop and the tourist crop. There is considerable evidence that each will bring better returns this year than during the 1932-33 season.

This is the time of year when sportsmen begin making preparations for the approaching hunting season. The experienced hunter is inspecting his favorite guns and putting them in good order. The veteran knows how important this is not only from the standpoint of accurate shooting but from the standpoint of safety.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 -- Business activity was somewhat lower during the final week in September, after allowance had been made for seasonal influences, but there was no change in trend from the preceding weeks, according to the weekly survey by the Department of Commerce made public today.

A realization that industrial code provisions prohibiting the "sale of goods below cost" are proving a boomerang to those industries which did not define costs carefully, caused considerable discussion in business circles here and in Washington last week.

All is not well with the plan for the leading banks here to sell capital notes to the RFC or the public or both by way of showing the lead to the banks of the country In the government's campaign to pump new capital into the banking system before, the deposit guaranty plan becomes effective.

Chancellor Harry Woodburn Chase announced yesterday that the house and grounds at University Heights occupied by Dr. Elmer Ellsworth Brown during the twenty-two years of his active chancellorship at New York University had been acquired by the university and would be used for the English department.

JERUSALEM, Sept. 15 -- The commemoration of a unique or important occasion by some special symbol or medal is not at all a modern custom -- it was known and practiced as far back as the days of the ancient Egyptians. Today we cast medals -- in those days a special scarab was carved.
LONDON, Oct. 7 -- Three men were killed and five persons critically injured when an auto skidded into a crowd watching the changing of the guard at Buckingham Palace today.
Scoring in every period, Poly Prep of Brooklyn opened its football season yesterday with a 25-0 victory over Concordia Colligiate Institute of Bronxville at Poly Prep Field.

The plan to furnish employment by entering upon large schemes of public works financed by the Government has not been succeeding as well or as rapidly as was hoped. Many projects have been approved, and money from the Treasury has been allotted, but contracts have not been executed as quickly as were expected.
ANDOVER Mass., Oct. 7 -- Andover won its second football game of the season today, defeating the Harvard freshmen, 7 to 0.
The New York Women's Field Hockey Association opened its eleventh annual Fall campaign yesterday, four games being played in the round-robin competition at Prospect Park, Brooklyn.

An Increase of economic consciousness among students who, in spite of the prolonged depression and the uncertainty of recovery within a short time, are returning to the colleges and universities of the land, was the salient factor revealed in an enrolment survey of widely scattered institutions conducted by THE NEW YORK TIMES.

SPLENDOR of jade and fine lacquer and magnificent brocade, beauty of delicate porcelains, exquisite embroideries and lotus buds opening to the sun so pervade this fascinating new book by Princess Der Ling that it seems like some legend of a lost fairyland.
SOUTH BEND, Ind., Oct. 7 -- A Kansas football cyclone roared out of the Western Plains today to shatter and topple a prized Notre Dame gridiron tradition that has stood for thirty-two years.

John J. O'Neill, 38 years old, of 40 Milbank Road, New Dorp, S.I., a disabled war veteran and former relief worker, attached to the Home Relief Bureau on Staten Island, was arrested at his home yesterday on a bench warrant charging misappropriation of city food tickets.
The Manual Training eleven recorded its second victory in as many starts by routing Samuel J. Tilden High, 26 -- 7, yesterday at the Brooklyn Sports Stadium.

Proposals for inflation in the United States such as those contained in the Thomas Amendment have been accompanied recently by demands in certain quarters for currency tinkering of a different and more permanent type. Once prices have been raised to a predetermined level by inflation, it is urged by some that the country "stabilize" them at the new level by monetary manipulation.

OCTOBER'S advent served considerably to speed up the local exhibition program. It marked the reopening of the Whitney. Museum of American Art, Which has still on view the work from the permanent collection that was shown last Summer.

ONLY those painters who carry something of the "primitive" stamp are admitted to the roll of "American Ancestors" at the Downtown Gallery. The title of the exhibition, which opens the season for this gallery, is explained to mean more specifically "the ancestry of contemporary American paintings" -- our own contemporaries, of course.
GENEVA, Oct. 6 -- The impact of Fascist and Democratic conceptions in the field of international government has marked the League of Nations Assembly sufficiently for some effects now to be noted.
LONDON, Oct. 6 -- Hitler diplomacy has won victories for France in London this week such as all the efforts of French diplomatists for years have failed to achieve.

To the Editor of The New York Times: You recently published a letter from one of your readers in which he advocates the erection of an official governmental radio station, located in Washington, to enable the President and others to address the country and to permit the broadcasting of the proceedings of the Senate and the House.
NEWARK, N.J., Oct. 7 -- Central High triumphed over the West Side eleven today by 14 to 7.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 -- Ten State entertainments, five dinners and five receptions, make up the program of White House official fetes for the season of 1933-34. The Cabinet dinner on Nov. 16 will open the series.

THE position of the oil industry under the provisions of the NRA promises to be the chief object of analysis and discussion at the annual meeting of the American Petroleum Institute scheduled to be held in Chicago from Oct. 24 to 26, inclusive.

MUKDEN, Manchuria, Sept. 9 -- The Manchukuo police have raised the veil of secrecy with which they had surrounded a series of recent political investigations and disclosed -- an extravaganza. It contained all the thrills and throbs of an "East Lynne," all the pomp and titles of a Gilbert and Sullivan and most of the props of Hollywood.

ROME, Oct. 7 -- According to data received by the International Institute of Agriculture, wheat production this year, despite the poor crop in North America, is about equal to the world's needs and there is no prospect for reducing surplus stocks greatly.
CLEVELAND, Oct. 6 -- Although the steel industry as a whole contracted further this week, operations here held their own or moved contrary to the general trend.

Only a small volume of sample orders was placed for Spring leathers by shoe manufacturers at the semiannual opening of leathers held at the Hotel Astor during the week, tanners reported yesterday. Buyers looked over the new styles carefully, but few actual commitments were made.

DUBLIN, Oct. 7 (AP) -- The political situation, throughout the Irish Free State was tense tonight as observers wondered what tomorrow might bring with a scheduled speech at Castlebar by General Owen O'Duffy, who arrived from Tralee with the declaration that he intended to protect himself as the result of an attack there last night.

BERLIN, Sept. 25 -- National socialism's exaction of political and racial conformity has now definitely robbed Germany of the services of hundreds of scientists and scholars. They include men renowned the world over, like Albert Einstein, James Franck, Max Born, Ernst Cassirer; to say nothing of highly trained specialists difficult or impossible to replace.
