Too Much Normality. IF motorists were not also normal human beings accident prevention would be easier. If all drivers responsible for highway casualties were abnormally vicious individuals, law and public opinion would have a relatively easy job with them.

A SECOND volume of the organ works of Juan Cavanillas, foremost Spanish composer for this instrument during the seventeenth century, has heen issued by the Institut d'Estudis Catalans, under the auspices of the Biblioteca de Catalunya, or Public Library, of Barcelona.

The master retail code which has embodied in it a "stop-loss" provision is still exciting comment. The opposition has been supplied in part by Agricultural Adjustment Administration representatives, who look on any such agreement as "price fixing."

To the Editor of The New York Times: The government is already looking to the day when the thirty-sixth State shall have ratified the repeal amendment. Those concerned with the raising of revenues are examining various plans to levy a tax which will yield as much as possible without encouraging smuggling or illicit and home manufacture.

American shipping has been hampered by the failure of the Senate to ratify the international convention for safety of life at sea which was drafted in London in 1929, according to Captain David W. Todd of the United States Shipping Board Bureau of the Department of Commerce.
VIENNA, Oct. 7 -- National Socialism is likely to sink somewhat lower in Austria and Czechoslovakia as a result of events of the last few days.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 THE war is over. The final shot was fired by Mel Ott in the tenth inning. The Washington centre fielder, Fred Schulte, followed it into the left-centre bleachers, which was as far as ha could go. A squad of Washington gendarmes rushed over and lifted Schulte back to the field again. The ball was not recovered by the Washington players.

CHICAGO, Oct. 5 -- There is every evidence now that when the gates to A Century of Progress Exposition close at midnight, Oct. 31, this city's centennial celebration will be found by certified public accountants to have been a financial success.

HANOVER, N.H., Oct. 7 -- Dartmouth, romped to a 39-6 triumph over Vermont today. In the opening game a week ago the reserves carried the Green to victory, but today the veterans rolled up four touchdowns in the first half.

IN a little house in the country not far from Berlin, there once lived an old musician who let two of his rooms to city vacationists. The noise of the children and of the women disturbed him much. But one Summer there came a 4-year-old boy who whistled and sang, mimicked drums and trumpets half the day without annoying the old man.

WOMAN'S extremities are fashion's opportunity when it comes to the dinner suit. Hat and shoes must be in the best of taste, for the fact that the suit is the ultimate expression of simple elegance makes head and feet more conspicuous than under ordinary circumstances, hence the same restraint is called for in fitting them out.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 -- The play-by-play description of the fifth game of the world series follows:

IT has become as axiomatic as anything can be in Hollywood that it is frequently easier and cheaper to produce luxury than squalor in motion-picture sets. First National confirmed that tenet when it began production of "I Loved a Woman," the Edward G. Robinson picture that is now being shown at the Hollywood Theatre.

BERLIN, Sept. 28 -- While the three leading personages in Nazi politics, who are also the three chief officials of the actual German Government, are protesting the peaceable intentions both of the government and of the National Socialist movement, it is nevertheless a fact that Germany is being prepared for war.

Restriction of liquor sales after repeal to State distributing agencies, with the elimination of private retailers, was recommended yesterday in a further instalment of the prohibition study sponsored by John D. Rockefeller Jr. Those who made the study concluded that this method offered the best approach to control of beverages with a high alcoholic content.

GARDNER HALE, who died in 1931, left an unfinished book on fresco painting, which, completed from his notes by Shaemas O'Sheel, has now been published by William Edwin Rudge. It should be read not on by the art world in general but particularly by all artists who are engaged in or who are inclined toward mural work.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Postmaster General Farley, apparently doing worth-while work, indicates that part of the problem of reducing the costs of postoffice operation develops from "free mail," the cost of which is placed at about $50,000,000 a year.

A LESS flamboyant reporter, who was with Richard Harding Davis in Holland during the war. once remarked to him that the Dutch always seemed to wash things in dirty water. Davis summed up his philosophy in a revealing answer: "Don't look at the dirt."

A warning that the speculative real estate interests of Manhattan should never be allowed to dictate terms for unification of the city's subway systems was issued to the residents of Brooklyn and Queens yesterday by John H. Delaney, chairman of the Board of Transportation.

THE new auction year at the American Art Association-Andersen Galleries makes an auspicious beginning on the 20th of the month with, a sale featuring what may have been the first copy sold of the first American play, owned by the first President of the United States.

UNDER the National Industrial Recovery Act the American Federation of Labor has increased its membership to within 50,000 of its wartime peak, President William Green has announced. His estimate of present A.F. of L. strength is at least 4,000,000, a gain of 1,300,000 since the act went into effect, and he has set as the next goal a membership of 10,000,000 through "organization of the unorganized in the mass-production industries."

The recent price concessions on both staple and apparel lines, while slight, have given point to retailers' belief that prices at wholesale have now gone about as high as they will for the remainder of the Fall and Winter season, reports here yesterday indicated.

The partnership of government and industry, as characterized through the NRA is America's answer to Soviet Russia's challenge to democracy, Dean Joseph W. Barker of the Columbia University School of Engineering declared in his annual report to Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of the university, made public yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 -- With the "now-is-the-time-to-buy" campaign starting tomorrow, General Johnson revealed with a striking series of letters that merchants and manufacturers saw a notable increase in business and were thus able to pledge full cooperation.

TOKYO, Sept. 18 -- Japan's revenue has been shrinking since 1930, but, thanks to large reserves and vigorous retrenchment, it was not until 1932 that red ink figures appeared in the national budget. The deficit in that year's accounts was 680,000,000 yen, and those of 1933 showed the still larger deficit of 950,000,000.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 -- Closing in on their game with all the certainty of a hunter who knows his quarry cannot escape, the Giants today brought the world's series of 1933 to a dramatic close.

THE problem of educating the child of low intelligence, especially when this handicap is aggravated by poor social adjustment, is being successfully dealt with through the progressive educational program recently developed at the Children's Village at Dobbs Ferry, N.Y.

OIL FOR THE LAMPS OF CHINA" is a novel of amasing scope. Containing in itself enough material for three novels of ordinary size and interest, it is nevertheless so successful in its purely narrative aspects, and its several themes have been so closely end artfully interwoven, that the reader is at first unaware of all Mrs. Hobart has set out to do.

The major indices of business showed some improvement last week, but the prospect was not entirely clear, because of the continuation of labor troubles in some industries. Indications were, however, that these were being reduced under the firm direction of the government.

THE future of the American dollar is one of the great questions now before the Roosevelt administration. One school of opinion has been urging currency inflation. More recently there has come to the front the proposal for devaluation of the dollar.

THE nation's gasoline bill has gone up. New York motorists today are paying 2 cents more per gallon of motor fuel than they did at the beginning of the touring season. Most of their brother car owners in the rest of the country who help purchase the 15,000,000,000 gallons of gasoline consumed annually in the United States pay somewhat higher prices.
Tentative plans for a campaign to improve the appearance of the city's streets were announced yesterday by Leslie Baker, Deputy Commissioner of Sanitation.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 (AP) -- A new revision of the retail trade code, if approved by President Roosevelt, would place the fate of company stores and commissaries in the hands of a presidential investigating commission.

RICHMOND, Va. AN authentic daguerreotype of Edgar Allan Poe, long hidden from public view, has come to light. Recently purchased by twenty Poe enthusiasts and presented to the Edgar Allan Poe shrine of Richmond, it was placed on exhibition at the shrine for the first time yesterday, Oct. 7, the anniversary of Poe's death.

Committee meeting's are being held regularly by the various groups arranging details for the annual Victory Ball which is to be held on. Armistice Eve, Nov. 10, in the grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria. Marking the fifteenth anniversary of the signing of the armistice, the event will be the thirteenth annual ball to benefit the American Legion welfare committee of New York County in its work among dependents of deceased and disabled World War veterans.

HARTFORD, Oct. 5 -- Town meeting day in Connecticut last Monday, one of the few opportunities for citizens to wrestle personally with the details of their governmental business, found the freemen in most of the towns giving consideration to their share of the New Deal by voting on projects to be carried out under the Public Work Administration.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 -- In a firm display of Executive authority, President Roosevelt laid down, today to owners of "captive coal mines" conditions which he evidently believed would end their labor troubles.

PARIS. NOW that the French cinema has reached its nadir, quantitatively speaking, the time has come to discuss its future, for there are unmistakable signs that probably never again will the film industry here reach such a low level.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 7 -- Harvard opened its season today with a five-touchdown, 33-to-0 victory over Bates.
CHICAGO, Oct. 6 -- A new dimension to the concept of history is sought in a course of lectures on the history of science which began at the University of Chicago yesterday.

The local NRA buying campaign, in which it is hoped to enlist most of the 138,000 rated merchants in this city, will be launched tomorrow, it was announced last night by Grover A. Whalen, city NRA chairman, at NRA headquarters at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

DURING the past few month the Roosevelt administration has displayed prodigious energy in developing its national recovery program. This program has been regarded in certain circles as "isolationist." As yet, however, there is little basis for this characterization.

On the ground that there "was not a scintilla of evidence" to sustain the complaint, Magistrate Aurelio in the Tombs Court exonerated yesterday Nicholas Roberts, president of S.W. Straus Co., bonds dealers, on a woman's charge that she had been defrauded of more than $10,000 through misrepresentation of the value of mortgage bonds.

Few persons are able to comprehend the mathematical details underlying the Einsteinian theory of relativity. But what the great physicist had to say to a large audience in London on the relations of the people who live in this corner of the universe is intelligible to all who have minds to understand.

SAN FRANCISCO, Calif., Oct. 4 -- Despite George Creel's prompt and emphatic repudiation of the boom launched by some of his admirers who think he would be an ideal Democratic candidate for Governor, events are providing cumulative evidence of a popularity which may compel him to reconsider his decision, though in the end he may refuse to reverse it.

IN his latest book that roving, sociological novelist and dramatic story teller, Thames Williamson, has invaded the Ozarks. One knows, without reading his brief dedicatory preface, that he has spared no pains to make his book regionally perfect.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 7 -- Dr. Hans Luther, the German Ambassador, came here today to be the chief speaker at the 250th anniversary celebration of the founding of Germantown, but refused to address a crowd of 15,000 because the swastika banner of the Nazis was not displayed on the platform.

ROOSEVELT FIELD, L.I., Oct. 7 -- The destruction of the papiermache village of "Depressionville" by giant keystone bombers of the United States Army's Second Bombardment Squadron from Langley Field, Va., was a feature of the National Charity Air Pageant which opened here today.
Mayor O'Brien moved yesterday to complete his dismissal of about 200 Bronx Democrats holding city jobs who swung over to support the candidacy of Joseph V. McKee.

IS there a magic formula for winning high marks in college? Stevens Institute in Hoboken believes that it has hit on one that at least helps -- the simple device of improving one's vocabulary. A new word a day keeps the low grade away, or at any rate further off!

THE New York half-glimpsed through the newspapers, where the underworld masquerades, with little hindrance and often with official connivance, beside the lawabiding, is pictured in Big Dick Butler's story of his own life. This product of Limehouse, who later reached a certain type of Broadway fame by way of numerous shady byways, talks frankly of the route he has traveled.

MINEOLA, L.I., Oct. 7 -- The Jamaica High football team sustained its first setback of the year when it lost to Chamlnade, 10 to 6, before 4,600 spectators at the Chaminade Bowl today. The triumph was the second in as many games for Chaminade.

Should research in the control of insects and plant diseases cease, the United States would face famine within ten years or less, according to Dr. A.L. Mehring of the Bureau of Chemistry, Federal Department of Agriculture. In a statement made public yesterday through the American Chemical Society at 419 Fourth Avenue, Dr. Mehring said that new problems threatening agriculture were constantly arising and that constant research was indispensable.

Few bonds were added last week to the list of those called to be paid in October before maturity. Calls of those to be retired in future months, however, were numerous and embraced several entire issues. The total for October is now $23,434,000, compared with $25,781,000 in September, and $8,760,000 for October, 1932, in corresponding weeks.

ACCORDING to the usual sources, they're having quite a time finding houses for all of Great Britain's theatrical ventures. There is a great boom in drama, just as there seems to he one along Broadway at the moment. Practically all the newest plays are hits.

EVERY now and then this column, which normally sticks pretty firmly to second act curtains and to Life, stoops to a discussion of economics. This time the concern is with standees. They haven't been around much for a long while, but apparently the New Deal -- and some good shows -- are bringing them down again from the Bronx, Park Avenue or wherever they live.

Returning to the city in increasing numbers, heads of families who passed the Summer at country homes, in Europe or at fashionable resorts in this country are now directing their attention to plans for the forthcoming social season, at the start mainly those for entertaining in honor of debutantes.
NEW YORK. Former United States Senator Cameron Morrison, Mrs. Morrison and Miss Angelia Morrison of Charlotte, N.C., are at the St. Regis.

The Horace Mann School for Boys will open its season on Friday, the 13th, but prospects for a successful gridiron campaign overshadow superstitions. For its initial opponent, Horace Mann will tackle La Salle Military Academy of Oakdale on the Horace Mann field.
MINEOLA, L.I., Oct. 7 -- Breaking 100 straight targets, R.H. Helsel took the registered shoot at the Nassau Trapshooting Club today. It was the first straight score of the Fall season.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 -- An assertion that President Roosevelt would, if necessary, declare a moratorium on farm mortgage foreclosures and evictions was made today by representatives of farm organizations after a conference at the White House.

NO ONE reading Mr. Polakov's competent and matter-of-fact presentation can fail to be impressed with the revolutionary consequences of the evolution of the technical means employed in the production of consumables. The striking changes arrived at unconsciously while consciously pursuing what appear to be entirely different and personal ends are nowhere demonstrated so clearly and concretely as in the development of man's tools of production.

VIRGINIA WOOLF, whose art has tended more and more toward the presentation of the unique states of consciousness, the special sensibilities of her characters, gives us in this "Biography" the world of a dog.

That Professor DATSKY should find evidence of a rise in temperature during the last half-century in Northern Siberia will not astonish geologists. The story told by rocks, the ten thousand lakes of Northern America and Europe, the gorge of Niagara, the clay banks that were once river beds, is plain to him who has the skill to read it.

GREENWICH, Conn., Oct. 7 -- Greenwich society is interested in the third annual horse show of the Byram River Beagle Club to be held at the club grounds in Glenville on Oct. 14. It will be an all-day show, with sixteen classes.

Members of society will pay well for the doubtful privilege of being called "scavengers" and for the opportunity to chase themselves around the island of Manhattan on the night of Nov. 1, if they subscribe to an "All-Hallowe'en Supper-Dance and Scavenger Hunt" for the benefit of the Maternity Centre Association.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Allow me to express hearty appreciation of the story of money now appearing daily and to congratulate THE TIMES on this effort at popular education on this fundamental of our economic life.

IN this day of bloodthirsty pictorial journalism, when a public which once shuddered at the wax images in the Museum of Horrors now digests a front-page telephoto of fifty massacred peons along with the eggs and coffee, this department is reluctantly beholden to report the grim destruction by prolonged torture of a young and promising librettist.

PAUL WILSTACH has been unfortunate in his choice of a title and unjust to the book. For it minimizes the volume's contents, purpose and spirit. It is, truly enough, occupied with places up and down the river at which people have made landings and have done memorable things and thereby rendered themselves interesting for centuries to come.

BOSTON, Oct. 6. THE alteratipns in "Let 'Em Eat Cake" began promptly. Before the second performance there were material cuts. More are to come. Several of the conversational scenes are also to be revised to bring about what Mr. Kaufman calls "a dictator approach."
Under the auspices of the New York and New Jersey chapters of the International Federation of Catholic Alumnae, a luncheon followed by bridge will be given on Thursday afternoon at the Commodore.
Fifty-one fellowships for a year's study at the Juilliard Graduate School have been awarded, according to an announcement made yesterday by Ernest Hutcheson, dean of the Juilliard School of Music.

LONDON. THAT there are many slovenly and stupid people about is quite obvious, but one was scarcely prepared for a revelation made by "A Publisher's Render" in the current Issue of The National Review.

Charging that private British interests have been making a bear raid on cocoa so that they may buy at a lower price in the approaching marketing months, E. A. Canalizo, former president of the New York Cocoa Exchange, has sent a letter to all the cocoa farmers In the world advising them to hold back their crops rather than sell "at today's ruinous prices."

LINCOLN, Neb., Oct. 7 (AP) -- George Sauer, 195-pound triple threat fullback, led Nebraska's football team to a surprising 26-to-0 victory today in its opening game against a heavier University of Texas eleven.
LAFAYETTE, Ind., Oct. 7 -- A fighting Ohio University football team, coached by Don Peden, gave Furdue a real opening-day battle today before going down to defeat, 13 to 6.

College coaches are complaining once more this Autumn, as they have for the past many years, over lack of time for coaching football. One man, a back field coach at one of the largest universities in the country, said recently that there was really no chance to teach punting to a player.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 -- The end of the trail came triumphantly for the Giants at Griffith Stadium this afternoon, a fitting climax to a campaign that started last March.

STATE COLLEGE, Pa., Oct. 7 -- Taking to the air for two touchdowns and rushing their way through the line for two other tallies, the Perm State football team opened its season by defeating Lebanon Valley College, 32 to 6, today.

AMONG "dominant personalities of the war." Mr. Lloyd George -- as he recalls "with horror"-- stands unique. It was in 1905 that he entered the British Cabinet, nor did he resign until 1922. During the whole "rending and tearing" of "the vitals of mankind" he, and he alone, occupied a position which he describes as "not inconspicuous."

The tuberculosis pavilion to be built at Bellevue Hospital, for which the city has applied for a 54,000,000 Federal loan and subsidy, will be the first large tuberculosis hospital to be erected in the heart of a large city, Dr. Mark L. Fleming, general medical superintendent of the Department of Hospitals, disclosed yesterday.

The President of the United States and Mrs. Roosevelt will address the Women's Conference on Current Problems at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria this week. Many other leaders in world thought will take part in the" program made public yesterday by The New York Herald Tribune, which is sponsoring the conference.

DURHAM, N.C., Oct. 7 -- Duke launched its "Big Five" championship drive with a 22-to-0 triumph over Wake Forest In the Methodists' stadium today. Duke scored its first touchdown in the second quarter when Cox carried the ball over.

The social and economic recovery of the United States will depend largely upon the progress of its educational systems, in the opinion of Dr. William H. Holmes, Superintendent of Schools in Mount Vernon, N.Y., who addressed the members of the High School Teachers Association of New York City yesterday at the Hotel Astor.

Period furniture and furnishings from the collections of the late James Benjamin Wilbur of Manchester, Vt., and of Mrs. George Holmes, Brook Lodge, Greenwich, Conn., Mrs. Lee Dodd. Whitneyville, New Haven, Conn., and Mrs. Thomas Garvan, Hartford, Conn., will be offered at auction next Friday and Saturday afternoons at the American Art Association Anderson Galleries, Inc., where the objects will be on exhibition until the time of sale.

LAUREL, Md., Oct. 7 (AP) -- George D. Widaner's Chicstraw, with Don Meade up, drove to a brilliant victory over five other crack 2-year-olds in the $2,500 added Richard Johnson Stakes, salient feature of a racing card witnessed by 15,000 persons today.
MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., Oct. 7 -- Two suits growing out of the affairs of the Mount Vernon Trust Company were started in the Supreme Court today by stockholders.

Wall Street received yesterday reports from several sources in Europe that Germany and Switzerland are about to reach, an agreement whereby the scrip to be issued by Germany for 50 per cent of the interest on corporation and municipal external bonds will be used by Switzerland at par to purchase coal and other commodities from Germany.

THE popular belief that the hand is quicker than the eye is a mistake; quick movement does not explain tricks of so-called magic. Not only is the hand slower than vision, but a good magician never moves quickly. The appeal of magic is mental, not visual, and the magician, therefore, must fool the minds, rather than the eyes, of his audience.

MADRID, Oct. 7 -- President Niceto Alcala Zamora tonight defied former Premier Manuel Azana and the Socialist and Left Wing parties, handing to Martinez Barrios, a lieutenant of Alejandro Lerroux, a decree for the dissolution of the Constituent Cortes and ordering him to form "a wide Republican coalition government."
WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 (AP) -- President Roosevelt late today signed the code of fair competition for the silk textile industry with its 100,000 employes.
PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 6 -- The momentum gained by retail trade in September is continuing this month. Carloadings this week are larger than a year ago.

TORONTO, Oct. 7 -- Canada's output of gold in July was 255,656 ounces, against 261,411 in June and 250,371 in July, 1932. In the first seven months of 1933 It was 1,713,579 ounces, or 2.2 per cent less than the 1,751,601 produced in the corresponding period in 1932.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 -- President Roosevelt appealed to capital and labor today for "unselfish patriotism" in the present crisis, complimented the majority on both sides for their unselfish support, but warned the recalcitrants, a minority, that "the horses that kick over the traces will have to be put in a corral."

CHICAGO, Oct. 7 (AP) -- Twenty-one persons were in custody in six widely separated cities tonight and $150,000 in bonds had been recovered by Federal operatives who have tracked down for ten months the perpetrators of a daring $250,000 Chicago mail robbery.
MORGANTOWN, W. Va., Oct. 7 -- The Pitt Panthers, using first, second and third-stringers, had little trouble in defeating West Virginia today, 21 to 0.

FOR, many a year the pioneer broadcasters wondered what might Inspire artists of distinction to sign ethereal contracts. Despite all arguments the performers usually replied that the microphone was not capable of handling their music with entire fidelity.

MUKDEN, Manchuria, Sept. 9 -- Discriminatory customs treatment in favor of Japanese kerosene is severely affecting British and American trade in Manchuria, according to representatives of three oil companies at present operating here. They have recently submitted strong protests to the Manchukuo Government, but do not expect any change in policy in the near future.

Decline of the dollar in international exchange baa checked the tendency of American producers to open branch plants abroad and encouraged them to increase production of export goods In home plants, according to information supplied here yesterday by manufacturers in a variety of major industries.

Progress of City Campaign. Former Mayor John F. Hylan and The New York American announced support of Joseph V. McKee for Mayor. Samuel Untermyer pledged support to Ferdinand Pecora and Nathan Straus Jr.

WHAT radio engineers at "The House of Magic" in the General Electric plant at Schenectady herald as "a real achievement" is a new compact four-tube superheterodyne entirely self-contained auto-radio receiver. They estimate the performance equal to that of any seven or eight tube set of a few years ago.

Although brokers were disappointed by the volume of business offered, Wall Street, or that portion committed to the advance, was pleased by the action of the share market at the close of the week. Even the small turnover had its cheerful aspect in that it suggested that liquidation had entirely dried up, for the time being at least.

WEST POINT, Oct. 7 -- Army, showing a much improved attack, went over the Virginia Military Institute's goal line for five touchdowns today and triumphed by 32 to 0. A crowd of 9,000 persons saw the battle in Michie stadium.

Accounting for a major upset, West Virginia Wesleyan's plucky football team repulsed the New York University eleven, 3 to 0, at the Yankee Stadium yesterday. The game marked the 1933 debut of the Violet, and a sad one it was for most of the 12,000 in the stands.

BASLE, Switzerland (AP) by mail) -- The first step toward transformation of the Bank for International Settlements into a European counterpart of the American Federal Reserve System has been taken by bank officials with the formulation of a plan to make active use of gold now lying idle in heavily guarded vaults.

SPANISH writers need no longer look enviously toward France, where generous literary awards are possible of attainment. In Spain literary prizes have been rare and of modest proportions. The sale of novels is not great, and many authors must enjoy the emoluments of a salaried position before deciding on a literary career.

WASHINGTON. AGRAY-HAIRED man of kindly face and urbane air sits at a desk in a window alcove in the Treasury Building, his window looking out toward the White House amid its trees and lawns. He is Oliver Mitchell Wentworth Sprague, since 1913 Converse Professor of Banking and Finance at Harvard University, and since last May financial adviser to the Roosevelt administration.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 (AP) -- After a thorough investigation today, including interviews with the principals, Baseball Commissioner Landis indicated that no further disciplinary action would be taken against Heinie Manush, Washington outfielder, who was banished by Umpire Charles Moran in the fourth game of the world's series.

IN this story Mrs. Sterne follows the fortunes of Manthy, the young girl of "No Surrender." In 1876 Manthy, or Amarantha as she now calls herself, leaves the Thomas plantation in Alabama to teach science In a woman's college in the North.

LAKE WACCABUC, N.Y., Oct. 7 -- Prince Charming, well-known bay gelding, owned by the Warfield Farms of Port Chester, N.Y., showed to excellent advantage in capturing blue ribbons in two events for hunters at the one-day Waccabuc horse show today.

Announcement of details of the government's lending program as applied to cotton caused a sharp advance of 35 points in early trading yesterday on the Cotton Exchange, but the improvement failed to hold, and final quotations were only 1 to 5 points better than on Friday.

Arthur S. Tuttle, New York State Engineer for the Federal Emergency Administration of Public Works, yesterday issued a statement denying the charges of F.H. LaGuardia, Fusion candidate for Mayor, that the Federal public works program here was being delayed by Democratic National Chairman James A. Farley and Secretary of State Edward J. Flynn to advance the candidacy of Joseph McKee for Mayor.

A sweeping victory for the Western railroads in a campaign for lower passenger fares will be concluded on Tuesday, when most of the Eastern managements are scheduled to fall in line by cutting their tariffs to pre-war levels. Both sections are to put the new rates in effect for a six-month experimental period beginning on Dec. 1.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 (AP) -- A corporation to look after the interests of American owners of over $1,000,000,000 worth of defaulted foreign securities probably will be created next week.
ATLANTA, Ga., Oct. 4 -- More than 10,000 saddened persons walked lingeringly past the bier of W.L. (Young) Stribling in the Macon Municipal Auditorium today.

CHICAGO, Oct. 7 -- A nation-wide campaign against public enemies to end their criminal activities and to bring them to justice was proposed today by Frank J. Loescb, president of the Chicago Crime Commission. In a letter to Homer S. Cummings, Federal Attorney General, Mr. Loesch requested that the Department of Justice, with the aid of crime-fighting groups throughout the country, compile a list of the most notorius criminals and their records.

OKLAHOMA CITY, Oct. 7 -- Sentences of life imprisonment, the maximum penalty under the new Federal Kidnapping Law, were dealt out today to Harvey Bailey, prison-breaking desperado; Albert Bates, Denver gangster, and Mr. and Mrs. R.G. Shannon, Texas farm folk, for the Charles F. Urschel kidnapping.

A decline in the purchasing of rails by the railroads had started before the depression began, figures issued by the Bureau of Railway Economics disclose. To stimulate their manufacture Joseph B. Eastman, Coordinator of Transportation, has obtained from the railways commitments for 844,000 tons, conditional on a reduction in price.

LONDON. THERE used to be a famous and magnificent generalization -- famous, at least, in the smoke-rooms of North Atlantic passenger steamers -- to the effect that "New York is the place to make money in and London is the place to live in."

GENEVA, Oct. 7 -- Joseph Paul-Boncour, the French Foreign Minister, who returned here today, compared notes tonight with Norman H. Davis, United States Ambassador at Large, on the German stand on arms.

MADRID. THE alliance that brought the second Spanish Republic into being is broken, and the forces that battle for possession of Spain take to the field again. Surprised historians called the farewell party of April 14, 1931, a "republican revolution" because they had no other name for it.

IN "One More River," completed before his death in January of this year. John Galsworthy brings to an end the third trilogy of the Forsytes, the uppermiddle-class family symbolic of English solidity and solidarity, whose fortunes were followed first through the three volumes of the "Saga" and then through the three volumes of "A Modern Comedy."

To the Editor of The New York Times: In the second of a series of articles, "Money and Inflation," the writer says: "As food was the primary need and cattle the earliest wealth, the first 'standard' unit of value was the ox or cow. It is no accident that the word pecuniary, meaning anything referring to money, has its origin in the Latin word pecus, meaning ox or cow.

The new laundry racket trials of Jacob Mellon and two of his associates charged with conspiracy, which wera scheduled to begin in the Kings County Court tomorrow, were temporarily stayed by order of the Appellate Division in Brooklyn yesterday.

COLON, C.Z., Oct. 7 -- Antonio C. Gonzalez, United States Minister, and Mrs. Gonzalez received a martial welcome on their arrival today aboard the steamship Santa Lucia. The new envoy reviewed on the pier a guard of honor -- a company of the First Coast Artillery from Fort Sherman -- and he greeted official representatives of Panama in excellent Spanish.

The Friars, which for seventeen years has occupied the six-story clubhouse at 110 West Forty-eighth Street -- known familiarly as "the Monastery" -- have taken up temporary headquarters at the Hotel Astor pending their removal to quarters less expensive than the Monastery.

The costly effort by Canada to provide an outlet for Western grain, by way of a water haul beginning far up on the west side of Hudson. Bay at Fort Churchill, seems in the first year of open port operation to be destined to failure unless it is supported by some form of government subsidy.

BERLIN, Sept. 14, 1933. IT looks like a Winter of lean pickings in the Berlin concert halls. One by one, in heartbreaking succession, distinguished foreign artists nave curtly refused to appear or else have canceled the arrangements they bad previously made.

HATS are not quite sure whether they are coming or going. Berets move forward -- threatening the nose. Bonnets slip backward -- exposing the hair; sailorswe still like them -- are anchored with ribbons under the brim, and toques are doing monkey tricks -- they actually look like the littlehats that simians doff when collecting coins for the organ-grinder.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 7 (AP) -- In a surprising victory over Miss Dorothy Round, British Wightman Cup star, Miss Alice Marble, 19-year-old San Francisco girl, successfully defended her Pacific Coast women's singles tennis title today. The score was 6-4, 6-1.

Fourteen letters written by the late President Theodore Roosevelt to Dora Watkins, who was his nurse from the time he was born until he was 3 years old, have come into the possession of Alwin J. Scheuer of 26 East Fifty-sixth Street.
PROVIDENCE, R.I, Oct. 7 -- A Brown football team that shaped up the best of any in years in the opening game scored a 26-to-0 victory over Rhode Island State College today.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 7 -- The inauguration of Yale's new football regime today under the aegis of Reggie Root and in the full attacking panoply of Notre Dame was not quite the new deal that had been looked for.

LOS ANGELES, Oct. 7 -- With Irvine Warburton setting a fast pace for his fellow Trojans, the University of Southern California won its first Pacific Coast conference game of the season today at the expense of Washington State, 33 to 0.

The National Academy of Design, which has been attacked for years by liberal artists as being the epitome of conservatism in this country, is not opposed to modern art per se, Harry W. Watrous, who was elected its president last Spring, said yesterday in an interview regarding the academy's plans for the coming season.

ATHENS, Oct. 7 (AP) -- Georgia built up an early lead today, looked on bewildered and almost helpless as Tulane rallied strongly to push, over two quick touchdowns, but then capitalized a final break to win its first Southeastern Conference football game, 26 to 13.

SAINT EXUPERY'S "Night Flight," published last year, had undoubted weaknesses; but it had also certain moments of breathless poetry which linger vividly in the mind. Such moments reoccur in "Southern Mail," a book which has also to do with the thrills and perils of flying.

BERLIN, Oct. 7 -- The Boerse was irregular today, but in general it was hopeful. Most stocks registered early gains, these ranging up to 2 per cent. Later, however, Lignite shares turned very weak, some of them losing as much as 7 per cent. This soon influenced the entire list and the market was soft when it closed.

PARIS. ALTHOUGH many fashionable people are still on the beaches at Biarritz and the Lido, or staiking the agile chamois in the mountains, the official beginning of the Paris season is marked by the reopening of Longchamps for the Fall racing.

THE storm that recently devastated Tampico was born in the heart of the doldrums and followed the course of the trade winds to the Mexican coast. The great gales that buffeted the Atlantic seaboard of the United States in late August and mid-September came up from the same breeding ground of hurricanes.

DETROIT. A NEW force in the crusade for vehicular traffic reform, with the aim of reducing accidents and promoting highway safety, has come into existence. It unites, for the first time on an international basis, officials entrusted with the administration of laws covering virtually all phases of motor vehicle operation and regulation.

CHEYENNE, Wyo., Oct. 4 -- With the national score on prohibition repeal 32 to 0, Wyoming is beginning to take notice of straws in the wind. About a month ago Governor Leslie A. Miller appointed a committee of fifteen laymen to aid in gathering information on which to base a State liquor control act for submission, at the proper time, to the Legislature.
DR. HUGO ECKENER, commander of the dirigible Graf Zeppelin, plans to broadcast from over the Atlantic while en route from Friedrichshafen, Germany, to the Century of Progress Exposition at Chicago.

BUENOS AIRES, Oct. 7 -- Frederico Pinedo, Minister of Finance, announced today that he had placed with local bankers 15,000,000 pesos ($6,000,000) of short-term treasury notes at 1 1/2 per cent a year. The notes are not renewable and not rediscountable.

SHANGHAI, Sept. 11 -- Excellent progress is being made in the campaign to increase the Communist armies in China to a maximum of 1,000,000 men, according to information, given out by agents of the Chinese Soviet.
TROY, N.Y., Oct. 7 -- Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute defeated City College of New York, 33 to 0, today, outplaying the visitors in every department of the game.

LOCUST VALLEY, L.I., Oct. 7 -- The final day of the annual Piping Rock Horse Show was well attended. The afternoon, classes included the colorful feature of the show, the Corinthian Class for hunters ridden with bounds by members of bunt clubs in livery.

CONTINUING at its improved level, retail trade in the week held fairly close to last year's figures. A few stores here are showing small gains over a year ago. Business on apparel lines has picked up somewhat and home furnishings have been more active.

BRUNO WALTER, who has been a steadfast exponent of the music of Mahler, will present the First symphony, in D, on this week's programs of the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra. Mr. Walter has directed here Mahler's Fifth and Second symphonies, and excerpts from the Seventh.

JOHN GALSWORTHY'S greatest work, which has now come to be accepted generally as one of the major creative works of the present century, appears this Fall in a new and handsome one-volume format, this memorial edition to which Mrs. Galsworthy has contributed an introduction.

OTTAWA, Oct. 5 -- It is an old grievance of Canadian railroads that they are subjected to unfair competition in the hauling of passengers and freight by motor vehicles which are in effect, they say, subsidized out of public funds in the provision of ready-made rights of way.

ELKTON, Md., Oct. 7 -- To remarry in Maryland after a Mexican divorce is to commit bigamy, a jury decided in Circuit Court here today when Justin H. Edgerton, New York credit executive, was convicted and received an eighteen-month "suspended sentence."
Ralph Adrian Gushee, for forty-one years proprietor of the historic Clarernont Inn, Riverside Park and 126th Stret, died there yesterday of a heart ailment after a week's illness. His age was 67.

CHENGTU, China, Sept. 13 -- Lysistrata, it will be remembered, had her own method for preventing the war of Greek against Greek. The wife of a carpenter in Chengtu, capital of Szechuan, China's most civil war-torn province, has evolved her own.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 -- Movements of vessels follow. All dates are Oct. 6 unless otherwise specified.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 -- They can ring the tells In Cuba as well as New York tonight. Stocky Adolfo Luque, Cuban right-hand relief star of the New York Giants, slipped a third strike past the swinging bludgeon of Joe Kuhel by the safe margin of a foot to end the Washington Senators' dying world's series threat.

GENEVA, Oct. 7 -- Germany served notice today that she would use her veto right, which the unanimity rule of the League of Nations gives, to prevent the adoption of the resolutions dealing with German refugees and minorities. She did this after both resolutions had been watered down considerably, partly to win her consent but more to meet the objections of other powers.

CHICAGO, Oct. 7 -- The twin debuts of Clark Shaughnessy as coach and Jay Berwanger at halfback on a rejuvenated University of Chicago football team saw the Maroons score a 32-to-0 victory today over a stubborn eleven from Cornell College of Iowa.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 -- President Roosevelt today took the unusual step of removing from office William E. Humphrey, a Republican member of the Federal Trade Commission. He asked Mr. Humphrey in July for his resignation, and this was refused.

THIS book is a kind of inspired home movie that can be highly recommended to strangers. William Graham Sumner always impressed both in person and in print and it has long seemed natural for those who know anything at all about him to speak of him rather fondly and intimately as of a mountain they have climbed.
Signs accumulated last week that the estrangement between the Wall Street banking community and the administration in Washington which has existed since last March, was being dissolved.

BERLIN, Oct. 7 -- While the Reich Ministry of Economics has turned against interference with big business still in Jewish hands because this proves unprofitable during the present economic crisis, the social ostracism of the German Jews continues unchecked.

Supreme Court Justice Salvatore A. Cotillo granted yesterday the application by the New York County Republican Committee to compel the Board of Elections to accept the certificate of nomination of its candidates for the Supreme Court in the district comprising New York and Bronx County, although the certificate was tendered a day late.

TOWARD the end of this personal narrative of Mr. Dell's, written in place of the autobiographical novel he had once hoped to complete, the author describes his surprise at learning that there "was a fringe of the general public" which fondly believed him to be an "apostle of Freedom in Love."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 (AP) -- President Grau of Cuba was reported today to be planning changes in his Cabinet next week which would make it entirely neutral. The State Department was so informed by Dr. Manuel Marquez Sterling, representative of the Cuban Government in Washington, after he had talked by telephone with President Grau in Havana.
OUR present cities are physically obsolete. They are unable either to satisfy the demands made by modern living or to make efficient use of opportunities offered by modern technics.
EXETER, N.H., Oct. 7 -- Phillips Exeter today defeated a powerful Yale freshman eleven, 13 to 7, in the first victory for the preparatory school over a Yale cub eleven in several years.

PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 7 -- Princeton University has 16,717 living alumni, according to the triennial directory recently published by the Graduate Council under the direction of its secretary, Thurston J. Davies.

SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Oct. 7 -- The new Springfield Museum of Fine Arts was opened formally this evening. The ceremonies included a brief address by Charles de Fontnouvelle, French Consul General, officially representing the French Government, which has lent in honor of this occasion a painting from the Louvre in Paris.

BROADCASTERS have a deep musical reservoir into which to dip their program buckets. The classics and jazz have been flowing into that pool for centuries. It ripples with tunes created by the masters; it surges with the modern blare from Tin Pan Alley.

THE WIZARD OF OZ" has been purchased for the screen by Samuel Goldwyn, whose announcement includes the information that he plans to make "an intimate fantasy" out of the juvenile classic. As a musical comedy it ran for several years without missing a performance, but Mr. Goldwyn will be satisfied with a little less than that for his film version.

TWENTY years ago Eills Island was a very busy place. There were many days when 5,000 prospective American citizens were examined and passed for entry. But now days when 500 aliens pass through Ellis Island are rare.

The shifting political panorama, not only here but abroad, has brought an entirely new group of public figures to the foreground and thrown many others who occupied the limelight a year ago into total eclipse.

HITLER'S movement is called youth movement and during the first months of the Nazi rule, while I was In Germany, this certainly seemed to be true. The streets of every city swarmed with brown shirts, echoed to the sound of marching men and Hitler songs; there were parades, monster mass meetings, celebrations of all kinds, day in and day out.

PARIS. Oct. 7 -- The publication of figures for August showing a continued decrease in tax receipts as compared with budgetary estimates has brought renewed discussion of the possibility of balancing the 1934 budget.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 -- A civic war on crime, in which general enlistment of the American people will be sought, will be formally declared and a mass offensive will be planned at a three-day conference called to open here Thursday.
SYRACUSE, N.Y., Oct. 7 -- Syracuse opened its 1933 season today by trouncing Clarkson Tech, 52 to 0. The Orange eleven got revenge for last year, when Clarkson held it to a 13-6 victory.

WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., Oct. 7 -- President Harry A. Garfield of Williams College today tendered his resignation to the board of trustees, to take effect June 30, which will be on the one hundred and fortieth anniversary of the founding of the college.

The annual Armistice Ball under the auspices of the First Division Lieutenant Jeff Feigl Post will be held the night of Nov. 14 in the new ballroom of the Astor. Colonel William Harrell heads the general committee for the ball. The ballroom will be transformed into a military setting for the event, with the decorations of the boxes, lighting and promenade carrying out that effect.
BERKELEY, Calif., Oct. 7 -- With a last-minute finish that sent 60,000 fans into a frenzy, California's rejuvenated Bears came from behind to upset St. Mary's, 14 -- 13, today.

ORLANTDO, Fla., Oct. 5 -- Florida long has nursed an ambition to offer the world tax-free homesteads. Now, when the State is considering voting on such a proposal, the people are being told that they cannot defeat the inexorable law which is that you cannot eat your cake and have it, too.
BRONXVILLE, N.Y., Oct. 7 -- Mrs. Charles R. Gibsbn of Bronxville will open her home on Monday for an exhibition and sale of handicraft made by refugee women in the Near East.

HAVERFORD, Pa., Oct. 7 -- A warning against threatened taxation of the national educational institutions as a "public calamity" which would crush the mainsprings of knowledge and research was voiced by Dr. James Rowland Angell, president of Yale University, speaking today at the Haverford College centenary celebration.

With Captain Sid Luckman scoring every point, Erasmus Hall High School launched its football campaign with a 20-0 victory over the Brooklyn College freshmen yesterday at Erasmus Field, Brooklyn. With the exception of the opening quarter, the winners tallied in each session.

DANBURY, Conn., Oct. 7 -- Hollyrood Boris took two of three heats to win the second division of the 2:18 trot at the banbury Fair today. Boris led the way in the first and third brushes, although Master Hanover raced the fastest mile of the day to score in the second whirl.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., Oct. 7 -- The Navy recovered, after Mercer tallied in the first quarter, to score four touchdowns in the other three quarters today and this won a stirring football game, 25 to 6.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, Oct. 7 -- Climaxing a successful Summer series of aquatic events, a gala water carnival, preceded by a costume parade and a torchlight tattoo, will be staged at the Langton Hotel on Friday.

ST. LOUIS, Oct. 4 -- Salem is a small town in the Missouri Ozarks but a court decision there this week may easily establish a precedent which will nullify all efforts of the Federal Public "Works Administration to assist communities In the State, thereby threatening the entire fabric of rehabilitation so far as Missouri is concerned.

THE Folk Festival Council opened its second season of Sunday evenings at the New School for Social Research last week with a session devoted to the folk dances of New England. Perhaps this choice of native material and the enthusiasm with which it was received can be considered a favorable augury for a season in which the American dance seems about to be crowded out of its own territory by importations from abroad.

MOSCOW, Oct. 6 -- It is just nine years since the Soviet Government finally abandoned the prohibition experiment by the re-introduction of vodka at approximately its prewar strength of 40 per cent alcohol.

The excise tax on dividends, enacted in the National Industrial Recovery Act, is imposed at the rate of 5 per cent upon the receipt of such dividends as are required by the Revenue Act of 1932, for income tax purposes, to be reported in the gross income of the recipient.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Oct. 7 -- A stalwart Ohio State eleven ran roughshod over the Cavaliers of Virginia before a crowd of 42,000 today to score a 75-to-0 victory. It was the largest score ever made in Ohio's Stadium.

BOSTON, Oct. 4 -- New England agriculture is having relatively a good year. The darkest spot in the picture is the milk industry, still unstabilized in spite of long-continued attempts to unify the producers and control the price. But truck gardening returns are excellent.
PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 4 -- When some one accuses Pennsylvania of being "dilatory" in spending Federal money these days an amazed onlooker may be pardoned for asking why.

BEING snowed under alone for five months is an experience that, happily, does not fall to the lot of many persons. Augustine Conrtauld tells how it feels in his contribution to "Northern Lights," the story of the British Expedition to Greenland to explore a Northern Air Route under the young Cambridge explorer "Gino" Watkins.

Plans for the relief of Jews suffering in Germany under Hitlerism were outlined yesterday by Rabbi Jonah. B. Wise, national fund raising chairman of the American Jewish Joint Distributaion Committee. The plans cover a program extending to next April, and in the meantime a further program will be formulated.

CHICAGO, Oct. 7 (AP) -- Yonkel, racing in the silks of A.A. Baroni, Reno (Nev.) sportsman, today easily won the Harvey Handicap, worth $2,060 to the winner, over one mile and a furlong at Washington Park.

George Prevosti, Curtis star, led borne the field in Group 1 as the annual series of city P.S.A.L. cross-country runs opened at Van Cortlandt Park yesterday. The Victor's time for the course of two and three-eighths miles was 12:18.

The application of the NRA to the oil industry is considered to have been highly successful so far and the consensus in the industry is that if Secretary Ickes and others who are charged with administering its affairs under the code continue to work along their present practical lines the industry will operate on a reasonably profitable and sound basis.

LEIPZIG, Oct. 6 -- The new German Goddess of Justice as unveiled before the Lawyers' Congress in session here by Dr. Frank, Reiche Commissioner for the Judiciary, will conform strictly to Nordic ideals as cherished in Nazi State, which means that she will be a blonde.

To raise funds for the maintenance of the Walter Scott Free Industrial School, 55 West Sixty-eighth Street, and the Lulu Thorley Lyons Home, in Claverack, N.Y., a card party will be given Nov. 15 in the grand hallroom of the Waldorf-Astoria.

LONDON, Oct. 7 -- With the utmost secrecy, Professor Albert Einstein sailed for New York from Southhampton tonight in tourist Class on the liner Westernland with Frau Einstein, who had embarked at Antwerp. The time of his departure was closely guarded.

Encouraged by the response or buyers of steel to the recent rise in prices of bars, plates and shapes, leading steel manufacturers are expected soon to advance prices of sheets. To the Editor of The New York Times: Commenting on Dean Shaler's admonition to Theodore Roosevelt, "It is a good plan not to make more of a damn fool of yourself than God Almighty intended you should," Arthur Elliot Sproul asks in a letter to THE TIMES whether "damn fool" is strictly the correct form of this useful phrase and if "damned fool" would not be more correct.

BLOEMFONTEIN, Orange Free State, Sept. 4 -- Sunday blue laws of a peculiarly rigid type have suddenly sprung into prominence here. In South Africa, as in the United States, they are a matter of provincial, or State, rather than national concern, but they are taken seriously by thousands of people.

LONDON, Sept. 22. WHEN, last August, Sir Barry Jackson organized his annual festival at Malvern, giving a series of plays historically representative of English drama from the earliest times to the present day, James Bridie's "A Sleeping Clergyman" was chosen as the modern instance, and having pleased audiences there has now been brought to London.

New York City's fandom tendered a whole-hearted reception to the world's champion Giants as the National League stars descended from their special train at the Pennsylvania Station last night. A crowd of 2,000 ardent rooters was on hand in the huge terminal as the Giant special drew in at 9:25, after a trip of a little more than five hours from Washington.
Tammany moved quickly yesterday to rehabilitate its city ticket, badly shattered by the "withdrawal" from it of M. Maldwin Fertig. candidate for President of the Board of Aldermen.
MANILA, Oct. 7 -- The latest moves in the independence fight have further confused rather than clarified the situation.

THE trial of Isidor J. Kresel on a charge of aiding in the misapplication of funds of an affiliate of the Bank of United States calls attention again to one of the largest bank failures and most involved liquidations in the nation's financial history.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 7 -- A crowd of 10,000 attended the Huntingdon Valley bunt races today on the estate of George W. Elkins, near Bethayres. The opening event had so many entries it wes necessary to run it in two divisions.
HAMILTON, N.Y., Oct. 7 -- Colgate's Red Raiders trounced St. Lawrence today, 47 to 0, after the visitors bad held the Raiders to fourteen points in the first half.
KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Oct. 7 -- After its reserves bad been hard pressed, the University of Tennessee was forced to employ its regulars today to defeat a stubborn Mississippi State eleven, 20 to 0.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 -- Weath conditions were made to order f today's world series game. The sun's warm rays bathed field a stands and made topcoats supe fluous raiment.
MEMPHIS, Tenn., Oct. 7 (AP) -- Bill Terry enthusiasm swept Memphis with renewed fervor today when his New York Giants became champions of the baseball world.

PARIS, Oct. 7 -- The French Government up to tonight had received no direct information concerning Germany's communications to Great Britain and Italy about what she proposes to reply at Geneva on disarmament.
FALL RIVER, Mass., Oct. 7 -- Stanley Alden Aldrich Sr., for thirty years a member of the cotton brokerage firm of Aldrich Hawkins until his retirement in 1927, died here today in Truesdale Hospital.

The dollar rallied sharply yesterday to 66.21 cents, measured in terms of the franc, a rise of a cent from Friday's close. The belief that the administration has turned its back for the time being upon inflationary measures continued to be the chief sustaining force.
PALO ALTO, Calif., Oct. 7 -- Stanford University's eleven had a hard battle on its hands today, but succeeded in defeating Santa Clara, 7 to 0.

CHICAGO, Oct. 7 -- A rearrangement of the books of the Bible, with Genesis yielding its traditional first place to Amos and becoming seventeenth, will be found in the "Short Bible," which will be published Monday by the University of Chicago Press.

ONE day last week the world's greatest airship, the Macon, quietly slipped its moorings at Lakehurst, proceeded South almost to Virginia and then Sailed for 300 miles up the coast, commanding with its sharp-eyed lookout thousands of square miles of the Atlantic Coast, casting its protective shadow over the homes of 20,000,000 people and now and then sending forth from his cavernous interior a scouting plane capable of flying more than three miles a minute.

A mid-season, furniture show, first to be held at the New York Furniture Exchange in years, will be staged here the week of Nov. 10 to 17, it was learned here yesterday. The exhibition will be held to give buyers a chance to view early Spring lines in advance of the formal Spring opening scheduled for January.

PANAMA, R.P., Oct. 4 -- Partisan political discussions appear to have occupied most of the time of the Colombian Congress during the two months that it has been in session. Although many laws have been introduced, few have been passed.

SCHENECTADY, N.Y., Oct. 7 -- An effective Union College offensive consisting of passes and line plays defeated Hobart today by a score of 32 to 0 in the twenty-fifth game of their series begun in 1896. Dain scored three touchdowns and Smerad and Stevenson one each.

The undefeated Curtis High School football team vanquished George Washington High of Manhattan, 20 to 6, yesterday before 4,000 spectators at Thompson's Stadium, Staten Island. The game was the season's opener for the losers.

Proponents of the improvement of the New York State Barge Canal and the conversion of the Chesapeake Delaware River Canal into a deep-sea ship waterway, advanced their causes during the week at meeting in Albany and Washington.

Domestic production of rayon yarn during the current year will reach a new high record of approximately 200,000,000 pounds, according to comment yesterday In the market. This is an increase of about 35 per cent over last year's total of 131,000,000 pounds and a gain of 27 1/2 per cent over the 1931 record of 144,800,000 pounds.

A Famous English Home. The home of WALTER BAGEHOT, the English ecnomist and journalist, is offered for private sale. It stands in Langport, in Somerset, where he was born and where he died, and is described as having a "stately front" and as commanding beautiful views that include the Somerset, Dorset and Devonshire hills.

LONDON, Oct. 7 -- Surprise, and even resentment, has been expressed in certain quarters at the British Government's action in making representations at Washington in regard to the new United States cruisers. Some American critics profess to see in this action an attempt to interfere with American domestic affairs.

BERLIN, Oct. 7 -- The Ministry of Justice in a detailed memorandum explaining the Nazi aims regarding the German penal code today announced its intention to authorize physicians to end the sufferings of incurable patients.

HOLLYWOOD. THE four corners of the earth continue to be drawn to the screen both actually and synthetically. Newest of the "fact" pictures is "Jungle Red Man" which MGM will make with the Tariano Indians near the headwaters of the Amazon, the studio announced this week.
The recent news from Germany shows fairly definitely that the German Government has prepared a concise program for the economic reconstruction of that country.
MADISON, Wis., Oct. 7 (AP) -- Wisconsin showed potential power in its 1933 football debut today by defeating Marquette, 19 to 0.

MARIE DRESSLER, whose ability to make audiences laugh is exceeded only by her power to make them weep, did not choose to discuss the cinema when interviewed at the Savoy-Plaza recently. Here for a six-weeks vacation, she displayed toward Hollywood and all its works a reticence which, in others, might have been construed as affectation, but which, in Miss Dressler's case, was plain modesty.
BERLIN, Oct. 6 -- The National Press Law proclaimed by the Hitler government yesterday is easily the most daring and penetrating of the Nazis' innovations.

CHICAGO, Oct. 7 -- Liquidation in grains was in evidence again today on the Board of Trade. All classes of traders were on the selling side after a small advance had been made early in response to the government's latest plan to lift and maintain the prices of agricultural commodities.
CHICAGO, Oct. 7 -- The fastest outboard motor boats in the country today began their struggle for national championships. Both the amateur and professional titles in Classes A and C changed hands.

PARIS, Oct. 5 -- A velvet taupe cuirassier helmet trimmed with a black willow ostrich "horsetail" created a millinery sensation at the Longchamps races last Sunday. Officers' collars, braided jackets and soutache trimmed coat frocks stressed the military note.

COMMACK, L.I., Oct. 7 -- Miss Judy Johnson again demonstrated her ability as a jockey when she captured three of the six events at the racing meeting today on the John Carll track. Miss Johnson captured two races with her brown gelding, Mediaeval, and one with Tiger Face.

Making light of his impost of 120 pounds, the Stimulus colt Sgt. Byrne yesterday overwhelmed his opposition in the featured Remsen Handicap at Jamaica. A crowd of 8,000 persons saw John Simonetti's color-bearer come from back of a fast pace and gallop on to win by five lengths.

WARSAW, Oct. 6 -- The Polish national loan to cover the budget deficit for the current year was more than twice oversubscribed, 260,000,000 zlotys having been offered this week instead of the 120,000,000 the Treasury asked for. The government, therefore, has authorized bonds for the whole amount and will be able to balance the budget for fifteen months.

An early recovery in the grain and cotton markets gave some encouragement to stocks in yesterday's brief trading period. Business was at a low ebb in the security markets, however, and interest was centred largely in the commodities.

The indictment of Mr. F.B. CAMPBELL for refusing, in defiance of the Federal statute of March 9 and subsequent executive orders, to surrender to the Government gold in his possession, is avowedly an action to test the constitutionality of that law. The Government's lawyers frankly recognize that such a test ought to be made.

OMAHA, Neb., Oct. 4 -- There are so many sides to the whole program of national recovery that the Corn Belt, in common no doubt with most of the rest of the country, finds itself confused trying to keep track of the progress of plans, purposes and results.

MOTORISTS exploring the dramatic beauties and historic interests of the Hudson River Valley, and business men hastening up-State on matters of trade, are finding a new flavor and better travel on the road between Peekskill and Beacon provided by a new bridge over Fishkill Creek.

The rugged Oglethorpe University football team defeated Manhattan, 6-0, submitting it to a rude shock and its first defeat of the season, before a crowd of 8,000 at Ebbets Field yesterday.

He arrived on these shores in knee breeches, attended school in Boston and received his first theatrical training at Dr. Curry's Dramatic School.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 -- An accounting made public today by the Reconstruction Finance Corporation showed cash advances had now passed the three-billion-dollar mark, the total being $3,096,691,789,59 from the date of establishment, Feb. 2, 1932, to Sept. 30, 1933.
Registration for the city election on Nov. 7 starts today, and the indications -yesterday were that the biggest "get-out-the-yote drive" of recent years will be under way during the week.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 -- Industry must face the responsibility of providing work opportunities for its laborers, not only in the rush season, but at times when the laborers are dependent, William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, declared today in an address at the National Cathedral.

The seven-story business building at 400 Fifth Avenue, near Thirty-sixth Street, bought last July by Frederick Brown, operator, from the City Bank Farmers Trust Company, has been resold by him to a syndicate for investment. The building occupies a lot 27.7 by 120 feet and was sold subject to a first mortgage of $400,000.

Braun declared in his sermon yesterday morning at the Cornell Memorial Methodist Episcopal Church, 231 East Seventy-sixth Street. "Until the gospel of Jesus Christ is accepted," he said, "there will be no change, for He is the only one who can solve the questions of our time."

Mr. CHASE MELLEN Jr., the new president of the New York County Republican Committee, must sadden some of his partisans when he warns "statesmen" off the premises. This seems to be a notice to those "distinguished Republicans" who are always caterwauling about the evil case of their party here.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 -- Important changes in the Federal Securities Act, as well as the Glass-Steagall Banking Law, will be advocated at the next session, of Congress. Representatives of some financial institutions have contended that the Securities Law must be simplified to remove alleged uncertainties, which, they argue, have deterred underwriters and investment houses from offering new issues.

Tammany is ready to begin this week its drive for the re-election of Mayor John P. O'Brien and for the election of the rest of its city and county tickets.

LEAVENWORTH, Kan., Oct. 8 (AP) -- Federal prison doors clanged shut here today behind Harvey Bailey and Albert Bates, sentenced to life terms for participation in the $200,000 kidnapping of Charles E. Urschel.

George H. Sherwood, director of the American Museum of Natural History announced yesterday that Mrs. F. Trubee Davison, co-leader of the expedition sent to Africa by the institution of which her husband is the head, has added a lion and a leopard to the specimens collected by it for the Akeley African Hall.
ALBANY, Oct. 8 -- In the first nine months of the year 17,596 stock companies have been organized, according to the September report of Secretary of State Edward J. Flynn, made public today.

CHICAGO, Oct. 8 -- The American College of Surgeons made public today the report of its Hospital Standardization Committee, listing 2,384 hospitals in the United States and Canada on its approved list, or 67 per cent of a total of 3,554 examined during the year.

The world's consumption of all kinds of cotton during August totaled 2,179,000 bales, compared with 2,104,000 bales in July and 1,819,000 bales in August, last year, according to the New York Cotton Exchange Service. The consumption was the largest for an August since 1927, when such records were begun.

TOKYO, Monday, Oct. 9 -- The budget controversy between the Treasury and the army and the navy over the demands of the armed forces which again are exceptionally large has reached a most acute stage and the press is flooded with political speculations, some of which anticipate the fall of the Cabinet.

PARIS, Oct. 7 -- The Bank of France's statement a of Sept. 29 showed a fresh decrease of 109,000,000 francs in the gold reserve owing to the dispatch of gold to Holland. The price rise in gold in London also seems due to withdrawals of capital for the Continent.

Lieutenant Joseph Devery opened the tall iron gates on the Broome Street side of Police Headquarters yesterday, as he does every morning of the year, and entered the little park, where the cannas and petunias had begun to wither on their frail stalks.

ITHACA, N.Y., Oct. 8 -- The "blue rainbows" of nearly 100 stars, made by their ultra-violet rays, have been caught with a new aluminum mirror by Cornell astronomers and physicists on top of an 8,000-foot mountain peak in Arizona.

It was a happy fate that the son of the author of the picturesque definition of a college, JAMES A. GARFIELD, college president himself and later President of the United States, should have for twenty-five years sat on the Hopkins end of the log. No student on the other end could have found a more congenial companion than HARRY A. GARFIELD.
McKesson Robbins, manufacturers of drugs and chemicals, entire twenty-fourth floor in 155 E. 44th St. from the Jacob Ruppert Realty Corp., through the Cross Brown Co.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 -- The proposed sugar stabilization agreement has been scrapped by the Roosevelt administration, following conferences between President Roosevelt and Secretary Wallace.

The Citizens Budget Commission Will join with city employe groups in pressing a legal battle if the city administration goes through with its plan to withhold its contribution of $17,500,000 from the Teachers' Retirement System and the New York City Employes' Retirement System, Peter Grimm, the commission chairman, announced yesterday.

RIDGEWOOD, N.J., Oct. 8 -- Johnny Kinder of Jumping Brook, State open, golf champion in 1931 and 1932, added the New Jersey P.O.A. title to his string today at the Ridgewood Country Club by defeating Victor Ghezzi of Rumson, 7 and 6, in a thirty-six-hole final match.

President ROOSEVELT made use of the dedication of the memorial to SAMUEL GOMPERS in order to enforce a few homely but needed truths. Drawing a moral from the patriotic attitude of the Federation of Labor during the war with Germany, he sought to apply it to the war for industrial recovery in which the country is now engaged.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 -- Declaring that "better times are here," and that "prices are going up," under the stimulus of improved conditions. General Hugh S. Johnson, National Recovery Administrator, in a statement tonight, called upon all consumers to join in the "now is the time to buy" campaign which starts tomorrow.

To the Editor of The New York Times: It is hard for the small taxpayer to understand the enormous reduction in assessed valuations in the City of New York. This last billion, we note, swells the total for the last three years to four billions, approximately 20 per cent of the assessed valuation as it stood on the books three years ago.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 8 -- Steel manufacturers here are anticipating new orders totaling $10,000,000 before the end of the month. The contracts, when they come, will be this section's share of approximately 1,300,000 tons of steel for new construction, rails, fastenings and other heavy work.

ALBANY, Oct. 8 -- The suicide rate in the State for August, 14.4 per 100,000 of population, was the lowest for any month since September, 1929, while the homicide rate of 6.0 was the highest except for 1930 and 1931 since 1907, the Department of Health showed in statistics issued today.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 -- President Roosevelt returned this evening from a short boating trip on the Potomac to find no perceptible progress so far in the settlement of the labor troubles in the captive coal mine fields, the principal problem up for administration consideration at present.

THE political memories of Charles Edward Russell go back a long way into the American past. When Lincoln Steffens, his brother in muck-raking, was still, riding his pony, in the Sacramento Valley of California, Russell was listening in Iowa to stories about General Weaver, the man who ran for President on the Greenback ticket in 1880.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 (AP) -- Secretary Hull and his associates tonight were awaiting with considerable uneasiness developments at tomorrow's meeting of the steering committee of the disarmament conference at Geneva which is to consider Germany's arms demands.

John F. Curry, leader of Tammany, and Samuel Seabury, leader of the Fusion forces, were attacked as bosses yesterday by Harry M. Durning, Collector of the Port, who is campaign manager for Joseph V. McKee.

VICHY, France, Oct. 8 -- With France and Europe listening, Premier Edouard Daladier at the closing dinner of the congress of his party here today made it clear that he did not consider himself master of events.
The Fusion candidates rested yesterday, at the close of a hard week of campaigning, in preparation for four weeks of even greater activity between today and election day.

CHICAGO, Oct. 8 -- The processes of life and the mystery of mind and matter involve a mechanism very similar to a radio set, depending for their growth, development and functioning on a definite series of radiations of various wave lengths, emanating from the living substance of the body.

With just a few exceptions, the past week-end's scholastic football games produced; anticipated results, as all but a very few teams saw action. Most of the leading Eastern prep school elevens fared successfully, spine recording their second straight triumphs and others starting their schedules victoriously.

ALBANY, N.Y., Oct. 8 -- The annual hunting season is about to open and the woodlands soon will be filled with sportsmen. They will find plenty of game, according to Lithgow Osborne, State Conservation Commissioner, who pointed out today that reports indicate that there will be an abundance of deer as well as other game.

BOSTON, Oct. 8 (AP) -- The burly Boston Redskins today opened their National Profesisonal Football League home season by overcoming the New York Giants for a spectacular 21-20 victory before a crowd of 15,000 at Fenway Park.

Obligations of the United States Government that will mature within the next twelve months amount to $2,903,991,200. They consist of Treasury certificates of indebtedness, notes and non-interest-bearing discount bills.

A brilliantly conceived aerial attack engineered by Red Grange's Chicago Bears proved too much for the Brooklyn Dodgers at Ebbets Field yesterday and enabled the visitors to romp off the field with a 10-to-0 victory.

By the recent turn in the municipal election, it seems to have become a mortal struggle between two political machines. Their respective leaders are abusing each other like pickpockets. The most violent words in the politician's vocabulary -- words like "renegade," "traitor," "crook" -- hurtle daily through the air.
CHICAGO, Oct. 8 -- An "international incident" involving the United States and Hungary has been averted through an apology made to the Hungarian Consul to Chicago.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 (AP) -- Britannia, long famed as "the ruler of the waves," may drop out of the race for ocean-liner speed and size honors in the North Atlantic.

Sharp declines were the rule last week in trading on local commodity exchanges. Only coffee futures were able to withstand the trend downward. Trading volumes were smaller than in the preceding week. Cash quotations were also lower.
NIAGARA FALLS, N.Y., Oct. 8 -- Niagara University and Marty Brill's La Salle College eleven opened the football season here today by playing a 7-to-7 tie in the rain before 1,500 spectators.

Samuel Untermyer, the city's financial adviser, yesterday accepted the chairmanship of the independent committee backing Frank J. Prial for Controller, and in doing so explained his attitude toward candidates for the "Mayoralty and other offices.

CHICAGO, Oct. 8 -- Prices of hogs are around the highest of the season, the best light weight, animals selling at $5.40 a hundred pounds. A week ago they were $5.10. The average for hogs here at the end of the week was $4.80, compared with $4.20 on Sept. 30.

A critical but unbiased analysis of President Roosevelt's recovery legislation has been made by a research group at Teachers College, Columbia University, it was announced yesterday. The surveys, consisting of fourteen pamphlets and a manual treating with all important legislation passed at Washington since March, are to be known as the National Crisis Series.

CHICAGO, Oct. 8 (AP) -- Evidence that a huge clearing house for stolen securities had its operating headquarters here has been uncovered by Federal agents investigating the $250,000 Chicago mail robbery, for which twenty persons have been arrested and several indicted.
The new football season has been no more backward than those of the past in seizing the first possible moment for unexpected results.
Several business buildings and a factory were included in the New Jersey realty turnover reported over the week-end.

WESTBURY, L.I., Oct. 8 -- To its open-championship laurels the Aurora team today added the last high-goal polo honors of the season by defeating Greentree, 12 to 9, on International Field of the Meadow Brook Club in the final of the Monty Waterbury Memorial Cup tournament.

CHICAGO, Oct. 8 -- The outstanding development in surgery during the past fifty years is the recognition by physicians and laymen of the value of aseptic cleanliness, it was stated here today in an interview by Dr. J. Bentley Squier, president of the American College of Surgeons, on the opening here of the twenty-third annual clinical congress of the college.
