OKLAHOMA CITY, Oct. 8 (AP) -- George (Machine Gun) Kelly and his wife, Kathryn Kelly, the last principal defendants in the Urschel kidnapping, are to go on trial tomorrow morning before Judge Edgar S. Vaught, who yesterday sentenced Bailey, Bates and Mr. and Mrs. R.G. Shannon to life terms, suspended a ten-year sentence on Armon Shannon and gave two Minneapolis men, Clifford Skelly and Edward Berman, five years each.

With the city election four weeks away, the indications yesterday were that the race for the Mayoralty would be between F.H. LaGuardia, Republican-Fusion candidate, and Joseph V. McKee, independent Democrat.

A letter by Martin Luther about his religious beliefs, perhaps the most important piece of autographic material by the leader of the Reformation that ever has come to this country, has been brought here from Europe by Gabriel Wells, who arrived last week from England.

"Tares also" was the subject of the sermon yesterday morning at the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church, Fifth Avenue and Fiftyfifth Street, by the Rev. Dr. Charles. R. Brown, Dean Emeritus of the Yale Divinity School, who denied the theory held by some persons that there is no such-thing, as evil.
HAVANA, Oct. 8 (AP) -- Sniping at soldiers and ABC radicals from housetops occurred in various parts of Havana this afternoon. No casualties were reported.

Publication of a pamphlet in which lay and religious leaders of Christian opinion condemn anti-Semitism in Germany was announced yesterday by the American Jewish Committee. Under the title, "The Voice of Religion," the committee also presents editorials on Hitlerism, gathered from the religious, press of fifteen, denominations.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 8 (AP) -- Keith Gledhill of Santa Barbara, Calif., today won the men's singles crown of the Pacific Coast tennis championships by a surprising victory over Lester Stoefen of Los Angeles. The score was 3 -- 6, 4 -- 6, 6 -- 4, 9 -- 7, 6 -- 3.

The first Sunday afternoon concert of the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, Bruno Walter conducting, took place yesterday afternoon in Carnegie Hall. In its first part the program repeated the material of previous concerts of a week, including Mr. Walter's rarely beautiful and inspired reading of the Beethoven "Pastoral" symphony.

CHICAGO, Oct. 8 -- The American League salvaged a bit of supremacy in post-season competition with the National League today when the White Sox, sixth-place team in the junior circuit, defeated the Cubs, third-place National League team, 5 to 1.

It would be a bold man who should advocate under any circumstances, and least of all under present circumstances, more government red tape. And yet a few of those preliminary checks which commonly pass by that name might come in handy even now in some cases. Take the proposed Fifty-seventh Street Bridge over the Hudson, for example, GUSTAV LINDENTHAL'S dream.

Preparatory to setting in motion the machinery that will give effect to the bankers' code of fair competition, the American Bankers Association is mailing to all banks in the United States copies of the code together with detailed instructions from the association's code committee.

Requested by Bernard S. Deutsch, president of the American Jewish Congress, to take the initiative in withdrawing the 1936 Olympic Games from Berlin, the executive committee of the American Olympic Committee took preliminary steps yesterday to have the matter brought on the floor of the quadrennial convention of the American Olympic Association at Washington next month.
Seven child-welfare organizations of New York City will join forces this Fall in a "Crusade for Chidren," with the double purpose of spreading knowledge of their work and of raising funds.

ROOSEVELT FIELD, L.I., Oct. 8 -- With 50,000 persons on the grounds of this airport and many more occupying every vantage point and in parked cars, the national charity air pageant ended this afternoon.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In THE TIMES editorial of Sept. 28 it was stated, in substance, that the fact that MR. McKee might change his mind and decide to accept an independent nomination for Mayor would not be a disqualification. It seems to me that if a man finds he has made a mistake and does not change his mind, that would surely be a disqualification.

CHICAGO, Oct. 8 -- On the anniversary of the great Chicago fire, the sole survivor of the O'Leary household where, according to legend, the cow kicked over the lamp, told today for the first time what happened at what now is 558 Da Koven Street.

SANDWICH, Mass., Oct, 8 -- A pair of checked pajamas, loud enough in the cabin of the 35-foot schooner Cimba, were no louder than the wind when they were hoisted as a distress signal during the northeast gale which lashed Cape Cod last night, but they brought aid from the Sandwich Coastguard station after the Cimba's three-man crew had barely kept their staggering craft offshore when their engine failed in the height of the gale.
Ed Danowski, burly Fordham football captain, assumed the lead in the race for Eastern individual scoring honors over the past weekend as the 1933 campaign got into full stride.

Little was indicated last week, on the Stock Exchange or in the markets for staple products, except inability of dealers to make up their minds. Speculative opinion seemed to change from day to day; speculative prices rose and fell alternately, frequently ending where they were a short time before.

Former State Senator Abraham Kaplan, long prominent in the political, legal and civic life of the city, was selected last night as manager of the city-wide campaign for the election of Mayor O'Brien, Frank J. Prial and Milton Solomon.

An analysis of the water-borne traffic at the port of New York in the recent Summer season shows improvements in many details, some of which had been steadily on the down-grade for three years, the New York Port Journal announced yesterday.

LONDON, Oct. 7 -- The Economist's fortnightly index of commodity prices in Great Britain, based on the average of 1927 as 100, stood on Oct. 4 at 64.7, as against 65.3 a fortnight before and 60.4 on Sept. 18, 1931, just before British suspension of gold payments.

BAY SHORE, L.I., Oct. 8 -- Hiding in a clump of bushes, Felice Errante, 60 years old, a jeweler of Brooklyn, shot and seriously wounded two of his daughters as they walked on Washington Avenue, Nesconset, this afternoon.

MADRID, Oct. 8 -- The formation of a coalition Cabinet today by Diego Martinez-Barrios ended a political impasse that threatened to involve Spain in its most serious trouble since the abdication of King Alfonso.

HOLLYWOOD, Oct. 8 (AP) -- The sons of two Hollywood film celebrities were christened in a double ceremony here today. They were Richard Ralston Arlan, 4 1/2 months old, son of Richard Arlen, screen star, and Jobyna Ralston, formerly of the films, and Gary Evan Crosby, 3 1/2 months, sort of Bing Crosby, actor and singer, and Dixie Lee, former actress.

Re-elected, President A.J. Weber of Brooklyn was chosen yesterday to head the New York Society of Teachers of Dancing, Inc., for the fourth consecutive term at the October meeting of the organization in the Hotel Astor. Roderick J. Grant of Yonkers and Elsa Heilich of Elizabeth, N.J., were chosen first and second vice presidents, respectively.

The Citizens Union made public yesterday its recommendations to the voters on the six referenda to be submitted on election day. The organization urged approval of four of the six and called for defeat of the two others.

AM increasing number of people in the United States are apprehensive of currency inflation and fearful of its results. Eight distinguished men, representing both major political parties, have approved and sponsored a series of articles presenting their viewpoint on the money problems of the day. The series is appearing in this newspaper in sixteen consecutive daily chapters. The fifteenth is presented herewith.
DUBLIN, Oct. 8 -- Further attempts to obstruct a meeting of the United Ireland party at Castlebar were made today when General O'Duffy, Frank MacDermott and other Opposition leaders spoke.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Oct. 8 -- The growing problem of crime is a direct challenge to American educational methods, Dr. Robert C. Clothier, president of Rutgers University, told the American Prison Association, here tonight.
TEHERAN, Oct. 8 -- Timurtash Khan, former Minister of the Court and for ten years the most important man in Persia next to the Shah, died in prison today of a heart attack. He was 45 years old.

An air service between New York and Atlanta has just put on a plane furnished with an upper and a lower berth for those who are not satisfied with a sitting posture during the night and want to sleep comfortably. The dimensions are six feet five inches by two feet four inches.

Taking the Republic of Uruguay to task as having made insufficient provision for service on its bonds held by American investors, the Institute of International Finance indicates that British creditors are receiving better treatment. The institute, which is conducted by the Investment Bankers Association in cooperation with New York University, issued yesterday a bulletin on the republic's finances.
BUENOS AIRES, Oct. 8 -- The newspaper La Prensa editorially urges an indefinite postponement of the Pan-American Conference, scheduled to open in Montevideo in December.

GENEVA, Oct. 8 -- Norman H. Davis, United States delegate to the disarmament conference, is expected to arrange a conference between the representatives of France and Germany in which they can thresh out their armament differences.

Hitler rendered the Jews a signal honor in selecting them as the first victims of his war on human freedom and peace, the Rev. Dr. Stephen S. Wise said in his sermon yesterday morning at the Free Synagogue, worshiping in Carnegie Hall.
One person was killed and three others slightly injured when two sedans were in collision yesterday afternoon at Sixty-first Street and Seventy-fifth Avenue, Glendale, Queens.

Charles Scribner's Sons announce that until further notice they will ''remainder" no copies of any copyright trado book. "We have long held the conviction," these publishers say, "that the binding of sheets to be remaindered and the dumping on the market of large overstocks has been prejudicial to the best interests of the book business.

The golden, jubilee of the Mission of Our Lady of the Rosary for the Protection of Irish Immigrant Girls, located at 7 State Street, was celebrated yesterday in four parts of tire city. It included two processions, a solemn high mass and a reunion meeting.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 -- In six months the International Ladies Garment Workers Union has grown from the twenty-third organization in the American Federation of Labor to the third, according to David Dubinsky, president, in a report made today at the quarterly meeting of the executive board.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 (AP) -- To clear up any doubtful points, Ferdinand Pecora, investigator of the stock market, plans to discuss in New York tomorrow with Richard V. Whitney, president of the New York Stock Exchange, a questionnaire sent to Mr. Whitney by Mr. Pecora as counsel for the Senate Banking Committee.
THE Committee on Early Autumn Decorations has made the following, recommendations:
'Long-term" faith was advocated yesterday by Dr. Harry Emerson Fosdick in his sermon at the Riverside Church.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 8 (AP) --Silence from the operators of "captive" mines and a split in the ranks of the men tonight met President Roosevelt's plea that thousands of striking coal miners go back to work pending adjustment of differences.

PARIS, Oct. 8 -- French leaders show no desire to follow other nations in denouncing the tariff truce sponsored by Secretary of State Hulk. They have regarded the truce as having little meaning because it was considered broad enough to permit almost any interpretation.
BUFFALO, N.Y., Oct. 8 -- Displaying a stone-wall defense that smothered the Georgetown University running attack, Canisius College scored a surprising 6-to-0 victory over the Hilltoppers today.

More than 125,000 members of Holy Name Societies marched yesterday in parades held in communities throughout Northern New Jersey. The parades were held under the auspices of the Diocesan Federation of Holy Name Societies of the Newark Diocese of the Roman Catholic Church.

Declaring that the sole issue in the coming mayoralty election is "a decent or a rotten city," the Rev. Donald B. Aldrich, rector of the Protestant Episcopal Church of the Ascension, Fifth Avenue and Tenth Street, endorsed the Fusion movement in a pastoral letter printed in the church bulletin yesterday.

BERLIN, Oct. 7 -- In the last statement of the Reichsbank there is shown an addition of 13,000,000 marks to gold holdings, but the exchange reserve is lower, having fallen to a mere 40,000,000 marks. The consequence is that the old proportion between gold and exchange reserves obtaining before 1931 is radically changed.

Of the billion dollars in currency which have gone back to the Federal Reserve banks and the Treasury since the end of February, about half consists of bills in denominations of $50 and over. This is ample evidence that the return flow has been from hoards and not from active circulation, since relatively little use is made of the larger denominations in day-to-day transactions.

Glory Enough for All Despite the close and thrilling contests which marked this year's world series, the attendance was disappointing. The clubs "in the money" will not have nearly so large an amount to divide as in former years.

MADRID, Oct. 8 -- Diego Martinez-Barrios announced today the formation of a coalition Cabinet, including all the republican parties except the Socialists. Although refusing to participate in the government, the Socialists, headed by former Premier Manuel Azana, promised their tacit support.
PITTSBURGH, Oct. 8 -- Western Pennsylvania's coal strike has cost operators and miners directly $7,845,000. Indirectly the district has suffered a business loss estimated at more than $20,000,000.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 8 -- Labor troubles resulting in the closing of several steel plants exerted a restrictive influence upon steel buying last week and the market was dull. Production has been supported in part by orders placed to take advantage of prices no longer available, particularly in sheets and strips.

CHICAGO, Oct. 8 -- A wave of buying that ranges from merchandise to steel and other lines has come in and has resulted in the best general feeling among merchants and manufacturers that has appeared in a year. This buying is ascribed to the necessity for stocking up and the anticipation of advanced prices.

Removal of virtually all restrictions on the sale of 3.2 beer and liberalization of any future regulations governing the sale of wine were recommended yesterday in a further instalment of the prohibition study sponsored by John D. Rockefeller Jr. as the most promising method of encouraging temperance after repeal.

The Governors Island four took a 2-0 lead in the series for the Colyer Trophy yesterday by defeating, the First Division polo team, 8 -- 7, before 6,000 person, the largest turnout of the year at Fort Hamilton, Brooklyn. Governors Island won the first game last month.

HAMILTON, N.T., Oct. 8 -- Colgate in 1932 was the perfect football team, the bright jewel of the Eastern, gridiron, firmament. Davis may be ranked as the greatest tackle to wear the Maroon since the days of Belf West. Kerr admits he has considerable possibilities, though he won't say that he is a world-beater until he has proven it.

Reports from up-State regarding the presence of game seem encouraging. From all accounts conditions are excellent for deer and game birds are abundant in many sections. Pheasant stocking by the State and the distribution of pheasant eggs have served to provide many of these birds for the fields and the woods.

The role of religion as a "stabilizer" of the "irregular streams and forces of life" was the theme of a sermon, delivered by the Right Rev. Warren L. Rogers, Bishop of Ohio, at St. Paul's Chapel, Columbia University, yesterday morning.

CINCINNATI, Oct. 8 (AP) -- A field goal from the foot of Joe Lillard, big halfback, gave the Chicago Cardinals a 3-to-0 victory over the Cincinnati Reds in a National Professional League football game today.

HUNTINGTON, L.I., Oct. 8 -- The Brooklyn Cricket Club won the championship of the Metropolitan and New Jersey Cricket Association by defeating the eleven of the Crescent Athletic-Hamilton Club in the play-off today. The score was 110 to 65.

American intervention in Cuba would only complicate matters for the Cubans, who are capable of solving their own problems, the Right Rev. Hiram R. Hulse, Bishop of Cuba, declared in a sermon yesterday at St. Mary's Protestant Episcopal Church, 340 Alexander Avenue, the Bronx.

NEW ORLEANS, Oct. 8 -- Business was sluggish in the cotton contract market here last week, making price fluctuations narrow until near the week-end. Then a downward tendency developed because of the approach of the government's report based on crop conditions on Oct. 1, which will be issued tomorrow morning.

William T. Tilden 2d, once the world's ranking amateur tennis player and now dominating the professional field, gave further evidence of his prowess yesterday when he crushed Vincent Richards in straight sets, 6-3, 6-2, 6-2.

Dealers in builders' supplies will begin operating next Friday under the new code just approved for their branch of the construction industry. The compact setting forth the rules of fair competition in the building-supply field was signed by President Roosevelt on Oct. 3 and will become effective ten days from that date.

With cooler weather stimulating retail trade, activity in the wholesale markets here showed somewhat of a gain over the two preceding weeks. New merchandise for quick delivery as fill-ins on current stock was sought. Increases were noted in orders for both dressy and sports coats.
The New York Giants, world's champions!

BOSTON, Oct. 8 -- The steamer Jacob Ruppert, flagship of the Byrd Antarctic Expedition, though fully loaded for the voyage, was delayed in sailing until tomorrow as Admiral Richard E. Byrd tried by telephoned to obtain permission from Washington naval officials to borrow 500 tons of chain for ballast.

PHILLADELPHIA, Oct. 8 -- Headliners in the music world and on the stage will participate on Wednesday night in the public auction of unsold seats for the Saturday evening concerts of the Philadelphia Orchestra, it was announced today.

CHICAGO, Oct. 8 -- Traders in grain are looking to the government in Washington to determine what is to be done in the market, rather than to the fundamentals that usually have goverend their operations. So many different reports are coming from the capital that traders are unable to base their operations on recognized trade conditions.

In spite of labor difficulties, the steel mils in the Pittsburgh district increased operations last week sufficiently to offset declines in other districts, with the result that the national average of production held at 38 per cent of capacity, according to the magazine Steel.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 -- Virtually all of the debatable policies before the fifty-third annual convention of the American Federation of Labor will be considered during the second and concluding week of the meeting which begins tomorrow.

BABYLON, L.I., Oct. 8 -- Harry T. Peters's upstanding bay gelding David, piloted in his rounds of the hunter course by Richard Armstrong, today was awarded the hunter championship of the twelfth annual Babylon horse show. Reserve to the title winner was the chestnut mare Scartian, owned and shown over the jumps by Miss Constance Regan.

NEW HAVEN, Oct. 8 -- Professor Irving Fisher's index number of commodity prices, based on 100 as the average for 1926, is 71.1, which compares with 71.4 a week ago, 71.6 two weeks ago, 71.1 three weeks ago and 70.9 four weeks ago. The average of two weeks ago was the highest of the year to date; the highest July figure was 70.4.
VIENNA, Oct. 8 (AP) -- Fifty thousand Socialists, thronging the Vienna stadium, cheered white-bearded Burgomaster Karl Seitz today as he ridiculed the Dollfuss-Fey regime as "verbal fireworks."

ROME, Oct. 8 (AP) -- An interview with Premier Mussolini, published in The Echo de Paris, in which he was quoted as saying that it is necessary to finish with the old ideas of liberal capitalism was read today with considerable interest by the Italian public.

PITTSFIELD, Mass., Oct. 8 -- The Stockbridge Mission House Association, Inc., of which Miss Mabel Choate is president, held its annual meeting last night at her home on Prospect Hill. It was voted to increase the number of trustees from seven to eleven, and the following were chosen: Mrs. George H. Hall, who is treasurer; the Rev. Dr. Albert R. Brown, clerk, and the Misses Marian Hague and Laura M. Bragg.

Mayor O'Brien, Fire Commissioner Dorman and Mgr. Michael J. Lavelle, rector of St. Patrick's Cathedral, praised the men of the Fire Department, both living and dead, at the annual memorial exercises held yesterday at the Firemen's Monument, 100th Street and Riverside Drive.
WARSAW, Oct. 8 -- Through German Silesia the train passed amid silent factories, smokeless chimneys and empty fields. It was depressing, Germany seemed, indeed, to be in a bad way.

CHICAGO, Oct. 8 -- When the final gun was fired this afternoon ending the national outboard championships, two of the eight titles in the regular classes had been taken by Eastern drivers and six by racers from the Middle West. The Pacific Coast failed to gain a title.
LONDON, Oct. 8 -- The British Cabinet is expected to deliver a flat refusal to Germany when it meets tomorrow to consider probably the gravest crisis simce the disarmament conference began.

The Brick Presbyterian Church, Fifth Avenue and Thirty-seventh Street, will celebrate on Oct. 29 the seventy-fifth anniversary of the dedication of its present edifice. The program is being arranged by the Rev. Dr. William P. Merrill, the pastor, and the Rev. Dr. James McCullough Farr, associate pastor.

BERLIN, Oct. 8 (AP) -- Dr. Paul Joseph Goebbels, Minister of Propaganda, called for loyal support of the Nazi regime by German-Americans in speaking today at the Carl Schurz Society's celebration of the 250th anniversary of the founding of the first German settlement in America.

Faith in man, not in God, was laid down as the fundamental basis of religion, yesterday by the Rev. John Haynes Holmes, pastor of the Community Church, meeting in Town Hall, 123 West Forty-third Street.

Mr. and Mrs. L. Clark Winter gave a dinner last night in the roof garden of the Waldorf-Astoria for Mr. and Mrs. Washington Dodge 2d. The other guests were Miss Cornelia Prime, Frank A. Vanderlip and John Begg.

St. Peter's College has acquired a new site in Jersey City for improvement, the Rev. Joseph S. Dinneen, S.J., president of the college, announced yesterday. The site is the former Young estate in Hudson Boulevard, between Glenwood and Montgomery Avenues.

ALBANY, Oct. 9 -- Banks, bond houses and other financial institutions are in receipt of a letter from State Controller Morris S. Tremaine,, giving a picture of the State's financial condition as of Oct. 1. He notes that "revenues are continuing at least to equal, and in some instances to exceed, the budgetary estimates."

ABOARD MOTOR SHIP WYATT EARP, Oct. 9 (By Wireless) -- Nearly 1,900 miles from Capo Town, South Africa, the Wyatt Earp, motor ship of the Lincoln Ellsworth Transantarctic Flight Expedition, which is bearing the expedition's plane, is rambling on before high winds and through choppy seas on her 7,000-mile long route to New Zealand, where Lincoln Ellsworth is waiting to take her to the Ross Sea.

HOLLYWOOD, Oct. 9 (AP). -- More than 500 Hollywood film players banded together today under the Screen Actors' Guild in an organization which severed connections with the New York stage and film actors' groups.

Failure of attempts to work out a system of socialized medicine was laid to "obstructionist tactics" by powerful groups of physicians, in the annual report of the Milbank Memorial Fund made public yesterday.

TRENTON, N.J., Oct. 9. -- After receiving a special message from Acting Governor Emerson L. Richards suggesting a study of liquor control, the Legislature adopted a resolution tonight authorizing the Acting Governor to name a "nonpartisan commission" of seven members to make a survey of liquor control measures.

BOSTON, Oct. 9 (AP). -- William M. Butler, former United States Senator, was named today receiver for the Hoosac Mills Corporation, described as the second largest manufacturer of fine textile goods in America. The company owns and operates mills for the manufacture of fine cottons, rayon and silk cloth in New Bedford, Taunton and North Adams.

LONDON, Oct. 9. -- Charles Laughton made his debut tonight as a member of the famous Old Vie Company, at a salary of u20 a week [about $93.85 at current rates]. He refused an offer of many times that amount for motion picture work in Hollywood, Calif., in order to gain experience in the plays of Shakespeare and other classics.
OTTAWA, Ont., Oct. 9. -- E.N. Rhodes, Dominion Minister of Finance, announced tonight the terms of the new loan open for subscriptions tomorrow. It is payable in Canadian funds.

In an effort to persuade the government that its plan for the big banks here to issue capital notes or preferred stock for sale to the RFC, the public, or both, is an uneconomic and useless gesture that could not accomplish the purpose that the government has in mind, a small delegation of Clearing House bankers will go to Washington today or tomorrow.

If Jacob Gould Schurman Jr., Fusion candidate for District Attorney, is elected, political protectors of racketeers will find themselves in jail, he promised yesterday in addressing the campaign school of the Women's National Republican Club.

BOSTON, Oct. 9 -- The original Roger van der Weyden "St. Luke Painting the Virgin," which arrived here last Friday from Berlin, Germany, where it had been sent to be restored, was opened today by officials of the Boston Museum and customs men.
TOKYO, Tuesday, Oct. 10. -- A Foreign Office spokesman indicated Continued on Page Fourteen.

WEST ORANGE, N.J., Oct. 9. -- Mrs. C.T. Williamson of Essex Fells and Mrs. J.E. Prizer of Essex County shared honors today at the end of the first day of the annual Fall 54-hole handicap medal play tournament of the New Jersey Women's Golf Association.

MOSCOW, Oct. 9. -- Where the Soviet has hitherto done its utmost to avoid tension with Japan, it is now determined to make Japan understand that this country will no longer tolerate what it considers disregard of its rights and offhand treatment of its protests concerning action against the Chinese Eastern Railway.

The five-story building at 183 Broadway, near Dey Street, is to be altered, at a cost of about $100,000, for Schwartz's Restaurant, according to Irwin Colvin, broker, who arranged a long-term lease of the structure for the Charles W. Wolf estate.
Memphis Bill Terry will manage the Giants for the next five years at a salary higher than any he has ever collected from the club.

GEORGE DANGERFIELD, who is writing a book on pre-war England for Harrison Smith, has likened the story of the Edwardian generation to a Greek tragedy hastening inexorably to its fateful denouement. The essence of the tragedy was that ail the storm signals pointed to it, yet no single person could do anything to avert collision.

GENEVA, Oct. 9. -- The steering committee of the disarmament conference met today with a full recognition of the fact that a chasm still divided the positions taken by Germany and by the other European nations.

The Manhattan Railway Company will sue its receiver, William A. Roberts, and the I.R.T. which leases it, for upwards of $30,000,000, Nathan Amster, president of the elevated company, announced yesterday in a letter to stockholders.

Samuel Seabury, chairman of the Fusion Campaign Committee, and F.H. LaGuardia, the Fusion nominee for Mayor, both turned their guns yesterday on former Aldermanic President Joseph V. McKee and the group that is backing him in his fight for the Mayoralty as an independent.

Offering of North American Trust Shares 1958 was announced yesterday by Distributors Group, Inc., sponsors of North American Trust Shares 1953, 1955 and 1956. A registration statement covering the new series was filed with the Federal Trade Commission on Sept. 18 and became effective yesterday.

PITTSFIELD, Mass., Oct. 9 -- The Lenox Art Room, of which Albert Sterner was one of the founders, has presented to the Lenox Library an etching, "Evening Wind," by Edward Hopper and a lithograph, "Young Woman," by Rockwell Kent.

Mayor O'Brien's program of reprisal against the Bronx Democratic leaders who swung to the candidacy of Joseph V. McKee ran into an unexpected snarl yesterday when it appeared he would be unable to remove Charles F. Griffin, Deputy Sanitation Commissioner, and Albert Liebenau, Deputy Commissioner of Water Supply, Gas and Electricity.

Without making an actual decision, Federal Judge John M. Woolsey indicated yesterday that, in his opinion, the Government of the United States, by act of Congress and by proclamation of the President, had been empowered to take action against the hoarding of gold.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 9 (AP). -- Possibility of a quick peace in the strike of 75,000 Western Pennsylvania miners appeared tonight with the announcement of Philip Murray, international vice president of the United Mine Workers of America, that Thomas Moses, president of the H.C. Frick Coke Company, had telegraphed he was ready for a conference with union officials.

Although the government's Crop Reporting Board yesterday raised its estimate of this year's yield of cotton by 471,000 bales, which was more than had been expected, prices on the Cotton Exchange yielded only 2 or 3 points and then advanced about 40 points and closed with net gains of 13 to 17 points.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 9 -- James Bryant Conant was formally installed as Harvard University's twenty-third president with a simple ritual in the college administrative building this afternoon.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 9. -- Relief was expressed in official circles that the Geneva disarmament conference did not blow up at today's meeting of the steering committee. State Department officials had regarded the meeting with considerable apprehension, in view of the possibility of drastic re-arming demands from Germany.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 (AP). -- The proposed sugar stabilization agreement crumbled completely today with formal announcement by Secretary Wallace that he had rejected it.

A resolution urging Governor Lehman to name a State commission to investigate the finances of the city and suggest methods of retrenchment was adopted yesterday by united real estate interests of the five boroughs.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 9. -- A group of 200 textile strikers marched on General Johnson's headquarters today, assailing the pay scale set up under the NRA and proclaiming that they would make their own codes "on the picket lines."

Tammany leaders moved yesterday to replace the name of M. Maldwin Fertig on the Democratic ticket with that of Milton Solomon, selected to make the race for President of the Board of Aldermen after Mr. Fertig had withdrawn.

New York's latest skyscraper, the R.C.A. Building in Rockefeller Center, soon will display an exhibition of architecture of some eighteen centuries ago as portrayed in a large-scale model of the ancient Roman temples of Baalbek in Syria.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 (AP) -- The Supreme Court today celebrated its busiest day of months by issuing orders in 307 cases.

The principal commodities were irregular or lower on local markets yesterday, with interest centred chiefly on sugar futures, which underwent the sharpest day's break since mid-July. Meanwhile the majority of the refiners posted prices 15 points higher at 4.75 cents a pound, effective at yesterday's close.

Gugllelmo Marconi left his hotel early yesterday morning on a radio inspection tour which began at the central headquarters of RCA Communications at 67 Broad Street. He saw the facsimile radio instruments demonstrated, also the facilities for handling foreign broadcast programs.

Fairly uniform strength in domestic corporation bonds and irregularly lower prices for United States Government issues and foreign loans on the Stock Exchange characterized a quiet session yesterday, in that market. Total dealings were only $8,781,000.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 9 -- Friends and military associates of Major Gen. Leonard Wood, late Chief of Staff of the army and Governor General of the Philippines, unveiled in the Harvard Memorial Chapel today a memorial tablet placed by sixteen who served with him as aides-de-camp.
WASHINGTON. Oct. 9. -- The Bureau of Navigation issued the following orders today, dated Oct. 6:

LAUREL, Md., Oct. 9 (AP) -- Hope to Do, carrying the royal purple silks of Admiral Clary T. Grayson, drove to an upset victory in the featured Eastern Handicap today. Under Apprentice Alien Tipton the Black Toney gelding led from flagfair to finish and at the end was easing up with a good two-length advantage.

After incoming vessels had been arriving with their navigators reporting the Atlantic as calm, the Red Star liner Minnetonka docked at Pier 60, North River, yesterday afternoon six hours late as the result of winds and heaving billows.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 9. -- The Federal Reserve Board's condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in 90 leading cities on Oct. 4 shows decreases for the week of $57,000,000 in net demand deposits, $15,000,000 in time deposits svnd $92,000,000 in reserve balances with Federal Reserve banks, and an increase of $19,00,000 in loans and investments.

Following the announcement of Kenneth Vought, Assistant United States Attorney, that the government had concluded the presentation of evidence against eight persons charged with conspiracy to divert commercial alcohol into bootleg channels, Judge Mortimer W. Byers in the United States District Court in Brooklyn yesterday ordered the dismissal of three of the defendants.

The organization of water transportation on the Atlantic seaboard to reduce unnecessary competition with rail and motor truck lines was discussed yesterday afternoon at a meeting of a special committee of shipping executives at the Maritime Association Building, 80 Broad Street.

Although the speculative fraternity continued yesterday to test the market carefully, there was a slow advance on the Stock Exchange, which was taken as an indication that traders are regaining their confidence. That was the commission houses' inference, at least.
Mayor O'Brien opened Fire Prevention Week yesterday when, he presented medals at City Hall to 200 school children who won the annual contest for essays on fire prevention in the home.

LOS ANGELES, Oct. 9 (UP). -- Net profit of $1,050,000 for the Union Oil Company of California for three months ended on Sept. 30, was reported today by its president, L.P. St. Clair. A quarterly dividend of 25 cents a share is payable on Nov. 10 to stockholders of record of Oct. 19.

PARIS, Oct. 9 -- Premier Edouard Daladier's declaration at Vichy yesterday that he was prepared to stake the life of his government on the financial reforms which he will introduce when Parliament reconvenes has opened the floodgates of speculation as to what he and his collaborators, Finance Minister Georges Bonnet, and Budget Minister Lucien Lamoreux, will propose.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 -- Upward revision of some of the minimum wage scales fixed in industrial codes, as well as reduction of work hours to less than forty, were among the proposals advocated today by Senator Wagner before the convention of the American Federation of Labor.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 (AP). -- Cotton production this year was forecast today by the Department of Agriculture at 12,885,000 bales of 500 pounds gross weight, compared with 12,414,000 bales indicated a month ago and 13,002,000 bales produced last year.

CHICAGO, Oct. 9 (AP) -- Leros, owned by J.C. Ellis of Owensboro, Ky., and ridden by Jockey G. Miller, won the top race at Washington Park today in a spectacular nose finish with Miss Melody. Desert Call, public choice, finished third in the six-furlong dash.

WARSAW, Oct. 9 (AP) -- One of Poland's most touching romances will culminate tomorrow morning when the aging, grief-bowed President, Ignace Moscicki, takes as his wife Mme. Mary Dobrzanska, young divorcee, whose life has been crossed by the shadow of tragedy.

CHICAGO, Oct. 9 -- Science has found a solution, to the problem of the narcotic addict who attempts to free himself of the habit, anesthetists of this country and Canada were told at their annual congress today.

HAVANA, Oct. 9. -- Four American officials of the Bethlehem manganese mines in Daiquiri, Oriente Province, for whose safety fears were held, fled unharmed to Santiago today. They said they were forced to escape to protect their lives after threats were made by the striking mine workers.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 -- Gold coin and bullion in circulation on Sept. 30 amounted to $312,630,877, a reduction of $132,294,000 in a year, while gold certificates outstanding totaled $232,148,049, a drop of $412,076,000, the Treasury announced today.

Democratic campaign headquarters at the Hotel Pennsylvania were opened formally last night, with a reception attended by Mayor O'Brien and other candidates. Frank J. Prial, who won the nomination for Controller in a primary fight against the organization, was not present when the reception began.
Ellsworth Vines has played his last Davis Cup match and professional tennis has wooed another prized recruit from the amateur ranks, according to an announcement made last night by William Tilden.

Don McCorkindale, South African heavyweight, won his first American ring struggle last night, without impressing as a world beater or even a dangerous man for some of the present crop of American fighters.
Sales of General Motors cars to consumers in the United States in September totaled 71,468 cars, against 86,372 in August and 34,694 in September, 1932, it was announced yesterday.

HAVANA, Oct. 9. -- Soldiers, marines and national police have been ordered held in their quarters beginning at midnight tonight to prevent possible disorders during tomorrow's celebration of Grito de Yara [Yell of Yara] marking the sixty-fifth anniversary of the sounding of Cuba's war cry for freedom from Spain.

Striped bass are being taken in several areas close to this city, according to reports received from fishermen within the past few days. The Montauk region is providing the largest of this species. Some catches include stripers well above fifteen pounds and one tipped the beam at twenty-two pounds.

CLEVELAND, Oct. 9 (AP) -- Milo Reno of Des Moines, Iowa, head of the farm holiday movement, has asked railway labor to cooperate in the holiday program and will obtain a hearing by the Railway Labor Executives Association at Washington Oct. 17.

SULLIVAN, Ind., Oct. 9. -- Following the bombings of several miners homes and a gun battle between miners and pickets at the Starburn Shaft, Governor McNutt ordered Sullivan County placed under, military rule today.

LYNCHBURG, Va., Oct. 9. -- The Lynchburg News and The Liynchburg Advocate, the two local newspapers owned by Senator Glass of Virginia, who was President Roosevelt's first choice for Secretary of the Treasury but declined the post, are not flying the Blue Eagle.

Dean Carl W. Ackerman of Columbia School of Journalism made public yesterday a statement emphasizing the importance of reaffirming the principle of the freedom of the press in the NRA newspaper, code. Dean Ackerman's statement, which will appear in the forthcoming issue of The Independent Journal of Columbia University, follows:
BERLIN, Oct. 9. -- American and other private. creditors of Germany will be able to get payment in full of sums due them if they are willing to use part of the funds to finance German exports.

Exclusive State sale of hard liquor in State retail shops for consumption off the premises only was proposed yesterday in a plan for liquor monopolies in States where alcohol is to be sold after prohibition repeal. The plan was detailed in a new instalment of the report of the results of a liquor control study conducted by Raymond B. Fosdick and Albert B. Scott and sponsored by John D. Rockefeller Jr.

ALBANY, Oct. 9 -- More than 45,000 men and women went back to work in factories in this State in September, Elmer F. Andrews, Industrial Commissioner, reported after scanning 1,653 statements from representative manufacturing concetns which report monthly.
WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., Oct. 9 -- The opening match in men's singles in the fifth annual Greenbrier Autumn lawn tennis championship was played this afternoon. In the large gallery were:

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Oct. 9 -- Legislation to check the criminal before the crime is committed, rather than extreme penalty laws, is needed for the protection of society today, according to Dr. Walter N. Thayer Jr., of Albany, New York State Commissioner at Correction.

In July President ROOSEVELT asked Mr. WILLIAM E. HUMPHREY, a Republican member of the Federal Trade Commission, to resign. The commissioner, appointed by Mr. HOOVER, had served but two years of a term of seven. In the polite correspondence that followed Mr. ROOSEVELT'S request, it appeared that it was not intended as a reflection upon the commissioner's past service.

Taken to Russia three years ago by his mother, Mrs. Sarah Grenoff, a widow and Russian citizen, William Grenoff, 11 years old, traveled alone from the interior of Russia back to his native land because he did not want to grow up to be a Communist.

The New York Stock Exchange has acquired the Lee, Higginson Co. building at 35-41 Broad Street, it was announced yesterday. The twelve-story structure, regarded as one of the most attractive in the financial district, was assessed by the city at $2,600,000 for 1933.

To the Editor of The New York Times: As a visiting European writer I have been traveling in the United States since October, 1932, and have viewed with admiration the rich and well-chosen material which is placed at the disposal of the public in the libraries and museums of even the minor cities.
Columbia in its customary light Monday workout yesterday at Baker Field directed all its efforts toward the contest with Princeton a week from Saturday.

WATCHING Mel Ott hit that home run in Washington, it was natural to think that all the inhabitants of New York were well pleased with Saturday's results. But that was a sad mistake. Under cover of the world's series excitement in Washington, some fellows in football uniforms executed a fiank movement and advanced on New York gridirons to do considerable damage.

Plans for new buildings and alterations filed with the Manhattan Department of Buildings during September showed a decided increase over the totals for the same month last year, according to a report issued yesterday by Samuel Fassler, Commissioner of Buildings.

Acting upon the request of 2,000 organized garage owners, the local NRA organization moved yesterday to stop all-night parking of automobiles in the city streets. Representatives of the garage owners, who recently concluded an agreement with the Garage Washers and Polishers Union under the NRA, called on Grover A. Whalen, NRA chairman.

BERLIN, Oct. 9. -- Trading on the Boerse was characterized today by a strong bond market and weakness in stocks. Bonds gained up to 2 1/2 per cent, despite the publication of per cent despite the publication of an optimistic report on business by the Institute for Business Research and an official announcement of further reduction in unemployment.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 (AP). -- Cotton of this year's crop ginned prior to Oct. 1 was reported today by the Census Bureau to have totaled 5,851,415 running bales, counting 195,128 round bales as half bales and including 616 bales of American-Egyptian.

A general pick-up, in retail sales in all stores in this city, in response to the nation-wide NRA buying campaign launched yesterday, was reported to Greyer A. Whalen City NRA Chairman, at NRA headquarters at the Hotel Pennsylvania, by H. Nelson Street, general manager of the National Retail Dry Goods Association.

The revolt in the Democratic organizations of New York City against the candidacy of Mayor John P. O'Brien and the leadership of John F. Curry, head of Tammany, which was begun in the Bronx, extended yesterday to Brooklyn and Queens.

CLEVELAND, Oct. 9. -- Herbert U. Nelson, secretary of the National Association of Real Estate Boards, today came to the support of the objectives of land developers and home builders assembled here to demonstrate to the government a need for Federal loans for building of individual homes.
F.H. LaGuardia, Fusion candidate for Mayor, said in an address yesterday that the McKee ticket was "appropriately named the 'recovery ticket.'"
BERLIN, Oct. 9 -- The much-her-alded screen play on the life and death of Horst Wessl, the youthful Nazi hero, was forbidden today by the Ministry of Propaganda.

RIVERHEAU, L.I., Oct. 9 -- The will and codicil of Mrs. Sarah Forrest Zabriskie of 23 Gramercy Park, Manhattan, and Nissequogue, St. James, filed for probate in the Suffolk County Surrogate's Court here, makes substantial bequests to several Protestant Episcopal churches and societies.

CHICAGO, Oct. 9. -- Heavy hogs had the call today in the live stock market here and prices advanced 10 to 25 cents a hundred pounds. Packers paid up to $5.55, equalling the highest mark since July, 1932, while the average was $5. Indications are that packers desire to make more lard, as stocks have been reduced heavily in the last thirty days.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 -- High officials of the administration were actively engaged today in conferences out of which may be evolved a great bank, designed to help liquidate the closed financial institutions of the country and release hundreds of millions of dollars in frozen deposits.

CHICAGO, Oct. 9 -- Shotgun executioners today assassinated Gus Winkler, North Side gang chief and public enemy in an effort to thwart the government's efforts, to solve the $250,000 Chicago Loop mail robbery of last December.

Nunc Pro Tunc. The decision of Justice Co-TILLO of the Supreme Court sustaining the validity of the Republican nominations of judges in this district was plainly based upon a broad interpretation of the election law.

WARSAW, Oct. 9. -- The exchange of ratification documents of the London pact defining an. "aggressor" will take place tomorrow between Soviet Russia and Rumania in the Polish Foreign Office. Nicolas Titulescu, Rumanian Foreign Minister, arrived here today and is the guest of the Polish Government.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 (AP). -- Crude petroleum production in the United States in August was 85,239,000 barrels, the commerce department announced today, saying that no State showed a material change in output, save Michigan, where production was 50 per cent above July.

BERLIN, Oct. 9 -- Next Sunday the distribution of Winter relief in Germany is scheduled to begin. It is hoped during the Winter to collect 500,000,000 marks [about $180,000,000] for the alleviation of hunger and suffering by means of the one-dish dinner once a month and the confiscation of 1 per cent of the net wages of all workers after other taxes have been deducted.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 -- The Reconstruction Finance Corporation, was represented today by Jesse H. Jones, chairman, as being prepared to advance funds to the Savings Banks Trust Company and the Institutional Securities Corporation of New York whenever application is made.

LISBON, Oct. 9. -- Panic and terror seized thousands in Oporto and in many Portuguese villages tonight as a result of a prolonged meteoric display. It was the grandest shower in many years, but the superstitious, believing the stars were falling to the earth, fled into the streets, screaming and invoking the mercy of heaven.

LONDON, Oct. 9. -- The British Cabinet held a long session today for discussion of the disarmament situation, but made no decision other than to continue efforts to save the Geneva conference by bringing France and Germany to terms.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In spite of an announcement in one of your recent issues to the effect that the so-called Dutch elm disease had been introduced into this country through a shipment of elm logs from Southern France, many persons and publications continue to refer to the disease as having been introduced into the United States from Holland.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Granted that the McKee candidacy is only politics, it may be doubted if it is smart politics, even if he should win. This country has long needed a regrouping of political parties into conservatives and radicals, and it looked as if Mr. Roosevelt was going to effect it.

The series of articles on money, of which this is the sixteenth and last, has been an attempt, as was set forth in the introduction, to discuss in terms which the layman could understand what money is, what its place is in the economic system and what it can and cannot do to promote recovery.

BASEL, Switzerland, Oct. 9. -- The World Bank board held its first meeting since the London Economic Conference today and heard informally the views of President Leon Fraser and Montagu Norman, governor of the Bank of England, both of whom have since visited the United States.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 9. -- Allegations that Henry Ford had not paid the debts of the Lincoln Motor Company as, it was contended, he promised when he bought it in 1922 for $8,000,000, wera made today by James Sweeten Jr., at the re-opening of a ten-year-old court fight involving the Ford Company and the Sweeten Automobile Company of this city.

A protest against certain provisions in the NRA code for motion pictures, including block and blind booking, and limitation on picture distribution to schools, churches and other non-theatrical agencies, has been addressed to President Roosevelt by the Motion Picture Research Council, headed by Dr. A. Lawrence Lowell, former president Of Harvard.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Oct. 9 -- Substitution of a modified convention, system for the direct primary method would allow candidates of moderate means to run for office and enhance free expression on the part of voters, Senator W. Warren Barbour told delegates to the New Jersey Newspaper Institute at the annual dinner at Cooper Hall, Rutgers University, tonight.

Quiet strength, in the security markets seemed yesterday to Wall Street to reflect the belief -- which was encouraged by reports from industrial centres -- that some of the major obstacles in the path of the recovery movement are being removed.

To the Editor of The New York Times: THE TIMES prints an article under the caption "Irish Look, to McKee for Political Jobs." Text and context proper might be humorous if it were not for the fact that the entire content reeks of seriousness. It seems that one Edward J. Flynn promised the Irish that Santa Claus, in the guise of Mr. McKee, would fill their stockings to overflowing if that gentleman were elected Mayor.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 -- Chairman Fletcher of the Senate Banking and Currency Committee investigating stock exchange practices expressed the opinion today that something should be done to end "excessive speculation" and "gambling" on the exchanges.

Plans to allot quotas in the American sugar market have gone awry. For several months Government agents and representatives of various groups of producers have been drafting an agreement. Secretary WALLACE calls it impracticable at the present time, due partly to "uncertainties regarding Cuban production" and partly to certain "difficulties of operation" disclosed by further study of the plan.

The voters of New York City turned out in force last night for the first day of registration and the tabulation revealed that 40,027 more persons registered on the first day than for the same period last year.

MOUNT KISCO, N.Y., Oct. 9. -- Mrs. L.C. DuBois of Wee Burn, former women's national senior champion, led the field in the one-day tourney of the Women's Westchaster and Fairfield Golf Association today.

BOSTON, Oct. 9. -- With 500 tons of navy chain laid between her oil tanks to bring her ballast up to the required weight, the steamer Jacob Ruppert, flagship of Admiral Richard B. Byrd's second Antarctic expedition, late this afternoon was pronounced ready to begin her long voyage to the south polar seas.

CEDAR LAKE, Ind., Oct. 9. -- Attacks on outboard motorboat world records were made today by the drivers who competed in the national championships at Chicago. They resulted in a-mile-a-minute speed being attained for the first time in the frail skimming shells that have motors slung over their sterns.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., Oct. 9. -- Playing with two partners, Walter Scheiber, brilliant young Hillcrest pro, finished first and second in today's one-day pro-amateur tournament held by the Long Island Golf Association at the Garden City Country Club.
Of all the sporting vocations, none is quite so hazardous and futile, so fraught with mortification and grief, as that of the football prophet.

BOISE, Idaho, Oct. 9 (AP). -- An assertion was made by President Ramon Grau San Martin of Cuba in a letter to Senator Borah, given out here today, that much matter made public about the new Cuban Government "originates from diplomatic and financial circles desirous of creating a local government subject to their beck and call.''

LONDON, Oct. 9 (AP). -- Offerings at the wool auction today amounted to 8,109 bales, of which 6,139 were sold. There was a moderate selection placed on the market and withdrawals were frequent among all kinds of wool owing to the low bids.

The Capital Administration Company, Ltd., a general management investment trust, reported yesterday that as of Sept. 30 net assets were equal to $1,697.83 for each $1,000 of outstanding debentures, or to $54.94 a share on the preferred stock and $1.26 a share on the Class A stock.

To the lengthening list of bright evenings in the theatre another item should be added, "The Pursuit of Happiness," which was acted at the Avon last evening. Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence Langner have written it under the elaborate pseudonyms of Alan Child and Isabelle Loudon, and Rowland Stebbins has produced it under his familiar pseudonym of Laurence Rivers.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 -- William E. Humphrey, Republican member of the Federal Trade Commission, who was removed Saturday by President Roosevelt, took his place at the regular meeting of the commission this morning.

Swamped with barbers' codes, the Recovery Administration in Washington has sent out an S O S which was picked up here yesterday by W. Averell Harriman, State NRA chairman, at NRA headquarters at the Hotel Pennsylvania.
Registration totals soared to a new high last night as the first day's tabulation was completed, even eclipsing the record established for last year's Presidential election registration.

It sometimes happens that a public man, or an old writer, outlives his fame. It was the good fortune of the late MORRIS HILLQUIT to outlive his first reputation as a dangerous agitator and a menace to our constituted society. When in 1917 he received as Socialist candidate for Mayor nearly 150,000 votes, the result was regarded by many worthy but timid citizens as a portent.

NEWMARKET, England, Oct. 8 (Canadian Press) -- Thirty-six horses were listed today as probable starters in the Cesarewitch, great Autumn handicap to be run Wednesday over the two-and-a-quarter-mile distance.
NEW YORK. Mr. and Mrs. Cornelius Vanderbilt Whitney will give a dinner tonight at the Central Park Casino for the Marquise Melchior de Polignac of Paris, aunt of Mrs. Whitney.

OKLAHOMA CITY, Oct. 9 (AP) -- Government prosecutors, bent on obtaining a quick conviction of George (Machine Gun) Kelly, defiant outlaw, and his quick-tempered wife, Kathryn, rushed the trial of the couple on kidnapping charges today after a row between the prisoners and their guards in which Kelly was pounded on the head with a pistol butt.

CHICAGO, Oct. 9 -- The following hospitals in New York City were inadvertently omitted yesterday from the list of those approved by the hospital standardization committee of the American College of Surgeons:
CHICAGO, Oct. 9 -- Following is the text of the address on "The Hippocratic. Code and the New Deal", delivered today by Dr. J. Bentley Squier, President of the American College of Surgeons:

Two 10-day-old, blue-eyed girl twins slept peacefully last night at the New York Foundling Hospital, Sixty-eighth Street and Third Avenue. They slept in happy ignorance of the trail of excitement that had followed them all day, and of their distinction, according to the memory of attendants, as the first twins brought to the hospital as foundlings.
Mayor O'Brien ended personal interviews with the City Hall reporters yesterday and said that hereafter all questions must be submitted in writing and would be answered in writing.

Sir Herbert Samuel, leader of the Liberal party in England, told more than 2,000 members of Hadassah, women's Zionist organization, yesterday that leaders in the British Government were "exceedingly sympathetic" to the opening of Palestine to Jewish refugees from Germany.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 (AP). -- The Supreme Court refused today to review the action of the Second Circuit Court of Appeals holding the Roxy Theatre Corporation had the right to use the name Roxy after Sept. 11, 1932.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 (AP). -- Collapse tonight threatened the master code for the $9,000,000,000 food and grocery industry as objections from manufacturing groups piled on top of open hostility to its main provisions by the Farm Administration.

CHICAGO, Oct. 9 -- Dr. Joseph C. Bloodgood of Johns Hopkins University told the American College of Surgeons tonight that at least three types of cancer could be eradicated as easily as is diphtheria.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 9 -- With the exception of Gulian at left guard and Nevin at right halfback, all the Harvard players who started Saturday's game with Bates took part today in the first signal drill of the week.

Await NBA 'Buy Now' Effects. The NRA "Buy Now "drive, which began yesterday, is being closely watched here for its effect upon wholesale orders. Manufacturers and wholesalers frankly admit that consumer buying stimulation is now vitally needed to offset the diminished reorders of the last three weeks.

The "Crusade for Children," the organization of which was announced on Sunday, will appeal for $400,000 this Fall and distribute the fund among seven child-welfare agencies for the care of dependent children.
In the face of the widespread defections to the camp of Joseph V. McKee, the leaders of Tammany still express the belief that Mayor John P. O'Brien can be re-elected.
The new trial of Jacob Mellon and two of his associates in the alleged laundry racket in Brooklyn was started yesterday before County Judge John J. Fitzgerald.

The speedy Brown Witch, a daughter of Brown Bud and Apparition, led from start to finish of the featured Trojan Purse at Jamaica yesterday to win by four lengths. The filly bore the colors of Mrs. John Hay Whitney and gave her a double on the day.

GENEVA, Oct. 9. -- The possibility of another big debate on the minorities question, this time before a plenary session of the Assembly of the League of Nations, was raised today when Germany reserved the right to speak when the report of the sixth commission reached the Assembly.

Samuel Dickstein, chairman of the Committee on Immigration of the House of Representatives, announced here yesterday that he would start an investigation next week into pro-Nazi propaganda in the United States.

With more than two tons of useful load aboard, including fourteen passengers, the largest airplane ever mounted on pontoons in the United States took off the water of Bowery Bay at Glenn Curtiss Airport, North Beach, Queens, yesterday in fifteen seconds.

GENEVA, Oct. 9. -- As the bureau, or steering committee, of the World Disarmament Conference reconvened privately here today, the Big Five explored the possibility of a compromise on war aviation, which many consider to be the heart of the German disarmament difficulty.
Jack Jordan of the Police Athletic League scored two knockout victories to carry off the honors in the 175-pound class at the amateur boxing show of the New York Athletic Club last night.

An action was started last night by the Joseph V. McKee forces to compel the Board of Elections to give the McKee candidates a separate line on the ballot for the coming election under the name of the Recovery party and the emblem of the emblazoned key.

TRENTON, N.J., Oct. 9 -- The Princeton Art Museum is to receive a sixteenth century crayon drawing under the will of the late Dr. Paul van Dyke, who died in August at his Summer home in Washington, Conn. He was 74 years old and unmarried.

CHICAGO, Oct. 9. -- Closing of spreads between wheat and corn, the former being sold, resulted today in an unsettled market for grains on the Board of Trade, wheat closing 5/8 to 1 1/8 cent a bushel lower than on Saturday, while corn, was 1 1/2 cent higher-and closed well toward the top.

The Federal Council of Churches has through its chairman made a statement expressing the point of view of "thoughtful groups in Protestantism" concerning the national recovery program. Twenty-six denominations affiliated with the Council were represented in the committee by seventy-eight members.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 9. -- Assurance that plenty of American-made whisky will be available to meet demand upon the repeal of prohibition was voiced today by government officials after a survey of probable requirements and supply.
WASHINGTON. Oct. 9. -- Movements of vessels follow; all dates are Oct. 7 unless otherwise specified:

TARRYTOWN, N.Y., Oct. 9 -- Nelson A. Rockefeller, second son of John D. Rockefeller Jr., underwent an operation ten days ago for appendicitis, it was learned here today. Mr. Rockefeller, who is 25 years old, is out of danger and is recuperating at his home in Pocantico Hills.

Shampan Shampan, architects, have been commissioned to prepare plans for reconstructing the boiler house building of the Interboro Beverage Corporation, E.M. Blumenkranz, president, fronting on Melrose and George Sts., near Central Av., Brooklyn. The cost of the work is estimated at $150,000.

BERLIN, Oct. 9. -- Difficulties in the detailed working out of the Nazi policy regarding women are beginning to be felt throughout Germany. Both by women and their employers demands are being made for a more guarded method of change.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 -- Ten registration statements, filed under the Securities Act and representing upward of $3,000,000 in new securities issues, were made public today by the Federal Trade Commission. They bring the total amount of securities registered to more than $255,000,000.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Oct. 9 (AP). -- Appeals to "keep a Republican Assembly between Tammany and up-State pocketbooks" were made to up-State business men tonight by Senator George R. Fearon and Assemblyman Joseph A. McGinnies, Republican, legislative leaders.

BUENOS AIRES, Oct. 10 -- The anti-war pact proposed by Foreign Minister Saavreda Lamas of Argentina was acclaimed here by Leopoldo Melo, Acting Minister of Foreign Affairs, this afternoon at the time it was signed in Rio de Janeiro.

The Rev. Dr. Charles Henry Parkhurst, the reformer who fought Tammany Hall, left an estate of less than $1,000, it was shown yesterday when his will was filed for probate in Surrogate's Court. Dr. Parkhurst died Sept. 8, as the result of a fall from the porch roof of his home at Atlantic City.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 -- The problems of owners and operators of vessels in the inland waterway trade of the country will be discussed at NRA hearings soon to be held in New York, St. Louis, New Orleans and San Francisco.

LONDON, Oct. 10 -- Two friendly cablegrams passing between the governing bodies of cricket in England and Australia have ended the controversy over "body-line" bowling that at one time necessitated the intervention of J.H. Thomas, Secretary of State for the Dominions, to avert an open breach of peace between the two countries.

Unfilled orders of the United States Steel Corporation decreased 114,704 tons in September to 1,775,740 tons at the end of the month, the lowest figure since the corporation was formed in 1901, it was announced yesterday.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., Oct. 10 -- Victor Ghezzi, assistant professional at the Rumson Country Club, and his brother, Joseph, were the winners today in the Metropolitan Golf Association's amateur-pro tourney at the Montclair Golf Club. They had a best-ball score of 72.
To the Editor of The New York Times: Your editorial on the test of the constitutionality of the law against owning gold must receive the commendation of all fair-minded individuals.

Plans for the establishment of a banking institution under the auspices, if not the actual direction, of the New York Stock Exchange, to perform many of the functions now left to commercial banks in Wall Street, are rapidly taking shape, it was reported among brokers yesterday.

TOKYO, Wednesday, Oct. 11 -- Official circles, particularly the War Office, express indignation at the Soviet's publication of documents alleged to be confidential Japanese dispatches concerning a reported plan to seize the Chinese Eastern Railway.
NEWMARKET, England, Oct. 10 -- With Lord Derby's Guiscard the choice at 15 to 2, thirty-four of Britain's leading handicap horses are expected to start in the classic Cesarewitch, tomorrow.

Segregation of the round-lot and odd-lot brokerage business was ordered yesterday by the governing committee of the New York Stock Exchange on the recommendation of a special committee which has been studying the odd-lot business since last January.

Mr. and Mrs. Cornelius Vanderbilt Whitney gave a dinner last night in the Pavillion of the Central Park Casino for the Marquise Melchior de Folignac of Paris, aunt of Mrs. Whitney. The guests were seated at an oval table decorated with yellow chrysanthemums and Autumn leaves.

Joseph V. McKee, candidate for Mayor on the Recovery party's ticket, assumed complete responsibility for the granting of the Equitable bus franchise in an affidavit submitted in answer to litigation brought against the city, Louis Waldman, State chairman of the Socialist party, charged last night in an address at the Community Church, 550 West 110th Street.

Professor MOLEY was born in Ohio. He taught school for a time in Cleveland. It was natural that the piety of the native place should lead him in a speech before the Ohio Society to reminiscences of Buckeye days, to the famous Clevelanders TOM JOHNSON and MARK HANNA.

A trophy was awarded to the Yankee Juniors of Lynbrook, L.I., the winning team in the Children's Aid Society's Sand Lot Baseball League, at a dinner given last evening at the Elks Club, 108 West Forty-third Street.
NEW YORK. Eric Hendrik Louw, Minister of the Union of South Africa, is at the Ambassador.

HAVANA, Oct. 10 -- The refusal of Cuba's student-army government to accept the cooperation of any of the opposition factions and its decision to hold the reigns of power alone have definitely terminated all hope of the formation of a national government which would have the support of the people.
Following is the text of the address delivered by F.H. LaGuardia, Fusion nominee for Mayor, before the Alumni Committee for Fusion at the Harvard Club last night:

More than 2,000 persons, including members of religious and philanthropic societies and several hundred clergy of the Roman Catholic Church, were present yesterday in St. Patrick's Cathedral at a memorial mass of requiem for the Right Rev. John J. Dunn, who was Auxiliary Bishop and Vicar General of the Archdiocese of New York.

In line with the nation-wide backing of the recovery plans of the administration, the colleges are giving patriotically some important traffic to railroads this week. Saturday's games involve travel on a larger scale than the second Saturday of October has seen in football in some time.

Carl Owen Hubbell, celebrated southpaw pitcher of the world champion Giants, who never received so much as a single vote before in the contest, emerged yesterday after the official balloting of baseball observers as the National League's "most valuable player" for 1933.
PITTSBURGH, Oct. 10 (AP) -- Two men met late today in a conference that may help determine whether war or peace will reign over the vast Western Pennsylvania coal fields.
After opening fairly steady, prices for commodities traded on local exchanges turned generally lower yesterday. Trading was in moderate volume. Cash quotations for most staples were also lower.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 -- Advocates of industrial unionism as against organization by separate crafts were overwhelmingly defeated today at the convention of the American Federation of Labor.
Opposition to further retrenchments in the city's public school Budget was voiced yesterday by the Joint Committee of Teachers Organizations and the Public Education Association.
LOS ANGELES, Oct. 10 -- I have become a professional tennis player because it is the only thing for me to do.

BERLIN, Oct. 10 -- After a brief interregnum a new case of a Nazi assault upon an inoffensive American had to be brought to the attention of the State Department in Washington today by American officials in Berlin.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 -- The Federal Reserve Bank governors met in regular Autumn session today and had before them for discussion many important problems in connection with those confronting the administration.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 -- Plans for the construction of low-rent slum clearance apartments in large cities at Federal expense, which would be built without the assistance of the municipalities and rented or sold direct by a government corporation formed for that purpose, have been prepared by Secretary Ickes and, it was said today, "have a fairly good chance of being put into operation."

In contrast to the effects of the depression on educational institutions throughout the country, Barnard College has accumulated "by a miracle" a surplus of more than $7,000 on its budget for last year, Dean Virginia C. Gildersleeve announced yesterday afternoon at the first student assembly of the present academic year, held in the Barnard gymnasium.

Daily average gross crude oil production in the United States last week was 2,398,850 barrels, compared with 2,446,850 barrels in the preceding week, a decline of 48,000 barrels, according to the American Petroleum Institute. A decline of 48,850 barrels in the average daily output of Oklahoma accounted for the drop, production in other areas being little changed from the preceding week.

CHICAGO, Oct. 10 -- An assertion that the mortality rate from appendicitis today is 50 per cent higher than it was fifteen years ago and is still increasing, was made before the clinical congress of the American College of Surgeons today by Professor Alton Ochsner of Tulane University.

A thorough review of its attacking repertoire and a vigorous test of its defense against West Virginia plays were the order of the ay for the Fordham football squad t Fordham Field yesterday. Drills ere speeded up for the invasion f the Mountaineers on Saturday at e Polo Grounds.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 (AP) -- Provisions for blacklisting film stars and their pictures in the event they violate their contracts without due cause and for licensing actors' agents were included in the second revision of the motion picture code, which was completed tonight by Sol A. Rosenblatt, deputy recovery administrator.

VIENNA, Oct. 10 -- The police raided today another secret Nazi headquarters, disguised as a flower shop, and announced that fourteen Viennese Nazis had been deprived of their Austrian citizenship after escaping to Germany.

BERLIN, Oct. 10 -- The boom on the bond market which set in yesterday as a result of approval by the Bank for International Settlements of the Reichsbank's open market policy Continued today. Obligations of States grained up to 4 per cent, mortgage bonds up to 2 per cent and many municipal obligations up to 1 1/2 per cent.

"Pay your taxes if you would improve municipal credit and thus reduce the cost of government," was urged in a forum on the "Secrets of Municipal Credit" given last night over a nation-wide hook-up of the National Broadcasting Company under the auspices of the Committee on Civic Education.

NEWARK, N.J., Oct. lO -- Satisfactory results in the first two days of the city's tax-collection drive were reported this evening by Reginald Parnell, city director of revenue and finance. He said that yesterday's receipts had totaled $56,295, as against $25,362 on the same day of last year, and that he expected today's receipts would total about $60,000.

The National Hockey League season will have an early opening this year, according to the schedule made public yesterday by Frank Calder, president of the circuit. The campaign will start on Thursday, Nov. 9, three days ahead of last year's opening, and will close on March 18.

The beer license of the International Beverage Company a wholesale beer distributor with offices at 5 Roebling Street Brooklyn, was revoked by the State Alcoholic Beverage Control Board yesterday. Beer racketeering in Brooklyn was charged.

RIVERHEAD, L.I., Oct. 10 -- Ring Lardner, author and humorist, who died at his country home in East Hampton on Sept. 25, left an estate valued at more than $10,000 personal and more than $30,000 real, according to the petition for probate filed here today.
JAMESTOWN, N.Y., Oct. 10 (AP) -- The Woman's Christian Temperance Union of New York State adopted a resolution today calling for the formation of a new national political party with W.C.T.U. ideals.

C.V. Whitney, owner of Equipoise, issued a statement last night clarifying the matter of the much discussed match race with the Australian thoroughbred Winooka, now at the Laurel race course in Maryland. Mr. Whitney emphasized that Winooka must prove his right to a race against Equipoise by winning against first class horses.

Representatives of trunk line railroads and Atlantic coast port authorities conferred yesterday at the offices of the Trunk Line Association, 143 liberty Street, on plans to retain the Import and export traffio through the Eastern ports, which is threatened by the proffer of new low rates by railroads serving the Gulf ports.

John L. Lewis, president of the United Mine Workers of America; David Kaufman, former United States Minister to Bolivia, and John S. Herron, Mayor of Pittsburgh, testified yesterday as character witnesses for Senator James J. Davis of Pennsylvania.

Money market was dull. Call loan replacements at 3/4, and small amounts of four-five months' money at 3/4, represented the sole business of the day. Commercial paper and acceptances markets were steady.

Registration continued to climb to new high records last night as the tabulation of the second day for registering was completed. The 1932 mark for the day was surpassed, as on Monday, and the total for this year's two days soared higher above that for 1932, a Presidential year.

Mayor O'BRIEN's speech of acceptance is a plea for re-election on the ground of what he has done amid enormous difficulties. The difficulties must be admitted. Mr. O'BRIEN took office at a time when the city finances were in a desperate state. How to keep the metropolis out of bankruptcy has been his daily problem.
JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Oct. 10 -- Florida today became the thirty-third State to vote for repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment. The margin for repeal was more than 4 to 1.

TOKYO, Oct. 10 -- The police have been forced to prohibit the use of the incidents of May 15, 1932, when Premier Inukai was assassinated by young naval officers and power stations were attacked by "patriots," as subject-matter for the stage, films and popular songs.

ELIZABETH, N.J., Oct. 10 -- The Sinking Fund Commission here bought today $27,200 of city bonds for various emergency purposes, retired $100,000 of the 1929 issue of tax-revenue bonds and purchased $100,000 of tax-anticipation notes maturing on Dec. 15.

Raymond B. Fosdick and Albert B. Scott, who have been studying the problems of liquor control for John D. Rockefeller Jr., made public yesterday a new instalment of their report explaining how the State liquor monopoly they favor, would function.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Oct. 10 -- The signing today by the Chilean diplomatic representative at Rio de Janeiro of the anti-war pact of the Latin-American nations is considered here the most important act in international relations affecting this country,-since the meeting late last year when the proposal of the treaty was first made public by Foreign Minister Saavedra Lamas of Argentina.

TRENTON, N.J., Oct. 10 -- With the task of formulating a plan of liquor control in New Jersey delegated to a nonpartisan commission of seven persons, the Legislature adjourned its special session at 3 o'clock this morning. A few hours later Governor A. Harry Moore returned to the State from a vacation abroad.

WESTBURY, L.I., Oct. 10 -- The club tournament season ended at the Meadow Brook Club today, with Great Island defeating the Vipers, 8 to 5, in the final of the Autumn Plates tournament for sixteen-goal polo teams.

Jockey Earl Porter, for the second time during the meeting scored a triple when he was first with three horses at Jamaica yesterday. One of his winners was Miss Merriment, owned by the Dorwood Stable and victor in the main event, the Yankee Princess purse.

The greater part of the assets of the Aviation Securities Corporation of New England has been acquired by the National Aviation Corporation, another investment trust, specializing in aviation stocks. The transaction involves about $937,000, or 66,974 shares of National Aviation stock taken at a net asset value of about $14 a share.

The $4,000,000 alienation of affections suit brought by Mrs. Helen Vogel Stern against Mrs. Ruth Erlanger Nathan, was withdrawn yesterday before Supreme Court Justice Hofstadter and a jury after the plaintiff's testimony had been concluded.

WEST ORANGE, N.J., Oct. 10 -- Mrs. John E. Prizer of the home club took the undisputed lead in the fifty-four-hole handicap medal play tourney of the New Jersey Women's Golf Association on the Essex County course today. After the second day's play she had a thirty-six-hole net total of 169.

The appointment of Vincent Astor, close personal friend and distant relative of President Roosevelt, as chairman of the executive finance committee of the Joseph V. McKee Independent Campaign Committee, was announced yesterday by Herbert Bayard Swope, its treasurer.

In the line-up at Police Headquarters yesterday Hugh Morrison, 28 years old, a seaman, of 31-69 Thirty-seventh Street, Astoria, and Patsy Santoro, 23, of 32-55 110th Street, Corona, denied a kidnapping charge.
