Representative Samuel Dickstein said yesterday that the announcement of this decision, as chairman of the Congressional Committee on Immigration, to start an inquiry into pro-Nazi propaganda in the United States had resulted in "an astonishing flood" of letters, telephone calls and telegrams offering more data for the inquiry and approval of its purppse.

GENEVA, Oct. 10 -- Coordination of international work for German refugees through a high commissioner named by the League of Nations Council was assured today when yesterday's compromise was adopted unanimously by the Assembly's second commission, with Germany abstaining.

F.H. LaGuardia, Fusion nominee for Mayor, in an address last night at the Harvard Club at a dinner given by a group of Harvard alumni committed to the Fusion cause, pledged support of the next city administration, in the event of a Fusion victory, to the four-year agreement with the bankers.
Madame Maria Jeritza, former prima donna of the Metropolitan Opera Company, arrived from Vienna yesterday on the French liner Be de France with her husband, Baron Leopold von Popper de Podraghy.

Both the Fusion party and Joseph V. McKee's Recovery party will have their name and emblem on the ballots at the coming election if a decision yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Salvatore A. Cotillo is upheld by the higher courts.

CAMDEN, N.J., Oct. 10 -- Amazement at the advanced stage reached by television in this country was expressed today by Senator Guglielmo Marconi, wireless inventor, during an inspection of the television laboratory of the R.C.A.Victor Company here.

LONDON, Oct. 10 -- A flying boat that is expected to be able to destroy submarines has been developed by the British Royal Air Force. It will carry a quick-firing gun that will fire 1 1/2-pound projectiles. Such shells would pierce the thin plates of underseas craft if caught on the surface.

Award of 355 scholarships to Columbia University students for the academic year 1933-34 was announced yesterday by Dr. Frank D. Fackenthal, secretary of the university. Students representing nearly every State in the Union, as well as graduates of colleges, technical schools and universities in all parts of the country, are among the winners.

The proposed Tugwell bill to regulate advertising in food, drugs and cosmetics was strongly assailed yesterday at a meeting of the Proprietary Association at the Hotel Biltmore. The association includes about 80 per cent of the producers of packaged medicines in the United States, it was said, and 250 members from various parts of the country attended.

Joseph V. McKee, independent candidate for Mayor, replied yesterday to the charge of Samuel Seabury that the switch of Democratic leaders to him was an attempt to get on the bandwagon, and save their jobs.

The Canadian Government offered yesterday a new issue of $225,000,000 in bonds, part of which bear interest at 3 1/2 per cent and the rest at 4. Its purpose is to refund outstanding " Victory bonds" carrying the rate of 5 1/2 per cent. The operation is similar to the recent British offer of u150,000,000 in 2 1/2 per cents, which has as one of its chief objects refunding Treasury bonds now bearing 4 1/2.

Mayor O'Brien, opening his campaign for re-election, pledged himself yesterday to a continuance of the five-cent fare and asserted that his administration had lifted the city from its financial difficulties.

LOS ANGELES, Oct. 10 (AP) -- Letters of administration were asked today in connection with the estate of Renee Adoree, film actress, who died Thursday. The estate was valued at $2,429. Public Administrator Frank A. Nance said the only heir is Mrs. Victoria Adoree, mother of the actress, living in England.

CHICAGO, Oct. 10 -- The government's report on the grain crops, issued today after the close of the Board of Trade, caused little comment here, the figures being so close to the estimates of a month ago as to have no effect on the opinions of traders.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 -- The United States and International Securities Corporation, a Dillon, Read Co. investment trust, had a shrinkage of $26,562,400 in its portfolio securities up to Dec. 31, 1932, according to testimony today before the Senate Banking and Currency subcommittee investigating stock market operations.

To the Editor of The New York Times: It is of extreme importance that the voters who desire to vote the Fusion ticket know exactly how the names of these candidates will appear on the ballot on election day.

The College for Jewish Teachers, successor to the Hebrew Union College School for Teachers, which was forced to close in June, 1932, port, was formally opened last night because of lack of financial supat Temple Emanu-El, 1 East Sixtyfifth Street.

Sheriff Quayle Quails. Among the distinguished partisans who have deserted Curry and McCOOEY in this day of their troubles is FRANK QUAYLE, candidate for Sheriff of Kings County on the regular Democratic ticket.

About 100 representatives of American export and import houses doing business in Argentina met yesterday in the offices of the First of Boston Corporation here to discuss plans to utilize "blocked paper pesos" held for American account. The meeting was held at the request of the Argentine Government.

GENEVA, Oct. 10 -- The disarmament talks seemed to develop today along two lines. One was a declaration by the Germans of the substance and the probably good reception of a speech Chancellor Hitter is expected to give tomorrow in answer to Premier Daladier of France.

A determined effort to end the prolonged strike of 70,000 silk workers in New York, New Jersey and Pennsylvania and make possible an agreement that would serve as a basis for a code for the industry was begun here yesterday at a hearing of the national labor mediation board, with Senator Robert F. Wagner, chairman, of the board, presiding.

"Her Man of Wax," a comedy adapted from the German of Walter Hasenclever by Julian Thompson, will have its premiere this evening at the Shubert Theatre. Lenore Ulric is the star and Lloyd Corrigan is the featured player.

CINCINNATI, Oct. 10 -- A declaration that "If our house needs cleaning, let's clean it," was made today by E.J. Hopple, chairman of the Ohio Public Utilities Commission, at the opening session here of the annual convention of the National Association of Railroad and Utilities Commissioners.

Former Governor Alfred E. Smith paid a, visit to his "old neighbors and friends" on the lower east side yesterday afternoon and attracted such a crowd that business and traffic near Market and Cherry Streets were halted for nearly an hour.

George S. Carr, a vice president and branch manager of the Bank of United States, was recalled as a State witness yesterday at the trial of Isador J. Kressel on the indictment charging the lawyer aided in the misapplication of about $2,000,000 of the bank's funds.

OKLAHOMA CTTY, Oct. 10 (AP) -- Geeraldine Arnold, the 12-year-old girl taken by George and Kathryn Kelly as a "blind" in their flight from the law, testified at their trial today that Kelly threatened to kill the judge, prosecutors and Charles F. Urschel, the millionaire he is accused of kidnapping for $200,000 ransom.

ATLANTIC CITY, Oct. 10 -- Joseph N. Ulman, presiding judge of the Supreme bench of Baltimore, addressed the annual congress of the American Prison Association here tonight. He asserted that if probation were given a chance to prove its possibilities, "prison populations would be reduced almost entirely to those who are either so defective or so anti-social that they must be kept for long terms or for life."
Hedging pressure continued yesterday on the Cotton Exchange and prices moved lower, closing at the bottom with losses of 13 to 16 points.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W.Va., Oct. 10 -- Wilmer Hines, former junior national tennis champion, came from behind to defeat George W. Reilly 3d, a comparative unknown, in the second round of the Greenbrier Golf and Tennis Club's annual Autumn tournament for the Mortland Challenge Bowl today. The score was 6 -- 8, 6 -- 2, 6 -- 3.

LAUREL, Md., Oct. 10 (AP) -- Jockey Johnny Bejshak narrowly escaped serious injury in a fall today. In the spill the finish pole was knocked from its socket and the boy sent hurtling against the inner rail in the path of the charging field at the end of the six-furlong first race.

PARIS, Oct. 10 -- According to information, here in circles that have kept in touch with war debt developments, the Anglo-American debt negotiations are based fundamentally on an attempt to bargain currency stabilization against a lump sum payment.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 -- About one-fourth of the non-Federal Reserve State banks have applied for membership in the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, Walter J. Cummings, chairman of the board, announced today. The total number of applications is 2,171 out of a total of 8,557 institutions.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 10 -- In a forty-five-minute scrimmage against the scrub eleven, Harvard's varsity football team today tallied three touchdowns. Francis Lane; brother of Myles Lane, former Dartmouth star, made all three scores.

Next Sunday marks the opening of the hunting season in New York State for deer, rabbits and some varieties of squirrels. The hunter, however, will do well to acquaint himself with the local laws of whatever community he intends to visit regarding the legality of shooting game on Sundays.

The bank debt of the United Corporation on Oct. 1 had been reduced to $8,000,000, comparing with $11,672,000 at the end of 1932 and $12,588,473 the year before, under a plan which will relieve the company of all bank indebtedness within the next nine months.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 -- Creation of a Federal corporation to take over non-liquid assets of closed banks and release about $1,000,000,000 of deposits is approaching solution, it was announced at the White House today after a aeries of official conferences.

Replies to the newspaper advertisements of Park Tilford, giving advance prices on liquor, indicate an early and widespread demand for it, Gordon Stewart, president of the company, said yesterday when asked about the public's response.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 -- Unemployment relief allotments of $5,000,000 to New York, $563,179 to Kentucky and $175,000 in special grants to eight States for the care of destitute transients were approved today by Harry L. Hopkins, Federal Emergency Relief Administrator.

ALBANY, Oct. 10 -- From his home in New York City, where he is recovering from appendicitis, Governor Lehman yesterday urged Secretary Ickes, as Federal Administrator of Public Works, to grant $10,000,000 to this State for construction of farm-to-market roads.

Cecil R. Berry, president of the Citizens National Bank of Waverly, N.Y., and Robert T. Stevens president of J.P. Stevens Co., Inc., of this city, have been recommended for nomination as directors of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York by the committee on nominations of the bankers associations of New York, New Jersey and Connecticut, it was announced yesterday.

One hundred and fifteen thousand names, said to be the largest number ever filed here, were appended to the petition of Joseph V. McKee, which is required by law to place his name on the ballots as the Mayoralty candidate of the Recovery party and which was filed last night with the Board of Elections.
CHICAGO, Oct. 10 -- Cyclopropane, a newly developed gas, was described before the congress of anesthetists here today as an anesthetic which promises "the ultimate in surgical aid."

Stocks were almost at a standstill yesterday, but where price changes occurred they mostly pointed downward. Trading was of a routine professional character with little or no public participation. The volume of business on the Stock Exchange was larger by about 90,000 shares than on Monday, amounting in all to 1,135,000 shares.
LYNN, Mass., Oct. 10 (AP) -- The official "welcome home Blondy Ryan" committee was caught napping today by the unexpected arrival of the New York Giants' scrappy shortstop.

PARIS, Oct. 10 -- What the French Government's financial proposals will be for bringing the budget into shape are being kept a close secret. After examination of the budget plans at a meeting of the Cabinet today an official communique confined itself to saying:
PLANDOME, L.I., Oct. 10 -- Miss Helen Hicks of the Rockaway Hunting Club, former national golf champion, was back on familiar ground today.
PATERSON, N.J., Oct. 10 -- A peace plan under which 15,000 silk dyers would end their strike will be placed before the dyers' local of the United Textile Workers Union tomorrow morning.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 -- Following is the text of the address delivered tonight by Hugh S. Johnson, Recovery Administrator, before the American Federation of Labor Convention:

A syndicate headed by the Guaranty Company of New York, R.H. Moulton Co., Inc., and Blyth Co., Inc., won yesterday the award at auction of a new issue of $6,000,000 State of California unemployment relief bonds, due $2,000,000 annually on July 1, 1938 to 1940.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 -- Stressing that the war debt of Great Britain to the United States should be regarded not as a commercial loan but as a matter of war necessity, representatives of the British Government began today a detailed submission of their case in a three-hour conference with the American experts.
PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 10 (AP) -- The fate of twenty-one members of the crew of the Greek freighter Annoula, reported by wireless as having foundered at sea, remained undetermined tonight.

ADOLF HITLER may be a "clumsy lout," as H.G. Wells says he is, and it is certain that he is no Winston Churchill who can pass from politics to authorship with the retention of any quality of brilliance. But it is not recorded that Attila, Genghis Khan, Juarez and "Bat" Masterson were masters of the written phrase; they didn't have to be.

MOSCOW, Oct. 10 -- A clear message to Russian public opinion that this country will no longer stand for what is regarded as Japanese infraction of treaty rights, but will protect those rights and its citizens at all costs, is found between the lines of the newspaper editorials here today.

The Brooklyn Democratic organization, chief ally of Tammany since the days of Hugh McLaughlin and Patrick H. McCarren, collapsed yesterday, so far as support of Tammany, John F. Curry, its chieftain, and John P. O'Brien, its candidate for re-election as Mayor, is concerned.

A timid-looking young man, who admitted that he had been the author of a crack-brained plan to extort $10,000 from Franklin A. Batcheller of Yonkers, and a young nurse who had helped him in the abortive attempt, were sentenced yesterday to serve ten and five years respectively in prison.

Marie Dressier, who was a star on Broadway before many of her countless current admirers were born, was the guest of honor last evening at a dinner at the Hotel Roosevelt. The dinner, attended by more than 500 persons prominent in theatrical, literary and social life, was given under the auspices of the Actors Dinner Club, to which the proceeds went.

Confidence that former Governor Alfred E. Smith would remain a "loyal Democrat" and, by inference, actively support Mayor O'Brien and the regular Democratic ticket, was expressed yesterday by Abraham Kaplan, Democratic campaign manager.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 -- The smallest wheat crop in thirty-seven years was predicted today by the Department of Agriculture, although the estimate of 514,816,000 bushels was about 8,000,000 more than the forecast last month.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 -- President and Mrs. Roosevelt gave a state dinner tonight at the White House, entertaining thirty-eight guests in honor of Dr. Harmodio Arias, President of Panama.

Jim McMillen of Chicago, weighing 223 pounds, met two opponents in succession last night before 5,000 persons at the New York Coliseum, but succeeded in throwing only one. In his first match, McMillen pinned Sid Westrich, 225, of the Bronx, with a flying tackle in 28 : 04.

FAYETTEVILLE, N.C., Oct. 10 (AP) -- En route to Florida, Serg Romm, contractor, of 450 West End Avenue, New York, was fatally injured today when his automobile overturned three miles from Fayetteville.

Only naval officers, including the Governor, who have been stationed at Guam, the tropical island transferred from Spain to the United States, are concerned about the future of the Chamorros, the native inhabitants. Including the naval establishment, the population in 1930 was 18,500, of whom 8,690 lived in Agana, the capital.

The prediction that by the year 2033 tuberculosis, diabetes and certain other diseases will be stamped out is good news for the unborn. But the further word from the meeting of the College of Surgeons, spoken by Dr. BLOODGOOD of Johns Hopkins University, who has for years been associated with cancer research, that certain types of cancer can now be eradicated, gives immediate hope to tens of thousands.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 -- Federal projects obtained $4,577,098 allocations from the Public Works Administration today, the Navy Department and Militia Bureau receiving the greater share, with a total of $3,573,847. The money will be expended for improvements and new equipment at several stations.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In Persia, we are told by Colonel Henry Yule, Kaikhata Khan, in 1294, had a financial officer called "Izzuddin Muzaffar," who seems to have been a sort of brain-truster, and who planned an issue of unsecured legal-tender paper notes.

Sentences of three to six years each in Sing Sing were imposed by Judge Donnellan in General Sessions yesterday on Arthur J. Hoffman and George Goodman, accountants, for defrauding the late Edward A. Ridley, eccentric wealthy land owner, of about $200,000 through fictitious bills for repairs.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 -- Labor does not need its strike weapon any longer, according to Hugh S. Johnson, the Recovery Administrator, who told the delegates to the convention of the American Federation of Labor tonight that under the Recovery Act and President Roosevelt's plan of mediation, strikes were superfluous because machinery to adjust disputes has been set up on a national scale.
The text of the address by Mayor ohn P. O'Brien accepting his nomination for Mayor yesterday follows:

Robert J. Byers, former department adjutant of the American Legion in Michigan, and George S. Krieger, described as having been in the army goods business, were placed on trial yesterday before Federal Judge John Knight and a jury on a charge of conspiracy to defraud the United States Government.

RICHMOND, Va., Oct. 10 -- Vigorous protests against government interference with the management of railroads were voiced here today at the annual meeting of stockholders of the Southern Railway Company.

BOISE, Idaho, Oct. 10 (AP) -- Captain Patrick J. Hogan of West Brighton, Staten Island, N.Y., died in the Veterans' Hospital today after being taken from his room in a local hotel last night suffering from injuries about his head.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 -- Federal projects obtained $4,577,098 allocations from the Public Works Administration today, the Navy Department and Militia Bureau receiving the greater share, with a total of $3,573,847. The money will be expended for improvements and new equipment at several stations.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In Persia, we are told by Colonel Henry Yule, Kaikhata Khan, in 1294, had a financial officer called "Izzuddin Muzaffar," who seems to have been a sort of brain-truster, and who planned an issue of unsecured legal-tender paper notes.

Alfred E. Smith, as a director of the Meenan Coal Company, Inc., of 44 East Twenty-third Street, was accused in the Supreme Court yesterday of aiding his friend, William F. Kenny; majority stockholder of the company, to oust Timothy J. Mara, sports promoter, as vice president and director of the company at a special meeting of the stockholders on Oct. 4.

CHICAGO, Oct. 10 -- Prices of hogs declined as sharply here today as they had advanced recently, being 10 to 40 cents a hundredweight lower than yesterday, while some other markets quoted prices down as much as 50 cents. Offerings were not especially heavy, but the demand was less active.

Residents of the North Atlantic Coast who wonder what tickles their toes when they go wading may find one answer in the latest addition to the exhibit of marine life in the American Museum of Natural History. Members of the sea worm family may be responsible.
The bolt of the Tammany district leaders to the McKee candidacy was referred to yesterday by Samuel Seabury, chairman of the Fusion campaign committee, as "the parade of the tin-box brigade."
His contract arranged for the next five years, and with definite ideas about some of his plans for next season for the Giants, Bill Terry left the city yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 -- The youngest pennant-winning manager ever to appear in the major leagues, Joseph Edward Cronin, today scribbled his name across a contract to pilot the Washington Senators through three more campaigns at an annual figure, clubhouse observers guessed, of $25,000 or less.

Evidence introduced yesterday in the trial of Jacob Mellon and two co-defendants, charged with unlawful conspiracy as the operators of a Brooklyn laundry racket, was that the now disbanded organization, controlled by Mellon had collected average weekly dues of more than $900.

SOUTH ORANGE, N.J., Oct. 10 -- Bank and business executives in New Jersey, New York and Philadelphia were guests here tonight at a dinner given by William L. Blanchard, vice president of the United States Trust Company of Newark, in honor of four men recently elected presidents of banks in Newark.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 -- The War Department Issued the following orders today, dated Oct. 7:

The 1934 city budget, amounting to $514,302,928.03 and showing a reduction of $4,062,865.96 from the 1933 total, was received formally by the Board of Estimate yesterday.

What did Champ Carnera say, Giving free advice away! Primo said, with toothful grin, These very words: "Mena sana in Corpore sano!" Not a sound Rose from all the crowd around. Off he strode with heavy tread, Leaving hia hearers there for dead.

The probability that Robert E. Sherwood's latest play, "Acropolis," would be shown in London before being presented in New York was made known yesterday. The author and Marc Connelly, who is to direct it, both sail on the Manhattan today with that idea in mind.

BERLIN, Oct. 10 -- The treason trial known as "the German people against Van der Lubbe and accomplices" was resumed today on the scene of the crime in the same Reichstag building whose burning cupola lighted the birth of the National Socialist revolution, and amid the wraiths of the German democracy that Adolf Hitler, "the Chancellor of the people," killed.

SANTA FE, N.M., Oct. 10 (AP) -- Carl W. Hatch, New Mexico Democratic leader and attorney, was appointed United States Senator today, succeeding Sam G. Bratton, who resigned recently to become a Federal Circuit Judge.

Mrs. Marie Del Rosso, the thin, dark-haired, 30-year-old mother who abandoned her twin baby girls and told her husband they were dead, stood tearfully through the routine of arraignment in West Side Court yesterday on a charge of abandonment. Defending her act she explained that she feared.
U.S. Department of Agriculture. Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices at New York.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 -- A saber of honor made for George Washington as a gift from the soldiers of the French Revolution was presented today to President Roosevelt by General the Count de Chambrun, for the French Council of Ministers. Washington died before it could be presented.

More than 20,000 persons paid a last tribute to Morris Hillquit, Socialist leader, who died on Saturday, as the body lay in state yesterday in the Debs Auditorium at the Rand School, 7 East Fifteenth Street. All day long the silent procession of mourners continued past the bier as it lay within a semicircle of wreaths sent by friends and co-workers of the dead leader from this and other countries.

Sir Herbert Samuel, leader of the British Liberal party, left New York yesterday for Baltimore, whence he will return to England. Through the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace, which arranged his Iectures during his visit, he issued a statement summarizing his impressions of the United States under the New Deal.

CHICAGO, Oct. 10 -- Seven persons, two of them women, were killed tonight when a transcontinental passenger plane of the United Air Lines in which they were riding crashed in flames about five miles southeast of Chesterton, Ind.

Final results of the popular referendums held Monday in Birmingham, Ala., on proposals to acquire or build municipal electric, water, steam heat and street railway facilities should be about a three-to-two defeat of the municipal electric and water-works projects and about a three-to-one defeat of the steam heat and street railway plans.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 11. -- The Federal Reserve Board's index for epartment store sales in September, made public today, shows 70 for that month on the basis of the 1923-1925 average as 100, compared with 77 in August and 70 in July.

WYNDHAM, Western Australia, Oct. 11. -- Wing Commander Sir Charles Kingsford-Smith completed a record-breaking flight from England, to Australia today, and it may be his last effort at "beating the clock" over vast open stretches of water with a single-engined machine.

Directors of the Stock Clearing Corporation, a subsidiary of the New York Stock Exchange, appointed Laurence G. Payson yesterday as director and president of the corporation to fill the vacancy caused by the death last week of Samuel F. Streit.

Carrying forward his campaign to punish violators of the President's re-employment agreement, General Hugh S. Johnson, National Recovery Administrator, stripped two establishments in New Rochelle of their Blue Eagles yesterday, ordering them to surrender their insignia to the local postmaster.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 11. -- Scrimmaging for forty-five minutes today against the scrubs, Harvard's three varsity teams produced only two touchdowns. Without Captain Dean in the back field, and the aggressive Warren Casey at centre, the first varsity, which made both scores, lacked a steady drive.

After several lean years at the box office, during which attendance dropped away alarmingly from the good old days of 1925-30, football is staging a recovery act that bids fair to make the 1933 season the best in point of patronage of the last four.

CHICAGO. Oct. 11. -- Allen B. Gallaher'a Swiftsport led home a field of six 2-year-olds in the seven-furlong feature at Washington Park today. The Young Brothers' Fiji was second, beaten by a length and a quarter, and Albert A. Baroni's Cash Surrender was third.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 11 (AP). -- Baseball's veteran strategist, Connie Mack, manager of the Philadelphia Athletics, speaking from the authority of fifty years in the game, justifies Joe Cronin's selection of young Cliff Bolton to pinch hit for the Washington Senators in that "hot spot" of the fourth game of last week's world's series.

ST. LOUIS, Oct. 11. -- Asserting that while Federal agencies now occupy a dominant place in the lending field, William F. Stevenson of Washington, chairman of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board, told the Mortgage Bankers Association of America tonight that the services of investment and mortgage bankers would be required when it was time for industrial refinancing and for placing bonds of government corporations with the public.

If the Supreme Court of the United States affirms the findings of Special Master RAWLS in the Delaware River boundary controversy -- which began in the seventeenth century -- Delaware will lose the Ship John Light oyster beds, but will still have title to the river within the twelve-mile circle from Newcastle, Del., and to low water on the New Jersey shore.
WEST NEW YORK, N.J., Oct. 11. -- While a woman member of their party watched unmoved, four assailants shot one man to death and wounded another seriously outside a night club here early this morning.

F.H. LaGuardia told a group of Fusion workers yesterday to make it widely known among the voters that if the next Board of Estimate should be controlled by the Fusion forces there would be no reduction in salaries for city employes in the classified civil service.

CHICAGO, Oct. 11. -- With their companies emerging from one of the most critical years in the history of American finance, several hundred life insurance executives convened here today to take stock of the situation and to discuss its probable trend.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 (AP). -- In the expectation that the Eighteenth Amendment would be repealed on Dec. 5, the administration today rounded out its plan to meet the situation.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 11. -- Discussion of Great Britain's war debt to the United States will be continued tomorrow, when Under-Secretary of State Acheson and his associates will again confer with the British mission. It Is expected that many aspects of the situation will be explored before the actual question of terms will be brought forward.

CAMBRIDGE, Maas., Oct. 11. -- Scbolastic prizes were awarded to the leading students of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology today when the 1933 honor roll, containing 553 names, was made known. Many of the coveted prizes were won by technology students from New York City.

The directors of the Continental Can Company, Inc., yesterday increased the annual dividend rate on the common shares from $2 to $2.50 by declaring a quarterly disbursement of 62% cents, payable on Nov. 15 to holders of record of Oct. 25. The dividend was thus restored to the basis that was in effect prior to July, 1932, when the rate was reduced.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 (AP). -- The White House kaleidescope, ever interesting, ever shifting, was in varied and colorful pattern today, in the observance of Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt's birthday. "Who's Who" said it was her forty-ninth.

A bolt from Tammany by John H. McCooey, Brooklyn Democratic leader, was intimated as a not impossible defection by Samuel Seabury, chairman of the Fusion campaign committee, in an address yesterday at New York University.

Charles G. Koss, an executor of the estate of Ella V. Von E. Wendel and lawyer for her family, who died Sept. 6, left most of his estate, believed to be worth several million dollars, to his daughter, Mrs. Isabel Koss Murray of 628 West End Avenue, it was disclosed yesterday when his will was filed for probate in Surrogate's Court.

MANILA, Oct. 11. -- The Philippine Legislature dealt with the Hawes Law directly today when the House adopted a resolution, 55 to 22, flatly rejecting the law. Leaders who favor the law insist it has not been killed, but is subject to resurrection before January.

Ray Impelletiere, huge Italian fighter, yesterday was established as an effective obstacle to future ring activities of Max Baer, King Levinsky and Johnny Risko. The State Athletic Commission ruled that until the Italian is removed by one or all of these fighters as a heavyweight title threat, none will receive consideration in connection with his own title plans.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 (AP). -- Butter was selected tonight as the first major far mproduct which the government will purchase in President Roosevelt's double-edged program of cutting down surpluses and feeding the needy.

Baron Erik von Barnekow, Countess Caroline Hochberg, the Countess de Monbrison and Baron George von Zedlitz are among the notables sailing tonight for the Channel ports on the North German Lloyd liner Europa. Others on the list are:

Hirsch Smulowitz bad died on Sept. 9 and a month had passed. At the Yonkers home of the New York Guild for the Jewish Blind that meant one thing. A successor must be chosen for the 109-year-old man who had only twenty-seven birthdays because he was born on Feb. 29.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The present local political situation is almost unique. It is impossible to recall an election in which the choice of the candidate for Mayor has been so difficult to make. The "decent" citizen is anxious to place the conduct of the city in honest, untrammeled hands.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 11. -- The three regional coordinating committees of the railroads were asked today by Joseph B. Eastman, coordinator of transportation, to name a committee of railroad officers to cooperate with a similar group selected by the Science Advisory Board of the National Research Council to determine whether efficiency or the roads could be increased by further scientific research.

A rump meeting of stockholders of the Electric Bond and Share Company developed spontaneously yesterday after the annual meeting had been held, when Martin T. Flannigan, an insurance and real estate man and holder of utility securities, attracted a following of other holders disgruntled over the tax, rate and government-ownership problems of electric companies.

Two directors and members of the executive board of the Bank of United States, testifying yesterday in the criminal branch of the Supreme Court as State witnesses in the trial of Isidor J. Kresel, said that they were not aware until later that the bank had lent $8,000,000 to three of its safe-deposit company affiliates on Jan. 13, 1930.

SHANGHAI, Oct. 11. -- Giving evidence of the large-scale preparations for the forthcoming anti-Communist drive, Generalissimo Chiang Kaishek is sending hurriedly to Kiangsi Province more than 10,000 hospital beds, to be ready to handle the wounded.
MORGANTOWN, W. Va., Oct. 11. -- A Scrimmage which lasted nearly an hour and a half featured the West Virginia squad's preparation today for the Fordham game.

NEWMARKET, England, Oct 11 (AP). -- The English-bred Seminole, sporting the silks of Joseph E. Widener of New York, covered the trying two-and-a-quarter-mile course in 3:47 In scoring a smashing upset in the classic Cesarewitch today.

GENEVA, Oct. 11. -- During all the twelve hours between, the arrival of Sir John Simon, British Foreign Secretary, this morning and the departure of Joseph Paul-Boncour, French Foreign Minister, tonight, the American, British and French delegations drove at high speed toward their ambitious project of achieving the main lines of a disarmament treaty within two or three weeks.
LONDON, Oct. 11 (AP). -- Following are the Board of Trade figures for September:

When the Central Savings Bank sold to the 67 Pike St. Realty Corp., Samuel Kilpatrick, president, the four-story dwelling at 466 W. 43d St. for $9,500, the bank took back a purchase-money mortgage for $8,000, payable in five years.

The Department of Agriculture has increased its estimate slightly, but still forecasts the smallest crop of American wheat in thirty-seven years. The figure is 515,000,000 bushels, compared with more than 700,000,000 last year and with an average in round numbers of 800,000,000 for the preceding decade.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., Oct. 11 -- Charles T. Newberry of Sleepy Hollow was elected president of the Westchester County Golf Association at the annual meeting of the organization at the Bonnie Briar Country Club tonight.
SYDNEY, Australia, Oct. 11. -- Peace had no sooner been declared in the cricket war between Australia and England over "bodyline" bowling than hostilities broke out afresh today.

DETROIT, Oct. 11 (AP). -- Manager Jack Adams of the Red Wings, Detroit's entry in the National Hockey League, announced today the acquisition of Gordon Pettinger, wingman with the New York Rangers last season, for an undisclosed sum of money.

LONDON, Oct. 11. -- British and American business men well known throughout the United States are among the members of the "London Advisory and Protective Committee," formed here to safeguard the interests of British investors in American securities.

MIAMI, Fla., Oct. 11. -- Cuba, divided into increasingly numerous factions which refuse to cooperate, is on the brink of anarchy, General Mario G. Menocal, former President, said today. The general strike now called on the island, he fears, will prove the most serious of all the recently developing threats to orderly government.
LONDON, Oct. 11. -- Faith in President Roosevelt's recovery plan and the business outlook in the United States was expressed today by Leonard J. Reid, financial editor of The Daily Telegraph.

Unemployed musicians, charging that the New York City Police Band, which they help support by taxes, is taking the bread out of their mouths by playing at private functions, started a legal action against Commissioner Bolan yesterday to restrain him from permitting this practice to continue.

A word of regret for the passing of "old-fashioned actors and old-fashioned stock companies," and a word or two of advice on how to write plays like Sardou's and Thomas Hardy's were dropped yesterday in the course of a richly discursive talk by Daniel Frohman, dean of American theatrical producers.

VIENNA, Oct. 11 (AP). -- Socialists attempted tonight to Interrupt a speech by General Karl Vaugoin, president of the Federal Railways, in Schwarzenberg Platz, but police succeeded in keeping them at a safe distance.

NORTHERN LIGHTS, by F. Spencer Chapman (Oxford $5). The official account of tho British expedition to the Arctic, under the late H.G. Watktns. Admiral Richard E. Byrd wrote a foreword for this American edition.

The work of rebuilding the Dodgers for next season got under way yesterday when Bob Quinn, new business manager, of Brooklyn, announced the purchase of Leslie Munns, right-handed pitcher, from the St. Paul club of the American Association.

PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 11. -- A long offensive scrimmage for the first two varsity teams featured Princeton's bard practice today. The first team engaged the third varsity eleven and the second team the scrubs.

With the return to action yesterday of Abe Scheuer, giant tackle, and John Kohler, veteran guard, the New York University football team regained its full strength. Both athletes received minor injuries in last Saturday's battle.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 11. -- In what was distinctly a surprise move, believed to be the forerunner of an early definition by the government of its monetary policy, the Treasury today called $1,900,000,000 of the Fourth Liberty Loan for redemption April 15, 1934.

Columbus Day, the 441st anniversary of the discovery of America by Christopher Columbus, will be celebrated today in this city and vicinity. Schools, banks, exchanges, higher courts and some business establishments will be closed here, although the stores and many offices will be open.

Mr. LAGUARDIA'S address on city finances, Tuesday evening, was admirable both in form and in substance. It reveals an unusual grasp of this difficult subject. He rejects outright the Tammany thesis that all the city's troubles are chargeable to the depression, maintaining instead that the "complete breakdown" of municipal financing could have been both foreseen and avoided.

The opening of "Ruy Bias," which had been announced for Oct. 23 at the Cort Theatre, has been postponed for a week or two. In the meantime the play, in which Walter Hampden portrays a dual role, will continue its preliminary tour. Next week the production will be seen at the Majestic Theatre, Brooklyn.

Despite the crowds that saw the National Charity Air Pageant at Roosevelt Field last Saturday and Sunday, it was revealed yesterday that the show had ended with a large deficit. A petition in bankruptcy was filed by the National Air Pageant, Inc., signed by John S. Reaves, its president, through Hardin, Hess Eder, attorneys for the corporation.

PITTSFIELD, Mass., Oct. 11. Dr. Harry A. Garfield, president of Williams College, observed his seventieth birthday today and received many flowers and best wishes. It was mountain day at the college, and all the offices were closed. Tonight Dr. and Mrs. Garfield were the guests in compliment to whom Professor Henry D. Wild of the department of latin and Mrs. Wild gave a dinner.
Deals involving properties on the west side of Manhattan, from Forty-third Street north to Washington Heights, featured real estate trading yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 11. -- Looking to creation of a permanent code compliance system, General Johnson said today that a committee was at work to compose views of the NRA, the Commerce, Labor and Justice Departments and the Federal Trade Commission.

EAST ORANGE, N.J., Oct. 11. -- Mrs. Thomas B. Stillman of South Orange and Mrs. Nellie K. Farnham of East Orange, with a score of 131 out of a possible 210 placed first this afternoon in the opening event, the women's pairs, at the third annual New Jersey State championship bridge tournament here.

Martin Conboy, who was a special counsel to former Governor Roosevelt in the Walker inquiry, was appointed yesterday to take charge of the State's investigation of the Brooklyn laundry racket as Federal, State and county authorities pressed their drive against racketeering in industry.

Included in the evidence offered for the forthcoming investigation of Nazi propaganda in the United States. Representative Samuel Dickstein, chairman of the Congressional Committee on Immigration, said yesterday he had reports at about fifty instances where Germans in this country had been brought to cooperate with the Nazi organizers through threats of reprisals against their relatives in Germany.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 11. -- Senator McAdoo was named to the Senate Banking and Currency Sub-committee investigating stock market practices today as having served Dillon, Read Co. as counsel in overcoming a legal difficulty when the firm floated a $12,000,000 Brazilian municipal loan in 1921.

The Public Service Commission announced yesterday an order effective Oct. 25 reducing all bills for electric metered service to general consumers in the Borough of Richmond by 10 per cent for one year. This will mean an estimated saving to consumers of $250,000.

All sections of the money market were quiet, and quotations for each classification unchanged from those of the preceding day. It was note-worthy, however, that while 3/8 prevailed in the Street market in the early dealings, a heavy offering of funds later forced the rate to 1/2. The Stock Exchange official charge remained at 3/4.

CHICAGO, Oct. 11. -- Lipstick, face powder and other cosmetics of the future may be required to have vitamin content, J.C. Clark, chief of the Central District of the United States Food and Drug Administration, told the convention of the American Dietetic Association today in discussing the proposed new food and drug act.

Several theatrical managers and ticket brokers appeared at the weekly meeting of the National Legiltinate Theatre Committee yesterday to answer charges of failure to comply with Regulations having to do with the sale and distribution of tickets.
The address of Joseph V. McKee at a rally at Cooper Union last night follows:

To the Editor of The New York Times: One of the most important steps toward financial recovery, it seems to me, is the restoration of confidence in real estate, both on the basis of sale, and on the basis of security for mortgage investment. The absolute demoralization of the mortgage market at this time is, without doubt, one of the main causes if not the fundamental cause of present conditions in the real estate market.

TOKYO, Thursday, Oct. 12. -- Foreign Minister Hirota is studying dispatches from Ambassador Ota in Moscow and reports made by Eiji Amau, Foreign Office spokesman, concerning his questioning of Alexei Nagei, the Soviet Tass News Agency correspondent in Tokyo.

LAUREL, Md., Oct. 11 (AP). -- Sylvester W. Labrot's Greyglade loomed as the early favorite to win the Maryland Futurity here Saturday when she raced to an impressive victory over five other 2-year-old fillies in the featured Wye Purse today. The Howe Stable's High Torque was second and Morton L. Schwartz's Hindu Queen third.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 (AP). -- Bureau of Internal Revenue agents have been assigned to investigate widespread complaints that wheat bootlegging is becoming prevalent in the grain belt, taking the form of violations by growers of regulations permitting them to have their own wheat ground into flour for home use, tax free.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 11 (AP). -- A former vice president of the Sweeten Automobile Company of this city, which is suing Henry Ford for $168,000, testified today that the Detroit manufacturer, his arm around the Philadelphian's shoulder, promised that his firm would "get back" its alleged losses.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Oct. 11. -- Frank J. Hermes, well known New York advertising man, secretary and treasurer of the Blackman Company, advertising agents, with which he had been associated for thirty-five years, died here this afternoon at his home, 139 Paine Avenue, after a prolonged illness.

R.G.A. van der Woude, formerly president of the Shell Petroleum Corporation, was elected yesterday president of the parent company, the Shell Union Oil Corporation. J. C. van Eck, president of the company since 1924, was elected chairman of the executive committee, a new position created by the directors.

A vigorous rally in the final 30 minutes of trading yesterday sent domestic corporation bonds higher on the Stock Exchange, in some cases erasing early losses. The inspiration was the news from Washington that the refunding of about one-third of the outstanding Fourth Liberty 4 1/4s would be attempted, although details of the plan were not announced until after the Stock Exchange had closed.

ROME, Oct. 11 (AP). -- Pope Pius XI appeared today in the regalia of a time when, the papacy held wide temporal power and blessed thousands gathered before the basilica of St. Mary Major, one of five cathedrals Holy Year pilgrims must visit for plenary indulgence.
No progress was made yesterday in either direction on the Cotton Exchange and prices ended with a decline of a point to an advance of 2 points after unusually narrow fluctuations in a 10-point range.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 11. -- After discussing with President Roosevelt today the legislative program for Congress's next session, Senator Robinson of Arkansas, the majority leader, said that the Appropriations committee would probably meet in advance of Congress so that approriation bills could be reported promptly.

A jury that for the last three and a half weeks has heard testimony in the trial of United States Senator James J. Davis on an indictment charging that he violated the Federal Lottery Law in 1931 will receive the case for determination today.

CHICAGO, Oct. 11. -- Modern medicine now makes it possible for the average person not only to add years to his life, but also to add life to his years, Dr. Charles H. Mayo of the Mayo Clinic, Rochester, Minn., told an audience of several thousand in the Chicago Stadium tonight at the annual community health meeting of the Congress of the American College of Surgeons.
HELENA, Mont., Oct. 11. -- Montana, through action of the 1933 Legislature, will have its own system of liquor supply stores.

When a playwright falls heir to a tremendous idea it behooves him to write a tremendous play. Walter Hasenclever seized upon a tremendous idea a few years ago when he wrote a play chronicling the return of Napoleon to a world that sorely needs leadership.

STETTIN, Germany, Oct. 11. -- Despite repeated injuctions by the Reich Minister of Economy and other high officials against Nazi onslaughts on department stores, an organization has been formed here designed to take as much as possible of their Christmas trade away from those of Stettin.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., Oct. 11. -- The semi-final round in the Greenbrier Golf and Tennis Club's annual Fall tennis tournament was reached today by George M. Lott Jr., J. Gilbert Hall, Wilmer Hines and E.W. Feibleman.

Steps are being taken to form a national federation of brokers to present a united front against the movement to regulate the various security and commodity exchanges of the country by legislative action.

Dr. George J. Ryan, president of the Board of Education, and other members of the board will appear before the Board of Estimate in an effort to obtain a loan of more than $16,000,000 through the Reconstruction Finance Corporation for needed school facilities.

A new issue of $2,500,000 State of West Virginia refunding bonds was awarded yesterday to a syndicate composed of the First National Bank, New York; Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc.; Bancamerica-Blair Corporation, Northern Trust Company of Chicago, Salomon Brothers Hutzler, Geo. B. Gibbons Co., Inc., and R.W. Pressprich Co.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 (AP). -- Thirteen thousand striking workers and their employer, the National Steel Corporation, were urged today by the National Labor Board to submit their differences to arbitration in order to restore industrial peace.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 11. -- By an overwhelming vote this evening delegates to the American Federation of Labor convention ignored the contention that solution of present-day economic and labor problems called for "an infusion of new blood" into the executive council, labor's supreme governing body.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 11. -- The Treasury Department circular advertising the issuance of a new series of 1943-45 bonds reads as follows:

WASHINGTON, Oct. 11. -- President Roosevelt will be prepared, with emergency regulations, to deal with the new situation growing out of repeal, until such time as Congress can enact permanent legislation.

For the second day in succession, and the third since the Jamaica meeting began, the eensational youngster Earl Porter yesterday rode three winners in one afternoon. He scored astride The Heathen, Manya and Apprehensive, and now has ridden fifteen winners in the nine days the Metropolitan Jockey Club's meeting has run.

LONDON, Oct. 11. -- The stock markets were cheerful and firm today, with industrial issues again outstanding in activity. British funds, which lately had been dull, improved. Foreign bonds hardened and the German loans were supported.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 11. -- All codes of fair competition now in operation are being analyzed and digested to uncover any divergencies and to make possible the working out of a system of standardized fair practice regulations for all businesses coming within the jurisdiction of the NRA, General Hugh S, Johnson, the administrator, announced today.

AMSTERDAM, Oct. 11. -- The correspondent of a leading Dutch newspaper who is reporting the Reichstag fire trial alleges that Marinus van der Lubbe's case is being prejudiced by inaccurate translation of his replies by the official interpreter.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 11. -- Coach Reg Root today drove the first and second Yale varsity elevens through forty-five minutes each of scrimmaging against strong scrub elevens and each Blue team registered two touchdowns against its gray rival.

A form of "local option" to meet the sentiments of small communities is suggested in the study of the liquor control problem sponsored by John D. Rockefeller Jr. Another part of the report was made public yesterday by Raymond B. Fosdick and Albert L. Scott, who conducted the study.
ALBANY, Oct. 11. -- Thousands of fingerprints of brewers and brewery employes have been filed with the State Alcoholic Beverage Control Board, Chairman Mulrooney said tonight.

Four football games to be played on fields in as many boroughs comprise the Columbus Day schoolboy program in New York City. Two of the contests on this afternoon's card mark renewals of rivalries that were started more than twenty years ago.

BERLIN, Oct. 11. -- Supported by a strong bond market, the stock market today gave signs of recuperation and advances were made all along the line. The quarterly report of Vereinigte Stahlwerke stimulated a demand for mining and steel shares and price levels were raised anywhere from 1 1/2 to 2 3/4 per cent.
John F. Curry, Tammany leader, pent most of yesterday at Tammany Hall for the usual Wednesday reception of his district leaders and other callers.

LONDON, Oct. 11 (AP). -- James and Betty Roosevelt, who again have been visiting the scenes of their honeymoon here three years ago, will leave tomorrow or Friday for Paris. Mr. Roosevelt is the eldest son of the American President.

Railway passenger revenues increased in some regions in July, although for the first seven months of the year they were below those of the same period in 1932, according to figures filed with the Inter-state Commerce Commission. The South and the Northwest increased their returns for July, while for all the railroads the total was close to the level of 1932.

Registration mounted once more last night for the third day of Registration week, and when the computation was finished it was disclosed that a grand three-day total of 961,900 persons had put their names on the books.

Heinz Schuengel, managing director of the North Atlantic Union, comprising the merged interests of the North German Lloyd and Hamburg-American Lines, said on his arrival on the Europa yesterday that the economies resulting from the merger of these two Atlantic companies would be considerable.

Abolition of freight differentials among ship lines serving the Gulf trade, which is proposed by a group of the more powerful Gulf lines, was attacked as unfair to shippers and a violation of the rights of the individual lines at the monthly meeting of the Shippers' Conference of Greater New York yesterday afternoon in the Merchants Association hearing room.

Examination yesterday of the petitions filed with the Board of Elections showed that nearly all the regular Democratic candidates for the Assembly and the Board of Aldermen in Brooklyn and Queens were also listed as running under the emblem of the McKee Recovery party.

Japan appears to be surprised as well as indignant at the stiff tone of the recent Russian notes to Tokyo, together with the bristling up of the official newspapers in Moscow. For a year the Soviet Government had been almost absolutely silent about Japanese encroachment upon Russian rights in the Chinese Eastern Railway and In other matters.

Men and women widely known in society, turf and polo circles will contribute today to the success of the special program of the United Hunts Racing Association on the estate of the late Hugh A. Murray, near Roslyn, L.I.

RICHMOND, Oct. 11. -- Control of the Virginia-Carolina Chemical Corporation, with assets of more than $28,000,000, passed today into the bands of a previous minority group headed by George S. Kemp, Richmond broker. The Kemp slate of eight nominees for the board of directors of fifteen members was elected at the annual stockholders' meeting.

The New York Stock Exchange yesterday expelled from membership John B. Stetson Jr., former United States Minister to Poland, who la floor partner In the Stock Exchange firm of Stetson Blackman. The firm, which has an office in Philadelphia, was suspended on Sept. 13, when Richard Whitney, president of the Exchange, announced that it was "in such financial condition that It cannot be permitted to continue in business with safety to Its creditors."

Uncertainty in the Iron and steel Industry is ascribed in the mid-week review of The Iron Age to the fact that the government's plans with respect to various important features of the recovery program have not been fully developed. This publication fixes the operating rate for the country at 44 per cent of capacity, compared with 42 per cent in the week before.

Decision on whether New York City is to vote by ballot or voting machine on Nov. 7 was put off until next Tuesday by the Board of Elections yesterday after an open hearing. By that time, the board hopes, enough candidates will have been eliminated through declination or successful protest to make the use of the machines possible.

The Paramount Theatre came yesterday within a few inches of gauze of losing its license. The gauze formed part of the costume of Sally Rand, fan dancer, and was too little a part of it to suit Sidney S. Levine, newly appointed Commissioner of Licenses.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 (AP). -- Agents of the Department of Labor were notified by Secretary Perkins today that they must not attempt to interfere in any way with newspaper editors.

FOLSOM PRISON, Calif., Oct. 11 (AP). -- After spending more than sixteen years behind prison walls waiting for a pardon and rejecting opportunities to seek other forms of clemency, Warren K. Billings, who with Thomas J. Mooney was convicted of bombing the 1916 San Francisco Preparedness Day parade, applied today for a parole.

The salary contracts of directors of the Paramount-Publix Corporation, which were ratified by stock-holders at their meetings in 1927 and 1928, were submitted yesterday at the bankruptcy hearing for creditors of the corporation, held before Henry K. Davis, Federal referee, at 140 Nassau Street.
To the Editor of The New York Times: A dispatch to THE NEW YORK TIMES from Teheran, Persia, telling of the death of Timurtash Khan contained certain statements which should be corrected.

ALBANY, Oct. 11. -- Former Governor Alfred E. Smith is to receive the degree of Doctor of Laws from the University of the State of New York at the sixty-ninth convocation which opens tomorrow night. Mr. Smith came to Albany tonight for that purpose. Mrs. Smith, who had come to Albany by motor, met him here.

CINCINNATI, Oct. 11. -- The value of informal conferences to settle gas rate controversies was shown to the National Association of Railroad and Utilities Commissioners today by George W. Woodruff of the Pennsylvania Public Service Commission.
Joseph V. McKee opened his campaign for the Mayoralty at Cooper Union last night with a declaration of political independence and a promise of sweeping reforms.

BERLIN, Oct. 11 -- Inquiries in diplomatic circles today reavealed that it is not only the American representatives here who have reached the point of insisting that real punishment be meted out to Nazis who make unprovoked attacks on foreigners in Germany.
Reggie Root, Bucky O'Connor, Charley Comerford and Ducky Pond were lolling in their chairs in the coaches' headquarters in the Whitney Gymnasium at Yale.

OKLAHOMA CITY, Oct. 11 (AP). -- A sealed verdict held the fate tonight of George (Machine Gun) Kelly and his wife, Kathryn, accused of conspiracy in the kidnapping of Charles F. Urschel, wealthy oil man.

A holiday matinee of "Carmen" and an evening performance of "La Boheme" are promised for tonight at the Hippodrome. Bruna Castagna, Edith Alexander. Bernardo De Muro and Ettore Nava are announced, for the first, and Annunciata Garrotto, Lucy Monroe, Franco Tafuro, Giuseppe Interrante, Pasquale Amato and Nino Ruisi for the second.

WEST ORANGE, N.J., Oct. 11. -- Mrs. C.T. Williamson of Essex Fells won the three-day handicap tourney of the New Jersey Women's Golf Association, which was concluded today at the Essex County Country Club.

Mayor O'Brien's outline of his unemployment relief record and program was attacked yesterday as "entirely unsatisfactory and absolutely inadequate" by Charles Solomon, Socialist candidate for Mayor. Mr. Solomon also assailed the Mayor for "saying not a word about housing in a speech made in the midst of some of the worst slum areas in the country."
The people backing the candidacy of Joseph V. McKee serve tea at headquarters, smoke perfumed cigarettes and have set up a "nice people's bureau."

Except for a handful of stocks in which there were fairly wide advances, the share market displayed yesterday the inaction that usually characterizes trading on the Stock Exchange on the eve of a holiday. Transactions ran only slightly above 1,000,000 shares.

BERLIN, Oct. 11. -- What was regarded by disinterested observers as a staggering blow to the moral foundation of the Nazi dictatorship and the case for the prosecution in the Reichstag fire trial was dealt today by Police Lieutenant Emil Lateit, who was the first police official to reach the scene of the crime and who made the first official investigation.

LONDON, Oct. 11. -- The change from Diesel to steam turbine engines in the Asturias and the Alcantara, announced by the Royal Mail Line about two weeks ago, has led to a discussion, according to the management of the White Star Line, over whether Diesel engines are suitable for transatlantic ships.

APOLLO, Pa., Oct. 11 (AP). -- Visiting the heart of the steel district under escort of more than 175 State police, Mrs. Gifford Pinchot told a meeting of 5,000 workers tonight that "steel trust officials" were to blame for Western Pennsylvania's industrial unrest.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Every citizen of the State of New York should use his influence to have continued the free adult education classes which have been maintained for the unemployed in twenty-one cities. These schools are doing a highly important work.

VALPARAISO, Ind., Oct. 11. -- After a secret inquest today into the death of seven persons in the crash of a transcontinental passenger plane five miles southeast of Chesterton last night, it was learned that four witnesses testified that they heard a terrific explosion as the plane was flying high in the air.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 11. -- A detailed report of all Nazi outrages against American citizens in Germany is being prepared by the United States Embassy in Berlin and the State Department for the information of Secretary Hull.

Mr. McKEE and his political advisers are naturally embarrassed by too great a Tammany desertion to their side. It is all very well to leave a sinking ship, but there is danger of overloading the ship of refuge. Especially unpleasing is the appearance of taking command of it. Mr. McKEE himself saw the need of repelling the implication.
VIENNA, Oct. -- 11. -- Frietz Horn, former secretary of Baron Leopold Popper, the husband of Maria Jeritza, brought suit against the Baron and the opera singer here today for slander.

CHICAGO, Oct. 11. -- Low prices for grain prevailed today on the Board of Trade, and while then was a strong rally at one time, it was due to short covering and local buying. Some of those who bought wheat on the way up went out of their holdings later to even up for the holiday tomorrow.
With organization Democrats throughout the city declaring for Joseph V. McKee, independent candidate for Mayor, there became evident yesterday a similar drift among Republicans.

There is a legend of a Heifetz who cannot err, who, with thoughtful, impassive countenance, masters his audiences by the inscrutable perfection and finish of his playing. After listening to Mr. Heifetz last night in Carnegie Hall the auditor realized again the fallibility of legends, and the further fact that Jascha Heifetz, an extremely sensitive musician and man, is as changeable in mood and human of feeling as other great musicians.

OSNARBRUECK, Germany, Oct. 11 (AP). -- Reinhold Tiling, 37 years old, noted builder of rockets, and a woman assistant, Angelica Buddenboehmer, died today from injuries received in the explosion of a rocket they were charging. Another assistant was less seriously hurt.

TRENTON, Oct. 11. -- The use of a radio typewriter to receive automatically police messages through the air was demonstrated here today to members of the New Jersey State police and other police authorities.

BALTIMORE, Oct. 11. -- The plan for merging the Baltimore Ohio Railroad with the Pennsylvania Railroad, as proposed by John Barriger, railroad examiner of the RFC, and endorsed by W.W. Atterbury, president of the Pennsylvania, was condemned by John J. Cornwall, general counsel of the B. O., at the Baltimore Live Stock Show dinner here tonight.

A luncheon and fashion show In behalf of Stony Wold Sanatorium will be held on Oct. 20 in the Egyptian Room of the St. Regis under the auspices of Auxiliary No. 6. Many young women of society will act are manikins in the showing of Autumn and Winter costumes and accessories.

Supreme Court Justice Cotillo granted yesterday the application by Chase Mellen Jr., chairman of the Republican county committee, to direct the Board of Elections to accept the nominating certificate of Chief Justice Frederic Kernochan for Judge of the Court of General Sessions.

JERUSALEM, Oct. 11. -- Although prohibited by the Palestine Government the Arabs here are preparing to hold a demonstration Friday in protest against large Jewish immigration here and extensive sales of lands to Jews.

GENEVA. Oct. 11. -- The fourteenth League of Nations Assembly ended today on its seventeenth day after the shortest and least productive session on record. President Charles te Water, in his closing speech, pleaded for a greater spirit of generosity everywhere, especially in Europe, as the thing needed above all for peace and neighborliness.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 (AP). -- Wholesale commodity prices recovered part of their loss during the week ending Sept. 30 and moved upward by two-tenths of 1 per per cent last week. The Department of Labor reported today that its index numbed of the general level of commodity prices for the week ending Oct. 7 was 71.3 against 71.1 for the previous week.

HONOLULU, Oct. 11. -- The members of the Hawaiian Commission which is going to Washington in an endeavor to convince Secretary Ickes that no change is needed in the organic law under which the Territory is governed were announced today.

One of the longest and most strenuous workouts of the year was held yesterday at Baker Field by the Columbia football team. The Lions spent the last hour of a four-hour drill under floodlights as they rehearsed offensive and defensive methods for their encounter with Princeton a week from Saturday.

A movement to improve the appearance of old buildings on the west side of Manhattan was initiated yesterday by the West Side Association of Commerce. James W. Danahy, managing director, announced that a single block had been selected on which the reconditioning campaign will be centred.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. King Smith of this city and Wolfeboro, N.H., of the engagement of their daughter. Miss Mary King Smith, to Robert Wood-ward Prosser 2d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Herman Alfred Prosser of New York and Greenwich, Conn. Miss King Smith on her paternal aide is a descendant of the Hopkins and Pomeroy families of New England.

CHICAGO, Oct. 11. -- The fate of the "sixty-day loss payment clause," invoked by fire insurance companies during the bank moratorium, came up for discussion today at the convention of the National Association of Insurance Agents.

All financial and commodity markets as well as banking institutions will be closed today in observance of Columbus Day. This means that business activity in the financial district will be almost entirely suspended. The exchanges and the banks will reopen tomorrow for business as usual.

PARIS, Oct. 11 (AP). -- President Roosevelt's recovery program will have a French counterpart with variations in a far-reaching program designed by Premier Edouard Daladier to balance his nation's budget and speed up the wheels of French industry.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 11. -- The Treasury Department circular addressed to fourth Liberty bond-holders notifying them that their bonds were called follows in full:

It is not capital but labor that worries the Administration and threatens recovery. It was natural that organized labor should take full advantage of its opportunities, and the Administration baa been distinctly liberal and kind to it. Having received privileges and advantages some of which were forced upon employers, organized labor should be content and cooperate heartily to make the NRA a success.

CHICAGO, Oct. 11. -- The American College of Surgeons held its second annual cancer symposium today. Participating were thirty of the leading specialists in this country and abroad, and the meeting was dedicated to the purpose of spreading the news that "cancer is curable if treated by a competent physician in the early stages."
NEW YORK. Mrs. J. Roosevelt Roosevelt of Hyde Park is at the St. Regis.

When the registration booth at 222 West Thirty-eighth Street closed last night the poll books contained the name of one qualified voter for the municipal election on Nov. 7. The voter was Rabbi Nathan Wolf.

CRISTOBAL, C.Z., Oct. 11 (AP). -- Colonel Irving Lindberg, Collector General of Customs and a member of the High Commission of Nicaragua, said today that the Nicaraguan Government would seek a temporary moratorium on its bonded indebtedness in the United States and Great Britain.
Business Gains Abroad. Belief that the tide of the depression has turned in many countries simultaneously finds support in dispatches received by the Department of Commerce from its attaches abroad.

Price movements on local commodity exchanges were irregular yesterday, with sugar, cocoa and hides quoted higher and other staples lower. Trading was fair in volume. In the cash markets, most prices were lower.

Chase Mellen Jr., the newly selected President of the New York County Republican Committee, made public last night an appeal to Republican candidates not to accept nominations, except from the Republican party and Fusion.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 11. -- Non-Federal projects totaling $24,846,611 were approved today by the Public Works Administration. The largest single amount, $8,000,000, was allocated to Chicago to continue work on the Sanitary District.

Arrangements have been made by Max Gordon to tour the Noel Coward play, "Design for Living," one of the major Broadway successes last season. Mr. Gordon, who presented the play originally, had expected to send the attraction on the road at the beginning of this Season.

The notable art collection of the late Thomas Fortune Ryan, flnancier, is to be sold at auction at the American Art Association Andersen Galleries, Inc., on Nov. 23, 24 and 25 by order of the Guaranty Trust Company of New York, executor of the estate, it was revealed yesterday.

PAWLING, N.Y., Oct. 11. -- Edward M. Evarts, a lawyer specializing in patent work, who had practiced in New York since 1917, died at his home here today of a complication of ailments on the eve of his forty-fifth birthday. His wife and three children survive.

The dollar rallied strongly for a time yesterday and then reacted to close at 66.12 cents, up 3 points, in gold valuation measured against the franc. In line with the recovery of the dollar yesterday morning and on Tuesday the Treasury's daily price for newly mined gold was reduced 35 cents an ounce to $30.91.

DETROIT, Oct. 11 (AP). -- The Chrysler Corporation announced today that more than 28,000 of the nearly 33,000 shop workers in all plants have accepted a plan providing for joint shop councils for collective bargaining between employes and the management on all matters concerning wages and working conditions.

George J. Horning resold to John Tonjes the two-story brick taxpayer at 513 Bergenline Av., southwest corner of 11th St., West New York, for $32,000. The buyer gave back in part payment a mortgage for $21,000 due Oct. 9. 1938. The seller acquired the realty from Mrs. Martha Krause last Feb. 2.

CHICAGO, Oct. 11. -- Prices of hogs have dropped today about 50 cents a hundredweight from the high point of earlier in the week, with light weights selling at the lowest level in two weeks. The top was off 15 cents today at $5.10, while the average was 10 cents down at $4.65.

MONTREAL, Oct. 11. -- Plans for reorganization of Price Bros. Co., now in bankruptcy, as proposed by Bowater Paper Mills of England, have been accepted by the Price protective committee for "compelling reasons," the committee notified bondholders today.

F. Trubee Davison, president of the American Museum of Natural History, and Mrs. Davison returned from Africa yesterday on the North German Lloyd liner Europa. They were accompanied by Lieutenant Elwood R. Quesada, their pilot during approximately 10,000 miles of air travel in the wilds of Africa.

The confessions of alleged murderers, who got $50 to $60 each for their services, were read yesterday to a jury in Judge James M. Barrett's part of Bronx County Court. The jury is hearing evidence against four men charged with killing Michael Malloy, a derelict stationary engineer, for $1,788 insurance they had placed on his life.

HAVANA, Oct. 11 (AP). -- A general strike again threatened Havana as the National Confederation of Labor, communistically influenced organization, which yet has to achieve government recognition, gave strike orders to its many affiliated unions.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 11. -- At the State Department it was considered improbable that Dr. Hans Luther, the German Ambassador to the United States, would respond to Representative Dickstein's Invitation to appear before the House Immigration Committee during the proposed investigation of alleged Nazi propaganda activities in this country.

BRUSSELS, Oct. 11. -- Albert Devese, the Minister of War, at a Ministerial Council today under the chairmanship of King Albert, asked for a credit of 750,000,000 Belgian francs [about $157,500,000] to carry out an extensive plan of fortifications, which will take more than two years to complete.

Two actions were begun in Supreme Court yesterday to force inclusion of $17,522,500 for pension purposes in Mayor O'Brien's 1934 budget, which had its first public hearing at City Hall during the day.

BARCELONA, Oct. 11. -- In a speech that is interpreted in some quarters as a rebuke to the American colony on the Spanish island of Majorca, Ambassador Claude G. Bowers declared that Americans who cannot maintain a sense of dignity abroad are the worst enemies in Europe of the United States.
Thousands of native and flight ducks have arrived in Long Island Sound and in the marshes bordering the Connecticut River, according to advices received yesterday.

THE special train of the triumphant Giants was rolling northward from Washington. Bill Terry, seated in a compartment with C.A. Stoneham and a couple of friends, was smoking a big cigar and telling a story. It was partly in dialect or good broken English put on where truth called for it.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., Oct. 11. -- The announced retirement of Mayor Clarence E.F. Hetrick, for eighteen years chief executive of the city, followed today the special election yesterday in which voters by a majority of 692 ballots decided to adopt the city manager form of government.

To the Editor of The New York Times: R.L. Duffus's interesting article on the liquidation of the Bank of United States in THE TIMES gave the impression that its attorney and head of its legral department had been responsible for the liquidation of the bank and for "bringing order out of chaos."

Columbia ended its heavy preparation, yesterday at Baker Field for its contest with the University of Virginia here tomorrow. Coach Lou Little had his charges go through a three-hour drill, rehearsing every phase of offensive and defensive work.
Renting of furnished apartments in cooperative buildings featured the large volume of leases reported in Manhattan yesterday. The lessees included the following:

Included in a long list of tenants signed up yesterday for space in Manhattan business buildings was R.H. Macy Co. The department store has taken 50,000 square feet of space in the Port Authority Commerce Building at 111 Eighth Avenue, the Port of New York Authority announced.

GENEVA, Oct. 12. -- For a second time an American sat at the table of the League of Nations Council today. Hugh Wilson, Minister to Berne, participated in the proceedings when the question of the appointment of new members of the Permanent Central Opium Board came before it.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 12. -- Conversion within about a year of the entire 4 1/4 per cent Fourth Liberty loan of about $6,200,000,000 was predicted today in some quarters, following the Treasury's call of about a third of the outstanding issue.
For the third day in succession and for the fourth time since the meeting began, Jockey Earl Porter gained a triple when he was first with three mounts at Jamaica yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 12. -- A band of thirty-five members of the Khaki Shirt organization today gave in to the insistence of Washington police and headed for home instead of camping in the national capital. Riding in four automobiles and a light truck, the group was met at the District of Columbia line by a sizable police guard and escorted to a precinct station near by.

BERLIN, Oct. 12. -- A shift in interest from bonds to stocks produced, quite a boom on the stock market today, while the bond market suffered from realization sales. Opening prices on the Stock Exchange were up 5 per cent in some instances.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Oct. 12. -- A flag of the Spanish race, the newly created symbol of Spanish-American unity, was hoisted today for the first time on San Cristobal Hill in the middle of the city, surrounded by twenty-two other flags of Latin-American republics.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 12. -- Argentina, by a law promulgated last Monday, will reduce tariff rates on a wide range of products under the terms of the Anglo-Argentine supplementary agreement, according to information received by the Commerce Department today from the United States Embassy in Buenos Aires.

MINE0LA, L.I., Oct. 12. -- Nassau County celebrated today its adoption of the NRA code with a monster parade which had its origin in the various county villages and ended at the Fair Grounds here. More than 5,000 persons, carried to the grounds in automobiles, passed in review.

In an article in Le Temps an ironist of delightful gravity recounts the catastrophe which France lately escaped. At Lille the building housing the archives of the department all but tumbled down under their weight. Bumbledom rose to the emergency. Some seventy tons of what one is tempted to call waste paper were lugged out and carried away to an unused prison.

Harold B. Franklin, president of Radio City Theatres, the RKO Theatre Circuit and other subsidiaries of the RKO Corporation, has resigned his offices, it was announced yesterday on behalf of M. H. Aylesworth. It was reported that, after a short vacation, Mr. Franklin would enter independent motion picture production, probably under some arrangement which will continue Ma relationship with the RKO group.

Straight seamanship and finelined hulls were victorious in most of the races in the sailboat regatta on Conservatory Lake in Central Park yesterday. Although the biggest boats were only 36 inches long and every afterguard had to remain on shore, prizes in the larger classes went to the boats with "sweet" lines, handled by veterans of the little lake.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 12. -- Officers of all the building trades unions now in Washington attending the convention of the American Federation of Labor said today they would resist all attempts, by NRA officials to reduce the wages of mechanics below those already fixed by agreement.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 (AP). -- The NRA met a challenge of its authority tonight with a declaration by Senator Wagner of New York, National Labor Board chairman, that Western Kentucky mine operators who had refused to attend an arbitration hearing "will be required to appear."

One of the longest and most vigorous sessions of the year occupied the Fordham football squad at Fordham Field yesterday, the Rams drilling in the morning and afternoon in preparation for the invasion of West Virginia at the Polo Grounds tomorrow.
