The number of consumer pledge cards signed and returned to NRA headquarters at the Hotel Pennsylvania now amounts to 4,225,000, it was announced last night by Grover A. Whalen, city NRA chairman.

The application of three steamship lines for designation of the union inland freight terminal at Fifteenth Street and Eighth Avenue as their delivery point in the metropolitan district for less than carload freight en route to points outside this area has been rejected by the Trunk Line Association, it was learned yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Oct, 12. --Extreme dissatisfaction with the working out of the Recovery Act in several important particulars, coupled with a demand that labor be represented on every board created under the act, marked today's session of the American Federation of Labor convention.

Joining in what seems to be a general uprising on the part of the smaller college teams this year, New Hampshire goes into the Harvard Stadium tomorrow extremely hopeful that it will at least score on the Crimson and that it will manage to make the game interesting all the way.

WASHINGTON, Oct, 12. -- Steel companies owning captive mines informed President Roosevelt in letters made public today that they would recognize conditionally the check-off system demanded by the United Mine Workers and would conduct negotiations with officials of that organization relative to the long existing dispute.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 (AP). -- President Roosevelt took a holiday of three hours today, motoring with his mother, Mrs. Sarah Delano Roosevelt, to the 130-year-old Colonial home of Mrs. William C. Eustis, a friend of the family, near Leesburg, Va.

PORT CHESTER, N.Y., Oct, 12. -- The race not always being to the swift, rugged Paul De Bruyn of the German-American A.C. triumphed in the ninth annual marathon from New York to Port Chester today. He outlasted his clubmate, Bill StelBer, in the last two miles.

GENEVA, Oct. 12. -- Sitting in public today the Council of the League of Nations decided to invite the United States to participate in an autonomous governing body that it is creating for the relief of German refugees.

The promises in regard to unemployment relief, education and transit unification made by Joseph V. McKee in his keynote address are "not to be trusted" in view of Mr. McKee's record, Charles Solomon, Socialist candidate for Mayor, declared last night.

LONDON, Oct. 12 (Canadian Press). -- Cheering trade reports came from different quarters today. Production of steel ingots and castings in September was announced as 238,700 tons larger than in the same month last year, and Prince George, opening the motor show at the Olympia, pointed to an increase of 27 per cent in domestic production and of 68 per cent in motor production for foreign trade.

OKLAHOMA CITY, Oct. 12 (AP). -- Prison "for the rest of your lives" was the government's firm answer today to George (Machine Gun) Kelly and Mrs. Kathryn Kelly, his wife, last of the Urschel kidnapping principals to be branded guilty.

Bank clearings for the last six days in twenty-one leading centres, of the country totaled $4,156,721,000, according to Dun Bradstreet, Inc. This compares with $3,354,959,000 in the corresponding week last year, which consisted of only five business days.

Joseph V. McKee and other candidates of the Recovery party were characterized by Samuel Seabury at New York University yesterday as "political hacks" who are trying "to save the city -- for themselves."

Carl H. Milam, secretary of the American Library Association, has reported a 40 per cent increase in four years in the number of persons using public library facilities, according to an announcement by the National Municipal League, 309 East Thirty-fourth Street.

A plucky Alexander Hamilton High School football team put up a stiff battle before bowing to the favored Manual Training High eleven, 7 -- 6, yesterday at the Brooklyn Sports Stadium in their traditional battle. An enthusiastic crowd of 8,000 spectators watched the clash.

The whole-hearted support of the Lyceum Theatre and its staff has been pledged by Charles Harris, its general manager, to the National Legitimate Theatre Committee in its efforts to correct abuses in the distribution of tickets, it was stated yesterday by Brock Femberton, chairman of the subcommittee on tickets.

Nathan Straus Jr., Recovery party nominee for President of the Board of Aldermen, replied yesterday to attacks made on him ,by Samuel Seabury with the assertion that Mr. Seabury had offered him the Fusion nomination for Mayor last Summer. He asked Mr. Seabury in what way his character had changed since then.

The threat of a renewal of the strike of 60,000 dressmakers, accompanied by a stoppage of their shops by contractors and consequent paralysis of the industry, was definitely removed yesterday as a result of the intervention of Grover A. Whalen, chairman of the local NRA organization.
NEWTON, Mass., Oct. 12. -- A touchdown in the final minutes of play gave the Boston College football team a 6-to-0 victory over the "Praying Colonels" of Centre College today.

OTTAWA, Oct. 12 (AP). -- Elimination of "vexing regulations" which hinder free intercourse of trade between Canada and the United States at border points was recommended today in a joint report of the Chambers of Commerce of the United States and Canada.

LONDON, Oct. 12. -- Two outstanding speeches were being discussed here today amid the controversy raging over "Roosevelt's experiment." The addresses, made last night by Sir Josiah Stamp, economist, and Walter Runciman, president of the Board of Trade, both expressed some doubt regarding the ultimate success of the experiment.

A well-known Harlem property, the Shaw Hotel at 2,193 Seventh Avenue, near 129th Street, has been gold by the General Synod of the Reformed Church in America to Adolf Teitlebaum. The five-story building is operated as a hotel by Mrs. Ada Lee Shaw.

MEXICO, D.F., Oct. 12. -- The World Statistical Congress paid special attention today to mortality from cancer following the reading of a paper by Dr. Wilmer Bohmert, chief of the German Statistics Department. Those who took part in the discussion were Professor Stuart of the University of Utrecht, Dr. W.F. Wilcox of Cornell University and Count Yanagisawa, head of the Japanese Statistical Department.
PHILADELPHIA, Oct, 12. -- The Columbus Day invasion of Washington by "a million and a half" American Fascists intent on forcing President Roosevelt to accept a dictatorship did not materialize.

Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt and her daughter, Mrs. Curtis B. Dall, received yesterday the first two garments labeled with the NRA insignia manufactured under the Coat and Suit Code Authority. At the ceremony were employer and labor leaders of the industry in the plant of the Del Monte-Hickey Company, 530 Seventh Avenue, whose head, Leo Del Monte, is president of the Industrial Council of Cloak, Suit and Skirt Manufacturers, Inc.

RED BANK, N.J., Oct. 12. -- Seventy-five members of the Monmouth County Hunt this morning participated in a drag hunt which covered ten miles of rough country. Earlier in the morning a hunt meet was held. Both events were arranged for the purpose of filming motion pictures to be shown in New York in connection with the National Horse Show, which will open at Madison Square Garden on Nov. 8.

BERLIN, Oct. 12. -- United States Consul General George S. Messersmith said tonight that nearly three-fourths of the cases in which Americans had been attacked by Nazi representatives were on file with the Consul General in Berlin in the form, of sworn affidavits. The rest, he said, were in different consular offices in Germany. A list of the cases follows:
CLEVELAND, Oct. 12. -- Miss Helen Wright Teagle, daughter of Mrs. Frank H. Teagle, was married here tonight to Robert Morrison Clements, son of Mr. and. Mrs. Thomas Clements of Phoenix, Ariz.

George Trosk, aide to Samuel Seabury in the city inquiry and Fusion nominee for Justice of the Supreme Court in the First District, moved yesterday in an attempt to oust six judicial candidates from places on the Recovery party, or McKee, ticket.
SULLIVAN, Ind., Oct. 12 (AP). -- Indiana National Guardsmen established virtual martial law in Sullivan County today.

With business at a standstill yesterday in all American financial markets, opinion with respect to the various important developments had to be withheld. All the financial and commodity exchanges as well as the banks will reopen for business this morning.

ALBANY, Oct, 12 (AP). -- James Byrne of New York, vice chancellor of the University of the State of New York since 1929, was elected today to the chancellorship to succeed the late Chester S. Lord. Chief Judge Cuthbert W. Pound of the Court of Appeals administered the oath.
Support for Joseph V. McKee, independent candidate for Mayor, and his associates on the Recovery party ticket, mostly from Democratic sources, continued to come in yesterday.

LAKEHURST, N.J., Oct. 12. -- The United States Navy airship Macon, largest dirigible in the world, left the Naval Air Station here at 6:10 o'clock this evening for a 2,600-mile, sixty-hour flight to Moffett's Field, Sunnyvale, Calif., where she will be stationed permanently as part of the West Coast fleet.

CHICAGO, Oct. 12. -- In an address in which he described President Roosevelt as a physician called to prescribe to a sick people, Cardinal Mundelein urged 1,500 Catholic women today to aid in preventing "a relapse" which may occur, he said, if America becomes indifferent to the President's prescriptions.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Oct. 12. -- Maurice Rapoport, general manager of the Shop-Town market here which was deprived of its NRA Blue Eagle yesterday by General Hugh S. Johnson still thinks his company was the victim of hasty action, he said tonight, but now that the situation has been made clear to him by local NRA authorities he is "happy to cooperate.".

CHICAGO, Oct, 12 (AP). -- Jessie Dear, racing in the colors of F.C. McAtee of Lexington, Ky., and ridden by Jockey H. Hughes, raced to an easy victory in the top race at Washington Park today. Struggling two and one-half lengths back of the victor came Open Hearth and Red Roamer.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 12. -- The make-up of twelve alumni advisory athletic committees at Yale was announced by the Athletic Association today. Their membership includes several noted graduates.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 (AP). -- Plans are being formulated for an effort to establish a satisfactory market for the $2,000,000,000 in bonds authorized for the Home Owners Loan Corporation, created by the last Congress to refinance home mortgages.

EAU CLAIRE, Wis., Oct. 12 (AP). -- Frances Perkins, Secretary of Labor, told a meeting of the Northwestern Wisconsin Teachers Association today that new demands will be made on education by the "New Deal."

JERUSALEM, Oct, 12. -- With hundreds of Arabs reported coming into Jerusalem from towns and villages tomorrow to participate in the demonstration of protest against Jewish immigration into Palestine and the sale of lands to Jews, the situation is assuming a grave aspect.

TOKYO, Friday, Oct. 13. -- While still delaying its answer to Moscow, the Japanese Government shows an attitude that definitely invites continuance of the negotiations for the sale of the Chinese Eastern Railway.

Further arguments in support of the contention that control of liquor after repeal should be vested in the State, to remove the private-profit motive from the liquor business, were advanced yesterday in another release of the text of the report prepared under the sponsorship of John D. Rockefeller Jr.

Home-loan applications in the metropolitan district totaling 20,880 and involving $127,746,003 have been received and classified as eligible for aid by the Home Owners Loan Corporation, according to a report issued yesterday by Vincent Dailey, State manager.

Mrs. Florence Streett Shields of St. Louis, widow of George H. Shields, and Guy A. Thompson, former president of the American Bar Association, were married at noon yesterday in Washington, D. C., it was announced by relatives here last night.

MOSCOW, Oct. 12. -- A new world's record for parachute jumping was made yesterday by a Red Army pilot, Victor Evceyef, who jumped from a height of 23,616 feet and dropped 23,124 feet before pulling the rip cord.
Much activity has been witnessed this week in Washington on the part of those who favor the Duck Stamp Tax Bill which, it is hoped, will be passed when Congress again assembles in January.
Governor Lehman announced last night that he would call a special session of the Legislature next week to enact into law the provisions of the city's agreement with its bankers.

BERLIN, Oct. 12. -- The tenacious insistence of Marinus van der Lubbe, the Dutch brick mason, that he alone set the Reichstag fire was supported tonight as torches glared fitfully in the darkened building in a reconstruction of the circumstances surrounding the blaze.
With banks, courts, city offices and many places of business closed, New York celebrated Columbus Day yesterday with exercises in various parts of the city.

WASHINGTON, Oct, 12. -- A gross profit of $6,608,376.73 was made by Dillon, Read Co. and their syndicate associates in the flotation of four Brazilian and Bolivian Government bond issues totaling $130,500,000, now in default, the Senate subcommittee investigating Stock Exchange practices was informed today by Robert Otis Hayward, a vice president of the firm.

The Treasury's announcement of its purpose to convert into twelve-year 3 1/4 per cents one-third of the outstanding Fourth Liberty 4 1/4 per cents appears to have taken the market by surprise. It had been assumed that so large a refunding operation would, in the present condition of the Government's finances, be deferred to a possibly more favorable occasion.

The sport of sailing dinghies during the Winter months will be on a firmer basis than ever this season, schedules announced yesterday by the Larchmont Yacht Club and the Manhasset Bay group of skippers indicate.

THE DEATH OF A WORLD, by Remain Rolland (Holt, $2.50). Continuing from the closing pages of "Mother and Son" the story of Annette Riviere and her son Marc. This is the fourth volume of Rolland's novel, "The Soul Enchanted."

College women from various sections of the country, members of twenty national sororities, will meet at a dinner dance tonight at the Panhellenic, 3 Mitchell Place, which will be held there to celebrate the fifth anniversary of the founding of the Panhellenio Association of fraternities.
LONDON, Oct. 12. -- Colonel Charles A. Lindbergh discussed transatlantic air routes with officials of the Imperial Airways at Croydon Airdrome today.

Varied speakers, ranging from Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt to a young woman still In college, expressed their faith yesterday that the youth of today would conquer the tremendous problems that their elders were bequeathing to them.
LONDON, Oct. 12 (AP). -- The weekly statement of the Bank of England shows the following changes, in pounds sterling:
NEW YORK. Mr. and Mrs. Mandeville Mullally of Homewood, Hewlett, L.I., will give a tea dance on Dec. 9 in the main ballroom of the Pierre to introduce their daughter, Miss Eleanor H. Mullally.

Virility and full-throated instrumental song or among the characteristics of Bruno Walter as conductor, and these qualities were admirably in place in the performance of the Handel Concerto Grosso which opened the program of the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra last night in Carnegie Hall.

The total cost of government of fifty-seven cities in New York State, excluding New York City, Buffalo and Rochester, rose 220 per cent in the fourteen-year period ended on Dec. 31, 1931, according to an exhaustive survey by William Parr Capes, executive secretary of the New York State Conference of Mayors.

BAYONNE, N.J., Oct. 12. -- The Jacob Ruppert, flagship of Admiral Richard E. Byrd's second Antarctic expedition, docked at 11:20 o'clock tonight at Pier 3 of the Tide Water Oil Company on Constable Hook near here.
SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 12. -- Alcatraz Island is a block of solid rock rising just a mile and a quarter from the Marina section of the San Francisco shore.

The Vatican Library, which was damaged in 1931 when its sixteenthcentury foundations collapsed, has been restored, according to Mgr. Eugene Tisserant, Pro-Prefect of the library, who arrived here yesterday on the Rex.

LOS ANGELES, Oct, 12 (AP). -- The colorful and daring career of Tom Bay, who as a film stunt man had doubled for many of HolIywood's Western stars in breath-taking episodes, was ended last night by A bullet wound.

John F. Curry, Tammany leader, continues to hold daily conferences with his trusted supporters, in an effort to rally the organization to the standard of Mayor O'Brien, and to the borough and county tickets.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W Va., Oct. 12. -- George M. Lott Jr of Chicago, Davis Cup doubles star defeated. Wilmer Hines, former national junior champion, today In the semi-finals of the men's singles in the Greenbrier Autumn lawn tennis championship tourney.

Registration mounted to 1,274,976 last night as tabulations of the fourth day's totals were completed. This mark was still ahead of the record established in last year's Presidential election registration, when 1,210,023 persons were registered for the same period.
An Editor's Lot. Taking one consideration with another, an editor's lot is not a happy one. This is especially the case when an election is impending. Then he is condemned for contrary reasons.

BUFFALO, Oct. 12 (AP). -- The Niagara Share Corporation's president, Jacob F. Schoellkopf Jr., denied today on the witness stand that its officers and directors made to benefit their own pocket-books, the deals on which stockholders base their $300,000,000 suit.
PARIS, Oct. 12 (AP). -- The weekly statement of the Bank of France shows the following changes, in francs:

To the Editor of The New York Times: H.B. Matthews in a letter to THE TIMES expresses annoyance over the "colloquialization" which, he complains, has crept into the English of reputable newspapers. While there is some basis for his complaint, his generalization is inept.

Because of the Columbus Day observance, all activity was suspended yesterday in Wall Street as well as in other important domestic centres. Foreign markets were firm, particularly in London. There was also a slightly firmer trend on the Canadian security exchanges.

BANGKOK, Siam, Oct, 12 -- Prince Bovaradej, a member of the royal family and former Defense Minister of Siam, is marching on Bangkok at the head of an armed force. He seized Donmaung airdrome, the headquarters of the royal aeronautical service, today.

LIMA, Ohio, Oct. 12. -- Three welldressed, armed men, posing as Michigan police officers, shot and fatally wounded Sheriff Jess L. Sarber in the Allen County Jail here today and then broke into the jail and escaped with John Dillinger, 30, who was being held here as a suspect in the $2,000 robbery of the Bluffton Citizens Bank.

Jimmy Foxx, batting king of the American League, yesterday entered that select circle of players who twice have been named as most valuable to their team through the season's campaign. Furthermore, he stands by himself as the only one ever selected twice in succession for that honor.

BERLIN, Oct. 12. -- The German Supreme Court held a starlight session in front of the Reichstag building tonight and watched the reconstruction of the incendiarism of Marinus van der Lubbe, the Dutchman who burned out the Reichstag chamber.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In the conclusions of the series of articles "Money and Inflation" there is the statement: "It [gold] constitutes the reserve behind the circulating money. As such it serves as an effective check on monetary abuses." This argument assumes that there is something automatic or self-regulatory about gold which frees it from the human frailties which attend the management required in the use of any other monetary standard.
BUCHAREST, Oct. 12. -- As is usual whenever statesmen in the Balkans plan to reduce the number of danger points, interested groups intervene and revive old acerbities.

ALBANY, Oct. 12. -- For the second time in its history, the University of the State of New York conferred the honorary degree of Doctor of Laws upon a man who had filled the office of Governor. Tonight that honor was given to Alfred E. Smith, for eight years Governor of the State.
Today, for many persons, is what the Ides of March were to Caesar. In other words, it is Friday the 13th.

ROSLYN, L.I., Oct. 12. -- The sapphire blue and emerald green colors of Mrs. Gwladys Whitney flashed to a richly deserved victory today in the Manhasset Steeplechase, the outstanding event on the program of the United Hunts Autumn racing meet.

ROCHESTER, Oct. 12 (AP). -- Before a notable assemblage of high church dignitaries, Bishops, monsignorl and priests and a crowd Which overflowed St. Patrick's Cathedral for several blocks about, the Most Rev. Edward A. Mooney of Youngstown, Ohio, titular Archbishop of Irenopoli d'lsauria and former Apostolic Delegate to Japan, was installed today as the fourth Bishop of the Catholic diocese of Rochester.

Hard pressed for revenues, New Jersey has followed the example of Illinois and taken stern measures to insure collection of past-due local taxes. In Cook County, made desperate by Chicago's previous tax strike, the county collector is now permitted to apply to the courts for appointment as receiver of properties in arrears; to date the law is reported to have brought "moderately satisfactory results."

More than 400 elementary school boys took part In the first annual track and field games of the George W. Thompson Association yesterday at St. Gabriel's Park. After six hours of competition the St. Gabriel's School athletes gained the initial leg on the Goddard Trophy by amassing 47 points.

EAST ORANGE, N.J., Oct. 12. -- Mrs, Thomas B. Stillman of South Orange and Mrs. Nellie K. Farnham of East Orange retained their lead this afternoon at the Second session of the women's pairs competition of the closed New Jersey State championship bridge tournament here.

In a courtroom crowded with members of the Loyal Order of Moose, who cheered at the verdict, Senator James J. Davis of Pennsylvania was acquitted last night of charges of violating the Federal Lottery Law.

Lynn Hunt, T.H. Lawrence and Tracy H. Lewis tied for the highover-all cup in the twentieth annual cosmopolitan championship decided over the traps of the Bergen Beach Gun Club yesterday. Each finished the shoot with a card of 98 out of 100 targets.

Henry Sherman, gangster, of New York and Detroit, expected to be "put on the spot" by enemies and his nervousness grew until early yesterday, when he borrowed a revolver from a brother and killed himself.

Mrs. Charles Dana Gibson, chairman of the women's division of the McKee campaign committee, expressed indignation yesterday at a Tammany statement, which, she said, suggested there was snobbery in the McKee campaign. The Tammany statement referred to "nice people" and "afternoon tea" at the McKee headquarters.
A migration of "thugs and guerrillas" to colonize Joseph V. McKee's home borough and cast fraudulent votes against him was reported last evening by District Attorney Samuel J. Foley of the Bronx.

WASHINGTON, Oct, 12. -- Acquisition of the military prison on rocky, inaccessible Alcatraz Island in San Francisco Bay for confinement of defiant and dangerous criminals was announced tonight by Attorney General Cummings.

The Gasoline Merchants of Brooklyn and Queens, Inc., whose membership controls more than 3,000 gas stations in the two boroughs, voted last night to boycott oil and grease products of the major companies beginning Monday morning, unless the present margin of profit on gasoline is increased.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct, 12 (AP). -- The threat of a strike was heard here today as actors and actresses, represented by the newly organized Screen Actors Guild, hurled new protests at reports that the motions-picture mode Under consideration In Washington would provide for a salary-fixing board.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 12. -- Schedules of the Tale hockey, basketball, swimming and water polo teams for the Winter were announced today by the Yale Athletic Association.

The State of New York has a university without either faculty or students of its own. But in its official authority it embraces all the educational agencies of the State, from the kindergarten to the university. It possesses chartered children even beyond the bounds of the Empire State: in Syria, Brazil, China and other parts of the earth.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 12. -- Germany's relations with this country occupied the centre of the official stage here today, as far as foreign affairs were concerned.

Lack of supervision, ignorance of the rules and poor medical attention yesterday were blamed by the presidents of the National Collegiate Athletic Association and the football coaches for deaths from the game, which already total fourteen for the season.

The United States liner President Roosevelt will arrive today from Hamburg, Havre, Southampton and Cobh. On board are members of the Czechoslovak team with the mounts the will ride in the International Horse Show. The officers are Captain Frank Statecny, Captain Hyneck Bycek and First Lieutenant Vaclay Schantin of the Cavalry School at Pardubice, and Captain Julius Cocek of the Third Cavalry Regiment.

CINCINNATI, Oct. 12. -- Stricter regulation of utility holding companies and affiliates was urged in a report today to the convention of the National Association of Railroad and Utilities Commissioners by its committee on intercorporate relations.

RIVERHEAD, L.I., Oct, 12. -- The benefit racing meeting held at the Suffolk County Fair Grounds today was attended by more than 1,000 persons. The proceeds will be added to the fund of the Suffolk County Agricultural Society.

HAVANA, Oct. 12. -- The American Coast Guard cutters at Matanzas and Puerto Padre on the north coast of Cuba and the destroyers at Cienfuegos and Manzanillo on the south coast have been ordered out of those ports.

Led by Dom Cafaro, who scored three touchdowns, De Witt Clinton High School's football team downed Morris High, 34 to 0, yesterday at George Washington High School Stadium. A crowd of 4,000 saw Clinton tally in every period to win the 1933 edition of its traditional rivalry with Morris.

GLOUCESTER, N.J., Oct. 12. -- Five men, believed to be the only survivors of the Greek freighter Annoula, which sank in a heavy storm 600 miles off the North Carolina coast early Saturday, came into Gloucester today aboard a rescue ship with graphic stories of their experience.

Invading the Bronx, political home of Joseph V. McKee, for a second time, F.H. LaGuardia, Fusion candidate for Mayor, came out strongly last night for a new charter for the city. He condemned the present charter as not only obsolete but too long and too complex.

WAYLAND, Mass., Oct. 12 (AP). -- Playing the course for the first time in six years, Johnny Farrell, Quaker Ridge professional, today clipped a stroke each way on the 7,000-yard Presidential layout to card a 70.
Cardinal Hayes yesterday promoted seven of his clergy to pastorates of suburban parishes and transferred many assistants in Manhattan, the Bronx and in the upState parishes.

VIENNA, Oct. 12. -- Further details today of the audience accorded in Rome by former Empress Zita to about seventy-five Austrian nobles indicates that Hapsburg restoration aspirations have shifted for the time being from Hungary to Austria.
PARIS, Oct. 12. -- "I am more than ever determined to bar inflation or any sort of monetary manipulation," Premier Daladier said in an address tonight at a banquet of the Automobile Club here.

The National Public Housing Conference went on record last night as favoring municipal authority over housing. Meeting at the Russell Sage Building, 130 East Twenty-second Street, it voted unanimously for a resolution calling upon Governor Lehman to back legislation to this end at the next session of the Legislature.
To the Editor of New York Times: The mystery of Mr. McKee's candidacy is rapidly being elucidated in a way that must lose him the support of all voters not interested in Democratic machine politics.

Nearly 1,000 books from the private library of the Czars of Russia have been consigned for auction to the Plaza Art Galleries, 9 East Fifty-ninth Street, according to announcement yesterday by the galleries.
Cardinal Hayes yesterday promoted seven of his clergy to pastorates of suburban parishes and transferred many assistants in Manhattan, the Bronx and in the upState parishes.

VIENNA, Oct. 12. -- Further details today of the audience accorded in Rome by former Empress Zita to about seventy-five Austrian nobles indicates that Hapsburg restoration aspirations have shifted for the time being from Hungary to Austria.
PARIS, Oct. 12. -- "I am more than ever determined to bar inflation or any sort of monetary manipulation," Premier Daladier said in an address tonight at a banquet of the Automobile Club here.

The National Public Housing Conference went on record last night as favoring municipal authority over housing. Meeting at the Russell Sage Building, 130 East Twenty-second Street, it voted unanimously for a resolution calling upon Governor Lehman to back legislation to this end at the next session of the Legislature.
To the Editor of New York Times: The mystery of Mr. McKee's candidacy is rapidly being elucidated in a way that must lose him the support of all voters not interested in Democratic machine politics.

Nearly 1,000 books from the private library of the Czars of Russia have been consigned for auction to the Plaza Art Galleries, 9 East Fifty-ninth Street, according to announcement yesterday by the galleries.

GREAT NECK, L.I., Oct. 12. -- Mort Fearey, Garden City Golf Club veteran, and his partner, Dwight Rockwell, returned a 66 to take medal honors by one stroke today in the first annual Eben M. Byers memorial tournament at the Deepdale Golf Club.

BEVERLY, Mass., Oct. 12. -- The crew of a fast power boat which plied to and fro on a mysterious mission in the night ignored the plight of three men clinging to an overturned dory near them in choppy Beverly Harbor early this morning and as a result two were drowned and the third badly affected by shock, immersion and exposure before he was rescued.

Foreign governments have often made protests in Mexico, South American republics, Cuba and Turkey against maltreatment of their nationals temporarily in those countries. But never before has a great Power like Germany been openly subjected to the reproach of not being able, or willing, to protect foreigners under her jurisdiction.

GENEVA,. Oct, 12. -- The disarmament deadlock tautened sharply here tonight when Dr. Rudolf Nadolny of Germany suddenly took a 1 o'clock train to get an airplane at Basle and fly to a Cabinet meeting over which President von Hindenburg will preside in Berlin tomorrow.

CHICAGO, Oct. 12. -- Further clinical evidence in support of the theory that several common diseases were the result of the abnormal activity of the adrenal glands, driving the sympathetic nervous system at too terrific a pace, was presented here tonight before the annual clinical congress of the American College of Surgeons.

Holiday Spurt in Trade Here. Retail trade here showed a holiday spurt yesterday, although the warm weather held back consumer purchases of heavier apparel, particularly women's coats. Most stores were well crowded, with considerable shopping around for special values reported.

DETROIT, Oct. 12 (AP) -- bit dusty from close contact with certain underparts of a railroad carriage, Horace (Patsy) O'Toole, the one-man cheering throng from Detroit, arrived home belatedly from Washington today to tell the city how President Roosevelt had "inquired" about him, and to place his voice in training for a tough season of football bellowing-on a national scale.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Oct. 12. -- Joseph B. Keenan, Special Assistant United States Attorney General who aided in prosecution, of George ("Machine Gun'.') Kelly and associates for the kidnapping of Charles F. Urschel, told delegates to the American Prison Association in convention here tonight that a central Federal crime detection bureau was necessary.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 12. -- In an effort to solve problems involving the National Recovery and the Agricultural Adjustment Administration, General Hugh S. Johnson, the recovery administrator; Secretary Wallace and George B. Peek, the agricultural adjustment administrator, held a long conference today in the office of Secretary Wallace.

MOSCOW, Oct. 12 (AP). -- A dispatch from Khabarovsk, Siberia, reported tonight the arrest of two more officials of the Chinese Eastern Railway, drawing renewed charges from the Soviet Government that authorities in Manchuquo were attempting to deprive legal Soviet agents of a voice in the administration of the railway.

CHICAGO, Oct, 12. -- In the livestock markets here today hogs of butchers grades weighing 225 to 260 pounds were taken in preference to light hogs at a premium of 10 to 15 cents a hundredweight. Prices for others were steady to 15 cents higher than yesterday.

PORT JEFFERSON, L.I., Oct. 12. -- Two stakes were completed at today's opening session of the twelfth annual Fall field trials of the Brookhaven Game Protective Association. Nineteen brace and one bye dog were run off in the Puppy and Derby Stakes on the trial grounds on Strongs Neck in East Setauket.
LAUREL, Md., Oct, 12 (AP). -- Sun Abbot, racing under the green, brown and orange silks of Willis Sbarpe Kilmer, drove to a cleancut victory in the Laurel feature today.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 (AP). -- Postmaster General Farley announced plans today for an Intensive week of conferences with local political leaders in New York State.
PATERSON, N.J., Oct. 12. -- A committee representing workers and employers in the broad silk strike left tonight for Washington for further discussion with Senator Wagner of strike settlement plans.
Nine persons were injured but none dangerously when two crowded automobiles crashed at 5:45 o'clock yesterday morning at Grand Street and the Bowery.

WESTBURY, L.I., Oct. 12 -- More than 100 members of the combined Meadow Brook and Smithtown Hunt Clubs started from the stables on the estate of Mrs. Harry Payne Whitney this morning in the first official fox hunt of the season.

BERLIN, Oct. 12. -- United States Ambassador Dodd will call on Chancellor Hitler tomorrow to discuss matters of interest in the relations of Germany and the United States. It is understood Foreign Minister von Neurath probably will be present at their conversation.

WASHINGTON, Oct, 12. -- The 525,000,000 "subsistence homestead" section of the National Recovery program, through which the government hopes to aid partially employed heads of families with homes and acreage sufficient to feed their families, was started today.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 (AP). -- Postmaster General Farley announced plans today for an Intensive week of conferences with local political leaders in New York State.
PATERSON, N.J., Oct. 12. -- A committee representing workers and employers in the broad silk strike left tonight for Washington for further discussion with Senator Wagner of strike settlement plans.
Nine persons were injured but none dangerously when two crowded automobiles crashed at 5:45 o'clock yesterday morning at Grand Street and the Bowery.

WESTBURY, L.I., Oct. 12 -- More than 100 members of the combined Meadow Brook and Smithtown Hunt Clubs started from the stables on the estate of Mrs. Harry Payne Whitney this morning in the first official fox hunt of the season.

BERLIN, Oct. 12. -- United States Ambassador Dodd will call on Chancellor Hitler tomorrow to discuss matters of interest in the relations of Germany and the United States. It is understood Foreign Minister von Neurath probably will be present at their conversation.

Three men were missing and three were burned, one fatally, last night by fire that destroyed a Standard Oil barge, the superstructure of a huge pier and threatened several loaded tankers moored at the Constable Hook plant of the Standard Oil Company of New Jersey in Bayonne.
To the Editor of The New York Times: I have been following with considerable interest THE NEW YORK TIMES articles of "Money and Inflation."

The question of supremacy between William Woodward's Dominus and Joseph E. Widener'g Golden Way will be decided today at Jamaica when the two meet in the Continental Handicap, closing day feature of the Metropolitan Jockey Club meeting.

With the duck-hunting season almost here, a warning issued yesterday by W.C. Henderson, associate chief of the United States Biological Survey, seems very timely. It brings to the fore once more the fact that a tremendous waste of wild waterfowl occurs every season.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Oct. 13 (AP) -- Supreme Court Justice Graham Witschief, in refusing an injunction to halt picketing of the Rosenthal, Ettlinger Clothing Company by members of the Amalgamated Clothing Union, today expressed opinions on labor sections of the NRA code for the industry.

LOS ANGELES, Oct. 13 (AP) -- Alice White's story of a terrific "beating" at the hands of John Warburton, movie actor from England, is told in a transcript of the blond actress's recent testimony before a grand jury, released today.

BERLIN, Oct. 13 -- The upward movement on the Boerse continued today, although at a somewhat slower pace. Gains mostly were within 2 per cent, bu specialties rose up to 4 per cent. Particular interest was manifested in Reichs-bank shares, which rose 3 1/2 per cent.

In the presence of representatives of metropolitan and neighboring universities, the University in Exile was dedicated last night to the pursuit of knowledge in a spirit of academic freedom and intellectual tolerance. Formal inauguration ceremonies were held at the New School for Social Research, 66 West Twelfth Street.

CHICAGO, Oct. 13 -- A medical code for employers in industry, calculated to eliminate or largely reduce the enormous toll of deaths and injuries in employment, has been presented in outline to the National Recovery Administration by representatives of the Committee on Industrial Medicine and Traumatic Surgery of the American College of Surgeons.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 13 -- With a powerful and versatile attack, Temple University got back in its winning stride by bowling over the Haskell Indians tonight, 31 to 0, before a crowd of 18,000. This was Haskell's first defeat of the season and the first time the Indians were scored upon in four games.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 13 -- A Common Pleas Court jury today ordered the Ford Motor Company to pay claims of $100,000 to the Sweeten Automobile Company, a bankrupt sales concern of this city, in connection with the purchase of the Lincoln Motor Company in 1922.

WAYLAND, Mass., Oct. 13 (AP) -- Putting for birdies on almost every green, Dave Hackney of Lowell today carded a 69, three under par for the 7,000-yard Presidential course, to finish in a first place tie with Jerry Gianferante, young Lexington professional, at the halfway point in the 72-hole Eastern open golf championship.

There were indications that County Judge John J. Fitzgerald would press a charge of contempt of court against Jacob Mandelbaum, chief counsel for the three men accused of laundry racketeering, on trial before him in Brooklyn when Mr. Mandelbaum threatened to withdraw from the case yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 -- Limitations which must be taken into consideration in any proposal by Great Britain to the United States for a settlement of the war debt problem were explored today at a two-hour conference between the representatives of the two nations.

Joseph V. McKee, independent candidate for Mayor, criticized Samuel Seabury, Fusion leader, yesterday for his attack on Governor Lehman in a speech in the Bronx Thursday night. Mr. Seabury was quoted as declaring that the Governor had done nothing to correct the evils disclosed by the Hofstadter committee investigation, of which he was counsel, and had done nothing to bring to justice the "criminals" shown to have stolen from unemployment relief funds.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 -- The Reconstruction Finance Corporation has authorized the purchase of $50,000,000 preferred stock in the Continental Illinois National Bank and Trust Company of Chicago, Chairman Jesse H. Jones announced tonight.

The Eastern railroads failed again yesterday to reconcile their views on reductions of passenger fares with those held by the managements in other regions and, in consequence, it was predicted that there probably would be no concession made in this region this year.

Educational institutions should cease giving pupils second-hand facts which they could better learn from the printed word and devote themselves to imparting genuine knowledge, Dr. John Erskine, author and educator, said yesterday in an address before the Women's Conference on Current Problems at the Waldorf Astoria.

BARCELONA, Spain, Oct. 13 -- Ambassador Claude G. Bowers of the United States gave Barcelona reporters today a glimpse of American informality as he sat on a desk in the consular office and greeted them as fellow-newspaper men.

A petition in bankruptcy was filed yesterday in the Federal Court in Brooklyn against the New York Investors, Inc., of 162 Remsen Street, Brooklyn. The petition, signed by our creditors, was filed by the law firm of Schiff, Dorfman Stein.
Tammany answered yesterday the Fusion challenge on charter revision with the declaration that Mayor O'Brien would name the proposed charter revision commission regardless of who may be elected Mayor.

Bonds identified as having been carried in the names of the only Objectors to a plan by which the Baltimore Ohio Railroad successfully met the maturity of $63,250,000 of bonds on March 1 have been deposited under the plan, it was disclosed yesterday.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., Oct. 13 (AP) -- The characteristic steadiness of Miss Joan Ridley of London more than offset the spectacular rallies of her youthful American opponent, Miss Anne Page of Philadelphia, today in the final of the annual Greenbrier Autumn tennis championships.

Professional penologists generally do not favor carrying the "isolation" theory to the literal extreme proposed by Attorney-General CUMMINGS. "The "idea of an island prison to isolate "criminals of definite and apparently "irredeemable anti-social tendencies "has been discussed for many years," said Warden LAWES of Sing Sing in a recent letter to the New York Prison Association.

CHICAGO, Oct. 13 (AP) -- Federal agents said an apparent attempt to kidnap Joseph Sans, held in connection with the $250,000 mail robbery here last December, was frustrated today as Sans was being transferred from the Federal Building to the county jail.

Marcelle De Witt Hull, Fusion candidate for Alderman in the Twelfth Assembly District, is running for an office that she believes should be abolished. And when, or if, she is elected, one of her first acts, she said yesterday, would be to insist that Aldermen's salaries be reduced from their present $5,000 a year to $1,800 or, perhaps, to $2,000.

Of the total of $11,022,710 of new State and municipal bonds to come up for award next week, only a small percentage is expected to draw bids from New York bankers. The list is headed by $3,800,000 city of Boston (Mass.) relief bonds, $2,500,000 State of Louisiana 5 per cent highway bonds and $1,500,000 city of San Diego (Calif.) El Capitan Dam bonds.

DOROTHY CANFIELD is one of the most able of all the able writers who mix the sweet sauce based on woman's magazine circulation recipes into good novels. There is meat enough in her new novel, "Bonfire" (Harcourt, Brace, $2.50) for about one-third of an "Arrowsmith," for about one-third of another "The Last Adam," but while it is very palatable it is still something of a stew.

Headed by the Hotchkiss-Kent game to be played at Kent, Conn., this afternoon's football schedule contains a number of important contests for the East's leading prep school elevens. In several of the encounters, college freshman squads will furnish the opposition for the school teams.

An opinion written by Milo R. Maltbie, chairman of the Public Service Commission, and concurred in by a majority of the commissioners, denied yesterday the application of the Jamaica Water Supply Company for permission to issue $500,000 principal amount of first mortgage thirty year 5 1/2 per cent gold bonds under an existing mortgage and 5,000 shares of $6 series cumulative preferred stock of no par value.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 -- The Roosevelt Administration was disclosed tonight to be preparing to halt distribution of Federal relief to strikers of Department of Labor investigators reported their strike unjustified.

The local NRA organization will transfer its headquarters today from the Hotel Pennsylvania to 45 Broadway. In the downtown building formerly occupied by the United States Shipping Board and later by the Hamburg-American Line both the city and the State NRA organizations will have quarters and will be prepared to continue their activities as usual on Monday.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Oct. 13 -- The selection of the island of Alcatraz, in San Francisco Bay, as the site for a Federal prison for confirmed criminals was praised today by leading penologists at the congress of the American Prison Association here.

CHICAGO, Oct. 13 -- Sweeping reductions in passenger fares on all railroads west of Chicago, St. Louis, Memphis and New Orleans supplemental to the cut in the basic rate voted last week, were announced today by the Western Passenger Association.

JERUSALEM, Oct. 13 -- An Arab demonstration today, protesting against Jewish immigration into Palestine and extensive sales of lands to Jews, was effectively frustrated by stringent police measures. Eleven persons were injured.

University graduates who cannot find positions in any of the professions should not turn away from factory work, Dean Alexander Baltzly of New York University told members of the Washington Square College Social Problems Club yesterday at a meeting in the college.

A special men's committee headed by Richard B. Scandrett Jr., lawyer and nephew of the late Senator Dwight W. Morrow, has been formed to aid the "Crusade for Children." The organization was established recently to raise $400,000 this Fall to be distributed among seven child-welfare agencies for the care of dependent children.
AKRON, Ohio, Oct. 13 (AP) -- A new, pale yellow oil, 9,200 times more potent than ordinary cod liver oil, was described to the Ohio-Michigan section of the American Chemical Society here today.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 -- The daily average volume of Federal Reserve Bank credit outstanding during the week ended Oct. 11, as reported by the Federal Reserve Banks, was $2,452,000,000, an increase of $26,000,000 compared with the preceding week and of $218,000,000 compared with the corresponding week in 1932.

LONDON, Oct. 13 -- The Archbishop of Canterbury, head of the Church, of England, tonight made an urgent appeal to Germany to make some peace sign at Geneva. Addressing a League of Nations Union "peace or war" demonstration in London, he said:

PARIS, Oct. 13 -- Premier Daladier's evident determination to get the budget in shape and the patient skill with which he, Finance Minister Bonnet and Budget Minister Lamoureux have been working seem to be having an effect.

PATERSON, N.J., Oct. 13 -- Despite reports from Washington and sections of the trade that peace had been accomplished, silk workers here tonight were unable to make definite announcement that the strike had been settled for jacquard and dye workers.

RICHMOND, Va., Oct. 13 -- An effort to annul the election of eight members of the Board of Directors of the Virginia-Carolina Chemical Corporation, which gave control of the $28,000,000 company to a previous minority group headed by George S. Kemp of Richmond, will be started on Monday before Judge William A. Moncure in the Chancery Court here.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 -- A planning board to include the St. Lawrence waterway project in the public works program was set up at a conference called today by Frank R. McNinch, chairman of the Federal Power Commission, at the request of President Roosevelt.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 -- The American Federation of Labor convention decided today to "join with other public-spirited organizations" in "officially adopting a boycott against German-made goods and services." after an impassioned speech by President William Green.
The text of President Roosevelt's speech, delivered in Washington last night and carried by radio to the Women's Conference on Current Problems at the Waldorf-Astoria, was as follows:

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 -- State Department officials have not been officially informed that France has denounced the London tariff truce. In the absence of detailed information they refused to comment, adding that no special significance would be attached to the denunciation as such, and that "it all depends on the reasons given."
"Champagne, Sec," a new adaptation of Johann Strauss's Viennese operetta "Die Fiedermaus," will open tonight at the Morosco Theatre. Peggy Wood, Helen Ford and George Meader are in the cast.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 -- While maintaining this government's neutrality in Cuban political battles, Secretary of State Hull said today the withdrawal of four United States war vessels from Cuban ports yesterday had no reference to the Cuban situation as a whole.

The 11,000-ton freighter Jacob Ruppert, with one of the most variegated and noisy cargoes ever assembled, moved out of her berth at Bayonne at 11:20 o'clock last night and set a course in the general direction of the South Pole.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 -- The Department of Justice, anticipating repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment by Dec. 5, is considering a proposal to abandon at once a large portion of the prohibition cases in which arrests have been made.

Reflecting a spread of re-employment, the trend in savings accounts has been reversed completely from one of decline to one of increase, in the last three months, according to Henry B, Kinsey, president of the Savings Banks Association of the State of New York.

BERLIN, Oct. 13 -- Ambassador Dodd did not see Chancellor Hitler today as had been planned to discuss matters of mutual German and American interest, including especially the attacks by Nazi storm troopers upon some thirty American citizens and the alleged failure of the German authorities to bring the culprits to justice.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on Oct. 7 totaled 654,428 cars, the American Railway Association announced today. This was 7,399 cars, or 1.1 per cent, fewer than for the preceding week, but 29,339 cars, or 4.7 per cent, more than for the corresponding week last year, and 109,390 cars, or 14.3 per cent, fewer than during the corresponding week two years ago.

Prices for commodities broke again to lower levels in trading on local exchanges yesterday, with the volume of transactions showing some increase. For the most part, the declines were attributed to the strength of the dollar in foreign exchange markets.

ANN ARBOR, Mich., Oct. 13 (AP) -- True to tradition, Coach Gloomy Gil Dobie tonight opined that "Cornell stands no chance of winning from Michigan" in their intersectional clash tomorrow. He observed that his small squad of twenty-seven players and "inadequate, inexperienced reserves" would assure Michigan an easy victory.

Although there was the basis yesterday for a heavy liquidating movement on the Stock Exchange, transactions amounted to only 1,263,000 shares, which represented only a small increase over the business done on Wednesday. The decline in values ordinarily would have involved a larger turnover.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 13 -- Eight Yale junior fraternities announced tonight the results of their annual Fall elections, 160 members of the class of 1936 being received into membership.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 -- Speeding up of judicial procedure, extension of Federal jurisdiction in cases of kidnapping and other serious crimes and greater severity in dealing with convicted offenders were among the recommendations advanced as crime deterrents and unanimously endorsed this morning by the anti-crime conference of the United States Flag Association.

U.S. Department of Agriculture. Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices at New York. General Conditions. Locally dressed supplies of most classes were relatively light. Trading in non-kosher meats was uneven. In a general way, the demand was only fair to slow.

A sharp rise in the dollar in foreign exchange, following news of the partial Liberty Loan conversion, weakened cotton yesterday with other commodities. Prices on the Cotton Exchange lost 21 to 28 points under steady selling.

The interval of Thursday's holiday wrought no change in the character of the money market. Business was as small, and quotations for all classifications unchanged from Wednesday. Routine requirements made up the day's business.

Consumers Now Testing Prices. Shopping around for values by consumers is now greatly on the increase, retail executives here reported yesterday. Many customers apparently still need to be convinced that substantial price increases are being made and still have the prices they paid for last year's garments quite fresh in mind.

Final appeals for every voter to make himself eligible to ballot on Nov. 7 by registering were issued last night by chieftains of all political groups as registration for the first five days mounted to 1,611,794.

Scoring Joseph V. McKee's position on slum clearance and housing as "completely anti-social," Charles Solomon, Socialist candidate for Mayor, in two meetings last night in Mr. McKee's home borough, the Bronx, called his opponent the candidate of "profit-seeking, speculative landlords."

The assessment of the North German Lloyd and Hamburg American steamship companies of fines totaling $182,000 for alleged violation of the rules of the Atlantic Passenger Conference was reviewed yesterday afternoon at a meeting of the conference members, 80 Broad Street.

Three amateurs led the outboard motor-boat drivers in the season's scoring, with Lewis G. Carlisle of East Islip, L.I., winning the highscoring medal offered by George H. Townsend, president of the American Power Boat Association. Announcement to that effect was made yesterday by George W. Sutton Jr., chairman of the committee that tabulated the scores for 1933.

Predicting success for the Treasury's plan for the conversion of 30 per cent of the Fourth Liberty Loan 4 1/4 per cent bonds and heavy cash subscriptions for the 3 1/4 per cent bonds that are to be issued, banks and specialists in government securities in Wall Street reported yesterday that the response to the offer had been slow thus far.

CHICAGO, Oct. 13 -- Eastern speculators who recently were on the buying side of grains, especially wheat, started today to liquidate their holdings on the Board of Trade and found the markets poorly supported.

BERLIN, Oct. 13 -- After having waited at the United States Embassy since 11:30 o'clock this morning, Ambassador Dodd obtained a conference with Foreign Minister von Neurath at 8 o'clock this evening concerning the affidavits filed by Americans complaining of molestation by Germans.

AMHERST vs. Union -- "Once more unto the breach, dear friends, once more; or close the wall up with our English dead!" The firing is getting heavier each week. Peering cautiously over the parapet, one timorous vote for Amherst.

Four Czechoslovak Army officers and eight horses arrived aboard the S.S. President Roosevelt of the United States Lines yesterday to compete in the military jumping events at the golden jubilee of the National Horse Show in Madison Square Garden from Nov. 8 to 14.

The trustees of the Paramount Publix Corporation were authorized yesterday by Henry K. Davis, referee in bankruptcy for the corporation, at a hearing at 140 Nassau Street, to defer the proposed sale of an interest in the Pontlac Theatre Corporation of Detroit to George W. Trendle, a theatre manager there, and to employ him for ten months on salary with a share of the profits of the theatre.

CHICAGO, Oct. 13 -- John W. Fowler, chairman of the executive committee of the United States Gypsum Company, and eight others were named today in an indictment returned by the Federal grand jury which charged use of the mails to defraud.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 -- The Federal Trade Commission today made public a rule for newspaper and periodical advertisements under the Securities Act for the class of securities registered on the commission's registration form A-l. This form is the one which applies to the generality of securities.
Former Governor SMITH hit the nail on the head in his brief response on receiving an honorary degree from the University of the state of New York:
Negotiations were completed yesterday for the sale of a property in the lower Sixth Avenue section involving approximately $2,000,000.
Though there is in evidence a general tightening of competition throughout the football world, the East more or less leaves the chief fireworks today to other sections of the land.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Oct. 13 -- Nineteen yachts still in commission, with their owners and crews defiant of Autumnal winds and cold, set sail tonight in the New Rochelle Yacht Club's race around Stratford Shoal Lighthouse, out in the middle of Long Island Sound, east of Bridgeport.
Columbia and the University of Virginia will meet in their third annual football game today, starting at 2:30 P.M., at Baker Field. A crowd of 10,000 is expected to attend.

The Board of Elections yesterday unanimously decided to throw out the petition of the American party nominating Axel T. Fredlund for Mayor. By this action the number of parties entitled to places in the Mayoralty column on the voting machine or paper ballots, whichever are used at the November election, was cut to sixteen.

All the financial and commodity. markets adjusted themselves yesterday to the altered conditions arising from the announcement, over the Columbus Day holiday, of the government's bond conversion plan. The dollar advanced sharply, as did the bond market, but stocks and commodities broke widely.

While the United states is studying ways of negotiating reciprocal trade agreements with Latin-American countries, Great Britain offers a finished sample. Dispatches from Washington yesterday summarized the terms of a new treaty between that country and Argentina.

NEW YORK. Mrs. William A. Barstow and Mrs. Franklin Q. Barstow will give a large dinner tonight in the roof garden of the St. Regis for Miss Lois Barstow and John Bacon Aspegren, who will be married Oct. 24.

INDIANAPOLIS, Oct. 13 (AP) -- Secretary Perkins said in an address here tonight that American industrialists who developed mass production are now being asked to find a way under NRA codes of developing mass consumption to balance it.

CINCINNATI, Oct. 13 -- Railroads should look to freight for a large part of their trade recovery, the committee on motor vehicle transportation reported today to the National Association of Railroad and Utilities Commissioners, in convention here.
WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Oct. 12 -- The will of Henry A. Dix, who tried to give his fortune away during his lifetime and failed by something like $500,000, was filed for probate here today.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 -- The problem of enforcing Blue Eagle agreements rose in the NRA today, with Hugh S. Johnson, the administrator, frankly admitting he did not know whether or not such contracts were enforceable in court.

Thirteen store heads representing various sections of the country have accepted appointments as regional vice chairmen of the retailers' protective committee which will present retailers' views on manufacturers' codes, it was announced yesterday by Walter N. Rothschild, vice president of Abraham Straus and chairman of the committee.

GENEVA, Oct. 13 -- The German Cabinet has decided to make its attitude on disarmament contingent on what happens in the meeting of the conference's bureau, or steering committee, here tomorrow afternoon, according to word received by the United states and other delegations tonight.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 -- Conferences between the National Recovery Administration and the Agricultural Adjustment Administration on whether to retain or eliminate the "mark-up" system from the grocery and retail trade codes continued today, but officials have evidently not decided to make their positions clear to the public.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Undoubtedly Mr. Rockefeller's motives in trying to solve the liquor problem cannot be questioned for honesty or altruism. But there are angles which must be discussed before the recommendations of his commission are adopted.

EAST ORANGE, N.J., Oct. 13 -- In a sensational upset Mrs. Maurice Levin of Bloomfield and Mrs. Helen Levy of Jersey City won this afternoon the women's pairs event in the New Jersey State championship bridge tournament here.
An interstate ring that mailed contraband narcotics throughout the country, according to Federal authorities, was broken up yesterday with the arrest of Morris Tractenberg, an escaped convict.
The text of F. S. LaGuardia'a address last night over Radio Station WOR follows:

SHANGHAI, Oct. 13 -- General Chiang Kai-shek's projected large-scale drive against the Kiangsi Province Communists is nearly ready to start, but the long delays in enlisting the cooperation of Canton and the famous Nineteenth Route Army in Fukien Province have resulted in the escape of large numbers of Kiangsi Reds from the area which will be the aim of the drive.

BERLIN, Oct. 13 -- The events in the burning of the Reichstag building on the night of Feb. 27 were described before the German Supreme Court today both by the policemen who first reached the scene and by attendants of the building itself.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 -- A protest was registered with the Department of Justice today by the San Francisco Chamber of Commerce against establishment of the Federal prison on Alcatraz Island, in San Francisco Bay.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 -- The text of the address delivered today before the American Federation of Labor by William Green, its president, denouncing the treatment of trade unionists and Jews in Germany follows:

GREAT NECK, L.I., Oct. 13 -- With the veteran Mort Fearey of the Garden City Golf Club performing such, deeds as holing an approach, shot out of the rough, the partnership of Fearey and Dwight Rockwell defied the medalist jinx in the first round of the E.M. Byers Memorial Cup tournament at the Deepdale Golf Club today.
OKLAHOMA CITY, Oct. 13 (AP) -- With a sneer on his lips, George (Machine Gun) Kelly was started for Leavenworth Federal penitentiary today aboard a locked, barred and bulletproof railway coach.

SOFIA, Bulgaria, Oct. 13 -- Foreign Minister Nicolas Titulescu of Rumania left Sofia today for Angora, Turkey, after lunching with King Boris. He was accompanied as far as Philippopolis by Premier Mushanoff.

Mayor O'BRIEN'S comparison of himself to COLUMBUS, at least in the matter of tribulations and mutinies, should win him the sympathy of tender hearts. The Mayor spoke from his soul and without any thought, we may be sure, of winning "the Italian vote." Neither COLUMBUS nor any other seaman has faced such a sea of troubles.

VIENNA, Oct. 13 (AP) -- Austria's only monarchist party, KaisertreueVolkspartei, outlined its aims and demands in a press conference today. Rival monarchists, however, immediately challenged its right to speak for Archduke Otto, son of former Empress Zita and claimant to the throne, or for the monarchist movement.

One of the "biggest moving jobs of the Fall season was started late yesterday when the Westinghouse Electric and Manufacturing Company began to transfer office equipment and furnishings from seven floors in 150 Broadway to four floors in the RCA Building, Rockefeller Center.

Justice Frederic Kernochan, Fusion candidate for the Court of General Sessions, told yesterday of a grand juror's allegation to him that the September grand jury had been prevented from carrying on a further investigation of charges that racketeers have political protection.
The brownstone mansion of the late Chauncey M. Depew at 27 West Fifty-fourth Street, said to be worth $160,000, is to be turned into a rooming house.

MADRID, Oct. 13 -- An attempt to restrict the activities of American and other foreign correspondents in Europe by international sanctions, forcing them to send news "compatible with the interests" of the country in which they are stationed, will be made again at an international press conference meeting in Madrid on Nov. 7.

Entries from France, Italy and Spain assure the success of the international motor boat regattas to be held in Florida in March, it was learned yesterday from cables received by the American Power Boat Association from George H. Townsend, president of the organization.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 -- Because of a parliamentary manoeuvre an expected battle between adherents of craft unionism and those favor ing the industrial form of organization, failed to materialize at today's closing session of the American Federation of Labor convention.

Friday the thirteenth, which happened to be yesterday, started out as if it were bent on a new hard luck record. It underwent a change of heart a few hours later and set about doing enough good deeds to qualify itself for membership in the Boy Scouts.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 -- A loan of $300,000 by Dillon, Read Co. of New York to Harvey C. Couch, before he became a director of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, was disclosed today at the Senate stock market inquiry.

Joseph V. McKee, independent candidate for Mayor, accepted last night Supreme Court Justices Philip J. McCook, Charles B. McLaughlin, Samuel I. Rosenman and Edward R. Koch of the First Judicial District and Justice Peter P. Smith of the Second Judicial District as candidates of the Recovery party and entitled to the use of its "key" emblem.

Interpreting the announcement of the Treasury's offer for partial conversion of the Fourth 4 1/4 Liberty Loan as an official renunciation of currency inflation, the financial markets responded sharply yesterday by a rise of 3 cents in the dollar and an abrupt fall in speculative prices.
To the Editor Of The New York Times: In a letter to THE NEW YORK TIMES B.M. Josephson, referring to the commandeering of gold by the government, states:

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 13 (AP) -- Coal operators and high union leaders joined tonight in expressing the belief that a "request" by Governor Pinchot to idle Western Pennsylvania miners that they return to work will break up the three weeks' walkout of coal diggers demanding Union recognition.

The Rev. Dr. George U. Wenner, who will be 90 years old on May 17, will complete sixty-five years of service in the ministry this month. Celebration of the anniversary will be held tomorrow morning in the Christ Lutheran Church, 406 East Nineteenth Street, of which Dr. Wenner has been pastor since Oct. 8, 1868.

Tammany leaders have been visibly at their wits' end since the launching of the McKee candidacy. Its effect in cutting deep into Tammany voting strength has thrown all their calculations awry. As they have learned of one desertion after another they have looked at each other in wild amaze, like men asking: "If the foundations be removed, what shall the righteous do?"

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 -- With receipts of $831,999,000 and ordinary expenditures of $750,346,000 for the fiscal year to that date, the Treasury on Oct. 11 had a surplus of $95,587,000. The surplus was computed exclusive of emergency expenditures, but inclusive of a surplus of $13,934,000 in trust funds.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Your editorial suggestion that the way to sanity in the sugar industry lies in international cooperation is a sound enough theory. To make it good, however, would require a degree of self-restraint that our own sugar growers did not show when they evolved the curious sugar agreement just rejected by the administration.

Analogics From History In his speech before the American Chamber of Commerce in Berlin, Ambassador DODD studiously avoided any reference to current German politics. It would have been a glaring indiscretion for him, even though addressing Americans chiefly, to express any ideas about the Hitler dictatorship.
TOKYO, Saturday, Oct. 14 -- The War Minister, Lieut. Gen. Sadao Araki, took the opportunity in a train interview yesterday to damp down fears of a Russo-Japanese conflict.

Faced by litigation aimed at forcing the inclusion of $17,700,000 in pension appropriations in the 1934 budget. Mayor O'Brien called a conference yesterday which is to decide upon the matter at his office today.

The trial of Isidor J. Kresel continued yesterday in the criminal branch, of the Supreme Court with testimony of C. Stanley Mitchell, chairman of the board of the defunct Bank of United States, as a State witness. The defendant, who was counsel for the bank, is accused of having abetted in the misapplication or about $2,000,000 of its funds, lent to one of its eight affiliates.

An attempt by 4,000 left-wing unionists to besiege the NRA headquarters in the Hotel Pennsylvania resulted yesterday in the calling of more than 100 policemen for riot duty and the arrest of fifty-five persons.

PARIS, Oct. 13 -- As a result of recent revelations concerning German espionage in France, it is reported that the government of the Saar Basin territory is considering taking the matter before the League of Nations.

The "dope box," as used in France and England, will be installed at Hialeah Park in Miami for the meeting beginning next Jan. 25, it was announced yesterday by Joseph E. Widener. The box is a device in which horses are examined and tested to determine whether a horse has been stimulated.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 (AP) -- Under Presidential influence, a provision was written into the revised motion picture code late today by Sol A. Rosenblatt, NRA Deputy Administrator, calling for the assessment of fines up to $10,000 against producers found to have hired talent at "unreasonably" high salaries.

LAUREL, Md., Oct. 13 (AP) -- The Brookmeade Stable's Anarchy, an outsider in the field of four juveniles, lasted to receive a nose decision over M.L. Schwartz's Hindu Queen in the Manor Purse, feature of a rain-dulled program of racing today.

Joining with Samuel Seabury, chairman of the Fusion Campaign Committee, and a number of his running mates on the Fusion ticket, F.H. LaGuardia, standard-bearer in the anti-Tammany fight of the Fusion group, retorted warmly last night to Joseph V. McKee, his rival on the Recovery ticket.

Kenneth F. Sutherland, Democratic leader of Coney Island who is supporting the candidacy of Joseph V. McKee, was removed from his post as assistant to the Aldermanic President yesterday as Mayor O'Brian's reprisal campaign spread from the Bronx to Brooklyn.

Governor Lehman will issue today a call for a special session of the Legislature, to convene at noon next Wednesday, for consideration of bills to enact the comprehensive financing and unemployment relief plan recently formulated by the city and its bankers.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 -- Suggestions for reducing empty-car mileage were invited today by Joseph B. Eastman, Federal Coordinator of Transportation, from the regional coordinating committees of the carriers. He said that car pooling would be considered, but that the carriers' organizations might have a better remedy to suggest.

The only threat to world peace lies in such people as still have imperialistic desires for expansion and domination, President Roosevelt declared last night in an address closing the Women's Conference on Current Problems at the Waldorf-Astoria.

The Appellate Division of the Supreme Court reserved decision yesterday on the appeal by the Tammany Hall law committee from the ruling by Justice Cotillo holding that the nominating certificates for five Republican candidates for the Supreme Court should be accepted by the Board of Elections although they were mistakenly filed a day late.

CHICAGO, Oct. 13 -- United Air Line officials announced tonight that evidence had been uncovered disclosing that a bomb explosion wrecked the transcontinental air liner in which seven persons fell to their deaths near Chesterton, Ind., on Tuesday night.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 -- Miners who have been demanding the check-off in "captive" coal mines must return to work or bear the responsibility of retarding the recovery drive, General Johnson declared today.

Phrases from the poems of Edna St. Vincent Millay seem second only to those from Shakespeare in their popularity as new book titles. The latest title taken from lines by Miss Millay is "Whistle For Me," which is on a new novel by Michael Jackson just published by Morrow.

CHICAGO, Oct. 13 -- The impressive annual convocation ceremonies of the American College of Surgeons, in which four honorary fellowships and 622 ordinary fellowships were conferred, took place here tonight in the presence of a distinguished gathering of physicians and surgeons.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Oct. 13 (AP) -- Lauding the publishers of town and suburban weekly newspapers for their support of the NRA, Postmaster General Farley described the progress of President Roosevelt's recovery program at a dinner of the New York Press Association tonight.

Strength in United States Government bonds, caused by the conversion offer on the Fourth Liberty 4 1/4 s, and further recoveries in domestic corporation bonds contrasted yesterday with weakness in the foreign group in the bond market on the Stock Exchange.

Mrs. Ida J. Hutchison, who for twenty years has been resident director of the Abbott E. Kittredge Club for Girls, was the guest of honor last evening at a gathering of the club's members, directors and friends at the clubhouse, 440 East Fifty-seventh Street.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 13 (AP) -- Robert Farquhar, 28, second-year student at the Tale Medical School, was taken from his home today and pronounced dead upon arrival at the New Haven Hospital.

ALBANY, Oct. 13 -- An assertion that the overcoming of illiteracy was not the sole function of the school was made today by Dr. Herbert S. Weet, superintendent of schools at Rochester, as an honorary degree of Doctor of Letters was conferred on him at the closing session of the annual convocation of the University of the State of New York.

William Howard Good, wellknown Brooklyn lawyer, died of a heart attack in his automobile yesterday morning as his chauffeur was driving him from the Brooklyn Supreme Court to his law offices at 44 Court Street. He had been suffering from heart disease for six months.

Any plan for control of alcohol after repeal must take into consideration the popularity that cocktails have attained in the United States, the report of the post-prohibition study sponsored by John D. Rockefeller Jr. declared in a further instalment made public yesterday.

Marshall Field Co., Inc., report for the quarter ended on Sept. 30 a consolidated net income of $955,000 after all charges, equal after preferred dividend requirements to 31 cents a share on 1,399,987 common shares. Net sales were $24,745,600 in value, or 51 per cent above the third quarter of last year.

Charles A. Pearce, a member of the editorial staff of Harcourt, Brace Co., called attention yesterday to marked similarities between passages in a series of articles on Russia, now being written by former Governor Henry J. Alien of Kansas, and parts of a book entitled "Red Virtue," by Eila Winter, wife of Lincoln Steffens.

BOTH before and since the death of Giacomo Puccini several biographies of him had been written. Now, ten years after his death, Richard Specht, a German with experience and competence in the writing of the lives of musicians, puts forth this book of mingled biography and criticism.

APPARENTLY the present situation in financial affairs affects the management of musical affairs in a way which is not to any one's advantage. New policies and short-sighted ones are consequent upon alarms in financial circles and the fact that many people who were formerly very wealthy are now in no circumstances to subsidize important musical undertakings, as they were in the past.

HELSINGFORS, Oct. 14. -- A large-scale war on Baltic liquor smugling was under way today as a result of the convention signed yesterday by Britain permitting Finland, with certain restrictions, to search or seize British rum-runners.

Secondary tariffs" in the form of special levies upon imported merchandise furnish almost as great a problem as regular tariffs, according to exporters, who are now asking the National Federation of Foreign Trade Associations to petition the State Department to seek adjustment of such assessments when negotiating reciprocal trade treaties with foreign nations.

ROME, Oct. 13. -- A decree which is expected to be promulgated soon for the protection of the Italian film industry will place a heavy burden on American producers, who hitherto have supplied 60 per cent of imported pictures doing about 90 per cent of the business in foreign films shown in Italy.

JUST now, when there is talk everywhere of the imminence of another war, nothing could be timelier than a book that reminds us once more what war is like and paints it in the vivid colors in which a trained observer saw it. It will surely be a wholesome thing for many people, lest they forget, to read these profoundly moving reminiscences of one of the most famous of the World War correspondents.

VILLANOVA, Pa., Oct. 14. -- Leonard Kachel of Newark, N.J., substitute tackle, played the role of hero in Bucknell's 19-17 victory over Villanova today. Entering the game in the closing minutes, he blocked Higgins's punt and recovered the ball in the end zone for the touchdown that defeated Villanova before a homecoming crowd of 10,000.

A NINE-WEEK trip through twenty-two States, sounding out as many people as possible for their reactions to the New Deal, leaves this impression: The general belief is that there is nothing fundamentally wrong with our present system.

IN his sixtieth year Guglielmo Marconi's enthusiasm for wireless is as great as it was in his youth. Peering into the future, be foresees new ethereal miracles; today, as tben, he dreams of a world run by wireless. He returned recently to this country -- his eighty-seventh Atlantic crossing -- "to have Americans put me wise, as they say, on what is going on over here."

BERLIN, Oct. 14. -- Dr. Paul Joseph Goebbels, German Minister of Public Enlightenment and Propaganda, read to assembled newspaper men in Berlin today an appeal made by Chancellor Hitler. The text follows:

THE Moscow Opera, known as the Bolshoi, opened the new season recently with a performance of Tchaikovsky's "Pique Dame." The first ballet presented was Gliere's "Red Poppy," which has been one of the most successful works in the repertoire of the theatre during the past few years.
