A careless turn by Charles Scheim of De Witt Clinton cost his team victory over the swimmers of Evander Childs, Manhattan-BronxRichmond champions, at the opening of the Public Schools Athletic League's annual series of dual meets for senior high schools of the three boroughs in the seventyfive-foot pool of George Washington High yesterday.

ATLANTIC CITY, Oct. 14. -- Joseph B. Keenan, special Assistant United States Attorney General, who headed the investigation that resulted in sending George (Machine Gun) Kelly and his partners in the Urschel kidnapping to jail, received threats against his life while here attending the sixty-third annual congress of the American Prison Association.

AS part of the widespread program to balance agricultural production and consumption, the Federal Government has set in motion machinery for buying at market premiums 4,000,000 pigs under 100 pounds and 1,000,000 sows soon to farrow.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The newspapers reported a few days ago that the Secretary of State was endeavoring to formulate a basis for a working agreement with the Soviet leaders. The reasons that guided Presidents Wilson, Harding, Coolidge and Hoover in refusing to enter into friendly relations with Russia may not apply today, according to this same report.

THE solution of the traffic problem, with accompanying reduction of accidents, depends upon intelligent regulations that will win public support and effective enforcement of them, according to the opinion expressed in a report prepared for the International Association of Chiefs of Police.

To the Editor of The New York Times: My letter in THE TIMES of Sept. 24 seems to have met the disapproval of certain readers who have taken me to task for expressing a historic fact concerning the suffix "ster" as indicating a grammatical feminine gender of the Old English period.

ONE of the prime requisites in the present recovery program is the expansion of credit -- not only bank or commercial credit, which is of prime importance, but long-term credit. The proceeds of long-term credit go into capital goods, in contrast to bank or commercial credit, the primary function of which is to finance self-liquidating projects.

LONDON, Oct. 13. -- This week's delays and uncertainties at Geneva have served to give more than academic interest to the question of what Great Britain would do in the event of a war crisis in Europe. Cocksureness in either direction appears unjustified.

THERE is a new axiom in radio -- "Vacuum tubes must fit the wave length on which they operate." This means if waves are tiny the tubes must be midgets. Engineers experimenting with micro-waves have developed a tube scarcely one-tenth the size of ordinary detectors and amplifiers; in fact, because of its size and shape they call it the "acorn" tube.

Executive officials of investment trusts were upset somewhat last week by the Senate committee's inquiry in Washington into the operations of Dillon, Read Co., especially as it reacted to trusts. They felt that little had been brought out that had not been written previously and that most of the practices that again were called to public attention as evil had been remedied long since.
DANVILLE, Va., Oct. 12 -- Virginia and Carolina tobacco growers are becoming restive over the delay in providing them with an outlet for their staple crop.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 14. -- Retail food prices again moved upward during the two weeks ending Sept. 26, after a slight drop during the two preceding, weeks, according to reports to the Bureau of Labor Statistics from retail dealers in fiftyone cities announced today.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 14. -- The national revolution in Germany is usually dated from Jan. 30, 1933, when Adolf Hitler was appointed Chancellor by President von Hindenburg.

REPORTS coming in to the United States Biological Survey from many regions in the Northern Hemisphere indicate that disease is ravaging the eel grass and causing its disappearance. The loss of this plant, used as food by wild geese and ducks and fish, is having serious effects on industries such as clamming, fishing and hunting, and a number of coastal areas are undergoing considerable alteration in topography.

GREENWICH, Conn., Oct. 14. -- The Greenwich Travel Club celebrated it thirtieth anniversary at the annual luncheon of the club, held in the Pickwick Arms yesterday. It was also past president's day. Mrs. Mills H. Husted, president, was toastmistress.

ROME, Oct. 14. -- Germany's sudden and decisive withdrawal from the disarmament conference and from the League of Nations came as a complete surprise to Italy, which was totally unprepared for such drastic action. The move is regarded here as an international calamity.

THE 1933 budget-completing campaign of the Federation for the Support of Jewish Philanthropic Societies of New York City will be set in motion at a dinner gathering of more than 1,000 persons at the Hotel Commodore tonight.

Tammany now sees a definite "swing to O'Brien" as having begun and predictions are being made that a drift back to the fold on the part of deserters will restore the organization strength to a marked degree by election day.

WASHINGTON. As the economic wave turns upward again after its long recession, with the hesitancy of a tide which advances and retreats and advances again as it strikes the dry sand, a simultaneous wave of labor troubles sweeps over the country.

SWARTHMORE, Pa., Oct. 14. -- Swarthmore College will offer, under the auspices of the William J. Cooper Foundation, a series of public lectures on the recovery program designed to present "the various phases of the economies of the New Deal."

THIS week statesmen from the important countries will gather at Geneva to make a further effort at disarmament. A continuation of the conference which opened in February, 1932, the meeting will be much more than a disarmament gathering.
HOLLYWOOD. NANA," which Samuel Goldwyn is making with Anna Sten, got away to a fresh start this week under the direction of Dorothy Arzner, with a revised story and several cast changes.

The break of 1 cent to 8 cents a pound in the domestic price of copper last week was attributed directly to the increase of approximately 20,000 tons since February in stocks held by custom smelters. Indirectly, it was said, it was caused by the refusal of producers with fabricating plants to share any of their outlets with custom smelters.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 14. -- The Federal Home Loan Bank System, created to perform much the same function in home mortgage finance as the Federal Reserve System has fulfilled in the national commercial banking structure, has made great progress in its first full year of operation, a survey by William F. Stevenson, chairman of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board, shows.

When Hitler, a novus homo in politics, first published "My Battle," to 1925, he attacked in it not merely Jews but capitalism, churches of all creeds, modern urban culture in almost every manifestation, democratic and international ideals and institutions, France, America and Freemasonry; he condemned the Kaiser for halfhearted military preparations and called for a new glorification of the army as a step to ultimate imperialistic expansion.
PROVIDENCE, R.I., Oct. 14. -- Brown defeated the Springfield College eleven, 13 to 6, today in a gruelling game.

LAUREL, Md., Oct. 14 (AP). -- Dark Secret, 4-year-old son of the Derby winning Flying Ebony, carried the purple and yellow silks of the Wheatley Stable to an easy victory today in the twentieth running of the $2,500 added Laurel Stakes at one mile over a heavy track.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In view of the importance of the Seventh International Conference of American States, commonly known as the Seventh Pan-American Conference, which will be held at Montevideo, the capital of Uruguay, in December, it is to be hoped that a few comments on that great gathering may be appropriate at this time.

ROMAIN ROLLAND is one of the great modern oracles of moral order, a lawgiver, a Moses self-exiled to a garden on a Swiss mountainside, whence he looks broodingly westward over France, the land he loves and hates.

Lady Erin, a fine bay mare owned by R.B. Pond, took the Jumpers' championship in the Clove Lake Fall horse show on Staten Island yesterday. The Pond entry gained the title after a hard struggle against a strong field and only after the most exacting competition.

Manhattan and Georgetown played to a 20-20 tie in a spectacular, see saw struggle at Ebbets Field yesterday. The Jaspers and the Hoyas kept the crowd of 18,000 in a constant frenzy as first one let and then the other and as finally they emerged in a well-deserved deadlock.

While no startling gains in retail trade developed during the initial week of the NRA "Buy Now" drive, a fair measure of improvement both here and in other cities was credited to the movement by retail executives. The consensus was that the campaign has yet to hit its stride.

Charles Solomon, Socialist candidate for Mayor, declared himself yesterday as "utterly opposed" to repeal of mandatory salary legislation and urged a five-day week and six-hour day in all city department. He called the move for repeal of mandatory salary legislation a disguised attack on salaries and living standards of civil service employes.

Commodities moved generally lower in yesterday's trading on local exchanges. For the most part, however, final losses were smaller than at the outset, as the markets tended to steady near the close. Trading was in good value. Cash prices were irregularly lower.

THE principal role in "The Private Life of Henry VIII," at the Radio City Music Hall, is occupied by that same Charles Laughton whose somewhat clinical portraits of Nero and other eccentric gentlemen have already won him his spurs in the American cinema.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 14. -- A legend that the printing of a pack of playing cards inspired Gutenberg to print the Bible was told by Mrs. Samuel H. Fisher of Litchfield, Conn., as she opened an exhibition of modern and ancient cards in the Sterling Memorial Museum at Yale University.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., Oct. 14. -- The recovery plan of the national government has its parallel in the colleges of today, Professor Albert E. Meder, acting dean of New Jersey College for Women, told 1,500 alumnae and students here today.

BERLIN, Oct. 14. -- Germany announced her withdrawal today from the League of Nations and the World Disarmament Conference because, in the words of Chancellor Hitler, she refused to be a nation "of second-class rights," and wants "equality and honor."

Dr. Sherwood Eddy, author, traveler and lecturer, returned yesterday aboard the Statendam of the Holland-America Line from a three-month tour through Russia, Germany, Poland, Austria, England and France. He said:

GENEVA, Oct. 14 (AP). -- Germany's bolt from the League of Nations, to which it was elected only after long deliberations by the other powers, leaves the League officially supported by only three of the great powers. Great Britain, France and Italy.

LA PAZ, Oct. 13. -- Bolivia's resources are adequate to carry her through another year of the Chaco conflict without taxing the resources of the people or running the risks of inflation, according to General Hans Kundt, German commander of the Bolivian army.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 14. -- In winding up one of its busiest weeks since it began operations ninetynine days ago, the Public Works Administration allocated $28,384,527 today for Federal and private projects.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 14. -- The ex- ecutive council of the American Federation of Labor today consid- ered the strike situation, particularly as it involved compliance with provisions of the many NRA codes, according to William Green, federation president, who declared that "we join wholeheartedly with the desire to avoid stoppages of work."

Silver objects from the noted Robert Hoe collection will be included in an auction sale of furniture and decorations from the collections formed by the late William Stursberg of this city, the late Mrs. Herbert Coppell of Tenafly, N.J., and H.L. Slade, also of New York, grandson of Robert Hoe, which will be sold on Friday and Saturday at the American Art Association Anderson Galleries.

The annual Fall list of honor students at the Stevens Institute of Technology in Hoboken was announced yesterday by Dean Franklin de R. Furman. A place on the dean's list ordinarily exempts students from penalties for failure to observe the usual academic routine, particularly attendance at classes.

HAVANA, Oct. 14. -- While rumors that dissension exists in the ranks of his army and navy flew thick and fast, Colonel Fulgencio Batista, erstwhile top sergeant, set out in earnest today to disarm the civilian groups heretofore working hand in hand with his soldiers.

RICHMOND, Oct. 12. -- The pathetic plight of public schools of Virginia and North Carolina and their teachers has been brought forcibly to the attention of the public of late, and the authorities of both States are Wondering what, if anything, can be done about it.

IT is already evident that, despite many other important phases of the disarmament question, a principal subject of debate at the Disarmament Conference opening at Geneva this week will be aviation; military aviation in the strict sense, and the control of civil aviation on the theory that it is readily convertible to military uses.

A letter left by a man who killed his wife and committed suicide pursuant to a joint plan was not ef- fective to dispose of money and se- curities under a ruling filed in the Supreme-Court yesterday by Jus- tice Julius Miller. The decision was based on a letter written by Henry Fehrmann, who entered into the death compact with his wife, Barbara E. Fehrmann.

The Hill School football squad of Pottstown, Pa., will visit Brooklyn on Friday to meet Poly Prep at Ebbets Field in one of the outstanding prep school gridiron contests listed for this Fall in New York City. Local fans are eagerly awaiting the arrival of the Hill team, for one of the best games of the campaign is anticipated.

IMPORTANT as New York City is to actor and manager as producing centre for plays in America, its shadow must not be allowed to reduce to invisibility the vast remainder of the country with its millions of persons who are again showing eagerness to enjoy stage drama when they can get it in decent quality.

SOMETIMES it seems to happen in the pages of this provocative and lively book that the cart and the horse get a bit entangled. Sometimes one wonders if the author, in his zeal for a better quality of literacy, does not forget that heaven in its wisdom has deplorably skimped both the quantity and quality of intelligence dealt out to the human race.

The rearmament plans of Nazi Germany have produced the crisis here predicted last week. Germany has quit the League of Nations and the World Arms Conference and Europe faces an international situation of a grave nature.

DETROIT. SHOULD automobile retailing prove difficult to regulate under the new NRA code, the business will face one alternative -- Federal licensing. Under such circumstances dealers shown to have violated the code of fair competition would be deprived of licenses and thereby forced out of business.

DELOS CHAPPELL, the Central City impresario, is going in for the celestial -- he has just picked up "The Heavenly Express." This one is by the Albert Bein, who wrote last Spring's "Little OI' Boy" and with it caused considerable discussion.

The Public Service Commission's hearings on temporary emergency reductions in gas rates were completed yesterday when final testimony was presented before Commissioner George B. Van Namee. Witnesses for the gas companies of the Consolidated Gas system attempted to sustain claims of increased expenses under the NRA, and city representatives countered with figures purported to show an increase in gas business under the NRA.
PRINCETON, Oct. 14. -- Professor Albert Einstein is expected to begin his work with the Institute of Advanced Study in Princeton the latter part of next week.
PARIS, Oct. 14 (AP). -- France feels safe, in might and right, in the face of German withdrawals from the disarmament conference and the League of Nations, according to a Foreign Office statement.

ALBANY, Oct. 14. -- Indications today were that the extraordinary session of the Legislature summoned by Governor Lehman for next Wednesday would develop into a battle similar to that which caused a deadlock at the session Which lasted through August.
ATLANTA, Ga., Oct. 14. -- Georgia Tech subdued Auburn Polytechnic Institute before 20,000 football fans today, 16 to 6.

WASHINGTON. PRESIDENT ROOSEVELT'S mail is the heaviest ever received by a Chief Executive of the United States. Mr. Roosevelt's popularity and the state of the nation combine to bring a letter flood unprecedented in White House history.

Honor to the Italian Minister of Fine Arts! The villa on the Sabine farm which he has officially certified as HORACE'S contains, we are told, twelve rooms and "numerous bathrooms." Whatever archaeologists and eminent classical scholars may think, simple Horatians will accept gladly the Minister's Judgment.

PROBABLY the strangest libra- ries in the world are the col- lections of sound tracks in mo- tion-picture studios. Every major studio has one, but not all are as extensive as that of Columbia Pictures, which claims a total of 8,000,000 feet of sound.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 14. -- The American Government considers prices not yet high enough to warrant stabilization of the dollar, it was learned tonight on high authority.

IT is a Winter with plenty of highlights in fashion. Many of them have already been dealt with in this column and many are waiting to be revealed. This is to be a glitter season. Fascinating, shining jet will glitter in the social arena.

Many pastors will refer in their sermons today to the Mayoralty campaign. Eulogies will be given of William R. Moody, son of the famous evangelist, Dwight L. Moody who died Thursday in East Northfield, Mass. In Reformed churches there will be observed the one hundred and sixtieth anniversary of the denomination's pension fund for ministers.

GLENVILLE, Conn., Oct. 14. -- Findale, stately chestnut gelding owned by Paul Plunkett of Port Chester, N.Y., captured the premier honors in the opening jumping sweepstakes, one of the feature events of the anual Fall horse show held at the Byram Beagle Club today.

CHICAGO, Oct. 14. -- More than 2,000 librarians from various parts of America and fourteen foreign countries were assembled here today at the opening of the first session of the International Federation of Library Associations to be held in the United States.

LOOKING back on any life, always one discovers certain crises dominated by special experiences which seem to outline its course. Sometimes the course seems fairly straight; sometimes it runs zigzag; often it moves to cross-purposes.

LONDON. IN writing of my father at the present time, now sixty-three years after his death, I am faced with the difficulty that almost everything that I can have to say must have been known already at some time or other to the reading public.

The plan of the United States Treasury to convert the Fourth Liberty Loan 4 1/4 per cent bonds, announced last week, affords the government an excellent means of obtaining a popular referendum on inflation. The refunding offer actually means nothing less than an appeal to the citizens.
NEW ORLEANS, Oct. 14. -- Tulane came back after an epidemic of fumbles to win, 20 to 0, from Maryland in a ragged football game today.

WILMINGTON, Del., Oct. 14. -- Two "air circus" stunt planes crashed together 2,700 feet above the heart of Wilmington this afternoon and started dropping while several thousand horror-struck spectators looked on.
MEMPHIS. Tenn., Oct. 14. -- "The greatest thrill I ever experienced off the playing field."
CHICAGO, Oct. 12 -- Two pulpits will be established in St. Paul's Reformed Episcopal Church, Adams and Winchester Streets, Chicago.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 (AP). -- With his desk cleared of all major work for the week-end, President Roosevelt bundled into a heavy topcoat today and drove in an open car over the roads of Western Maryland for a few hours of recreation.

THE University of the State of New York is the official incorporation of the State's highest purpose, the embodiment of the noblest aspiration of a democracy, the evidence of an urge which is life's "mightiest mystery" -- an institution in which, to use a phrase of the late Laureate of England, "the unseen takes shape to common eyes."
SYRACUSE, N.Y., Oct. 14. -- The powerful Syracuse University eleven routed Ohio Wesleyan by a 40-to-0 score before 16,000 spectators in Archbold Stadium today.

The Rev. Dr. George W. Woodall, retired Methodist Episcopal clergyman and missionary and a former resident of New York City, died suddenly of a heart attack Wednesday at his home in Moriah, N.Y. His age was 77. Dr. Woodall had been a minister for forty-six years, most of the time up-State.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 14. -- The United States Government places squarely upon Germany the blame for slowing down and impeding the movement toward general disarmament, Secretary of State Hull indicated today. He said this government was greatly disappointed and very seriously regretted Germany's move in withdrawing from the disarmament conference.

SHANGHAI, Sept. 16. -- Great has been the stir caused in diplomatic and Chinese Government circles by publication here in an American-owned magazine of an article in which an American charges that the rich province of Yunnan will probably soon be filched from China by France, just as Manchuria was taken by Japan.

FROM "Night Flight," a novel written by Antoine de SaintExupery, a French air mail pilot, Clarence Brown has wrought a forceful and fast-paced pictorial drama that is easily the outstanding screen contribution on aviation.

MENDHAM, N.J., Oct. 14. -- The Schiff Scout Reservation, gift of the late Mrs. Jacob H. Schiff, mother of Mortimer L. Schiff, to the Boy Scouts of America and the youth of the country as a memorial to her son, will be dedicated here Wednesday afternoon at 2:30 o'clock.
AMES, Iowa, Oct. 14. -- A smooth working Nebraska football machine, which never fully opened up, trounced Iowa State today 20 to 0.

EMIL LUDWIG, by this time, is safely enrolled among the writers at the Warner Brothers' studios and, unless the silence is ominous, is busily at work as consultant and technical adviser on "Napoleon: His Life and Loves." When he passed through New York several weeks ago, the biographer was somewhat worried about this Hollywood business.

At a conference yesterday of the executives of Arnold Constable Co., Fifth Avenue and Fortieth Street, which is celebrating its 106th anniversary this year, Isaac Liberman, its president, reviewed the progress the store has made since it was founded.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 14. -- Charges that a score of sane Indians are confined to an asylum at Canton, S. D., "as the result of the greed and selfish inhumanity of certain interests there" and that conditions under which they are virtually imprisoned are "sickening and intolerable" have been filed with Secretary Ickes by Dr. Samuel A. Silk, medical director of St. Elizabeth's Hospital here.
LOS ANGELES, Oct. 14. -- An irresistible impulse of a St. Mary's football player for conversation with his fellows may have coat his team a tie with Southern California today.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Oct. 12. -- In Essex County, in the heart of tha Adirondack forest preserve, a silvery ribbon of new macadam winding up the granite side of Whiteface Mountain is the realization of the dream of an Adirondack pioneer, 89-year-old Marcellus A. Leonard, retired North Country merchant, now living in Saranac Lake.

SOFIA, Oct. 14 (AP). -- Four Bulgarians were killed today and many injured in the Dobruja district of Rumania (formerly Bulgarian territory) while Nicholas Titulescu, Rumanian Foreign Minister, was in this city, making preparations for a forthcoming conference between King Carol of Rumania and King Boris of Bulgaria.

Policemen and Motorists. SOME of the recommendations in the Halsey traffic report, summarized on this page today, could be adopted in any city tomorrow. The report proposes a comprehensive system of vehicular control that requires time for legislation and organization before it can go into effect as a whole, but a police department general order would immediately put a number of its provisions to work.
ST. LOUIS, Oct. 14 (AP). -- Showing a much stronger combination than Illinois displayed a week ago, the Chicago University Maroons trounced the Washington University Bears today, 40 to 0.

Cowboys who leap without trepidation to the backs of wild Brahma steers were embarrassed yesterday morning when more than 300 energetic New York City children stampeded into the Madison Square Garden arena, swarmed around them, snatched at their saddlegirths and even plucked tentatively at the horses tails.

SCARSDAL.E, N.Y., Oct. 14. -- The committee of one hundred of the Scarsdale Woman's Club will sponsor a dance and fashion show on Wednesday evening at the Scarsdale Golf Club. The proceeds will be devoted to the following institutions in Westchester: The Children's Village, Eastview County Home, Westfield State Farm for Women, Grasslands Hospital, Jennie Clarkson Home and Rosary Hill Cancer Home.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 14. -- The willingness of the mill owners on the Buffalo waterfront to deal directly with their striking employes in working out a wage and hour agreement satisfactory to all parties was cited today by Senator Wagner of New York, chairman of the National Labor Board, as "an example of an attitude of mind among employers of the greatest service to national recovery."

GENEVA, Oct. 14. -- Germany's decision, to withdraw from both the League of Nations and the disarmament conference left the delegations here, including many of the Germans, incredulous at first and then dumfounded.

AFTER two months of the stupidest sort of flim-flam the theatre district of New York has become a remarkably stimulating neighborhood. From famine we have been giddily whisked to a harvest feast. Although the prospect looked attractive on paper in the middle of September, no one could foresee the swift transmutation in spirit that has occurred during the past four weeks.

EACH year at approximately the same date Lady Verity Destrier receives a letter in which she and two men are threatened with death because of a monstrous crime which the writer accuses them of having committed during the World War.

IF Mr. Courtney Burr, seeking an outlet for his ecstasy, seems to be doing impromptu Highland flings these days without benefit of kilts or the skirl of the pipes, let it be said for him that the provocation is great, even as it has been long delayed.
Curtis High School's undefeated football team vanquished Hempstead High, 32 to 0, yesterday before 4,000 persons at Thompson's Stadium, Staten Island. The victors scored in every period.

CHICAGO, Oct. 14. -- Ernest J. Stevens, receivership manager of the Stevens Hotel and former vice president of the Illinois Life Insurance Company, was found guilty of embezzlement tonight by a jury. He faces a mandatory sentence of one to ten years in prison.

Democratic leaders who have swung away from Tammany Hall to back Joseph V. McKee for Mayor have been closely allied in the past with regular organization policies and tactics, an analysis of their records disclosed yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 14. -- The text of the statement made today by Norman H. Davis, chairman of the United States delegation to the General Disarmament Conference at Geneva, at a meeting of the bureau of the conference was given out by the State Department as follows:

SHANGHAI, Sept. 27. -- Safely back in his walled temple on a sacred mountain in Shantung Province, Marshal Feng Yu-hsiang, erstwhile "Christian General," can view with some complacency the record he made during this last year when he was in open rebellion against the government at Nanking.

ON his return from his annual visit to Europe, B.W. Huebsch of the Viking Press announced general important plans for the coming year. Stefan Zweig, whose "Marie Antoinette" is still a best seller, is to be the official representative of the Viking Press for Europe.

BERLIN, Oct. 14. -- Following the call made by Ambassador Dodd last night upon Foreign Minister von Neurath, at which the two discussed the state of public feeling aroused in the United States by the failure to inflict punishment upon any Nazis guilty of assault upon Americans for not giving the Hitler salute, two interesting announcements are made by a Berlin news agency tonight.

WHILE investigating an area in Panama last year where cattle had been killed by snakes, I saw signs of the work of vampire bats among the herds. Wounds in the hides of the animals and "ropes" of dried blood descending there-from constituted the evidence.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 (AP). -- Cotton consumed during September was reported today by the Census Bureau to have totaled 499,486 bales of lint and 76,451 bales of linters, compared with 588,570 bales of lint and 83,271 of linters in August this year, and 492,742 and 65,487 in September last year.
PARIS, Oct. 12. -- Paquin's long capes composed entirely of fox used in vertical bands are the season's most sumptuous late-afternoon and evening wraps.

CORNELIUS VANDERBILT might have felt right at home on a stage of the Fox studios while "Berkeley Square" was being filmed, for he would have found the rug out of his former Fifth Avenue home on the floor of one of the sets.

DENVER, Col., Oct. 8. -- Farmers of Colorado and New Mexico are severely critical of the Federal Farm Loan Board in general and the Federal Land Bank at Wichita, Kan., in particular. A new land bank is demanded, devoted exclusively to the Mountain States and located, presumably, at Denver.

BERLIN, Oct. 14. -- George S. Messersmith, American Consul General, was notified when it was reported the lawyers expelled from the Reichstag fire trust had been taken to the Police Presidency "for questioning." He hurried there, but was told Mr. Gallagher was held at the Reichstag building, where the trial was in session.

MILAN. IT is not often that a statesman -- such a statesman as Benito Mussolini -- "unlocks his heart." The less statesman he? Oh, but so much more human than the popular conception of him! What most surprises us in his "Vita di Arnaldo" (Milan: Popolo d'Italia) is the simplicity and the warm human tone, and often the plaintive human bitterness, of these pages written in commemoration of his only brother.

LONDON, Oct. 14. -- Without panic, but without any attempt to hide the seriousness of the situation, the British people and government tonight were weighing the consequences of Germany's withdrawal from Geneva.

TOWARD the close of the week cooler weather turned trade upward. Columbus Day trade here was fairly good, but the temperature was too high to bring about substantial sales of heavier apparel. Small home wares buying is still active, though heavier purchases have dropped.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The St. Lawrence Seaway project is not for the creation of a new transportation route, but to increase the usefulness of an important existing water route, that has served the people of two nations for more than 100 years, by the "replacement of obsolete equipment" and the standardizing of depths and capacity to meet present-day needs.

"Were it not for reservations and animal parks," declares E.G. BOULENGER, Director of the British Zoological Society, "the Age of Mammals would be hurrying to its close." In Africa the "sportsman" has already exterminated the quagga. Just in time the white rhinoceros has been saved.

LONDON. KING GEORGE'S head gamekeeper at Windsor, the late Edward Dadley, died recently, leaving an estate valued at $8,395. That sum seems a trifle when contrasted with the fortune left by the late head gamekeeper to the Duke of Buccleuch, which amounted to $213,605.

BONFIRE," which is certainly one of the most ambitious and interesting novels Dorothy Canfield has yet given us, stands in striking contrast to her previous work, both in scope and subject-matter, and in its underlying attitudes.

Horace Havemeyer's twelve-meter yacht Mouette, winner of the class championship during the past season's racing on Long Island Sound, is credited with a percentage of .756 in the standings announced yesterday.

The Savings Banks Association of the State of New York will open tomorrow its annual two-day convention, meeting in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel. The principal business will be consideration of the attitude savings banks should take toward the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, created under the Banking Act of 1933 and to start operations with the new year.

Many Southerners in New York are expected to attend the annual dinner and ball of the New York Southern Society, which will be given in conjunction with members of the Alumni Society of the University of Alabama, on the night of Oct. 27 in the grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria, The ball will follow the football game between the University of Alabama and Fordham University, which will be held here in the afternoon.

More than 1,000 Barnard College students, alumnae, trustees of the college and friends are expected to attend the formal opening of the new Barnard camp, to be held today on the camp site. Dean Virginia C. Gildersleeve will preside at the ceremony.

KENT, Conn., Oct. 14. -- Hotchkiss School's eleven, showing deception and power, routed Kent in their annual engagement today on Alumni Field. A large student crowd from both institutions saw the Lakeville invaders triumph, 26 -- 0, for their second consecutive victory over a stalwart Kent team.

DUNKIRK, already second only to Marseilles among the seaports of France in volume of traffic, is entering upon a new phase of development, looking to a considerable expansion of its water commerce -- another step in its long and checkered history.

A LARGE, broad-shouldered man in a mixed gray suit and a flock of curly hair to match was seated in one of the lower rooms at Madison Square Garden. Leaning against the opposite wall was a fellow whose face seemed familiar, but it was hard to place him. He was a big fellow, too. Dark suit, dark hair, square jaw, and a light gray felt hat. Was he a fighter, a wrestler or --?
In preparation for the Northeast tournament next month, the women's New York Field Hockey Association will soon begin the task of selecting two teams to represent this area.

Sales of the first twenty chainstore systems reporting for September, or that approximate period, were 5.7 per cent ahead of September, 1932, according to a compilation, made by Lehman Brothers. That percentage of gain, it is stated, incidentally is identical with the gain shown in August over the corresponding month of 1932.
Columbia came back from the brink of defeat at Baker Field yesterday to conquer the University of Virginia eleven, 15 -- 6, before 10,000 surprised spectators.

THE TIDE," is a newspaper novel in something the same way as "The Front Page" and "Gentlemen of the Press" were newspaper plays. It is witty, sometimes hilarious, engaging, realistic in its descriptive passages, somewhat shyly thoughtful and quite modest in its more serious aspects.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 12.-- In addition to the force of appeals of President Roosevelt and NRA officials to workers on strike to return to their jobs, leaving it to the National Labor Board and other mediating agencies to settle the differences, another phase of the back-to-work movement is developing in a number of districts of the Pittsburgh area.

TROY, Oct. 14. -- St. Lawrence University defeated Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute by a single touchdown in the last three minutes of play today, 6 to 0. Held on the 3-yard line, Brown, who featured in several brilliant end runs, dropped back and tossed a 30-yard pass to Blackford in the end zone for the score.
AT its annual conference, the British Labor party was unanimous in an outspoken declaration to boycott war.
CARLISLE, Pa. DICKINSON COLLEGE, the twelfth, oldest college in the United States and last of the Colonial colleges, will formally celebrate its 150th anniversary on Friday, Saturday and next Sunday.
Mayor O'Brien signed yesterday the city bill placing a tax of 1 1/2 per cent on the gross monthly income of public utility companies during the emergency for which the city must provide relief funds.
PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 14. -- The University of Pennsylvania opened its fifty-seventh football season today by scoring an unimpressive 9to-0 victory over a valiant Franklin and Marshall eleven.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 14. -- The War Department issued the following orders today, dated Oct. 13:

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 14 (AP). -- Joe Cronin, manager of the Washington Senators, and Frank (Lefty) O'Doul, Giants' outfielder, whose pinch hit was a factor in the Giants' world's series victory over the Senators, arrived home today to be welcomed by thousands of San Franciscans assembled at the ferry building.

Public utility companies in the Pacific Northwest are aroused over the allocation of $83,000,000 from the national public works funds two weeks ago for the purpose of building two power plants on the Columbia River in the States of Oregon and Washington.

FRANCE lately estimated that the money boarded in that country amounted to 70,000,000,000 francs and devised two ways to lure it from hiding. One was by starting another lottery; the other by authorizing the playing in French casinos of roulette and trente et quarante.

TORONTO, Ont., Oct. 14. -- Solution of the mining riddle of the Canadian Northwest, which is transportation, can be hastened materially by a small expenditure on the Great Bear River and on the purchase of boats, and such steps will open another area promising to add much to the prosperity of the Dominion, Colonel George A. Drew. chairman of the Ontario Securities Commission, told the Empire Club of Canada here this week.

BETHLEHEM, Pa., Oct. 14. -- A stubborn Johns Hopkins football team bowed to Lehigh, 14 -- 7, before a crowd of 6,000 persons today. The victory was Lehigh's first in three battles with the Baltimore eleven.

McCOOK, Neb., Oct. 14 (AP). -- Senator Noiris, independent Republican supporter of President Roosevelt, urged inflation of the currency today in a statement expressing hope that the President would change his plans and issue new money instead of bonds to retire a portion of the Fourth Liberty loan.
Ferdinand Pecora'a participation in the city campaign will be "more notable for its absence than for anything else," the Recovery candidate for District Attorney declared yesterday.

Following its swing in an upward direction in the previous week, THE NEW YORKS TIMES weekly index of business activity has recorded another gain, of half a point. For the week ended Oct. 7 the index advanced to 78.9 from 8.4 in the pre- ceding week. A year ago the number stood at 67.4.

WHITEMARSH, Pa., Oct. 14. -- Morris H. Dixon of Newtown Square, riding Joseph Neff Ewing's entry, Our Hope, suffered a broken collarbone when the horse fell while taking a hurdle at the Whitemarsh Valley Hunt Club's Fall race meet today on George D. Widener's estate at Erdenheim.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 14. -- The text of the remarks by Sir John Simon, chairman of the British delegation to the disarmament conference at Geneva, at the meeting today of the bureau or steering committee of the conference, was given out by the State Department as follows:

CHICAGO, Oct. 12. -- The mid-West city dweller again is on the move countryward, but has changed his destination from the old homestead in the hinterland to a small but self-sustaining acreage within striking distance of the population centres.

AUBURN, Ind., Oct. 14 (AP). -- Three men invaded the Auburn city police station at 11:40 o'clock tonight, held up the only man on duty and robbed the gun-case of six high-powered guns and several smaller arms.

NEWARK, N.J., Oct. 14. -- A new track record for 3-year-old pacers was established by Miss Cherry Mac, owned by J.B. Gilligan of South Orange, at the fourteenth matinee of the Road Horse Association of New Jersey at Weequahic Park today.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 14. -- A firmer tendency was evident in several important lines of business activity in the first week in October, although the statistics of production do not indicate a change in trend, the Department of Commerce said today in its weekly survey of domestic business conditions.

VIENNA, Oct. 13. -- The burden of the interest that a formerly indifferent world is beginning to feel in Central European affairs shifted during the week from the struggles of the Austrian and Czechoslovakian Governments against Hitlerism to the broader question of Danubian economic reconstruction.

Growing conviction in the primary dry-goods market that the national administration plans a further reduction in industry's operating hours and increases in minimum-wage levels has upset both mills and wholesalers considerably within the last two weeks, according to opinions expressed here yesterday.

The calling of part of the Fourth Liberty Loan 4 1/4 per cent bonds featured the announcements last week of securities called for payment before their dates of maturity. Aside from this redemption, calls were few. Several small lots of municipal warrants were added to the October list, and some small amounts of municipal and foreign bonds, to that for future months.

The agreement under which the commercial banks of New York will finance the city for the next four years "is not a cure but a palliative," Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of Columbia University, warned last night in a radio address from Station WJZ.
NEW YORK. Mr. and Mrs. Ernest G. Vietor will give a dinner dance Nov. 24 at the St. Regis for Miss Miriam Hall, daughter of W. Hunt Hall.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 14. -- Displaying a strong running game Harvard's football team turned back New Hampshire's eleven, 34 to 0, before a crowd of 15,000 at Soldiers Field today.
HAVANA, Oct. 13. -- The development of the Cuban situation as a Cuban problem being solved by Cuban methods without American intervention is highly gratifying to American official circles here.

THE Colonial kitchen, homelike and picturesque, has been a source of inspiration for many a modern interior. Its decorative influence has, however, seen felt chiefly in our living rooms, for the kitchen of today bears little resemblance to its early prototypes.

Influences that continued to depress speculative markets generally unsettled cotton, again in yesterday's early trading. Prices at one time lost neatly a dollar a bale, or 1-5 cent a pound, sending March off $8 a bale, or 3-5 cent a pound, from recent high figures.
POTSDAM, N.Y., Oct. 14. -- Clarkson Tech defeated the University of Vermont, 13 -- 8, at Snell Field today in a hard-fought game.

New York University's determined football team paid back an old debt by repulsing the Lafayette eleven, 13 to 12, at the Yankee Stadium yesterday. A missed kick from placement in the final second of play proved to be the margin of victory.

LOS ANGELES, Calif., Oct. 11. -- California's record as a go-getter has not been impaired by applications for government funds for public works. State projects call for investments of nearly $800,000,000, about one-half the Federal allotment available for construction work throughout the nation.

With the United States army rushing construction on sixty-three camps in New York State and New Jersey to be used as Winter quarters by the Civilian Conservation Corps, additional relief for the unemployed was promised yesterday. The city's Home Relief Bureau announced it would soon distribute 1,000,000 pounds of pork, the first instalment of a total of 5,000,000 pounds allotted to New York City by the Federal Relief Administration.

The dollar rose further in gold valuation yesterday but fell in terms of sterling and some other non-gold currencies. Measured against the franc, the United States currency reached 69.82 per cent of its par value, a gain of 91 points from the previous close.

NORTHPORT, L.I., Oct. 14. -- Robert Jacob Jr.'s yawl Nimbus, one of the Larchmont class boats, won the New Rochelle Yacht Club's cruising race out around Stratford Shoal Lighthouse, in the middle of Long Island Sound east of Bridgeport, Conn., and thence to this port.

To help keep the bathing beaches of the metropolitan district free of refuse and oil Captain R. Drace White, Supervisor of the Port, has issued an appeal to the operators of all ship lines serving this port to refrain from discharging refuse within fifty miles of Ambrose Lightship, dumping oil between the Ambrose Channel and Nantucket Lightships and pumping bilges or oil tanks within 100 miles of Ambrose Lightship.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 14. -- The executive council of the American Federation of Labor took practical steps today to carry to the "tradeunion family," now totaling more than 20,000,000, the appeal of the organization to boycott German goods and services.

Mayor O'Brien stood before an Irish audience early today and made his peace with the city's Irish-Americans by telling a cheering crowd that his mother "came from Limerick and my father from Tipperary." Despite his early schoolings in humbleness and self-effacement, he was glad at times, he said, of this "little bit of Tipperary in me."

The speaking campaign for the candidates on the Recovery party ticket, Joseph V, McKee for Mayor, James I. Cuff for Controller and Nathan Straus Jr. for President of the Board of Aldermen, to which the ratification meeting at Cooper Union last Wednesday night was preliminary, will start Tuesday night with a meeting at Jamaica High School.

PARIS, Oct. 13. -- The new Parliamentary session will open Tuesday. Premier Edouard Daladier has announced that, within the following ten days, either France's financial situation will be assured or this country will have a new government.

In many of the State capitals, as well as at Washington, Government officials are already counting the dollars they hope to receive from liquor taxes following repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment. Messrs, FOSDICK and SCOTT point out, in the study of post-prohibition problems which they have made for Mr. ROCKEFELLER, that an increase of public revenues is frequently described as the primary objective to be pursued in taxing liquor.
ST. LOUIS is witnessing the completion of its new municipal auditorium and civic centre, and one of the first events to be housed in it is a season of grand opera. Guy Golterman is the impresario.
An interesting bit of advice was offered the incoming class at Harvard this year in the welcoming article written for them in the Harvard A.A. New by William J. Bingham, graduate manager.

Sweeping Light, winner of the Champagne as a juvenile and last week the victim of sponging, was the victor yesterday in the Continental Handicap, feature event of the closing program at Jamaica. Leading from start to finish of the mile and seventy yards, the brown son of the English sire, Manna, triumphed by a head over the Belair Stud's Dominus.
EISENACH, Germany, Oct. 14 (AP). -- Nazi anti-Semitism is being emphasized anew in the annual observance of Luther festival week.

Market movements were influenced again yesterday by further consideration of the bond conversion plan of the United States Treasury, for which the financial community had not been adequately prepared. The process of readjustment continued on all the exchanges as Wall Street, upon further reflection, concluded that reckless inflationary proposals have been definitely rejected.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 14. -- General Johnson took drastic action today to prevent other than accredited newspaper or business paper correspondents from attending his semiweekly press conferences.

MANCHESTER, N.H., Oct. 14. -- Brooklyn College was defeated by St. Anselm's 27 to 0, today in a game which marked the dedication of St. Anlsem's new alumni field. The most Rev. John B. Peterson, D.D., Bishop of Manchester, and Mayor Damase Caron took part in the exercises.

GENEVA, N.Y., Oct. 14. -- Hobart College upset the jinx which has ruled over all Hobart's home football games during the past five years and broke into the victory column today by defeating Hartwick College of Oneonta, N.Y., 13 -- 0.
ANN ARBOR, Mich., Oct. 14. -- Michigan University uncovered a strong running game today and gained an easy victory over Cornell by 40 to 0 before a crowd of 45,000.

A Siamese temple in Park Avenue -- of no particular concern, strangely enough, to real estate operators -- is but one prospect of many for the annual Fall Military Ball to be given by members of the Seventh Regiment on the night of Nov. 4 in their Armory at Park Avenue and Sixty-sixth Street.

OMAHA, Neb., Oct. 11. -- Chiseling is evidently not the exclusive thorn in the flesh of the NRA; the AAA has its chiselers, too, although their method varies somewhat from that pursued under the Blue Eagle.

VANCOUVER, B.C., Oct. 12. -- An extraordinarily convincing story of a marine monster seen in the Gulf of Georgia off Vancouver Island has been told by two officials of the provincial government. They have related their separate experiences for their scientific value, knowing quite well the ridicule with which the tale will be received in many quarters.

The subject has become one of wide discussion. It has even entered school debates in the United States. A letter from an ingenuous maiden in a Western State asks for information and advice concerning the topic. But interest in it here is not nearly so great as, of all places, in Great Britain.

LONDON. H.G. WELLS'S sixty-seventh birthday happened to fall on the day that he was the guest at one of Foyle's literary luncheons. He confessed that he had forgotten all about this coincidence until he caught sight of the enormous iced cake set before him.
AMONG the paradoxes of the period of intellectual depression in Europe of the postwar era, that of the relations between Italy and Yugoslavia is not least striking.

WHILE several great assemblies were included in my recent itinerary, giving me contacts with notable personages, my impressions of the situation in Europe were picked up in its lanes and byways, among men and women who represent the great masses of the people.
George Washington High School's eleven came from behind to gain a 12-12 tie with the High School of Commerce at the Washington Stadium yesterday.

PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 14. -- The Princeton Tiger went on another rampage today, and a well-proportioned Williams College team that came into Palmer Stadium like a lion was more badly mauled than was Amherst a week ago.

GREAT NECK, L.I., N.Y., Oct. 14. -- After sailing along so majestically during the first two days of the Eben M. Byers Memorial Cup tournament the Garden City Golf Club partnership of Dwight Rockwell and Mort Fearey foundered today.

ALTHOUGH there weren't any printing presses, editions of the Koran appeared in great if laborious profusion. And Mr. Dimand of the Metropolitan tells us why. Copying the Koran was one of the acts of piety that could assure a Muslim's admittance to Paradise.

BERLIN, Oct. 14. -- Presiding judge Wilhelm Buenger at the eichstag fire trial expelled from the court room today four of the have foreign lawyers observing the trial, including Leo Gallagher, an merican. They were arrested, hen they failed to leave the court doom at once, on charges of having slandered the German authories.

Dickinson High School scored its eleventh straight victory and third of this season at Jersey City yesterday by vanquishing Stuyvesant High of New York, 20 to 6, before 3,000 persons. The victors made ten first downs to one for the losers.

PARIS. THE Winter hostess is going to be alluring, with a capital A, whether she receives in the intimacy of her boudoir or the formal setting of her drawing-room. Indeed, if anything could reinstate the famous "salons litteraires," which played such a prominent role in the social life of those epochs now inspiring so many of our styles, it would be the gowns designed by Paris couturiers for some of the leading modern Egerlas.

COLUMBIA, Mo., Oct. 14 (AP). -- A polished aerial offensive directed by Quarterback Lee Morgan, coupled with smashing line charges manned principally by Captain Ralph Graham, fullback, enabled Kansas State College to administer a crushing 33-to-0 defeat to the Missouri Tigers today.

appeal to NRA officials to give the grocery industry sixty to ninety days in which to prove the workability of its proposed code clause against the retailing of merchandise at a mark-up of less than 7 1/2 per cent will be made in Washington this week, according to word in food trade circles yesterday.

IN the "Chemical Embryology" of Professor Joseph Needham of Cambridge a quaint picture is reproduced from a manuscript supposed to have been written by St. Hildegarde in the twelfth century. God is a rhomboid from which hangs a hose leading to what polite circles call an "expectant mother."

This is air important day in the lives of many thousands of sportsmen of New York State and surrounding regions, for it marks the advent of another hunting season. Though our puritanical forebears in other years thought that hunting on Sunday was not in good order and so created laws against such activities, the opening date for the season is, nevertheless, this very Sunday.

With the exception of United States Government bonds, which closed generally higher, bonds listed on the Stock Exchange moved lower during the brief trading period yesterday. Foreign loans were weak, notably German issues, which declined on the withdrawal of the Reich from the League of Nations, and domestic corporation bonds swung lower for the first time since Oct. 3.

CHICAGO, Oct. 14. -- A free press is a fixed principle of life today, Marlen E. Pew, editor of Editor and Publisher and honorary president of Sigma Delta Chi, told the convention of the journalistic fraternity meeting in Evanston today.

George Washington's own autographed copy of the early American play, "The Contrast," will appear in the first book sale of the season at the American Art Association Anderson Galleries, Inc., next Friday afternoon.

THERE was meat for consideration in the successful tests as a seaplane last week of Admiral Byrd's big Condor transport, specially fitted for the second Antarctic expedition. With its twin Edo floats, each thirty-two feet long and able to carry a load of 16,800 pounds, it handled better than many a small water-going plane.
BALTIMORE, Oct. 14. -- Dr. Charles C. Plitt, professor of botany at the School of Pharmacy of the University of Maryland, died last night at the age of 64.

GENEVA, Oct. 15. -- Baron von Neurath's telegram submitting Germany's withdrawal from the disarmament conference reached President Arthur Henderson this afternoon and was immediately published. When the League of Nations office closed, however, the official notice of withdrawal from the League had not been received, although officials did not doubt it was coming.

OTTAWA, Canada, Oct. 11. -- Canada approaches the fifth Winter of the great depression with a feeling of confidence confirmed by developments of recent months and gradually permeating all strata of the population.

Because of many requests from cities in this country to exhibit Whistler's famous painting, "Portrait of the Arist's Mother," the Museum of Modern Art, 11 West Fifty-third Street, which borrowed the painting last year from the Louvre in Paris, has decided to request an extension of the loan so that the picture may be shown in other parts of the United States.
BERLIN, Oct. 13. -- Now that labor and the peasantry have had their days of glorification, "German art" will have its pageant in Munich this Sunday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 14. -- Without discussion or dissent, the anticrime conference at its closing session today endorsed the proposed establishment at Washington of an Institute of Criminology and creation of a new Federal Department of Applied Education for the solution, lawlessness, crime and nation, lawlessness, crime, and national and international problems.
AMHERST, Mass., Oct. 14. -- With Harry Thomas in the starring role, the Amherst eleven returned to winning form today to trounce Union on Pratt Field, 46 -- 0.
A new letter of John Brown the abolitionist, of particular interest to New Yorkers, has been discovered and is published in the October number of the Quarterly of the New York Historical Association.

UNTIL recent years the chief source of supply for collectors of Hebrew manuscripts was Italy. In the last century the Interest of Jewish scholars in the unpublished literature of their race led to a search through various libraries in Europe and the East.

HIGHTSTOWN, N.J., Oct. 14. -- In one of the major games of its season, Peddie's football team defeated Brooklyn Poly Prep, 17 to 0, today. Joe McGuiness, Peddle quarterback, led his team's attack, tallying 11 points.

ROME, Sept. 29, 1933. THE Roman daily Il Messaggero has just published a full advance announcement, which it claims to have from authoritative sources, regarding the bill of the coming season at the Royal Opera House.

The Brooklyn Museum in Eastern Parkway has received many rare and valuable Egyptian relics dating from before 1000 B.C. They were unearthed at Tell-el-Amarna, where the Egypt Exploration Society has been making extensive excavations on the site of the heretic Pharaoh Akhenaten's capital.

To the Editor of The New York Times: May I express my sympathy with Geneva Viola Wolcott's sense of affront over those Irish who "look to McKee for political jobs." With her I hope that machine politics and the mere lust for soft jobs are in for a lesson which is long overdue.

EAST LANSING, Mich., Oct. 14 (AP). -- Michigan State today displayed a brilliant reversal of form in the second half portion of its game with Illinois Wesleyan to gain a 20-to-12 victory. The losers led by 12 -- 0 at half time.

THE customary variety is to be found in Columbia's October list, which, while not startling, does contain one quite superb item. Before going into details it may be of interest to point out the ecletic nature of what may be taken as an average monthly release from this company.
CHICAGO, Oct. 14. -- Speaking to the Illinois League of Women Voters, Frances Parkins, Secretary of Labor, asserted today that the existing labor disturbances "aren't strikes at all."

THE 1934 Studebakers, officially introduced here last Thursday, comprise three lines -- Dictator six and Commander and President eights. The new cars are characterized by a closer approach to streamlining, particularly noticeable in the flowing, "aerodynamic" design of the rear fenders and back section.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 (AP). -- A report of "very definite progress" was the only announcement today from a conference of silk manufacturers, labor leaders and NRA officials reviewing the textile situation and attempting to reach settlement of strikes affecting about 65,000 employes in New Jersey, Pennsylvania and New England.

Registration for the city election reached 2,322,382 last night as the registration period closed. The grand total for the week was only slightly under the record mark of 2,338,804 established in the registration for last year's Presidential election.

LONDON, Oct. 14 (AP). -- The Tot- tenham Hotspurs lengthened their lead in the first division of the English Soccer League today when they pulled out a close 1-0 victory over Portsmouth on the latter's grounds.

Mrs. Charles H. Thieriot has enlisted the aid of many prominent women to further the sale of boxes and seats for the performance of "Let 'Em Eat Cake," the new musical comedy, to be given on the night of Oct. 31 at the Imperial Theatre, which has been taken over for the benefit of the Travelers Aid Society.

MELBOURNE, Oct. 13. -- Austra- lians have become suddenly conscious of the defenselessness of the Commonwealth. Before the great war there was a vigorous desire to safeguard the country. A small but efficient navy was maintained and young men had to undergo a period of compulsory military training.

A division of opinion on store-door delivery service between the New York Central on the one hand and the Pennsylvania Railroad and the Van Sweringen lines on the other was seen yesterday as a possibility at a meeting of railroad officials here on Thursday.

WASHINGTON. CONSUMER, consumer, who's got the consumer?" is Washington's newest game. Never was that shy soul so sought after, so courted, so flattered. He and his wife, and all the little infant consumers, form the subject of weighty discussion and thoughtful pamphlets.

PARIS. QUESTION any French official about France and he turns to the map hanging on the wall behind his desk. The map is always there, and it is never the map of France. That geographical self-projection, so definite and firmly outlined, no Frenchman needs to look at.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In these days, when loyalty to people or to a cause is being sorely tested and sometimes questioned, it may interest your readers to know of a loyalty the details of which are cognizant only to the writer and which have never before appeared in print.

VANCOUVER, Oct. 6. -- British Columbia, which, throughout its history has been content to entrust its affairs to either of the old-line parties, Conservative or Liberal, has for its general election on Nov. 2, an array of parties unique in the history of Canada.
BERLIN, Oct. 14. -- The complete text of the address of Chancellor Hitler of Germany today on the disarmament question follows:

Led by Captain Sid Luckman, who scored 13 points, the undefeated Erasmus Hall High School football team scored a 19-0 victory over James Madison in their annual clash before a capacity crowd of 12,500 at Erasmus Field, Brooklyn, yesterday.

THERE will be four soloists with the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra during this week's concerts. Elsa Alsen and Paul Althouse will assist at a Wagner program this afternoon; Artur Schnabel will play Beethoven's Fourth concerto, in G, on Thursday evening and Friday afternoon, and Mishel Piastro will perform the Glazunoff violin concerto on Saturday evening.

HAMILTON, N.Y., Oct. 14. -- Colgate's Red Raiders defeated Rutgers today, 25 -- 2, although the Rutgers eleven broke the unscored-on record of Colgate by blocking a kick for a safety in the fourth quarter.
WESTFIELD, N.J., Oct. 14. -- Perth Amboy High School defeated Westfield High today, 13 to 6.

WEST HILLS, L.I., Oct. 14. -- Mrs. T.W. Durant's Little Dan captured the third running of the Long Island Hunt Cup, the featured race of six staged by the West Hills Racing Association today over the course on the estates of Colonel Henry L. Stimson and Thomas F. White.

EVERYWHERE signs multiply of a near-stampede of grownups back to school and library. Four million new borrowers of public library books since 1929 are reported by the American Library Association on the eve of its annual convention in Chicago this week.

LONDON. PROMINENCE in the news of the cinema world has natural- ly been given over here to the announcement that the Fairbanks, father and son, have joined up with a new organization, London Film Productions, of which Alexander Korda is the directing head, and will collaborate in the making of at least three pictures in the next twelve months.

Butter. The market closed the week with the better grades still firmly supported under pegging operations. However, an extremely large quantity of surplus fresh goods is having to be taken off the market in order to accomplish this result. The week's transactions under the Exchange call in 90 score and better totalled over 13,801 tubs-an all time record for the period Government surplus buying Is expected to start in the near future.
PITTSBURGH, Oct. 14. -- A stubborn Navy team held Pitt to a 7-0 score for two bitterly fought periods in the Pitt Stadium today before a gathering of 45,000. And then came the deluge.

MADRID, Oct. 13. -- Brighter sun shone on Spain this week, and hope, which had taken a sharp dive into the depths after months of Parliamentary deadlock, took a sharp turn upward when President Alcala Zamora dissolved the Cortes, which had endured two and a half years.

Marshaling the arguments that will be used against revision of the Pure Food and Drugs Act at the coming session, of Congress, drug manufacturers declared yesterday that 53 per cent of the wholesale drug volume of the country is in proprietary or trade-marked Items, that the proposed rewriting of the act will affect adversely these goods and that it will tend to reduce the tremendous volume of advertising which the industry does.

Although some skepticism was shown in Wall Street, the general attitude yesterday was that, after the government's ambitious bond conversion program, the advocates of currency inflation cannot expect to make much headway in the near future.

PARIS, Oct. 3. -- Characteristic Autumn social activities, such as pheasant shooting, which begins about Oct. 1; the races at Long-champs, the inauguration of gala dinners and cabaret performances in the well-known restaurants, or in some new ones, have given the Paris season quite a busy aspect, with many Americans mingling in the Parisian and cosmopolitan set which keeps in tune with fashion.

Business conditions were unsettled last week, reports from the various Federal Reserve centres indicating an absence of coordination between consumption and production and growing uncertainty regarding prices, potentialities of profits under the NRA and the continuance of the re-employment drive.

WHEN the world first dreamed of wireless and Marconi made it all come true, there were imaginative souls bold enough to predict that some day messages would be flashed through the air from the North and South Poles.

ROBINSON JEFFERS so often writes with such searing power and such flame of emotion that his poetry as a whole is something to be reckoned with. He is an uneven writer, with the result that when the power lags his verse can be as raucous as the voice of a calliope, his colors become as splotched and patternless as the daubs on a painter's palette.

WHEN a newspaper reader learns that Department of Justice operatives have run down a gang of kidnappers, like that recently convicted in the Urschel case, or caught a band of train robbers or cornered a murderer whose crime came under Federal jurisdiction, he may have in mind a Sherlock Holmes or a Philo Vance.
MADRID, Oct. 14. -- France has approached the Spanish Government with a view to military cooperation in case of need, it is learned from authoritative sources here today.

All German bonds were weak on the Stock Exchange yesterday on receipt of the news that the Reich had withdrawn from the League of Nations and that the Reichstag had been dissolved and an election called for Nov. 12.
MOSCOW. THE Soviet Union had an attendance of 2,000,000,000 at cinemas in 1932, which is an answer to the well-known cinema slogan here, "Let the reve- nue from the cinema replace that from vodka.''

THE department of England's police organization with which the author, himself a retired member of it, deals is that whose duty it is to guard the safety of the nation rather than that of the individual. Its mission is to hunt down traitors, spies, anarchists and other persons and organizations of revolutionary tendencies, and also to combat such evils as the drug traffic, white slavery and the like.

AN institution for juvenile delinquents with none of the traditional marks upon it will be officially opened today at Warwick, N.Y., when the State's Training School for Boys is dedicated by Governor Lehman.

At the same time, by inference always, frequently by direct statement, we have the story of the struggles in this country of the race itself.

The wages of all "white-collar" emergency workers in this State are being revised from a flat rate to a budgetary basis, it was learned yesterday. The new plan will increase relief in some cases and diminish it in others.

ROGER FRY'S recently painted pictures are at the Ehrich Galleries this month. Blond and large in feeling whether measuring few or many inches, to look at them with any knowledge of the past is to realize how accurate a report they render of a quarter-century in a painter's attitude toward his art.

MINNEAPOLIS, Oct. 14. -- Purdue, bewildered for three periods by a strong Minnesota team's dazzling rushing and aerial attack, intercepted a pass in the last quarter today to pave the way for a touchdown and a 7-to-7 tie before 26,000 spectators.

DUBLIN, Oct. 13. -- The riotous scenes that marked the United Ireland party meeting at Tralee, at which General Owen O'Duffy was assaulted, were not repeated last week-end. When General O'Duffy addressed a meeting at Castlebar Sunday and a second meeting at Sligo Tuesday, the government took special precautions, with large forces of police and military, to prevent an attack by Opposition leaders.

Dr. Frederick B. Robinson, president of City College, who will celebrate his fiftieth birthday tomorrow, believes that the tendency of education in the future will be to remedy the weaknesses which developed in the rapid expansion that took place during his lifetime.
Former United States Ambassador to Germany. THOSE who would solve the riddle of Hitlerism and the present extraordinary attitude of the German people must search the history of Germany.

WAYLAND, Mass., Oct. 14. -- Paul Runyan's consistently fine play over the 7,000-yard Presidential course today gave the White Plains, N.Y., professional a two-stroke victory over Leo Diegel of Mexico, his Ryder Cup teammate, in the first Eastern Open championship in the history of golf.

BERLIN, Oct. 14. -- The decision of the Hitler government to terminate Germany's membership in the League of Nations and her participation in the disarmament conference marks the conclusion of a seven-year epoch, in post-war German foreign, policy.

BERLIN, Sunday, Oct. 15. -- Chancellor Hitler's radio speech explaining Germany's withdrawal from the League of Nations and the arms conference was broadcast a third time at 1 o'clock this morning in German, English, Spanish and Portuguese over a Continental and transatlantic hook-up.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Oct. 14. -- Army overwhelmed University of Delaware under a 52 to 0 score today before 20,000 spectators in Michie Stadium. The Cadets ran wild throughout the early stages of the game, scoring six touchdowns in the first two periods while their varsity players were in action.

The lull in dresses and formal coats was offset to some extent during the week by the active ordering of suits, according to the market report prepared especially for THE TIMES by McGreevy, Werring Howell, Inc. The demand for suits, which found manufacturers unprepared, represented about 95 per cent of the orders for outer apparel, the buying office noted.
MADRID, Oct. 13. -- The interparliamentary conference, which was ended this week in Madrid, adopted a resolution which read:
CHAMPAIGN, Ill., Oct. 14 (AP). -- Illinois decisively outplayed Wisconsin today, 21 to 0, in the opening Western Conference game for both teams, scoring in every period except the first.

CHICAGO, Oct. 14. -- Long grain came out in volume early today on the Board of Trade and sent the markets crashing downward, with the result that deferred deliveries of wheat, oats and rye and all deliveries of corn dropped to new low levels for the season and December wheat and oats threatened to reach their previous bottom marks.

The Board of Estimate was unable to agree yesterday on whether $17,700,000 in pension funds should be included in the 1934 budget, from which they had been omitted because of a $200,000,000 surplus in the funds.

CASSADAGA, N.Y., Oct. 14 (AP). -- Commenting on the call for a special session of the Legislature to help New York City out of its financial troubles, Speaker Joseph A. McGinnies of the Assembly said here today any plan presented by the city "must have the approval of the business as well as the political people."

MEN IN WHITE," the play about a young hospital interne's dilemna, which added-considerable weight to the current theatrical list on its opening, is another instance of a play that reached presentation only after prolonged delay.

DENVER, Oct. 12. -- After months of skirmishing the Colorado Federation of County Taxpayers Associations has opened an attack on the main sector. The federation will in the next few weeks send organizers into every community in the State and institute a speaking campaign to make known the record of every State legislator on all recent tax measures.
BRUNSWICK, Me., Oct. 14. -- Bowdoin beat Wesleyan today, 14 -- 0, the Connecticut team making only two first downs, compared with nineteen by the victors.

ORDINARILY the dedication of a book has import only for those immediately concerned, namely, the writer and the object of the dedication. Bat the fact that "AE" (George William Russell) inscribes his book "The Avatars," to W.B. Yeats is of wider significance than at first appears.

Many prominent men and women of society as well as debutantes are aiding in arrangements for the performance of "The Divine Drudge" on the night of Nov. 1 at the Royale Theatre, which has been taken over by the directors of the Seamen's Church Institute of New York.

WITH the death of Morris Hillquit the American Socialist movement has lost its most eminent figure, a man who belonged to the earlier generation of Socialists and who, with Eugene V. Debs and Victor L. Berger, was influential in shaping the course of the Socialist party, its programs and organization work.

CHICAGO, Oct. 14. -- Juan Zabala, Argentina's Olympic marathon champion, pounded his way over the pavements and through a dense world's fair crowd today to win the National Amateur Athletic Union's 30,000-meter championship.

In behalf of the Women's Trade Union League a recital by Jose Iturbi, pianist, has been arranged for the night of Nov. 13 by a group of prominent women who long have been actively allied with the work of the organization. Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt, who has been interested in the league since its founding, is honorary chairman of the benefit committee, and Mrs. Otto H. Kahn is active chairman.

The Shippers Conference of Greater New York will support the Pennsylvania Railroad in its proposal to establish a store-door collection and delivery service. The plan was opposed by the New York Central Railroad on the ground that the service would invade the territory of other railroads and was a form of unfair competition.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 14. -- Plans for the establishment of a Federal bank, which would make provision for the release of more than $2,500,000,000 in frozen deposits of closed banks, received further consideration at a White House conference today.
BERLIN, Oct. 14. -- The National Socialist government of Germany announced today the Reich's withdrawal simultaneously from the disarmament conference and from the League of Nations.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 14. -- "Token" paments on all State and local governmental debts, similar to the procedure adopted by Great Britain in offering a small amount on account of her last debt payment to the United States, are suggested by Senator Hatfield of West Virginia in a letter addressed to Governor Kump of his State and made public today.

LIKE Mrs. Armer's story "Waterless Mountain," which was awarded the Newbery Medal in 1931, "Dark Circle of Branches" is a picture of Indian life, presented with so much understanding and inner knowledge that the perceptive reader has the feeling that he is undergoing a real experience and living for a time in the Navajo hogans.

TODAY. WAGNERIAN MUSIC -- Elsa Alsen, dramatic soprano, and Paul Alt-house, tenor, of the Metropolitan Opera Company, assist in this presentation at Carnegie Hall of the immolation, scene from Wagner's "Gotterdammerung." Bruno Walter conducts the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra for the duet and other parts depicting Siegfried's death and funeral march.

DURHAM, N.C., Oct. 14. -- Duke's Blue Devils laughed in the face of Tennessee's long string of victories by defeating the saffron-shirted Vols, 10 to 2, today. And In the doing they heaped high the happiness of a homecoming crowd of 22,000.

WHEN the Captains and the Kings have slaughtered their last ragged battalions, uttered their final blasphemies, and packed up their medals and departed, their victims sometimes manage to make themselves heard.

LEAVENWORTH, Kan., Oct. 14 (AP). -- Locked in a solitary-confinement cell in the Federal Penitentiary here with all privileges denied to him, George (Machine Gun) Kelly, convicted kidnapper, today began a life sentence boasting that he would free himself before long.
LONDON. AMERICAN tourists returning from a Summer in Europe seem to nave taken borne harrowing tales of the vagaries which the fall in the dollar has played with the American colonies in Europe.

MINEOLA, L.I., Oct. 14. -- Breaking fifty straight targets, A.C. Webb captured the High Scratch Cup in the weekly shoot of the Nassau Trapshooting Club today. Fred Wise defeated five other gunners in a shoot-off for the handicap prize.

A recommendation that taxes on liquor be made relatively low during the first years, at least, after repeal of prohibition was contained yesterday in a further release of the report on post-prohibition problems, compiled under the sponsorship of John D. Rockefeller Jr.

BANGKOK, Siam, Oct. 14 (AP). -- The Siamese Government, besieged by rebellious forces which reached the outskirts of the city, smashed back today in a counter-attack which was officially described as victorious.

Foreign students can now develop their English through the medium of The American News, a newspaper written in a controlled vocabulary of only 800 words. The newspaper, published by the Language Research Committee, with offices at New York University, made its appearance last week and has been adopted by the Board of Education for use in all the schools throughout the city where English is taught to foreigners.

TOPEKA, Kan., Oct. 12. -- The announcement that Dr. John R. Brinkley of Milford, famed locally as a great gland specialist, radio speaker and stormy petrel of politics, will shake the dust of Kansas off his feet and move to Texas is good news for the master strategists of both political parties.

DURHAM, N.C., Oct. 14. -- Duke's Blue Devils laughed in the face of Tennessee's long string of victories by defeating the saffron-shirted Vols, 10 to 2, today. And In the doing they heaped high the happiness of a homecoming crowd of 22,000.

WHEN the Captains and the Kings have slaughtered their last ragged battalions, uttered their final blasphemies, and packed up their medals and departed, their victims sometimes manage to make themselves heard.

LEAVENWORTH, Kan., Oct. 14 (AP). -- Locked in a solitary-confinement cell in the Federal Penitentiary here with all privileges denied to him, George (Machine Gun) Kelly, convicted kidnapper, today began a life sentence boasting that he would free himself before long.
