NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 14. -- Yale's varsity football team scored a clean-cut and an encouraging victory in the Yale Bowl today over a good Washington and Lee eleven, 14 to 0.
Fordham's football team clashed with its first major opponent yesterday and emerged the victor over a shifty, threatening West Virginia eleven, 20 to 0, for the Rams' third triumph of the season.

SWARTHMORE, Pa., Oct. 14. -- Germany's withdrawal today from the League of Nations may result in a serious crisis of international affairs, according to President Frank Aydelotte of Swarthmore College, who spoke at the afternoon session of the joint conference of the Women's International League for Peace and Freedom and the Fellowship of Reconciliation.

GUGLIELMO MARCONI watched Dr. Vladimir Zworykin's television images cavort on a screen in the RCA-Victor research laboratories several days ago and expressed amazement -- in fact, he predicted television outfits would soon be available for the home.

INCURABLE romanticist, perennial optimist, still vibrant with the spirit of youth at 76, Dr. Martin has made a happy choice in the selection of a title for the story of his life. The narrative indicates in its minute, manifold details an intense and sustained pleasure and interest in the persons and circumstances with which he has found himself surrounded.

Joseph V. McKee, independent candidate for Mayor, sent a telegram yesterday to F.H. LaGuardia, his Fusion opponent, calling upon him to disavow the criticism of Governor Lehman by Samuel Seabury, his chief supporter.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 14. -- Slight increases in the average prices of farm products from, the mid-September to the first week of October are reported by the Bureau of Agricultural Economics.
BERLIN, Oct. 14 (AP). -- Germany, on the day of its "liberation," as the papers universally called it seemed too much overwhelmed and dazed by the rapidity of events to celebrate.

PORT JEFFERSON, L.I., Oct. 14. -- Sport Windem Pal, a white and lemon pointer dog owned and handled by George B. Gerard of Huntington, L.I., won the featured open all-age stake as the twelfth annual field trial of the Brookhaven Game Protective Association came to a close today.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, Oct. 12. -- Cincinnati's election bids fair to be of more than local interest because of a proposal for municipal ownership of gas and electricity. It comes up in the form of an initiated ordinance to be voted upon, directly.
FRIEDRICHSHAFEN, Oct. 14 -- The Graf Zeppelin, piloted by Dr. Hugo Eckener, started unostentatiously at 9:15 o'clock this evening on a triangular flight that will bring her to Chicago.

DENVER, Oct. 12. -- Not for a generation have the silver advocates been so confident that their pet fetish, bimetalism, will soon be a reality. The inflationary legislation of last April gave them renewed confidence, as did the partial success of Senator Pittman's efforts at London in June.

More than 1,000 members of the United Polish Societies of the Bronx and Harlem, participated in joint ceremonies yesterday in honor of Generals Pulaski and Kosciuszko, heroes of the Continental Army in the Revolutionary War.

BERLIN. IN the Spring of 1914 the civi- lized world heard the stirring news of the discovery of a primitive man found by the German explorer Hans Reck in Oldoway Ravine, Africa. Theretofore only two or three fossilized relics of those early ages of the human race had been known to us.

Reports that many Latin-American countries are raising tariffs so that they will be in a "trading position" at the Pan-American conference at Montevideo in December caused concern among exporters here last week. One South American republic advanced its rates on candy and a number of other articles more than 100 per cent recently.

CHANGCHUN, Manchuria, Oct. 14. -- Another dream of Japanese imperialists was realized today as the first train direct from Changchun to the shores of the Sea of Japan moved along the new route to Seishin, Korea. The new line is about 400 miles long.

Whether or not the government intended, by its great bond-conversion program, to pledge itself to the preservation of a sound currency, that purpose was naturally taken for granted in Wall Street. The reasoning is simple: Obviously the administration would not ask investors to participate in a refinancing plan of such scope if there was any immediate likelihood of dilution of the currency.

The Glory of Aroostook. Among all the tubers of the world the potatoes of Aroostook County are most persistently cultivated, watched, defended represented at Washington. They never have to weep their eyes out because of neglect.

Johnny Wilson, captain of the Jamaica High harriers, yesterday scored his second individual triumph in as many starts this season. He led the Group 1 pack in the weekly P.S.A.L. cross country meet at Van Cortlandt Park in the splendid time of 12:03 for the course of two and three-eights miles.

SARANAC LAKE, N.Y., Oct. 14. -- Continued Republican control of the Assembly is necessary to prevent Tammany Hall from dumping New York City's financial burden on the remainder of the State, north country leaders were told today at the Republican Women's Regional Conference here.

CHICAGO, Oct. 14. -- Northwestern's Wildcats, caged two weeks ago-by Iowa in one of the football season's prize upsets, stuck out their paws today and flattened the national championship hopes of Stanford before a crowd of 35,000.

PEIPING, Sept. 21. -- Discoveries of a rather surprising nature have been made in recent months at the caves of Choukoutien, forty miles southwest of Peiping, where, in 1929, a young Chinese paleontologist, W.C. Pei, uncovered the skull of a primitive human type, which later became known as "Sinanthropus," or "the Peking Man."

THE arrival of Uday Shan-kar comes fittingly with the seasonal announcements of the many groups of dancers which are active in the propagation of social, political and economic theories; for Shan-kar, too, is a propagandist.

POTTSTOWN, Pa., Oct. 14 -- The Hill School eleven defeated Yale Freshmen seconds today, 12 to 6. Hill scored twice in the second quarter, once a pass from Jesse Spalding to Smale, and then, after a 15yard penalty on Yale, on a plunge by Brown.

PARIS, Oct. 14. -- France, which becomes easily excited over little matters, learned this morning with astonishing calm of Germany's decision to quit the League of Nations and the disarmament conference. The news came near the end of a Cabinet meeting where financial measures for balancing the budget were discussed.

The Republicans who so far have not taken a very active part in the Fusion campaign are preparing to enter the fight aggressively this week. They are determined to block attempts made by the supporters of Joseph V. McKee to bring about a Republican defection to the Recovery party.
To the Editor of The New York Times: I have been reading accounts of the investigation in ship subsidies, rates for mail-carrying which amount to subsidies, intimations of bribery,

Completing the Autumn schedule of all-breed dog shows, the Bronx County Kennel Club will stage its nineteenth annual exhibition today in the 105th Field Artillery Armory, at 166th Street and Franklin Avenue, the Bronx.

CHAPEL HILL, N.C., Oct. 14. -- Georgia's powerful football machine defeated North Carolina by 30-0 before a crowd of 12,000 today. Sticking to straight football and passing only when necessary, the Bulldogs scored in every quarter, with two touchdowns in the second.

PHOENIX, Ariz., Oct. 14 (AP). -- The Macon, the navy's newest dirigible, cruised over the mountains and deserts of Arizona in bright sunshine this afternoon, nearing the end of its transcontinental flight.

EAST ORANGE, N.J., Oct. 14. -- Max Hochberg and Sidney Silcoor of Newark, with 252 of a possible 432 match points, today topped the field of twenty-four teams that qualified for the finals in the pairs competition of the New Jersey State championship bridge tournament at the Wbist Club of the Oranges.

TODAY is an anniversary in the annals of aeronautics. On Oct. 15, 1783, in Paris, the young Jean-Francois Pilatre de Rozier climbed into the wicker basket of a Montgolfier paper balloon and ascended to a height of eighty-four feet.

PRAGUE, Oct. 14. -- Semi-official comment here on Germany's withdrawal from the Disarmament Conference and the League of Nations is that the government will take no stand until Paris, London and Washington have made their position clear.
BLOOMINGTON, Ind., Oct. 14. -- Two flashes of brilliant football gave Notre Dame a hard-fought 12-to-2 victory over Indiana University today.
SOUTH BEND, Ind., Oct. 14. -- Gugiielmo Marconi, inventor of wireless and a Senator of Italy, received the honorary degree of Doctor of Laws today at Notre Dame University in a special convocation.
HANOVER, N.H., Oct. 14. -- The Dartmouth attack was good for a pair of touchdowns today against a fighting team from Bates and the Green scored a 14-0 victory.
RIVERSIDE, Mass., Oct. 14. -- Boston. University scored a 9-to-7 victory over Colby at Nickereon Field today for its first victory of the season.

BERLIN, Oct. 14. -- The Boerse, which had closed before the political bomb of Germany's withdrawal from the League of Nations burst, was dull and irregular today. The market opened father soft, but showed good resistance and closed undecisive.

As in past years, members of society are subscribing early to one of the important events of each Autumn in New York, the Victory Ball, which is to be held on Nov. 10 at the Waldorf-Astoria under the auspices of the New York County Welfare Committee of the American Legion.

PEIPING, Sept. 16. -- While Henry Pu Yi, once boy Emperor of China, has regained, as Chief Executive of Manchukuo, a vestige of his former station, the memory of his predecessors on the Dragon Throne is suffering shocking degradation through the spoliation of their last resting place by vandal Chinese soldiers.

CHICAGO, Oct. 14. -- William Walton Hall, 31 years old, law student and treasurer and part owner of the Sea Dog Inn, a Chicago River yachting rendezvous, was reported tonight to be in the hands of kidnappers demanding a $5,000 ransom.

PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 14. -- Campaigning for the eligible campus votes, Princeton University undergraduate organizations for the support of Joseph V. McKee and Mayor John P. O'Brien in the New York campaign have launched drives here for their respective candidates.

WOODBURY, L.I., Oct. 14. -- Colonel and Mrs. Francis L. Robbins Jr. were hosts tonight at their country place in the West Hills at the annual hunt ball following the twelfth meeting of the United Hunts Racing Association this afternoon.
Several flats, including two in Jersey City bought by residents of Germany, were included in the New Jersey realty transactions reported over the week-end.
GREAT NECK, L.I., Oct. 15 -- The youngest pair to start in the Eben M. Byers memorial tournament outlasted every one else in the event.

So far as regards the general movement of recovery, last week indicated no great change. Results in retail trade were favorable as a whole, but production for the wholesale trade continued below the midsummer maximum. Although weekly steel output, for instance, rose to 44 per cent of capacity, comparing with 41 a fortnight ago, it still remained well under the 59 per cent of the second week in July.

Endorsement of all Fusion candidates for city, borough and county offices was announced yesterday by the Citizens Union. In connection with the announcement the organization made public its analysis of the candidates endorsed as well as some of those that were not.

WARSAW, Oct. 15 -- The Polish Government said today that it had been warned by Italy by Germany's intentions and that yesterday's moves were, therefore, not unexpected. Warsaw is not alarmed but considers that the European atmosphere has been cleared up.

Champion Benson of Crombie won his twentieth best-in-show award last night. He was named by Louis J. Murr of Spring Valley, N.Y., as the outstanding specimen among the 509 dogs benched in the nineteenth annual all-breed exhibition of the Bronx County Kennel Club, which was held in the 105th Field Artillery Armory, the Bronx.

Those responsible for the present state of social unrest in Europe might read the life of Thaddeus Kosciusko and imbibe his love of liberty, Mayor O'Brien declared yesterday at City Hall Park at a celebration commemorating the 150th anniversary of the Polish hero's appointment as a Brigadier General in the Revolutionary army.
A publication that helped make American history just after the Revolution is revived at Columbia University today under its original title, The Independent Journal.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Supplementing the letter of John J. Mead, may I suggest that there will be need for homes, as there always has been, and the building of homes of the smaller class provides more employment than any other Industry I can think of for the amount invested.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 15 -- Operations in steel mills have held up better than the trade expected, there having been only minor fluctuations in the last thirty days and no distinct trend in either direction.

NORFOLK, Va., Oct. 15 (AP) -- Two nations joined the State of Virginia and the community of Hampton Roads tonight in a farewell to Rear Admiral Richard Evelyn Byrd, the State's native son, and his expedition, soon to sail fro mhere for the Antarctic.

VIENNA, Oct. 15 -- Five thousand Nazis today tried to force their way into the Ottakring Cemetery to hold a memorial demonstration at the graves of two Nazis killed a year ago in a clash with Socialists.

The publishing firm of Ray Long and Richard R. Smith, now conducted by A.J. Hammerslough, has just issued what they describe as a "blurbless" catalogue of new titles. Most of the hooks are described with only one complimentary sentence.

PARIS, Oct. 15 -- The sharp recovery of Friday in dollars and sterling obviously was due to covering by bears, speculators having been impressed by persistent rumors of dollar stabilization which would naturally follow the stabilization of sterling.

BERLIN, Oct. 14 -- The Reichsbank continues to purchase gold in Paris even in weeks when the total intakings of foreign currencies barely covers the outgoings for service on foreign debt. This involves an unbroken increase of gold reserve at the cost of the exchange reserve.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 15 -- Prospects for material revision of the Securities Control Act at the next session of Congress were seen as heightened here today when it was revealed by the Chamber of Commerce of the United States that groups representing business, banking and the bar are working to that end.

The United States Lines, Inc., is considering an appeal to the Department of State as a result of the alleged intervention of the German Government in commercial traffic moving between American and German ports, according to Basil Harris, vice president of the lines.
Except for Hotchkiss School's 26-to-0 victory, there was a surprising scarcity of clean-cut triumphs recorded for the East's major prep school football ranks during the past week-end.

Uniform State and Federal taxes to yield $700,000,000 annually were advocated in yesterday's installment of the report on liquor control prepared for John D. Rockefeller Jr. by Raymond B. Fosdick and Albert. L. Scott.

BERLIN, Oct. 14 -- Germany's internal trade is improving. The unemployed on Sept. 13 totaled 3,850,000, against 5,103,000 in September, 1932. These figures, however, do not take into account the members of labor camps or the compulsion of employers to take on men they do not need, besides other exceptional measures.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 15 -- In the first of a series of price indexes, the Commerce Department estimated today that retail sales in five and ten cent to one dollar variety stores for September were 4.7 per cent above a year ago.

The first in this season's series of Sunday night "concerts" at the Winter Garden -- a tradition at that house in the years before it was converted into a motion-picture theatre in 1928 -- was held last evening, now that the famous theatre has been returned to the list of legitimate houses.

Mercury, the City College humor magazine, makes its first appearance today under the editorship of Morton S. Goldstein. Harold Barnett, last year's business manager, has been named business associate for the present semester. Members of the staff are:

Tammany Hall and the present city administration were denounced in a sermon yesterday by the Rev. Dr. Malcolm James MacLeod, pastor at the Collegiate Reformed Church of St. Nicholas, Fifth Avenue and Forty-eighth Street.

LONDON, Oct. 15 -- Prime Minister MacDonald returned to Downing Street tonight from Chequers, where in the course of the day he had telephone conversations with Sir John Simon, the Foreign Secretary, in Geneva, on the best move for the government to make next as a sequel to Germany's withdrawal from the disarmament conference.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 15 (AP) -- The nation's leading steel operators perked up the other day when the government announced it may buy more than $30,000,000 in rails, but at least one of them said tonight he is less enthusiastic now that he has studied the conditions under which the order would be placed.
GENEVA, Oct. 15 -- The Disarmament Conference will make an effort to go on without Germany. The general commission, at its public session tomorrow afternoon, will be asked to do three things:

Much has been said and written about the decrease in the number of ducks which are likely to reach the shooting grounds in the United States this year. As a consequence one might suppose that the season, which opens today in this section, would fail to provide much good sport.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The trouble with Dr. Crile is that he is working under a discarded hypothesis. The Darwinian theory of evolution has been abandoned by advanced thinkers because it no longer fits the known facts. It was never much better than reveraed transcendentalism, anyway, since it merely transferred to environment the potentials previously vested in God.

KWEIHUA, Suiyuan, Oct. 15 -- If the Nanking Government does not promptly and generously grant their demands, Mongolian nationalists and Inner Mongolian leaders will not hesitate to seek assistance of the State of Manchukuo in an effort to establish autonomy and cut off from China an area of 160,000 square miles.
The Brookhattan soccer team scored its first American League victory of the season by defeating the Newark Germans at Starlight park yesterday. The score was 2 to 1.

Widespread acceptance of the principles of the New Deal is necessitating a change on the part of individuals from their former attitude of devotion to personal interest to one in which consideration for the public welfare is paramount, the Rev. Dr. Harry Emerson Fosdick declared yesterday in his sermon at Riverside Baptist Church, 122d Street and Riverside Drive.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 15 (AP) -- To speed the development of President Roosevelt's plans for housing an feeding the destitute, his aides in the administration are proceeding as rapidly as possible toward creation of the proposed Federal Housing Corporation.

COPENHAGEN, Oct. 15 -- The growing tension in the German-Danish borderland worries the Danes and their government. Premier Thorvald Stauning, the towering red-bearded, bass-voiced cigar roller who became the leader of the Social Democrats and the strong man of the North, is the anti-thesis of the diminutive Chancellor Dollfuss of Austria, but he faces a similar situation growing out of persistent Nazi agitation in South Jutland.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 15 -- Impending foreclosures on 2,451 urban homes valued at $6,991,006 were prevented as a result of its activities during the week ended Oct. 6, according to an announcement made today by the Home Owners Loan Corporation, based on reports from State and branch offices.

CHICAGO, Oct, 15 -- Medium and light weight hogs are being taken liberally here by packers and are in good supply. For more than a month packers preferred light hogs, but many now want medium weights and are paying $3.90 to $4.35 a hundredweight for them, while for 400 to 500 found packers; they pay $3.30 to $3.70.

LOS ANGELES, Oct. 15 -- Hollywood will retain its high salaries. Existing, contracts preclude any possibility of a drastic change. There is doubt that the NRA code will exert any influence in the long run. It is being fought tooth and nail by various factions in the industry, even to the producing organization in so far as it concerns salary regulation.

Seated on benches at the south crosswalk of the parkway in Broadway at Eighty-eighth Street, three men and a woman basked in the warm noon sun yesterday and watched the steady stream of motor traffic flowing swiftly at both sides.

MUNICH, Oct. 15 -- Chancellor Adolf Hitler, who yesterday led Germany out of the family of nations, today laid the cornerstone of Germany's "House of German Art" in this art capital. The building is intended to become the symbol of Germany's cultural unity.

MUNICH, Oct. 15 -- The opening night of Gerhart Hauptmann's latest drama, "The Golden Harp," was turned into a great ovation for the aged poet. Public acclaim centred on a work that he himself had characterized as "a very modest piece."

BERLIN, Oct. 15 -- Before dawn today billboards throughout Germany were displaying a huge cerise poster carrying the government's election proclamation ending with the question which four weeks hence the electorate can only answer in the affirmative.

DOYLESTOWN, Pa., Oct. 15 -- The "revitalization of American industry" will go down in history as one of the greatest accomplishments of President Roosevelt's administration, Herbert D. Allman of Philadelphia, president of the National Farm School, asserted today at the thirty-sixth annual meeting and harvest festival of the school.

EAST ORANGE, N.J., Oct. 15 -- Max Hochberg and Sidney Silodor of Newark won this afternoon the pair championship in the closed New Jersey State championship bridge tournament. With 312 match points of a possible 506 top, Mr. Hochberg and Mr. Silodor won on the basis of their joint score for last night and today.

BOISE, Idaho, Oct. 15 -- Senator William E. Borah said today: "We are facing the possibility of another war." Commenting on Germany's withdrawal from the arms conference and the League of Nations, he declared the situation "can be charged to no single nation."
Plans were announced yesterday for establishment of the Rockefeller Center Bonded Warehouse, which will occupy underground space in the midtown commercial and amusement development.

NIAGARA FALLS, N.Y., Oct. 15 -- Niagara University and St. Bonaventure played an exciting 20-to-20 tie contest before 5,000 today, leaving the title of Little Three champion and the Bishop Turney Trophy undisturbed.
PARIS, Oct. 15 -- A policy of watchful precaution with regard to Germany is urged upon France in most of the comment in the Paris press today.

BERLIN, Oct. 14 -- Dr. Schacht, president of the Reichsbank, although closely associated with the Hitlerites, and sympathizing with their crusade aganist international capital, has good reasons for maintaining for the present the July agreement to transfer 50 per cent of the bond interest.

The annual fund-raising campaign to provide by private contribution for the budgets of ninety-one organizations depending on the Federation for the Support of Jewish Philanthropic Societies in this city was opened last night at a dinner at the Hotel Commodore attended by more than 1,000 persons.

Assets of approximately $18,000,00,000 at the end of 1932 were reported by the fifty-three life insurance companies doing business in his State, according to a report made public yesterday by George S. an Schaick, State Superintendent of Insurance.
PITTSBURGH, Pa., Oct. 15 -- Western Pennsylvania's coal fields were settling down today for a Winter of work, with even the irritating "captive" mine question nearing solution.

HARRISON, N.Y., Oct. 15 -- Rexina Royal, a beautiful 7-year-old chestnut mare, captured the major honors in the Harrison Junior Horse Show held today at the Kentucky Riding Stable ring. Owned by Charles F. Henry of Devon, Pa., and ridden by Mrs. Henry, the mare won two blue ribbons and a red.

Reports of several sales in Brooklyn served to enliven the real estate market in the metropolitan district over the week-end. The properties involved included an apartment building and a number of single-family dwellings.

A man who described himself as Sam Transky, 26 years old, of 947 Montgomery Street, Brooklyn, was shot through the back and seriously wounded last night, when he tried to escape from two detectives who surprised him while walking through Eighty-second Street near Shore Road, Brooklyn, with a woman's mink coat over his arm.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 15 -- The National Civil Service Reform League, through W.W. Montgomery, chairman of its executive committee, has urged President Roosevelt to direct Harry M. Durning, Collector of the Port of New York, to refrain from acting as campaign manager for Joseph V. McKee, Recovery Party candidate in the New York Mayoralty race.

GENEVA, Oct. 15 -- Assertions that Germany's withdrawal from the League of Nations and the disarmament conference make it "more necessary than ever" that the conference should continue and offer Germany substantial disarmament and economic sanctions against violators were cheered again and again at an imposing international manifestation held in the Salle de la Reformation here tonight.

ROME, Oct. 15 -- The necessity of an immediate postponement sine die of the disarmament conference and a re-examination of the whole armament problem in a more suitable atmosphere is an immediate consequence of the bombshell Adolf Hitler exploded yesterday, in the view of official Italian circles.

CHICAGO, Oct. 15 -- Chicago will be host this week to the annual conference of the American Library Association, assembling about 3,000 persons, those who write books, those who read them, those who buy and those who dispense them through libraries of the world.

CHICAGO, Oct. 15 -- Strenuous efforts are being put forth in this territory by manufacturers, wholesalers and retailers, particularly the last, to stimulate business, and while the results have varied, their efforts have been rewarded by returns moderately in excess of those of previous weeks.

CHICAGO, Oct. 15 (AP) -- Federal authorities, fresh from smashing the Urschel and other kidnapping rings, today plunged into the search for William Walton Hall, law student and heir, who has been in the hands of kidnappers since Friday night.

"Home Safety Week" will open in the Bellevue-Yorkville Health Demonstration area today in an effort to cut down the number of accidents in homes. The drive will be under the supervision of Savel Zimand, administrative director of the demonstration, and an effort will be made to reach every adult in the district.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 15 -- Formation of a deposit liquidation division of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation to assist in the release of deposits in closed banks was announced today by President Roosevelt as the latest development in the administration program to stimulate credit expansion and increase purchasing power.

MOSCOW, Oct. 15 -- With timely haste the Soviet Government tonight through Premier Vyacheslaf Molotoff replied to the request of Viscount Cecil of Chelwood for its views on the question of disarmament.

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, Oct. 15 -- Grains continued this week their decline from the already low records of the previous week in sympathy with the lower markets in Chicago and Liverpool. Wheat here is now under 5 pesos a quintal, which affects the psychology of the Argentine farmers the same as lower than 50 cents a bushel affects growers in the United States.

NEW YORK. Dr. and Mrs. James C. Ayer, who passed the Summer and Autumn at Shadowland, Glen Cove, are expected today at the Pierre, where they will be until they go to Ayerdale, their Winter home in Nassau, N.P.

The Fusion movement is merely a Republican stalking horse designed to elect a Republican Governor next year and to make Ogden L. Mills President in 1936, Charles Solomon, Socialist candidate for Mayor, charged last night.

The accurate passing of Benny Friedman proved too much for the Cincinnati Reds at Ebbets Field yesterday and enabled the Brooklyn Dodgers to gain an easy 27-to-0 victory in a National Professional Football League contest before a crowd of 12,000.

The outstanding spiritual fact of our day is the shattering of men's self-confidence, the Rev. Dr. Henry Sloane Coffin, president of Union Theological Seminary, said in a sermon yesterday morning. Dr. Coffin was guest preacher at the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church, Madison Avenue and Seventy-third Street.

CHICAGO, Oct. 15 -- Prices of wheat on the Board of Trade here declined 10 3/4 to 12 1/2 cents a bushel, corn 3 1/3 cents and oats 4 7/3 to 5 1/3 cents in the face of the shortest crops in more than thirty years. Rye dropped 5 7/8 to 6 cents and barley was off 6 cents.

The drive of the Fusion candidates continued yesterday, with speeches by F.H. LaGuardia, nominee for Mayor; Langdon W. Post, candidate for President of the Borough of Manhattan; W. Arthur Cunningham, candidate for Controller, and Jacob Gould Schurman Jr., nominee for District Attorney of New York County.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Steps are being taken to form an organization of brokers to fight extreme curbs on their business and end public hostility. The purpose of this organization will be to dispel the many popular misconceptions about the brokerage business and to do away with the harsh and unjust criticisms that have been raised against them within recent times.

An unusually high registration almost equaling the record total established in 1932 was hailed yesterday by leaders of anti-Tammany groups as open evidence that the voters of the city were determined to end the reign of the O'Brien administration at City Hall.

Henry Harmon, cashier of Ye Eat Shoppe, at 734 Eighth Avenue, near Forty-fifth Street, successfully resisted two gunmen who held him up early yesterday morning, although the waiter who aided him was wounded seriously. Less than half an hour later, faced with a suspect, Harmon dropped dead.

Tammany, according to an announcement from campaign headquarters last night, begins its campaign in earnest this week. Hundreds of speakers will be on the firing lines in all boroughs, and bands and radio addresses will be used to whip up enthusiasm for the regular Democratic ticket.

Nearly 5,000 shoe workers in the metropolitan area, who have been on strike for eight weeks, will return to their jobs today in conformity with the boot and shoe manufacturers' code just signed by President Roosevelt. The workers will receive increases in pay as well as a reduction in their hours of labor.

Reformation of the city's machinery for workmen's compensation Insurance, with substantial budget savings and better treatment for injured employes as twin goals, is under consideration by Samuel Untermyer, special adviser to the Board of Estimate.

Trade associations and chambers of commerce throughout the country are arranging to assume a number of functions formerly carried on by the Bureau of Foreign and Domestic Commerce under the United States Department of Commerce, according to a statement issued yesterday by E. P. Thomas, president of the National Foreign Trade Council.

The bankers' code of fair competition will become effective today. It contains provisions for most of the reforms of the present banking system that are desired by the public, the government and the bankers alike, according to F.N. Shepherd, executive manager of the American Bankers Association.

Sharp breaks occurred last week in all commodities traded on local exchanges, principally as a result of indications that the administration had committed itself to a non-inflationary policy and the consequent strength in the dollar. Trading was in fair volume.

ITHACA, N.Y., Oct. 15 -- Nine Southwestern Owls believed to be types of a species new to science are on their way to Cornell University, Dr. George M. Sutton, curator of birds at Cornell, said today on his return from two joint Cornell-Carnegie Institute scientific expeditions.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 15 -- Opening the Four Weeks 1933 Mobilization for Human Needs, a drive for funds to help care for the unemployed this Winter, President Roosevelt called on the nation tonight to be liberal in private charity despite the fact that the government was increasing its aid.

LOS ANGELES, Oct. 15 (AP) -- Mose Barnett, 38, said by a detective lieutenant to be connected with the abduction of Charles F. Urschel in Oklahoma, was arrested yesterday as he watched a football game here. Turned over to Department of Justice agents, Barnett was taken to an outlying town for questioning.

CROTON-ON-HUDSON, N.Y., Oct. 15 -- A log-cabin camp, gift from the alumnae to Barnard College, was dedicated here this afternoon. A bronze key was turned over by Miss Helen Erskine, president of the Associate Alumnae, to Dean Virginia C. Gildersleeve, who in turn preesnted it to Miss Margaret Holland, faculty chairman of the camp.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 15 -- Dissent to some of the remarks made by General Johnson before the American Federation of Labor is voiced by Matthew Woll, vice president of the federation, in a letter to Frank Powers of Chicago, president of the Commercial Telegraphers Union of North America.
Builders and building material men are pinning their chief hope of an early grain in construction work on the Federal program and are watching developments in Washington eagerly.

The Merchants Association of New York has asked Governor Lehman to intercede with the Foreign Relations Committee of the United States Senate to withhold ratifipation of the St. Lawrence waterway development treaty until a competent American commission can report on its potential effect on American commerce and industry, the association announced yeserday.

PARIS, Oct. 14 -- The index number for wholesale prices in September compiled by the Statistique Generale, is 386, comparing with 394 for August and with 397 for September, 1932, and an average for 1932 of 407. Native products averaged 433 in September, unchanged from August, and comparing with 445 in 1932.

Now Sounding Familiar. Until last week many old-timers in this city doubted if a municipal campaign was really going on.Things seemed very tame. No one was "hurling" charges. The various candidates were altogether too polite to each other.
"Homecoming Day," commemo-rating its 123d anniversary, was celebrated yesterday by the congregation of the Central Church of the Disciples of Christ, 142 West Eighty-first Street.

Mayor Jack Spero, confusion candidate for chief of the New York League of Locality Mayors, completely upset the plans and the equilibrium of Head Mayor Stitch McCarthy last night as the league's campaign began officially at a dinner in Mayor Lou G. Siegel's restaurant at 209 West Thirty-eighth Street.

PARIS, Oct. 15 -- It is occasionally asked exactly how prices in France were affected by the legal devaluation of the franc in 1928. The process was difficult to follow, because the franc's international valuation had long been depreciating, and in 1926, when the public stopped buying defense bonds, actual panic over the currency broke out.

A procession of Knights Templar in full regalia, bearing American and British flags, wound through the historic churchyard of St. Paul's Chapel, Broadway and Fulton Street, yesterday afternoon to inaugurate the twelfth annual British harvest festival.

CONSERVATISM was the keynote on Saturday. But in some areas the action was too conservative. Yale Washington and Lee, 0. Brown, 13; Springfield 6 Penn, 9; Franklin and Marshall, 0. Perhaps the big fellows were just saving themselves. But it looses like downright hoarding.

Absence of outstanding improvement in general business, the rise in the exchange value of the dollar, an increase in the government's estimate of the cotton crop, and a decrease in the rate of domestic consumption of cotton led last week to an extension of the downward movement of the prices for cotton.
LONDON, Oct. 15 -- Sir Lancelot Carnegie, former Ambassador to Lisbon, died here at the age of 71.
PITTSFIELD, Mass., Oct. 15 -- Dr. and Mrs. Austen Fox Biggs of The Knoll, Stockbridge, gave a dinner last night in compliment to the Medical Advisory Board of the Austen Fox Riggs Foundation.

TOKYO, Monday, Oct. 16 -- Government circles are closely watching the effects upon Russia of Germany's action, in which far-sighted observers see a possibility of changes favorable to Japan's policy in the Far East.

PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 15 -- Justifying Germany's demand for limited rearmament, Raymond Leslie Buell, research director of the Foreign Policy Association, in a statement issued today at his home at 83 Mercer Street. Princeton, criticized the United States and the former Allies for having allowed the Geneva conference to crash upon a "relatively minor issue."
The charge of anti-Semitism against Joseph V. McKee, independent candidate for Mayor, indirectly expressed by F.H. LaGuardia, his Fusion opponent, found a sponsor yesterday in Samuel Untermyer.

New York University's victory over Lafayette's football team at the Yankee Stadium last Saturday was a costly one, it was revealed yesterday. The Violet is faced with the prospect of playing the remainder of the season without the services of Harry Temple, its captain.

The belief that the influence of American business interests in Cuba have had a detrimental effect on Cuban social and political life is a misconception widely held throughout the United States, the Right Rev. Hiram Richard Hulse, Bishop of Cuba, declared in a sermon at St. Bartholomew's Episcopal Church, Park Avenue at Fiftieth Street, yesterday morning.
Rentals on the upper east side and in the Washington Square area made up a large part of the apartment leasing activity reported over the week-end. The tenants included the following:
CHICAGO, Oct. 15 (AP) -- Representatives of seventeen States will meet at Harrisburg, Pa., Friday to take the first step in a movement to end interstate truck and bus controversies.

The Vanderbilt Theatre has been selected for the opening on Thursday evening of "The Curtain Rises," a comedy by B.M. Kaye. It will be presented by Morris Green and Frank McCoy and was tried out during the week of Aug. 21 at the Boulevard Theatre, Jackson Heights.
BOSTON, Oct. 15 (AP) -- The right arm and right leg of Press Presnell today provided the Portsmouth Spartans with a 13-0 victory over the Boston Redskins before 20,000 at Fenway Park.

A faster, harder-hitting Philadelphia eleven routed the New York Field Hockey Association's team, 11 to 0, in an exhibition contest at Prospect Park, Brooklyn, yesterday. This was New York's first interassociation game and was attended by a crowd of 1,000.
HAVANA, Oct. 15 -- A student Homero Valdes, shot and killed a soldier, Joaquin Camejo, 28 years old, on a street corner tonight. Student and army circles were thrown into excitement.

Fifty-three life insurance companies represented in New York carry 80 per cent of the policies in force in the United States. Their financial position is thus a matter of national interest. It is briefly described in a statement issued today by Superintendent VAN SCHAICK, summarizing data which will appear in his report for 1933.

Due, it is understood, to a mistake in answering the bridge telegraph bells in the engine room, the steamship Ilsenstein, from Antwerp via Havre, crashed into Dock C, a steel and concrete pier at Weehawken. N.J., yesterday morning. The damage to the pier will cost 150,000 to repair.
HALIFAX, N.S., Oct. 15 (AP) -- Busy with breakfast, Dr. Albert Einstein came back to America today with a studied silence and a keen interest in a soft-boiled egg.

The eve of the reopening of the Geneva arms conference presents only one hopeful fact, declared the Rev. Dr. William P. Merrill in his sermon yesterday morning at the Brick Presbyterian Church, at Fifth Avenue and Thirty-seventh Street.

Rationalism and reason returned to football on Saturday, and for the first time since the chaotic season got under way the prophet was able to walk among his fellow-men with head erect and honor restored.

LONDON, Oct. 14 -- The week ended with the dollar-sterling rate moving rather wildly. After falling to $4.54 to the pound it closed at $4.57 1/4 against $4.60 1/4 on Friday. The rise in the dollar was due largely to Continental bear covering, owing to the impression that the American Treasury's refunding operations definitely mark the end of dollar depreciation and bring stabilization appreciably nearer.

what is popularly known as the "Lame Duck" amendment to the Constitution went into full effect yesterday. It provided that the sections relating to the terms of office of the President and Vice President and of Senators and Representatives should take effect upon, the fifteenth day of October following ratification of the article.
WARWICK, N.Y., Oct. 15 -- The State Training School for Delinquent Boys was dedicated to New York State here this afternoon as "a laboratory for the study of human behavior."

THE Lord Fool of New York has broken loose again. We refer, of course, to Ogden Nash, whose "Happy Days" (Simon Schuster, $2), illustrated by the wonder man O. Soglow, is here to annoy that delightful fellow who once complained in The London Times Literary Supplement that Mr. Nash's verse "would be improved if the author took more care with his rhymes."

The American dollar was strong last week. Based on the French franc quotation, the dollar soared to 69.82 cents on Saturday, highest in one month. From the low of the week, 65.85, reached on Monday, to the top of 69.82, there was a gross gain of slightly less than 4 cents. Range a year ago was 99.98@99.63 cents.

Retail stocks were sufficiently ample to take care of the improved store business last week, with the result that only a small volume of reorders appeared in the local wholesale markets. In order to keep goods moving, merchants are working on the smallest margins possible.

A tremendous registration, generally interpreted as indicating a citywide revolt against Tammany; a surprising show of strength, for F.H. LaGuardia, Fusion candidate for Mayor, and a steady flow of support for Joseph V. McKee, independent candidate, most of it seemingly from Tammany, were the major developments in the city campaign last week.

The last meeting on the Jockey Club circuit will begin today when the Fall session of the Empire City Racing Association opens at the Yonkers course. Fifty-three horses have been entered in the six contests down for decision, with all of the fields well balanced.

One of the numerous unhappy products and by-products of Federal prohibition was the swamping of the Federal courts with petty cases. The calendars grew apoplectic with them. A sort of calendar-delivery, the disposal of big batches of them with small fines or remissions of fines, became the only method offering a little respite for the weary judges.
Appearing on their home gridiron for the first time this season, the New York Football Giants overwhelmed the Philadelphia Eagles in a National Professional League game yesterday, 56 to 0.

Men today are engaged in a desperate search for truth in an effort to achieve freedom of mind and soul, said the Rev. William V.H. Davies in a sermon yesterday morning in the Holy Trinity Lutheran Church, Central Park West and Sixty-fifth Street.

Unemployed men in Westchester County now can register for jobs on public works projects at the county office of the National Reemployment Service in the County Building at White Plains, W.H. Winans, New York State director of the service, announced yesterday.

Operating utility companies should not be allowed to sell and distribute any stocks or bonds unless directly secured by their own plant and properties, according to an opinion of Milo R. Maltbie, chairman of the Public Service Commission, made public yesterday.
PARIS, Oct. 15 -- Premier Daladier, who never moves or speaks without ripe deliberation, will as usual take his time before he replies to Chancellor Hitler's speech of yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 15 -- While the State Department today silently awaited further developments in Europe as a result of Germany's quitting the League of Nations and the disarmament conference, the Foreign Policy Association made public here a report of the measures taken by the Hitler government against the Jews and "other political opponents."

Current methods of determining the value, and efficiency of a teacher are largely subjective and show a low degree of reliability, it was said yesterday by Dr. Lloyd Percy Young, research graduate at Teachers College, Columbia University. Dr. Young reached this conclusion after a survey of the administration of merit teachers' salary schedules.

The thirtieth annual National Business Show will open at the Grand Central Palace this afternoon and continue until next Saturday night. Coincident with the opening the name of the young woman chosen "queen" of the exposition will be announced.

LONDON, Oct. 15 -- Chancellor Hitler is introducing more and more into foreign affairs the methods which have answered him well in the internal politics of Germany," says The London Times in commenting on Germany's withdrawal from the Disarmament Conference and the League of Nations.

Two inquiries of THE TIMES in letters to the editor concern the Reserve Banks' purchases of government securities. One of the questions is whether Reserve Banks buying government obligations pay for them by issuing new Reserve notes, or only by using those already in existence. To this the answer is that such notes are not used at all in payment for these purchases.

If Johann Strauss's melodic "Die Flederruaus" had no book the task of the modern producer would be much easier. He would not have to pretend that the book is roguish and that all the singers are imps. "Champagne, Sec," which was opened at the Morosco Saturday evening, is an attempt to make "Die Fledermaus," palatable as a book out of respect for the rapture of its music.

Mrs. Felix M. Warburg, who with Mrs. Sidney C. Borg heads the women's division of the Federation for the Support of Jewish Philanthropic Societies, will give a tea this afternoon at her home, 1,109 Fifth Avenue, to open that organization's part in the campaign for funds to carry on the work of the federation.

Half of the program given by the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, Bruno Walter, conductor, yesterday afternoon in Carnegie Hall was devoted to Wagner, the excerpts consisting of passages from the "Ring," with Paul Althouse and Elsa Alsen as soloists.

Registration last week in this city has been a six days' wonder. Presidential elections are commonly supposed to be the only magnet that will draw out the stay-at-home vote; this year it is plainly responding to the issues and excitements of a municipal campaign. Necessary as registration is in order to safeguard the integrity of the balilot, it is a troublesome formality for many.

New York City received from the State $46,173,006.85 for unemployment relief between Nov. 1, 1931, and Sept. 1, 1933, according to an official report submitted to Governor Lehman and the Legislature by Alfred H. Schoellkopf, chairman of the State Temporary Emergency Relief Administration, and made public yesterday.

A hard-riding First Division polo team from Fort Hamilton triumphed, over the Governors Island quartet, 12 to 3, in the third game of the annual series for the Colyer Cup before 4,000 spectators at Governors Island yesterday.

The best advice given at Geneva, when the German announcement fell there like a shell from Big Bertha, was to "keep cool." In the presence of an almost insanely excited Germany, other nations should strive to maintain their poise. They will require time and thought to take in the whole Significance of this German explosion and to study its consequences.

SUNNYVALE,Calif., Oct. 15 (AP) -- The silver-hued, Macon came to her home base today after spanning the nation from Lakehurst, N.J., in 70 hours and 17 minutes to the time when her nose was placed in the cup of the mooring mast here.

John Charles Thomas gave the first of his season's recitals at the Town Hall yesterday afternoon. It was a concert of many distinctions, like those the baritone has been giving during the past few years. Not the least impressive aspect was the capacity audience -- a large number of persons were turned away -- which came despite the severe competition of an Indian Summer out-of-doors.
To the Editor of The New York Times: Is Mr. McKee's candidacy for the benefit of the people of New York City?
GUAYAQUIL, Ecuador, Oct. 15 -- Interest in the attempt of Congress to oust President Martinez Mera was revived by his return here today.

CHICAGO, Oct. 15 (AP) -- The Chicago Bears, last year's professional football champions, today defeated the Chicago Cardinals, local rivals, by 12 to 9 before a crowd of about 12,000 at Wrigley Field. This marked the fourth victory for the Bears against no defeats, and strengthened their hold on the first place position.

LONDON, Oct. 14 -- Accumulating indications of reviving trade are having a very heartening effect on financial and business sentiment throughout the country. Steady improvement in the national revenue, as disclosed by the Exchequer returns, increase in employment, rising railway receipts, and an increasing money turnover, are evidence of this, while the latest and perhaps the most encouraging indication of better trade is the expansion of Great Britain's exports.

Fall styles in beauty were demonstrated yesterday at the opening of the convention of the New York Hairdressers and, Cosmetologists Association at the Hotel Astor. With more than 2,000 representatives of the beauty industry attending, the convention will continue through Thursday.

PARIS, Oct. 16. -- Importuned by legislators and the press to make a statement on the situation created by Germany's action in quitting the disarmament conference Premier Daladier may do so tomorrow when the Chamber of Deputies resumes its sittings.
The radio address of Joseph V. McKee over Station WABC last night follows:

WASHINGTON, Oct. 16. -- Representative Dickstein of New York, chairman of the House Immigration Committee, called on Secretary Hull today to discuss with him his committee's proposed investigation of alleged Nazi propaganda in the United States.
Clear and rather balmy weather greeted the duck hunters and the upland game hunters when shooting got under way yesterday.

EAST ORANGE, N.J., Oct. 16. -- Taking seven of the last ten boards played, the Orange Lawn Tennis Club foursome, in a spectacular finish, captured the team-of-four title in the concluding event of the five-day closed New Jersey State championship bridge tournament here.

TARRYTOWN, N.Y., Oct. 16. -- Sal Sava of Kings Ridge and Herman Barren, the professional at that club, triumphed in the one-day pro-amateur tourney staged by the Metropolitan Professional Golfers Association at the Rockwood Hall Country Club today.

BERLIN, Oct. 16. -- Under the auspices of the Ministry of Propaganda, Baron Constantin von Neurath, German Foreign Minister, assembled some 500 foreign correspondents and German political writers this evening at the Ministry's office in the Wilhelmstrasse and for three-quarters of an hour expounded to them the government's version pf its action at Geneva.
PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 16. -- Princeton engaged in a long drill on kicking and passing today in preparation for the Columbia game.

Further wide breaks took place In the local commodity markets yesterday in sympathy with general declines in other markets and the vigorous gains scored by the dollar. Trading was heavy as sellers crowded the markets. Cash prices continued their decline.

Plans for a citizens' committee to draw up a unified program for slum clearance and low-cost housing with government aid were perfected at a meeting of civic and welfare leaders in the City Club yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 16. -- In a sweeping gesture to eliminate unfair practices within the oil industry and to stabilize prices from the well to the consumer, Secretary Ickes issued an order today fixing the price of oil products throughout the entire country, effective Dec. 1.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 16. -- Plans for immediate purchases of large quantities of beef and butter for distribution among the destitute unemployed during the Winter were announced today by Harry L. Hopkins, Federal Emergency Relief Administrator.

ST. LOUIS, Oct. 16 (AP). -- Stating that the Eighteenth Amendment is "now on its last legs," Louis H. Breuer, United States District Attorney, today dismissed a charge of conspiracy to violate the Volstead Act against Heber Nations of Jefferson City, former State Labor Commissioner.

A section of English countryside, illustrative of the bird life of Northern Europe, was presented yesterday at the American Museum of Natural History. This New Forest group, which is the seventh of a series designed to depict bird life in the world's major fauna areas, was unveiled in the presence of museum officials and ornithologists.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 16. -- Steps to accelerate the release of $1,000,000,000 of the deposits tied up in banks which have closed since Jan. 1 were taken today at a meeting of the deposit liquidation board, the formation of which as a division of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation was announced last night by President Roosevelt.

GLEN RIDGE. N.J., Oct. 16. -- A best-ball score of 67, five under par, grave Mike Seaman and Bill Wollen of North Jersey an easy victory in a pf of essional-amateur competition held by the Professional Golfers Association of New Jersey today at the Glen Ridge Country Club.

JOSEF RADETZKY, a veteran of Marengo, Wagram and other smoky battles of the Napoleonic wars, was one of the military glories of the now defunct Austro-Hungarian Empire. He lived to be over 90 and died in harness. For years he fought the red-tape artists who taught that military science, like the Rock of Ages, never changed.

A city highway authority and a municipal housing authority to work in cooperation with the Federal Government on construction projects were proposed yesterday by Langdon W. Post, Fusion candidate for Manhattan Borough President.
The Irving Trust Company reported yesterday to a Congressional subcommittee and the United States District Court upon its activities as Federal receiver and trustee in bankruptcy cases.

Never before has the librarian been in public demand so much as in these days of unemployment for millions and of larger marginal leisure for millions more. Thus the annual gathering of the American Library Association in Chicago takes on an even greater importance than usual.

Selling of stocks and commodities which bad been accumulated when Inflation of the currency seemed to be probable in the last few months weakened the cotton as well as other markets yesterday and prices on the Cotton Exchange closed at the bottom, 40 to 48 points lower than Saturday.

Leasing of stores on the east side of Manhattan constituted a feature of commercial rentals reported by brokers yesterday. Retail space on Lexington Avenue appeared to be in brisk demand, and stores on Broadway also were taken. The leases were made by a variety of concerns, ranging from beauty-parlor operators to tailoring establishments.
PHILADELPHIA, Pa., Oct. 16. -- Art J. Smith, "Commanding General" of the Khaki Shirts of America, Inc., came out of hiding today and surrendered to the police on a fraudulent conversion charge.

Major Alexander P. de Seversky, holder of the amphibian speed record, flew from College Point, Queens, to a point a few miles below Wilmington yesterday, dragging, unknown to himself, a rope tail 200 feet long below his speedy plane.

If HITLER expected that his brusque attack upon the Disarmament Conference would cause it at once to give up the ghost, he is already undeceived. It is to carry on. The reply which its chairman, Mr. ARTHUR HENDERSON, at once sent to the abrupt notification by the German Government was polite but pointed.

The Appellate Division of the Supreme Court affirmed yesterday the decision of Justice Cotillo directing the Board of Elections to accept the nominating certificates of the five Republican nominees for the Supreme Court in New York and Bronx Counties, and the Fusion nomination of Justice Frederic Kernochan of Special Sessions for General Sessions.

GENEVA, Oct. 16. -- Arthur Henderson, President of the Disarmament Conference, emphasized in two addresses today that efforts to complete a disarmament treaty must be speeded because of the disturbed condition of Europe. He made a radio broadcast to the United States and spoke to a delegation from peace societies.

CHICAGO, Oct. 16. -- Owing to cuts in funds for books and salaries, makeshift economies, increased public demand and general bewilderment, librarians know they are facing a change, but do not know what the direction will be, Harry Miller Lydenberg of the New York Public Library told the annual convention of the American Library Association tonight.

CHESTER, Pa., Oct. 16. -- One man received a broken leg and several others were cut and bruised when several hundred men who returned to work today at the Ford Motor Company's assembly plant here were attacked as they started for home.

HAMILTON, N.Y., Oct. 16. -- In an attempt to strengthen the team that will face N.Y.U. in Yankee Stadium Saturday, Coach Andy Kerr of Colgate today shifted Lew Brooke of Flushing to left tackle, in place of the injured Warren Davis, who cannot play for at least two weeks.

The question of whether the 5 cents paid by each taxicab passenger to the city's fund for unemployment relief under the recent municipal law is a tax or a fee was argued before Supreme Court Justice Albert Cohn yesterday. Justice Cohn is hearing a suit by the United Taxicab Board of Trade and others to ha e the act declared illegal.

CINCINNATI, Oct. 16 (AP). -- Mrs. John S. Sheppard of New York told women Republican leaders of the nation today that a system of graded licenses, making liquor harder to get than beer or wine, will be the only solution of liquor control if and when prohibition is repealed.

Alice Roosevelt Longworth has rewritten her book of reminiscences, "My Crowded Hour," since its magazine serialization. She has added more chapters and the book has lengthened from about 70,000 words to more than 100,000. It is also considerably more outspoken, it is said.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 16. -- The New York Stock Exchange today refused to require members of the Exchange to reply to the questionnaire of the Senate Banking and Currency subcommittee investigating Stock Exchange practices.

Domestic production of newly mined copper in September amounted to approximately 17,500 tons, compared with 17,000 tons in August, according to estimates in the trade. Production from scrap copper, however, was unchanged at 15,500 tons in each month.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 16. -- The United States will hold aloof from the int r-capital conferences which will take place in Europe this week, it was learned today. Officials here apparently believe that these discussions will be of such a purely European political character that no useful purpose would be served by the participation of Norman H. Davis, Ambassador at Large and

BISMARCK, N. D., Oct. 16. -- Governor William Langer late today signed a proclamation prohibiting shipment of wheat from North Dakota. It will be effective at mid-night Wednesday and continue indefinitely.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Oct. 16. -- The Rev. Joseph Ellsworth Curry, 71 years old, of Cranbury, N.J., was elected moderator of the Synod of New Jersey, Presbyterian Church in the U.S.A., at the opening session of its annual meeting here today.

BERLIN, Oct. 16. -- Germany's withdrawal from the League of Nations and the Disarmament Conference dominated the financial markets here today. The Boerse responded to the government's action with a sinking spell which depressed stock quotations generally between 2 and 3 per cent and in some cases up to 5 per cent.

The second Byrd expedition to the Antarctic, which made a definite start with the sailing of the 11,000-ton freighter Jacob Ruppert, should reach the Bay of Whales Defore Christmas or in the Summer season, when explorations can be made by plane or with dogs and motor traction.

LAUREL, Md., Oct. 16 (AP). -- R.J. Tubbs's Cutie Face, a 3-year-old daughter of Chilhowee and No Regrets, bred in Kentucky, handily defeated four others of her age and sex over the six furlongs of the Anne Arundel Purse, feature at Laurel today.

No attempt has been made to treat Moliere reverently in "The School for Husbands," which the Theatre Guild mounted at the Empire last evening. In the opinion of this lawless column that is a good thing. For Moliere's classical morality of the same title is, according to modern standards, a meagre and commonplace exercise.

LONDON, Oct. 16. -- The shock of Germany's withdrawal from Geneva failed today to upset the financial community here, although sentiment was depressed by the darkening clouds of political uncertainty over Europe. Except for a marked rise in armaments shares and a slump in German bonds, the stock market preserved almost unruffled calm.

The proposed meeting between Equipoise and Winooka appears to be off. Rufe Naylor, manager of the Australian horse's tour, sent a telegram yesterday to C.V. Whitney, owner of Equipoise, declining to run his charge at a mile.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 16. -- Indications on Soldiers Field today were that when the Harvard football team starts against Holy Cross on Saturday the line-up will be the same as it was against New Hampshire.

PARIS, Oct. 16. -- The dollar and the pound sterling rose sharply today on the foreign exchange market here, along with the gold currencies of other "neutral countries" as a result of Germany's desertion of Geneva. Responding to the psychological stimulus of an ultimate war threat, the dollar, which closed on Friday at 17.16 francs, opened this morning at 18.10 and touched its highest point at 18.50 at noon.

NEW ORLEANS, Oct. 16. -- Senator Huey P. Long was booed, heckled and hissed during his speech at the South Louisiana State Fair at Donaldsonville yesterday, especially when he assailed President Roosevelt.

On the eve of the opening of the Tammany campaign tonight at Tammany Hall, the organization had had no word from former Governor Alfred E. Smith Or United States Senators Robert F. Wagner and Royal S. Copeland that they intended to participate in the rally.
The National Academy of Design innounced yesterday the establishment of two funds totaling $228,000 intended to further the study and appreciation of mural painting in this country.

HASTINGS-ON-HUDSON, N.Y., Oct. 16. -- Miss Jane K. Fraser, last of the children of the late Thomas Fraser, New York merchant and benefactor of this village, died yesterday of a heart attack at her Summer home, Lovat, on South Broadway.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 16. -- Head Coach Root of the Yale football team today indicated his starting line-up for the Brown game Saturday by using the combination that defeated Washington and Lee last Saturday.

Three more former directors of the defunct Bank of United States testified yesterday at the trial of Isidor J. Kresel, former counsel for the bank, that they knew nothing of the $8,000,000 lent by the bank to three affiliates in 1929 until after the loans had been made.

At the informal football dinnei presided over by Dave Stnyth at the Coluipbia University Club last week the question came up as to the benefits or disadvantages accruing to a big college team in opening its season against major opposition.

Speaking before two audiences in Queens, composed largely of small home owners, F.H. LaGuardia, Fusion candidate for Mayor, declared that a recent boast of the present city administration that there had been a reduction of $1,500,000,000 in the assessment of real property for taxation purposes was a deception.

The successes of the colorbearers of Mrs. S.H. Fairbanks in the past few weeks continued yesterday, when her Playing On captured the race which had the place of honor on the opening-day program at Empire City. Playing On Is a daughter of Sweep On and Playing High, and was the first favorite to score during the afternoon.

The report of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company for the nine months ended on Sept. 30 shows net income of $101,225,317, equal to $5.42 a share on 18,662,275 capital shares, comparing with $110,704,774 for the 1932 period, equal to $5.93 a share on the capital stock.

CHICAGO, Oct. 16 (AP). -- Captain Red, racing in the colors of C.E. Davison, won the Inaugural Purse at Sportsman's Park today in a spectacular nose finish over Miss Melody. Help Yourself finished third in the seven-furlong event.

Police Commissioner Bolan announced yesterday that, to forestall any charges by candidates of police favoritism, every patrolman in the city would be shifted on election day to a borough other than that in which he works normally.

For years there have been efforts to bring about closer relations between the American Bar Association and the local and State associations and between the two latter. They have not been successful. In a general way it may be said that the three classes of societies have gone each its own road.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 16. -- The rubber tire industry presented its code of fair competition today to the National Recovery Administration. The code, it was stated by its proponents, reflects only the views of the industry and none of the provisions are to be regarded as having received the approval of the Recovery Administration.

MUKDEN, Manchuria, Tuesday, Oct. 17. -- Preliminary negotiations marking the first large incursion of foreign capital into Manchukuo have been concluded between Vice President Hatta of the South Manchuria Railway and Andre d' Olivier, a representative of French capitalists.

MOSCOW, Oct. 16. -- The Soviet press abandoned today its reserve about Germany's exit from Geneva, and both the Pravda and Izvestia devote their leading editorials to the subject. The Izvestia's editorial occupies almost the whole of the front page.

CHICAGO, Oct. 16. -- Liquidation was resumed today in the markets for grains, provisions and other commodities on the Board of Trade, and while the grains made a strong rally after an early decline, a break developed and wheat, rye and barley dropped 5 cents a bushel from Saturday's closing prices, the maximum permitted under the regulations of the Exchange.
GENEVA, Oct. 16. -- Dr. Salvador De Madariaga of Spain, before adjournment of the disarmament conference today, asked what the conference expected to do when it resumed Oct. 26.

The women's division of the Federation for the Support of Jewish Philanthropic Societies opened its campaign yesterday at a meeting at the home of Mrs. Felix M. Warburg, 1,109 Fifth Avenue. Mrs. Warburg is co-chairman of the women's drive with Mrs. Sidney C. Borg.

An agreement to send back to work about 6,000 boot and shoe workers who have been on strike for nine weeks was signed yesterday at the office of the local NRA organization by the Shoe Manufacturers Board of Trade and the Boot and Shoe Workers' Union, an A.F. of L. organization.

A charge that F.H. LaGuardia, the Fusion candidate for Mayor, was allied with a group that sought to destroy American capitalism through the united action of radical parties was made last night by Lloyd Paul Stryker, lawyer and historian, and speaker for Joseph V. McKee's Recovery Party.

The shipping industry acted yesterday to settle the problem of the rights of labor under the terms of the proposed code for shipping, while other shippers' groups and independent ship lines announced that they were prepared to fight the code already submitted to the National Recovery Administration by the American Steamship Owners Association.

An undertaker, one of four men charged with murdering Michael Malloy, a derelict stationary engineer, for $1,788 insurance, took the stand in his own defense yesterday. The trial is being held before Judge James M. Barrett in Bronx County Court.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Oct. 16. -- The trial of a nuisance suit against Justice of the Peace Wilbur K. Hitchcock of Mount Pleasant and his wife, Mrs. Hope Robinson Hitchcock, took on a touch of realism this afternoon when Dr. F.R. Cook, a New York X-ray specialist, accommodated the court by barking to illustrate the annoying vocal characteristics of a certain one of the forty-odd English sheep dogs kept by Mrs. Hitchcock.

NEWARK, N.J., Oct. 16. -- A meeting of the Friends of the New Germany, the reputed Nazi organization for propaganda in the United States, broke up here tonight in a near-riot outside of Schwabenhalle, 593 Springfield Avenue. A body-guard of nearly a dozen men, steering Heinz Spanknoebel, president, was attacked, and a free-for-all fight ensued as 800 persons attending the meeting encountered nearly 1,000 assembled outside the hall.

LONDON, Oct. 16. -- The British Government hopes that in the nine days intervening between now and the date to which the Bureau of the Disarmament Conference has been adjourned, some way may be found to persuade Germany to return to the Geneva negotiations.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 16. -- The filing with the Federal Trade Commission of twenty additional registration statements of issues under the Securities Act was announced today. They amount to about $11.000,000, bringing the grand total of such registrations to date to $266,000,000.

The first public meeting of the recently formed National Laymen's Back-to-Church Movement will be held in Town Hall on Saturday evening, Oct. 28. Protestants, Jews and Roman Catholics will participate. The movement will be nonsectarian.

HAVANA, Oct. 16. -- Members of the Student Directorate today detained Colonel Juan Cruz Bustillo, chief of Cabanas Fortress during the Machado regime, as he attempted to leave Havana by airplane for Miami this afternoon.
ALBANY, Oct. 16 (AP). -- Mrs. William S. Clarkson, 24 years old, of Yonkers was killed today by a fall from the roof of the home of her father, George J. Hatt 2d, an attorney.
"Ten Minute Alibi," the London success by Anthony Armstrong, will have its Broadway premiere this evening at the Ethel Barrymore Theatre, under the management of Crosby Gaige and Lee Shubert.

Alan G. Villiers, author and owner of the four-masted bark Parma, which won the annual grain race from Australia to England last May after making the passage round Cape Horn in eighty-three days, arrived, yesterday from London on the American Farmer of the American Merchant Line.

State of Louisiana. The State of Louisiana awarded yesterday a new issue of $2,500,000 of 5 per cent highway bonds to the Union Bond and Mortgage Company of Baton Rouge, La. The bonds are dated Oct. 15, 1932, and mature $500,000 annually from 1936 to 1940.

Mary Jane Dane, 16 years old, a high school student, shot and killed herself yesterday in a rooming house at 101 West Forty-third Street because fellow-students had made jests about her weight, her mother told Detective Michael Ward.

CHICAGO, Oct. 16. -- A bound volume of sample copies of proposed miniature editions of THE NEW YORK TIMES to supplant the full-size rag-paper editions which the newspaper has been issuing since Jan. 1. 1927, attracted the attention today of delegates to the American Library Association.

BERLIN, Oct. 16 (AP). -- Testimony regarding an underground passage from the Reichstag building to the official residence of Aviation Minister Hermann Wilhelm Goering provided a new sensation today in the trial of five men on charges of setting fire to the Reichstag building last Winter.
GENEVA, Oct. 16. -- The disarmament conference adjourned today for ten days, until Oct. 26, to allow the European powers to take stock of the situation created by Germany's withdrawal.

The Brooklyn Democratic district leaders failed to get their show-down yesterday on the O'Brien and McKee Mayoralty candidacies because of the illness of the county Jefferson Building, 4-5 Court Square, for seven minutes, but no action was taken.

Wall Street appraised yesterday's, share market as an exceptional one, in which the usual speculative impulses were not operating. The conclusion everywhere was that traders had been obliged to orient themselves after a bewildering series of developments.

Joseph V. McKee, independent candidate for Mayor, denied last night that he had any racial or religious prejudice, and denounced F.H. LaGuardia, his Fusion opponent, for having injected the issue into the campaign.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 16. -- Foreclosures averted in New York State as a result of activities of the Home Owners Loan Corporation number 318, representing mortgages of $1,911,278, the corporation announced today.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 16. -- A strike in steel mills at Weirton, W. Va., was settled today, the strikers agreeing to go back to work tomorrow without outright recognition of their union.

BUENOS AIRES, Oct. 16. -- Two nephews of President Getulio Vargas of Brazil were killed last night when Argentine sailors attached to the Harbor Master's Office at Santo Tome, Province of Corrientes, repelled an attack of a party of armed Brazilians trying to land In Argentine territory from a launch.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 16. -- Charges made by John Collier, Commissioner of Indian Affairs, that conditions at the Canton (S.D.) Federal Hospital for Insane, where a number of Indians are incarcerated, were "intolerable and filthy," today led Secretary Ickes to dismiss summarily Dr. Harry K. Hummer, superintendent of the institution.

Tax rates upon the liquor trade after repeal should embody the principle of a tax upon the profits of manufacturers and distributers, the report of the post-prohibition study made under the auspices of John D. Rockefeller Jr. declared.

To the National Recovery Act, with its shorter work week and increased demands upon executives for more comprehensive statistics and records, was attributed the sharp upturn in the sales of business equipment in the last few months, by officials of the leading companies exhibiting at the National Business Show, which opened yesterday at the Grand Central Palace.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 16. -- In order to determine the correct tax liability of individuals engaged in speculative stock activities, brokers will be required to render returns showing the names of customers and details of their profits, losses or other information indicating income taxes due.

YONKERS, N.Y., Oct. 16. -- James Kershaw Cuddy, secretary of the corporation, of Oppenheim, Colling Co., merchants of New York, and a member of the New York bar, died today at his residence, 268 Van Cortlandt Park Avenue, Yonkers, after a long illness.

Reorders Spotty Here. A spotty situation featured the start of the week in the wholesale markets here yesterday. Reorders came through for a substantial variety of goods from merchants in some centres, while others placed little or no additional business.

Although repeal is still nearly two months away, the seven distilleries of the National Distillers Products Corporation are already working at capacity, Seton Porter, president of the concern, announced yesterday. The annual capacity of the plants is 32,000,000 gallons of rye and bourbon whisky.

GENEVA, Oct. 16. -- The disarmament conference's general commission decided this afternoon to tell Germany that her reasons for with drawal from the parley were invalid. In view of the new sitution caused by Germany's with-drawal, it merely noted the Simon program recommended by the conference's bureau Saturday and agreed to adjourn until Oct. 26, with the bureau meeting Oct. 25.
H.J. Cox, shipping surveyor for Lloyd's in the Far East, arrived yesterday on the Cunard liner Samaria en route to Kobe, Japan, after a three-month holiday in England.

A woman and her brother were arrested for violation of the Sullivan law after she had shot herself accidentally yesterday in their home at 2,323 Walton Avenue, the Bronx. They were Mrs. Gertrude Wicks, 40 years old, a widow, and Samuel Fassler, 38.
RENO, Nev., Oct. 16. -- Millicent Pierce Kemp obtained a divorce today from David W. Kemp of New York, on a charge of cruelty. A property Agreement was made part of the record.
The Brooklyn laundry racket trial was enlivened yesterday by the story of an alleged offer of a 2,500 bribe and by the mention of the names of two city officials during the day's hearing.

BERLIN, Oct. 16. -- In the face of the intensive boycott movement against German goods in many countries, the Reich Statistical Office announced today that the foreign trade balance for September was the best of the year. September exports surpassed those of the previous year.

Bond prices fell sharply yesterday on the Stock Exchange, with the exception of United States Government issues which finished irregularly higher. The break in THE NEW YORK TIMES average of forty representative domestic corporation bonds was the widest since Sept. 21.

A city-wide investigation to determine to what extent New York City business houses are participating in the NRA program will be launched soon, it was announced last night by Grover A. Whalen, NRA administrator for the City of New York, at the new headquarters of the local NRA, 45 Broadway.

The American Hebrew, a Jewish weekly, has taken up the question of secondary education that was outlined in the article, "A Serious Problem," which appeared in the May number of The Catholic World. Although the article was of moment primarily to Catholics, it pointed out a state of affairs that might well take up the attention of the Jewish people.

Ever since Jim O'Rourke visited Manhattan with his father a year ago, he kept pouring tales of its wonders into the eager ears of Raymond Blow, his playmate. Standing on the banks of the Hudson in their home town of Troy, they would gaze wistfully down the river, dreaming of the time when they might make the trip together.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 16. -- Colonel and Mrs. E. M. House will be over-night guests at the White House tomorrow. Mrs. House and Mrs. Roosevelt will attend tomorrow evening the opening concert of the Philadelphia Symphony Orchestra, while the President and the friend and adviser of his Democratic predecessor in office renew their war-time association in discussion of peacetime problems.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 16. -- Treasury officials expressed gratification today at a substantial oversubscription of the offering of 5500,000,000 in ten to twelve year bonds placed on the market today. The bonds bear 4 1/2 per cent interest the first j year and 3 1/4 per cent thereafter.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 16. -- The Federal Reserve Board's condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety leading cities on Oct. 11 shows increases for the week of $79,000,000 in net demand deposits and $50,000,000 in reserve balances with Federal Reserve Banks and a decrease of $12,000,000 in loans and investments.
