For his many contributions to the advancement of high-speed flying, specifically his breaking of both the East-West and the West-East transcontinental records, Colonel Roscoe Turner of Los Angeles received the Harmon Trophy yesterday through the American chapter of the Ligue Internationale des Aviateurs.

Discussing the European political situation at the reopening of the Institute of Arts and Sciences at Columbia University last night, Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of the university, warned that the situation was delicate and could "only be dealt with by a reinterpretation of the war settlement in the terms of tomorrow."

Mrs. Adelaide Torrance Howland, widow of Meredith Howland and granddaughter of Commodore Cornelius Vanderbilt, left an estate appraised yesterday at $2,220,975 gross and $2,146,292 net, of which $2,102,866 was in securities. Mrs. Howland, who died in Paris on Sept. 12, 1932, named as chief legatee her cousin, Herbert Thorn King of Tuxedo, who received $200,000 in cash and the residuary estate.
Professor Albert Einstein will arrive today from Europe on the Red Star liner Westernland to resume his work at Princeton University. He is accompanied by Mrs. Einstein. Others on board include:

PARIS, Oct. 16. -- The French Parliament opens tomorrow what many consider its most fateful session since the World War. Decisions will have to be taken before the Deputies and Senators complete their work, which may well affect the destiny of Republican institutions in France, as well as the attitude of the country toward Germany.

The Last Leaves of Autumn. A mild and windless first half of October accounts for the freshness of the tree foliage and the survival of flowers in garden beds. Usually at this time of the year Jack Frost has touched the maple, the oak and the elm with, his magic brush, but until Saturday morning there was very little change from the Summer green in the neighborhood of New York.

Charles Solomon, Socialist candidate for Mayor, appealed last night to housewives of the city to support the Socialist ticket in the municipal campaign because of the party's position in favor of lower electric rates and public ownership and operation of utilities.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 16. -- George Crawford, the Negro who is under indictment for the murder of Mrs. Agnes Boeing Ilsley and her maid. Minnie Buchner, at Middleburg, Va., in January, 1932, lost his fight against extradition from Massachusetts when the Supreme Court today refused to review his case.

PEIPING, Tuesday Oct. 17. -- There are indications of a modification of the Japanese military policy in North China now that Fang Chen-wu and Chi Hungchang, rebel leaders, have been captured, attempting to escape in disguise.

The social futility and economic waste of another war, described as imminent unless the people of the United States raise an audible protest, was emphasized yesterday by peace leaders at the unveiling of the "world's biggest book," which is to contain the Signatures of opponents of war.

The decline of security values during the past few days has coincided with recovery of the dollar. But from the decline of the dollar last month stocks derived as little satisfaction. Between the end of August and the close of the markets for their holiday last week, the dollar lost approximately 4 cents in terms of currencies still on gold.
Louis Camps, metropolitan 118-pound boxing champion, won two bouts in the third anniversary open house tournament at the Downtown A.C. last night.

Stitch McCarthy's voice rose in pitch and intensity yesterday afternoon as he denied by telephone a suggestion that he did not actually mean to take to court the impending election of the New York League of Locality Mayors.

To the Editor of The New York Times: It was stated in a letter to THE TIMES, referring to Mr. McKee, that "he forgot that, while a member of the Board of Estimate for seven years, he had voted without a single protest for the measures advocated by the equally corrupt and dishonest Walker administration."

The Board of Elections, at a meeting today in its offices in the Municipal Building, is scheduled to approve the use of voting machines in the November election rather than paper ballots, according to reports from usually reliable sources last night.

VIENNA, Oct. 16. -- The discovery of an alleged plot to deliver the Linz garrison to the Nazis and the secret circulation of new Socialist orders to prepare for a general strike climaxed a feverish twenty-four hours today which began with nation-wide Nazi rioting in universities.

The New York University football team began preparations for its battle on Saturday with Colgate by engaging in a spirited two-hour session at Ohio Field yesterday. With the exception of Captain Harry Temple, the squad reported in excellent condition.
BOSTON, Oct. 16 (AP). -- Three teams were locked in a first-place tie, a lap ahead of the other ten entries in the Boston Garden's six-day bike race, after the 11 o'clock sprints tonight.

The article which has resulted in the charge of anti-Semitism against Joseph V. McKee, independent candidate for Mayor, was published in the May, 1915, issue of The Catholic World, when Mr. McKee was a teacher in De Witt Clinton High School.

Proposition No. 1, to be voted on at the election next November in this city and State, authorizes the State to issue up to 560,000,000 of bonds for unemployment relief. They are to be repaid over a ten-year period, one-tenth each year, so that the burden will fall neither on the taxpayers next year nor on those of another generation, but will be spread over a reasonable time.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., Oct. 16. -- For a time it appeared as if Celestin Durand of Timber Point and Willie Klein of Wheatley Hills would be outright winners with a test-ball of 68 in the weekly amateur-pro tournament held at the Old Westbury Golf Club today.

With a clean slate thus far in its 1933 campaign, Fordham's football eleven began preparations at Fordham Field yesterday for a battle with its traditional foe, Boston College, at the Polo Grounds on Saturday.

NEW YORK. George B. Wagstaff will give a dinner dance on Dec. 22 in the ball-room of the Ritz-Carlton to introduce his daughter, Miss Beatrice Wagstaff. Miss Wagstaff is also a daughter of the Hon. Mrs. Lionel Forbes-Semphill of London.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 16. -- How the American Farm Bureau Federation offered its "gigantic machinery" to the American Ship Owners Association in 1930 in a propaganda campaign for a more adequate merchant marine if the association would contribute $94,750 will, it was announced today, occupy the attention tomorrow of the special Senate committee investigating ocean mail contracts.

PARIS, Oct. 16. -- Today's French press indicates clearly the uncertainty which exists as to the course France should follow with regard to Germany's withdrawal from the League of Nations and the disarmament conference.
Jim Browning, giant Missourian, retained his world's heavyweight wrestling title by throwing Rudy Dusek, Nebraskan, last night at the Seventy-first Regiment Armory.

A new policy of financing unemployment relief, under which communities will be enabled to spend more money for this purpose without additional drain upon their treasuries, while those communities less able to bear the burden will not be called upon to curtail their relief programs, was announced yesterday by Governor Lehman.

About the only contradictory note introduced into the financial markets yesterday was the moderate decline in bonds. The speculative markets continued, however, to conform to the pattern designed in the closing days of last week when the details of the government's bond conversion program had become known.

The Harvard Club of New York paid its annual tribute to William J. Bingham, director of athletics, and Eddie Casey, head football coach, in a testimonial dinner at the Harvard Club last night. The affair was attended by a gathering of 250, principally alumni and newspaper men.

A steering committee for the Recovery party campaign in Queens, headed by Robert M. Harriss, chairman of the Queens campaign committee, was appointed yesterday. Harry M. Durning, McKee campaign manager, denied a report that Mr. Harriss had been displaced.

Governor Lehman was asked yesterday by Assemblymen Abbot Low Moffat and Herbert Brownell Jr. to extend the scope of the special legislative session, opening at noon tomorrow, to make possible further economies in city government and the establishment of and "honest" budget for 1934.

MEDIA, Pa., Oct. 16. -- Passive, 8-year-old mare owned by W.D. Cleland of the Bedminster (N.J.) Stock Farms, won the J. Howard Lewis Plate in the two-mile steeple-chase at the opening day's racing of the Rose Tree Hunt Club, near here, today.

The Columbia football team turned its attention yesterday toward its encounter with Princeton on Saturday. The workout at Baker Field lasted nearly three hours. Heavy drills also are scheduled for today and tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 16. -- In an atmosphere much calmer than that of six weeks ago -- when this correspondent took a holiday-the administration is moving toward the fork of the road where it must inevitably choose the right or the left turning. Six weeks ago every activity of government centred ia General Johnson's office, where frantic labors were proceeding.
PATERSON, N.J., Oct. 16. -- The silk strike went Into its seventh week today, with strikers still enforcing a complete shut-down in dye shops and jacquard, broad silk and throwing mills.

Convinced that he is facing his last important chance to remain near the top in boxing, Mickey Walker has settled down to a vigorous training campaign for his light-heavyweight title battle with Maxie Rosenbloom in Madison Square Garden on Nov. 3.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 16. -- The right of the Pennsylvania Railroad Company to acquire 30 per cent of the stock of the Lehigh Valley Railroad and 49 1/2 per cent of the Wabash, which in turn owned about 19 per cent of the Lehigh stock, will be passed upon by the Supreme Court, which today granted to the Interstate Commerce Commission a review of this issue, so important in the railroad world.

THERE were some notable points brought up at Mr. J. Francis Meehan's Saturday football soiree, including the two points that went to Rutgers in the Colgate game. It was the first time since 1931 that Colgate was scored upon and the assembled coaches, scouts, friends, Romans and countrymen, still ignorant of the details at that time were wondering how it had happened.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., Oct. 16. -- Mr. and Mrs. Anthony J. Drexel Jr. entertained with a luncheon for ten persons at the Casino today. Mr. and Mrs. Anthony J. Drexel 3d, after passing the week-end here, left last night for New York.
Two Manhattan properties and nine parcels in the Bronx were sold at foreclosure auctions yesterday. The holdings were bid in by the plaintiffs in each case, as follows:

SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, Oct. 16 -- Leo R. Sack received a cordial welcome today on presentation of his credentials as United States Minister to President Jimenez, who said President Roosevelt's good neighbor policy was "a promise of cordiality which will be a source of increasing sympathy in the international relations between your great nation and the Latin-American countries."

Most of the mutual savings banks outside New York State have not decided yet whether to enter the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation created by the enactment of the Glass-Steagall banking bill or whether to stay out, according to Philip A. Benson, president of the National Association of Mutual Savings Banks.

Ralph Reed Lounsbury, secretary of the new Black Mountain College at Black Mountain, N.C., where he also was Professor of Government and Public Law, died on Monday night at his residence there as the result of a paralytic stroke which occurred on Oct. 6.

New York City landlords pay the equivalent of three months' rent in city taxes before they can meet other fixed charges on their properties, Harold Riegelman, counsel to the Citizens Budget Commission, said last night.

The seeds of more than 300 species of American flowering plants, a majority of which have never been seen in cultivation, have been brought to this city by an expedition which set out to search for them two months ago from the New York Botanical Garden.

LONDON, Oct. 17. -- Sir John Simon insisted tonight that he had not misrepresented Germany's position on rearmament and had not been responsible in the slightest for her abrupt withdrawal from the disarmament conference. Striking back at the German Government in a radio speech to the whole British Empire, the Foreign Secretary declared he was "perfectly and absolutely right" in what he had said about Germany's sudden change of front in the last fortnight.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 17. -- Albert H. Wiggin, retiring last Winter as chairman of the Chase National Bank, received from the executive board a salary for life of $100,000 a year. He had received about $1,500,000 in salaries and bonuses from the bank and other corporations in the four and a half years immediately preceding his retirement.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 (AP). -- The administration arranged today for the purchase of about 1,000,000 bushels of wheat and completed its cotton loan program in moves calculated to provide resistance to recent falling prices of the two commodities.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Oct. 17 (AP). -- The Presidency tonight in an official announcement used the expression "fatal mistake" in describing the shooting to death at Santo Tome, Argentina, of five Brazilians.
PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 17. -- Princeton's varsity football squad went through an hour's scrimmage against the freshmen on rainsoaked University Field today in preparation for the Columbia contest.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 17. -- An exchange of correspondence made public today showed that President Roosevelt had been made a victim of Harvard undergraduate pleasantry.

KANSAS CITY, Oct. 17. -- An order restricting oil production in Texas to 957,555 barrels daily was issued today by the Texas Railroad Commission, while officials of oil regrulatory bodies of Kansas and Oklahoma indicated those States would voluntarily bring oil production within Federal limits by Nov. 1.

The council of the Actors Equity Association ruled yesterday that Oliver Wakefield, an English entertainer, may appear in the "Ziegfeld Follies," which will be presented by the Shuberts, despite the fact that he has been in this country for some time doing radio work and is classed as an alien on his second extension.
George Odom's Irene's Bob, the fleet gelding by The Turk, added another victory to his string when he annexed the Stillwell Purse, feature at Empire City yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 17. -- Substantial progress in the clearing up of the national strike situation was told by the National Labor Board today.

SINGAPORE, Oct. 17. -- The return from European exile of Luang Pradit, Radical leader, and his appointment as Minister of the Interior, are reported by residents of Bangkok who have reached Singapore to have been the spark that started the present revolt.

Fake economy and boss rule were attacked last night by Joseph V. McKee, Recovery party candidate for Mayor, in opening his Queens campaign at a meeting in Jamaica High School. Queens, he declared, needs not only a new deal but a square deal.

The City of Detroit (Mich.) Bondholders' Refunding Committee announced yesterday that the initial payment of interest on Detroit's funded debt, exclusive of water and street railway bonds, since it went into default in February, would be paid on or before Dec. 15.

LONDON, Oct. 17. -- Conditions were quiet in the stock markets today. Fresh buying was on too small a scale to offset the adverse influence of overnight Wall Street news and European uncertainty. German bonds were a trifle better. British funds were dull, but they improved in the afternoon.

The first local NRA test case to determine whether Blue Eagle employers may refuse to deal with employe representatives picked for collective bargaining was begun yesterday by Grover A. Whalen, NRA administrator for the City of New York.

F.H. LaGuardia, Fusion candidate for Mayor, promised yesterday that with the aid of disinterested real estate specialists he would end current abuses in tax reductions and condemnation awards if elected.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 17. -- A signal drill in which Yale's varsity football teams worked up and down the university polo field comprised the Elis' chief work today because of rain and a gridiron heavy with, mud. As Coach Reg Root had planned only one day of scrimmaging this week, which will probably be held tomorrow, today's curtailment in plans, was slight.

Frank J. Prial, Democratic nominee for Controller, read last night from the platform of Tammany Hall a declaration of complete independence of the leaders of his party, and a denunciation of them for their "political arrogance."

HOW much do the strangeness and the dinginess of the post-Civil War American past owe to the quality of the mechanisms used to record it? Were the Seventies as "dreadful" as Don Seitz said they were? Did Vernon Parrington doctor his dice when he wrote of the period of our great industrial expansion in terms of "the great barbecue"?

WASHINGTON, Oct. 17. -- R.E. Desvernine, counsel for the Association of Stock Exchange Firms of New York, presented an Exchange code to the NRA at a hearing today before Deputy Administrator Whiteside. The sponsors, said Mr. Desvernine, represent firms on all markets in the United States.
SHANGHAI, Oct. 17. -- Despite denials in Tokyo and Manchuria that French interests are to lend funds for Manchurian developments, confirmation of the loan agreement was obtained today.

Over the vigorous protests of two licensed boxing club promoters, and despite the admonition of Colonel John Reed Kilpatrick, president of Madison Square Garden, that it was "setting a bad precedent," the State Athletic Commission yesterday issued to Promoter Jack Curley licenses under which he will be able to conduct catch-as-catch-can wrestling programs in two more local armories.

The first new production of the season which the Yiddish Art Theatre mounted last night should shrink the distance between Broadway and Second Avenue as much as its illustrious predecessor, "Yoshe Kalb" (which still shares the week with it) did last year.

BERLIN, Oct. 17. -- Ambassador William E. Dodd discussed matters of mutual German and American interest with Chancellor Hitler today. The conversation took place in the presence of Baron Constantin von Neurath, German Foreign Minister, and lasted an hour.

The twelve-story office and store building at 43-45 West Thirty-fourth Street was bid in at a foreclosure auction yesterday by the Bowery Savings Bank, as plaintiff. The bank's bid was $1,000,000. The action was against the Vegreen Holding Company, Vivian Green president, and others to satisfy a $1,267,292 lien, with back taxes totaling $93,800.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 17. -- Representative Dickstein of New York announced tonight in a radio address the purpose and scope of his proposed investigation of Nazi propaganda in this country, which he declared to be an organized movement directed and financed by the Hitler government, the assertions of the German Ambassador, Dr. Hans Luther, to the contrary notwithstanding.

Reflecting the coordination of control between the Reading Company and the Central Railroad of New Jersey, the balance sheet for Aug. 31 shows a drop of $24,000,000 in investments in other than affiliates. This change was made because the Reading's investment in the Jersey Central, which was long in escrow, has been returned by the courts.

No word was received officially by the New York Yacht Club yesterday of the challenge for the America's Cup on behalf of T.O. M. Sopwith, but members gathered there last night and discussed it, with the possibilities of defending the famous trophy.

The candidacy of Jacob Gould Echurman Jr. for District Attorney on the Fusion ticket was approved and Chief Justice Frederic Kernochan of the Court of Special Sessions was endorsed as a candidate for the judge of the Court of General Sessions by the Association of the Bar of the City of New York at a meeting last night in its building at 42 West Forty-fourth Street.

TRENTON, N. J., Oct. 17. -- The commission created by the Legislature to prepare a liquor control code met today at the State House for the purpose of organization. An executive session will be held in Newark Friday. Meetings also will be held there on Thursday and Friday of the following week.

Supreme Court Justice Alfred Frankenthaler reserved decision yesterday on an application by the Mexican Government to dismiss a suit brought by Silas Ezra of Chicago, as owner of defaulted Mexican bonds, to compel Thomas W. Lament and others as members of the International Committee of Bankers on Mexico to account for a balance of $6,952,148 held by the committee since 1928.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 17. -- Administratlon advisers are studying various features of the Glass-Stegall Banking Act, particularly the deposit insurance section, in expectation of a drive for amendments when Congress assembles in January.
The Welfare Council's coordinating committee on unemployment asked the Board of Estimate yesterday to increase the city's monthly relief appropriation to $10,000,000.

The Irish World in its current issue has declared for Joseph V. McKee on the ground that he is the best equipped of the Mayoralty candidates. This newspaper usually has supported the regular Democratic ticket.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 17. -- Activities of the American Farm Bureau Federation in return for contributions from national trade associations were scored by Democratic members of the special Senate committee investigating ocean mail subsidies today as evidence in the record showing payments to it of $69,250 in the past three years by six national organizations.

GEORGE CRAWFORD, a Negro, was indicted in Louden County, Va., for a double murder committed in January, 1932. He took refuge in Massachusetts. In the Spring of 1933 Governor POLLARD asked for his extradition as a fugitive from justice charged with felony.

More than 200 women have been enrolled for courses at the School for Jewish Women, being held afternoons and evenings in the Congregation Shearith Israel, 2 West Seventieth Street, it was announced yesterday. Registration and tuition are free, although voluntary contributions are accepted.

An investigation by the Federal Government into the salaries and bonuses received by executives of large corporations caused yesterday a storm of protest from officials of such concerns in this city. Several officers declared that the government was seeking information hitherto regarded as highly confidential without even disclosing the purpose of its inquiry.
WEST NEWTON, Mass., Oct. 17. -- The Boston College football team was given a set of new plays today for its annual tussle with Fordham, which will be played at the Polo Grounds on Saturday.

With market movements suddenly reversed, securities and commodities succeeded yesterday in canceling a good part of their recent decline. The downward movement was interrupted on all the domestic markets and there was a broad recovery in the foreign currencies, to the temporary disadvantage of the dollar.

Today will be dedicated the reservation which Mrs. JACOB H. SCHIFF gave to the Boy Scouts of America in memory of her son, MORTIMER L. SCHIFF. He was unanimously elected to the presidency of the national organization only a short time before his death, and also was America's representative in the International Scout Committee.

HAVANA, Oct. 17. -- A bomb exploded this morning at the F.W. Woolworth store at San Rafael and Amistad Streets. The plate-glass show windows were shattered and considerable damage was done to the main entrance The damage is estimated by the management at $2,500.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 17. -- The fate of the retail trade code was in President Roosevelt's hands tonight. He will decide whether this important agreement, and also the charter for the grocery business, shall retain the mark-up provisions which the NRA argues will stop desperate price-cutting wars, but which the Agricultural Adjustment Administration strongly opposes as tending to raise commodity prices to the farmers.
The text of Frank J. Prial's address last night at Tammany Hall follows:

HITLER'S international policy, so far as he can be said to have any, is just now left hanging in the air. First of all, it made a distinct lurch away from Great Britain. After doing many things to propitiate the British Foreign Office, the German Government suddenly gave it up, and HITLER, in his speech last Saturday, seemed preparing to throw himself into the arms of Marianne at Paris.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 17. -- Curtailment of practices by the United States Government which have interfered with native business in Panama were announced in a joint statement issued today at the conclusion of conversation between President Roosevelt and President Arias of Panama.

PERNAMBUCO, Brazil, Oct. 17 (AP). -- The Graf Zeppelin arrived here at 8:10 A.M., today, setting a record of 72 hours and 40 minutes from Friedrichshafen, Germany. A capacity load of passengers was carried.
Two homes and a residential plot were reported sold in Westchester County yesterday.

Charles Solomon, Socialist Mayoralty candidate, charged in a speech last night that conditions in the city's hospitals and out-patient departments represent a breakdown of government at one of its most vital points.

A.A. Berle Jr., one of President Roosevelt's advisers, told the Savings Banks Association of the State of New York at the closing session of its annual meeting here yesterday that the Federal Banking Act of 1933 needs "a thoroughgoing revision" and that he believes Congress in January will be ready to do it.
Thomas Octave Murdoch Sopwith, called Tom from the contraction of his initials, has played a prominent part in British aviation. He began to fly in 1909.

Business leasing, succeeding the peak apartment-rental activity, continued yesterday to furnish a long and varied list of tenants in Manhattan. While retail-store rentals comprised a large part of the tenancies arranged, larger organizations in both the manufacturing and distributing fields also were represented.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 17. -- An impressive public summary of the improvement in the business situation of the country is being planned by the administration, and the reporters are to be the members of the President's Cabinet. Mr. Roosevelt himself may make the final summation (though he has not yet "signed up"), the purpose being to inform the country on most distinguished testimony what has been accomplished by administration policies.

While the government's direct intervention in the grain markets may have been seized upon as a more important development than it actually was, Wall Street thanked Washington for the turnabout on the various exchanges. With stocks following wheat, it was remarked that there was something of a government-inspired market for commodities as well as securities.

Prices on the Cotton Exchange turned upward abruptly yesterday and a rise of $2.50 a bale not only wiped out all of Monday's loss but left the list 10 points, or 50 cents a bale, higher than on Saturday. The day's net gains were 47 to 54 points.
Ralph D. Blumenfeld, chairman of the board of The London Daily Express and its editor for thirty years until his recent retirement, arrived yesterday on the White Star liner Olympic.
Conveyance of a four-story factory in Jersey City featured the New Jersey realty Items reported yesterday.

BERLIN, Oct. 17. -- Paying unexpected heed to charges raised abroad in connection with the Reichstag fire, the German Supreme Court decided today to call before it as witnesses General Hermann Wilhelm Goering. Premier of Prussia; Dr. Paul Joseph Goebbels, Reich Minister of Popular Enlightenment and Propaganda, and three other Nazi chieftains.

CHICAGO, Oct. 17. -- The National Life Insurance Company of the United States of America, largest life isurance company in Illinois, was put in receivership today at the request of Ernest Palmer, State Superintendent of Insurance.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 17. -- THE NEW YORK TIMES today, in an account of the hearing on a code of fair competition for the rubber tire industry, stated that the code provided that Newton D. Baker would be the arbiter of the industry. This was an error.
After deliberating for five hours, a jury in the Kings County Court found Jacob Mellon, Morris Rothenberg and Samuel Solomon, codefendants in the Brooklyn laundry racket trial, not guilty last night.

TOKYO, Oct. 17 (AP). -- The prospect of another 1,000,000,000-yen ($270,000,000) deficit in the 1934-35 budget, with which the government is now struggling, overclouds Japan's political and economic outlook.

The International Paper Company announced yesterday that a maximum working- week of forty hours had been made effective this week in all its mills in this country and that, with the reduction in hours of labor, an average increase of 12 per cent had been made in the hourly rates of wages.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 17. -- On the theory that the elimination, of unfair trade practices, particularly between producer and distributer, would go far to stabilize business and aid the recovery program, Gerard Swope, chairman of the Business Advisory and Planning Council for the Department of Commerce, has appointed a special comImittee headed by Lincoln Filene of the William Filene Sons Company of Boston to make an intensive study of the subject.

The anti-Semitic issue, raised against Joseph V. McKee, Recovery party nominee for Mayor, continued yesterday to be a factor in the campaign. Attacks on Mr. McKee continued. Some persons accepted the explanation made in his radio speech the night before as satisfactory.

PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 17. -- The Princeton-Columbia game on Saturday will be the sixteenth between the institutions, which have carried on one of the longest football rivalries in the country. The first game was played in 1874.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Oct. 17. -- With improved child health as the chief goal, 2,000 delegates to the annual conventions of the New York League of Nursing Education, New York State Organization for Public Health Nursing and New York State Nursing Association opened two-day sessions tonight.

LONG BEACH, L.I., Oct. 17. -- A proposed city ordinance authorizing the issuance of $856,000 of refunding bonds to replace bonds of a similar amount which will mature within the next four years was introduced tonight at a meeting of the Long Beach City Council.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 17. -- Officials of the Agricultural Adjustment Administration, seeking to raise farm prices to a parity with industrial indices, appeared concerned today lest the North Dakota wheat embargo spread to other States and menace the processing tax program.

Reports that the government is buying wheat completely reversed the tread in local commodity markets from one of continued decline to one of brisk recovery yesterday. Trading was heavy as the halting of the dollar's rapid recovery also aided the advance.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Oct. 17. -- An anti-Nazi resolution expressing sympathy for the Jews in Germany and asking the intervention of President Roosevelt was rejected here today by the synod of New Jersey of the Presbyterian Church in the United States of America.

Formation of a permanent committee of distinguished Americans to be chosen by President Roosevelt to protect the interests of American holders of foreign bonds is expected to be announced in Washington soon. This committee, it was learned on good authority yesterday, will not be the one for which provision was made in the Securities Act because of objections raised by the State Department, which foresaw that it would be regarded as official by foreign governments.

Colonel D. John Markey of the United States Battle Monuments Commission is sailing today for France on the United States liner President Roosevelt to inspect the cemeteries where American soldiers are buried. Others leaving on the ship for the Channel ports are:
It is difficult to say whether a majority of sportsmen in and about the metropolitan area are, at this time, chiefly interested in duck hunting, deer hunting, game bird hunting or fishing.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 17. -- With the white ball in use for the first time this season the Harvard varsity football squad went through a rugged workout today in anticipation of a stern test when it meets an unbeaten Holy Cross team here Saturday.

PARIS, Oct. 17. -- Government inspection, licensing and participation in the profits from the manufacture and sale of war materials are among the French Government's proposals for covering the budgetary deficit, which Premier Daladier placed before the Chamber of Deputies today.

Sales billed by the General Electric Company for the first nine months of 1933 were $97,426,146, comparing with $113,049,475 for the 1932 period, a decrease of 14 per cent, Gerard Swope, president, announced yesterday. Sales billed for the third quarter were $35,652,732, against $32,838,986 last year, a gain of 8.57 per cent.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Your editorial on the Fifty-seventh Street Bridge contains several incorrect statements, to which I wish to call your attention in the public interest and in fairness to the North River Bridge Company and myself.

BERLIN, Oct. 17. -- The Boerse recovered its stability today following the first depressing effect of Germany's withdrawal from the League of Nations, although business was quiet and the trend irregular. Nevertheless, fractional gains predominated.

HAVANA, Oct. 17. -- Reliable sources reported tonight that Colonel Fulgencio Batista was having difficulty keeping the united support of his army and that Communists were making considerable headway within the enlisted ranks.

In a talk before the students of New York University last night Mr. RIEGELMAN of the Citizens Budget Committee estimated that three months' rent is the "tribute" which apartment-house owners commonly pay to the city before they can set aside anything for interest, depreciation, maintenance and operating expenses.

Four candidates for Mayor stood in the pulpit at Temple RodelpH Sholom, 7 West Eighty-third Street, yesterday afternoon, and one after another asked members of the New York Section of the National Council of Jewish Women to supports their respective tickets at the polls Nov. 7.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 17. -- Following the promulgation of price-fixing regulations for the oil industry, which are effective Dec. 1, Secretary Ickes, administrator of the oil code, notified the producing industry today that drastic steps would be taken on Nov. 1 as circumstances required to curtail shipments in interstate commerce.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 17. -- President Roosevelt and General Hugh S. Johnson, Administrator, of the National Recovery Act, tonight invoked the Wide powers conferred upon them by Congress to enforce the agreements signed by employers, whether or not they had signed temporary codes or had come under permanent codes approved for entire industries.

ALBANY, Oct. 17. -- On the eve of the second extraordinary session of the Legislature this year, called to provide financial relief measures for New York City, there is a fair prospect that the lawmakers Will complete their work quickly and adjourn finally on Thursday with their task completed.

MEMPHIS, Tenn., Oct. 17. -- An appeal to the public utility industry "to show a measure of business leadership which will make the country forget the disgrace which was cast on the industry during the past decade" was made here today by David E. Lilienthal, director in charge of the Tennessee Valley Authority, in an address before the Rotary Club.

SHORT HILLS, N.J., Oct. 17. -- Setting a precedent by holding the annual meeting in conjunction with a dinner, the delegates from the New Jersey State Golf Association gathered at the Baltusrol Golf Club today.

The estate of Joseph Force Crater, former Supreme Court Justice, who disappeared Aug. 6, 1930, is valued at about $73,000 by his widow, Mrs. Stella M. Crater, who applied yesterday to Surrogate James A. Delehanty for permission to pay more than $3,000 in debts owed by the estate.

PATERSON, N.J., Oct. 17. -- Despite attempts at mediation by the general strike committee of the silk workers here and representatives of the manufacturers, two meetings resulted tonight in a virtual lockout for at least one division of the strikers.

THE coronation of Edward VII -- this is a story told by M.P. Greenwood-Adams, author, lecturer and traveler -- took place in 1901 in London and celebrations were held throughout the empire and dominions. So there were coronation games on the cricket grounds of the little town of Kerang in Victoria, Australia.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The recommendation of the Rockefeller-sponsored liquor control survey for a State liquor control monopoly is to be thoroughly condemned. It is the best method I know of to revive and strengthen bootlegging and illicit traffic.

The decision as to whether the city will use voting machines or paper ballots in the election Nov. 7 was postponed yesterday by the Board of Elections until tomorrow. It was clearly indicated, however, that the board would decide in favor of the machines.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 (AP). -- A two-year program for sharp curtailment of production on corn and hog farms was started by Secretary Wallace today in his newest and most extensive effort to improve agricultural prices.

RICHMOND, Va., Oct. 17 (AP). -- Playing steadily on a soggy course despite trouble with her putter, Mrs. E. Boyd Morrow of Baltimore, the defending champion, today eliminated Mrs. R.N. Sutton of Washington, 9 and 7, in the first round of match play of the women's Middle Atlantic golf championship.

NEW YORK. Mr. and Mrs. Ernest G. Vietor will give a dinner dance on Dec. 29 at the St. Regis for Miss Audrey Achelis, debutante daughter of Mrs. Frederic G. Achelis, and Miss Eleanora Vietor, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. John A. Vietor, also a debutante of the season.

District Attorney Samuel J. Foley of the Bronx condemned yesterday the recent transfer of police commanders from that borough on the ground that they had taken place just as "colonies of guerrillas" were being formed in the Bronx for election purposes.

The four-year financing plan recently worked out by the city and its bankers is not a "mere palliative," as recently charged by Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, but a real cure for the city's financial ills, Samuel Untermyer declared yesterday in a radio address from Station WEAF.

The volume of bankers' acceptances outstanding increased $21,137,073 in, September, the American Acceptance Council reptirted in" its monthly survey of the bill market, published yesterday. This advance lifts the total of bills outstanding to $713,148,684, which is $31,959,538 above the total at the end of September, 1932.

Daily average gross crude oil production in the United States last week was 2,419,650 barrels, compared with 2,398,850 barrels in the preceding week, an increase of 20,800 barrels, according to the American Petroleum Institute. An increase of 28,450 barrels in the daily output of Oklahoma was the most important change.

Irving Bitz, who with Salvatore Spitale gained world-wide attention last year when they were enlisted by Colonel Charles A. Lindbergh in the hunt for his kidnapped son, is a fugitive from justice. Bitz failed to appear in General Sessions yesterday to be tried on a charge of possessing a pistol.

The trial of Isidor J. Kresel, charged with abetting the misapplication of about $2,000,000 of the funds of the defunct Bank of United States in 1930, continued in the criminal branch of the Supreme Court yesterday with the testimony of George W. Egbert, first deputy superintendent and chief examiner of the State Banking Department.

Dr. John L. Tildsley, District Superintendent of Schools, demanded last night that the city's school system be taken out of politics on the ground that a politically appointed Board of Education and Board of Superintendents were obstacles to its growth.

The volume of merchant shipping under construction throughout the world rose in the third quarter of this year, for the first time in two years, according to the quarterly report of Lloyd's Register of Shipping, published yesterday. A total of 756,752 tons are on the ways, a gain of 24,257 tons since June 30, the report said.

A quarter of a century ago "metabolism" was a word used by physiologists in private. Now every doting mother counts the calories in each spoonful of milk fed to baby and talks knowingly of the conversion of food into heat and other forms of energy. The most famous of white-tiled restaurants once indicated the calorific value of the dishes listed on its bill of fare.

The Roosevelt Administration's first venture in price-fixing has been announced by Secretary ICKES. Beginning Dec. 1 it will be regarded as a violation of the NRA and one of its supporting codes for any producer or distributer to sell or to buy petroleum or its products at less than a stated price.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 17. -- The return to employment of more than 620,000 workers in September was announced by Miss Frances Perkins, Secretary of Labor, today. This continued for the sixth Successive month a steady rise in payrolls and employment from the low point of March.

One of the first results of the new college system of intramural sports noted at Yale has been a smaller freshman football squad than has been the case in recent years. It is generally believed that in the future most of the varsity and freshman squads will be smaller in number.
The address of Mayor O'Brien at the ratification rally at Tammany Hall last night follows:

By BROOKS ATKINSON. Anthony Armctrong author of "Ten Minute Alibi," which was acted at the Ethel Barrymore last evening, believes in automatic control from the Driver's seat. No doubt he is right. Once he gets his vehicle rolling along through clues and suspicions, it reaches a high rate of speed and proceeds smoothly with fingertip control.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 17. -- Freedom of the press is not being endangered by General Hugh S. Johnson or any one else in the government The question having been raised, in an oblique quarter, it may be well to offer a reassuring opinion to any who may fear that the New Deal, as thus far revealed, includes an attempt to nullify the First Amendment to the Constitution.

Compelled to work indoors because of the heavy downpour yesterday, Fordham's football squad occupied three hours in a complete rehearsal of its plays in preparation for the encounter with Boston College at the Polo Grounds on Saturday.

BERLIN, Oct. 17. -- Chancellor Hitler's spokesmen declared tonight that Germany intended to live up to treaty obligations even though she had announced her withdrawal from the League of Nations and the disarmamnt conference.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Oct. 17 (AP). -- Plans for reorganization of the Empire Steel Corporation, which has four plants in Niles and one each in Cleveland, Ashtabula and Mansfield, were announced today by the reorganization committee headed by Colonel Frank A. Scott.

Paul E. Mead, vice president of the Irving Trust Company, was accused of giving evasive answers in his testimony yesterday at the Congressional bankruptcy inquiry. The witness denied the charge, which was made by Representative Emanuel E. Celler, chairman of the House subcommittee before which the hearings arc being held at the County Court House.

VIENNA, Oct. 17. -- Foreign Minister Benes of Czechoslovakia will arrive in Vienna tomorrow to discuss with Chancellor Dollfuss the possibility of closer Austro-Czechoslovak trade relations within the frame of the Italian Danubian plan.

BERLIN, Oct. 17. -- United States Ambassador Dodd left after an hour's conversation with Chancellor Hitler today "feeling considerably better over the international outlook than at any time since last Saturday."

Buyers' Arrivals Down. A large drop in the number of buyers registered in the market during the week ended yesterday was noted In comparison with the figures for the preceding week and for the corresponding week a year ago, according to the lists published in THE TIMES.

PARIS, Oct. 17. -- With the words, "We are not deaf to any proposals but neither are we blind to any facts." Premier Daladier in the Chamber of Deputies today summed up briefly his government's attitude toward Chancellor Hitler's offer of direct conversations and Germany's action in leaving the disarmament conference and the League of Nations.

An appeal to 3,000 clergymen of all faiths in New York City to cooperate in the NRA "Buy Now" campaign will be made by William H. Ingersoll, chairman of the local NRA "Buy Now" committee. Mr. Ingersoll made the announcement yesterday after a conference with a committee of the clergy.

PARIS, Oct. 17. -- In today's Paris press there is evidence of a growing advocacy of the idea that the best way out of the impasse into which Germany has thrust disarmament by quitting the conference, and out of danger of complete and fatal disagreement, is for France to accept Chancellor Hitler's invitation and begin direct conversations.

The question of whether a captain of a vessel is legally as well as morally obliged to go to the rescue of passengers on a disabled boat, if he can do so without danger to his own craft, was argued for the first time yesterday in Federal court.

Mayor O'Brien pledged his assistance yesterday in obtaining two new high schools for Staten Island to several hundred residents of that borough who appeared before the Board of Estimate to ask for one school.

CHICAGO, Oct. 17. -- A better college education could be obtained with less expenditure of time and money if the library were the only educational building and all classes became reading periods, Louis S. Shores of Fisk University library told delegates to the convention of the American Library Association today.

The listed bond market rallied moderately yesterday, foreign loans making the best recoveries. In the domestic corporation issues, utility bonds showed wider average gains than did railroad and industrial issues. United States Government bonds on the Stock Exchange closed irregular, six of the thirteen active issues holding unchanged, three moving up 1-32 to 2-32 point and four easing 1-32 to 4-32.
LOS ANGELES, Oct. 17 (AP). -- A petty theft charge was brought today by Claire Windsor, actress, against Alfred C. Read Jr.

GENEVA, Oct. 17. -- The complete eight-year program for equality by rearmament that Germany demanded and for which she quit the disarmament conference and the League of Nations would cost her $1,213,000,000 in gold at the lowest.

BISMARCK, N.D., Oct. 17. -- Governor Langer moved tonight to extend the North Dakota wheat shipment embargo to six other States la what he termed "a patriotic service to the government" by seeking higher prices for the farmer.

LAUREL, Md., Oct. 17 (AP). -- Bazaar, which won the rich Hopeful Stakes for E.R. Bradley, Kentucky sportsman, returned to winning form when she handily defeated five other 2-year-old fillies over a muddy track in the first division of the mile Charlotte Hall purse today.

Dr. Albert Einstein arrived here yesterday to take up his scientific duties at the Institute for Advanced Study in Princeton and went immediately into seclusion. He let it be known that he would give no interviews and would confine his activities entirely to teaching and research.
The Columbia eleven worked for two hours yesterday at Baker Field constructing a defense against the type of attack expected from Princeton on Saturday.

ROME, Oct. 17. -- An official communique announced today the arrest of three men who are said to have confessed to having had a part in the bomb outrage in the basilica of St. Peter's last June 25, when two persons were injured and the Holy Year crowds thrown into a panic.
Nymphs of Pentelic marble and Gothic polychromed saints in the Metropolitan Museum of Art probably will shudder audibly next week when Mars is scheduled to rumble in the basement.

CHICAGO, Oct. 17 (AP). -- Blue Day went to the post limping in the top race at Sportsman's Park today, but the 5-year-old son of Whisk-away-Style, racing for A.G. Tarn of Canada, displayed more speed than any of his rivals and won the purse by a length over a heavy track.

A group representing railways, shippers, truck and steamship operators and savings banks under the chairmanship of Harry A. Wheeler, president of the Railway Business Association, discussed legislation to be put forward as an alternative to government ownership at a meeting yesterday in the Commodore Hotel.
BERLIN, Oct. 17 (AP). -- The Reichsbank statement as of Oct. 15 shows the following changes in reichsmarks:
Borough President Levy opened his campaign for re-election yesterday by outlining to reporters the accomplishments of his office during his incumbency.

The challenge of T. O. M. Sopwith is the fifteenth for the America's Cup, the historic prize that was merely a yachting cup in 1851, when it was won by the schooner yacht America in a race around the Isle of Wight.
LONDON, Oct. 17. -- England today challenged the "United States to another series of races for the America's Cup.

200 Letters a Day. An article in last Sunday's TIMES described in a most interesting way how the White House mail has increased from an average of 600 letters a day in HOOVER'S time to 3,800 a day at present.

The National Council of the Steuben Society of America, a patriotic organization of American citizens of German extraction, made known yesterday that it had forwarded to the President a statement in which the boycott of German goods was denounced as "detrimental to the interests of the American people."

LONDON, Oct. 17 (AP). -- A sensation was created among bridge players today by a statement that aceshowing in contract slam bidding had been forbidden by the Portland Club, the rules of which govern the game in Great Britain.
Two prominent Democrats supporting the Fusion candidacy of F. H. LaGuardia attacked Joseph V. McKee's Recovery party yesterday for posing as the favored, child of the Roosevelt Administration.

William Faulkner writes Harrison Smith, his publisher, that his new novel will be "a little on the esoteric side"; that he is "pecking away at it slowly, but it is coming along better than anything else I've ever done." He has several suggested titled for it, one being "Requiem for a Nun."
WASHINGTON, Oct. 17. -- Alternate members of the special board to review veterans' claims in the New York City area were approved by President Roosevelt and announced today as follows:
RYE, N.Y., Oct. 17. -- To Mrs. Leo G. Federman of Glen Oaks went the honor of winning the last tournament of the season staged by the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association today.
The quotations are for three-four months paper.
WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Oct. 18. -- The Westchester County Golf Association brought its 1933 season to a close today under conditions that were none too auspicious.
MOSCOW, Oct. 18. -- The German-Geneva crisis continues to be the subject of passionate discussion in Moscow, both in Russian and foreign diplomatic circles.

Ernest Hemingway's new book of short stories, "Winner Take Nothing," is dedicated to Archibald MacLeish, winner of this year's Pulitzer prize in poetry. Nine of the fourteen stories in the book have never before been published. Others were published in Scribner's Magazine. Scribner's will bring out "Winner Take Nothing" on Oct. 27.

More than anything else, the incident of yesterday which touched off the sharp decline on the Stock Exchange was the selling of steel stocks. One block of Steel common amounting to 4,900 shares changed hands at 38, and thereafter the reaction gathered momentum steadily in other sections of the list.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 18. -- Federal insurance of bank deposits up to $2,500 will go into effect Jan. 1, with the original program unchanged, it was said today at the White House.

In response to a request from the President, the New York Clearing House banks finally agreed yesterday to "take the lead" in the government's campaign to expand bank capital preparatory to Federal Insurance of bank deposits beginning next January.

PRINCESS ANNE, Md., Oct. 18. -- A mob of nearly 2,000 battered its way into the county prison tonight, dragged out a Negro prisoner accused of attacking an aged white woman and lynched him in front of a judge's home.

RENO. Nev., Oct. 18. -- Mrs. Lorraine Gould is here, establishing residence with the intention of filing suit to divorce Clarence F. Gould of New York. She will charge non-support. A young daughter is with her.

COPENHAGEN, Denmark, Oct. 18 (AP). -- Premier Stauning's declaration before the Folketing yesterday that the southern Danish frontier would be defended to the limit was featured in the whole Danish press today.
The Transit Commission denied yesterday the application of the Staten Island Coach Company, Inc., for permission to operate routes under a franchise recently voted by the Board of Estimate.

The Citizens Union made public yesterday its list of recommendations to voters as to candidates for the Assembly to be elected in the city on Nov. 7. In line with the policy it has adopted this year, no Democratic candidate is endorsed or even considered, qualified for election.

CHEYENNE, Wyo., Oct. 18 (AP). -- Sale of all properties of the Producers and Refiners Oil Corporation at auction between next March 15 and April 15 was ordered late today by Federal Judge T. Blake Kennedy. The order will be followed within thirty days by a formal decree listing the properties to be sold.

It takes the Chicago Bar Association to be perfectly thorough, frank and told in giving an opinion on the merits and demerits of nominees for the bench. The Association of the Bar of the City of New York is more conservative and cautious, responding perhaps to the supposed temperament of the East as compared with that of the West.

PARIS, Oct. 18. -- Opposition to almost every item in the government's budget proposals, developing today in the press or in the lively discussions of the finance commission, indicated the measure would be considerably revised before adoption.

BUENOS AIRES, Oct. 18. -- A sensation was caused in business and financial circles this morning by the publication of an order issued by Finance Minister Pinedo prohibiting remittance to any country of funds blocked previous to May 1, on the ground that such action would violate the Anglo-Argentine trade treaty.
From the evidence at hand thus far, the strongest brand of football that is being played this year is to be found in the Middle West.
NEW YORK. Prince and Princess de Caraman Chimay of Paris are at the Savoy-Plaza. The Princess before her recent marriage was Mrs. Elizabeth Rutherfurd Stuyvesant.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 18 (AP). -- Glenn Presnell, former star at Nebraska, led the Portsmouth Spartans to a 25-to-O victory tonight over the Philadelphia Eagles, new members of the National Professional Football League.

ALBANY, Oct. 18. -- Swiftly and with no apparent friction, the Legislature at its second extraordinary session this year put through today the New York City financial relief program and the measure which had threatened to defeat it, the Monroe County Relief Bill espoused by the Republicans.

For the sixth consecutive month both employment and payrolls in American factories increased in September. This is shown by the indices of the Federal Bureau of Labor Statistics. In March employment was estimated at 55.1, on a scale with the average for the full year 1926 reckoned at 100.

GENEVA, Oct. 18. -- Two developments in the situation created by Germany are found encouraging in League circles. One is the continued failure of Chancellor Hitler to notify the League officially of Germany's intention to withdraw.

MINEOLA, L.I., Oct. 18. -- Contending that his property in Glen Cove has been overassessed by more than $1,000,000, J. P. Morgan got a writ of certiorari today calling for a review of the action of the assessors of the city of Glen Cove. The writ is returnable on Nov. 20.
OSSINING, N. Y., Oct. 18. -- Emil De Ryss of 32 Tunstall Road, Scarsdale, a civil engineer, was killed instantly late this afternoon by a bullet from the gun of a duck hunter.

CHICAGO, Oct. 18.-- Continued buying of cash wheat and futures on the Board of Trade, which operators attributed to the government, more than offset today the heavy profit-taking sales in futures by the local and Eastern interests that appeared yesterday to have advance information as to the government's action.

Following four consecutive quarterly reports showing gains over the preceding periods, the Continental Can Company, Inc., issued yesterday a statement of earnings for the twelve months ended on Sept. 30 which showed continuation of the progress.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 18. -- Through the testimony of Malcolm Stewart, its secretary-treasurer, the Middle West Foreign Trade Committee was added today to the list of organizations shown by the special Senate investigating committee to be actively campaigning for increased government aid to shipping without disclosing their financial support by beneficiaries of the Federal policy.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 18. -- Harvard's football team that Coach Casey intends to start against Holy Cross on Saturday today put in a strenuous day. The players had a twenty-minute drill on defense against forward passes in a dummy scrimmage, then engaged in real football against the freshmen for seventy minutes.
ALBANY, Oct. 18. -- The text of Governor Lehman's message to the Legislature follows:
WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 (AP). -- The thirty-three States which have voted for repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment have averaged a three-to-one margin.

HOLLYWOOD, Oct. 18. -- Joseph M. Schenck, president of the recently organized Twentieth Century Pictures, Inc., is negotiating for the purchase for that company of a controlling interest in the United Artists Corporation, which operates the studio under that name.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Kenneth S. Sutherland, Tammany leader of the Sixteenth Brooklyn Assembly District, is reported in THE TIMES as having delivered the following at a Mc Kee meeting in Coney Island:
NEW ORLEANS, Oct. 18 -- "Every Man a King," Senator Huey P. Long's autobiography, made its appearance here today, filled with praise for himself and denunciation for his enemies.
LONDON, Oct. 18. -- The official silence was so complete after today's meeting of the British Cabinet to discuss the disarmament situation that a quick growth of rumors sprang up from the hush.

A traveling discussion unit comprising a rabbi, a Catholic priest and a Protestant minister was commissioned yesterday by the National Conference of Jews and Christians to tour the United States for the express purpose of "resisting the duplication in this country of the outbreak of intolerance abroad."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 18. -- Conversations looking to a readjustment of the war debt of Great Britain to the United States were continued at the Treasury today. It was said that no definite proposal had been made.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 18. -- President Roosevelt spent a large part of four hours today conferring with officials on the retail trade code, a paramount plank of the recovery program.
VIENNA, Oct. 18 (AP). -- A nationwide Nazi military organization has been developed in Austria, it was disclosed today, despite the handicap of the party's dissolution.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Oct. 18. -- In spite of a drop of $5,000,000 on the local assessment roll, the city of White Plains will have a tax rate in 1934 of $3.54 per $1,000 less than this year. The Common Council this morning adopted a net 1934 budget of $3,312,138, a reduction of $719,357.

The New York Stock Exchange issued yesterday a warning that the quoted price for the Class A stock of the Pierce Arrow Motor Car Company was out of line with the price quoted for the company's preferred stock. It was the first time within the memory of brokers that the Exchange had warned customers of brokers of such a situation.

NEWARK, N. J.,Oct. 18. -- Representatives of the management of the Ford plant at Edgewater will meet a committee of striking workers at the plant tomorrow morning, it was announced today. The report was made by Colonel J. Lester Eisner, chairman of the New Jersey State Recovery Board, at the close of a conference with Ford officials at State NRA headquarters here.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In the editorial "A Celebrated Case" you discuss the findings of Special Master Rawls, examiner for the Supreme Court of the United States in the matter of a bill brought to determine the rights of Delaware and New Jersey in the Delaware River.
U. S. Department of Agriculture. Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices at New York.

Nathaniel Xi. McCready, "Union League Club resident and a member of an old New York family, who died at Thurso, Scotland, on Oct. 3, left most of his estate of undetermined value to charity, it was disclosed, yesterday when his will was filed in Surrogate's Court.

Financial "starvation" through false economy is crippling the city schools, increasing the size of classes, and contributing to the "present high percentage of failures and retardation among school children," Charles Solomon, Socialist candidate for Mayor, charged last night.

Election of Dr. Everett W. Gould as alumni trustee of Columbia University was announced yesterday by Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of the university. Dr. Gould succeeds Dr. Linsly R. Williams.

The candidacy of Frank J. Prial, regular Democratic nominee for Controller, which had lagged for the last two weeks, gained new impetus yesterday as a result of Mr. Prial's declaration of independence delivered at Tammany Hall on Tuesday night.

SCARSDALE, N. Y., Oct. 18. -- The committee of one hundred of the Scarsdale Woman's Club sponsored a dance and fashion show tonight at the Scarsdale Golf Club. The beneficiaries include the Children's village, Eastview County Home, Westfield State Farm for Women, Grasslands Hospital, Jennie Clarkson Home and Rosary Hill Cancer Home.

J.W. N. SULLIVAN is a very talented Irishman. He is a mathematical physicist who, like Eddington, possesses a singularly lucid, popularizing style. Something of a mystic, he is impressed with the great esthetic beauty and simplicity of certain mathematical formulae, and he writes about Einstein with a little of the spirit of an Arthur Symons contemplating Cologne Cathedral.

Parishioners and friends, including a group of fellow-ministers, joined in paying tribute to the Rev. Dr. George U. Wenner at a dinner given in his honor last evening at New York Turn Hall, Lexlngton Avenue and Eighty-fifth Street. The occasion was his completion of sixty-five years as pastor of Christ Lutheran Church, 406 East Nineteenth Street, which he founded and of which he has been the only pastor.

To end the career of John Kelly, 17 years old, as a figure in the Chelaea dock laborers' internal war, three gunmen, one of them armed with a machine gun, late last night invaded a beer garden at Tenth Avenue and Thirty-fifth Street and killed a customer and wounded the proprietor as well as the youth.

R. C. Holmes, a director and former president of the Texas Corporation, who is seeking proxies for a special meeting of stockholders to increase the number of directors, has sent out another letter to stockholders charging that the present management is using the company's resources to urge stockholders not to sign the call for the special meeting.
Two transactions involving Manhattan business properties, one in the downtown district and the other on Fifth Avenue, enlivened the real estate market yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 18. -- The value for rate making purposes of the Union Pacific Railroad System and Terminal Company, which it controls jointly with other carriers, was placed at $501,258,082 in a final report made public today by the Interstate Commerce Commission, the figure including $15,845,234 for working capital.

Abolition of the Tenement House Department and the Board of Standards and Appeals was advocated yesterday by Langdon W. Post, Fusion candidate for President of the Borough of Manhattan. Mr. Post spoke with Borough President Samuel Levy, who is seeking re-election, and James J. Hoey, Recovery party nominee for the office, at a luncheon of the Uptown Chamber of Commerce in the Hotel Whitehall, Broadway and 100th Street.

James Byrne, chancellor of the University of the State of New York, will be the principal speaker at the celebration at City College next Thursday of the seventieth birthday of Dr. John H. Finley, who for ten years was president of the college.

Purchase of two West Side properties required for the construction of the midtown tunnel under the Hudson River was announced yesterday by the Port of New York Authority. The deals were of particular interest because they marked a resumption of buying of land for the tunnel project, after a lapse of about two years.

A nose finish, with an apprentice who never before had had a winner riding the long-shot victor, thrilled a rather chilled crowd at Empire City yesterday. The horse was Energetic Boy, a son of Stimulus, which had been played down from 30 to 1 to 15 to 1.

One of the warmest family debates polo has known in years centres about the prospective national ranking for 1933 of the country's foremost three players, Thomas Hitchcock Jr. of New York, Elmer J. Boeseke Jr. of California and Cecil Smith of Texas.

The annual meeting of the American Mission to Lepers began last night at the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church and will continue through today. Distinguished physicians and heads of leper colonies in various parts of the world told of their experiences in leprosy relief.

PARIS, Oct. 18 (By Wireless). -- The greater part of the press errs in considering Germany's withdrawal from the Disarmament Conference and threat to leave the League of Nations as a bombshell or as a revelation, at last, of Germany's real policy.

MEDIA, Pa., Oct. 18. -- My Care, owned by J. H. F. Hagen, came through with a rush to win the Bear Hill Plate Steeplechase, one of the features of the second day, of the Rose Tree Hunt Club's meeting near here today.

Penalties imposed by the National Legitimate Theatre Committee, the enforcement division of the theatrical code, against the Broadway Theatre Ticket Company and Courtney Burr, producer of "Sailor, Beware!" at the Lyceum Theatre, were rescinded yesterday by Sol A Rosenblatt, deputy administrator who assisted in drawing up the regulations affecting virtually every organized branch of the legitimate entertainment field.

Mr. A, A. BERLE, usually described as one of President ROOSEVELT'S advisers, said to the Savings Banks Association on Tuesday that the Glass-Steagall Banking Act of June needs " thorough, overhauling." He appears to have intimated that it will get such revision from Congress.

Heavy buying of contracts for cotton, attributed to government agencies, caused yesterday an improvement of a quarter cent a pound in early trading on the Cotton Exchange, but unsettling effects of a weak stock market cancelled the entire gain, and the market closed, with net losses of 10 to 13 points.

Timothy J. Mara, sports promoter, who is being sued with Patrick F. Kenny, Yonkers contractor, by the County Trust Company for $70,000 on notes made during the Alfred E. Smith Presidential campaign in 1928, told Supreme Court Justice McCook and a Jury yesterday that they were signed at the dictation of William F. Kenny when money was coming in too slowly, and that the signers were assured they would not have to pay.

Operations in the steel industry have fallen this week to a national average of 39 per cent of capacity from 44 per cent a week ago, according to the review of The Iron Age. This organ notes that a "much lighter demand is reported in leading consuming areas" and that the industry "faces the remainder of the year with increasing pessimism."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 (AP). -- Confidence that the strike situation over the country would be worked out "If we keep our heads" was expressed today by Senator Wagner, chairman of the National Labor Board, as he announced a denial from the Ford Motor Company that Henry Ford "is unalterably opposed to collective bargaining" with his employes.

The development of automotive, air and water transport services, supplementing or competing with the railroads, "is forcing the formulation of new transportation policies" to correlate these facilities, C. E. R. Sherrington, secretary of the British Railway Research Service of London, said yesterday.

PARIS, Oct. 18. -- Premier Daladier's statement in the Chamber of Deputies yesterday in reply to Chancellor Hitler had a good reception today in the Paris press, even in that section which is habitually critical of everything the Left leaders and parties do and say.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 18. -- A complaint has been issued by the Federal Trade Commission against the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company charging violation of the Clayton Act in price discriminations favoring Sears, Roebuck Co.

Efforts to perfect the defense of the New York University football team against Colgate formations continued at Ohio Field yesterday. The three-hour workout was marked by the first scrimmage of the season between the varsity and freshmen, the latter eleven employing Maroon plays.
MENDHAM, N. J., Oct. 18. -- Nearly 500 acres of tree-covered hills, brilliant in the colors of Autumn, were dedicated here this afternoon as the Mortimer L. Schiff Boy Scout Reservation.
Numerous dwellings In various communities of the metropolitan area constituted the bulk of the New Jersey realty turnover reported yesterday.

The prosecution gained an important point yesterday in the trial of Isidor J. Kresel when Justice Taylor admitted a stenographic report of the defendant's testimony before the grand jury that investigated the Bank of United States collapse.

HAVANA, Oct. 18. -- United States Ambassador Simmer Welles was accused by two local newspapers this evening of inspiring the three major oil companies, the Standard Oil, Sinclair and Shell-Mexican units, in Cuba to cause a shortage of gasoline in the island, which would tie up automotive transportation.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 18. -- After a lapse of one year, the series of international exhibitions held in Pittsburgh by the department of fine arts of Carnegie Institute is resumed this season. The 1933 show -- the thirty-first in the Carnegie series-had a preview this evening and opens to the public tomorrow.
The Newspaper Guild of New York was finally launched last night in definite form at a meeting in the City Club attended by about 150 of the 1,000 working newspaper men and women of this city.

General Gerardo Machado, who was deposed as President of Cuba Aug. 12 and took refuge in Canada while young revolutionists vowed to track him down and kill him, has been in New York within the past week, it was etsablished yesterday.

The widespread effects of the NRA program on the cotton-textile Industry, first among the country's business groups to earn the right to the Blue Eagle, were outlined yesterday to more than 200 mill executives and selling agents at the annual convention of the Cotton-Textile Institute, Inc., at the Hotel Biltmore yesterday.
IT WAS THE NIGHTINGALE, by Ford Madox Ford (Lippincott, $3). Gossipy autobiography of a writer and editor who is a friend of dozens of other writers and editors.

The application by George Trosk, Fusion candidate for Supreme Court in New York and Bronx Counties, to compel the Board of Elections to eliminate candidates named by independent groups for five judicial vacancies from places beneath the name and emblem of the Recovery party, was denied yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Salvatore A. Cotillo.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 18. -- From capital and earnings, the Chase Securities Corporation set aside in the depression years after 1929 to last June 30, reserves of $119,138,075.87 against losses and depreciation in the value of the securities in its portfolio.

FORT WORTH, Texas, Oct. 8. -- Horse racing will return to Texas to the accompaniment of parimutuel wagering tomorrow when W. T. Waggoner, prominent sportsman, throws open his $2,000,000 Arlington Downs plant for a three-week meeting in the presence of high governmental officials.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Oct. 18. -- Jascha Helfetz will give a violin recital at the Westchester County Centre here Friday night Mrs. Julian Olney will bring to the centre a series of musical events, of which the Heifetz recital is to be the first.

BERLIN, Oct. 18. -- The Boerse continued its recovery today, both stocks and bonds showing a firm undertone and gains ranging up to 2 and 3 per cent. Heavy industrial and public utility shares profited by a report that the production of electric current in August was 13 per cent greater than in the same month last year.

NEWARK, N.J., Oct. 18. -- Mayor Meyer C. Ellenstein urged the citizens of Newark to pray for the election of F. H. LaGuardla as Mayor of New York in an address today at the Newark Advertising Club luncheon. He said Mr. LaGuardia's election might cause the Stock Exchange to move here.

Renewed liquidation on the Stock Exchange yesterday halted the latest advance and produced a set-back which more than wiped out the hard-won gains of the previous day. But for the fact that some of the grains displayed strength, no doubt because of the government's purchases of wheat, the drop in securities might have been much more violent.

A campaign to raise $4,000,000 to help the city's family welfare agencies in providing assistance to those needy and unemployed who will not toe reached by the government relief programs this Winter will be conducted next month by a group of prominent financiers, philanthropists and welfare workers.
GUAYAQUIL, Oct. 18. -- The Senate today removed President Juan de Dios Martinez Mera. The twenty-two Senators present voted unanimously for the impeachment charges. The opposition did not attend.

After opening at about Tuesday's closing levels and working higher early, commodities weakened yesterday on local exchanges and closed at net losses in most cases. Trading was not so heavy as in the preceding session. Cash prices were irregular.

Robert J. Byers, welfare officer and department adjutant of the American Legion of Michigan, denied yesterday before Federal Judge John Knight and a jury that he had defrauded the government by selling army goods intended for distribution among the poor at a profit.

Store leasing in various parts of Manhattan continued to form a major part of commercial rental activity, as is shown by reports of brokers yesterday. Retail space in the Fifth Avenue, Broadway and Bronx trade centres appeared to be in good demand.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 18. -- The Federal Trade Commission made public today the terms of a questionnaire sent to 2,000 corporations, listed on the New York Stock and New York Curb Exchanges, asking them to report the salary schedules of their executive officers and directors.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 18. -- A decrease of 3 per cent from August figures in the number of relief cases was reported for September to the Federal Emergency Relief Administration today by State relief administrations. The figures were based on preliminary reports for 135 cities and urban counties in forty-seven States and the District of Columbia.

The worst break in French francs in recent years, precipitated by a wave of alarm in Paris over the European political situation and the safety of the gold standard in France, sent the dollar up yesterday 2.78 cents in gold value to 70.94 per cent of parity.

Mrs. Mary E. Callahan, wife of John H. Callahan, retired hotel proprietor of Rochester, N.Y., took the witness-stand yesterday to tell Federal Judge Alfred C. Coxe and a jury how she and her husband had been swindled of $141,000, their life savings.

MONTREAL, Que., Oct. 18 -- Gordon W. Scott, trustee in bankruptcy for Price Brothers Co., received today details' of the proposal made by Bowater's Paper Mills, Ltd., of England to creditors and holders of preferred and common shares of Price Brothers.

GENEVA, Oct. 18. -- Detailed estimates of the costs involved in the opposing proposals for the attainment of arms equality by Germany over an eight-year period have been prepared by official experts here.

Mr. CURRY of Tammany Hall has not before been known as a specially acute judge of campaign oratory. But on Tuesday evening after the grand ratification and rally at Tammany Hall he appeared as a very Sir Oracle. All the speeches, he declared, had been "wonderful." Not only wonderful, but fearful, the untutored listener would think.

The Pennsylvania Railroad has informed the other Eastern managements that it has withdrawn a proposed tariff for door-service throughout its system. This action was taken although Joseph B. Eastman, Federal Coordinator, had approved the Pennsylvania's plan over the protest of the New York Central.

A price of $16,000,000 has been agreed upon by the Board of Transportation and the Long Island Railroad for the purchase by the city of the Far Rockaway and Rockaway Beach divisions of the road to tie up with the new Queens Boulevard subway, George Le Boutellier, vice president of the Long Island, announced last night in a speech before the Rockaway Board of Trade at Grogan's Restaurant, Beach Ninety-second Street, Rockaway Beach.

LONDON, Oct. 18. -- Robert W. Bingham, the American Ambassador, addressing the English-Speaking Union at a dinner tonight in his honor, made no direct reference to the disarmament conference, but he urged Anglo-American unity of action to preserve peace.
PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 18 -- Princeton went through another hard practice session today, scrimmaging for an hour at the conclusion of the drill.

TOKYO, Thursday, Oct. 19. -- The army's claims to take a leading part in, framing national policies became more definite last night, when the War Office issued to the newspapers an informal statement on the conferences of the Premier and the Ministers of War, of the Navy, of Finance and of Education on the arms appropriations policy.

Rules for Bicycles The bicycle craze is creating new difficulties for metropolitan traffic officers. Charleston, S. C., has promulgated an edict against "handle-bar passengers," and bicycles must obey the general traffic rules.

BERLIN, Oct. 18. -- The now famous subterranean tunnel leading into the Reichstag building from the official residence of General Hermann Wilhelm Goering, now Nazi Premier of Prussia and President of the Reichstag at the time of the fire, was inspected today by the German Supreme Court and press representatives and many foreign correspondents.

VIENNA, Oct. 18. -- Not only the new Mussolini but the old Tardieu plan for Danubian economic reconstruction were discussed between Chancellor Engelbert Dollfuss and Dr. Eduard Benes, the Czechoslovakian Foreign Minister, on the latter's arrival here today.
