LONDON, Oct. 18. -- How close President Wilson came to committing the United States to war in the early Spring of 1916 is stressed in the second volume of David Lloyd George's war memoirs, to be published here tomorrow.

Cowboy and cowgirl contestants at Madison Square Garden, about 100 strong, banded together yesterday and signed a petition which will be mailed today to General Hugh S. Johnson in Washington, asking that they be "segregated and coded" under the Blue Eagle.

Asserting that the medical profession is undergoing one of the greatest revolutions in its history, Dr. Henry E. Sigerist predicted last night at a meeting of the New York Academy of Medicine that some form of socialized medicine was inevitable.

ST. PAUL, Oct. 18 (AP). -- Four Northwestern railroads serving North Dakota tonight challenged the legality of Governor Langer's wheat embargo, determining to "abide by the laws of Congress" and accept wheat for shipment.

ROCHESTER, Oct. 18. -- Reduction in health agency budgets was declared a short-sighted menace to the nation's health program by Dr. C. E. A. Winslow, Professor of Public Health at Tale University, before New York State organizations of nurses in convention here today.
Despite the protest of his counsel, Samuel Kantor must be placed on trial for alleged vote fraud before to coming election, it was decided yesterday by Federal Judge Alfred C. Coxe.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 18. -- Seven or more United States Attorneys in various parts of the country, appointed or reappointed by former President Hoover for definite tenurea, have defied the present administration in its attempts to remove them from office, according to information at the Department of Justice.

BUENOS AIRES, Oct. 18. -- Fritz Busch received an ovation last night at the Colon Theatre such as has not been accorded any orchestra conductor here for many years. It was his farewell concert previous to his sailing today for Europe to conduct at Copenhagen, London, Milan and Home.

For the size of its population Vermont vies with any State in the Union in the number of citizens qualified for high, office. There have been periods when Vermont Senators at Washington challenged comparison with, those of any other State in ability and usefulness.

PARIS, Oct. 18. -- The French Foreign Affairs Commission came to the conclusion today that the Four-Power European peace pact was killed in its first test, Germany's withdrawal from the disarmament conference.

LAUREL, Md., Oct. 18 (AP). -- Bright Haven, a recent arrival from New York where he won his last two starts at Jamaica, drove to an upset victory in the featured Magothy Purse for 2-year-olds at six furlongs today.

PATERSON, N.J., Oct. 18. -- Broadsilk weavers affiliated with the Associated Silk Workers approved today the proposal of a $27 weekly basic wage. They authorized Frank Schweitzer, general secretary of the American Federation of Silk Workers, to discuss settlement terms on that basis.

A luncheon was given yesterday by Mrs. Ernest Frederick Eidlitz at her home, 920 Fifth Avenue, for Mrs. Philip H. Wootton, who returned here recently after several years' residence in Japan and California. The other guests included Mrs. James Madison Macdonald, Mrs. John Jay Hopkins, Mrs. Ellis Douty. Mrs. James Dauchy Oakley, Mrs. John J. Dickie, Mrs. John Park Wright, Mrs. Frederic C. Zanes, Mrs. Herbert R. Wilde and Miss Ethel Irving.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 18. -- Matters connected with the forthcoming Pan-American Conference, opening at Montevideo on Dec. 3, occupied the principal place in conversations today that Dr. Jose Manuel Puig Casauranc, Secretary of State of Mexico, held with President Roosevelt, Secretary Hull and other officials.

PEIPING, Oct. 18. -- Bert Hall, member of the Lafayette Escadrille during the World War and former aviation adviser to the Nanking government, was arrested Tuesday at Tangku as he debarked from a steamer arriving from Japan. He is accused by United States consular authorities of obtaining $9,775 from a Chinese general under false pretenses.

HOLLYWOOD, Oct. 18 (AP) -- Two of the film industry's leading figures, Joseph M. Schenok and Samuel Goldwyn, said tonight they were supporting players in opposition to certain provisions of the NRA motion picture code.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Oct. 18 -- El Mercurio points out editorially that the continual demands for financial aid by the Chilean nitrate industry on the Central Bank place the bank in a dangerous position in view of its depleted gold reserves. The hank recently was called on for a $10,000,000 advance to finance nitrate operations until a permanent reorganization is effected.
ALBANY, Oct. 18 (AP). -- Can you spell "desiccated," or "gratuitous," or "indispensable"?

PRINCESS ANNE, Oct. 18. -- The march to the scene of the lynching of Armwood was wild in the extreme. The mob members seemed crazed, continually leaping on the Negro, even after he fell to the ground and was unable to rise.

Just before the so-called Eastern Insull public utilities group was placed in receivership it was "like a little dog chasing its tail around," a witness declared yesterday at the Congressional bankruptcy hearing in the New York County Courthouse.

Supporters of Joseph V. McKee nominee for Mayor, planned yesterday for more intensive work from now until election. Mr. McKee will make at least half a dozen speeches of a constructive nature, and his backers will make every effort to improve his hurriedly put together organization for effective work on election day.

NEWARK, N. J., Oct. 18. -- Participation by German and Austrian war veterans in the Newark Armistice Day, a practice inaugurated last year, will be forbidden this year under a resolution adopted by the Armistice Day committee, it was announced today, unless the matter is reconsidered at the committee's next meeting, Friday night.

A warning that specious prosperity may be produced by any form of inflation was sounded last night by Linhart Stearns, vice president of I. Edwin Tanenbaum, investment counsel, at a meeting of the Metropolitan Controllers Association of the National Retail Dry Goods Association.

BERLIN, Oct. 18. -- Foreign Secretary Simon's London radio speech on the arms situation yesterday was characterized today as "turning facts upside down" by the Deutsche Diplomatische-Politische Korrespondenz in an article which is believed to have been officially inspired.
ALBANY, Oct. 18. -- Following is the text of the memorandum on New York finances sent by Governor Lehman to the Legislature today:

WASHINGTON, Oct. 18. -- President Roosevelt has been informed by Secretary Woodin that the Treasury's current offering of $500,000,000 in ten to twelve year bonds had been oversubscribed about four times, but that all the mail subscriptions have not been tabulated.

BOSTON, Oct. 18 (AP). -- The Federal Government has no desire to interfere with the initiative of industry in fulfillment of the NRA program, General Johnson, the Recovery Administrator, declared in a message tonight to the annual meeting of the Associated Industries of Massachusetts.
The game bird hunting season will open in Connecticut tomorrow. From all reports there will be plenty of game and numerous places for the hunters to ply their sport.

Among the great detectives at recent years, none has been more highly regarded than Charlie Chan of Honolulu. He has solved his problems in the pages of what are whimsically called nationally circulated magazines. He has appeared also in nationally circulated movies.

THE cheering over the world's series has died away to a faint whisper, and yet something came of that series that has left baseball fans still muttering to themselves in wonder. Comrade Terry of the Giants is now engaged on the Five-Year Plan. There he sits, on top of the baseball world. He tried every dodge to escape his fate but it overtook him in the end.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 18. -- The Yale varsity eleven today drove two touchdowns across the Gray squad's goal line in an hour's scrimmage session, but the opposition also scored twice on the regulars.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 18. -- It is as disappointing to the local chroniclers as to their readers that they cannot as yet give a categorical reply to the widespread question: "What is the President going to do about the currency?" The probable reason is that the President has not made up his mind what he is going to do.
LONDON, Oct. 18 (AP). -- O. M. Fleming, Ely Culbertson's British representative, said today that a ruling by the Portland Club had not barred any particular contract bidding conventions.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 18. -- Permission of the Currency Controller for conservators of closed banks to exchange Home Owners Loan Corporation bonds for mortgages held as collateral for loans was announced today.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 18. -- While a departmental report showed today a slight weakening in the advance of wholesale commodity prices, which is the essence of the recovery movement, President Roosevelt pointed to gains over a year ago and bade the country not to be disheartened by a temporary setback.
F. H. LaGuardia offered his relief program and urged Governor Lehman to set up board to study city share of State taxes.

To the Editor of The New YOTK Times : Definite reaction against inflation has taken place during the last few weeks, with the result that far less is heard of the subject now. However, it is necessary to guard against any feeling of overconfidence; the possibility of inflation is by no means settled for good.

Cardinal O'Connell of Boston, Henry S. Alien, Mrs. Elsie Allen, Mr. and Mrs. William Alien White, Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence Copley Thaw, Giovanni Gerolami, Miss Dorothy S. Ives, Mrs Guy D. Randle, Miss James D. Walters and Mr. and Mrs. J. Gates Williams are among those who will arrive today from Mediterranean ports on the motor ship Vulcania of the Italian Line.

RIVERSIDE, Calif., Oct. 18 (AP). -- Richard Bonelli of New York, Metropolitan Opera Company baritone, and Miss Mona Chapman Wood, daughter of the late Charles Modini-Wood, opera singer, were married in Riverside Inn today by Dr. Remsen Bird, president of Occidental College and close friend of Mr. Bonelli.

BERLIN, Oct. 18. -- The district loaders of National Socialism are now in Berlin, summoned to plan a campaign for unanimous endorsement by the German people of the government's attitude toward disarmament and the ideals of Geneva.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 18. -- An Executive order, directing the Tariff Commission to investigate imports to determine what if any restrictions should be put on foreign goods to keep them from destroying the domestic production price balance sought under the industrial recovery program, was reported today as well on its way to the White House for President's Roosevelt's promulgation.

The maintenance of character-forming agencies as part of the 1933 campaign for the Mobilization for Human Needs was impressed upon 300 leaders of the Young Men's and Young Women's Christion Associations yesterday at a luncheon in the Hotel Shelton.

The local NRA organization, of which Grover A. Whalen is chairman, fall into line without delay yesterday with the orders issued by President Roosevelt to General Hugh S. Johnson, National Recovery Administrator, to proceed energetically against violators of NRA codes and the President's Agreement in an effort to weed out "chiselers" in the campaign for national recovery.
MANAGUA, Nicaragua, Oct. 18 (AP). -- Three Americans were killed late today in an airplane that plunged from a height of 2,000 feet into Lake Managua.

German steamship lines have no knowledge of orders issued by the German Government to importers, requiring them to use flag ships exclusively in booking their shipments, Christian J. Beck, director of freight traffic of the Hamburg-American Lines, declared yesterday.

The America's Cup situation settled down to a period of expectant waiting yesterday following Tuesday's announcement from London that the Royal Tacht Squadron had issued a challenge for the historic trophy on behalf of Thomas Octave Murdoch Sopwith.

LONDON, Oct. 18. -- Asserting that Great Britain's battle fleet, "the backbone of our defense," is now "getting past its prime," Admiral Sir Ernie Chatfield, First Sea Lord and chief of the naval staff, tonight warned that "the nation must take stock of its defense position."

CHICAGO, Oct. 18. -- Libraries were held essential to the "existence of a democratic society" and the "continuity of civilization" by three foreign scholars in addresses today before the convention of the American Library Association. The value of libraries to the people in periods of economic stress was also emphasized.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 18. -- Attorney General Cummings has been urged to give an immediate and definite opinion upon the legality of the liquor advertising campaign which is being carried on by a group of importers and wholesalers in anticipation of prohibition repeal.
BISMARCK, N. D., Oct. 18 (AP). -- The entire North Dakota National Guard was ordered held in readiness by Governor Langer today to enforce his wheat embargo.

Prices of bonds were reactionary en the Stock Exchange yesterday, all groups of domestic corporation and foreign obligations finishing moderately lower on the day. United State's Government loans, however, moved irregularly higher, closing up 4-32 to down 2-32 points.

A jury in Judges james M. Barrett's part of Bronx County Court retired at 7:16 o'clock last night to consider a verdict in the ease of four men charged with murdering Michael Malloy, a derelict stationary engineer, for $1,788 insurance they had placed on his life.

NORFOLK, Va., Oct. 18 (AP). -- The condition of Rear Admiral Richard E. Byrd, confined to his bed at the Monticello Hotel because of throat trouble since Sunday, was reported today as "steadily improving."

A strike of about 3,500 employes of towboats, barges and other similar craft will be called tomorrow night unless their employers agree to an eight-hour working day, it was announced yesterday by William A. Maher, secretary of the Associated Marine Workers.
Columbia reached the peak of its training yesterday at Baker Field in preparation for its contest with Princeton on Saturday.

A strike of about 3,500 employes of towboats, barges and other similar craft will be called tomorrow night unless their employers agree to an eight-hour working day, it was announced yesterday by William A. Maher, secretary of the Associated Marine Workers.
Columbia reached the peak of its training yesterday at Baker Field in preparation for its contest with Princeton on Saturday.

The Jackson Democratic Club, the regular Democratic organization in the Fourth Assembly District of the Bronx, deserted its leader, Park Commissioner Thomas J. Dolen, who is supporting Mayor O'Brien, last night. It endorsed the county leadership of Edward J. Flynn and pledged its efforts to elect Joseph V. McKee and the full Recovery party ticket.

In one's childhood parrots seemed to come straight from "The Arabian Nights," and the talking birds had the plumage of the gorgeous East. There was something human and yet something sardonic and devilish about them. You mustn't think, writes some wise-acre in the Encyclopedia, that because the parrot repeats sounds and words and phrases, it is anything more than a mimic or "understands what it is saying."

Hirsch Jacobs, who hopes to set a modern record by saddling more than 100 winners this season, added another to his long string when he sent out the B.B. Stable's Field Goal to win the featured fourth race at Empire City yesterday. Field Goal won by the scant margin of a head.

Discussion of the proposed international series among twelve-meter yachts next Summer, which was thrown into a state of considerable uncertainty by the challenge for the America's Cup, is expected to play an important part in the annual general meeting of the North American Yacht Racing Union at the Yale Club on Nov. 17.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 19. -- The Public Works Administration allocated $4,392,500 today to the Interior Department for construction and repair of roads and buildings at various national military parks and battlefields and $2,113,000 to the Bureau of Indian Affairs for construction of fifty day schools on Southwestern Indian reservations.

ST. PAUL, Oct. 19 (AP). -- A strike of farmers at noon Saturday was called tonight by directors of the National Farm Holiday Association, who hoped to increase prices by drying up the channels through which produce flows to market.

BERLIN, Oct. 19. -- Only a few hours before Germany's formal notification of her withdrawal from the League of Nations was sent to Geneva today, the officially inspired Diplomatische-Politische Korrespondenz asserted that "it will be easy to find a basis of understanding for regulating the equality question" if the other powers defined their disarmament intentions.
BISMARCK, Oct. 19 (AP). -- Wheat laden cars trundled out of North Dakota tonight in defiance of Governor Langer's embargo, aimed to produce higher prices for the grain.

The Department of Labor acted last night to prevent a strike of the 3,500 employes of tugboats and self-propelled lighters in New York harbor which is threatened by the refusal of operators of the craft to grant an eight-hour workging day. A representative of the department was ordered here to investigate the situation.

HAMILTON, N.Y., Oct. 19. -- Thirty-two Colgate players departed tonight, after a final workout on the home field, for the game with N.Y.U. The injured tackles, Warren Davis and Jim O'Hara, did not make the trip. In the squad were six ends, four tackles, six guards, three centres and thirteen backs.
F.H. LaGuardia, Fusion Mayoralty nominee, continues to lead in the poll being conducted by The Literary Digest, according to figures released for publication today by the magazine.

PELHAM, N.Y., Oct. 19. -- Alded by a streak of brilliant putting on the second nine, Mrs. Edgar Arnold of the Middle Patent Club annexed the low gross honors in the one-day tourney of the Women's Westchester and Fairfield Golf Association held over the Pelham Country Club links today.

To the Editor of The New York Times: This country persists in approaching the legal restoration of liquor as if the industry were an outlaw. Thirty-three States so far have bashed prohibition as fast as their election machinery permitted, and yet, on the whole, we shouder over the thing we are so exuberantly unleashing, as if we had voted to turn the prison population loose upon society.

Freeman Pinkett, 35 years old, a six-foot Negro who has served two terms in Sing Sing tor burglary, was arrested yesterday afternoon as he was leaving his home at 202 West 118th Street and locked up at the East Sixty-fifth Street police station charged with robbery.

ARLINGTON DOWNS, Texas, Oct. 19. -- Horse racing with legal betting came back to Texas today for the first time in more than a quarter of a century. A card of seven races at this $3,000,000 track Attracted Vice President John N. Garner and other notables.

Zeppelin and Macon. Chicago is soon to have a visit from the Graf Zeppelin, piloted by Dr. ECKENER. He Knows how to advertise airship transportation. The prospect of traveling by dirigible would be dark if the Graf Zeppelin had not remained in commission and ranged the seas and continents.

LONDON, Oct. 15. -- George Lansbury, leader of the Labor party, warned tonight that the British working masses would never help in any "preventive war" or other coercion that might be tried against Germany.

In peak form for the battle with Boston College at the Polo Grounds tomorrow, Fordham's football team participated in a three-hour workout at Fordham Field yesterday. The drill was the final heavy workout before the encounter with the Eagles.

Despite the program of humanized, non-political public relief announced by Mr. LAGUARDIA, those who have to do with relief in this city are beginning to make plans for collecting a fund of $4,000,000 to carry on the work of family agencies. The Gibson committee last year raised a fund of $18,000,000 for varied emergency relief purposes.

For the second day in a row the New York University varsity football team engaged in a brisk scrimmage against the freshman eleven at Ohio Field yesterday. This workout practically concluded the most intensive week of preparation the Violet has undergone thus far this season.

HANOVER, N.H., Oct. 19. -- Dartmouth finished preparations for the Pennsylvania game today as the squad went through its last practice of the week. No drill is scheduled for tomorrow and the team will leave in the afternoon for New York, staying there until Saturday morning.

CHICAGO, Oct. 19. -- Big Ten football stadium turnstiles, already lubricated by an approximate turnout of 200,000 fans last week, will sing their merriest tune in five long years if the weather is half-way reasonable on Saturday.

The last time an Army team headed north through the tunnel above the little station at West Point, bound for the Middle West and a game with Illinois, a big, blond-haired man with a ready smile was in charge as coach. Among the cadets in the car reserved for the varsity players was a square-shouldered chap with curly reddish brown hair.

BERLIN, Oct. 19. -- Following Chancellor Hitler's keynote speech to Nazi leaders yesterday, in which he offered his hand to former domestic opponents who "prove that they are adherents of German honor and love for peace," Cardinal Bertram, Archbishop of Breslau, issued an appeal to the government today to cease its persecution of political opponents.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 19. -- On a theory that some kidnappings of recent months may have been the work of criminals having knowledge of the Lindbergh abduction outrage, that unsolved case was transferred today to the Department of Justice for renewed investigation.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 19. -- Secretary Ickes, Administrator of the Petroleum Code, ordered sweeping limitations today upon all oil refineries in order to "set up proper ratios between gasoline inventories and sales for each district."

"The Green Bay Tree," a play by Mordaunt Shairp which has been a London success, will have its Broadway premiere this evening at the Cort Theatre. Jed Harris is presenting the play and James Dale, Laurence Oliver, O.P. Heggie, Jill Esmond and Leo G. Carroll appear in the cast.

The four men on trial before Judge James M. Barrett in Bronx County Court for murdering Michael Malloy, a derelict stationary engineer, were found guilty of murder in the first degree at 4:16 A.M. yesterday. The evidence showed that the defendants cashed $800 insurance they had placed on Malloy's life.
LONDON, Oct. 19. -- Colonel Charles A. Lindbergh made the regretful statement today that there could be no regular Atlantic air service over the Greenland route for another year or more.
Prices on the Cotton Exchange fluctuated nervously and Irregularly yesterday in a range of $1 a bale and ended unchanged to 5 points lower than on Wednesday.

A plan for slum clearance in the Red Hook district of Brooklyn to be laid out on the marginal railroad terminal property at a cost of $6,665,935 was submitted to the Board of Estimate yesterday by the Henry Street Basin Housing Association.

HAVANA, Oct. 19 (AP). -- The militant and numerically strong ABC Radical secret society, one of the chief supporting factions of the Grau San Martin government when it took control of Cuban affairs, announced tonight it was withdrawing its support from the present leaders.

PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 19. -- The Princeton football squad went through it last hard practice of the week today and will take a light workout in Palmer Stadium tomorrow to finish its preparation for the Columbia game here on Saturday.

Reports that Dr. William J. O'Shea, Superintendent of Schools, retiring at the end of January, will be succeeded by Dr. Harold G. Campbell, deputy and associate superintendent, were unconfirmed yesterday at the Board of Education.

NEW YORK. Mr. and Mrs. Edward Livingston Burrill will give a dinner dance at the Pierre Dec. 1 for her granddaughter, Miss Ellen Tuck French, in advance of the first Junior Assembly. Miss French was formally introduced to society in Newport during the Summer.

LONDON, Oct. 19. -- Mysterious buyers of gold in the London bullion market are rapidly filling the vaults of leading banks and safe deposits with bars of the precious metal, and it is understood that some banks are seeking additional storage space in the expectation that the buying craze will continue.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 19. -- President Roosevelt issued the customary proclamation tonight designating Nov. 11 as Armistice Day, as follows:

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Oct. 19 (AP). -- One coal miner was killed today as he and 15,000 fellow members of the Progressive Miners of America swarmed into the State capital with demands for union recognition.

After owning the seventeen-story Green Sixth Avenue Building at 100 Sixth Avenue for a week, the Junior Leasing Corporation has resold it to the Corporation of Trinity Church, it was announced yesterday. The structure was held at about $2,000,000 and was built three years ago by Vivian Green, who sold it last week to the Junior Leasing Corporation.

ABOARD THE GRAF ZEPPELIN, Oct. 19. -- The Graf Zeppelin, aided by a ground crew of 200 soldiers, landed at Campo Affonsos, Brazilian military field in the suburbs of Rio de Janeiro, precisely on schedule time at 6 A.M. today with nineteen passengers, some of them making the triangular trip from Europe to South America and the United States.

The Federal Reserve System is expected to participate actively soon in the affairs of the Bank for International Settlements through the election of George L. Harrison, governor of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, to the board of the World Bank.

With a loss of 2.2 points for the week, The Annalist weekly index of wholesale commodity prices dropped to 103.2 on Tuesday, from 105.4 the week before. The decline was attributed to the announcement of the government's refunding program, which was taken by the speculative public as indicating that "greenback" inflation of the currency was not favored by the administration.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 19. -- Much of the blame for a perceptible increase in liquor smuggling into the United States was laid by government officials today at the door of medicinal liquor distributers who have shot up their prices since the liberalization of prescription regulations.

Louis Benson, formerly a stenographer for the New York County grand jury, resumed his testimony yesterday as a State witness at the trial of Isidor J. Kresel in the Criminal Branch of the Supreme Court. Mr. Kresel is accused of abetting in the misapplication of about $2,000,000 of the funds of the defunct Bank of United States in 1930.

These orders were issued yesterday: Special Notice. Deputy chiefs of department shall forward consolidated reports on Monday, Oct. 23, giving the number of bonfires extinguished by the various companies under their jurisdiction on Election Day, 1932.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 19. -- A tentative milk marketing agreement covering the Greater New York-New Jersey area, the nation's largest milk-consuming territory, was laid before the Agricultural Adjustment Administration today by a committee of eighteen, headed by Henry S. Manley of the New York Milk Control Board.

Savings and loan associations have been notified by the State Banking Department that dividends must be limited after Dec. 15, it was learned yesterday. Instalment and accumulative prepaid shares, on which some associations have paid 6 per cent, are limited to 4 1/2 per cent.

Plays like "The Curtain Rises." which was acted at the Vanderbilt last evening, are not so much written as assembled out of the theatre's shed of spare parts. B.M. Kaye, the author, is here relating the story of the rich young girl who falls in love with her poor but modest teacher.

The address by Joseph V. McKee at Public School 84, Brooklyn, last night follows: I come here tonight to talk of hunger. Come down to Powell Street here in Brownsville with me and peek into the windows of one of those unfortunate families who through no fault of their own are today on the city's relief rolls.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 19. -- Attorney General Cummings disclosed today that he was trying to persuade George Medalie, Republican, to remain as District Attorney in the Southern District of New York until his term expires under the law.
A memorial meeting at Town Hall in honor of the late Dr. Charles H. Parkhurst, life-long foe of Tammany Hall, was turned into a Fusion rally last night.

CHICAGO, Oct. 19. -- A prediction that ranks of the unemployed in the United States would be cut by 3,000,000 or 4,000,000 by Spring as a result of the $3,300,000,000 public works fund was made today by V. Gilmore Iden of New York, a member of the staff of the American Institute of Steel Construction, at the institute's convention meeting in the Stevens Hotel.

BERLIN, Oct. 19. -- The stock market displayed a sagging trend today, due mainly to scarcity of buying orders, but losses usually stayed within 1 to 2 per cent. The public has adopted a waiting attitude, and, although many speeches by political and business leaders have exerted a calming influence, some foreign interests continue to liquidate.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 19.-- The Interstate Commerce Commission today authorized the Baltimore Ohio Railroad to file tariffs, canceling further operations over several routes of the Buffalo, Rochester Pittsburgh Railroad, which it owns.
Outside of a factory deal in Union City the New Jersey realty trading reported yesterday was confined almost exclusively to one-family dwellings.

Although rumors flew and bets were placed here and in London that France would leave the gold standard within a few days, Paris appeared yesterday to have recovered from its alarm over the franc. The French exchange rallied smartly from its severe break of Wednesday, carrying with it all other important foreign currencies and forcing down the gold value of the dollar 67 points to 70.27 per cent of par.

Charge Payments Continue Gain An increase of 2.52 per cent in retail charge account collections for September is shown by the index covering twenty local key stores, it was announced yesterday by the Credit Bureau of Greater New York, Inc.

LONDON, Oct. 19. -- A committee representing holders of German bonds here asked the British Government today to protest against agreements recently concluded by Germany with her Dutch and Swiss creditors.

CAMBRIDGE, Maas., Oct. 19. -- A twenty-minute defensive drill against forward passes and a dummy scrimmage between the A and B and the B and C varsities today ended the Harvard football squad's hard work for the Holy Cross game.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 19. -- Regulations issued by the Argentine Finance Ministry to the effect that no exchange should be released to foreign creditors on terms more favorable than those provided in the recent Anglo-Argentine agreement leave the American creditor no worse off than he has been for the past two years, according to views held here today.

Almost entirely as a result of the intervening Columbus Day holiday, which occurred in the preceding week last year, bank clearings at twenty-one leading cities showed a drop of 11.7 per cent from last year, according to Dun Bradstreet, Inc. The review points out that for the two weeks the clearing's this year were 2.8 per cent above 1932.

Although some 13,000 complaints of violations of codes and the President's Re-employment Agreement have been filed with the local NRA organization against New York employers, only a small part of these have been found valid or requiring serious investigation, it was revealed yesterday at the NRA headquarters, 45 Broadway.

While most of the markets were confused and irregular yesterday, stocks continued to point steadily downward under the pressure of more aggressive selling. Prices on the Stock Exchange declined 1 to 6 points in trading that aggregated 2,900,000 shares, the heaviest of the month and comparing with 1,734,000 on Wednesday.

MILAN, Italy, Oct. 19. -- Talk of the possible marriage of Archduke Otto, claimant to the Austrian throne, and the Italian Princess Maria was ridiculed tonight by Premier Mussolini's newspaper II Popolo d'Italia.

DETROIT, Oct. 19 (AP). -- Promises of support from the Roosevelt administration for ratification of the Great Lakes-St. Lawrence seaway treaty were heard tonight by the Great Lakes Harbors Association, along with demands that the seaway be constructed as an effective measure of farm relief.

For the first time in the history of the Brooklyn police, a mounted patrolman, John H. Heingartner of Troop E, has been suspended from duty pending trial on charges of beating his horse about the head with a nightstick. He also will be tried for abusing citizens and being intoxicated while on duty.

The better tone prevailing in the wheat and cotton markets, following a period of heavy liquidation, is attributed in some reports to buying by the Government. Its action gives effect to the policy, recently announced, of direct Federal purchases of food and clothing for distribution among the destitute unemployed.

Judge Robert A. Inch in the Brooklyn Federal Court deferred action yesterday on an application by counsel for a group of minority bondholders of the bankrupt Realty Associates Securities Corporation for the removal of Frank Fox as a receiver.

Charles Solomon, Socialist candidate for Mayor, challenged his Fusion opponent, F.H. LaGuardia, last night on the issue of municipal housing and unemployment relief. He termed the Fusion candidate's municipal, housing program a "mockery" and assailed the ''Republican allies of Fusion" for the defeat of the municipal housing bill in the State Assembly on Wednesday.

Yesterday's reduction of the New York Reserve Bank's rediscount rate brings it down to 2 per cent. Until the world-wide and rapid decline of money rates, in the first year after the panic of 1929, such a "bank rate" would have been described as the lowest ever known.

A definite move to liquidate the assets of the Harriman National Bank and Trust Company was indicated yesterday through an announcement by the Manufacturers Trust Company that Frederick V. Goess, vice president of the Manufacturers, had been appointed receiver of the Harriman, effective as of Oct. 16.

Prices for future deliveries continued to decline yesterday on local commodity exchanges. They opened lower than they had closed on Wednesday and sagged until late in the day, when a moderate recovery occurred. Cash prices also finished lower.

COLUMBIA, S.C., Oct. 19. -- Before a State fair crowd of 14,000 persons, Clemson and the University of South Carolina played their annual game today under sunny skies, South Carolina triumphing, 7 to 0.

As a result of yesterday's decline on the Stock Exchange, which matched that of the day before, stock price averages were carried to the lowest level since last May. The net decline in these averages, as compiled by THE NEW YORK TIMES, has amounted to $8.34 for the month to date.

HONOLULU, Oct. 19. -- Greeted by dignitaries of Hawaii, hula girls and a crowd of 10,000 enthusiasts, George Herman (Babe) Ruth arrived today for two exhibition baseball games and as much golf as he is able to squeeze in during his ten-day visit to the Territory.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil, Oct. 19 (AP). -- A half hour after its arrival here early today, the Graf Zeppelin departed for Chicago with seventeen passengers, most of whom were bound for the Century of Progress Exposition.

The Chrysler Corporation reported yesterday a net profit of $7,190,148 for the quarter ended on Sept. 30, which was equivalent to $1.67 a share on 4,305,209 shares of $5 par value capital stock. This contrasted with a loss of $5,346,146 in the corresponding period of 1932.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 19. -- Members of the National Legitimate Theatre Committee in New York, who yesterday moved to stop alleged unfair practices in ticket selling to Broadway attractions, moved too rapidly, in the view of the National Recovery Administration.

Graft and political favoritism by Tammany in the administration of the relief funds were charged last night by Joseph V. McKee, Recovery party nominee for Mayor, in a speech at Public School 84 in the Brownsville section of Brooklyn.

A strike of 25,000 gasoline filling station attendants in New York and vicinity was threatened last night by the newly formed Gasoline Station Workers Union at a meeting in Odd Fellows' Hall, 301 Schermerhorn Street, Brooklyn. At the meeting the union received a charter from the American Federation of Labor.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 19. -- Albert H. Wiggin testified today before the Senate Banking and Currency Committee that he and his family were interested in stock-market operations from 1927 to 1932, in which large blocks of Chase National Bank shares were sold.

PARIS, Oct. 19. -- Chesley W. Jurney, the sergeant-at-arms of the United States Senate and former secretary to Senator Copeland of New York, had to do a lot of explaining today, because of his lack of knowledge of the French language and the eagerness of France to further the sale of its wines in the United States after repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment.

All is not brotherly love in the Conservative party of Great Britain. At the recent conference of Conservatives and Unionists at Birmingham, two challenging and divisive resolutions were on the agenda. One sharply attacked the Government's policy in India.

Advertising of alcoholic beverages other than light beer "should, where possible, be rigidly restricted or forbidden" under either a State monopoly or a State license plan, Raymond B. Fosdick and Albert L. Scott assert in the instalment of their liquor control report released yesterday.

Tammany men have begun to express the belief that the bitter campaign being waged by Joseph V. McKee and F.H. LaGuardia against each other may result in sufficient damage to both to permit the re-election of Mayor O'Brien.

E.M. Delafield, author of the Provincial Lady diaries, will be guest of honor at the Dutch Treat Luncheon on Tuesday noon and will then leave for Chicago, she decided yesterday. She will stay in Chicago and other mid-West cities until Nov. 20, when she will return here for about ten more days before sailing for home.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 (AP). -- Indicated expenditures for all building construction were reported today by the Bureau of Labor Statistics to have increased 9.7 per cent in September as compared with August, with the total number of building permits declining 3.7 per cent.

The Family Welfare Committee's campaign for a $4,000,000 fund to finance unemployment relief activities by family welfare agencies of the city was praised yesterday by directors of the Federal, State and city relief administrations.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 19. -- The rise in the general level of wholesale commodity prices which began in March continued unbroken during September, according to an announcement made by the Bureau of Labor Statistics of the Department of Labor.

To the Editor of The New YorK Times: Ordinarily a local campaign possesses but an academic interest to one living a distance from the City of New York and is no affair of his; hut the anti-Semite charge brought against Mr. McKee, one of your candidates for Mayor, deeply concerns Jews wherever they live.

The pledging of 101 freshmen by eighteen fraternities at Columbia College was announced yesterday by Nicholas McD. McKnight, associate dean of the college, at the close of the first three days of the pledging period.

WESTBURY, L.I., Oct. 19. -- Mrs. Robert Bacon, chairman of the national woman's committee for Washington Cathedral, was hostess this afternoon at Old Acres, her country home here, at a tea which followed a meeting of persons interested in the work of the cathedral which is in progress at Mount Saint Albans in Washington.

Almon G. Rasquin, Collector of Internal Revenue, who took charge of the First New York District, including all of Long Island and Staten Island, last Aug. 21, announced yesterday at his office in Brooklyn that he had asked for the resignation of eighteen of his deputies, to become effective Nov. 15.
Dr. John H. Finley, former president of Knox and City Colleges, observed his seventieth birthday quietly yesterday, spending a large part of the day at his desk.
BERLIN, Oct. 19 (AP). -- Chancellor Hitler today reiterated his demand that equal rights be accorded to Germany, said she wanted only peace and declared she had heavy domestic burdens.

A plan for reorganizing the Paramount Publix Corporation will be submitted soon to creditors and to security holders' committees by Sir William Wiseman of Kuhn, Loeb Co., bankers for the film concern, has announced. In addition to the bankruptcy of the parent organization many of the operating subsidiaries are in receivership, making the situation complex, he said.

Many parties were given at the St. Regis last night in conjunction with the opening for the season of the Seaglade. During the evening a program of entertainment was presented featuring several prominent theatrical and vaudeville performers.

New York City's water is as limpid and clear as usual as it runs from householders' faucets, but up at its source in the Cats-kills, water supply engineers disclosed yesterday, it looks more like a reddish paint these days than anything fit to wash in or drink.

NEW PROVIDENCE, N.J., Oct. 19. -- Nicholas J. Delmore, a former Republican leader here and one of a group of men indicted for the murder of John G. Finiello, a Federal prohibition agent, during a government raid at the Rising Sun Brewery, Elizabeth, Sept. 19, 1930, was captured this morning when Chief County Detective Roy A. Martin and County Detectives Frank Bruggy and Michael Tevnan awakened him in his country home in Snyder Avenue here.
PARIS, Oct. 19 (AP). -- The weekly statement of the Bank of France shows the following changes in francs:
BERLIN, Oct. 19. -- Germany tonight formally notified the Secretariat of the League of Nations of her withdrawal from the League.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 19. -- President Roosevelt undertook today a study of possible legislation under which the government, through use of its taxing power, could curb high salaries paid by industry.

F.H. LaGuardia slapped Mayor O'Brien on the back yesterday and characterized him as personally honest but machine-shackled at a luncheon yesterday of the New York League of Business and Professional Women and the New York Exchange Club at the Hotel New Yorker.

In publishing its latest returns of the Mayoralty poll in this city, The Literary Digest properly and cautiously refuses to draw positive inferences from the figures. They are yet far from being complete, and contain several puzzling features. The vote for Mayor O'BRIEN, only 34,922 out of a total of 281,090, is so small as to be inexplicable.
Joseph V. McKee, Recovery party candidate for Mayor, and his backers hit back yesterday at F.H. LaGuardia, Fusion nominee.

The Labor Bureau's general index of manufacturing employment in September, which was issued in Washington Tuesday, compares as follows with preceding months and years, with the average for the full year 1926 reckoned as 100. Comparisons are based on eighty-nine industries since the end of 1930 and on fifty-four for earlier dates.
The twentieth and final performance of "The Romance of a People," Jewish historical pageant, was held last night before 18,000 persons at the Kingsbridge Armory.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 19. -- Prizewinning pictures in the thirty-first Carnegie international exhibition of modern paintings were announced today and the prizes, totaling $3,300, were awarded by Samuel Harden Church, president of the board of trustees of Carnegie Institute.

Samuel Untermyer denounced as a "demagogic play to the galleries" Joseph V. McKee's pledge to repeal the water rate increase, in an address broadcast last night. Mr. Untermyer, financial adviser to the city and sponsor of the rate rise, spoke over Station WOR.

The Pennsylvania Railroad announced yesterday that it would file tariffs on Oct. 28 with the Interstate Commerce Commission and with State commissions for door collection and delivery of less than carloads of merchandise to take effect throughout its system on Dec. 1.

Decision whether voting machines or paper ballots are to be used in the Nov. 7 elections was postponed again yesterday by the Board of Elections until today. The board spent the day listening to argument over whether a number of minor party candidates should be put off the ballot.

Ogden L. Mills, Secretary of the Treasury under President Hoover, entered the fight for Fusion last night. In a radio address from WOR he strongly urged the election of F.H. LaGuardia and his running-mates.

The Federal Reserve Bank of New York yesterday reduced its rediscount rate to 2 per cent from 2 1/2 per cent, the rate which had been in effect since May 26. At the same time the weekly report of the Federal Reserve System showed that the reserve's open-market campaign to expand credit had been slowed down by a reduction of the weekly rate of purchases of United States Government securities from $35,000,000 to $31,000,000.
ALBANY, Oct. 19. -- Governor Lehman is expected to sign tomorrow the two New York City Relief Bills which were among those passed yesterday at the brief session of the Legislature.
BERLIN, Oct. 19. -- The German Government announced today the creation of a "Reich Office for Foreign Trade" as a part of its plans for recapturing world markets for German goods.
"Bombshell," with Jean Harlow, Lee Tracy and Frank Morgan, will be presented at the Capitol this morning.

A peaceful hour of musical competition between Cardinal O'Connell of Boston and William Alien White, newspaper editor of Emporia, Kan., was reported in detail by Mr. White when the liner Vulcania arrived yesterday from Trieste and Mediterranean ports.

FORT WORTH, Oct. 19. -- Vice President Garner and Postmaster General Farley headed a party of government officials participating here today in laying the corner-stone for the new $1,000,000 Federal Building and civic events incidental to a Democratic good-will tour of Texas.

CHICAGO, Oct. 19 (AP). -- A Century of Progress Exposition will observe "personal responsibility day" on Nov. 8, officials announced today in anticipation that prohibition repeal will have been voted by thirty-six States.
The Board of Estimate will receive today the proposed 1934 budget, which probably will show an increase of $37,609,135 over the 1933 budget total of $518,365,793.
WASHINGTON. Oct. 19. -- Because the strike in the "captive mines" in the Pennsylvania coal fields has reached a deadlock, the problem is now in the hands of President Roosevelt for solution.

On the first Armistice Day fifteen years ago George Grey Barnard, the sculptor, began work on his huge peace memorial rainbow arch. Next Armistice Day he will invite the public to see the completed plaster model which he is setting up in his improvised studio a former powerhouse at 216th Street and the Harlem River.
LINCOLN, Oct. 19. -- A revolt against the NRA broke out today in Nebraska, home of insurgent political leaders.

BOSTON, Oct. 19. -- Adventure still rides the tropic seas in vivid trappings, as Captain George H. Grant can testify. Captain Grant brought the steamship San Bruno of the United Fruit Company back to port today, leaving in her wake scenes of peril, awe and mystery.

DECATUR, Ala., Oct. 19 (AP). -- Judge W.W. Callahan of Morgan County Circuit Court announced today, after a conference with Attorney General Thomas E. Knight and Judge James E. Horton, that a special term of court would be called for Nov. 27 to try the "Scottsboro cases."

BALTIMORE, Oct. 19. -- By order of Governor Ritchie an investigation was begun today into the lynching last night of George Armwood, Negro, and the wounding of thirteen State troopers by an infuriated mob of men and women at Princess Anne.

The "loss-limitation" provision in the proposed retail code is designed to curb the use of "loss-leaders" obviously offered as "bait," and would affect the consumer, the farmer and labor by promoting "fair and healthy competition, which is the life of trade," according to Major B.H. Namm, president of A.I. Namm Son, Brooklyn.

The text of the address of Ogden L. Mills in support of the Fusion ticket over Station WOR last night follows: Unless all signs fall, the people are about to sweep out of office the representatives of the political organization which for sixteen years has held this city in complete domination.

Conferences between railroad and colliery officials to effect reductions in the cost of coal to the railroads were authorized yesterday by the Eastern coordinating committee at the instance of Jospeh B. Eastman, Federal Coordinator. The railroads had been urged to act on findings by the Interstate Commerce Commission, which contended that excessive prices for fuel were being paid by the carriers.

Receivers for the American Commonwealths Power Corporation have applied to the Chancery Court in Wilmington, Del., for permission to participate in the reorganization plans of the National Gas and Electric Corporation and the General Public Utilities Company, formerly subsidiaries of the Commonwealths company.

Philip Schlanger, the State's Chief witness and a complainant in the recent Brooklyn laundry racket trials, was accused yesterday of engaging in a racket of his own. He appeared before the Court of Special Sessions charged with coercion on the complaint of Aaron Deutsch, a laundry agent who said Schlanger had intimidated him into transferring his business from one laundry to another.
Representing the United States in the international military competitions at the National Horse Show will be the same team that won the chief trophy last year.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 19. -- The whole field of Anglo-American relations was called into question in a letter made public today from the Navy League of the United States to the Navy League of Great Britain.

PARIS, Oct. 19. -- Pronounced weakness of the French franc today, evidenced by the fact that every other currency rose sharply against it, led Georges Bonnet, Finance Minister, to authorize the Havas news agency tonight to declare that the renewed reports that France would leave the gold standard were entirely without foundation.

A further slowing down in the rate of business activity, which began late in July, was shown in the last six weeks, according to the monthly report of the conference of statisticians of the National Industrial Conference Board yesterday.

CHICAGO, Oct. 19. -- Scientific methods are becoming increasingly important in library work and librarianship is an integral part of social science, the American Library Association was told at its conference here today by Pierce Butler, Professor of Bibliography in the Graduate Library School of the University of Chicago.

LOU LITTLE is a great one for gathering the assistant football coaches about him and having what he calls a staff meeting. He holds one almost every day of the week in his office on the fourth floor of John Jay Hall at Columbia. The janitor of the building has protested, but, so far, without avail.

The resignation of John F. Galvin as chairman of the Port of New York Authority was accepted at a meeting of the commissioners yesterday afternoon at the executive offices, 111 Eighth Avenue. Major Gen. George R. Dyer, one of the six New York representatives in the body, was elected to succeed him.

Progress in transportation, communication, industry, commerce and journalism will be illustrated in a comprehensive exhibition to be opened in the lobby of the Hollywood Theatre on Wednesday evening, under the auspices of Warner Brothers.

Magnificent performances of Brahms's Third Symphony and Beethoven's Fourth Piano concerto distinguished the concert given last night in Carnegie Hall by the Philharmonic - Symphony Orchestra, Bruno Walter conductor. This concert, in fact, proved the most brilliant musical event, thus far, of the season.

Stitch (Samuel Rothberg) McCarthy, chief mayor in New York's League of Locality Mayors, obtained yesterday a Supreme Court order from Justice Cotillo requiring Louis Zeltner, chairman of the league, to show cause next Thursday morning why he should not be restrained from holding the next league election in Atlantic City.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 19. -- The daily average volume of Federal Reserve Bank credit outstanding during the week ended Oct. 18, as reported by the Federal Reserve Banks, was $2,497,000,000, an increase of $45,000,000 compared with the preceding week and of $262,000,000 compared with the corresponding week in 1932.

LAUREL, Md., Oct. 19 (AP). -- Hastipast, black 3-year-old filly racing for F.A. Carreaud, Texas horseman, lasted to gain a nose decision over Ladino in the six-furlong feature over a heavy track today. Longford was third in the field of seven.
Mayor John P. O'Brien, speaking last night from a platform on the Criterion Theatre, overlooking Times Square, addressed his largest audience of the campaign thus far.

LONDON, Oct. 19. -- More than the usual tributes to a new Ambassador were paid to Sir Eric Drummond, former secretary general of the League of Nations, at a luncheon today on the eve of his departure to represent Britain in Rome.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 19. -- In the Winter of 1932 proponents of a sales tax not only sought to disguise it under the name of a manufacturers' excise levy, but they exempted food and clothing to give the measure a chance for its life. Neither device was successful. A bipartisan group, led by Senator Norris and Representatives LaGuardia and Doughton, killed the bill.

LONDON, Oct. 19. -- Earl Beatty, Admiral of the Fleet, charged tonight that Great Britain had weakened her navy until she was "incapable of playing the part of a great power or guaranteeing safe passage at sea to her ships."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 (AP). -- Clinton L. Bardo, president of the New York Shipbuilding Company of Camden, N.J., filed a brief today with General Hugh S. Johnson, NRA Administrator, asking, that the thirty-two-hour provision of the shipbuilders' code be raised to forty hours a week.

The opening of the hunting season in New York State was marked by several forest fires and a number of accidents, first reports show. In all cases failure to observe primary rules of woodsmanship and hunting was the chief cause of the trouble.

Bond prices moved lower on the Stock Exchange yesterday with the exception of United States Government long-term issues, which finished unchanged to 4-32 point higher. A single exception in the government group was the Treasury 3 3/8s, due in 1943 and callable 1940, which eased 1-32.

Philip S. Harburger, chairman of the National Collegiate A.A. and Intercollegiate S.A. committees on swimming records, gave out yesterday the list of new standards approved for registration by the committees he heads.

Plans for the Hendrik Hudson Memorial Bridge over the Harlem ship canal, which have lain dormant on paper for almost thirty years, were revived yesterday by the Plant and Structures Department, which anounced that it would seek a $10,000,000 Federal loan for the project.

FORD MADOX FORD is one of the most enigmatic fellows in the world. But not when he is writing novels; his Tietjens series, commencing with "Some Do Not," is as objective as one could wish. It is when he turns to gossip about himself that the vast complexity which is Mr. Ford begins to take shape through the mist. "It Was the Nightingale" (Lippincott, $3), Mr. Ford's autobiography, provides us with a fascinating rigmarole.

Appointment of the Irving Trust Company as standing receiver eliminated the abuses common under the so-called bankruptcy ring, Senior Judge John C. Knox of the United States District Court testified yesterday at the Congressional inquiry into the bankruptcy situation here.

Former Governor Henry J. Allen of Kansas returned from Europe yesterday and replied to charges of singular duplications in the wording of one of his articles on Soviet Russia and a book on Russia by Ella Winter, the wife of Lincoln Steffens.
LONDON, Oct. 19 (AP). -- The weekly statement of the Bank of England shows the following changes, in pounds sterling:
LONDON, Oct. 19 (AP). -- The weekly statement of the Bank of England shows the following changes, in pounds sterling:

TARRYTOWN, N.Y., Oct. 19. -- The Town Board of Greenburgh, meeting here today, reduced the assessed valuation of the town from $153,000,000 to $138,000,000. Since the tax rate is $1.19 on each $100, the $15,000,000 reduction will save the 40,000 property owners $178,500 in taxes.

Testimony that the County Trust Company had advanced $1,500,000 for the Presidential campaign of Alfred E. Smith, later its chairman, in October, 1928, was given yesterday before Supreme Court Justice McCook and a jury. The testimony was heard in the suit by the trust company to recover $50,000 on a note signed by Timothy J. Mara, sports promoter, and $20,000 on one signed by Patrick F. Kenny, plumbing contractor.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Oct. 19 -- Surrogate Slater said here today he would appoint County Treasurer T. Darrington Semple of Westchester administrator of sixty-four of the many estates that have not yet been settled because of complications following thefts of $250,000 by former Deputy County Treasurer Leonard Teed, who is now in prison.

Philip S. Harburger, chairman of the National Collegiate A.A. and Intercollegiate S.A. committees on swimming records, gave out yesterday the list of new standards approved for registration by the committees he heads.

Plans for the Hendrik Hudson Memorial Bridge over the Harlem ship canal, which have lain dormant on paper for almost thirty years, were revived yesterday by the Plant and Structures Department, which anounced that it would seek a $10,000,000 Federal loan for the project.
BISMARCK, N.D., Oct. 20 (AP). -- Sheriffs were ordered today to enforce the State wheat embargo as Governor Langer shifted his line of attack in an effort to force prices upward.

Publication by the Citizens Union of its recommendations regarding the Board of Aldermen may serve not only as a guide to the independent voter but as a warning. The Aldermen are customarily of little importance. Only on the rarest occasions have any of the Tammany members shown the slightest independence.

Despite the advent of the hunting season in this State and Connecticut, the metropolitan sportsmen need not confine their efforts to sport in the fields, marshes or woods, if the inclination to do a little angling still lingers.

BERLIN, Oct. 20. -- Tne Nazi regime was in effect acquitted by the German Supreme Court today of complicity in the Reichstag fire when two of its outstanding representatives, charged in "the Brown Book of the Hitler Terror" with having led a Nazi "arson squad" into the Reichstag building, took the witness stand and denied under oath that they had anything to do with the blaze.
CLEVELAND, Oct. 20 (AP). -- Bob Zuppke's experienced Illini and the grim but determined Army came to Cleveland today for tomorrow's intersectional football team in the Stadium -- and the rubber game.

The Near-East Foundation is carrying forward rural projects in seven countries which, it is believed, will be valuable in aiding like areas throughout the world. For fourteen years the Near-East Relief gave to meet emergency conditions in that part of the world to which the West owes more than it can repay in material things.

ANN ARBOR, Mich., Oct. 20. -- The big, fast football squads of the University of Michigan and Ohio State, regarded as the 1933 gridiron giants of the Midwest got in their final practice sessions today in preparation for their battle in the Michigan Stadium tomorrow.
Howard H. Bellows has opened a realty and insurance office in 65 W. 73d St. He was formerly an officer of Goodwin Goodwin, Inc.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Oct. 20. -- President Roosevelt boarded his official yacht, the Sequoia, here tonight for a leisurely cruise to Chestertown, Md., where tomorrow he will receive the degree of Doctor of Laws from Washington College and participate in ceremonies in honor of George Washington, a founder of the college.

HARRISBURG, Pa., Oct. 20 (AP). -- Terming himself "Federal coordinator of railroads and doctor of transportation," Joseph B. Eastman said tonight the remedy for his sick patient lies in a single, Federal administration of all transportation regulation.

PARIS, Oct. 20. -- The news of President Roosevelt's invitation to the Soviet arrived here late tonight. The move had been fully expected here for several months and was frequently discussed, and hence it is safe to predict that considerable satisfaction will be expressed.

A large luncheon and fashion show were held yesterday in the Egyptian Room of the St. Regis for the benefit of Auxiliary No. 6 of Stony Wold Sanatorium, which provides care and treatment for young women suffering from pulmonary tuberculosis.

Former Governor Alfred E. Smith testified yesterday before Supreme Court Justice McCook and a jury that he told Timothy J. Mara and Patrick K. Kenny, being sued by the County Trust Company for $50,000 and $20,000, respectively, on notes, that as chairman of the trust company's board he must advise them to pay the notes, although given to aid in financing his campaign for President in 1928.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 20. -- The statement in THE NEW YORK TIMES today that the Federal Reserve System was expected to participate more actively in the affairs of the Bank of International Settlements through the election of Governor George I. Harrison of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York to its directorate caused little surprise in official circles today.

HUNTINGTON, L.I., Oct. 20. -- A.C. Allyn Co. of New York City won today the award of an $18,500 refunding water-bond issue of the South Huntington Water District. They bid $100.31, with interest at 5 1/4 per cent. Other bidders and bids were: Bank of Huntington and Trust Company, par, at 6 per cent; Sherwood, Merrifield Co., par, at 5.5 per cent; P.B. Roura, par, at 5.7 per cent with accrued interest.

A late rally yesterday turned losses into gains in most staples traded on local commodity exchanges. The reversal, which was attributed in part to reports of recognition of the Soviet Government, increased trading in futures, which had been dull.
BERLIN, Oct. 20 (AP). -- With the slogan "Germans refuse to be treated as an inferior nation," Dr. Paul Joseph Goebbels inaugurated tonight the government's campaign for the Nov. 12 plebiscite.

J.P. Morgan did two unusual things yesterday upon his arrival home on the Cunard liner Berengaria. He gave the ship news reporters their first good chance to interview him since September, 1931. More unusual still, however, he consented after the interview to go up on deck and pose for the photographers.

CARNEGIE TECH v. Notre Dame -- Carnegie Tech was founded in 1900. Notre Dame was founded in 1842. Thus Carnegie Tech is younger and has the better record so far this season; two victories in two games. Notre Dame has one victory, and one scoreless tie. Nevertheless and notwithstanding, the secretary will cast the usual vote for Notre Dame.

A plan for composition of the conflict between holders of securities of the United American Utilities, Inc., and its subsidiary, the Pacific Freight Lines Corporation, Ltd., has reached the stage where it will become the object of a petition before the Chancery Court in Wilmington, Del., early next week.

The New York University football team will oppose Colgate at the Yankee Stadium today, the contest being the seventh in a series which began in 1921. The Violet and Maroon each have won twice and two of the games ended in ties.
MACON, Ga., Oct. 20 (AP). -- Outplayed for a large part of the game, the University of Georgia eleven finally won today from the Mercer Bears, 13 to 12, by the margin of a placement.

HAVERFORD, Pa., Oct. 20. -- Haverford College's soccer team won the annual game with Princeton, 4 to 0, today. Russ Richie scored twice for the winners. Tom Brown and Al Stokes accounted for the other markers.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 20. -- Retail grocery sales for September, as indicated by a sampling of chain stores, rose 3.1 per cent in value over August, as compared with an increase of 1.1 per cent for September, 1932, over August of that year, according to preliminary estimates by Dr. Willard L. Thorp, director of the Bureau of Foreign and Domestic Commerce.

The Artists and Writers Dinner Club, which has given approximately 7,000 meals since last April to needy followers of the two crafts, has only $6 left in its treasury with which to face the Winter, while applications have been received from 240 additional persons in distress, most of them women.
The five-story building at 34 West Ninety-first Street has been leased furnished by John F. Gowlan, as broker for E. Balensweig. The tenant plans to alter the building into one and two room suites.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 20. -- State Department officials were busy today informing inquiring diplomats that the United States does not intend to lay an embargo on the wines and liquors of foreign countries.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 20. -- A grant of $2,614,595 to New York for unemployment relief was announced today by Harry L. Hopkins, Federal Emergency Relief Administrator. This allotment was on the matching basis of one Federal dollar for three of public expenditure within the State from all sources during July and August.
GENEVA, Oct. 20. -- Germany arranged today to start immediately dealing with the League of Nations through a consul, as the United States once did and Japan is doing now.

EDGEWATER, N.J., Oct. 20. -- Picket lines of strikers were resumed today at the assembly plant of the Ford Motor Company here, while demands of the workers were forwarded by plant officials to the main offices of the Ford company at Detroit.

BASLE, Oct. 20. -- Asked about the report that George L. Harrison, Governor of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, might replace Gates W. McGarrah on the board of the Bank for International Settlements, Leon Fraser, president of the world bank, today confined himself to saying that he knew nothing about it and had heard nothing of it.
The text of Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler's address at the Fusion meeting in Mecca Temple last night follows:

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Oct. 20. -- The Rutgers junior varsity eleven, coached by George Little, former head coach at Michigan and Wisconsin, opened its season today with a victory over Panzer College of East Orange, 32 to 0.

Statistically the share market did not vary greatly yesterday from the day before, except in the price changes. The volume on the Stock Exchange was 2,697,000 shares, against 2,895,000. But in the character of trading there was a vast difference.

HAVANA, Oct. 21. -- The ABC radical group which broke away from the main ABC body to support the student-army government issued tonight a proclamation bitterly criticizing the government and asserting that it had failed to establish peace, order, justice and liberty.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 20. -- The President took the big headlines away from the disgruntled Western farmers by selecting today for his announcement of diplomatic negotiations between this government and Soviet Russia. In the political community here tonight he is getting credit for another masterly publicity coup.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 (AP). -- American consumers will be called on to shoulder a tax load of more than $1,000,000,000 to finance the administration's program for a gigantic retreat in farm production.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 20. -- Temple's football team, playing its last game under floodlights this season, defeated West Virginia's eleven before 15,000 at the Temple Stadium tonight, 13 to 7. The Owls have not lost a night game in the last three years.
Conveyance of a Union City factory and a Mahwah estate sale featured the New Jersey realty trading reported yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 20. -- President Roosevelt's move to open discussions with Russia on the problems that have been holding that country and the United States apart in the diplomatic world met a generally hearty response in official circles today.

George Washington's autographed copy of "The Contrast," the first American play to prove a success on the American stage, brought $3,100 yesterday at the American Art Association Anderson Galleries, Inc., at the auction of books and autographs from the collection of James B. Wilbur of Manchester, Vt.

NEW YORK. Mrs. Paul Gibert Thebaud will give a supper dance Dec. 28 at the Colony Club to introduce to society her granddaughters, Miss Dorothy Mathilde Thebaud and Miss Marie Eugenie Thebaud, daughters of Mr. and Mrs. Paul G. Thebaud Jr.

"Mary of Scotland," one of the major theatrical events of the current season and the Theatre Guild's third offering, will begin its Broadway engagement at the Alvin Theatre on or about Nov. 13. The Alvin is directly oposite the Guild Theatre in West Fifty-second Street, where the Eugene O'Neill play "Ah, Wilderness!" featuring George M. Cohan, is housed.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 20. -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on Oct. 14 totaled 664,058 cars, the American, Railway Association announced today. This was 9,630 cars, or 1.5 per cent more that for the preceding week, and 14,368 oars, or 2.2 per cent more than for the corresponding week last year, but 97,538 cars, or 12.8 per cent fewer than during the corresponding week two years ago.
PARIS, Oct. 20. -- Some idea of the difficulties being experienced by the de luxe hotel industry in Paris is contained in the annual report today by the company operating the Hotel Majestic.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 20. -- President Roosevelt made public today the correspondence between him and President Kalinin bearing upon the question of Russian recognition, which is printed below.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The Department of Agriculture has overlooked two vitally important facts in its vast and expansive program of farm relief. In the first place, low prices of commodities are the natural result of labor-saving machinery and economical devices.

Albert Eugene Gallatin gave a dinner last night in the Neptune grill of the Pierre. His guests were Mr. and Mrs. Orme Wilson, Mr. and Mrs. Reginald B. Lanier, Mr. and Mrs. Alexander Nelidow and Mr. and Mrs. O'Donnell Iselin.

CHICAGO, Oct. 20. -- Limited receipts of hog's here resulted today in an early advance of 10 to 20 cents a hundredweight in prices, but after the supply had been picked over the remainder received generally bids at yesterday's levels from packers.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 20. -- Despite the fact that the rubber industry will show a substantial deficit this year, it will pay about $33,000,000 in Federal taxes for the tax year 1933, A.L. Viles, general manager of the Rubber Manufacturers Association, asserted today in testimony on the rubber tire code.

Thirty-four institutions here and abroad share legacies totaling $370,000 and personal bequests of more than $300,000 are disposed of in the will of Miss Georgiana Kendall, daughter of the late Isaac Choate Kendall, and Elizabeth Rogers Kendall, welfare worker and antivivisection supporter, filed yesterday in Surrogate's Court.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 20. -- President Roosevelt announced today that arrangements had been made for an early discussion between him and Maxim Litvinoff, Russian Commissar for Foreign Affairs, of the problems surrounding recognition by this country of the Soviet Government.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 20. -- The public works administration should help develop a system of suitable airports throughout the country as a means of national defense and for promotion of commercial aviation, Hiram Bingham, president of the National Aeronautic Association, declared in opening the association's annual meeting today.

PATERSON, N.J., Oct. 20. -- Violence flared up in the silk dyers strike today when 500 strikers who had gathered before a mill in East Paterson, a silk-manufacturing settlement across the Passaio River from this city, engaged in a pitched battle with more than fifty policemen, Sheriffs' deputies and private guards.

Hedging pressure, which is normally the oversahdowing feature at the present stage of the cotton marketing season, was again comparatively light yesterday on the Cotton Exchange and prices moved upward 30 points at one time. Early trading was slow, but an improvement in other markets on reports that an important announcement was about to be made in Washington started commission house and professional buying.
The United States and the rest of the world must go forward to communism or it will revert to barbarism, John St. Loe Strachey, British author and former member of Parliament, said yesterday.

ATHENS, Oct. 20. -- Entrenched on the narrow ground that separates the Greek bankruptcy laws from the American, Samuel Insull tonight expressed himself as confident that united forces or the American and Greek Governments would again find his position impregnable at his second United States extradition hearing tomorrow morning.

LAUREL, Md., Oct. 20 (AP). -- Mrs. F.M. Gould's Daniel Soot qualified cleverly for his Chevy Chase Handicap engagement here Wednesday when he raced to a clean-cut victory in the Bucklands Steeplechase of two miles today.

The recognition of Soviet Russia by the United States, which is expected to result from the conversations between President Roosevelt and Foreign Commissar Litvinoff, will lead to a development of trade relations between the two countries, according to financial circles who have been following Russian economic developments.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 (AP). -- The Senate committee investigating ocean mail contracts heard today that nothing was done about a Department of Justice report in 1930 which said that favors granted a Merchant Fleet Corporation official by a ship line head "might constitute criminal acts."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 20. -- The Senate Banking and Currency Committee decided today to seek information on stock market practices since 1928 direct from the members of the New York Stock Exchange instead of through the Exchange's cooperation.

When a hunter shoots an elephant, even one which has been charging him, the first feeling on walking up to the fallen animal is regret, F. Trubee Davison, president of the American Museum of Natural History, who recently arrived from Africa with five elephants, told guests at a dinner in his honor at the Waldorf-Astoria last night.

Speaking on the same night, Judge SEABURY as a Democrat and OGDEN MILLS as a Republican defined in the same way the object and method of the Fusion movement. In it partisan politics were to be ignored. Public-spirited members of both parties agreed to sink their political differences for the sake of electing a nonpartisan government to clean up this city.

TRENTON, N.J., Oct. 20. -- The State Sinking Fund Commission has gone to the financial rescue of Jersey City, it was disclosed today, by the purchase of $1,027,000 in 6 per cent bonds, which were exchanged for those of other municipalities.

MOSCOW, Oct. 20. -- Although recognition of the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics by the United States would put a crown on Soviet achievements, the Russians are not willing to admit this. There are no eager congratulations and no excitement in Moscow over the exchange of notes between President Roosevelt and President Kalinin whereby Foreign Commissar Litvinoff will go to Washington to discuss the matter of recognition with President Roosevelt.

Aided largely by contracts for public works projects, building construction totals throughout the country are showing encouraging gains. September was the first month this year having an aggregate of contracts practically equal in total to corresponding month in 1932, according to the F.W. Dodge Corporation.

BERLIN, Oct. 20. -- Testimony at the Reichstag fire trial today revealed that Count Wolf Heinrich von Heldorff, accused abroad as having been one of the commanders of the alleged Nazi "arson squad," was present at a "mystery" seance by the famed occultist Hannussen, just before the blaze, at which the latter was quoted as saying, "I see the building in flames."

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 20. -- Harvard held a light practice on plays and kicking today in final preparation for tomorrow's football game with Holy Cross. The Worcester eleven is regarded as a formidable third-game opponent.

Repeal Items Actively Bought. Retailers are showing strong interest in repeal items. Department stores have enlarged old or opened new departments to handle this merchandise, while women's specialty shops which have never sold these articles are beginning to feature them.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 20. -- Complete harmony prevailed today between Sol A. Rosenblatt, Deputy Administrator of the NRA, and members of the National Legitimate Theatre Committee after a conference on Mr. Rosenblatt's veto of the committee's recent penalizing of a Broadway ticket agency and a producer.

Three games involving undefeated teams stand out on today's Eastern prep school football schedule. They are the Taft-Hotchkiss contest at Lakeville, Conn.; the Choate-Deerfield encounter at Wallingford, Conn., and the Peddie-Mercersburg game at Hightstown, N.J.

OMAHA, Oct. 20 (AP). -- Farm leaders, headed by Milo Reno of Des Moines, president of the National Farmers Holiday Association, came to Omaha today to bid for the support of Midwestern business interests in the "nationwide" agricultural strike by the association to begin tomorrow noon.

Traders in bonds were hesitant yesterday and the trend of prices was not clearly defined. The main body of domestic railroad issues rallied moderately, but utility and industrial loans were a trifle lower on the day. Pressure against the leading foreign exchange rates weakened bonds of the foreign group, while United States Government obligations finished 4-32 point higher to 3-32 point lower on the day.

Apprentice Jockey Eddie Yowell, the leading rider of the Empire City meeting, suffered a broken nose and a broken leg yesterday when he was unseated from Zorana in the third race at the Yonkers course. Yowell is one of the youngest members of the riding colony, and was pitched out of the saddle after about a furlong had been run.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 20. -- President Roosevelt's policy for the recognition of Soviet Russia is in sharp contrast with the attitude of the three preceding Republican administrations and the attitude of Bainbridge Colby as Secretary of State in the closing years of the Wilson administration.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 (AP) -- President William Green of the American Federation of Labor said tonight that he still had "faith in the President," believing that before recognizing Russia, Mr. Roosevelt would insist that the Third International cease attempting to promote "world revolution through force and violence."

To the Editor of The New York Times: THE TIMES editorial "Dictators and Democracy" refers to the recent volume on the future program of the Labor party in Great Britain, making special mention of the chapter written by Sir Stafford Cripps.
