MOSCOW, Oct. 20. -- A Foreign Office spokesman who gave out copies of the messages of President Roosevelt and President Kalinin said that "President Roosevelt's step comes at a moment of a very serious and complicated international situation in which the cause of peace is being assailed in many parts of the world."

TOKYO, Oct. 20. -- The conferences of the "Big Five" in the Cabinet, concluded today, were primarily concerned with the army's and navy's appropriations, but showed how the army is holding that defense, in the broadest sense, covers every aspect of national life and is claiming an influence in every department of the administration.

An appropriation of $2,832,792.70 for work and home relief for October was voted yesterday by the Board of Estimate. The item was on the board's calendar for reference to the committee of the whole, but was rushed through at the request of Frank J. Taylor, Commissioner of Public Welfare, who is also chairman of the Emergency Work and Relief Administration.

MOSCOW, Oct. 20 (AP). -- Some indication, of the importance Moscow attaches to President Roosevelt's move is given in the diversion of Maxim Litvinoff from another important diplomatic journey to go to Washington. He was scheduled to depart Oct. 22 for Istanbul to participate in the celebration of the anniversary of the Turkish Republic, returning the visit made here last year by Ismet Pasha.

CHICAGO, Oct. 20. -- Before the American Library Association today, George F. Zook, Federal Commissioner of Education, urged the extension of adult education, citing the increased leisure time of many persons. Such education, he held, is necessary that people in all walks of life may adjust themselves to the "complexities of the modern order."
Joseph V. McKee, Recovery party nominee for Mayor, hit back yesterday at F.H. LaGuardia, his Fusion opponent, and Ogden L. Mills, former Secretary of the Treasury.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 20. -- A declaration that the Roosevelt administration had not only resulted in a labor government in control of the United States, but also was being carried to a stage of "outright socialism" was made here tonight by Virgil Jordan, president of the National Industrial Conference Board.
PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 20. -- The Princeton cross-country team opened its season today with an overwhelming victory over the Lafayette harriers. The victors took the first ten places to win by 15-40.

The text of Dr. Butler's speech at Fusion rally, Page 4. The City Campaign. F.H. LaGuardia informed Republican rally, at which party leaders spoke for Fusion, that he planned a strictly nonpartisan city regime.

Within a few minutes after hearing argument yesterday the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court affirmed the decision of Supreme Court Justice Salvatore A. Cotillo upholding the filing of independent nominations for Supreme Court Judges under the name and emblem of the Recovery party.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 20. -- Difficulty is being experienced in France at maintaining the volume of business at the higher level to which it had risen earlier in the year, the Department of Commerce reported today in its weekly survey of foreign business conditions based on advices from commercial attaches abroad.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 20. -- Internal revenue collections in September showed a sharp increase over August and July, capital stock taxes and the usual quarterly payments of income taxes more than offsetting declines in miscellaneous receipts.

Encouraged by a confident advance in wheat and by other developments which helped to strengthen the market's morale, stocks engaged yesterday in a moderate recovery after two or three hours of hesitancy in the forenoon. The tone of all markets was greatly improved.

City Chamberlain Charles A. Buckley of the Bronx was removed from office yesterday by Mayor O'Brien. Former State Senator John V. Sheridan of the same borough was immediately named in his place and sworn in. Mr. Sheridan is one of the group recently named by the Tammany organization to conduct Mayor O'Brien's re-election campaign in the Bronx.

Reorganization of the compliance board of the local NRA organization preparatory to enforcement of the President's orders to proceed energetically against violators of the National Recovery Act was announced last night by Grover A. Whalen, NRA chairman.

Steps to put football back on the sports curriculum at St. John's University were taken yesterday for the first time since the sport was dropped two years ago. A pep meeting and rally was held in the downtown school's gymnasium. Ray Lynch, former head football coach; James A. Freeman, director of athletics; Dr. Phillip A. Brennan, and Dr. George W. Matheson spoke.
BERLIN, Oct. 20. -- Professor Ewald Banse's book "Wehrwissenschaft" ["Military Science"] has been ordered confiscated.

The interest of Premier Mussolini in America's problems, especially the recovery program of President Roosevelt, was recounted yesterday by Gilbert T. Hodges, chairman of the board of the Advertising Club at 23 Park Avenue.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 20. -- For the second straight season the University of New Hampshire triumphed over Harvard and Dartmouth in a triangular cross-country meet over the Harvard course today. The winners tallied 26 points, Harvard 39 and Dartmouth 72.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 20. -- The first meeting of the American Bond-holders Protective Committee was held here today. After a preliminary discussion of the possibilities of collecting on foreign securities now in default, the members of the committee conferred with President Roosevelt.

The Tide Water Associated Oil Company reports for the quarter ended on Sept. 30 a consolidated net income of $2,464,886 after all charges and reserves, equal, after preferred dividend requirements, to 26 cents a share on the 5,613,800 common shares outstanding.

BERLIN, Oct. 20. -- The Boerse was quiet today and quotations fluctuated indecisively. The close left prices practically unchanged, gains and losses balancing one another. Heavy industrials, machineries, rubbers, shippings and Reichsbank shares were steady to firm.

HELSINGFORS, Finland, Oct. 20. -- Baby Matti Nurmi's feet, seemingly too small for a great runner's son, may have been a factor in the separation of Paavo Nurmi and his wife, but the story of Mrs. Nurmi, as revealed today, is that her husband's extreme taciturnity and unshakable absorption in track athletics contributed chiefly to the break-up of their married life within a year and a half.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 (AP). -- Early Presidential Intervention in the Western Pennsylvania coal strike was forecast tonight by Representative Snyder after a visit at the White House.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W.Va., Oct. 20. -- An Autumn fashion show was held in the ballroom of the Greenbrier tonight in the interest of the local chapter of the Needlework Guild of America. There was a large attendance. The models were young women of the colony and students from Greenbrier College.
The Board of Estimate adopted at 2:30 o'clock this morning the proposed budget for 1934, amounting to $620,562,176.54.
The Congressional subcommittee investigating the bankruptcy system here adjourned yesterday after holding public hearings all week, to reconvene after election.

PARIS, Oct. 20. -- News dispatches from Washington, reporting that the American Government has established an embargo on wines and liquors which may be imported under the terms of the Prohibition Law provoked some unfriendly comment in the French press today and was responsible for many inquiries at the United States Embassy regarding the nature of the ruling.

CHICAGO, Oct. 20. -- The Peoples Gas Light and Coke Company lost $151,910 in the three months ended on Sept. 30, James Simpson, its chairman, said today in a letter to stockholders explaining why the directors had found it necessary to interrupt dividends for the first time in twelve years.
LONDON, Oct. 20. -- H.M. Tomlinson, who was a famous war correspondent before he became a novelist, revealed yesterday that he was embittered and deeply pessimistic over recent events in Europe.

To the Editor of The New York Times: W. Lee White, in a letter to THE TIMES, stated that the greatest amount of money that has been in circulation in this country in the last quarter of a century was $6,319,514,854, which was the amount in circulation March 31, 1933.

Mother Tongue Defended. Courses in the correct use of English will begin next week at the Police Academy. The purpose is to set a standard in the use of the oral and written language to which all of New York's 18,000 cops may repair.

MOSCOW, Oct. 20 (AP). -- The exchange of notes between President Roosevelt and President Kalinin occasioned universal Satisfaction in the Soviet Union today because from the resumption of official relations Soviet Russia hopes for a threefold result:

In its first financial report, covering from July 11 to Sept. 30, the Schenley Distillers Corporation reports net earnings of $814,626, equivalent to 77 cents a share on the 1,050,000 shares of capital stock outstanding. The net income was computed after interest, depreciation and estimated taxes, but Harold Jacobi, president, said the statement was unaudited.

The officers and men of the Manhattan, unit of the 101st Cavalry, Squadron A, New York National Guard, Major Frederic A. Vietor commanding, will ride in parade tomorrow morning to a Special military service in St. James Lutheran Church, Madison Avenue and Seventy-third Street.

Irving School of Tarrytown came from behind to register an 18-to-13 football victory over the Horace Mann School for Boys at Horace Mann Field yesterday. Forward passes thrown by Meade figured in all touchdowns by the victors. Meade heaved an aerial 30 yards over the goal line to Wilde to account for the winning points in the third period.

BANGKOK, Oct. 20. -- Prince Sithiporn, a brother of Prince Bovaradej, the leader of the present revolt, has been arrested and the insurrection, which seems to be confined now to Korat, is not expected to continue long.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 20. -- The statement issued by the White House today on the discussion by President Roosevelt and a group interested in the creation of an organization for the protection of American holders of foreign securities, read as follows:

Tammany, which has been stressing in its campaign to date the unemployment relief work carried on by the city administration, plans to augment both work and home relief payrolls substantially between now and election day, according to reliable information yesterday.
ALBANY, Oct. 20 (AP). -- The difference between a movie "talkie" and a stage play must be decided by the Court of Appeals.

CLEVELAND, Oct. 20 (AP). -- A prominent member of the medical profession took a look at his countrymen today and concluded that "under our present form of education" Americans as individuals "are great men, but collectively we are a failure."

The Bruce Johnson Four, an exuberant and furiously paced Negro orchestra, is the most applauded feature of the new Seventh Avenue Roxy stage show. Julius Tannen, mixing his dialects; William O'Neal, a tenor; Serge Flash, a middling juggler, and Fritz and Jean Hubert, comedy pantomimists, are also included on the bill.

No one associated in the production of "The Green Bay Tree," which was acted at the Cort last evening, believes in doing a slovenly or incomplete job. When the curtain rings down after a long, tense evening you feel that the entire story has been told brilliantly and forcefully.
Herbert B. Lederer, husband of Isabel Leighton, playwright and author, committed suicide early yesterday morning in the apartment he and Mrs. Lederer had occupied at 1,045 Park Avenue.

PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 20. -- Princeton will seek its first major football victory of the season tomorrow when Columbia invades Palmer Stadium for the second game of a two-year home-and-home series. The Lions won by 20 -- 7 at Baker Field last year.

A strike of 3,500 workers on tugboats and lighters was averted yesterday when representatives of the boat owners agreed to discuss the terms of a new wage settlement with their employes at the request of the Department of Labor and the National Labor Board.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 20. -- President Roosevelt was represented this afternoon as hoping to complete his study of the retail code and affix his signature by the first part of next week. The President had the code before him this afternoon and conferred with Donald R. Richberg, general counsel of the NRA, upon the disputed "mark-up" section.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 20. -- Claims by the United States and its nationals against Russia, resulting from the repudiation of obligations and the confiscation of property by the Soviet Government following the revolution of Nov. 7, 1917, total approximately $800,000,000, according to the latest compilations made here.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 20. -- As the farm revolt in Nebraska, Iowa and other Western States gained strength today administration officials were considering the extension of loans to the farmers by the Commodity Credit Corporation.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 (AP). -- Fewer than half the war veterans whose future benefit payments depend on proving their presumptive disabilities to be service connected seemed in line for continued compensation today.

LONDON, Oct. 20. -- News that the United States is "to recognize the Soviets," as newspaper headlines in later editions of London's morning papers put it, reached here too late for reporters to get the observations of those British Ministers like Sir John Simon, Foreign Secretary, who regard Russia as their particular concern.

To the Editor of The New York Times: THE TIMES report of my recent speech before the Savings Bank Association convention suggests that I "Intimated" that there might be a change in the Banking Act (Glass-Steagall act) of 1933.
ALBANY, Oct. 20. -- The six bills passed at the extraordinary session of the Legislature Wednesday were signed yesterday by Governor Lehman.

A large Polish exhibition, organized and presented by the International School of Art in New York, opened to the public yesterday at the Brooklyn Museum, where it will remain until Nov. 26. Most of the work is modern, but the scope is extensive, embracing oils, water colors, graphic art, caricatures, commercial art, applied art produced by peasants and a selection of prints made in the Polish art schools.

Republicans of national prominence made their appearance last night in the Mayoralty campaign to support F.H. LaGuardia and his running-mates on the Fusion ticket. A distinct impression was permitted In go out from an authoritative Republican source, however, that the distinguished company that appeared at the Mecca Temple had been engaged only for a one-night stand in the Fusion campaign.

CHICAGO, Oct. 20. -- The grain markets on the Board of Trade reacted violently today from an early break, and only the limtis on the day's fluctuations prevented wheat and rye from reaching more than 5 cents a bushel from yesterday's finish.

CHICAGO, Oct. 20. -- Faith that the early future has better times in store for this country and the world was expressed here tonight by Myron C. Taylor, chairman of the board of the United States Steel Corporation, in an address at a dinner concluding the two-day convention of the American Institute of Steel Construction.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 20. -- Final cash subscriptions for the Treasury's $500,000,000 offering of ten to twelve year bonds amounted to $1,989,015,000, it was announced today by Acting Secretary Acheson. The bonds bear 4 1/4 per cent interest the first year and 3 1/4 per cent thereafter.
MEMPHIS, Tenn., Oct. 20 (AP). -- Bill Terry will be back at his old job this Winter.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Oct. 20. -- The fourth series of musical presentions by Mrs. Julian Olney at the Westchester County Centre here opened tonight with a concert by Jascha Heifetz, noted violinist. who played to an audience of more than 2,500.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., Oct. 20 (AP). -- Charles Hayden, New York banker, said today that the United States could risk $25,000,000,000 to help itself out of the depression if it could risk that much "to help France lick Germany."
NEW HAVEN, Oct. 20. -- Yale and Brown will clash tomorrow in the Bowl in their thirty-eighth game before about 30,000 spectators. The line-ups are somewhat unsettled, due to injuries.
PARIS, Oct. 20. -- What may be called the second battle of the franc is being waged in Paris with the utmost vigor.
The big push begins in football today. The pounding of the little fellow is over with, and all along the front the big guns, from now on, will look down each other's muzzles.

PASADENA, Calif., Oct. 20. -- A quiet-mannered, thinly bearded man, who is fond of tennis despite his sixty-seven years, is the professor named for the 1933 Nobel Prize in Medicine, Dr. Thomas Hunt Morgan.

Headed by the issue of $29,500,000 State of New York bonds which is to be awarded on Tuesday, new municipal financing on the calendar for next week amounts to $38,014,559. The revised total for this week is $13,114,710, and the weekly average for the year to date is $13,290,348.

"Farm strikes," embargoes on wheat and proclamations of protest in the Middle West are directed against prevailing prices for agricultural products. That these are lower than the Government would like is evident. But when some of the protestants go on to suggest that the farmer is the "forgotten man" in the plans of the Administration, they are not speaking by the record.

"Let 'Em Eat Cake," which is the sequel to "Of Thee I Sing," opens this evening at the Imperial Theatre. The book is by George S. Kaufman and Morrie Ryskind, the music by George and Ira Gershwin. William Gaxton, Lois Moran and Victor Moore are the three leading players.
The big push begins in football today. The pounding of the little fellow is over with, and all along the front the big guns, from now on, will look down each other's muzzles.

PASADENA, Calif., Oct. 20. -- A quiet-mannered, thinly bearded man, who is fond of tennis despite his sixty-seven years, is the professor named for the 1933 Nobel Prize in Medicine, Dr. Thomas Hunt Morgan.

Headed by the issue of $29,500,000 State of New York bonds which is to be awarded on Tuesday, new municipal financing on the calendar for next week amounts to $38,014,559. The revised total for this week is $13,114,710, and the weekly average for the year to date is $13,290,348.

"Farm strikes," embargoes on wheat and proclamations of protest in the Middle West are directed against prevailing prices for agricultural products. That these are lower than the Government would like is evident. But when some of the protestants go on to suggest that the farmer is the "forgotten man" in the plans of the Administration, they are not speaking by the record.

"Let 'Em Eat Cake," which is the sequel to "Of Thee I Sing," opens this evening at the Imperial Theatre. The book is by George S. Kaufman and Morrie Ryskind, the music by George and Ira Gershwin. William Gaxton, Lois Moran and Victor Moore are the three leading players.

ORANGE, N.J., Oct. 20 (AP). -- It was revealed today that Kathryn Josephine Palmer, stage beauty under the name of Kathryn Ray, was married a week ago in the office of Judge Edward L. Davis, to Martino de Alzaga Unzue, Argentine rancher.

SIXTEENTH-CENTURY Russia is far away and cold and seems rather stiff stuff to read about. But there were excitements there, murders and wars and the gossiped return of ghosts, that have never been staled in school books. In his "Boris Godunof" (Yale, $2.50) Stephen Graham brings some of these excitements back out of the dark of loosely recorded history, sets them in swift narrative, and they make fresh and lively rerding.

The Citizens Union issued a statement yesterday urging the defeat of all members of the present majority on the Board of Aldermen. Joseph Clark Baldwin 3d, the sole Republican on the board, was the only Alderman whose re-election the union favored.

BERLIN, Oct. 21. -- The startling theory that civilization was not cradled in the Old World but in the Americas was propounded last night to a scientific audience at the University of Berlin by Dr. Robert Henseling, German astronomer.

DES MOINES, Oct. 21. - Milo Reno, president of the National Farmers Holiday Association, tonight carried to industrial labor his plea for support of a national farm strike, which started at noon today.

An encouraging subscription is reported for the performance of "The Divine Drudge" on the night of Nov. 1 at the Royale Theatre, which has been taken over by the directors of the Seamen's Church Institute of New York to raise funds for the maintenance of that organization.
Miss Molly Townsend gave a dinner last night in the Seaglade of the St. Regis for Miss Lois Barstow and John Bacon Aspegren, whose marriage will take place on Tuesday in West Orange, N.J.

BURLINGTON, Vt., Oct. 19. -- Vermont is preparing for a double-barreled campaign to fill two places in Congress. The death of Senator Porter H. Dale leaves a vacancy in the Senate. Representative Ernest W. Gibson of Brattleboro, Vermont's single Representative in the House, announced the first of this week that he would resign to become a candidate for the vacancy in the Senate and it will be necessary to fill his seat in the House.

PARIS, Oct. 20. -- Germany's action last Saturday in walking out of the Disarmament Conference and resigning her membership in the League of Nations has not had the effect on France many imagined it would.

CLEVELAND, Oct. 21. -- A new method for treating four diseases which he believes are the penalty paid by many men and women for the furious pace of modern life was described today by Dr. George W. Crile, Cleveland surgeon, at the closing session of the International Medical Assembly.

PARIS, Oct. 19. -- Medium-length cape-backed loose coats worn over fitted frocks are typical of Molyneux's new between-season collection. A successful sports model of fawn brown has a tight, laced, two-thirds length tunic; the coat is the same length.

In compiling the duck-hunting regulations for this year and in reducing the daily bag and possession limits, the Biological Survey sought to give greater protection to certain species which were decreasing more rapidly than other wild water fowl.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 21. -- Howard Harpster, nemesis of Notre Dame as a player for Carnegie Tech when the late Knute Rockne guided the destinies of the South Bend elevens, achieved a notable distinction today when his Carnegie Tartans downed Notre Dame, 7 to 0.

THIS book is a sign-post that blazons in unmistakable language the distance the world has traveled -- backward -- during the last dozen years. Then one sensed everywhere hope, determination, conviction, that there could not be, should not be, another war, at least for many generations to come.

PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 21. -- One man was killed and four injured tonight when an automobile in which they were returning home from the Princeton-Columbia football game crashed into a tree beside the Lincoln Highway between here and Kingston, N.J.

BERLIN, Oct. 21. -- To any one bred in the Anglo-Saxon tradition the outstanding feature of the present developments in Germany is the utter divergence of the Anglo-Saxon and German viewpoints. Between the two mentalities a great gulf is fixed.

CLEVELAND, Oct. 21 (AP). -- Three hundred thousand men can be returned to American industrial payrolls if the United States and Russia complete an economic rapprochement, Professor Kenneth H. Donaldson, expert on Soviet industry, has advised the State Department at Washington.

JOHN PETER ZENGER, onetime apprentice and printer's devil for William Bradford, comes vividly out of tie night of time, with the ink stains still on his fingers and the eagerness of the born journalist shining on his honest German face, as the 200th anniversary of his struggle for the freedom of the press in America rolls round.

THE October issue of Design is devoted to the Century of Progress and contains a wide range of brief articles of interest, well illustrated. Among the subjects treated are architecture and color, modern mural decorations, pylons, sculpture panels, the Hall of Science and the radio motifs used on its entrance, together with other matters directly connected with the Chicago Fair.

PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 21. -- The Princeton Engineering Association and former students of Dr. Cyrus Fogg Brackett will celebrate the 100th anniversary of the birth of Dr. Brackett, for thirty-five years Professor of Physics at Princeton, in the John C. Green Engineering Building on Tuesday.

ALTHOUGH the new production season is an infant of three months, Paramount has more than half of its scheduled films either completed or in work. By New Year's Day, Emanuel Cohen, Vice president, in charge of production, expects to have the whole program completed, and work will start immediately on the 1933-34 schedule.

EXETER, N.H., Oct. 21. -- The Phillips Exeter football team unleashed a fast attack today to defeat the Northeastern freshmen, 42 to 0. The first touchdown was scored by Gordon Clark after his teammates had advanced the ball to the 10-yard line.

ONE of the most striking examples of post-war conditions as they affect music is the arrival, now near, of Arnold Schonberg, about to make his first American visit, to teach in Boston. This proceeding appears singularly at variance with Schonberg's past and with his position in modern music.

EAST HAMPTON, L.I., Oct. 21. -- Childe Hassam, the American painter and etcher, celebrated his birthday at his Egypt Lane studio-home here this week by reviewing with satisfaction his ability to continue his work and to take a dip in the ocean at the age of 74.

Tuxedo Park will be the scene on Saturday night of the first important event for debutantes of this season -- the annual Autumn ball at the Tuxedo Club. The ball itself will serve both as the formal introduction to society of several young women and to bring together many other debutantes who will be in the Park for several days in various house parties.

THE most ruthless attack on the romantic criticism of Shakespeare comes from Professor Stoll. the "hard-boiled professor from Minnesota," as Logan Pearsall Smith described him while admitting regretfully that Professor Stoll has the future with him.

Definite indications that the Recovery Administration has turned to that phase of its program designed to assure fair competition in industry cheered business executives here during the week. Coincident with the formation of a fair trade practice committee, headed by Lincoln Filene of Boston, it was learned that expert accountants will advise deputy administrators on the various cost provisions included in codes.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 (AP). -- Saying that the letter he wrote to Charles S. McCain of the Chase National Bank was purely a personal one, Harvey Couch, a director of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, announced tonight his willingness to appear before the Senate stock market investigating committee and answer any questions asked of him.

HAVANA, Oct. 21. -- The Santiago express from Havana was blown from the track about forty miles outside Havana early this morning. Dynamite is believed to have been placed on the roadbed by striking railway workers.

A GREAT exhibition of etchings by David Young Cameron is hanging in the Keppel Galleries. Great in numbers, in rare examples, in master-pieces; but especially in those preludes to masterpieces which are bursting with promises, not all to be fulfilled, yet often more moving than fulfillment.
CHICAGO, Oct. 21 (AP). -- Science is trying to get a better view of Venus through the use of infra-red rays.

Gaining momentum in the final period, Manhattan College's football machine overrode a stubborn Brooklyn College eleven, 28 -- 0, before a crowd of 6,000 at Ebbets Field yesterday. The Jaspers scored all except eight of their points in the fourth quarter.

The charge that F.H. LaGuardia, Fusion nominee for Mayor, "gouged the city" in collecting padded $28,000 fee as Special Assistant Corporation Counsel in the Queens water case was made last night by James I. Cuff, Recovery party nominee for Controller.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, Oct. 21. -- With military pageantry and colorful ceremony, His Excellency the Governor, Lieut. Gen. Sir Thomas Astley Cubitt will open Colonial Parliament on Monday, delivering his speech from the throne in the council chamber, in the presence of naval and military officers and dignitaries of Church and State.
CHICAGO, Oct. 21 (AP). -- The use of blanket advertising upholding trustworthy doctors as against quacks was approved last night by the Cook County Medical Society.

LONDON, Oct. 21 -- A David Lloyd George talkie interview on the international situation, released through the British Movitone News, was ordered cut from the news-reels of 3,000 motion picture the-atres of the Gaumont British circuit today.

TUCSON, Ariz. ONCE more the path of Mrs. Isabella Greenway, by reason of her election as the first woman Representative in Congress from Arizona, has crossed the Roosevelt path. The association of her family with the Roosevelts began nearly fifty years ago, when Theodore Roosevelt the elder, then a young man, became a partner of Mrs. Greenway's father in a sheep ranch in North Dakota.

BERLIN, Oct. 21. -- A statement credited to "Berlin political circles," issued tonight by a news agency close to the government, challenged the facts and figures in a Geneva dispatch to THE NEW YORK TIMES on Oct. 17 concerning the armament demands of Germany.

WALLINGFORD, Conn., Oct. 21. -- The winning streak of the Choate School football team, which had extended through fourteen consecutive games, was checked today, the Gold and Blue eleven being held to a scoreless tie by the Deerfield Academy combination of Deerfield, Mass.

BORIS GODUNOF" is one of those rare books which relieve even an exacting critic of the ungrateful duty of noting defects and which offer him the opportunity of bestowing sincere and whole-hearted praise. One closes it with the feeling that it is not only one of the best historical biographies of the season, but also a genuine literary achievement.

Growing uncertainty throughout the country, attributed to the spread of labor troubles, conflicts over the NRA program, unsatisfactory retail trade and further but proportionately smaller recessions in commodity prices, is reflected in last week's reports from the Federal Reserve centres.

OTTAWA, Oct. 19. -- Fifty years ago, when the Canadian Pacific Railway was being constructed across Canada, ore was uncovered near Sudbury which laid the foundations of the nickel-copper industry in this country and made the fortune of Northern Ontario.
What are the Winter rules in golf?

PARIS. AFTER the big couture openings come the social openings; both are equally important in setting new fashions. At present every night is a first night in Paris. Theatres, restaurants and night clubs have reserved their dates for weeks in advance.

WINIFRED WELLES is an unusually fine poet. She has a unique way of seeing the physical world of beauty and a consequently unique use of language and imagery. For her nature is drawn in the finest of designs.

With a painting symbolic of the "Christ of the modern world" as a rallying point, an international coalition of Christian forces behind a program of missionary endeavor is being created under the auspices of the Universal Christian Council, It was announced here yesterday.

IT is 450 years since there was born in Europe a man who changed the course of history. Millions at people, in the New World as well as the Old, inscribe his name upon their churches. Of his personality and achievements, it is fitting that there should be a responsible appraisal.

STARS seemed to rain from the heavens in the Northern European skies recently. From Siberia to Belgium peasants were as terrified as were their forefathers centuries ago at similar displays. Why the countryside should have superstitiously reverted to the Middle Ages in these days of village schools is at least partly explained by the brief telegrams that were received at Harvard from European observatories.

THE Man With 250 Faces is the title they append most persistently to Paul Muni, who will be revealed cinematically at the Hollywood Theatre on Wednesday evening in "The World Changes." His real name is Muni Weisenfreund, and he was born in Vienna Sept. 22, 1897.

American Hide and Leather Company-Twelve weeks ended Sept. 17: Net profit after depreciation, interest and reserve for taxes, $148,048, equal to $1.48 a share on 100,000 $100 par shares of 7 per cent preferred stock on which there is an accumulation of unpaid dividends.
EVANSTON, Ill., Oct. 21. -- To the accompaniment of forked lightning, blinding sheets of rain and semidarkness, Northwestern overwhelmed Indiana today, 25 to 0.

MOST youthful of the physical sciences, biochemistry is likely in time to become fundamental to our understanding of all biological phenomena. Of the tour major units known today as sharing in the development of living organisms -- genes, secretions of the endocrine glands, enzymes and vitamins -- the vitamins have attracted the greatest public attention in recent years.
As one looks around the inner fashion circle one finds that there are many things worthy of consideration. They are the style points that add spice to sartorial offerings.

BERLIN, Oct. 20. -- Grandmothers are coining into their own again in Germany. The little old lady has Jbeen for many years neglected, if not forgotten, in most countries of the world. Whether she was alive or dead, the contemporary generation had little time to devote to her.

EAST NORTHFIELD, Mass., Oct. 21. -- When William Revell Moody, who died last week, took over the direction of the Northfield Seminary for Girls and the Mount Hermon School for Boys, founded by his father, Dwight L. Moody, the evangelist, the joint endowment of the two schools was $550,000 and the value of their plants was $800,000.
LONDON, Oct. 21. -- Sir John Simon, the Foreign Secretary, tonight urged three reasons why Britons should take a deep interest in disarmament. In an interview | for a film he said:

THE administration's recent call for bids on 844,525 tons of steel rails, to be purchased by forty-seven railroads, generally at a price lower than $40 per ton, draws attention to the steady decline both in the production and price of this important commodity.

Curtis High School's undefeated football team vanquished St. Francis Prep of Brooklyn, 14-6, yesterday at Thompson's Stadium, Staten Island. Curtis has won three games and tied one this season. The Curtis touchdowns were made by Morel in the first period and Destasio in the last session.

ONE has heard about this trilogy for a long time, and one has waited with some impatience for its appearance in English. The impatience was indeed justified; it can be said at the outset that in spite of its weaknesses and defects "Three Cities" is one of the most absorbing, one of the most vital, one of the most richly creative works of fiction that have appeared in our day.

CARLISLE, Pa., Oct. 21. -- Democratic government will succeed in the long run "because it is the only system which respects the self-respect of individual people," President Harold W. Dodds of Princeton University asserted today at Dickinson College's sequi-centennial celebration.
Efforts of shipping groups to draft a code of business practices for the industry were complicated last week by conflicting demands and interpretations of the recovery legislation.

St Luke's Hospital, which inherited real estate worth nearly $1,000,000 on Riverside Drive, and which has received $1,716,276 and will get $2,332,000 more under the will of Mrs. Mary Ann Fitzgerald, has found the gift a problem which has been submitted to the Supreme Court for solution.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 21. -- The Rev. Edmund A. Walsh, regent of the School of Foreign Service of Georgetown University and an authority on the Russian question, declared in a statement tonight that President Roosevelt was not committed to any future course of action by the "bare fact" that he had provided an opportunity for a discussion with the Russian Government of "the grave difficulties existing between two sovereign States."

IT is a poor theatrical season indeed which does not afford to Broadway some eminent emissary -- in one form or another -- from the emerald isle of Erin. Last season it was the whole troupe of peregrinating players from the Abbey Theatre in Dublin.

MOSCOW, Oct. .21. -- "A momentous day in world affairs and for the cause of peace" -- that is the way the Moscow press hails the move by President Roosevelt for opening Soviet-American negotiations toward recognitio.

ORLANDO, Fla., Oct. 19. -- Now that Florida is in step with the national parade for repeal, the citrus industry begins to consider the wine industry. Years before grapes were grown in California wine was made from oranges, and C.H. Courser, a local utility man, upon learning of this, has turned the attention of his new business committee of the local Chamber of Commerce to the subject.
DUBLIN, Oct. 20. -- Talk of a general election has again been revived as a consequence of the government's postponement of local County Council elections from November to June.
The unbeaten Flushing High School eleven gained its third victory in four starts, which also include a tie game, by vanquishing Grover Cleveland, 9 -- 0, yesterday at Flushing Memorial Field.

LONDON, Oct. 20 -- If any one asked the writer, after his twelve years' residence in the Soviet Union, what single factor most distinguished life here from that in capitalist countries he would reply without hesitation, "Its impermanence," meaning, particularly, the way people Jump or get jumped from one job and one place to another.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 21. -- To put the NRA cart behind the horse, instead of in front of it, is still the administration's major problem. When the amazing new government vehicle first began its journey, it was hoped and believed by many that the switch in position could be accomplished while the road was level. Now it is distinctly uphill and narrow, multiplying the difficulties of the task.
CHICAGO, Oct. 21. -- Chicago's football hopes, lifted to the highest crest in ten years, crashed today before a torrent of Purdue backs and rainfall, 14 to 0.
LIMA, Oct. 21. -- The press is much concerned over rumors of discovery by the police of a revolutionary plot.

With an entry larger than in any previous year, the tenth annual field trial meeting of the English Springer Spaniel Field Trial Association will be started at 8 o'clock on Tuesday morning at Fishers Island, N.Y., and continue through Friday.
Copyright, 1933. by NANA, Inc. LONDON, Oct. 21 (By Wireless). -- The program evolved at the Paris peace conference had not two but three vital parts:
Governor Herbert H. Lehman was progressing satisfactorily at Mount Sinai Hospital last night, after having undergone an operation for appendicitis in the morning.

BERLIN, Oct. 21. -- After four weeks of searching for the truth there emerges the possibility that only the dark power that drove Marinus van der Lubbe to set fire to the Reichstag Building was his own twisted mind that mixes a streak of pyromania with an undigested political philosophy.

BOSTON, Oct. 20. THE event of the moment in Boston is Miss Le Gallienne and her plays. Word had spread that not too much was to be expected of her "Romeo and Juliet"; that "Alice" was the better reliance.

TEN times as many books are sold in Rumania these days as in the days prior to the war. And the native novel which before the war simply did not exist has become the most popular form of literature and has raised the standard of Rumanian letters to a higher level than they ever were in the past.

CLEVELAND, Oct. 21. -- The Army football team met its first major test of the season successfully today. Opposing a favored Illinois eleven the Cadets, showing a strong running game and a consistent defense, turned back the fighting Illini by the score of 6 to 0.

THE seventy-fifth anniversary of the birth of Theodore Roosevelt finds another Roosevelt in the White House; another Roosevelt grappling with the greatest problems of national life, incessantly busy with heavy tasks, the cynosure of American and European eyes.

Mr. NASH deserves well of the Republic. He bas given it another good book. May garlands and hosannahs and things attend his way. In the past, he bas tormented the language of Manhattan into some of the most flagrant and beguiling lyrics of our time.

DETROIT. ENFORCEMENT of the NRA code provision relating to used car trade-in allowances is certain to be delayed until mid-November. When the code was signed by President Roosevelt, the understanding was that regulated prices would become effective thirty days later, or on Nov. 2.

AMIRAL BYRD in a foreword to this book says that "there are certain qualities that inevitably attach themselves to any British polar expedition -- a keen regard tor detail, a high resolve and, above all else, a beautiful seriousness of spirit that illuminates it from beginning to end."

DANVILLE, Va., Oct. 20. -- While prices offered for the bright tobacco grown by farmers in the Old Belt of Virginia and North Carolina were higher than at any time since 1922, the opening of the selling season this week was marked by conflicting emotions.

ATLANTA, Ga., Oct. 18. -- Among the many notables who visited Atlanta this week was Jesse Jones, chairman of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation. Mr. Jones passed the majority of his few hours here with local bankers. They greeted him cordially, but did not give him much encouragement on his three-fold plan.

TOKYO, Sunday, Oct. 22. -- Emperor Hirohito departed by special train this morning to assume personal direction of the army's annual manoeuvres, conducted this year on the shores of the Sea of Japan, the section of the homeland closest to Siberia.

LAKEVTLLE, Conn., Oct. 21. -- Hotchkiss and Taft, football rivals since the turn of the century, put on a thrilling battle today before 1,500 spectators. Hotchkiss snatched a 12-7 triumph in the final minute and a half.

SPORT and legend, beauty of nature and dark shadow of politics and the curses of the wise woman bringing the vengeance of the bog upon those who would destroy it are curiously mingled in this new romance by Lord Dunsany.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 21. -- An allotment of $25,000,000 for national defense was made to the army and navy today by the Public Works Administration.

Orphaned infants and young children under supervision of the Alice Chapin Adoption Nursery will be aided by a bridge and musicals to be held on Tuesday afternoon in the Roof Garden of the St. Regis. The guest artists will be Mario Cozzi, baritone of the Metropolitan Opera; Marie Sundelius, soprano; Rafaelo Diaz, tenor; Marjorie Fulton, violinist, and Marjorie Normand, coloratura soprano.
Scoring an outstanding upset in New Jersey school football, the East Rutherford eleven halted Dickinson's 11-game winning streak at Jersey City yesterday, 14 to 12.
EASTON, Pa., Oct. 21. -- Joe Reznichak and Joe Rhuebright led the Bucknell football team to a 21-0 victory over Lafayette today before 7,000 fans.
ST. JOSEPH, N.B., Oct. 21 (Canadian Press) -- With fire still eating away at the new wing of St. Joseph's University today, gutting of that section appeared inevitable.

PORTLAND, Ore., Oct. 18. -- Oregon's politiacl caldron, already boiling for the May primaries, last week brought to the surface something new-a recall petition against the Governor of the State. While recall provisions were incorporated in the State Constitution in 1908, this is the first time it has ever been directed against a Governor or any other major State officer.

BUMPER crops in Russia this Fall are not only of grain but of school children. In her grade and high schools sit today 25,600,000 youngsters, more than three times the number ever enrolled in the days of the Czar.

AN effect of the depression has to do with the administration and management of the residence halls. Under ordinary circumstances our residence halls have been fully occupied. This situation has tended to cultivate an unjustified attitude of satisfaction with the part that our residence halls have played in the social and educational life of the college.

The Associated Press reported from Washington last week that the Tariff Commission is to investigate the recent upturn of our import trade, in order to determine whether additional measures are needed to protect the higher wages and prices sought In connection with the NRA.

Mayor O'Brien announced last night that he had forbidden German-Americans to hold a meeting scheduled for next Sunday night at the Sixty-ninth Regiment Armory. He expressed the fear that there would be violence at the meeting that might result in injury or loss of life.

BURLINGTON, N.J., Oct. 21. -- The first full-size driving unit tat a $2,000,000 electric power plant, which is to be operated by any breeze better than six miles an hour, was exhibited here yesterday by Julius D. Madaras, a Hungarian engineer.

The first of a series of suits for the reorganization of mortgaged properties now in default for which guaranteed certificates estimated at nearly $500,000,000 have been sold, were heard during the last week under conditions which led to the belief that certificate holders generally would accept the reorganization plans proposed by the New York Guaranteed Mortgage Protective Corporation.

Monetary inflation as a recovery step will prove "futile" and, until it is recognized that consumption has been checked because product value has been greatly exceeded by the non-productive or service costs to be paid out of the consumer's dollar, other measures for economic improvement are also doomed to failure, according to Carl Fast, marketing counselor.

TOKYO, Oct. 21. -- The disposition that has recently become fashionable in some circles here to represent Russia as Japan's potential land enemy and the United States as the potential antagonist at sea insured the liveliest interest in the news from Washington regarding the move for recognition.

R.J. Baker, secretary of the American Steamship Owners Association, issued an appeal yesterday for employment of United States vessels in transporting goods between this country and Russia in the event of recognition.

To the Editor of The New York Times: As one of the trainers of the Sugar Stabilization Agreement, I would like to point out certain misstatements which have appeared in connection with the agreement, and in particular in connection with the letter of Albert D. Barker.

RUMSON, N.J., Oct. 21. -- A benefit dinner and dance was held this evening at the Rumson Country Club here to aid the Monmouth Memorial Hospital, Long Branch. A representative gathering of New York, Long Island, Rumson and Seabright society attended, many coming from the Monmouth County Hunt meet, held at the Amory L. Haskell estate, Middletown, in the afternoon.

TRUE regional novels of American life seem to be increasing B in number and improving in quality. Color and character and dialect are the ornament and technically the principal ingredients of these novels, but behind them and below the surface there should be a sense of history and a feeling for (to drag in, for lack of something better, a dreadful word combination) comparative sociology.

Although retail trade continues to bold up In the Industrial centres, there has been a decline at other points in unit sales and turnover, with the result that the heavy Inventories of the stores are holding reorders down, according to the market report prepared specially for THE TIMES by Kirby, Block Fischer.

KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Oct. 21 (AP). -- A code set up under the National Recovery Act was termed "an arbitrary edict by the President, who has been made a dictator" during argument in Federal court here today on a suit contesting the constitutionality of the act.

COOLER weather had its accustomed effect in helping trade during the week, but the gains were not as substantial as retailers would wish to see them. The demand for seasonal apparel improved. Home furnishings slowed up further.

NEWARK, N.J., Oct. 21. -- The Newbrook Stables' 3-year-old trotter, Mariana, and Miss Cherry Mac, local 3-year-old pacing champion owned by J.B. Gilligan of South Orange, won the feature events of the weekly matinee at Weequahic Park today.

DES MOINES Oct. 21. -- The new corn-hog program strikes the shackles off the hands of the Iowa farmer and gives him the chance to create for himself the greatest degree of agricultural prosperity the State has ever known.

LAURENCE SCHWAB, who just a few weeks ago was reported to be through (forever) with all shows having music in any form, now appears to be repentant. At all events it seems that Mr. Schwab is to be considerably interested in "She Loves Me Not," which Mr. Wiman and Mr. Weatherly are offering.

TORONTO will celebrate next year the centenary of its incorporation on March 6, 1834, and preparations are already under way for the occasion. From a primitive settlement of 100 years ago it has grown to be the second largest city in Canada.

Philatelists from many countries are expected in New York during the week of Nov. 20, when the first part of the Arthur Hind collection of stamps will be sold at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel. The sale will include Mr. Hind's collection of United States stamps.

THE world has never yet discarded the most terrible weapon it has been able to invent. The power of modern aircraft as a weapon is simply enormous. Aircraft equipment should be so complete and so powerful that war simply could not start.

IN spite of all the skeptics who said it could never be done, the actual preliminaries in the establishment of an American ballet are now under way, under the auspices of the Morgan Memorial Museum in Hartford. The organizers of the project are A. Everett Austin, director of the museum; Lincoln Kirstein, one of the editors of "Hound and Horn" and perhaps our most energetic "balletomane"; James Sobey and E.M.M. Warburg.

The telephone and the typewriter have made a hopeless task of the identification of original documents and manuscripts because they "have robbed the written word of say sense of completeness and abolished the authority of uniqueness," Roger Howson, librarian of Columbia University, declares in his annual report to Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of the university, made public yesterday.

MISHEL PIASTRO and Alfred Wallenstein, concert-master and first 'cellist respectively of the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, will appear with the orchestra as soloists this week. Mr. Piastro will play the Glazunoff concerto this afternoon and Mr. Wallenstein the Lalo concerto in D minor Saturday night and the Tartini concerto in D major next Sunday afternoon.

ATHENS, Oct. 21. -- Samuel Insull, one-time chief of a great utilities empire, began his fight against extradition to the United States here today in a court room so jammed with spectators that the doors and windows were blocked.

All sections of the bond market ended the two-hour trading period yesterday at lower prices generally. Despite strength in the dollar in the foreign, exchange market, United States Government bonds on the Stock Exchange closed generally at recessions, losses amounting to 1-32 to 14-32 point.

ANN ARBOR, Mich., Oct. 21. -- Ohio State's bid for Big Ten football honors failed to match the desperate effort of Michigan today and the Wolverines sent the Buckeyes home with a crushing 13-to-0 defeat.
Mark down one more victory for Colgate, making sixteen in a row to date, and an honorable defeat for New York University.

EUTHANASIA" has become world news again. Recently an Associated Press dispatch from Berlin reported a proposal of the German Ministry of Justice "to authorize physicians to end the suffering of incurable patients."
ROANOKE, Va., Oct. 21 (AP). -- Washington and Lee's Generals, outrushing their favored rivals from start to finish, today defeated the previously unconquered University of Kentucky eleven, 7 to 0.

It will surprise many to learn that "The Elements of Euclid" has been included among books "to be read in bed or on a holiday," and as "difficult "as any detective story to lay down "when once begun." Such is the alluring statement made by Sir THOMAS L. HEATH in an introduction to Volume 891 in Everyman's Library.

ROME, Oct. 21. -- The first fight for the world's heavyweight title ever to be staged in Italy will take place in Rome tomorrow afternoon when the sturdy Basque, Paulino Uzcudun, will attempt to wrest from Primo Camera the crown which the latter only recently won from Jack Sharkey.

While the steady pressure-against the share market yesterday was inexplicable to many in Wall Street, particularly in the light of overnight developments, it may have been explained by vague unconfirmed reports from Washington that steps were being taken to curtail speculative operations on the Stock Exchange.
NEW YORK. The Hon. Waldorf Astor, son of Viscount and Viscountess Astor, arrived on the Bremen and is at the Waldorf-Astoria.

THE uprising of the Nazis in Germany, their dramatic withdrawal of the Reich from the disarmament conference and their notice of an intention to leave the League are developments that have compelled the rest of Europe to size up the general position.

New York University's varsity and freshman cross-country teams opened the season yesterday and triumphed over their Columbia rivals in Van Cortlandt Park. The Violet varsity won, 23 to 32, while the Cubs beat the Morningside yearlings, 27 to 28.

ST. LOUIS, Oct. 18. -- The Missouri General Assembly, called into extraordinary session this week by Governor Park, was charged by him with, enacting adequate liquor-control laws, bolstering the depleted State revenues and furnishing sufficient funds for emergency relief.
RADIO CITY will be formally dedicated on Armistice night, Nov. 11, when a gala program will be broadcast internationally from radio's new sky-scraper home in Rockefeller Center.

BUENOS AIRES, Oct. 21. -- Well-informed private sources here, in Asuncion, Paraguay, and in Rio de Janeiro insist that President Justo of Argentina and Vargas of Brazil, at their recent meeting in Rio de Janeiro, drew up a new Chaco peace formula and presented it to Bolivia and Paraguay.

Women who have been active for years in behalf of the philanthropic enterprises of the Goddard Neighborhood Centre have taken over the performance of "Champagne Sec" on election night, Nov. 7, at the Morosco Theatre in aid of that organization. The benefit has already attracted the interest of members of society as well as many persons prominent in the political world, particularly since the election returns will be announced during the intermissions.
GREAT NECK, L.I., Oct. 21. -- The Lake Success races held at the Rice Brothers' Stables in Great Neck before a large crowd today were dominated by Miss Judy Johnson, who won four of the five events.

HAVERSTRAW, N.Y., Oct. 21. -- William B. Hoke, vice president of the National Bank and Trust Company of Haverstraw, shot himself to death yesterday at his home in Tomkins Cove, near here. His death was not made known until today when Coroner John C. Dingman announced a verdict of suicide.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 21. -- Only "minor changes" occurred in the rate of industrial operations in the week ended on Oct. 14, slight declines being reported in some of the major indexes of business activity, according to the weekly survey made by the Department of Commerce, the results of which were announced today.

SHANGHAI, Sept. 27. -- With the second anniversary of the so-called "Mukden Incident," which on Sept. 18, 1931, marked the beginning of Japan's conquest of Manchuria, even the most harsh critics of Japanese policy must admit that Manchuria today is better off and better governed than it has ever been.

HOLLYWOOD. INTEREST here during the past week or two has changed from cinematic productions to economics and finance. In a dull sort of way the local members of the industry seem to suspect that the platinum era of the business is over; that every one may have to get back to a gold standard, or even a silver basis.

Displaying a powerful running attack, the unbeaten Manual Training High School eleven crushed Boys High, 28 -- 0, yesterday at the Brooklyn Sports Stadium. A capacity crowd of 6,500 spectators saw the winners gain their fourth consecutive victory.

BERLIN, Oct. 20. -- None of us who sat in Geneva on Sept. 10, 1926, will ever forget the exaltation of the moment when Germany entered the League of Nations. And no one in Berlin these days will easily forget the shock of Germany's sudden exit, as startling to the Germans as to the rest of the world.

Samuel R. Rosoff, president of the East Side Omnibus Corporation, explained yesterday that the company had refused to place in its buses cards advertising the Fusion candidacy of Jacob Gould Schurman Jr., for District Attorney because of a fixed policy against all political advertising.

Officials of New York City and Yonkers officially opened the new link between the Saw Mill River Road and Van Cortlandt Park at ceremonies yesterday morning on the city line. Thomas J. Dolen, Bronx Park Commissioner, cut a ribbon across the roadway at 11:45 o'clock and waiting lines of traffic, both northbound and south, began to move.

THE Actors Dinner Club is the only show in town that has had an uninterrupted run of twenty-three months and is still packing them in; and just to celebrate the club is pulling an allstar benefit jamboree, at tha Imperial Theatre on.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 (AP). -- Government by corporation has become the vehicle of Franklin D. Roosevelt's New Deal for America. It has replaced the "Hoover commission" form of executive action.

The formation of a new temperance society, "set up perhaps on a national basis and divorced from old groups and methods that have outlived their usefulness," was suggested yesterday In a further release of the text of the Rockefeller report on post-prohibition problems.
THACA, N.T., Oct. 21. -- Syracuse rallied to register its first victory over Cornell today since thelir football series began in 1891. The score was 14-7.
WASHINGTON. WITH repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment rapidly approaching, the Coast Guard is laying plans for continuance of its warfare against liquor smugglers after prohibition ends.

MR. CARPENTER'S book is fourth in the series of Martin Classical Lectures, founded in honor of Charles Beebe Martin, and the archaeology with which it deals is strictly limited to that of classical Greece. The author pleads for a better understanding of the value of this archaeology.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 21. -- A nation-wide walkout of silk strikers loomed as a possibility tonight after the failure yesterday of the National Labor Board, headed by Senator Wagner, to effect a settlement of the silk strikes concentrated largely in the area around Paterson, N.J.

The voters of San Francisco will approve or reject on Nov. 7 a project of the Board of Supervisors of that city for municipal distribution of power to be generated at the proposed Red Mountain. Bar plant on the Tuolumne River, which will become a part of the city's Hetch Hetchy water development.

OLIVER LA FARGE'S "Laughing Boy," which has been teetering on the brink of film transcription for the last year, seems definitely headed for the screen this time. W.S. Van Dyke, with his "The Prizefighter and the Lady" safely in the Metro cutting rooms, is bound for the Navajo Indian reservation in Arizona to make exterior scenes for Mr. La Farge's Pulitzer Prize novel.

THE Professor of the History of Christianity at the Colgate-Rochester Divinity School was compelled to write this book. As a believer in Christian ethics he felt conscience-bound to take this step toward undoing the great wrong inflicted by Christianity upon Judaism in fastening the blame for the crucifixion of Jesus upon the Jewish people.

CHESTERTOWN, Md., Oct. 21. -- From the summit of a hillock where George Washington once addressed a gathering at Washington College, President Roosevelt today challenged the idea of a dictatorship and renewed his appeal for a "spirit of cooperation" on which he said the Republic was founded.

A letter from Abraham Lincoln, refusing to interfere with New York City politics in 1863 to support the candidacy for Mayor of General John A. Dix, whom he privately favored, was recently withdrawn from the Museum of the City of New York by its owner, Thomas F. Madigan, autograph collector, 2 East Fifty-fourth Street.

CHICAGO, Oct. 21. -- A Century of Progress Exposition, scheduled to close Nov. 12, will reopen next year providing a suitable program be formulated to make such action possible, it was strongly indicated today by officials as they made public a letter from Franklin D. Roosevelt.

IOWA CITY, Iowa, Oct. 21. -- Three long years of bitter disappointment were wiped out today by a powerful and deceptive Iowa eleven, which overwhelmed Wisconsin, 26 to 7, before 39,000 home-coming fans.

IT pays to obey the rules of the air. The aeronautics branch of the Department of Commerce reports that eighty-seven of the 228 flights in violation of the department's air commerce regulations which occurred during the first six months of this year resulted in accidents.

PULLMANN, Wash., Oct. 21. -- Aided by the mighty passing arm of Phil Sorboe, their quarterback, Washington State's Cougars outplayed California's Bears in their conference football game today, but lacked the drive to give them more than a 6-to-6 tie.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Oct. 21. -- Declaring that the schools have uncomplainingly assumed their share in retrenchment, Dr. Robert C. Clothier, president of Rutgers University, urged adequate State support of education, both in the public schools and in higher institutions of learning, in his annual report, made public today.

CAIRO, Egypt, Oct. 21. -- The Egyptian Government is determined not to pay the interest coupons on the unified public debt bonds in gold regardless of any decision that the Court of Appeal of the Mixed Tribunals may make.

BUENOS AIRES, Oct. 21. -- Important government measures designed to solve Argentina's financial and economic problems will be considered at a Cabinet meeting Monday afternoon. The meeting was called at the request of Finance Minister Federico Pinedo during an informal talk of Cabinet members with President Augustin P. Justo today following the President's return from Brazil.
SIMSBURY, Conn., Oct. 21. -- A well-drilled and powerful Westminster eleven subdued Kent School, 19-0 today, reversing the score of last year's game in which Kent was the victor.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 21. -- Testimony that D. Harvey Sykes, a former constable, took to the office of State Senator John J. McClure "protection" money collected from rum boats, gambling houses and speakeasies in Delaware County was placed today in the records of the graft conspiracy trial of McClure and seventy-six others.
GLASGOW, Mont., Oct. 21 (AP). -- History may repeat itself around the site of old Fort Peck.
MOSCOW, Oct. 20. -- The Geneva crisis has brought out an interesting illustration of the operation of Soviet mentality in the face of an unexpected emergency.

Sixteen of the forty-six largest railroads in the United States are expected to show net earnings for 1933, according to an estimate by Dow, Jones Co. Some of the lines for which deficits are predicted have been earning their, interest charges in recent months, but not in sufficient amount to offset losses earlier in the year.

The order last week of Secretary Ickes of the Interior Department, as oil administrator, fixing a minimum price for crude oil and its products, as it now stands, will virtually eliminate the small independent refiner and the independent distributer, according to those who have analyzed it.
VIENNA, Oct. 21. -- Germany's exit from Geneva was the event of the week for Central Europe.

Autumn Presents. As a matter of news to mentally city-bound motorists, it should be reported at this time that Autumn in the woods and hills near New York is gorgeous. Or rather, it was last week-end, with the promise that the chromatic display would continue, and even get better, as long as October continued to behave itself as the Ziegfeld of the calendar.

ALBANY, Oct. 21. -- The constitutional safeguards which afford holders of State bonds "a security second to none" are cited by State Controller Morris S. Tremaine in identical letters sent out today to commercial and savings banks and insurance companies.

The Society of Naval Architects and Marine engineers announced yesterday that it had requested the Federal Government to build a new basin for the testing of ship models and for use in other tests and investigations essential to the development of shipbuilding.

ONE effect of the depreciation of the dollar in terms of foreign currencies has been the swift rise of Paris as an important market for dollars. And this is not without a certain practical importance for us. Paris is known in Europe as "the storm centre of foreign exchange."

The Independent Bondholders Committee for the Republic of Colombia, headed by former Senator Owen of Oklahoma, lodged a complaint yesterday with the State Department in Washington against the action of the Colombian Government "in impairing the rights of American holders or dollar bonds of the Mortgage Bank of Colombia and the Mortgage Bank of Bogota" while at the same time benefiting local interests.

PARIS, Oct. 21. -- The future of Premier Edouard Daladier's government, and with it the future of the franc, seems highly unfavorable tonight. The government, which has lasted since January, is expected to be defeated in the Chamber of Deputies.
ANDOVER, Mass., Oct. 21. -- A light, scrappy Brown freshman eleven battled Andover to a 6-to-6 tie today.

Acting on the suggestion of President Roosevelt the leading steel companies have reduced the price of rails from $40 a ton to $37.75 in the hope of obtaining orders for more than 1,000,000 tons of rails and fastenings.

ELIZABETH, N.J., Oct. 21. -- An order barring meetings of Nazi sympathizers and distribution, of Nazi circulars in this city has been Issued by Chief of Police Mulcahy to all police captains. A city ordinance recently adopted here will be invoked to ban the distribution of circulars and no permits for rallies will be issued, according to Chief Mulcahy.

REFUNDING operations by the Treasury have drawn attention to the Status of the national debt. On Sept. 30 the gross was $23,050,754,554.51. Less the net balance In the general fund, the total came to $21,905,199,763.10. Before the United States entered the World War the total gross national debt stood, for 1916, at $1,225,145,568.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., Oct. 21. -- The Naval Academy defeated the University of Virginia today by a score of 13 to 7. A crowd of 25,000 saw the game.

Joseph V. McKee, Recovery Party candidate for Mayor, further identified his candidacy with the Roosevelt administration in issuing last night a statement in which he asserted that conservative Republicans were backing F.H. LaGuardia, Fusion nominee for Mayor, to "strike a blow at Democratic national prestige in Washington."

SAN FRANCISCO, Calif., Oct. 18. -- California for the past two weeks has been the scene of conflict which it is hardly exaggerating to call civil war. Although the actual bloodshed has not been great -- four persons killed and perhaps a score wounded -- the psychology of war has prevailed over the troubled area of the southern San Joaquin Valley.

THE Private Life of Henry VIII," a British film which attracted hosts of persons to the Radio City Music Hall last week, is by all odds the most ambitious production to come from England's studios. It is a picture which is not only noteworthy for Charles Laughton's talented portrayal in the title role, but also for its admirable direction, its excellent script and the general artistry of its settings.

BERLIN, Oct. 21. -- The prospect of diplomatic recognition of Soviet Russia by the United States is far from pleasing to Germany. Its first result is seen as insuring a further curtailment of German exports by the transferring to the United States of orders for machinery, textiles and other goods which Russia must obtain abroad and of which Germany now supplies a fair share.

THE concert life in this city begins to grow this week. Up to the present the Philharmonic-Symphony and a handful of scattered recitals and the Chicago Opera Company have held the fort. The Philadelphia Orchestra, led, of course, by Leopold Stokowski, arrives this week for the first of its annual series of ten concerts, and a larger number of recitalists and ensemble venture forth to the public eye.
BALTIMORE, Md., Oct. 21. -- Western Maryland defeated Georgetown University, 20 to 0, before a disappointing crowd in the fifth annual meeting of the two elevens today.

MEDFORD, Mass., Oct. 21. -- Tufts College opened its home season today and defeated Connecticut State College 42 to 0 for its third straight triumph of the 1933 season. MacLean, Tufts halfback, made three touchdowns on fine runs.

Charles Solomon, Socialist candidate for Mayor, appealed last night to householders to support the Socialist ticket as the only one offering an adequate program of relief for the "overburdened small home owner." He made the appeal in Staten Island, which he called a "home owners' borough," at a meeting in Public School 20, Heberton Avenue, Port Richmond.

STOCKHOLM, Oct. 10. -- In anticipation of decisions in the Kreuger litigation shortly forthcoming from the High Court of Justice, the final court of appeal here, attention Is again directed toward this most dramatic criminal case ever submitted for Swedish adjudication.

At its Student Series concert in Carnegie Hall last night, the Philharmonic - Symphony Orchestra under Bruno Walter repeated Brahms's third symphony and Janacek's "Taras Bulba" from the Thursday night program. The new number was the Glazounoff violin concerto with Mishel Piastro, concertmaster of the orchestra, as soloist.

CHICAGO, Oct. 21. -- "Al Smith Day" at A Century of Progress Exposition was rained out today, necessitating postponement until Monday, but, despite a steady downpour, the former Governor devoted twelve hours or more to official receptions, interviews, luncheons and sightseeing at the fair.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 21. -- George Washington University defeated Auburn, 19 to 6, today before a crowd of 18,000.

MEMPHIS, Tenn., Oct. 18. -- With the Eighteenth Amendment well on its way to oblivion, Tennessee, along with Arkansas and Mississippi, is awaiting the next move in the way of liquor control with increasing interest. To the extent that a successful system of control eliminates the bootlegger and at the same time prevents the return of the old-time saloon, will these tri-States seriously consider any tampering with the present bone-dry State laws.

LONDON. THE vogue of the Western story, as an alternative to the detective story. Is rapidly spreading over Great Britain from America. That, at any rate, is the belief of Clifford Sharp, former editor of The New Statesman.

PEIPING, Oct. 17. -- Fossil animals, fish, insects and delicate gossamer flies 100,000,000 years old and perfectly preserved have been found embedded in the rocks of Central Asia by Dr. Sven Hedin's scientific mission, which has just closed six and a half years of intensive research and exploratory work.
VIENNA, Oct. 20. -- Since the Austrian Government's suppression of the Nazi press the Nazis have succeeded in maintaining, despite constant arrests, a subterranean service of party communiques.

FOR the part few years, with all their arrogance about contemporary life, Broadway has seen generally committed to plays about the problems and foibles of today. The costumes have come from the adjoining fashion shops where the curves and drapes of contemporary dandies are disdainfully inspired.

The latest statement of the State Bank of the Soviet Union, that for July 1, shows gold holdings of 779,464,520 gold rubles, equal to $401,112,400, against a note issue of 3,356,253,240 rubles, or approximately $1,727,127,900 at the par value of the ruble, 51.46 cents.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The possibility of borrowing large sums of money from the national government for "projects" of one sort or another encourages fantastic notions in many minds. The promoter who had begun to find the world a cold and cheerless place is becoming optimistic once more.

RECENT events in the Far East have again turned attention to the relations between Soviet Russia and Japan. There has been protracted haggling in negotiations for the sale of the Chinese Eastern Railway by the Russians to Japan or the State of Manchukuo.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Oct. 21. -- Mike Latvis, substitute halfback, starred as undefeated Washington Irving High of Tarrytown registered a 14-to-13 football victory over White Plains High before 8,000 at Parker Stadium today.
Appointments of general managers of the Pontiac, Buick and Olds divisions of the General Motors Corporation were announced yesterday by Alfred P. Sloan Jr., president of the corporation.

Setting a terrific pace through the hills, Steven Szumachowski, 18-year-old senior of Mont Pleasant High School of Schenectady, strode smoothly to a record-breaking victory in the ninth annual Manhattan College interscholastic cross-country run over the schoolboy course of approximately two and one-half miles in Van Cortlandt Park yesterday.
HIGHTSTOWN, N.J., Oct. 21. -- Displaying a smooth runnnig offensive, Mercersburg Academy conquered the Peddie eleven, 21 to 7, today before a large crowd at Alumni Field.

The first disqualification of the Empire City meeting took place yesterday when Dunlilt was deprived of second place in the Golden Leaf Purse at the Hilltop course. The victory went to Miss Merriment from the Dorwood Stable.

IN the constellation Ophiuchi a "nova" or "new star" recently blazed before the delighted eyes of L.C. Peltier, amateur astronomer of Delphos, Ohio., Harvard photographs soon confirmed Peltier's discovery. Now, wherever there is an observatory with a good telescope, astronomers are making spectographs of the nova.

DOWN in the Southland "the Old Ark's a-Moverin," and between thunderclaps Ol' Brother Noah argues with his God that he needs TWO kaigs of likker on board "caize there's pizen snakes in the hold." And "Gabriel," yes-man of Heaven, is shouting "Gangway for de Lawd Gawd Jehovah" for the first time below the Mason and Dixon line.

A RADIO showman recently remarked that the old orthodox idea, that radio stars must be signed up for a minimum of thirteen weeks will soon be as obsolete as the speakeasy. To attract the ears of the populace, according to the modern formula, a broadcast must possess freshness and novelty from week to week, also dramatic surprises.
NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Oct. 21. -- Mixing an effective overhead game with a powerful running attack, Rutgers downed a heavy Pennsylvania Military College eleven, 10 to 0, today before a crowd of 6,000.

OMAHA, Neb., Oct. 20. -- Strikes in factory, mill and mining districts have their agricultural counterpart in the Middle West in the growing spirit of discontent over the persistent disparity between farm income and the cost of farm purchases.

WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., Oct. 21. -- A hard-driving Bowdoin eleven conquered Williams, 13 -- 0, today. Hubbard starred for the victors, reeling off long gains through the Purple line on fast spinner plays.

Whether or not American corporations pay too lavishly for their executive talent, the salaries of their officers always are an interesting subject. Now that President Roosevelt has interested himself personally in the matter, it may be assumed that the administration disapproves of the general scale of compensation for industrial managers. Perhaps the objective will be a $60,000 yearly maximum such as has been set for railroad presidents.

IT is an inspiring procession of men that marches through the pages of Dr. Sigerist's book, men whose achievements fascinate, whose lives and labors move to admiration, whose personalities intrigue the imagination, whose contributions to human welfare have been so great and far-reaching that they fill the mind with a sentiment akin to awe.

CHICAGO, Oct. 21. -- Support that came again today to the wheat market was attributed to the government. The buying was under way early in the session mainly, and failed to come into the market at the close, as in the operations from Tuesday to Friday.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Oct. 21. -- Pennsylvanla State won at soccer from the Naval Academy today, 3 to 1. Corbett of the visitors scored first, but Geist evened the count. Fingel and Masters gave the victors their two-goal margin.

DETROIT. WITH a large tract of land as his laboratory, Henry Ford is putting into effect what might be called his "design for living." For a decade Mr. Ford, has been evolving a new pattern for the economic life of the nation; in his large tracts and scattered plants in the vicinity of Dearborn one begins to see the pattern -- a merger of farm and industry -- take form.

Many pastors will preach sermons today on the duty of parents to send their children regularly to Sunday school or to weekday religious classes. The day win mark the formal organization in a goodly number of the churches in Manhattan of their graded Bible schools for the Winter.

ABOUT 150,000 young men and women are graduated from the various universities, colleges and other institutions of higher learning in the United States each year. How many enter the public service as employes of the Federal, State and local governments?

PARIS, Oct. 21. -- French opinion sees in President Roosevelt's overtures to the Soviet Government a political rather than an economic move, and Le Temps offers the United States the advice not to admit Bolshevist propaganda along with the negotiations.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 21. -- Hugh S. Johnson, Administrator of the NRA, has asked Keith Neville, who resigned as chairman of the Nebraska State Recovery Board because he was "out of sympathy" with the way the recovery program was being conducted in Nebraska and other States, to reconsider his resignation and again join "whole-heartedly" in the effort to make the President's recovery program a success.

THE Scottish fishermen who in all weather follow the herring schools around the northerly coasts of the British Isles fear that their livelihood is in danger and are hoping for aid from the government. The herring industry brings in about $10,000,000 annually, and fresh backing is needed to meet Continental competition, especially to provide new boats.

BUFFALO, Oct. 19. -- In addition to an unusually interesting contest for Mayor, Buffalo this year is a principal centre in the State-wide struggle for control of the New York Assembly. The total Republican membership in the Assembly last year was reduced to 77.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 21. -- A Holy Cross eleven which evidently had absorbed the philosophy of its distinguished alumnus, Blondie Ryan, that "They can't beat us," upset Harvard, 10 -- 7, in the Crimson's stadium today.
