CHICAGO, Oct. 21. -- A wider understanding of international movements for the betterment of mankind through the reading of books and periodicals was urged at the final session of the American Library Association convention today. The principal speaker was Frederick P. Keppel of New York, president of the Carnegie Corporation.

THE next sale of books and manuscripts at the American Art Association Anderson Galleries resolves itself into something of a field day. In two afternoon sessions, on the 25th and 26th of the month, will be sold the library of the late Charles P. Senter of St. Louis, Mo.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 (AP). -- On the ground that no permanent good had been done to the Negro in relief subsidies in cities, Kelly Miller, dean of Howard University, made a plea today that the National Recovery Administration aid members of his race to establish themselves on farms.

OBERAMMERGAU, Oct. 20. -- The cast for next year's Passion Play represents only three changes in the major roles. The part of Mary Magdalen will be played by Clara Mayr. Johannis by Willi Bierling and Judas by Hans Zwink.

CHEYENNE, Wyo., Oct. 19. -- As this is being written, State engineers, special counsel and official representatives of Wyoming, Colorado and Nebraska are again packing their brief-cases with new charts, statistical material and irrigation data in preparation for what is hoped will be a final conference for the settlement of difficulties arising out of North Platte River water division among the three States.

MEEKER, Okla., Oct. 21. -- More than 10,000 Oklahoma baseball fans visited Meeker today to help this village of 750 residents welcome Carl Hubbell, "screw-ball" pitcher of the world's champion New York Giants, back home.

To the Editor of The New York Times: THE TIMES article on the model of the ancient Roman temples at Baalbek, soon to be exhibited at Rockefeller Center, oddly repeats the curious prejudice that has persisted for eighteen centuries against the Emperor Hadrian.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 21. -- With Captain Bob Lassiter playing in his whirlwind form of 1932, Tale turned back the dangerous challenge of a bruising and at times almost irresistible Brown eleven today to score a 14-to-6 victory in its first major test of the season.

When two peoples, one numbering 125,000,000 and the other numbering 160,000,000, resume diplomatic relations after a hiatus of sixteen years, it is a matter of great importance. In view of the domestic situation in the United States, on the one hand, and in Russia, on the other hand, and also in view of the problems of international relations throughout the world, it is a matter of still greater importance.

CHICAGO, Oct. 21. -- No extraditable offense is alleged in the indictment against Samuel Insull, in the opinion of Dean Emeritus John H. Wigmore of the Northwestern University Law School, and therefore he cannot be legally extradited. In part, Professor Wigmore's opinion follows:

BBRLIN, Sept. 23. HOWEVER self-centred Germany's political aspect may seem, the German stage after an interim of three Summer months appears to have been scarcely touched. The Fall crop of plays is springing up all around but the hue is indicative only of the tried and successful product of international calibre.

IT is not easy to think of Charles Edward Russell as a person old enough to have been able to go to Des Moines, Iowa, in December, 1881, and there found "the Iowa State Free Trade League, the first of its kind in the country." Not that there are not any number of men born in the early Sixties or late Fifties who are still vigorous and thoroughly up to date.

FARMINGDALE, L.I., Oct. 21. -- The New York Aggies football team scored a 12-6 triumph over an Alumni eleven today. With less than two minutes of the contest remaining, Malcolm Kuhn broke a 6-all deadlock by picking a fumble out of the air and dashing down the field fifty yards for the touch-down that decided the battle.

SHANGHAI, Sept. 22. -- Hereafter provincial governors, generals, mayors and other officials whose will is their only idea of law must not wantonly arrest, torture nor execute Chinese newspaper men who arouse their ire.

The task of organizing the banks of New York State under the bankers' NRA code is being advanced rapidly under the leadership of the New York State Bankers Association. A committee headed by William K. Payne, chairman of the National Bank of Auburn, N.Y., and past president of the State association, has arranged for a aeries of meetings of bankers throughout the State to put the code into operation.

DESSAU, Germany, Oct. 21. -- A reorganization of the Junkers Works has followed the retirement of Professor Hugo Junkers from its management. It is understood he will henceforth devote himself exclusively to technological research. It is also stated that the plant will be enlarged following a satisfactory settlement of the organization's finances.

WHEN Soviet Russia is mentioned, the personality of Joseph Stalin, Secretary of the Central Committee of the Communist party, most frequently comes to the minds of outsiders. Yet to the people of the U.S.S.R. Mikhail Ivanovich Kalinin, President of the Presidium of the Central Executive Committee, the supreme legislative, executive and administrative body of the government, is as familiar a name and and even more familiar presence.

The annual series of P.S.A.L. cross-country group runs will be brought to a close on Saturday morning over the Van Cortlandt Park course. The P.S.A.L. borough championship races will be conducted then, with the Curtis, De Witt Clinton, Manual Training and Bryant teams defending titles.

MEXICO, D.F., Oct. 19. -- Following my lecture before the Mexican Bankers Association here on the present financial problems of the United States and Mexico, I went for a conference with General Plutarco Elias Calles at Tehuacan, at which health resort he is taking a course of treatment.

BERNARDSVILLE, N.J., Oct. 21. -- One stake was completed and a start made on a second in the annual Autumn meeting of the Jockey Hollow Field Trial Club, which started today on the Fenner estate in Jockey Hollow.
STATE COLLEGE, Pa., Oct. 21. -- Sweeping to victory on the crest of a sensational aerial attack, the Penn State eleven defeated Lehigh in an Alumni Day game today, 33 to 0.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 21. -- A twelve-year effort to obtain passage of a State soldier bonus program in Pennsylvania reaches its climax at the Nov. 7 election. Veterans' groups are split on the proposal and the American Veterans Association, organized last year on a nation-wide scale in protest to the American Legion's nro-bonus activities, is preparing to wage an intensive two weeks' drive against the proposal.

No one withholds sympathy from the grain producers of the West, distressed by the low prices at which they had long been obliged to sell. The sense of disappointment has been general, that reduction of 29 per cent in this year's crop should not have brought Autumn wheat prices back to the old-time level.

Education can reduce social prejudice and create in children a more appreciative and tolerant attitude toward the Negro, Professor Harvey W. Zorbaugh, director of the clinic for gifted children of the New York University School of Education, said yesterday following a recent study.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Oct. 19. -- Behind the paradoxical situation of New York City being compelled to wait until a handful of Monroe County Assemblymen decided the time had come to grant it sufficient funds to meet relief expenses lies more than meets the eye.

RED BANK, N.J., Oct. 21. -- Taking command at the half-way mark and running from there as though he were competing in a sprint race. Sea Chart, the noted gelding which races for Mrs. Francis P. Garvan, today captured the seventh running of the Monmouth County Hunt Gold Cup.

Considering the hopeful character of the over-night news, the action of the share market, and of some of the other markets for that matter, was disappointing yesterday. Instead of extending the promising advance of Jate Friday, stocks turned sharply downward, with a depressing effect upon bonds and commodities.

RENO, Nev., Oct. 21 (AP). -- Elsie Janet Burgess charged cruelty in filing suit here today for a divorce from W. Starling Burgess of Darien, Conn. She asked court approval of a property settlement agreement.
PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 21. -- Drexel Institute ran roughshod over City College of New York to win by a 32-to-0 score today on Drexel Field before 2,000 persons.

Robert J. Byers, Department Adjutant and welfare officer of the American Legion of Michigan, and George S. Krieger, New York merchant, were convicted yesterday by a jury in Federal court of conspiracy to defraud the Government of the United States.
LONDON, Oct. 21. -- The Sunday Observer welcomes President Roosevelt's move toward recognition of the Soviet Union.

CHICAGO, Oct. 19. -- How municipalities throughout the country are cutting taxes in the face of the rising cost of government, at the same time making needed public improvements and adding to surplus accounts, was told at the eighth biennial public ownership conference recently held here.
The City Campaign. F.H. LaGuardia denounced pollticians for curtailing funds of the Health Department and promised not to "economize at the expense of human life."

The National Conference on Government on Nov. 9, 10 and 11 in Atlantic City will be under auspices of the National Association of Civic Secretaries, the Proportional Representation League, the Governmental Research Association, the National Municipal League and the National Conference of Citizens Councils.

Still another new sport is being introduced to collegians through the medium of the intramural games at Cornell, where intramural play in more popular, in several instances, than varsity competition. The new game is called speedball.

PARIS, Oct. 21. -- Admiration for the courage and dignity with which Americans have been facing the hardships of the economic depression was expressed today by Francois Latour, former President of the Paris Municipal Council, on his return from a visit to the United States in behalf of the France-America Society.

RALEIGH, N.C., Oct. 18. -- The perennial question of control of the Democratic party machinery in North Carolina has been brought sharply to the front by the resignation of former Governor O. Max Gardner as a member of the Democratic National Committee, and with it has become entwined the question of prohibition.

GREENWICH, Conn., Oct. 21. -- The Greenwich Society of Artists will hold a special exhibition of water-colors, drawings, pastels and work in black and white in the Greenwich Library, commencing Nov. 12 and continuing through Nov. 26.

To the Editor of The New York Times: You have been publishing articles on "Money and Inflation," and the letters of approval following them. A grand time seems to have been had by all. Since everything is therefore going along smoothly one wonders why the articles were necessary.

To the Editor of The New York Times: John Chamberlain's review of Dr. Logan Clendeningr's book "Behind the Doctor" has some very amusing passages in it. He quotes with, great gusto just those passages which represent serious blots on an otherwise splendid book.

THE five-toed dragons are rather friendly to man, but the three-toed ones are very, very bad. So much we learn from the long dissertation on dragon lore that Philo Vance pours Into the unwilling ears of District Attorney Markham.

MINEOLA, L.I., Oct. 21. -- R. Marano won both the 16-yard regular event and the skeet shoot at the Nassau Trapshooting Club today. In the former fixture, M.E. Grout topped the field with 49 out of 50 targets, but shot for targets only, Marano taking the cup with 48.

AIR express," said one of the country's big airline executives last week, "is going to be the answer to air transport's problem just as freight has been the answer to the question of how the bills are to be paid in most other forms of transport."

Play and Depression. People who are inclined to be down-hearted because the NRA is not working out as well as one might wish will remember, on the other hand, that the football season is only swinging into its stride.

Billy Petrolle, Fargo, N.D., welterweight, decisively outpointed Sammy Fuller of Boston in the ten-round feature bout at the Ridgewood Grove last night. Thereby he settled the question of supremacy, that arose over their previous meeting in Boston early last month which ended in a draw.

LONDON, Sunday, Oct. 22. -- Three great powers have barred the transfer of disarmament negotiations to the four-power European pact, according to the diplomatic correspondent of The London Sunday Observer. He says he understands that Britain, France and the United States have agreed that this treaty cannot be used as an alternative to the League of Nations for this purpose.

"LET us imagine two great arches or gates set up somewhere in Germany. Over one of these portals is the inscription 'Entrance to the Kingdom of Heaven'; over the other 'Entrance to Lectures on the Kingdom of Heaven.'
GAINESVILLE, Fla., Oct. 21. -- Florida gained its first football victory in history over the University of North Carolina, 9 to 0 today before a crowd of 10,000, including Governor Dave Sholtz.

WHILE States are assuming increased financial responsibility for a larger mileage of highway construction, and maintenance, the past year showed a decided slump in the funds furnished the State road departments for this work, and the amounts for 1933 and 1934 will again decline, W.C. Markham, executive secretary of the American Association of State Highway Officials, declared at its annual meeting held recently in Milwaukee.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 21. -- Dartmouth emerged triumphant from its initial major football test of the current season, sending Pennsylvania down to a 14-to-7 defeat before 45,000 spectators at Franklin Field today.

The local NRA Compliance Board will act on the first case of alleged violation of the President's Agreement tomorrow. A contractor holding a government contract has been directed by Grover Whalen, NRA administrator here, to appear at the NRA headquarters, 45 Broadway, to answer charges.

ANACACHO RANCH, Texas, Oct. 21 (AP). -- James A. Farley, Postmaster General, knows today that "son-of-a-gun" in cowboy parlance means a meat stew. But he did not find out until after Will Rogers, humorist, had roped him by the heels as he ran down a private right-of-way at the R.W. Morrison ranch.
ROME, Oct. 21. -- It would be very difficult accurately to define Italian public opinion toward the disruption of the Geneva Disarmament Conference caused by Germany's withdrawal.

The first of the Evelyn Brandt Musical Evenings will be given next Thursday at Essex House. Harold Henry will play his own compositions for piano. Mary Craig, soprano, and Sigurd Nillsen, bassbaritone, will sing.
Mayor O'Brien signed yesterday an application for a Federal loan to the city of $2,020,000 to build a steel shed at Pier 32, North River, and provide funds for incidental improvements to the pier.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 21. -- A recommendation to President Roosevelt that immediate financial relief be provided to farmers in the Grain Belt through the Commodity Credit Corporation is expected from Secretary Wallace tomorrow as an answer to the farmers growing dissatisfaction with the recovery program.

While workers and employers In the Jewelry trade were meeting yesterday to ratify an agreement ending the strike of about 8,000 jewelry workers tomorrow, the Gasoline Station Workers Union, an American Federation of Labor ffiliate, requested conferences with two groups of gasoline distributers In an effort to avert a strike of 25,000 filling-station employes in the metropolitan district.

Between Oct. 30, the date set for a national campaign rally in Chicago of all communities raising funds for welfare work, and Nov. 20, New York City will seek to collect $8,600,000 in three separate drives, it was said yesterday by Newton D. Baker, chairman of the 1933 Mobilization for Human Needs.

MUKDEN, Manchuria, Sept. 18. -- Two years ago this evening a small explosion occurred at a lonely spoton the South Manchuria Railway. It damaged one or two railway ties and twisted a steel fishplate, and traffic was delayed for an hour or two.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Oct. 21. -- The history of Westchester County will be reviewed in addresses at the annual dinner of the Westchester County Historical Society next Saturday at the Hotel Gramatan in Bronxville. The dinner will celebrate the 250th anniversary of Westchester's founding.

MEDIA, Pa., Oct. 21. -- Coming as a complete surprise, Vangergold, the entry of J.W.Y. Martin, was defeated in the Rose Tree Hunter Challenge Cup, a three-and-a half-mile timber race, by Tout Droit, owned by R.B. Young, at the final day of the Rose Tree Hunt Club's meeting near Media today.

APPROPRIATE and smart with Colonial and other period furnishings are fabrio-covered walls, now becoming a definite fashion. Panels of antique chintzes or linens are used; or whole walls are covered with reproductions of old textiles.

THE new link of the Saw Mill River Parkway, providing a direct connection with New York City, la expected to expedite the enormous volume of motor traffic between the metropolis and points in Westchester County and beyond.
VILLANOVA, Pa., Oct. 21. -- Villanova's Wildcats crushed Gettysburg, 40 -- 0, before 6,000 persons today.

VIENNA, Oct. 21. -- Austria's fighting five-foot Chancellor, Dr. Engelbert Dollfuss locked a German Nazi Princess in her romantic Carinthian castle tonight "for an indefinite period" and threw her princely husband into jail for six weeks.

LONDON. LONDON'S next Lord Mayor. Alderman and Sheriff C.H. Collet, who was recently "elected" at the Guildhall, is the head of a large hosiery firm and a wealthy man. He will need his income, for holding the office of Chief Magistrate of the ancient city of London is a costly privilege.

Controller George McAneny issuec a statement yesterday in which he sought to explain how the 1934 budget total has been brought to $555,976,996, although the city intends to spend $620,562,176,54 next year.

IF the National Industrial Recovery Act -- an emergency law -- continues its measure of government control of industry, will the act seek equally to control labor? This question, which cannot yet be answered definitely, is now being debated within the ranks of labor.

LONDON, OCT. 6. UNTIL this week London knew Miss Josephine Baker only by repute. "We had heard how the Folies-Bergere dancer of 1925 caught with her violent contortionism and primitive frenzy a passing fancy of Paris and how, as soon as her vogue showed signs of exhaustion, she quitted the Fblies-Bergere to reappear at the Casino de Paris in 1930 as a queen of revue.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In a letter published in one of your early September issues I referred to the "Securities Act of 1933" as "brainstorm legislation" which would effectually dry up the flow of capital for all industrial development.

GENEVA, Oct. 20. -- One thinG both responsible American and League of Nations circles here agreed, is certain among all the fear-breeding uncertainties this week has produced. They hold it certain there is no way out of the present situation for any one that can be guaranteed to be without danger.

A FINE, vigorous story of two boys and two girls who, it is said on the jacket, are the children of Knut and Marie Hamsun. Fortunate boys and girls they are, for they live all the year round on a Norwegian farm. Instead of dogs and cats for pets, each one owns a cow.

Much interest is being shown by Southerners living in New York in the annual dinner and ball to be given by members of the New York Southern Society on Friday night in the Grand Ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria. In addition to well-known Southerners who are expected to attend, there will be also, many younger Southern football enthusiasts, since the University of Alabama-Fordham University football game will be held here on Saturday.

The dance season was officially opened yesterday afternoon with a performance at Carnegie Trail by Uday Shan-Kar and his company of Hindu dancers and musicians. The audience was large, the welcome extended to the dancers was unmistakably cordial, and the art of ShanKar, surmounting a serious obstacle or two, proved itself again an exquisite form of choreographic theatre.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 21. -- Several thousand clergymen and lay members of the extreme ritualistic group in the Protestant Episcopal Church will be in this city to attend the Catholic Congress, held at this time in celebration of the centenary of the Oxford Movement, which has already been widely observed in England.

SAN JUAN. P.R., Oct. 19. -- Improvements at Mayaguez and Arecibo, made possible by funds allotted from the Federal public works appropriations, will, whenfinished, give the island four deepwater harbors. San Juan and Ponce now are well developed ports.

LEBANON. Pa., Oct. 21. -- Lebanon Valley defeated the Mount Saint Mary's eleven on the Bethlehem Steel Field today by 10 -- 8 by virtue of a sensational come-back after trailing by 8 -- 0 at the half. Smith's field goal in the final minutes of play provided the margin of victory.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 21. -- Hiram Bingham, former Senator from Connecticut, was re-elected president of the National Aeronautic Association president to replace Rear Admiral at the closing session of the annual convention today. He was unopposed.
PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 21. -- Princeton moved back Into the full glare of football greatness before 40,000 persons In the Palmer Stadium today.

Voices both in Europe and in the United States that have been predicting a speedy outbreak of war have become more shrill since Germany's withdrawal from the League of Nations and from the Disarmament Conference. The cynical comment is made that we are face to face now with the "tragic paradox" that what was to be disarmament is becoming rearmament.

The Rockefeller committee recommends the retailing of liquor in government stores only. This means that we won't be able to buy a drink in public. The gentlemen in charge of the study do not seem to realize that the Americans are not crying for liquor, but they do desire to regain their lost liberties.
IN the first place, it is very pleasant indeed to welcome a resumption of the Carnegie International series after the lapse of a season in which this important theatre of activity has been "dark."

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 21. -- Howard Harpster, nemesis of Notre Dame as a player for Carnegie Tech when the late Knute Rockne guided the destinies of the South Bend elevens, achieved a notable distinction today when his Carnegie Tartans downed Notre Dame, 7 to 0.

MANHATTAN, Kan., Oct. 21. -- A 59-yard dash by Halfback Hub Boswell, which enabled Fullback George Sauer to drive over for a touchdown from the 1-yard mark, and a field goal by Quarterback Bernie Masterson gave the champion Nebraska Cornhuskers a 9-0 victory today over Kansas State College.

PROFESSOR ZURCHER limits his study of the democratic experiment in Europe to postwar Germany and the Russian and Austro-Hungarian succession States. In all of those States, as a result of the political revolutions of 1917-19 inspired by the World War and dominated in importance by the events in Russia, democratic constitutions were adopted, but in none of them was democracy, as a controlling principle, inherent in the political tradition.

WALTER STARKIE writes "Litt. D." after his name, he is Professor of Spanish in the University of Dublin and a fellow of Trinity College, that city. But he had a vacation of sheer delight, of a thousand satisfactions, of pleasure undiluted, when he tucked his fiddle under his arm.

VANCE RANDOLPH has made his home in the Ozarks for many years. He is the author of two valuable books, "The Ozarks: An American Survival of Primitive Society" and "Ozark Mountain Folks." Thames Williamson's recent poetic melodrama, "The Woods Colt," is dedicated to Randolph as the recognized authority on Ozark language and customs.
