Thames Williamson's recent poetic melodrama, "The Woods Colt," is dedicated to Randolph as the recognized authority on Ozark language and customs.
ATLANTA, Ga., Oct. 21. -- A sensational 101-yard run back of the ikck-off starting the second half enabled the Tulane Green Wave to upset Georgia Tech's eleven today, 7 to 0.

FASHION, this Fall, is a small girl turned loose in grandmother's garret. Rummaging in trunks put away when the World's Fair of 1893 was over, emerging from cupboards with both hands full of the glamourous garb of 1910, tying tie throat up in enormous bows, cocking a picture hat on her bobbed head and slipping a huge muff over painted fingernails, she struts and preens and manages somehow to look exactly like these topsy-turvy times.
NEWPORT NEWS, Va., Oct. 21 (AP). -- With a cheerful good-bye to his native Virginia, Rear Admiral Richard E. Byrd today pointed the prow of his flagship Jacob Ruppert toward the bottom of the earth.

The progress of plans for recognition of Soviet Russia by the United States, announced late last week, is considered generally in financial circles one of the most important economic developments of the year to date. Recognizing the step as of tremendous moment, Wall Street is nevertheless in something of a quandary as to its immediate results.

GENEVA, Oct. 21. -- In comment on the forthcoming Soviet-American negotiations, League of Nations officials today voiced satisfaction at the way Washington and Moscow have become more friendly to Geneva, in almost direct relation to the increasing chilliness of Tokyo and Berlin.

Keyed to a fighting pitch for their traditional contest yesterday, Fordham and Boston College battled fiercely on even terms for two periods. Then a second-half Maroon onslaught gave Fordham a 32-to-6 triumph at the Polo Grounds.

Time and events have been wearing down the obstacles standing in the way of correct diplomatic relations between the United States and Soviet Russia, though President ROOSEVELT in his note to KALININ is careful to state that serious difficulties remain. The two legalistic requirements in extending recognition to a new regime is that it shall be stable and that it shall be ready to meet its foreign obligations.

CHILD prodigies flock to the microphones in great numbers, but few get by the broadcast hours set aside for juvenile performers on Sunday morning's. There is one new star, however, who recently broke away from the crowd and she is Mary Small, popularly known as "the small girl with the big voice."

IT was in 1794 that Louis Duclot, a French printer who had fled the Negro uprising in Santo Domingo, landed in New Orleans and almost immediately started the first newspaper. It was called Le Moniteur de la Louisiana and it had for its motto, "Bombalio, Clangor, Stridor, Taratantara, Murmur."

PORTLAND. Ore., Oct. 21. -- A battling band of Beavers from Oregon State College today registered a startling upset by holding the University of Southern California football team to a scoreless tie and ending the Trojan string of twenty-five successive victories.

BOSTON, Mass., Oct. 21. -- A "mechanical heart, beating like a human heart, was demonstrated last night for the first time by the inventor, Dr. George Levene, 36, director of the Roentgenology Department of the Massachusetts Memorial Hospitals.

DALLAS, Oct. 20.-Business throughout this district has been greatly stimulated in the last two weeks by the receipt of nearly $29,000,000 in cotton plow-up checks by farmers who cooperated in the agricultural recovery program.
GENEVA, Oct. 21. -- In a thirty-five-word note, which neither explained nor justified her action, Germany officially notified the League of Nations today of her intention to withdraw.

Twelve paintings by Claude Monet, bought from the artist by the late James F. Sutton, will be included in an auction sale of paintings, mainly of the Barbizon and Impressionist schools, which will be held at the American Art Association Anderson Galleries next Thursday evening.

SHREVEPORT, La., Oct. 21 (AP). -- Senator Huey P. Long came to Shreveport today in the private railroad car of the Couch brothers, railroad and utilities magnates, and at a bridge dedication urged the redistribution of wealth.

TWENTY young American painters are represented in the current show at the Montross, among them Holmead Phillips, Miron Sokole, Raphael Soyer and Loran Wilford. Visitors will find here Lee Townsend's groups -- dull in color but striking in composition; Revington Arthur's challenging, if too acid, landscape and figure studies and Eugene Small's sleeping figure with draperies in a gray dawn light.

Copyright, 1833, by The Associated Press. WASHINGTON, Oct. 21. -- With an eye toward repeal, which officials believe to be imminent, the administration is drafting its tax program In the expectation of receiving a minimum of $500,000,000 in taxes from distilled liquors during the first year of legal sale.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 21. -- The fiftieth anniversary of the Graduate School of Arts and Sciences of the University of Pennsylvania will be observed Oct. 31. Distinguished leaders in graduate education will participate in exercises in the Irvine Auditorium.

GRACE CHURCH begins today the celebration of the 125th anniversary of its founding. The original building, an offspring of Trinity, the "Mother of Churches," was consecrated on Dec. 21, 1808, being located at the corner of Rector Street and Broadway.

SANTIAGO, Chile. Oct. 21. -- Chile's resumption of payments on her foreign debt service is a remote possibility, according to a statement issued yesterday by the Central Bank. The same conditions that forced suspension of service in 1931 obtain today, the bulletin states, aggravated by a further decline in the exchange value of the peso.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 21. -- The United States delegation to the Pan-American Conference, scheduled to open at Montevideo on Dec. 3, has been tentatively selected, but official announcement will be withheld for several days. Hotel reservations have been made for the delegation at Montevideo and officials here discount published rumors of postponement of the conference.

THE December issue of The American Mercury will be the last to appear under the editorship of H.L. Mencken, who will retire in order to devote more time to the writing of books. Mr. Mencken has served as editor of the Mercury ever since its first issue in 1924, and he succeeded in giving the magazine an individual character that commanded attention from the very first.

Colonel Manuel Despaigne, Secretary of the Treasury in the student-soldier government of Cuba, told this writer in Havana last week that if governmental revenues continued to decline at their present rate Cuba would have to make a decision by December regarding a moratorium on her foreign debt, most of which is owed to investors in the United States.
LAUREL, Md., Oct. 21. -- C.V. Whitney's Jabot defeated M.L. Schwartz's Hindu queen by a neck today to capture the $10,000 added Selima Stakes, the richest purse of the Laurel season -- $22,175.

BERLIN, Oct. 21. -- The week-end session of the Boerse was generally, firm, despite some irregularity. Stocks gained up to 3 per cent and bonds up to 1 1/2. The market was stimulated by the continued buoyancy of Reichsbank shares which rose 4 per cent, although their highest level was not maintained.

M.FAY has chosen artfully a title that at once declares Its object and strikes the reader with surprise. Who is this second Franklin thus to be enshrined? The doctor's grandson, Benjamin Franklin Bache. The slightest reflection, however, shows that this addition to the list of fathers conies naturally and with a beautiful symbolism from a house-hold devoid of severe genealogical scruples and taking a liberal view of paternity.

MINNEAPOLIS, Oct. 21. -- Pittsburgh's Panthers were blasted out of the national football picture by a powerful Minnesota eleven, which scored a surprising 7-3 victory over the favored Easterners today. The attendance was 28,000.
Two champion swimming teams met surprising defeat yesterday in the second series of annual dual meets conducted by the P.S.A.L. for senior high schools.

BOSTON, Oct. 18. -- The general convention of the Universalist Church meets today in Worcester with perhaps a thousand delegates in attendance. This is expected to be by far the most important meeting of the convention in many years.

LONDON. WITH characteristic impetuousness, Chancellor Hitler has ventured upon another gamble -- the most daring in scope he has yet undertaken. Having saved Germany from democracy and, as he claims, from communism, he now purposes to save her from foreign humiliation by defying the predominant opinion of most of the Western world.

THE death of Adelaide Crapsey in 1914 left a coterie of friends wondering as to her fame. Misa Osborn's competent biography will go a long way In establishing it. Since her death, however, the anthologists have given recurrent recognition of her verse until by now this creator of the "Cinquain" is fairly well impinged on the critic consciousness.

MASON'S ISLAND, Conn., Oct. 21. -- A two-day frostbite dinghy regatta under the auspices of the Mystic Island Yacht Club opened today in Fishers Island Sound. Twenty-two boats competed in a stiff southeast wind.

Time was when the physicist regarded evolution a little superciliously. Theory? Magnificent generalization were a better designation. A theory must be based on experiment and on facts that can be statistically analyzed. Resting as it did solely on observation, evolution failed on both counts.
LAWRENCEVILLE, N.J., Oct. 21. -- The Lawrenceville School eleven defeated Franklin and Marshall Academy by 6-0 today.
The quality of British leadership is today at the lowest ebb in forty years, declares Wickham Steed, former editor of The London Times, in 'an article in November Current History.

Richard Whitney, president of the New York Stock Exchange, issued yesterday a statement protesting against a remark of Ferdinand Pecora, counsel to the Senate Banking and Currency Committee, that there was no further occasion for inviting Mr. Whitney's cooperation in the committee's investigation since it had been sought and not obtained.

ABOARD THE GRAF ZEPPELIN, Oct. 21. -- Passengers on board the dirigible Graf Zeppelin today received engraved certificates as they were crossing the Equator at 2 P.M. (about noon New York time) on their way north-ward from Pernambuco to Miami. The initiation was conducted, by "Aeolus" in place of the "Neptune" who officiates at sea.

SANTIAGO, Cuba, Oct. 21 (AP). -- This provincial capital was like a beleaguered city tonight because of a soldiers' mutiny. One soldier was killed in fighting among troopers who mutinied because of dissatisfaction over a change in their commanding officers.

Copyright, 1933, by NANA, Inc. BERLIN, Oct. 20 (By Wireless). -- At this most critical juncture in German relations with the rest of Europe since the World War, I have received from the German Chancellor, Adolf Hitler, the most detailed and direct definition of Germany's attitude in international politics that he has ever made.

A defense of the Erie Railroad's commutation rates, including the contention that the 15 per cent increase of Jan. 1, 1933, merely meets the rates of the steam lines of the Delaware, Lackawanna Western serving "almost identical territory," was offered by Erie officials yesterday at the second and closing session of an Interstate Commerce Commission hearing.

ONLY the dove or peace has seen more wars than Frederick Palmer. He has spent the last three dozen years breathing the smoke of battle and writing about the futility and the treacherous excitement of it. Today he is a pacifist and philosopher.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 -- Maxim M. Litvinoff, Soviet Foreign Commissar, is expected to come to Washington soon in response to President Roosevelt's invitation to a discussion of mutual problems, leading to possible recognition. Recognition is likely to result from the meeting, most officials believe.

The Greenfield and Carroll Club elevens remain the only unbeaten and untied teams in the round-robin competition of the New York Women's Field Hockey Association. Both won yesterday at Prospect Park, Brooklyn.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 21. -- The success of the boycott by American workers of German-made goods, in protest against the "persecution" of trade unions and the Jewish people by the Hitler government, was acclaimed here today by William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor.

PLAINFIELD, N.J., Oct. 21. -- After placing third in the first heat, J.I. Lyle's Hollyrood Onward came back to win the next two heats and third race At the Borough Park track today. The event featured a light harness matinee staged by the Central New Jersey Horsemen's Association.

Two developments last week enhanced the prospects for successful operation of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, which, in its temporary form, will begin on Jan. 1, next. These were the drastio fall in security and commodity prices and the arrangements made by the government with the New York Clearing House banks to increase bank capital by the sale of capital notes or preferred stock to the RFC.

LONDON, Oct. 20. -- If by any chance Great Britain should take a dip on its own. account into this "shirt" era of modern history, it is not likely it will use the Fascist label. Neither will its symbolic garb be the black shirt of Italy, the brown of Germany, the blue of Ireland or even the khaki of America's Art Smith.

President Roosevelt's step toward resumption of diplomatic relations with Russia helped to advance prices for cotton in early trading yesterday on the Cotton Exchange, but later weakness in the stock market canceled the improvement. At one time an increase in buying lifted quotations 15 points, but outside liquidation left the list 2 points higher to 3 points lower than on Friday.
KNOXVILLE, Tenn, Oct. 21. -- For the first time since 1924, the University of Tennessee suffered defeat in a football game on home grounds when Alabama turned back the Volunteers today, 12 to 6.

HARTFORD, CONN. From The Courant. The recognition of Russia should not be based on the possibilities of its resulting in expanding our trade with that country, alluring as that prospect may seem. Rather should it be based on the fact that comity requires that we take diplomatic cognizance of a government that is just as stable as are various other governments with which we exchange Ambassadors.
Mayor O'Brien continued his "whirlwind" campaign last night with appearances in several places in Manhattan and the Bronx, only to find speechmaking at some of them difficult.

Charles Solomon, Socialist candidate for Mayor, denounced yesterday the reported plan of the Board of Education to name a new Superintendent of Schools next Wednesday to succeed Dr. William J. O'Shea.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 (AP). -- Although a drive for modification has been begun by some business interests, Congressional leaders do not believe the Glass-Steagall Banking Act will be changed at the next session.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 22. -- Allocations for public works have passed the $2,000,000,000 mark.

The United German Societies will meet at 8 P.M. tonight at the New Yorker Turnhalle, Lexington Avenue and Eighty-fifth Street, to decide what to do about their German Day celebration, which has been prohibited by Mayor O'Brien on the ground that the doctrines of Hitler would be discussed and that disorder would result.
The cotton market last week reached the lowest level in a month, but it recovered sharply and closed the week with little net change. It was subjected to strongly conflicting forces.

Civilization will be a total wreck unless mankind reforms and becomes cleaner, kinder and unselfish, the Rev. Dr. Paul Scherer warned in his sermon yesterday at the Holy Trinity Lutheran Church, Central Park West and Sixty-fifth Street.

JERUSALEM, Oct. 22. -- Strong resentment prevails in Jewish Agency circles and is spreading among the Jewish public in general over the issuance by the Palestine Government of only 5,500 labor immigration certificates for the next six months.

After having won its first two games of the season by large margins, Hotchkiss School's football team was called upon to rally for victory on Saturday when defeat was impending. The Blue eleven proved itself equal to the task.

CHICAGO, Oct. 22. -- Alfred E. Smith visited the World's Fair today and took in the sights without fuss or flurry. "Just an ordinary citizen from New York," he described himself, but he attracted more attention than any dignitary who has viewed the fair in five months, during which the presence of officials has become so common that some of them did not even rate a raised eyebrow from a gate lieutenant.

VIENNA, Oct. 22. -- A perusal of the correspondence files and documents confiscated yesterday at Castle Pitzelstaetten in Carinthia when its owner, the German Prince Bernhard von Sachsen-Meiningen, was jailed on a charge of being a participant in a Nazi conspiracy, has revealed to the police a long list of names and addresses indicating a nation-wide organization of his activities.

BERLIN, Oct. 22. -- The master showmen who are now ruling Germany staged another great spectacle in Berlin today and it was a good one. This time it was a procession seven miles long of German workers, particularly handicraftsmen, closing a week which had been devoted to glorifying the handicraftsmen as opposed to the mere machine minder, the small indivualist living by his own skill as against the corporation employe.

LONDON, Oct. 21. -- The financial markets here faced with wonderful composure the sudden political crisis that developed a week ago following Germany's withdrawal from the League of Nations. The United States and the Continent were much more disturbed than London, which sees nothing very alarming and much theatrical in Germany's action.
NIAGARA FALLS, N.Y., Oct. 22. -- Niagara lost today to the De Paul University eleven of Chicago, 18 to 0. Oldani tallied twice for the visitors, Stadly accounting for the other score.

Politics has played no part either in the public works program of the Federal Government in the city or in the administration of the work and home relief by Mayor O'Brien, Rear Admiral Frederic R. Harris declared in a statement issued yesterday.

Lawrence Connor, 4 years old, narrowly escaped burning to death yesterday morning when he was rescued from the living room of an apartment at 40-22 Forty-fourth Street, Sunnyside, Queens. The structure had caught fire while the boy's parents, John and Julia Connor, were attending church services near by.

VIENNA, Oct. 22. -- Striking confirmation of the reported differences between Prince Ernst Ruediger con Starhemberg, commander-in-chief of the Heimwehr and Chancellor Dollfuss's deputy in the Patriotic Front, and Major Emil Fey, Heimwehr Vice Chancellor, was forthcoming tonight when newspapers were unofficially forbidden to publish a fiery speech delivered by the young Heimwehr commander at Bad Gastein today.

NEWPORT, R.I., Oct. 22. -- Governor Theodore Francis Green of Rhode Island was a guest at the luncheon given today by Mrs. Skirvin Adams at Beachmound. Eighteen persons were present. Miss Mary E. Hughes, national chairman for the women's division of the NRA, who had planned to attend, was obliged to depart for New York this morning, sooner than she had expected.
To the Editor of The New York Times: It is curious that Arthur Krock, in his article on your editorial page this morning, does not proceed to draw the logical inference from some of his revelations.

ROME, Oct. 22. -- Primo Carnera, recently crowned world's heavyweight champion, today retained his title against the onslaught of the 35-year-old Basque, Paulino Uzcudun, in one of the most one-sided contests ever seen.

TOKYO, Monday, Oct. 23. -- Charges that the United States Naval Administration in Guam deprived Ichiji Shimizu, a Japanese subject, of his legal rights on the island are being investigated by the Japanese Foreign Office.

PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 22. -- Today was the 187th anniversary of the founding of Princeton University. The date also marks the anniversary of the change of title from the College of New Jersey to Princeton University in 1896, the dedication of the graduate college in 1913 and the dedication of Fine Hall in 1931.

Governor Lehman appealed yesterday to the electorate of the State to vote on Nov. 7 in favor of the proposition providing for a $60,000,000 bond issue for unemployment relief. The bond issue is essential to provide for adequate relief for the unemployed, he declared.

The award of the Perkin Medal of the Society of Chemical Industry for 1934 to Dr. Colin G. Fink, Professor of Electrochemistry at Columbia University, and the discoverer of ductile tungsten, which is used in electric light bulbs, was announced yesterday by officials of the society.

Obligations of the United States Government that will mature within the next twelve months amount to $2,903,409,200. They consist of Treasury certificates of indebtedness, notes and non-interest-bearing discount bills.

NORFOLK, Va., Oct. 22 (AP). -- The steamer Jacob Ruppert, flagship of Admiral Byrd's Antarctic expedition, left the shores of Virginia this afternoon after having spent seven hours anchored in Lynnhaven Roads, near Cape Henry, while her cargo was being stored and made secure.
The Stapleton football club scored a 33-2 victory over the Temple Club of Philadelphia in an exhibition game at Thompson's Stadium, Stapleton, L.I., yesterday.
ABOARD THE GRAF ZEPPELIN, Oct. 22. -- The Graf Zeppelin passed over Santo Domingo, capital of the Dominican Republic, at 6 P.M. today.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 22. -- Since the inauguration of President Roosevelt unemployment in the United States has been reduced by about 3,600,000, President William Green of the American Federation of Labor stated today. Of these more than 1,700,000 have been reemployed, Mr. Green said, as a result of the functioning of the President's recovery program.

Major LAGUARDIA had declared that from the moment he enters the City Hall as Mayor -- if he does -- he will be "out of politics." He meant, of course, out of State or national politics. They ought to be kept out of a municipal election, if for no other reason in order to comply with the plain design of the Constitution of the State of New York.

The creation of a conference of ship lines operating between ports of the Atlantic coast and the Gull has been discussed in the last few days by representatives of the leading lines and will be continued this week, with a view to effecting an agreement on rates, sailings and other problems.

As long as the United States and the former allied nations refuse to disarm, "abhorrent conditions" will continue in Germany, the Right Rev. Dr. William Hall Moreland, Bishop of Sacramento, declared in his sermon yesterday morning at the Protestant Episcopal Church of St. Mary the Virgin, 139 West Forty-sixth Street.

PITTSFIELD, Mass., Oct. 22. -- Mrs. E. Parmalee Prentice entertained 200 persons at Mount Hope Farms, Williamstown, yesterday it her fourth musicale and tea of the season. Archer Gibson, organist, and Conrad Thibault, baritone, gave a popular program.

LONDON, Oct. 22. -- The suggestion is made tonight by the financial editor of The Daily Herald that the Bank of England is using u40,000,000 in British gold in an attempt to bolster up the French franc.

After scoring two touchdowns in each of his team's first three games, Ed Danowski, Fordham captain, was held to a single tally on Saturday by Boston College. His lead in the Eastern individual scoring race was reduced.

Traditionally, a rise or fall in stocks must be explained on the spot by Wall Street and, when Wall Street is wearied with repetition of one explanation, it is always expected to produce another. At the outset, the irregular decline since the middle of September was assigned by Stock Exchange philosophers to the foreign exchange market's simultaneous advancing of "the dollar's valuation."

DES MOINES, Oct. 22 (AP). -- The National Farmers Holiday Association has received offers of support from two labor federations in its strike for higher agricultural prices, Milo Reno, head of the association, announced tonight.

PARIS, Oct. 21. -- The origin of the sharp recovery of the pound and the dollar this week certainly cannot be sought in France. Public opinion here received the news of the attitude adopted by Germany at Geneva with calm, and it is considered that this will have the merit at least of making other countries appreciate France's position and the extent to which she has gone to enable the disarmament conference to succeed.

Operations of the national recovery measures are steadily bringing into prominence the extent to which major sections of the national economy are dependent upon overseas markets for prosperity, James A. Farrell, chairman of the National Foreign Trade Council and former president of the United States Steel Corporation, said yesterday in a statement in which he stressed the importance of exports to the NRA program.

Mayor O'Brien was among the 3,000 persons who assisted yesterday at the consecration services of the new Hellenic Eastern Orthodox Cathedral, 319 East Seventy-fourth Street. The edifice, which was built at a cost of $600,000, is modeled in part after the "Great Church" of St. Sophia in Constantinople, the first of all surviving Greek cathedrals.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Oct. 22. -- Horse racing returned to the old Dickerman track on Ward's Acres today when a program of five contests, sponsored by the local American Legion Post 8, was staged before 1,200 persons. The card comprised three races on the flat and two over timber.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 (AP). -- A complete revision of the Federal tax structure, embracing a tightening of the Income Tax Law and a revamping of liquor levies in expectation of prohibition repeal, is the purpose of a study to get under way tomorrow before a Ways and Means subcommittee.
"Her Master's Voice," a play by Clare Kummer, will open tonight at the Plymouth Theatre. Roland Young and Laura Hope Crews head the cast.

Bishop William T. Manning of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of New York urged the public yesterday to remember that nothing would be gained "if one political machine is replaced by another which represents the same methods, includes many of the same men, and will be used for the same ends."

NEW HAVEN, Oct. 22. -- Professor Irving Fisher's index number of commodity prices, based on 100 as the average for 1926, is 71.5, which compares with 72.2 a week ago, 71.1 two weeks ago, 71.4 three weeks ago and 71.6 four weeks ago. Last week's average was the highest of the year to date; the highest July figure was 70.4.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 22 (AP). -- An antique ring worn by an actress has brought together the daughter and son of two stage families and returned to the son a treasured heirloom of his father. As a result the actress is richer by $1,500.

Dr. William H. Park, "conqueror at diphtheria" in this city and an internationally-known authority on public health, soon will apply to the Board of Estimate for permission to continue in the research post he has held in the Health Department for the last forty years, it was reported yesterday.

The attitude of the student body at Barnard College has changed during the last year from one of "blase indifference" to that of "serious interest in work and play," Dean Virginia C. Gildersleeve asserted in her annual report to Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of Columbia University, made public yesterday.

A complete NRA check-up of all employers in New York City will begin tomorrow. The survey will have two objectives: First, that of determining exactly what the NRA has done for this city and, secondly, stopping what NRA officials denounce as "the whispering campaign" predicting failure of the NRA.
It is extremely doubtful that any Saturday of recent years has seen quite the carnage that was wrought in the erstwhile upper strata of football the past week-end.

The rising menace of juvenile delinquency can be traced to the politicians who protect the "big-shot" racketeers, Justice Frederick Kernochan told a group of Negro voters yesterday afternoon at a meeting at his headquarters in the Paramount Building.

A greatly liberalized attitude by insurance companies toward granting policies to the blind was reported yesterday by the American Foundation for the Blind, on the basis of a study covering the period from 1923 to 1932.
The First Division polo four defeated Governors Island yesterday at Fort Hamilton, 10 to 3, creating a deadlock in the annual series for the Colyer Trophy.

ATHENS, Oct. 22. -- Today's three hour hearing in the Insull extradition trial was occupied by the continuance of the argument begun yesterday by P. Rhallis of defense counsel. The attorney attempted to prove that the Federal dossier was juridically unacceptable under American law and therefore inadmissible under Greek law.

WATERFORD, N.J., Oct. 22. -- Three persons were killed, four were critically injured and nine were severely shaken and bruised in a collision between a northbound sedan and a southbound Beach Haven bus on White Horse Pike, here, at 10 o'clock tonight.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 22. -- A plea for Americans to abandon Protestantism and return to the Christianity of the early apostles was voiced here today by the Right Rev. Benjamin F.P. Ivins, Bishop of Milwaukee and president of the Sixth Catholic Congress of the Episcopal Church, which opens formally tomorrow.

HASBROUCK HEIGHTS, N.J., Oct. 22. -- Despite the appearance of Earle W. Hopping at No. 3 for Oraworth, West Point defeated that team at Teterboro Field by 10 to 9 today. Lieutenant Sam Walker scored the winning goal after two minutes of a "sudden-death" extra period.
F.H. LaGuardia, Fusion candidate for Mayor, carried his campaign to the city's housewives yesterday with a promise to cut their grocers' and butchers' bills by from 10 to 15 per cent.

LONDON, Oct. 21. -- A steady but unobtrusive advance has occurred in discount rates in this market. Four weeks ago the government was borrowing on three-month Treasury bills at less than one-fourth of 1 per cent, while the market rate for commercial bills was only three-eighths of 1 per cent, but the current rate for Treasury bills is three-quarters of 1 per cent and for commercial bills seven-eighths of 1 per cent.
ROME, Oct. 22 (AP). -- The fight today was Primo Carnera's first defense of the title he won by knocking out Jack Sharkey in six rounds at New York on June 29.

CHICAGO, Oct. 22. -- Prices for hogs here are the lowest in six weeks, despite the recent government buying and prospects of its resumption in the near future. Big packers have bought comparatively little, while shippers and small packers have absorbed moderate quantities.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 22. -- President Roosevelt's new gold policy, as outlined in his address tonight, was interpreted here as the first definite step in the direction of a managed currency. Heretofore the dollar has been left to seek its own level.

NEW YORK. Mr. and Mrs. George Valentine Smith of this city and Rye will give a dinner dance Dec. 28 in the Crystal Room, of the Ritz-Carlton for their debutante daughters, the Misses Madeline and Oramella Smith.
The Third Moravian Church, 410 West Forty-fifth Street, celebrated yesterday the thirty-second anniversary of its founding. The Rev. Victor G. Flinn, its original pastor, delivered the sermon.

BERNARDSVILLE, N.J., Oct. 22. -- Running a wide and speedy race and showing class in his work on game, Rumson Farm Sid was awarded the highest honors today in the amateur All-Age Stake, the leading event in the two-day meeting of the Jockey Hollow Field Trial Club.

FOR years Frederick Palmer went forth to the wars and reported them for newspapers in America. More than Richard Harding Davis, who never thought very deeply about what he saw, Palmer became a sort of philosophic connoisseur of the Protean manifestations of Mars. He saw the last "smoke-powder" war, fought by the Greeks and the Turks in 1896 under the peaks of Pelion and Ossa.

The present deer season in New York State has occasioned much discussion among sportsmen since the opening on Oct. 15. Comment has not been in regard to the bags which have been made so much as over the conditions existing in the woods.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., Oct. 22. -- Henry S. Cram of New York and Bluffton, S.C., was among the many taking part in the second community fox hunt of the season, organized by Sidney Z. Mitchell of New York. The riders left the Greenbrier before daylight yesterday and, after breakfast on O'Farrell's Mountain, returned with a live fox, which Mr. Mitchell will send to his estate in Alabama.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 22. -- A new chapter in American history, containing the first evidence that human beings lived on the Atlantic coast as far back as the time of Christ, has been written by a 2,000-year-old stone axe dug up in Albemarle County, Va.
The New York Giants strengthened their hold on third place in the National Football League by turning back the Brooklyn Dodgers at the Polo Grounds yesterday.
Steel operations declined 6 points last week to 34 per cent of capacity for the industry at large, according to the magazine Steel.

A brakeman pulled the emergency cord on a fifteen-car excursion train as it rolled into Grand Central Terminal at 11:23 A.M. yesterday at between fifteen and eighteen miles an hour. Eight hundred passengers standing in the aisles were jarred from their feet.

NO harm done at all. Certainly, Notre Dame was defeated and the Pitt Panthers were tossed into a cage by the gallant Gophers of Minnesota. Southern California was held to a scoreless tie by the busy Beavers of Oregon State. The famous Tennessee Volunteers were defeated for the second time in eight days and the fourth time in eight years.

Praising President Roosevelt's "honest attempt to introduce social justice into business," the Rev. Thomas L. Graham, preaching yesterday at high mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral, denounced employers who "keep the law, but violate the spirit of the NRA."
BUFFALO, N.Y., Oct. 22. -- Hiker Joy's Canisius College eleven defeated a light but plucky St. Vincent's team of Latrobe, Pa., 59 to 20, today.

CHICAGO, Oct. 22. -- A subcommittee of the United States Senate will meet in Chicago tomorrow to investigate the growth of racketeering and kidnapping throughout the nation and particularly in the Middle West. Hundreds of witnesses will testify and some "startling" evidence will be presented, according to Senator Royal S. Copeland of New Tork, chairman.

NEW ORLEANS, La., Oct. 22. -- The cotton futures market here last week was alternately active and sluggish and there were wide and erratic fluctuations. The extreme spread of fluctuations in the December position, the most active month in the list, reached 78 points.

GENEVA, Oct. 22. -- A plan to turn the Nov. 12 German plebiscite to the account of the League of Nations by mobilizing world opinion against the dangers to peace seen in Chancellor Hitler's rejection of the conference method is being quietly studied in influential circles here.

CHICAGO, Oct. 22. -- The "perfect crime" of Edward J. McCann, 53 years old, operator of a Detroit speakeasy and student of criminology, was exposed today by his arrest and confession that he killed his wife, 34 years old, in their home in Detroit on Labor Day and hacked her body to pieces.

"The Same Promises as Last Time," says one of the Presidential election bulletins in "Let 'Em Eat Cake," which was put on at the Imperial Saturday evening. The same characters and stinging point of view as in "Of Thee I Sing," the Messrs.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 22. -- Negotiations are proceeding in Washington and New York for the extension of approximately $500,000,000 in credit to the Soviet Government for purchases of American factory and farm products in the next five years.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 22. -- The prepared text of President Roosevelt's radio speech tonight was as follows:

In the past, old Brazilian travelers have not been greatly impressed by the bird collection at the Bronx Zoo. On leaving the Bird House a few have been known to shrug in a rather contemptuous manner, and one or two have been heard muttering to themselves: "What, no Cock-of-the-Rock?"

Although F.H. LaGuardia, Fusion candidate, still appears to have the lead in the race for the Mayoralty, developments of the last week indicated that the contest of the three major candidates was still undecided and that there was a strong possibility that they might come closer together in the home stretch.

The evolution of John Marin's work in the water-color medium is now spread upon the walls of An American Place at 509 Madison Avenue. As an exhibition, it proves important both because of the beauty of many of the examples selected for this occasion and because of the opportunity thus afforded to review the phases through which an American artist of genius has passed.

Price fluctuations in local commodity markets were wide last week, and at the close the net changes included both gains and losses. The irregularity was attributed generally to the government's wheat-purchasing program, which affected some other staples.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 22. -- Speaking by radio to the nation, President Roosevelt announced tonight that as a major step in his economic program he had authorized the Reconstruction Finance Corporation to establish a government market for gold newly mined in the United States, and to buy and sell gold on the world market if necessary.
LONDON, Oct. 22. -- The postponement of the disarmament conference will be debated by the Cabinet at a special meeting summoned for tomorrow afternoon.

Edward Tyrrell, the ruddy-cheeked cabby at the Hotel Brevoort for the last thirty years, died yesterday morning on his way home to 164 Fourteenth Street, Brooklyn. Mr. Tyrrell, who was 64 years old, had been driving a hack since 1883 and was as well known to most residents of Washington Square as the arch itself.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 22. -- Continuing its efforts to speed up the release of $1,000,000,000 or more of deposits in closed banks, the Deposit Liquidation Board, recently created as a division of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, made public today a letter on policy which it has sent to the chairmen of advisory committees set up in each of the twelve Federal Reserve districts.

Chile's champion soccer team, Audax de Italiano, defeated the Brooklyn Celtics by 4 to 2 in an exhibition game at Commercial Field yesterday before a crowd of 2,000. The game was the last for the victors before they sail for Rio de Janeiro next Saturday to continue their world tour.

BERLIN, Oct. 21. -- The withdrawal of Germany from the League of Nations and the disarmament conference wag unfavorably received by business men, capitalists and the investing public here. They fear an era of aggravated bad relations between Germany and the outside world, with the possibility that later anti-German measures may be taken by France and her allies.

Five safe burglars surprised two watchmen in the seventeen-story Jewelers' Exchange Building at 74 West Forty-sixth Street last night, bound and gagged them and, unmolested, devoted the next five hours to looting four safes in two offices on the tenth floor.

OSSINING, N.Y., Oct. 22. -- Striking back at a statement by Supreme Court Justice Selah B. Strong that life in jail was "made too easy for the criminal." Warden Lewis E. Lawes of Sing Sing prison declared here today that Sing Sing was "doing its full duty to the State, to society and to its prisoners."

Officers and men of the Manhattan unit of the 101st Cavalry, Squadron A, New York National Guard, Major F.A. Vietor commanding, rode in parade yesterday morning to St. James Lutheran Church, Madison Avenue and Seventy-third Street, and attended a colorful military service.

Reorganization of the Board of Education to free the schools from political influence was promised last night by Joseph V. McKee, Recovery party candidate for Mayor. This pledge was made in a radio address to teachers from Station WABC.
Nurmi's Artistic Temperament. PAAVO NURMI has grown cold to his young wife, she charges, because she has borne him a son who is not qualified to follow in his father's footsteps.

Renewing its attack on the proposed treaty with Canada for the canalization of the St. Lawrence waterway, the Merchants Associattion of New York asked Chairman Frank P. Walsh of the State Power Authority yesterday to provide statistics on the investment to be made by the United States in Canadian materials and labor in the completion of the work.
The New York Field Hockey Association vanquished the North Jersey Field Hockey Association in two challenge matches at Prospect Park, Brooklyn, yesterday.

BOSTON, Oct. 22 (AP). -- John Gorch, 37 years old, alias Steve Sederak, alias Steve Jamkowski, was arrested in a Back Bay apartment today and the police said that the once had been sought by the New Jersey police investigating the kidnapping of the Lindbergh baby.

Precisely what does "production" mean in the various industrial codes that are to carry out the economic program of recovery? For example, the cotton textile industry may not install "additional productive machinery" without good reason and must specify "the extent to which such installation "is for replacement for a similar number of units or to bring operation "of existing machinery into balance."
Mayor O'Brien made a Sunday afternoon tour yesterday that included visits to three churches and attendance at a professional football game at the Polo Grounds.

The revised budget adopted by the Board of Estimate in the small hours of Saturday morning is at once more honest and more startling than its precursor. It is more honest, because it includes, at least provisionally, $16,800,000 which Mayor O'BRIEN had previously hoped to "save" by sharply curtailing the annual appropriations to the teachers' and city employes' pension funds, and also the $23,950,000 tax-delinquency reserve required under the terms of the bankers' agreement.

The National Power and Light Corporation reports consolidated net income of $7,487,800 for the year ended on Aug. 31, equal after preferred dividends to $1.06 a share on the common stock, comparing with $9,340,653, or $1.41 a share, in the preceding year.

The second volume of the memoirs of Lloyd George will be published in November and there are two more to come after that. The former Prime Minister is now well into his third volume, industriously turning out on the average of 1,500 words a day.
BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, Oct. 22. -- Prices of grain here last week reached the lowest level in thirty-four years.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 22. -- Louis McHenry Howe, secretary to the President, said in a radio address over a National Broadcasting Company network tonight that recovery was now making "deliberate and regular progress" and working to destroy depression.
ROME, Oct. 22. -- The following is the round-by-round description of the Carnera-Paulino bout today:

The city's budget for 1934 can be balanced without resort to another general cut in the salaries of city workers if the Board of Estimate has "the will and the courage" to adopt further economies, amuel Untermyer, special adviser to the board, declared yesterday.

MASON'S ISLAND, Conn., Oct. 22. -- Cornelius Shields of Larchmont, N.Y., with his new Class B dinghy Softy, won a leg on the Henry B. Plant Cup as a fleet of forty dinghies sailed in the two classes today.

President ROOSEVELT'S friendly advance to the Soviet Government has been, on the whole, well received in this country. Most people felt that something of the kind was inevitable. Mr. ROOSEVELT wrote significantly of the need of bringing two "peoples" into official relations.

Bruno Walter's program for the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, which he conducted yesterday afternoon in Carnegie Hall, began with Haydn's spmphony in G major (B. and H. No. 13) and concluded with Brahms's first symphony.

About a dozen planes bound for Long Island airports yesterday afternoon were forced to land elsewhere because of a heavy fog that rolled in from the sea. The fog caused little or no delay to shipping in New York harbor, although it shrouded the region off Sandy Hook most of the day and rolled up the bay twice to within a mile and a half of the Battery.

PARIS, Oct. 22. -- President Lebrun's absence from Paris was the official pretext, and the hope that an agreement can be made between the Government and the Socialists was the real reason, why today's Chamber of Deputies debate on the financial situation was left inconclusive and the issue was postponed until tomorrow.

AUGUSTA, Me., Oct. 22. -- Depositors in Maine's thirty-seven closed State and national banks will lose about $35,000,000, including $15,000,000 in nineteen State banks, $15,000,000 in eighteen national banks and $5,000,000 in interest, according to Chief Justice William R. Pattangall of the State Supreme Court.

ABOARD THE MOTOR SHIP WYATT EARP, Oct. 22 (By Wireless). -- Exactly on the opposite side of the world to New York and a mile further south of the Equator than New York is north, the Lincoln Ellsworth transatlantic flight expedition ship, the Wyatt Earp, bearing the expedition's plane, is drifting slowly.

President Roosevelt's announcement of plans for the government to attempt control of the price level through the purchase and sale of gold and the control of exchange bewildered orthodox bankers and economists last night.

Coat and dress lines felt the effects or limited buying in the wholesale apparel markets last week. The demand for fur-trimmed coats fell off sharply and a slight easing in prices for such garments developed as manufacturers attempted to keep stocks moving.
CHICAGO Oct. 22. -- For the second successive Sunday, the educated toe of Jack Manders, former Minnesota star, gave the Chicago Bears of the National Football League the margin of victory today.

MOSCOW, Oct. 22. -- The question of debts, arising from the Soviet refusal to recognize foreign obligations of the Czarist Government or from the confiscation of property belonging to foreign nationals, has been one of the chief problems of Soviet foreign relations.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 22. -- Final figures on the 1932 Presidential election, compiled by Simon Michelet, president of the National Get-Out-the-Vote Club, show that President Roosevelt received 22,821,858 votes against 15,761,841 cast for Hoover, or a plurality of 7,060,017, as against a Republican plurality of 6,423,484 in 1928.

BOSTON, Oct. 22 (AP). -- The Boston Redskins held Joe Lillard, spark-plug in the Chicago Cardinals' attack, in check as they romped to a 10-0 victory before 16,000 spectators today in a National Professional Football League game at Fenway Park.

CHICAGO, Oct. 22. -- A nationwide campaign to raise $200,000 for the building and maintenance of Hadassah University hospital and a graduate medical school at Jerusalem was launched here today by Hadassah, the women's Zionist organization of America.

Expressing his approval at the Soviets' success in abolishing the church in Russia, the Rev. Dr. John L.Davis declared yesterday that even in this country the church was more concerned with "fleecing people than ministering to them."

The NRA codes have sent back to school in New York State, according to the State Education Department, from 10,000 to 12,000 boys and girls 14 and 15 years of age. A far larger number -- from 40,000 to 50,000 -- who are free to go to work, have been forced to remain in school because of not finding jobs.

MINEOLA, L.I., Oct. 22. -- Evidently nettled because Robert Moses, chairman of the Long Island State Park Commission, did not appear here yesterday in person in response to a notice from the Nassau County NRA Committee, H.F. Kammeyer, chairman of the committee, issued a statement assailing Mr. Moses for his failure to be present.

MUNICH, Oct. 22. -- From the platform of the Hall of Liberation at Kelheim, in which Greek antiquity, German imperial glamour and Wagnerian music seemed synthesized, Chancellor Hitler delivered an election speech today that was a defiance of and a plea to the world.

F.H. LaGuardia, Fusion candidate for Mayor, told 500 leaders of orthodox Jewry last night that any person who made a point of proclaiming his friendship for members of a certain race showed that he considered himself superior.

PATERSON, N.J., Monday, Oct. 23. -- Plans for a large picket demonstration of striking dyers today were abandoned early this morning after the owners of about 100 silk dyeing plants had agreed to postpone the scheduled reopening of the plants until tomorrow.

CHICAGO, Oct. 22. -- Business in this area is holding its own, except in a few industries which have reported a slight recession in buying. While there are indications of enlargement, big grains are not expected for the remainder of the year except in holiday goods, which are coming in now for greater attention.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In the Real Estate Section of your issue of last Sunday, under the heading "Would Base Tax on Land Income," Morton R. Cross makes a valuable contribution in stating: "Our whole system of taxation is wrong. * * * Land has no value except in so far as it can be made to produce income."

About 150 members and guests of the Swedish Chamber of Commerce of the United States attended a farewell luncheon yesterday to Olof H. Lamm, who recently resigned as Consul General of Sweden. The luncheon was held on the Swedish-American liner Kungsholm. Mr. Lamm will sail today for Sweden, where he will engage in marine insurance.
GALWAY, Oct. 23 -- Colonel and Mrs. Charles A. Lindbergh landed at Galway at 5 P.M. today after a flight of 6 hours 15 minutes from Southampton, England.

Not the least striking among the anomalies of a season that threatens to set a record for its irregularities is the fact that the Notre Dame style of attack is faring well in almost every one of its major bailiwicks save the one to which it is most indigenous.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 -- The Federal Reserve Board's condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety leading cities on Oct. 18 shows increases for the week of $56,000,000 in loans and investments, $173,000,000 in net demand deposits and $61,000,000 in reserve balances with Federal Reserve Banks.
Decisions by football officials in college games of last Saturday were commented on widely yesterday.

The right of a Christian church to fly the church flag above the United States flag will be made the subject of an inquiry by the Federal Council of the Churches of Christ in America following an appeal yesterday to the general secretary, the Rev. Dr. Samuel McCrea Cavert.

FISHERS ISLAND, N.Y., Oct. 23 -- With the largest entry in its history, the English Springer Spaniel Field Trials Association will open its tenth annual field trial meeting tomorrow morning. A total of 105 entries in nine stakes will keep owners, handlers and judges busy for the next four days.

LAUREL, Md., Oct. 23 (AP) -- Mrs. John Bosley's Chase Me maintained his unbeaten march when he cleverly won the featured Glenwood purse at a mile and a sixteenth today. It was the Purchase gelding's third straight score.

Sharp and general advances occurred yesterday in the local commodity markets, partly reflecting the administration's new statement of intention to raise the price level by controlling the value of the currency and partly as a result of short covering.

LOS ANGELES, Oct. 23 -- Joseph M. Schenck, president of the Twentieth Century Pictures and of United Artists organization, and Samuel Goldwyn, the film producers, have tendered their resignations from the Motion Picture Producers and Distributors of America, Inc., of which Will H. Hays is the head, they admitted today.
The pheasant hunting season will open in New York State next Monday and continue until the following Saturday, inclusive. From all accounts there are plenty of birds in a great many sections.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Oct. 23 -- Westchester voters made an "off year" registration record on their four registration days in the last two weeks, according to figures compiled here today. The approximate total registration is 219,309, compared with 197,698 in 1931, the last "off year."

YONKERS, N.Y., Oct. 23 -- The Rev. Charles T. Murphy, rector of St. Mary's Roman Catholic Church, one of the oldest and most prominent Catholic parishes in Westchester County, died here today of a heart ailment in the rectory on South Broadway.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 (AP) -- A review was promised today by the Supreme Court to the first challenge of recovery legislation it has received, and the decision may determine constitutionality of the administration's farm relief efforts. The case was set for hearing on Dec. 4.

E.I. du Pont de Nemours Co. report for the three months ended on Sept. 30 a net income of $11,981,980 after charges and taxes, equal, after dividends on the debenture stock, to 95 cents a share on the 10,961,479 common shares outstanding.

As successor of President OSBORN of the American Museum of Natural History, F. TRUBEE DAVISON had to live up to the ideals of an executive, scientist, explorer and sportsman. The museum under President OSBORN was expanded into a treasure house of exhibits of the natural world.

LONDON, Oct. 23 -- The impending conferences with Russia at Washington may have the effect of speeding the negotiations for a new Anglo-Russian trade agreement, which have been languishing since the British engineers' trial in Moscow last Spring.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 -- President Roosevelt directed tonight the establishment of a special division of cooperation with State banks to assist and encourage the 8,600 banks outside the Federal Reserve System in obtaining additional capital to pass on to business and agriculture in the form of credits.

As a result of the brisk upward movement on the Stock Exchange yesterday, the general share market canceled all the losses that had been recorded since last Tuesday. The combined averages of THE NEW YORK TIMES showed a net gain of $3.36, and the average of twenty-five industrials, $5.10.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 -- Following is the text of the retail code as signed by President Roosevelt:

Under the benevolent rule of the New Deal it is possible to have and to enjoy such a fluffy comedy as Clare Kummer's "Her Master's Voice," which was acted at the Plymouth last evening. Excepting "Amourette," which succumbed to several rare diseases a few weeks ago, Miss Kummer has not been represented in New York for some time.

For several months boards of review have been considering the so-called "presumptive" disabilities for which benefits are paid to ex-soldiers. These are the cases in which various illnesses and injuries are "presumed" to have been incurred in line of duty, despite lack of direct evidence.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In your issue of Oct. 17, in the article headed "2,330-Pound Book of Peace Unveiled," I find that the Rev. Dr. Francis J. McConnell, Bishop of the New York Methodist area, is quoted as saying: "The only aim of the French movement against Germany can be to put Germany out of business."

It was said of the late Senator ALLISON of Iowa that he could walk on eggs across the Senate Chamber without cracking a shell. That kind of cautious skill has been increasingly in demand here in our city election. Candidates and their managers are more and more acting like men walking on a tight-rope, and knowing that to fall off on either side would be fatal.

Uncertainty as to the form of liquor control after prohibition has created suspense among artists here who are waiting anxiously to learn whether there will be barrooms to decorate with mural paintings.

CHICAGO, Oct. 23 -- Alfred E. Smith in an address at A Century of Progress Exposition today declared that "the heavy, cold, clammy hand of bureaucracy" had done much to hinder industry. Although there may be times when private industry needs "the curb and bit of government regulation," he said, "still it is vastly superior to government planning and government control of business and of all human effort."

The advancement of investment banking procedure will be discussed at four specially organized forums as part of the main program of the annual convention of the Investment Bankers Association of America to be held from next Saturday until the following Wednesday at Hot Springs, Va.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 -- The late Henry W. Catlin received $55,000 from the Chase National Bank for his services in connection with its loans to the Machado government in Cuba between 1927 and 1930, according to evidence offered today before the Senate Banking and Currency Committee.

PELHAM, N.Y., Oct. 23 -- John T. Brook, former president of the Pelham National Bank, was arrested late this afternoon at the Peldean Court Apartments. He was lodged in the county jail in default of $25,000 bail on charges of "injury to property by misconduct and neglect in office and fraud."

John J. Egleston of Worcester, Mass., and Patrick E. Sullivan of Seattle, Wash., were sentenced yesterday by Federal Judge Alfred C. Coxe to serve five years each in the Northeastern Penitentiary, Lewisburg, Pa., for mail fraud.

The monetary policy announced by President Roosevelt was regarded in Wall Street yesterday as committing the government to the most extreme form of currency management known to monetary theory -- the commodity dollar. As such, the policy was almost universally condemned as impractical.
Voting machines will be used in the Nov. 7 election and not paper ballots, the Board of Elections decided yesterday.

PRAGUE, Oct. 23 -- That Premier Mussolini of Italy no longer exerts any real influence in Berlin and must now throw his weight wholly on the other side or be used by Chancellor Hitler is the interpretation here of Germany's formal notice of withdrawal from the League of Nations.

Except that outside money on call loans was easier at 1/2, compared with 6/3 @ 3/4 last week, little else of interest transpired in the day's money market. Business was small and quotations for all classes unchanged.

GENEVA, Oct. 23 -- There were many conflicting tendencies today among the disarmament delegations as to what to do about the conference when its bureau meets Wednesday. The tendency that seemed to have most support, at least temporarily, was to establish a drafting committee to put on paper all the treaty provisions on which agreement with the Germans has already been reached, reserving till later those on which the break turned.

Sidney Levine, City License Commissioner, replied yesterday to criticisms made by the American Civil Liberties Union on the conduct of his office and declared that he had not exceeded his authority in suppressing indecent theatrical performances.

Satisfaction that the long delay in the signing of the retail code has been ended was tempered in retail circles here yesterday by a feeling that the new version of the controversial "loss leader" or "loss limitation" provision in the code was "ambiguous and tends to add fresh confusion.
CHICAGO, Oct. 23 (AP) -- The racing colors of Mrs. Edward McCuan of St. Louis triumphed twice at Sportsman's Park today.

LONDON, Oct. 23 -- Dr. Donald John Armour, brain surgeon, died suddenly tonight while attending a council meeting of the Medical Society of London of which he was treasurer. During recent years, he was known as one of the most prominent surgeons in his field.

The estate of David Belasco, who died May 14, 1931, was appraised yesterday at $1,598,000 gross and $1,249,144 net, of which $1,177,509 was in securities. An accounting in the estate in June showed that the value of the securities had decreased $432,034.
BUENOS AIRES, Oct. 23 -- Sentiment is rapidly crystallizing throughout the cereal belt of Argentina against harvesting unless the government establishes minimum prices or other relief measures.

Purchasing executives here yesterday interpreted President Roosevelt's statement on a controlled currency as indicating that the government intended setting up an equalization fund similar to that operated by England. This would be for the purpose of keeping the dollar at a discount abroad and maintaining price levels for commodities at home.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 -- Katsuji Debuchi, the Japanese Ambassador, received instructions today from his Foreign Office to report in Tokyo as soon as practicable. The message from Tokyo said that the Foreign Minister wished to confer with him personally on questions connected with the improvement of relations between Japan and the United States.

LONDON, Oct. 23 -- As a result of President Roosevelt's speech, the stock markets generally opened firm today. Internationals, which at first were lower on New York advices, subsequently recovered rapidly and prices were higher on balance.

TRENTON, N.J., Oct. 23 -- Louis Cohen, assistant attorney general and counsel to the State Department of Banking and Insurance, today told members of the commission created by the Legislature to study the banking situation that, in his opinion, a State bank deposit insurance system was unnecessary.

After almost two hours of uproar, the United German Societies decided last night to send a committee today to persuade Mayor O'Brien that the annual German Day celebration, which he has prohibited, will not be turned into a Nazi propaganda meeting and that the disorder that the Mayor feared will not occur inless the Jewish War Veterans attack the 165th Regiment Armory.
DES MOINES, Iowa, Oct. 23 (AP). -- The status of the strike called by the National Farmers Holiday Association in twenty-one States, a survey tonight indicated, was as follows:
NEW YORK. Lord Ebbisham and his daughter, the Hon. Elizabeth Blades, are at the Waldorf-Astoria.

RICHMOND, Va., Oct. 23 -- Evidence and argument in a legal battle for control of the $28,000,000 Virginia-Carolina Chemical Corporation will be completed tomorrow before Judge W.A. Moncure in Chancery Court, with the newly elected majority directors disputing the position of junior shareholders that control no longer should rest with the 7 per cent prior preferred stockholders.

As far as life of children in the city is concerned, the 1934 executive city budget might well be termed the "murder budget," Charles Solomon, Socialist Mayoralty candidate, declared yesterday. At the present rate it will take 185 years to get the playgrounds which city officials reported were urgently needed in 1930, he said.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I leave to others the unhappy pleasure of replying in detail to Mr. Gerard's article in THE TIMES Book Review. Not many will miss the warning implicit in the statement of a "representative citizen" that Hitler's brutal suppression of science and truth, his chauvinism and war mania, his destruction of labor organizations and his defense of junkerism are "all good"!

The Eastern qualifying tournament for the national three-cushion championship began yesterday at Jack Doyle's Broadway Academy with Arthur Wood of Buffalo and Alfredo De Oro of New York scoring victories.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 -- An increase in total weekly wages of nearly $64,000,000 shown in September as compared with the weekly payroll aggregate of last March was cited tonight by Secretary Hull as one of the concrete gains of the NRA program.

BERLIN, Oct. 23 -- The prosecution in the Reichstag fire trial, having obtained a virtual acquittal of the Nazis, today threw into battle some of its heavy artillery in the shape of three experts who testified that Marinus van der Lubbe's account of setting the fire all alone must be false.

PARIS, Oct. 23 -- Agitation and anger over the Daladier government's projects for increasing taxation and cutting the salaries of civil servants, which have been evident all over the country, were only kept in check today by such a display of potential force as has not been seen here in years.
The weekly pro-amateur tournament of the Long Island Golf Association at the Queens Valley Golf Club at Forest Hills yesterday ended in a tie for first place.

PARIS, Oct. 23 -- President Roosevelt's program for directing the value of the dollar aroused a mixture of relief and skepticism here today. The French are glad that the President has finally taken a stand after months of hesitation, which made financial circles here confused and anxious.
MOSCOW, Oct. 23 -- The most important Soviet delegation ever sent to any foreign country has just left Moscow to attend the celebration on Sunday of the tenth anniversary of Turkish independence.

McClelland Barclay, magazine illustrator, was arrested yesterday in a studio at the Beaux Arts Apartments, 310 East Forty-fourth Street, on complaint by his former wife, Mrs. Nan Barclay, that he had failed to deposit $34,000 in a trust fund at the Bankers Trust Company here.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 -- President Roosevelt issued an executive order today exempting from codes employers in towns of less than 2,500 population employing not more than five persons.
HANOVER, N.H., Oct. 23 -- A flood of injuries, coming the week before the Harvard game, reduced the Dartmouth back field contingent considerably today.

A warning that the entire State and local relief program may have to be discontinued unless Proposition 1, providing for a $60,000,000 bond issue for unemployment relief, is voted upon favorably at the forthcoming elections was sounded yesterday by William Hodson, executive director of the Welfare Council of New York City.

Adjustment of the value of the American dollar to the wholesale price index of the Department of Labor, advocated by Professor George F. Warren of Cornell University in an interview which will appear in The Country Home tomorrow, in the opinion of financial authorities is the real crux of the plan for a managed currency announced by President Roosevelt in his radio speech Sunday night.

The jury before Supreme Court Justice McCook In the suit by the County Trust Company against Timothy J. Mara and Patrick F. Kenny had not agreed at 5 o'clock yesterday afternoon. The suit is for $70,000 on notes which the defendants asserted they signed to aid the financing of the Smith Presidential campaign in 1928 on an agreement that they would not be called on to pay.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 -- By voting to sustain the present scale of wages for 14,000 New York bricklayers, the National Labor Board began a movement today that is expected to have important repercussions not only in New York but also in the general construction Industry.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 -- Major Robert Y. Stuart, chief of the Forest Service, was killed this morning in a fall from a window in an office adjoining his own on the seventh floor of the Agricultuural Department building.

Mr. LAGUARDIA has joined the ranks of those seeking further light on the possibility of the city's obtaining a larger share of State taxes. This is a hobby of Mr. UNTERMYER, who is wont to complain that the city is being "treated by the State like a browbeaten "stepchild, and stripped of almost every "available source of revenue except "taxes on real estate."

BERLIN, Oct. 23 -- With all known Germans of anti-Fascist tendencies in jail or in concentration camps, the government's propaganda for the so-called election on Nov. 12 is being based on the slogan, "Peace and equal rights," with all speeches accenting the peace part.

A plan to raise prices of cocoa has been worked out by Canalizo, Witkin Co. of 80 Wall Street for submission to the conference of cocoa producing countries to be held in London in November. It calls for the destruction in producing countries of less than 8 per cent of the world's annual crop for two years.

President Roosevelt's announced determination to raise domestic price levels had a stimulating effect yesterday on the cotton as well as other speculative markets. Active buying on the Cotton Exchange advanced prices a quarter cent a pound, but the heavy marketing of new cotton resulted in selling from producing sections and the session ended with gains of only 7 to 13 points.

A 14-year-old pupil at the Dewey Junior High School in Brooklyn was arrested yesterday and charged with having started sixteen fires in the borough In seven weeks. No fatalities resulted from the fires, and with one exception no serious damage was done.
MIAMI, Oct. 23 (AP) -- Delayed by rain squalls, the Graf Zeppelin left here tonight for Chicago after a fourteen-hour visit following arrival from Brazil.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 -- Secretary Hull plans to sail from New York on Nov. 4 for the seventh Pan American Conference, scheduled to open in Montevideo on Dec. 3, he announced today. The Secretary of State will go by the Pacific coast of Latin America and will pay visits to government authorities in Peru, Chile and Argentina en route, according to the present plans.
FAR HILLS, N.J., Oct. 23 -- The eighteenth annual meeting of the Essex Fox Hounds will open on the Froh-Heim estate here Wednesday with a card of five events, three of them steeplechases.
CHICAGO, Oct. 23 -- Soaring of grain prices today accompanied buying enthusiasm over President Roosevelt's address, especially his pledges of higher agricultural values, and of a gold control plan.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 23 -- The only Harvard players in Saturday's game against Holy Cross who were scrimmaged against the scrubs today were Eddy Rogers and Wilton Burton, the substitute tackles for Francisco and Kopans, and Frank Casale, substitute left guard.

Captain G.H. Baum, master of the British freighter Kohistan, brought his vessel into Quarantine at 11 o'clock yesterday and made entries in his log-book which told that he had brought the season's first cargo of Persian palm-dates into port in 26 1/2 days out of Basra.

TOKYO, Tuesday, Oct. 24 -- The newspaper Asahi reports that Ambassador Debuchi will be replaced by a new Ambassador to be chosen after Foreign Minister Hirota has discussed the situation with Mr. Debuchi.
PARIS, Oct. 21 -- Few people here, if any, expect to see the dollar some day stabilized much higher than the present rate.

LATONIA, Ky., Oct. 23 (AP) -- Principal attention at Latonia today centred on the fifth race, in which seven of the better-grade selling platers competed. Flying Cadet, from the stables of Racing Commissioner Polk Laffoon, was a driving winner, leading throughout the mile and a sixteenth Journey.

BRONXVILLE, N.Y., Oct. 23 -- More commuters' wives were kissed at the railroad station here this morning than at any time since Bronxville was founded. Most of it was bootleg kissing, done in defiance of a police order, and probably tasted better for that reason.

The entire common stock of the Central Utilities Service Company (Ohio), consisting of 995 shares, will be offered to the highest bidder at auction at 12:30 P.M. on Nov. 8 by the Chase National Bank, under a lien which the bank holds on the shares.
Columbia started the work of rehabilitating its football forces yesterday at Baker Field in preparation for the contest with Penn State here on Saturday.

Joseph V. McKee was criticized in court yesterday by Corporation Counsel Arthur J.W. Hilly because of his action in restoring Francis McT. McEneny as chief examiner for the Board of Aldermen just before the Court of Appeals upheld Mr. McKee in removing McEneny for breach of trust.
Maxie Rosenbloom, world's light-heavyweight champion, is taking nothing for granted in advance of the defense of his title against Mickey Walker in Madison Square Garden Nov. 3.

PATERSON, N.J., Oct. 23 -- The strike of 15,000 silk dye workers which began six weeks ago appeared to have ended tonight when a tabulation of voting among union members showed a desire to return to work under an agreement reached two weeks ago with the shop owners.
U.S. Department of Agriculture. Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices at New York.

Representatives of the New York towboat and lighter operators and their employes conferred yesterday at the Towboat Exchange with H.J. Brown of the Department of Commerce on terms of a new wage agreement for the coming year. The men have demanded an eight-hour day and their employers have refused on the ground that it would be economically impracticable.

TRENTON, N.J., Oct. 23 (AP) -- Testimony was begun today before Federal Judge Phillip Forman in an action to set aside a transfer of about $1,500, in bonds from the Miner Edgar Chemical Corporation to the Consolidated Chemical Corporation.
The City Campaign. F. H. LaGuardia charged that Joseph V. McKee and Edward J. Flynn had connived with contractors in grafting on labor.
